title: Armco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain on the sale of a unit of $15,200,000 for both the quarter and year, and losses on discontinued insurance operations of $24,000,000 and $44,000,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also included a $6,700,000 gain on early retirement of debt; a $5,400,000 loss from an accounting change, and a $42,800,000 gain on income from a change in inventory accounting. c-Included a $35,100,000 loss from discontinued insurance for both the quarter and year; the quarter included a $13,500,000 loss on reversal of a tax credit and the year included a gain of $8,300,000 on early retirement of debt and the year also included a $3,900,000 tax credit.

title: Hunt, J B Transport Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change of $3,556,000.

title: Murphy Undergoes Surgery on Knee
description: Dale Murphy, the Atlanta Braves' outfielder who won the National League Most Valuable Player Award in 1982 and 1983, underwent arthroscopic surgery yesterday to repair a slight cartilage tear in his right knee. Murphy, 32 years old, felt a clicking in the knee while playing with his five sons over the weekend. ''It was kind of strange,'' he said. ''I wasn't having any pain or swelling, but as I bent down, I would hear strange noises down there.'' Dr. Joe Chandler performed the surgery at Piedmont Hospital in Atlanta. ''The torn portion was removed and he should be able to start exercising very shortly,'' said the doctor. ''He should be running in three weeks and be at full strength in from three to five weeks.'' Chandler said Murphy would probably miss the Braves' opening workout on Feb. 22, but should be ready for the first exhibition game on March 2.(AP)

title: Albany International Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest fourth quarter net was reduced by 10 cents a share as the result of a financial strategy established in the third quarter which effectively exchanged $100 million of floating rate U.S. dollar debt for fixed lower rate yen debt.

title: Texas Eastern
description: The Texas Eastern Corporation, a Houston-based natural gas transmission company, said it had met with several banks on Saturday to discuss the financing of a possible restructuring or recapitalization as an alternative to the $42-a-share tender offer from the Coastal Corporation. The meetings were held one day before Texas Eastern formally rejected the Coastal bid as inadequate.

title: Foster Is Reinjured
description: Greg Foster has broken his left arm again. Foster, the 1984 Olympic silver medalist in the 110-meter high hurdles, broke his arm last summer, two weeks before the trials for the Seoul Olympics. He fractured it again Monday night while playing basketball with friends in West Los Angeles. Bob Kersee, Foster's coach, said the hurdler broke the arm undeneath the metal plate inserted during surgery for the previous injury, which occurred when he tripped over a hurdle. This year he was making a strong return indoors. He beat Roger Kingdom, the Olympic gold medalist, in his first race. (AP)

title: About New York; Etymologically, 'The Big Apple' Ages 18 Years
description: David Shulman just received a most welcome letter. The editor of the Oxford English Dictionary wrote to say the next supplement to the prestigious lexicon would list Big Apple as a synonym for New York City. Heretofore, Big Apple has been listed only as a dance.

title: KMW Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Commodore International Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $5.7 million for the quarter and $7 million for the 6 months.

title: U.S. Agency Broadening Inspections of Boeing Jets
description: The Federal Aviation Administration today broadened a series of mandatory inspections of passenger jets made by the Boeing Company, ordering airlines to check wiring and fire extinguishers on hundreds of jets produced in the last eight years.

title: Mediq Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $279,000 from discontinued operations and a $3,347,000 gain from a debenture buyback.

title: Brady Sees No Urgency To Put Curbs on Buyouts
description: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady told Congress today that there was no urgency in adopting measures to curb debt-financed corporate takeovers, adding that Wall Street's enthusiasm for leveraged buyouts might have peaked.

title: Wine School to Leave Waldorf-Astoria
description: After nearly three decades at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, Harriet Lembeck's Wine & Spirits Program, one of the oldest wine courses in the country, will move next month to the New York Helmsley Hotel, 212 East 42d Street. A rent increase at the Waldorf necessitated the move, Mrs. Lembeck said.

title: German Atomic Sale Challenged
description: Administration officials say a West German company's 1984 export to India of a material that can be used in nuclear bombs did not have the required permission of American export authorities.

title: Radiation Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Tempest Over Tower Is Nearing End
description: After nearly three decades, the closing chapter in the epic of the West Side Urban Renewal Area is finally being written. Like earlier episodes, it is the story of a battle to balance new housing and neighborhood character in a changing part of upper Manhattan.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: A First Record

title: Bucky Dent Has His Own Wall
description: ''Look at that baby,'' Bucky Dent said. ''Awesome, isn't it?''

title: French Report Finds Inside Trading
description: The agency that oversees France's financial markets said today that large-scale insider trading took place before Pechiney acquired Triangle Industries, the American packaging company, and it announced that it had turned the case over to criminal investigators.

title: About Education
description: Colleges compete furiously for the same group of top-ranking minority high school graduates. When everybody tries to recruit from the same pool, the number of black and Hispanic undergraduates does not grow. In recent years, it has actually shrunk. The National Center for Education Statistics reports that blacks earned fewer college degrees in 1985 than in 1977.

title: Borden Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Real Estate; 125th Street Experiences New Vitality
description: AFTER decades of decline, 125th Street, the crosstown throughfare that has long been the economic and cultural heart of Harlem, is making a commercial comeback.

title: Review/Dance; Puns Seen and Danced
description: Momix is not a dance company for purists. The company, formed in 1980 by Moses Pendleton, also a founder of Pilobolus, tends to take gimmicks like props or visual puns as the departure points for the pieces created by this choreographers' collective.

title: Catfish Achieve Upward Mobility
description: LEAD: CATFISH is the Cinderella of seafood, transformed by scientists from a bewhiskered, muddy-tasting, bottom-feeding wild creature into a cultured and cultivated delicacy. Only a few years ago the channel catfish was recognized as a good candidate for farming. Now consumers, chefs and nutritionists are finding the mild white flesh of farm-raised channel catfish tasty and healthful.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The kind of economic growth we want is the kind that doesn't shorten our breath or our life.

title: Montana Power Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Eddie LeVeque Dead; A Keystone Kop, 92
description: Eddie LeVeque, the last of the original Keystone Kops, the troupe of slapstick gendarmes whose comic antics endeared them to a generation of silent film fans, died Saturday. He was 92 years old.

title: Fast-Track Tool: A Walk With Style
description: FOR most people, walking is a simple matter of putting one foot in front of the other. In the cosmic scheme of things, it is up there with sleeping and sitting, something we take for granted, as life shambles along. But there is a new movement afoot.

title: Pennzoil Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $1.7 billion extraordinary gain, after expenses and estimated current and deferred taxes, or $42.62 per share, associated with the $3 billion cash settlement of the litigation between Pennzoil and Texaco Inc. After-tax non-cash charges of $303 million resulting from the disposition and write-down of certain assets and other charges, were also reflected in 1988 earnings. Excluding extraordinary and special items, earnings from operations were $2.58 per share. Revenue for the latest year excludes the extraordinary item. Quarterly earnings include results from the Filtration Products Company, and Facet Enterprises Inc., which was acquired in May 1988.

title: Corrections
description: An art show listing in the New Jersey Weekly last Sunday, for Englewood, identified the artist incorrectly and misstated the opening time for his show of oil paintings. The artist is Kurt Ritta. The opening will be held today at the Intermission Gallery of the John Harms Center for the Arts in Englewood, N.J., from 5:30 to 9:30 P.M., not 9 A.M. to 5 P.M.

title: Sun Shines And Profits Wither Away
description: No snow here, so the city is postponing the winter festival that every year but this year turns downtown State Street into a ski run.

title: The Easiest Money
description: Ronald Reagan came out of the White House rested up and raring to go. During his first week out in the world of free enterprise he signed up to write a memoir, compile a book of his speeches and go on the lecture circuit.

title: U.S. Agencies Investigating Resale of Used Aircraft Parts
description: A Federal grand jury and several Federal agencies are investigating whether airplane part suppliers have been buying used or surplus parts from aerospace companies and reselling them with false certification to unknowing aviation companies, a newspaper has reported.

title: USF&G Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included realized losses on investments of $26,281,000 and $74,184,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and tax credits of $200,000 and $15,500,000 for the same periods, respectively. c-Included realized losses on investments of $9,576,000 and $107,414,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and tax credits of $7,425,000 and $13,816,000 for the same periods, respectively. The company attributed its earnings decline in the latest fourth quarter and full year to several factors, including high first-year costs on increased annuity sales and high start- up costs for its new financial services operations.

title: Making Facilities Available for Elderly Prisoners
description: To the Editor:

title: Avondale Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,151,000 and $4,695,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $973,000 for the quarter and $5,994,000 for the year. The company said net income per share was reduced by preferred dividend requirements of $1,590,000 in the latest year; $1,460,000 for the year-ago quarter; and $6,120,000 for the year. The preferred stock was redeemed April 8, 1988.

title: Greenspan Defends Lifting Rates
description: By raising interest rates substantially in the last 10 months, the Federal Reserve helped extend the nation's long economic expansion, Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, said today.

title: Revamping Announced By Xerox
description: After more than two decades of stumbling in an attempt to become a major player in the automation of the office, the Xerox Corporation said yesterday that it was restructuring some operations, eliminating 2,000 jobs and taking a $275 million pretax charge in the fourth quarter.

description: LEAD: How shall we call ourselves? Negroes?

description: The hearing on Dr. Louis W. Sullivan as Secretary of Health and Human Services was delayed at the White House's request. Page A14.

title: Robert Henle, 64, I.B.M. Research Official
description: Robert A. Henle, director of the advanced silicon technology laboratory at the International Business Machines Thomas J. Watson Research Center in Yorktown Heights, N.Y., died of lymphoma Friday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 64 years old and lived in Clinton Corners, N.Y.

title: Jersey May Restrict Drexel
description: State gaming officials moved today to bar Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. at least temporarily from its lucrative business with New Jersey's casino industry because of the firm's involvement in the Wall Street insider trading scandal.

title: Don't Be Fooled by South African 'Reforms'; Trouble in Namibia
description: To the Editor:

title: Control Data Posts a Loss
description: Hurt by poor results in its mainframe and supercomputer operations, the Control Data Corporation yesterday reported a $12.8 million loss for its fourth quarter, in contrast to a profit of $10.8 million, or 26 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1987. Control Data, based in

title: INSIDE
description: Fighting Financial Fraud

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THE felicitous combination of rosemary and lemon is found often in northern Italian cuisine, most successfully in simple, quick veal dishes. Virtually any dish that is made with veal can be replicated with chicken breast, which is less expensive.

title: Yellow Freight System Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Carolina Freight Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Dow Corning reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Panama Moving to Improve Jails Before Rights Inspection
description: Anticipating a key human rights inspection by international observers, the Panamanian authorities are cleaning up jails and scrambling to eliminate what monitors here say are widespread abuses.

title: McDonald & Co Investments Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-After a gain of $314,000 from the retirement of debt for the quarter and 9 months.

title: PLAN TO BAN FEES SPURS LAWMAKERS
description: While Congressional leaders are trying to work out legislation banning outside speaking fees, members of Congress are rushing to book paid engagements in advance of the expected ban, lobbyists here say.

title: Tower's Personal Life Is Scrutinized
description: The hearing on the nomination of John G. Tower to be Secretary of Defense took an unexpected turn today when witnesses and senators were drawn into a public discussion of allegations of womanizing and drunkenness against the him.

title: Icahn-Texaco
description: Carl C. Icahn, the New York investor, has raised his stake in Texaco Inc. to 17.3 percent from 16.6 percent. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Mr. Icahn said he had bought the shares before he reached an agreement with Texaco that bars him from increasing his Texaco holdings above the 17.3 percent level and making a takeover bid for seven years.

title: United Technologies Fills 2 Senior Positions
description: Robert F. Daniell, chairman and chief executive of the United Technologies Corporation, continued yesterday to put his mark on the company, naming two executives to senior posts in a realignment of management.

title: USX Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-Included a $13,000,000 gain from an accounting change. The company said operating income from its energy segment was $116,000,000 for the latest quarter, compared with a $17,000,000 loss in the fourth quarter of 1987. For the year, the segment posted operating income of $475,000,000, up from $444,000,000 in 1987.

title: Harman International Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Ward Stirs Hispanic Ire For 2d Time
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward, who offended a group of Hispanic people last fall with a remark about drug dealing, met with members of the same group yesterday to try to make amends, but outraged them even more, participants in the session said.

title: Cyprus Minerals Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest year included after-tax gains of $25.1 million from the sale of Cyprus' calcium carbonate and limestone operations. These gains were offset in part by after-tax charges of $10.9 million related to the restructuring of certain industrial minerals, coal and specialty metals operations.

title: Catharine Deaver Lealtad, 93, Pediatrician
description: Dr. Catharine Deaver Lealtad, a pediatrician who supervised medical services for displaced children in Germany at the end of World War II, died Monday at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Brooklyn. She was 93 years old and had been a patient at the V.A.'s extended care center in St. Albans, Queens, for nine years.

title: A Princess's Baedeker: Opera to AIDS
description: A history lesson of sorts was in progress on lower Fifth Avenue yesterday as Helene Featherstone positioned her 6-year-old daughter, Amy, in front of a window display at the Williwear shop.

title: Jan Bell Marketing Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain from an accounting change of $1,027,000. The 1988 results are adjusted for a 50 percent stock dividend issued in October.

title: Wreck of Argentine Vessel Poses Threat of Oil Spill Off Antarctica
description: An Argentine ship, adrift after running aground off Antarctica, is in danger of spilling more than 250,000 gallons of diesel fuel and causing the continent's first major environmental crisis, officials of the National Science Foundation in Washington reported yesterday.

title: Sakharov Election Chances Rise
description: A member of the Soviet Politburo has apparently withdrawn from the race for Moscow's at-large seat in the new Soviet congress rather than face a contest against Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist and human rights campaigner.

title: The Negative Side Wins Out For a No. 1 Squash Player
description: Alicia McConnell used to dream of being the Billie Jean King of women's squash and turning her sport into a multimillion-dollar enterprise. Now the seven-time national champion is quitting the game, disillusioned, disheartened and, for the most part, broke.

title: 19 Are Killed as Air Force Jet Crashes on Takeoff in Texas
description: A military refueling jet bound for Hawaii crashed in a ball of flame on takeoff today at Dyess Air Force Base, killing all 19 people on board, the Air Force said.

title: Keithley Instruments reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Tribune Net Rises 45.6%
description: The Tribune Company, parent of The Daily News of New York and The Chicago Tribune, reported yesterday that its net income rose 45.6 percent in the fourth quarter.

title: Commercial TV Plan for Schools Draws Fire
description: A proposed daily 12-minute television news program, including commercials, that has a potential national captive audience of six million junior and senior high school students is being viewed dubiously by some educators.

title: Decision Close on Chief For National League
description: The five-man search committee seeking a president for the National League is meeting in New York this week and could emerge with a recommendation for a successor to A. Bartlett Giamatti.

title: Greyhound Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $10,750,000 from an accounting change. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $61,706,000 for the quarter and $51,491,000 for the year, and the year also included an extraordinary charge of $6,211,000 from the early extinguishment of debt. The company said the latest quarter and year net from continuing operations included gains of $3,115,000, or 8 cents a share, and $4,644,000, or 12 cents a share, respectively, both from the sale of real estate. Year-ago quarter and year net from continuing operations included losses of $2,781,000 and $4,890,000, respectively, both from the sale of real estate.

title: Grace Pickens Offer Is Enjoined
description: A Federal judge has enjoined the hostile tender offer for the Clemente Global Growth Fund Inc. by Grace Pickens Global Acquisition Partners. Federal Judge John F. Keenan enjoined the offer because he said it appeared that the Grace Pickens bid had violated a provision of the Investment Company Act of 1940 that prevents one investment firm from acquiring another such firm.

title: Banta, George Co reports earnings for 13wks to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $420,000 and $1,838,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $206,000 for the quarter and $1,376,000 for the year. Sales for the latest 13 weeks and 52 weeks included $57,463,000 and $157,316,000, respectively, from an acquisition which was accounted for as a purchase effective April 1, 1988.

title: Chicago Country Spot May Fade Into Sunset
description: They're heading for the last roundup at the 40-year-old Bar Double-R Ranch, but the trail bosses hope they can find a new pasture for the only no-cover, no-minimum, country-music basement nightclub in downtown Chicago. An office skyscraper is planned for the site where the Sundowners trio entertains the crowd, and 30 varieties of chili are served to folks who stroll in off Randolph Street.

title: Prices Paid to Farmers Increase 1.4% in Month
description: The prices that farmers get for raw products increased by 1.4 percent from December to January and were up by 12 percent from a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Diplomacy Intensifies on Afghanistan
description: An intense late round of diplomatic efforts to forge a political compromise among warring factions in Afghanistan is expected to take place here over the next few days, culminating with a visit by the Soviet Foreign Minister on Saturday.

title: How to Pay for Honest Government
description: Nobody can be proud of the backhanded way Congress raises its members' salaries. But experience shows that it's either that way or no way, because few members will risk political oblivion by voting publicly to increase their own pay.

title: Sonics' Home Streak Is Stopped by Nets
description: Buck Williams's 3-point play with 38 seconds left put New Jersey ahead to stay and the Nets snapped Seattle's 17-game home winning streak with a 118-112 victory tonight.

title: Books of The Times; Fury of the Outcast Over the Male Heir Adored
description: Passion and Prejudice A Family Memoir By Sallie Bingham Illustrated. 525 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $22.95.

title: Judge Leans to Allowing Rule That Trapped Aliens in Texas
description: A Federal judge said today that he would probably allow the Immigration and Naturalization Service to reinstate a policy that requires immigrants seeking political asylum to remain at the point where they entered the country until their application is processed.

title: After 229 Years, Irishwoman to Lead Parade
description: For the first time in its 229-year history, the annual St. Patrick's Day parade up Fifth Avenue will be led by a woman.

title: Warner-Lambert Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said gains in share earnings on an annual basis were achieved despite an after-tax charge of nearly $30 million to write down and deconsolidate operations in Argentina.

title: Kerr-McGee Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
People
description: * Francis J. Kelly 3d has joined Leonard Monahan Lubars & Partners, Providence, R.I., as executive vice president and director of client services.

title: In Sudan Peace Effort, U.S. Meets A Representative of the Guerrillas
description: Senior Bush Administration officials have met here in the last few days with a leading representative of the Sudanese guerrilla forces as part of a new American effort to try to end the five-year-old civil war in the strategically situated African country.

title: Prices Are Mixed in Slow Trading
description: The prices of Treasury notes and bonds recovered from their lows of the day and closed narrowly mixed in very slow trading yesterday.

title: Griffith Joyner Runs At a Different Level
description: Just five months ago, she seemed to be everywhere at once, with her flashy clothes, those long finger nails, world records and Olympic gold medals. If you knew nothing else about the summer track season, you knew of Florence Griffith Joyner, who began 1988 as a good sprinter and ended it as Flojo, the world's fastest female.

title: Wright, Bentsen to Respond
description: House Speaker Jim Wright and Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, the 1988 Democratic vice-presidential candidate, will deliver their party's response to President Bush's speech to Congress on Feb. 9, Mr. Wright and George J. Mitchell, the Senate majority leader, said today.

title: Indians Termed Victims of Job Fraud
description: A Federal investigor told lawmakers today that a Government inquiry had uncovered widespread fraud among companies that pretend to be controlled by American Indians to win millions of dollars in Federal contracts reserved for minority concerns.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption and article on Saturday, about a gathering in remembrance of a Brooklyn man killed in a parking dispute, gave his name incorrectly. He was Stephen Kelly. The caption, in some copies, misidentified the men shown. From the right were Stephen Jr., Erik and Stanford, sons of Mr. Kelly, and Robert Abraham, a family friend.

title: Person Pours in 47, But Knicks Prevail
description: It figured to be an easy game for the Knicks last night. The Indiana Pacers came to Madison Square Garden with the second-worst road record in the Eastern Conference (1-19) and the second-worst overall mark (11-30).

title: German Engineering Concern Admits Link to Libyan Plant
description: A state-owned West German engineering company announced today that it had found a document linking plans it had prepared for another West German company to a chemical plant in Libya.

title: Dollar Rises After Pledge On Inflation
description: The dollar rose sharply yesterday, moving close to what many traders and economists believe is the upper limit against the West German mark agreed to by Washington and its economic allies.

title: Logicon Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest quarter included a pre- tax charge of $1.2 million related to a contract with the U.S. Air Force.

title: Cooling-Off Period Near at Eastern
description: The National Mediation Board took the first step yesterday toward beginning a 30-day cooling-off period that could lead to a long-awaited confrontation between Eastern Airlines and its machinists' union.

title: Restraining Order Against Tyson
description: A Federal judge issued a restraining order against Tyson Foods Inc. Monday, saying the company may have violated Federal securities law to gain an undue advantage over Conagra Inc. in their billion-dollar fight to acquire the Holly Farms Corporation. Tyson, which has offered to buy Holly Farms for $1.15 billion, was ordered to refrain from making false, misleading, inaccurate or incomplete statements involving Holly Farms.

title: Article 847089 -- No Title
description: The present and former owners of an industrial park here that has been polluted with toxic wastes for more than 100 years will pay more than $24 million to clean the site, according to an agreement disclosed today by the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Foster, L B Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $2,299,000 from the cumualtive effect of an accounting change. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $6,778,000, a gain on disposal of discontinued operations of $30,913,000, a provision in lieu of income taxes of $9,267,000 and a tax loss carryforward of $8,334,000.

title: T Rowe Price Associates Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a non-recurring gain equal to 47 cents a share related to pension plan changes. c-Included a non-recurring gain equal to 18 cents a share related to pension plan changes.

title: Bass Group Says It Owns 5.6% of Houghton Mifflin
description: In a disclosure that Wall Street took as a signal of a possible takeover battle, the Robert M. Bass Group said yesterday that it owns 5.6 percent of the Houghton Mifflin Company, a textbook publisher based in Boston.

title: Syntro Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Hugh Wolff Crosses the Hudson To Make His Philharmonic Debut
description: If you ask Hugh Wolff how he feels about making his New York Philharmonic debut, the 35-year-old music director of the New Jersey Symphony and principal conductor of the St. Paul Chamber Orchestra will admit to some trepidation - but no more than he feels when leading any orchestra for the first time.

title: A Young Elite's Power Over Ads
description: A small group of junior employees at advertising agencies have come to wield tremendous influence over the placement of the $120 billion spent on advertising each year.

title: Steinberg Jury: Arguing, Joking, and a Verdict
description: For eight tense days, six men and six women weighed Joel B. Steinberg's fate in an ordeal of stubborn arguments relieved at times by bursts of laughter. Some who had given up smoking stepped into the corridor to light up cigarettes. Others closed themselves off in the restrooms to escape. At least one impasse was broken by changing the seating arrangement.

title: Executive Shuffling Continues at Salomon
description: The executive shuffling continued yesterday at Salomon Brothers Inc., which announced a realignment of responsibilities that are intended to strengthen the firm's efforts in the potentially lucrative area of merchant banking.

title: City's Chaos Swells an Afghan Diaspora
description: A fresh stream of refugees - most of them women, children and old men - are struggling through the mud, ice and snow of the Nawa Pass and into Pakistan. They are fleeing harsh fighting around Jalalabad, an Afghan Government strongpoint that seems on the brink of falling to the guerrillas.

title: Reviews/Music; 'Focus' Series at Juilliard Looks a Short Way Back
description: In the days, not all that long ago, when fine musicians like Fritz Kreisler and John McCormack thought it possible to appeal both to connoisseurs and a popular audience, a common strategy was to weight down the first half of the program with serious works, then lighten up with virtuoso showpieces or familiar melodic morsels. In extreme instances, it could seem that a performer had begun his encore period an hour or so too soon.

title: 2 Officers Are Indicted in Tompkins Melee
description: Two more police officers have been indicted by a Manhattan grand jury on assault charges arising from the melee between the police and demonstrators at Tompkins Square Park on the Lower East Side last August, the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, said yesterday.

title: Pryor Has Eye Surgery
description: Aaron Pryor, the former junior welterweight champion, had eye surgery yesterday at St. Mary's Hospital in Rochester. Pryor, 33,had a cataract removed from his left eye and was checked for a possible detached retina. A news conference was scheduled for today to announce the results.(AP)

title: Warsaw Says Priests' Deaths Weren't Politically Provoked
description: The Polish Government said today that there was no evidence indicating that the recent deaths of two pro-Solidarity priests were political provocations.

title: Addenda
description: * Joseph K. Fisher, formerly chairman and chief executive officer of Fisher Jackson Levy Flaxman, has formed Fisher & Co., a marketing consulting firm whose specialty will be corporate and financial communications.

title: Book Notes
description: Meese's Memoirs

title: Lomas Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary net gains of $8,333,000 for the quarter and $10,952,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss and after an extraordinary gain of $6,448,000 for the quarter and 6 months. The year-ago periods' losses from operations included the previously reported $141 million pre-tax charge resulting from restructuring decisions announced last February.

title: Lisa's Legacy: Awareness of Child Abuse and With It, Alarm
description: Fourteen months after she was beaten to death, 6-year-old Lisa Steinberg seems to have left as her legacy an increased awareness of child abuse - and a new readiness to report cases in which abuse is suspected.

title: U.S. Officials Weigh Plea Bargain in Case Of Computer Virus
description: Federal prosecutors have urged that Robert T. Morris, whose computer program disabled a Pentagon data network in November, be allowed to plead guilty to a misdemeanor charge in connection with the incident, according to law-enforcement officials familiar with the case.

title: CENSUS PREDICTS POPULATION DROP IN NEXT CENTURY
description: The Census Bureau projected for the first time today that the United States population would decline in the 21st century after peaking at slightly more than 300 million.

title: Limits on Savings Units Set
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board issued new guidelines today restricting the ability of insolvent and poorly capitalized savings institutions to invest in high-yield ''junk bonds.''

title: U.S. Students Place Low On Math and Science Tests
description: American teen-agers scored last in mathematics and well below the mean in science in an international survey, the Educational Testing Service said yesterday.

title: Judge Blocks Random Tests For Drugs at Interior Dept.
description: A Federal district judge has blocked a program of random drug testing at the Interior Department, calling it an example of ''bureaucracy run amok'' that would deprive thousands of people of their right to privacy.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Cyanamid Co., Wayne, N.J., a chemical research company, said it had sold its Canadian retail fertilizer business to Cargill Ltd. for an undisclosed sum.

title: Good Guys Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Westerners Discover a Chinese Secret: Cooking With Tea
description: OUT of the teapot comes more than the soothing or ceremonial cup. Tea can add subtle flavor and rich color to a variety of foods.

title: Arguments Begin at 2d GAF Trial
description: Lawyers for the defendants and the Government presented their opening arguments in the second GAF Corporation stock price manipulation trial yesterday, with both sides tailoring their arguments to testimony from the first trial.

title: Critic's Notebook; Encore! From Stage to Screen
description: In the decades when there was an active, self-starting Broadway theater, successful musicals and plays -especially those by Tennessee Williams - were almost unfailingly transformed into Hollywood movies. But in recent years, Broadway and Hollywood have generally regarded each other at a cool, bicoastal distance.

title: Japan Chief Seeks Good Start With Bush
description: Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita left for Washington today to become the first foreign leader to meet with President Bush, amid concern in Japan about new strains in its alliance with the United States and Mr. Takeshita's loss of political support at home.

title: Control Data Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-After extraordinary charges of $6.7 million and $5.7 million for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: National Steel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After credits of $8.8 million for the quarter and $22.6 million for the year. c-After a credit of $2 million for the quarter and year. The 1987 earnings have been restated as a result of an accounting revision by the Iron Ore Co. of Canada, in which National Steel holds an equity interest. The company said the restatement increased net income by $2.5 million. National Steel is a joint venture owned equally by National Intergroup Inc. and NKK Corp. of Japan.

title: Reebok International Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
E.P.A. NOMINEE SAYS HE WILL URGE LAW TO CUT ACID RAIN
description: William K. Reilly, President Bush's choice to head the Environmental Protection Agency, signaled a sharp break with Reagan Administration policies today by saying he would propose legislation to reduce acid rain.

title: Leonard-Hearns Rematch Set to War Theme
description: Under the mirrored balls of Roseland Ballroom, nine dancers in camouflage fatigues slinked and strutted and tapped their feet in aggressive unison. The production number was intended to convey the martial theme of the rematch between Sugar Ray Leonard, the World Boxing Council supermiddleweight champion, and Thomas Hearns.

title: Beanpot Threatening Top-Ranked Harvard
description: Harvard's hockey team, ranked first in the polls, has two former Olympians among a dozen point-producing forwards; a solid corps of six defensemen, and two freshman goaltenders who have been outstanding. Until it was upset by Yale, 3-1, last night at New Haven, the Crimson had won all 15 of its games.

title: Kimball Defenders Cite Some Previous Problems
description: Letters to a judge on behalf of Bruce Kimball described the 25-year-old Olympic diver as remorseful, devastated and battling alcohol problems for nearly a decade.

title: Review/Music; Composer Puts His Stamp on Past Virtues
description: The Latvian Concert Association presented a program of songs and violin music Saturday afternoon at Weill Recital Hall, all composed by Arnolds Sturms, a composer from Riga who came to the United States in 1949.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; New Ambassadors
description: The White House intends to appoint Michael H. Armacost, Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, as Ambassador to Japan and John D. Negroponte, Deputy National Security Adviser, as Ambassador to Mexico, senior Bush Administration officials said today.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Economic and Social Council

title: Austerity Plan Heralds Hardship fo All But Reflects the Government's Confidence
description: In their scope and severity, the cutbacks announced by the Sandinista Government this week were just what its opponents had been waiting for: a signal of economic distress from a regime that had clashed with business leaders and used confiscations and market manipulation to keep its ideological program alive.

title: H. James Barnum, 68, Ad Agency Founder
description: Dr. H. James Barnum Jr., the founder, chairman and chief executive officer of Barnum Communications Inc., an advertising and public relations agency that represents medical and pharmaceutical companies, died of cancer Sunday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 68 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Fairfield Communities Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax benefits of $579,000 for the quarter and $1,134,000 for the year. c-After tax benefits of $295,000 and $577,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: At Issue IS Determining Responsibility When Awareness Is Discriminated by Drugs
description: In the crowded jury room in the Manhattan Criminal Courts Building, the men and women who decided Joel B. Steinberg's fate were also grappling with a fundamental question of criminal law: When are people responsible for the consequences of their own actions?

title: Testimony Opens in Murder Trial of Stock Analyst
description: The first wife of a Wall Street stock analyst accused of killing his second wife testified today that she decided not to tell the police that her former husband had asked her if he could bury the victim in her back yard in Massachusetts.

title: William Wrigley Jr Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Review/Piano; Concentration And Finger Power
description: Veda Zuponcic played an uncompromisingly difficult piano program on Monday evening at Weill Recital Hall. Miss Zuponcic, who is the head of the music department at Glassboro (N. J.) State College, is a formidable player, with an unwaveringly strong technique, and clear well-considered ideas about the music she played.

title: Springs Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for 1988 included an after- tax charge of $11,200,000 made for anticipated expenses connected with relocation of equipment and closing or sale of facilities within the next two years.

title: SSMC Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a pre-tax charge of $17.6 million for restructuring in both periods; the year also included a loss from discontinued operations of $900,000. c-Net income and included losses from discontinued operations of $9.2 million and $12.9 million for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also included a gain of $4.2 million from an accounting change. The company said that losses incurred in its European operations contributed to a decline in the company's earnings, before the restructuring charge, compared to the previous year. The company said the 1988 results were also hurt by price controls and recessionary conditions in Brazil and lower shipments of furniture in the U.S.

title: Seoul Ends Inquiry on Chun Government Abuses
description: Prosecutors today announced the end of their investigations into Government corruption and human-rights abuses of the last eight years.

title: Dow Rises 18.21 Points After Late Surge
description: After being down as much as 15 points earlier in the day, the Dow Jones industrial average surged in late trading to close 18.21 points higher, at 2,342.32.

title: Accounts
description: * Snapper Power Equipment, McDonough, Ga., to J. Walter Thompson, Atlanta, for its garden-equipment advertising. The budget in 1988 was $12 million to $15 million.

title: The Artful Dodger of the Rangers
description: Tomas Sandstrom, who had slipped checks and eluded opponents all night, did not have a bad night dodging questions, either. After the game Monday, Sandstrom, his shoulder pads having been replaced by a long black leather coat, sidestepped the issue of whether he ought to shoot more, brushed off the suggestion that he had cleaned his play of its nasty stickwork, and ducked completely around talk about his future with the Rangers.

title: Mr. Cuomo Cuts, Mr. Koch Bleeds
description: Gov. Mario Cuomo sent New York City a blunt message in his austere budget proposal: Share the pain. Now Mayor Edward Koch has come up with an equally blunt response: Pain is one thing; state-inflicted wounds are another. Who is right? So far, the Mayor sounds more credible.

title: Topics of The Times; South American Revelation
description: No bigger candle is hidden under so vast a bushel as art treasures in the American Museum of Natural History. That is illustrated afresh by the just-opened Hall of South American Peoples, a huge permanent gallery with 2,300 objects spanning 12,000 years. The 11,000-square-foot hall not only fills an ethnographic gap; it is a dazzling esthetic revelation composed of beads, threads, clay and gold.

title: Independent Films Get Better but Go Begging
description: Film critics, film makers and film lovers met in this small ski town last week to celebrate the American independent film just when changes in the movie industry are sending an avalanche into the path of such pictures.

title: Philadelphia Journal; Project Is a Sad Chapter For Historic Waterfront
description: Willard G. Rouse 3d's imprint on this city is as big as its tallest building, One Liberty Place, the 61-story skyscraper the developer completed last year.

title: Sutton Speaks Out
description: Eddie Sutton says he doesn't believe his reputation as a basketball coach has been tainted by the National Collegiate Athletic Association's investigation of the University of Kentucky basketball program. But he is beginning to think of options if he is unable to coach the Wildcats next season. Sutton said that if he resigns or is dismissed when the investigation of 18 allegations of wrongdoing is completed, he would consider coaching at another college or in the N.B.A. The coach also said the other day that he has kept a journal since the investigation began, with the idea of a book in mind. Sutton said he has already been offered aguarantee of at least $100,000 from New York literary agents.(AP)

title: Wright, in Gesture to Bush, Shelves Bill on Covert Acts
description: President Bush's appeal for bipartisanship in foreign policy bore fruit on Capitol Hill today when the Speaker of the House announced that he was shelving legislation that would have required the White House to notify Congress of any covert operations within 48 hours.

title: USX Net Up; Armco Posts Big Increase
description: The USX Corporation, the nation's largest steelmaker, and Armco Inc., another large producer, yesterday announced improved earnings for the fourth quarter.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Friday about Elizabeth Knowlton, a mountain climber, misstated an accomplishment in her career. Miss Knowlton climbed peaks in the Himalayas more than 20,000 feet high in 1932, but she was not the first woman to do so; Fanny Bullock Workman of Worcester, Mass., achieved the feat before World War I.

title: Insteel Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $185,000 and a gain of $600,000 from an accounting change.

title: Worse Than We Knew
description: No nuclear weapon has been exploded on an enemy since World War II. The world knew it had come close to a catastrophe in the 1962 Cuban missile crisis. But it never knew how close until Soviet disclosure last weekend that 20 nuclear warheads, along with their missiles, had actually been deployed in Cuba.

title: The Fascination of the Abomination
description: Lisa Steinberg was a pretty little girl who lived with her lawyer father and her book editor mother on a pretty little street in New York City. Only good things were supposed to happen to her. But one day in November 1987 she was taken to the hospital, brain-dead. Those well-educated parents turned out to be a man with a violent temper and the woman he'd punched into insensibility. Joel Steinberg and Hedda Nussbaum didn't lift a finger to help the child they'd left unconscious on a bathroom floor. Their hands were curled around cocaine pipes.

title: 3d Man Charged as Insider
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday accused a college classmate of a former analyst at Morgan Stanley & Company of illegal insider trading.

title: Polaroid Is Sued On Buyback Plan
description: Shamrock Holdings Inc. filed suit to block the Polaroid Corporation's recapitalization plan, which appears intended to foil Shamrock's $3.2 billion hostile bid. Polaroid last week rejected the $45-a-share bid from Shamrock and Monday announced the recapitalization plan under which it will buy back $1.1 billion of its common stock. It will finance the repurchase partly by issuing $300 million of convertible preferred stock to Corporate Partners L.P., a private investment fund.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Open Ear Policy
description: In the spirit of the Bush Administration's desire for bipartisanship, Secretary of Education Lauro F. Cavazos is doing his best to show that he is ahead of his time.

title: Marion McIlveen, Pediatrician, 78
description: Dr. Marion McIlveen, a pediatrician and clinical professor of pediatrics, died of heart failure Saturday at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J. She was 78 years old and lived in Ridgewood.

title: Sharansky Is a Favorite For Israeli Post at U.N.
description: The Israeli Government is considering appointing Natan Sharansky as Israel's United Nations representative. Mr. Sharansky spent nine years in a Soviet prison before immigrating here in 1986.

title: Premark International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $15,900,000 loss from an accounting change. Year-ago quarter results included pre-tax charges of $36,400,000 for asset writedowns and warranty costs relating to its Bartco Plastics operation. The company said the charge was offset by tax benefits and did not impact net income for 1987.

title: KEY RATES
SELECTION OF JURY BEGINS FOR NORTH
description: Nearly 11 months after he was indicted on criminal charges stemming from the Iran-contra affair, Oliver L. North today finally came face to face with some of the men and women who may judge his guilt or innocence.

title: Harrison M. Davis Jr., 80, Ex-Headmaster
description: Harrison Merrill Davis Jr., headmaster of several preparatory schools during his long career as an educator, died of complications of Parkinson's Disease Monday at the Montgomery (N.Y.) Nursing Home. He was 80 years old and lived in Cornwall-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for speical items.(Loss) *Loss in year-earlier period.

title: MICROWAVE COOKING
description: THERE is more to fish than simple grilling. There are many great soups that are hallmarks of the regions where they were developed. And in any season, a fish soup can introduce a meal or become a whole one.

title: Review/Theater; Two Women as Nearly Anyone Else
description: Kathy Najimy and Mo Gaffney, the authors and stars of ''The Kathy and Mo Show: Parallel Lives,'' are San Diego's amusing answer to Cagney and Lacey, Kate and Allie and other strong-minded pair-bonded women. Kathy and Mo are not detectives or careerists but playful post-feminist satirists.

title: Alfonso de Borbon, 52, of Spain Dies in Colorado Skiing Accident
description: Alfonso de Borbon y de Dampierre, the Duke of Cadiz, was killed Monday in a skiing accident here. He was 52 years old.

title: Mine Workers Call Off Strike Against Pittston Coal Group
description: The United Mine Workers today dropped a strike that had been scheduled for midnight against Pittston Coal Group and said 1,700 miners would continue working without a contract.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Consumers Distributing Inc., Edison, N.J., appointed John Pflug executive vice president. It also named Michael Nussman senior vice president-human resources and a member of the executive committee.

title: Europe's Inflation Rises
description: The European Community's inflation rate rose to 4.4 percent in 1988 from 2.6 percent the previous year, the community's statistics office said today. Last year's rate equaled the United States inflation rate and significantly exceeded Japan's rate of nine-tenths of a percent. The community's consumer price index rose three-tenths of a percent in December, with Portugal, Greece and Spain posting the largest increases.

title: Allied-Signal Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $59,000,000 for both the quarter and year, and the year also included income from discontinued operations of $3,000,000 and a $79,000,000 gain on disposal of discontinued operations. The company said 1988 year net included net restructuring provision of $111,000,000. Also included is an after- tax gain of $36,000,000, or 24 cents a share, on the sale of the company's investment in Akebono Brake Industry Co. Ltd.; an after-tax gain of $81,000,000, or 54 cents a share, from the sale of Bendix electronics business and the formation of a joint venture between the company and Union Carbide Corp., partly offset by an after-tax provision of $14,000,000 for environmental expenditures for shut down facilities. The company also said 1987 year included an after-tax gain of $73,000,000, or 44 cents a share, on the sale of the company's remaining interest in Henley Group Inc. and other related transactions, partly offset by an after- tax loss of $30,000,000 related to the repurchase of high coupon bonds. It also included an $82,000,000, or 49 cents a share, after-tax gain related to an increase in the value of equity of Union Texas Petroleum Holdings Inc. as a result of its initial public common stock offering.

title: G&K Services reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Witness Says He Saw 2 Flee Byrne Slaying
description: A man who was being guarded by a police officer when the officer was murdered testified yesterday that he had seen two of the four men accused in the killing fleeing the murder scene in Queens.

title: Varity Again Seeking To Acquire Fruehauf
description: The Varity Corporation, the Canadian maker of farm and industrial machinery, is making another takeover attempt for the Fruehauf Corporation, the truck trailer and auto parts concern that it came close to buying last year.

title: Sullivan Hearing Is Delayed At Request of White House
description: Hearings on Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, President Bush's choice for Secretary of Health and Human Services, were postponed indefinitely today at the request of the White House.

title: Commodities Exchange Seeks Advice
description: The Chicago Board of Trade announced today that it had hired a former assistant United States attorney to advise it and its members on the use of Federal racketeering laws in white-collar crime cases.

title: G.E. Unit to Offer 10-Year Notes
description: The General Electric Capital Corporation, a unit of the General Electric Company, is offering $250 million worth of 10-year notes through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., which successfully bid for the bond issue yesterday.

title: Centerior Energy Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Latest quarter and year included a write-off of $349 million. Year-ago results are restated to comply with Public Utilities Commision of Ohio (PUCO) orders.

title: In the Search for Baby, a Last Resort
description: ''Oh, you look very attractive,'' said the handsome young man.

title: Topics of The Times; 'Jan Palach Lives!'
description: Two thousand demonstrators recently crowded the main square of Prague to honor the memory of Jan Palach, a 20-year-old student who immolated himself on Jan. 16, 1969. Hundreds of them were beaten and scores were jailed, including Czechoslovakia's most renowned playwright, Vaclav Havel.

title: 'Soft' X-rays May Bring Better Computer Chips
description: The race to build computer chips capable of storing thousands of times the information squeezed into today's most complex chips is almost certain to hinge on the development of a device that can generate X-rays that act much like light. These longer, or ''soft,'' X-rays will still have wavelengths much shorter than visible light, making it possible to etch on silicon wafers circuits far finer than those being made with light and optical lenses.

title: Seville Journal; Expo 92's Promise: New Life or Stale Gazpacho?
description: Ordinarily, it would be a time of joy in this city of fun, flamenco, bullfighting and gazpacho as it spruces itself up for Expo 92.

title: Colombian Jet Hijacking
description: A hijacker who doused a passenger with gasoline and threatened to set a Colombian airliner on fire was arrested today with four accomplices at the airport here, Costa Rican officials said. The hijacker, a Nicaraguan Miskito Indian, surrendered to the authorities after the Boeing 727 of the ACES airline landed at San Jose's airport. It was seized shortly after takeoff from the Colombian island of San Andres on a flight to Medellin, Colombia.

title: Koch and Others Visit Albany To Criticize Cuomo's Budget
description: Insisting that he bore no ill will toward Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, but also saying negotiating with the Governor over the budget was like dealing with an 800-pound gorilla, Mayor Edward I. Koch led a procession of mayors and county executives who traveled here today to criticize Mr. Cuomo's spending plan.

title: Hydraulic Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said its earnings decline was attributable to a drop in earnings for its Bridgeport Hydraulic Co. subsidiary. It also said the prior- year earnings benefited by 22 cents a share from property sales by its nonutility real estate subsidiary.

title: Youngsters Learning to Cook In a Real Restaurant Kitchen
description: ''HERE comes the future!'' some of the staff called out as eight youngsters, led by Georges Masraff, the executive chef at Tavern on the Green, trooped into the restaurant's kitchen. Mr. Masraff was conducting the first of four classes in a series of after-school cooking lessons for children.

title: Microage Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Jackson And Ewing Are Chosen As All-Stars
description: Center and point guard have long been considered the two most important positions in pro basketball. The Knicks are strong at both spots, and yesterday the Eastern Conference coaches named Patrick Ewing and Mark Jackson as substitutes on the All-Star team.

title: Don't Be Fooled by South African 'Reforms'
description: To the Editor:

title: Xerox Canada Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: No Luggage-Cart Fee At European Airports
description: To the Editor:

title: Gondrezick Seeks Help
description: Grant Gondrezick, a reserve guard for the Los Angeles Clippers, told his teammates Monday night before they lost their 15th straight game that he had contacted the National Basketball Association office in New York and requested admission to a substance-abuse treatment center in Van Nuys, Calif. He then asked permission to suit up for the home game against the Atlanta Hawks, but Coach Don Casey would not permit it. ''I don't know what effect it had on the team,'' said Casey. ''I had no suspicion. It's very embarrassing, but he'll get better and his life will go on.'' The Clippers, in announcing Gondrezick's admission to the rehabilitation program, did not specify whether his problem was with drugs or alcohol. Gondrezick, who was averaging 3.9 points, spent his rookie season, 1986-87, with the Phoenix Suns. At the end of that season, Gondrezick, two teammates and two former Suns players were indicted on cocaine-related charges. Gondrezick pleaded guilty to a charge of witness tampering and was fined $100 and placed on three years' probation. The drug charges were dismissed. He played last season with a team in France. (AP)

title: Sequent-Unisys
description: Sequent Computer Systems Inc. reached an agreement to sell its computers through the Unisys Corporation. Sequent said the five-year agreement is expected to produce $10 million in revenues in the first year and up to $240 million more in the remaining four years. Sequent, based in Beaverton, Ore., manufactures parallel processing computers. ''It's quite significant,'' said Jeffery Canin, an analyst at Hambrecht & Quist in San Francisco. He said he had raised his earnings estimates for Sequent.

title: India Economic Outlook
description: A senior World Bank official predicted today that India, buoyed by its best grain harvest in its 40 years of independence, would record one of its highest rates of economic growth this year. ''India seems to be on the move,'' said Attila Karaosmanoglu, a vice president of the World Bank. A report by the Reserve Bank of India estimated that the economy would grow by 9 percent this year. That increase would reflect a 20 percent increase in grain production and a 9 percent rise in industrial production. The record grain harvest is estimated at as much as 175 million tons.

title: Bush Belongs to 3 Men's Clubs
description: In response to press inquiries, the White House issued today a list of the clubs to which President Bush belongs.

title: Bush and Dukakis Took Illegal Money
description: LEAD: The idea has gotten around that the ''soft money'' the Presidential candidates used to supplement their Federal campaign dollars was raised through a loophole in the 1974 Presidential campaign finance law. That's nonsense. There is no loophole. Soft money is illegal.

title: Review/Television; 'Raisin in the Sun' Through '89 Eyes
description: In bringing to the stage a black working-class family, none of whose members sang or danced, ''A Raisin in the Sun'' made a resounding impact on Broadway in 1959. (Naturally, a musical version followed, in 1974.) The 26-year-old playwright, Lorraine Hansberry, furnished the Youngers' already crowded South Side Chicago living room not only with the black-white frictions of a changing society but also, less familiar to theatergoers, with the tensions between generations and sexes in a black household trying to hold its own under tough conditions.

title: What's Gorbachev Paid? $30,000 and Perks
description: Venturing into the shadowy area of Kremlin leaders' private lives, a youth newspaper in the Soviet republic of Moldavia has published an interview reporting Mikhail S. Gorbachev's salary and defending his wife's stylish wardrobe.

title: 2d Psychiatric Worker Accused of Sex Crimes
description: A second employee at the troubled Western New York Children's Psychiatric Center has been charged with sexually abusing a patient, the police said yesterday.

title: Fighters Are Fined
description: The National Basketball Association fined Bill Laimbeer of the Detroit Pistons and Brad Daugherty of the Cleveland Cavaliers $5,000 each yesterday for fighting during a game last Friday. The players had received one-game suspensions without pay -costing Daugherty $10,000 and Laimbeer $7,300 - and both missed games on Sunday. Wayne Embry, the Cavaliers' general manager, was fined $1,000 for leaving his seat behind the Cleveland bench and charging onto the court during the fight. Daugherty is appealing his fine. ''I was wrong to take a swing at him, but to put me in the same boat as Laimbeer is ludicrous,'' he said.(AP)

title: Free-Market Health System: New Thatcher Goal for Britain
description: The Conservative Government announced today that it planned sweeping changes in the National Health Service that would apply free-market methods to the state-financed system.

title: Reviews/Music; Music Out of the Holocaust
description: When music of very different kinds is bound into one thematic concert, it is usually in the lives of its composers that a common bond is found. Saturday night's concert at the Emanu-El Midtown Y, however, remembered not the sharing of lives but of deaths. Eleven composers represented in this long and arduous evening died between 1942 and 1945 and at such places as Furstengrube, Auschwitz, Wulzburg and Dutmergen.

title: W. Paterson Wavers on Namesake
description: Once upon a time, the city of Paterson was so prosperous that two neighboring farming communities longed to be identified with its industrial glory. And so in 1914 a section of Little Falls seceded and became West Paterson, and in 1916 the residents of Dundee Lake chose the name East Paterson.

title: Maxus Energy Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $70 million from an accounting change. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $52.7 million.

title: EDUCATION: Lessons
description: With the possible exception of Thomas Jefferson, who instructed his tombstone carver to recall that he was ''father of the University of Virginia'' but not that he was President of the United States, there is little precedent for how to be an ''education President.''

title: EATING WELL
description: WITH minor exceptions, the Federal Government's Recommended Dietary Allowances are the same for people in their 80's as they are for those who in their 40's. It seems ridiculous on the face of it, but so little work has been done on the nutrient needs of older people that what is available has simply been extrapolated from the work done on adults 50 and under.

title: Japan Adopts Insider-Trading Regulations
description: The Japanese Cabinet approved the details of toughened insider-trading regulations today, defining for the first time what kind of information usually tight-lipped Japanese companies must make public before employees can use it to execute trades.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Federal-Mogul Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge for extinguishment of debt of $1,722,000. c-Included a gain of $4,640,000, or 37 cents a share, from the sale of the company's interest in a joint venture for both the quarter and year.

title: Kohlberg, Kravis to Collect $75 Million RJR Nabisco Fee
description: Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company will collect $75 million for arranging its own $24.88 billion purchase of RJR Nabisco Inc., according to documents filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: U.S. Sets Up Task Forces on Market Fraud
description: The Justice Department will establish task forces in six cities in coordination with other Federal agencies to combat fraud in the nation's securities and commodities markets, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said today.

title: Xerox Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a pre-tax restructuring charge of $275 million. The company said the restructuring charge was equal to $2.40 a share. Before the charge, income in the fourth quarter was $167 million, up 8 percent from a year ago, and share earnings would have been up 10 percent to $1.57. The company also said year net before the fourth quarter restructuring charge was $632 million, a 9 percent increase from 1987, and share earnings for the 1988 year, before the charge, rose 10 percent to $5.90. The largest part of the fourth-quarter $275 million pretax restructuring provision, amounting to about $140 million, came from the writeoff of excess manufacturing capacity in Fremont, Calif., and the closing of a Xerox medical systems plant in Monrovia, Calif., plus selected inventory writedowns. The other major portion of the provision is $100 million for the overhead and employment reductions. c-Net income

title: Tribune Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1987 results included pre-tax charges of $21.7 million for the fourth quarter and $40.1 million for the full year relating to employee severance charges at the New York Daily News. The company said latest-quarter improvement was due to improved newspaper and newsprint results and a lower effective income tax rate.

title: Sunday Shopping Has Its Drawbacks
description: ON several occasions over the last six months I tried to shop for groceries in Manhattan on a Sunday night. On each occasion I gave up and bought carryout food instead.

title: Schering-Plough Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

Market Place;
Asset Managers Attract Interest
description: LEAD: THE stock market's recent revival has caused a spurt of interest in the stocks of asset-management companies. In such an environment, strong earnings suddenly get noticed.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY The Justice Department will establish task forces in six cities to combat fraud in the nation's securities and commodities markets. Attorney General Thornburgh said the permanent structure would lead to more and faster prosecution. [ Page D1. ] The Federal Reserve helped extend economic expansion by raising interest rates in the last 10 months, Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, told Congress. [ D1. ] Treasury Secretary Brady said there was no urgency in adopting measures to curb debt-financed corporate takeovers. [ D2. ] The prices farmers get for raw products rose 1.4 percent from December to January and 12 percent from a year ago. [ D6. ] COMPANIES Xerox will restructure and eliminate 2,000 jobs, taking a $275 million pretax charge in the fourth quarter. [ D1. ] The Bass Group owns 5.6 percent of Houghton Mifflin, whose stock surged $8.875 on the news, to close at $45.25. [ D1. ] Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts will collect $75 million for arranging its own purchase of RJR Nabisco, according to S.E.C. documents. [ D2. ] Eastern Airlines and its machinists are moving closer to a showdown. A 30-day cooling-off period will soon begin. [ D3. ] The shuffle continued at Salomon Brothers, which announced a realignment intended to bolster its merchant banking. [ D4. ] The second GAF stock price manipulation trial began, with both sides making opening arguments. [ D5. ] Control Data posted a $12.8 million loss in the fourth quarter. [ D3. ] USX and Armco announced improved earnings. [ D4. ] Varity is making another bid for Fruehauf, the truck trailer and auto parts concern it came close to purchasing last year. [ D4. ] Carlyle Group raised its offer for Fairchild to $16.30 a share in cash, or a total of $234 million. [ D4. ] MARKETS The dollar rose sharply, moving close to what many traders and economists believe is the upper limit against the West German mark that Washington and its allies have agreed to. [ D1. ] The Dow Jones industrial average surged in late trading to close 18.21 points higher, at 2,342.32. It was the sixth advance in a row, and volume was up sharply. [ D8. ] Prices of Treasury notes and bonds recovered from their lows of the day and closed narrowly mixed. [ D15. ] Soybean and grain prices were sharply higher. [ D16. ] The Chicago Board of Trade hired a former assistant U.S. Attorney to advise it and its members on the use of Federal racketeering laws in white-collar crime cases. [ D5. ] INTERNATIONAL Large-scale insider trading took place before Pechiney acquired Triangle, a French regulatory agency found. [ D6. ] Japan's Cabinet approved insider-trading regulations, defining what companies must make public before employees make trades. [ D6. ] TECHNOLOGY The race to build denser computer chips is certain to hinge on a device that can generate X-rays that act much like light. [ D7. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS More agencies are relying on young media planners to determine where companies should put their ads. Advertising. [ D1. ] Costa Rica's financial negotiators have turned the tables on their commercial creditors. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [ D2. ] The stock market's revival has caused a spurt of interest in the stocks of asset-management companies. Market Place. [ D8. ]

title: Hospital Suspends 3 in Sexual Assault Case
description: Two doctors and a security guard at the Metropolitan Hospital Center in Manhattan have been suspended, bringing to eight the number of employees who have been relieved of their duties while officials investigate complaints that a psychiatric patient there was sexually assaulted.

title: Fernando Namora, Novelist, 69
description: Fernando Namora, one of Portugal's best-known novelists, died today. He was 69 years old.

title: One Designer's Trademark: Restaurants That Tell Stories
description: PAT KULETO, one of the West Coast's most sought-after restaurant designers, has designed 125 restaurants over the past 20 years. Ten more of his creations will open this year. While design is only one element of a restaurant's success, 122 of his restaurants have lasted at least five years, a fact considered remarkable in an industry where restaurateurs say 8 out of 10 ventures fail the first year.

title: Results Plus
description: N.H.L. Canadiens 5, Penguins 1: Mats Naslund and Mike Keane each scored twice, and Patrick Roy stopped 38 shots for Montreal last night at Pittsburgh. Mario Lemieux was held without a point for only the second time in the last 27 games. (AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL/WOMEN Texas 69, Tennessee 67: Clarissa Davis, who was not expected to play because of a sprained ankle, scored 38 points last night to lead 11th-ranked Texas to the upset at home of second-ranked Tennessee (18-2). The Lady Longhorns (13-4) took their first lead at 43-41 with 12:08 left on a jumper by Davis, who scored her team's next 16 points. Tennessee's hopes ended with 25 seconds left when Bridgette Gordon was called for a double dribble with her team trailing, 68-65.(AP) Louisiana Tech 71, New Orleans 62: Venus Lacy had 26 points and 11 rebounds for third-ranked Louisiana Tech, which extended its home winning streak to 39. (AP) HIGH SCHOOL BASKETBALL St. Anthony 69, LaSalle Academy 47: Bob Hurley Jr., the 6-1 all-America point guard, scored 22 points to lead undefeated St. Anthony of Jersey City, the nation's top-ranked team, last night at Draddy Gymnasium in the Bronx. The Friars' victory was their 20th of the season and 38th straight over all.

title: Reviews/Music; Carlo Bergonzi's Arias
description: Carlo Bergonzi, who sang at the Brooklyn Academy of Music Sunday afternoon, is now at the career stage that the great tenor Beniamino Gigli had reached in the early 1950's, when Mr. Bergonzi was starting out. The voice, aged but not abused, is still recognizably itself; the temperament is authentic, the bond of affection with the public is strong.

title: The City; Deaths and Arrests Mount, but the Drug Trade Is Flourishing
description: Although 44,000 drug dealers and users have been arrested in two years, the police in the District of Columbia have failed to shut down the open-air markets that have helped create one of the country's worst illegal drug problems.

title: Coca-Cola Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bush Accepts Reagan Medicare Cuts
description: President Bush plans to propose a $5.5 billion reduction in the projected growth of Medicare, closely following the budget his predecessor, Ronald Reagan, submitted earlier this month, Mr. Bush's budget director said today.

title: Alexander Smalley, 79, Retired Executive
description: Alexander Smalley, a retired executive and former labor leader, died Jan. 24 at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J., after a long illness. He was 79 years old and lived in Boca Raton, Fla.

title: Riverside Chooses New Minister
description: Riverside Church, which conducted a nationwide search to find the right person to carry on the advocacy and eloquence of its prominent pulpit, has picked a man from right across the street to lead the congregation.

title: Citicorp Paper Rates Mixed
description: Interest rates were mixed yesterday at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper.

title: Bridge
description: Longevity and bridge expertise seem to go together. One piece of evidence for that proposition is the original list of 10 life masters established by the American Contract Bridge League in 1936. Nine of them had long careers, living to an average age of 78, and the 10th, Sam Fry, is still going strong at 79.

title: Yankee Food in a Land Where the Crumpet Is King
description: A REUBEN sandwich with white Russian dressing? Buffalo chicken wings in a Tex-Mex restaurant? Welcome to London's version of Yankee cooking. Until five or six years ago American restaurants here mostly served hamburgers and pizzas. Now a more sophisticated assortment of edible Americana has invaded the English restaurant scene: somewhere between burgers and haute cuisine, it consists of British interpretations of American diners, steakhouses, delicatessens, even fine food stores.

title: Cuomo Drops Insistence on Lilco-Pact Ratification
description: Adopting a conciliatory tone, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today dropped his insistence that the State Legislature ratify his accord on closing the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: G.M. Agrees to Settle Blacks' Suit
description: In a move to end a six-year legal battle with its black managers, professionals and clerical workers, the General Motors Corporation has agreed to settle a lawsuit covering 10,000 current and former black workers in the Midwest, it was announced today.

title: Penobscot Shoe Co reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 25
description: Results for 1988 included gains of $28,000 from the sale of assets and securities; results for 1987 included similar gains of $299,000.

title: Florio's Challenge: Avoiding Pitfalls of '81
description: James J. Florio, the man who lost the race for Governor eight years ago by 1,797 votes, has again emerged as the leading candidate to occupy the governor's mansion next January.

title: Study of Foster Infants Finds New York City Failed Them
description: A study of infants who entered New York City's foster-care system in 1985 has found that three years later, the majority remained without permanent homes, their cases often testimony to poor social work, sloppy record-keeping and inaction.

title: The Stealth Fiasco
description: LEAD: If President Bush is serious about closing the budget gap and putting United States security policy on a sound footing, he should start by canceling the Stealth bomber.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 24 about the acquittal of a New York City police officer on departmental charges of striking a New York Times photographer described a picture of his incorrectly.

title: Economic Scene; Costa Rica's Debt Message
description: AS goes Costa Rica's economy, so goes Latin America's? Fears of setting a precedent for the Latin mega-debtors - Mexico, Brazil, Argentina, Venezuela - have stopped foreign banks from settling accounts on realistic terms with this tiny nation. But now Costa Rica's sophisticated financial negotiators have turned the tables on their commercial creditors.

title: Viruses Reported to Be Growing Resistant to Drugs
description: Doctors have found the first significant evidence that viruses are becoming resistant to drugs that are widely used to treat viral infections, especially in AIDS patients.

title: After Suffering Misfortune, Many Give to Neediest Cases
description: Evelyn Lloyd is a single parent living in Manhattan without much money, but she emphasizes, ''I am blessed with a roof over my head and a job to support my two boys.''

title: BP America Restructures
description: BP America Inc., the United States arm of the British Petroleum Company, said it would unify all of its domestic retail gasoline marketing under the single brand name BP. The company has also changed the names of most of its American business streams to reinforce the worldwide emphasis on the BP name.

title: Freddie Mac Sets Offering Of Real Estate Securities
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, is offering $500.1 million worth of real estate mortgage investment conduit securities through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

title: Carlyle Raises Fairchild Offer
description: The Carlyle Group, a Washington-based investment banking concern, has raised its offer to acquire Fairchild Industries to $16.30 a share in cash, or a total of $234 million.

title: A Tea Bag Says No to Congressional Raise
description: To the Editor:

title: Mapco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1987 net included a gain of $51.1 million, or $2.45 a share, from an accounting change.

title: In Search for Diversity, Brandeis Is Challenged
description: At this time of the year, Evelyn E. Handler, the president of Brandeis University, finds herself doing her most important work not at this hilly New England campus with its bare, spidery trees but in the sunshine of Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Don't Be Fooled by South African 'Reforms'; Peace in Angola
description: To the Editor:

title: WINE TALK
description: JUST north of the hamlet of Cussac, the road through the Medoc straightens out and aims directly for Chateau Beychevelle. It is perhaps the most dramatic introduction to any of the famous wine communes of Bordeaux. Even the renowned Pauillac has nothing to match this little allee going up from the cow pastures and marsh land to the vineyards of St.-Julien.

title: Block Drug Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3 percent stock dividend declared in October.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-10

title: Johnston Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Goody Work Goes to Waring
