The estimated loss on disposal, together with the cabinet business operating loss, have been separately classified as loss from discontinued operations. The after-tax losses from discontinued operations for 1988 and 1987 were $67.2 million and $5.5 million, respectively. The 1987 year also included the cumulative effect of a change in the method of accounting for income taxes which increased net earnings by $10.8 million, or 15 cents a share. c-Net income The company said operating results for the latest quarter and year included a charge of 14 cents a share and 20 cents a share, respectively, on an after-tax basis for a portion of the warranty charge related to product sold by Heil-Quaker. The company also said that earnings for 1988 were also adversely affected by higher material costs not recovered through increased pricing, higher levels of interest expense and weaker results from the company's Brazilian affiliates. The effect of these adverse factors was partially offset by a reduction in the federal income tax rate.

title: First American Bancorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest periods included a charge of $20 million from an addition to the company's loan loss reserves.

title: Drug Issue in Riot Raised
description: A 23-year-old black motorcyclist whose fatal shooting by a police officer touched off three nights of violence had traces of cocaine in his system and was carrying a small amount of marijuana, The Miami Herald reported today. The man, Clement Anthony Lloyd, was shot to death by a Hispanic officer, and his passenger died the next day of injuries suffered in the ensuing crash. Homicide victims are routinely tested for drugs.

title: Sullivan's Rough Trip From Halls of Academe
description: Dr. Louis W. Sullivan has had a bruising initiation into the capital's rites and customs, and his trek so far provides a painful lesson in the perils and pitfalls awaiting an innocent traveler in the Washington wilderness.

title: Profit Taking Ends Dow's String of Gains
description: LEAD: Stock prices continued to show an upward trend yesterday, although profit taking in blue chips ended a string of six consecutive gains for the Dow Jones industrial average.

title: Great American Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest fourth quarter included a provision for possible loan losses of $13.7 million and $29.4 million in writedowns of real estate.

title: Bridge
description: In every war there are unknown heroes who would receive medals if anyone knew about their deeds of valor and reported them. Sometimes, as when one dead man is found surrounded by fallen foes, we can infer a remarkable feat of arms.

title: Bausch & Lomb Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Weis Markets Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Florida East Coast Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
USG Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain from divestiture of discontinued operations of $43,664,000 for both periods; the quarter also included a loss from discontinued operations of $2,668,000, and the year included net from discontinued operations of $9,109,000. c-Included net from discontinued operations of $8,083,000 and $31,134,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said the latest fourth quarter and year results reflected recapitalization and restructuring to avoid a hostile takeover. In the latest quarter, the company sold its Masonite Corp. unit and Kinkead division, resulting in the gain of $43.6 million. The company also said its recapitalization plan continues to progress and that its term bank loan has been reduced to $1.05 billion from $1.6 billion. Its U.S. Gypsum Co. unit increased wallboard shipments in 1988 and improved its leading U.S. market share.

title: Kemp Fees for Talks Are Said to Exceed Limits of the House
description: Jack F. Kemp, whom President Bush has chosen for Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, accepted thousands of dollars in speaking fees in excess of the limits set by House rules and Federal law, according to his own financial disclosure statements.

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for speical items.(Loss) *Loss in year-earlier period.

title: FDP Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included a tax credit of $324,191.

title: Where Contemporary Art Is the Decor
description: VACUUM cleaners encased in Lucite are the first thing that visitors encounter when they step off the elevator. Then comes a glimpse of ''In the Vicinity of History'' hanging over the pool table.

title: Alco Standard Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $57,325,000 for the latest quarter and $2,667,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: What's in a Word?
description: To The Home Section:

title: Jorgensen, Earle M Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago periods' nets included $839,000 from recovery of estimated inventory losses charged against income in 1986.

title: Banks Petition Against Grabill
description: A group of banks is trying to force the Grabill Corporation, an industrial conglomerate, and its founder, William Stoecker, into bankruptcy after it failed to make a loan payment.

title: 'Art of Passover'
description: An exhibition titled ''From Seder to Stella: The Art of Passover in the Collections of the Jewish Museum'' is to open Monday at the museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92d Street. The exhibition, which is to run through Oct. 19, includes ceremonial objects used in the observance of Passover and examples of work by 20th-century artists that was inspired by the Passover theme. Admission is $4 for adults, $2 for children and the elderly. Information: 860-1888.

title: Ribi Immunochem Research Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Warning: Campaign Finance Laws Are Enforced
description: To the Editor:

title: New Therapy Found to Aid Sufferers of a Sleep Disorder
description: Doses of an amino acid freed eight narcolepsy patients from their irresistible desire to sleep, French doctors have reported.

title: Charges of Corruption Divide Ancient Navajos
description: A painful new chapter in the long and troubled history of the proud Navajo Nation is unfolding across this vast reservation of stark beauty, chronic poverty and, many say, ingrained corruption.

title: Metro Matters; Can a Candidate Who Stays Cool Ignite Voters?
description: David N. Dinkins is no Jesse Jackson, even though Mr. Jackson is encouraging him to run for mayor. Few politicians are as articulate and charismatic as Mr. Jackson. Nor, stylistically, is Mr. Dinkins an Edward I. Koch or a Harrison J. Goldin, two likely opponents for the Democratic mayoral nomination this year.

title: Snap-On Tools Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

Currents;
Updating a Little Bit Of Gilbert's Terminal
description: LEAD: UNTIL the 1980's the Brooklyn Army Terminal in Sunset Park, a stalwart building designed by Cass Gilbert in 1918, was a military warehouse. But with the terminal obsolete and manufacturing leaving New York some years ago, there came a plan to save both the building and some local manufacturing.

title: Space Shuttle Mission Delayed About 3 Weeks
description: The space agency announced yesterday that it would delay the launching of the next space shuttle mission for about three weeks to replace suspect engine parts whose failure could cause a catastrophic explosion.

title: Star Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $3.5 million writedown of excess inventory. c-Net income

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Builders Transport Inc., Camden, S.C., a trucking company, said Lee A. Gay had resigned as vice chairman and a director for health reasons. His brother Charles C. Gay Jr. will succeed him and take on the post of chief executive formerly held by their father, Charles C. Gay Sr., who continues as chairman. In addition, the company named John R. Morris president, chief operating officer and a director.

title: Rodman & Renshaw Capital reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Stuart Hall reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included an $82,000 gain from an accounting change.

title: G.M.'s Geo Prizm Is Priced at $9,660
description: The General Motors Corporation said that its new Geo Prizm will carry a suggested retail price of $9,660 when it is introduced at certain Chevrolet dealerships next month. Like the Chevrolet Nova, which it succeeds, the Prizm is manufactured by New United Motor Manufacturing Inc., or Nummi, the Fremont, Calif., joint venture between General Motors and the Toyota Motor Corporation. Both the Nova and the Prizm are based on models of the Toyota Corolla, also made by Nummi.

title: Leading Indicators Up by 0.6%
description: The Government's principal economic-forecasting index climbed six-tenths of 1 percent in December, the eighth straight month in which it has reversed direction, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Beverly Investment Properies reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bill Set on Surrogate Mothers
description: A bill to ban surrogate mother contracts will be introduced in Congress Thursday, two House members have said.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL ATLANTA (NL) - Agreed to terms with Gerald Perry, first baseman, and Charlie Puleo, pitcher, on one-year contracts. CALIFORNIA (AL) - Agreed to terms with Chili Davis, outfielder, on a three-year contract. CINCINNATI (NL) - Invited Jeff Gray, pitcher, to spring training as a nonroster player. CLEVELAND (AL) - Agreed to terms with Brad Havens, pitcher, on a one-year contract. METS (NL) - Agreed to terms with Rick Aguilera, pitcher, on a one-year contracts. MILWAUKEE (AL) - Agreed to terms with Rob Deer, outfielder, on a two-year contract, and Dan Plesac, pitcher, on a one-year contract. ST. LOUIS (NL) - Agreed to terms with Todd Worrell, pitcher, on a one-year contract. SAN DIEGO (NL) - Signed Jack Clark, first baseman, to a two-year contract. COLLEGES WESTERN KENTUCKY - Named Jack Harbaugh head football coach. FOOTBALL INDIANAPOLIS (AFC) - Named Milt Jackson receivers coach and Bill Muir defensive line coach. JETS (AFC) - Named Ralph Hawkins defensive coordinator. HOCKEY IINTERNATIONAL LEAGUE - Announced that Phoenix had been granted a franchise and will begin play next season. Named N. Thomas Berry Jr. commissioner. TUESDAY BASEBALL BALTIMORE (AL) - Signed Carl Nichols, catcher, and John Habyan and Mike Smith, pitchers, to one-year contracts. Named Bob Brown, director of publications; Rick Vaughn, public relations director; Bob Miller, assistant public relations director; Wayne Moss, community relations assistant, and Sven Holmes, team counsel. CALIFORNIA (AL) - Announced that Dave Concepcion, infielder, will attend spring training as a nonroster player. CINCINNATI (NL) - Signed Keith Brown and Mike Roesler, pitchers, and Terry McGriff and Eddie Taubensee, catchers, to one-year contracts. MILWAUKEE (AL) - Agreed to terms with Ted Higuera, pitcher, on a one-year contract. PHILADELPHIA (NL) - Signed John Russell, catcher, to a one-year contract. PITTSBURGH (NL) - Announced the retirement of Charlie Muse, traveling secretary. Named Greg Johnson traveling secretary and Jim Lachimia director of media relations effective March 1. SAN FRANCISCO (NL) - Signed Tracy Jones, outfielder; Paul McClellan and Russ Swan, pitchers; Francisco Melendez, infielder, and Jose Pena, catcher, to one-year contracts.

title: BT Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Citadel Holding Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allied-Signal Inc., Morristown, N.J., said that its Allied-Signal Aerospace Co. subsidiary, through its Los Angeles division, Airesearch, had received a contract to provide major components for the environmental systems of the new Airbus A330 and A340. The contract is estimated to be worth $150 million.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY Oil and gas companies are continuing to cut spending on exploration in the U.S. Those plans reflect both the relatively low price of oil and brighter drilling prospects abroad. [ Page A1. ] The index of leading indicators rose 0.6 percent in December, the eighth straight month in which it has reversed direction. But many analysts believe the economy has begun to slow. [ D1. ] Construction spending rose 2.5 percent in December. [ D13. ] The Chicago Merc is considering two changes in trading, traders and lawyers said. One would ban ''verbal orders'' from one broker to another; the other change would reduce the range of trading prices at opening and closing. [ D1. ] President Bush will meet with banking and savings industry officials today to discuss proposals for the savings industry. [ D5. ] The first drug thought to prevent a deadly pneumonia in AIDS patients will be made available next week by Lymphomed. [ A1. ] The E.P.A. found a risk of cancer in a pesticide used on apples but will leave it on the market for at least 18 months. [ A1. ] INTERNATIONAL North and South Korea agreed in principle to a private joint business project, the first such agreement in 43 years of unremitting hostility between the two nations. [ A1. ] COMPANIES Norman Lear will return to producing television programs, in a joint venture with Columbia Pictures Television. He said his first show would be in the ''Mary Hartman'' mold. [ D1. ] Chrysler and Hyundai reached a preliminary agreement under which Chrysler's 1,400 Jeep-Eagle dealers will begin selling a version of Hyundai's Sonata in 1991. [ D1. ] General Motors will indefinitely shut its assembly plant in Framingham, Mass., putting 2,100 employees out of work. [ D3. ] Farley will sweeten its offer for West Point-Pepperell, to $52 a share, or $1.4 billion in cash. [ D2. ] Rexene and Sunshine Mining ended their agreement for Sunshine to buy Rexene for $865 million. [ D2. ] Ryder System will buy back up to 15 percent of its common stock and is exploring the sale of three subsidiaries. [ D4. ] Compaq Computer's profits soared by 88 percent, somewhat lower that its growth of the last two years. [ D4. ] MCI Communications' profits rose fivefold in the fourth quarter, as revenue climbed 38 percent. [ D4. ] Circle K hired an investment banker to explore options to enhance shareholders' value. [ D4. ] MARKETS Stock prices continued to show an upward trend, but profit taking in blue chips ended a string of six consecutive gains for the Dow Jones industrial average, which fell 4.11 points to 2,338.21. [ D8. ] Prices of Treasuries inched higher after the Treasury said that it would sell $28.75 billion of notes and bonds next week. [ D14. ] Yields rose for C.D.'s, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds. [ D11. ] The dollar finished higher against most major currencies in a late surge of buying. [ D15. ] Copper futures prices tumbled on news that a labor agreement had averted a strike in Chile. [ D15. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Madison Avenue is moving west, after six decades on the other side of town. Advertising. [ D1. ] Dillard Department Stores hopes to buy out Vendex, the Dutch company that holds 41 percent of its shares. Talking Deals. [ D2. ] Individual investors have still not returned to the stock market, the Investment Company Institute reported. Market Place. [ D6. ]

title: Tempers and Patience Short In Pay-Conscious Congress
description: It was member against member, offical position against private desire, as Congress wrestled today with whether to let a 50 percent pay increase take effect next week.

title: Nance to Miss Knick Game
description: Larry Nance, who was named to the Eastern Conference All-Star team, will not be playing tonight for the Cleveland Cavaliers when they meet the Knicks in Madison Square Garden.

title: Marie Fish, 88, Dies; Navy Oceanographer
description: Marie Poland Fish, an oceanographer and marine biologist whose research in underwater sound detection helped the United States Navy to distinguish schools of fish from submarines, died yesterday at the Mediplex Nursing Home in Westport, Conn. She was 88 years old and had lived for many years in Kingston, R.I.

title: Treasury Issues Advance Slightly
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds inched slightly higher in slow trading yesterday.

title: Miller's Campaign Files Subpoenaed
description: Federal prosecutors have begun a new inquiry into the financial dealings of two New York State legislators, Assembly Speaker Mel Miller and Senator Martin Markowitz, with the convicted head of a credit union, the United States Attorney in Brooklyn said yesterday.

title: Pact for Crayon Maker
description: Binney & Smith Inc., known for its Crayola brand crayons, has entered into a licensing and royalty agreement with Magic Marker Industries to make and sell products under the Magic Marker name and trademark. Terms were not disclosed. Magic Marker, based in Trenton, has been operating under the protection of Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code since April 1986.

title: O'Sullivan Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Brookfield Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Chemed Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain from discontinued operations of $1,070,000 and $1,335,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; a gain on the termination of a pension program of $472,000 for both the quarter and year, and the year also included a gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change of $1,664,000. The latest quarter and year results reflected the acquisition of Century Papers in July 1988 by the company's National Sanitary Supply Co. unit.

title: Review/Art; Hilma af Klint, Explorer In Realm of the Abstract
description: The two main exhibitions at the P.S. 1 Museum in Long Island City, Queens, form an odd yet effective couple.

description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $18,000 for the quarter and $141,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $483,000 and $526,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and the 6 months also included a credit of $743,000 from an accounting change. Revenue represent rental income.

title: Review/Photography; At Met Museum, Ambitious Images From a Pioneer
description: ONE hundred and fifty years ago, photography was invented not once but twice.

title: Runner From Kenya A Featured Attraction
description: Paul Ereng's experience at the Seoul Olympics last summer proves how much anybody really knows about handicapping a race in track and field. Here was this skinny sophomore from the University of Virginia representing his native country, Kenya, with nothing more than one National Collegiate Athletic Association outdoor championship at 800 meters as his foremost credential.

title: Vikings Ready To Grab Players
description: When the names and numbers from the National Football League's new free-agency system began rolling in yesterday, Mike Lynn rubbed his eyes and checked his list twice.

title: Poll Rates Hazards to Air Travel
description: A majority of Americans support increased anti-terrorist measures on international flights. Even so, nearly two out of three say inadequate airplane maintenance poses a greater danger to air travelers than terrorism does, according to a Media General-Associated Press survey.

title: Viguerie's Target
description: Students of arithmetic may think there are two years from 1988 to 1990. Students of politics know better. For example, according to a Richard A. Viguerie, an advocate of conservative causes who was a highly visible figure in the 1988 election campaign, the 1990 battle has now been joined. The proposed 51 percent Congressional pay rise - to $135,000 from $89,500 -will be ''the No. 1 issue in the 1990 Congressional elections''

title: Mullin Player of Month
description: Chris Mullin, Berry's former college teammate at St. John's University, has been named National Basketball Association Player of the Month for January. Mullin averaged 29.1 points and 7.5 rebounds a game for Golden State.

title: Saving-Unit Quarantine Is Proposed
description: The General Accounting Office told Congress today that regulators should take control of the nation's remaining 350 insolvent savings and loan associations as soon as Congress settles on a plan to deal with the savings crisis.

title: Kyoto Journal; After 600 Years of Serving Emperors, Is It Over?
description: For 650 years, the woodcutters of Yase village have buried Japan's emperors.

title: Allen Organ Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
As Campaign Looms, Goldin And Koch Turn Up Rhetoric
description: The New York City mayoral campaign has barely begun, but its rhetoric turned red-hot yesterday as one unannounced candidate, Mayor Edward I. Koch, accused another, Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin, of using Nazi propaganda tactics to criticize him, and Mr. Goldin demanded an apology.

title: Credo Petroleum reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $82,000 and $18,000 for the latest year and year- earlier period, respectively.

title: Makarova, Home Again, Dances at the Kirov
description: Natalia Makarova stood center stage at the Kirov Theater on Wednesday night, looked up at the heavenly blue walls and the gilded balconies, crossed her arms over her chest, closed her eyes and cried.

title: Bic Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
Bay State Gas Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bridgestone Plans 2d Tennessee Plant
description: The Bridgestone Corporation said it would build a radial truck tire manufacturing plant in Tennessee at a cost of $350 million. The Tokyo-based company said the plant, to be in Warren County, about 65 miles southeast of Nashville, should be operating by 1991 and should generate about 750 new jobs. The daily initial output is expected to be 2,000 tires.

title: Zemex Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Shareholder Sues Apple Computer
description: Apple Computer Inc. said a shareholder's lawsuit had been filed against the company. The suit maintains that Apple failed to disclose in a timely manner information related to the company's expected financial results for its second quarter. Apple said last week that its second-quarter earnings would be depressed because of excess inventory of dynamic random access memory chips bought at inflated prices last summer.

title: Tyson Adds a Trainer
description: After his workout Wednesday in Las Vegas, Nev., Mike Tyson, the heavyweight champion, said that Jay Bright would be assisting another trainer, Aaron Snowell, in preparing him for his Feb. 25 heavyweight title defense against Frank Bruno. Bright has lived in the Catskill, N.Y., home of Camille Ewald, where Tyson was raised, after he was paroled at age 14 to the fight manager Cus D'Amato.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Saatchi Plans to Help Soviet Broadcasters
description: The Soviet Union's experiment in economic restructuring took another step westward yesterday with the announcement that Saatchi & Saatchi, London, will help Gostelradio, the Soviet state radio and television authority, learn to sell and broadcast advertising.

title: International Mirtone Inc reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: The results are in Canadian currency.

title: McGraw-Hill Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Gunman's Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Listing of Black History Month Events
description: February is Black History Month. Here is a sampling of related events. Today FLUSHING COUNCIL ON CULTURE AND THE ARTS, Flushing Gallery, 136-73 41st Avenue (718-463-7700). Exhibition of the work of James Van Der Zee, who opened his first studio in Harlem in 1914 and went on to photograph many famous black personalities, including Marcus Garvey, Bill Cosby and Eubie Blake. Through March 18. Hours: Wednesday through Saturday, 10 A.M. to 1 P.M. and 2-5 P.M. Free. JUST FRIENDS NETWORK OF THE ARTS, Sam Levenson Theater at Brooklyn College, Flatbush and Nostrand Avenue (718-434-1900). George C. Wolfe's play ''The Colored Museum.'' Today, tomorrow and Thursday at 8 P.M. and the next two Sundays at 2 P.M. $3. NEW YORK CITY FIRE MUSEUM, 278 Spring Street (691-1303). An exhibition called ''Black Firefighters - A Photographic Salute,'' which chronicles black firefighters past and present. Through February. Tomorrow at 2 P.M., a special lecture by Charles F. Williams, the grandson of Manhattan's first black fire chief. Reservations required. Museum hours: Tuesday through Saturday, 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Free. SOUTH STREET SEAPORT, A. A. Low Building, 171 John Street (669-9400). A play, ''Life Sea Treasures: Black Americans in Maritime New York,'' covering 100 years of maritime history and the roles that blacks played. For children in grades 3 to 7. After the play, students will meet with actors and staff for workshops. Monday through Friday at 10 A.M., through March 3; Feb. 11 and Feb. 19 at 3 P.M. $5, group rate, $4. Reservations necessary. STATEN ISLAND CHILDREN'S MUSEUM, 1000 Richmond Terrace, Building M, Snug Harbor, Livingston (718-273-2060). Tonight at 7:30 P.M., the Haitian Dance Theater's ''Ethnic Dance Concert,'' a showcase of Caribbean folk traditions. Free. Tomorrow AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street (769-5315). Tomorrow, Amadoma Bediako, performing West African songs with children from the audience. Tomorrow and Sunday, Akyoe, a Ghanaian actor, and Ed Schockley, a pianist, performing works of African and African-American artists. Tomorrow and Sunday, a slide lecture on black cowboys, Native Americans and pioneers presented by George Tooks, a writer. On Sunday, Papa Banko Susso singing traditional Senegalese songs. All at 1 to 4:30 P.M. in the Leonhardt People Center. On Sunday, the group Message From Our Ancestors, performing traditional West African dances and songs from Mali, Senegal, Nigeria and Ghana in the Kaufman Theater at 2 and 4 P.M. Contribution at the viewer's discretion. BROOKLYN CHILDREN'S MUSEUM, 145 Brooklyn Avenue, Crown Heights section (718-735-4432). This weekend, ''Black History Makers'' are illustrated through workshops, performances and discussion with real-life role models. Tomorrow at noon, a corn-husk doll-making workshop with Yla Eason, creator of the Sunman Superhero dolls. At 2 P.M., a black-history and collage workshop with Stella Pollonco, a representative of Con Edison. On Sunday at 2 P.M., an overview of black family life as seen through art and photography, presented by Hazel V. Rodriguez of the Metropolitan Museum of Art; children may make a piece of memorabilia to take home. $2 suggested contribution. CITY OF NEW YORK PARKS AND RECREATION DEPARTMENT, at the edge of Marcus Garvey Park, West 122d Street near Madison Avenue (397-3080). Tomorrow at 2 P.M., a free hour-and-a-half tour of the park with the Urban Park Rangers. UJAMAA THEATER, Lincoln Square Theater, 250 West 65th Street (535-4797). Tomorrow ''The Gospel of the Harlem Renaissance''; on Sunday ''A Tribute to Malcolm X.'' Both at 8 P.M. $20 in advance, $25 at the door. Sunday MUSEUM OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street, (534-1034). On Sunday at 2 P.M., Woodie King Jr. screening and discussing his 1979 film, ''The Black Theater Movement: From 'A Raisin in the Sun' to 'For Colored Girls . . .' '' in the museum auditorium. $3 adults, $1 children.

title: Agency to Study and Shift Cases of Troubled Families
description: In the wake of disclosures that a New York City agency had failed to monitor hundreds of troubled families under its care, child-welfare officials said yesterday that they would begin an extensive review of cases and redistribute them to reduce workloads.

title: Call to Arms Over a Phone on the Green
description: Town greens tend to be sacred ground in New England - especially here in Litchfield County, where the instinct for historical preservation often outmuscles the boldest developer.

title: Ipswich Journal; Fighting Lyme Disease at Its Worst
description: Alice Shurcliff used to love watching six or seven deer nibble on leaves outside her house in the morning. Now she hires a hunter to shoot them.

title: Lucas Carton Sale
description: A Japanese brewing company has bought the Lucas Carton restaurant, reputed to be among the top dozen in the world, for 43 million francs, or about $7.1 million. A spokesman for the cognac producer Remy Martin et Cie, the restaurant's owner, said the Paris culinary landmark had been sold to Asahi Breweries Ltd., a unit of the Sumitomo group. A crucial part of the deal is that the chef Alain Senderens will remain in the kitchens of the restaurant, in the Place de la Madeleine in the Paris city center.

title: Moving Out of Projects And Toward a Future
description: By the time she was 20 years old, Victoria Reed had two children, no job and a one-room apartment in the same bleak inner-city neighborhood where she grew up. ''I was going nowhere , because I had nowhere to go,'' she said recently.

title: McKinney Wins Downhill to End U.S. Slump
description: After skiing the best downhill of her career to win the gold medal in the combined at the world Alpine championships today, Tamara McKinney was still trying to put her achievement in perspective.

description: Swimming Lessons and Other Stories From Firozsha Baag By Rohinton Mistry 250 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $16.95.

title: Memorial for Trey Wilson
description: A memorial service for the actor Trey Wilson is to be held Tuesday at 2 P.M. at the Golden Theater, 252 West 45th Street. Mr. Wilson, who died of a cerebral hemorrhage on Jan. 16 at the age of 40, appeared in the plays ''The Debutante Ball,'' ''The Front Page,'' ''Peter Pan'' ''Tintypes'' and ''Foxfire,'' and the movies ''Bull Durham,'' ''A Soldier's Story,'' ''F/X,'' ''The House on Carroll Street'' and ''Raising Arizona.''

title: Review/Film; Enemies as Allies in a Time of War
description: Now it can be told, if not too effectively: a number of the Viet Cong guerrillas were good, brave, idealistic freedom fighters. The only easily identifiable villains in the Vietnam War were Communist Party functionaries.

title: MDU Resources Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Syncor Names Chief; Chairman to Remain
description: LEAD: The Syncor International Corporation, a distributor of time-sensitive pharmaceuticals that are used in chemotherapy, diagnostic imaging and antibiotic therapy, has named Gene R. McGrevin president and chief executive. Mr. McGrevin replaces Monty Fu, the company founder, who will remain chairman of the 13-year-old concern.

title: Our Towns; Some Neighbors Still Aren't Seen As Neighbors
description: Like a lot of small-town newspapers, the Glen Cove Record-Pilot tries to stress the good. If there's bad news, it usually gets played down. For example, last week there was just one paragraph on a Glen Cove man charged with attempted murder. The story did not name the man or his victim. Maggie Polk, the editor, says that in sensitive matters it's best not to. ''An assistant publisher once told me we don't want to embarrass a guy's family.''

title: Astrosystems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
White Will Accept Offer To Head National League
description: The committee searching for a new National League president has decided to recommend Bill White to succeed A. Bartlett Giamatti, a high-level executive of a league club said yesterday.

title: Ashkenazy Mining a Mahler Vein
description: ''What can I tell you? Do you want me to sound like a musicologist?'' the pianist and conductor Vladimir Ashkenazy protested when asked about the works in which he is leading the Royal Philharmonic this weekend. Mr. Ashkenazy, like many other musicians, has long contended that his performances embody all he has to say about music. And in recent years, his recordings of both the piano and orchestral literature have demonstrated that he has a great many original ideas to express. But if he is a reticent speaker at first, once he warms to the idea of discussing his art he does so with a concise eloquence.

title: Repsol to Sell Stake
description: The Spanish national oil company, Repsol Exploration S.A., said it would offer up to 30 percent of its stock to private investors in the country's biggest privatization. The offering could raise around 165 billion pesetas, or about $1.38 billion, an analyst said. About a third of the shares will be offered to institutional investors in the United States, Japan, West Germany, France, Britain and Switzerland, Repsol's chairman, Oscar Fanjul, said. Repsol was formed in 1987 through the merger of state-owned refining, chemicals and oil exploration companies.

title: Revamping Planned by SmithKline
description: Executives of the SmithKline Beckman Corporation said yesterday that they might create separate companies from the company's eye-care, medical equipment and clinical laboratories units.

title: Tropical-Oil Exporters Seek Reprieve in U.S.
description: Malaysia and the Philippines, which produce most of the world's palm and coconut oils, are waging a campaign to persuade Americans -and through them, major food companies - that tropical oils have no ill effects on health. But the battle already appears to be lost.

title: MCN Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $3,170,000 on bond redemption for the quarter and year.

title: Restaurants
description: One question often posed to a restaurant critic is, ''What is the difference between a three-star and a four-star restaurant?'' Indeed, it is a fine distinction. A succinct explanation would be: a three-star establishment must excel; a four-star must excel and inspire. Le Bernardin, the all-seafood restaurant that received four stars in 1986 shortly after it opened, is a paradigm of a restaurant that does both.

title: Hecla Mining reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included net gains of $1.3 million and $5 million for the quarter and year, respectively, due to the reassessment of the company's income tax liability and the application of the liability method of accounting for income taxes. c-Included a loss of 5 cents a share from an accounting change.

title: Extradition Is Upheld for Bombing Suspect
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn ruled yesterday that a naturalized United States citizen accused in a 1986 terrorist attack on a bus in the Israeli-occupied West Bank could be extradited to Israel. Judge Edward R. Korman overruled a decision by a magistrate who had found the arrest of the man, Mahmoud Abed Atta, 35 years old, was ''impermissible.''

title: Purdue Upsets No. 2 Illinois by 76-72
description: Melvin McCants scored 12 of his 16 points in the second half and Purdue made 61 percent of its shots to upset No. 2 Illinois, 76-72, tonight in a Big Ten Conference game.

title: 4 Kidder Executives Quit Firm
description: The turmoil at Kidder, Peabody & Company intensified yesterday as the head of the firm's investment banking department and three other executives resigned.

title: U. of Chicago Bars Recruiters of Top Firm Because of Slurs
description: The University of Chicago Law School yesterday barred the world's largest law firm from recruiting on campus for a year, a result of a student's complaint of racist, sexist and anti-Semitic slurs by a partner during a job interview.

title: 'Forgotten War'
description: After almost four decades, American veterans of the Korean War will finally have a memorial commemorating their service and the 165,707 killed, wounded and missing from 1950 to 1953 in what has come to be called the ''Forgotten War.''

title: Review/Theater; After Deaths, Wandering Through One's Own Life
description: ''The Cezanne Syndrome,'' the opening play in the SoHo Rep's three-week festival of new French-Canadian drama, is a brief hallucinatory chronicle of a death retold. A mother and child have died in an automobile accident and the grief-stricken father goes through daily domestic routines while his mind wanders in time and fantasy. He imagines that his wife has returned from the grave to help explain the apparent inexplicability of the collision.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Monday described a rise in the number of lesbians who are bearing children, usually after artificial insemination. It included the psychological speculation of clinicians, whom it did not identify, that children of lesbian parents might develop problems in intimate relationships or sexual identity. It said these difficulties could be worse if lesbian parents are openly hostile to men.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums ''THE SNOW QUEEN,'' a play with music, adapted from the Hans Christian Andersen tale by Randolph Pearson, who is also the director, with music by Judy Spencer, l and 3:30 P.M. Saturdays, at Hartley House Theater, 413 West 46th Street. Tickets: $5. Reservations: 666-1716. ''HEARTS AND HANDS,'' a family workshop led by Pegi Vail, who will show prints and period settings at the Museum of the City of New York that trace the development of Valentine's Day customs, and teach how to make Victorian valentines, 2 P.M. tomorrow, at the museum, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street. Tickets: children, $1; adults, $3. Information: 534-1034. CHAMBER MUSIC CONCERT, a program of works by Mozart and Beethoven, presented by Steven Lubin and Myron Lutzke, both of the Mozartean Players, and Mary Ann Frank, a soprano, who will introduce young listeners to chamber music, 3 P.M. tomorrow, at the Armor Hall, Wave Hill, 675 West 252d Street, the Bronx. Tickets: children, $3; adults, $5. Information: 549-3200. STORYTELLING WITH PUPPETS, a show with music, by the Hudson Vagabond Puppets, including some giant puppets, 1 and 3 P.M. Sunday, at the school, 25 School Lane, Scarsdale, N.Y. Tickets: $5, includes hot cocoa and cookies. Information: (914) 693-5595 or (914) 723-1169. ''HANSEL AND GRETEL,'' a show by Nicolas Coppola's Puppetworks, 1 and 3 P.M. Sundays through Feb. 26 at 287 Third Avenue, in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn. Tickets: children, $3.75; adults, $4. Reservations: (718) 834-1828. ''THE BEAST,'' musical by Tom Oliver with audience participation, 1 and 3 P.M. Saturdays, and ''The Rose That Refused to Bloom,'' a musical, 1 and 3 P.M. Sundays at the 13th Street Repertory Company, 50 West 13th Street. Tickets: $4. Information: 675-6677.

title: Nader's Crossed Line
description: Ralph Nader went on the Pat Sajak television talk show this week to deplore the Congressional pay rise that will take effect next week unless it is blocked by Congress. He invited listeners to telephone his office to offer their opinions. Unfortunately, he gave the wrong telephone number.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Ogilvy Posts Gains
description: The Ogilvy Group reported 1988 revenues of $838.1 million, a 13.5 percent increase over the previous year. Net income for the year rose 10.7 percent, to $32.9 million, or $2.25 a share, a record for the company. The revenue growth was stronger than most analysts had expected, said Emma Hill, who follows advertising stocks for Wertheim, Schroder & Company. But the company's announced operating profit margins of 7.9 percent, while slightly higher than last year's operating margins of 7.8 percent, are ''still below where investors would like to see them,'' she said.

title: Trion Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a one-time reduction of $366,000 in accumulated deferred income taxes due to implementation of an accounting standard.

title: Action Auto Rental Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
American Filtrona Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Microdyne Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: b-After a loss of $19,000 for the quarter and a $208,000 gain for the year, both on the disposal of discontinued operations.

title: Coastal Says F.T.C. Seeks Data on Bid
description: The Coastal Corporation said the Federal Trade Commission had requested additional information under Federal antitrust laws on its $2.6 billion offer for the Texas Eastern Corporation, an oil and gas producer. The request extends the waiting period for buying Texas Eastern's shares under a tender offer that was about to expire on Wednesday until 10 days after Coastal complies with the request. Coastal said it was studying the request and would comply as soon as possible.

title: One Mile of Gowanus Expressway Is Closed
description: A one-mile stretch of the southbound Gowanus Expressway in Brooklyn was closed yesterday when a routine inspection for New York State uncovered cracks in the steel structure under the roadway, state and city transportation officials said.

title: Zonic Corp reports earnings for
description: b-Net loss

title: Nuclear Waste in Colorado May Be Loaded on Boxcars
description: The Energy Department said today that it might have to put radioactive waste from its Rocky Flats nuclear plant near Denver aboard boxcars and ship it to military bases in Western states.

title: Britain Approves Minorco's Pursuit of Consolidated Gold
description: The British Government gave approval today for the overseas investment arm of the Anglo American Corporation of South Africa to pursue a multibillion-dollar takeover bid for Consolidated Gold Fields P.L.C.

title: At the Movies
description: Anne Archer's Choices

title: Gannett Co reports earnings for 13wks to Dec 25
description: b-Included a pretax gain of about $45 million from the sale of the company's investment in Cowles Media in February 1988.

title: Fairchild Rejects A Sweetened Offer
description: Fairchild Industries, a military electronics company, rejected as inadequate a sweetened $16.30-a-share bid from the Carlyle Group, a Washington-based investment firm. Carlyle controls a partnership that owns 10 percent of Fairchild's stock. Before making its latest proposal on Tuesday, worth $230 million, it offered $15.50 a share earlier last month.

title: Buffton Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Unemployment Rate Can Drop Below 4%
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Need for Tritium Is Seen as Less Urgent
description: The Government has more time than previously believed to reopen a South Carolina plant that produces a vital gas used in nuclear weapons, Administration officials said today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Succession at Barnum
description: Barbara Barnum has been named to succeed her late husband, H. James Barnum, as chairman of Barnum Communications, a New York agency specializing in advertising and public relations for pharmaceutical and medical products. A former director of the Division of Health Services, Science and Education at the Teachers College of Columbia University, Mrs. Barnum has been a member of the agency's board since 1986. Her husband died of cancer last week after a long illness.

title: Warriors Top Nets For 7th Straight
description: Mitch Richmond scored 32 points, and Terry Teagle tied his season high with 22 and had 10 rebounds as the Golden State Warriors rallied for a 127-113 victory over the New Jersey Nets tonight.

title: Chubb Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After realized investment losses of $9.5 million for the quarter and $13 million for the year. c-After realized investment losses of $36.7 million and $14.6 million for the quarter and year, respectively. The latest quarter included tax benefits of 12 cents a share and 48 cents a share for the quarter and year, respectively, relating to ''fresh start'' adjustment compared to benefits of 17 cents a share for the year-ago quarter and 68 cents a share for the year. The company said the latest quarter also included charges relating to the rain insurance program of 38 cents share and 84 cents a share for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Soviet Joins Shootout
description: Rimas Kurtinaitis, the leading scorer in the Soviet Union's 82-76 victory over the United States in the Seoul Olympics last summer, will participate in the Long Distance Shootout on N.B.A. All-Star Saturday, Feb. 11, at the Summit in Houston. The 6-foot-5-inch Kurtinaitis had the highest single-round score in a recent Lithuanian 3-point shot contest, an event based on the N.B.A.'s event. (AP)

title: Amgen reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Officer Indicted In Man's Death In Traffic Fight
description: A police officer was indicted yesterday in the off-duty slaying of a 59-year-old Brooklyn man in a traffic dispute.

title: Information Solutions reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
Coca-Cola Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest fourth quarter included results of Coca-Cola Bottling Co. of Memphis, Tenn.; the Florida operations of Coca-Cola Bottling Co. of Miami; and all of the Maryland and a portion of the Delaware operations of Delaware Coco- Cola Bottling Co., all acquired in the first quarter of 1988. It also included results of Coca-Cola Bottling Co. of Mid-America through the date of its sale, Dec. 16, 1988. The company also said its income for the latest quarter was reduced by a pretax restructuring charge of $27 million and a pretax gain of $103.8 million, or about 43 cents a share, from the sale of Coca-Cola Bottling Co. of Mid-America.

title: Foothill Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest year and year-ago periods included gains of $359,000 and $602,000, respectively, both from tax credits and the early extinguishment of debt.

title: Dance for Children
description: On Sunday, the Corner Store Dance Company will present ''The Day I Had a Cold,'' a modern-dance program of stories, poems, props and songs for preschool and elementary-school children at the Ansche Chesed Synagogue, West End Avenue at 100th Street. The 2 P.M. performance is a benefit for B.J.'s Kids Day Care Community. Admission: $5 at the door or tickets may be bought at Eeyore's Books for children, 2212 Broadway, at 79th Street. Information: 877-0684.

title: Bush and Takeshita Explore Problem-Solving
description: Pledging closer economic and political cooperation, Japan and the United States began today to explore new mechanisms to work out trade disputes and other issues.

title: Valero Energy Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-Included a gain of $72.8 million on partnership formation, a loss from discontinued operations of $14.4 million, an extraordinary loss of $11.6 million and a gain of $7 million from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Gateway Federal Savings & Loan Assn reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $274,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. c-Included tax credits of $265,000 and $2,595,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company began public trading in June 1987 and no share earnings comparisons are available for periods prior to that time.

title: Homosexual Lawyers Keep Fighting Barriers
description: Richard Failla had kept his private life under wraps as he rose through the ranks of the Manhattan District Attorney's office to become one of the most respected members of the elite homicide bureau.

title: M/A-Com Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest first quarter included a gain of $1.1 million from the partial sale of securities of an unrelated company.

title: A First for Some Businesses: Contributing to the Neediest
description: Paul Stuart, the Madison Avenue clothier, is a new contributor to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Travelers Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included realized investment gains of $41 million for the quarter, and the year included realized investment losses of $327 million and a gain of $33 million from the sale of several investment properties in Hartford, Conn. c-Included realized investment loss of $55 million. Fourth-quarter operating income in 1988 included $13 million in tax benefits from property-casualty fresh- start provisions, compared with $25 million in the same period of 1987. The company said provisions for actual and potential losses from real estate investments had a major effect on 1988 results. The primary impact of these provisions occurred in the second quarter when, as previously reported, the company added $415 million to real estate reserves. Operating income for the year included $50 million of fresh-start provisions, compared with $72 million in 1987.

title: Pitney Bowes Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $6,190,000 gain from discontinued operations and $125,000 in net from discontinued operations. c-Included net from discontinued operations of $696,000 and $4,159,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. Year-ago periods were restated to reflect the required consolidation of previously unconsolidated financing subsidiaries in accordance with Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 94, as well as for discontinued operations.

title: United Investors Management reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is part of Torchmark Corp. and until early last year was named TMK-United.

title: IRAN MAY BORROW AT BANKS ABROAD TO REVIVE ECONOMY
description: On the 10th anniversary of its revolution, Iran has decided to borrow abroad for development projects and to resume exports of natural gas to the Soviet Union, Iran's oil minister said today.

title: Tampa Market Chain Offers High-Yield Debt and Stock
description: Kash N' Karry Food Stores, a supermarket operator based in Tampa, Fla., is offering $155 million of notes and debentures and four million units of stock through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Respironics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Taylor Devices reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Net income in all relevant periods was less than one cent a share.

title: Review/Dance; The Perils of Drinking
description: Emily and Brendan are in love. So are Allison and Joshua. Kira wants to be a dancer. They are attractive young people. But most of them love liquor more than they do themselves or one another.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We could see a scenario develop under which there will be 10 or 20 votes on this thing this year. The two bodies each want to get the ball bounced into the other one's court for the last pass. It's kind of interesting watching it. The last body doing it is the one that will get blamed, presumably.'' - Senator Larry Pressler, Republican of South Dakota, an opponent of a Congressional pay raise. [ A1:2. ]

title: Foremost Corp of America reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $383,000 and $1,049,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; income from an accounting change of $4,290,000 for the quarter and $5,360,000 for the year, and the quarter included an after-tax gain of $578,000 and the year included an extraordinary loss of $1,953,000. c-Included extraodinary losses of $777,000 for the quarter and $1,955,000 for the year, and gains from discontinued operations of $3,270,000 and $11,487,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: The Drug Train
description: It is a familiar nightmare; we have all had it. The train is coming right down the track at somebody you know, and you scream, ''Get out of the way, get out of the way!'' But he doesn't move, and the train comes on and on and you wake up sweating.

title: Irwin Recovers and Stalks Leaders
description: Hale Irwin, two-time winner of the United States Open, was struck on the forehead Wednesday by a golf ball an amateur hit from an adjacent fairway during the pro-am prelude to the Nissan Los Angeles Open.

title: Bowmar Instrument reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included a loss of $245,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Africa Posted Growth in '88
description: Economic reforms are starting to bear fruit in southern Africa, but the region faces a series of tough challenges, including the need to slow population growth, if it is to preserve what are still fragile successes, a senior World Bank official said today.

title: Up From Reagan
description: Forget all that family hoopla, the pork rinds nonsense and the good-old-boy image-making. Reserve judgment on the savings account ''fee'' fiasco. All that's par for the course for any new President. On two major fronts, however, the Bush Administration really has asserted itself as an improvement on its predecessor.

title: Kentucky Roots
description: Kentucky Roots, a bluegrass group, is to perform tomorrow at 9 P.M. at the Eagle Tavern, 355 West 14th Street (924-0275). Admission is $7.

title: Dragons and Dancers, Firecrackers and Food
description: Whether pondering the puns or unraveling the riddle, one may join in various New Year's festivities in Chinatown in lower Manhattan, the new Chinese community in Flushing, Queens, and throughout New York this weekend and during the following week.

title: First Financial Corp of Wisonsin reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax benefits of $110,000 for the quarter and $3,784,000 for the year. c-Included tax benefits of $1,426,000 and $5,027,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also included a charge from a penalty on the payment of debt. The company said the year-ago results are restated for the March 31, 1988 merger conversion of National Savings & Loan Association, which was accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Gang's All Here

title: Chamber Symphony
description: Christoph Eschenbach is to lead the New York Chamber Symphony in music of Mozart, Prokofiev and Hindemith at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue, tomorrow evening at 8 o'clock. Mr. Eschenbach, who began his career as a pianist and is now music director of the Houston Symphony, is to be the soloist in the Mozart Piano Concerto No. 21. Also on the program are Mozart's Symphony No. 38, Prokofiev's ''Classical'' Symphony and Hindemith's ''Trauermusik.'' Jean Dane is to be the soloist in the Hindemith. The program is to be repeated on Sunday at 3 P.M. Tickets are $17 to $22.50. Information: 996-1100.

title: Goulds Pumps Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said latest year earnings would have been 16 cents a share greater had it not been for startup costs associated with the Raytec Water Group Partnership which it entered a year-ago.

description: b-After a charge of $118,000 from early retirement of debt. c-After a tax credit of $554,000.

The increase in shares outstanding mostly resulted from the conversion of the company's $27.7 million in convertible debentures into 1,881,000 common shares in September 1988.

title: Herbert Ross, 61, Designed of Supermarkets
description: Herbert Ross, an industrial designer who specialized in supermarket interiors, died of cancer Sunday at the Tisch Hospital of New York University. He was 61 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: A. P. Keasbey Jr., 72, Insulation Contractor
description: Aertsen P. Keasbey Jr., an engineer and a leader in the insulation industry, died of cancer Sunday at the Northern Westchester Medical Center in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 72 years old and lived in Mount Kisco.

Botha Quits as Head Of Nationalist Party; To Remain President
description: President P. W. Botha, recuperating from a stroke, resigned abruptly today as leader of the National Party, which has governed South Africa for the last 40 years.

Pregnant Woman in Coma Is Focus of Abortion Debate
description: The fate of a comatose, pregnant woman has drawn supporters and opponents of abortion to a courtroom here for a case that both groups say could set legal and medical precedents.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary by The Associated Press on Wednesday about Alfonso de Borbon y de Dampierre, the Duke of Cadiz, described a court action incorrectly. After a 1984 car crash in which the Duke's elder son was killed, a Spanish court granted the boy's mother temporary custody of the other son. But six months later the court ruled that the child could be returned to his father's custody. The article also misidentified the Duke's former wife. She is Maria del Carmen Martinez-Bordiu y Franco.

title: Duquesne Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Aid for Driving Course Barred
description: Education Department officials said today they had banned an Indianapolis-based trade school from participating in Federal student aid programs for such classes as a truck-driving correspondence course.

title: Review/Film; Mixing Infatuation And Doubt
description: The people who made ''The January Man'' can breathe more easily this morning - theirs is no longer the worst movie of 1989. That distinction now goes to ''Her Alibi,'' a romantic melodrama of a boringness to make your average tooth extraction seem preferable.

title: Dionne Goes to Denver
description: Marcel Dionne, 37 years old and playing in his 18th National Hockey League season, will report to the Rangers' International Hockey League team in Denver Tuesday for two weeks of conditioning, the club announced yesterday.

title: Fruit of the Loom Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from debt refinancing of $5,400,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Net loss and after income from discontinued operations of $5,000,000 and a $56,200,000 loss from debt refinancing. The company said the 1988 net included a gain of $23,400,000, or 38 cents a share, related to the effects of the sale of the company's investment in tax benefit leases.

title: Greenspan Emphasizes Seriousness of the Deficit
description: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, dismissed as fanciful today the notion that concerns about the deficit have been overblown.

title: Warsaw Pact's Chief Is Replaced By One in Tune With Gorbachev
description: The Soviet leadership announced today that Marshal Viktor G. Kulikov would be replaced after 17 years as military commander of the Warsaw Pact by Pyotr G. Lushev, a four-star general regarded as a strong supporter of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's military policies.

title: Thornburgh Help for 2 Is Considered Unlikely
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh is unlikely to grant a request by the Rev. Jesse Jackson that the Attorney General help free two former Maryland legislators while they appeal criminal convictions, Justice Department sources speaking on condition of anonymity said today.

title: Home Sales Up by 0.6% In Month, 0.9% in Year
description: New-home sales rose six-tenths of 1 percent in December, but for all of 1988, sales edged up just nine-tenths of 1 percent, a lackluster increase that analysts attributed to the dampening effect of higher mortgage rates.

title: 'Disabled' Man Taped As He Changes a Tire
description: A man who sued the Transit Authority for $2 million, claiming a bus accident left him so weak he needed a cane to walk, withdrew his claim Wednesday after the authority showed the judge a videotape of him changing a tire.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alexander & Alexander Services Inc., an insurance broker, appointed Peter C. Godsoe, vice chairman of the Bank of Nova Scotia, as a director. W. Douglas H. Gardiner has retired from the board.

title: 2 Transit Officers Called 'Partners in Crime'
description: Two New York City transit police officers who are charged with making false arrests ''were partners in patrolling the New York City subway system and also partners in crime,'' a Federal prosecutor said yesterday.

title: Trans Leasing International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Peru's Inflation Rate Up
description: Peru's inflation rate reached 47.3 percent last month, compared with 41.9 percent in December and 12.8 percent in January 1988, the National Statistics Institute said today. The rate rose to 2,280 percent for the last 12 months.

title: Galaxy Chesse reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Nissan Purchases
description: The Nissan Motor Company, Japan's second-largest car maker, said it planned to increase its purchases of American-made semiconductors. The products now account for 2 percent of total semiconductor use by Nissan in its cars and trucks, and the company is hoping to increase that share to 10 percent in 1992. Nissan and its affiliated component makers will form a committee to study ways of increasing the use of United States semiconductors, a spokesman said.

title: Freshman With a Past Opens Doors With Humor
description: Representative Ben Jones, a freshman Congressman from Georgia, came to town this year carrying some heavy political baggage.

title: Shaklee to Sell Japanese Stake
description: The Shaklee Corporation, which sells vitamins, household items and personal-care products in the home, said yesterday that it had signed an agreement to sell its 78 percent interest in Shaklee Japan K.K. to the Yamanouchi Pharmaceutical Company for about $350 million. The company, based in San

title: January Sales Strong at Big Retailers
description: The nation's biggest retailers yesterday reported strong January sales, ending their 1988 fiscal year on a surprisingly solid note compared with the year before.

title: Hannaford Brothers Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings results have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split which will be distributed Feb. 28.

title: Review/Art; With Caricatures, Doings of the French Revolution
description: During the French Revolution, a Parisian could remain informed about the meaning of a recent decree or the significance of the latest beheading by wandering into a print shop or strolling through the garden of the Palais-Royal, where caricatures were sold. These 18th-century political cartoons were often hastily produced by anonymous artists and sometimes by artists of the first rank like Jacques-Louis David.

title: Inspeech Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included a $2,470,000 loss on marketable securities. The figures for 1987 were restated for fiscal year-end adjustments.

title: Lawyers Shown Evidence From Commodities Inquiry
description: After more than two weeks of telling commodity traders and brokers that they were under investigation for a broad range of possible trading abuses, Federal prosecutors became specific today and told more than a dozen brokers that the Government had concrete evidence of one type of offense, defense lawyers said.

title: American Family Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Standard Havens Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included gains from discontinued operations of $169,584 and $15,892 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

Shifts Seen In World Debt Policy
description: For the first time since James A. Baker 3d, who was then the Treasury Secretary, laid out a strategy more than three years ago for funneling money into developing countries, the United States is expected to support an effort to make major changes in the plan.

title: Nichols-Homeshield Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Ogilvy-Omnicom Tie
description: After a gestation period of nearly a year, Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide and the Omnicom Group, two of the world's largest advertising companies, announced yesterday that they had given birth to an elephant, a new joint venture to negotiate for and buy time and space from broadcasters and publishers in Europe. The Media Partnership is only one of several European media-buying combines being contemplated by American-based agencies, which are trying to compete with several enormous indigenous media-buying services in Europe for favorable treatment by the large communications conglomerates there.

title: Telos Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $89,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Knicks Rout Cavaliers As Strickland Sparkles
description: Anyone who still needed convincing that the Knicks made the right move last summer when they made Rod Strickland their top draft choice as Mark Jackson's backup got it last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Chrysler Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago year sales were restated to reflect consolidation of Chrysler Financial Corp. results. Fiscal 1988 included an $85 million pretax gain from an initial public offering in Japan for Mitsubishi Motors Corp., of which Chrysler owns 21 percent. The gain is equivalent to 23 cents a share after tax. Latest year also included a $93.1 million provision taken in the first quarter for previously reported plant closings in Chrysler's Acustar parts subsidiary. Prior year earnings were reduced by $86.4 million by adoption of a new financial accounting standard for pensions.

title: 2 BUSH NOMINEES FACE NEW SCRUTINY
description: John G. Tower and Dr. Louis W. Sullivan encountered new troubles today as the Federal Bureau of Investigation extended its examination of the two nominees for the Cabinet.

title: Tenneco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included net from discontinued operations of $775 million and $823 million for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss and included losses from discontinued operations of $82 million and $206 million for the quarter and year, respectively. Revenue for all periods was from continuing operations. Latest fourth-quarter results included after-tax restructuring charges of $199 million. The company said its net for the latest quarter before the special charges was $22 million, or 11 cents a share. The year-ago fourth-quarter results also included an aftertax special charge of $181 million. Latest-year loss from continuing operations included fourth-quarter after-tax charges of $199 million. The charges include $125 million related to a previously-announced increase in take-or-pay and contract reformation costs for Tenneco's pipeline group; $58 million involving the rationalization of certain chemical manufacturing capacity; and $16 million related to the company's decision to dispose of the farm and construction equipment business in South Africa. The company said its 1988 net income before the special charges was $198 million, or $1.19 a share. The company also said its 1987 loss from continuing operations included a pipeline group aftertax charge of $181 million related to the take-or-pay issue.

title: McClain Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Mitek Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Profit Up 10.5% at Gannett; McGraw-Hill Posts Increase
description: The Gannett Company said yesterday that its earnings rose 10.5 percent in the fourth quarter, while McGraw-Hill Inc. said its earnings improved by 10.2 percent. Gannett

title: Electronic Futures Trading Cleared
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission today approved a global computer trading network, called Globex, which will enable the futures and options trading markets to operate electronically after regular trading hours.

title: Youth Pleads Guilty In Murder of a Broker
description: A 19-year-old youth faces 30 years in prison after pleading guilty to murder in the fatal shooting of a Greenwich, Conn., stockbroker on June 2, lawyers said.

title: Suspect Held in W. Virginia After Discovery of 6 Bodies
description: The authorities have discovered the bodies of six people who were shot in the head with a shotgun near a trailer compound, and one of the residents has been charged with two of the deaths.

title: L'Affaire Bastille: Yahoos' Triumph
description: On Jan. 13, Daniel Barenboim got fired from his job as director of the Bastille Opera in Paris, which was scheduled to be inaugurated early next year. On Jan. 30, it was announced that Mr. Barenboim had another job. He will succeed Sir Georg Solti as musical director of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra.

title: Roto-Rooter Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $282,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Oilers Name Holovak To Replace Herzeg
description: Mike Holovak, who engineered the draft strategy that helped put the Houston Oilers into the National Football League playoffs the last two seasons, was named the club's general manager yesterday. Holovak replaces Ladd Herzeg, who resigned unexpectedly Wednesday night. Holovak, 69 years old, joined Houston in 1981 and was an assistant to Herzeg, who spent 13 years with the Oilers.

title: Pop/Jazz; A Legacy Of Black Culture
description: All across New York City this weekend, Black History Month gets under way. There's probably no better place to celebrate it, either, what with New York's myriad of African-descended cultures. The plethora of regularly scheduled religious, musical and dance events are all bolstered with special shows demonstrating the richness and variety of the African legacy in the Americas.

title: Knopf Editor Is Named Publisher at Atheneum
description: Lee Goerner, an editor at Alfred A. Knopf, has been named publisher of Atheneum Publishers. The announcement was made Wednesday by Barry Lippman, the president and publisher of the Macmillan adult-trade group. Atheneum is an imprint of Macmillan.

title: Bureaucracy and Big Repairs Stall '86 Plan for Drug Centers
description: In 1986, faced with a crack epidemic, Mayor Edward I. Koch promised the state 10 buildings to use as drug treatment centers. Since then, only one building has been transferred to a drug treatment group, and it will not open for months. Two burned, five have liens on them, two have been condemned and all are in such serious disrepair that they will not be ready until late this year or next year.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Avon Products Inc. will sell part of the assets of its Retirement Inns of America Inc. unit for $11 million in cash and the assumption of $4 million in debt to American Retirement Villas Inc., Costa Mesa, Calif.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; An Exhibit That Honors 2 Standouts
description: GEORGE GOMES and Dick Loew, a pair of commercial auteurs who have kept television viewers giggling and sighing for two decades, are being honored by the Museum of Broadcasting with the first exhibition in its history devoted exclusively to the work of individual commercial directors.

title: Drexel Property Expert Moves to Smith Barney
description: William S. Rubinstein, a real estate financing expert with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., has left to join Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company as a managing director.

title: Review/Music; Post-Modern Sounds
description: Scott Johnson is a post-modern rhapsodist. His compositions peregrinate from idiom to idiom, from Minimalism to progressive rock to electronics to snippets of speech to the sweet-and-sour melodicism of Milhaud or Prokofiev. But the music balances variety and continuity, as Mr. Johnson spins out musical ideas in a plausible yet unpredictable succession.

title: Memories Of a Night In Asuncion
description: Just the sight of the Paraguayan players brought it all back for Bob Seguso and Ken Flach: the curses, the coins flying through the air, the threat of knifeplay in the dark Paraguayan night.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a Connecticut Supreme Court ruling on removal of life support misstated the role of the Society for the Right to Die. The society joined the case as a friend of the court; the patient's family was represented by the law firm of Wise & Layton.

title: Getting Out With Honor; Soviets Focus on Task of Afghan Pullout As a Pact Fades and Analysis Is Deferred
description: As the last Soviet troops muster in Kabul for their convoy home from Afghanistan, the Kremlin has already turned its attention to a desperate salvage operation aimed at snatching as much honor as possible from the jaws of retreat.

Intel in Technology Pact With A.T.&T.
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Intel Corporation have formed a product and technology exchange agreement on microelectronic chips for communications use. Under the five-year accord, the companies will produce and market each other's existing chips and work to develop and manufacture future products.

title: Reviews/Film; Behind the Voices of the Townships
description: The documentary ''Voices of 'Sarafina!' '' makes it easy to understand why the Broadway show's young South African performers have such incandescent energy onstage, and why they seem such a close-knit band. As to the latter point, they shared the common experience of living at the house of their director, Mbongeni Ngema, for the first several months of their stay in the United States. And, at least as they are seen on camera, they seem to do everything en masse.

title: Lomas & Nettleton Mortgage Investors reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Riddle to Illuminate The Chinese New Year
description: CHINESE New Year, which begins Sunday at midnight, is a time not only for exploding firecrackers, festive lion and dragon dancers and elaborate banquets, but also an occasion when the Chinese penchant for riddles and puns runs wild. As the Year of the Snake (4687) dawns, literal-minded meanings get thrown to the wind, and celebrations abound in the 300,000-strong Chinese-Americans of New York.

title: Indian Contracts Sought With Gifts
description: Contractors seeking business reserved for Indians on the Navajo reservation in Arizona told a Senate committee today that they provided the tribe's chairman with free airplane rides, a $35,000 loan that was never repaid and other favors, The allegations concerning the chairman, Peter MacDonald, were made by two whites and a Navajo who own construction companies, testifying under immunity before a special panel of the Senate Select Committee on Indian Affairs, which is investigating corruption in programs intended to help Indians. The witnesses said they set up dummy concerns headed by Indians whose sole purpose was to qualify for jobs reserved for Indians.

description: Judging from recent events in New Jersey, one thing judges cannot abide is being judged themselves.

title: PARAGUAY GENERAL LEADS A REBELLION
description: Army units rebelled against the Government Thursday night, and early today a spokesman for the political opposition said President Alfredo Stroessner, the Western Hemisphere's longest-ruling leader, had been put under arrest.

title: Ashford Calls for an End To Women's Steroid Use
description: Proclaiming herself a ''natural athlete,'' the Olympic sprinter Evelyn Ashford made an emotional plea on Capitol Hill today for an end to the use of performance-enhancing drugs by some of her fellow female track stars.

description: As often happens in Davis Cup competition, both sides saw advantages from the blind draw yesterday for the round between Paraguay and the United States, which begins today in Fort Myers, Fla.

title: Saudis Seen as Top Mideast Buyer of U.S. Arms

title: The Alliance, Without an Enemy
description: LEAD: Americans, Europeans and Japanese are natural competitors. But in the past, none of their commercial and financial rivalries could become political rivalries because of the looming presence of a threatening Soviet Union. Strategic cooperation in the face of the common threat always had absolute priority.

title: Farm Status Unhealthy, Cabinet Nominee Says
description: Clayton K. Yeutter, the nominee for Secretary of Agriculture, said at his confirmation hearing today that American agriculture was far too dependent on taxpayers for its livelihood.

title: Economic Scene; Social Security And the Budget
description: PRESIDENT BUSH plans to present his revisions of President Reagan's final budget next week. The Bush changes are likely to include a reduction in the growth of military spending to zero from Mr. Reagan's 2 percent, adjusted for inflation. That should shave a few billion dollars from the proposed military outlays of $293.8 billion in 1990. Also likely is a $5.5 billion reduction in the projected growth of Medicare, which is facing a near-term financial crisis; a rise in interest payments on the public debt, as rates have been running higher than Mr. Reagan's economists forecast, and a slowing of economic growth from 3.5 percent to a bit more than 3 percent.

title: Chrysler and Renault in Venture
description: In its second international deal this week, the Chrysler Corporation said yesterday that it had entered into a $500 million joint venture with Renault, the French auto maker, to build a small sports utility vehicle.

The Editorial Notebook; Who Makes Foreign Policy?
description: White House officials are upset about a Times story reporting that President Bush has put the national security adviser at the heart of the foreign affairs decision-making process. The officials understandably don't want to start a war with the State Department and the Pentagon. But they shouldn't be surprised at the consternation; there are few touchier relationships than that between the security adviser and the Secretary of State.

title: Devils, Kings in 6-6 Tie

title: Review/Music; Quick Answers in Conductor's Debut
description: The most promising young American conductor to come along in many years, Hugh Wolff, made his debut on Wednesday evening with the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall. In previous New York appearances at the head of the New Jersey Symphony, of which he is music director, Mr. Wolff produced results that raised hopes for his future dangerously high. How would the slim 35-year-old deal with a major orchestra with a long history of being hard on mediocre or poorly prepared guest conductors?

title: TV Weekend; A Way With Killers
description: In case anybody was wondering, ''Unsub,'' the uneuphonious title of the hourlong crime series that starts tonight at 10 on NBC, is short for ''unknown subject.'' The ''unsub'' in question this week is a serial killer whose behavior invites the skills of the Behavioral Science Lab, a super-special unit of the Justice Department (it says in the program notes) that is ready to travel from Washington to wherever murder strikes.

Admission is free. Information on hours: 870-7507.

title: On Stage
description: A 'Lampoon' for Broadway It's more than a dream, a gleam in the eye and even talk - nevertheless, it's still amorphous. It's what producers describe as ''in development.'' But by fall, if everything goes according to plan, it should be a show called ''National Lampoon's American Tricentennial'' and, depending on which producer you're talking to, by the end of the year, or spring 1990, after regional tryouts, it should be on Broadway, at the Ritz Theater, to be exact.

Valukas, the United States Attorney in Chicago, on the people who had complained about his methods.
