title: Rockets Sign Berry
description: Walter Berry, who was released by the Nets Monday, was signed to a contract for the rest of the season by the Houston Rockets yesterday and will be in uniform tonight for the game against Chicago. ''Walter Berry gives us a different dimension,'' said Coach Don Chaney of the Rockets. ''We have obtained a great one-on-one player who adds to our depth.''

title: Reviews/Film; Missteps of a Gumshoe: 'Who's Harry Crumb?'
description: Surely John Candy has a funny film inside him somewhere, but it refuses to come out. In ''Who's Harry Crumb?'' Mr. Candy has a varied role, a good supporting cast, a script full of comic setups and every imaginable opportunity to shine. But the result, which opens today at the Gemini Twin and other theaters, is little more than a weak comedy, one that suggests Mr. Candy is potentially a great deal better than his material.

title: Dining Out Guide: Romantic
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. Bouley ** (Nov. 20, 1987), 165 Duane Street (608-3852) - With Valentine's Day approaching, many couples are seeking restaurants that have not only good food but a romantic ambiance as well. Bouley, one of New York's prettiest restaurants, serves a Provencal menu in its dining room decorated with Impressionist paintings and 18-foot window boxes, now planted with tulips and wildflowers. Current appetizers include cured gravlax of tuna, and Maine salmon with crab meat, tomato horseradish and chervil vinaigrette. Among the entrees are sea scallops with verjus sauce on puree of celery root; rack of lamb, and roasted pigeon served on sweet onions and red cabbage. An appropriate dessert might be the ''romantic chocolate plate'' with five chocolate treats. The five-course lunch is $32 prix fixe; the nine-course tasting menu at dinner is $65. A la carte prices at dinner are $6 to $16 for appetizers, $19 to $27 for entrees. Open noon to 3 P.M. and 6 to 11 P.M. Friday, 6 to 11 P.M. Saturday. Closed Sunday. Restaurant Raphael ** (Nov. 28, 1986), 33 West 54th Street (582-8993) - Elegance and tranquillity in a town house setting are characteristics of this restaurant. The long rectangular dining room has a decorative fireplace and pale yellow walls alternating with murals of southern France. A romantic dinner could begin with duck confit salad or seafood ravioli in saffron sauce. Among the entrees are marinated and roasted lamb with green lentils, poached lobster with fresh pasta, and veal medallions with rosemary sauce. For dessert, passion-fruit mousse is recommended. Appetizers are $9.50 to $10.50, entrees $19.50 to $28. Dinner 6 to 10 P.M. Friday, 6 to 11 P.M. Saturday. Closed Sunday. The Terrace ** (March 21, 1986), 400 West 119th Street (666-9490) - The Terrace has many romantic enticements, among them sensational views uptown and down. Well-spaced tables are delicately appointed with tall candles and single red roses, and the menu leans toward classic French with a light touch. Some of these preparations include appetizers of Wellfleet oysters with sauce mignonette, and terrine of roasted eggplant, tomato and sweet pepper. Featured main courses are medallions of salmon with caviar and sorrel, grilled beef fillet with red-wine-marrow sauce, and breast and confit of Muscovy duck with port wine and figs. Raspberry napoleon is an exceptionally good dessert choice. On Valentine's Day the Terrace offers a $58 prix fixe menu from 6 to 9:30 P.M. (A $20 deposit is required.) Regular a la carte prices are $9.50 to $21 for appetizers, $24 to $28 for entrees. Open 6 to 10 P.M. Friday and Saturday. Closed Sunday. Trastevere ** (Sept. 6, 1985), 309 East 83d Street (734-6343) - This tiny slice of a Roman-style restaurant has a candlelit, brick-walled dining room. Trastevere's traditional homespun offerings are prepared with quality ingredients and include appetizers of lightly fried spiedino alla Romana made with prosciutto, mozzarella and anchovy sauce, and mussels in garlic-spiked tomato broth. Good pasta choices (which can be divided as a first course) are linguine with white clam sauce, and cappellini primavera. The limited entree menu has three chicken, three veal and four seafood dishes. Appetizers are $5.95 to $7.95, entrees $10.95 to $24.95. Open 5 to 11 P.M. Friday to Sunday. Water's Edge * (Jan. 2, 1987), East River Yacht Club, 44th Drive at the East River, Long Island City, Queens (718-482-0033) - There is romance on the industrial waterfront of Queens: the Water's Edge, cool-white and glassy, offers a stunning panorama of midtown Manhattan and a setting designed to inspire heartfelt conversation. The menu includes appetizers of grilled quail breasts and chestnut ravioli, and white bean and shrimp chili. Recommended entrees are sauteed Dover sole and rack of lamb. Other choices from the current menu are grilled bluefin tuna, and veal chop with a potato napoleon, green peppercorns and cognac. Strawberry shortcake might be a romantic's choice for dessert. For Valentine's Day, the restaurant will offer a four-course dinner for two for $100 from 6 to 10:30 P.M. The shuttle boat from East 23d Street will operate off-season for that evening only. Regular prices are $9.50 to $18 for appetizers, $23 to $30 for entrees. Hours are 5 to 11 P.M. Friday and Saturday, 5 to 10 P.M. Sunday. What the stars mean, page C22.

title: Review/Music; Cecil Taylor, Clearinghouse Of Jazz Ideas
description: Perhaps more than any other jazz artist, the pianist Cecil Taylor's performances have to be seen in concert. He is a spectacle, and people come to see him flail away at the piano, where he'll cock his arms stiffly for a second, roll the backs of his hands over the keyboards, or drop his elbows across the keys. His performances -and the image he's created for himself - drip with European notions of the romantic artist, swooning under the influence of the muse.

title: Cash In on the Homeless
description: The ragged, deranged man shivering on a steam grate symbolizes a costly potential burden for society - but he may also represent something much more positive: thousands of dollars in potential cash benefits from Government programs. The mentally ill street people, perhaps the most pathetic of the homeless and those who most disrupt the quality of life, may be eligible for especially large payments. Yet New York City's programs for dealing with them rarely mine this gold.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: The Taffetas

title: Judge Presses For an Accord In Lilco Case
description: For almost seven hours yesterday a Federal judge alternately lectured to and debated with a more than 30 lawyers in an apparent effort to force a resolution of the racketeering case against the Long Island Lighting Company. The outcome could determine the future of the utility's Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: Gentex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Europe-Indonesia Deal
description: The European Community has agreed to allow Indonesia to export 25.5 million knitted garments to the community this year, the largest quota granted to any supplier, a textile trade group said today. Hong Kong, previously the largest supplier of knitted garments to the 12-nation trading bloc, received a quota of 25.32 million pieces, said Chamrul Djafri, an executive of the Indonesian Textile Association.

title: General Public Utilities Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the reduction in latest quarter earnings resulted primarily from the refueling and maintenance outage at the Oyster Creek nuclear generating station, an expected disallowance of replacement power costs pursuant to the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities nuclear plant performance standard, and a favorable tax settlement for the years 1979- 1982 that was recognized in the fourth quarter of 1987.

title: AFGHAN REBEL SEES AN EARLY COLLAPSE
description: An Afghan guerrilla leader predicted today that Kabul would be captured ''in weeks, not months,'' because steps had been taken to encourage the city's collapse from within.

title: Noble Affiliates Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The prior year included a pre-tax gain of $20,096,000 from exchange of note receivables from Nobel Drilling Corp. for 5,112,782 shares of Noble Drilling common stock.

title: Federal Screw Works reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: MANILA AIDE VISITS AN AILING MARCOS
description: The Philippine Vice President arrived here today to visit former President Ferdinand E. Marcos, who was said to be critically ill after a respiratory operation.

title: 4 BUSH NOMINEES BACKED BY SENATE
description: The Senate gave quick and unanimous approval today to four high-level nominees of President Bush, including Jack F. Kemp as become Secretary of Housing and Urban Development and Manuel Lujan Jr. as Secretary of the Interior.

title: Molson Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results are in Canadian currency.

title: HDR Power Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Brazil's Debt Can Save the Amazon
description: Brazil owes the world $115 billion. The world wants Brazil to stop recklessly destroying the Amazon rain forest, an extraordinary natural wonder. Those two conditions invite a deal, a grand debt-for-nature swap that would ease Brazil's burden of foreign borrowing and preserve the Amazon forests. What stands in the way of so compelling a solution? Brazil's President, Jose Sarney, for one thing. Last month his Foreign Minister, Roberto de Abreu Sodre, received an American delegation that included Thomas Lovejoy, a tropical biologist, and Senators Tim Wirth, Albert Gore and John Heinz. Mr. Sodre enthusiastically endorsed the idea of a Brazilian foundation to administer a debt-for-nature swap. But when the group reached the presidential palace, Mr. Sarney rejected the idea as foreign interference. ''We don't want the Amazon to become a green Persian Gulf,'' he said.

title: Albany Still at Odds Over Shoreham
description: Two months after a proposed deal to close the Shoreham nuclear power plant died for lack of legislative approval, attempts to revive the deal have been stalled by virtually the same issue: who will take political responsibility for it?

title: KEY RATES
William Stephenson, British Spy Known as Intrepid, Is Dead at 93
description: Sir William Stephenson, the Canadian-born millionaire industrialist whose adventures as Britain's World War II chief of intelligence in the Western Hemisphere were chronicled in the 1979 bestseller ''A Man Called Intrepid'' died Tuesday in Paget, Bermuda. He was 93 years old. Sir William, who had been living in retirement in Bermuda and Jamaica for many years, was given the code name Intrepid by Winston Churchill because long before his cloak-and-dagger days began he had been one of Britain's top fighter pilots in World War I, an inventor and a financier.

title: Tempest Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GNI Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $144,160. c-Net income d-Included a loss of $3,141 for the quarter and income of $58,407 for the 6 months both from discontinued operations, and tax credits of $89,188 and $131,473 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: H.C.A. Suitor To Sell Units
description: TF Investments Inc., the management group that is seeking to acquire the Hospital Corporation of America in a $3.6 billion leveraged buyout, will have to sell certain assets to repay a $1.3 billion bridge loan within two years after the completion of the buyout.

title: Treasury Issues Little Changed
description: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes were little changed in extremely light trading yesterday as market participants chose to wait for this morning's release of January employment data before establishing new positions.

title: Royal International Optical reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Morris Pike, 92, an Ex-Insurance Executive
description: Morris Pike, an actuary and lawyer who was a vice president of the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company before his retirement in 1961, died of pneumonia on Jan. 27 at White Plains Hospital. He was 92 years old and lived in White Plains.

title:
About Real Estate;
7-Story Condo Is Built in Sunnyside
description: LEAD: Building sites are hard to find in desirable areas of Queens, especially in the more densely populated older residential neighborhoods close to Manhattan.

title: Fiserv Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Forida Rock Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $1,507,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The company said the increases in sales and profits are primarily attributable to the inclusion of the result of Arundel Corp., which was purchased on Jan. 26, 1988.

title: Amdahl to Buy Key Computer
description: The Amdahl Corporation agreed to acquire Key Computer Laboratories Inc., a private company based in Fremont, Calif., for Amdahl stock valued at about $30 million. With 60 employees, Key specializes in computer systems based on Unix, the industry standard operating system developed by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, and other mainframe computer technologies.

title: Maritrans Partners LP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings are in units.

title: Southern Indiana Gas & Elecric Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
New Ventures Are Planned For 2 Koreas
description: The founder of the Hyundai Corporation, Chung Ju Yung, announced plans today for several more joint ventures between North and South Korea amid some Government concern about the pace of economic cooperation.

title: Coke Bottler's Net Surges
description: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., the bottling company spawned by the Coca-Cola Company, reported today that its net income quadrupled in the fourth quarter because of a one-time gain from the sale of a subsidiary.

title: Profits Scoreboard
MS Carriers reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Official Resigns At Nomura
description: Robin S. Koskinen resigned Wednesday as executive vice president at Nomura Securities International Inc., where he was in charge of the fixed-income operations unit. The unit, which Mr. Koskinen started four and a half years ago, employs 120 people handling Government and corporate bonds, mortgage-backed securities and Japanese yen bonds.

title: Green Van Carries Hope of New Housing
description: A green van with a city seal on the side stopped in front of the welfare hotel on West 104th Street, and seven women and one man got in. A seat in the van was probably their last chance at finding a permanent place to live in New York City.

title: U.N. Plans to Start Kabul Airlift Soon
description: Overcoming opposition from the Afghan guerrillas, United Nations officials say they believe they will be able to start flying food and medicines to Kabul, the Afghan capital, in the next few days.

title: Torchmark Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included securities losses of $8,551,000 and $5,111,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes a securities loss of $12,338,000 for the quarter, and the year includes a securities gain of $429,000 and an extraordinary loss of $7,903,000. Results for 1987 included non-recurring after-tax gains from the sale of subsidiaries of $14 million, or 21 cents a share.

title: Alico Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Charles Galbraith, 64, A Medical Educator
description: Charles L. Galbraith, a creator of patient simulation models used to train medical students and doctors, died of leukemia Saturday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York. He was 64 years old and lived in Jersey City.

title: What's Wrong With Last-Minute Petitions to Stay Execution
description: To the Editor:

title: Gap Between Cost of Drug Epidemic and State Money Shuts California Clinic
description: The only clinic providing routine health care to the bulk of this city's poor closed today, a victim of insufficient state reimbursement of medical costs that have risen dramatically because of the crack epidemic.

title: Arvin Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $7,979,000 for the quarter and $12,929,000 for the year. c-Net income d-After losses from discontinued operations of $147,000 and $28,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Swing for Dancing
description: Bill Conway and Swing Express will play swing music for dancing in a program presented by the New York Swing Society, on tomorrow at the Cat Club, 76 East 13th Street (505-0090). Doors open at 7 P.M., with music beginning at 8; tickets are $8, $4 for the elderly.

title: Aquanautics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-After net from discontinued operations of $75,000 for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Bill White a Unanimous Choice to Head National League
description: Bill White's name was not on the first list of candidates to succeed Bart Giamatti as National League president. But yesterday, when White was officially introduced to the news media at a midtown hotel, it was clear he was the popular choice. The longtime Yankee broadcaster, who will take office April 1, will become the National League's 13th president. More significant, he will be the first black to head a major professional sports league.

title: P. I. Prentice, 82, Former Publisher of Time
description: P. I. Prentice, a former publisher of Time magazine and other periodicals, died Thursday at Morton Plant Hospital in Clearwater, Fla. after suffering a series of strokes over the last three years. He was 89 years old and lived in Belleair, Fla.

title: 4 Olympians Suspended For South Africa Trip
description: John Powell, winner of two Olympic bronze medals, was suspended for six years yesterday for participating in a track and field tour of South Africa last year, and three other Olympians were suspended for four years each.

title: Touring Soviet Dancers Left Without Funds in Baltimore
description: Fifty-nine ballet dancers from the Soviet Union who opened a United States tour in Baltimore on Thursday may have to return home because their American producers have lost expected financing. ''We don't even have the money to feed them,'' a spokesman for the producers said yesterday.

title: RLI Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TCI International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago quarter net per share was restated for 10-percent stock dividend in September. Year-ago quarter revenue was restated to include consolidated results of BR Communications from Oct. 1, 1987, which was previously accounted for under the equity method of accounting.

title: Aquino's Vice President Asks Sympathy for Ailing Marcos
description: The Philippine Vice President returned to Manila today after publicly urging that his onetime rival, Ferdinand E. Marcos, be treated with ''compassion and forgiveness.''

title: General American Investors reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Assets represent net assets. The company said the latest year net assets per share are after long- term capital gain distributions of $1.69 a share in December and 21 cents a share in February, and income dividends of 24 cents a share in December and 1 cent a share in February.

title: Much of the U.S. Shivers and Skids
description: An ocean of Arctic air that engulfed much of the nation this week with the year's bitterest cold continued its assault yesterday, sending temperatures plunging to merciless lows from the Pacific Northwest to the Great Lakes and icing the landscape from Texas to New England.

title: Grace Hayes, 93, Dies; Stage and Film Actress
description: Grace Hayes, an actress, died on Wednesday in Las Vegas, Nev. She was 93 years old.

title: Dodging in Albany
description: Showing appropriate toughness, New York State's Commission on Government Integrity threatens to subpoena top legislative leaders if they don't voluntarily testify about campaign finances. Assembly Speaker Mel Miller, a Democrat, and Ralph Marino, the State Senate majority leader, a Republican, contend that their appearance at a commission hearing would violate the constitutional separation of powers between the Legislature and the executive branch.

title: Voluntarism Should Focus on the Urban Poor; Catholic Bishops' Work
description: To the Editor:

title: First Bancorp (N. C.) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said earnings have been restated to reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid Jan. 20.

title: Cooper Cos.  reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $68,815,000 and $66,665,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and an extraordinary gain of $11,272,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Net income d-Included losses from discontinued operations of $8,915,000 $16,758,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and an extraordinary credit of $700,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary charge of $17,200,000 for the year. The company said prior year results are restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: Micron Products reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest quarter and year share earnings reflected preferred dividend requirements.

title: Review/Opera; A Welsh 'Falstaff' Plays Brooklyn
description: The Welsh National Opera's 1988 production of Verdi's ''Falstaff,'' seen Thursday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, was a fascinating, heartening experience, quite apart from the pleasure it presumably afforded Di-watchers.

title: How to Un-Veto Federal Ethics
description: Government service, the new President says, is a ''noble calling'' and his Administration will not tolerate even the ''appearance of what is wrong.'' The two ideas, whose declaration from the White House is warmly welcome, reinforce each other. A strong way to assure the nobility of public service is to make clear that public servants live by high standards.

title: Dow Off a 3d Straight Day but Up for Week
description: Stock prices ended mixed yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average dropped for the third consecutive day.

title: Japan Surplus Up in Month
description: Japan said today that its trade surplus in December was nearly $1 billion higher than it was in December 1987, but that for the year the surplus slipped 2 percent, to $94.79 billion.

title: James F. Darr, Communications Executive, 72
description: James Franklin Darr, a leader in shifting wire service transmissions from teletype and telephone lines to computers and satellites, died of heart failure yesterday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Stamford, Conn. He was 72 years old and lived in Stamford.

title: Review/Film; Bronson and the Japanese
description: Here is one important cultural difference between Tokyo and Los Angeles, according to ''Kinjite'' (which is subtitled ''Forbidden Subjects''): In Tokyo, a man can furtively grope a woman on a crowded subway car and be confident that she will be too embarrassed to call attention to his behavior. If he tries the same thing on a Los Angeles bus, though, he may be shrieked at, accosted by his fellow passengers and angrily pursued by Charles Bronson.

title: South Korean Debt Falls
description: South Korea's foreign debt declined by $4.4 billion during 1988, the Bank of Korea reported today. The country's foreign debt fell to $31.2 billion in December 1988 from $35.6 billion in December 1987, the bank said. Bank officials said South Korea registered a record trade surplus of $14.27 billion in its current account in 1988, up 44.8 percent from $9.85 billion in 1987. It was the third consecutive year of a trade surplus.

title: Paraguay Coup: Battle for Succession
description: The overthrow of Paraguay's aging dictator, Gen. Alfredo Stroessner, followed an intense power struggle within his regime between two factions fighting to control the country after his death.

title: P.L.O. Shift on Violence 'Irrelevant,' Arens Says
description: Moshe Arens, Israel's new Foreign Minister, believes that nothing could be more irrelevant than the Israeli Army's recent finding that Yasir Arafat's arm of the Palestine Liberation Organization has ceased guerrilla attacks against Israel.

title: JERSEY'S IS DOWN
description: The unemployment rate in New York State edged up slightly last month, while New Jersey's figure returned to nearly its lowest level in two decades, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Group of 7 to Try to Keep Dollar at Present Levels
description: The Group of Seven industrial countries agreed today to try to keep the dollar at its current levels, despite pressures in the financial markets to push it higher.

title: F.F.O. Financial Group reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The per share earnings not applicable; bank converted to stock form of ownership on Oct. 13, 1988.

title: Scientist Says Antarctic Oil Spill Does Significant Harm to Wildlife
description: Looking out at a wrecked Argentine ship, an American biologist in Antarctica yesterday reported the ''depressing'' toll of the leaking oil on the fragile and once unspoiled environment. He described spreading oil slicks, dying sea life, penguins in peril, and adult birds disappearing and leaving their chicks to predators.

title: U.N. Reports Iran-Iraq Talks Are Picking Up
description: Iran and Iraq are showing some movement in their long-stalled peace negotiations, offering small concessions in talks with a United Nations mediator, Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar reported today.

title: North Africa Bloc Seen
description: Five heads of state will meet in Marrakesh, Morocco, this month to discuss forming a North African trade union, the Moroccan Foreign Ministry said today. The trade bloc -to be known as the Arab Maghreb Union - would link the 62 million people of Algeria, Morocco, Tunisia, Libya and Mauritania in a type of common market. Supporters say that forming the bloc would strengthen the region's position in international trade talks and enable the countries to capitalize on their natural resources.

title: New Aide for Browns
description: George Sefcik, who was the offensive coordinator for the Kansas City Chiefs last season, has been hired by the Cleveland Browns as the new coach of running backs. Sefcik was the offensive backfield coach for the Browns from 1975 to 1977.(AP)

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Money Market Funds
description: Money market mutual funds are more popular today than they have been in some time. Investors pulling back from recent volatility in the stock and bond markets have been using mutual funds as a parking place while they decide which investment route to take. Individuals are also using the funds as a savings or cash management tool, in addition to other kinds of investments. Third-quarter data for 1988 indicate thatthe number of shareholder accounts and total assets in money market funds will surpass 1987 levels, when there were a record 16.8 million accounts and assets were at a record $255 billion. The average yield of a money market mutual fund last week was higher than both six-month and one-year certificates of deposit and bank money market accounts. *2*Yield Current Year Ago Accounts (Percent) (Percent) Money Market Fund 8.76 6.53 Bank money market account 6.33 5.61 Six-month C.D. 8.37 7.06 Passbook savings 5-5.19 Unchanged (Sources: Investment Company Institute; Donoghu's Money Fund Report)

title: NEW GUIDE, LESS SQUINTING
description: Help for the visually impaired shopper is now at hand in the form of a new guide published by Consumer Reports.

title: Biocraft Labs reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Review/Music; Dutoit and the Montrealers In Debussy and Beethoven
description: There is a wide, all but unbridgeable, gap between playing a piece of music and performing it. Disputes between listeners often involve this distinction, although it is seldom clear from the rhetoric vented that either party recognizes exactly what divides them. Audiences sometimes seem torn between those listeners, often amateur musicians themselves, who can be tremendously excited by hearing playing that is without technical flaw, and those who require something more of music. The second group faithfully attends concerts and recitals hoping now and then to hear a genuine performance, one that brings not only moment-by-moment pleasure but also one that may arouse intense, essentially indescribable, feelings of participation in a ritual whose secrets are the property of a blessed few initiates.

title: How Congress Can Rescue Thrifts
description: LEAD: The savings and loan industry has amassed $100 billion in losses, bankrupting its insurance fund - the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation - several times over. Before we, the taxpayers, are through cleaning it up, the debacle will have cost the typical family of four $2,000. The sad - and frustrating - part is that it didn't have to happen.

title: Dime Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said fourth quarter and full year 1988 figures included the results of operations of City Savings Bank following the completion of its acquisition by Dime Financial on Dec. 2, 1988.

title: Fuentes to Write Series On Columbus for TV
description: The Mexican author Carlos Fuentes will write and narrate a five-part television series to commemorate the 500th anniversary of Columbus's voyage, the Smithsonian Institution has announced.

title: Armatron International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $41,000. c-Net loss The latest first quarter operating net included a pretax gain of $584,000 from the sale of a building.

title: L.I. Man Is Sentenced In Murder of His Wife
description: Matthew Solomon was sentenced to 18 years to life in prison today for murdering his wife, Lisa, on Christmas Eve in 1987.

title: Illinois Is Urged To Repeal Law For AIDS Tests
description: The first year of mandatory prenuptial AIDS testing in Illinois has turned up few cases of the virus and has caused tens of thousands of people to flee the state to be married and untold others to put off marriage altogether, Illinois health officials say.

title: Growth Stock Outlook Trust Inc reports earnings for As of Dec 31
description: Assets represent net assets. Per share results for the latest year reflect distributions of 40.6 cent a share in December 1988 and 1.28 cent a share in April 1988.

title: Quayle, in San Salvador, Discusses Human Rights
description: Vice President Dan Quayle arrived today and forcefully re-emphasized the United States' commitment to human rights.

title: Spread Some My Way
description: When the question before the house is, Shall wages be raised? my vote is always aye. This is not just because my nature is generous and humane. Noble impulse in such cases is leavened by self-interest.

title: Uproar Over Pay Dogs Democrats in House
description: Some 140 House Democrats left Washington this morning for a long-planned weekend conference at the Greenbrier, an opulent old resort in the mountains here, but the furor over the proposed 50 percent Congressional pay increase dogged them all day.

title: Food Lion reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Advanced Telecommunicaions reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $1,171,000 and $3,451,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Included tax credits of $1,381,000 for the quarter and $2,995,000 for the 9 months. Latest 9 months included after-tax charge of $885,000 related to expenses incurred in the merger with Microtel.

title: Tutu Asks U.S. Jews to Urge Palestinian Pact
description: Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu, the 1984 Nobel Peace Prize winner, asserted this week that he found events in the Israeli-occupied territories similar to those in South Africa. He urged American Jews to press Israel to reach a settlement with the Palestinians and to repudiate its joint programs with the South African Government.

title: Senate Panel Proposed For Trial of U.S. Judge
description: The Senate Rules Committee has rebuffed a request by Federal District Judge Alcee L. Hastings that the full Senate convene to hear testimony in his impeachment trial, which could begin in March.

title: Malone's 28 Points Lead Jazz Past Nets
description: Karl Malone scored 28 points and added a career-high 9 assists as the Utah Jazz routed the New Jersey Nets, 129-101, tonight.

title: Midwest Communications Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
F.T.C. Clears Way for Nabisco Deal
description: The largest takeover in the nation's corporate history cleared its final hurdle today when the Federal Trade Commission announced that it would not challenge Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company's agreement to acquire RJR Nabisco Inc. for $25 billion.

title: United States Leads Paraguay, 2-0, in Davis Cup
description: Victor Pecci and Hugo Chapacu tried not to think about the violent overthrow of the Paraguayan Government Thursday night.

title: Quixote Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included losses from discontinued operations of $865,000 and $1,670,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Nintendo Amends Atari Games Suit
description: Nintendo has filed another suit in its long dispute with American companies over the $2.3 billion annual video-game market. Nintendo of America on Thursday filed legal action in United States District Court against Atari Games Inc., charging patent infringement. Also named was Tengen Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of Atari Games. The charge is an amended complaint to Nintendo's Jan. 5 lawsuit charging Atari Games and Tengen with trademark infringement, breach of contract and unfair competition.

title: Lockheed Stock Up
description: Shares of the Lockheed Corporation rose on renewed takeover speculation and rumors that the investment bank Goldman, Sachs & Company was working with the aerospace company on a restructuring plan. Lockheed rose $1, to $48, as the New York Stock Exchange's ninth-most-active issue, after being up more than $2 during the day. The Calabasas, Calif., based company and Goldman, Sachs declined to comment on the rumors. Market sources said Goldman, Sachs was ''restricted'' on Lockheed stock, which often means that a firm is working on an extraordinary transaction with a company.

title: Del Webb Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $18,193,000 and $15,229,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $8,514,000 and $85,854,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also included a loss from early extinguishment of debt of $1,050,000 and a loss from an accounting change of $3,834,000.

title: Lilly (Eli) & Co. (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $225.1 million for the quarter and $233.2 million for the year. The share earnings are on a fully diluted basis.

title: A Dutchman With a Look of Success
description: Rudolphus Franciscus Marie Lubbers plays field hockey on Sundays with a neighborhood team called Leonidas. The Dutch Prime Minister is by all accounts a scrappy, driven player.

title: Mitchell-Lama Proposal Sells Out Middle Class
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: A brief article in Weekend yesterday about concerts at the 92d Street Y tonight and tomorrow afternoon named the performers incorrectly. Toav Talmi will lead the New York

title: A New Face for Old Policies in South Africa
description: Frederik W. de Klerk, the newly elected leader of the governing National Party, is seen as a man likely to reflect, rather than drastically alter, the prevailing attitudes of South Africa's minority Government.

title: Badger Meter Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sag Harbor Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $446,000. c-After tax credits of $317,000 for the quarter and $1,036,000 for the year. There are no per share earnings for the 1987 periods because the bank converted to stock form of ownership on Sept. 1, 1987.

title: Interior Chief Would Open U.S. Land to Oil Search
description: Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. said today that he shared President Bush's position that energy resources on public lands should be exploited in ''an environmentally acceptable manner,'' and he called for opening the vast Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in northern Alaska for oil exploration and drilling.

title: Blacks Start Church in 'Whitest' State
description: Before moving to Vermont from Michigan last year to work at the university here, Rodney S. Patterson asked about the whereabouts of churches ministering to the needs of blacks. He was disappointed, but not surprised, to find that there were none. After all, Vermont is the state that Ebony magazine called ''the Whitest state in America.''

title: Deaver Abandons Appeals On Convictions for Perjury
description: Michael K. Deaver, a former White House aide, today abandoned his appeal of perjury convictions for lying about his lobbying, saying he wanted to ''get on with my life.''

title: Dominion Federal S & L reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-Net income

title: A Symbol of Change: William DeKova White
description: Forty-two years after Jackie Robinson crossed the line and took the heat as the first black player in the major leagues, William DeKova White passed another milestone with grace and honor yesterday when he was named the 13th president of the National League and the highest-ranking black executive in professional sports.

title: House of Music Benefit
description: The Bloomingdale House of Music is to celebrate its 25th anniversary with a gala benefit featuring the folk singer Odetta on Monday at the Trinity School, 101 West 91st Street. The evening will begin with cocktails at 6:30 P.M. and a performance by Odetta at 7:30, followed by dinner. Tickets are priced from $1,000 to $50. Information: 663-6021.

title: Central Jersey Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Global Warmth In '88 Is Found To Set a Record
description: The average temperature around the world in 1988 was the highest since reliable records began nearly a century ago, British scientists reported today.

title: Cagle's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $248,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net loss and included lossses from discontinued operations of $824,000 and $1,590,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The latest 9-month net from continuing operations included a pretax gain of $2.9 million from the sale of stock in Select Laboratories Inc. during the first quarter.

title: S.A.S. Lifts Stake
description: Scandinavian Airlines System has increased its stake in the Texas Air Corporation to 9.9 percent from 7.9 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, S.A.S. said that on Tuesday and Wednesday it purchased an additional 802,200 Texas Air shares, at an average price of $15.38. With these purchases, the Stockholm-based airline reached the maximum amount of shares that it can purchase under a recent agreement between the two airlines. Texas Air's stock slipped 25 cents a share today, to $14.25, on the American Stock Exchange. S.A.S. and Texas Air entered into an alliance in October to link their schedules and flights around the world.

title: Chelsea Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said LIFO costs impacted net income in the latest first quarter by $100,000 and by $526,000 for year-ago period.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: SKIING Girardelli Captures Gold: Marc Girardelli of Luxembourg won the first men's gold medal at the world Alpine championships with a victory in the combined downhill yesterday in Beaver Creek, Colo. Girardelli, an overwhelming favorite for the combined title after finishing third in the slalom Monday, was one-hundredth of a second behind the pacesetter, Michael Mair of Italy, in the downhill. Mair was clocked in 2 minutes 4.63 seconds, Girardelli in 2:04.64 and Markus Wasmeier of West Germany, who was third, in 2:05.50. Paul Accola of Switzerland won the silver medal, and Guenther Mader of Austria took the bronze.(AP) GOLF Lyle and Calcavecchia Lead: Rain halted play in the second round of the Nissan Los Angeles Open in Pacific Palisades, Calif., yesterday shortly after Sandy Lyle took a share of the lead with Mark Calcavecchia. Both finished their rounds at five-under-par 66 to be in front by two strokes with totals of eight-under 134. When play was stopped for the day, 71 of the 144 golfers were on the 6,946-yard Riviera Country Club course. Calcavecchia, who won the Phoenix Open two weeks ago, had five birdies and no bogeys. Hal Irwin, who was struck over the right eye with a golf ball during the pro-am Wednesday, continued to play well despite the accident. Irwin, 43, who won the 1976 Los Angeles Open, shot a 67 for a total of 137. HIGH SCHOOL BASKETBALL St. Anthony 67, Warren Harding 28The No. 1 high school team in the nation held No. 12 team, from Bridgeport, under 10 points in every quarter last night in Jersey City before a crowd of 4,500. Jerry Walker, the 6-foot-7-inch center for the Friars (21-0) had a game-high 20 points and 18 of his 24 rebounds by the third period. N.H.L. Penguins 3, Blues 3: Paul Coffey, Mario Lemieux and Troy Loney scored in a 3-minute-28-second span of the third period last night, lifting the Penguins into a 3-3 tie in Pittsburgh. The Penguins came back from a 3-0 deficit.(AP) Capitals 1, Whalers 0:In Landover, Md., Bengt Gustafsson scored a second-period goal and Pete Peeters made 32 saves for his fourth shutout of the season for the Capitals. The Capitals extended their unbeaten streak to six games. (AP) Bruins 4, Jets 2 Cam Neely broke a 2-2 tie with with 5:44 to play and added an empty-net goal with 56 seconds for the Bruins.(AP)

title: Aides to Leaders of 2 Koreas Are Said to Discuss Summit
description: A close aide to President Roh Tae Woo met in Singapore last week with a North Korean official to discuss a possible summit meeting with the North Korean leader, Kim Il Sung, South Korean press reports said tonight.

title: Bell, W & Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 24
description: Latest quarter and 6-month results included a tax credit of $761,000. Year-ago quarter and 6-month results included a tax credit of $1,318,000.

title: Don't Count King Glorious Out Yet on Derby Day
description: King Glorious, whose handlers seemed to indicate last week was no longer under consideration for the Kentucky Derby, is now about 50-50 to run in the May 6 race, according to one of his owners.

title: Review/Jazz; 4 Kinds of Swing Gain Momentum in Unity
description: Swing, that ambiguously defined rhythmic movement characteristic of jazz, has personality. Each musician swings differently; contrasting notions of swing often define a group's character. So it is with the band convened at the Village Vanguard on Wednesday night by the longtime Count Basie saxophonist and flutist, Frank Wess.

title: What to Expect of 'Miracle' Gadgets
description: Americans spend millions of dollars on gadgets that promise high-tech solutions to age-old problems. There is more advertising copy than proof that these devices work, but that does not stop the sale of products like ultrasonic rodent repellers, Christmas tree ornaments that extinguish fires and machines that blow hot air into the nose to relieve cold and allergy symptoms.

title: Sun Distributors L P reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Share earnings represent class A limited partnership interest. Prior-year loss included non-recurring costs of $13.6 million, related to the acquisition of Sun Distributors from Sun Co.

title: G.O.P. Group Agrees to Fine Over Help to 12 Campaigns
description: The National Republican Senatorial Committee has agreed to pay a $20,000 civil penalty for violations in its contributions to Senate candidates in the 1986 campaign, the Federal Election Commission said.

title: About New York; 'Ambassadors' Of the Subway Learn Diplomacy
description: Some 15 token-booth clerks - assembled for a lesson in courtesy - had just been told that top-notch service should include greeting customers, paying full attention to them and thanking them for their patronage.

title: Paraguay's Republic of Fear
description: Paraguay is well rid of Gen. Alfredo Stroessner, deposed in a violent coup early yesterday by one of his own army commanders and ordered into exile. A canny and cold-blooded tyrant, General Stroessner sustained himself in power for almost 35 years by creating a republic of fear.

title: Review/Ballet; Martins Plumbs Mozart Complexity
description: As a choreographer, Peter Martins has been especially successful in his use of 18th-century music, and one of the two premieres for the New York City Ballet that he presented on Thursday night is danced to Mozart, well within this lineage.

title: Officials Say Tampa Suspect May Have Suffocated
description: A black man whose death in police custody set off two nights of stone- and bottle-throwing may have suffocated while lying tied and handcuffed in a patrol car, medical investigators said today.

title: The Soft-Drink Solution to Junked Cars
description: LEAD: Why is there no return deposit on cars containing a ton of steel when there is a nickel deposit on soft drink cans containing one ounce of aluminum? This simple requirement could go a long way to solving the problem of junked cars.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 4, 1989
description: The Economy

The company said costs associated with the previously announced divestiture of Meritor's consumer finance subsidiary and the planned divestiture of its West Coast mortgage banking unit accounted for $81.3 million of the fourth quarter loss.

title: Wachtler to Act on Lawyers' Panel Fight
description: The chief judge of New York State said yesterday that he would ask the state's highest court to decide whether to intervene in a dispute between the top appeals judge in Manhattan and the former chief counsel of a court agency that disciplines lawyers.

title:
Your Money;
Picking a Broker: How to Cut Risks
description: LEAD: While there appears to be a lively debate over whether the stock market's revival is luring smaller investors back to Wall Street, there is virtually no debate over whether individual investors should be cautious when choosing a stockbroker.

description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50.

Jersey Mayor, Fresh From Gun Class, Holds Off Burglar
description: The mayor of Camden, N.J., fresh from a course in pistol-handling techniques, used his 9-millimeter handgun to hold off a burglar who smashed into his house before dawn Thursday after breaking away from police and leaping, handcuffed, across rooftops and alleys in the southern part of the city.

title: Yankees, in a Reversal, Decide to Sign Guidry
description: Months after the Yankees made it obvious that they had no interest in the return of Ron Guidry, their veteran pitcher and co-captain returned yesterday with a one-year contract. Guidry is guaranteed $250,000 and will earn an additional $250,000 if he makes the team.

title: Peace, if Not Prosperity, at Texaco
description: Texaco Inc. has survived the largest jury verdict ever awarded, the biggest bankruptcy ever filed and an attack by Carl C. Icahn, the corporate raider. Now the question is: How good an oil company is it?

title: Chrysler Buildings
description: The Chrysler Corporation donated four buildings at its closed plant in Kenosha, Wis., to local officials for use as a manufacturing site and a human resources and employment center. The four buildings, including the main general plant offices, have more than 500,000 square feet of office space.

title: Bridge; A skillful bid is 'simply a matter of trust' between French partners.
description: Most players can recall some spectacular misfortune in which they were innocent but the gods of the game seemed to be mocking them. But few could match the diagramed example from a French selection event a quarter-century ago. The victim in the East seat was Jean Paul Meyer, then a young star on his way up.

title: Stennett Returning
description: Rennie Stennett, the former second baseman for the Pittsburgh Pirates, will end a five-year absence from professional baseball this season. Stennett, whose career seemed to suffer badly after he broke his right ankle while sliding into second base in 1977, signed yesterday to play with the Pirates' Class AAA farm club in Buffalo.

description: Baseball

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping; With Ways to Send Things
description: Sending a document, letter or package from here to there used to be simple. The choice was the United States Postal Service or, for a short distance, a personal messenger.

title: Singular End For a 49ers Fan
description: Les Boatwright was going to meet his bookmaker that Monday when he suffered a heart attack, and as swiftly as a score in a game might change, he went to meet his maker instead.

description: b-After an extraordinary charge from the prepayment of debt of $4,269,000. The 1987 year's net from operations included a writeoff of FSLIC secondary reserves of $825,000.

title: Europe Flight Delays Up
description: Nineteen percent of European airline flights were delayed by at least 15 minutes in 1988, up from 14.9 percent in the previous year, the Association of European Airlines reported today. It said the delays affected 13 million passengers, up from 9.5 million in 1987. In its annual report, the group also said its 21 member airlines posted a 6.1 percent growth in passenger traffic in 1988. Growth was strongest on the European and Far Eastern routes, where traffic rose 8.5 percent and 7.2 percent, respectively, the report said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''General Stroessner has surrendered and finds himself in perfect health, deprived of liberty, being shown all human rights, at a residence within the First Army Corps.'' - Gen. Andres Rodriguez, the new president of Paraguay. [ 5:3. ]

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-5, 28 Paraguay's President was toppled in a coup led by another general that reportedly left scores of people killed and wounded. President Alfredo Stroessner was the Western Hemisphere's senior leader. Page 1 News analysis: The Paraguay coup followed an intense power struggle within Gen. Alfredo Stroessner's regime between two factions warring to control the country after his death. 5 Vice President Quayle, in El Salvador, forcefully re-emphasized the United States' commitment to human rights, but declined to link American aid directly to the Government's human-rights record. 5 An accounting of Stalin's victims by a Soviet historian appeared in a mass-circulation newspaper. The report indicated that about 20 million died in camps, forced collectivization and famine. 1 The chief U.S. arms negotiator for talks over strategic missiles in Europe will be Richard Burt, the Ambassador to West Germany, the White House announced. 3 The Israeli Foreign Minister's view of the P.L.O. is that the group has remained unchanged and that a recent finding that Yasir Arafat's wing has ceased guerrilla attacks against Israel is irrelevant. 4 Tutu asks U.S. Jews to urge Palestinian pact 4 Britain is pressing to end sanctions by the West that were imposed on the Soviet Union after its forces swept into Afghanistan in 1979. The Bush Administration has not indicated its position. 3 Kabul's imminent collapse is predicted 3 Iran and Iraq have shown movement in their long-stalled peace negotiations, offering small concessions in talks with a United Nations mediator, Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar reported. 3 National 6-10, 50 The number of workers surged last month, creating a record in the proportion of working-age people who held jobs. The number of those who wanted jobs also grew, slightly increasing the unemployment rate. 1 New Jersey's jobless rate drops, New York's is up 50 A rise in the dollar was stopped by another round of coordinated dollar-selling in the foreign exchange markets by the Federal Reserve Board and European central banks. 33 1988's average global temperature was the highest that has been recorded in this century, British scientists said. The findings do not contradict a recent report about average temperatures in America. 1 Arctic air around much of the nation continued its assault of bitter cold, sending temperatures plunging from the Pacific Northwest to the Great Lakes and icing the landscape from Texas to New England. 10 The White House counsel held a job as chairman of a $500 million company for six years while working for Presdient Bush. And the counsel, C. Boyden Gray, lacks familiarity with Government ethics procedures. 1 Dr. Louis Sullivan will not take pay from outside sources while serving as the Secretary of Health and Human Services, Bush aides say, in a move to head off criticism of the Administration's ethical standards. 8 A plan to rescue the savings industry that puts the burden on private industry rather than taxpayers will be submitted to President Bush today by the Treasury Department, officials and industry experts said. 1 The fight over Congressional pay heated up with angry protests, criticism of the Senate from the Democratic leadership of the House, and an angst-ridden meeting of Democratic lawmakers. 1 AIDS testing as a prerequisite for marriage in Illinois has detected few cases of the disease in the program's first year, officials say. But it appears to have prompted thousands of people to get married elsewhere. 6 Philadelphia's child welfare agency has had its license revoked by Pennsylvania state officials for failure to meet the rising incidence of child abuse. The officials said government generally must do more to protect children. 6 Oil exploration and drilling in Alaska at the vast Arctic National Wildlife Refuge was backed by Interior Secretary Lujan, who said energy resources on public lands should be exploited in an acceptable manner. 8 John Tower has sat through hearings on his confirmation as Secretary of Defense with grim-faced stoicism as former Senate colleagues, Federal agents and reporters raked through his personal life. 8 William Bennett's new role as leader of the Federal effort against drugs will clash with the roles of other Administration officials, Mr. Bennett acknowledged. He said he will nevertheless develop a coherent policy.

title: Filling Big Skates
description: Mike McPhee of the Montreal Canadiens and Joe Nieuwendyk of the Calgary Flames will play in the National Hockey League All-Star game Tuesday night in Edmonton, Alberta, as substitutes for injured players. McPhee will replace his teammate Mats Naslund, who is nursing a sprained ankle. Nieuwendyk will take the place of Denis Savard of the Chicago Blackhawks, who is also suffering from an ankle injury.

title: President Bush Breaks the Reagan Ice
description: President Bush has been working for weeks to distance himself from Ronald Reagan, mostly in terms of symbolism and style. His restless energy, folksy ways with Congress (''just call me George'') and affable handling of the press have won favor even from his opponents. Now there are plausible signs of substantive changes as well.

title: O.W. Sipple, 47, Who Blocked An Attempt To Kill Ford in 1975
description: Oliver W. Sipple, a former marine who thwarted an assassination attempt on President Gerald R. Ford, was found dead Thursday in his apartment in San Francisco. He was 47 years old.

title: Big Employer On L.I. Agrees To Stay There
description: Accepting a package of economic incentives offered by Suffolk County, one of Long Island's largest and fastest-growing companies said today that it would keep its headquarters on the Island.

title: Trump Is Nearer Shuttle Takeover
description: Donald J. Trump, the real estate developer, cleared the next-to-last Government hurdle in his quest to take over Eastern Airlines' lucrative Northeastern shuttle service as the Transportation Department declared his organization financially fit to run an airline. Mr. Trump must still get a certificate from the Federal Aviation Administration, which has to determine whether he can keep the hourly flights between Boston, New York and Washington running safely.

title: Live Hootenanny
description: WQXR's folk series, ''Woody's Children,'' celebrates its 20th anniversary with a two-hour live hootenanny from 7 to 9 o'clock tonight in the WQXR concert hall at The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street. Pete Seeger, Tom Chapin, Christine Lavin, Ruth Pelham and Doug Mishkin, among others, will perform; Robert Sherman is host. Admission is free. Information: 556-1144.

CONTINENTAL AIR'S PRESIDENT QUITS
description: Martin R. Shugrue resigned as president of Continental Airlines yesterday, the carrier's second top executive in a year and a half to fall victim to the tough management style created by Frank Lorenzo, the chairman of the Texas Air Corporation, Continental's corporate parent.

title: Nissan to Pay $605,600 to Settle Race and Age Bias Case
description: The Nissan Motor Corporation's distributor in this country has agreed to pay $605,600 in back pay to settle a case of race and age bias involving 92 workers, without admitting wrongdoing, the company and the Government said today.

description: The New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority voted today to allow a developer to build a convention hotel, two office buildings and a sports museum on 16 acres in the Meadowlands Sports Complex here.

title: Envoy to Germany Is Named Chief U.S. Arms Negotiator
description: President Bush has selected Richard R. Burt, the Ambassador to West Germany, as the chief American negotiator in the strategic arms talks but has yet to resolve other key questions about the American arms control team.

Boyden Gray, chosen by President Bush to enforce his call for the highest possible ethical standards, shows that he has been chairman of a $500 million communications company for the last six years while working for Mr. Bush and lacks familiarity with Government ethics procedures.

title: Review/Music; Bolcom Work on Stanford Quartet Tour
description: The Stanford String Quartet, founded in 1983, now consists of two veteran players - Andor Toth, the first violinist, and Bernard Zaslav, the violist - and two younger musicians, Zoya Leybin, violinist, and Stephen Harrison, cellist. The quartet is on a tour of major American cities and London as part of the Stanford University centennial celebrations. Featured on the tour program is the String Quartet No. 10 of William Bolcom, who earned his doctorate at Stanford. The quartet received its first New York performance at Alice Tully Hall Monday night.

title: Patents
description: Next Sunday, Raymond V. Damadian will be inducted into the National Inventors Hall of Fame by the Patent and Trademark Office, an honor that places him alongside pioneering figures like Thomas A. Edison and Alexander Graham Bell.

title: Vehicle Sales Picked Up in Late January
description: Sales of new American-made cars and light trucks rose 5.8 percent in late January from the comparable period a year earlier, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today.

title: Pepperell Up for Sale; New Farley Bid Fails
description: West Point-Pepperell Inc.'s directors put the company up for sale today, saying that a sweetened bid of $1.54 billion from Farley Inc. was unacceptable but that they would entertain higher bids from others.

description: A Soviet weekly newspaper today published the most detailed accounting of Stalin's victims yet presented to a mass audience here, indicating that about 20 million died in labor camps, forced collectivization, famine and executions.

title: Knife-Wielding Man Is Shot and Wounded
description: A New York City police officer shot and wounded a man in a Bronx hospital emergency room last night after the man slashed a security guard and injured three other people, the police said.

COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Ascom Holding A.G. and Rockaway Corp., Parsippany, N.J., said they had signed a definitive agreement for the previously announced merger of Rockaway into a U.S. subsidiary of Ascom. The transaction is valued at $112 million.

title: John Cassavetes, Major Director In U.S. Cinema Verite, Dies at 59
description: John Cassavetes, an actor, screenwriter and director who was in the forefront of American cinema verite, died yesterday in Los Angeles. He was 59 years old.

title: Joint Action Stalls Rally In Dollar
description: As the finance ministers of the United States and its major trading partners met in Washington yesterday, the Federal Reserve Board and European central banks engaged in coordinated sales of dollars to stop a rise in the dollar.

title: U.S. Links Man With 3 Bombs To a Terror Plot
description: The Federal Government asserted today that a Japanese man convicted of possessing three powerful homemade bombs was part of an Japanese Red Army terrorist plot seeking revenge for the United States air raid against Libya in 1986.

title: CUOMO LOOKS AT DEFERRING 1990 TAX CUT
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who has insisted that this year's phase of the New York State income tax cuts be preserved despite the state's daunting budget problems, suggested today that he would consider deferring the tax cuts scheduled to go into effect in 1990, a gubernatorial election year.

description: Burt Chosen for Arms Talks

title: Huge Soviet Convoy Leaves Kabul
description: A huge Soviet military convoy pulled out of Kabul in a snowstorm during the night. Soviet officials said no more than 1,500 Soviet troops were left in the besieged Afghan capital.

title: Low-Key Cuts by British Designers
description: On her whirlwind visit to New York this week, the Princess of Wales's good looks transcended her clothes. Her neatly groomed blond hair and greyhound-slim figure, along with her gracious personality, impressed those she met as well as those who just glimpsed her during receptions, tours and the opera.

Shamrock, the Burbank, Calif., investment group that has pursued Polaroid since July, said last month that it would seek control of the board through a proxy fight to advance its $3.2 billion takeover bid, which Polaroid has rejected. Polaroid said it had no comment on the Shamrock move.
