title: Kaufmann, Alsberg
description: The New York brokerage firm Kaufmann, Alsberg Company has acquired a 5.1 percent stake in Interactive Technologies Inc. and said that it opposes the St. Paul alarm system's $37 million merger agreement with the Network Security Corporation. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Kaufman, Alsberg said that it ''believes that the fair market value of the company's common stock may be substantially in excess of the proposed $17.375 per share'' offering price. Interactive's shares edged higher by 12.5 cents today, to $17.50, in over-the-counter trading.

title: Dutch Share Offer Is Oversubscribed
description: The offering of a minority stake in the Dutch state-owned chemicals company DSM, the country's largest share offering, drew surprisingly strong interest and was oversubscribed several times, the bank managing the deal said today. In the Netherlands alone, more than 100,000 private investors applied for some of the 12 million shares, or 33 percent of the company, which were offered at 108 guilders ($51) each, Amro Bank said.

title: Cries of Police Brutality Follow Death
description: The death of a young black man in police custody has prompted complaints by many blacks of police brutality and raised tensions in this historic town, which has long prided itself for being progressive on social issues.

title: Bonds Recover Most of Early Losses
description: An unexpectedly large increase in employment last month surprised participants in the credit market yesterday and knocked down the prices of Treasury bonds and notes. But as the day wore on with the Federal Reserve taking no action to tighten credit, most of the earlier losses were erased.

title: Factory Orders Up Strongly For December and Year
description: Factory orders rose by 4.1 percent in December as American manufacturers, bolstered by a boom in export sales, posted their best showing last year since 1979.

title: Selective Insurance reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included capital gains of $331,000 and $1,023,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included capital gains of $838,000 and $8,369,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and tax credits of $339,000 and $1,825,000 for the same periods, respectively.

title: Atlanta Gas Light reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $2,908,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: New Beckett Book Makes a Dramatic Entrance
description: Before presenting the first reading in the United States of Samuel Beckett's most recent work, ''Stirrings Still,'' Barry McGovern offered a disclaimer. He said the text was prose and not meant to be performed. But as with late Beckett short plays like ''A Piece of Monologue'' and ''Rockaby,'' it is a brief, dense interior monologue. With book in hand, the Irish actor gave the piece compelling dramatic life.

title: Morsemere Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Special Camp Fair
description: A Special Camp Fair, from noon to 5 P.M. tomorrow at the Jewish Guild for the Blind, is to feature 70 programs for children and teen-agers with disabilities. The fair is sponsored by Resources for Children with Special Needs, the 92d Street Y and the International Center for the Disabled. Directors from the 70 programs will be on hand to give advice on day and sleep-away camps, travel, early childhood and remedial education programs and volunteer and job opportunities. Spanish and sign interpreters will be available. Admission is free. The Jewish Guild is at 15 West 65th Street. Information: 677-4650.

title: Pretoria Says Apartheid Foe Worked as Its Spy Since '81
description: The Government confirmed today that Olivia Forsyth, a former anti-apartheid militant who took refuge in the British Embassy in Angola last year, was a South African spy.

title: Why Gun Laws Won't Stop Shootings
description: Humane people react to the lack of ready solutions for tragedies like the Stockton, Calif., school massacre by crying out for gun control. I do not believe that gun bans can overcome the basic socio-economic and cultural factors that produce violence in America.

title: Jefferson Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Allstar Inns reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $280,000 for both the quarter and year.

title: For Catholic Charities, A New Credit Card
description: It may be more blessed to give than to receive, but the national office of Catholic Charities has joined the ranks of those proposing to do both at the same time. The organization has started to promote its new Caritas Mastercard, christened with the Latin word for charity or love. Any time Caritas cardholders use their cards, one-half of 1 percent of the sales price will go to Catholic Charities.

title: Equifax Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting change of $5,400,000.

title: Concord Computing reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Article 813089 -- No Title
description: American Airlines Inc. is expected to announce orders and options for 160 jet airliners worth about $7 billion from the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, according to industry analysts and trade publications.

title: Lee Stevens, 58, of Talent Agency
description: Lee Stevens, the president and chief executive officer of the William Morris Agency, died of lymphoma on Thursday at the Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 58 years old.

title: U.S. Court Says Awards Based On S.A.T.'s Are Unfair to Girls
description: New York State's method of awarding merit scholarships to high school students on the basis of their scores on Scholastic Aptitude Tests discriminates against girls, a Federal judge in Manhattan ruled yesterday. He ordered the state to change its selection process.

title: Businessland Backs I.B.M.
description: Businessland Inc., one of the nation's largest retail computer chains, said today that it would not sell personal computers designed by other manufacturers to compete with the Microchannel feature of the International Business Machines Corporation's Personal System/2 computers.

title: American Capacity reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Home Federal Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KEY RATES
Indiana Federal Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1987 per share figure is not available because the company converted to stock ownership in February 1987.

title: Beatrice Lillie's Retort
description: To the Editor:

title: American Water Works Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Great Southern Federal Savngs Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Ramage Suspended
description: Rob Ramage, a Calgary Flames defenseman, was suspended for eight games yesterday by the N.H.L. for a stick infraction on Jan. 15 in which he knocked down Doug Bodger of the Buffalo Sabres. ''Although Ramage does not have a previous history of stick fouls, players must understand that there can be no excuse for reckless swinging of their sticks at opponents,'' said Brian O'Neill, the N.H.L.'s executive vice president. (AP)

title: Golden Poultry Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 24
description: b-Net loss

title: Pseudo-Spring, Real Guilt
description: It was the best of Januaries and the worst of Januaries. Best because the midday sun felt like late March, the evening air gave hints of April, the snowdrops popped up even earlier than usual. Worst because of the worry that this was the greenhouse effect, already starting to warm us up.

title: Rangers Call Up Goalie
description: The Rangers summoned Mike Rosati, a goalie, from Niagara yesterday to serve as Bob Froese's backup for the game tonight at Montreal. Coach Michel Bergeron decided to leave John Vanbiesbrouck home for the weekend to prepare for tomorrow night's game against the Minnesota North Stars at Madison Square Garden. Rosati, 21 years old, was selected by the Rangers in the seventh round of last year's draft and was 18-10-2 in 36 games with Niagara. The Rangers also recalled Darren Turcotte, a center, from Denver, where he had 17 goals and 23 assists in 34 games.

title: Curlew
description: Curlew, an avant-rock quintet, is to perform at 9 and 11 o'clock tonight at the Knitting Factory, 47 East Houston Street (219-3055). Tickets are $7 in advance, $9 at the door.

title: Johnson Unit Sues Amgen
description: The Ortho Pharmaceutical Corporation, a division of Johnson & Johnson, filed suit today in Federal District Court in Delaware charging that Amgen Inc. has not honored the terms of a 1985 agreement between the companies regarding erythropoietin, or EPO, a hormone used to treat anemia.

title: END TO SANCTIONS ON SOVIETS SOUGHT
description: Britain is pressing vigorously for the formal lifting of Western economic sanctions that were imposed on the Soviet Union after its forces swept into Afghanistan in 1979.

title: Ringier Withdraws W.A. Krueger Bid
description: The W. A. Krueger Company, a commercial printing concern based in Scottsdale, said that Ringier A.G. of Zurich had withdrawn its offer of $10 a share, or a total of about $321 million. But Krueger said that the Swiss concern, which is also a printing company, still remained interested in acquiring Krueger.

title: Federal Signal Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Jim Moore Photos
description: ''Jim Moore Photographs: A Variety of Performing Artists'' runs through Feb. 25 at the Amsterdam Gallery, 111 Amsterdam Avenue, at 65th Street. The exhibition, a 15-year retrospective sponsored by the New York Public Library and the Museum of Performing Arts, presents 100 black and white photographs of clowns, magicians, mimes and jugglers, some famous, some not. Admission is free. Information on hours: 870-1630.

title: Joyner-Kersee Ties World Mark in 55-Meter Hurdles
description: Never one to go too long without distinguishing herself, Jackie Joyner-Kersee twice equaled the world indoor record in the women's 55-meter hurdles last night in the Panasonic Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden.

title: New Parents Try to Share Joy Through Gifts to the Neediest
description: Before the birth of their first son, Daniel, a few weeks ago, Nancy and Michael Butler of Manhattan sent their first contribution to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Hannah Goodman, 78, Radio and TV Writer
description: Hannah Grad Sverdlin, a radio and television writer known professionally as Hannah Grad Goodman, died of kidney failure on Jan. 19 at Doctors Hospital. She was 78 years old and lived on the Upper West Side.

title: New Yorkers on the Princess: Boffo to Blase
description: ''I have to put on my skates and move on,'' the Princess of Wales told guests yesterday morning at a private reception in the British Consul General's apartment.

title: Black-Jewish Benefit
description: ''Song and Dance: An Evening of Black-Jewish Creativity'' is to take place at 8 o'clock tonight as a benefit for Brooklyn Ecumenical Cooperatives, an interfaith, interracial group that promotes housing for the poor. Avodah Dance Ensemble, Louis Johnson Dance Theater Ensemble, the Brooklyn Heights Synagogue Choir and the Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church Choir will appear at the benefit, at the Church of St. Ann and the Holy Trinity, at Montague and Clinton Streets in Brooklyn Heights. Admission: $10. Information: (718) 522-2070.

title: F.B.I. Resumes Inquiry On Tower Background
description: Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, looking into allegations that have delayed the confirmation of John G. Tower as Secretary of Defense, today interviewed a conservative lobbyist in Florida and the staff of a restaurant in Washington.

title: Concern Voiced on New Chief and Drug Trade
description: The United States said today that it hoped the military coup in Paraguay was a step toward democracy, but American officials expressed grave concern about reports linking the leader of the coup to narcotics traffic.

title: 49ers Visit White House
description: At a reception in the East Room of the White House today, President Bush congratulated the San Francisco 49ers for their victory in Super Bowl XXIII and said they ''rewrote the record books'' with their triumph over the Cincinnati Bengals.

title: Pull of the Past, Both Comforting and Destructive
description: A Casual Brutality By Neil Bissoondath 376 pages. Clarkson N. Potter. $18.95.

title: EMPLOYMENT SURGE REPORTED BY U.S. FOR START OF YEAR
description: A persistently vigorous economy and exceptionally mild weather caused employment to surge last month, creating a record in the proportion of people of working age who have jobs, the Labor Department said today.

title: Soviets Accept Beijing Offer Of Summit Meeting in China
description: China today formally invited the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, to come to Beijing for their nations' first summit meeting in 30 years, and the Soviet Union accepted.

title: Philadelphia's Agency For Young Loses Permit
description: Pennsylvania state officials have revoked the license of Philadelphia's child welfare agency for failure to cope with a rising incidence of child abuse.

title: Bush Aides' Plan on Savings Units Is Said to Place Cost on Industry
description: The Treasury plans to submit proposals to President Bush on Saturday that will place much of the burden for dealing with the savings and loan crisis on private industry, Congressional aides and industry experts said today.

title: United Financial Banking Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bonn Seizes Chemical Ordered for Libya Use
description: The West German customs police have seized 255 tons of a chemical bound for Libya that could be used to make poison gas, a Government spokesman said today.

title: Firefighter Dies As He Searches For Fire Victims
description: A ten-year Fire Department veteran searching a blazing Brooklyn apartment building yesterday became the first New York City firefighter killed in more than a year, the Fire Department said.

title: Key Centurion Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share earnings were restated for a 10 percent stock dividend paid in December 1988.

title: 2 Boys, 13, Held in Drug Sale
description: Nassau County police have arrested two 13-year-old boys for selling crack, along with their two adult customers, Detective Sgt. Jerry Richardson said today.

title: Chicago Inquiry, 2 Years Old, Still Has a Long Way to Go
description: The Government's investigation of commodity trading continues to make headlines and to cast a pall over Chicago's financial district. But just where it will lead is far from clear.

title: Model Airplane Show to Go On at County Center
description: LEAD: IN a legal battle that still might not be over, a group of model airplane hobbyists won the right last week to put on its yearly show in late February at the County Center.

title: Making 'Cousins': An Excursion Into Relativity
description: The secret of making a successful movie is simple, according to the director Joel Schumacher: All you have to do is find a leading lady with whom everyone falls in love.

title:
ART;
'California Surrealism' in Bronx Show
description: LEAD: THE death of Salvador Dali last month put Surrealism squarely in the public eye once again. But the most resilient of art movements has never been absent for long, for as its founders declared, Surrealism is less an art movement than a way of life - a life that permeates present-day New York with its strange juxtapositions of visual phenomena on every street corner.

title: Ms. Glendinning to Wed T. H. Pough
description: Mrs. John Andrew Glendinning of Bellerose Village, Queens, has announced the engagement of her daughter Victoria Jean Glendinning to Tristram Hooper Pough, a son of Dr. Richard H. Pough of Pelham, N.Y., and Chilmark, Mass., and the late Moira Flannery Pough. The couple plan to marry April 22.

title:
ART;
Images and Reality: Essay on Viewpoint
description: LEAD: THE Anthony Giordano Gallery at Dowling College in Oakdale, which recently became a satellite facility of the nearby Islip Art Museum, is now featuring an installation, created for this space, by William Ramage, an artist who lives in Vermont.

title: THE WORLD: North-South Diplomacy; Dreams and Realities Of Korean Unification
description: SOUTH KOREA's leading capitalist returned from his old hometown in the North last week with more than just a preliminary agreement for the first business ventures between North and South Korea. He also brought new momentum for a rush toward rapprochement that is leaving South Koreans both excited and unnerved.

title: In Boston, Things Are Starting to Resemble the Bronx Zoo
description: They don't open spring training for nearly two weeks and the Boston Red Sox already have expended a season's worth of turbulent energy. The turmoil that has engulfed the team is, to a great extent, the result of an epidemic of foot-in-mouth disease. As soon as one player contracts it, another supplants him and becomes the focal point of the week.

title: Johnson in 1992?
description: He has been banned from track and field for two years because of his positive drug test at the Seoul Olympics last year, but Ben Johnson is nevertheless preparing to compete in the 1992 Olympic Games at Barcelona, Spain, a report published in Spain said yesterday.

title: Review/Dance; Eliot Feld's Classical Pastiche
description: ''A Footstep of Air'' was always one of Eliot Feld's jollier ballets, and Friday night's revival of this 1977 work - the first since 1985 - is a welcome one.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a review of John Costello's ''Mask of Treachery'' on Dec. 25 misstated the year in which the spies Guy Burgess and Donald Maclean fled Britain for the Soviet Union. It was 1951.

title: POSTINGS: 48 Duplex Condos; Subsidized Town Houses Near Clinton Hill
description: A coalition of private and public groups is helping to subsidize a $5.9 million development of 48 two-bedroom condominium apartments at the interestion of Grand and Gates Avenues on the edge of the Clinton Hill Historic District in Brooklyn.

title: No Headline
description: The Islanders achieved a bittersweet victory over the Hartford Whalers tonight.

title: Modern Trends In Medals
description: MEDALLIC art has changed since the first flattering portraits in metal commissioned by Italian princes and German merchants during the 15th and 16th centuries. The American Numismatic Society at 155th Street and Broadway is showing modern examples of the art from around the world. The exhibition will run through April 1.

title: Building Million-Dollar Mansions, On Spec
description: IN a nostalgic embrace of the excesses that helped shape the Roaring Twenties, builders today are erecting multimillion-dollar mansions on speculation, targeting buyers who want to step into opulent new surroundings without the bother of collaborating with architects and designers.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Jamaica, Vt.;
Planners Balk At Resort Plan
description: LEAD: JOSEPH J. STEINER, project director for the Tamarack Golf and Country Club, spends his days in an office here waiting to answer questions from concerned citizens about his project, the largest ever proposed in this southeastern Vermont town of fewer than than 700 residents.

title: 'Degrassi': A Series For Children That Goes for the Gut
description: Over the coming months, viewers of more than 250 stations affiliated with the Public Broadcasting Service will have an opportunity to re-acquaint themselves with the real-to-life dramas of Degrassi Junior High, site of the weekly half-hour program of the same name that has been remolding the pat-a-cake image of what the industry, with at least some sense of paradox, likes to call ''children's television.''

title: Tough Guessing Game on Worldwide Toll of AIDS
description: While the AIDS epidemic has spread to most of the world, Africa and the United States have by far the most cases and the widest spread of the deadly virus. The disease is gathering force in Latin America and Europe, experts warn, but so far Asia has been largely spared.

title: A Marginal Case in Point
description: To the Editor:

title: RUSSIA IN THE RED
description: THE COMING SOVIET CRASH Gorbachev's Desperate Pursuit of Credit in Western Financial Markets. By Judy Shelton. 246 pp. New York: The Free Press. $22.50.

title: Add Real Human Suffering to Abortion Debate; Being Truly Pro Life
description: To the Editor:

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Coram $200,000 20 Howard Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 14-year-old colonial; Florida room, finished basement, pool; taxes $4,400. Glen Cove $372,000 19 Francis Terrace 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 78-year-old colonial; dining room, new eat-in kitchen, family room with fireplace, pool; taxes $3,800. OTHER AREAS Greenwich, Conn. $2.65 million 98 Glenwood Drive 11-bedroom, 6 1/2-bath, 90-year-old Victorian; water views, includes carriage house, 0.9 acre; taxes, $7,945. Sea Girt, N.J. $154,500 1905 World Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 12-year-old ranch; new roof, full basement, family room; taxes $1,521.

title: NEW ACCOUNT GIVEN OF ETHICS BRIEFING
description: The deputy to C. Boyden Gray, the Presidential counsel and ethics aide who has maintained his chairmanship of a $500 million communications corporation, says he told Mr. Gray in November about a White House policy that prohibited involvement in outside business interests.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE VILLAGE BY THE SEA By Paula Fox. 147 pp. New York: Orchard Books/Franklin Watts.

title: Taste Buds Travel
description: To the Editor:

title: 1-800-BAD-NEWS
description: LEAD: We're supposed to be able to remember telephone numbers more easily by seeing them turned into words. For example, to reach an outfit called Value Rent-a-Car, you don't have to recall anything more brain-twisting than 1-800-GO-VALUE. Should you want to list your hostelry in the Small Inn and Lodges section of this very newspaper all you have to do is dial 1-800-44TIMES - although I hope that's not literally true.

title: THE MAN WHO SAVED THE LIBRARY: AN ODE TO VARTAN GREGORIAN
description: LEAD: Editors' Note: In 1981, Vartan Gregorian, the brand-new president of the New York Public Library, faced a physical plant in decay, a demoralized staff and a grave shortage of money. The great library - the ''people's university'' of New York - had fallen on evil days since it was created, 86 years earlier, by merging the private libraries of John Jacob Astor and James Lenox with funds from the Tilden Trust.

title: Keeping the Profits From Your House
description: The runup in real estate prices over the past few years is leaving more and more owners with huge profits when they sell their properties. The tax bill on those profits will be put off for many of the owners when they file their 1988 returns in coming months and show that they rolled the gains into another house. Indeed, careful planning can help to whittle the size of the bill that eventually will come due.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our clapboard garage is built on a cement-block foundation and is on sloping ground. On one side, the bottom row of clapboards is one foot above ground level, but on the other side the bottom row is nine inches below grade. This is one foot from our neighbor's property line, so it is impossible to regrade the soil. I have dug a foot-wide trench to the level of the cement blocks and am considering filling the trench with rocks to keep soil out. The other option is to fill the trench with cement. What is the best way to do this, short of raising the foundation?

title: FARE OF THE COUNTRY Austria's Favorite Wurstel
description: LEAD: AUSTRIA, renowned for the invention of the waltz, whipped cream and psychoanalysis, has another, little known claim to fame. It has long been the greatest sausage maker in the world. Its humble Wurstel was the original fast food and remains the national snack of choice, antedating and far surpassing in per capita consumption America's ubiquitous hamburger.

title: FICTION
description: THE BODY POLITIC. By Victor Gold and Lynne Cheney. (St. Martin's, $15.95.) When art seeks so blatantly to imitate life, one asks, at the minimum, that it be done creatively. In ''The Body Politic,'' a slim novel annotated with fictitious transcripts and official-looking memorandums that attempts to hook readers with its snapshots of power plays inside the White House and on Capitol Hill, it unfortunately is not. Many of the worst cliches in American politics have been thickly strung together in this book by Victor Gold, a Washington author and the biographer of President Bush, and Lynne Cheney, a novelist and the chairwoman of the National Endowment for the Humanities. It opens with an upper-crust Yankee Republican Vice President who serves an immensely popular but not too bright Commander in Chief. Inconveniently and unceremoniously, the Vice President dies of cardiac arrest while in bed with an extremely aggressive White House correspondent for a major television network. The plot unfolds over the next 200 pages: how and why the White House staff, the network star and the Vice President's wife agree to a cover-up that seeks to keep alive ''Stewart Bulloch (Bully) Vandercleve - Vice President, former Governor, ex-Ambassador, one-time Secretary of Defense, erstwhile perennial candidate for the Republican presidential nomination'' until after the Wisconsin primary. Dubbed Operation Avis, the plan to keep Bully alive is assisted by his able press secretary, Frank Lee, and a black mimic whose voice so closely resembles that of the dead Vice President that he can conduct a convincing telephone conversation with the President. Balanced precariously on a shaky foundation that mixes national security with the good of the Republican Party, this scheme is all too successful. Bully Vandercleve becomes a cult hero, although he hasn't been seen for months, and he emerges as the long-shot but likely winner of his party's nomination. Even in an election year, this would hardly be credible.

title: U.S. Weighing Plan to Take Over 350 Insolvent Savings Institutions
description: The Bush Administration is considering a proposal to move quickly to take control of the nation's 350 insolvent savings and loan associations and place them under the management of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, industry officials said today.

title: Pianists Playing to a Different Drummer
description: Stylistic categories in music may not be disappearing, but they are certainly shifting with a frequency that alarms some and excites others. In recent months, three pianists who emerged from the world of jazz have released records that extend eagerly into the classical arena.

title: White House Sticks With Tower Despite a Renewed Inquiry
description: The revived Federal investigation of John G. Tower, the Secretary of Defense-designate, has not caused the White House to back away from its nomination of the former Senator, Administration officials said today.

title: Jane Mencher Plans to Wed
description: A July wedding is planned by Jane Lizabeth Mencher and Andrew Robert Gold, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Steven Gold of Princeton, N.J. Their engagement has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Stuart A. Mencher of Bethesda, Md.

title: Wayward Notes From a Distant Country Cousin
description: ''I understand too little too late/ I realize there are things you say and do you can never take back . . . .I'd like to reconsider please if it's not too late . . . '' speaks the singer Lyle Lovett in the middle of a song on his new record, ''Lyle Lovett and His Large Band'' (MCA 42263, all three formats). He finishes the sentence with the words ''make it a cheeseburger.''

title: Addressing A Need for Paramedics
description: LEAD: STEPHEN J. NARDOZZI of Lewisboro knows what it is like to save lives and revive the seemingly dead. He recalled one experience as a paramedic for an ambulance service in New Rochelle when he rushed to an emergency call and saw a young boy crying over his father's apparently lifeless body. After quick action by Mr.

title: Dr. Karen R. Rosenkrantz Is Married To Dr. Cornelis P. Terhorst in Boston
description: Dr. Karen Rice Rosenkrantz and Dr. Cornelis Pieter Terhorst were married yesterday at the Ritz-Carlton in Boston by Justice of the Peace Richard J. George. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. Jens Georg Rosenkrantz of Cincinnati and the late Dr. Rosenkrantz. The bridegroom is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Cornelis Terhorst of Son en Breughel, the Netherlands.

title: Why General Mills May Go Up
description: Long before the takeover battles for the Pillsbury Company and Kraft Inc. pushed up the stock prices of food companies, General Mills Inc.'s shares had been rising. Investors were responding favorably to its efforts to focus on food and restaurants and to divest itself of unrelated businesses. But with the restructuring completed, do fundamentals or takeover rumors explain why the stock is trading on the New York Stock Exchange at about $56 a share, near a 52-week high of $58?

title: Review/Music; Sixties Overview Ends With 3 From the East
description: The 1960's are probably still too close to us, chronologically and emotionally, for anyone to be satisfied with an overview of its music, or even just its ''serious'' music. Still, Joel Sachs made a heroic stab at just such an overview last week in his six-concert Focus series with the forces of the Juilliard School.

title: Dear Grandchildren
description: The Federal Government has fallen steadily deeper in debt for eight years now, but the sky hasn't fallen. The nation prospers; interest and inflation rates remain subdued. Politicians, financiers and academics now dare to think the unthinkable: Could it be that deficits don't matter after all?

title: Ending Sidetracks
description: It seemed to be all downhill for Frank L. McNamara Jr. after his appointment as the United States Attorney for Massachusetts in 1987. The Senate Judiciary Committee held up his confirmation because of questions about his income tax returns. Some of his staff complained that his decisions on key personnel matters were politically motivated. Then a Justice Department report concluded that he had falsely accused his predecessor, William F. Weld, of smoking marijuana. The department began an investigation to determine whether he deliberately lied, and 28 of his 39 assistant attorneys signed a letter to Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, seeking Mr. McNamara's removal or resignation. Last week, Mr. McNamara resigned, saying, ''The work of this office is far too important to be sidetracked by any controversy.''

title: Deirdre Barrett To Wed in April
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James P. Barrett of Manhasset and Quogue, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Deirdre Ann Barrett to Donald Gregory Denihan, a son of Irene Denihan of Manhasset and the late Benjamin J. Denihan. The couple plan to marry in April.

title: CD Video Gives Old Art New Life
description: The 12-inch video version of the compact disk, which has been marketed under the name CD video for only a few months, already offers a catalogue of thousands of film, music and documentary titles with the high-quality sound, durability and instant access of the regular five-inch CD, and a cleaner, crisper video image than VHS or Beta tape.

title: 45 Hurdles to Building in the County
description: SUCCESSFUL building projects elude Westchester developers for 45 reasons, according to Kenneth Nadler, a partner in a Mount Kisco real-estate and development firm. Construction sites are in 45 different jurisdictions, he explained, and each village, town and city has its own say in what a builder can do.

title: Review/Theater; Hypocrisy and Greed Are Focus of 'The Visit'
description: The town of Guellen has fallen on hard times. Rich in cultural heritage (Goethe once spent the night in the local inn and Brahms composed a quartet there), Guellen has sold its one museum to America and its only asset is a broken typewriter in the Town Hall. There is nothing even left to tax.

title: Bush Took Unconstitutional Oath of Office; But It's Only Symbolic
description: To the Editor:

title: Sky Control
description: To the Editor:

title: Robots In Space: New Goal for Grumman
description: LEAD: AS the nation prepares to embark on a new wave of space ventures after the successful launching of the shuttles Discovery and Atlantis late last year, the Grumman Corporation in Bethpage is engaged in a close race for a contract to build the first ''smart'' robot for use in outer space.

title: 'Balm in Gilead'
description: To the Editor:

title: NONFICTION
description: THE THREE FAMILIES OF H. L. HUNT. By Ardis Burst. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $19.95.) The late Texas oil tycoon H. L. Hunt was one of the great eccentrics of American business - a man who thrived on high-stakes gambling, both at the poker table and in his business dealings. He also played high-risk games in his personal life. Through most of the years of his long and ostensibly happy first marriage, Hunt maintained separate family households with, successively, his two mistresses and his children by them. All told, Hunt fathered 15 children, the best known being Herbert Hunt and Nelson Bunker Hunt, who also gambled big in their unsuccessful bid to corner the world silver market in 1979-80. This love of high-risk wheeling and dealing is one of the major legacies H. L. Hunt left his children, Ardis Burst suggests in ''The Three Families of H. L. Hunt,'' her detailed family saga. Ms. Burst, a freelance writer in San Antonio, documents this provocative family history in a reportorial style that is heavy on facts but somewhat less satisfying when it comes to analysis. At times, distinctions between the many children and their families begin to blur - perhaps inevitably, since it would be difficult for any son or daughter to loom larger than H. L. Hunt himself, whose image was best captured by his daughter, June: ''He did not see himself as having to go by the ethics of - anything. . . . It was as though he was a god unto himself who could make his own rules. And the end justified the means.''

title: Ski Resorts Seeking New Image
description: LEAD: THE New Jersey ski industry is struggling for recognition, say the operators of the state's six ski areas.

title: Michael I. Hirsch, AIDS-Services Advocate, 34
description: Michael I. Hirsch, an advocate for services to people afflicted with AIDS, died of complications of the disease on Friday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 34 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Long Beach Rejects Tighter Zoning
description: LEAD: AN outpouring of public sentiment has defeated a plan to rezone Long Beach to prevent the construction of two-family houses.

title: A Letter To Martin
description: MARTIN, the dream has faded and it is now wake-up time. Twenty-one years have passed and our people are still in the dream state. Still singing, ''We shall overcome'' and still saying, ''We are living the dream.'' I'm beginning to wonder, whose dream are we living? It is time to rise from the world of dreams. The hard-won progress of blacks has stalled in recent years, and the economic gap with whites is widening. Except for upper-income black families, there really hasn't been any progress over the past decades. In fact, there has been some slippage. The median income for black families is $18,098. That is only 56 percent of the income of white families, the lowest level in over two decades. A third of all blacks are living in poverty, up two percentage points since 1986, while white poverty dropped from 11 percent to 10.5 percent.

title: PERSPECTIVES: Superluxury Rentals; Building for the Wealthy on E. 72d Street
description: AMONG the new crop of Manhattan apartment buildings, none is more striking than the sleek glass giant called One East River Place, which Sheldon Solow is completing off 72d Street at the East River. But as modern as the design may be, the building is in a sense a throwback to the city's distant housing past.

title: THE GUIDE
description: REFURBISHED CLASSIC A refurbished film print of ''Gone With the Wind,'' shown at the Radio City Music Hall last weekend, will run daily during the week of May 20 at the Paramount Theater in Peekskill. It is one of a series of twenty-four 1939 films at the theater at 8 P.M. Saturdays and 2 P.M. Sundays for the next few months. ''Goodbye, Mr. Chips,'' starring Robert Donat and Greer Garson, will be shown at 2 P.M. today.

title: Virginia Ferrara Weds Alan Richard Twaits
description: The wedding of Virginia Marie Ferrara, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Richard J. Ferrara of Grosse Pointe, Mich., to Alan Richard Twaits, the son of Helen B. Peace of Middletown, N.J., and the late E. A. Twaits, took place yesterday at the Grosse Pointe United Congregational Church. The Rev. David Kaiser performed the ceremony.

title: NONFICTION
description: FAST FADE: David Puttnam, Columbia Pictures, and the Battle for Hollywood. By Andrew Yule. (Delacorte, $19.95.) Intensely ambitious and devoted to quality, David Puttnam, the British producer, attracted attention in the early 1980's with such films as ''Local Hero,'' ''Chariots of Fire'' and ''The Killing Fields.'' Success led Mr. Puttnam to become head of a major studio, Columbia Pictures, even though Hollywood and its mindless ''product'' represented everything he purported to detest. After a series of incautious pronouncements, Mr. Puttnam quickly alienated most of the prestigious agents, producers and movie stars he had to deal with. Finally, Columbia's parent company, Coca-Cola, dismissed him after a year. In the course of ''Fast Fade,'' we learn a lot about how movies are made today and especially how studios function within the huge multinational corporations that now own them. The endless backbiting that apparently sustains people in the film industry also offers its own perverse fascination. However, Andrew Yule's cautionary tale is too often invested with an air of grand tragedy that it does not deserve, and his obsessive dissection of Mr. Puttnam's downfall eventually becomes tiresome and repetitive. The writing is pedestrian when it is not gee-whiz, and Mr. Yule, the author of ''Hollywood-a-Go-Go,'' unfortunately seems to think that readability is best achieved through the piling on of cliches. We hear too much about what everybody thinks of Mr. Puttnam and not enough about what it all means. After a host of excruciatingly detailed analyses of each participant's motivation - compounded by a ''Rashomon''-like complexity of competing versions that are rarely reconciled - the reader may ultimately decide that he does not really care whose fault it all was.

title: Teen-Agers, AIDS And Abstinence
description: The pathetic attempt at logic printed under the title ''Teen-Agers and AIDS: Protection, Yes, but How?'' (Opinion page, Jan. 8) is, one hopes, not an example of the thinking of many so-called educators.

title: 100 Chemicals for Apples Add Up to Enigma on Safety
description: Growers use a wide variety of toxic chemicals on the nation's apple crop to control pests or regulate the growth and appearance of the fruit, but there is sharp disagreement over whether they pose a risk to public health.

title: Stubborn Problems Plague B-1, Report Says
description: Major problems still plaguing the Air Forces' B-1B bomber may reduce its expected range and payload capability, says a report issued by an investigative agency of Congress.

title: Looking Beyond Numbers in the Arms Talks
description: When the Warsaw Pact revealed its inventory of troops and weapons this week in advance of the conventional arms reduction talks, it rejected assertions that the Soviet-led alliance vastly outnumbered the North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces.

title: On Stage: the View From J.H.S. 22
description: Forty junior high school students from the Lower East Side of Manhattan gave a poignant twist last week to a near-universal rite of passage: the school play.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE COURAGE OF THEIR CONVICTIONS. By Peter Irons. (Free Press/Macmillan, $22.95.) In 1965, Peter Irons was convicted of refusing to report for induction into the military and was sentenced to three years in prison. He served more than two years, and though his conviction was overturned by a Cincinnati Federal court in the early 1970's, his anger and bitterness remained.

title: Bush Took Unconstitutional Oath of Office; Presidential Ghosts
description: To the Editor:

title: THE LESSONS OF ST. JOE'S
description: AT FIRST, IT RAN like other Montessori schools: my daughter, Laura, and the other little ones playing with paints and blocks and learning to learn. Classes met in the pastel-colored basement of The Living Church, a born-again congregation in the old railroad suburb in which we live; but there was no mention of Jesus.

title: Town Finding Solution on Ex-Patients
description: LEAD: WILLIAM BENFER, treasurer of the Ocean Grove Homeowners Association, says things are looking up both for residents of this small seaside community and for the deinstitutionalized psychiatric patients who have been placed in the town's rooming houses and boarding homes. ''We're on the right track,'' he said.

title: Recitals from Vienna and Canada
description: VISITORS from England, Austria and Canada bracket the week at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers, with the pianist Stephen Hough giving a recital there today at 3 P.M. and the violist Thomas Riebl joining the Orford String Quartet at that same hour next Sunday.

title: IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut; A 1.2 Million-Sq.-Ft. Platinum Mile Project
description: By JOSEPH P. GRIFFITH

title: HEALTH CARE'S HIGH COST
description: The article, ''Taking a Scalpel to Health Care Costs'' (Jan. 8) prompted an unusually strong response from readers. Some of their comments follow. To the Editor:

title: Tal Defeats Timman in an Exhibition Match
description: MIKHAIL TAL of the Soviet Union, who held the world championship in 1960, won the 1988 KRO Exhibition Match on Dec. 23 in Hilversum, the Netherlands, against the Dutch grandmaster Jan Timman. Tal scored 3 1/2 to 2 1/2 in the six-game contest sponsored by Katholieke Radio Omroep and the Interpolis insurance company.

title: Madeleine L'Engle's Life in Books
description: LEAD: For 40 years Madeleine L'Engle, the author of such children's books as ''A Wrinkle in Time,'' was married to the stage and television actor Hugh Franklin. When he died of cancer in 1986 at the age of 70, Ms. L'Engle reconciled his death in the way she knew best: she wrote about it.

title: 'Orphans' Explores Power and bonding
description: IN a stirring and honest staging of ''Orphans'' at the Boston Post Road Stage Company in Fairfield, the director, Douglas Moser, has located the heartbeat in a play that is known - to the extent that it is known - for its visceral sensations.

title: Doubts on Peary's Polar Feat Tied to Misreading of a Paper
description: Recent charges that Robert E. Peary deliberately faked his assertion that his 1909 expedition was the first to reach the North Pole were based on a ''completely erroneous'' interpretation of a key document, according to navigation experts studying the dispute.

title: Woman's Fight Against Navy Radar Raises Health Issue
description: LEAD: DOROTHY POWELL telephones the Navy's Aegis command testing site in Moorestown up to 20 times a day. She has written countless letters to legislators and environmental protection officials. She maintains a voluminous file of correspondence with military and regulatory agencies.

title: Not Just at Home on the Range
description: Images from an American-art show: Adirondack lakes at sundown, brilliant apple-green water under a chrome sky. Winter light on snowy Connecticut hills. A tabletop bronze of society polo players, men and mounts tangled, twisting, falling. All bear a single signature: Frederic Remington. Remington? Where is the Wild West of horses and sagebrush? ''He's far more than cowboys and Indians,'' said Michael Shapiro, chief curator of the St. Louis Art Museum and co-organizer of ''Frederic Remington: The Masterworks,'' which opens Saturday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. ''Remington is uncannily modern, one of the most brilliant and complex American figures from the turn of the century. He's also the most consistently, even insistently, dismissed.''

title: Schools Scramble for Coaches
description: LEAD: IN early January, Fairfield High School canceled the boys' varsity swim team program, because the athletic director was unable to find a coach.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE NORWALK MARITIME CENTER;
A Tourist Attraction in the Market for More Tourists
description: LEAD: WHEN the Norwalk Maritime Center opened last summer, it was heralded as a major new tourist attraction that would draw visitors from throughout the Northeast. Now, just six and a half months later, the center's marketing director is convinced that few people outside Fairfield County know that it exists.

title: Question Of the Week; What Do The Mets Need to Add In 1989?
description: Oh sure, the Mets could always use some more good pitching. But what they really need they can't buy. They need to act more like a team, to toot their own horns less, to let their actions speak for themselves. See Kevin McReynolds. ANNIE MAHR Somerset, N.J.

title: Kiss Is Just a Kiss, Between Friends
description: The well-written piece, (''Once Again, a Kiss Is Just a Kiss'' Jan 22) was amusing only on the surface. It failed to acknowledge that Americans are a varied lot. Some people are more warm-blooded than others. Ms. Keith should feel free to choose chillier friends. Mildred M. Jeffrey Melville

title:
DINING OUT;
Home-Style Fare in Bronxville
description: LEAD: SOME diners will find the bentwood chairs and the too-high ceilings with their capacity for noise uncomfortable; but, on balance, Pondfield's convenient location on the southern edge of the main shopping street and not too far from the railroad station, its starched linens and pretty table appointments and tasty, home-style fare all help make this a popular neighborhood dining spot.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
NAIVE AND NIFTY
description: LEAD: As the authors readily acknowledge, ''primitive'' and ''folk'' are imperfect appellations for the rich and varied display of objects represented in AMERICAN PRIMITIVE: Discoveries in Folk Sculpture (Knopf, $75). An array of material both revealing and confounding in its diversity is assembled in 400 photographs, more than half in color, accompanied by useful descriptions of each object.

title: Roxanna Anspach to Marry Fellow Student, M. W. Devlin
description: Roxanna Bodne Anspach and Michael William Devlin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Devlin of Baldwin, L.I., plan to be married in May. The future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Andrew A. Anspach of New York and Edgartown, Mass., announced the engagement.

title: Temporary Shelter in Freezng Weather
description: LEAD: AN austere barracks has become a symbol of the county's newest effort to bring people - literally and figuratively - in from the cold.

title: POSTINGS: A Tale of 2 Towns; Factory-Built Units Straddle a Border
description: Assembly-line housing is being put up in an unusual condominium project that straddles the Maplewood-Irvington Township border near Newark in Essex County, N.J. The first apartments in a cluster of 14 two- and three-story buildings are to be ready this month, with all 51 two-bedroom units finished by the end of the year.

title: THE WORLD: New Rules in Poland; Jaruzelski Tries to Buy Peace With Pluralism
description: POLAND'S leader and his supporters had to threaten to resign in order to persuade the Communist Party Central Committee to talk to Solidarity. The tactic amounted, a Solidarity strategist said later, to a ''declaration of martial law on the Central Committee.'' But the hard part for Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski may be only beginning.

title: 'PUTZI, I TELL YOU THAT MAN IS NEUTER'
description: 1933 By Philip Metcalfe. Illustrated. 316 pp. Sag Harbor, N.Y.: The Permanent Press. $21.95.

title: 2 Men Killed and Girl Is Wounded Near Rink
description: Two young men were killed and a teen-age girl was wounded early yesterday morning when two men opened fire outside a roller-skating rink in Harlem, the police said.

title: THE NATION: Five Views on the Bush Pentagon; Whether and Where to Cut the Military Budget
description: WITH President Bush still promising not to raise taxes and to cut the deficit at the same time, members of Congress are eager to see what he will say about Pentagon spending when he appears on Capitol Hill Thursday evening to discuss the budget for 1990.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Will Free Agency In Football Work Well?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Where Wheat and Cattle Grow, So Does Anxiety Over Cold
description: A siege of brutally cold weather gripping much of the country has delivered cruel punishment to farmers and cattle growers in the Midwest, a region already suffering from drought and drying winds.

title: Review/Music; Improvisatory Double Bill
description: Thursday's double bill at the Kitchen was a bit less than gripping. While good portions of a piece by Lawrence (Butch) Morris played by the Spring Quartet had some tension, the work lasted too long. And while the music and poetry played and read by the Marilyn Crispell trio - which doubles as three-quarters of the Anthony Braxton quartet - also had carefully thought-out moments, it, too, overstayed its welcome.

title: Mineral Shop Offers a Mine of Curious Fun
description: WITH plastic miner's helmets atop their heads, 7-year-old Robby Brown and his brother, Danny, , age 6, sorted through their little paper sacks, seeking out glittering bits of amethyst and quartz with professional thoroughness. The boys gained their knowledge of gemstones through visits to the Rare Earth Gallery in West Redding.

title: Irwin Has Some New Fans
description: Hale Irwin, the 43-year-old two-time winner of the United States Open title, suddenly blossomed as the big crowd favorite today while putting his way into a tie for the lead during the incomplete third round of the Nissan Los Angeles Open.

title: The Boom in New York City Bed-and-Breakfasts
description: When New Yorkers think of bed-and-breakfasts, they might imagine a New England farmhouse in the woods or a European cottage by the sea. Rarely would they think of looking down the block or right next door.

title: Katrina Yee, Lawyer, Wed to Bruce Rathie
description: Katrina Angela Yee, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rowan Yee of Sydney, Australia, was married yesterday to Bruce Rathie, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David H. Rathie of Brisbane, Australia, at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Andrew J. W. Mullins performed the ceremony.

title:
GARDENING;
Gardening Near the Shore Is Different
description: LEAD: NEAR the shore, gardening can differ from that inland. The size and nature of the water and its relation to the property play a large role.

title: Innumeracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Meeting Oneself, the Second Time Around
description: IS love lovelier the second time around? How about the first time, the second time around?

title: If Time Flies, It Can Hop, Skip and Jump
description: AND now, fashion watchers, an up-to-the-minute report: at 3:15, a woman in boots and a miniskirt was seen hurrying up Fifth Avenue. Just 20 minutes earlier, a chic woman in a fur-trimmed leather suit designed by Gianfranco Ferre was hurrying uptown. Other timely spottings were made at 2:25 and 5:35. And did you catch the 7:14? Wow!

title: Question Of the Week; What Do The Mets Need to Add In 1989?
description: Looking back on the Mets' 1988 season, it is apparent that they had all the tools to make it to the World Series. But superiority at the plate and on the field was undermined by the lack of consistency a championship team needs.

title: Outbreak of AIDS Triples the Testing in a Soviet City
description: Health officials investigating the circumstances under which 27 babies and five of their mothers contracted the AIDS virus in a city 750 miles south of Moscow have tripled the number of people being tested there for the virus to 12,000.

title: Stephen Munger And Linda Zwack Exchange Vows
description: Linda Jeanne Zwack, a vice president of fixed-income securities sales at Shearson Lehman Hutton, and Stephen Reese Munger, a vice president in corporate finance at Morgan Stanley & Company, were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York. The Rev. John Derek Stubbs performed the ceremony.

title: WHEN RADICAL CHIC COURTED THE GUILLOTINE
description: LEAD: On the face of it, no term fits the Parisian beau monde of the late 18th century better than the one invented 200 years later by Tom Wolfe, who mocked the ''progressives'' of Park Avenue, socializing with black revolutionaries, as exponents of ''Radical Chic.'' Indeed, the fashionable Faubourg St.

title: Nanci J. Palm to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry Palm of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nanci Joy Palm, to Frank Adi Giovannetti, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Adi A. Giovannetti of New York and Dix Hills, L.I. Miss Palm attended Marymount Manhattan College. Her mother, Audrey Palm, is the controller for Il Monello and Il Nido, New York restaurants owned by the future bridegroom's father. The future bridegroom is the director of Il Monello.

title: Linda Tsu Becomes Bride Of Wing Wong, Engineer
description: Linda B. Tsu, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Sheang Tuey of Monterey Park, Calif., and Wing Yen Wong, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Ho Sing Hoo of New York, were married yesterday. The Rev. Dr. Ralph E. Brushaber performed the ceremony at the Oneonta Congregational Church in South Pasadena, Calif.

title: Cashmere Outpost
description: COLD weather is an occasion for luxury at N. Peal, the cashmere clothier based in London. N. Peal recently opened its first New York boutique, at 118 East 57th Street, ''the better to serve a 5,000-name mailing list in Manhattan,'' said Nancy Kravette, manager of the store. In addition to sweaters, dressing gowns and shifts, N. Peal's designers have adapted cashmere to elegant accessories, all made in Scotland.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: A RUSSIAN IN HARTFORD A Soviet play with a Soviet director and an American cast will open at the Hartford Stage Company for previews on Saturday, to Feb. 16. The play, ''The Paper Gramophone,'' will run from Feb. 17 to March 18. The director, Yuri Yeremin, who has adapted the work from an unproduced screenplay by Alexander Chervinsky, is making his American debut with this production. Mr. Yuremin is the artistic director of the 75-year-old Pushkin Drama Theater in Moscow. According to the Hartford Stage Company, this is the first time that a Soviet director has come to America to work on an American-produced Soviet play.

title: What Was Lost In Afghanistan
description: IN 1979, as tens of thousands of Soviet troops streamed into Afghanistan, Moscow's strategy seemed straightforward and completely in line with its world view: A bold military strike, reminiscent of moves into Hungary and Czechoslovakia, would prevent insurrection and chaos from toppling a pro-Soviet and Marxist regime. But Afghanistan was not Eastern Europe. The Afghan adventure dragged on for nine years, humiliating Moscow's military machine, killing an estimated 13,000 Soviet troops and wounding an additional 22,000. The occupation lost support at home and cost Moscow friends and influence throughout the developing world, which voiced its overwhelming condemnation every year at the United Nations.

title: Claudia B. Repp Weds in Vermont
description: Claudia Brainard Repp, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Inslee Repp of West Hartford, Conn., and South Pomfret, Vt., was married yesterday at St. James Episcopal Church in Woodstock, Vt., to Michael Tupanjanin, the son of Else Aarestrup Tupanjanin and Vukosav Tupanjanin, both of Glen Rock, N.J. The Rev. Donald Boyer officiated.

title: Celebrating the Year of the Snake: Feasts and Friends
description: LEAD: TOMORROW marks the year 4687 in the Chinese lunar calendar. Dating from 2637 BC, the calendar represents the longest chronological record in history. Unlike our Western system, this zodiac has five subcycles of 12 years each, the whole completing a grand cycle of 60 years. We are now in the 78th cycle, which began in February 1984.

title: John Reed Bumps Into Reality
description: Talking with John S. Reed, the chairman of Citicorp, is a little like standing on the bow of an oceanliner and peering into the distance through a spyglass. There, just barely visible on the horizon, is the fuzzy outline of the Citicorp of tomorrow.

title: Yoko Ono's New Bronze Age At the Whitney
description: As well as being one of the world's most fabled widows, Yoko Ono is one of its wealthiest artists. Yet even stranger for one so famous is that her art is actually little known. A participant in New York's underground scene of the early 1960's and one of the very first members of the international Fluxus art movement - a loosely knit group of musicians, artists, poets and film makers who tried to blur the boundaries between art and life, and in some ways were the first hippies - Yoko Ono became the personification of way out, experimental art after she met John Lennon in 1966.

title: Multiple Listing
description: To the Editor:

title: THE REGION  Q & A: The View From the Ballistics Unit; Where the Guns Are, What They Are, Who Has Them
description: IN 1988, the police seized 16,370 guns in New York City, about 9 percent more than the 14,600 they confiscated in 1978.

title: County Pursues Its Plan for Bus Garage
description: LEAD: THREE years after scuttling a proposal to build a bus garage in Yorktown in the face of strong local opposition, the county is seeking to build a 100-bus garage in Mount Pleasant.

title: Sleeping Pills
description: IN THE DIM LIGHT OF MY bathroom, I looked into a vial at a dozen oval, sky-blue sleeping pills. I was getting desperate. At 2 A.M., an emergency-room doctor at the hospital had awakened me to get some advice. Since then, my brain had buzzed without mercy. I tried all the rituals of the insomniac until 3:30, when I pulled out my rarely used bottle of Halcion with the anxiety of someone hesitant to plunge into the unknown known. I accepted the trade-off of possible side effects for needed sleep in my patients, but could I afford them later that working day?

title: Long and Quiet Career is Prelude to a Coup for Hastings Composer
description: THIS is a story that should help artists of all kinds get up in the morning. It concerns a Hastings-on-Hudson resident named Stanley Wolfe, who since 1963 has been the director of the extension division of the famed Juilliard School in Manhattan. Mr. Wolfe teaches courses on composition, music theory and contemporary music, and has himself been a composer for more than 30 years.

title: OREGON ORIGINAL
description: The president of the Carlsberg Brewery in Copenhagen once explained why he was busily selling franchises all over the world. ''Beer,'' he said, ''is 90 percent water. Why should I pay to send millions of gallons of water around the globe?''

title: Review/Dance; Music by Tchaikovsky In a City Ballet Evening
description: The New York City Ballet danced an all-Tchaikovsky program on Friday night at the New York State Theater, thereby honoring one of the ballet world's greatest composers. Curiously, not one of the three choreographic works was accompanied by a score specifically written for dancers. Yet Tchaikovsky's orchestral and instrumental music is so rhythmically supple and emotionally expressive that it can easily send dancers whirling.

title: Lisa Beth Joseph to Wed Daniel Zelson Next Year
description: The engagement of Lisa Beth Joseph to Daniel M. Zelson has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, William K. Joseph of New York and Carole Young of Westport, Conn. A January wedding is planned.

title: Census Bureau Demographer's Unqualified Prediction: 'We Will Be Wrong'
description: The Census Bureau's bold projection that the United States population could shrink in 50 years may prove as precise as a cloudy crystal ball. Or historians late in the 21st century may look back with astonishment at the accuracy of the forecast.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: So Fond of Doom

title: TOUGH TALK FOR DEMOCRATS
description: Joseph Califano's talk to Democrats was not only tough, but so cynical it will fail to serve his party in any way. All he explains is how to take some votes away from Republicans. He does not address the larger problem: how to persuade the other half of the electorate - the half that does not vote at all - to go to the polls. That is the big picture. JEROME CLEGG New York, N.Y.

title: Peter Knobloch Wed To Laura Nathanson
description: The wedding of Laura Gimbel Nathanson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Nathanson of New York and Fairfield, Conn., to Peter Thomas Knobloch, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin T. Knobloch of Jamesburg, N.J., took place yesterday at the Puck Building in New York. Acting Justice Thomas B. Galligan of State Supreme Court performed the ceremony.

title: Give a Cold Shoulder to the Freeze
description: President Bush and his spokesmen continue to express the hope that the Federal budget can be balanced using the ''flexible freeze'' approach that he outlined during his campaign. But at the same time they have shown no inclination to retreat from their commitments to leave Social Security untouched, keep real defense spending constant, and not raise taxes.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Bombay
description: Bombay is India's richest and most vibrant city, its capital of entrepreneurship, its fashion center, home to the country's movie industry and leader in the performing arts. The city's skyline resembles downtown Manhattan's, but the high-rise buildings of south Bombay, with their glittering jewelry and dress showrooms, contrast sharply with the hovels and poverty of sidewalk dwellers.

title: Going After the Gray Dollars
description: Murray Sockolow can hear the difference. The 71-year-old retired local civil servant in Tenafly, N.J., says he is getting ''10 times more calls'' these days from stock brokers and insurance agents than a year ago. The calls come from tiny independent offices as well as giants like Merrill Lynch and Dean Witter, and Mr. Sockolow has been offered everything from penny stocks to single-premium life insurance.

title: Ms. Remes Wed To Craig Stewart
description: Emily Rebecca Remes, a lawyer for the New York State Commission on Government Integrity, and Craig Andrew Stewart, an assistant United States Attorney, were married yesterday at the Loft in Manhattan. Judge Robert W. Sweet of Federal District Court officiated.

title: CRIME
description: ''If a baby wasn't safe from the maniacs in this city, then who was?'' Meyer Meyer, one of the conscientious cops of the 87th Precinct, gets no answer to this one in Ed McBain's gritty new police procedural. LULLABY (Morrow, $17.95) opens on New Year's Day with the double murder of a 6-month-old infant and her 16-year-old baby sitter. Even the case-hardened detectives are appalled, which both energizes the criminal investigation and reassures us that the author has not caved in to the cynicism of the metropolis he writes about.

title: Waiting for the Resumption of Politics
description: THE talk here in recent weeks has been so relentlessly cordial and civic-minded that it sometimes appeared that the nation's leaders were trying to change a two-party system into a no-party system.

title: A Lack of Nurses Brings Changes at County Hospitals
description: HOSPITALS in the county, as in the rest of the state, are struggling to cope with the effects of a prolonged, nationwide shortage of registered nurses that shows little sign of easing.

title: Domes Could Mushroom on the Urban Landscape
description: In the beginning was the Astrodome, plopped down in 1965 like a wayward flying saucer in a sweltering pasture south of downtown Houston.

title: 3 Accused of Murder in a Plot To Get $1 Million in Insurance
description: The founders of an athletic clothing chain and a California doctor were charged Friday with murdering a man in a $1 million insurance swindle in which the dead man was deliberately misidentified as one of the founders.

title: NONFICTION
description: WAIT TILL NEXT YEAR: The Story of a Season When What Should've Happened Didn't and What Could've Gone Wrong Did. By William Goldman and Mike Lupica. (Bantam, $19.95.) There are those who still watch replays of the Mets' miraculous finish in the sixth game of the 1986 World Series or the Giants' drubbing of the Denver Broncos in Super Bowl XXI. ''Wait Till Next Year'' brings, to those who care to look again, replays from New York's 1987 seasons in professional baseball, football and basketball in alternating chapters written by Mike Lupica, the New York Daily News sports columnist, and William Goldman, the novelist. The scenes include Dwight Gooden weeping silently when confronted with a report saying his urine tested positive for cocaine, members of the Yankees setting fire to a press statement by George Steinbrenner and Mark Gastineau being spat at by his teammates as he crossed the Jets' picket line during the 1987 strike. Mr. Lupica provides most of this action in sections called ''The Reporter's Notebook,'' which are an undigested collection of observations. Mr. Goldman's contributions, called ''A Fan's Notes,'' are presumably intended to tell the season's story from the point of view of the die-hard fan and thus shed light on the passion of fandom. Mainly he free-associates about players of earlier eras (better than today's, he insists), familiar sports arguments like Chamberlain versus Russell (Wilt all the way, he says) and sports announcers, and offers heated recitations of statistics. Mr. Goldman is a pretty good play-by-play guy himself when he describes one football game in Columbia University's monumental losing streak. His description of the tentatively hopeful crowd suggests a kind of tender attachment that may hide within a fan even as blustery as himself.

title: Brazil Cardinal's Praise of Castro Stirs Protest
description: The head of Brazil's largest Roman Catholic archdiocese has provoked an outcry in conservative circles here by writing a letter to President Fidel Castro expressing the hope that he will always govern Cuba.

title: Judge Finds Pennsylvania Welfare Officials in Contempt Over Financing
description: A Federal district judge today found the Public Welfare Secretary of Pennsylvania and his deputy in contempt of court, saying they had not complied with an order for the state to pay for habilitative services to mentally retarded Philadelphians who live at home.

title: HEALTH CARE'S HIGH COST
description: The article, ''Taking a Scalpel to Health Care Costs'' (Jan. 8) prompted an unusually strong response from readers. Some of their comments follow. To the Editor:

title: Crux of Problem: Animal Suffering
description: Continuing the discusions of deer population control, Thomas V. Connors (Letters to the Editor, Jan. 22) pleads that logic should prevail in governmental decisions affecting animal conservation. However, he completely overlooks the basic crux of the controversy between hunters and animal rights activists -- that is, the pain and agony caused to the innocent deer.

title: Future of 'Sandwich Generation'
description: LEAD: ROSE and Joseph Saletti and Antonette and Joseph Perrone went to the West Islip Public Library the other night to do ''some homework,'' Mr. Saletti said.

title: Flights of Fancy in 'Home Games'
description: IF instant gratification were all, ''Home Games'' could be a winner.

title:
GARDENING;
Gardening Near the Shore Is Different
description: LEAD: NEAR the shore, gardening can differ from that inland. The size and nature of the water and its relation to the property play a large role.

title: In a Philippine Town, Child Prostitution, Despite Protests, Is a Way of Life
description: Drive into this green and quiet town 40 miles southeast of Manila and groups of men will run alongside your car, banging on the windows, offering a choice of the local attractions: A boat ride to the scenic waterfall or a child prostitute.

title: TALKING: Security; Systems Getting Smarter
description: DURING the last decade, as centrally monitored electronic security systems were being installed in ever-increasing numbers in single-family houses - about 1 in 12 now has such a system, according to a 1988 survey by Security Distributing and Marketing magazine - they turned out to be something of a mixed blessing.

title: Cancer Therapy From a Tree
description: LIKE the ugly duckling, the Pacific yew tree has a new image.

title: Daphne B. Wood To Wed in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sander Vanocur of Washington have announced the engagement of Mrs. Vanocur's daughter, Daphne Boyer Wood, to Thomas Victor Hicks, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Hinshaw Hicks of Baltimore. A May wedding is planned. Miss Wood, also the daughter of James T. Wood 3d of Santa Barbara, Calif., is a graduate of Choate Rosemary Hall and the University of Vermont. She is the manager of the Janet Russo women's clothing shop in New York. Her father is a lawyer. Her stepfather is a senior correspondent with ABC News in Washington and the anchor of the network's ''Business World'' program. The future bridegroom, a salesman in New York for Victor Graphics in Baltimore, graduated from Denison University. His father is the president of Victor Graphics.

title: Starling Triumphs in the 9th
description: Marlon Starling won the World Boxing Council welterweight title tonight when he stopped the champion, Lloyd Honeyghan, at 1:19 of the ninth round of a scheduled 12-round bout at Caesars Palace.

title: Vanished Colonial Town Yields Baroque Surprise
description: On a cold winter day the fields betray little evidence of the grand scheme. But just beyond the turning edge of the plowshare lies the evidence of a vanished city believed to be the first elaborately designed urban center in North America.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Track and Field

title: TOUGH TALK FOR DEMOCRATS
description: If we Democrats follow Joseph Califano's advice, we will win national elections again. Our current Presidential nominating process guarantees Democratic defeat. The process forces candidates to appeal only to narrow segments of the electorate. A survivor of that undemocratic nominating process forfeits the chance to win the general election. NEWTON N. MINOW Chicago

title: Who's Stricken and How: AIDS Pattern Is Shifting
description: Eight years after AIDS made its startling appearance, it is changing its face. Once overwhelmingly an affliction of homosexual men, acquired immune deficiency syndrome is more and more becoming a disease of poor, black and Hispanic heterosexuals in the inner city.

title: Computers That Help Skippers Navigate and Ferret Out Fish
description: On-board weather-monitoring computers are enabling captains of ocean fishing vessels not only to sail the safest routes, but to increase the size of their catches.

title: 11 New York City Districts Have Too Few Pupils
description: Since Jan. 1, the New York City school system has violated a major provision of the school-decentralization law: 11 of the 32 locally run community school districts have fewer pupils than required by the state.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE NORTHERN WESTCHESTER CHINESE SCHOOL;
Absorbing the Traditions of China
description: LEAD: WITH ancient, syncopated music, three giant papier-mache lions animated by a dozen children and wishes for prosperity and longevity, the Chinese New Year - the Year of the Snake, 4687 - was welcomed last weekend at the Northern Westchester Chinese School. The holiday is actually tomorrow, but the school scheduled festivities to coincide with its own graduation ceremonies and 20th anniversary party.

title: Q and A
description: Island Wedding

title: To West Germans, The Far Right Isn't Just Another Fringe
description: BY the standards of most functioning democracies, a rise of fever on the far right in times of stress is not a cause for undue alarm, unpleasant as it may be to acknowledge the tenacity of xenophobia and bigotry. But in West Germany the boundaries of political sentiment are still constrained by history and suspiciousness: While a shift to the left raises allied suspicions of a latent German longing for neutrality, a blip on the far right still touches off the ''neo-Nazi'' alarm.

title: Big Achievement for Little St. Anthony
description: It's not always easy to tell what kind of game St. Anthony High School of Jersey City has been playing by looking at the scoreboard. Last Tuesday, for instance, it appeared that the Friars, the No. 1 high school basketball team in the country, had routed LaSalle Academy of Manhattan by 22 points, 69-47.

title: Cabinet Choice Fielding Hard Questions in Drills
description: It's called a ''murder board'' in the trade, and Dr. Louis W. Sullivan has been getting murdered regularly for the last week. ''Murder board'' is Washington jargon for a mock hearing, where officials who are about to face Congressional questioning train for the event.

title: Plot and Character Entwine in 'Murder'
description: AS a play, Terence Feely's ''Murder in Mind'' offers not only murder and mystery but also international art and antiques fraud, an airline disaster, sadism, mistaken identity, mind-altering drugs and madness. As a production, Arena Players Repertory Company's version offers flawless direction and a superb cast, including one of the best performances to be seen on the Island this season.

title: Switching Channels
description: A high-stakes cast change is coming to prime-time news. After more than a decade with CBS News, Diane Sawyer is leaving to become a co-anchor on a new prime-time news program on ABC. Ms. Sawyer, who has been a correspondent on ''60 Minutes'' since 1984, and Sam Donaldson, the former ABC chief White House correspondent, are to be co-anchors of a program that the network has been planning for several years and is likely to begin by this summer. Contract terms were not disclosed. She was reportedly getting about $1.2 million from CBS under a contract that allowed her to go elsewhere for an anchor position. Ms. Sawyer paid tribute last week to her CBS bosses, who had tried to keep her. She said of her new job, ''This is a very exciting new venture.''

title: 'Batman' Battles for Big Money
description: Holy oblivious to the mist falling about his gentian fedora, Jack Nicholson presses an orange bullhorn to his mouth - a permanent leer of red in a whiteface mask - and begins his ascent to the helicopter.

title: Columbia-Presbyterian Laying Off 300
description: Beset by continuing financial pressures, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center has laid off 50 employees and plans to cut another 250 from its 6,200-member staff in the next two weeks.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: NATURAL HISTORY. By Joan Perucho. Translated by David H. Rosenthal. (Knopf, $17.95.) The vampire, from Bram Stoker's seminal Count Dracula to Anne Rice's rather sympathetic Lestat, has come to occupy an esteemed place in literature. In ''Natural History,'' the eminent Catalan novelist Joan Perucho gives us Onofre de Dip, a 13th-century Catalan nobleman who fell prey to the curse of vampirism while on an ambassadorial mission to Hungary.

title: Saltwater Fishing Licenses Are at Issue
description: Although many seacoast dwellers, particularly those whose locks are grizzled, become apoplectic when there is talk of saltwater sport fishing licenses, some states have them and others are edging in that direction.

title: 'Orphans' Explores Bonding
description: IN a stirring and honest staging of ''Orphans,'' at the Boston Post Road Stage Company, the director, Douglas Moser, has located the heartbeat in a play that is known - to the extent that it is known - for its visceral sensations.

title: Correction
description: An article on Jan. 8 about Shiite Muslim terrorist attacks on Saudi diplomats characterized the Hejaz region of Saudi Arabia incorrectly. It is not part of the eastern province and does not have a large Shiite population.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Honolulu; 5,000-Apartment Project Revived
description: A DEVELOPER is reviving plans for a residential development on Oahu that may include as many as 5,000 units.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Prime-Space Vacancies; Downtown Overtakes Midtown
description: FOR the first time in more than five years, owners of prime office buildings in midtown Manhattan are facing higher vacancy levels than those of their downtown counterparts.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: SOVIET DRAMA

title: A Lawyer Is Wed To Beverly Deric
description: Beverly Joyce Deric and Eugene Francis Cowell 3d were married yesterday. Graduates of Yale University with the class of 1979, they are, respectively, a partner in the investment firm of Amster & Company and a senior associate in the law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell, both in New York.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Chicago;
Near Northwest: Lots for Lots
description: LEAD: THREE weeks ago the City Council's Committee on Land Acquisition, Disposition and Leases approved bids totaling $650,000 for properties throughout the city. Among the winning bids were two for small, vacant, city-owned lots in the Near Northwest - one fetching $82,000, the other $41,000.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE WEEPING AND THE LAUGHTER. By Noel Barber. (McGraw-Hill, $17.95.) Title notwithstanding, ''The Weeping and the Laughter'' will hardly stir a great swell of emotion. In fact this 32d book by Noel Barber, who died last summer, is pure plot. The novel follows Prince Nicki Korolev through 28 tumultuous years, starting in 1919 when the members of his family flee their native Russia dressed as peasants.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
A $50 Million Clifton Riverfront Project
description: LEAD: FOR nearly a century a group of factory buildings that were once part of the Waldrich Bleachery have lined the Third River in the Delawanna section of Clifton, home to one of several industrial pockets in this Passaic County community.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: HOME TOWN NEWS: William Allen White and the Emporia Gazette. By Sally Foreman Griffith. (Oxford University, $24.95.) When William Allen White wrote his autobiography in minute and repetitious detail - spanning the period between the morning of Feb. 10, 1868 and the year 1923 - he left little out.

title: Sports of The Times; Bill White Keeps Fighting, His Way
description: In his Brooklyn Dodger uniform, Jackie Robinson's number was 42.
