Coincidentally, 42 years after the arrival in 1947 of major league baseball's first black player, Bill White is now the National League's first black president. And when White was asked what he remembered of Robinson in 1956, his rookie season as the New York Giants' first baseman and Robinson's last season, he laughed.

title: Fiat Fights to Stay on Top in Europe
description: Giovanni Agnelli, Europe's most famous and most powerful business executive, has long been called the unofficial king of Italy. But it is only in the past year that his Fiat empire, which was on the verge of going under a decade ago, could also claim to have reached kingly heights.

title: Beatrice Gray, Psychiatrist, Is Married to John Johnson
description: At St. Lawrence O'Toole Roman Catholic Church in Brewster, N.Y., Dr. Beatrice Anne Gray, the daughter of Mary A. T. Gray of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., and the late Dr. Nelson M. Gray, was married yesterday to John Johnson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Gronek of Penndel, Pa.

title: Time Traveler
description: To the Editor:

title: Innumeracy
description: To the Editor:

title: A Pianist, 2 Singers and 2 Violinists
description: Hiroko Nakamura

title: 'Balm in Gilead'
description: To the Editor:

title: Universities Are for Students
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: 105 Connecticut Artists Picked for Stamford Show
description: THE ''Connecticut Art'' exhibition is the 19th of its kind to be displayed at the Stamford Museum and Nature Center in as many years.

title: Seeking a Higher Return Abroad
description: Although hardly a stampede, a growing number of big corporations, including General Motors, American Telephone and Telegraph, Philip Morris and GTE, have been increasing the portion of their pension funds invested in foreign stocks.

title: Toll Collector Shortage Snarls Traffic at Two Bridges
description: The authority that oversees the toll bridges and tunnels connecting New York City's boroughs says it faces a critical shortage of toll collectors and has been forced to close toll lanes for the last month at two of its bridges.

title: Sri Lanka's President Appeals for an End to Political Killings
description: President Ranasinghe Premadasa appealed today for an end to campaign-related violence that has killed hundreds of people and threatens Sri Lanka's first parliamentary elections in 11 years.

title: RIVER BLINDNESS
description: Erik Eckholm's article on river blindness in West Africa was interesting (''River Blindness: Conquering an Ancient Scourge,'' Jan. 8). I had the opportunity to travel some years ago in Upper Volta, and saw this devastating illness firsthand. William C. Campbell and his team, who discovered ivermectin, and Merck & Company, which is providing the drug without charge, are to be commended, along with the international team that is coordinating the dispensing of the drug. Their task is truly a worldwide effort. Perhaps this is what George Bush had in mind when he talked about a ''kinder, gentler nation.'' MELVIN S. SCHNEIDER St. Louis

title: Furillo's Wife Should Be Paid
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Samuel Vincent Wed To Ellen P. Hockeimer
description: Ellen Patricia Hockeimer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry E. Hockeimer Sr. of Washington and Bloomfield Hills, Mich., was married yesterday at her parents' home in Bloomfield Hills to Samuel Allen Darlington Vincent, a son of Mrs. Edwin S. Murphy of Fairfield, Conn., and the late Samuel M. Vincent. Mayor Nancy Polk of Bloomfield Hills performed the ceremony.

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: Pascali's Island Starring Ben Kingsley, Charles Dance, Helen Mirren. Directed by James Dearden. 1988. International Video Entertainment. 101 minutes. $89.95. Rated PG-13. Includes a flash of partial nudity and some violent deaths.

title: Medal in Balance
description: He was banned from competition for life after admitting to using steroids to improve his strength before the 1984 Los Angeles Olympic Games, but Jacques Demers, the Canadian weight lifter, will probably not have to give up the silver medal he won in the 165-pound class. That, at least, seems to be the feeling of many Canadian and international athletic officials.

title: Thriving on Road, Bucks Top Bullets
description: Ricky Pierce scored 9 of his 21 points in the fourth quarter tonight, leading the Milwaukee Bucks to a 113-102 victory over the Washington Bullets.

title:
Long Island Q&A;: Robin Chandler Duke;
Soldier in an Unpopular War: Population Control
description: LEAD: FROM her Upper East Side apartment, Robin Chandler Duke may seem an unlikely soldier in what many consider a nasty battle: World population control and abortion rights.

title: Exhibit Offers a Step Into Assembly's Past
description: The General Assembly affects the lives of everyone in Connecticut, but until now, there was no way to learn about its history. Now, the past is in easy view, as visitors who stop at the new Legislative Office Building in Hartford will discover.

title: Dr. K. E. Mostov Plans To Wed Ms. Silverman
description: The engagement of Emily Leah Silverman to Dr. Keith Elliot Mostov, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Philip Mostov of Groton, Conn., has been made known by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Silverman of New York. The couple plan to marry in April.

title: Ames Cushing Plans to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. John P. Jennings of Mill Neck, L.I., and Howard G. Cushing Jr. of Newport, R.I., of the engagement of their daughter Mary Ames Cushing to James A. Tollefson, a son of Mrs. John J. Egan Jr. of Newport and the late Dr. George A. Tollefson. A June 24th wedding is planned.

title: Proposition 42: Debate Goes On
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Princess Yasmin Aga Khan Wed to Christopher Jeffries
description: Princess Yasmin Aga Khan and Christopher Michael Jeffries, a real estate developer, were married yesterday at the bride's home in New York by Judge Edmund L. Palmieri of Federal District Court.

title: TV Sports in the Year 2000: Cable Heaven
description: LEAD: Television first aired sporting events 50 years ago, an experiment so novel that viewers were willing to watch while standing outside department store windows, straining their eyes to glimpse faint, flickering images on tiny black and white screens.

title: Billingsley Retiring
description: As the man who created the diving program at Indiana University, Hobie Billingsley has had his share of triumphs. Now, after 30 years on the job, he has decided it's time to take time to savor them. He announced that he would retire as coach at the end of the season but remain at Indiana as a teacher.

title: HEALTH CARE'S HIGH COST
description: The article, ''Taking a Scalpel to Health Care Costs'' (Jan. 8) prompted an unusually strong response from readers. Some of their comments follow. To the Editor:

title: Public Housing Entering New Era
description: HOUSING officials - city, state and Federal - say they hope the scheduled demolition of a high-rise public housing complex in New Haven is a further sign that a misguided era is over.

title: Auto Racing; Paul Returns From Prison
description: In a sport as conscious of public relations as auto racing, John Paul Jr. would seem to be a pariah.

title: IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Hartsdale, N.Y. $350,000 50 Birchwood Lane 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 36-year-old remodeled ranch; fireplace, deck, eat-in kitchen, family room; taxes $5,558. Ossining, N.Y. $245,000 6 Donald Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 36-year-old ranch; fireplace, deck, family room, utility room; taxes $4,102. Yonkers, N.Y. $230,040 80 Gramercy Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 42-year-old Cape Cod; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, family room, pool; taxes $3,437. Greenwich, Conn. $2.65 million 98 Glenwood Drive 11-bedroom, 6 1/2-bath, 90-year-old Victorian; water views, includes carriage house, 0.9 acre; taxes $7,945. Monroe, Conn. $320,000 101 Lazy Brook 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 8-year-old colonial; on golf course, in-law apartment, 0.5 acre; taxes $3,109. Wilton, Conn. $605,000 15 Turner Ridge 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 7-year-old Dutch colonial; separate studio with bath, private setting, 1.8 acres; taxes $5,980. OTHER AREAS Delaware, N.J. $200,000 Mezzaros Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 2-year-old ranch; family room, brick fireplace, deck, 3-acre lot; taxes $3,412. Lakewood, N.J. $138,000 1384 Alvaredo Drive 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 12-year-old ranch; patio, fireplace, pool; taxes $1,953. Coram, L.I. $200,000 20 Howard Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 14-year-old colonial; Florida room, finished basement, pool; taxes $4,400.

title:
A GUIDE TO CRUISES WORLDWIDE;
Here Come the Big Ships
description: LEAD: CHANGE in the world of cruises normally means following the seasons from warmer regions in the winter to cooler regions in the summer, but in the last year the industry has seen a series of complicated mergers and construction of ever larger ships. The industry, which in the last 10 years has seen a doubling in demand for cruises, hopes to attract a share of the 95 percent of

title: Big Issues From a Small Volcanic Island in the Pacific
description: MORE than 4,000 miles south southwest of San Francisco lies a tiny volcanic island enveloped in the aura of a famous mutiny: the revolt led by Fletcher Christian against Lieut. William Bligh of the Bounty in 1789.

title: Add Real Human Suffering to Abortion Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Submarine Silence
description: To the Editor:

title: Bit by Bit, Estonia Is Cutting Ties To Moscow
description: A PARADOX comes to life here in Estonia, an example of a life and death question for the Soviet Union. Mikhail S. Gorbachev has taken off many restraints that have held the country back, but have also held it together. Will it fly apart without them?

title: German Asserts Libyan Plant May Contain U.S. Computer
description: The central computer at a suspected poison gas factory in Libya is reported to have been made in the United States, the head of one of West Germany's governing coalition parties said today.

title: The East-West Flow of People and Ideas
description: RATHER like the little Dutch boy with his finger in the dike, East Germany's leader, Erich Honecker, vowed recently that the Berlin wall would remain standing for 50 or 100 years since it was needed ''to protect our Republic from thieves, not to speak of those who are ready to disturb stability and peace in Europe.''

title: Late Great City; A Fairer Perspective
description: In writing off New York ('The Late Great City' Jan. 8), Kathleen Kennedy appears to abandon her effort to 'balance the bad with the good' in the city.

title: Shoreham Isn't Like Chernobyl
description: Regarding letters bout Shoreham that recently appeared in yourcolumns, it is demagogic for N. Lawrence (or Governor Cuomo) to compare Chernobyl to Shoreham. Only the major difference is that Chernobyl had no containment vessel. Many Long Islanders are suffering from nuclear phobia, and they will pay dearly for it in increased power costs and increased pollution from more fossil fuel power plants. David Burner St. James

title: Prospects; The Dow Creeps Up
description: The stock market, which has been climbing since the first of the year, last week rose to its highest level since the October 1987 collapse. On Friday, the Dow Jones industrial average closed at 2,331.25. The markets in London, Tokyo and Frankfurt have also risen sharply this year. Financial experts are debating whether this is the beginning of a new, global bull market or just the ''January effect'' - when stock prices rise at the start of a new year. Four analysts assess the market's strength. Gerald S. Zukowski Manager of the Boston Company's Capital Appreciation Fund.

title: Jaguar and Nissan 1-2
description: A Jaguar XJR9 and a Nissan GTP battled for the lead tonight as the Daytona 24 Hours moved past the six-hour mark. The Jaguar of Jan Lammers of the Netherlands, Davy Jones and the

title:
GARDENING;
Gardening Near the Shore Is Different
description: LEAD: NEAR the shore, gardening can differ from that inland. The size and nature of the water and its relation to the property play a large role.

title: More Voices for Poor Children
description: Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York calls this the Decade of the Child. A blue-ribbon study group now seconds that commitment to children at risk, and urges spending priorities to save the next generation.

title: Signs of Strength Raise Some Jitters
description: Statistical signs of strength in the economy heightened anxiety among those worried that the Federal Reserve may raise interest rates further to cool the economy and dampen inflation tendencies. The most startling figure was a 408,000 rise in the number of nonfarm jobs created in January. An increase of about 300,000, the monthly average gain last year, had been expected. The labor report also gave another hint of price pressures by posting a rise of 1.2 percent in average weekly earnings last month. But the large number of jobs created was not enough to take care of all the people entering the labor force. January's unemployment rate rose by one-tenth of a percentage point, to 5.4 percent.

title: CONSUMER RATES

NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Jamaica, Vt.;
Planners Balk At Resort Plan
description: LEAD: JOSEPH J. STEINER, project director for the Tamarack Golf and Country Club, spends his days in an office here waiting to answer questions from concerned citizens about his project, the largest ever proposed in this southeastern Vermont town of fewer than than 700 residents.

title: Parties Around Town
description: Dance at Maxim's

title: The 'Challenge' of Bow Hunting
description: I have read Thomas V. Connors's letter (''Ban on Bow Hunting Is Without Logic'' Jan. 22) reacting to mine (''Deer Hunting on Fire Island'' Jan 8) urging a ban not, unrealistically, on hunting per se, but on bow hunting only. But I found myself distanced from understanding Connors's milieu even further by his reference to such weapons' use as a ''logical extension of hunting practices that outdate all but the cavemen's spear.'' and by his assertion that the number of interested archers is increasing as the ''challenge'' of bow hunting is appreciated.

title: India Plans to Increase Arms Imports and Exports
description: India plans to increase exports of its own arms industry to raise funds to import high-technology weapons systems and upgrade its military forces, the Defense Minister has announced.

title: Concerto Premiere
description: Stanislaw Skrowaczewski is to conduct the American Composer's Orchestra in the New York premiere of his own Violin Concerto, and the world premiere of Aaron Jay Kernis's ''Invisible Mosaic III,'' at Carnegie Hall at 3 P.M. today. Also on the program is the William Schuman Violin Concerto. Robert McDuffie is to be the soloist in the Skrowaczewski and Schuman works. Tickets are $11 to $23. Information: 247-7800.

title: The Deficit Melts if Spending Is Fixed
description: The question of how to reduce the chronic Federal Government deficit is on the front burner. The flexible freeze concept, which I developed in 1978 and presented to George Bush - who was running for President - at a meeting in Kennebunkport, Me., in August of that year. The freeze appeared then - as it does now - to be the most economically sound and politically feasible approach to reducing the deficit. No one wants higher taxes or fewer Government goodies, but few would object, I reasoned, to unchanged tax rates and no real, or inflation-adjusted, growth in Government spending.

title: Blairstown Journal; Town Adjusting to Life After Real-Estate Boom
description: LIKE many other rural New Jersey communities, Blairstown whirled through a frenzied period of house building and buying in the mid-1980's. The flurry of activity has slowed now, almost to a standstill in some parts of the market, and residents of this old-time dairy town are adjusting to the not so quiet life after the real-estate boom.

title: The Salty Oasis of Cedar Key
description: WE were a half tank out of Orlando, somewhere near Yankeetown, heading north for Cedar Key, when the urge for oysters struck. With the top down on our rented red Chrysler, unfolding the road map was difficult. Fortunately, we were cruising through a part of Florida where it's hard to get lost: the Big Bend.

title: For Volunteers, The Choice Is Theirs
description: Thank you for printing Helene Verhaegen Buchen's thoughtful article, ''For Food Pantry Volunteers, All Is Not Peaches and Cream,'' about the mixed emotions she felt as she volunteered at a Church Food Pantry [ Opinion Page, Jan. 8 ] . She touches on the feeling many of us feel who volunteer to work with ''the poor.'' She uses but questions the word ''charity'' and this word is perhaps the true word, just as she says ''the angry clients show me the true face of charity.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-21

title: The Case of the Purloined Party
description: MARDI GRAS is invariably associated with New Orleans. However, the event is a regional one and actually started in 1704 in Mobile, Ala., a smaller, more provincial city 150 miles east of New Orleans. As the celebration has flowered in Louisiana, Mobilians have become truculent and defensive about their party, which seems to have abandoned them like an ungrateful son who ran after a painted woman, settling down happily in the sin and carelessness of New Orleans.

title: Quayle's Warning to Salvador: Aimed at Congress
description: Vice President Dan Quayle's sharp warning Friday to the Salvadoran Armed Forces to respect human rights was aimed as much at the United States Congress and American audiences as at the army or any officials here, American officials accompanying the Vice President said.

title: Action Is Called For On New Road Salt
description: As the co-sponsor of legislation in the State Senate last year that would have permitted New York to begin experimenting with calcium magnesium acetate as a winter road de-icer, I was very interested in your recent coverage of the decision by International Business Machines to begin testing this substance [ ''A Substitute for Road Salt Faces Its First Test in County,'' Nov. 27 ] .

title: Leslie Gaberman to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Gaberman of Fairfield, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter Leslie Sue Gaberman to John Brooks Harkavy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Harkavy of New Rochelle, N.Y. Miss Gaberman, an associate at the Boston law firm of Nissen & Lumsden, graduated from Lafayette College and received a J.D. degree at the Suffolk University Law School. Mr. Harkavy, an associate at the law firm of Peabody & Arnold in Boston, graduated from Boston University and its law school.

title: Putting the Best Foot Forward
description: BARRINGTON'S of East Islip does its best. Whether it's a special occasion or a special diet, it comes through. This is a restaurant that's warm, willing and welcoming. When diners call for reservations, they are often asked if a birthday or anniversary is being celebrated. If so, a cake may appear for dessert. Barrington's also remembers those who have nothing to celebrate, but are faced with the task of dining out while on restrictive diets. For them, the menu is annotated with small hearts indicating American Heart Association recommendations. The chef also prepares salt-free and special light meals upon request.

title: Question Of the Week; What Do The Mets Need to Add In 1989?
description: The Mets need to add nothing. With the team they have now, they could easily win the Series. But it would be nice to see a superstar like Joe Carter or Ellis Burks playing center field for the Mets. They should give third base to Jefferies, second base to Miller and Fernandez's slot in the rotation to West. After that, it would be nice to have a Rob Murphy-like pitcher setting up Myers in the pen, but I repeat, the Mets need to add nothing. MICHAEL A. RUBIN New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: The Once And Future Jerseyans
description: WE'VE all heard the jokes. Some people actually still tell them. You know the people I mean - those tardy trend-followers who have only now discovered Carribbean restaurants, Akitas and high-tech little telephones you can carry into the bathroom. For the rest of us, though, dumping on New Jersey has become extremely unfashionable (or ex-fashionable, which is far worse).

title: CONNECTICUT OPINION
description: OUR son was coming home from California for a holiday visit, and as my husband and I drove out to meet him at Kennedy Airport, we heard the news of the Pan Am crash in Scotland. Like many of the friends and relatives of the passengers on Flight 103, we, too, were heading for the Pan Am terminal on that somber, rainy evening. The trip, which usually takes an hour, took almost three.

title: Twilight in Pretoria
description: The end of President P. W. Botha's reign in South Africa draws near. Disabled by a stroke two weeks ago, the 73-year-old President will remain as head of Government but has resigned as leader of the National Party.

title: Innumeracy
description: To the Editor:

title: FOCUS: San Francisco; 20-Year Rehabilitation Effort Is About to Bear Fruit
description: The first of what are to be 11 buildings in a mixed-use complex that has been more than 20 years in the making is expected to have its first tenants by April 1.

title: Summit in May Is Set by China And the Soviets
description: China and the Soviet Union will hold a summit meeting in mid-May to achieve a ''complete normalization of relations,'' the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, announced here today.

title: Political Notes; Cuomo's War Chest Swells as He Readies for Battle
description: Next year's gubernatorial campaign is under way behind the scenes, and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo already has a war chest of $4,771,789, according to a report filed with the State Board of Elections by his continuing campaign organization.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Lifetime Post At Mount Holyok

title: RACING'S CALIFORNIA OASIS
description: In the days of the California gold rush, a prospector named Elias (Lucky) Baldwin came upon a cool green valley at the base of the San Gabriel Mountains. He said he had found paradise, and vowed to return someday. In 1875, having made his fortune in mining, he came back to the valley, bought the land that today includes the towns of Pasadena and Arcadia, and built a massive horse farm called Rancho Santa Anita.

title: Winograd to Return to the Hartford
description: ARTHUR WINOGRAD ended his long tenure as the music director of the Hartford Symphony in April 1985, but on Tuesday and Wednesday at 8 P.M. he will return to the podium at Bushnell Hall. The maestro's son, the violinist Peter Winograd, will make a guest appearance and play the Second Violin Concerto of Prokofiev.

title: Authentic Scenario
description: To the Editor:

title: Now Why Not Talk?
description: From Afghanistan to Paraguay, Poland to Cambodia, it is a time of extraordinary change in the world. Rooted positions are yielding to the logic of history. Might that begin to happen soon in the country that has for so long stood out against change, South Africa?

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: JOHN P. KOSTER JR.;
A Theory on 'Scientific' Atheism
description: LEAD: ''THE ATHEIST SYNDROME,'' a soon-to-be-published book by John P. Koster Jr., offers the theory that ''scientific'' atheism - which he says is ''the use of scientific method to attack religious beliefs as impossible or absurd'' - is a form of mental illness.

title: THAT OLD TIME RELIGION
description: LADY OF THE BEASTS Ancient Images of the Goddess and Her Sacred Animals. By Buffie Johnson. Illustrated. 386 pp. San Francisco: Harper & Row. $34.95.

title: Irish Call 'First Lady' A Grand One Indeed
description: The first year Dorothy Hayden Cudahy asked for the job, the Irishmen said an Irishwoman could not even enter the race. In the second, third and fourth years, they allowed her to run, but a man defeated her each time.

title: Chefs Imparting Their Secrets
description: LEAD: ONE recent Saturday morning several business executives, a high school French teacher and a handful of retirees were among those who looked on intently as Vince Scully, clad in chef's whites, deftly demonstrated the boning of a duck.

title: TOUGH TALK FOR DEMOCRATS
description: Joseph Califano said a lot of things that I, as a lifelong Democrat, did not want to hear. But I believe his diagnosis is accurate and that full recovery is possible only if the patient has the courage, the determination and the discipline to take the medicine he has prescribed. WILLIAM H. CROOK Former United States Ambassador to Australia San Marcos, Tex.

title: Fighting Scofflaws With Paper Power
description: FINES and tow-away threats hardly faze illegal parkers in New York City. But a garish, gooey piece of paper is making them pay attention, the Sanitation Department says.

title: The 60's Reinvented: Only the Beat Goes On
description: When CBS's sitcom heroine Murphy Brown, a star television journalist in her early 40's, first meets her new, 25-year-old executive producer, she doesn't ask him about his news experience or format plans. She simply demands, ''Do you know who the Shirelles are?''

title: POSTINGS: What Price Parking?; A 2d Garage Condo
description: Brooklyn is getting its second condominium parking garage, this one in the Cobble Hill neighborhood. A development group has bought a 50-year-old, three-story factory at 187 Pacific Street between Court and Clinton Streets and converted it into 130 condominium parking spaces priced at $27,500, $30,000 and $40,000, depending upon size - an average of about $262 a square foot. Nicholas Guzzone, a partner in the development, known as The Parking Club, said 24 units have been sold. He said the garage, which is park and lock, will be attended 24 hours a day. As an added sales inducement, Mr. Guzzone noted that the monthly maintenance fee, $115, includes 24-hour limousine transportation to and from the garage for owners living within a mile and a half of it, a radius that would encompass parts of Brooklyn Heights and Carroll Gardens. The project is only the second condominium garage accepted by the New York State Attorney General; the first, with 145 spaces, opened three years ago at 841 Union Street in the Park Slope neighborhood.

title: POSTINGS: $11 Million Apartment House; A High Riser On 86th Street
description: An 18-story apartment house is rising on the north side of 86th Street near Second Avenue on the site of a cluster of Yorkville row houses, some part of the Rhinelander development of a century ago. When erected in the 1880's there were six buildings with the addresses 237-247 East 86th Street, but the structures had been modified considerably over the years before their demolition last year. The Rhinelander family accumulated large tracts of land on the Upper East Side near their summer house close to Gracie Mansion, subdivided the acquisitions and developed them into row houses and apartment houses, mainly in Yorkville.

title: PARTY IN HUNGARY SIGNALS A DIVISION
description: An unscheduled meeting of the Communist Party's Central Committee has been called for next week following serious public disagreement among the party's top three leaders.

title: In a Rebellious Mood Over the Tax Burden
description: THE Long Island tax structure clearly reflects the overlayered Long Island governmental structure, a lack of foresight and an unfortunate loss for our children.

title: Lebanese Papers See Hostage Releases Soon
description: Several Lebanese publications predicted today that some foreign hostages held in Lebanon will soon be released. One magazine said two of the nine missing Americans will be freed.

title: Peru Says It Holds a Rebel Leader
description: A leading Peruvian guerrilla was being questioned at the police headquarters today, and President Alan Garcia described the arrest as a decisive blow against the rebel insurgency that has created widespread violence in Peru.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our clapboard garage is built on a cement-block foundation and is on sloping ground. On one side, the bottom row of clapboards is one foot above ground level, but on the other side the bottom row is nine inches below grade. This is one foot from our neighbor's property line, so it is impossible to regrade the soil. I have dug a foot-wide trench to the level of the cement blocks and am considering filling the trench with rocks to keep soil out. The other option is to fill the trench with cement. What is the best way to do this, short of raising the foundation?

title: SOVIETS NEGOTIATE TO AVERT VIOLENCE IN AFGHAN PULLOUT
description: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, arrived here early today for last-minute negotiations with Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto and other Pakistani officials in an effort to avert political chaos and violence in Afghanistan once the Soviet withdrawal is completed.

title: U.S. Takes Wait-and-See Stand on Paraguay
description: State Department officials today reiterated their hope that the new military regime in Paraguay would fulfill its vow to institute a more democratic government.

title: Prague Spring
description: THE UNBEARABLE LIGHTNESS OF BEING Starring Daniel Day-Lewis (in photo), Juliette Binoche (in photo), Lena Olin, Derek de Lint, Erland Josephson, Pavel Landovsky, Donald Moffat. Directed by Philip Kaufman. 1988. Orion Home Video. 172 minutes. $89.98. Closed captioned. Rated R.

title: A Gift of Carvings, A Show of Prints
description: A GIFT bestowed on Montclair State College in 1986 is currently the subject of an exhibition in the college's art gallery. It is a small selection of African and Oceanic wood carvings that come from a collection assembled by Paul Wingert, who died in 1974, and his wife, Emily.

title: Ex-Jamaican Leader Is Front-Runner in Poll
description: In a few days, Michael N. Manley, who challenged United States policies in the 1970's and tried to bring democratic socialism to Jamaica, expects to once again become Prime Minister.

title: Travel Is Safer, and Federal Rulemakers Take Credit
description: TRAVELERS today have many specific worries:

title: Budget Conjecture Widening Tensions
description: FOR weeks, the General Assembly and its tag-along army of lobbyists have trudged through the fog of pre-budget uncertainty, straining for a landmark or a sign that could reveal the outlines of the budget Gov. William A. O'Neill will propose this week.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE YEAR OF SILENCE, by Madison Smartt Bell. (Penguin, $6.95.) In the author's fourth novel about depressed esthetes living in the cracks of New York's crumbling underside, an illustrator named Marian kills herself with a drug overdose. In 1987 our reviewer, Roberta Silman, said Madison Smartt Bell has ''an uncanny understanding of the way many people must struggle to live.'' THE PAPER: The Life and Death of the New York Herald Tribune, by Richard Kluger with the assistance of Phyllis Kluger. (Vintage, $16.95.) Incorporating Horace Greeley's New York Tribune and James Gordon Bennett's New York Herald, The New York Herald Tribune earned a reputation as a newspaper that took stylish writing as seriously as good journalism. Tom Wolfe and Jimmy Breslin got their starts at New York magazine, which was once part of the paper's Sunday fare. Richard Kluger, who edited The Herald Tribune's Sunday book section in the 1960's, has told the story of the ill-fated newspaper, which died in 1966, with ''a narrative sweep that is always absorbing and sometimes breathtaking,'' The Times's Christopher Lehmann-Haupt said in 1986. EMPEROR OF THE AIR, by Ethan Canin. (Perennial/ Harper & Row, $7.95.) In the title piece of this collection of short stories, a high school astronomy teacher's campaign to save an old elm tree threatens to erupt into a neighborhood war. Though some of the stories are excessively artful, David Leavitt said here last year, ''one comes away from reading the best of them with the refreshing sense of having encountered a writer earnestly devoted to his craft.'' MONEY AND CLASS IN AMERICA: Notes and Observations on the Civil Religion, by Lewis H. Lapham. (Ballantine, $4.95.) Whether they inherit their fortune or accumulate it on their own, millionaires are an unsavory lot, Lewis H. Lapham claims, doing little to sustain the ''architecture of civilization.'' Writing last year in The Book Review, Andrew Hacker said this polemic is ''acerbic in tone; hyperbolic when not hit-and-run; withal, an amusing and provocative tract.'' WOODCUTTERS, by Thomas Bernhard. Translated by David McLintock. (University of Chicago, $10.95.) Having escaped an interminable dinner party with the most obnoxious of culturati, a writer takes revenge with this fictional diatribe on the pretensions of Vienna's artistic circles. Last year our reviewer, Mark Anderson, called the novel ''an unusually intense, engrossing literary experience.'' BUDDY BOYS: When Good Cops Turn Bad, by Mike McAlary. (Charter, $4.95.) Until 1986, when the scandal was uncovered, an alarming amount of the crime in Brooklyn's Bedford-Stuyvesant section was committed by the police. This book was constructed from interviews with the offenders, and ''the voices . . . are pure cop,'' Edna Buchanan said here last year. The book is ''searing, outrageous and painful. . . . Contrite and regretful, the Buddy Boys tell their sorrowful stories, but it seems that what they regret most of all is getting caught.'' PAST CONTINUOUS, by Yaakov Shabtai. Translated by Dalya Bilu. (Schocken, $11.95.) Nine months after the death of his father, an Israeli intellectual commits suicide. Densely woven from the stories of three friends in Tel Aviv, this novel is ''a long, complex, ambitious work of literature,'' Alan Lelchuk said here in 1985. It is ''part elegy, part etiology, with a music all its own.'' TALKING TOMBSTONES: And Other Tales of the Media Age, by Gary Gumpert. (Oxford University, $7.95.) When these essays on the sociological effects of the electronic media were published in 1987, our reviewer, Neil Postman, compared the author to Marshall McLuhan. The book, he said, ''is well written; it has the stamp of a distinctive personality; and it is filled with the only kinds of sentences that generate thought about the familiar - strange and open-ended questions.'' THE COUNTRY-HOUSE BURGLAR, by Michael Gilbert. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $4.95.) After a mysterious explosion rocks a quiet English village, Liz Artside sets out to find the culprit and to exonerate her son. ''The author has invented one of the most ingenious methods of setting fire to a house, not to mention its occupants, that you are likely to encounter,'' one reviewer said in 1955. Harper & Row has also reissued the author's novel CLOSE QUARTERS ($4.95). First published in 1947, it tells how a young Scotland Yard detective spends his holiday investigating strange goings-on at a cathedral where his uncle is dean. MEDICINE, MIND, AND THE DOUBLE BRAIN: A Study in Nineteenth-Century Thought, by Anne Harrington. (Princeton University, $12.95.) While the right brain is now the cerebral hemisphere of choice, it was once considered the seat of criminality and madness. In 1987 our reviewer, Elaine Showalter, said this book ''casts cold light . . . on the perennially fascinating process by which science, despite all its pretenses to objectivity and truth, reflects individual, cultural and philosophical prejudices.'' VOYAGER, by Jeana Yeager and Dick Rutan with Phil Patton. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) Working with a freelance crew of independent aeronautical designers, Jeana Yeager and Dick Rutan in 1986 became the first people to fly around the world on a single tank of gas. Their book ''gives the reader a good sense of who they are and why they were the right ones for this monumental undertaking,'' Michael Collins said here in 1987.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Comrade Deng Xiaoping believes that the main objective of the meeting is the following: to close the page on the past and open up the chapter on the future. His vivid thought also expresses what the Soviet leadership would like to do.'' - Eduard A. Shevardnadze, on a summit meeting with China. [ 1:5. ]

title: FOCUS: San Francisco; 20-Year Rehabilitation About to Bear Fruit
description: THE first of what are to be 11 buildings in a mixed-use complex that has been more than 20 years in the making is expected to have its first tenants by April 1.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: SPIRITUAL CONCERT The Harlem Spiritual Ensemble will focus on authenticity when it presents a concert next Sunday afternoon at the Williams Center in Rutherford, performing such favorites as ''Swing Low, Sweet Chariot'' and ''Go Tell It on the Mountain.''

title: Drink Deep, We'll Dance
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Seaman Engaged To Eric M. Schwartz
description: Diane Ellen Seaman and Eric Mark Schwartz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert R. Schwartz of Riverdale, the Bronx, plan to marry in March, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Burton S. Seaman of Lake Success, L.I., have announced.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our clapboard garage is built on a cement-block foundation and is on sloping ground. On one side, the bottom row of clapboards is one foot above ground level, but on the other side the bottom row is nine inches below grade. This is one foot from our neighbor's property line, so it is impossible to regrade the soil. I have dug a foot-wide trench to the level of the cement blocks and am considering filling the trench with rocks to keep soil out. The other option is to fill the trench with cement. What is the best way to do this, short of raising the foundation?

title: Review/Music; Recent Works for Flute
description: The Bowery Ensemble devoted most of its Tuesday evening concert at Cooper Union to new or recent music for the flute, played by Barbara Held. But as it turned out, the most striking work on the program was the only one not written for the flute, Bun-Ching Lam's ''After Spring,'' for two pianos.

title: EUROPEAN REPORT: MILAN, LONDON AND MADRID
description: In the short film that accompanied his most recent show of women's fashions, Franco Moschino, Italy's self-appointed gadfly of the runways, publicly tweaked the establishment by declaring fashion ''full of chic.'' Moments earlier, the designer had cheerfully lampooned the existing order, trotting out onto the catwalk such affronts to good taste as a tight-fitting low-cut evening dress festooned with metallicized lampshade fringe.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
The Commercial Market's Marking Time
description: LEAD: THE outlook for Long Island's commercial market this year is for moderate growth, with demand for space coming mostly from companies that already have a local presence rather than from outside corporations considering a relocation.

title: Eighth Avenue
description: To the Editor:

title: BRING ON THE ENTITLEMENTS
description: THE MODERN SOCIAL CONFLICT An Essay on the Politics of Liberty. By Ralf Dahrendorf. 219 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $17.95.

title: A Marble-Clad Museum With Box-Office Power
description: In some ways it seems not a decade but a lifetime since the East Building of the National Gallery of Art opened, so entrenched has this building become in the cultural life of the nation. I. M. Pei's crisp, hard-edged palace of pink Tennessee marble, its central atrium a glass-roofed space enlivened by a vast Calder mobile, has proved one of the great architectural draws of modern times. The crowds lined up on the day of the East Building's opening in mid-1978, and more than 10 years later they have not stopped coming.

title: Halpin Responds on Tax Increases
description: The article, ''In Election Year, Tax Rise At Issue'' (Jan 15) concerning property tax increases in Suffolk raises two questions: Could a large county property tax inrease have been avoided? Who is responsible for the one now facing homeowners? Yes, large property tax increases could have been avoiced. Suffolk's property taxes, from all levels of government, are entirely too high. Also, the property tax system is outdated, unfair and probably illegal in many areas.

title: Ann S. Watson to Wed J. C. Lipham
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank A. Allen 3d of New York and Nonquitt, Mass., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Allen's daughter, Ann Standish Watson, to Joseph Carlton Lipham, a son of Wilma K. Rowe of Atlanta and the late Glynn E. Lipham. A June wedding is planned.

title: Cathleen ni Houlihan, at Last
description: Since 1985, Dorothy Hayden Cudahy has wanted to be grand marshal of the St. Patrick's Day parade for the very good reason that she thinks the honor should go to the most qualified person.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our clapboard garage is built on a cement-block foundation and is on sloping ground. On one side, the bottom row of clapboards is one foot above ground level, but on the other side the bottom row is nine inches below grade. This is one foot from our neighbor's property line, so it is impossible to regrade the soil. I have dug a foot-wide trench to the level of the cement blocks and am considering filling the trench with rocks to keep soil out. The other option is to fill the trench with cement. What is the best way to do this, short of raising the foundation?

title: CONTAGION AND THE CONSTITUTION
description: PRIVATE ACTS, SOCIAL CONSEQUENCES AIDS and the Politics of Public Health. By Ronald Bayer. 282 pp. New York: The Free Press. $22.95.

title: AMORALITY ON THE RAMPAGE
description: THE HUNGRY GIRLS And Other Stories. By Patricia Eakins. Illustrated. 137 pp. San Francisco: Cadmus Editions. Paper, $8.95.

title: The Baby Market
description: 'We came to believe that an illegal underground ''black market'' may exist in New York in the private placement of children for adoption.' - A Manhattan grand jury reporting on its investigation into how Joel B. Steinberg obtained Lisa, the child he was convicted of killing.

title: DATA BANK: January 29, 1989
As Europe Crumbled
description: GRAND ILLUSION Starring Jean Gabin, Pierre Fresnay and Eric von Stroheim. Directed by Jean Renoir. 1937. Connoisseur Video Collection. 111 minutes. $59.95.

title: Medicare Law: Disaster for Elderly
description: The article on Medicare catastrophic coverage (Jan 15) indicates the disaster that this legislation portends for the elderly. On Long Island, where costs are high and more income is required to live, many more seniors than given will have to pay the maximum premium and tax of $3,125 pr couple in 1993. Unfortunately, they will get little or no additonal coverage for this, depending upon their prsent employment pension or medigap coverage.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: WOMEN ARTISTS, WOMEN EXILES: ''Miss Grief'' and Other Stories. By Constance Fenimore Woolson. Edited by Joan Myers Weimer. (Rutgers University, Cloth, $42; Paper, $15). Although she was the grandniece of James Fenimore Cooper, an intimate friend of Henry James and a respected writer of her day, Constance Fenimore Woolson (1840-1894) has not fared well with posterity.

title: AFTER THE COLD WAR
description: IS THE COLD WAR OVER? AND, IF SO, what does this mean for American policy toward the Soviet Union?

title: Marion Sinwell Weds R. L. DeGroff Jr.
description: The wedding of Marion Parsons Sinwell to Ralph Lynn DeGroff Jr. took place yesterday at the Dickey Memorial Presbyterian Church in Baltimore. The Rev. Thomas G. Speers 3d performed the ceremony.

title: Classes Resume at Academy Where Regimen Proved Fatal
description: Classes resumed today at the police academy where one cadet died and 16 others become ill after a strenuous workout last fall.

title: HEALTH CARE'S HIGH COST
description: The article, ''Taking a Scalpel to Health Care Costs'' (Jan. 8) prompted an unusually strong response from readers. Some of their comments follow. To the Editor:

title: Message: Girls Are At Home in Hi Tech
description: I read the article, ''Technology Is the Generation Gap's Great Divide'' by Joyce Ship Zaritsky in the Westchester Weekly [ Opinion Page, Jan. 1 ] and was deeply insulted. I am a 15-year-old girl who believes that female teen-agers have at least as much technological ability as male teen-agers.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE LONG WHITE. By Sharon Dilworth. (University of Iowa, $17.95.) In ''Mad Dog Queen,'' perhaps the best story in this collection by the winner of the 1988 Iowa Short Fiction Award, a woman named Beth suddenly tells her boyfriend, Jim, that he must accompany her when she defends her title as the wine-drinking champion at a winter carnival.

title: Review/Theater; A 'Henry IV' Triangle With Working-Class Angst
description: In ''Henry Lumper,'' Israel Horovitz's working-class Massachusetts version of ''Henry IV, Part 1 and Part 2,'' Hal and Hotspur (Harry Percy) were high school classmates. Hal, a star quarterback, fell in love with a pretty cheerleader, who later married Harry. This makes the Hal-Hotspur feud a triangle as well as a duel to the death.

title: THE REGION: A Warm Economy; New York Is About to Find Out What Happens After a Boom
description: TRUE to predictions, 1988 marked the abrupt end of Wall Street's boom. But it also showed that the metropolitan region's six-year economic recovery still has some steam, especially outside Manhattan. Jobs are still being produced, though much more slowly than in the past, and economists expect growth to continue in 1989, though they are not sure for how long.

title:
GARDENING;
An Early Start Leads to Harvests
description: LEAD: A few years ago, when five rainy weekends delayed early planting, my spring garden was less than successful. All the hardy plants were planted too late to benefit from the rainfall and cool weather of early spring.

title: INSIDE
description: Brazil Yields on the Amazon

title: Getting Around
description: As she often does on royal tours, the Princess of Wales mingled with high society and society's less fortunate on her three-day trip to New York last week to promote British products and the Welsh National Opera. There was the glitter of the opera at the Brooklyn Academy of Music and an elegant charity dinner at the Winter Garden of the World Financial Center. But at the other extreme of the city's spectrum, Diana visited a day-care center and chatted at the Henry Street Settlement on the Lower East Side with seven women who had been homeless. She also toured the pediatric AIDS unit at Harlem Hospital, where she picked up and hugged a 7-year-old boy who has the disease. The visit, said Dr. Margaret Heagarty, the hospital's pediatrics director, showed that ''folks with this disease can be hugged, can be cared for.''

title: Landfill Linked to Cases of Leukemia and Low Birth Weight
description: People living close to the nation's No. 1 Superfund toxic-waste cleanup site, the closed Lipari landfill, were more likely to contract adult leukemia or produce babies with low birth weights than people beyond one kilometer, a state study has concluded.

title: TOUGH TALK FOR DEMOCRATS
description: Beyond recommending changes in old programs, such as affirmative action and school busing, which have achieved more success than he seems willing to admit, Joseph Califano offers Democrats a strange prescription for winning the Presidency: in effect, become Republicans. RUTH MANSBERG Pound Ridge, N.Y.

title: Rodriguez Honored
description: He may not have been the biggest money winner during his 25 years on the PGA Tour, but few golfers of his generation attracted as many devoted followers as Chi Chi Rodriguez. Now, at the age of 53, Rodriguez has become a big money man on the Senior Tour and has received some high-level recognition, too. At the United States Golf Association's annual meeting in New Orleans yesterday, he received the 1989 Bob Jones Award as golf's man of the year.

title:
DINING OUT;
A Lively Steakhouse in Edgewater
description: LEAD: THE River Palm Terrace in Edgewater has gained a loyal enough following in the five and a half years since it opened that even with a reservation, it is frequently necessary to wait in line for a table. In fact, on weekends there can be a considerable wait just to check coats.

title: A Mac That Hears Its Master's Voice
description: The executive stands at the front of the meeting room. ''Regional sales,'' she says, and a spreadsheet appears on the projection screen. When she says ''bar chart'' the numbers are replaced with a graphical representation that resembles the Manhattan skyline.

title: THE NATION: In Federal Departments; Are Judge and Agency Too Close for Justice?
description: WHEN a corporation or a private citizen disputes a Federal agency's decision - involving, say, a disability pension or an allegation of unfair labor practices - an administrative law judge decides who is right. But more and more, critics are raising questions about the atmosphere in which these decisions are rendered, given that one party in every case is the agency that employs the judge.

title: LEFT BEHIND AT THE FORGE
description: SPARROWS POINT Making Steel - The Rise and Ruin of American Industrial Might. By Mark Reutter. 494 pp. New York: Summit Books. $24.95. AND THE WOLF FINALLY CAME The Decline of the American Steel Industry. By John P. Hoerr. Illustrated. 689 pp. Pennsylvania: University of Pittsburgh Press. Cloth, $39.95. Paper, $14.95.

title:
Westchester Q&A;: Gary G. Brokaw;
Iona Coach Criticizes Proposition 42
description: LEAD: GEORGETOWN UNIVERSITY'S basketball coach, John Thompson, garnered headlines last month when he walked off the basketball court during a game to protest a decision by the National Collegiate Athletic Association on basketball scholarships.

title: Some Jews Favor Easing Soviet Trade Curbs
description: Some Jewish organizations are moving toward the conclusion that the United States should recognize the big increase in Jewish emigration from the Soviet Union in 1988 by removing some of the trade and tariff barriers imposed on Moscow in the last 15 years.

title: Reviews/Music; Mahler, Shostavkovich and Ashkenazy
description: Both pieces on Friday's program by the Royal Philharmonic at Carnegie Hall belong to the 20th century, though the Mahler Fourth Symphony just barely. The newer of the two was the Shostakovich First, written some 25 years after the Mahler and played for the first time in 1926.

title: SOUTHERN GOTHIC
description: LEAD: PASSION AND PREJUDICE A Family Memoir. By Sallie Bingham. Illustrated. 525 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $22.95.

title: Solving Toilet Problems
description: AS mysterious as they may seem sometimes, toilets function rather simply. Most problems can be diagnosed and remedied easily.

title: Christian Louis Dyer Plans to Marry Leila Gordon, a Bank Officer, in May
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph K. Gordon of Haverford, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter Leila Gordon to Christian Louis Dyer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. R. Richard Dyer of Haverford. The couple plan to marry in May.

title: Moynihan Criticizes Delay in Building Courts
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan complained today that plans to build new Federal courtrooms in Manhattan were moving too slowly and that the city's war on drugs was sure to suffer as a result.

title: HER SOUL WOULD NOT BE STILL
description: LEAD: THE BRONTES Charlotte Bronte and Her Family. By Rebecca Fraser. Illustrated. 543 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $25.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: ''PAUL ROBESON'' by Martin Bauml Duberman (Knopf, New York, $24.95) is a passionate, tantalizing book. Approach its 803 pages carefully; it returns the reader to yesterday's headlines, relentlessly opening and probing old wounds to pursue the larger-than-life story of one of the most significant black figures in American history.

title: Cornelia J. Reeder to Wed
description: The engagement of Cornelia Jane Reeder to William Taylor Mitchell, a son of Mrs. Frank Wells of Bedford, N.Y., and Donald Mitchell of Lakeville, Conn., has been announced by Cornelia Wales Reeder of Hopewell and Mantoloking, N.J., mother of the bride-to-be. Ms. Reeder, also a daughter of the late John Merrick Reeder, is the retail advertising representative at Vogue magazine in New York. Her fiance is an account executive at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company in New York. The couple plan to marry in May.

title: Blacks and The Box Office
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Human Values' Are Fine, But Don't Forget Proficiency
description: ONE RECENT MORNING, somewhere on Long Island:

title: They Were Clean And Neat but They Didn't Smile Much
description: Abby Aldrich Rockefeller's American folk art collection - the first ever presented in a comprehensive museum exhibition when it was shown at the Museum of Modern Art in 1932 - is back in Manhattan, part of the collection at least, installed at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

title: Braves' Hall Loses
description: When Glenn Wong, the arbitrator, awarded Albert Hall a $250,000 salary yesterday instead of the $310,000 the player had bid for, Hall became the second player and the second Atlanta Brave outfielder to lose in salary arbitration this winter. Hall had the same salary last year. Dion James, the other Brave, is the only other player whose case has been decided in arbitration. Two players settled their cases yesterday. Mark Gubicza, the Kansas City pitcher, more than doubled his 1988 salary of $635,000, accepting $1,375,000. Scott Bradley of Seattle negotiated a $290,000 salary.

title: U.S. Takes Doubles And Moves Ahead
description: Focusing on expertise rather than emotion, the doubles team of Bob Seguso and Ken Flach clinched a Davis Cup round for the United States today by beating Victor Pecci and Francisco Gonzalez of Paraguay, 6-1, 6-3, 6-4.

title: Edward L. Mabry, Executive, 91
description: Edward L. Mabry, retired chief executive of the Vick Chemical Company, died Wednesday at his house in Litchfield, Conn. He was 91 years old.

title: Multiple Listing
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Cities' Duel for Air Is Deflated by Judges
description: The City of Winooski has been denied the right to tax neighboring Burlington for using the air over Winooski.

title: Mary V. Powers To Marry in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. William T. Powers Jr. of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Virginia Powers to Andrew Francis Gallivan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Xavier Gallivan of Newburgh, N.Y.

title: Is January The Cruelest Month?
description: My idea of movie hell is a place where the floors stick, the sound is half a second out of sync, the person behind me repeats every punchline to his companion and the only films to be seen are the kind that get released in January. It's well known that January films have a character that is, let us say, distinctive. That isn't to call them the year's worst - though many January films certainly have tendencies in that direction - but merely to point out how peculiar they can be. January is to film releasing roughly what the Bermuda Triangle is to navigation.

title: GEORGIA ON MY MIND
description: Sunday,'' said our interpreter, ''we are going to a feast at a friend's home in Tbilisi.''

title: That German Accent in American Modern Dance
description: The German strain of contemporary dance as it has manifested itself in the United States is usually overlooked if not unacknowledged. There is general agreement that modern dance, a 20th-century phenomenon, has been dominated by Americans. But it is also true that between the World Wars, Germany was a major center in the growth of the free dance, as the creative form outside the ballet tradition was formerly called. The influence of the German school's disciples who emigrated to the United States has yet to be systematically explored.

title: Incurable Suburban Disease: The Home Party Syndrome
description: I CAN'T seem to shake loose the Home Party Syndrome. It's an incurable suburban disease and we all know the symptoms: a big heart, pocketbook, telephone, friends.

title: Q and A
description: Moving Expenses

title: Shirai Recital Postponed
description: A recital by the mezzo-soprano Mitsuko Shirai, scheduled for 5:30 P.M. today at Alice Tully Hall, has been postponed because the singer is ill. The recital will take place on May 10 at 8 P.M. All tickets will be honored on that date. Information: 362-1911.

title: Butter Sculptures
description: For the next month, visitors to the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West and 79th Street, will be able to see eight Tibetan monks from the Gyuto Tantric Monastery create more than 25 pastel-colored butter sculptures. The sculptures, or the 15 Chupas, which are part of Buddhist ritual, will be on view for two to three weeks after their completion in late February. Demonstrations will be Tuesday through Sunday, 10:30 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission is $3.50 for adults and $1.50 for children. Information: 769-5305.

title:
GARDENING;
Gardening Near the Shore Is Different
description: LEAD: NEAR the shore, gardening can differ from that inland. The size and nature of the water and its relation to the property play a large role.

title: Patterson Resigns
description: The Arizona State basketball coach, Steve Patterson, resigned yesterday, just one hour before the Sun Devils were to play at home against California in a Pacific-10 Conference game.

title: 200 Soviet Muslims Protest For More Religious Freedom
description: More than 200 Soviet Muslims marched from a mosque through the Uzbek capital of Tashkent to press the Government to take up their religious demands, Tass reported today.

title: CANDIENS STEAL LAFLEUR'S LIMELIGHT
description: Guy Lafleur was as graceful and productive as ever in his first game on Montreal ice since the Canadiens eased him into what turned out to be a premature retirement in 1984.

title: HISPID MISANTHROPE GROWS UP
description: WALLACE STEVENS The Later Years, 1923-1955. By Joan Richardson. Illustrated. 462 pp. New York: Beech Tree Books/William Morrow & Company. $27.95.

title: Friendlier Skies for Fassengers and Fuel Savings for Planes
description: Several companies have developed systems to bring real-time weather data from the Government's weather satellite to airlines.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Bankruptcy Puts Ship Line On the Beach

title: Fun Is a Checkpoint Away for Beirut Revelers
description: Despite frequent street battles, many Syrian checkpoints and power cuts, the resilient nightlife of Beirut is still in full swing.

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.
description: LOOK at it this way: there are an unlimited number of dire possibilities. What if a terrible snowstorm closes up the city? What if the supermarket is jampacked and the checkout line stretches to infinity? What if whatever you want is out of stock? What if you have an irresistible urge for soup at 2 A.M. and there isn't a can in sight? What if friends pop in and you haven't so much as a peanut to feed them?

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Add Real Human Suffering to Abortion Debate; A Table in a Dirty Room

title: THE GUNS OF SLAVADOR
description: STILL HAGGARD AND GAUNT FROM his time in the mountains of El Salvador, the guerrilla official put a recording of a Haydn symphony on the stereo and sat down to talk. It was his 13th year of fighting to overthrow his country's government. As Haydn's reassuring tones filled the room, the rebel visibly relaxed, safe now in a nearby country outside El Salvador. But he stiffened when he leaned forward to speak.

title: Add Real Human Suffering to Abortion Debate; Not Civil Disobedience
description: To the Editor:

title: Pledge to Flag In Massachusetts
description: MUCH was made in last year's Presidential campaign about Gov. Michael S. Dukakis's veto of a Massachusetts law to require public school pupils to recite the Pledge of Allegiance each school day. What effect did the sound and fury have on school policy in Massachusetts?

title: GANGS, SUPERGANGS AND KIDS ON THE CORNER
description: PEOPLE AND FOLKS Gangs, Crime and the Underclass in a Rustbelt City. By John Hagedorn with Perry Macon. Illustrated. 237 pp. Chicago: Lake View Press. Cloth, $29.95. Paper, $10.95.

title: STREETSCAPES: St. Michael's Episcopal Church; Restoration, and Perhaps A Striking Tiffany-Style Finish
description: ST. MICHAEL'S EPISCOPAL CHURCH, at the northwest corner of Amsterdam Avenue at 99th Street, was built in 1891 with an unusual exterior and interior. Its Tiffany chancel and windows, for which it has long been famous, are now being restored.

title: A Memorable Ride
description: MR. BRADLEY, MY neighbor from across the hall, offered me a ride to work the other day. Not a remarkable occurrence in itself: I'm sure people all over the country are offered rides to work every day. But this is New York City. Not only do people not offer you rides; most of them don't even own cars. Mr. Bradley does; I had often seen him parking it on our block, a big dark sedan out of another era.

title: On That Good Montana Powder
description: A SMALL group of skiers had gathered in the Snowgoose Grille at the base of Big Mountain. It was the end of a full day of powder skiing on the alpine slopes of Whitefish, a small town in northwest Montana. The halogen lights of nighttime skiing shed an amber glow across the lower reaches of Hibernation, a favorite intermediate run.

title: A LA CARTE
description: AMERICANS have an insatiable sweet tooth. Recent surveys show that we are a two-faced nation.

title: WHAT LITTLE GIRLS ARE MADE OF
description: CAT'S EYE By Margaret Atwood. 446 pp. New York: Doubleday. $18.95.

title: NONFICTION
description: EGYPT AFTER NASSER: Sadat, Peace and the Mirage of Prosperity. By Thomas W. Lippman. (Paragon House, $22.95.) Drawing on his years as The Washington Post's resident correspondent in Anwar el-Sadat's Cairo, Thomas W. Lippman provides a dyspeptic survey of the failure of Egypt's political leadership to meet the growing needs of the country over the last 20 years. Rambling and occasionally repetitive, ''Egypt After Nasser'' makes abundantly clear his unfavorable assessment of much of Egyptian life, from the prevalence of slovenly work habits and appalling sanitation to pervasive economic mismanagement, political corruption and religious intolerance. Mr. Lippman shares the inclination of many Egyptians to lay the blame for the country's woes at the feet of its political leaders. He suggests that, for all his good intentions, Gamal Abdel Nasser ran the country into the ground with his socialist fervor. Similarly, Mr. Lippman believes, despite his best efforts, Sadat was too lazy, theatrical and out of touch with Egyptian realities to seize the economic opportunities presented by the oil boom and the collapse of Beirut during the 1970's. Finally, Hosni Mubarak, Sadat's successor, is once again well-meaning, but too unimaginative and plodding to meet the challenge of staggering population growth. Filled with useful facts and figures and lots of the humorous anecdotes Egyptians like to tell about themselves, ''Egypt After Nasser'' is both informative and very funny in places. It might be a good book for a dedicated devotee of current affairs to take along on a Nile cruise; it would make a knowledgeable, if cranky, traveling companion.

title: A Sliver of Unpaved Florida
description: IN southwest Florida the residents joke that the state bird is neither the flamingo nor the egret but the construction crane, and visitors can sometimes feel that it is a challenge to find an attractive stretch of beach before it is paved over.

title: Kentucky Accepts Fault
description: The University of Kentucky, in responding to National Collegiate Athletic Association allegations against its basketball program, will accept responsibility for a package of money said to have been sent to the father of a recruit, The Lexington Herald-Leader reported today.

title: Add Real Human Suffering to Abortion Debate; When Is Fetus Human?
description: To the Editor:

title: Little Is Certain in Scramble for Free Agents
description: The National Football League's new system of free agency, which gave more than 600 players the right to negotiate with other teams until April 1, left all 28 teams' scouting departments scurrying for statistics, charts and details as if they were doing homework for the college draft.

title: Job Program for Retarded Fills a Need
description: LEAD: FRED COSCIA, owner of the S&L; Deli here, was skeptical when the Young Adult Institute asked him to hire one of its clients. The institute, a Manhattan-based agency with a Westchester branch on Court Street, just around the corner from the delicatessen, serves people who are mildly to profoundly mentally retarded.

title: Dinosaur Lover's Unending Quest
description: LEAD: BY his own admission, Robert K. Denton Jr. was a difficult child. For example, he didn't like to eat.

title: New Tides In Latin America
description: The grand inaugural get-together is a new Latin American tradition, a way of celebrating yet another peaceful and democratic transfer of power. It is now the seventh time in a row for Venezuela, but last week's gathering for the swearing in of President Carlos Andres Perez was something special.

title: Peaks and Valleys in Papp's Marathon
description: When it comes to amassing culture, Americans like to collect the complete set. This is the impulse that leads us to sign up for the Book-of-the-Month Club when it offers every last volume of Will and Ariel Durant, or to dial an 800 number when Vincent Price beckons us from the depths of cable television to purchase recordings of all the world's great music on the installment plan. So it was no surprise that the public rushed to enlist in Joseph Papp's Shakespeare Marathon, as announced in an ad in these pages in November 1987. ''For the first time in America, see all of Shakespeare!'' read the headline. ''All of William Shakespeare's 36 plays performed by most of America's finest actors!'' Charter subscribers were promised a free ''I've seen it all'' T-shirt, as well as a glass of celebratory champagne with Mr. Papp, when the marathon reaches completion at the Public Theater on Sept. 15, 1993.

title: Nicaragua Currency Tumbles And American Dollar Is King
description: A recent commercial for the state-run television company here has all the makings of a tear-jerker: a lonely evening, a grandmotherly caller, loved ones living abroad. But just as viewers pick up the phone to reach out and touch someone, the announcer adds a selfish suggestion: Don't pay for it yourself - call collect.

title: Terminology Tested
description: THERE has always been a trans-Atlantic difficulty, in bridge terms, about the meaning of protection. In Britain the word describes the act of reopening an auction that would be ended by a pass: The idea is to protect a partner who may have passed with a good hand.

title: Video/Hans Fantel; Videodisk Players Offer Double Value
description: The recent revival and current mini-boom of videodisks was sparked not only by the swift expansion of the disk repertory. The growing popularity of this hitherto neglected video medium owes a great deal to several excellent and versatile videodisk players by Yamaha, Sony and Pioneer. This radically updated playing equipment now makes videodisks attractive to a growing number of viewers eager for the utmost in picture quality.

title: Michelle Oaklan to Marry
description: Mrs. Marie Oaklan and Norman Oaklan, both of Buffalo, have announced April wedding plans for their daughter Michelle Oaklan and John Michael McFaul, a son of John McFaul of Watertown, N.Y., and the late Mary McFaul. Miss Oaklan, a graduate of the Rochester Institute of Technology, is the director of public relations at Loews Hotels in New York. Mr. McFaul, a partner in the law firm of Hatter, Donovan & McFaul in Lynbrook, L.I., graduated from the State University at New Paltz, N.Y., and received a J.D. degree from Brooklyn Law School.

title: The Way of All Flesh
description: BODIES are George Boykin's business. Just a few feet from his desk and his less-than-flourishing philodendron plant reside the remains of several dozen Long Islanders.

title: Question Of the Week; What Do The Mets Need to Add In 1989?
description: The answer to your question is: a ration of humility. S. E. BERGNER Edison, N.J.

title: Huge State Project to Aid Tennis Rattles Vermont
description: A proposal for a $15 million sports and arts complex in southern Vermont was a plan without a home this week as the state's government drew fire over its handling of the matter.

title: Knicks Struggle To Defeat Pacers
description: There is something about the Indiana Pacers that brings out the worst in the Knicks.

title: Benefit for Quake Victims
description: Mirella Freni, Placido Domingo, Aprile Millo, Elena Obraztsova, Samuel Ramey, Frederica von Stade, Paata Burchuladze, Mstislav Rostropovich, Vladimir Viardo, Alexander Toradze and other artists will perform in a benefit concert for the Soviet-Armenian Earthquake Relief Fund of the American Red Cross, Feb. 21 at 8 P.M. at Carnegie Hall. Loris Tjeknavorian will conduct members of the American Symphony Orchestra. Seats in the first tier and parquet at $1,000 and $250 may be ordered by calling 903-9650. Tickets at $60, $45, $30 and $15 are available at the box office or through Carnegie Charge: 247-7800.

A Colombian poet's perdurable love for a woman is tested by life's changing conditions. 14 14 16 ANYTHING FOR BILLY, by Larry McMurtry. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) The exploits of Billy the Kid, as shared by a dime-novel writer. 15 13 32 ALASKA, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $22.50.) The history of the 49th state told in fictional form. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction 1 1 14 ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert Fulghum. (Villard, $15.95.) Inspirational essays about everyday matters. 2 8 2 BLIND FAITH, by Joe McGinniss. (Putnam, $21.95.) The family tragedy that came to light after the 1984 murder of a Toms River, N.J., woman. 3 2 42 A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking. (Bantam, $18.95.) A scientist reviews efforts to create a unified theory of the universe. 4 3 12 GRACIE, by George Burns. (Putnam, $16.95.) The life of the comedian Gracie Allen, recalled by her widower and show business partner. 5 5 16 THE LAST LION, by William Manchester. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) The second volume of a biography of Winston Churchill, covering the years 1932-40. 6 * 7 4 PARTING THE WATERS, by Taylor Branch. (Simon & Schuster, $24.95.) The rise of the American civil rights movement under the leadership of Martin Luther King Jr. 7 4 13 CHILD STAR, by Shirley Temple Black. (McGraw- Hill, $19.95.) The former actress's autobiography. 8 6 15 A BRIGHT SHINING LIE, by Neil Sheehan. (Random House, $24.95.) A biography of Lieut. Col. John Paul Vann that is also a history of American involvement in Vietnam. 9 9 17 THE FIRST SALUTE, by Barbara W. Tuchman. (Knopf, $22.95.) An expose of tall tales that have become part of our national heritage. 11 * 10 7 ''WHAT DO YOU> CARE WHAT OTHER PEOPLE THINK?'' by Richard P. Feynman with Ralph Leighton. (Norton, $17.95.) Memoirs of the Nobel Prize-winning physicist. 12 12 12 DON'T BEND OVER IN THE GARDEN, GRANNY, YOU KNOW THEM TATERS GOT EYES, by Lewis Grizzard. (Villard, $15.95.) Humor with a Southern accent. 13 11 15 GOLDWATER, by Barry M. Goldwater with Jack Casserly. (Doubleday, $21.95.) The memoirs of the longtime Senator from Arizona. 14 13 16 CHRONICLE OF THE 20TH CENTURY, edited by Clifton Daniel. (Chronicle Publications/Prentice Hall, $49.95.) (Harper & Row, $17.95.) How to lower your blood cholesterol level. 2 2 12 THE DICTIONARY OF CULTURAL LITERACY, by E. D. Hirsch Jr., Joseph F. Kett and James Trefil. (Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) An annotated list of ideas and facts ''Americans need to know.'' 3 3 2 WEALTH WITHOUT RISK, by Charles J. Givens. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) A Florida entrepreneur's advice about how to make a personal fortune. 4 165 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $16.95.) A standard reference work in a 1983 revision. 5 5 15 WEBSTER'S NEW WORLD DICTIONARY. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) The Third College Edition of a standard work, revised in 1988. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 28,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) FIVE SEASONS, by A. B. Yehoshua. (Doubleday, $19.95.) A best seller in Israel, where it was published in 1987, Mr. Yehoshua's vivid novel presents the love life of a good, sweet-tempered, dutiful civil servant whose wife has died just before the book begins. THE SATANIC VERSES, by Salman Rushdie. (Viking, $19.95.) Expatriation, exile, history and dreams mingle in this heady comic novel, which concerns two men from Bombay who, just for starters, fall out of an airliner and into England. HOW I GOT HIM BACK: Or, Under the Cold Moon's Shine, by Valerie Sayers. (Doubleday, $17.95.) Clear and forceful writing sustains this fine second novel, whose complex plot involves the marital tug-of-war and several related issues in Due East, S.C. ''A PEOPLE'S CONTEST'': The Union and Civil War, 1861-1865, by Phillip Shaw Paludan. (Harper & Row, $27.95.) A historian's fascinating study of the effects on the North of the Civil War, hugely transforming everything, from economics to ideology. WAR AND PEACE IN CENTRAL AMERICA, by Frank McNeil. (Scribners, $19.95.) A broad assessment of our dealings with Central America since 1977, as well as the personal experiences of the author, formerly our Ambassador to Costa Rica; those dealings, he finds, have often been characterized by irrationality. SECRET AND SACRED: The Diaries of James Henry Hammond, a Southern Slaveholder, edited by Carol Bleser. (Oxford University, $22.95.) Amazing exercises in self-pity and self-justification by an unpleasant man who succeeded in South Carolina politics. HENCE, by Brad Leithauser. (Knopf, $18.95.) At the heart of Mr. Leithauser's provocative and smartly written novel, set in 1993, is a man-versus-machine chess game in which the computer's approximations to humanity surpass those of the human player.

title: Sports of The Times; Sometimes Even Good Things Happen
description: Things are always getting worse. I made that pronouncement the other night after having to fill my own gas tank again.

title: A Gust of Competition in Meteorology
description: Temperatures as low as 80 degrees below zero in Alaska over the last 10 days have wreaked untold damage - causing a few planes to crash, pipes to burst, utility wires to snap and industry to come to a virtual halt. But losses would have been greater, weather experts say, had the state been caught completely off guard. Knowing of the cold front two weeks in advance allowed residents and businesses to prepare at least to some extent.

title: Belaga Moves to TV
description: JULIE D. BELAGA, the former gubernatorial candidate, has taken a job in television, following the path of another former Connecticut politician, Toby Moffett.

title: Cash Flow-Factors
description: To the Editor:

title: Whimsy and Weight Blend at the Nixon Archives
description: The staff at the Nixon Presidential Materials Project had seen nothing like it. In just a few days last summer, 12,000 requests for copies of the same item arrived.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Philadelphia;
Work Advances On Riverfront
description: LEAD: DESPITE a setback for Penn's Landing, the centerpiece of waterfront redevelopment efforts here, private developers are going ahead with residential and commercial projects north and south of the Penn's Landing site.

title: 2 Arabs Die and Red Cross Worker Is Hurt in Gaza
description: Israeli troops killed two Palestinian teen-agers and wounded an International Red Cross field worker in the Gaza Strip today, Palestinians and the army said.

title: Ulster Protestants and Catholics Talk Secretly
description: Leading politicians from four Protestant and Catholic parties in Northern Ireland have acknowledged secretly talking to each other since October about resuming a dialogue on ways out of the violence that has killed 2,700 people since 1969.

title: Extra Bits Add Bite to CD Players
description: Keeping track of the winners of the annual audio Grands Prix, we reported last week on the top-rated loudspeakers and stereo receivers.

title: Taiwan Desire For Mainland Is Dwindling
description: In the four decades since they lost the Chinese civil war, the Nationalists who have ruled Taiwan since then have been animated by a dream that has become a way of life: ''Recover the mainland!''

title: Paraguay Ponders Changes As Much Remains the Same
description: With many questions about the future still unanswered, Paraguay returned rapidly to normal today after Friday's ouster of the country's long-ruling dictator, Gen. Alfredo Stroessner.

title: THE BROTHERS WOLFF
description: ON THE WALL OF GEOFFREY WOLFF'S JAMESTOWN, R.I., living room is an early American portrait of a Colonial matron whose half-smile suggests, improbably, a flinty New England Mona Lisa. Wolff refers to the painting as a ''generic ancestor portrait'' whose subject's ''knowing smirk'' has often made him wish that she were in fact a relative. Now, as he sits beneath it, talking about his mother, what's striking is how closely the spirit of the painting resembles that of the woman he is describing.

title: Bush to Stress Domestic Issues in Speech
description: Reflecting different priorities from the Reagan Administration's, President Bush plans to ask Congress Thursday for increased Federal spending in several domestic areas, including education, environmental protection, fighting illegal drugs and helping historically black colleges, Bush aides said.

title: Prague Playwright Is Jailed Again, But With New Problems for Regime
description: For Olga Havel, the wife of the jailed playwright Vaclav Havel, the endless waiting, the uncertainty, the tortured doubts are the same. But she says there is a new quality to the Government's latest attempt to crush her husband's dissent.

title: FICTION
description: THE CAGE KEEPER AND OTHER STORIES. By Andre Dubus 3d. (Dutton, $17.95.) The characters in this debut collection of seven stories are not a happy bunch. They include a teen-age girl who allows two boys to sexually abuse her, a waitress who cheats on her Vietnam-veteran boyfriend and a convict by the name of Forky who is not to be trusted handling eating utensils. They're all desperadoes and small-time losers, helpless to avert the downward drift of their lives.
