Good intentions don't get them too far; in the story ''White Trees, Hammer Moon,'' for example, a former alcoholic named Rory kindly decides to take his two stepchildren on a camping trip and ends up spending it in drunken oblivion. Like much recent fiction, the stories in ''The Cage Keeper'' unfold against a harsh fluorescent backdrop of all-night convenience stores and anonymous doughnut shops. Andre Dubus 3d shares with his writer father a talent for delineating the everyday pathos of obscure, unglamorous lives. But his voice isn't always convincing. He relies heavily on words like ''lookin,'' ''drinkin'' and ''smellin,'' which risk reducing his characters to stereotypes; and in some of the stories, profanities seem almost as common as the word ''the.'' But strained effects are perhaps inevitable in the work of a young writer who is reaching for the moon, as Mr. Dubus clearly is.

title: Signs Of Discrimination At Medical School
description: I DON'T think any rational person would disagree with the premise that we need to ''Keep Racism Out of the School Of Medicine,'' as a recent New Jersey Opinion page article (by Gordon MacInnes) proclaimed. Indeed, it is for this very reason that a full investigation of the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey is clearly in order, because whether or not higher-ups or their public relations advocates are willing to admit it, racism has already entered the New Jersey Medical School in Newark.

title: What the States Are Doing for Industry
description: DOUG ROSS, the director of the Michigan Commerce Department, met recently with his counterparts from other Middle Western states, and proposed a kind of industrial disarmament accord. If the other states would do likewise, Mr. Ross proposed, Michigan would stop using local property tax abatements as a lure to entice manufacturers and other businesses to relocate in his state.

title: The Charm Of the Ordinary
description: To the Editor:

title: Cardinal Promotes 5-Year Plan to Expand the Role of the Laity
description: If there is a Catholic equivalent of stumping, John Cardinal O'Connor is doing it. The Cardinal is not, of course, running for office, but at gatherings in Yonkers, Staten Island, Manhattan, the Bronx and Rockland County, he has been campaigning for a five-year plan intended to pump new life into the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York.

title: Boyhood MemoriesOf China's New Year
description: COME tomorrow, for the Chinese and some of our other friends in Asia, it will be another Year of the Snake.

title: Liberal South African Whites to Form United Party
description: Three of South Africa's white anti-apartheid parties agreed today to end their fragmentation and form a unified multiracial political party to challenge the governing National Party.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Westport
description: FIFTY years ago Westport was known as the ''Hollywood of the East,'' with Bette Davis and F. Scott Fitzgerald making their homes in the bucolic town along Long Island Sound. Today, little has changed. Paul Newman and Phil Donahue live in secluded parts of town, and Main Street, which is lined with chic boutiques, is often referred to as ''the Rodeo Drive of Connecticut.''

title: BURLEY COLE IS DEAD AND WELL IN L.A.
description: SEDUCTION BY LIGHT By Al Young. 338 pp. New York: A Seymour Lawrence Book/Delta Fiction. Paper, $7.95.

title: Combat Pay in Gulf May End
description: The general in charge of the United States Central Command has recommended suspension of combat pay for sailors in the Persian Gulf, Pentagon officials say. The recommendation, under review by the Joint Chiefs of Staff, is the strongest indication yet that American defense officials believe the truce between Iran and Iraq may hold.

title: Distinguished Dabblers
description: To the Editor:

title: Getting Advice on the Housing Maze
description: LEAD: NONPROFIT organizations that wish to develop low- and moderate-income housing face various obstacles - including financial and governmental ones - but a recent program of seminars attempted to help steer them through the process.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Providence, R.I.;
Downtown Plan Taking Shape
description: LEAD: A 13-STORY building rising here is this capital city's first new office tower in four years and one of the first steps in its ambitious Capital Center downtown redevelopment.

title: Aouita Helps Make Millrose a Stunner
description: For all the memories of the Panasonic Millrose Games Friday night in Madison Square Garden, few may be more lasting than the closing moments of the men's 3,000-meter race and the women's mile.

title: Using Yak Hair to Woo Business
description: Dwarfed by the bedraggled red curtain that covers the faded pink walls of the Hotel Intourist dining room here in the Soviet Far East, a Japanese businessman taps relentlessly through dinner at a shiny laptop computer. Continuing even after a stern, slow waitress flicks an abacus to tally his check, he is straddling two very different worlds: one breaking out of the late 19th century, another hurtling into the 21st.

title: Professional Pointers
description: LAST week's up-and-down thermometer was especially difficult for plants because, to date, there has been no snow cover, nature's blanket, to protect them. Spring/summer will be wait-and-see seasons to assess any damage, particularly to buds, which may swell in ''false spring'' temperatures only to be clobbered by the cold. On Pruning

title: ONE MORE TIME: NO. 1. TEAM TRIPS
description: The No. 1 jinx hit Oklahoma today as the Sooners, in only their second game as the nation's top team, lost by 77-73 to Oklahoma State.

title: Question Of the Week; What Do The Mets Need to Add In 1989?
description: Unquestionably, the injection of a right-handed power hitter to fill the void that is being created by the aging of Gary Carter.

title: A MATTER OF SELF-CONFIDENCE
description: THE MAKING OF A SENATOR Dan Quayle. By Richard F. Fenno Jr. 180 pp. Washington: CQ Press. $19.95.

title: Algebra That Brings Smiles of Success
description: IT was midway through algebra class at Dickinson High School here when a voice from the back of the room announced, ''Alexander, I know you don't like this, but you're going to do it anyway.''

title: A Way for Commuters to Help Homeless
description: The Long Island Rail Road commuters can help the homeless in Penn Station. By purchasing a one-way ticket to Woodside ($2.50), the homeless person will now have a right to this public place -- Penn Station -- just as you and I. (Ticket good for one year).

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: Lawyers vs. Lawyers; The System That Will Decide the Fate Of Maddox and Mason
description: THE Tawana Brawley case is a matter of debate again. This time attention is not on the black teen-ager and her contention that she was abducted and repeatedly raped by several white men, but on the two lawyers who represented her.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Jan. 22 about Blue Mountain Arts, a greeting-card company, misidentified the editor of Greetings Magazine, he is Milton Kristt.

title: Purchase Students Offer Escorts
description: LEAD: KEVIN IRVINE, a sophomore at the State University of New York at Purchase, was upset last fall when some of his friends began turning down invitations to on-campus events because they feared for their safety. ''I love this campus and I hated hearing people refuse to go out at night because they were afraid,'' he recalled recently.

title: A Sign Of Change
description: He won't take over as National League president until April 1, but Bill White has already performed his first official duty: providing the Rawlings Sporting Goods Company with the signature that will appear on all National League balls.

title: HOWIE AND THE HUMAN MIND
description: THE MEZZANINE By Nicholson Baker. 135 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $15.95.

title: Heather Hatfield To Wed Engineer
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John D. Hatfield of Archbold, Ohio, of the engagement of their daughter Heather Anne Hatfield to Rodney Donald Gibble, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Gibble of Chatham Township, N.J. A September wedding is planned.

title: 19 Places Easier to Find
description: NINETEEN Connecticut communities have finally been put on the map.

title: Daniel F. Pallace Wed To Irene V. Robinson
description: At St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., Irene Victorine Robinson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander L. Robinson Jr. of Greenwich, was married yesterday to Daniel Francis Pallace, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Patrick Pallace Jr. of Baltimore. The Rev. Ralph R. Warren Jr. performed the ceremony, assisted by Msgr. Thomas P. Guinan.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: A Sculptural Exchange WHO says Glasnost is limited to Moscow and Washington? If Peter Marbury has his way, Westhampton Beach and its resort counterpart in the Soviet Union, Sochi on the Black Sea, may soon open their borders to some new East-West understanding.

title: Constance Ayars Becomes a Bride
description: At the Epiphany Roman Catholic Church in New York yesterday, Constance Mary Ayars, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. Zeiger of Madison, Conn., was married to David M. LeMay, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michel J. LeMay of Millbury, Mass. The Rev. George Baker officiated.

title: THE GIFT OF LIFE
description: It was with great difficulty that I read William Squadron's article ''Two Lives on Hold'' (Dec. 18). A friend handed me the article, showing me Joan Longer's picture, and said, ''This is the woman who received Tiffany's heart and lungs.'' Tiffany was my daughter.

title: Stuck for the Season And Enjoying It
description: IT is that time of year when pictures of palm trees appear in travel advertisements and cruise clothes decorate department store windows. People stare out from behind frosted windowpanes and dream of being somewhere else. Call it what you will - post-holiday depression, cabin fever, or the winter blahs - everybody feels crummy.

title: Marking Bush's Inaugural
description: AND NOW THE BIG news, strictly from the point of view of grammarians, about the Inaugural Address of President George Bush: he has legitimized and popularized the use of the conjunction >and to start a sentence.

title: Crystal L. Moffett To Wed March 11
description: A March 11 wedding in New Orleans is being planned by Crystal Louise Moffett and Richard Wayne Perry. The daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Robert Moffett of New Orleans, the bride-to-be attended the American School in Lugano, Switzerland, and graduated from the University of Texas. Her father is the chairman and chief executive officer of Freeport-McMoran, a diversified natural-resources company in New Orleans.

title: Brazil Agrees to Accept Aid to Save Rain Forests
description: Government officials have disclosed that, in a major policy switch, Brazil is willing to accept international funds to protect the rain forests of the Amazon.

title: HEALTH CARE'S HIGH COST
description: The article, ''Taking a Scalpel to Health Care Costs'' (Jan. 8) prompted an unusually strong response from readers. Some of their comments follow. To the Editor:

title: Japan's Whaling Expedition Stirs Up Old Conflict
description: Conflict over Japan's winter whaling expedition heightened in recent days after a Greenpeace environmentalist boat collided with a Japanese whaling vessel in Antarctica, prompting a senior Japanese official here to charge Greenpeace with practicing ''terrorism on the high seas.''

title: Winter's Gift Is the Chance to Relax
description: ''WINTER storm warning in effect.'' Just the sound of those words coming across the radio or television fills me with a sense of anticipation that makes me feel 8 years old again. And anything that can make me feel that age once more is to be treasured.

title: TOUGH TALK FOR DEMOCRATS
description: Joseph A. Califano Jr. has a good diagnosis of the Democratic Party's problems, but he doesn't offer much of a cure (''Tough Talk for Democrats,'' Jan. 8).

title: Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: Getting a Taste Of 'Slow' Food Along the Gulf
description: ON a land cruise from Apalachicola to Pensacola, along the seaward side of Florida's panhandle, motorists pass through groves of loblolly pine and clumps of palmetto interrupted by aquamarine bays fringed with beaches of crystalline, snow-white sand. In the busier beach towns, there are endless T-shirt emporiums, minigolf wonderlands and pastel motels, although not in the density found in south Florida.

title: Higher Taxes, Dire Prospects
description: LEAD: GOADED by jarring increases in property taxes, Long Island homeowners and businesses were smoldering last week with the kind of rage that can ruin whole careers for officials who may be held to blame.

title: Tracking Lightning Bolts For Stadiums and Utilities
description: Weather forecasters are able to predict with greater certainty today when and where lightning will strike ground.

title: Around the Horn in 80 Days?
description: Four sailboats are at sea on a quest to beat the 135-year-old sailing record of the clipper ship Flying Cloud from New York to San Francisco.

title: Nose Job
description: ''WE ARE TRYING TO COME AS close as possible to nature,'' says Dr. Braja D. Mookherjee. ''Nature is the greatest inventor in the Universe.'' Mookherjee, vice president and research director of natural products and exploratory research for International Flavors & Fragrances, is speaking about the technique he and a colleague, Bob Trenkle, have developed to collect and then simulate the scent of a live flower.

title: Forging a Glib Style, With Flair
description: RICHARD GREENBERG was recalling his first days at Princeton. ''Our resident adviser asked us to sit around in a circle and introduce ourselves. Everyone was saying things like, 'My name is Andy and I just got back from three years in Switzerland' and 'My name is Paul and I just got back from six months in China.' I was really starting to feel socially intimidated, so when my turn came, I said, 'My name is Rich and I just got back from 18 years on Long Island.' That sort of broke the ice.''

title: Syracuse Rolls Past Pitt, 103-80
description: Syracuse is one of the nation's highest-scoring teams, and Sherman Douglas - one of the most prolific point guards in National Collegiate Athletic Association history - is the player who points the point-hungry Orangemen in the right direction.

title: A Working Girl Who Acts on Her Own
description: In a hailstorm at dawn recently, Joan Cusack was sitting with Melanie Griffith in a Winnebago trailer that was parked in the bowels of the Staten Island ferry. She was about to be made up for a music video based on Carly Simon's theme song for the movie ''Working Girl,'' in which Miss Cusack plays Miss Griffith's best friend and fellow secretary, a ''little person'' from Staten Island whose rainbow-colored eyes look like blinking color displays for a beauty correspondence school.

title: Spicy Cooking Adds Heat to a Cold Day
description: THERE is nothing like spicy food to take the chill off a gray winter day. From Italy, the American Southwest and from China, the following recipes are simple to make - and a little exotic. They are also light and extremely low in saturated fats.

title: Exposure and Light How to Overcome the Reciprocity Failure
description: HAVE you ever taken pictures just after sunset and found later that they come out underexposed with an unattractive shade of green? Have you ever had some of your flash pictures come out darker than they should? If so, you may have been a victim of what's known as reciprocity failure.

title:
IDEAS AND TRENDS;
A New Kind of Mining Disaster
description: LEAD: LAST spring in the high desert of northeast Nevada, more than a thousand ducks, geese and other migratory birds flocked to what seemed an inviting habitat. But the water they discovered was a tailings pond from a gold mine filled with runoff contaminated with cyanide. More than 1,200 birds died before B.

title:
MUSIC;
McPartland Jazz Joins a Classical Series
description: LEAD: MARIAN McPARTLAND, the jazz pianist, recording artist and radio personality, describes her own playing as traditional jazz. ''You couldn't call my playing far out,'' she said.

title: Students Find Many Ways To Raise Funds for Neediest
description: A group of second graders at Public School 81 in the Bronx and their teacher, Carolyn Ross, organized a cake sale the other day to raise money for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: DATA UPDATE
Have You Seen Many Cows in Norwalk County?
description: IF you ask me where I live, I'm going to lie. I'm going to say that I live on Main Street in Westport, 10 feet from the front door of the Westport Library, 15 feet from my office and my Rolodex. I won't lie because I'm trying to impress you with my Westport address. It's just that I'm sick of trying to explain why I drive 50 miles to work.

title: REDNECKS, MILLIONAIRES AND CATFISH FARMS
description: A TURN IN THE SOUTH By V. S. Naipaul. 307 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: Cash Flow-Factors
description: To the Editor:

title: Gaps in the Cuban Missile Crisis Story
description: During last week's round-table discussion among Russians, Cubans and Americans who, like me, had lived through the Cuban missile crisis, the hope of coming closer to the origins and facts of the event was substantially realized.

title: The Perfect and Not-So-Perfect Schubert
description: Should we be excited that year two of the 92d Sreet Y's Schubertiade is upon us? Some think it a Quixotic idea - all the Schubert repertory performed over a 10-year span and in the order it was written. An endurance test? Spiritual weight-lifting? An ambition endearing but perhaps a little foolish? Total abandonment of sound business practices? A little of all these.

title: 'Lonesome Dove' Dusts Off the Western Myth
description: Lithe and lazy, good at cards and generous with a jug, fast moving when the bad guys act up and easily moved by a pretty lady or a pure-hearted sporting girl, Robert Duvall, a narrow smile glinting when he drawls an amiable put-down of a dim companion, ambles through ''Lonesome Dove'' as to the ranch house born. He plays Augustus McCrae, a ''wore-out old Ranger,'' who with his buddy, Capt. Woodrow F. Call (Tommy Lee Jones, coiffed and bearded in a patriarchal mode), makes the trek from the tiny town of Lonesome Dove, Texas, within rustling distance of the Rio Grande, all the way up to unsettled Montana with a herd of cattle, a couple of pet pigs and a passel of softhearted, thickheaded cowboys. There's more sweep than depth here, but while he is onscreen, Mr. Duvall makes the doings downright original.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Peace is better than war. Why fight when they are doing the job I wanted to see done.'' - Carl C. Icahn, on his accord with Texaco.

title: Proposition 42 Called Feeble
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Correction
description: An obituary last Sunday about Martin Popper, a New York lawyer who died on Jan. 27, omitted the disposition of a court action involving him. His conviction in 1961 for contempt of Congress, after he declined to tell a Congressional committee whether he was a Communist, was reversed in 1962 by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.

title: Italian Fare in a Minimalist Setting
description: Danbury has another new restaurant, Ciao. It opened in November on Ives Street, which is being called Restaurant Row locally, and perhaps prematurely, as there are just two other eating establishments on this short street off Liberty Drive.

title: HIGH ON REVOLUTION
description: LENIN By Ronald W. Clark. Illustrated. 564 pp. New York: An Edward Burlingame Book/ Harper & Row. $27.95.

title: 'The Years Go By, The Skin Sags'
description: IT is not just the rich and famous who are having cosmetic surgery these days. People from all walks of life are now asking surgeons to fix their physical flaws, big and small, said a Waterbury cosmetic surgeon, Paula A. Moynahan. For some, it means forgoing a vacation or a second car; for others, it is simply a quick dip in the savings or checking account.

title: Luxury Hotel Due in Yonkers
description: SUGGESTING that the economic renaissance Yonkers has been seeking for two decades is approaching realization, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke and Mayor Nicholas C. Wasicsko announced last week that the largest operator of first-class suite hotels nationwide - Embassy Suites Hotels - is to operate a luxury hotel on the northern edge of the city.

title: Bush Took Unconstitutional Oath of Office
description: To the Editor:

title: And in This Gallery, We See the Ancient Moog
description: My old friend took it very well, I thought, when he read that a Moog synthesizer had been placed in a museum. No dropping of the jaw in amazement, no forehead slapping, no tiresome jeremiad about the accelerating tempo of modern existence. But the news did shake him up, I could tell. After all, the Moog in a museum? Wasn't it only last week that the most famous of synthesizers was at the cutting edge of modern art?

title: PARENTS WHO KILL
description: WAVERLY PLACE By Susan Brownmiller. 294 pp. New York: Grove Press. $18.95.

title: Teen-Agers, AIDS and Abstinence
description: This is about expectations.

title: Reaching Out to Potential Nurses
description: THERE are no quick solutions to the nursing shortage, but one group is converting ideas into action to try to improve the situation in the county.

title: When the Law Becomes Big Business
description: The law has become big business. Today, several firms have more than 1,000 attorneys, with gross revenues of $250 million or more. Modern ''mega-firms'' emphasize profitability, productivity and business generation in an atmosphere of competitiveness and bureaucracy. But as these firms grow, some of the values important to the practice of law have been sacrificed.

title: Gail Collins Is Married
description: Gail A. Collins, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Norman R. Collins of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Victor S. Khosla, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ranpat Rai Khosla of New Delhi. The Rev. Donald Shoup, a United Methodist minister and an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Collinses' home.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: SOVIET PIANIST On her third private visit to the United States, Valentina Schubinskaya, a noted Russian pianist and composer, decided that it was time to play for the American public. And since it's Long Island she visits - her sister, Tamara Jouraweff, lives in Shirley - East Hampton is where she will make her American debut this afternoon. A graduate of the Moscow Conservatory of Music, where she and pianist Bella Davidovich studied together (Ms. Davidovich has written a program note for the concert), Ms. Schubinskaya has an international reputation as a recording artist with the Grand Symphonic Orchestra of the U.S.S.R. and tours extensively throughout her homeland and Eastern Europe. She's also a faculty member of the Gnessin Institute of Music in Moscow. In her appearance at 2 P.M., at Guild Hall's John Drew Theater on Main Street, she'll perform Mozart, Liszt, Debussy, Metner and one of her own compositions, ''Russian Pictures.'' For ticket information call 324-4051. PLAYERS PLAY ON

title: Getting a Direct Line to the State Department
description: FOR 10 years, the Bureau of Consular Affairs in the State Department has been preparing, revising and rescinding informative notices to Americans about travel abroad. These information sheets, or travel advisories, to give them their official name, are based on reports from State Department people in the field. They may be headed ''warning'' or ''caution'' or labeled simply ''travel to'' the country in question, and range from reports on hotel crowding - during an international fair in Baghdad, Iraq, last October, for example - to a continuing warning of the danger of guerrilla land mines in rural areas of El Salvador.

title: Question Of the Week; What Do The Mets Need to Add In 1989?
description: First and foremost, concentrate on pitching. Keep Gooden, Cone, Fernandez and Myers. Trade Aguilera and Ojeda. Also, trade Carter. He's too old, too slow, can't throw out runners and can't consistently hit for power. Trade Johnson; keep Jefferies.

title: EUROPEAN REPORT PARIS
description: As the first group of models glided down the runway at the Claude Montana spring show, the murmur of the audience was almost audible over the powerful drench of background music. There they were. Soft shoulders. Perhaps padded a bit, yet rounded. It was a silhouette shift that had been seen in Milan, New York, even London. But here it was in Paris! And being endorsed by Mr. Sharp Shoulders himself. That settled it. The sloping feminine shoulder was ''in.''

title: Edith Kupsaw To Wed in May
description: The engagement of Edith Kupsaw to Dr. Timothy Lee Lawrence, a son of Dr. Ruth Lawrence and Dr. Robert Lawrence of Rochester has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Murray Kupsaw of Warwick, R.I. A May weddding is planned. Ms. Kupsaw, a research psychologist at the Mount Sinai Medical Center and the Bronx Veterans Administration Center, graduated from Brown University and received a master's degree in clinical psychology from Fordham University, where she is a candidate for a Ph.D. degree in clinical psychology. Her father is a consultant in organization and human resources at the Rogers Corporation, a manufacturer of microwave and circuit components in Rogers, Conn.

title: Maitland Lee Griggs, 86, Retired Executive
description: Maitland Lee Griggs, a retired carpet company executive, died of heart failure Thursday at Phelps Memorial Hospital in North Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 86 years old and lived in Ardsley-on-Hudson.

title: Where to Get More Details
description: Abercrombie & Kent, 1420 Kensington Road, Oak Brook, Ill. 60521 (312-954-2944; 800-323-7308 outside Illinois).

title: Now if at This Time Gorbachev Halted Soviet Tritium Production
description: To the Editor:

title: Experts Foresee a Social Gap Between Sexes Among Blacks
description: A dramatic decline in the number of black men in college is raising concern that a gap in social and economic status is opening between black men and black women.

title: Mafia-Aided Scheme Evades Millions in Gas Taxes
description: Shortly before Phillip Moskowitz was murdered, Federal agents secretly recorded the Brooklyn gasoline wholesaler as he explained to another dealer how the Mafia shared in the theft of perhaps as much as $1 billion a year in Federal gasoline taxes in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Sentencing Panel Finds Fair, Workable, Sophisticated Solutions
description: To the Editor:

title: American, Delta Plan Partnership
description: In a bold move to strengthen their competitive positions, American Airlines and Delta Air Lines Inc. announced yesterday that they would form a partnership to operate a global computer reservation system.

title: Jersey Outdoing New York in Race for Jobs
description: Once considered little more than a source of manpower for New York City, New Jersey is emerging from the 1980's as an increasingly diverse and independent economic powerhouse that in many ways outshines New York.

title: Georgetown Shuts Down Villanova
description: Jaren Jackson scored 27 points, but it was stifling man-to-man defense that lifted sixth-ranked Georgetown to a 69-55 victory over Villanova today in a Big East game.

title: 82 Percent in Poll Oppose The Congressional Raise
description: Few people know how much United States senators and representatives are paid each year, but that does not stop the majority of the public from opposing the proposed Congressional pay increase, a new Gallup Poll has found.

title: Inner City Under Siege: Fighting AIDS in Newark
description: The AIDS virus has reached deeply into the nation's black and Hispanic ghettos, devastating communities and families already overwhelmed with social and medical ills.

title: Defense Tactics Hinted In North Jury Selection
description: Four days after it began, the process of choosing a jury for the criminal trial of Oliver L. North indicates some of the strategy Mr. North's lawyers may use in his defense.

title: Reviews/Dance; Soviet Troupe Presents 'Giselle' in Baltimore
description: A touring production of ''Giselle' that is danced with the high style and purity of the one presented here this afternoon by the Donetsk Ballet from the Soviet Union is hard to come by. In short, this is a troupe with a beautifully schooled corps, stylistic coherence and an exquisite home-grown Giselle in its young ballerina, Inna Dorafeyeva.

title: Review/Theater; Running Away From Home
description: We are, as the Playbill announces, ''in the state of Alaska, in the middle of nowhere'' in Cindy Lou Johnson's new play, ''Brilliant Traces.'' The setting is a wood cabin more forbidding than Charlie Chaplin's in ''The Gold Rush.'' Outside is a howling blizzard; inside is one indistinct occupant, sleeping beneath a bundle of blankets. And soon comes a fierce knocking on the door. The sleeper, a young man played by Kevin Anderson, awakens to admit a distraught young woman, played by Joan Cusack, who invades his cabin in full bridal regalia, from silver satin slippers to ice-encrusted veil.

title: Bridge
description: Each year, the Solomon Award is awarded to the best-played hand of the year by the International Bridge Press Association. The 1988 winner, announced in Venice in October, was Trond Rogne of Norway for his play of the diagramed deal. The key bid was North's three-diamond cue-bid, which showed a strong interest in reaching game in the light of the previous auction.

title: Boy, 11, Goes Jogging And Never Comes Back
description: An 11-year-old boy has been missing from his home in Harlem since he went jogging along Riverside Drive last Friday afternoon, the police said yesterday.

title: Review/Music; Bobby Brown Holds a Garden Party
description: There are times when a performer seems to own the moment. At Madison Square Garden on Saturday night, the singer Bobby Brown, whose album ''Don't Be Cruel'' has sold more than three million copies and is lodged in the No. 1 spot on the Billboard pop chart, owned the moment.

title: Schools Lag On Seeking Drug Funds
description: More than two years after Federal funds were made available for a program to improve education about illegal drugs, the New York City Board of Education has yet to apply for its share.

title: Bush Savings Bailout Plan Expected Today
description: After a detailed weekend review of the savings and loan crisis, President Bush is expected to announce a plan on Monday to deal with the industry's problems.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
description: THE Reading Railroad paid nothing for its place in ''Monopoly,'' but half a century later Continental Airlines paid $30,000 to appear in a new children's game.

title: How to Phone For I.R.S. Help
description: The Internal Revenue Service's Tele-Tax system allows taxpayers to call a toll-free number and hear tape-recorded messages on nearly 140 tax topics.

title: Reviews/Dance; Balanchine and Robbins With Diminutive Works
description: Some little dances can seem very grand. That was the lesson the New York City Ballet taught Saturday night at the New York State Theater when the program included works that, though small in choreographic or musical scale, nevertheless created great impressions.

title: Israel Reports Killing 5 Arabs On Edge of Zone in Lebanon
description: Israeli troops killed five armed Palestinian guerrillas in a firefight on the edge of Israel's border zone in Lebanon early today, the army reported.

title: Review/Music; Duo on Violin and Piano
description: Kate Ransom, a violinist, and Anthony Sirianni, a pianist, have been performing as the Highlands Duo since 1984. This year, the players are to become an ensemble in residence at Brevard College in North Carolina, and they are changing their name to the Brevard Duo.

title: Softball Tournament on Snow
description: Doug Bradbury, coach of the snowshoe softball team from the local lumber yard here and one of the four Bradbury brothers on the team, shrugs at his squad's perennial shortcomings in the town's annual Snowshoe Softball Tournament.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Feb. 6, 1989: MONDAY General Mtrs Corp Zurn Inds Inc TUESDAY Central Ill Pub Svc Co Diamond Shamrock R&M Emerson Elec Co General Housewares Kansas City Pwr & Lt Co Monarch Mach Tool Co Source Cap Inc WEDNESDAY Alco Std Corp American Business Prods CSX Corp Carlisle Cos Inc Federal Mogul Corp Gerber Prods Co Illinois Pwr Co Rockwell Intl Corp Sysco Corp THURSDAY Beneficial Corp Curtiss Wright Corp Dover Corp Guardsman Prods Inc Maytag Corp Wisconsin Pub Svc Corp FRIDAY Chelsea Inds Inc Deluxe Corp Raymond James Finl Inc Safety Kleen Corp Union Elec Co

title: Lilly Profits Set a Record
description: Eli Lilly & Company, the pharmaceutical concern, on Friday reported record profits and sales for its fourth quarter and full year, attributing the gains to improved results in all its basic businesses.

title: Anamosa Journal; In Prison, Pornography Becomes a Rights Issue
description: From the outside the old stone castle looks like an Ivy League college building. It is, to be sure, an institution devoted to the learning of lessons.

title: 3 Iowa Players Treated
description: Three University of Iowa basketball players were enrolled in drug treatment programs last summer at a cost of more than $16,000, The Des Moines Sunday Register reported today. University officials said that the money came from a general expense fund in the athletic department, not from tax money.

title: Shooting Shakes Washington's Elite
description: It was only a single incident, perhaps even an aberration: the shooting here the other day that left four students wounded and crying for help on the front walk of a high school in one of the city's quietest and most affluent neighborhoods.

title: Davis Cup; Americans Relish Sweep of Paraguay
description: Already assured of victory, the United States still had a couple of points to make today in its Davis Cup rematch against Paraguay. First, the Americans made a point with their racquets, then Andre Agassi made another one with a gesture.

title: Gladys Buchanan North, Editor, 81
description: Gladys Buchanan North, who helped her husband, Sterling North, write popular and award-winning children's books, died of a stroke early yesterday morning at Morristown Memorial Hospital. She was 81 years old and lived in Harding Township, N.J.

title: Children Take to the Slopes
description: ANY skier who has ever seen a tot whiz by knows that children can learn to ski. But children also learn differently from the way adults learn.

title: Kindness Is Foundation As Bush Builds Bridges
description: Robert Strauss stood with President Bush one recent night on the Truman balcony of the White House, overlooking the capital's gleaming monuments, and told him of the time he had chatted with President Carter on the same spot.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Chiat/Day's Deal
description: Chiat/Day said it had reached agreement with the management of Mojo MDA to pay $67.2 million for all the outstanding shares of the publicly held Australian advertising agency. The bid is still subject to approval by the United States Foreign Investment Review Board and by Mojo's shareholders.

title: Super Science, Superexpensive
description: Science continues to get bigger. The titles tell the story - supercolliders, supercomputers, superconductivity. Unfortunately these superprojects are supercostly. President Bush would be rash, in the budget plan he'll offer this week, to approve all the science extravaganzas his predecessor endorsed.

title: ACC Fills Two Posts; Plan for Merger Is Off
description: Richard T. Aab, chairman and chief executive of the ACC Corporation, a small long-distance communications company based in Rochester, made two announcements last week. The company filled the posts of company president and president of a subsidiary, and it said it has no intention of resuming merger talks it had terminated with the much larger Rochester Telephone Corporation.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Cuba's Quarantine for AIDS
description: Cuba has an unusual AIDS policy. A third of its population has already been tested for the virus, and the 240 people found to be infected have been put into quarantine. Since no cure is in sight, their isolation is indefinite.

title: Coke Proposal Challenged in India
description: A plan by Coca-Cola to re-enter the Indian soft-drink market is being challenged by Pepsi-Cola's Indian partners in a major food-processing and soft-drink project.

title: Stroessner Flies Into Brazil Exile; Election Is Promised in 3 Months
description: Sixty hours after being overthrown and arrested, Paraguay's former dictator, Gen. Alfredo Stroessner, was today flown out of the airport here that still carries his name and sent into exile in neighboring Brazil.

title: Short-Term-Rate Rise Expected
description: Led by the United States, major industrial nations may set in motion soon - perhaps as early as this week - a coordinated round of interest rate increases, credit market analysts said.

title: Wartime Military Budget
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Sitting President
description: Much has been said and written and otherwise observed about the difference in Presidential tone between George Bush and Ronald Reagan.

title: Jamaica Front-Runner Urges Steps to Avert Election Strife
description: Michael N. Manley, the front-running candidate for Prime Minister of Jamaica, called today for the formation of civic patrols to assist security forces in preventing violence on election day Thursday.

title: Purchasers See Slowing Of Growth
description: The growth rate of the nation's economy fell sharply in January to its lowest level in two years, the National Association of Purchasing Management said in its monthly report, scheduled to be released today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Europe to Play 'Jeopardy'
description: Thanks to Lintas: World-wide, Europeans will have the opportunity to watch locally produced and culturally rele-vant versions of the American game shows ''Jeopardy'' and ''Wheel of Fortune''.

title: Members Elect A New Pastor At Riverside
description: After an electrifying sermon that brought the congregation joyously to its feet, Riverside Church elected a new pastor yesterday who promised to lead the congregation and - through it, New York City - to ''release the song locked up in all of us.''

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: China Gives the Dates For Gorbachev's Visit
description: China said today that Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, would visit here from May 15 to May 18 for the first Chinese-Soviet summit meeting in 30 years.

title: Jobless Rate Falls in Japan
description: The Japanese Government reported Friday that the nation's unemployment rate had dropped in December to only 2.3 percent, the lowest rate in six years.

title: HBO's Script Is Rewritten by Starling
description: In the expensive seats just outside the Caesars Palace ring, the faces on the HBO executives were as long as Las Vegas Boulevard.

title: Sony to Expand Plant
description: The Sony Corporation said Thursday that it would expand its television manufacturing plant at Bridgend in Wales, creating 300 jobs. The Japanese electronics company said the investment of $:36 million, or about $63 million, would make the 15-year-old factory one of the most advanced in the world. It said increased production of Trinitron color televisions and tubes would start in May.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bell Atlantic Corp., Philadelphia, has elected the former Secretary of Defense, Frank C. Carlucci, to its board of directors.

title: Pirates Thrive Under Carlesimo's Care
description: As the oldest of 10 children, P. J. Carlesimo has helped many people grow. That childhood has aided Carlesimo as Seton Hall's basketball coach. When he arrived on campus in 1982, the Pirates' program needed plenty of nurturing.

title: Jethro Burns, 69; Mandolin Player Of Country Team
description: Jethro Burns, the mandolin-playing partner in the Homer and Jethro country music team, whose cornball humor and musical talents won the duo a Grammy Award, has died at 69 years old.

title: Dublin Journal; Past vs. the Future: Who'll Win the City's Heart?
description: The shape of this city's future and the faded elegance of its past are entangled in a controversy that, to some Dubliners, is pitting preservation against progress.

title: Washington Talk: The White House; Sununu, the Staff Chief, Is Learning the Ropes the Hard Way
description: The two-week education of John H. Sununu as White House chief of staff has been a tough crash course in Washington politics.

title: Hungarians Shocked by News of Vast Poverty in Their Midst
description: More than four decades after the ruling Communist Party proclaimed that it had eradicated poverty, recent television and press disclosures of widespread hunger and need have shocked Hungarians.

title: Time Inc.'s Magazine Drought May Be Ending
description: After a long hiatus and one spectacular failure, Time Inc. has finally succeeded in getting a new magazine off the ground, with more modest expectations this time.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Economic and Social Council

title: Sports World Specials; Man's Best Frienddn
description: The cocker spaniel, the most popular dog breed in this country since 1984, remains on top, according to registration figures compiled by the American Kennel Club.

title: Skiing; Walliser Easily Wins Downhill at Vail
description: Maria Walliser of Switzerland, who won the World Cup downhill title the past two seasons, today won her second world Alpine downhill championship.

title: Pit Bull Mauls Woman, 18; The Dog Is Seized for Tests
description: A pit bull terrier bit off a portion of the right ear of an 18-year-old girl who was playing with the dog in the hallway of a her Brooklyn apartment building yesterday, the police said.

title: Glenna Collett Vare, 85, Golfer
description: Glenna Collett Vare, a pioneer in American women's golf before the professional era and a charter member of the Women's Golf Hall of Fame, died at her home in Gulfstream, Fla., on Friday. She was 85 years old.

title: Review/Music; Margaret Price and Chorale
description: The Collegiate Chorale's performance of the Verdi Requiem at Carnegie Hall Saturday night originally offered the enticement of Sharon Sweet, an American soprano who has had significant success on Europe's opera stages.

title: Bush's Emperor of Ethics Is Wearing No Clothes
description: ''I want you to know I have always recused myself from anything to do with communications,'' insisted Boyden Gray, President Bush's longtime family friend, legal counsel and adviser on ethics.

title: John Duka Memorial Set
description: A memorial service for John Duka, a former style reporter and columnist for The New York Times who later headed a public relations agency, will be held at 11 A.M. Thursday at All Souls Unitarian Church, 1157 Lexington Avenue, at East 80th Street. Mr. Duka, who was 39 years old, died Jan. 21.

title: 2 Small California Art Museums Grow With the Economic Climate
description: Along the bustling gold coast between Los Angeles and San Diego, two small but weighty museums of contemporary art are finding the economic climate highly conducive to growth. Backed by the increasing availability of corporate and individual money, the La Jolla Museum of Contemporary Art and the Newport Harbor Art Museum have each hired big-name architects to expand their buildings, and embarked on campaigns to raise construction and endowment funds.

title: Disorder Is Eclipsing Italy's Fiscal Resolve
description: Italy's public finances, always messy and at times almost unfathomable, have fallen into fresh disarray, threatening the country's political stability and sending shivers through the financial markets in Milan.

title: TRIAL IS APPROVED ON JOB CONDITIONS
description: In a case that had been watched by business groups and prosecutors around the country, the Illinois Supreme Court has cleared the way for criminal prosecution of five factory officials whose employees contended they were injured by unsafe working conditions.

title: Phillip Keeps 500 Title
description: Bruce Phillip, Manhattan College's standout senior sprinter from the Caribbean island of Dominica, easily defended his 500-meter title at the 47th Metropolitan Intercollegiate indoor track and field championships at Seton Hall's Brennan Gymnasium.

title: Golf Clubs With a Touch
description: rrComing up with a new idea in golf clubs occasionally means rethinking the old.

title: Munsingwear Names Men's Unit President
description: ''I got Charlie through the mail,'' Lawrence L. Horsch, chairman and chief executive of Munsingwear Inc., said last Friday. He was speaking about the new president chosen for the company's men's division, its principal unit.

title: Less Propaganda, Please
description: Every four years, it is suggested in this corner that the new Administration could double the efficiency of its public-relations operations by cutting the Federal P.R. budget in half. This modest proposal is usually reversed by the Government's doubling the budget and cutting its efficiency, but the suggestion is still valid.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-7 Soviet troops completed withdrawal from Kabul, Radio Moscow reported, and the last Soviet soldiers are expected to cross into their homeland in a few days, ending Moscow's nine-year military intervention. Page A1

title: U.S. Military Contracting Hasn't Gone Overseas; Technology Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Tarnished Season for an All-Star
description: GRANT FUHR has never met his mother. He believes he met his father once by chance in a bar, where they chatted and parted once again.

title: Mark Silverman, 36, A Film Producer, Dies
description: Mark Silverman, a producer of independent films, died of complications from acquired immune deficiency syndrome on Friday at the Beth Israel Medical Center. He was 36 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Even the Apple Has Fallen
description: There was a time, well within the memory of most Americans, when one approached meals with a certain innocence. Provided the roast pork wasn't pink in the middle, one assumed that one was getting up from the table in the same good health as when one had sat down. According to the new wisdom, we were eating ourselves to death.

title: Shevardnadze Extends His Talks in Pakistan
description: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, extended his stay in Pakistan by an additional day today after a series of meetings with Pakistani officials on the shape of a future government in Afghanistan.

title: Donations To Neediest Top Record
description: Contributions to the 77th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund have surpassed last year's record, with three weeks remaining in this year's campaign.

title: U.S. to Study Fat Substitute
description: One year after the Nutrasweet Company introduced what it said was a completely natural, cholesterol-free fat substitute requiring no regulatory approval, the Food and Drug Administration is beginning its review of the product.

title: Business and the Law; Spleen Suit Vexes Biotech Industry
description: THE enlarged spleen of John Moore, a seltzer sales representative from Seattle, is vexing the biotechnology industry.

title: A Confident Schneider Rolls Along
description: There was nothing tentative or hesitant about Vreni Schneider as she walked across the hotel lobby. This was a supremely confident young woman. A ski racer who had won 10 consecutive slalom and giant slalom races on the World Cup circuit.

title: New Aqueduct Jockey Starts To Make Her Way to Front
description: WINTER can be a gloomy season at Aqueduct, especially on frigid days when swirling seagulls outnumber the railbirds and flying chunks of frozen earth sting the faces of jockeys unlucky enough to be in the chase instead of the lead. But the cold and quiet haven't daunted Diane Nelson, the scene's latest ingenue and the only jockey here to sport a chestnut ponytail that rivals those of the horses she pilots.

title: A Program on Hirohito's War Guilt Is Denounced
description: A forthcoming public-television docudrama that holds the Japanese Emperor Hirohito fully responsible for the attack on Pearl Harbor has prompted scholars and experts on Japan to denounce the program and call for its cancellation.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Geographic Marketing
description: Two top executives and a former client of the Geographic Marketing Group, which specializes in regional marketing strategies, have acquired the agency from Tracy-Locke, Dallas. Mel R. Korn, president of G.R.G.; Margaret P. Dembowczyk, its executive vice president, and Arthur Broll, a former Pepsi Cola franchise holder, bought the agency for an undisclosed sum. It had been an independently operated subsidiary of Tracy-Locke, an Omnicom Group division, since 1983.

title: Fury Over Lawmakers' Raise Finds an Outlet on the Radio
description: On the listener call-in line at the radio station KILT in Houston, it is the hottest topic since the bombing of the Marine barracks in Beirut in 1983. In Los Angeles, producers at the radio station KFI say callers will not let the talk show hosts discuss any other subject. And in Detroit, home of the Motown sound, amateur composers are setting their protests to music.

title: MOSCOW REPORTS EXIT OF 'LAST SOVIET SOLDIER' FROM AFGHAN CAPITAL
description: Soviet troops completed their withdrawal from the Afghan capital of Kabul yesterday, Moscow radio reported, and the last columns of Soviet soldiers were expected to cross into their homeland shortly, ending the Kremlin's nine-year military intervention in Afghanistan.

title: Panel Urges Deadlines For Votes on Landmarks
description: After a year studying the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission, a special panel has concluded that the open-ended process by which buildings become landmarks should be conducted under time limits and in a more systematic and predictable way.

title: College Basketball; Kentucky Trustees Review Allegations
description: Members of the University of Kentucky board of trustees were briefed today on the school's response to the National Collegiate Athletic Association's allegations of wrongdoing in the men's basketball program.

title: Satellite TV For Britain
description: Satellite television became available in Britain today with much fanfare but few viewers.

title: A Mover and Shaker Behind Bush Foreign Policy
description: ''We're sitting there,'' said a longtime employee of the State Department, ''waiting for the government to start.''

title: Canada Bank Compromise
description: Canada's big banks have backed down from a confrontation over the American Express Company's effort to establish a bank here after the Canadian Government agreed Friday to delay its opening for a year.

title: Books of The Times
description: Almost as powerfully as Proust's uneven paving stones managed to do, the following memorandum from President Richard M. Nixon to Mrs. Nixon, written early in his first term of office, recaptures a lost time:

title: Father Charged After His Son Dies in Crash
description: A 12-year-old Bronx boy died and his father was charged with driving while intoxicated yesterday after the car the father was driving crashed into a divider on the Bronx River Parkway, a police spokesman said.

title: A Headhunter Finds 2 Heads Are Acquainted
description: New York, they say, is just a collection of small towns. But that doesn't only mean places like Bensonhurst and Little Italy. It refers to all the worlds that meet in the city that is the capital of so many Americas.

title: ON YOUR OWN: Fitness; Health Club Can Help Give A Sedentary Person a Routine
description: CARL ALLEN, a trainer at the Vertical Club, a Manhattan health club, looked out over the people toiling on stationary bicycles recently and summarized his philosophy of getting a sedentary person started on the road to fitness.

title: Illinois Police Raid a City Hall
description: The police raided city government offices here on Friday, reportedly looking for evidence of official misconduct.

title: Into the Real-Life Parallel Lives of Kathy and Mo
description: Seated on the edge of the stage of the Westside Arts Theater are Kathy Ann Najimy, 31 years old, and Maureen Elibebeth Gaffney, 30. Standing between them is Albert Finney. Albert Finney? ''Our good friend Al Finney,'' Ms. Najimy says, and strokes his head gently.

title: Plan to End Europe Havens
description: The European Commission will propose measures this week to abolish tax havens within the European Community, Jacques Delors, the president of the commission, said today.

title: Fund Seeks Alabama TV Station
description: The Alabama Retirement Systems, the $8 billion state pension fund, has applied to the Federal Communications Commission for the right to buy WSFA-TV, an NBC affiliate that is the oldest television news organization in Alabama.

title: Marriott Defies a Hong Kong Custom
description: Kent Maury, an affable executive with the glittering new Marriott hotel in Hong Kong, says that when he goes to meetings or parties with other hotel executives here, some assiduously avoid him and others, when introduced, will not even shake his hand.

title: For '88 Returns, '86 Tax Cuts Are All in Place
description: As taxpayers begin filling out their 1988 returns in the next few weeks, many will be paying at the lowest rates since World War II. The reason is that 1988 was the first year in which the rate reductions of the Tax Reform Act of 1986 were fully effective.

title: Sports World Specials; On Pace for Record
description: Not many college basketball coaches have had players with epilepsy on their squads, but Nick Marachuck, the Fordham coach, has had two in the last few years. Both have been very productive.

title: New Report Warns of Alliance of Racist Groups
description: For the second time in three months, an organization that monitors white supremacist groups is warning that the movement is being revitalized by the emergence of volatile gangs of neo-Nazi youths with close-cropped hair.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Soviet Muslims Seek Leader's Ouster
description: Soviet Muslims have mounted a campaign to oust the Islamic leader of Soviet Central Asia, charging him with drinking, womanizing and excessive subserviance to secular authorities, according to Muslims interviewed here today.

title: Steinberg Jurors' Final Seesaw Day
description: After all the shouting and threats among the members of a hung jury, the final hours of deliberation in the murder trial of Joel B. Steinberg came down to persuading three jurors to end their holdout against the verdict they would ultimately reach last Monday - first-degree manslaughter.

title: Minivan Case Tests International Accord; End Safety Exemption
description: To the Editor:

title: Results Plus
description: Horse Racing Nasr El Arab Wins Strub Stakes: Nasr El Arab captured the $500,000 Charles H. Strub Stakes for 4-year-olds at Santa Anita yesterday under Patrick Valenzuela. He covered the mile and a quarter in 2:02 1/5, scoring by four lengths over Perceive Arrogance, with Silver Circus third in the field of seven. Nasr El Arab, the high weight at 123 pounds, returned $6.40 for $2 to win. Owned by Prince Khalid Abdullah of Saudi Arabia, the colt posted his fifth victory in 11 starts and brought his career earnings to $817,344.(AP) Victory for Cryptoclearance: Cryptoclearance, the favorite, uncorked a powerful late run to catch the pacesetting Slew City Slew and score a 1 1/2-length victory yesterday in the $200,000 Donn Handicap at Gulfstream Park. Ridden by Jose Santos, Cryptoclearance ran a mile and an eighth in 1:50 1/5 and paid $4.40 for $2. The victory moved Cryptoclearance, owned by Phil Teinowitz of Chicago, into second place in earnings among horses still in training. He has $2,437,317 in 35 starts.(AP) Hedgeabout Rallies for Victory: Hedgeabout, with Chris Antley aboard, rallied in the stretch and outlasted Las Manitas by three-quarters of a length yesterday to win the $66,700 Berlo Handicap for fillies and mares 3-years-old and up at Aqueduct. Las Manitas, who led most of the way, finished a length ahead of Bodacious Tatas. Hedgeabout covered six furlongs in 1:10 4/5 on the fast track to earn $40,020 for Regal Oak Farm with her first victory in two starts this year. The winner returned $4.60for $2. Auto Racing Close Finish at Daytona: Porsche regained its hold on the Daytona 24 Hours yesterday as Derek Bell of Britain, Bob Wollek of France and John Andretti of the United States won the closest finish in the 22-year history of the race. The victory gave Porsche its 12th Daytona 24 Hours victory in 13 years. A Jaguar XJR-9 driven by Price Cobb, John Nielsen of Denmark, Andy Wallace of Britain and Jan Lammers of the Netherlands, battled for the lead through the final four hours. Wollek drove the final two hours in the 962, crossing the finish line 1 minute 26.665 seconds ahead of Lammers in the second-place car. (AP) Track and Field New York Wins Challenge: Alicia Moss set a meet record of 4 minutes 41.14 seconds yesterday to win the mile and leading New York to a 158-99 victory over Boston in the Reebok Challenge, a track meet between athletes from Boston and New York held at Boston University. The victory was the fifth in a row for New York, which has never lost in this competition. Road Racing Trunkes and Malaxos Prevail: Mike Trunkes of the Central Park Track Club and Suzanne Malaxos of Australia were the winners yesterday in the New York Road Runners' 14th annual seven-mile run, which attacted 810 competitors to Central Park. Trunkes, who led his club to the men's team title, won in 36 minutes 39 seconds. Richard Pendall of West Point was second in 36:45. Malaxos won in 40:04 and Melissa Marsted of New York was runner-up in 45:44. The Millrose Athletic Association won the women's team title.(AP) Tennis Navratilova Takes Title: Martina Navratilova fought back from a 3-5 deficit in the final-set tie breaker yesterday to beat Lori McNeil, 6-7, 6-3, 7-6, for the singles title in the Pan Pacific Open in Tokyo. Navratilova, ranked No. 2 in the world, received $50,000 for the 140th singles title of her career.(AP) Fendick Beats Cordwell: Patty Fendick of the United States, the defending champion, beat Belinda Cordwell of New Zealand, 6-2, 6-0, yesterday to win a $75,000 Virginia Slims tennis tournament in Auckland, New Zealand. The victory was worth $12,000; Cordwell earned $6,000.(AP) Boxing Van Horn Captures Title: Darrin Van Horn captured the International Boxing Federation junior-middleweight championship yesterday, overpowering the titleholder, Robert Hines, to secure a 12-round unanimous decision in Atlantic City. Van Horn, 153 1/4 pounds, is 39-0 with 24 knockouts. Hines, 24-2-2 with 16 knockouts, lost in his first title defense.(AP) College Basketball Purdue 76, Michigan St. 70: Machelle Joseph scored 25 points as ninth-ranked Purdue beat Michigan State, 76-70, yesterday in a Big Ten Conference women's game in East Lansing, Mich. Rhonda Mateen scored 19 points for Purdue (17-2 over all and 8-1 in the conference). Cherie Swarthout scored 17 for Michigan State (11-8, 5-4).(AP) Iowa 63, Northwestern 53: Robin Christian scored 24 points yesterday in leading seventh-ranked Iowa to a 63-53 Big Ten women's victory over unranked Northwestern in Evanston, Ill. Iowa improved to 18-3 over all and 8-1, while Northwestern fell to 7-11 and 3-6.(AP)

title: The Anatomy of a Debut That Wasn't
description: The word was out on Sharon Sweet. This 37-year-old soprano from Gloversville, N.Y., had been singing professionally for only three seasons, but in those three she had moved to the top of the field about as fast as one can move in the world of opera. Fans, impresarios and managers from all over the country were lined up in eager expectation to hear her American debut in the Verdi Requiem, with the Collegiate Chorale Saturday night at Carnegie Hall. It didn't happen. And thereby hangs an unusual tale, amusing to some and heartbreaking to others, of clashing personalities and last-minute choices in the world of high-powered singing. Ms. Sweet had already been engaged by the likes of Zubin Mehta, Carlo Maria Giulini, Lorin Maazel, Simon Rattle and Giuseppe Sinopoli. She had earned glowing reviews in hard-to-cast roles like Aida, Leonora in ''Trovatore,'' even that pinnacle of dramatic bel canto, ''Norma.'' An Unhappy Busload

title: Review/Television; Columbo Returns On ABC
description: Columbo is back. His raincoat looks as if it has been slept in for the dozen years since the long-running series about the shrewd and shambling homicide lieutenant met its end. And Peter Falk, tie askew and eyes asquint, still looks as right in the role as the cigar that he occasionally lights but rarely puffs looks between his teeth.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Democrats, Under Fire, Play It Cool
description: They like to think of themselves as members of ''the people's House,'' and there was, in fact, something profoundly and zanily democratic about the House Democrats Saturday night, dressed up in the garb of the 1950's and 1960's, getting down to the Peppermint Twist.

title: Grabill Seeks Chapter 11
description: William Stoecker, a 31-year-old former welder who made a fortune by building an empire of small manufacturing businesses, resigned Friday as chairman of his largest company, which sought protection from its creditors.

title: IRANIAN DISMISSES PROSPECT OF THAW WITH WASHINGTON
description: Hojatolislam Ali Khamenei, the Iranian President, today dismissed the prospect of an early improvement in relations between his country and the United States.

title: Keeping Outsiders Out: Passes for Sea Gate
description: Sea Gate, a private enclave of homes and apartment buildings sprawled along the Brooklyn waterfront near Coney Island, has quietly barred outside pedestrians from its streets.

title: F.D.A. Said to Be Re-evaluating Order for More Studies on an AIDS Drug
description: In an unusual move, the Food and Drug Administration is reconsidering its recent decision to require further studies before approving a drug used to treat a pernicious viral infection that robs many AIDS patients of their vision, a senior official at the agency says.

title: Market Place; 2 Theorists Split On Elliott Wave
description: A DECADE ago, Ralph N. Elliott was a forgotten stock market analyst. Then two men of different generations resurrected his ideas and gained growing public attention with the forecast that the 1980's would see a surging bull market, perhaps topping out in 1987 with the Dow Jones industrial average near 2,800. At the time, a forecast of the Dow again hitting 1,000 was deemed to be daringly bullish.

title: AFGHAN FACTIONS TO HOLD ASSEMBLY
description: A senior leader of the Afghan insurgents said in an interview here today that the 15 guerrilla groups had agreed to form a council and would meet in Islamabad, the Pakistani capital, within a few days to form a government.

title: Chrysler Unit To Reorganize
description: The Chrysler Motors Corporation said today that it would restructure its vehicle engineering operations to focus product development on an entire vehicle rather than on its individual components.

title: Joseph G. Raposo Is Dead at 51; Helped to Create 'Sesame Street'
description: Joseph G. Raposo, a creator of the children's television show ''Sesame Street'' and a composer, died of complications from lymphoma yesterday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 51 years old and lived in Bronxville and Chatham, Mass.

title: Dooley Decides Not to Run
description: Vince Dooley, who retired as the Georgia football coach in December, said tonight that he would not run for governor and would remain as the university's athletic director. Dooley was to step down as athletic director March 1.

title: Indoor Track; Aouita Impressive, But Misses Record
description: Said Aouita of Morocco today won his second race on a five-stop tour of the United States with the sixth-fastest time ever in an indoor 5,000-meter competition.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Nov. 15 about a meeting of the National Association of Scholars reported that many members of the group echoed complaints expressed in Allan Bloom's book ''The Closing of the American Mind,'' which accused liberal arts education and college students of letting interest groups alter the established curriculum and impede intellectual freedom. The article referred to a speech by Alan C. Kors, a University of Pennsylvania history professor, and might have left the impression that he supported the Bloom contention.

title: Lakers Run Away From Nets
description: Magic Johnson had 27 points and 13 assists and the Los Angeles Lakers broke open a close game tonight with a 21-5 run in the fourth quarter to beat the New Jersey Nets, 134-116.

title: Arthur Ellis, Photographer, 77
description: Arthur Ellis, a photographer for The Washington Post for 47 years until his retirement in 1977, died of cardiac arrest Friday at Sibley Memorial Hospital in Washington. He lived in Washington and was 77 years old.

title: INSIDE
description: Bush's Style: The Personal Touch Representative Thomas E. Coleman and his wife, Marilyn, in a snapshot President Bush took in the Lincoln Bedroom of the White House. Mr. Bush is using informality to ''enfold.'' Page A13. Airline Booking Merger American and Delta will market a joint worldwide reservations system that is likely to strengthen their positions at some airports. Page D1. Boon to Homebuyers A planned Michigan savings program would guarantee first-time homebuyers a down payment. Page A8. A Mover on Foreign Policy Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser, is playing a large role in the early formation of the Bush foreign policy. News analysis, page A3.

title: Donald Harry Cowles, Retired General, 71
description: Liet. Gen. Donald Harry Cowles, retired, an Army deputy chief of staff in the mid-1970's, died Saturday at Alexandria Hospital. He was 71 years old.

title: Golf; Calcavecchia Wins On Sharp Chipping
description: Mark Calcavecchia, fast becoming one of the most popular golfers on tour with his long drives and fearless attack on pins, utilized a couple of delicate chips into cups today to achieve his second PGA Tour victory in two weeks.

title: Light From Courtroom Cameras
description: The case for cameras in the courtroom could almost rest on the Joel Steinberg trial, all its horrors notwithstanding. By shedding a brilliant spotlight on child abuse, the televised proceedings proved both dramatic and educational.

title: Pakistan Claims Major Gains In Developing Its Own Arms
description: The Pakistani Government has successfully tested two types of surface-to-surface missiles and may be within two years of producing its own tanks, the army chief said today.

title: The English-Spanish Battle For Hispanic Miami Viewers
description: The two leading Spanish-language television stations in the nation's most concentrated Hispanic market are facing an intensified challenge for their viewers from English-language stations here.

title: Simulated Flights but Real Profits
description: During a descent toward Teterboro Airport outside New York City recently, the No. 2 engine on a Falcon 50 business jet caught fire. The co-pilot, an instructor, quickly shut down the engine, radioed air traffic controllers that he would be making an emergency landing and then brought the airplane down safely using the two remaining engines.

title: Bhopal Case To Resume
description: A new judge in the compensation case for the 1984 Bhopal gas disaster said Saturday that hearings, which had not been held for more than 15 months, would resume Feb. 18.

title: Crash of B-1 Laid to Its Pilots
description: An Air Force report on a B-1 bomber crash last November concluded that pilot error was to blame for the crash at Ellsworth Air Force Base in South Dakota.

title: Buyouts Only Divide Owners and Managers
description: To the Editor:

title: Islanders Edge Nordiques, 3-2
description: Tom Fitzgerald's first National Hockey League goal proved to be the game-winner as the Islanders beat the Quebec Nordiques, 3-2, tonight.

title: As Oakland Rises, Its Paper Endures
description: Robert C. Maynard, the owner, president and editor of The Tribune, has spent nearly six years trying to cut costs, woo advertisers and improve the long-struggling newspaper.

title: Michigan Plans Help in Buying a Home
description: Gov. James J. Blanchard of Michigan says he will institute a state savings program that will guarantee first-time homebuyers the money for down payments on houses of their choice, regardless of how much housing prices rise.

title: Army Tests Defenses Against Biological Weapons
description: The United States Army laboratories responsible for defending American troops against biological weapons are testing potential treatments in China and Argentina, the laboratories' commander has disclosed.

title: Ann Berman, a Writer, Married to Daniel Feld
description: Ann Berman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mandell L. Berman of Franklin, Mich., and Longboat Key, Fla., was married yesterday to Daniel Feld, a son of Mrs. David Feld of Detroit and the late Dr. Feld. Rabbi David Lincoln performed the ceremony at the University Club in New York.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Motorola Back at Y.&R.
description: Young & Rubicam has won back the Motorola corporate advertising account that its Chicago office had lost to Lintas: U.S.A. a year ago. The budget is about $5 million annually.

title: Sports of The Times; How Ewing Lifted Gotham
description: ALL we knew about the 22-year-old Patrick Ewing when he was drafted by the Knicks in 1985, the first college player chosen by the pros that year, was that he would be one of the greatest players ever, save the sinking team, and return a lusted-after winner to Gotham.

title: Hospital Calls Layoff of 300 A Last Resort
description: Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center's decision to lay off 300 employees was a last-resort response to financial problems that are becoming more common for private hospitals treating poor patients, hospital representatives said yesterday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Pravda's special correspondents report that on Sunday the last Soviet soldier left Kabul.'' - Moscow radio. [ A6:2. ]

title: U.S. Military Contracting Hasn't Gone Overseas
description: To the Editor:

title: Boat Maker Sold at Auction
description: Murray Industries, the maker of Chris-Craft pleasure boats, was sold on Saturday to the Outboard Marine Corporation in a courtroom auction.

title: Sports World Specials; Sibling Rivalry
description: Basketball has brought out the best and worst in two brothers at Yeshiva University. The sport has triggered their competitive nature and allowed them to reach great heights. But their competitiveness has also resulted in violent fights.

title: Let's Do All We Can for Gorbachev
description: LEAD: From the point of view of America's national interest, nothing is more obvious than the desirability of doing all that we can to keep Mikhail S. Gorbachev in office. He is patently dropping out of the arms race and cold war and asking us to come along.

title: Defendants Win Fees in Suit on Contra Aid
description: A Federal district judge has awarded $1 million in legal fees to a Nicaraguan rebel leader, a former Central Intelligence Agency official and others who had been accused in a civil lawsuit of mounting an illegal scheme to aid the rebels.

title: Publishing: And They All Said It Wouldn't Sell
description: WHOEVER said the unexam ined life is not worth living apparently never intended to go into book publishing, where there is almost no research and where much of the conventional wisdom is a pastiche of folklore, myth and wishful thinking. ''All the maxims are true,'' a former editor has said, ''until books come along that disprove them. Then the opposite is true.''

title: Rangers Fall Out Of First Place
description: John Vanbiesbrouck blamed himself for what happened to the Rangers last night, and he could trace that blame back to the very first shot the Minnesota North Stars fired at his net.

title: Man Already on Death Row Faces Trial in 14 More Deaths
description: A man on death row for killing two peo-ple in a shooting spree in Russellville goes on trial this week, charged with murdering 14 members of his family in the days preceding the rampage.

title: Business Digest
description: Companies

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Thank-You Trip
description: The night George Bush won the New Hampshire primary, he pledged that if he was elected President, when he stood on the steps of the Capitol for the swearing-in ceremony, he would deliver a tribute, four words that had meant a lot to him at the outset of the Presidential campaign:

title: TV Notes
description: Criticism of 'Nightline'

title: GLOBAL BRIEFS
description: * Turkey and a Canadian-led group will sign a $500 million agreement today to build the first nine miles of a rail system in Ankara, a municipal spokesman said. A fifth of the lines will run underground. Canada's Urban Transport Development Corporation and its Turkish partners, Gama Endustri and Guris Insaat, were awarded the four-year contract in July. By the year 2015, the complete system is expected to carry 45,000 people an hour. The capital's population, now three million, is expected by then to reach five million.

title: Sports World Specials; Bradley's Tipoff
description: It's been 12 years since he ended his career with the Knicks, so it should come as no surprise that at the age of 45, Bill Bradley is not the basketball player he once was.

title: Outdoors: Watching the Wind for Geese
description: NO amount of skill at decoying or calling Canada geese is of much value to hunters if the weather doesn't cooperate, a fact that was hammered home to me during a special coastal zone season that ended Saturday for those birds in Massachusetts.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Before there was a New York Rangers' franchise in the National Hockey League, wasn't there a team called the New York Americans? How successful was it?

title: Joe Morrison, 51, Former Giant
description: Joe Morrison, the head football coach at South Carolina and a star running back and receiver in a 14-year career with the New York Giants, died of a heart attack Sunday night. He was 51 years old.

title: Kitty Litter's Fans Victorious
description: Coca-Cola discovered what can happen when you tinker with success. Now it's Kitty Litter's turn.

title: Nastiness Signals Bitter Race for Koch and Goldin
description: The discourse between two of the most important men in New York City began last week with Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin accusing Mayor Edward I. Koch of divisiveness and bad development policies, and ended with Mr. Koch comparing Mr. Goldin's tactics to Nazi propaganda.

title: 3-Year Notes to Start Treasury Refunding
description: Most of the attention this week will be focused on the Treasury's quarterly refunding, which includes $9.75 billion of new 3-year notes, $9.5 billion of 10-year notes and $9.5 billion of 30-year bonds. The week will begin with today's regular weekly auction of new three-month and six-month Treasury bills.

title: Westchester Clerk Gives Up Executive Race
description: The Democratic effort to unseat Andrew P. O'Rourke as the Westchester County Executive was simplified today when the County Clerk, Andrew J. Spano, stunned a gathering of 800 party members at a Democratic ''victory breakfast'' by announcing that he would not be a candidate for the post.

title: Devils Top Oilers; No Pain, No Gain
description: Joe Cirella didn't really want to look at the scoreboard that had just posted the result of Philadelphia's game against the Capitals, or at least he didn't want to be seen looking at it. Still, he looked and instantly regretted it, although he also realized that most of his Devils teammates had just done the same thing. The Flyers had beaten the Capitals, and now the Devils had 60 minutes of hockey to play against the Oilers.

title: Barbara Bush Says She Backs Prohibiting Assault Weapons
description: Barbara Bush says she fears guns and, despite her husband's membership in the National Rifle Association, favors banning the rapid-fire assault weapons used in a wave of gang killings and the California school shooting that left five children dead and 29 wounded.

title: Central Park Could Get A Little Island Unto Itself
description: An island on the island of Manhattan is being planned by the New York City parks commissioner, to bring a touch of Lake Placid to the edge of Harlem.

title: Relief Agencies Say Return Of Afghans May Take Years
description: Representatives of Western relief groups aiding Afghanistan say that it may take two or three years before the five million Afghan refugees in Pakistan and Iran return after the last Soviet soldiers leave.

title: Minivan Case Tests International Accord
description: To the Editor:

title: John O'Grady, 46; Was Salomon Manager
description: John L. O'Grady, the former managing director of sales and trading for Salomon Brothers Inc., died of a heart attack on Saturday while skiing with his family. He was 46 years old and lived in Mt. Kisco, N.Y., and Delray Beach, Fla.

title: Accord on Seabrook Suits
description: The Public Service Company of New Hampshire disclosed Friday that it had agreed to pay $2 million to four former owners of the Seabrook nuclear power plant to prevent them from suing the utility over its management of the stalled project.

title: Texas to Offer Export Plan For Beef Without Hormones
description: Texas, which produces about a fifth of American beef, is putting pressure on Washington to resolve a trade conflict with the European Community over its ban on imports of meat treated with hormones.

title: Output of U.S. Workers Increased 1.4% in 1988
description: American workers increased their productivity by 1.4 percent last year, an improvement over 1987 that nonetheless revived doubts about the economic projections in President Bush's spending plans.

title: High PCB Levels Found In Eskimo Breast Milk
description: The milk of nursing Eskimo women in northern Quebec has a higher level of PCB's than that of women anywhere in the world, according to a new study.

title: An Army With Its Spirit in Disarray
description: As Soviet troops return from Afghanistan to flag-waving welcomes at the Soviet border, some of those left behind are giving vent to the frustrations and disillusionment common to an army in retreat.

title: Pennzoil Owns 8% of Burlington Resources
