description: ''ON Valentine's Day, people like something that goes to their heart - like roses,'' said Dieter Schorner. Mr. Schorner was commenting on Cupid over a cappuccino and freshly baked apple tart - and amid a profusion of roses - in his new Patisserie Cafe Didier in the Georgetown section. For Valentine's Day, Mr. Schorner is offering lots of sweet treats. If thick pecan pie or Swiss-chocolate genoese with chocolate ganache are not romantic enough, try the chocolate heart cake with pink pulled-sugar ribbons and bows, or the mocha meringue heart cake with mocha buttercream and sugar roses. The 8- to 10-inch cakes are $25 to $30.

title: CPC International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $126 million, or $1.54 a share, from restructuring activities.

title: Olivetti Computers
description: Ing. C. Olivetti & C. S.p.A., the Italian business machine group, introduced a line of personal computers that are equipped with microchannel architecture. The microchannel system improves linkage between the internal and external components of the computer, allowing it to move large amounts of data more smoothly. The new computers are the P500 desktop, which will cost about $5,200 and the P800, which will cost about $12,500.

title: KEMP VOWS ATTACK AGAINST URBAN ILLS
description: Jack F. Kemp, the new Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, said today that he intended to push for ''bold, radical, experimental programs'' in the fight against what he called ''the intractable problems of the inner cities.'' And he pledged that he and his aides would form ''the cutting edge'' of a renewed Republican appeal to blacks.

title: Reviews/Music; Yoav Talmi Conducts Chamber Orchestra
description: It is a music season currently rich with cancellations and substitutions. Less last-minute and consequently less dramatic than the recent histrionics at the Opera Orchestra of New York and Collegiate Chorale was Yoav Talmi's appearance over the weekend with the New York Chamber Symphony at the 92d Street Y. Christoph Eschenbach was to have conducted this two-concert series, but his withdrawal four weeks ago brought Mr. Talmi to town.

title: Ward Recalling Vehicle Cards From Civilians
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward, angered by the questionable civilian use of police vehicle-identification cards, ordered the recall yesterday of thousands of the cards. New York City will replace them with redesigned credentials to be issued solely to people involved with law enforcement.

title: New Heat Pump Cuts Power Cost
description: The Electric Power Research Institute and an air-conditioner manufacturer have produced a new heat pump for homes that is 30 to 40 percent more efficient than current models. It uses computer technology and advances in electric motor controls and produces hot water as a byproduct during the summer.

title: Wine Talk
description: DEPENDING on whom you talk to or read, wine prices are continuing to climb unconscionably or they are moving up moderately or they are leveling off.

title: Anheuser-Busch Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Sales represent gross sales.

title: Book Notes
description: About Numbers

title: L.I. Man Is Named Guardian Of Pregnant Comatose Wife
description: A State Supreme Court justice appointed the husband of a pregnant comatose woman her legal guardian today, allowing him to authorize an abortion he says will save her life. But hours later an appellate judge stayed that ruling, pending an appeal by abortion opponents.

title: Aging Pioneer Discovers Fresh Plan for Survival
description: If a horseplayer finds just the right seat in the clubhouse during the late afternoon at Caliente Race Track, he can experience a transcendent parimutuel moment.

title: Intel Loses Copyright Case to NEC
description: In a landmark copyright case in the electronics industry, a Federal judge ruled today that the NEC Corporation had not infringed on microprocessor copyrights held by the Intel Corporation.

title: William C. Steere, 81, Botanist and Teacher
description: Dr. William Campbell Steere, a botanist and educator who was president emeritus of the New York Botanical Garden, died yesterday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y., after a short illness. He was 81 years old and lived in Bronxville.

title: Gibson Greetings Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

Capital Gains Tax: Kind or Unkind Cut?;
We Can't Afford It
description: LEAD: Tomorrow, President Bush will unveil his proposal to reduce the maximum capital gains tax rate to 15 percent. He will argue that a reduction would raise revenue, increase saving, stimulate venture capital investments, boost productivity growth and improve American competitiveness in world markets.

title: Capital Cities/ABC Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: The company said results for 1988 and 1987 reflect reductions in entertainment programming and sports rights at the ABC Television Network from historic costs to fair market values recorded in connection with the acquisition of ABC. These reduced costs benefited per share earnings in 1988 and 1987 approximately $6.60 and $3.85, respectively.

title: Woman's Hospital Visit Marks Gay Rights Fight
description: Karen Thompson walked into Sharon Kowalski's room at the Miller-Dwan Medical Center in Duluth, Minn., last week and said quietly: ''Hi, Sharon. Do you remember me?''

title: Budapest Journal; The Lasting Pain of '56: Can the Past Be Reburied?
description: Finally, 31 years after they were hanged, Imre Nagy and his closest associates are going to be permitted decent burials.

title: Newspaper Ad Bureau
description: Leonard Forman, a former director of planning and chief economist for The New York Times Company, was named executive vice president of the Newspaper Advertising Bureau yesterday. Mr. Forman was most recently the senior vice president of Telemundo Inc., a Spanish-language television network formed in 1987.

title: FOOD SHORTAGES REPORTED IN KABUL
description: Shortages of food and other essential commodities have reached the emergency stage in Afghanistan, the United Nations coordinator for Afghan relief said here today.

title: PAY INCREASE PLAN KILLED IN CONGRESS
description: Congress killed the proposed 51 percent Federal pay increase today, leaving a tangle of political problems, including judges demanding a raise and critics promising to continue the fight over Congress's taking honorariums from private groups.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm convinced that John Tower at one time months or years ago had a serious problem with alcohol. The question on all of our minds is whether he has corrected that problem.'' - Senator James Exon, Democrat of Nebraska. [ A24:6. ]

title: The U.N. Today
description: Economic and Social Council

title: Review Set on F-16 Deal
description: The National Security Council has asked six agencies to submit recommendations by Friday on whether the United States should proceed with a project under which Japan would develop a new version of the F-16 fighter, Administration and Congressional officials said today.

title: Senators Hear Tapes on Money For Top Navajo
description: Senate investigators today released tapes of secretly recorded conversations in which they said Peter MacDonald, chairman of the Navajo tribe, urged a business associate to cover up tens of thousands of dollars in payoffs to the tribal leader and his family.

title: Chance Looms for John
description: Tommy John, who was apparently discarded by the Yankees at the end of last season, will likely be back with the team this spring, although it is uncertain whether he will hold a job on the pitching staff.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY Moving swiftly to carry out President Bush's plan to deal with the saving crisis, regulators assumed control of four insolvent institutions. [ Page A1. ] In Texas, investors and savings executives voiced concern that the F.D.I.C. would move too swiftly to sell assets of the institutions it takes over. [ D6. ] Savings industry executives are preparing to fight the Bush plan in Congress. [ D6. ] The White House's point man is Richard C. Breeden, a 39-year-old Presidential aide. [ D6. ] President Bush's budget will propose that military spending not rise beyond what is needed to offset inflation. [ A1. ] Americans took out $5.4 billion more in credit than they paid off in December as consumer debt grew at a 9.9 percent rate. [ D2. ] INTERNATIONAL President Bush will not block Monsanto's sale of its semiconductor subsidiary to a West German conern. [ D1. ] The European Commission will seek a minimum withholding tax on interest and dividend income. [ D6. ] COMPANIES McDonnell Douglas received orders for aircraft that could be worth more than $10 billion in the next decade. [ D1. ] A.T.& T. cleared a major hurdle in its bid to become a partner in the overhaul of Italy's telephone system. [ D1. ] Williams Telecommunications signed an agreement to acquire Lightnet in a $365 million deal that will create the nation's fourth largest telecommunications company. [ D5. ] The nation's telecommunications are vulnerable to large-scale terrorist attacks, Government scientists warned. [ D5. ] A Federal judge ruled that NEC had not infringed on Intel's microprocessor copyrights. He also ruled that certain instructions embedded in microprocessors were eligible for protection. [ D1. ] Capital Cities/ABC's profits rose 20 percent in the fourth quarter, helped by a strong gain at ESPN. [ D19. ] Salomon reported a fourth-quarter loss despite a record performance in its energy business. [ D4. ] Holly Farms' board unanimously affirmed its earlier merger agreement with Conagra. [ D4. ] MARKETS After four days of declines, stock prices rebounded. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 26.07 points, to 2,347.14. [ D10. ] Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved higher, helped by Japanese participation in the Treasury's auction. [ D17. ] The dollar finished mixed against major foreign currencies, in trendless trading marked by speculation over interest rates. [ D16. ] Coffee futures rallied for the fourth straight day, bolstered by renewed fears of tightening supplies. [ D16. ] A national penny-stock brokerage has been temporarily banned from soliciting business in New York State. [ D4. ] TECHNOLOGY A new heat pump for homes is 30 to 40 percent more efficient than current models. It uses computer technology and advances in electric motor controls. [ D8. ] Keeping the crunch in pickles may be easier with a recent innovation at the Agriculture Deparment. [ D8. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The heads of CBS, NBC and ABC agreed that the networks' share of the viewing audience will decline. Advertising. [ D1. ] Costa Rican officials are encouraging ''debt for nature'' swaps. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [ D2. ] This might be a good time to hold onto the stocks of savings institutions. Market Place. [ D10. ]

title: Students See Film on Prinicpal's War
description: Up on the screen was the principal, Joe Clark, in the person of Morgan Freeman, the actor, storming through Eastside High School, keeping order with his trademark bullhorn and baseball bat.

title: Profits Scoreboard
The Hellinger Theater Is Leased to a Church
description: The Nederlander organization has rented the Mark Hellinger Theater to the Times Square Church for five years for $1 million a year, James M. Nederlander, the organization's chairman, said yesterday. The Hellinger has long been considered one of the best and most beautiful theaters for presenting Broadway musicals.

title: Seeing Eye to Eye
description: President Bush may lack a Republican majority in the House and Senate, but a majority of the senior staff members in both bodies are in harmony with his views on major issues, a survey shows.

title: A Jewish Center, Officially Approved, Will Open in Moscow
description: More than 100 Jews from around the world are planning to be in Moscow next week for the opening of the Soviet Union's first officially sanctioned Jewish cultural center.

title: GTE Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After one-time gains of $26 million, or 8 cents a share, related to pension settlements and a sale of real estate.

title: Brand Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and the year is after a gain of $1,088,000 from an accounting change.

title: Pepperell-Farley
description: West-Point Pepperell Inc. said it had agreed to provide non-public data to Farley Inc. on the condition that Farley, which has made an unsolicited $1.5 billion offer for the textile giant, keep it confidential.

title: Lee Goode Kingsley, Publicity Associate, 80
description: Lee Goode Kingsley, who worked in the New York music world for many years, was killed on Jan. 30 by a hit-and-run motorist at 67th Street and Broadway. She was 80 years old.

title: Nothing Progressive in Catastrophic-Cost Law; Nursing-Home Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Keeping the Pickle Crunchy
description: Since man first tossed cucumbers in brine - and savored the sour results - the pickle business has not exactly sparkled with technical innovation. But now a researcher for the Department of Agriculture has developed a patented process to make kosher dills keep their crunch. Some say the development could amount to a small revolution for the $400 million industry.

title: Withholding Tax Plan on Investments Is Likely in Europe
description: The European Commission, the executive branch of the European Community, is expected to propose on Wednesday a minimum withholding tax on interest and dividend income on investments that the community's citizens make in community nations other than their own.

title:
BUSINESS DIGEST;
President's Job Is Filled At Film-Making Group
description: LEAD: Charles J. Weber, an independent film industry consultant who has run the production companies of George Lucas and Norman Lear, has joined the Management Company Entertainment Group as president. the company's chairman and chief executive, Jonathan D. Krane, said yesterday.

title: Topics of The Times; Clio's Friend
description: To some academic historians, Barbara Tuchman was flawed. She lacked a Ph.D., and indeed had not been improved by any graduate education. Unforgivably, her books - at least six of them - were best sellers. But she wrote superlatively, with a strong narrative line, and brought ancient controversies and forgotten leaders back to life.

title: Review/Film; Visions of a Psychopath
description: ''Rorret,'' Fulvio Wetzl's Italian film opening today at Film Forum 1, is terror spelled backward. It's also the name of the central character, the sort of shy, fastidious psychopath once played by Peter Lorre.

title: Pretoria Asks U.S. Aid on Mozambique Peace
description: South Africa has asked the United States to help broker a peace settlement in Mozambique, Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha said today.

title: Reporter's Notebook; This Was No Day for a House Party
description: There are few things quite so ugly as the collapse of a complicated legislative deal. That the deal was supposed to produce a 51 percent pay increase for the legislators only adds to the irritability.

title: Kitty Dukakis Will Be Busy In Treatment
description: Kitty Dukakis will undergo a strict regimen of group therapy, individual counseling and alcohol education in her four-week stay at Edgehill Newport, the drug and alcohol rehabilitation center in Newport, R.I., that she checked into Sunday.

title: Salomon Has Deficit In Quarter
description: Salomon Inc. yesterday reported a fourth-quarter loss despite a record performance in its energy business.

title: Defendant Gets 30 Years in Jail In Bombing Plot
description: A Japanese national described by Federal authorities as one of the first international terrorists caught and convicted in the United States was sentenced today to 30 years in prison for possession of three pellet-laden bombs.

title: Bush Seeks to Tie Military Budget To Rate of Inflation in Next Year
description: President Bush, in a challenge to Congress to set new budget priorities, will propose Thursday that military spending in the next fiscal year rise only enough to keep pace with inflation, Administration officials said today.

title: MCI Complaint on Award
description: In a move that could delay the replacement of the Federal Government's telephone system, the MCI Communications Corporation has protested the General Services Administration's award of a $25 billion contract to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the U S Sprint Communications Corporation.

title: Penny-Stock Brokerage Is Barred
description: A national penny-stock brokerage has been temporarily banned from soliciting business in New York State because of suspicions that it has defrauded thousands of investors, the State Attorney General, Robert Abrams, announced yesterday.

title: South African Prison Strike
description: Nearly 200 black detainees, some held without charge for nearly three years, are staging a hunger strike to demand their freedom, parents of the prisoners said today. All 191 detainess at Diepkloof Prison in Soweto, the huge black township outside Johannesburg, have stopped eating, parents of some detainees told reporters. The strikers are among the approximately 1,000 prisoners still held without charge under the 32-month emergency decree.

title: Back to the Basics At a Catskills Bakery
description: IN the office of Bread Alone, a bakery in the Catskills village of Boiceville, about 90 miles north of Manhattan, there is a color photograph of two smiling men standing waist-deep in a sunny North Dakota wheat field, an ''America the Beautiful'' kind of scene that brings ''amber waves of grain'' immediately to mind.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: FOUR years ago, Bud and Mary Farmer sold their 100-acre apple orchard near this old gold-mining town about 60 miles from San Diego, and went full time into the retail end of the apple business. It was a change for Mr. Farmer, whose family settled in this mountainous rural community in 1884, but was in keeping with the evolution of Julian itself, from a sleepy community to an attraction for tourists.

title: Licenses Sold for Research With New Protein
description: The Cambridge Bioscience Corporation said yesterday that four health-care companies had acquired the right to use a patented protein in developing new diagnostic tests, vaccines and therapies for AIDS.

title: Nothing Progressive in Catastrophic-Cost Law; Break for Corporations
description: To the Editor:

title: As Power Wanes for Kollek, A Dream for Jerusalem Fades
description: Two things seem fairly certain about Jerusalem's municipal elections this month. First, Mayor Teddy Kollek is likely to win re-election. But second, he will probably lose control of the City Council - and also lose his 22-year struggle to bring Arab and Jewish Jerusalem closer together.

title: Injunction Remains Against MAI Basic
description: A Federal judge said he would continue to block MAI Basic Four Inc.'s $1.3 billion offer for Prime Computer Inc. because Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., which is helping to finance the bid, did not provide all the information sought by the court.

title: San Jose, That Upstart in Hinterland, Takes On San Francisco
description: From San Francisco, 50 miles northwest of here and separated by cultural and historical light-years, San Jose seems an unlikely challenger.

title: Excerpts From U.S. Report on Israelis and Arabs
description: Following are excerpts from the State Department's report on the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, compiled for ''Country Reports on Human Rights Practices for 1988.''

title: Soviets Evasive on Continued Afghan Bombing
description: Soviet officials refused today to rule out continued bombing of Afghan territory from air bases in the Soviet Union after their troop withdrawal is completed.

title: American Cyanamid Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $11,600,000. The share earnings in 1987 included a gain of about 13 cents a share from the sale of the Jacqueline Cochran fine fragrance and skin care businesses and 13 cents a share associated with the 1985 divestment of the Formica brand products business. Sales represent worldwide sales.

title: Democrats Clash Over Cuomo's Budget
description: New York's top Democratic officials today broke ranks over the state budget, accusing each other of mishandling the state's tremendous fiscal problems.

title: Charles Z. Offin, 90, Artist and Art Patron
description: Charles Z. Offin, an artist, publisher and art patron, died Sunday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 90 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Reviews/Music; Skrowaczewski Leads
description: The conductor and composer Stanislaw Skrowaczewski led the American Composers Orchestra in three works, including his own Concerto for Orchestra (1986), on Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. All three were in an abidingly conservative idiom; in fact, the oldest, William Schuman's Violin Concerto (1950), did not sound appreciably older than the most recent, Aaron Jay Kernis's ''Invisible Mosaic III'' (1988).

title: Eating Well
description: Increasing poverty among children in the United States has generated such concern among educators that the National Education Association has released a report documenting the deleterious effects of hunger on a child's ability to learn.

title: Charles W. Dow, 82; Headed Equitable Life
description: Charles W. Dow, a former president of the Equitable Life Insurance Society of the United States and a former chairman of the finance committee of the CIT Financial Corporation, died of pneumonia Tuesday at the Hilaire Farm Nursing Home in Huntington, L.I., where he had been a patient for several years. He was 82 years old and lived in Northport, L.I.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: VALENTINE'S DAY My love stirs in the breeze Like the paper hearts Strung along the ceiling Of the stationery store. My love's a lacy heart Packed with neat rows Of extravagant treats. Accept my heart - and bite The crisp exterior To reach the marshmallow Beating inside. - LEWIS GARDNER Dear Diary:

title: Ruiz Fights To Put Off His Removal
description: State officials are grappling with an arcane question of law that State Senator Israel Ruiz Jr., who was convicted of a Federal felony last week, hopes will allow him to remain in office.

title: Rubbermaid Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Sales represent net sales.

title: First Executive Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included investment gains of $411,000 and $8,000,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-After investment losses of $3,481,000 for the quarter and investment gains of $4,012,000 for the year.

title: Environmental Treatment & Technologies Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: LESSONS
description: Everyone agrees that improved public schools are important in helping American industry compete with the rest of the world. A visit to Ford Motor Company plants and offices in and around Dearborn suggests that the reverse may be true as well.

title: Zagat Restaurant Guides: Whose Voice Is Being Heard?
description: WITHOUT a doubt, Tim and Nina Zagat have made it in the food world. Their restaurant guides to eight urban areas - with more to come in the spring - are rapidly gaining influence and circulation. The New York guide, which started as a single-sheet summary 10 years ago, sold nearly 200,000 copies last year, making it the top-selling restaurant book in the city. Excerpts from Zagat guides appear repeatedly in newspapers and magazines. The current issue of Cook's magazine, for instance, summarizes many of their findings and describes the books as ''America's best guides'' to eating out.

title: A Sequel to Earth Day Planned in April 1990
description: The first Earth Day, April 22, 1970, hailed as the birthday of modern environmentalism, is going to have a sequel in 1990 that organizers hope will dwarf the original.

title: Inter-Regional Financial Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $112,000 for the quarter and $881,000 for the year from repurchase of debt. c-Net income and after tax credits of $306,000 for the quarter and $3.2 million for the year.

title: Cyanide-Poison Victim Dies
description: A 17-year-old boy who lapsed into a coma after eating cyanide-tainted yogurt Jan. 3 died today after he was disconnected from life-support equipment, his family's lawyer said. The youth, Thomas Lee, of Haddonfield, died at 10:33 A.M. at West Jersey Hospital-Voorhees. Police have investigated the possibilities that Mr. Lee committed suicide, that he was murdered or that the yogurt was tampered with anonymously, although they have all but dismissed that possibility.

title: Home Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After realized investment losses of $3.8 million for the quarter and realized investment gains of $6.1 million for the year. c-After realized investment losses of $14.8 million for the quarter and realized investment gains of $53 million for the year. The 1988 net from operations included a net charge of $13 million from a special addition to loan loss reserves by Home Group's Canadian unit, the Commonwealth Insurance Co. Results reflected those of Carteret Bancorp Inc. from its acquisition in August 1988 and Gruntal Financial Corp. from its acquisition in August 1987.

title: To Jamaica's Vote Forecaster, More Than Slings and Arrows
description: As Jamaica prepares for elections this week, one of the most talked about people in the capital is a university professor and political polltaker named Carl Stone.

title: Security Firms Hired to Check Albany Offices
description: The New York State Comptroller and the Assembly Speaker, both of whom are under investigation, have hired private companies at public expense to upgrade security at their offices, state officials said today.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Treasury Prices Move Higher
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved higher yesterday, initially spurred by a successful auction of new three-year notes that included strong participation by Japanese investors.

title: Holy Deadlock In the Kitchen
description: WHAT is it about cooking together that makes some otherwise happily married couples agree to disagree in the kitchen?

title: Another Backward Slider
description: Alvin T. of Mattoon, Illinois, writes that he is 11 years old, wants to be a consultant when he grows up, and asks which colleges have the best courses in consulting.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: COD has always seemed suitable to cold-weather cooking, since it thrives in the icy North Atlantic and is harvested year round.

title: In Confirmation Process, Hearings Offer a Stage
description: Pamela J. Turner, a lobbyist for the White House in the Reagan Administration, compares the Senate's confirmation of Presidential appointees to a stage play. ''A thousand things go on backstage that the whole world does not necessarily see,'' she said.

title: PepsiCo Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included net from discontinued operations of $2.5 million for the quarter; the year included a loss from discontinued operations of $10.3 million. Year-ago figures have been reclassified to report under equity method for accounting certain previously consolidated bottling operations contributed to joint ventures in early 1988. Discontinued operations reflected the sale of La Petite Boulangerie Inc. retail bakery operations in March 1987. The company said 1988 earnings included a $14.5 million charge related to the reorganization of the domestic soft drink business and a $9.4 million loss resulting from the sale of a foreign winery. Earnings for 1987 included a $10.3 million gain resulting from the sale of a company-owned foreign bottling operation. Results for 1987 also included a $12.5 million favorable adjustment to a 1986 charge, primarily reflecting a $10 million gain resulting from the sale of a cookie manufacturing facility. The 1986 charge of $52 million at Frito-Lay related to the discontinuance of certain non-salty snack products and reduction of cookie production capacity. Results for 1987 also included a $7.5 million gain resulting from the sale of certain foreign pizza restaurants and an $8 million charge related to the reorganization of Kentucky Fried Chicken's domestic operations. The latest periods were comprised of 17 weeks for the quarter and 53 weeks in the year, compared with 16 weeks and 52 weeks for same periods, respectively.

title: Offering by New York City To Include Taxable Bonds
description: New York City tapped the debt market with a $746.8 million issue of general obligation bonds yesterday and for the first time the city included taxable bonds in a financing.

title: Cummins Engine Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter and year included pretax charges of $50,500,000 and $49,000,000, respectively, related to the disposition of certain products and operations, and finalization of restructuring activities.

title: Infatuation With Things Australian Now Turns to Notable Wines
description: LET an Australian reveal his nationality at a party these days and someone is almost bound to mention the terrific Aussie wines just discovered at the neighborhood liquor store. And for less than $10 a bottle, too.

title: A Lasting Gift
description: A friend presented Samuel K. Skinner, the new Secretary of Transportation, with a toy aircraft yesterday, greatly pleasing the Secretary, an aviation enthusiast who is a licensed pilot.

title: A Lot of Hit Songs From an Unsung Lyricist
description: The most prolific and versatile lyricist to be represented on Broadway this season remains virturally unknown, his name buried in the fine print of the Playbill song credits for ''Ain't Misbehavin''' and ''Black and Blue.''

title: Della Femina Releases First Ads for Pan Am
description: Less than three months after making its first presentation to what was then a prospective client, Della Femina, McNamee WCRS has released its first television ad for Pan American World Airways. The spot features children and was filmed at the Day School on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. Jerry Della Femina, the agency's chairman, said the ''real people'' approach, which was part of the shop's original pitch to Pan Am, wouls be maintained throughout the campaign.

title: Emerson Electric Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Transactions
description: BASEBALL CINCINNATI (NL) - Agreed to terms with John Franco, pitcher, on a one-year contract. Signed Chris Hammond, pitcher, and Lenny Harris, infielder, to one-year contracts. MILWAUKEE (AL) - Signed Tim Watkins and Mark Knudson, pitchers, and Greg Vaughn, outfielder, to one-year contracts. Named Del Crandall a scout. MINNESOTA (AL) - Agreed to terms with Doug Baker, infielder, on a one-year contract. PITTSBURGH (NL) - Purchased the contract of Rick Reed, pitcher, from Buffalo of the American Association. Agreed to terms with Bob Kipper, pitcher, on a one-year contract. BASKETBALL MILWAUKEE (NBA) - Signed Tony Brown, guard-forward, to a 10-day contract. NETS (NBA) - Placed John Bagley, guard, on the injured list. Signed Corey Gaines, guard, to a 10-day contract.

title: Centex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $50,100,000 from an accounting change.

title: Turning Point Has Arrived for Trenary
description: A year ago, she was thrilled to place fourth in the Calgary Olympics. Jill Trenary had not expected to win a medal anyway, so finishing behind Katarina Witt of East Germany, Elizabeth Manley of Canada and Debi Thomas, the American champion, was hardly a disappointment.

title:
Market Place;
Bullish Approach To Savings Units
description: LEAD: With all the tumult over the nation's savings and loan industry, many investors might think it a good time to sell the stock of savings institutions. They might be wrong. While the Bush Administration's $90 billion plan to rescue the savings industry may blur the distinctions between savings associations and commercial banks, some experts believe that well-run savings institutions will prosper.

title: Reliance Group Holdings Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Latest quarter and year results included a charge of $37.4 million from the writeoff of a subordinated note in a Texas savings and loan association. Latest-quarter's pretax losses on sales of investments of $40,527,000 included the $37.4 million aftertax charge from the writeoff of the subordinated note in the Texas savings and loan. Latest-year's pretax losses on sales of investments of $12,635,000 also included that aftertax charge. Year-ago quarter results included pretax losses on sales of investments of $2,519,000. Prior-year results included pretax gains on the sales of investments of $42,184,000. It also included pretax gains of $22.9 million on the sale of office buildings and a gain of $7 million from the sale of certain management consulting operations.

title: Gifts to the Neediest Honor New York as Host
description: A United Nations staff member from the Netherlands, Dirk Salomons, expressed appreciation for New York as a host city with a contribution to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: 2 Black Former Stars Hope Bill White's Job Is a Start
description: Two black members of baseball's Hall of Fame, both former teammates of Bill White, said yesterday that White's selection as president of the National League was ''a milestone'' in race relations. But both said the full impact could not be judged until it became clear that White was not alone as a black executive in the major leagues.

title: Nothing Progressive in Catastrophic-Cost Law; Taxation by Age Group
description: To the Editor:

title: Schlumberger Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $22,287,000, or 9 cents a share. c-Included a $220,000,000 loss on discontinued operations and a $70,080,000 extraordinary gain. Latest-year results included gain of $35,000,000, or 13 cents a share, from the sale of the electricity control and transformers division of Schlumberger Industries. Year-ago quarter and year results included gain of $222,000,000, or 80 cents a share, from favorable settlement of a tax case; the year also included a gain of $69,000,000, or 25 cents a share, on the sale of the company's investment in Compagnie Luxembourgeoise de Telediffusion.

title: Kean Proposes Concert Hall For Newark
description: Gov. Thomas H. Kean announced plans today to build the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra a permanent home, a concert hall here that would be the first phase of a state performing arts center he proposed 18 months ago.

title: DeSoto Rejects $50-a-Share Offer
description: DeSoto Inc. said it had rejected an unsolicited offer of $50 a share contained in a letter from the investor William Spier. The chemical-coating maker said it did not intend to pursue talks with Mr. Spier.

title: Lent's Start Finds Fasting Still Has a Religious Role
description: Wearing hair shirts and sleeping on bare boards have become historical oddities, at least in most societies, but the start of Lent today is a reminder that one ancient practice of religious self-denial, fasting, keeps its hold in the modern world.

title:
Capital Gains Tax: Kind or Unkind Cut?;
We Can't Afford Not To
description: LEAD: The capital gains tax -what you pay on the difference between the price you paid for a corporate stock, farm, small business, family home, and the price you sold it for -is an important tax. Because taxpayers are very sensitive to its rate, it can directly and broadly affect the economy. Indeed, high rates dramatically reduce investment in new ventures, diminish international competitiveness, impede technological innovation and actually reduce

title: Tentative Praise From Texas Savings Industry
description: President Bush's sweeping plan to restore the savings industry to financial health drew tentative endorsements today from investors, executives and industry advisers in Texas, where the losses have been the most severe.

title: Nothing Progressive in Catastrophic-Cost Law; Who's Affluent?
description: To the Editor:

title: Man Freed in Queens Triple Slaying
description: At 8:45 P.M. on June 4, 1987, a lone robber took about $1,000 at a Queens liquor store, forced the two owners and a customer into a tiny bathroom at the rear and killed each one with a bullet in the head.

title: Joseph T.P. Sullivan, Lawyer, Is Dead at 93
description: Joseph T. P. Sullivan, a lawyer long active in Democratic politics in New York City, died of heart failure Sunday in his apartment at the Yale Club in Manhattan. He was 93 years old.

title: G.O.P. Senator Joins Race to Replace Kean
description: State Senator Gerald Cardinale announced today that he will seek the Republican nomination to succeed Gov. Thomas H. Kean. Dr. Cardinale's announcement came one day after Cary Edwards, the former State Attorney General, said that he would seek the Republican nomination. Mr. Edwards was the first candidate to announce for the June 6 primary.

title: Researchers Pick Buffalo And Rutgers
description: The State University of New York at Buffalo and Rutgers University in New Brusnwick, N.J., have been elected to the Association of American Universities, a group of the leading research universities in the United States and Canada.

title: German Company May Seek Scherer
description: A West German concern that holds a 6.8 percent stake in the R. P. Scherer Corporation said it was investigating the company's financial data with the intention of making an offer for the Troy, Mich., gelatin capsule maker.

title: Books of The Times; Robeson: A Triumphant Life Turned to Agony
description: Paul Robeson By Martin Bauml Duberman Illustrated. 804 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95

title: Downey Savings & Loan Assn reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included net gains of about $5.9 million, or 55 cents a share, from the sale of securities and real estate.

title: LOS ANGELES BANS RAPID-FIRING GUNS
description: After a noisy one-hour hearing, the City Council of Los Angeles voted today to ban the sale or possession of semi-automatic weapons. The vote was 12 to 0.

title: Stacy V. Jones, 93, Author, Dies; Wrote Times's Column on Patents
description: Stacy V. Jones, who for 36 years wrote a weekly column in The New York Times on newly issued patents, died Monday at his home in Falls Church, Va. He was 93 years old.

title: Big Orders Give a Lift To McDonnell Douglas
description: Just six years ago, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation's jet transport business was so grim that its executives were talking about withdrawing from the commercial airplane market and ceding the business to the Boeing Company, the industry giant.

title: 2 TOP DEMOCRATS READY TO OPPOSE TOWER NOMINATION
description: John G. Tower's chances to become Secretary of Defense were further damaged today when the two top Democrats on the Senate Armed Services Committee turned against his nomination.

title: EG&G Inc reports earnings for 13wks to Jan 1
description: The company said the prior fourth quarter and year results have been restated to reflect acquisitions accounted for on a pooling of interest basis.

title: Kansas Gas & Electric Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results for the year-ago periods were restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: Gulf Canada Resources Ltd reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The 1988 net equaled less than 1 cent a share after preferred share dividends. This is the company's first full year of operations. It was created July 1, 1987 following a reorganization of its predecessor, Gulf Canada Corp. For the 6 months ended Dec. 31, 1987, the company had net income of $98 million, or 47 cents a share, which included a special gain of $12 million. Revenue totaled $445 million. The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: End of High-Tech Sales Ban on Moscow Weighed
description: The Bush Administration has begun an interagency review to consider lifting controls on the sale of high-technology items to Moscow, the State Department announced today. The controls were imposed after Soviet troops went into Afghanistan in 1979.

title: Nicaraguan Sees Revival of Arias Plan at U.N.
description: The Nicaraguan Foreign Minister said today that Central American countries appear ready to move ahead with their long-stalled regional peace plan. Officials from five nations are to meet Wednesday and Thursday at the United Nations.

title: Dow Rises 26.07, to 2,347.14; G.M. a Factor
description: After four days of declines, stock prices rebounded strongly yesterday as blue-chip issues rallied. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 26.07 points, or 1.12 percent, to 2,347.14, another post-crash high.

title: Joseph S. Breen, Educator, 70
description: The Rev. Joseph S. Breen, a vice president of St. John's University, died, apparently of a heart attack, Monday night at his home at the university in Jamaica, Queens. He was 70 years old.

title: Topics of The Times; Mr. Lauder's Money
description: New York City elections have long suffered from a lack of real Republican competition. The mayoral candidacy of former Ambassador Ronald Lauder, and the chance that former U.S. Attorney Rudolph Giuliani may also run, could finally restore healthy two-party rivalry. What's decidedly unwelcome, however, is Mr. Lauder's refusal to participate in the city's new public campaign finance system.

title: Embattled Soviet Islamic Leader Quits Post
description: The Islamic leader of Soviet Central Asia resigned today in the face of a highly unusual public challenge from critics who accused him of failing to live up to strict Muslim discipline.

title: 2 Admirals Are Named to Battle Drug Smuggling
description: Two Coast Guard admirals will lead sweeping joint military efforts to stop drug smuggling on the Atlantic and Pacific coasts, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Judge's Suicide: Town Searches Its Soul
description: Superior Court Judge Richard C. Noren's life was a tableau of small-town virtues and vices. He was a regular at the Saturday-night spaghetti dinners held by the North Woodstock Country Store and Restaurant. He often worked weekends at the courthouse preparing for cases, and he presided over meetings of the local historical society. A 47-year-old Harvard-educated bachelor, he lived alone after the death of his mother and sometimes, people say, he drank too much.

title: Tax Code, Simpler for Most, Is Now Harder for Investors
description: For investors, the reporting of income has grown far more complicated, and for many, tax liabilities have risen as a result of the nation's new tax laws, even though the Reagan Administration and Congressional supporters promised individual tax cuts and simplicity.

title: Shultz Named To G.M. Board
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it had named George P. Shultz as an outside director, a position he had held for slightly more than a year when he resigned to become Secretary of State in 1982.

title: Nothing Progressive in Catastrophic-Cost Law; Wealthy Pay Less
description: To the Editor:

title: Pact for Reds' Franco
description: John Franco, the Cincinnati Reds relief pitcher who led the National League with 39 saves last season, avoided arbitration when he agreed yesterday to a one-year contract worth $1.067 million.(AP)

title: Williams Telecommunications to Buy Lightnet
description: The Williams Telecommunications Group, a fast-growing digital telecommunications company, said today that it had signed an agreement to acquire Lightnet, another fiber-optics company, for about $365 million.

title: About New York; 80's Book Party: Models, Money And No Author
description: Those who follow this column are doubtless aware of its high literary mission. No surprise, then, that we fired off a positive reply upon receiving an invitation to a book party held Monday night at Au Bar, the trendy club at 41 East 58th Street.

title: 18 Prisoners Suffocate in Brazil; 51 Locked in a 4-by-10-Foot Cell
description: Eighteen prisoners were asphyxiated and died Sunday when Sao Paulo policemen forced 51 naked inmates into a tiny cell, police officials and human rights workers say.

title: India Believes in Global Path to Nonproliferation
description: To the Editor:

title: Swastikas and Star Painted On Ben-Gurion's Tombstone
description: Vandals painted swastikas and a Star of David on the tombstone of David Ben-Gurion, Israel's founding father and first Prime Minister, an official at the memorial site said today.

title: Frank J. Emblen, 49, An Editor at The Times
description: Frank J. Emblen, a copy editor for the metropolitan desk of The New York Times, was killed last night when his car went out of control and crashed on Route 3 in Clifton, N.J., the police said.

title: GTE Income Off 2.4% in Quarter
description: The GTE Corporation said yesterday that its net income in the fourth quarter declined 2.4 percent, to $326 million, or 96 cents a share, from $334 million, or 99 cents a share, in the comparable 1987 period. Revenues rose to $4.3 billion from $4.1 billion a year ago.

title: 2 Captives, One an American, Are Freed by Colombia Police
description: The police rescued a Colombian industrialist and an American today, 11 days after they were abducted in this western city, but their captors fled, the authorities said.

title: Early Spring for 8
description: Eight Yankee players already were in camp yesterday, in a special workout program for players coming back from injuries.

title: Review/Dance; Exploring the Grimmer Facts of Life
description: Ralph Lemon and Company danced two elegies Sunday afternoon at the Bessie Schonberg Theater. Mr. Lemon's new ''Sleep'' began mysteriously when a nude woman walked between the rungs of a ladder that had been laid flat on the floor. The rest of the work consisted of anguished movements for Chris Kaufman, Hetty King, Ted Marks, Kelly McDonald, Michael Nolan and Nancy Ohrenstein. Wearing simple costumes by Kay Stuntz, they thrashed through choreographic sequences that acknowledged such grim facts of life as suffering, loss and mortality itself.

title: Stock Holdings Disqualify Thornburgh From Cases
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh's extensive holdings in blue-chip stocks have forced him to remove himself from a variety of legal and policy issues since he took office in August, records show.

title: Eating Well; School Lunches Need Not Be Feared
description: THE National Education Association report recommends that teachers, school officials and other school employees work in their schools to improve participation in lunch and breakfast programs. The report provides these practical suggestions for improving school programs:

title: Gretzky Sparks Campbell Stars
description: He began the night introduced in a shroud of artificial smoke, whereupon he was promptly drowned in waves of genuine applause. But when everything cleared - the special effects and the audience's eyes -Wayne Gretzky stood and played as he always has: dominant from start to finish.

title: There's No Energy Crisis Brewing
description: LEAD: Since oil prices collapsed in the fall of 1986, critics have been warning that there is poison in the nectar of low prices. We will pay dearly, they maintain, in another energy crisis -the third in two decades.

title: Household International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $16.5 million for the quarter and $63 million for the year. c-After income from discontinued operations of $11.1 million for the quarter and $57.5 million for the year. The company said that as a result of its plan to spin off a portion of its manufacturing operations and sell the remaining units, results for Household Manufacturing for all periods are included in discontinued operations.

title: On the Go
description: President Bush, seemingly intent on becoming one of the most peripatetic Presidents, is hurtling around Washington to swear in his Cabinet.

title: Canada Oil Drilling Up
description: Petroleum drilling activity in western Canada is increasing at a modest rate, an oil industry group reported today. The Canadian Association of Oilwell Drilling Contractors said the number of rigs working for the week ended today rose to 206, out of 528 available, from 191 the previous week. The association earlier forecast an average 250 rigs would be active in the first quarter. At this time last year, 359 out of 558 rigs in western Canada were active.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: FOR Richard Johnson, an administrator at the University of Vermont here, the words ''soul food'' conjure up the cuisine of black Americans who ''made a celebration of being together to share in a meal.''

title: Nashua Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Salomon Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest quarter and year results included a special $180 million income tax provision related to the company's decision to remit certain foreign earnings to the U.S. and to provide U.S. taxes on an additional amount of foreign earnings no longer considered to be indefinitely invested outside the U.S. Results for 1987 included a $100 million charge from terminating the company's interest in the New York City Coliseum project and a net $7 million charge relating to the restructuring of the securities segment business, and related tax benefits of $49 million. The company said its pretax earnings for the year were bolstered by the energy segment's record earnings of $245 million, up from the $70 million in 1987. The securities segment's earnings of $486 million were up from 1987, when it earned $261 million.

title: Nothing Progressive in Catastrophic-Cost Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Israelis Dispute Charge by U.S. Of Rights Abuse
description: Israel said today that it saw no merit in the United States' assertion that there had been ''a substantial increase in human rights violations'' as a result of Israel's response to the Palestinian uprising in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.

title: Review/Recital; New York Debut For a Flutist
description: Joseph Piscitelli, a flutist, made his New York debut at Weill Recital Hall on Sunday afternoon. In works by Telemann, Enesco, Dutilleux and Prokofiev, he played with an attractive, well-focused tone and a great deal of inherent musicality. He also offered the premiere of a work composed for him, Glen Cortese's Variations.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Bucks 115, Cavaliers 106: Terry Cummings scored 31 points and Ricky Pierce had 10 of his 24 in the fourth quarter last night as Milwaukee rallied with a late 13-4 run at home. The Bucks have with 19 victories in their last 23 games. The Cavaliers were led by Brad Daugherty with 28 points and Mark Price with 20.(AP) Jazz 96, Heat 77: Karl Malone scored 26 points and John Stockton added 20 and had 9 assists as host Utah snapped a two-game losing streak. (AP) Bulls 118, Hornets 93: Michael Jordan scored 14 of his 32 points in the final 7:03 of the third quarter for the Bulls at home. (AP) HORSE RACING 150th Steeplechase Victory: Peter Scudamore became the first jockey to win 150 steeplechase races in a single British season yesterday. In his first outing of the day, in the Ryton Novices Hurdle at Warwick, the 30-year-old rider finished first by 10 lengths on Anti Matter. He bettered Jonjo O'Neill's 11-year-old mark of 149 winners. In the next race, Scudamore won on Pertemps Network to put his victory total at 151. With 17 weeks of the season left, Scudamore needs only 7 winners to become the third British steeplechaser to record 1,000 victories, following Stan Mellor and Francombe. (AP) TENNIS Mecir Is Beaten: Top-seeded Miloslav Mecir suffered a humiliating first-round defeat yesterday in the $425,500 Rotterdam tournament in the Netherlands, falling to Patrick Kuehnen, 7-5, 6-1. Mecir, the defending champion, went down in an uninspired match against the West German, who took advantage of Mecir's sloppy game. Marty Davis of Harbor Bay Isle, Calif., ousted the No. 4 seed, Jonas Svensson of Sweden, 6-2, 6-4. (AP)

title: Hopping In, Tuning Out and Turning Off
description: FLOTATION tanks, once associated with sensory-deprivation experiments in the 1950's and a decade later, with psychedelic self-realization schemes, have become increasingly popular tools to combat pain and reduce stress.

title: Nerco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge on the prepayment of notes of $9,100,000.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Management Systems Inc., Arlington, Va., a computer consulting concern, said Ivan Selin would retire as chairman to accept an appointment as Under Secretary of State for management.

title: Flaws in Health Care System Emerge as Epidemic Rages
description: The changing AIDS epidemic is exposing gaps and weaknesses throughout the nation's health care system as growing multitudes of patients need a wider array of services.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-16

title: Vermont College and Bronx School Collaborate to Lure Minority Pupils
description: Middlebury College, the small, select liberal arts college in Vermont, sent 10 of its faculty and admissions staff members to De Witt Clinton High School in New York City on Monday to spur more students from the Bronx school to consider going to Middlebury.

title: Conner Leads Nets Past Sonics
description: Even before tonight's game began, Lester Conner knew he was in for a challenge. Conner has the flu and his backup at point guard, John Bagley, was placed on the injured list by the Nets earlier in the day with a severely sprained left ankle. That meant Conner would get all the playing time he wanted against the Seattle SuperSonics. Maybe more than he wanted. It also meant that for New Jersey to win, Conner would have to play well.

title: Food With a Hint of Licorice: Good for More Than a Lick
description: CHILDREN munch Good and Plenty candies at the movies, and adults sip sambuca after dinner. Licorice flavors are enjoyed by young and old, and the attraction is growing.

title: Green Talks to Bronx Board
description: The New York City Schools Chancellor, Dr. Richard R. Green, held a formal meeting today with the members of Community School Board 12 in the Bronx, a step that is a legal precursor to suspending the board and replacing it with trustees.

title: BANK REGULATORS ASSUMING CONTROL OF 4 SAVINGS UNITS
description: Moving swiftly to carry out the first phase of President Bush's plan for the savings and loan crisis, bank regulators announced today that they had assumed control of four insolvent savings associations with total assets of $5.6 billion.

title: Ah, the Simpler Life!
description: Sheila Tate, who was Nancy Reagan's press secretary and served in the campaign and transition period as George Bush's spokeswoman, has no regrets about not being in the White House.

title: Salvadoran Rebels Add Cease-Fire to Election Plan
description: Leftist guerrillas widened their recent peace offer today by proposing a 60-day cease-fire if the elections are postponed, as the rebels suggested last month.

title: The Best From Down Under Is Close at Hand
description: NOW that there are scores of estimable Australian wines available at wine shops, often at attractive prices, deciding what to buy can be a challenge. Rather than taking a scattershot approach, it is best to start by focusing on a few important categories.

title: Fedders Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax benefits of $2,639,000 and $7,042,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included tax benefits of $1,167,000 for the quarter and $5,356,000 for the year.

title: Knicks Get Big Boost From Oakley's Effort
description: For the Madison Square Garden crowd of 19,452, Patrick Ewing was the visible hero last night, with his 12 points in the final quarter being chiefly responsible for the Knicks' 117-105 victory over the Washington Bullets.

title: PARAGUAY'S CHIEF SHAKES UP ARMY
description: Paraguay's new ruler, Gen. Andres Rodriguez, consolidated his grip on power today by shaking up the top military command and virtually securing the Government party's nomination for presidential elections here May 1.

title: U.S. JUDGES BITTER OVER RAISE DEFEAT
description: Federal judges interviewed today reacted bitterly to the Congressional disapproval of their long-sought pay increase, saying it would further erode judicial morale and drive younger judges off the bench.

title: J. Henry Neale, 84, a Lawyer and Banker
description: J. Henry Neale, a lawyer and banker, died of a stroke Monday at White Plains Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived in Scarsdale.

title: Teaching How to Protect Children From Abuse and Neglect
description: To the Editor:

title: Hanson Raises Stake in Cummins
description: Hanson P.L.C. has raised its stake in the Cummins Engine Company to 9.79 percent from 8.32 percent and said that it had received Government permission to increase its stake in the nation's largest diesel engine manufacturer to as much as 15 percent. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Hanson, a British conglomerate, said it had bought the additional shares for an average $64.27 a share.

title: The Pop Life
description: New Label, Old Hands

title: Bush Won't Block Chip Unit's Sale
description: President Bush has decided not to block the sale of the Monsanto Company's semiconductor subsidiary to one of the largest chemical companies in West Germany, the White House said today.

title: New Albany Audits Collect $28 Million From 12 Tax Cheats
description: A random, computer-assisted investigation of wealthy New York State taxpayers claiming to live outside the state has found that the first 12 people audited all were falsely filing as out-of-state residents, officials said today. That has resulted in the collection of $28 million in back taxes.

title: Consumers' Debt Rose $5.4 Billion in December
description: Americans took on $5.4 billion more debt than they paid off in December as consumer credit grew at an annual rate of 9.9 percent.

title: Lionel Newman, 73, Winner of an Oscar As a Film Composer
description: Lionel Newman, who composed, conducted or supervised the scores of more than 250 movies, including ''Hello, Dolly!'', for which he won an Academy Award, died of a heart attack Friday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center. He was 73 years old. Mr. Newman's 11 Oscar nominations included those for scoring the music of such films as ''Doctor Doolittle,'' ''Mardi Gras,'' ''Let's Make Love'' and ''The Pleasure Seekers.'' He also wrote the score for ''Love Me Tender,'' in which Elvis Presley made his film debut, and conducted the scores for ''Cleopatra,'' ''Planet of the Apes'' and ''The Omen.'' He shared the Academy Award with Lennie Hayton for the musical adaptation of Jerry Herman's score for ''Hello, Dolly!,'' the 1969 movie that starred Barbra Streisand. Played Piano for Mae West

title: Eaton Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included net from discontinued operations of $800,000 for the quarter and $2.3 million for the year, and the year also included a $17.7 million loss related to a jury award against the company. c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $18.1 million for the quarter and $5 million for the year. The company said the prior year net from continuing operations included a net gain of $4.4 million on the sale of the industrial polymer products operations.

title: Capital Cities/ABC Posts 20% Quarterly Profit Rise
description: Capital Cities/ABC Inc. yesterday reported a 20 percent rise in fourth-quarter earnings as poor performances at its ABC television network and publishing unit were offset by a strong gain at ESPN and its other broadcasting operations.

title: Citicorp Rates Increase Again
description: Interest rates rose yesterday at Citicorp's regular weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper.

title: The Dapper Touch: Handkerchief Elegance
description: ONE of the most practical items to pop up in some time is ''Fashion Folds for Men & Women,'' subtitled ''The Pocket Handkerchief Handbook.'' An 18-page illustrated paperback, ''Fashion Folds'' is crammed with information for those with a nose for knowledge of handkerchief history and etiquette.

title: Jacobs-Shaklee
description: An investment group led by the Minneapolis investor Irwin L. Jacobs has raised its stake in the Shaklee Corporation to 9.7 percent from 6.4 percent. In Securities and Exchange Commission filings, Mr. Jacobs said he had bought 383,900 more Shaklee shares for an average of $31.51 a share. Mr. Jacobs gave no reason for his additional stock purchases. Shaklee's shares gained 87.5 cents today, to $34.375, on the Big Board.

title: Airlines Report Rise In Late U.S. Flights
description: Late arrival of flights increased among major American airlines in the most recent monthly Government report, but the industry is still doing better than it was a year ago.

title: Service Is the Secret To a Hotel's New Self
description: LEAD: The secret to success, according to Stan Bromley, is a mantra that he chants into people's ears: ''Sufficiently inquiring mind.'' Mr. Bromley is not a holy man. He is a hotel man. And while his maxim doesn't assure enlightenment, it has encouraged the staff of the Four Seasons Clift Hotel here, where Mr.

title: Flyers' Brown to Oilers
description: The Philadelphia Flyers sent Dave Brown, a right wing, to the Edmonton Oilers yesterday for Keith Acton, a center, and an undetermined future draft pick.

title: Review/Music; Singing Songs of Azerbaijan
description: Shy audience members brought bouquet after bouquet onstage when Zejneb Khanlarova sang on Friday night at Symphony Space. Others sprinkled rose petals over her head or danced in front of the stage; one man tossed paper money at the singer and her band. In a concert presented by the American Azerbaijan Culture Center, Miss Khanlarova, a major star from the Republic of Azerbaijan in the Soviet Union, had brought music from home.

title: Soviets Revise Casualty Toll In Violence in Transcaucasus
description: Ethnic violence in Armenia and Azerbaijan killed 91 people and injured 1,650 last year, a Soviet official said today. The figures are the highest yet offered by officials.

title: The Costs of a Cowardly Congress
description: Faced with ferocious public opposition, the House yesterday capitulated and voted down the 51 percent raise that was to have lifted Congressional pay to $135,000 a year, starting today. Thus what Ralph Nader called a Congressional ''salary grab'' was thwarted at the last minute.

title: Pirates Sell Out Opener at Home
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates have sold out their April 11 home opener against the Mets. It is the first time the club has sold out a game before the start of the season.

title: Polish Plan: Doubts Cast; From the Opposition, Words of Frustration
description: Poland's Communist leaders unveiled their plans Monday for overhauling the ship of state, preferably leaving their own people firmly at the helm.

title: Holly Board Backs Conagra
description: The Holly Farms Corporation said today that its board had unanimously confirmed its earlier merger agreement with Conagra Inc. after reviewing bids from both Conagra and Tyson Foods Inc.

title: Ex-Aquino Deputy Striving for Top Office in 1992
description: The quick visit by Vice President Salvador H. Laurel to the ailing former President, Ferdinand E. Marcos, in Hawaii last week was a signal that the 1992 presidential campaign is under way in the Philippines.

title: Gooden Near 3-Year Deal
description: Dwight Gooden's agent said yesterday that ''we're getting pretty close'' to an agreement on a three-year contract that would reportedly make the 24-year-old pitcher the highest-paid member of the Mets at an average of $2.2 million over three years.

title: Review/Television; Inevitable Romance In 'Ask Me Again'
description: Leslie Hope, as Elizabeth, and Robert Bruce, as Nelson, make such an attractive couple that it is easy to see why their upscale parents should have tried, since the two were kids, to get them together and keep them that way. Naturally, feisty Elizabeth resists and resists - until she succumbs, which is pretty much the story of ''Ask Me Again,'' tonight's ''American Playhouse'' offering at 9 on Channel 13.

title: Ex-Chairman of Saks Gets Taubman Posts
description: After an apparent failure to obtain the price it wanted for the two companies, the Taubman Investment Company said yesterday that it would keep both the Woodward & Lothrop stores in Washington and the John Wanamaker stores in Philadelphia, and it tapped a former chairman of Saks Fifth Avenue as their new chairman and chief executive officer.

title: Ads Ask Mercy For Elephants
description: Dianne Douglas Graham was outraged a decade ago by the searing images of baby seals being clubbed to death for their fur. Ms. Graham, an associate creative director at Saatchi & Saatchi, drew on those memories to create three television spots protesting the slaughter of elephants for their tusks.

title: Bases Into Prisons
description: To the Editor:

title: Palestinian Group and Iran Tied to Pan Am Bomb
description: Evidence in the investigation of who planted the bomb that destroyed a Pan Am jumbo jet over Scotland in December increasingly points to a Palestinian terrorist group working in concert with hard-line elements within the Iranian Government, United States officials say.

title: TV Networks See Smaller Audience
description: While maintaining that network television is still the pre-eminent advertising medium, the heads of CBS, NBC and ABC agreed yesterday that its share of the viewing audience would continue to decline and one predicted that the networks' share could fall below 60 percent of the prime-time audience.

title: Will Ruling on S.A.T. Affect College Admissions?
description: College officials around the nation say a Federal district judge's finding last week that New York State's use of the Scholastic Aptitude Test discriminates against girls will have little impact on how students are selected and scholarships are awarded.

title: Austral's Value Drops by 25%
description: Customers besieged banks today to acquire United States dollars, pushing the value of the inflation-battered Argentine national currency down by 25 percent and intensifying the nation's economic crisis.

title: Review/Theater; A Writer Recalls His Immigrant Grandfather
description: Looking as formal and out of place as a penguin at the Equator, a young Jewish refugee from Russia arrives in Hamilton, Tex., in 1909 and begins to build a new life. Many years later, the man's grandson, Mark Harelik, would write a play about his grandfather's experience. The result, ''The Immigrant,'' at the American Jewish Theater, is a dramatized oral history chronicling the Americanization of Haskell Harelik.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about testimony in the GAF stock manipulation trial misidentified, in some editions, the party whose lawyer is Arthur L. Liman. It is GAF.

title: Winds Ascendant at Merkin
description: Steve Richman's Harmonie Ensemble, which appeared for a delightful program last Wednesday night at Merkin Concert Hall, harks back to the late 18th century, when one of the most popular forms of concert music was the wind band. For such ensembles, treading the line between cultivated and vernacular before that line was as firmly drawn as it is today, composers wrote superior scores, and arrangers - superior and otherwise - busily transcribed everything from complete grand operas to popular tunes of the day.

title: Pacific Telecom Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Providence Coasts Past Pitt, 88-78
description: Matt Palazzi broke out of a shooting slump with 22 points and Eric Murdock scored 19 of his 21 in the second half tonight to lead Providence to an 88-78 victory over Pitt in the Big East Conference.

title: Richfood Holdings Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 7
description: The comparable year-ago quarter and 9-month per share nets were not applicable; the company went public on May 1, 1988.

title: Real Estate; New Interest In Office Sites In Danbury
description: WHEN the Union Carbide Corporation pulled up stakes at 270 Park Avenue in 1981 and moved to a 600-acre headquarters complex in Danbury, Conn., city officials there hoped the move would turn Interstate 84 into something akin to a corporation-rich stretch of Interstate 287 in Westchester County.

title: A Subgenus of the Sparrow May Have Fallen
description: Reports of the dusky seaside sparrow's extinction may have been greatly exaggerated. New genetic studies indicate that the small Florida bird may not have been a true subspecies after all, but just another member of the common seaside sparrow flock so numerous along the Atlantic coast.

title: This Was A Football Player
description: Joe Morrison was annoyed. He usually played only one game of racquetball, but he had lost, 21-3, so he played another game. Now, as the South Carolina football coach sat in his black bathrobe and a black baseball cap early Sunday evening, his face was ashen.

title: Economic Scene; Saving the Forest In Costa Rica
description: FORTY years ago, 75 percent of this Vermont-sized democracy sandwiched between Nicaragua and Panama was covered by forests. Half the wilderness has since been cleared to harvest hardwoods and to open thin, easily eroded soils to subsistence farming. If deforestation continues at the current pace, Costa Rica will run out of trees by the year 2015, with much of this fragile land ending up as low-quality pasture or scrub too poor to cultivate.

title: Reviews/Music; On the Road With Verdi's 'Traviata'
description: About this time every year, the National Company of the New York City Opera packs one production into its trunks and sets off across the country. The current opera is ''La Traviata'' by Verdi. This month and next, alternating casts, some workable scenery designed by Peter Dean Beck and a small orchestra under Joshua Greene are making their way as far north as Maine and Canada, south to Arkansas and Florida and into the Midwestern worlds of Iowa, Indiana, Kansas, Wisconsin and Michigan.

title: Review/Opera; Mozart's 'Idomeneo' Is Revived at the Met
description: Until the New York City Opera made a brave stab at Mozart's ''Idomeneo'' in 1975, neither of the city's major companies had ever produced the work, an oversight difficult to understand. In 1982, Jean-Pierre Ponnelle mounted an ''Idomeneo'' for the Metropolitan Opera that almost made up for past sins of omission. When his production returned to the repertory on Monday evening for the first time in three years, it reinforced one's opinion that this ''Idomeneo'' is the most significant contribution left the Metropolitan by the late director.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Dow Chemical Co., Midland, Mich., said its Dowbrands Inc. unit had reached an agreement to buy First Brands Corp.'s European household products business. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Cincinnati Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a capital loss of $500,000 for the quarter and a capital gain of $4.1 million for the year. c-Included a capital loss of $4.9 million and a capital gain of $2.5 million for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Jefferies Questioned Further
description: Boyd L. Jefferies testified yesterday that he did not recall verbatim a crucial conversation in 1986 with a senior executive of the GAF Corporation. The Government contends that the conversation was part of an illegal scheme by GAF and Mr. Jefferies to manipulate the price of the Union Carbide Corporation's stock.

title: Experts Say Phone System Is Vulnerable to Terrorists
description: Top scientific advisers to the Government warned today that the nation's telecommunications system was increasingly vulnerable to large-scale disruption by terrorist attack.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: LEAD: AN evening of flying pucks and sports food Southern style awaits hockey lovers who venture into the Winston-Salem Memorial Coliseum to watch the Carolina Thunderbirds, the state's only professional ice-hockey club.

title: INSIDE
description: Church Rents the Hellinger

title: For Bush, an 11th Grandchild
description: President Bush became a grandfather for the 11th time today. The White House announced that Mr. Bush's son Neil, and his wife, Sharon, became the parents of Ashley Walker Bush, a 7-pound, 2-ounce girl. Ashley Bush, born at Rose Medical Center in Denver, is the third child of Neil, who is in the petroleum business in Denver. She is the seventh granddaughter in the Bush clan.

title: Steitz Steps Down
description: Edward S. Steitz, who joined the Springfield College athletic department 43 years ago as a graduate assistant and later served 10 seasons as basketball coach, announced yesterday that he was retiring as the school's athletic director after 33 years on the job.

title: Kansas City Power & Light Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
In Trump, the Game, The Object Is Money
description: First there was Trump: the real-estate developer. Then there was Trump: the best-selling book. Now there is ''Trump: The Game.''

title: Bush Aide Who Put The Pieces Together
description: When President Bush announced his rescue plan for the savings and loan industry, seven Cabinet officers and regulators who had contributed to the ultimate proposal were behind him on the platform.

title: KEY RATES
Strong City Journal; Stampede Is Feared On Range
description: The Z Bar Ranch is a vast stillness of hills, valleys and tree-lined creeks where hardly a sign of human beings intrudes. A ranch house of native limestone is tucked behind a hill, and on a far rim, a few horses graze, small brown shapes outlined against the sky.

title: North Lawyers Seek to Stop Trial Over Selection of Jury
description: Lawyers for Oliver L. North moved to stop his trial today on the ground that the jury selection, which had been under way for six days, is illegal.

title: Vernitron Offer
description: The Vernitron Corporation said it might raise its hostile $23-a-share tender offer for the Kollmorgen Corporation if Kollmorgen's confidential financial data ''justifies such an increase.'' In a letter Monday to the Kollmorgen board of directors, Stephen W. Bershad, Vernitron's chief executive, also said the company would take legal action, if it was not included in the bidding for the Stamford, Conn., electrical machinery manufacturer.

title: 19 Die in Mexico Bus Plunge
description: A bus driver yelled ''I have no brakes'' moments before a city bus slid off a winding stretch of road and plunged down a 60-foot cliff, killing 19 people and injuring 22, the authorities said today. The accident took place on Monday about four miles from the downtown area of this Baja California resort, fire department officials said. The bus, operated by the Rojo y Blanco line, had not had a mechanical inspection in five years and had no insurance, as required by state law, said Miroslava Cuellar, a spokeswoman in Ensenada.

title: Polaroid Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Latest fourth-quarter results included a pre-tax restructuring charge of $54.9 million. Results for 1988 included total pre- tax charges of $151.9 million related to restructuring activities and expenses related to the company's takeover battle with Shamrock Holdings Inc.

title: Savings Industry Ready To Fight the Bush Plan
description: The opening bell has sounded in what is likely to be a struggle over the Bush Administration's attempt to overhaul the savings industry.

title: IE Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $4,547,000 from an accounting change.

title: Whales Know How to Avoid Hydrofoils
description: To the Editor:

title: Future of Blacks in U.S. Draws 400 to Harvard
description: Michelle Davis, a black sophomore at Harvard University, said some white students believed that academic standards had been lowered to let blacks into prestigious schools.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Science Times on Jan. 31 with an article about the use of lime to reduce acidity in lakes referred to the Pocono Mountains incorrectly. They are in eastern, not western, Pennsylvania.

title: Food Notes
description: Charcuterie on E. 11th

title: Dresher Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a pre-tax charge of $942,000 from a writedown of 50 percent of the carrying value of the company's loans and equity investment in Doxey Furniture Corp. c-Net income Corrected from yesterday.

title: Deadly Reach of Needle Proves Difficult to Block
description: The greatest challenge in reducing the spread of AIDS and its future toll, most experts believe, is curbing the spread of the virus among intravenous drug abusers. Concentrated in the inner city, drug addicts, along with their sex partners and babies, account for an increasing share of the nation's cases.

title: Toll Increase Inspires Calls for a Free Ride
description: The Garden State Parkway, the nation's most heavily traveled toll road, is headed for its first general toll increase since opening 35 years ago.

title: Bridge
description: If an expert sits down to kibitz someone he does not know, he can usually tell after one deal whether he is watching an experienced player. But he may receive mixed signals: The bidding and the play may point in opposite directions. In such cases, the play is a better guide. An expert may make a bad-looking bid because of some partnership understanding or because he is riding a hunch, but he is very unlikely to make a bad play.

title: Jackson's Focus: Redlining
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson urged Congress today to link the Federal bailout of savings institutions to tougher laws against redlining. Some lenders have been accused of this practice, which means denying loans for property in poor neighborhoods.

title: Tokyo Opposition Leader Quits in Stock Scandal
description: In a move that appears likely to increase political pressure on Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita, the chairman of the opposition Democratic Socialist Party announced today that he would step down because of his involvement with a widening stock-trading scandal.

title: Regina Is Exploring Possibility of a Sale
description: The Regina Company, the embattled maker of vacuum cleaners, said yesterday that it was exploring the possible sale of the company.

title: Sihanouk's Lust for Power Threatens Cambodia
description: In his quest to establish himself as the undisputed leader of post-war Cambodia, Prince Norodom Sihanouk is undermining his own position as the key to a Cambodia settlement.

title: At 41, Mamby Can Still Slip a Punch
