description: Saoul Mamby had his first professional fight in Kingston, Jamaica, in 1969. Strictly by chance.

title: Man Indicted in Toxic Dumping
description: A Long Island man and his three electro-plating companies were indicted by a Brooklyn grand jury yesterday on charges of dumping drums of cyanide and arsenic in two vacant lots in the East New York section.

title: A.T.&.T. In Italian Venture
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company cleared a major hurdle yesterday in its bid to become a partner with Italtel S.p.A., Italy's state-owned telecommunications equipment company, in a project to help overhaul Italy's antiquated telephone network, industry officials said.

title: In New York, Cuts Are Not Enough
description: In the trendy world of Washington politics, raising taxes has become impermissible. In the gritty world of deficits, strained public services and people in need - the world of New York - revenue increases now appear unavoidable.

title: Micro D reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Borg's Trip to Hospital Makes Some Big News
description: First he ate something that made him sick. Then he took some sleeping pills that made him even sicker. Finally, he went to a hospital to have his stomach pumped out and was released four hours later.

title: Old Sentiments Never Fade
description: There's so many kinds of valentines, Some made of lace and glue. There's comics and the stand-up kind, And then there's postals too. But when I choose my valentine I'm going to choose just you.

title: Acuson Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Near a Vulnerable Afghan City, Confident Rebels Await War's End
description: On the outskirts of the largest city in eastern Afghanistan, guerrilla commanders are debating whether to mount an attack or continue to tighten the siege.

title: Real-Estate Concern Agrees To Refunds on Land Sales
description: The Patten Corporation, a real-estate concern whose land-selling techniques in the Catskills and other rural areas in the Northeast have prompted widespread criticism, has agreed to make refunds to consumers who can prove they were deceived by the company in five states, the New York State Attorney General announced today.

title: Talking Deals; Joint Soviet Deal, But Based in U.S.
description: ALVIN DUSKIN, like a number of other American businessmen, wants to take advantage of the opportunity to join with the Soviet Union in new ventures. But, unlike his compatriots, his headquarters for a joint company will be here, not there.

title: Hitting Ancient Nails on the Head
description: LEAD: ''EIGHTEEN SEVENTY-SIX. That's the year to look out for. I'll always trust a date on a house authenticated before that year, because people had nothing to gain by falsifying it.''

title: Albert B. Maris, 95, Federal Appeals Judge
description: Albert B. Maris, a Federal appeals judge who served on the Federal bench longer than any other active jurist, died Tuesday at North Penn Hospital Center in Lansdale, Pa. He was 95 years old and lived at a retirement center in Gwynedd, Pa.

title: Ryder System Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $18,581,000 relating to the company's repurchase of $158 million of its unsecured notes and was reflected net of income taxes. The latest 12 months' earnings were reduced by $52 million, or 66 cents a share, as a result of charges relating to the restructuring of certain businesses and a downward revaluation of goodwill. The fourth quarter of 1988 included a portion of the provision for restructuring, largely offset by the realization of income tax benefits related to goodwill written off. The company said its results for all of 1988 included a number of extraordinary and unusual items which in total increased net earnings by $10.2 million, or 13 cents a share. Effective Jan. 1, 1988, the company adopted Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 96, accounting for income taxes. The cumulative effect of $81,096,000 in the latest year reflected primarily the reduction of deferred income taxes as a result of lower tax rates enacted in 1986.

title: Defeat of Congressional Pay Increase Demolishes No-Vote System
description: A 22-year-old system for raising the pay of top Government officials without a Congressional vote has been demolished by the furor that defeated the 51 percent pay increase this week, lawmakers said today.

title: Hemacare Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Review/Television; Miss Marple Is at It Again
description: Mysteries don't get any more English than ''The Murder at the Vicarage.'' Not only does it have a vicar to go with the vicarage, but it also has thatched roofs, cyclists between the hedgerows, a poacher, a tea party, a neurotic curate, a dyspeptic detective inspector and an overbearing colonel with plenty of enemies who is found dead in the study. Not to mention Miss Marple.

title: Virginia Electric
description: A $150 million issue of first- and refunding-mortgage bonds sold by the Virginia Electric and Power Company went to an underwriting group led by Bear, Stearns & Company in competitive bidding yesterday. The 9 3/4 percent bonds due 2019 are offered to the public at a price of 98.843, to yield 9.87 percent, or about 1.08 percentage points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. Nonrefundable for five years, the bonds are rated A-1 by Moody's and A+ by Standard & Poor's.

title: ABC Gives 'Home' a New Coat Of Paint
description: ''HOME,'' the how-to television show that ABC hoped would steal late-morning viewers from game shows and reruns of sitcoms, has just celebrated its first birthday amid poor ratings and some household changes.

title: IRAN WILL RELEASE CERTAIN PRISONERS FOR ANNIVERSARY
description: Iran announced today that it would release several thousand political prisoners to commemorate the 10th anniversary of the Islamic revolution on Saturday. But it said about 900 opponents of the Government accused of murder and other serious crimes would not be freed.

title: Central Americans Cite Progress in Reviving Arias Plan
description: The Foreign Ministers of five Central American countries said tonight that they were moving ahead again with their long-stalled peace plan for the region after a day of talks with Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar.

title: AIDS Children in Hospitals Wait for Funds
description: To the Editor:

title:
FIVE DESIGNERS: FIVE DECORATING STRATEGIES;
Spending Styles
description: LEAD: IDENTIFYING the personality of a client helps Jack Kreitinger, an interior designer based in Chicago, determine how to spend their money. He places his clients in four categories: purist, investor, dramatist and realist.

title: Kollmorgen Reply To Vernitron
description: The Kollmorgen Corporation said it would provide its hostile suitor, the Vernitron Corporation, with certain confidential financial data only if Vernitron drops its tender offer of $23 a share, or a total of $294 million. On Tuesday, Vernitron, a Deer Park, N.Y., medical equipment maker, demanded access to the same information that Kollmorgen had offered to unnamed third parties.

title: Q&A
description: Q.The top of our new rosewood dining room table has a milky-white stain that was caused by a hot serving dish. The dish was resting on a wicker server but apparently enough steam heat was transmitted to mar the finish. We have tried to remove the stain with combinations of linseed oil, turpentine and furniture polish, but none have worked. Do you have a suggestion? A.If the stain is in the finish, not the wood, you may be able to remove it with a very mild abrasive. Try rubbing with a toothpaste that advertises that it has ''extra whiteners.'' Or try rubbing with table salt mixed with a little lemon oil.

title: From Designers, Pictures And a Thousand Words
description: NEVER mind that this is the age of facsimile machines, overnight mail and portable telephones; decorators are still sending messages the old-fashioned way - on postcards. These are not the sort picked up in museum gift shops or airports, but postcards depicting rooms the decorators have done. Emily Todhunter, who runs Designs by Emily, with offices in Manhattan and London, sends a card with a watercolor of a room she completed this winter for the Royal Oak Designer Show House in New York. ''It was a drawing I did as I was conceptualizing the space,'' she explained.

title: Notre Dame and Georgia Tech Win
description: Iona and Fordham had visions of toppling two college basketball heavyweights in Madison Square Garden last night. And both for a half looked their opponents squarely in the eyes and matched elbow for elbow and spurt for spurt.

title: Midwest Energy Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said a $14 million reduction in electric rates in 1988 contributed to the fourth-quarter earnings decline.

title: Sony Introduces Video Equipment
description: The Sony Corporation introduced video equipment that it said uses 8-millimeter tape but has the same sharpness as products that use the wider Super VHS format. Sony said the new EV-S900 videotape recorder would be priced at $1,850 and the CCD-V900 combined camera-recorder at $1,880. Both will be available in Japan in April and in the United States in May or June.

title: Stocks Move Lower and Dow Drops 3.93
description: Stock prices moved lower yesterday and the Dow Jones industrial average suffered its fifth loss in the last six sessions. But more stocks on the New York Stock Exchange rose than fell.

title: Review/Music; Upholding a Zydeco Legacy
description: The name Clifton Chenier was emblazoned on the accordion that his son C. J. Chenier played Tuesday night at S.O.B.'s. Along with the instrument, Mr. Chenier has inherited most of his late father's Red Hot Louisiana Band and a daunting legacy.

title: Eastco Industrial Safety reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Speech to Congress to End Honeymoon
description: The speech that President Bush is to deliver to a joint session of Congress on Thursday will mark the end of the honeymoon between the President and Capitol Hill, if in fact that season of unrealistic sweetness and light didn't peter out altogether earlier this week in the partisan battle over Secretary of Defense-designate John G. Tower.

title: TJ International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Gibson, C R Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings reflected a 6-for- 5 stock split paid in January.

title: Broker Study By Exchange In Chicago
description: The Chicago Board of Trade said today that it would appoint a committee to study whether to ban broker groups. Such groups have roused deep resentment among competitors.

title: Independent Insurance Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After realized investment losses of $666,000 for the quarter and $20,000 for the year. c-After a realized investment loss of $3,126,000 for the quarter and a realized investment gain of $155,000 for the year.

title: Review/Rock; Zahar in Cultural Crossover
description: Zahar, a new group, made a spectacular Manhattan debut at the Knitting Factory on Tuesday night. The group - Hasaan Makmoun on electrified sintir (a Moroccan cross between a cello and a bass), Yuval Gabay on drums, and Hahn Rowe on guitar and violin - were not only intense musically, but they caught a cultural movement. Mixing Gnowan Moroccan music (itself a merger of black African and Arabic musical traits) with rock, they fed a burgeoning interest in music from the Arab world, with cross-cultural experimentation added.

title: Profit Scoreboard
4 Members of L.I. Family Stabbed, 2 Fatally
description: Four members of a Long Island family were stabbed, two fatally, in their home in Roosevelt last night, and a fifth member of the family was arrested and charged in the incident, the police said.

title: U.S. Energy System Is Vulnerable To Terrorists, Senate Panel Is Told
description: The nation's electricity system is vulnerable to terrorists and could take a long time to recover from an attack, experts testified today and Tuesday before the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, captions with the Advertising column on the first page of Business Day yesterday were reversed in some copies.

title: Politics, Not Affection, Is the Bond
description: In the days of crisis over John G. Tower's nomination as Secretary of Defense, President Bush has been gripped by the twin pressures of Washington politics and a three-decade relationship with Mr. Tower born when Texas Republicans joked about holding conventions in a telephone booth.

title: CBS Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included gains on the disposal from discontinued operations of $3 million for the quarter and $869.6 million for the year, and extraordinary losses on the extinguishment of debt of $3 million for the quarter and $3.1 million for the year. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $49.6 million for the quarter and $135.5 million for the year, and gains on the disposal from discontinued operations of $179.6 million and $181.3 million for the quarter and year, respectively, and extraordinary losses of $100,000 and $300,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from extinguishment of debt.

title: Senate Approves Yeutter
description: The Senate today unanimously approved the nomination of Clayton K. Yeutter as Agriculture Secretary.

title: DeLorean Loses Plea
description: John Z. DeLorean, the colorful auto executive who built a futuristic-looking sports car in Northern Ireland, lost a bid in Federal court on Tuesday to block a $53 million legal judgment imposed against him in Britain.

title: Film Industry Preparing For a Strike by Actors
description: Less than a year after a devastating writers' strike, the movie industry is reluctantly preparing for a potential work stoppage by its 72,000 actors in the Screen Actors Guild. The actors brought movie and television production to a halt in 1980 with a 10-week strike that the industry said cost it more than $100 million.

title: Joe Mullen's Star Rises Among the Best
description: Wayne Gretzky, who had just been awarded a car after being named the most valuable player in the National Hockey League's 40th annual All-Star Game, was asked what he planned to do with his latest prize. It was the 14th car he had won in his career, Gretzky said, and he planned to give it away.

title:
FIVE DESIGNERS: FIVE DECORATING STRATEGIES;
The Long View
description: LEAD: ''INVEST in a long-range plan'' is the advice of the interior designer Richard Holley to anyone embarking on a design project, regardless of the budget.

title: U.S. Issues Slip in Active Trading
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds slipped in active trading yesterday as traders reacted defensively after results of a $9.5 billion sale of 10-year notes were announced.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Milestone for Congress
description: The Library of Congress kicked off its commemoration of a Congressional anniversary yesterday by draping a 60-foot banner over the front entrance of its Madison Building with the legend: U.S. Congress -200 Years - Celebrate.

title: Madeleine Low, 94, Hudson Guild Trustee
description: Madeleine M. Low, a trustee of the Hudson Guild neighborhood house for 55 years, died of heart failure on Tuesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 94 years old.

title: Another Soviet Taboo Is Broken: Journal Attacks Communist Party
description: A Soviet magazine has broken another taboo by publishing a scathing attack on the Communist Party, including the first irreverent barbs directed at Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: Ewing Gets a Scare as Knicks Triumph
description: There is something about Glenn (Doc) Rivers and the Omni. They spell trouble for Patrick Ewing. With 9 minutes 57 minutes remaining in the third period tonight and the Knicks trailing, 64-52, Ewing tried to spin to the basket from the left post. He was poked in the right eye by Rivers, the Atlanta Hawk playmaker, who was double-teaming.

title: Media Manipulated!
description: Let's lift the veil today and sneak a look at how an adept White House can set the Bigfeet of journalism tromping on each other's toes.

title: The New York Times Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $1,964,000 for the quarter and $6,719,000 for the year. c-After net from discontinued operations of $1,024,000 and $4,069,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The latest periods also included after-tax equity in earnings of forest products group of $8,111,000 for the quarter and $28,928,000 for the year. The year-ago periods also included after-tax equity in earnings of forest products group of $7,054,000 and $17,990,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Portraits of a Vanguard: 'I Dream a World'
description: When Brian Lanker mentioned to a friend his idea for a book-length photographic essay on influential American black women, he was asked whether there were enough black women of stature around for such a project. What he found, he said, was that there were more such women than he had space for.

title: Sun Electric reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $2.2 million restructuring charge. The company, which recently changed its fiscal year-end to Dec. 31 from Oct. 31, said it also reported net income of $151,000, or 2 cents a share, on sales of $28,431,000, for the two months ended Dec. 31. For the year ended Oct. 31, 1987, the company said it posted net of $4,951,000, or 70 cents a share, which included a tax benefit of $1,688,000. Sales were $203,904,000.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Business People column of Business Day yesterday about the Management Company Entertainment Group Inc. misstated the new title of Charles J. Weber. He will be president and chief operating officer. William J. Rouhana Jr., the company's vice chairman, will remain responsible for the company's long-term finances.

title: Times Mirror Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included pre-tax gain on the sale of assets of $1,975,000 and $58,880,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes pre-tax loss on the sale of assets of $43,725,000 and $29,225,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. Losses for 1987 on the sale of assets have been reclassified to conform to 1988 presentation. The company recorded charges against earnings of about $36 million related to the amortization of goodwill and assets revalued as a result of the acquisition of four special-interest magazines in the fourth quarter of 1987 and the February 1988 purchase of Richard D. Irwin, a college textbook publisher. That expense was partially offset by a $19.8 million benefit realized from a change in accounting for inventory at Matthew Bender, the company's legal publisher.

title: Hemotec Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Killer Joe Piro, Who Popularized Discotheque Dancing, Dies at 68
description: Frank (Killer Joe) Piro, a dance instructor to high society and popularizer of many of the steps of the discotheque era of the 1960's and 1970's, died of kidney disease Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Bonn Suspends Missile Project
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl suspended development of a conventionally armed short-range missile today after press reports about the weapon threatened a public outcry.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: St Lawrence Cement reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: West German Rightist Boasts of Nazi Service
description: The head of a far-right party, flush with a strong showing in West Berlin, regaled an overflow rally in Bavaria today with his message of guilt-free nationalism, declaring in the process that he was not ashamed of his own service in the Waffen SS.

title: Manson Is Denied Parole
description: A parole board today denied freedom for Charles Manson, leader of the infamous ''family'' that in 1969 murdered the actress Sharon Tate and eight other people. The board's decision marked the seventh time that Mr. Manson had been denied parole. The board considered the latest psychiatric study of Mr. Manson and his prison history, which listed six citations for behavioral problems since his last parole hearing, in February 1986.

title: Japan to Amnesty 30,000 to Honor Hirohito
description: Japan said today that it will grant amnesty to more than 30,000 suspects and convicts on the day of Emperor Hirohito's funeral this month and ''restore civil rights'' to 11 million others punished for minor infractions.

title: Many Donate To Neediest To Aid Infirm
description: Lary and David Greiner and Eileen Berasi of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., sent a gift to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund with the request that it go to ease the suffering of children with cancer. Their $780 was sent in memory of Rose Berasi, with a special request that the money ''not be used for the purchase of war toys.''

title: Jets Make a Change
description: The Jets made their second coaching change of the off season yesterday by naming Rod Humenuik to replace Dan Radakovich as offensive line coach. Humenuik was dismissed by the Patriots in December after holding the concurrent titles of line coach, assistant head coach and offensive coordinator. Coach Joe Walton is believed to have wanted a firm commitment from Radakovich on whether he would return next season. But Radakovich is looking for a coordinator's or head coach's post and would not assure Walton of remaining if another offer came along. The Jets' offensive line, a young one, had been a trouble spot for several years but was coming along late in the season. Humenuik is known for his ability to teach a line to cut down on sacks. The Patriots yielded only 23, second in the league.

title: CLOSE TO HOME
description: AT five in the morning of the day Ted Bundy died a headache woke me. Headaches often do, but I don't mind my predawn prowls through the house - hunting for the Advil, fumbling for a glass. In fact I like looking out at the dark windows on the other side of the garden, and knowing that the rest of my small world is still asleep. Standing at the sink, though, I remembered. At this moment somebody was probably shaving the spot on Ted Bundy's head. The juice I was pouring had reminded me. Oranges. Florida.

title: Texas Utility Revenue Bonds
description: The Matagorda County Navigational District Number One, in Texas, is tentatively offering $104.7 million of tax-exempt, collateralized pollution-control revenue bonds and collateralized revenue refunding bonds for a Houston Lighting and Power Company project through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Innovative Urban Plans From Two Architects
description: ALTHOUGH the architects Emilio Ambasz and Steven Holl each have very different styles, their work has been paired in a show, the fourth of five exhibitions by the Gerald D. Hines Interests Architecture Program.

title: BUSH ASKS REVIEW OF AFGHAN POLICY
description: President Bush has ordered a high-level review of American policy toward Afghanistan in light of the Soviet withdrawal, senior Administration officials said today.

title: Travel Packages Available for Skiers
description: rrFor most people, going skiing means getting into a car and driving to the mountains. But in recent years, other ways to travel have become available and are often faster and easier and sometimes no more expensive than driving.

title: Great Western Bank's Offering
description: Great Western Bank of Beverly Hills, Calif., is offering $250 million of 9.80 percent notes, due 1994, at a price of par to yield about 80 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Investor May Seek Di Giorgio Control
description: A Somerset, N.J., investor, Arthur M. Goldberg, reported he had acquired a 5.8 percent stake in the Di Giorgio Corporation and said he might seek control of the San Francisco-based food concern. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Goldberg said that any decision to seek Di Giorgio ''will depend upon a number of factors, including the market price of the stock and availability of financing.''

title: Bush's Speech on T.V. And Radio at 9 P.M.
description: President Bush's address to Congress at 9 o'clock tonight will be televised by ABC, CBS, NBC, CNN and C-Span. Some affiliates of PBS, including Channel 13 in the New York area, and of the Spanish-language network Univision, including Channel 41 in New York, will also carry the address.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Commercial Production Costs Faulted
description: ONE of the advertising industry's leading creative executives yesterday blamed the fees charged by top commercial directors and their production companies for the skyrocketing cost of television advertising production.

title: State Dept. Weighs Plan for Arms Control Focus
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d is considering a plan to reorganize his department's national security responsibilities with an eye to stepping up efforts to combat the spread of nuclear weapons, chemical arms and missile technology, State Department officials said today.

title: Accord Seeks to Cut Crowding in Psychiatric Wards
description: In a tentative agreement to relieve overcrowding in psychiatric emergency rooms and wards in New York City's municipal hospitals, officials said yesterday that New York State would double the number of mentally ill patients it accepted from the municipal hospitals each month.

title: Ex-Financial Planner Pleads Guilty
description: A former financial planner, Henry Gherman, who fled to Asia last summer with nearly $10 million in investors' money, pleaded guilty Tuesday to Federal embezzlement and mail fraud charges.

title: Bush Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
General Magnaplate Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings were adjusted to reflect a 4-for-1 stock split paid in January 1988.

title: Washington Post Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included non-recurring after-tax gains of $115.7 million, or $8.99 a share, from the sale of interests in cellular telephone operations. c-Included non-recurring after-tax gains of $54.3 million, or $4.24 a share, from the sale of interests in cable sport programming operations. Latest-quarter results included a one-time after-tax charge of $12.6 million related to restructuring activities at Newsweek. Year-ago quarter results included a non-recurring after-tax gain of $23.5 million, or $1.83 a share, from sales of certain of the company's cellular telephone interests.

title: Athletes Who Overtrain Share Personality Traits
description: Researchers are identifying a particular pattern in mood and performance that signals when an athlete has pushed too hard in training.

title: Palo Alto Journal; Talk About AIDS in Kindergarten? The Teachers Say Don't
description: It was approaching midnight when agenda item XII-B reached the floor of the school board meeting here, but the kindergarten teachers were still in attendance, resolute and sensing victory.

title: Coe Won't Run
description: Sebastian Coe of Britain abandoned, at least temporarily, his comeback bid by withdrawing yesterday from the 800-meter run at the European indoor championships next week. British officials said Coe, who still holds the world indoor and outdoor records for the distance, was concerned about a calf injury that caused him to withdraw from a recent meeting in Genoa, Italy. Coe has not competed since the trials last August for the Seoul Olympic Games. He failed to qualify. (AP)

title: Electronics Co-op in First License Pact
description: The Microelectronics Computer and Technology Corporation, the nation's first cooperative research effort mounted by major competitors in an industry, said today that it had its first licensing agreement.

title: Chemical Waste Management Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Cancer Panel Suggests Limits on Tobacco
description: If the nation wants to reach a goal of cutting the cancer death rate in half by the year 2000, it should greatly restrict the use and availability of tobacco and make early diagnostic tests available to all, the National Cancer Advisory Board said today.

title: Philip Pratt, Federal Judge, 64
description: Philip Pratt, chief Federal judge for the Eastern District of Michigan, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in Bloomfield Hills, Mich. He was 64 years old.

title: New York Libraries Receive Their Share
description: To the Editor:

title: Backstage at Savings Rescue: Urgent and Secretive Process
description: On the way to President Bush's bailout plan for hundreds of bankrupt savings institutions, senior Administration officials and Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, decided on Sunday night to pump billions of dollars in emergency loans into the institutions if the plan touched off a run on deposits.

title: Kentucky School, Pressed, Revises Smoking Rules
description: The University of Louisville has scaled back a policy that put restrictions on smoking to satisfy state lawmakers who threatened to cut the school's budget if the policy remained unchanged.

title: Review/Theater; Greed's Triumph Over Family Ties
description: One of the sturdiest bridges between Spanish-writing dramatists and English-speaking audiences is the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater, which has been offering New Yorkers bilingual theater since 1967.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Telephone and Telegraph Co. has completed its acquisition of Paradyne Corp. for $10.25 a share.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 Iran said it would release prisoners by the thousands to commemorate the 10th anniversary of the Islamic revolution on Saturday. Page A1

title: Market Place; The Pits Hang On To Dual Trading
description: CRITICS of dual trading, in which traders sometimes act for customers and sometimes for themselves, had better not hold their breath until the practice is abandoned. The decision by directors of the Chicago Board of Trade not to ban the practice is but one indication of how deeply ingrained it is at the nation's largest futures market.

title: Brinkmann Instruments reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Epic Healthcare Group Inc. In a $115 Million Offering
description: Epic Healthcare Group Inc., an Irving, Tex., operator of 36 general acute-care hospitals, is offering $115 million of units through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I look back on the good old days of heroin. Heroin didn't destroy their ability to be human the way crack does.'' - Judge Leah Ruth Marks of Family Court in Manhattan. [ A1:2. ]

title: Decorating: How Far Can $10,000 Take You?
description: NOT so long ago, it was possible to build an entire house with $10,000. Today, according to a 1988 survey by the American Society of Interior Designers, the average cost of a residential decorating project is $68,200. At Blair House in Washington, America's official residence for visiting dignitaries, the decorator Mario Buatta managed to spend $20,000 on a pair of silk curtains - albeit elaborately swagged and draped curtains. ''And that,'' he pointed out, ''was wholesale.''

title: Show's Subjects Gather to Celebrate Sisterhood
description: There was a celebration of sisterhood in Washington today as some 50 black women, the subjects of an evocative photographic exhibition by Brian Lanker, gathered at the Corcoran Gallery of Art.

title: Bridge
description: Several groups of players assemble in a private home or club for a weekly game that continues year after year. One of the most unusual is the Monday night game at the Cavendish Club, 105 East 73d Street. It has been going for 35 years, with several founding members still playing. The game is the cut-in team variety, scored by imps. The standard is high, as the diagramed deal, reported by Andrew Arkin, demonstrates.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Jet Crashes in Azores

title: An Inexact Copy
description: To The Home Section:

title: Yields Mixed For Week
description: Yields for certificates of deposit and bank money market accounts rose for the week ended yesterday, while yields for money market mutual funds dipped slightly.

title: Indictment Says Client Ordered Lawyer Beaten
description: A New Jersey woman on trial in Manhattan for fraud was indicted yesterday on a charge that she paid to have her lawyer's legs broken with a baseball bat to gain a mistrial.

title: Georgetown Defeats UConn, 70-58
description: Jaren Jackson scored 8 of his 18 points during the first 7 minutes 52 seconds of the second half as second-ranked Georgetown went on a 20-10 run tonight to defeat Connecticut, 70-58, in a Big East Conference game.

title: Judge in North Trial Rejects U.S. Effort To Censor Testimony
description: The Federal district judge in the trial of Oliver L. North today rejected a Justice Department effort to censor testimony dealing with national security. The ruling set up a legal battle that could force a dismissal of some or all of the 12 remaining charges against Mr. North.

title: Did We Elect Another Carter?
description: LEAD: If these are tricky times for President Bush, they're also difficult for those in the press and elsewhere who are obliged to interpret his actions. Enthusiasm is ebbing, but hope is still subordinating candor.

title: Blockbuster Entertainment Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Penny Stock Rule Offered
description: To crack down on penny-stock fraud and high-pressure sales tactics, the Securities and Exchange Commission today approved for public comment a rule that would set tough procedures for brokers trying to sell risky stocks to new customers.

title: S.E.C. Disclosure Plan Is Opposed by Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange has formally opposed the Securities and Exchange Commission's proposal to expand the private placement market and has made some counterproposals of its own.

title: Where California Design Is the Star
description: LEAD: Tucked amid fruit trees near a 1776 Spanish mission, the Center for the Study of Decorative Arts opened today with a mission of its own: to remind visitors, and future generations, that California, though a young state, has a history of interior design as rich as its outdoor landscape.

title: Savings Bailouts Are Put on Hold; Pending Deals Likely to Collapse
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which is taking control of more than 200 insolvent savings and loan associations, today froze all negotiations for the sale of ailing institutions. It said any deals involving Government guarantees and other debt obligations would be dropped.

title: Robert Middlebrook, Executive, Dies at 72
description: Robert W. Middlebrook, formerly president of Squibb International, senior vice president of Richardson-Merrell Inc. and a vice president of Pfizer International, died of a heart attack Saturday at a vacation home in Fort Myers, Fla. He was 72 years old and lived in Washington, Conn.

title: Revising One's Outlook, Or, Editors Who Write
description: In his spare time, Richard Marek, president and publisher of E. P. Dutton, tapped a different part of his brain, he says, to do what his authors do. He wrote a book (''Works of Genius'') and got it published (Atheneum, 1987).

title: Design Solutions in Just a Day
description: MARTIN HUTNER was embarking on a one-day job as a decorating consultant. His clients, Bob and Elizabeth Lunt, had just moved to a 1920's Tudor-style house in Westchester from Manhattan and, he said, ''I don't know anything about them.''

title: Pretoria Acts On Currency
description: South Africa's central bank announced tighter measures this week to stop abuses of foreign exchange controls after a series of currency scandals.

title: A.B.A.'s 2 Models For 'Baby M' Laws
description: The American Bar Association, without endorsing surrogate motherhood, has offered states a blueprint for legalizing the practice and making surrogacy contracts enforceable.

title: Malaysian Investor May Bid for SSMC
description: A Malaysian investor, Vincent Tan, said he was prepared to pay more for SSMC Inc. than the offer of $30 a share, a total of $163 million, which the SSMC board has accepted from Semi-Tech Microelectronics (Far East) Ltd., a Hong Kong-based concern. In a letter dated today to the SSMC board, Mr. Tan requested the confidential financial information that SSMC made available to Semi-Tech. Mr. Tan, who holds 10 percent of SSMC stock, said his group is ''prepared to review this material quickly.'' The letter was contained in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Review/Cabaret; Whiting, With Elan
description: Among New York's veteran cabaret singers, Margaret Whiting is a kind of unofficial cheerleader. Her big chesty voice carries so well in a small club that she doesn't need a microphone. Even when singing morose ballads she lends them an upbeat energy, along with a perspective that views life's downs as minor interruptions in a continuing celebration.

title: Krug International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $491,000 for the quarter and income of $7,510,000 for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations. c-Net income and after a loss from discontinued operations of $118,000. d-After income from discontinued operations of $253,000.

title: Cepeda Returns
description: Orlando Cepeda, a two-time National League most valuable player, returned to the team he once starred for as he was named s special assistant for player development of the San Francisco Giants yesterday. ''He will be an outstanding influence on some of our younger players, and will be especially helpful in providing a link with our greatly increasing number of Spanish-speaking players, and with the Spanish population in the Bay area,'' said General Manager Al Rosen. A .297 career hitter, Cepeda was the most valuable player for the Giants in 1961 and St. Louis in 1967. He hit 379 career home runs with 1,365 runs batted in.(AP)

title: Soviet Life Lives
description: Once there was a Socialist utopia where all workers were happy and the sun always shone on model collective farms. Such was the fantasy offered in the glossy pages of Soviet Life, a monthly magazine published by the Soviet Embassy in Washington. But as Moscow has changed, so has the magazine - and its outlook.

title: Finance and Behavior Questions Prolong F.B.I. Background Check
description: Administration officials said today that persistent questions about John G. Tower's private life and campaign finances were extending the Federal Bureau of Investigation's background check of the nominee to head the Pentagon.

title: Two Will Duel to Succeed Boitano
description: They resemble each other only in their determination to succeed Brian Boitano as national figure-skating champion, a title Boitano held four times before winning the Olympic gold medal last year in Calgary.

title: Women Gain Ground In Wages, Study Shows
description: Working women earn only 65 percent of men's wages but are gaining ground, according to a Rand Corporation survey released today.

title: N.C.A.A. Rules Shut Some Students Out; Learning Disabilities
description: To the Editor:

title: Germans Pledge Curbs on Chemical Plants
description: A West German official today briefed Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d on measures planned by Bonn to prevent the export of equipment that could be used to make chemical weapons.

title: Somoza Officers Are Allowed To Leave Managua Embassy
description: Two former army officers of the ousted Somoza Government ended nearly 10 years of political asylum in the Venezuelan Embassy today and were given permission to leave the country.

title: Charter Jet Crash in Azores Kills 144
description: An American charter jet carrying Italian vacationers to the Caribbean crashed into a fog-shrouded mountain in the Azores today while trying to land and all 144 people on board were believed killed.

title: Destroyer of Families, Crack Besieges a Court
description: Family Court in Manhattan is an increasingly frayed conveyor belt of violent tales and misery these days, largely because of crack.

title: Columbia Gas System reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
VERDICT IS MIXED ON BRAIN SURGERY
description: An experimental brain operation to treat Parkinson's disease has produced moderate improvement for some victims but not the ''miracle'' that an earlier report suggested, a researcher said.

title: U.S. Needs Data on Drug and Sex Habits to Halt AIDS, Study Says
description: To slow the spread of AIDS, the Federal Government needs to greatly increase studies of AIDS incidence, sexual behavior and drug abuse, the National Research Council said today. In addition, the council said the Government should support more frank and aggressive programs to change risky behavior.

title: Tossing a Hat Into the Ring: It's All a Matter of Timing
description: Ronald Lauder announced for mayor in January. David N. Dinkins is to declare his intention to run next week, Rudolph W. Giuliani in late February or early March, Harrison J. Goldin in April, Edward I. Koch in May or June, and Richard Ravitch has yet to decide when.

title: London Journal; Making It: From Petty Crime to Community Help
description: In the rough rhythm of the street, Lawrence Fearon once defined the good life as partying with a pretty woman, buying the latest fashions and committing crimes without getting caught.

title: A Leash That May Be More Humane
description: ''It's a miracle,'' said James Drakeford, an assistant department manager at Dean and DeLuca in New York City, after walking a friend's dog with a new device called the Gentle Leader. Mr. Drakeford had previously been dragged down the street by his friend's 50-pound mutt. ''With the halter,'' he said, ''the dog simply couldn't pull.''

title: Study of Death Penalty Requires Better Data
description: To the Editor:

title: Pogo Producing Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and included a gain from a deferred tax adjustment of $16,851,000. Latest year results included a pre- tax writedown of $22 million taken in the third quarter.

title: Review/Jazz; 23 Years at Village Vanguard
description: The big band Mel Lewis and Thad Jones organized in 1966 to play Monday nights at the Village Vanguard is observing its 23d anniversary in Max Gordon's celebrated cellar and, as it always does on its anniversaries, it is playing for a full week, through Sunday.

title: Curtiss-Wright Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $563,000 and $2,023,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-After an extraordinary charge of $234,000 for the quarter and an extraordinay credit of $3,548,000 for the year.

title: What's Still Wrong With Political Assassination
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpts From Remarks by Bush About Tower
description: Following are excerpts from remarks here today by President Bush about the nomination of John G. Tower as Defense Secretary, at a photography session with William J. Bennett, the designated director of the National Drug Control Policy. A transcript was provided by the White House. The Controversy

title: Atlantic Energy Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BUSH BACKS TOWER AMID NEW CHARGES INVOLVING NOMINEE
description: President Bush strongly defended his choice of John G. Tower as Defense Secretary today, denouncing the ''frenzied speculation'' about Mr. Tower's character and challenging critics to produce ''hard information'' in support of their doubts about the nominee.

title: Audit Cites Flaws in Program For Nuclear Reactor in Space
description: The Federal Government's main program to fashion a nuclear reactor for use in outer space is seriously flawed and in danger of failing, according to a Government audit made public yesterday.

title: Death of Arrested Man Is Linked to Drug Use
description: The death of a young man here in police custody was brought on by drug use and not police brutality as some residents have contended, officials said today.

title: Smith International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $1,644,000 and $41,666,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net income Preferred dividend requirements erased latest quarter per share net. Latest-quarter results included $666,000 positive adjustment as a result of adopting the local currency as the functional currency for certain of the company's international operations. Latest-year results included a $23,400,000 charge for estimated costs to be incurred in closing the company's Irvine-based operations and consolidating all U.S. manufacturing into Ponca City and Houston. Results also included a $2,200,000 gain as a result of adopting the local currency as the functional currency for certain of its international operations. Year-ago quarter results included $91,400,000 reorganization gain, a $6,800,000 gain on settlement of certain pension obligations, and $24,800,000 in unusual charges to provide for further consolidation of operations and other non-recurring items. Prior-year results included $91,400,000 gain resulting from adopting bankruptcy organization plan, a $38,900,000 gain resulting from an account change regaarding pensions, and a $28,700,000 unusual charge to provide for further consolidation of operations and other non-recurring items.

title: Journalists' Double Standard
description: LEAD: It's virtually breathtaking to see the arrogance that surfaces among some journalists when the tables turn and questions arise about their possible conflicts of interest.

title: MOLECULE IS SEEN AS AN AIDS FIGHTER
description: Hybrid molecules closely related to CD4, a substance being tested as a promising drug against AIDS, may themselves have value in treating that deadly disease, scientists reported yesterday.

title:
FIVE DESIGNERS: FIVE DECORATING STRATEGIES;
The 'Good Bones' Approach
description: LEAD: ''WHILE the overall effect of a room is important, the average one still needs 'good bone structure,' said Lemeau, a partner in the Lemeau & Llana interior design firm in New York City. ''I'm not talking about glazed walls or ones with 25 coats of paint. Rather, there has to be some sense of proportion and style added to an ordinary room.

title: Afghan Rebel Tactic: Shut Airports
description: Afghan guerrillas plan to close airports as the first step to force the surrender of Afghanistan's cities, a guerrilla news organization said today.

title: Diagnostek Inc reports earnings for
description: b-Net loss Latest periods' results included Health Care Services, which was acquired in Febrary 1988.

title:
FIVE DESIGNERS: FIVE DECORATING STRATEGIES;
The Comfort Zone
description: LEAD: ''FIRST things first,'' said the interior designer Ginger Barber of Houston and Los Angeles. ''Regardless of the money you have, you will need to create a comfort zone. In others words, a place to sit down.'' Expect to spend about half of a $10,000 budget on good-quality upholstered furniture, basic items like a sofa, a club chair and perhaps an ottoman.

title: CALENDAR: A TRIBUTE TO COWBOY MYSTIQUE
description: Two at the Met,

title: L. Janette Richardson, Professor, 63
description: L. Janette Richardson, a professor of literature who specialized in Chaucer, died of cancer Jan. 28 at the home of a friend in Piedmont, Calif. She was 63 years old and lived in Oakdale, Calif.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly SPECIAL COMMITTEE ON DECOLONIZATION - 10:30 A.M. Economic and Social Council ORGANIZATIONAL SESSION - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. STATISTICAL COMMISSION - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: 40 Presidents Hath U.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: INSTALLING a wall-mounted cabinet may seem intimidating. But by planning the job thoroughly, using proper tools and fasteners and having an assistant to help hold the unit, amateurs can do the job without much difficulty.

title: Pacific Telecom Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Washington Talk: Briefing; Session or Meeting?
description: When President Bush addresses the Senate and the House tonight, will he be addressing a joint session or a joint meeting of Congress?

title: F.D.I.C. Has No 'Magic' In the Savings Industry
description: When the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation began taking control of insolvent savings and loan institutions on Tuesday as part of the Bush Administration's plan to solve the crisis in the industry, the Pacific Savings Bank of Costa Mesa, Calif., was as good a place to start as any.

title: Head of F.A.D.A. to Resign
description: Gerald P. Carmen, who took over the much-criticized Federal Asset Disposition Association last year, said today that he was resigning as president and chief executive of the Government agency, which manages and sells real estate that is acquired when ailing savings and loans are taken over.

title: Alan Bennett and the Verdigris of Life
description: There is an unofficial greeter at the gate to Alan Bennett's London house. She is a shriveled old woman, wearing a tattered wool cap, hunched over in her wheelchair, accosting would-be visitors with vaguely threatening gestures and indecipherable grunts. She lives in a decaying green van that occupies virtually all of the English writer's modest driveway, and she has been there since 1976.

title: The Isolation Of a Young Tennis Player
description: rrHenry Merlo's old conduct code was looking better and better last weekend. Particularly when Andre Agassi put his thumbs in his ears and started wiggling his fingers at the Paraguayan Davis Cup team.

title: Cooper Development reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included a $465,000 extraordinary charge for both the quarter and year. c-Net income and after a gain of $59,721,000 on the sale of discontinued operations for both the quarter and year, and an extraordinary gain of $4,189,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary charge of $522,000 for the year, and the year also included income of $7,775,000 from discontinued operations. The company said financial results for 1988 are not directly comparable with those of a year-ago, or with results reported in prior quarters. In January 1988 the company acquired an antiviral product line and the net assets of the Revo sunglass business. These businesses accounted for all of the company's sales in 1988.

title: Review/Recital; A Cellist's Idiosyncracies
description: Andres Diaz, the cellist who won the Naumburg Competition in 1986, displayed a strongly personal interpretive vision at his recital at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday evening. There were times when that vision was downright quirky, but the cellist's views always seemed deeply considered rather than superficial or manufactured.

title: Kelly Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Two More Cooling System Cracks Found in a Nuclear Arms Reactor
description: In another indication of the difficulties officials face in reopening the Savannah River nuclear weapons plant, the Energy Department said today that it had found two more cracks in the cooling system of a reactor that produces a crucial gas used in nuclear weapons.

title: Working Overtime: A bind for Parents
description: AT about 4 P.M. every day, working parents around the nation start getting nervous. They pace, tap pencils and take aspirin. It is an hour away from the moment of truth, when carefully orchestrated child-care arrangements can be thrown into a tailspin by a business meeting that runs long, a last-minute invitation from a superior to ''stop by,'' or by a manager who asks, ''Will you stay to finish this project?''

title: 2 Former Regina Officers Plead Guilty to Fraud Charges
description: Two former top executives of the Regina Company, a vacuum-cleaner maker, both admitted today that they had mailed falsified 1988 financial statements to investors, brokers and the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Salvadorans See Stick Over Carrot in Rebel Plan
description: While Salvadoran guerrilla commanders were putting the finishing touches on their peace proposal, their ''urban commandos'' put a bomb in the house of the Defense Minister's mother.

title: Miners' Strike Is a Test for Warsaw and Solidarity
description: Thousands of miners defied the authorities today by continuing a strike at a major coal mine feeding Poland's largest power-generating station.

title: Chicago Politics' New Twist: Civility
description: The two top contenders in the Democratic mayoral primary here are entering the final weeks of a campaign that seems conspicuously out of character for Chicago: low-key, civil and notably without the racial appeals that have scarred the city's recent history.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: In 3 Craft Shows, Color and Joy
description: RADIANT color and emanations of joy are the common features in the work of three uncommon artists whose exhibitions opened last week.

title: Review/Music; Andiamo In Works Old and New
description: The Andiamo Chamber Ensemble was formed six years ago and, led by a flutist named Barbara Siesel, it has enlisted a group of musicians mostly younger and less well known than those who appear with the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, Chamber Music at the Y and other such groups.

title: U.S. Sees Signs of Iraqi Unrest
description: The United States has evidence of unrest among Iraqi Army officers in mid-December that led to arrests and unconfirmed reports of executions, State Department officials said today.

title: Times Co.'s Net Income Rises 18.5% in Quarter
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that its net income in the fourth quarter rose by 18.5 percent, to $50.4 million, or 64 cents a share, from $42.5 million, or 52 cents a share, in the 1987 quarter. Its revenues rose by 3.3 percent, to $450 million from $435.5 million.

title: The World Series Of the Caribbean
description: It may seem odd that the Caribbean Series, winter baseball's annual championship, is being played this week on the shores of the Pacific Ocean, but that quirk is very much in keeping with the character of the February Classic.

title: Gooden Agrees to 3-Year Pact Making Him Top-Paid Met
description: Dwight Gooden, saying his career with the Mets was ''like a family thing'' that he wanted to preserve, agreed to a three-year contract for $6.7 million yesterday and will become the highest-paid player in the Mets' history and, at least for the time being, the highest-paid player in baseball.

title: Final Four Candidates
description: Byrne Meadowlands Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., is among four arenas that have been invited to bid on the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Final Four for 1994 and 1995, Cedric Dempsey, the chairman of the N.C.A.A. Basketball Committee, announced yesterday. Presentations will be made to the committee on July 2 by representatives of Byrne arena, the Charlotte Coliseum in North Carolina, the Seattle Kingdome and the Indianapolis Hoosier Dome. The Byrne Arena has hosted N.C.A.A. tournament games in recent years but not the Final Four. (AP)

title: Metro Matters; Commissioner Exchanges Desk For Driver's Seat
description: The lanky 37-year-old wearing a blue corduroy cap and a red ski jacket over his brown sweater settles behind the wheel of cab No. 9N64 on West 41st Street. He slides his hack license into the dashboard frame. It lists Gorman Gilbert as chairman of the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission. License 437511 identifies the driver as Jack S. Lusk.

title: Maier and Hangl Are First In World Alpine Super G
description: No one has really figured out the super G. It is a cross between the downhill and giant slalom, shorter than one, longer than the other. When the gates are set, it is very often more of one than the other.

title: Small Change at the Checkout
description: When New York City and Westchester shoppers pay for their groceries at D'Agostino supermarkets this month, they can also help provide hot meals for the homebound elderly. A clever innovation at the checkout counter makes it possible. Customers are asked to ''round up'' their bills to the next dime or dollar. The extra change goes to Citymeals-on-Wheels, which, in cooperation with New York City's Department for the Aging, delivers hot meals to nearly 8,000 homebound elderly on weekends and holidays. Any amount can be given, from pennies to dollars. The customer's receipt itemizes the donation along with the applesce and prodc.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Pan Am Shuttle Starts Big Drive
description: In the battle for the skies of the crowded Northeast Corridor, Pan Am is emphasizing the finer points of flying.

title: Louis A. Couderc, Executive, 60
description: Louis A. Couderc, a former executive of the Michelin Tire Corporation, died of pancreatic cancer Tuesday at the Falk Clinic in Toronto. He was 60 years old and had homes in Roslyn Estates, L.I., and Southampton, L.I.

title: James Patterson, 80, Former Congressman
description: James Patterson, a Republican who represented Connecticut's Fifth Congressional District in the House of Representatives from 1947 to 1959, died Tuesday at Our Lady of Lourdes Hospital here. He was 80 years old and lived in Bethlehem, Conn.

title: But We Are Going to Pay
description: Not many have noticed the bottom line of President Bush's plan to rescue the savings and loan industry. Over the next 30 years it is going to cost us, the taxpayers, upwards of $100 billion.

title: Ashland Enters a Plea Of No Contest in Spill
description: Ashland Oil Inc. has pleaded no contest to Federal environmental violations in the spill of more than 700,000 gallons of diesel fuel into the Monongahela River last year.

title: Bush Plan For Gains Tax Likely
description: President Bush is expected to propose a plan on Thursday that would re-establish a lower tax rate on capital gains for individuals, contending that it will bring the Treasury an extra $5 billion next year, according to a source with close ties to the Administration.

title: Ex-Justice Has Pneumonia
description: Former Associate Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. of the Supreme Court, who was hospitalized Monday after suffering from dizziness, has pneumonia and will remain at Baptist Medical Center for several more days, a spokesman for the medical center said today. Mr. Powell, who is 81 years old, was being treated with antibiotics and was reported to be in good condition with no respiratory distress. He retired from the Court in 1987.

title: Biedermeier and More on Grand Street
description: FINDING top-quality merchandise is a problem nearly every antiques dealer encounters these days. Not so Niall Smith, whose shop full of Biedermeier furniture has been a fixture at 344 Bleecker Street (10th Street) for 18 years.

title: Thomas Victor Is Dead; Photographer Was 51
description: Thomas Victor, a photographer of authors and performing artists, died Tuesday at his sister's home in Detroit. He was 51 years old. He died of leukemia, said his longtime assistant, Benjamin Ford.

title: TRW Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Home Intensive Care reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Shamir Upholds Force to End Violence
description: The Israeli Government focused on the American State Department's unusually harsh criticism of human rights practices in the occupied territories today, but only for as long as it took to affirm that the army will not change its behavior.

title: Eastman Kodak Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1988 results included the contribution of Sterling Drug Inc. from the effective date of its acquisition, Feb. 23.

title: Behind the Tower Smoke
description: John Tower's nomination to be Secretary of Defense is now in serious jeopardy. The cloud of rumors about his private life still appears to be mostly smoke. Yet even some former colleagues on the Senate Armed Services Committee have come to doubt his fitness. The White House and the committee have now agreed to postpone voting on the nomination, which gives time for reflection on Mr. Tower's candidacy.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Burson Gets Award
description: Harold Burson, the chairman and founder of Burson-Marsteller, has been named public relations professional of the year for 1989 by Public Relations News, a weekly industry newsletter. Mr. Burson is the first two-time recipient of the award, which he last won in 1977.

title: Temple-Inland Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Article 013789 -- No Title
description: Citing lower sales tax receipts and a projected drop in state aid, the Suffolk County Executive, Patrick G. Halpin, said today that he was prepared to cut county spending by up to $45 million this year.

title: Response to Amnesty
description: Human-rights organizations and Western diplomats gave a qualified welcome today to Iran's decision to free thousands of political prisoners.

title: In a Hard-Up Hungary, Unions Seek Raises
description: While the Hungarian leadership is seeking ways to resolve open political disagreements between the Communist Party chief and two other Politburo members, it has received sharp reminders this week of the economic woes that are foremost in Hungarians' lives.

title: Gordon E. Hyde, 92, Retired Ad Executive
description: Gordon E. Hyde, an advertising executive for half a century and a former president of the Grand Jury Association of New York County, died of pneumonia on Saturday at his home in North Salem, N.Y. He was 92 years old.

title: Champion Spark Plug Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $1,500,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Net loss d-After a loss of $3,600,000 for the quarter and income of $2,800,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bain & Co., Boston, a management consulting firm, said Paul M. Cholak had been named vice president for human resources.

title:
FIVE DESIGNERS: FIVE DECORATING STRATEGIES;
Keeping It Simple
description: LEAD: THE less complicated the look, the easier it is to accommodate a $10,000 budget, said A. J. Duarte, an interior designer in Carmel, Calif. Mr. Duarte would not advocate using busy patterns and prints or elaborate, time-consuming paint finishes. Instead he would emphasize monochromatic color schemes and simplicity in the overall look.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about alcohol addiction gave an incorrect date for Kitty Dukakis's entry into an alcohol treatment center. It was Sunday, not Friday.

title: Chilean Opposition Party Names Candidate
description: After four months of internal squabbling, the Christian Democratic Party has nominated its leader to run for President of Chile in elections in December.

title: Mannes College Joins the New School
description: The Mannes College of Music will merge today with the New School for Social Research, the presidents of both institutions said yesterday.

title: Indicted School Board Member Steps Aside
description: New York City's Schools Chancellor, Richard R. Green, said yesterday that a Bronx school board member who was accused of bribery in an indictment last month was ''voluntarily'' taking a leave of absence, and Dr. Green commended him for the action.

title: N.C.A.A. Rules Shut Some Students Out
description: To the Editor:

title: I.B.M. and Rebels Head for Battle
description: Personal computer users who have been thinking of upgrading to a more sophisticated machine should take note: The war between I.B.M. and the rebel coalition of computer makers is far from over.

title: A Guide to Building and Remodeling
description: BUILDING a new house from scratch or significantly remodeling an old one is a dicey project, especially for novices.

title: Bloomingdale's Fills Vice Chairman's Job
description: Lester Gribetz, a New Yorker who began his career as a member of Bloomingdale's executive training squad in 1954, was named its vice chairman yesterday, becoming the first to hold that job in many years.

title: Denver Airport Plan Runs Into Trouble
description: Six months before construction is scheduled to begin, the United States' first major new airport in 15 years faces the strong possibility of delay.

title: Computers Ferret Out Tax Fraud
description: New York taxpayers beware: Locked in a drawer in Joseph M. Catalina's desk, deep in the Revenue Opportunity Division of the New York State Tax Department, is a small computer disk containing hundreds of ideas about potential tax-fraud investigations.

title: CBS Net Income Tumbled 84.1% in the Fourth Quarter
description: CBS Inc. reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter net income plunged 84.1 percent, reflecting a large special gain in the comparable 1987 quarter.

title: Kroger Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-After a one-time credit of $63,344,816, or 79 cents a share, for a change in accounting for income taxes. Sales represent total sales. The latest periods included $195 million in pre-tax non-recurring costs associated with the restructuring and other non-recurring reorganization costs.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Kroll Hires Ex-Head Of New York City Police
description: LEAD: Robert J. McGuire, former chief executive of Pinkerton's Inc. and before that New York City Police Commissioner, has been named a senior managing director of Kroll Associates, which specializes in investigations for law firms, financial institutions and corporations.

title: Attacker Is Now Accused of Abduction
description: One of two brothers who were awaiting sentencing in a bias-related assault in the Bronx was arrested late Tuesday on charges of kidnapping a 19-year-old man who the brothers contend actually committed the assault.

title: Frederick Close, 83, Ex-Chairman of Alcoa
description: Frederick J. Close, a former chairman of the Aluminum Company of America, died Monday at Lake County East Hospital in Painesville, Ohio, after a fall at his home there. He was 83 years old.

title: Pepperell Sets Deadline for Bids
description: West Point-Pepperell Inc. set a deadline of noon next Wednesday for bids for the giant textile company, which was put up for sale by its directors last week. The company, based here, also announced that a special shareholders meeting to consider a hostile takeover bid by Farley Inc., based in Chicago, had been postponed from Feb. 25 to March 2, with Farley's agreement.

title: Saving for Education Costs: The Strategy Has Changed
description: To many families, one of their biggest and most important expenses is the children's education. Under the nation's new tax laws the best ways to save for those costs have changed, as have financial strategies for other dependents.

title: Stolen Plaque Is Returned to a Bangkok Museum
description: Through the good offices of a curator at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, a piece of stolen art has been returned voluntarily to Thailand for the first time in memory.

title: Washington Talk: The Secretary of State; Hitting the Road Without a Map of Foreign Policy
description: James A. Baker 3d heads off for a tour of Canada and 14 Western European countries Friday on his first outing as Secretary of State, leaving behind a State Department that is still trying to adjust to his management style and a foreign affairs community still puzzled over what policies he intends to adopt.

title: Holiday Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $2,000 for the quarter and a $29,591,000 charge related to the early retirement of debt for the year. c-After a loss of $3,060,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and year, and a $3,178,000 extraordinary charge for the quarter and a charge of $6,636,000 related to early retirement of debt for the year.

title: UDC-Universal Development LP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Washington Talk: Briefing; Dukakis Reflects
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts was on Capitol Hill yesterday, but his business was largely local, a contrast to trips he made to Congress last year when he was the Democratic Presidential nominee.

title: 'Trouble in Tahiti'
description: The American Symphony Orchestra is to commemorate Leonard Bernstein's 70th birthday with a performance of his ''Trouble in Tahiti'' at Carnegie Hall, on Feb. 19 at 3 P.M. The concert, with George Hanson conducting, will also feature Leonidas Kavakos as soloist in Tchaikovsky's Violin Concerto. Tickets are $25, $20 and $15. Information and tickets: 247-7800.

title: Children's Car Safety Debated
description: The National Transportation Safety Board today urged another agency to change its recommendation on the safest way to put a seat belt on a child.

title: Personal Health
description: At 15 years old, Diane S. had large flashing eyes, a well-developed body and a razor-sharp mind. But as far as she was concerned, all that anyone noticed was her ''enormous'' nose.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: SUSAN attributes her straight-A average at college to a great deal of dedication and hard work. ''It's gotten me a lot of awards and scholarships,'' she said. ''But I'm sick a lot. I have a lot of depression. Since July I've had constant headaches.''

title: Sanctions Are Sought On Pretoria
description: The foreign ministers of the Commonwealth nations decided today to seek ways to strengthen financial sanctions against South Africa after it was disclosed that a Canadian bank had made a large loan to a South African-controlled company.

title: Hasbro Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
description: Hasbro said it incurred $16.4 million in pre-tax costs during the first 9 months of the year, associated with the now-discontinued development of an interactive video entertainment system.

title: Hershey Foods Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $16,063,000 and a gain of $53,380,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations. c-After income from discontinued operations of $4,568,000 for the quarter and $24,097,000 for the year.

title: Post for Goodman Is Weighed
description: Republican members of the New York Congressional delegation held a secret meeting today with an aide to the White House Chief of Staff to decide whether to block State Senator Roy M. Goodman, Republican of Manhattan, in his effort to obtain a high-level appointment in the Bush Administration, sources close to the legislators said.

title: Board of Trade to Weigh Changes
description: To bolster public confidence and demonstrate that it can regulate itself, the Chicago Board of Trade said today that it would consider a number of changes in its trading procedures.

title: Pro-Life, to the Death
description: Last Dec. 13, the Klein family of Upper Brookville, L.I., suffered a terrible tragedy. Nancy Klein, 32 years old, the mother of a child and about two months pregnant, was in an automobile accident that left her severely brain-damaged. She has been in a coma ever since, and her doctors don't hold out much hope.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Jefferies Credibility Is Assailed
description: In several dramatic confrontations, defense lawyers yesterday assailed the credibility of Boyd L. Jefferies, the Government's main witness in the GAF Corporation stock manipulation trial and two other major securities cases.

title: Nuggets' Moe Awarded Another Extension
description: Doug Moe, who has coached the Denver Nuggets since 1980, yesterday signed his third contract extension, one that will take him through the 1992-93 season. Terms of the contract were not disclosed. Moe, 50 years old, whose current contract expires next October, has been with the same team longer than any other active National Basketball Association coach. Moe has won two division titles with Denver and has led the Nuggets to the playoffs seven straight times. He was named the N.B.A. coach of the year for the 1987-88 season when the Nuggets finished with a 54-28 record, the best in Denver's history, and won the Midwest Division championship. The Nuggets are in fourth place in the Midwest Division this season with a 24-23 record.(AP)

title: Soviet Composers Union Readmits Rostropovich
description: The Soviet cellist and conductor Mstislav Rostropovich, stripped of his citizenship in 1978 while in the United States, has been restored to membership in the Soviet Composers Union, the Tass news agency said today.

title: Assault Rifles Assault Common Sense
description: Patrick Purdy, the Stockton, Calif., schoolyard killer, might have inspired national soul-searching about violence in American life. Instead he inspired a bonanza in gun sales. On learning that Mr. Purdy had used a $400 Chinese-made military assault rifle to kill five children and wound 30 others, Californians jammed the stores and within days had snapped up the inventory of such weapons.

title: Two Plays Are Postponed
description: Two Off Broadway productions have postponed their openings. ''Love's Labor's Lost,'' the Shakespeare comedy transposed to the early 1930's, was to have opened next Tuesday at the Public Theater, but is now to open Feb. 22. ''In a Pig's Valise,'' a musical with book and lyrics by Eric Overmyer and music by August Darnell, which was to open this Sunday at the Second Stage, is to open Tuesday. Both shows will continue at these theaters in previews.

title: Irene Mattone, Teacher, 56
description: Irene Mattone, a teacher and president of the Queens division of the American Cancer Society, died of breast cancer Tuesday at Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 56 years old and lived in Douglaston, Queens.

title: Imasco Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a special charge of $110 million for the quarter and year. c-Net income d-After a special charge of $29,079,000. The company said last month that it would take the $110 million fourth- quarter special charge to provide for the cost of reorganizing it Peoples Drug Stores unit. The results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: HEALTH: Mental Health; Psychiatric Care: Orphan of Insurance Coverage
description: Millions of American families are discovering that their insurance covers a far smaller portion of care for mental illness than it does for medical and surgical treatment.

title: U.S. Studies Compromise in Beef Dispute
description: The Bush Administration is weighing whether to offer the European Community a compromise in the dispute over the community's ban on imports of beef raised with growth hormones, Administration officials said today.

title: North Korea Threatens to Boycott Talks With Seoul
description: North Korea said today that it would boycott a planned meeting with the South on Friday because South Korea was going ahead with joint military exercises with the United States, according to South Korean press reports.

title: O'Neill Offers Tax Increases To Close Gap
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill, saying Connecticut was prosperous enough to meet its budget crisis without severe cuts in essential services, proposed today $737 million in new and increased taxes, including a sales tax on utility bills.

title: TV Notes
description: An Albatross for CBS

title: What's Still Wrong With Political Assassination; Law of the Land
description: To the Editor:

title: KEY RATES
Coleman Pleads Guilty
description: Derrick Coleman of Syracuse University, who is among the nation's leaders in rebounding and blocked shots, pleaded guilty yesterday in Syracuse City Court to harassment and disorderly conduct charges stemming from a fight and break-in incident on campus last December. Coleman, a junior, was sentenced by Judge James Tormey to 50 hours of community service and was ordered to make restitution for damages he caused during the Dec. 11 incident. Because both of the charges are classified as violations, Coleman will have no criminal record, his attorney, Donald Martin, said.(AP)

title: 2 Indicted in Big Tax Fraud Case
description: In what prosecutors described as one of the largest tax fraud cases ever, a New York financier and a Florida businessman were indicted yesterday on charges of engaging in a scheme involving $38 billion in bogus trades that generated hundreds of millions of dollars in tax benefits for investors.

title: Freshly Cut Firewood Delivered to Your Door
description: FOR 10 years, Sam Henderson has been chopping oaks, ashes, beeches and maples near his home in upper Bucks County, Pa., and delivering firewood three times a week to 150 customers in Manhattan, Queens and Brooklyn.

title: Books of The Times; In Doctorow's Latest, the World as Underworld
description: Billy Bathgate By E. L. Doctorow 323 pages. Random House. $19.95.

title: Fabrics In a Greek Motif
description: AT first glance, the floral-covered folder heralding its spring collection looks like many others produced by Brunschwig & Fils. But this season the fabric company has a new angle.

title: Drexler Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss of $246,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net loss d-Included losses from discontinued operations of $408,000 and $1,427,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Philadelphia Bank Offers 9 3/4% Notes
description: The Philadelphia National Bank, a unit of the Corestates Financial Corporation, is offering $50 million of 9 3/4 percent deposit notes due 1993 at a price of 99.85 to yield 9.80 percent through Prudential-Bache Capital Funding.

title: Kirshbaum Cello Recital
description: Ralph Kirshbaum, the cellist, is to play sonatas by Samuel Barber and Cesar Franck, Bach's Suite No. 2 (BWV 1008) and Janacek's ''Pohadka'' at Weill Recital Hall tonight at 8. Tickets are $12. Information: 247-7800.

title: Now! On Video! Harry, Watching His Grass Grow
description: Dr. Wally Shaw, a respected anesthesiologist and America's top-ranking amateur film maker, thinks the problem may be biological, and the 35-year-old suburban male seems most vulnerable. By 35, the suburbanite's got himself a car, a house, an insurance policy, a couple of nice calendars from his agent and then, suddenly, this perfectly decent man gets a craving to bore and humiliate everyone dear to him. No matter what the consequences or what the price, he is going to buy a video camera.

title: Schools Speed Their Efforts to Lock Violence Out of Classroom
description: LEAD: Shaken by recent shootings at schools, particularly the killing of five children in California three weeks ago, educators have renewed their search for ways to assure students' safety.

title: Rangers Snap 3-3 Tie To End Losing Streak
description: It would have been hard for any of the Rangers to have imagined a less likely instrument of victory.
