But the power play, a clanking, laboring, all but inoperable bit of offensive machinery recently, finally ground out a goal for them last night, and the result was a 4-3 victory over the Winnipeg Jets.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Briefing; Presidential Prose
description: The late Malcolm Baldrige worked hard as Commerce Secretary in the Reagan Administration to stop the spread of bureaucratese in Government memorandumss and announcements and to nudge everyone toward writing more muscular and interesting prose - ''halfway between Zane Grey and Ernest Hemingway,'' as he put it. This does not seem to have rubbed off on his old friend, George Bush.

title: Colgate-Palmolive Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a charge of $42 million from a one-time payment under a new royalty agreement at Hill's pet products division and a gain of $125 million from the sale of Kendall Health Care for both the quarter and year. c-After a restructuring provision of $150 million.

title: When to Sell Secrets to Moscow
description: With the Soviets finally dragging themselves out of Afghanistan, a question now divides Western policy makers: Should the United States drop its blanket ban on high-technology sales to the Soviet Union and simply decide them on a case-by-case basis, as it did before the Soviet invasion?

title: Bhopal Court Declaration
description: A court today declared Warren Anderson, the former chairman of the Union Carbide Corporation, an ''absconding offender'' in an effort to extradite him from the United States to face charges in the Bhopal gas leak.

title: Angeles Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Year-ago quarter and 6-month nets were exceeded by preferred dividend requirements.

title: Elmira Savings Bank reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Leoni Neumann Claman, Physician, 87
description: Dr. Leoni Neumann Claman, a physician and allergist, died of cancer Sunday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. She was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Expert in Specialty Cars Heads Maserati Exports
description: LEAD: Mario Tozzi-Condivi, a lifelong expert in the worldwide market for specialty cars, has been named general manager for global exports of Maserati, the Italian luxury car whose manufacturer is controlled by De Tomaso Industries.

title: Heist, C H reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
Corrections

description: b-After realized investment losses of $12,828,000 for the quarter and $24,810,000 for the year. c-After realized investment losses of $17,381,000 and $28,870,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Surgeons Offer U.S. A Break for Many Enrolled in Medicare
description: The American College of Surgeons has offered to have its 85,000 members lower their fees for Medicare patients who have low income or require emergency surgery.

title: Centrust Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After gains of $8,614,000 on the sale of loans and investments. c-Net income and after gains of $26,097,000 on the sale of loans and investments.

title: Boggs Challenges Suit
description: Wade Boggs will contest Margo Adams's lawsuit in court rather than try to reach a settlement with the woman with whom he had a four-year extramarital affair, the Boston Red Sox third baseman said yesterday after giving an eight-hour deposition in Tampa, Fla.

title: Mr. Coffee's Agency Rejects 'Mr. Tea'
description: The most interesting feature of a new advertising campaign for the Iced Tea Pot by Mr. Coffee might well be what it does not do - refer to the gadget as ''Mr. Tea.''

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the mayoral election in Chicago gave an incorrect date for the general election in some copies. It is April 4, not May 2.

IEH Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Net income and after tax credit of $19,000. c-After a $156,000 tax credit.

title: Century Bancorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Review/Ballet; Basel's Treatment of Love and Meddling
description: ''La Fille Mal Gardee'' has led a charmed life. It was first produced in 1789 with choreography by Jean Dauberval - choreography that was forgotten long ago. But for the last 200 years, other choreographers have been inspired to do their own versions of this ballet, which shows how two young lovers, Lise and Colas, outwit the attempts of Lise's mother to marry her off to Alain, a wealthy nitwit. Surprisingly, many of these later stagings have been good.

title: Itel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-After anti-trust charges of $7.3 million for the quarter and year. The latest fourth quarter included an $8 million non-recurring expense for a bridge-loan fee related to Itel's purchase of assets from Henley Group Inc. In addition, acquisitions added about $15 million to interest expense in the latest quarter. The results included provisions in lieu of federal income tax, which is not accruable or payable, of $3.2 million and $18.8 million for the latest quarter and year, respectively, and $2.7 million and $11.8 million for the year-ago quarter and year, respectively. The nets for the latest fourth quarter and 1987 year were exceeded by preferred dividend requirements.

title: Household International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $16.5 million for the quarter and $63 million for the year. c-After income from discontinued operations of $11.1 million for the quarter and $57.5 million for the year. The company said that as a result of its plan to spin off a portion of its manufacturing operations and sell the remaining units, results for Household Manufacturing for all periods are included in discontinued operations.

title: Carmike Cinemas Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WASHINGTON TALK: Briefing; Buttons for a Senator
description: Senate Republicans greeted President Bush at their caucus meeting this week adorned with large green and white buttons bearing the slogan, ''Run Nancy Run.'' The subject of the campaign is Senator Nancy Kassebaum, a two-term Kansas Republican who is up for re-election in 1990.

title: 'Traviata' in Brooklyn
description: The New York City Opera National Company is to perform Verdi's ''Traviata'' at the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College, Flatbush and Nostrand Avenues in the Flatbush section, Sunday at 4 P.M. The cast includes Donna Zapola, a soprano; Paul Hartfield, a tenor, and Ron Peo, a baritone. Joshua Greene is to conduct. Tickets are $20 to $14. Information: (718) 434-2222.

description: b-Included investment gains of $544,000 and $3,508,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-After investment losses of $2,058,00 for the quarter and investment gains of $58,346,000 for the year, and the year also included a tax loss carryforward of $3,978,000.

title: About Real Estate; Developer Challenging Uniformity
description: When a developer has the opportunity to build on a large tract of land, the customary approach is to keep all the homes on similarly sized lots, with roughly equal standards of luxury or affordability.

title: Braintree Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said its fourth quarter and full-year results included low-income housing tax credits of $137,000 for 1988, while 1987 included $465,000 of historical rehabilitation tax credits.

Financial News Network Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said comparable year-ago figures not applicable; company changed its fiscal year-end to June 30 from Aug. 31.

title: Howard Names Coach
description: Howard University announced the appointment yesterday of Steve Wilson, a former Denver Broncos defensive back, as the school's football coach. Wilson, a 1978 graduate of Howard, played with the Broncos for the last six years after playing with the Dallas Cowboys.

title: Jordan Acts on Dinar
description: Jordan forcibly closed offices of moneychangers around the nation today, blaming them for speculating against the weakened dinar. Police locked and sealed the premises of more than 70 exchanges in Amman, the capital, and elsewhere, including exchanges at borders and airports, witnesses said.

description: b-Included a tax credit of $2,700,000 and $10,400,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included a tax credit of $3,100,000 and $8,100,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also included a charge of $3,200,000 from the extinguishment of debt.

title: Rock at the Ritz
description: Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds, a rock band, will perform tonight about 12:30 A.M. at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street (24-2800). The Wolfgang Press opens at 11 P.M. Tickets ar $14.50.

title: Halliburton Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a $9 million gain from adoption of uniform cost capitalization for certain inventories and manufactured equipment. The latest periods included a pre- tax charge of $27.2 million incurred in recognition of Halliburton's logging and geophysical businesses.

title: Aviation Officials Warn of Delays In Steps to Tighten Flight Security
description: Heightened airport security measures ordered in response to the recent bombing of a Pan American jetliner will take many months or even years to put into effect, Government aviation security officials said today.

description: Reno's Commentary

Saturdays, at the Promenade Theater, Broadway and 76th Street. Tickets: $10 and $14. Reservations: 677-5959. title: Court Upholds Abortion Right In L.I. Dispute
description: A New York State appeals court in Brooklyn last night upheld the right of a Long Island man to authorize an abortion for his pregnant, comatose wife that he says will save her life. But hours later, the state's highest court stayed the ruling pending an appeal by abortion opponents.

title: Valley West Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Savings Rescue to Cost Taxpayers An Extra $20 Billion, Data Show
description: The amount of taxpayer money needed under President Bush's plan to rescue the savings and loan industry is almost $20 billion higher than initially described by the White House, according to an analysis of data released by the Administration.

title: A.T.&T. Deal With Italtel Advances
description: Italy's principal state holding company today approved a plan for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to become a partner with Italtel S.p.A., the state-owned telecommunications equipment manufacturer, putting A.T.&T. a step closer to clinching a major part of one of Europe's largest telecommunications modernization programs.

title: A Free-Spirited Young Skater Blooms Under the Lights
description: It did not take Jessica Mills long to relegate her recent victory at the world junior championships to no-big-deal status, if it had ever been a big deal in the first place.

title: Afghan Rebel Alliance Ousts Leader
description: Within hours of the convening of an Afghan exile council charged with electing a unified alternative government to the Kabul regime, the guerrilla alliance has abruptly changed its leadership.

title: Wheelabrator Technologies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company attributed its improved earnings in 1988 to its refuse- to-energy business, primarily related to two new facilities that began operations in the year.

title: Hatcher Injured
description: Kevin Hatcher, the Washington Capitals' top goal-scoring defenseman with 11 goals, will be out for at least 10-12 days with a bone fracture in his left foot, Coach Bryan Murray said yesterday. Hatcher was hurt Sunday, when he was struck by a shot taken by Mike Bullard of Philadelphia. X-rays on Tuesday showed fractures in the second and third metatarsal bones.(AP)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY President Bush presented a revised $1.6 trillion version of the Reagan budget that features a one-year freeze in the military budget at the level of inflation and modest spending increases in some domestic programs. He said the projected revenues for 1990 will be $80 billion more than they are this year. [ Page A1. ] The budget also contained a cut in capital gains taxes and provisions that would encourage businesses to conduct research, drill for oil and gas and establish operations in distressed areas. [ D1. ] The amount of taxpayer money needed under President Bush's plan to rescue the savings and loan industry is almost $20 billion higher than initially described by the White House, according to an analysis of data released by the Administration. [ Page A1. ] The abrupt decision by Federal regulators to cancel discussions over the likely sale of more than 70 insolvent savings institutions in Texas has angered many prospective investors. [ D2. ] The Government's effort to prosecute fraud in the savings industry is not likely to lead to large recoveries of stolen funds, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said. [ D1. ] COMPANIES A.T.&T.'s plan to become a partner with Italtel won approval from Italy's principal state holding company. The move put A.T.&T. a step closer to clinching a major part of one of Europe's largest telecommunications modernization programs. [ D1. ] Sears, Roebuck reported a 78.8 percent drop in fourth-quarter earnings, although the retailer said revenues set a record. [ D2. ] Texas Air reported a loss of $224.4 million in the fourth quarter. NWA said its earnings for the period rose sharply. [ D4. ] A California wine maker has agreed to a cross-investment with one of France's most prestigious vineyards. [ D4. ] Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts has completed its $24.88 billion tender offer for RJR Nabisco. [ D4. ] Regina sued its former chairman, who has pleaded guilty to having falsified the company's financial statements in 1988. [ D13. ] Mazda Motor introduced its Miata sports car, an entry designed to attract younger, less-affluent buyers and to inspire nostalgia for the bygone era of British two-seat sports coupes. [ D5. ] A popular new idea in television advertising is the ''unwired network,'' an arrangement that offers companies a national audience for their ads at a lower cost than time on the networks. [ D17. ] MARKETS The dollar fell sharply in a flurry of selling prompted in part, traders said, by suddenly lower expectations on the impact of President Bush's budget proposals. [ D1. ] Treasury bond prices posted their biggest declines in more than three months, reflecting a weaker dollar and poor investor response to the Treasury's auction of 30-year bonds. [ D12. ] Cattle futures prices dropped on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange after a Government report showed a larger-than-expected cattle herd. [ D14. ] Stock prices plunged and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 20.17 points, to 2,323.04, its biggest drop since it lost 23.93 points on Jan. 3. [ D6. ] The Chicago Board of Trade is developing a computerized after-hours trading system. The system would take place only outside regular trading hours and would not be available to nonmembers. [ D6. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS New players in the commodities futures business say their importance to the markets is belied by their lack of influence over exchange policies and practices. Market Place. [ D1. ] Otto Lambsdorff, the head of West Germany's Free Democratic Party, warns that nationalistic and protectionist pressures remain strong in some European countries although trade barriers are to be lifted in 1992. Leonard Silk: Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Avia Athletic Footwear has released a new ad campaign that differs markedly from its previous effort. Advertising. [ D17. ]

title: Dickenson Mines Ltd reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a special gain of $1,257,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Stocks Slide as Dow Tumbles 20.17 Points
description: Stock prices plunged yesterday and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 20.17 points, to 2,323.04, its biggest drop since it fell 23.93 points on Jan. 3.

title: Economic Scene; Concerns Grow On 'Europe 1992'
description: WILL a Western Europe without internal trade barriers mean a more open market for the United States and other countries? Or will this Europe, to be created by the end of 1992, become ''Fortress Europe'': an inward-looking bloc that will accelerate a global trend toward regional trading blocs?

title: American Maize-Products Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-After extraordinary charges from the repurchase and early retirement of debt of $107,000 and $411,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said the latest quarter included a $4 million provision to restructure the building materials business and write-off intangible assets. The company also said year-ago periods included a gain of $858,000 from the conversion of certain American Maize-Products debentures into American Fructose Corp. common stock.

title: Service for Henri Peyre
description: A service for Henri Peyre, Distinguished Professor Emeritus of French at the City University Graduate School who had been the Sterling Professor of French Emertius at Yale University, will be held Tuesday at 6:30 P.M. in the auditorium of the CUNY Graduate Center at 33 West 42d Street. Professor Peyre died Dec. 9 at the age of 87.

title: Jason Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Tobacco Company, Stamford, Conn., promoted Preston H. Leake, John H. Hager and Leonard M. Tilley to vice president.

title: Tax Refunds Delayed a Week
description: About 450,000 tax-refund checks will be delayed a week because of a computer programming error, the Internal Revenue Service said today.

title: Potential Investors Put on Hold Are Angry
description: The abrupt decision by Federal regulators to cancel discussions on the likely sale of more than 70 insolvent savings institutions in Texas has angered many prospective investors, say lawyers and industry officials.

title: Austrian Skier Posts Upset in Giant Slalom
description: As he prepared for his second effort down the giant slalom course today at the world Alpine ski championships, all that Rudolf Nierlich of Austria had to do was prove that his winning time in the first run was no fluke. He was ahead of such giants of the slalom as Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland, Marc Girardelli of Luxembourg, Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden and Alberto Tomba of Italy.

title: B'nai B'rith Apologizes for Letter Containing Anti-Arab Statements
description: An Arab-American group has demanded and received an apology from B'nai B'rith International, the world's largest Jewish organization, for sending out a fund-raising letter to 14,000 of its members that said: ''The Arab presence on campus is poisoning the minds of our young people.''

title: Invitation to Bush
description: At Yale University, opposite Davenport College, where George Bush once resided and studied, there stands the St. Thomas More Catholic Chapel. Each Wednesday a group of students, faculty, spouses and others run a soup kitchen there for the needy and hungry of downtown New Haven. It's always crowded, with sometimes as many as 200 people pushing in to escape from the cold and to get warm food. The contrast between their poverty and Yale's general prosperity could not be more marked.

title: Brandon Systems Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
Fidelity Federal Savings Bank of Indiana reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Police Biased, Hispanic Unit Tells Koch
description: A delegation representing 30 Hispanic organizations in New York City told Mayor Edward I. Koch yesterday that they had lost all faith in Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward's ability to deal with their longstanding complaints but were prepared to work directly with the Mayor to resolve them.

title: Monarch Machine Tool Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Review/Ballet; Sense of Brooding Mystery
description: ''Divertimento'' from ''Le Baiser de la Fee,'' presented by the New York City Ballet on Wednesday night at the New York State Theater, is one of George Balanchine's odder ballets. A thing of pieces, it is set to excerpts from two works by Igor Stravinsky, one of them inspired by Tchaikovsky and by Hans Christian Andersen's ''Ice Maiden.'' Balanchine tinkered with the ballet over 37 years, coming up at last, in 1972, with a plotless ballet that was virtually a completely new work and that was itself later amended.

title: National Education Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Latest fourth-quarter and year results included an after-tax charge of $1,485,000 related to the merger with Spectrum Interactive Inc. which was completed in the latest fourth quarter. Year-ago fourth-quarter and year results included an after-tax charge of $20,400,000 resulting from consolidation costs of the merger. Results restated to include operations of Spectrum on a pooling-of-interest basis.

title: Books of The Times; 'Guernica': Few Ripples at First, Many Since
description: Picasso's Guernica History, Transformations, Meanings By Herschel B. Chipp Illustrated. 316 pages. University of California Press. $37.50.

title: Honeywell Rises On Unisys Rumor
description: The shares of Honeywell Inc. climbed today amid rumors that the Unisys Corporation, the computer maker, was interested in buying the Minneapolis-based company. Honeywell's stock soared $3 a share, to $67, on the New York Stock Exchange, after touching $69. Analysts said the company might command $4 billion, although they doubted whether a takeover bid would emerge. Honeywell may also be worth more divided up than as one company, they said.

title: Numerica Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest fourth quarter included a $5,185,000 charge associated with the discontinued operations, a $2,129,399 loss from mortgage banking activities and a $5,723,980 increase in the loan- loss provision.

title: Genrad Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income of $1,864,000 for the quarter from discontinued operations and a loss of $39,125,000 for the year. The latest year included a restructuring charge of $10 million. The year-ago quarter is after a $2 million charge from a provision for the expected carrying costs of idle facilities. The 1987 year loss from discontinued operations included a provision of $34.5 million from the discontinuance of the company's semiconductor test division.

title: Lincoln as Lawyer: Transcript Tells Murder Story
description: In the summer of 1859, a year after he was defeated by Stephen A. Douglas for the United States Senate and less than a year before he received the Republican nomination for President, Abraham Lincoln spent four sweltering days, from Aug. 31 to Sept. 3, in the Sangamon Circuit Court here in his hometown, successfully defending a young man named Peachy Quinn Harrison against a charge of murder.

title: Abdul-Jabbar Is Added to Stars
description: David Stern, commissioner of the National Basketball Association, today named Kareem Abdul-Jabbar to replace the injured Magic Johnson on the Western Conference roster for Sunday's 39th annual All-Star Game at the Astrodome.

title: Coastal Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said prior year results included a one-time gain of $45 million from the reversal of an accural for crude oil costs.

description: b-Net loss The latest fourth quarter loss included a $1.8 million charge at the company's Bemac securities unit and an $800,000 writedown of BankEast's investment in CRC International, a British merchant banking firm. The year-ago fourth quarter loss included a $19 million writedown of BankEast's stock portfolio.

title: A.T.&T.'s Bid On Duty Gains
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company's effort to persuade the Government to impose higher duties on small-business telephone equipment imported from the Far East has cleared a hurdle in the International Trade Commission.

title: Asuncion Journal; After the Late Unpleasantness, Palace Pleasantries
description: Only three days had passed since the ouster of Gen. Alfredo Stroessner, but the transfer of loyalties to Paraguay's new military leader was moving ahead smoothly, if somewhat sweatily, as scores of politicians elbowed and shoved for an opportunity to greet Gen. Andres Rodriguez.

title: Jamaican Vote Sweeps Manley to Power
description: Michael N. Manley, a social democrat who presided over Jamaica for eight tumultuous years in the 1970's, swept to victory tonight in national elections.

title: Sears Income Retreated By 78.8% in 4th Quarter
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's biggest retailer and a leading financial services company, said yesterday that its net income plummeted 79 percent although revenues reached a record in the fourth quarter.

title: Andreas Bach Recital
description: Andreas Bach, a pianist, is to play a recital at the 92d Street Y, on Lexington Avenue, tomorrow evening at 8. His program includes Beethoven's Sonata No. 4 in E flat (Op. 7); Schumann's ''Davidsbundlertanze'' (Op. 6), Liszt's ''Apres une Lecture de Dante'' and selections from Bartok's ''Out of Doors'' Suite. Tickets are $20 to $15. Information: 996-1100.

title: Baker-Shevardnadze Meeting Is Reportedly Due March 7
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze are to meet on March 7, a Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman, Gennadi I. Gerasimov, told a news conference today.

title: Horses, Yes, But Please, No Ranches
description: These are nervous times for Bob and Mary Sargent and other horse owners scattered around this hilly country township.

title: U.S. Planning to Issue Extra Immigrant Visas
description: The State Department announced today that 10,000 extra visas a year would be issued randomly in 1990 and 1991 to immigrants from 162 countries.

description: b-Net income The company attributed its losses in the latest periods to losses incurred on the sale of mortgage loans and mortgage-backed securities, as well as loan-loss provisions.

title: New Life After Kraft For Ice Cream Maker
description: It is not unusual for a family to sell its business to a large corporation, but how many get the chance to buy it back at a much lower price?

title: SALVADOR REBELS MAKE NEW OFFER
description: Leftist guerrilla commanders agreed today to come here to talk about a peace initiative outlining conditions under which the rebels would take part in elections for the first time.

description: b-After extraordinary charges of $123,000 and $555,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said the extraordinary charges in the fourth quarter and 1987 year result from the repurchase and retirement of debt.

title: Market Place; Old Habits Dominate in the Pits
description: Few industries have grown as rapidly as the commodities futures business or changed as little while they were doing so.

title: Bonn Bans Neo-Nazis; Raids Their Houses
description: The West German Government banned a neo-Nazi fringe group today and raided the houses of supporters across the country in what the Interior Minister described as an ''unmistakable warning signal'' to the far right.

title: Iran and Iraq Say They Are Ready to Talk
description: Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati of Iran and his Iraqi counterpart, Tariq Aziz, both said they were ready to meet here Friday to resume stalled talks on a Persian Gulf peace settlement.

title: C.I.A. Sees a Developing World With Developed Arms
description: The Director of Central Intelligence told Congress today that third-world countries were expanding their ability to make ballistic missiles and chemical weapons despite Western efforts to curb the spread of such arms.

title: Carl R. Oman, Dentist, 96
description: Dr. Carl R. Oman, a dentist and retired professor of dentistry at the Columbia University School of Dental and Oral Surgery, died of cardiac arrest Wednesday at North Carolina Memorial Hospital in Chapel Hill. He was 96 years old and lived in Chapel Hill.

title: Review/Film; Lesbian California Dreaming
description: Dorothee, a West German journalist writing about romantic love, fantasizes that California is an island paradise inhabited solely by black Amazons riding wild horses. The San Francisco she arrives in halfway through ''Virgin Machine'' is true to the spirit, if not the letter, of her desires. Monika Treut's film turns out to be a blunt tribute to the not-revolutionary idea that lesbians can be lusty romantic fools just like anybody else.

title: Savings Fraud Losses Seen as Lost for Good
description: The Government's effort to prosecute fraud in the savings industry is not likely to lead to large recoveries of stolen funds, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh told the Senate Banking Committee yesterday.

title: GOVERNMENT MOVE TO DELAY THE TRIAL OF NORTH IS DENIED
description: A Federal appeals court panel today rejected a plea by the Bush Administration that the criminal trial of Oliver L. North be temporarily halted to protect national security secrets.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Economic and Social Council

title: Something Borrowed, Nothing Blue
description: For eight years, President Reagan delivered speeches to Congress that were long on inspiration and relatively short on programs. President Bush's understated address tonight lacked Reaganesque flourishes, but it offered a long list of minor spending increases covering fields from education to outer space.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: BOXING Two Titles to Brown: Glenwood Brown won the World Boxing Association Americas and New York State welterweight titles when he took a unanimous decision from 41-year-old Saoul Mamby in a 12-round bout at Felt Forum last night. The former World Boxing Association lightweight champion, Edwin Rosario, stopped Jesus Gallardo in the eigth round of a scheduled 12-round bout and welterweight Aaron Davis of the Bronx remained undefeated (22-0) when his opponent, Jose Bezerra De Lima, was disqualified in the fourth round for excessive holding. GOLF Adjustment Helps Fabel: Brad Fabel took a one-stroke lead yesterday in the first round of the $750,000 Hawaiian Open in Honolulu. Fabel birdied half the holes he played and did not make a bogey in a nine-under-par 63 on the Waialae Country Club course. Fabel, 33, said a friend ''found I was taking the club back real quick and it had thrown my putting off.'' Jim Carter was second at 64. (AP) N.H.L. Penguins 5, Nordiques 2:Mario Lemieux scored his 56th goal and added 3 assists to raise his league-leading point total to 145 and help the Penguins at home. Lemieux set up two third-period goals 50 seconds apart that helped the Penguins break open a close game and maintain their hold on first place in the Patrick Division. (AP) Bruins 4, Kings 1:Randy Burridge scored three goals and set up another as the Bruins gave Terry O'Reilly his 100th National Hockey League coaching victory last night at home against the slumping Los Angeles Kings. Burridge got his first career hat trick as Reggie Lemelin, playing in his 400th N.H.L. game, had 18 saves, including a spectacular dive to stop Wayne Gretzky on a third-period breakaway. (AP) Oilers 3, Flyers 1: Craig Simpson scored two goals and Grant Fuhr turned aside 37 shots, giving the Oilers their first victory at the Spectrum in more than six years. Simpson broke a 1-1 tie when he fired a slap shot from the top of the left faceoff circle between Ron Hextall's pads at 13:07 of the final period. The victory was the Oilers' first at the Spectrum since a 4-3 victory Nov. 13, 1982. (AP) North Stars 3, Canucks 2: Dave Gagner scored his second goal of the game with 4:19 to play, lifting the North Stars over Vancouver in Bloomington, Minn. Vancouver, which lost its fourth straight, remained 2 points ahead of Winnipeg in its fight for the final Smythe Division playoff spot. (AP) Flames 5, Blues 3: In St. Louis, Doug Gilmour tipped in Rob Ramage's slap shot from the point for his second goal of the game with 5:15 remaining as Calgary beat the Blues, extending the Flames' unbeaten streak to nine games. Gilmour, who has 19 goals, also had an assist in his first visit to The Arena since traded by St. Louis on Sept. 5.(AP) HORSE RACING Turning for Home Rallies to Win: Turning For Home overcame Go For Commadore in the stretch yesterday and won the feature race at Aqueduct by 1 3/4 lengths. It was his first victory in three starts this year. Turning for Home, carrying 115 pounds and ridden by Chris Antley, was the favorite in the field of five. Turning for Home covered a mile and an eighth on the fast track in 1:53 and earned $24,600 for his owner, Cedar Valle Stable. Turning for Home paid $4.60 for $2 to win.(AP) YACHTING Sloop Hits Snag: The yacht Thursday's Child has been slowed by poor winds in a quest to break a New York-to-San Francisco speed record that has stood for 135 years, Nancy Lush, a spokeswoman said yesterday from the St. Francis Yacht Club in San Francisco. The racer reported by radio at midday yesterday that it was 300 miles south of the Golden Gate Bridge. If the 60-foot, 10-ton sloop arrives today, Thursday's Child will break the mark set in 1854 by the clipper Flying Cloud by 10 days. (AP)

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 453 money market mutual funds increased by $2.26 billion, to $287.62 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Those of the 137 institutional funds decreased by $171.40 million, to $74.24 billion. The assets of the 224 general-purpose funds were up by $649.30 million, to $90.87 billion. The 92 broker-dealer funds increased by $1.78 billion, to $122.51 billion, the institute said.

title: Review/Art; 'The German Image'
description: First the good news about Thomas Krens's first major statement as director of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum. ''Refigured Painting: The German Image 1960-88'' - opening tomorrow - is a very ambitious show. It raises the complex issue of the human figure in postwar German painting. It places in some kind of artistic context such familiar figures as Georg Baselitz, Anselm Kiefer, Markus Lupertz, A. R. Penck, Sigmar Polke and Gerhard Richter - the artists around whom the show is built.

description: The United States Commission on Civil Rights, relegated in the Reagan Administration to the fringes of national debates on the issues it normally addressed, is an agency in search of a mission.

title: Indecorp Acquires Drexel Holding
description: Indecorp Inc. said it had acquired the Drexel Holding Company, creating the nation's largest black-owned financial institution. Indecorp, the holding company for the Independence Bank of Chicago, said after the deal was completed, its assets would increase to more than $227 million, from $117.5 million. Indecorp, a private company, earned more than $1.4 million in 1988, while Drexel earned $1.2 million, the companies said.

title: Restaurants
description: For all the clamorous charms of Chinatown, there are times when one is in the mood for Chinese food served in a more relaxed setting. A half-dozen or more uptown Chinese restaurants offer food that equals the best found downtown - at uptown prices, of course. Four-year-old Fu's remains one of the best of this lot.

title: BUSH BIDS CONGRESS JOIN HIM IN MISSION OF U.S. 'GREATNESS'
description: President Bush, summoning the nation to a ''mission of goodness and greatness,'' urged Congress tonight to work with him on a budget intended to reduce the deficit and give less emphasis to the military and more to children and the disadvantaged.

Shielding Retirement Funds: Several Scenarios to Study
description: When it comes to taxes, retirement is no time to take it easy. Indeed, even financial planning for retirement requires a great deal of work, and taxpayers this year will face several important decisions.

title: Dining Out Guide: Two-Star Chinese Restaurants
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times, with the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. Auntie Yuan (June 13, 1986), 1191A First Avenue, near 65th Street (744-4040) - The original kitchen staff of this stylish restaurant was exclusively female, an ''auntie's garden,'' in the words of the owner. And auntie's garden is an approximate translation of this restaurant's name. The all-black decor accented by pinpoint lighting is the scene for food that rivals Chinatown's best. Some of the most notable are appetizers of barbecued quail glazed with garlic paste, and cold sesame noodles. Recommended entrees are crisp orange beef, steamed salmon with black beans, and Peking duck. For the Chinese New Year, which started at midnight Sunday, a 10-course dinner ($45 prix fixe) is being served through Wednesday. Appetizers are $5 to $14, entrees $15 to $23. Lunch: noon to 4 P.M. Friday; dinner: 4 P.M. to midnight Friday and Saturday, until 11 P.M. Sunday. Chin Chin (Oct. 16, 1987), 216 East 49th Street (888-4555) - The Chin brothers work the dining room like a political advance team, greeting patrons, answering questions, then stepping back to monitor the proceedings. . Shredded duck salad with rice noodles and coriander, and pan-fried dumplings are good ways to start. Main courses include an excellent Peking duck; three-glass chicken, and prawns Sichuan style. Appetizers are $3.50 to $8, entrees $12.50 to $19.50 (Peking duck dinner is $26 a person, minimum of two people). Lunch: noon to 4 P.M. Friday to Sunday; dinner: 5 to 11:30 P.M. Friday and Saturday, until 11 P.M. Sunday. China Grill (Nov. 27, 1987), 60 West 53d Street (333-7788) - East meets West, at least on the plates, at this oversize restaurant inspired by Chinois on Main, one of Wolfgang Puck's southern California successes. The menu combines the simplicity of Oriental cuisine with whimsical New American style in such offerings as Chardonnay steamed mussels, and Beijing oysters served with vinegar sauce laced with shallots. Recommended entrees include Shanghai lobster, grilled squab with fried noodles, and sizzling whole fish, quick-fried and served with a soy-based ponzu sauce. Appetizers are $7.50 to $14, entrees $11.50 to $25.50. Lunch: noon to 2:30 P.M. Friday; dinner: 5:30 P.M. to midnight Friday and Saturday, 6 to 10 P.M. Sunday. Fu's 1395 Second Avenue, at 73d Street (517-9670) - Review on page 22. Phoenix Garden (March 6, 1987), 46 Bowery, inside the arcade (962-8934) - To reach this source of exceptional Cantonese cuisine, one must enter a garish Chinatown arcade. The experience is worth it for the authenticity of the food and the efficient service. Among the recommended dishes are roast squab with lemon sauce, salty baked chicken, lobster with ginger and scallions, and snow-pea leaves in crab sauce. A house specialty, seasoned and deep-fried ''pepper and salty'' shrimp, is almost addictive. Until the end of Chinese New Year celebrations on Feb. 20, Phoenix Garden offers traditional banquet dinners for groups of 10 ($328 per banquet). Lunch and dinner from $3.50 to $18. Open 11:30 A.M. to 10:30 P.M. daily. What the stars mean, page C22.

title: Astronomers View Creation of a Pulsar Amid Stellar Debris
description: Astronomers report that they have glimpsed the birth of a pulsar, an extremely dense star spinning nearly 2,000 times a second inside the debris of a recent stellar explosion. The observation appears to provide clinching evidence for a theory about the sequence of events in a supernova, the explosive collapse of a massive star.

title: Rail Equipment Merger Blocked
description: A Federal district judge has issued a preliminary injunction to block the planned merger of two railroad equipment manufacturers. Judge Richard A. Enslen on Wednesday granted the Federal Government's request to halt the merger, pending the outcome of a lawsuit filed in Grand Rapids, Mich. The Government contends that merging Jackson Jordan Inc., based in Ludington, Mich., with the Toronto-based Canron Inc. would violate antitrust laws.

title: Review/Art; Yoko Ono on Her Own, Storming the Barricades
description: Before she became famous as the wife of one of the Beatles, Yoko Ono was familiar to a coterie of performance artists, musicians, poets and film makers as one of their own, a maker of experimental films and an organizer of avant-garde happenings. Recently, Ms. Ono decided it was her former self that the public should get to know better, and as it happened, there was one institution only too willing to help. The depressing result is ''Yoko Ono: Objects and Films,'' now at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

description: For the police and Federal drug agents here, it remains a curious but persistent truth: Crack use has never reached the epidemic proportion in Chicago that it has in many other major urban areas.

title: The Cruelty That Isolates Iran
description: Perhaps 10,000 political prisoners - or perhaps only 3,000 - may benefit from an amnesty to take effect tomorrow when Iran observes the 10th anniversary of its revolution. The uncertainty is typical of a chaotic, revolutionary society in which no one knows who's in charge of what, and in which the closest thing to decisive power is wielded by a joyless, glowering fanatic.

title: Review/Art; Frank Stella's 1988
description: In his current exhibition at M. Knoedler & Company, Frank Stella presents the first new body of work since his 1987 retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art. Unlike the ''Polish Village'' series he unveiled after his 1970 retrospective at the Modern when his work announced his new allegiance to built-up reliefs, these pieces, all made in 1988, do not mark an exciting or surprising shift in direction, at least not in the visual sense.

title: The Kronos Quartet
description: The Kronos Quartet is to give the New York premieres of Tina Davidson's ''Cassandra Sings'' and Henryk Gorecki's ''Already It Is Dusk'' at Alice Tully Hall tomorrow at 8 P.M. The ensemble - David Harrington and John Sherba, violinists; Hank Dutt, violist, and Jean Jeanrenaud, cellist - is also to play Terry Riley's ''Conquest of the War Demons'' and Alfred Schnittke's ''Quartet No. 3.'' Tickets: $18. Information: 874-6770.

title: MINERS IN POLAND GO BACK TO WORK

description: House Speaker Jim Wright said today that he had known for a month that the public would not accept enactment of a Congressional pay increase without a vote. But he said he could not convince his colleagues.

title: Chuck-Wagon Dining: Hot, Hotter, Hottest
description: TAKING in the wealth of Western and Southwestern culture galloping through the city these days can sure build a hefty appetite. Fortunately, New York's gastronomic campfires offer a wide variety of food that falls into the amorphous corral called Western - that is, Tex-Mex, Tex-Tex, Mex-Mex and that hot (literally and figuratively) regional hybrid called Southwestern. Here is a selective roundup.

title: Continental Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $62.5 million and $121.6 million for the quarter and year, respectively, and realized capital gains of $1 million for the quarter and realized capital losses of $1.5 million for the year. c-After realized capital losses of $89 million and $108.4 million for the quarter and year, respectively, and a loss of $7.5 million for the quarter and a gain of $12.3 million for the year, both from discontinued operations. The latest quarter and year included losses on disposal of subsidiaries of $33.6 million and $29 million, respectively. The company said the latest year net is less than one cent a share because of preferred stock dividend requirements. The latest quarter and year also included a pre-tax charge of $76 million to strengthen prior years' loss reserves in the company's international, reinsurance and excess lines businesses.

title: On Barks and Bites, Leases and Leashes
description: If a dog bites the little girl next door after she stomps on its tail, what are the legal consequences? If the landlord tries to evict a tenant for violating a ''no pets'' clause in a lease, is there any recourse? When the neighbor demands a new pair of Gucci loafers after the dog fouls his walkway, can he collect in court?

title: TV Weekend; Maggie Smith, Solo, Peoples a Country Village
description: My conviction that Maggie Smith is the world's most accomplished English-speaking actress is probably subject to debate. Other distinguished names can undoubtedly be thrown into the hopper: certainly Vanessa Redgrave, perhaps Glenn Close and Meryl Streep. Among the more luminous veterans we still have Dame Peggy Ashcroft and Jessica Tandy. But there is no arguing that Miss Smith gives what is likely to be the most brilliant performance of the year, in ''Talking Heads: Bed Among the Lentils,'' this Sunday's ''Masterpiece Theater'' presentation at 9 P.M. on Channel 13.

title: Great Lakes Group reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Briefing; Top Military Annoyed
description: Nobody is talking about a military coup, but many generals and admirals are irate because Congress has rejected a pay increase for itself, Federal judges and senior civilian officials and thus, indirectly, for senior officers.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Feb. 1 about a projection by the Census Bureau -that the United States population will begin to decline in the next century -characterized the novelty incorrectly. It was not the first of its kind by the bureau; a similar projection was made in 1982.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about President Bush's political ties to John G. Tower misstated, in some copies, the results of Mr. Bush's campaigns for the Senate in Texas. He was defeated.

title: Jazz Trio
description: Kirk Lightsey on piano, Cecil McBee on bass and Joe Chambers on drums are to play jazz at 8 P.M. Sunday at the Village Green, 531 Hudson Street (255-1650). There is a $5 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: King's 32 Lift Oklahoma; Missouri Coach in Hospital
description: Stacey King scored 32 points and made a crucial 3-point play in the final minute tonight as fifth-ranked Oklahoma beat third-ranked Missouri, 112-105.

title: North Africa Pipeline
description: King Hassan II of Morocco and President Chadli Benjedid of Algeria agreed on Wednesday to build a gas pipeline across North Africa to Europe, symbolizing a new era of cooperation between the former rivals.

title: Smoking Is a Health Issue, Not a Rights Issue; Exhaling's the Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: Melbourne Journal; City Doesn't Let Slaying Poison the Air on Poor
description: When a prominent interior designer was slain outside her showroom on Thanksgiving Eve, fear spread throughout this coastal community. Two days later, a suspect was in custody, and for many the fear curdled into anger.

title: Chase Medical Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Electromagnetic Sciences Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Review/Art; Remington's War and Old West
description: Even when every allowance is made for institutional schizophrenia, there is still something disconcerting about the present look of the main entrance of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Where the name of Degas not so long ago hung down in majesty, the banner now bears the name of Frederic Remington.

title: Auctions
description: trc01 Passed Back, Not Down

title: Azores Flight Recorder Found
description: Investigators today found a flight recorder from an American airliner that crashed in the Azores Wednesday, killing all 144 people on board, and continued their search for clues to the cause of the accident. The chartered Boeing 707, carrying 137 tourists from the Italian city of Bergamo and 7 American crew members to the Dominican Republic, flew into a mist-shrouded mountaintop as it tried to make a scheduled refueling stop on the mid-Atlantic island. Rescue teams have recovered about 100 bodies.

title: 5 Latin Lands End Talks Still Divided Over Rights
description: Officials from five Central American countries ended two days of talks here today still divided over steps to insure greater respect for democracy and human rights throughout the region.

title: Smoking Is a Health Issue, Not a Rights Issue; A Planeload Died
description: To the Editor:

title: Hornets Stun Hawks
description: Robert Reid made a 15-foot jump shot with 10 seconds remaining tonight, lifting the Charlotte Hornets over the Atlanta Hawks, 110-108.

title: Langston Signs
description: Mark Langston of Seattle and Scott Garrelts of San Francisco avoided salary arbitration by agreeing to one-year contracts yesterday.

title: Doctor Defends Cocaine Treatments
description: For 50 years, Dr. Milton Reder, a prominent New York physician, has used cocaine to treat pain. The practice was recently banned by New York State health officials, but Dr. Reder has ignored the ban, moving into the forefront of physicians who say the treatments should be allowed until more research has been done.

title: Secure Airports Still in Future
description: It will take months or even years to carry out heightened airport security measures ordered after the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103, Government aviation security officials said.

title: Bank of Tokyo
description: A Bank of Tokyo Ltd. unit said it would pay $13 million less than it had planned for the Los Angeles-based Union Bank. A reason for the lower payment was not disclosed. Union Bank, a subsidiary of Union Bancorp, was purchased last March from Standard Chartered P.L.C. of London for $750 million and merged in November with the Bank of Tokyo's California First Bank subsidiary in San Francisco. The two currently operate as Union Bank.

title: Helix Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Review/Theater; Sloughing Off Scars Of a Bad Childhood
description: If social consciousness were all, the Circle Repertory Company would deserve a brace of humanitarian citations for presenting ''Dalton's Back,'' a play about child abuse. But at a time when two or more New Yorkers cannot meet for dinner without debating the moral and psychological complexities of Hedda Nussbaum, who needs a bland, earnest drama dedicated to the unsurprising proposition that the wounds of child abuse don't easily heal? ''Dalton's Back'' is a topical play in the way that the daily weather report is front-page news.

title: NWA Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said latest-quarter revenue included a $24 million increase in passenger revenue resulting from an annual review and adjustment of the air traffic liability account.

title: American Heritage Life Inestment Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a realized investment loss of $451,429 for the quarter and a realized investment gain of $99,571 for the year. c-After a realized investment loss of $1,336,644 and a realized investment gain of $764,579 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Bush Backs Drilling and Research
description: In addition to a much-heralded cut in taxes on capital gains, President Bush tonight presented a budget containing provisions that would encourage businesses to conduct research, drill for oil and gas and establish operations in distressed economic areas.

title: Stranded Russians Dance To Thank Baltimore for Aid
description: A Soviet dance troupe gave a free performance here Wednesday night to thank the city that helped feed and house the group after investors ended their support for its United States tour. At show's end, the dancers had received $4,000 in donations.

title: Tesoro Petroleum Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company said its results were affected by the sale during fiscal 1988 of all of its unprofitable domestic oil and gas producing properties and the discontinuance of its contract drilling operations, which were also unprofitable.

title: Community Bank System reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Cross-Park Skiing
description: The Great Lawn in Central Park will be transformed into a four-acre arctic zone tomorrow for the park's annual Winter Festival. Six inches of machine-made snow will blanket the lawn - which is mid-park at 81st Street - making it a mecca for cross-country skiers, snow sculptors and snowman builders. Six hundred pairs of cross-country skis, poles and shoes will be lent at no charge by Ski Industries America, a trade organization, and instructors from Eastern Mountain Sports will give free ski lessons. Cross-country slalom and obstacle races are also planned during the event, which runs from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Information: 360-8126.

title: Cambrex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss of $401,800 from discontinued operations and a gain of $2,461,700 on the sale of discontinued operations. The company said fourth quarter net income was reduced by 6 cents a share because of fees and expenses related to the termination of negotiations to acquire Pfizer Inc.'s iron oxides business.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Abraham Lincoln's birthday, actually Sunday, will be observed on Monday. Below are holiday schedules. NEW YORK

title: Chambers Development Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $1,272,000 from an accounting adjustment. c-Included a gain of $308,000 from the refinancing of debt for both the quarter and year.

title: Waste Management Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Latest-year results included a gain of $11,354,000 from the agreement in which the company contributed assets to a new enterprise, Wheelabrator Technologies Inc.

title: Solti and the Chicago
description: Sir Georg Solti is to conduct the Chicago Symphony Orchestra in the Schubert Symphony No. 5 and the Shostakovich Symphony No. 8 at Carnegie Hall tonight at 8. The orchestra will perform a second program - Bartok's Music for Strings, Percussion and Celesta, and the ''Miraculous Mandarin'' Suite, as well as the Brahms Symphony No. 4 - tomorrow evening at 8, also at Carnegie. Tickets are $50 to $17. Information: 247-7800.

title: First Women's Bank reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Eldorado Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Chargers Select Henning as Coach
description: Dan Henning was named coach of the San Diego Chargers yesterday, ending a seven-week search for a successor to Al Saunders, who was dismissed. Henning, 46 years old, a Washington Redskins assistant and former head coach with the Atlanta Falcons, was signed to a five-year contract and became the eighth head coach in San Diego's 29-year history.

title: Home Unity Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $377,000. c-After a loss of $191,000 for the quarter and net of $944,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations. The company said latest fourth quarter results included a non-recurring loss of $6.9 million on the sale of $138 million of fixed-rate assets. Trading profits during the qyarter, which are not typically viewed as a recurring source of income, resulted in a $1.1 million gain. In addition, the results included an increase in the fourth quarter of about $4.6 million in reserves against possible loan and real estate losses.

title: Bond Prices Post Large Declines
description: Treasury bond prices posted their biggest declines in more than three months yesterday, pushed lower because of tepid investor demand at an auction of new 30-year bonds and a drop in the dollar's value.

title: Now It Can Be Told: Those Pro Wrestlers Are Just Having Fun
description: The promoters of professional wrestling have disclosed that their terrifying towers in spandex tights, massive creatures like Bam Bam Bigelow, Hulk Hogan and Andre the Giant, are really no more dangerous to one another than Santa Claus, the Easter Bunny and the Tooth Fairy.

title: Review/Film; 'Cousins,' an Adaptation
description: The wedding scene that opened Jean-Charles Tacchella's blithe 1976 romantic comedy ''Cousin, Cousine'' was a warmly familial affair, and the one that opens the American remake, ''Cousins,'' is also jam-packed with festive relatives. But beyond this, all similarity ends. The French party was charmingly chaotic, played lightly but with considerable subtlety and humor. The American one is merely big and loud, featuring clapping, belching, drinking, yelling, the dancing of the Hokey-Pokey and a spirited rendition of the theme song from ''The Brady Bunch.''

title: Angola Accuses Pretoria of Breaking Peace Pact
description: Angola asserted today that South Africa had violated the recently signed peace accords by sending troops back into southern Angola. South Africa denied the accusation.

title: Fight Choreography
description: ''A Night at the Fights,'' a revue of fight choreography and stage combat, is to be presented this weekend by the Midtown Arts Common. Fists, whips, swords and daggers will be the weapons of choice for the cast, who are also members of ''Fights R Us,'' a stunt group based in New York. The show is being presented at the Theater of St, Peter's Church, Citicorp Center, 54th Street and Lexington Avenue, today and tomorrow at 8 P.M., with an abbreviated show tomorrow at 12:15 P.M. Suggested donation: $5. Information: 753-4318.

title: Country in the City, In Clubs and on the Air
description: Surprisingly, given New York's voracious appetite for all things American, and all things Western, country music has never been a major item here. But within the last six months, two clubs - the Lone Star Roadhouse and Delta 88 - have opened that occasionally feature country bands.

title: Review/Film; Tam Tam,' Starring Baker
description: As of today, the most enchanting ''new'' film in town is ''Princess Tam Tam,'' at Film Forum 2.

title: US Home Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $1,795,000 and $1,493,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss and included a loss from discontinued operations of $23,859,000 and $28,513,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Harried Madrid Chief Is Said to Consider Quitting
description: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez is passing through the deepest crisis of his six years in power and may resign before Spain's next scheduled general election in early 1990, politicians, journalists and diplomats say.

title: Bush's First Budget: Like Reagan's Last
description: The 193-page budget document the White House released tonight speaks of reshaping priorities, of reducing military spending and of new initiatives in education, environmental protection, shelter for the homeless and drug control.

title: Coddling Black Athletes
description: LEAD: Georgetown University's basketball coach, John Thompson, is no longer boycotting his team's games to protest Proposition 42 -setting minimum academic standards for athletic scholarships - but the issue is far from decided. Shelved for now, the rule will be reconsidered by the National Collegiate Athletic

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Mayor's Talent Bank Doesn't Represent Political Corruption
description: To the Editor:

title: Friedrich Solmsen, Professor, 84
description: Friedrich Solmsen, a retired professor of classics, died of a perforated ulcer Jan. 30 at North Carolina Memorial Hospital in Chapel Hill. He was 84 years old and lived in Chapel Hill.

title: Culbro Corp reports earnings for 13wks to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss of $1,800,000 for the quarter and a gain of $1,960,000 for the year, both from distributed consumer finance business which was spun off in December 1988. c-Net income d-Included gains from the distributed consumer finance business of $2,362,000 and $6,057,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also included a gain of $19,709,000 from the sale of Culbro's snack food business. The company said 1987 included a $5.1 million pre-tax gain from the sale of 20 percent of Culbro's interest in Centaur Communications Ltd. The company said that its results from continuing operations for the year 1988 were adversely affected by a temporary labor interruption and the loss of business from a major customer at its Moll Tool plastics subsidiary, start-up and acquisition interest costs associated with the formation of CMS Gilbreth Packaging Systems, and charges relating primarily to personnel reductions and facilities consolidations in the consumer products businesses. The company also said revenues included revenues of real estate subsidiaries, which are fully consolidated in accordance with Statement of Financial Accounting Standard No. 94. The 1988 periods included the results of Gilbreth International Corporation and Trine Manufacturing from the dates of acquisition, April 26, 1988, and July 29, 1988, respectively. The coporation's consumer finance business was spun off in a tax free distribution to Culbro shareholders on Dec. 16, 1988. Results of operations of this business are included through the spin-off date and included approximately $3.4 million of non-recurring spin-off expenses, and the effect of adoption of a new accounting rule FAS 91, offset in part by reduced income taxes. On Aug. 31, 1987, the corporation sold its snack food business for $55 million.

title: SPX Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included after-tax income of $1 million from a change in accounting. c-Net loss Results for 1987 periods included a special after-tax charge of $12 million.

title: Galoob, Lewis Toys Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Jersey's Reach for Welfare Reform
description: A year ago, Lynn Schmitt was on welfare and going nowhere. ''I wanted to do something but I felt my hands were tied,'' she says. Today she has a $20,000 job at a Hackensack company, producing computerized drawings for prison security systems.

title: Ericsson, L M Telephone Co reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The net income figures represent consolidation income before appropriations and taxes. The share earnings are after taxes. Capital gains totaled $55 million in 1987. Sales represent net sales. Results are in U.S. dollars. Results have been translated at the rate of SEK 6.145 to the dollar, the exchange rate on Dec. 31, 1988.

title: Once Again, Devils Win On the Road
description: John MacLean scored two goals and added three assists tonight as the Devils beat the Detroit Red Wings, 6-3, and extended their unbeaten streak on the road to six games.

title: Coca-Cola Spokesman
description: Peter Horton, who plays the frustrated academic Gary on ''Thirtysomething,'' the hit series on ABC, will follow another cast member, Timothy Busfield, into the role of advertising spokesman. Mr. Horton will star in a commercial for Coca-Cola Classic, designed by McCann-Erickson, that will make its debut on Valentine's Day. Mr. Busfield, who plays Elliott, appears in an ad from the Beef Industry Council that encourages consumption of beef.

title: Onbank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Adjusted by $1.1 million for the after-tax income related to partial recapture of the overfunded pension plan and $1,326,000 related to utilization of previous years net operating loss carryforwards.

title: The Blues, in a Festival at Triplex
description: THE blues has innumerable faces. It can be a stomping, three-chord exorcism or a sophisticated jazz excursion; it can be dance music or tormented introspection. It can slip between the lines of a cabaret song or ennoble a rock truism. The blues binds together American popular music because while its essence is unmistakable, its form is flexible - it respects no pigeonhole.

title: Kustom Electronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Afro-Asian Ensemble
description: Fred Ho, a saxophonist, is to lead the seven-piece Afro-Asian Music Ensemble in new jazz pieces at 8 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday at the 14th Street Dance Center of the Emanu-El Midtown Y, 344 East 14th Street (673-2207). Tickets are $10.

title: Soviets Are Glum About Kabul's Future
description: The Soviet Government offered a bleak picture today of the situation facing the Afghan Government as preparations continued for the completion of the Soviet troop withdrawal.

title: Review/Ballet; Feld Puts Shoe on the Other Foot
description: ''Asia,'' a new work by Eliot Feld, is a winner. This harem-pants ballet of wit and irony, full of implied commentary on male-female relations, is sensationally performed - by five women acting like a collective Theda Bara and a sole man in an imaginary seraglio.

title: Texas Air Has Deficit In Quarter
description: The Texas Air Corporation, the owner of Continental and Eastern airlines, yesterday reported a loss of $224.4 million in the fourth quarter while NWA Inc., the parent of Northwest Airlines, said its earnings for the period rose sharply.

title: New Cards Televised
description: Univision, the Spanish-language television network, announced yesterday that, in association with Don King Productions, it would present seven 90-minute boxing events featuring rising Latin fighters. Joe Weidensall, Univision's director of sports, made the announcement.

title: Laurel Entertainment reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Net income

title: McDowell, Johnson Will Sign With Mets
description: One day after they agreed to sign Dwight Gooden for three years at $6.7 million, the Mets continued to dispense dollars and avoid arbitration when they reached agreement yesterday with Roger McDowell and Howard Johnson on one-year contracts.

title: The World of 2038
description: Gazing far into the future tends to diminish the events of the present. When the Census Bureau predicted recently that in a half-century the U.S. population would peak at about 302 million and shrink thereafter, such matters as John Tower's troubled nomination or Dwight Gooden's new contract or Mayor Koch's election prospects began to seem ephemeral.

title: CMS Enhancements reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
United Bankshares reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bush Aide Says Tower Reported Limiting Wine on Doctor's Advice
description: A senior White House official said today that John G. Tower, in an effort to salvage his nomination as Defense Secretary, has told two key Senators and President Bush that he limits his drinking to two glasses of wine a day on the advice of doctors who treated him for cancer.

title: Kodak Seeks To Cut Costs
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said today that it wanted to cut costs by 15 percent and might do so by trimming its work force, selling businesses or ending product lines.

title: Halifax Engineering Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a $27,000 loss from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The year-ago results were restated to reflect the adoption of SFAS 96.

title: BAKER IS PRESSED ON SELLING STOCK
description: Tougher ethical standards in Government are forcing Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d to decide whether he has to sell long-held investments, a State Department legal adviser said tonight.

title: Fleming Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest quarter included a gain equal to 46 cents a share and the year results included a pre-tax gain of $22,886,000, from the sale of the company's White Swan unit. Year-ago quarter's net included a restructuring charge equal to 45 cents a share and 1987 results included a pre-tax charge of $20,583,000 for restructuring and asset revaluations.

title: Security Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $737,000 for the quarter and $1,968,000 for the year. c-After a tax credit of $557,000 for the quarter and year.

title: Gundle Environmental Sysems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a pre-tax charge of $519,000 from the early extinguishment of debt.

title: KEY RATES
From Art to Apparel, West Has Come East
description: WHEN the word was passed along, more than a century ago, that young men should go West, wise young New Yorkers stayed put, knowing that the West, like anything else worth seeing, would eventually make its way to town. A cultural sagebrush of song, cooking and style has been pushing up through Manhattan's concrete mesa, and now a roundup of art from the West lends special bouquet to what has all the earmarks of being a trend.

title: Compression Labs reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Dream Match Off in Mile; Race Against Clock Is On
description: It was to have been the feature of the Vitalis Meadowlands Invitational Friday night, a dream mile matching Marcus O'Sullivan of Ireland, the world's best indoor miler, and Said Aouita of Morocco, the world's best middle-distance runner.

title: 3 Perish in Fire at 14th-Floor LeFrak City Apartment Used as Group Home for Girls
description: Three people were killed and 23 were injured yesterday when windblown fire tore through a 14th-floor apartment in Queens that was being leased as a group home for girls, fire officials said.

title: DEMOCRATS, WARY, PLEDGE THEIR HELP
description: While pledging to cooperate with President Bush, Democrats on Capitol Hill complained tonight that his idea of bipartisanship seemed to involve making the politically popular decisions himself and dumping the painful ones on Congress.

title: Vanfed Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said share earnings for the periods are not meaningful because the conversion of the company from mutual to stock form was not completed until this month.

title: Plight of Needy Spurs Donors
description: Every time Jamie Wharton walks in New York City and sees people with no food, no money, no home, he thinks how lucky he is. Jamie is 11 years old and lives in Armonk, a village in Westchester County, but often comes into the city on weekends.

title: WSMV-TV Is to Be Sold
description: WSMV-TV, the NBC network affiliate here, is to be sold by Gillett Broadcasting of Tennessee Inc. to a partnership formed by a New York group and a company owned by native Alaskans.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY RENAISSANCE DRAWINGS

title: Old Republic International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included realized investment gains of $1,085,262 and $3,753,247 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included realized investment losses of $152,016 for the quarter and realized investment gains of $9,505,779 for the year. d-Net income

title: Spielberg Aids Ballet School
description: Steven Spielberg, the director of ''E. T. the Extra-Terrestrial,'' ''Empire of the Sun'' and ''The Color Purple,'' has donated $850,000 to the School of American Ballet.

title: Chairman of Navajos Defends Receiving Gifts
description: Peter MacDonald, the chairman of the Navajo tribe, who is accused of taking kickbacks in tribal transactions, said his accepting gifts, in observance of Indian tradition, was minor compared with the excesses of Washington politicians.

title: Shakespeare's 'Troilus'
description: The Riverside Shakespeare Company is presenting Shakespeare's ''Troilus and Cressida'' at the company's home at 165 West 86th Street. Performances are tonight, tomorrow, Monday, and Feb. 16 to Feb. 19. at 8 P.M. Admission is free. Information: 877-6810. The company is also holding a pre-Valentine's Day benefit, with scenes from Shakespeare performed by such actors as E. G. Marshall, Eli Wallach, Ann Jackson, Gene Hackett and Pamela Reed, on Sunday at 7:30 P.M. at Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street. Tickets: $25 ($100 tickets include a party afterward at Birdland, a nearby jazz club). Reservations: 864-5400.

title: Russian High Tea
description: The Pro Arte Chorale, as part of its yearlong celebration of its 25th anniversary, will give a High Tea, in the tradition of Imperial Russia, from 4 to 7 P.M. Sunday in Ridgewood, N.J. Russian tea from a samovar, citrus gems and tea cakes, as well as Russian cordials and other Russian delicacies, will be served. Entertainment from the Troika balalaika orchestra will follow the meal. The tea will be at Christ Church Parish Hall at Cottage Place and Franklin Avenue. Tickets: $20. Reservations and directions: (201) 445-0952.

title: Costar Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 3
description: b-Included a gain of $89,000 from a change in accounting for manufacturing costs. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $43,000 and $462,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and gains from the disposal of discontinued operations of $22,000 for the quarter and $627,000 for the year, and the year also included a tax credit of $307,000.

title: Goodrich, B F Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $4.3 million fo the quarter and $16.9 million for the year; the year also included a gain of $2.7 million from an accounting change. c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $8.1 million and $4.4 million for the quarter and year, respectively; losses on the extinguishment of debt of $200,000 for the quarter and $3.3 million for the year, and tax credits of $5 million for the quarter and $29.1 million for the year. The latest periods' nets lowered by about $11 million due to non-recurring charges, principally for formation and funding of a foundation to make charitable contributions. The year-ago periods' nets reduced by about $5 million due to non-recurring charges.

title: Profile In Terrorism
description: Name: Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine - General Command (P.F.L.P.-G.C.) Date Formed: 1968 Estimated Membership: 500 Headquarters: Syria Area of Operations: Middle East, especially Lebanon, Jordan and Israel Leadership: Ahmed Jabril Other Names: None Sponsors: Syria, Libya

title: THE LAW: At the Bar; Alienated lawyers seeking - and getting - counsel in making the transition to other careers
description: Fidel Castro did it. Francis Scott Key and Tony LaRussa did it. Paul Robeson and Peter Ilyich Tchaikovsky did it. Even Cole Porter did it. Let's do it. Let's leave the law. It's a song many seem to be singing these days. And Celia Paul, a 44-year-old career counselor to disaffected lawyers, is leading the chorus.

title: Tandy to Shift Marketing
description: The Tandy Corporation, one of the nation's largest consumer electronics manufacturers and retailers, said today that it would announce an important shift in its marketing strategy at a meeting to be held in Dallas next Tuesday.

title: Canron Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $2,088,000 for the quarter and $4,937,000 for the year, and a special gain of $5,309,000 for both the quarter and year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $610,000 and $1,273,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and special charges of $2,359,000 for the quarter and $9,859,000 for the year. The company said results have been restated to account for discontinued operations. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Bush to Get Order to Tighten Rules on Secrets
description: An order being prepared for President Bush's approval would give Cabinet officers and other agency heads sweeping authority to grant or deny access to secret Government information. The right to appeal those decisions would be greatly diminished.

title: Transcript of President's Address to a Joint Session of the House and Senate
description: Following is a transcript of President Bush's address to a joint session of Congress in Washington last night, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Roy Peratrovich, 79; Led Alaskan Natives
description: Roy Peratrovich, a leader in battling discrimination against Alaskan natives, died Tuesday. He was 79 years old.

title: Smithfield Foods Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: b-Included an inventory benefit of $300,000, or 3 cents a share, and $900,000, or 10 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Share net reflected a 2-for-1 stock split in September 1988. The company said the decline in third-quarter and 9-month sales was attributable to a sharp drop in sales at Patrick Cudahy Inc., which permanently ceased its slaughtering and canning operations in the latter half of fiscal 1988.

title: Nerco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge on the prepayment of notes of $9,100,000.

title: Big Cable TV Deal Weighed For High School Basketball
description: A major cable network is negotiating to televise nationally for the first time a high school basketball game of the week.

title: Mayor's Talent Bank Doesn't Represent Political Corruption; Hard Work and Exams
description: To the Editor:

title: Webster B. Todd Is Dead at 89; Ex-Leader of Jersey Republicans
description: Webster B. Todd, a former New Jersey Republican chairman who was an influential party leader in the state for three decades, died of a heart attack Wednesday in his home in Oldwick, N.J. He was 89 years old.

title: Compuchem Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Pogo Producing Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and included a gain from a deferred tax adjustment of $16,851,000. Latest year results included a pre- tax writedown of $22 million taken in the third quarter.

title: Textron Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss from arbitration relating to a former line of business of $8,000,000 and $28,000,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also included a loss from early redemption of debt of $9,700,000. c-Included a gain from discontinued operations of $1,400,000 and $3,500,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; an extraordinary loss from the early redemption of debt of $6,700,000 and $32,600,000 for the same periods, respectively; and the year also included a gain on the sale of discontinued operations of $24,300,000.

title: Trouble at Oklahoma
description: While prosecutors in Norman, Okla., were charging three University of Oklahoma football players with first-degree rape yesterday, the school's board of regents was adopting a recommendation that any athlete charged with a crime be prohibited from playing sports while the charges are pending. Nigel Clay, Glen Bell and Bernard Hall, none of whom are starters, were accused of raping a 20-year-old woman Jan. 21, District Attorney Tully McCoy said. The charges resulted from an investigation into a woman's report that she was raped in a dormitory. David Swank, president of the university, made the recommendation to the regents, who approved it. In an unrelated incident, Swank reprimanded Billy Tubbs, the basetball coach, for his behavior at a game against Missouri Thursday night. Fans threw debris onto the court to protest officiating calls, and Tubbs picked up a microphone and told the crowd to stop, ''regardless of how terrible the officiating is.''(AP)

title: Man Convicted in 14 Killings Jury Votes for Death Penalty
description: A jury found a man guilty of capital murder today in the shooting and strangulation deaths of 14 family members and recommended that he be sentenced to die for the killings.

title: F.B.I. Played Real Role in Civil Rights in 60's; Judge It as a Movie
description: To the Editor:
