title: International Aluminum Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest periods included losses from discontinued operations of $408,000 for the quarter and $565,000 for the 6 months.

title: BRIDGE
description: For players in New York City, this weekend presents the most varied program in the annual calendar. Last night, novices played with experts at the Beverly Club, 130 East 57th Street, in the annual Pro-Am event. Today, mixed foursomes with rotating partnerships will play in the Betty Kaplan Team event, and the Swiss Team qualifying stage of the Grand National Teams event will be played tomorrow.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about President Bush's political ties to John G. Tower misstated the year when Mr. Bush won the first of two terms in the House of Representatives. It was 1966, not 1962.

title: A Traffic Jam in East Beirut Leads to Battle, Killing One
description: A quarrel on rival claims of right of way in an East Beirut traffic jam today developed into a clash between the Christian militia and the Lebanese Army in which one person was killed and five were wounded, the police said.

title: Provident Life & Accident Insurance Co of Amer reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included capital losses of $2,813,000 for the quarter and capital gains of $5,747,000 for the year. c-Included capital gains of $3,050,000 and $78,474,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Jens T. Holm, Professor, 69
description: Jens T. Holm, professor emeritus of marine engineering at the Webb Institute of Naval Architecture in Glen Cove, L.I., died of Parkinson's disease at the Doylestown (Pa.) Hospice on Feb. 1. He was 69 years old and lived in Carversville, Pa.

title: In Latin America, Winter for Democracy . . .
description: LEAD: During his confirmation hearings, the Secretary of State, James A. Baker 3d asserted that, ''Despite guerrilla efforts, the democratic political process has become established in El Salvador.''

title: Stocks Plummet as Dow Loses 36.97 Points
description: LEAD: Stock prices dropped sharply yesterday in heavy trading, amid new worries about interest rates and inflation.

title: U.S. Captain on Trial in Boat People Case
description: The court-martial of a United States Navy captain accused of refusing to assist a group of Vietnamese boat people began today.

title: Review/Music; Rosemary Clooney's Apple Pie
description: Rosemary Clooney exudes comfort, coziness and serenity, just as her friend and champion, Bing Crosby, once did. If her delivery is not as soft as that of a crooner, she also never really raises her voice. The tone she adopts for both ballads and uptempo songs is warm but matter-of-fact. Like Crosby's, her technical proficiency is such that her singing seems nearly effortless, though of course it isn't.

title: Weirton Steel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company, which is employee- owned, said the net income for the latest fourth quarter was after a $16,025,000 provision for profit sharing. The 1987 fourth-quarter provision was $7,847,000. The 1988 full-year provision was $75,013,000, compared with $40,282,000 in 1987.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50.

title: Bye Bye, American Pie
description: Browsing in The New Yorker, I find two distinguished citizens expressing faith in the singular American character of apple pie.

title: Flute and Saxophone
description: James Moody, a flutist and saxophonist, is leading a quartet tonight and tomorrow at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, at Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a fatal fire in Queens characterized a possible cause incorrectly in some copies.

title: Conference on Penny Stocks
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission's New York regional office held a one-day conference of 45 state, Federal and securities industry enforcement officials on Thursday as part of its effort to combat penny-stock fraud in the New York City area.

title: Review/Television; A Bored Factory Worker Sheds Her Boring Boyfriend
description: Joyce Maddox is desperate over her existence as an unattached woman in a Southern town, ''workin' in a factory and gettin' knocked around whenever your man gets a snootful.'' Actually, her current man is so mild that he puts her to sleep even when he tries to get her to bed; Joyce is battered by boredom. The way she manages her own breakout, by arranging a breakout from the Louisiana State Penitentiary, is the gist of ''The Outside Woman,'' tomorrow night's ''CBS Sunday Movie,'' which, says the press release, is based on ''real events.'' You can catch it at 9 P.M.

title: Network Systems Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest periods included a pre- tax charge of $4.8 million for inventory reserves.

title: Atlas Consolidated Mining & Development Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included total gains equal to 4 cents a share and 18 cents a share for the quarter and year, respectively, from tax credits and the extinguishment of debt. c-Net loss

title: Dying Cultural Outposts
description: LEAD: So the long story of the Museum of the American Indian is ended. It will move from its location on the magnificent Audubon Terrace on 155th Street and Amsterdam Ave. in New York City. It will move not down four miles to the Museum of Natural History, not down to the tip of Manhattan into the old Customs House (though a small part will be exhibited there) but to Washington, joining that brontosaurean collection of block-buster museums on the Mall.

title: Court Backs F.C.C.'s Repeal Of the Fairness Doctrine
description: A Federal Court has upheld the repeal of the Fairness Doctrine by the Federal Communications Commission.

title: Ethics Aide Advised to Amend Report
description: The Office of Government Ethics has suggested that the White House counsel, C. Boyden Gray, amend his financial disclosure reports to show $86,900 in outside income that Mr. Gray has said he earned from his family company in 1985 and 1986 but did not report for those years.

title: Victor Herbert Songs
description: Selections from Victor Herbert's stage works will be performed by Marie Bogart, Christina Bair Schropp and Letitia Scordino, sopranos, and Robert Rutt, a tenor, at the Metropolitan-Duane United Methodist Church, Seventh Avenue at 13th Street, at 3 P.M. tomorrow. Earl Wentz is to be the accompanist. Suggested donation is $5. Information: 243-5470.

title: Sparton Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Please Buy the Copies, Not the Antiquities
description: To the Editor:

title: McCaw Cellular Communicaions Inc . reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and included a gain of $138,400,000 from the sale of cable television and a tax credit of $40.2 million.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 11, 1989
description: The Economy

title: The Wages Of Congress And Athletes
description: In the recent debate over whether members of Congress deserved a 51 percent pay raise, several Representatives and Senators argued that their salaries were meager compared with those earned by professional athletes.

title: 30 to Leave Paine Webber And Form Their Own Firm
description: About 30 investment bankers who specialize in transportation companies plan to leave Paine Webber Inc. to form their own boutique firm, which will be partly backed by the big Wall Street concern, representatives of Paine Webber and the executives said yesterday.

title: Savings and Loan Withdrawals In December a Record $8.1 Billion
description: Depositors at the nation's savings and loan associations withdrew $8.1 billion more than they deposited in December, setting a monthly record, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today.

title: Bush, in Ottawa, Now Vows To Pursue Acid Rain Pact
description: President Bush met with Prime Minister Brian Mulroney today and agreed to pursue an international accord with Canada to reduce the acid rain that falls on both sides of the border.

title: Bush Is Said to Favor Continuing Arms Supplies to Afghan Rebels
description: President Bush has decided in principle to continue supplying the Afghan rebels with military aid as long as the Soviet-backed Kabul Government remains in power, senior Administration officials said today.

title: Increase in Sales Expected by Nike
description: Nike Inc.'s chairman, Philip Knight, said the company's efforts to broaden its business lines could add $150 million in sales next year. Sales from the Cole-Haan line of dress shoes, bought in 1988, and other products could produce ''as much as $150 million in sales in products and segments that didn't even exist for Nike at this time a year ago,'' Mr. Knight said Thursday at a trade show.

title: Shared Medical Systems Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Wayne L. Hays of Ohio Dies at 77; Scandal Ended Career in Congress
description: Former Representative Wayne L. Hays, a member of the House of Representatives for 27 years whose affair with a Washington staff member touched off a scandal that destroyed his political career, died today. He was 77 years old.

title: Wisconsin Public Service Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
His Future Clouded, Coach Presses On
description: For seven years, Jim Hulick endured the mediocre skaters, the overbearing parents, the early practices and the other frustrations that come with coaching, just to reach this moment. Now, he refuses to let even his serious illness get in the way.

title: Surprising Inflation Report Pushes Dollar Up Sharply
description: The dollar rose sharply yesterday, recovering almost all the ground it lost in a steep fall Thursday.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 32.

title: Dan Kelly, Hockey Announcer, 52
description: Dan Kelly, the broadcaster of St. Louis Blues games for the last 21 years, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Chesterfield, Mo. He was 52 years old.

title: Review/Music; Listening For a Mahler Connection
description: Shostakovich's spiritual and technical debt to Mahler, evident even in his earliest music, grew steadily over the course of his commissar-hounded career. In no work is the Mahler connection more plainly and painfully exposed than in the Soviet composer's Symphony No. 8 in C minor, a dark and frequently violent work that he completed in 1943. Perhaps because of its undisguisedly fearsome nature, the wartime Eighth has never been as favored, either by conductors or the public, as some of his more plausibly heroic symphonies. It is nevertheless a masterly score whose nerve-exposing intensity can be felt keenly in a performance such as Leonard Slatkin conducted on Thursday evening with the New York Philharmonic.

title: Cyclops Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included a loss from discontinued operations of $30,918,000. The company said the 1988 results included 5 months of operations for Eastern Stainless Corp., acquired on July 29, 1988. Comparative results for the full year unavailable; company began operations in July 1987.

title: PacifiCorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said on a merged basis with Utah Power & Light Co., fourth-quarter pro forma net was $105,900,000, or 82 cents a share, versus $116,200,000, or 90 cents a share. Revenue was $931,700,000 versus $851,300,000. Pro forma net for the year was $1,046,200,000, or $3.46 a share, versus $1,031,200,000, or $3.18 a share. Revenue was $3,519,300,000 versus $3,277,000,000. The company merged with Utah Power & Light last month.

title: PRODUCER PRICES POST BIGGEST RISE SINCE OCTOBER '85
description: In a sign of higher inflation that troubled the financial markets, producer prices rose last month at the fastest rate in three years.

title: Lone Star Technologies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: A Correction: The Budget
description: A table yesterday with a front-page article about President Bush's budget for fiscal year 1990 misstated differences between some of President Ronald Reagan's proposed spending for the year and President Bush's in the same categories. an explanation appears on page 9.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-5, 28 American supplies to Afghan rebels will continue as long as the Soviet-backed Government remains in power, Administration officials say. The Soviets have left behind a lot of weaponry, they said. Page 1 At Afghan guerrilla talks, confusion reigns supreme 5 Soviets say 89,000 troops are home 5 The Vatican declared racism a sin, issuing a document that touches on apartheid, anti-Semitism, tribal conflicts, the rights of aboriginal peoples and the discrimination encountered by migrants. 1 Panama's economy has survived months of sharp contraction and concerted pressure from the United States, and in a remarkable show of resilience some sectors are reporting a modest rebound. 4 Salvadoran political parties agreed in principle to meet with leftist rebels to discuss a peace initiative that would lead to rebel participation in national elections. 3 President Bush met Canada's leader, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, in Ottawa and agreed to pursue an accord to reduce acid rain, a commitment Canada has eagerly sought. 3 News analysis: Jamaica's election of Michael Manley as Prime Minister occurs when the Caribbean country's economy is on the rise. But doubts run high over whether Mr. Manley can continue the progress. 3 A liberal view of Hungary's uprising in 1956 - that a neutral Hungary would not be a Soviet threat - was printed by the official press. Differing views on the uprising are considered the focus of a deeper debate over pluralism. 28 Bonn defers decision on short-range missiles 3 National 6-10, 32 The biggest price increases in years were recorded last month by the Government's producer price indexes. Upward pressure on interest rates to head off higher inflation in consumer prices appears likely. 1 Large banks increase prime rate 35 Stocks drop sharply amid inflation and interest-rate worries 38 Depositors withdrew $8.1 billion more from savings associations than they deposited in December, a record, the Government said. Industry experts predict that January net withdrawals will be greater. 1 Lawmakers assailed Bush proposals for the budget only a day after welcoming the President on Capitol Hill. ''We started reading the fine print,'' a Senator said. 1 Ronald Brown was elected chairman of the Democratic National Committee. He is the first black to head a major American political party, one that has become better financed in recent years but remains dispirited. 1 Man in the news: Ronald Brown, the son of middle-class parents in Harlem, is a well-paid, powerful lawyer and lobbyist for several big corporations. He is also deeply rooted in liberal Democratic politics. 8 A request to halt the North trial was denied by a Federal appeals court panel that told the Justice Department it could only prohibit disclosure of classified information in the case against Oliver North. 6 C. Boyden Gray's financial reports should be amended to show $86,900 that the White House counsel has said he earned in 1985 and 1986 but did not report, the Office of Government Ethics has suggested. 10 New control over Federal secrets proposed by a Presidential order will be countered in a campign mounted by the A.C.L.U. The order would give agency heads sweeping authority to deny access to information. 32 The examination of John Tower, nominee for Secretary of Defense, has confounded Federal agents and senators trying to cut through the fog of gossip about his private life. 10 John Tower's surgeon found ''no evidence that the Senator abuses alcohol,'' after conducting extensive tests, the surgeon said. 10 A clash between U.S. and Texas officials came in the border town of Harlingen, where local officers raided the Federal immigration office, evicting workers and aliens because of alleged fire and health code violations. 6 Anti-black violence against a church in Alton, Ill, is worse than any in the church's 125-year history, members say. Two fires last year follow years of vandalism. 6 Michael Milken sought a ruling from a Federal judge to reject or modify a Government settlement with Drexel Burnham. Under the plea-bargain, Drexel would dismiss Mr. Milken and withhold compensation. 35 Illinois students locked in punishment boxes 32 Regional 29-32 Abortion opponents trying to block a Long Island man from ordering an abortion for his comatose wife failed in appeals to New York Court of Appeals and the United States Supreme Court. 29 Governor Kean's next post will be as 10th president of Drew University, a liberal arts college in northern New Jersey. Mr. Kean would assume office when his term as Governor of New Jersey expires next January. 29 Some local school board members in New York City are taking steps to circumvent a new law intended to reduce conflicts of interest, the sponsor of the bill says. He is considering legislation to close loopholes. 29 The removal of radium in Queens from an abandoned medical supply plant is about to start, and Federal officials are planning a campaign to head off neighborhood fears about the operation's safety. 31 A small fire in Queens mushroomed into tragedy, killing three people in a high-rise, because of errors commonly made by fire victims, the authorities said. 31 Most of Yonkers seems reconciled to the construction of low-income units in white neighborhoods, six months after the city attracted nationwide attention by defying a court order. 30 Queens man who said police beat him is cleared in case 30 Goodman imbroglio splits New York G.O.P. 31 Neediest Cases 32

title: Hoffa's Daughter Files Suit To Obtain Records of F.B.I.
description: The daughter of James R. Hoffa has filed a lawsuit here seeking the release of Federal documents in an effort to identify who was behind the 1975 disappearance of her father, the leader of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: Ernesto Sabato Wins Jerusalem Prize for 1989
description: Ernesto Sabato of Argentina has been named the winner of the Jerusalem Prize for writings and activities that express the idea of ''the freedom of the individual in society,'' the prize jury said. Teddy Kollek, the Mayor of Jerusalem, is to present the prize at a ceremony during the 14th Jerusalem International Book Fair, from March 12 to 18.

title: Two Pesos Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $3,400,000 charge for an adverse litigation judgment. c-Net income

title: Let's Have a Blue-Ribbon Panel to Screen TV Campaign Spots
description: To the Editor:

title: A Correction: The Budget
description: A table yesterday with a front-page article about President Bush's budget for the fiscal year 1990 misstated differences between some of President Ronald Reagan's proposed spending for the year and President Bush's in the same categories.

title: Corrections
description: The Auctions column in Weekend yesterday misidentified a brand of watch. It is a World Time, not a Waldheim.

title: Yonkers Moves Past Housing Battle
description: Six months after Yonkers attracted nationwide attention by risking bankruptcy to defy a Federal judge's housing-desegregation order, most of the city seems reconciled to construction of the first of the low-income units in white neighborhoods.

title: Canadian Tire Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,869,000 and $4,928,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and an extraordinary gain of $862,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $250,000 for the quarter and $481,000 for the year. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Stelco Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $1,600,000 extraordinary charge. Figures are in Canadian funds. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Charge Is Dropped Against Queens Man In a Brutality Case
description: A Queens man who said he was unjustifiably beaten by the police was cleared yesterday of charges that he obstructed the police in the incident.

title: Danaher Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,658,000 for the quarter and $1,030,000 for the year, and the year also included a $9,050,000 tax credit and a $4,009,000 loss on early retirement of debt. c-Net loss d-After a loss of $28,000 for the quarter and income of $991,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations; tax credits of $692,000 and $8,558,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and losses on early retirement of debt of $7,530,000 for the quarter and $9,630,000 for the year.

title: Mr. Brown's Democratic Party
description: Democrats and Republicans alike can welcome the selection of Ron Brown as chairman of the Democratic National Committee. The choice of a black man to head a major political party marks another milestone on the way to racial equality.

title: Prime Rate Up 1/2 Point, To 11%
description: Large commercial banks increased their prime lending rate by a half percentage point yesterday, to 11 percent, for the fifth consecutive increase over the last 12 months.

title: New Rule on Security Clearances Attracts Opposition
description: The American Civil Liberties Union and several labor unions mounted a campaign today to block a proposed Presidential order that would tighten controls over Government secrets and dilute the rights of appeal by those denied access to such information.

title: Appeal on Abortion Refused; Woman in Coma Is Readied
description: New York State's highest court refused today to hear an appeal by abortion opponents seeking to block a Long Island man from ordering an abortion for his pregnant comatose wife. Afterward, doctors at a Long Island hospital began preparing to perform the operation on Saturday.

title: Many in the Arts Donate to the Neediest Cases
description: Twenty-two members of the New York City Ballet Orchestra were among the latest contributors to the 77th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which runs through the end of this month.

title: Disabled Pupils Locked in Boxes; Illinois Officials Are Investigating
description: Three elementary schools have disciplined pupils who are mentally ill or disabled by locking them inside wooden boxes for up to 30 minutes, a punishment that one critic said had not been seen ''since the Dark Ages.''

title: Soviets Say 89,000 Troops Are Home
description: The Soviet military said early today that it had withdrawn slightly more than 89,000 soldiers from Afghanistan, leaving an estimated 11,000 men to be pulled out before next Wednesday's deadline.

title: Giorgio Zancanaro, Ill, Is Replaced in 'Nabucco'
description: Giorgio Zancanaro, who was to sing the title role in concert performances of Verdi's ''Nabucco'' with the Philadelphia Orchestra in Philadelphia and New York this month, has withdrawn because of a bronchial condition, the orchestra has announced.

title: Simon Virsaladze, 80, Designer
description: Simon Virsaladze, one of the Soviet Union's leading designers of ballet, film and opera, died of leukemia Thursday in Tbilisi, Georgia. He was 80 years old.

title: MAN IN THE NEWS: Ronald H. Brown; Elite Son Of Harlem
description: ''I'm rediscovering my own people,'' Ronald H. Brown confided to a friend recently as he found himself surrounded by several black Democrats.

title: Morrison Knudsen Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $32,650,000 for the quarter and $90,119,000 for the year. c-After losses of $8,987,000 and $50,121,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from discontinued operations. The year-ago quarter and year results were restated to reflect discontinued shipbuilding operations.

title: Oceaneering International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Alternative Minimum Tax: A Credit Is Now Helpful
description: More taxpayers than ever are now having to pay the alternative minimum tax, as a result of changes in the income tax laws, professionals say. And while many will want to restructure their finances to avoid the tax in the future, that is not necessarily the best strategy, given the new A.M.T. credit that is allowed beginning with 1988 returns.

title: An Emergency Cradle for Flat Tires
description: A tire cradle designed to end the hazards and dirty work that have long made ''flat tire'' two of the nastiest words to drivers is being sold by a Connecticut company.

title: Texas Instruments, Marietta Get Job
description: The Army chose Texas Instruments Inc. and the Martin Marietta Corporation to develop jointly a new shoulder-fired anti-tank weapon, a product that could mean more than $3 billion in business for the companies. No figure was announced for the development contract, which will be awarded before April 28. But the Army earlier said it planned to buy more than 70,000 of the weapons for the Army and Marines after the development phase.

title: Interest Rates Soar in Credit Markets
description: Interest rates jumped in the credit markets yesterday after the report of an unexpectedly sharp rise of 1 percent in the January Producer Price Index, a portent of higher inflation. The markets also reacted to a half-point increase in banks' prime lending rate, to 11 percent.

title:
CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping;
With Plans for Summer Camp
description: LEAD: School is in session for another four months, but now is the time to select a summer camp for your child.

title: Texans Raid U.S. Immigration Office
description: Police officers and fire officials in the border city of Harlingen, Tex., raided the Immigration and Naturalization Service office there today, evicting Federal workers and aliens alike and accusing the service of violating fire and sanitation laws.

title: Tower's Doctor Says He Saw No Signs of Alcohol Damage
description: Responding to allegations that John G. Tower, the Defense Secretary-designate, has a drinking problem, the surgeon who treated him for cancer said today that he had conducted extensive tests and found ''no evidence that the Senator abuses alcohol.''

title: F.B.I. Played Real Role in Civil Rights in 60's; Scottsboro Revisited
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Dance; Magic Afoot Again in Oberon's Land
description: George Balanchine's ballet version of ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' loses no time in plunging into its music and dancing. The plot is not given short shrift but is compressed with cinematic swiftness into a minimum of dramatic posturing.

title: Vatican Document Condemns All Forms of Racism as Sinful
description: The Vatican condemned all forms of racism yesterday in a major document touching on apartheid, anti-Semitism, tribal conflicts, the rights of aboriginal people and the discrimination encountered by migrants.

title: Kirk Gets One Year For Tax Evasion
description: Dana Kirk, the former Memphis State basketball coach, was sentenced to one year in prison and fined $20,000 yesterday for income tax evasion and obstruction of justice. Kirk, 53 years old, declined to comment on the sentence but said he was considering an appeal. United States District Judge Odell Horton said he agreed with the jury's verdict that Kirk was guilty of cheating on his taxes and trying to intimidate a grand jury witness. His salary over seven years at Memphis State ranged from $35,000 to $62,500, but outside earnings increased it to as much as $300,000. (AP)

title: New York Date for Soviet Troupe
description: Told that they would have good luck if they rubbed the foot of George Washington's statue in the Capitol Building, members of a Soviet ballet company that has been stranded in Baltimore lost no time in doing so today.

title: Artist Asks the Guggenheim To Withdraw His Painting
description: Charging that the Guggenheim Museum has ''defamed'' him and his work, Wolfgang Cihlarz, a West German artist known professionally as Salome, has asked the museum to remove one of his paintings from its current show, ''Refigured Painting: The German Image 1960-88.''

title: DEMOCRATS ASSAIL THE BUSH BUDGET, TERMING IT VAGUE
description: A day after warmly welcoming President Bush on Capitol Hill, Democratic members of Congress took a second look at his budget proposals today and sharply criticized them on the ground that they were vague and hid many cuts in domestic spending.

title: Kuhlman Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $2,220,000 from an accounting change. c-Net loss The company said the latest year loss was primarily due to restructuring the company's operations and to its closing of operations at Borse Plastics Products Corp.

title: Noverco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title:
Your Money;
Municipal Bonds Retain an Edge
description: LEAD: Despite the fact that yields on high-quality municipal bonds have fallen recently, they may still offer better after-tax value than Treasuries for certain investors, experts say.

title: Corrections
description: The Sports of The Times column on Thursday misidentified the president of the Louisiana-Pacific Corporation. He is Harry A. Merlo, not Henry

title: KEY RATES
Rochester Telephone Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $5,733,000 gain from an accounting change. Year-ago fourth-quarter results included a $4,081,000 charge for the pending sale of the western part of a long-distance subsidiary and the elimination of obsolete microwave equipment in the same subsidiary.

title: Two-Legged Rogues Are on the Run
description: As visitors fly by bush plane into the heart of this sprawling reserve dedicated to the preservation of African wildlife, a military camp with a fleet of army trucks and rows of tents suddenly looms into sight.

title: O'Sullivan and Ivan Cruise; Aouita Struggles
description: Marcus O'Sullivan of Ireland ran away with the men's mile tonight in the Vitalis Meadowlands Invitational indoor track meet with the fifth-fastest time in history. Paula Ivan of Rumania ran away with the women's mile with the second-fastest time in history.

title: Ban on Assault Rifles Urged
description: Declaring that the nation's streets are becoming a combat zone, police officials urged Congress today to ban assault rifles like the one used to kill five children last month in a California playground.

title: Julius Rolnitzky, Lawyer, 77
description: Julius Rolnitzky, a retired assistant United States attorney, died of cancer Sunday at the Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan. He was 77 years old and lived in Long Island City, Queens.

title: The Smoke Surrounding John Tower
description: Cutting through the fog of gossip about the private life of John G. Tower has proved confounding both for Federal agents carrying out a check on his background and for the senators who must weigh his nomination as Secretary of Defense.

title: Joseph J. Enright, Teacher, 78
description: Joseph J. Enright, a Christian Brother and a retired teacher, died yesterday at New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital, after a long illness. He was 78 years old and lived in New Rochelle.

title: INSIDE
description: Pleas to Halt Abortion Fail

title: MacMillan Bloedel Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Margit Van Leight-Frank, 91, Psychologist
description: Margit Van Leight-Frank, a clinical psychologist who was a founding member of the C. G. Jung Institute of New York, died Wednesday at her home in Weston, Conn. She was 91 years old.

title: Kean Named New President Of Drew U.
description: Gov. Thomas H. Kean, an old history teacher who has always retained a love of the classroom, today was named the 10th president of Drew University, a small, private liberal arts university in northern New Jersey.

title: Islanders Lose by 3-1
description: Alain Chevrier continued his hot goaltending, stopping 27 shots tonight as the Chicago Blackhawks defeated the Islanders, 3-1.

title: V Band Chairman Weighs Takeover
description: Thomas E. Feil, the founder and chairman of the V Band Corporation, said he might make an offer to acquire the Elmsford, N.Y., telecommunications equipment manufacturer and added that he was seeking others to join in exploring a transaction. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Feil said that he had hired Bear, Stearns & Company to act as his financial adviser.

title: Safety-Kleen Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $3,800,000 from the sale of a restaurant services business and a charge of $2,900,000 for removal of underground storage tanks.

title: Bank Branches At K Mart to End
description: First Nationwide Bank, a unit of the Ford Motor Company, said it would close its 170 branches in K Mart stores, effective March 10. The decision represents the end of a bold experiment for First Nationwide, a San Francisco-based savings institution, to grow quickly without having to build new branches. But company officials have recently acknowledged that the K Mart branches were not doing well.

title: Can a Film do Justice to Literature?
description: The motion before the house - a gathering of London's literati in the vast splendor of Merchant Taylors' Hall on Thursday night - was this: ''Good literature is too substantial to fit through the lens of a camera.''

title: F.A.A. Fined Boeing in '87
description: The Federal Aviation Administration confirmed today that it had levied a $125,000 civil penalty against the Boeing Company on June 10, 1987, in connection with locknuts used in 22 of the Boeing 767 aircraft. The locknuts did not meet specification, the F.A.A. said.

title: In Latin America, Winter for Democracy . . . In Prague, Still No Thaw
description: Despite Mikhail S. Gorbachev and despite (or perhaps because of) the impending withdrawal of some of his 80,000 occupation troops, Czechoslovakia's rulers are going at it harder than ever to stifle their own people.

title: Young Consumers: Perils and Power
description: How savvy are children as consumers? A communications company has given the question new currency by planning to test-market a daily television news program with commercials in six public schools next month.

title: Review/Film; Another Look at Insecthood As a Possible Way of Life
description: One of the sadder things about today's taste for movie sequels is the correct, unimaginative nomenclature that goes with it. The film that opened yesterday at the National is entitled ''The Fly II,'' but it's a ''Son of . . . '' movie if ever there was one.

title: Yanks Make Offer to John
description: George Steinbrenner met for two hours in Florida yesterday with Tommy John and his wife and gave the 45-year-old pitcher the same offer he made last week to 38-year-old Ron Guidry: Come to spring training for $250,000 and, if you make the team, you will get another $250,000. If not, take another job in the organization.

title: Goodman Quest Splits New York G.O.P.
description: State Senator Roy M. Goodman's quest for a job in the Bush Administration has provoked strife and division in New York's normally quiet Republican Congressional delegation.

title: F.B.I. Played Real Role in Civil Rights in 60's
description: To the Editor:

title: Orange Crop Forecast
description: The nation's orange harvest is estimated at about 215 million boxes for the 1988-89 season, virtually unchanged from the previous forecast a month ago, but 7 percent higher than last season's production, the Agriculture Department said Thursday.

title: The Bush Budget: Alive on Arrival
description: President Bush has given new life to the ''dead-on-arrival'' budget that Ronald Reagan submitted only four weeks ago. Mr. Bush mainly repeats the Reagan program, re-flavoring it with small alterations. More important than his details, he avoids confrontation and invites negotiation.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about arrests of housing inspectors, supervisors and building owners in New York City referred incorrectly in some copies to one accused owner. He was identified as John Nazarewycz, and he was not arrested.

title: Progressive Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Latest-quarter and year results included gains on securities sales of $4.8 million, or 16 cents a share, and $5.9 million, or 19 cents a share, respectively. The 1987 quarter and year results included losses on securities sales of $16.9 million and $1.6 million, respectively. The 1987 fourth-quarter and year results also include a 13-cents-a-share accounting change gain.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Honeywell Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter loss included a $158,000,000 tax provision, which included effects of the company's inability to record tax benefits for 1988 charges where tax deductibility will occur in the future. It also included reclassification to current liabilities of previously provided deferred taxes. The company also said the latest year included a $150,800,000 provision for discontinuance of product lines and a $33,700,000 gain from the sale of real estate. Latest quarter also included a $126,000,000 provision for discontinuance of product lines. Other charges in the quarter totaling $115,000,000 cover a broad range of actions throughout the company's businesses to reduce risks and enhance competitiveness. Those charges included severance for work force reductions, a reorganization of a semiconductor facility and consolidation of research and development efforts.

title: Cross, A T Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Visual Graphics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
First Black Chosen by Democrats To Head the National Committee
description: Ronald H. Brown, an influential Washington lawyer, was elected today as chairman of the Democratic National Committee, the first black ever to preside over a major political party in the United States.

title: Emily Kimbrough, 90, Magazine Editor And Popular Author
description: Emily Kimbrough, an author, lecturer and former radio commentator, died yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 90 years old and had suffered from lung cancer, said a longtime friend, Sophia Yarnall Jacobs.

title: Review/Theater; Comic Doings in a Diner And Male Pillow Talk
description: By MEL GUSSOW

title: Ruiz Dropped From Payroll Of New York
description: State Senator Israel Ruiz was removed from the New York payroll today after the State Attorney General determined that Mr. Ruiz's Federal felony conviction last week made his seat vacant.

title: Dataproducts
description: The Dataproducts Corporation, a manufacturer of computer printers, instructed its investment banking firm, Goldman, Sachs & Company, to seek a buyer for the company. Dataproducts, which has annual sales of about $345 million, said it had not made a final decision to sell the company but that it believed it could obtain the best value for its shareholders by putting itself up for sale. Dataproducts shares jumped $1.875 a share today, to $16, on the American Stock Exchange, where its 15.2 percent gain was the highest of the day.

title: Marsh Supermarkets reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 7
Patents; A Device for Television To Help Sight-Impaired
description: Richard Feinbloom, a Long Island entrepreneur, won patent approval this week for a device that helps people with severely clouded vision to watch television.

title: India's Dowry Murders Mark Rise in Violence Against Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Royal Trustco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Excerpts From Vatican's Declaration on Racism
description: Following, in official translation, are excerpts from the Vatican document on racism issued today:

title: Manley Returns to His World Stage
description: Michael N. Manley, who was overwhelmingly elected Prime Minister of Jamaica on Thursday, is taking charge of one of the most richly endowed countries in the Caribbean with an economy that is on the rise.

title: Court Backs 24-Hour Watch On Spy's Ailing Wife in Prison
description: A Federal magistrate, hearing a complaint about the medical treatment of the wife of the convicted spy Jonathan Pollard, has refused to suspend round-the-clock medical surveillance despite her doctor's contention that it aggravates her problems.

title: Cliff Buck, Olympic Official, 88
description: Cliff Buck, president of the United States Olympic Committee from 1969 to 1973, died Wednesday night at the Heritage Park Care Center in Carbondale, Calif. He was 88 years old. Mr. Buck was an administrator in amateur sports for more than 30 years. He worked for the Rocky Mountain Amateur Athletic Union and the national A.A.U. as well as the United States Olympic Committee.

title: Jiffy Lube Income
description: Jiffy Lube International Inc. said it expects to take a $39 million charge on its third-quarter earnings, which are to be released next week.

title: A Prize Winner's Debut
description: William Sharp, a baritone who was the winner of the 1987 Carnegie Hall International American Music Competition for voice, is to make his Carnegie Hall recital debut on Monday at 8 P.M. The program will include Poulenc's ''Tel jour telle nuit,'' four of Wolf's ''Morike Lieder'' and works by Virgil Thomson, George Gershwin and others. Tickets, at $19, $15, $13, $11 and $9, are available at the box office. Information: 247-7800.

title: Medco Containment Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Hungary Prints a Liberal Soviet View of 1956
description: As the Communist Party Central Committee met to try to heal a leadership rift stemming from differing interpretations of the 1956 uprising, the official press today published comments by a Soviet academician that appeared to support a liberal view.

title: Williams Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $102.9 million. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $36.3 million and $66 million for the quarter and year, respectively; an extraordinary charges of $4.9 million and $2.5 million from early retirement of debt for the same periods, respectively; and the year also included a gain of $4 million from an accounting change. d-Net income

title: Dravo Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $19,569,000 for both the quarter and year, and the quarter also included an extraordinary loss of $2,261,000. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $76,603,000 for the quarter and $145,404,000 for the year, and the year also included an extraordinary gain of $8,000. The company said 1988 and 1987 results have been restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: Patents; Developing Brain-Like Computers
description: Within the last two weeks, two separate teams of inventors have obtained fundamental patents in the field of neural network systems, a still embryonic class of computers that tries to mimic the human brain.

title: St. Anthony Tops Elizabeth, 72-44
description: St. Anthony of Jersey City, the nation's top-ranked team, and Elizabeth, the second-best team in New Jersey, had their showdown tonight before a crowd of 4,500 at St. Peter's College and a national cable-TV audience.

title: George B. Walsh, Professor, 42
description: George B. Walsh, chairman of the department of classical languages and literature at the University of Chicago, died of cancer Tuesday at Bernard Mitchell Hospital in Chicago. He was 42 years old and lived in Chicago.

title: U.S. Takes Over 6 Savings Concerns
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation forged ahead today with President Bush's program to take control of insolvent savings institutions and announced that it had assumed control of six more of them, with assets totaling $13 billion.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Keeping Sweets Fresh
description: About $605 million worth of chocolate is expected to be sold as gifts for Valentine's Day, according to the Chocolate Manufacturers Association. To insure that what you buy is fresh, go to a store that does a brisk business. Chocolate keeps well if properly stored; in general, it requires a dry place and a temperature of 60 to 75 degrees. At warmer temperatures, chocolate will develop a gray haze, or bloom, which is unattractive but harmless. Chocolate can be refrigerated if it is in plastic wrap, foil or the original box, but the cold may make it brittle. If refrigerated chocolate has been kept too long, the texture may change and fillings may weep. Chocolate can be frozen, but that does not lengthen its shelf life. Freezing can also change the texture of chocolate that contains nuts, praline or fruit. Chocolate Shelf Life Solid dark or milk without nuts Two years refrigerated; 9 months at room temperature Solid white; solid dark, milk or One year refrigerated; 2 to 3 white with nuts at room temperature Filled, hand-dipped or molded Six months refrigerated, one month at room temperature Truffles Three months refrigerated; 2 weeks at room temperature. Dipped strawberries Twenty-four hours refrigerated.

title: Canseco Gets a Ticket
description: Speed and power have brought Jose Canseco all sorts of honors in his three-year career, including the American League's most valuable player award for last season. Early yesterday morning in Florida, that combination brought him a ticket after the police estimated that his 1989 Jaguar was traveling more than 120 miles an hour along Interstate 95 in northern Dade County. According to Lieut. Tim Betts of the Florida Highway Patrol, Canseco, the Oakland Athletics' right fielder, was cited for reckless driving and allowed to drive away. Betts said Canseco was scheduled to appear in court March 16. The penalty for reckless driving could be imprisonment for not more than 90 days, or a fine of not less than $25 and not more than $500, or both, Betts said. (AP)

title: Unilever Sets $1.55 Billion Faberge Deal
description: The consumer-products giant Unilever said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Faberge Inc., a leading cosmetics company, for $1.55 billion in cash, raising its investment in the American market in the last two years by almost $5 billion.

title: Uribe Is Detained
description: Jose Uribe, the San Francisco Giants' shortstop, cannot leave the Dominican Republic until he stands trial on a rape charge, a district attorney there said yesterday. Jose Francisco Rodriguez, prosecution attorney in the province of San Cristobal, outside the capital of Santo Domingo, said a woman filed a complaint accusing Uribe of threatening her with a gun and raping her. Uribe denied the charge, Rodriguez said. The district attorney said Uribe, who was born in the Dominican Republic, spent three days in jail and was freed on his own recognizance. The Giants' general manager, Al Rosen, said yesterday that he spoke to an agent of Uribe who assured him that the matter ''should be cleared up within 72 hours.'' Uribe, 29 years old, underwent a difficult 1988 season. His wife, Sara, died June 1, a day after giving birth to the couple's third child, Enrique. Uribe went on the disabled list June 2 because of emotional distress and came off June 17. He batted .252 with three homers and 35 runs batted in. (AP)

title: Tacoma Backs Needle Swap
description: A government role in a program that gives free hypodermic needles to drug addicts when they turn in used ones received final approval Thursday from the Tacoma-Pierce County Health Board. The program, aimed at fighting the spread of AIDS, was started on a private basis in August by a former drug counselor, Dave Purchase. The board's action appropriates $43,000 to provide him a van, needles and a salary. Tacoma, a city of 160,000 people, has about 3,000 intravenous drug abusers.

title: J P Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After gains from discontinued operations of $344,000 for the quarter and $3,145,000 for the year. c-After gains from discontinued operations of $889,000 and $3,235,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Forschner Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Buckeye Financial Corp., Columbus, Ohio, cut its staff to 300 in January from 417 last June after a study on improving operating efficiency.

title: New U.S. Move to Halt North Trial Fails
description: A Federal appeals court today rejected the Bush Administration's third attempt in two days to halt the trial of Oliver L. North to prevent the disclosure of state secrets, and the Administration said it would make a final plea to the Supreme Court Saturday morning.

title: Alphonse Riesenfeld, An Anthropologist, 77
description: Alphonse Riesenfeld, professor emeritus of anthropology at Hunter College, died Tuesday at Mount Sinai Hospital after a series of strokes. He was 77 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Banks Seen As Gaining In Rescue
description: Commercial bankers may not want to gloat about it, but they may well turn out to be clear winners in the Government's rescue plan for the savings and loan industry.

title: Leaders of Brooklyn Groups Guilty of Harassing Builders
description: Three former leaders of black and Hispanic organizations in Brooklyn were convicted late Thursday of intimidating, harassing and threatening to stop the work of construction contractors who refused to make payoffs to them.

title: Teheran and Baghdad Agree to March Talks
description: The Foreign Ministers of Iran and Iraq have agreed to hold a new round of direct peace talks on the Persian Gulf in March after talks with Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, the Secretary General announced today.

title: At Afghan Guerrilla Talks, Confusion Reigns Supreme
description: With cries of ''Down with Russia!'' and ''God is great!'' several hundred Afghans met here today in the hope of forming the next government of Afghanistan.

title: Patents; Developing Machinery the Size of a Molecule
description: Physicists from the University of Colorado and Boston University won a patent this week for a way to make patterns that could be used in developing molecule-sized machinery.

title: Halt at Ford Plant
description: The Ford Motor Company said that it had interrupted production at an assembly plant this week, its first such shutdown in years. Bert Serre, a spokesman for Ford, said the plant, in Hermosillo, Mexico, would resume production of the Mercury Tracer subcompact on Monday. The car had been accumulating on dealers' lots, a rare problem for Ford, which for years has produced all the cars it could and sold all that it produced. Auto industry analysts have said that overall industry sales have been strong, but not strong enough to justify Detroit's production plans for the first quarter. These plans can be fine-tuned, by actions such as Ford's.

title: E.P.A. Preparing for Radium Removal in Queens
description: The Federal Government is about to begin the process of removing dangerously radioactive radium from an abandoned medical supply plant in Woodside, Queens, and officials are planning a campaign to reassure neighborhood businesses and residents about the safety of the four-month operation.

title: New Orleans Rejects Parisian Transplant
description: A restaurant that was once part of the Eiffel Tower in Paris has closed in New Orleans, a victim of the poor Louisiana economy, its developer and chief chef said Thursday.

title: Patents; New Method Created For Machine Vision
description: Stephen Grossberg and Ennio Mingolla, both professors of computer science at Boston University, won patent approval this week for a computational method to create machine vision that replicates the brain's ability to make sense out of streams of incoming signals.

title: Victims' Errors Blamed in Fire Deaths
description: Windblown flames that roared through an apartment and hallway and killed three people in a high-rise in Queens on Thursday began as a small terrace fire and mushroomed into tragedy because of errors commonly made by fire victims, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Alfred Brendel
description: Alfred Brendel, the pianist, is to play Beethoven's ''Diabelli Variations'' and variation sets by Mozart, Brahms and Liszt at 8 P.M. tomorrow at Carnegie Hall. Tickets are $25 to $14. Information: 247-7800.

title: Dibrell Brothers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Irving Brown, 77, U.S. Specialist On International Labor Movement
description: Irving Brown, an international affairs specialist for the American trade-union movement for more than four decades, died of intestinal cancer yesterday at his home in Paris. He was 77 years old.

title: Racial Strife Still Haunts Church Started by Slaves
description: From slavery to segregation, the New Bethel African Methodist Episcopal Church was a haven in the prairie for a tiny community of freed slaves and their descendants. But in recent months the little 125-year-old church has been beset by what members say is an outbreak of anti-black violence.

title: A Jersey Museum Director Is Arrested on Arson Charges
description: The director of this city's historical museum has been charged with setting a fire that damaged some of its irreplaceable artifacts last month, the police said today.

title: St. Jude Medical Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Jury Rejects Harassment Suit
description: A Passaic County jury has ruled in favor of the principal of Eastside High School here, Joe Clark, in a lawsuit in which he was accused of intentionally inflicting mental stress on a teacher, a lawyer said today. Adam Mujica, said that Mr. Clark and other school employees had harrassed him after four students accused him of sexual misconduct over four years. The jury decided that Mr. Clark did not act ''in an extreme and outrageous manner.'' Mr. Mujica was suspended with pay on May 21, 1985, and went on sick leave until last December.

title: BONN IS DEFERRING DECISION ON MISSILE
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl made it clear today that he did not intend to commit his Government this year on the politically touchy issue of upgrading short-range American nuclear weapons in West Germany.

title: 11 Bases Listed as Sites for Missile Trains
description: The Air Force today issued an environmental statement listing 11 military bases around the country where railroad trains carrying MX missiles might be located if the Bush Administration decided on such a plan to hide the missiles' whereabouts.

title: Sins of the Fathers and Mothers
description: Second Chances Men, Women, and Children a Decade After Divorce By Judith S. Wallerstein and Sandra Blakeslee 329 pages. Ticknor & Fields. $19.95.

title: Two Brothers' Lives, Begun in Turmoil, End Hours Apart
description: The two graves, side by side in Cedar Lawn Cemetery, are a closing chapter in a family saga that became entwined with the story of America.

title: Cable Concerns Revive Billion-Dollar Merger
description: After several weeks of negotiations, United Artists Communications Inc. and the United Cable Television Corporation announced that they had revived their on-again, off-again billion-dollar merger agreement.

title: Klecko Plans to Retire
description: Joe Klecko, a longtime Jets hero, has decided to retire, while Harry Carson, the longtime Giants hero, says he is staying retired. Sort of.

title: Against the Odds, Panama's Economy Stays Afloat
description: In a remarkable show of resilience after months of sharp contraction and American economic sanctions, Panama's economy has avoided collapse.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We cannot ignore the history of this moment. In choosing the first American of African descent to lead one of America's political parties, you have made history.'' - Ronald H. Brown. [ 1:4. ]

title: Doctor Forced Out for Plagiarism Is Reappointed to Hospital's Staff
description: An eminent psychiatrist who admitted plagiarism and was forced to resign as director of a hospital affiliated with the Harvard Medical School has been reappointed as a staff psychiatrist at the hospital.

title: About New York; Paradise Found: A Slice of Tahiti In the Icy North
description: Enough, already! The thermometer dips, the wind howls and forecasts are for more of the same. All this and the charms of New York City, too - people urinating in subway cars, roaches laying claim to refrigerators and the $2 beer a fast-fading memory in favored saloons.

title: Salvador Political Parties Agree to Talk to Rebels
description: Salvadoran political parties agreed in principle today to meet with leftist rebels to discuss a peace initiative that would lead to their participation in national elections.

title: Milkens Challenge Drexel Accord
description: Striking back at a plea-bargaining agreement between Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and the Government, Michael R. Milken and his brother Lowell yesterday formally objected to provisions requiring that the investment house dismiss them and withhold their bonuses and compensation for 1988.

title: Robert J. Lynch, 87, Retired Businessman
description: Robert J. Lynch, a retired executive in the foreign trade industry, died of pneumonia Thursday at Palm Beach Gardens Hospital in North Palm Beach, Fla. He was 87 years old and lived in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: H H Robertson Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included $4,999,000 income from discontinued operations. c-Net loss and included $1,823,000 income from discontinued operations. d-Net income and included $17,483,000 income from discontinued operations. The 1988 year results included a $21,800,000 reorganization charge, a loss of $44,000,000 from the discontinuation of custom curtain wall operations and a $13,000,000 charge related to its Spectrum division. These charges were partially offset by a $62,000,000 gain on the sale of Freeman Chemical operations.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Gilbert Beats McEnroe: Brad Gilbert upset John McEnroe, 6-4, 6-3, yesterday in the quarterfinals of the Volvo Chicago tournament. Earlier, 16-year-old Michael Chang withdrew with tendinitis in his right leg, putting Horacio de la Pena of Argentina into the semifinals. Gilbert will face de la Pena in one of today's semfinals. In the other semifinal, Tim Mayotte will play the winner of the Ivan Lendl-Kevin Curren match.(AP) Hlasek Advances: Jakob Hlasek of Switzerland trounced Eric Jelen of West Germany, 6-1, 6-1, yesterday to advance to the semifinals of the Rotterdam Grand Prix tournament. Hlasek will face Yannick Noah of France. Darren Cahill of Australia will play Anders Jarryd of Sweden in the other semifinal.(AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL Princeton 71, Columbia 54: Kit Mueller scored 16 points last night as Princeton took possession of first place in the Ivy League. Princeton is 13-5 over all and 5-1 in the league. The Tigers moved ahead of Penn, which lost to Cornell. Columbia, playing at home, fell to 6-13 and 2-5.(AP) GOLF Hill Keeps Lead: Mike Hill shot a one-under-par 71 yesterday and held on to a one-stroke lead after two rounds of the 50th PGA Seniors Championship at Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. (AP)

title: U.S. Won't Press Israel On Peace, Quayle Says
description: Vice President Dan Quayle said today that the Bush Administration remained deeply suspicious of Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, and that the United States would not seek to impose a Middle East solution on Israel.

title: Bermuda Star Line reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Incentives Are Heating Up the Credit Card Race
description: Credit card companies are battling for consumer loyalty these days, but in most cases they are not trying to win with lower interest rates, cheaper annual fees or longer grace periods. Instead they are using enhancements - extra features provided free or at a reduced charge.

title: Scandals and School Decentralization
description: When New York City's public schools were decentralized in 1969, one goal was to give parents a voice in their children's education. But parents remain shut out. Local politicians quickly gobbled up the powers relinquished by the central Board of Education.

title: Wilkens and K. C. Jones Elected to Basketball Hall of Fame
description: K. C. Jones and Lenny Wilkens, two guards who were noted more for defense than offense during their playing days, were elected today to the Basketball Hall of Fame. William (Pop) Gates, who played with the New York Renaissance and other teams through the early 1950's, was also elected.

title: Walesa Urges Halt to Strikes
description: Lech Walesa called today for a six-week strike moratorium in Poland, saying there was a plot to stir up labor unrest and undermine Solidarity's talks with the Government. The Government said four strikes erupted in different parts of Poland. The Government spokesman, Jerzy Urban, called them dangerous because of the difficult economic situation.

title: Heekin Can Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
7-UP GOLD: THE FAILURE OF A CAN'T-LOSE PLAN
description: It seemed like a sure-fire strategy for creating a new soft drink. Test the flavor to make sure people like it, sell it under the brand name of an established product and back it with $10 million in advertising.

title: Arizona's Top Scorer Now Emphasizes Defense
description: John Thompson sent Sean Elliott a message when he cut the all-America forward from the United States Olympic basketball team last summer: Elliott needed to work on his aggressiveness and on his defensive skills.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Abraham Lincoln's birthday, actually tomorrow, will be observed on Monday. Below are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Federal and state offices open, local offices closed. Post offices: Regular delivery. Banks: State-chartered banks have option to close; federally chartered banks open. Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation: No collections or street cleanings. Schools: Closed. Financial markets: Open. Transportation: Subways and buses, Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North on regular weekday schedule. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Federal offices open, state and local offices closed. Post offices: Regular delivery. Banks: Option to close. Schools: Local option. Transportation: N.J. Transit on regular weekday schedule. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Federal offices open, state and local offices closed. Post offices: Regular delivery. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: New Haven line on regular weekday schedule.

title: Efforts Seen To Subvert School Law
description: Although a new law intended to reduce conflicts of interest on New York City's local school boards is only a few months old, some board members are already taking steps to avoid its consequences, election records and political associates indicate.

title: Brown & Sharpe Mfg Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company said the latest fourth quarter and year results included gains of $908,000 and $1,206,000, respectively, from settlement of pension plans.

title: Overtaking a Clipper Ship After 135 Years
description: A 60-foot yacht designed in the anything-goes style of ocean racing is expected to sail through the Golden Gate Bridge finish line late Saturday and break what many sailors consider to be the last great sailing record.

title: Fires Leave 15,000 Homeless
description: Three mysterious fires broke out within hours of each other in metropolitan Manila, razing 2,000 houses and leaving up to 15,000 people homeless, police said today. The first fire broke out Friday afternoon in Tondo, a Manila slum district, destroying about 2,000 houses in a four-block area. Several people, mostly children, were missing but there were no reports of deaths, police said. A second fire of unknown origin began a street away and burned down four other houses. And in San Juan, a Manila suburb, a fire broke out today in a 12-story commercial building, but firefighters said they had the blaze under control.

title: Katy Cranton, Kindergarten Teacher,Becomes Engaged to Peter C. Thomes
description: The engagement of Kathleen Ann Cranton to Peter Carlisle Thomes, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell F. Thomes Jr. of New York and Southold, L.I., has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Norman W. Cranton of Groveland, Mass. An April wedding is planned.

title: RAMBO ECONOMICS
description: THE ECONOMICS OF CHAOS On Revitalizing the American Economy. By Eliot Janeway. 402 pp. New York: Truman Talley Books/E. P. Dutton. $22.50.

title: Lori B. Katz, Elaine Gendel And Laura Goldstein to Wed
description: Lori Barbara Katz and Michael Jon Goldstein plan to marry next month. The future bridegroom's sister, Laura Megan Goldstein, and Mark David Yumkas are to be married in September, and Marc David Goldstein, the brother of Michael and Laura Goldstein, is to marry Elaine Miriam Gendel in December. The engagements were announced by the parents of the future brides, Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Katz of Sunrise, Fla.; Blanche K. Goldstein of Montclair, N.J., and Dr. and Mrs. Howard Gendel of Jericho, L.I.

title: ABE, HONESTLY AND OTHERWISE
description: Although many publishers seem to think that young readers are most interested in the childhood of historical figures, contemporary children, surrounded by complicated social issues and aware of unpleasant problems, are more apt to ask, ''What was so great about him?'' and ''Did he get shot?'' For Abraham Lincoln, neither question receives much of an answer in the most durable of the juvenile biographies - ''Abe Lincoln Grows Up'' by Carl Sandburg, with illustrations by James Daugherty, and ''Abraham Lincoln,'' written and illustrated by Ingri and Edgar Parin d'Aulaire.

title: Dun & Bradstreet's Bid to Stay Ahead
description: George J. Feeney, the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation's senior vice president for advanced development, leaned across the table in his utilitarian Manhattan office and talked about, of all things, oil.

title: NONFICTION
description: SUSAN B. ANTHONY: A Biography of a Singular Feminist. By Kathleen Barry. (New York University, $27.95.) Those who dimly recall Susan B. Anthony as Tonto to Elizabeth Cady Stanton's Lone Ranger will be surprised, and perhaps provoked, to read in ''Susan B. Anthony: A Biography of a Singular Feminist'' that Anthony was a charismatic leader who was, for decades, the heart of the women's movement, that she often had to cajole or blackmail her older friend into political participation and that she may have desired Stanton sexually. Kathleen Barry, a sociologist at Penn State University, narrates Anthony's political evolution with skill and acumen, but her sympathy for her subject leads her to take Anthony at her word on matters of motivation and feeling. Ms. Barry celebrates Anthony's decision to remain single as of immense significance both in her ability to develop feminist theory and in providing a respectable alternative model for women who did not wish to marry. Yet Ms. Barry never gives psychological or emotional dimension to that decision, nor to the important related matters of Anthony's attitudes toward her mother and toward her own sexuality. While providing extensive evidence to the contrary, Ms. Barry insists that Anthony had no ambivalence about being a woman and contends that her childhood and psychological makeup were in no way unusual, that she was simply a female counterpart to the Jacksonian common man. This otherwise thorough and adventurous biography is marred by Ms. Barry's failure to consider the psychological growth of Susan B. Anthony as yet another historically specific aspect of her life, and this in turn undermines some of her more controversial claims about her subject.

title: What Happened to the Architects of Iran's Revolution
description: IT was 10 years ago this weekend that Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, Shah of Shahs, Light of the Aryans, and America's anointed policeman of the Persian Gulf, left Iran, carrying a small jar of his native soil, an aide kissing his head in a last obsequious gesture. In his place came Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the implacable exponent of a new theocracy of Shiite Islam.

title: PERSIAN MINIATURES
description: THE BLINDFOLD HORSE Memories of a Persian Childhood. By Shusha Guppy. 246 pp. Boston: Beacon Press. $17.95.

title: Kuwait Frees 2 of 17 Jailed For 1983 Bombing Attacks
description: Two of 17 jailed terrorists whose release is the major demand of kidnappers holding American hostages in Lebanon have been freed after serving five-year prison terms, Kuwait's Interior Minister said today.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORTS;
With Expansion, N.B.A. Comes of Age
description: LEAD: Until the mid-1960's, I thought expansion was what your waistline did when you ate too much pasta, which was called spaghetti back then.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: QUALITY WHOLESALE FLORIST;
Keeping Up With 'Sophisticated Tastes'
description: LEAD: IN this season of hearts and flowers, Neil Galligan Jr. concentrates on flowers. Hearts, yes - balloons, vases, little decorations to accompany assorted blooms. But mostly, flowers - thousands and thousands of them, destined to express affection, esteem and true love forever this Tuesday.

title: Crop Income Increases For New York Farmers
description: New York farmers grew more apples, tomatoes and pears last year than in 1987 but smaller quantities of sweet corn, cabbage, cherries and onions, according to a series of year-end reports issued by the New York Agricultural Statistics Service here.

title: She's Not Buying
description: Why did Dorothy Huntley-Flint sneak back into the clubhouse on Friday after getting a hole-in-one at a local club at Barton-on-Sea, England? Because it was her fourth hole-in-one, and she couldn't face another round of congratulations? Because at the age of 90 she'd had enough excitement in her life?

title: Help for Compulsive Disorders
description: LEAD: FOR years, a 34-year-old West Haven woman was consumed with thoughts of self-destruction. Persistent fears of swallowing glass or poison, or driving off the highway, took over her life. Psychotherapy did little to help her.

title: The Image Reflected in the Cookware Pan
description: I NEEDED pots and pans. After eight years of marriage and what seems like dozens of cheap, on-sale sets of generic brands, I decided it was time to invest in quality cookware.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some of the most notable releases of the last few months. BELLMAN AND TRUE - Richard Loncraine's tale of a computer systems engineer (Bernard Hill) and his stepson (Kieran O'Brien) forced by gangsters to pull off a bank heist. ''An unexpectedly upbeat and satisfying film.'' (Maslin) 1987. Cannon. 2:01. $79.95. R. BIG DEAL ON MADONNA STREET - Marcello Mastroianni, Vittorio Gassman and Claudia Cardinale star in Mario Monicelli's sendup of crime capers. The direction is ''as peppy as the jazz score.'' (Goodman) 1957. Connoisseur Video. $69.95. 1:31. In Italian, with English subtitles. THE BLOB - Chuck Russell's update of the 1958 science-fiction film. ''More professional in every way.'' (Maslin) 1988. RCA/Columbia Pictures Home Entertainment. 1:35. $89.95. CC. R. BLOOD MONEY - Andy Garcia and Ellen Barkin star in Jerry Schatzberg's film, made for cable, about two outsiders thrown together by a murder. ''Ms. Barkin and Mr. Garcia are terrific.'' (O'Connor). 1988. J2 Communications. 1:49. $79.95. Not rated.

title:
GARDENING;
Time for Seeding Is Drawing Near
description: LEAD: THE myth of the groundhog notwithstanding, it is a good bet that wintry weather will remain at least another four to six weeks. Yet the time to prepare for spring planting is drawing close. Fast-growing seedlings like tomatoes and marigolds can become tall and lanky if sown too early. But plants like pansies and perennials and slow growers like celosia, impatiens, coleus, geraniums and vincas should be sown right away if they are to be large enough to plant at the correct time.

title: The Pentagon's Handout to Japan
description: President Bush's first formal foreign trip, marking the importance of relations with Japan, will be to attend Emperor Hirohito's funeral later this month. But Mr. Bush is starting off on the wrong foot, having inherited an impending deal on fighter aircraft production that is decidedly unfair to the United States.

title: THE BRADY BUNCH GOES TO MOSCOW
description: BACK IN THE U.S.S.R. An American Family Returns to Moscow. By Jerrold Schecter, Leona Schecter, Evelind Schecter, Michael Shafer, Sudakkha Steve Schecter, Suprabha Schecter, Kate Schecter, Ari Roth, Doveen Schecter and Barnet Schecter. Illustrated. 468 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $24.95.

title: Singing Hospital Blues: Staffs Are Given a Show
description: On a makeshift stage in a hospital auditorium, an actress in nurse's smock and cap complains of being demoralized and fatigued by her struggle to care for the seemingly endless stream of people arriving in the emergency room.

title: Claudia Rattazzi Plans To Marry Ron Papka
description: Dr. and Mrs. Mario C. Rattazzi of Port Washington, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Claudia G. Rattazzi, to Ron Papka, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Papka of South Paterson, N.J. A June wedding is planned. Ms. Rattazzi, a writer and freelance editor, graduated magna cum laude from Columbia College, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. Her father, a professor of pediatrics at Cornell University Medical College, is the physician in charge of the human biochemical genetics laboratory at the North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. Her mother, Serena Bardelli Rattazzi, is the associate director of the Brooklyn Museum.

title: AH, THOSE DAYS OF VINYL AND ROSES
description: Nothing ever said in this column drew more dismayed reaction than an opinion expressed on Jan. 8, when it was suggested that inherent drawbacks of the LP hastened its decline in the face of competition from compact disks.

title: Borrowing Costs Have Risen Again
description: The prime rate increased last week by a half a percentage point, to 11 percent. The move by banks to raise their base lending rate, which influences borrowing costs to consumers and small and medium-size businesses, was no surprise. Over the last few weeks, the Federal Reserve Board has increased the Federal funds rate on overnight loans. That rate, which now stands at 9 1/8 percent, influences the borrowing costs of banks.

title: Louise C. Bond To Wed in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Calhoun Bond of Lutherville, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter Louise Cover Bond to Robert William Heck, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Heck of Venice, Fla. A May wedding is planned. Miss Bond, a social worker at the Catholic Home Bureau in New York, graduated from Trinity College in Hartford and received a master's degree in social work from Hunter College. Her father is a partner in the Baltimore law firm of Cable, McDaniel, Bowie & Bond. She is a granddaughter of Mrs. James Piper Jr. and the late Mr. Piper and of the late Mr. and Mrs. Henry M. Bond, all of Baltimore.

title: Changing Garden Loses Customer
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Black Eagle Recalls His War
description: LEAD: IN the 43 years since he was mustered out of the Air Force, Jean Esquerre has compiled an impressive resume: from engineering supervisor of rocket engine systems on the lunar-module program at the Grumman Corporation, where, as the first black elected to its board, he became the first black corporate director of a major aerospace company, to leadership in civil rights efforts and community organizations on Long

title: There Are Divisions, Iranian Concedes
description: Iran's President today publicly recognized the existence of divisions among Iranian leaders, but asserted that the nation remains committed to the ''revolutionary ideas'' that marked the birth of the Islamic revolution 10 years ago.

title: Cynthia Rodgers To Marry in May
description: Dr. and Mrs. John Barclay Rodgers of Delmar, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Cynthia Joanne Rodgers to Dr. Barry Miles Belgorod, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Howard H. Belgorod of New York. A May wedding is planned.

title: Thrill of Seeing The Babe Point
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: TALKING: Tranquility; When Neighbors Are Noisy
description: SOMETIMES the irritating noise is made by young children dragging toys across a hardwood floor, sometimes by a teen-age drummer determined to become the next Ringo Starr. Then there are the mavericks who run the washing machine at midnight and people who unwind by slamming doors.

title: 2,628 Entries for Westminster
description: In the political arena, in 1877, Rutherford B. Hayes was serving his first year as President. In the racing world, the Kentucky Derby had its third running, with Baden Baden winning a $3,300 purse. In canine circles, the Westminster Kennel Club held its first show.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I have a stall shower that has tiled walls up to the painted ceiling. Every two or three years this paint peels and flakes and we have to repaint. Is there a special paint I can use?

title: Cable Cars
description: To the Editor:

title: A Collection of Semipostals Can Be Challenging
description: ''YOUTH will be served,'' the English proverb has it, and since 1912 Switzerland has been serving youth through the issuance of stamps to raise money for children's causes.

title: Putting Artwork In State Prisons
description: ON the same day that the Governor of Massachusetts announced several austerity steps to help close a state deficit, the Massachusetts Division of Capital Planning and Operations reported that it had earmarked $1.1 million over the next seven years to beautify state prisons with art.

title: A Dinner for Two, Especially for Valentine's Day
description: ON Valentine's Day, it's dinner for two. Lavishing care and attention on such a mini-feast can be extremely rewarding, perhaps in more ways than one.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Essex, Vt.; For Starters, A Condo Hotel
description: A 97-ROOM condominium hotel is rising in this rapidly growing suburb of Burlington, Vermont's largest city, as part of the first phase of the ongoing Lang Farm development.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Oyster Bay Burger Battle JOE DELLAMONICA is thinking of taking his hamburger fight to the President of the United States. ''Maybe I should see Bush,'' he said. ''After all, we're talking discrimination here.''

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Manteo, N.C.;
Barrier Island Plan Opposed
description: LEAD: FRIENDS of Roanoke Island, one of several conservation groups formed in the last two years, is trying to stop development of a luxury residential subdivision on Roanoke Island, N.C., where America's first settlement was established in 1585 - only to vanish within a few years.

title: Quotation of the Day
