description: ''I will obey Christ and serve in His name.'' - Bishop Barbara C. Harris. [ 26:1. ]

title: The Pace of Automation Increases
description: WHENEVER camera journalists get together, there's always one wag in the group who remarks, ''Well, the next thing you know, they'll make a camera that automatically composes the picture for you.'' I used to think this was a joke. Welcome, friends, to the brave new world of the ''automatic programmed zoom composing system.'' It comes to us, courtesy of Chinon, in the form of the Auto 5001 Handyzoom (hereafter to be referred to as the Handyzoom).

title:
DINING OUT;
Korean Cuisine Arrives in Yonkers
description: LEAD: AT last, a restaurant offering Korean food has crossed county lines. But Aria is a find already found. With little advertising and no telphone listing as yet, the place attracts an enthusiastic, mostly Asian clientele that packs the place by 6:30 and doesn't let up until closing time. It's like dining out in

title: Communism Knew Diversity Before Gorbachev
description: To the Editor:

title: Meeting His Terms
description: Dwight Gooden, owner of the best pitching record in major league baseball, says that being with the New York Mets is ''like a family thing.'' Last week, he got his allowance raised. The 24-year-old Gooden agreed to a three-year, $6.7 million contract that will make him the highest paid Mets player in history and, at least briefly, the highest paid player in baseball. Orel Hershiser, whose pitching helped the Los Angeles Dodgers become world champions last year, may settle for more money in his contract talks this week, as may Roger Clemens of the Boston Red Sox. Gooden, who took a pay cut to $1.4 million last year, was obviously pleased with his deal. ''It relaxes me,'' he said.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: A STEP INTO THE PAST The most distinguished document in the ''Liberties and Legends'' exhibition on the 350-year history of the state is the original Fundamental Orders of 1639.

title: Adultery Penalty May Change
description: The State House of Representatives has passed a bill repealing a 200-year-old law that makes adultery a crime punishable by a year in jail. The measure, passed 201 to 149 on Thursday, goes to the Senate, where a similar bill was defeated two years ago. Supporters of repeal said the law was unenforceable, while their opponents said repeal would lead to a perception that New Hampshire tolerates adultery.

title: Closing In On 20 Feet
description: In what has come to resemble an intramural display of Soviet air power, Sergei Bubka regained the world indoor pole-vault record yesterday from Rodion Gataullin.

title: Correction
description: A report last Sunday about the engagement of Leslie Sue Gaberman to John Brooks Harkavy misidentified the prospective bridegroom's undergraduate university. It was Brown.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales
description: Branford, Conn. $119,000 151 Monticello Drive 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, town-house condominium; 10 years old, end unit, fully finished family room on lower level; monthly common charges $117, taxes $1,102. Madison, Conn. $185,000 84 Woodsvale Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 20-year-old ranch; wooded lot, large screened porch, swimming pool, 1 acre; taxes $1,610. Trumbull, Conn. $208,000 260 Fersdale Avenue 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 30-year-old contemporary; new open kitchen, passive solar family room, 0.25 acre; taxes $1,825. Chappaqua, N.Y. $502,500 20 Glen Terrace 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 17-year-old colonial; 2 fireplaces, large deck, new kitchen, 2-car garage, 1 acre; taxes $6,805. Larchmont, N.Y. $415,000 46 Maple Hill Drive 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 47-year-old colonial; fireplace, screened porch; taxes $6,667. Scarsdale, N.Y. $480,000 6 Leone Close 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 32-year-old split-level; fireplace, cathedral ceiling in living room, 2-car garage; taxes $9,115. OTHER AREAS Locust Valley, L.I. $285,000 33 George Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 22-year-old colonial; den, fireplace, screened patio, finished basement; taxes $3,100. Massapequa, L.I. $235,000 18 West End Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old split level; dining room, eat-in kitchen, basement, 2-car garage; taxes $4,000. Morris Township, N.J. $235,000 6 Upperfield Road 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 25-year-old split level; c/a, family room, den; taxes $2,911.

title: Air Pressure
description: To the Editor:

title: At Heartbreak Hotel,Saxophones and Stolen Dreams
description: In the swirling fog at the corner of Neon and Lonely Streets, by the bar of the Heartbreak Hotel, a ghostly figure in a trenchcoat and slouch hat steps out under a blue streetlight. Launching into a smoky jazz-flavored ballad, James Taxi, a pint-size private eye, huskily drawls out an ode to rain-soaked streets at 2 in the morning, whisky and shining saxophones.

title: Hand-Spun Wools in Vermont
description: IN hollows all over Vermont members of a new generation of wool growers, heirs to the state's 19th-century wool industry, are offering hand-spun and machine-spun yarn from their own flocks. Spinners can buy an unprocessed soft mound of wool freshly sheared from the sheep.

title: Ms. Mestel Plans Winter Wedding
description: Laura Midge Mestel and Frederic Ellis Rubin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Burton Rubin of Woodmere, L.I., plan to marry in December, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Mestel of Bayside, Queens, have announced.

title: Ellen Massoth, Executive, Is Wed to Victor M. Husty
description: The Unitarian Church of All Souls was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Ellen Massoth and Victor M. Husty. The Rev. Deborah Raible performed the ceremony.

title:
A GUIDE TO RIVER AND FREIGHTER CRUISES;
Sailing at a Slower Pace
description: LEAD: AS an alternative to regular cruises, hotel barges, river boats and freighters offer vacations that provide a different perspective, combining the historical with the scenic. As Thomas Jefferson wrote of the Canal du Midi in France in 1787, ''Of all the methods of traveling I have ever tried, this is the pleasantest .

title: Italy's Strikes Are Irritating Even Unions
description: The Iraqi Airways flight was supposed to be nonstop from Baghdad to Rome. But the plane was barely airborne one day several months ago when a sudden strike by air controllers at the Fiumicino airport outside Rome forced a detour to Cyprus.

title: CUSTOMIZED ART IS DISTINCTIVE BUT IS RARELY MOVED OR SOLD
description: Because of the influence of professional art advisers, corporate art collections today include more than the traditional paintings and drawings. Large-scale works custom-designed for particular sites - and therefore almost always commissioned - have become widespread.

title: Not-So-Wild Turkeys Disturb Massachusetts Communities
description: Wild turkeys have been making nuisances of themselves in suburban communities near Plymouth Rock, perching on cars and taking over bird feeders, state wildlife officials say.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I have a stall shower that has tiled walls up to the painted ceiling. Every two or three years this paint peels and flakes and we have to repaint. Is there a special paint I can use?

title: At a Moscow Voters' Meeting, Ascendancy of Ivana Q. Public
description: Anna Saminskaya arrived Thursday afternoon at the voters' meeting in the Moscow House of Scholars, a wishful skeptic on the subject of Soviet politics.

title: Did O'Malley Laugh Last?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Rescuing A Turtle, Reviving Nature's Balance
description: AS I followed the Alley Pond Park nature trail that February morning, evidence of the last snowstorm was practically gone, save for traces under the thicker underbrush. The ice of the stream melted into a still pond of brownish water topped with a few floating leaves.

title: Capital Gains Tax Rise Hurt Middle Class Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Leon Festinger, 69, New School Professor
description: Leon Festinger, a leading professor of psychology who developed the theory of cognitive dissonance, died of liver cancer yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 69 years old.

title: Wraparound Nighttime Glamour
description: CHRISTMAS may be long gone, but there are still fancy wrappings around town. Most are long and sumptuous, covering up evening dresses in a turn-of-the-century manner. As we approach the year 2000, perhaps that's entirely appropriate.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''We will see that the guarantee to depositors is forever honored. We will see to it that the system is reformed comprehensively so that this situation is not repeated ever again.'' President Bush, after announcing a plan to rescue the savings and loan industry.

title: Karen Brandt and Kenan Onel, Students, to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Hubert J. Brandt of Lido Beach, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Karen Rose Brandt to Kenan Onel, a son of Miriam Onel of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Dr. Joseph Onel. An April wedding is planned.

title: Cutting Old Bronxville Tree Opposed
description: LEAD: EMOTIONS are running high in Bronxville over a proposal to remove a giant white oak tree on Willow Road.

title: WHERE SHOULD BABY SLEEP?
description: Excuse me, but the last time I checked, I was living in New Jersey and there wasn't a !Kung village in sight (Body and Mind: ''Where Should Baby Sleep?'' by Melvin Konner, Jan. 8). Dr. Konner's article indulges in a cross-cultural romanticism that I, as a parent, am tired of. Sleep with your children until they leave home, if that's what pleases you. Let's just keep anthropology out of the nursery. NOLA HEALY LYNCH Roselle, N.J.

title: JUDGE DISMISSES RACKETEERING CASE OVER LILCO RATES
description: A Federal judge yesterday dismissed a racketeering case against the Long Island Lighting Company, ruling that the question of whether Lilco had lied to obtain rate increases belonged before state utility regulators and should never have been tried under Federal law.

title: WHERE SHOULD BABY SLEEP?
description: Parents who sleep with their babies are likely to spend more time touching them, and there is much scientific support for the benefits of touching. Touching has profound effects on growth and development. Studies of the benefits of touching in humans have led to changes in hospital procedures for premature and boarder babies. DANIEL MAHER Wantagh, N.Y.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Can Yanks Use Guidry And John?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: In Northwest, a Woman's Coma Ended After She Gave Birth
description: Barbara Blodgett, one of the few comatose women in medical history to give birth, began a recovery in December that has confounded her doctors.

title: AIDS Impact High Among Minorities
description: BLACK and Hispanic people and women make up a disproportionate number of AIDS patients on Long Island, mirroring recent national statistics.

title: 70 Years' Service to the Red Cross
description: LEAD: WESTON and Westport residents have become familiar with the voice of Kathryn Teaze. Each time the local chapter of the American Red Cross schedules a blood bank, she calls the regular blood donors and, in a gentle, coaxing voice, urges them to attend. Mrs. Teaze, who turned 91 last month, was recently honored for 70 years of service to the American Red

title: Shirley Decides She's Had Enough
description: ''Sentimental? What do you mean sentimental?'' Willy Russell grabs the text of his play ''Shirley Valentine.'' He reads a passage in which Shirley, a working-class Liverpool housewife, is declaring that men cannot talk to women:

title: A Tale of Two Theaters
description: To the Editor:

title: Drawing with a Global Point of View
description: LEAD: RANAN LURIE'S first political cartoon appeared in an Israeli newspaper when he was 16 years old. Today, at 56, his work appears in 500 newspapers in 61 countries, including China, where he is the first foreigner to be a syndicated political cartoonist.

title:
FILM;
'True Believer' Makes a Case For Idealism
description: LEAD: ''I liked expressing the idea that there are second acts in American life,'' says 34-year-old Wesley Strick, who began his professional career as a music critic for Rolling Stone and has now written the script of ''True Believer,'' which opens on Friday.

title: Tropical Carnival With Menu to Match
description: DURING the dreariest days of winter, it seems as though half of Long Island is making a beeline for sunny climes. The other half might find some small compensation at Hempstead's Caribbean Cafe.

title: Prague, in Quelling Dissent, Ousts Editor of Party Paper
description: The Government in Prague has moved to quash dissent within its ranks, dismissing the editor of the Communist Party's cultural weekly.

title: Ortley Beach Journal; Secession Drive Brings Criticism
description: RESIDENTS of this mile-square section of Dover Township in Ocean County are closing in on their five-year goal of turning the little oceanfront community into New Jersey's 568th independent municipality.

title: New Major in College is Weatherz
description: THE 15 students who signed up for an unadvertised and unofficial meteorology major at Western Connecticut State University last September are apparently already adept at determining which way the wind is blowing.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: FADE. By Robert Cormier. (Delacorte, $15.95.) Since writing several well-regarded novels for adults in the 1960's, Robert Cormier has published highly praised novels for adolescents, including ''The Chocolate War.'' Now he has returned to writing for adults - or at least that's how this new book is being marketed.

title: Far From the Promised Land
description: To the Editor:

title: BAKER ASSERTS U.S. WON'T BREAK OFF ITS P.L.O. DIALOGUE
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that the United States had decided not to break off its dialogue with the Palestine Liberation Organization now, despite an appeal from Israel. The Israeli appeal followed a clash between P.L.O. guerrillas and Israeli troops last weekend in southern Lebanon.

title: Landmarks Unit Studies Scribner Store's Interior
description: Books may never be sold there again, but the inside of the Scribner Book Store on Fifth Avenue is likely to become an official New York City landmark, which would be welcomed by its owners.

title: Executives Fight Loneliness at Top
description: LEAD: ANTHONY FLOREZ knows the operational end of his business inside out. He has shared the top spot at Abco Peerless Sprinkler Corporation, Garden City Park, for 30 years, since he bought into the company, which installs automatic fire sprinklers.

title: Golden Gates
description: French-Japanese, California-Italian, Mediterranean-American, Southwestern-French - defining cuisine today isn't easy. In restaurants in the United States, ingredients, cooking techniques and presentation styles overlap and blur. A torte of black beans is as likely to appear on the menu at a French restaurant as creme de cresson. And it becomes hardly surprising to find a ham-and-mozzarella sandwich on red-pepper brioche at a restaurant serving Southwestern fare. Chinese food seems to be the least affected by this creative borrowing and blending.

title: Officials Say Utility Will Still Probably Settle
description: Although the Long Island Lighting Company emerged the clear winner in yesterday's Federal court decision, officials said that the utility is still likely to agree to a proposed settlement whose provisions are the same as those it was considering when it faced the possibility of multibillion-dollar damages in the case.

title: When the Train Takes a Back Seat To a Car - Zounds!
description: LAST January, after years of happy commuting on Metro-North, I traded my timetable and train buddies for a job in Westchester that required that I drive.

title: The All-Stars Predict Entertainment Aplenty
description: Someone asked Charles Barkley if the National Basketball Association All-Star Game Sunday would be entertaining even though Magic Johnson and Larry Bird would not be playing, because of injuries. When Barkley heard the question, his face twisted into a menacing grimace, the type of look he usually saves for referees after they whistle a foul on him.

title: Shareholders
description: To the Editor:

title: Walking Tall Into Manhattan
description: ENCOURAGED, perhaps, by the New Jerseyans who commute to Manhattan, three of the state's museums are visiting there. To be precise, the Montclair Art Museum, the Newark Museum and the State Museum in Trenton, have sent samplings of their permanent collections to the International Business Machines Corporation's Gallery of Science and Art, 590 Madison Avenue, at 56th Street.

title: 'GEE, THIS IS MAGNIFICENT'
description: LEAD: HOOVER DAM An American Adventure. By Joseph E. Stevens. Illustrated. 326 pp. Norman: University of Oklahoma Press. $24.95.

title:
FARE OF THE COUNTRY;
A Northern Italian Feast In a Chafing Dish
description: LEAD: THE cooking of Piedmont, a region in northwest Italy, is rich and varied. And its people are just as proud of their superb veal, mountain cheeses and flavorful vegetables as they are of wines like Barberesco and Barolo. Piemontese relish the supple, hand-cut noodles called tajerin, beef braised in old Barolo, and fonduta, melted fontina cheese thickened with egg yolks.

title: Trenary Captures Singles
description: Kristi Yamaguchi, the 82-pound teen-ager who won the national pairs championship Friday night with Rudi Galindo, skated a dazzling freestyle program today to become the first American woman in 35 years to qualify for the world figure-skating championships in two events.

title: Towns and Garbage Haulers at Odds Over Fingerprinting
description: LEAD: IT will not make national headlines, the way Islip's garbage barge did two years ago, but garbage is at the center of another disagreement on Long Island.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
The Rules of Romance, 1950's Style
description: LEAD: WOMEN remember their first love the way they remember giving birth. We only think of the good parts or we'd never do it again.

title: McEnroe's Advice
description: He's heard his share of lectures on how tennis players should conduct themselves, so it should come as no surprise that John McEnroe, the one-time enfant terrible of the sport, takes some of his younger competitors to task from time to time, especially after he's lost a match.

title: DATA BANK: February 12, 1989
For Embassy in Managua, Isolation
description: At night, the American Embassy here is one of the city's most spectacular sights. Bathed in brilliant spotlights, surrounded by double fences of curved steel spikes and coiled razor wire, it stands out in gleaming relief against the dark background of the city.

title: POSTINGS: 660,000 Sq. Ft. in the 'Village'; Union Quarters
description: New York area carpenters' unions have purchased a former Western Electric building on the western fringe of Greenwich Village for use as a headquarters for their district council and as a center for their pension and benefits office. The 10-story building at 395 Hudson Street, the blockfront between West Houston and Clarkson Streets, was erected in 1921 and had been used as a repair center for telephones and other communications equipment and as a storage facility.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: WHEN CHILDREN WANT CHILDREN: The Urban Crisis in Teenage Childbearing. By Leon Dash. (Morrow, $18.95.) Leon Dash, a reporter for The Washington Post, confesses early on that he is ''a reporter who needs an editor.'' Readers of ''When Children Want Children'' will wish that his publisher had assigned him an effective one.

title: Who Can Be Made to Pay For Another's Violence?
description: IN recent years, some courts have ruled that psychotherapists and other professionals may be legally responsible for crimes committed by people in their care. Now a lawsuit is testing whether the parents of an emotionally unstable adult can be held to a similar standard.

title: A Call for Persistence
description: With Workfare I read with interest the article ''Few Show Up for Workfare Jobs'' [ Jan. 29 ] . I'm not surprised. Since the beginning of December I've been visiting the Elmsford Motor Lodge almost daily - trying to get people off welfare. And, the results have also been discouraging.

title: U.S. EXPECTS DELAY ON CHEMICAL BAN
description: A senior Administration official has told Congress that the United States and its negotiating partners are years away from devising satisfactory monitoring arrangements for a treaty banning the development and possession of chemical weapons.

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.
description: IT'S difficult to believe, but there are people who don't talk to themselves. They think the things that many others say aloud, they form sentences and phrases in their minds, and occasionally they go so far as to move their lips - but no sound emerges. In fact, these people are apt to consider those who do talk to themselves a rather strange lot, next door to street mutterers and just a few degrees away from the men and women who carry on loud and rambling conversations with phantoms on buses and subways.

title: Maria Edgeworth's Names
description: To the Editor:

title: Darman Balances Hard Decisions and Hard Numbers
description: As the final touches were being put on the budget proposals President Bush delivered to Congress Thursday night, a disagreement developed between Jack F. Kemp, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, and Nicholas F. Brady, the Treasury Secretary.

title: Hunting for Bargains in Insurance
description: Most consumers think nothing of conducting an exhaustive time-consuming search for the best deal on such items as a compact disk player or an air conditioner. But insurance? That's a different matter. ''Insurance is about negative, troubling ideas, like your house burning down, your car being stolen or someone dying; no one wants to face it,'' said Kevin Foley, Deputy Superintendent of the New York State Insurance Department. ''People just grab the first thing they hear about.''

title: Unchecked Thumbs On Nuclear Buttons
description: The United States and its NATO allies continue to espouse a policy of first use of nuclear weapons. We believe the President, Congress and the American public should reject this policy, including the early use of nuclear weapons in a crisis. It is not credible to our enemies and it increases the risk of nuclear war. And decisions about new weapons and new treaties should rest on the assumption that nuclear weapons would only be used as a last resort in response to a nuclear attack.

title: From Indonesia, Images and Tales Woven in Cloth
description: ''These are fossils of the past,'' said Anita Spertus, describing the collection of Indonesian textiles that she and her husband, Jeff Holmgren, have acquired over the last 16 years. An exhibit from their holdings opens at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Tuesday and runs through May 14.

title: 'We're All Supposed to be Pencil-Thin'
description: CYNTHIA H. ADAMS has been teaching health courses at the University of Connecticut in Storrs for 16 years and has counseled hundreds of students with eating disorders like anorexia nervosa and bulimia.

title: Question Of the Week; Will Free Agency Work In Football?
description: Although on the surface it would appear that more than a third - about 600 - of N.F.L. players will be free to negotiate with any team between Feb. 2 and April 1 in attempts to better their respective situations, the jury will be out for quite some time before the verdict is in as to how well free agency is working. For the overriding question will be: Will N.F.L. owners sign free agents or simply ''Go fishing?'' NICHOLAS D. DeCURTIS New York

title: Case of the Intentional Belch Goes Before Supreme Court
description: The State Supreme Court is being asked to decide when a belch is intentional and willful, especially when it skews the results of a blood-alcohol test being given to a driver suspected of being drunk.

title: Computer Program for Deaf Children
description: LEAD: A NEW computer program to help deaf children improve their reading and writing is now available. It allows students who know American Sign Language to use their sign-language competence to learn written grammar and vocabulary.

title: Woman Is Consecrated as Episcopal Bishop
description: In a deeply moving three-hour ceremony here marked by loud and joyous acclamation and strong protest as well, the Rev. Barbara Clementine Harris, a 55-year-old priest, today became the first woman consecrated as a bishop in the Episcopal Church.

title: Princeton Clubs Pressed by End of Traditions
description: Outside Princeton University's two all-male eating clubs last week, protesters greeted sophomores arriving to participate in ''bicker,'' the equivalent of fraternity rush. ''Women as Members, Not Just Dates,'' the protesters' signs read.

title: Towns Are Adding Required Recycling
description: WHEN she heard her town was setting up mandatory recycling, Carlene E. Kulisch, the head of the Branford Condominium Association, thought it would be difficult to separate her trash. After a few weeks of putting aside cans, bottles and newspapers, Ms. Kulisch said that although the task was not so difficult, the recycling program will not be universally liked when it is fully instituted next month.

title: TRANSCENDENTAL RHYTHM
description: EMERSON AND THE ART OF THE DIARY By Lawrence Rosenwald. 159 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $24.95.

title:
GARDENING;
Time for Seeding Is Drawing Near
description: LEAD: THE myth of the groundhog notwithstanding, it is a good bet that wintry weather will remain at least another four to six weeks. Yet the time to prepare for spring planting is drawing close. Fast-growing seedlings like tomatoes and marigolds can become tall and lanky if sown too early. But plants like pansies and perennials and slow growers like celosia, impatiens, coleus, geraniums and vincas should be sown right away if they are to be large enough to plant at the correct time.

title: NORTH ISSUE GOES TO SUPREME COURT
description: The Bush Administration, turned down in two lower Federal courts in its efforts to delay the trial of Oliver L. North, today asked the Supreme Court to stay the case to avoid risk of ''irreparable injury'' to the nation from uncensored testimony and argument about intelligence matters.

title: A Tax 'Fix'
description: To the Editor:

title: Garbage Is One Thing, but Garbage From New York? Forget It
description: For one brief shining moment, officials of a small central Arkansas city thought they were sitting on a gold mine of potential garbage pits.

title: A Greece of Forests And Mountain Lakes
description: FOR years, my vision of Greece consisted exclusively of naked, sun-scorched rock and pristine sugar-cube villages rising out of an expanse of blue sea. Then, gradually, I became drawn to another, more subtle Greece, not Mediterranean but Balkan; an autumnal land of fir forests, stately poplars and dark green mountains grooved with snow, evoking the background of an old master's painting rather than the usual watercolor sketch of sea and stone.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: SEARCHING FOR THE EMPEROR. By Roberto Pazzi. Translated by M. J. Fitzgerald. (Knopf, $17.95.) In ''Searching for the Emperor,'' the Italian poet and literary critic Roberto Pazzi avoids the more familiar aspects of the fall of the Romanov dynasty and focuses instead on the lonely and forlorn last days of Czar Nicholas II and his family, under house arrest in Siberia.

title: Seton Hall Tops Villanova, 83-77
description: John Morton scored 23 points tonight to lead 11th-ranked Seton Hall past Villanova, 83-77, for the Pirates' first victory on the Wildcats' home court in 15 years.

title: Among Mayors, a Tide Of Drugs Brings Forth Desperation and Ideas
description: ''ALL we do is meet about the drug problem,'' said Police Chief Maurice T. Turner Jr. of the District of Columbia. ''It's driving the resources of the metropolitan police department.''

title: THE TROULBE WITH THOSE PEOPLE
description: THE CLOSED CIRCLE An Interpretation of the Arabs. By David Pryce-Jones. 464 pp. New York: An Edward Burlingame Book/ Harper & Row. $25.

title: Lilco Trial: RICO Law Troubles Experts
description: LEAD: WHEN a Federal jury found in December that the Long Island Lighting Company had violated a Federal racketeering statute known as RICO, the issue of the Shoreham nuclear-power plant was cast into a controversial area of Federal law.

title: Conspiracy Inquiry Results in 8 Convictions
description: LEAD: IN September 1984, following a two-year investigation of the garbage-carting industry on Long Island by New York State's Organized Crime Task Force, indictments handed up by a Suffolk County grand jury accused 16 corporations and 21 individuals with conspiring to control the industry in Nassau and Suffolk

title: Tearful Recall Of Carl Furillo
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Emmary Armstrong Allen To Wed Lawrence Carlson
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John A. Allen of Westport, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter Emmary Armstrong Allen to Lawrence Bruce Carlson, a son of Mrs. Bruce Carlson of Wilton, Conn., and the late Mr. Carlson. An April wedding is planned.

title: Getting Away With Murder
description: LEAD: The verdict in the Lisa Steinberg case brings to mind two similar cases of recent memory: the deaths by violence of Jennifer Levin and Bonnie Garland.

title: Concern Over Race Seen in Westchester Study
description: Well over half the people surveyed at a public meeting last month in White Plains said race relations in Westchester County were getting worse. And almost half of those questioned believe there is a great deal of racial prejudice in the county.

title: STREETSCAPES: O'Reilly Brothers Warehouse; A Marvel of Fancy Brickwork Awaits the Dawn of a New Day
description: THE O'Reilly Brothers Warehouse is something of a one-note building, but the note is exquisite. Now vacant and boarded up, the nine-story structure at the northeast corner of 123d Street and St. Nicholas Avenue is fairly plain, without ornament, but it presents a rich interplay of orange brick and brownstone.

title: Touring Turkey
description: To the Editor: Articles on Turkey, clipped over the last four years, took slight space in my baggage and added to the scope and economy of my Elderhostel tour of Turkey this fall.

title: Susan F. Peck, a Paralegal, To Wed Mark Lauderdale
description: Susan Foster Peck and Chief Petty Officer Jon Mark Lauderdale, U.S.N., a son of JoAnn Lauderdale-Tong of Ardmore, Okla., and the late William Lauderdale, plan to marry in April. Their engagement was made known by the future bride's parents, Louise I. Peck of Locust Valley, L.I., and Andrew F. Peck of New York.

title: HAUNTED BY HER SINFULNESS
description: INTIMACY By Susan Chace. 161 pp. New York: Random House. $14.95.

title: Italian Etchers Sing a Siren Song In Boston
description: We tend to describe the course of art history during the 16th and 17th centuries in Europe almost exclusively through paintings, sculpture and architecture, but it was hardly less through the humbler medium of the print that art was experienced at the time. When King Francis I commissioned an elaborate decorative program for the palace at Fontainebleau from the Bolognese painter Francesco Primaticcio, it was the influence of Parmigianino that could everywhere be felt in the result. Parmigianino completed few paintings but his version of the Mannerist style had already become familiar in France through the proliferation of his etchings and through prints by other artists based on his canvases. Something along the lines of what could be seen in those works on paper was what the King expected from Primaticcio.

title: Identity Crisis?
description: To the Editor:

title: Shrinking Movies For Television
description: To the Editor:

title: Why the Garbage Is Never Really Gone
description: ACROSS much of the United States, trash is still disposed of in the old-fashioned way, with bulldozers and open landfills. But the metropolitan areas of the Northeast were forced by geography to move farther and faster toward large-scale incineration and, more recently, recycling.

title: Keeping Busy Indoors With Chores
description: INDOORS start seed of impatiens, begonias, snapdragons, petunias and any wild flowers; be sure the pots are clean and the seed starting medium sterile to avoid any fungus diseases. This month is ideal to contract with professional arborists to have overgrown shade trees pruned, trimmed or thinned. Clip branches of forsythia to force into bloom indoors. Cut twigs from witch hazel and enjoy the fragrance indoors. Look Around

title: Good Ethics Is Good Business - Really
description: As scandals mount in the financial and commodities markets, economists theorize that the market determines one's ethicality. If ''everybody'' cheats, those who don't will be wiped out. Like much economic writing, this conclusion is not based on factual observations of ethical traders who went bankrupt, but on abstract theories about ''perfect competition.''

title: Highest-Paid Player? It's Your Pick
description: The answer could be (a) Dwight Gooden, (b) Gary Gaetti, (c) Eddie Murray, (d) Gary Carter or (e) Dan Quisenberry. The question: Just who is the highest-paid player in baseball?

title: Tanglewood Announces 1989 Season
description: The 1989 Tanglewood Music Festival in Lenox, Mass., is scheduled to open on June 30 with a concert by the Boston Symphony Chamber Players at the festival's theater. The first concert by the full Boston Symphony will follow on July 7 in the shed.

title: Right to Life is Freedom to Choose
description: I BELIEVE in life. I believe in choice. I am pro-life and pro-choice. I see no contradictions in combining the two. The only problem I see is with the people who use those words, but who do not understand the underlying reality and concept behind them.

title: The 'Lower Half': Not So Many Cheers
description: Charles Schnabolk's ''Cheers for the Lower Half'' (Opinion Page, Jan. 8) should be criticized not so much for the points it makes, but for the way it goes about making them.

title: The Worm and the Apple; Down by the Station: Hail Amtrak
description: A grandmother who hadn't visited New York for a year arrived during the bustling holiday season via the Metroliner from Wilmington. She emerged from Penn Station prepared, as usual, to engage in dubious battle for a taxicab on Seventh Avenue (she'd long ago learned to avoid Eighth).

title:
ART;
Emotion, Reason and Classicism on Display
description: LEAD: RADICALLY different directions combine in the Bryant Library's current exhibition devoted to three artists who are Long Island residents: the painters David Fludd and Reginald Fludd and the sculptor Robert White. This allows some useful comparisons between impulsive, energetic imagery appealing to the emotions, reasoned abstraction appealing to a desire for perceptual discovery, and classic bronze and terra-cotta figurative pieces appealing to the appreciation of order and expressive volume.

title: >NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: NAVY BAND CONCERT The United States Navy Band, one of the world's truly fine musical organizations, will perform at 8 P.M. on Feb. 22 in Lakewood High School. Tickets for the free concert must be ordered by mail.

title: Bush's Bailout Plan
description: On Monday, President Bush announced a plan to bail out the troubled savings and loan industry. To pay for the plan - which is projected to cost taxpayers about $60 billion - the Government will sell bonds and raise premiums for Federal deposit insurance. In addition, the Government would take control of 350 troubled savings associations. Some critics fear that this plan is not comprehensive enough. Four experts give their views. Ned Eichler Chairman, Ned Eichler Associates, and research associate at the University of California at Berkeley.

title: Review/Theater; Three Little Ghouls From School
description: When we first meet Jana, Jena and Jinna Gimmel, the identical triplets who reek mischief in Jeffrey Essmann's madcap comedy ''Triplets in Uniform,'' the scene is Prussia and the year 1919. The simpering adolescent trio has just returned for another semester to the forbidding Kaiserina Wilhelmina School for Girls, whose stern headmistress, Frau Fotze, has an inexplicable phobia about mirrors. Moments before the triplets' arrival, Frau Fotze has engaged a mysterious young woman, Frau Nietzsche, to be the school's new penmanship teacher. To Frau Fotze's astonishment, the demure young instructor has informed her that she is a hermaphrodite, and in spite of herself the poor headmistress finds herself inflamed by the confession.

title: FOCUS: Cumberland, Me.; Maine's Coastal Estates Are Now Hot Properties
description: When residents of this affluent suburb of Portland voted in December not to buy the 25-acre estate known as Conifer Ledges, they confirmed what many here have felt for some time: Oceanfront property has become too expensive for public agencies. The estate would have given the community its only waterfront park.

title: Projecting an Image - You Are What You Buy
description: Companies have a new rationale for assembling art these days. Not only are they amassing beautiful objects to decorate their offices and for the sake of investment. They are also using art to make statements. And the developments are not only influencing the art companies are buying, but corporations' roles in the art world.

title:
BODY AND MIND;
Asking - and Telling
description: LEAD: SOME YEARS AGO, A NEW YORK WOMAN was informed by her gynecologist that she had an ovarian tumor and needed immediate surgery. Naturally, she was upset, and, as a former cancer researcher with special knowledge of the subject, began to ask the doctor specific questions. He had a timer on his desk. He set it, and told her she had exactly three minutes to ask questions.

title: Corina Noel Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Walter M. Noel Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter Corina Monica Noel to Andres Piedrahita, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Piedrahita of Bogota, Colombia. The couple plan to marry in May.

title: 'Enlightened Approach' To Land Use
description: Many thanks to the developer Karl Kehde and the Ohly family for their enlightened approach to land use (''Home Plan Saves Land for Refuge,'' Jan. 15). As a native of New Jersey, I watch the bulldozing of farms and woodlands and wildlife habitat with dismay.

title: Sports of The Times; Going to BAT for Baseball's Own
description: He could hit, he could run and he had good hands. One of the first to enjoy baseball's free-agent bonanza more than a decade ago, he signed a five-year contract worth more than $1.5 million. But that big money somehow slipped through the fingers of those good hands. He had a job but in the chill of a hard winter, his wife and two children were shivering. Their furnace had to be replaced. And he didn't have the money to buy a new furnace.

title: Arabesques A la Woody Allen?
description: Picture this and try not to laugh: A soulful ballerina enters onstage from her yellow stucco tract house. In the distance, a curved portion of freeway overhangs a fairground, where her lover guzzles a bottle of Air Wick. Death and romance suffuse the air.

title: Many Donate To Neediest As Memorial
description: A homeless man named Ruben Rodriguez who lived in Hicksville, L.I., was recently killed in a traffic accident. Carla and Joseph Samodulski, also from Hicksville, sent a donation to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund in Mr. Rodriguez's memory with the request that it be used ''to help another homeless person.''

title: 2 Designs Satisfy Lofty Goals
description: LEAD: JERSEY CITY'S zoning regulations for the Colgate Redevelopment Project are not intended to restrict the expressive freedom of the architect, said Richard Bass, the city's Planning Director, but to allow for both good waterfront planning and innovative architectural design.

title: Arafat Sees a 'War Scenario'
description: The Palestinian chairman, Yasir Arafat, has said that the Israeli authorities are in secret contact with the P.L.O. but that the Government was preparing new attacks against the Palestinian leadership and a ''war scenario'' in southern Lebanon.

title: FROM MARTHA'S VINEYARD TO THE KILL FLOOR
description: LEAD: STRAIGHT THROUGH THE NIGHT By Edward Allen. 270 pp. New York: Soho Press. $17.95.

title: POSTINGS: Redcoats? No, Greycoats; Britons on Fifth
description: A British development company has stolen a march on its American competition by capturing a prime corner on Fifth Avenue for the site of a new office tower. The Greycoat Real Estate Corporation of London has bought 546 Fifth Avenue, at 45th Street, and will erect a 22-story building that is being designed by the architectural firm of Emery Roth & Sons.

title: Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: HOUSE

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Northern Litchfield Resisting Developers
description: NORTHERN Litchfield County is fighting to keep development at bay in what a real estate broker who specializes in the Northwest Corner calls ''the last bastion of beautiful land in Connecticut.''

title: Chris Mullin: Grown Up, And an All-Star At Last
description: The moves - the stutter steps, fakes and jukes that leave defenders leaning the wrong way - have become so refined that they often go unnoticed. But Chris Mullin has not gone unnoticed. He has been recognized as an All-Star for the first time in his four-year pro career.

title: New Troyanos Recital Date
description: Tatiana Troyanos will sing songs from Hugo Wolf's ''Spanisches Liederbuch,'' Falla's ''Siete Canciones Populares Espanolas,'' and works by Brahms, Ravel and Mahler in a recital on March 6 at 8 P.M. at Alice Tully Hall. Warren Jones will be her accompanist. Tickets from Miss Troyanos's canceled recital on Dec. 4, will be honored. Additional tickets, at $22, are available at the box office or through Center Charge, 874-6770.

title: Art and Money Converge
description: LEAD: HARRIET KLINE is not your typical artist, and her inspiration does not come from typical sources. For that matter, neither do her art supplies.

title: Having It All, Through Sharing
description: A recent article in the Westchester Weekly section prompted me to put down some thoughts of my own. [ ''Daughter Follows Mother's Footsteps,'' Westchester Opinion, Jan. 29. ] A mother of a 21-year-old girl in college wrote saying how she's preached choice to her daughter for 20 years. The daughter is headed for a promising career in museum work and at the same time has announced her engagement. This mother, who chose the role of housewife over a career, feels her daughter will be doing the same, even though the girl feels she ''can have it all.''

title: SWIMMING WITH THE BIGGEST FISH AROUND
description: SPECIAL RELATIONSHIPS A Foreign Correspondent's Memoirs From Roosevelt to Reagan. By Henry Brandon. Illustrated. 436 pp. New York: Atheneum. $24.95.

title:
ART;
German Expressionists and 1850's Photos
description: LEAD: GERMAN EXPRESSIONISM came in two distinct waves, which are now being compared at the Yale Art Gallery. The splashier, often abstract thought that began in 1960's and still continues, commands the main galleries. On the fourth floor in the print galleries is vintage Expressionism, which was firmly a style by 1911 and continued into the 1920's.

title: Planning Board Member Pursues 'Ideal'
description: LEAD: ''ISN'T this ugly?'' Joyce Copleman said as she drove through a development of newly constructed large houses here.

title: The Worm and the Apple; Down by the Station: The M.T.A.'s Tunnel Vision
description: In its zeal to demolish rundown subway newsstands and stores, New York's Metropolitan Transportation Authority ignores the se-curity, convenience and life that concessions can provide. That earns the M.T.A. a big worm.

title: Mr. Bush's Bacon
description: What are America's most pressing domestic needs? In his new budget, President Bush lays out these answers: (1) to increase productivity; (2) to invest in people; and (3) to end the scourge of drugs. Admirable. Many Americans share these goals. But there's a problem. Though the captain's new chart plots a sensible destination, his boat is too small to get there.

title: Born to Travel
description: To the Editor: I agree with Thomas Swick and Waugh (''Born to Travel,'' Nov. 27) that a poor travel book is better to read than a novel.

title: The Steroid Subculture
description: LEAD: IN the subculture of synthetic supermen and superwomen on Long Island, size and strength are sold under names like Dinabol and Stanozolol.

title: At Purchase, Fears About Budget Cuts
description: LEAD: THE president of the State University of New York at Purchase said he saw a ''sad irony'' in the timing of the state's current budget crisis. It comes, said Dr. Sheldon N. Grebstein, just as his state-supported institution has ironed out longstanding internal problems and needs only one thing - money - to help it realize its full potential.

title: Cemetery Completes a Planned City, at Last
description: After 20 years the nation's first planned community has a final sign of maturity -its own cemetery.

title: Charlotte A. Lowell Wed To Charles T. Munger Jr.
description: Charlotte Amanda Lowell, a daughter of Mrs. Arthur Carter Lowell of Newport Beach, Calif., and the late Colonel Lowell, U.S.M.C., was married yesterday to Charles Thomas Munger Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Munger of Los Angeles. The Rev. John Phillip Ashey performed the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church in Newport Beach.

title: North Trial Issue Goes to Justices
description: The Bush Administration asked the Supreme Court to stay the trial of Oliver L. North or risk ''irreparable injury'' to the national security.

title: Mass Transit Since Moses
description: To the Editor:

title: Environmentalists, Dreaming of River Without Dam, May Contest License
description: Back in 1974 the dam across the Kennebec River here broke in a heavy rainstorm, and a section of the river suddenly looked as it did before the dam was built in 1836.

title: Norwegian Surprises, From Opera to Symphony
description: The composer Christian Sinding (1856-1941) is remembered for one of music's great chestnuts, ''Rustle of Spring,'' which brought his name into many a genteel parlor in Europe and the Americas. His symphonies, sonatas and concertos are overshadowed today, even in his native Norway, by those of his greater compatriots, Svendsen and Grieg. The last thing one would have expected from Sinding is a first-rate opera, yet such is ''Der Heilige Berg'' (Norwegian Music Productions CDN 31002; two compact disks).

title: A Senior Becomes a Freshman, And There's a World of Difference
description: MY daughter was for sale last year. Did I love her? Yes! Did I like her? No! I didn't know exactly where to place the ad, but ''Help Wanted'' was the area that I deemed to be most appropriate.

title: Linda Buchin Plans to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Stanley I. Buchin of Boston have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda Chase Buchin, to Michael Hobart Sullivan, a son of Dr. Hobart B. Sullivan Jr. of Philadelphia and Maria G. Sullivan of Berwyn, Pa. An August wedding is planned.

title: Affordable Housing: A Necessity Both for People And for Business
description: THE growing shortage of affordable housing in New Jersey is now a serious concern for tens of thousands of young working people unable to buy a home, for thousands more who cannot afford skyrocketing rents and, of course, for the 25,000 of our citizens who are homeless.

title: FICTION
description: ON OUR OWN BEHALF: Women's Tales From Catalonia. Edited by Kathleen McNerney. (University of Nebraska, $24.95). It's probably no great surprise that even a collection of work as specialized as one devoted to contemporary feminist women writers of Catalonia could bring together such characters as a vagabond, a lapsed lesbian and a woman who says her rosary during sex. But a gang-rape victim who quits her job and devotes her energies to tracking, trapping and emasculating her assailants? A widow who rebels against her lowered social status by crowding her house with clocks, old calendars and house plants? Such is the breadth and bounty of this anthology of short stories and novel excerpts from five Catalan writers, as rendered into English by a number of attentive translators. Kathleen McNerney, an associate professor of Spanish at West Virginia University, complements this introduction to the work of Carme Riera, Helena Valenti, Maria-Antonia Oliver, Isabel-Clara Simo and Montserrat Roig with an informative introduction and brief descriptions of each author's interests and style. As in all good stories, the characters in ''On Our Own Behalf'' could as easily live in Michigan or Illinois as modern Spain. But here in the United States, it is common to find literary celebrations of friendship between women - while in even the most recent of these pieces, which dates from the mid-1980's, women are mostly isolated from other women. They envy men their friendships with other men and look to them for love. What they mostly get is trouble.

title: A Civics Lesson for Congress
description: FROM the beginning, the strategy to put through a 51 percent raise for members of Congress, Federal judges and senior officials was based on the presumption that there was no way to convince the public that this was a good idea and therefore no way to win a vote for it in Congress.

title: TARGET: KABUL
description: ROCKET LAUNCHERS ARE STACKED IN A CORNER of the cramped windowless room and Kalashnikov assault rifles hang on hooks along the walls. Outside, dusk has fallen and the blue-white lights of Kabul off in the horizon outline the skeletal remains of nearby bombed-out houses. The winter stillness is interrupted at regular intervals by the dull thud of artillery.

title: Review/Music; Pushing a Cello to Its Limit
description: One enjoys the driven quality in Ralph Kirshbaum's cello playing for its ability to make tension swell and expand rather than narrow into hardness. In his concert with Jonathan Feldman at Weill Recital Hall Friday night, Mr. Kirshbaum pushed tempos hard without ever really rushing them. The first movement of the Franck Sonata rarely lingered, but never was it out of breath.

title: Jennifer L. Stafford and John Farrow, Furniture Importers, to Wed in June
description: The engagement of Jennifer Lee Stafford to John Glen Farrow, a son of Glenn W. Farrow of Thousand Oaks, Calif., and Dorothy Kilkenny of Woodland Hills, Calif., has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. John R. Stafford of Essex Fells, N.J. A June wedding is planned. Miss Stafford, a screen and television actress, is a graduate of the Pingry School and Northwestern University. She and Mr. Farrow own and operate Gattini Ecc.,an importer of handmade furniture and accessories in Malibu, Calif.

title: Bashing The Media Is No Solution
description: Residents of Nassau and Suffolk Counties have more Long Island television news available to them now than ever before. Cablevision's News 12 Long Island provides 24-hour news service for subscribers - about half the television households on Long Island.

title: Team Loses Game And Then Its Bus
description: Walhalla High School's basketball team lost more than its 23d game of the season Friday night. The Razorbacks also lost their bus after the 87-66 loss to Chapman in Inman.

title: Basketball Coach Basks in 400 Wins
description: LEAD: MIKE DEL VAL, varsity basketball coach at Alexander Hamilton High School here, is a modest man. This winter, he won the 400th game of his career - something only two other Westchester high school basketball coaches have done. As a gracious team leader, he simply shrugs and says, ''I've been lucky to have great guys playing for me.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Upper West Side
description: IT is 18 months since Lichtman's bakery closed, 20 since the projector sputtered to a halt at the Thalia theater and nearly four years since the New Yorker bookshop shut down - all victims of creeping development and galloping rent rises.

title: Defending His Custom
description: Peter MacDonald, chairman of the Navajo tribe, says he acted in accordance with a traditional custom of accepting gifts; but Congressional investigators suspect he was following a custom of more recent origin - accepting bribes. Mr. MacDonald, who has invoked the Fifth Amendment in declining to appear before a Senate committee investigating allegations that he took kickbacks, went on the radio last week to defend himself. Speaking over KTNN in Window Rock, Ariz., he said he committed no crime in accepting gifts, and compared his acts to those of politicians. ''Nobody is offering me $5,000 a night for speaking engagements,'' he said. But he was offered, and did accept, according to Senate testimony, considerations including a $50,000 cash kickback for helping arrange the tribe's purchase of a $33.4 million ranch.

title: Long Island Is Still a Home To Sea Turtles, Scientists Say
description: A sizable population of juvenile sea turtles still calls Long Island home, three scientists reported today.

title: Designing A Jewelry Jungle
description: MIA FONSSAGRIVES-SOLOW, right, was in the fashion business with the designer Vicky Tiel in Paris in the 1960's. When she returned to the United States she became a sculptor, making larger-than-life-size animals. Recently she has interpreted animal shapes as jewelry, including walking cats, swinging monkeys, butterflies with folded wings, lions' heads and standing meerkats (African mongooses). There are gold or silver pins, pendants, earrings, cuffs, charm bracelets and charm necklaces. Prices range from $72 for silver earrings to $2,000 for a gold bracelet. The jewelry is sold through an agent, Judy Tishman, at 212-988-8855.

title: WESTCHESTER FOLLOW-UP
description: Appeals Court Supports Fanelli THE County Executive has lost another round in his battle to dismiss the County Probation director, Marino J. Fanelli - the first department head Mr. O'Rourke has attempted to remove in the six years of his administration. A unanimous decision by the State Supreme Court's Appellate Division upheld a State Supreme Court ruling that dismissed the county's legal arguments for removing Mr. Fanelli.

title: Litchfield's Voice When Trouble Hits
description: LEAD: WHEN disaster strikes in Litchfield County, residents now have a concerned voice of their own on the air. Between disasters, the county is being treated to some unusual programming.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Movies Lost in Translation
description: By self-appointment film purveyor to the world, Hollywood, in turn, has always welcomed artists from abroad. Some great directors, such as Jean Renoir and Max Ophuls, came and went. F. W. Murnau, Billy Wilder and Fritz Lang, among others, stayed, responded to the environment and prospered. Each in his own way enriched the American movie idiom. As melting pots go, Hollywood has been one of the busiest, if not one of the most cost efficient.

title: Barenboim's Chicago Connection
description: There are times when musical history seems determined to repeat old tunes, as if hoping this time to get them right. There was something hauntingly familiar, for instance, about the situation in which Daniel Barenboim found himself recently when, in the midst of acrimonious wrangling over his dismissal as music director of Paris's Bastille Opera, the news broke of his appointment as music director of the Chicago Symphony, effective in 1991. He apparently had been negotiating for two high-profile, time-consuming jobs, both of which he wanted and felt he could juggle.

title: Figure in Molestation Case Is Being Freed to Await Trial
description: A defendant awaiting trial in a molestation case involving preschool children will soon be freed after five years in prison on $1.5 million bail raised by his friends.

title: Pitt Upsets No. 2 Hoyas
description: Jason Matthews scored 24 points and Pitt held No. 2 Georgetown to 8 points in the final 10 minutes to upset the Hoyas, 79-74, today in the Big East Conference.

title: Deficit Figuring Doesn't Add Up
description: In the few months since George Bush's election, there has been a remarkable swing of sentiment on the Federal budget deficit. In November, a sharp drop in the financial markets was regarded by some as signaling a deficit ''crisis.'' Former and present Federal Reserve Chairmen Paul A. Volcker and Alan Greenspan, former Presidents Gerald R. Ford and Jimmy Carter and economists of every political allegiance took up the cry: without very fast action to cut the deficit right away, we were facing an American recession, a world economic crisis, or worse.

title: David Ives Engaged To Nancy Ann Corey
description: Mr. and Mrs. Marshall T. Corey of Armonk, N.Y., and Hilton Head Island, S.C., have made known the engagement of their daughter Nancy Ann Corey to David John Ives, the son of Betty P. Berry of Franklin, Tenn., and the late Col. Albert R. Ives. A June wedding is planned.

title: Miss Metsky to Wed in May
description: Karen Beth Metsky and Robert Cowen 3d are planning a May wedding, the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Marvin Metsky of Livingston, N.J., have announced. A graduate of the University of Pittsburgh, Miss Metsky is a vice president of Sports Minded, a sports-equipment marketing company in New York. Mr. Cowen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Cowen Jr. of Convent Station, N.J., graduated from Newark Academy and Lehigh University. He is an independent television producer.

title: In Cable Dispute, Sports Fans Lose
description: THE winter hockey season is more than half over and the basketball season is approaching its halfway point, but Cablevision viewers still cannot watch either the New York Knicks or the Rangers. Each team is having its best season in years. While talks on the programming dispute have been continuing between Cablevision and the Madison Square Garden Network, Richard Kessel, the mediator, said, ''The bottom line is that nothing has changed and the programming is still not on.''

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Coram $131,000 7 Hale Lane 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 16-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, den, a/c, 1-car garage; taxes $2,400. Locust Valley $285,000 33 George Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 22-year-old colonial; den, fireplace, screened patio, finished basement; taxes $3,100. Massapequa $235,000 18 West End Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old split level; dining room, eat-in kitchen, basement, 2-car garage; taxes $4,000. Sayville $121,500 10 High Street 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 34-year-old Cape Cod; 2 fireplaces, basement; taxes $2,800. Seaford $170,000 3905 South Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 60-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, basement, 2-car garage; taxes $1,700. Westbury $248,000 732 High View Avenue 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 30-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, finished basement, attic; taxes $4,300. title: Furillo Thanked For Giving Hope
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Miss Preston Has Wedding
description: Electra Preston and George Watkins Ahl 3d were married yesterday in Bedford, N.Y. The Rev. Richard Visconti performed the ceremony at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church.

title: 10 AIDS Babies Baffling Moscow Hospital Team
description: New cribs lined the children's ward at Infectious Diseases Hospital No. 2 here, each with a fresh set of linens, and a bed nearby for each child's mother.

title: After Lilco: A Future for RICO Against Regulated Industries?
description: A Federal judge's decision yesterday overturning the use of the RICO statute to find the Long Island Lighting Company liable for criminal fraud in a rate-setting case could limit RICO's use against regulated industries, several legal experts believe.

title: Rebecca Adams to Marry Paul Montgomery in March
description: A March 11 wedding is planned for Rebecca Wendling Adams, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Banks Tolson Adams Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and Paul Macrae Montgomery.

title: Dana Stahl to Marry David M. Mermelstein
description: Dr. and Mrs. Martin B. Stahl of Edison, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter Dana Marci Stahl to David Max Mermelstein, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon B. Mermelstein of Bear Creek, Pa. An April wedding is planned.

title: Cool Customers Who Scorn Senior Citizen Label
description: To the Editor:

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Hamilton Township $130,000 310 Montana Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 26-year-old ranch; fenced yard, full basement, eat-in-kitchen; taxes $1,703. Livingston $347,000 26 Rumson Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 32-year-old split level; den, fireplace, professionally landscaped; taxes $4,501. Morris Township $235,000 6 Upperfield Road 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 25-year-old split level; c/a, family room, den; taxes $2,911. Randolph $170,000 26 Calais Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; h/w floors, sun porch, dining room; taxes $1,848. Summit $410,000 83 Maple Street 6-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 81-year-old colonial; 4 fireplaces, new furnace, newly renovated; taxes $4,478. Vernon $186,500 Susan Valley Terrace 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 2-year-old ranch; eat-in-kitchen, 2-car garage, full basement; taxes $2,298. OTHER AREAS Locust Valley, L.I. $285,000 33 George Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 22-year-old colonial; den, fireplace, screened patio, finished basement; taxes $3,100. Trumbull, Conn. $208,000 260 Fersdale Avenue 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 30-year-old contemporary; new open kitchen, passive solar family room, 0.25 acre; taxes $1,825. Chappaqua, N.Y. $502,500 20 Glen Terrace 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 17-year-old colonial; 2 fireplaces, large deck, new kitchen, 2-car garage, 1 acre; taxes $6,805.

title: Anne Alexander Is Engaged
description: Mrs. Chester Alexander of Gloucester, Va., has made known the engagement of her daughter, Anne Stokes Alexander, to Davis Ratcliffe Marshall, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Beverley R. W. Marshall of Gloucester. The couple plan to marry in April.

title: Outbreak of Road Shootings Plagues Detroit
description: Every year, the police here receive two or three reports of highway shootings. But ever since Michael K. Warner was shot and killed on Interstate 75 south of Detroit around midnight Nov. 19, the shootings have multiplied and the reports have multiplied even more. The police say that the shootings seem to be unrelated and that some are imaginary; often stones or debris are the culprits. ''Somebody loses a window, they think they got shot at,'' said Inspector Gerald Johnson of the state police. But about half the 28 shootings reported since November are probably authentic, the police say. As with a string of 30 freeway shootings in Los Angeles in the summer of 1987, most seem to start with fights between drivers, who are replacing the angry honking of a horn or flashing of lights with the firing of a gun. ''If people weren't carrying guns in cars,'' said Inspector Johnson, ''this wouldn't be happening.''

title: For Octogenarian, Work Conquers All
description: THERE are mornings when Coral Goldstein of Stamford feels that she just will not be able to get through the day.

title: A Nicaraguan Canal Is Under Study Again
description: Nicaragua says it has formed an international group of experts to study the construction of a canal to link the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans across Nicaragua.

title: Boxing
description: Jacquot Wins Title: Rene Jacquot became the first Frenchman in 30 years to win a world boxing championship by scoring a unanimous 12-round decision over Donald Curry of the United States for the World Boxing Council super-welterweight title last night at Grenoble, France. The scoring by the judges was: Sid Nathan of Britain, 117-113; Justo Vasquez of Spain, 118-115, and Jesus Arias of Mexico, 118-116, all in favor of Jacquot. It was the first defense of the W.B.C. crown for Curry. The Frenchman's record improved to 24-9 with one draw. Curry dropped to 31-3. The last Frenchman to hold a world boxing crown was Alphonse Halimi, who was the bantamweight champion from 1957 to 1959.(AP) Mitchell Stops Italian to Keep Crown: Brian Mitchell of South Africa stopped Salvatore Bottiglieri of Italy in the eighth round last night to retain his World Boxing Association super-featherweight title in Capo d'Orlando, Sicily. Mitchell is 37-1 with two draws, while the challenger is 27-4.(AP) Golf Carter Leads Hawaiian Open: Jim Carter retained the lead yesterday after two rounds of the rain-shortened Hawaiian Open. A flooded Waialae Country Club course forced officials to delay the second round and reduce the tournament to a three-round, 54-hole format, with the final round today. Carter, seeking the first victory of a three-year PGA Tour career, held a 2-stroke advantage with a 36-hole total of 130. David Ogrin and Gene Sauers were next at 132.(AP) Horse Racing Krone Rides 5 Winners: Julie Krone rode five winners at Aqueduct yesterday, including Scorned Lass in the $86,400 Rare Treat Handicap for fillies and mares 3-years-old. Scorned Lass scored a 4 1/4-length upset victory over Rose's Cantina, who finished 4 3/4 lengths ahead of To the Hunt. Scorned Lass covered the mile and an eigthth in 1:51 1/5 and returned $14 for $2.(AP) Track and Field Missouri Sprinter Breaks Record: Natasha Kaiser of Missouri set a women's collegiate indoor record in the 400-meter dash last night, beating the old record-holder, Linetta Wilson of Nebraska, at the Frank Sevigne Husker Invitational in Lincoln, Neb. Kaiser ran the 400 meters in 52.39, more than a tenth of a second faster than the record of 52.52 Wilson set in last year's Husker Invitational. (AP) Speed Skating Dutchman Leads Flaim of U.S.: Leo Visser, the European champion from the Netherlands, held a narrow lead over the defending champion Eric Flaim of the United States after the opening two events of the men's world championships yesterday at Oslo. Visser placed only 14th in the opening 500-meter race in 39.48 seconds, but came back strongly to win the 5,000-meter event in 7 minutes 3.52 seconds for a total of 81.832 time points. Flaim had 82.117 points before today's 1,500- and 10,000-meter events. He placed second in the 500 meters in 38.96 and 11th in the 5,000 with 7:17.57.(AP) Auto Racing Schrader Gains Daytona 500 Pole: Ken Schrader won the Daytona 500 pole for the second successive year yesterday, taking the top qualifying spot in the first round of time trials for next Sunday's race. Schrader turned a fast lap of 196.997 miles an hour on the 2.5-mile oval at Daytona International Speedway at Daytona Beach, Fla. Darrell Waltrip, also in a Chevrolet Monte Carlo, took the other front-row position at 195.916. (AP) Bowling Voss Takes His Seventh Crown: Brian Voss of Seattle, the 1988 Professional Bowlers Association Player of the Year, captured his seventh career title yesterday when he beat Pete Weber, 225-194, in the title game of the $140,000 Bowlers Journal Florida Open.(AP) Swimming East German Excels in Breast-Stroke: Susanne Boernike of East Germany swam to a world-best time in the 200-meter World Cup breast-stroke event yesterday and Nick Gillingham of Britain posted a European-best time in the men's event at Bonn, West Germany. Boernike set the world best time of 2 minutes 22.92 seconds. Gillingham swam the men's event in 2:09.81. (AP) Men's Fencing Penn State 17, Columbia 10: At Temple University in Philadelphia yesterday, the Nittany Lions handed the Columbia Lions, the two-time defending N.C.A.A. champions, their first dual meet loss since Feb. 13, 1985, a 51-match span. Penn State, which swept the epee events, is 15-0 this season. Columbia, which defeated Haverford by 22-5 later in the day, is 9-1.

title: INSIDE
description: A Hungarian Compromise

title: Betting on a Gambit When Time Is Short
description: THERE is nothing so much to be wished for by a player trailing in a short match than a novel gambit to unsettle the opponent and make up the lost ground. But producing one when you need it is a rare achievement.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Savannah
description: Unlike some other time-worn towns, Savannah doesn't believe in keeping the family treasures in a display case, to be seen but not touched. House museums, frequent private tours and friendly homeowners offer a hands-on history lesson. Laid out by Gen. James Oglethorpe 256 years ago, Savannah has the country's largest urban National Historic Landmark District, which includes free-standing mansions, row houses on Gordon, Jones and Gaston streets and 22 park-like squares. In addition, there is the Factor's Walk restoration on Bay Street. There, cotton merchants, called factors in the early 1800's, inspected bales of Sea Island fibers before closing a deal. Today, boutiques, antiques stores, offices and apartments can be found in Factor's Walk.

title: WHEN OLD IS NEW
description: In this era of eternal youth, speeding up the aging process may seem like a strange idea, but it has become big business in the design world. It is now possible to get the feeling of perfectly faded fabrics or the rich patina of century-old woods without paying the price of time. The tricks, to be sure, are theatrical: soaking freshly printed chintzes in vats of tea; smearing mud into shiny surfaces; mixing eggshells, finely ground dust or coffee grinds into paint; beating fabrics with stones. Such techniques produce that well-worn feeling one once assumed only age itself could create.

title: Intrepid Director Goes in Search Of Adventure
description: Under a withering African sun that scorches the pale green acacia trees and tawny earth in the Ngong Hills not far from here, Bob Rafelson, a multicolored wool cap protecting his head, is directing two actors dressed in tattered Victorian garb. One is on crutches; the other appears quite spry. Both are sweltering in heavy coats and gaiters as they say farewell to each other.

title: Star Steals the Show in 'Social Security'
description: IT isn't just that Reizl Bozyk steals the show ''Social Security'' at the Forum Theater as, last summer, she stole the film ''Crossing Delancy.'' Mrs. Bozyk simply is the show, the whole show, and that's that.

title: For Khmer Rouge, There's Gold in the Ruby Mines
description: The Khmer Rouge is earning tens of thousands of dollars a week by selling passes to people who want to mine rubies in areas it controls inside Cambodia, numerous Cambodians interviewed in this refugee camp just inside Thailand say.

title: JERSEYANA
description: LEAD: THE date is Feb. 13, 1935, and you, reader, are a member of the jury in the trial of Bruno Richard Hauptmann for the kidnapping-murder of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr. For the last six weeks you and your 11 fellow jurors have spent your days in the courtroom in Flemington listening to the evidence in what the press calls the trial of the century.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: X IN PARIS. By Michael Brodsky. (Four Walls Eight Windows, Paper, $9.95.) The universe presented in this collection of short fiction is a heartless and despairing one, a bleak landscape in which those who strive for something more than mere survival are, in the end, thoroughly defeated. In the Proustian title story, a man, vacationing with his wife and son in France, leaves them behind to travel to Paris, ''an exercise in despair,'' to pursue the undefinable state of being he calls ''X .

title: FOCUS: Cumberland, Me.; The Rich Gobble Up Coastal Hideaways
description: WHEN residents of Cumberland, an affluent suburb of Portland, voted in December not to buy the 25-acre estate known as Conifer Ledges, they confirmed what many there have felt for some time: Oceanfront property has become too expensive for public agencies. The estate would have given the community its only waterfront park.

title: Defense Radar Must Turn Off As Planes Land
description: For 14 months operators of a huge radar installation in central Georgia that is part of the United States' defense warning system have had to turn off the system while military aircraft landed at a nearby base.

title: Design of Waterfronts Undergoing Scrutiny
description: LEAD: LOOKING at the buildings already erected as part of New Jersey's waterfront redevelopment boom, state and local officials say they do not like everything they see. As a result, they have begun to develop planning guidelines aimed at taking control of design elements that affect what a building looks like and how it fits in with its surroundings.

title: POSTINGS: New Crop, Old Acres; Farmland Project
description: A 26-acre tract in central New Jersey that had been farmed for more than a century and that still retains an 1832 farmhouse is being developed into a 76-unit complex of town houses and apartments. The tract is two miles north of downtown Princeton on Mount Lucas Road.

title: Alcohol Is a Problem When It's a Problem
description: BY what standards should society judge whether someone is a problem drinker? That issue arose last week as Senators continued to consider how seriously to take speculation that John G. Tower, the nominee for Defense Secretary, has a drinking problem and when Gov. Michael S. Dukakis said that his wife, Kitty, had entered an alcoholic treatment program.

title: Theatrical Richness Of the Nonprofit Stage
description: The Jan. 8 article ''Theater in the State: A 'Coming of Age' '' ignores one of the most versatile, diverse theatrical resources in New Jersey: the nonprofit, nonprofessional theater. In central New Jersey alone, where our organization has existed for more than 35 years, there are more than 15 such theaters, run by volunteer members united in common devotion to an art form.

title:
DINING OUT;
Festive Chinese in Scotch Plains
description: LEAD: Now that the lunar Year of the Snake has been well rung in with feasts, toasts and firecrackers, most Chinese restaurants in the state are settling back to normal. However, East Winds in Scotch Plains, for one is carrying on with banquets and festivities until the end of February.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: February 12, 1989
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 2 THE SHELL SEEKERS, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (Dell, $4.95.) A woman and a painting tie together three generations of an English family. 2 2 INHERITANCE, by Judith Michael. (Pocket, $5.50.) The jealousies and rivalries of a wealthy family on Boston's Beacon Hill. 3 11 THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe. (Bantam, $5.95.) A bond trader caught in the jungles of New York. 4 3 MORTAL FEAR, by Robin Cook. (Berkley, $4.95.) An American tourist in the Soviet Union stumbles on a K.G.B. plot to strike at the American heartland. 7 8 ROCK STAR, by Jackie Collins. (Pocket, $4.95.) The glory and anguish of three rock-and-roll performers in tinselly southern California. 8 16 LONESOME DOVE, by Larry McMurtry. (Pocket, $4.95.) The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Compaq Sharpens Its Video Option
description: Computer-aided design and computer-aided engineering, or CAD-CAE, used to be done almost exclusively on powerful work stations costing tens of thousands of dollars. Today, most CAD work is done on personal computers, especially on machines that are powered by the Intel 80386 processor. That chip has enough muscle to display and redraw complex graphics and drawings.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: CHAMPIONS OF THE WORLD. By Douglas Mine. (Fireside/Simon & Schuster, Cloth, $17.95; Paper, $7.95.) One of the striking paradoxes of Argentina's 1978 World Cup victory in soccer was that while the country was playing host to this open international competition its military dictatorship was brutally kidnapping, torturing and murdering suspected of anti-Government activity.

title: With the Thrifts, What Haven't the Regulators Tried?
description: EXPERTS agree that the savings and loan industry's 20-year slide toward its current crisis can be linked in one way or another to the Federal Government's role. Whether the industry was over-regulated or under-regulated is open to debate; few question that it was misregulated.

title: The Double Standard Of Terrorism
description: Judging from Carl Bosch's own bewilderment over terrorism (''What Do You Tell Children About Terrorism,'' Opinion page, Jan. 15), I don't wonder that he was unable to explain it to his daughter.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Jan. 15 with an article about Katmandu misidentified the site shown. It was the Ranipokhari, the Queen's Pond, not the royal palace.

title: Review/Theater; A Japanese-American Protester in '42
description: Most dramatizations of the United States Government's internment of Japanese-Americans during World War II fall into one of two categories. They are either documentaries or they are based on personal memories. In contrast to previous treatments of the subject at the Pan Asian Repertory Theater, R. A. Shiomi takes a third approach.

title: Clubs at Princeton Curb Drinking
description: It was a weekend in which alcohol abuse sent eight students to the infirmary, including two whose moderate poisoning required a transfer to a hospital, but Princeton University officials were relieved. ''It was a minor affair,'' said a university spokeswoman, Jacqueline Savani. ''It was nothing like last year.''

title:
New Jersey Q & A: Jeff Torborg;
Taking Over the White Sox Helm
description: LEAD: WHEN Jeff Torborg recalls his 10 years in baseball as a player, the memories of his days as a catcher for the Los Angeles Dodgers and the California Angels are fresh in his mind. Some of the events he was involved in have found their way into baseball's record books; memorabilia from others can be seen on display, encased by protective glass in Cooperstown, N.Y., at major league baseball's Hall of

title: Margaret M. Byrne to Marry Frank P. Christian 3d
description: Margaret Mary Byrne and Frank Philip Christian 3d plan to be married April 1. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Terence C. Byrne of Hackettstown, N.J., and Mr. and Mrs. Christian 2d of Clarks Summit, Pa.

title: SEEKING EXPOSURE, COMPANIES TAKE THEIR SHOWS ON THE ROAD
description: While corporations have long patronized the arts, they are much more active participants in the process these days. ''They are not merely lending works to museum shows, but are organizing shows and sponsoring tours drawing from their own collections,'' said Judith A. Jedlicka, president of the Business Committee for the Arts, an industry group that encourages business to take a more active role in the arts.

title: A NEW PILL, A FIERCE BATTLE
