description: WITH HIS MOP OF black hair and his brown ankle-high boots, Dr. Etienne-Emile Baulieu comes across at once as a different kind of scientist. His breezy, almost brash manner and hyperkinetic nature give him the air more of a populist politician than of a meticulous medical researcher, an expert in hormones at France's National Institute of Health and Medical Research.

title: Of Dolls, Barbie Is Still Queen
description: THIS past year was a big one for Barbie. Like the baby boomers who were first presented with this wondrous creation, the Barbie doll has finally hit ''thirtysomething.''

title: Karen Toby Judlowe To Wed Spencer Smul
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Stephen B. Judlowe of Murray Hill, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter Karen Toby Judlowe to Spencer Gary Smul, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sanford Smul of New York. The couple plan to marry in November.

title: Swiss Barrels To Gold
description: Vreni Schneider wasn't taking any chances in the giant slalom today. Going into the world Alpine ski championships, she had a reputation for winning in the second run of World Cup slalom and giant slalom races.

title: Heartfelt Dancing Is Her Signature
description: ''She dances not as a gypsy but as a lady, and within this range her mastery of nuance, the accuracy with which she makes her point, is unparalleled. The lightest of ironies colors her suggestion of passion, of speed, of grace. And it keeps her performance within the bounds of what may be done with good taste in public.'' So wrote the critic Edwin Denby in 1943 of the legendary Spanish dancer, Argentinita.

title: Philosophy Provides the Key to a Pianist
description: ''When I was young,'' the pianist Russell Sherman said, ''I came across a statement made by Jung, who said that it is the function of an artist is to rectify the imbalances of the period in which he happens to live. I feel - and this is perhaps my prejudice and imprint - that ours is an age which is lacking in soul. And I believe myself, presumptuous as it sounds, to be a protagonist of the soul. I think of the soul as the seat of mystery, wonder and compassion.

title: Cedeno Returns
description: It has been 19 years since he broke in with Houston, and now at the age of 37 and two years into apparent retirement, Cesar Cedeno is attempting a comeback with the Astros. He has been invited to spring training to try out as a pinch-hitter. ''We need bench strength from the right side of the plate, and we think he might fill that void,'' said a club spokesman, Rob Matwick.

title: LET THE DIALER BEWARE: A NEW PAY PHONE ERA
description: Harry Poulakakos, the owner of Harry's Bar in the Wall Street area, received a ballot in the mail last month from the New York Telephone Company that asked him to choose a company to provide long-distance service to the seven pay telephones in his establishment.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: SONG AND DANCE MAN By Karen Ackerman. Illustrated by Stephen Gammell. Unpaged. New York: Alfred A. Knopf.

title: Review/Rock; Avant-Garde Guitarist And Friends
description: For the last three weeks, the Kitchen has been host to a new-music series it is presenting with Roulette, the smaller downtown Manhattan performance space that has eclipsed the Kitchen's musical reputation in recent years. Thursday was the first of three nights of concerts with Fred Frith, the English art-rock avant-gardist.

title: Secrecy vs. Fairness
description: 'I want to do my level best to protect the national secrets of this country. But I want to do even more to give this man a fair trial. This is not a trial of the national security system; this is not a political trial. It is a trial of Oliver North.' - Judge Gerhard A. Gesell, on a Justice Department proposal to censor testimony dealing with national security at Mr. North's trial.

title: This 'Love's Labor's' Is a Labor of Love
description: LEAD: Shakespeare's sonnet play, ''Love's Labor's Lost'' - the first play to bear his name on a title page (in the 1598 quarto edition) - opens Feb. 22 at the New York Public Theater (it is currently in previews), the seventh in Joseph Papp's marathon series of the Bard's dramatic works. It is the only Shakespeare play for which praise from one of his own players in the King's Men is on record - praise from Richard Burbage himself.

title: Anne E. Schmutz, A Teacher, to Wed Donald C. Hovey
description: Mr. and Mrs. Roger C. Schmutz of Bailey Island, Me., and Marco Island, Fla., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Anne Elizabeth Schmutz, to Donald Campbell Hovey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald O. Hovey of Saint Davids, Pa. The couple plan to marry in July.

title: Where to Get More Details
description: Abercrombie & Kent/Continental Waterways, 1420 Kensington Road, Oak Brook. Ill. 60521 (312-954-2944; 800-323-7308 outside Illinois).

title:
TV VIEW;
All Those Critters Look Cute, but . . .
description: LEAD: Every Sunday evening, George Page steps out of some jungle or desert onto my television screen and says, ''Hi! I'm George Page for 'Nature!' '' Usually, I mutter back, ''That's nice. So is almost everybody.''

title: Condominiums Are Not for Everyone
description: THE other day my wife and I went to the Condo - not to stay, just to look it over. The salespeople made us admit that the house we've lived in for the last 20 years is too big for us, that we are tired of mowing the lawn and shoveling snow. But I don't think we're ready for the Condo. Not just yet.

title: Spano Withdrawal Evokes Gratitude from Democrats
description: COUNTY CLERK ANDREW J. SPANO earned the gratitude of Westchester's Democratic Party leadership last week with one simple but agonizing move - withdrawing as a candidate for County Executive - on the occasion of the party's biggest celebration.

title: 4 Artists Show LandscapesAt the Pelham Art Center By VIVIEN RAYNOR
description: 'LANDSCAPES'' is the title of the current show at the Pelham Art Center and landscapes are what it consists of - 39 of them by four artists.

title: Valentine Protocol: Children Know Best
description: SATURDAYS at the library are different from other days of the week; a certain lightness fills the air. Cartoon-pitched children's voices float brightly over the muffled sound of rustled pages emanating from the reading room. One can feel the staidness lifted; the building swarms with frisky Lilliputians, who might easily erupt in giggles if told reading was for anything but fun.

title: The New, Revealing Look of Taiwan Elections
description: Elections used to be simple things here. The ruling party would nominate candidates who would win elections, and candidates would wear clothes.

title: Illegal Pitch?
description: To the Editor:

title: COACH UNDER FIRE
description: When it comes to the relationship between athletics and academics, there may be a lot of hypocrisy on the nation's college campuses, but apparently not at Prairie View A&M. If some of his players are telling it right, Haney Catchings, the football coach at the Texas school, makes no pretense about being anything but strictly an athletics man.

title: Why Students Enroll in Program
description: THERE are 35 students enrolled in each year of the program at the Center for Advanced Technology in Telecommunications on the Polytechnic University campus in Hawthorne. Classes are kept small, the school said, to encourage interaction between the students and instructors.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ended Jan. 28 MANHATTAN East Midtown $175,000 322 East 54th Street 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 1,300-sq.-ft. prewar duplex co-op with half the space in the basement; 2 fireplaces, garden; maintenance $1,533, 80% tax-deductible (Broker: Arthur P. Brooks Realty) Greenwich Village $1.06 million 832 Broadway (12th St.) 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 4,000-sq.-ft. prewar loft co-op; dining room, large kitchen, arched windows, fluted columns; maintenance $1,650, 70% tax-deductible (Broker: Ambrose Mar-Elia) Upper East Side $2.2 million 45 East 80th Street 4-bedroom, 4-bath, 3,000-sq.-ft. postwar duplex condo; 24-hr. doorman, concierge, manned elevator, dining room; common charge $3,500, taxes $2,520 (Broker: Corcoran Group) Upper West Side $661,100 52 Riverside Drive (77th St.) Prewar co-op penthouse, 1 bedroom, 1-bath, 1,100-sq.-ft.; 24-hr. doorman, manned elevator, dining room, maid's room, fireplace, terrace, Hudson River view; maintenance $1,350, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Weichert Realtors) Upper West Side $310,000 107 West 86th Street 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 1,100-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, large kitchen; maintenance $620, includes gas and electricity, 40% tax-deductible (Broker: Eden Realty) BRONX City Island $122,000 30A Carroll Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, single-family cottage; dining area, windowed kitchen, beach rights, 200- by 100-ft. leased lot; taxes $100 (Broker: Jacqueline Kyle Kall) Parkchester $240,000 1340 Fteley Avenue 3-family, semi-attached, brick house; 3 bedrooms, large kitchen in two units; 1 bedroom in other; 1 bath, dining room in each; 1-car garage, 25- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,100 (Broker: Marland Real Estate) BROOKLYN Park Slope area $98,000 1209 8th Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 950-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; dining room, large kitchen, roof rights, Manhattan skyline view; maintenance $452, 67% tax-deductible (Broker: Larkin-Gibbs LTD) Prospect Heights $187,500 20 Plaza Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,300-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining area, large kitchen, renovated bath; maintenance $559, 43% tax-deductible (Broker: Warren Lewis Realty) Windsor Terrace $210,000 1614 11th Avenue 2-family, 3-story, attached, brick house; 3 bedrooms in primary unit; 2 bedrooms in other; 1 bath, dining room, large kitchen in each; 625-sq.-ft. of commercial space on the ground floor, 24- by 51-ft. lot; taxes $1,440 (Broker: Barbara D'Erasmo) QUEENS Astoria $235,000 21-19 23d Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, single-family, attached, brick house; dining room, new windows, finished basement, 1-car garage, 20- by 117-ft. lot; taxes $950 (Broker: Century 21/Elms Realty) Forest Hills $129,500 110-07 73d Road (Wakefield) 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 1,000-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; part-time doorman, large kitchen, original moldings; maintenance $386, 50% tax deductible (Broker: Rhona Realty) STATEN ISLAND Dongan Hills $165,000 121 Holly Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, single-family, detached ranch; large kitchen, study, full attic, 75- by 184-ft. lot; taxes $1,200 (Broker: Century 21/Appleseed Agency) West Brighton $166,000 696 Delafield Avenue 2-bedroom, 2-bath, single-family, detached colonial; dining room, large kitchen, full basement, second kitchen, 1-car garage, 30- by 181-ft. lot; taxes $1,110 (Broker: RE-MAX-Preferred)

title: Family-Style American in Darien
description: IF Bugbee & Brownell seems familiar, it's because it is. The relatively new restaurant, on the Post Road in Darien (next to Friendly's, just off Exit 13 of Interstate 95), is actually the old Harper's and has simply changed its name. The new name, inspired by an old Boston tea company which has no connection to the restaurant, is meant, in one waitress's words, ''to sound good, as part of our upscaling.''

title: Recipients of Medicare Also Face Rise in Cost of Private Insurance
description: Older Americans already paying higher premiums and a surtax this year for expanded Medicare coverage are angrily discovering that supplementary private insurance, which they thought would become less expensive, is costing more, too.

title: Corrections
description: A map on Jan. 22 with an article about private dining clubs in London located Harry's Bar incorrectly. The club is on the east side of South Audley Street.

title: Two Architects Who Tap Into Our Deepest Moods
description: The first pleasure in the Museum of Modern Art's new architecture exhibition, ''Emilio Ambasz/Steven Holl,'' is the extent to which it makes the never-ending debate about style seem tiresome, even trivial. The work of these architects is too original, and too good, to be bound by stylistic labels. Are Emilio Ambasz and Steven Holl Modern, post-Modern, neo-Rationalist or Deconstructivist? There are moments when their work suggests every one of these things, but none of these labels does either of these architects justice, and one turns away from the whole issue of style with relief. It is the architecture that is important here, not the category. This exhibition transcends ideology; it presents the work of two very different architects who share only a common commitment to the seriousness of their art, and to the possibility that architecture can enrich social experience.

title: Real Estate Is Alive and Well
description: Who says real estate has seen the end of ''boom times'' in Fairfield County? (Real Estate Bids Goodbye to Boom Times, Dec. 25). A few buyers who couldn't ''steal'' a house? A few sellers who are still on the early spring price kick of 1986? A few brokers who have to work harder to make and keep sales together? A few lawyers who have to complain about something? A few members of the media who claim disaster has loomed.

title:
GARDENING;
Time for Seeding Is Drawing Near
description: LEAD: THE myth of the groundhog notwithstanding, it is a good bet that wintry weather will remain at least another four to six weeks. Yet the time to prepare for spring planting is drawing close. Fast-growing seedlings like tomatoes and marigolds can become tall and lanky if sown too early. But plants like pansies and perennials and slow growers like celosia, impatiens, coleus, geraniums and vincas should be sown right away if they are to be large enough to plant at the correct time.

title: No U.S. Broker Role Here, Mozambique Says
description: Mozambique has told South Africa that the United States should not try to mediate in the insurgency in Mozambique, but that some other ''constructive role'' by it or another nation would be welcome.

title: Review/Dance; A Respect For Earth And Life
description: Choreographic modesty was one of the virtues of Shelley Lee's ''Maize'' Thursday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio, but it was responsible for some bland sequences in the hourlong work offered by Shelley Lee and Dancers.

title: CUTS THREATENED IN AID TO ISRAEL
description: Key members of Congress responsible for setting foreign aid levels say that Israel's treatment of Palestinians in the occupied territories is unacceptable and could weaken Congressional support for American aid to Israel.

title: First Interstate's Turn to Squirm
description: A little more than two years ago, Joseph J. Pinola, chairman and chief executive of the First Interstate Bancorp, made an audacious bid to buy the BankAmerica Corporation. BankAmerica was more than twice First Interstate's size, but it was in shambles - its stock was depressed, its capital base weak and its management surprised by a series of loan losses and other misfortunes.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; A CORRECTION
description: An article on Feb. 5 misidentified the broker in a sale of 66 acres on the Long Island Expressway in Islandia to Related Properties of Manhattan. He was Paul Amoruso, president of Oxford & Simpson in Jericho.

title: Abreast of Telecommunication's Change
description: BACK when ''the telephone company'' was the only game in town, corporate managers simply called the American Telephone and Telegraph Company when they had problems with their telecommunications. But after the A.T.&T. divestiture five years ago, information systems changed so dramatically, that managers soon found they needed specialized training.

title: In Remaking Itself, Texas Hasn't Lost Its Myths and Memory
description: IN 1981, Larry McMurtry wrote an essay for the Texas Observer that set off furious howls throughout Texas. Mr. McMurtry virtually dismissed all of Texas literature, saying Texas writers were unduly fixated on the past and largely because of that had produced almost nothing of lasting value. He lamented that he had been far too optimistic when he predicted 14 years earlier the demise of literature extolling the rural glories of wide-open spaces and yahoos on horseback.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: New York Shuts 2 Gay Theaters As AIDS Threats
description: New York City health officials closed two gay theaters in Manhattan last week in an effort to halt the spread of AIDS.

title: The Secret Life Of Thurber In Paris
description: ''DON'T try it,'' would surely have been James Thurber's advice to me if I'd asked him about picking up his traces in Paris. A literary man, he had little use for the literary pilgrimage and had dropped few handkerchiefs for the pilgrim on his trail. But I thought I was entitled to at least try.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I have a stall shower that has tiled walls up to the painted ceiling. Every two or three years this paint peels and flakes and we have to repaint. Is there a special paint I can use?

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Essex, Vt.;
For Starters, A Condo Hotel
description: LEAD: A 97-ROOM condominium hotel is rising in this rapidly growing suburb of Burlington, Vermont's largest city, as part of the first phase of the ongoing Lang Farm development.

title: Q and A
description: Ban on Dishwasher

title: Clare Louise Hollensteiner Marries Dr. James Smyth
description: Clare Louise Hollensteiner, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Hollensteiner of New York, and Dr. James Patrick Smyth, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Smyth of Pearl River, N.Y., were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Jean Baptiste in New York. Msgr. Eugene Clark performed the ceremony. Molly Baldrige was her cousin's maid of honor. Mr. Smyth served as best man for his son.

title: A Different Breed of Competition
description: This tiny city of 5,123 people, and the track that shares its name, bridge two nations, two states, and two breeds of race horses.

title: Auto Insurance Is Daunting Issue for Jersey Rivals
description: As the race for governor heats up, candidates are beginning to confront the high cost of automobile insurance, an issue that infuriates almost everyone in New Jersey and is understood by practically no one.

title: Pass the Indian Nuts
description: YESTERLINGO IS the fondly remembered language of the recent past. Nostalgia may not be what it used to be, as Simone Signoret suggested in the title of her autobiography, but the ghost words of our youth haunt us still.

title: PERSPECTIVES: Environmental Review; The Battle Over 'Negative Declarations'
description: ALONG the East River in an industrial pocket of the Bronx, James Granito and his partners in the Con-Agg Recycling Corporation crush rocks. They have been doing it for about five years on five acres of formerly idle, rubble-strewn urban-renewal land leased from the city.

title: Sharing the Language of the Stage
description: A play called ''The Paper Gramophone'' opened to previews last night at the Hartford Stage Company and brought full circle a cultural union between the artistic director of the Hartford and an artistic director from Russia.

title: High Cost of Deteriorating Environment Is Charted
description: The world can expect widespread economic decline and social disruption in the 1990's unless national leaders make a serious commitment to reverse the deterioration of the earth's environmental systems, a Washington-based research group said today.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Good Mother 1988. Touchstone Home Video. 1 hour, 44 minutes. $89.95. Closed captioned (CC). Rated R. Diane Keaton stars in Leonard Nimoy's drama, based on the novel by Sue Miller, about a recently divorced woman who unwittingly risks losing her daughter when she takes a lover. With Liam Neeson and Jason Robards. ''For all its potential to challenge and disturb, 'The Good Mother' is finally no more wrenching than a placid Maine landscape on a summer day.'' (Maslin) The Family 1987. Vestron Video. 2:08. $79.98. PG. Ettore Scola's drama recalls 80 years in the life of a large, loving upper-middle-class Roman family. With Andrea Occhipinti, Vittorio Gassman, Stefania Sandrelli, Jo Ciampa and Fanny Ardant. The film ''is too abstract - perfunctory, really - to be especially moving on its own.'' (Canby) The Wizard of Loneliness 1988. Virgin Vision. 1:50. $89.95. Laser disk (LD) Image Entertainment, $39.95. PG-13. Lukas Haas stars in a chronicle of a lonely, bratty boy adrift in a friendly Vermont village in 1944. With Lea Thompson. ''Poignant and colorful.'' (Dunning) Someone to Love 1987. Paramount Home Video. 1:44. $79.95. CC. Not rated. A personal film by Henry Jaglom that takes place during a Valentine's Day party given by a director in an old Santa Monica theater for his single and divorced friends. With Orson Welles, Henry Jaglom, Andrea Marcovicci, Michael Emil and Sally Kellerman. ''The next best thing to being trapped in a 1960's encounter session with people you'd just as soon not encounter.'' (Goodman) The Presidio Paramount Home Video. 1:37. No suggested list price. CC. R. Sean Connery plays an Army officer caught up in a mystery over the shooting of an M.P. Peter Hyams directed; with Meg Ryan and Mark Harmon. The material is ''forced'' and the direction is ''intent on stylish overkill.'' Mr. Connery ''is a fine actor under any circumstances, but he doesn't do much acting'' here. (Maslin) Young Guns 1988. Vestron Video. 1:42. $89.98. R. An update of the Billy the Kid legend, with Emilio Estevez, Kiefer Sutherland, Lou Diamond Phillips and Charlie Sheen. Directed by Christopher Cain. ''Emilio Estevez gives Billy a convincingly humorous side, and some of the other actors - most notably Kiefer Sutherland - help to keep things genial. . . . Best watched in the playful spirit in which it was made.'' (Maslin) Red Heat 1988. International Video Entertainment. 1:48. $89.95. R. Arnold Schwarzenegger stars as a homicide cop from Moscow who teams up with a Chicago detective, played by James Belushi, in Walter Hill's comedy. ''A topically entertaining variation on the sort of action-adventure nonsense that plays best on television. Though Mr. Belushi is the comedian of the film, the most consistently comic performance is Mr. Schwarzenegger's.'' (Canby)

title: Review/Music; Brazilian Sounds at Birdland
description: Lloyd McNeill, a flutist, brought a quartet to Birdland on Thursday night to play a set of pleasant, unobtrusive Brazilian music.

title:
MUSIC;
Englewood Premiere for 'Telemacco'
description: LEAD: THE Pro Arte Chorale, as part of its 25th anniversary season celebration, will present the American and New York premieres of Christoph Willibald Gluck's opera ''Telemacco'' in concert performances in New Jersey and New York.

title: Williams Trade Is Still a Rumor
description: Speculation that Buck Williams of the Nets will be traded before the Feb. 23 deadline is continuing this weekend. The latest rumor has Williams, a 6-foot-8-inch forward, being traded to Portland in exchange for Jerome Kersey and the Trail Blazers' first-round draft pick in 1989.

title: Patrice Soriero Marries
description: The wedding of Patrice Soriero, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Soriero of New Hope, Pa., to Jeffrey Stambovsky, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lazar Stambovsky of Springfield, Mass., took place last evening at the Steps Dance Studio in New York. Rabbi David B. Kahane officiated. The bride, a graduate of Pennsylvania State University, is a choreographer and the artistic director at the studio, of which she is the co-owner. The bridegroom, the manager of the high-yield bond department at Wertheim Schroder Inc. in New York, graduated from Vassar College and received an M.B.A. degree at the University of Chicago.

title: Ice Bridge Lures Thrill Seekers
description: Although it is officially banned, trekking across the ice bridge that forms at the base of the Horseshoe Falls in frigid weather is a thrill that some people compare to going over the falls in a barrel.

title: 'Reformed' Man Back in Jail
description: SEVENTEEN years after fleeing a prison in Louisiana, where he had begun serving 15 years for manslaughter, Henry Staggs was recaptured in Columbia, Tenn., apparently a changed man. During his freedom he had built a solid reputation as Douglas Gillette, the hard-working owner of an auto repair shop and a law-abiding family man.

title: Devils Finally Come Alive, But Too Late
description: There can't be many predicaments more daunting than the one in which the Devils found themselves tonight at the Forum. A scant four minutes into the second period, they were behind by 5-0.

title: In Sweat Suits and Jogging Shoes, Walkers Are Taking to Malls
description: IF you go to the mall only to shop, chances are you have never seen them. They are there at dawn, hours before the first cash register rings, often before the first janitorial shift. Clad in sweat suits and jogging shoes, they come to walk the store-lined corridors, back and forth, over and over. They are mall walkers, and for them, the suburban shopping mall, with its controlled climate, security guards, level floors and restrooms, is the perfect exercise track.

title: PAIN, HEALING AND 15 TONS OF LAUNDRY
description: LIFE AND DEATH The Story of a Hospital. By Ina Yalof. 357 pp. New York: Random House. $18.95.

title: Impressionism Revisited: Context Is King
description: During the last 15 to 20 years, art historians like Robert L. Herbert have changed art history. They believe that nothing can be understood apart from its social context and that absolutely everything in art has meaning. Each splash of color, each odd angle and each straight line is seen as a product of intention and choice. If everything in and around a work of art can be pinned down, they believe, the essential meaning of the art will emerge.

title: Koch Looks to Rivers for Development
description: ARMED with a sheaf of environmental studies of river currents, sunlight penetration, fish migration and other aspects of aquatic life, the Koch administration is preparing a campaign to let developers build office towers, apartment buildings and other large structures on piers and platforms over the East and Hudson Rivers.

title: Slow Going for Yacht
description: Slowed by light winds over the last two days, the yacht Thursday's Child failed to reach San Francisco today, but was still on course to break a 135-year-old sailing record by Sunday morning.

title: WHEN MORAL LIFE IS IMPOSSIBLE
description: LEAD: THE FINAL OPUS OF LEON SOLOMON By Jerome Badanes. 272 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: GREYLORD: Justice, Chicago Style. By James Tuohy and Rob Warden. (Putnam, $19.95.) It has all the ingredients of ''The Front Page'' with a little ''Guys and Dolls'' thrown in: judges on the take, lawyers with payoffs and pinky rings, bumbling law-enforcement officers. Despite its farcical aspects, however, the facts in ''Greylord: Justice, Chicago Style'' are all too real.

title: Reviews/Music; Solti With the Chicago And More Shostakovich
description: Periodically, the guardians of our New York concert life make earnest noises about trying to coordinate their programming. But right now, Leonard Slatkin and the New York Philharmonic are in the midst of a subscription series at Avery Fisher Hall in which the centerpiece of the program is Shostakovich's Symphony No. 8 (it had been announced as the same composer's Symphony No. 4, but was changed some time back). And on Friday, Sir Georg Solti and his Chicago Symphony arrived at Carnegie Hall with a program the centerpiece of which was, yes, Shostakovich's Symphony No. 8.

title: Getting People to Watch Stars
description: LEAD: IN an effort to broaden the attendance for the sky shows at the Andrus Planetarium at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers, Texaco and the United Way recently invited representatives of community and social-service organizations to the museum to acquaint them with the planetarium.

title: Romance Is as Romance Does
description: IS a glass of champagne more romantic than a mug of hot cocoa? I don't think so. That's why, when a writer friend recently interviewed me for her article on ''Keeping Romance Alive in Marriage,'' she was slightly disturbed at my answers.

title: THE DECADENCE OF A REMEMBERED WORLD
description: FORBIDDEN TERRITORY The Memoirs of Juan Goytisolo, 1931-1956. Translated by Peter Bush. 235 pp. San Francisco: North Point Press. $18.95.

title: DEBATING THE VIRTUES OF ART CAN ALTER THE CORPORATE CULTURE
description: Corporate art collections are proving to be valuable vehicles through which companies can communicate with their employees and even change the corporate culture.

title: Miss Toffey to Wed James Mauro in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. John J. Toffey 4th of Great Barrington, Mass., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Hannah Toffey, to James Christopher Mauro, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Mauro of Massapequa, L.I. A May wedding is planned.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Mount Lebanon, Pa.;
A $35 Million Indoor Mall
description: LEAD: FIRST CITY COMPANY, a Pittsburgh developer, is converting a former Kaufmann's department store into an indoor mall in this Pittsburgh suburb.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: 'Smarter' Office Buildings; Computers Now Do Less, But They Do It Better
description: AFTER creating a great first impression in the early 1980's, ''smart'' office buildings flunked real-life testing. Now less-grandiose strategies for computerized automation are reshaping the way buildings work.

title: Those Embarrassing Gaps On the President's Team
description: ''I AM fascinated by people who have never been players in the process running around trying to suggest that there is a much better way to do this than the way it's being done,'' said a senior White House official last week, bristling at the suggestion that the Bush Administration's A-team, chosen for its knowledge of how Washington works, has hit the ground at less than cruising speed.

title: Midwife Program Offers Promise
description: Hats off and kudos to the Suffolk County Department of Health and Community Hospital of Western Suffolk for bringing safe, available and competent prenatal care to hundreds of needy mothers-to-be [ ''Midwives Gaining L.I. Role,'' Jan. 22 ] .

title: Persistent Romantic Pursues a Fantasy
description: I HAVE been married to the same man for more than 40 years, so naturally you would assume that I have become resigned to his no-nonsense ways. Not so. I must confess that I have spent years trying to mold him into the Prince Charming of my romantic fantasies. A case in point is Valentine's Day.

title: Review/Rock; Gatton Visits, With Guitar
description: Very few things sound as archetypically American as the sound of a Fender Telecaster guitar abusing a Fender amplifier into hysterics. It's the sound of early rock, of harsh metallic blues, of the new music that changed the sound of American pop in the 1950's.

title: Celebration For a Famous Cent
description: IF ever a coin could be called endearing, the Lincoln cent earns the title hands down. Celebrating its 80th year, more than a quarter-trillion of the coins have been minted. Although it is known commonly as the penny that term is an anachronism from British colonial times.

title: The Bush Budget: Promises to Keep, Messes to Mop Up
description: FEDERAL budgets are pies of taxpayer money that the President and Congress slice up and pass around to aircraft builders, disabled miners, urban transit authorities and, directly or indirectly, to virtually all the other participants in the economy. Usually the pie grew from year to year, so that even less favored sectors and constituencies could get a little more than before.

title: For Good Books, Look Beyond the Best-Sellers
description: As a novelist whose five books have had respectable but not staggering sales, I cannot help but wish that Clayton Curtiss, in his essay, ''Parents Should Teach a Love of Books'' (Opinion Page, Jan. 15), had not concentrated exclusively on the best-seller list.

title: Herbert Stein's 'Modest Proposal' to Revise Budgeting
description: It is budget season in Washington and Herbert Stein, one of its veterans, has published a new book about budgeting that should make some of his friends wince. ''Governing the $5 Trillion Economy,'' (a Twentieth Century Fund essay, Oxford University Press) makes the case that the budget deficit is not the primary problem. Rather, it is that the United States needs to make better use of all its resources. As Mr. Stein put it at a recent luncheon in New York, George Bush was wrong when he said we had the will to spend but not the wallet. ''I think it is the other way around,'' said Mr. Stein. ''We have the wallet but not the will.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-25

title: Walker Wins One for His Father
description: Kenny Walker of the Knicks almost skipped today's Gatorade Slam-Dunk Contest at the Summit because his father died Wednesday. But he decided to participate, saying he would dedicate his performance to his father.

title: Playing His Songs
description: Some of the most memorable songs on Broadway this season were written by an all but forgotten lyricist, Andy Razaf. The American-born son of an Malagasy nobleman, Razaf wrote the words to more than 500 tunes, mostly in the 1920's and 30's, before he died in 1973. Among them are seven songs in the long-running ''Ain't Misbehavin' '' and five in the recently opened ''Black and Blue'' - including the title songs. The latter, with its refrain, ''What did I do to be so black and blue?'' is considered America's first racial protest song. His fans hope that Razaf's name will someday be as deeply embedded in the lexicon of American music as those of his chief collaborators - Fats Waller, Eubie Blake and W. C. Handy. One fan, the singer Bobby Short, recorded an album of Razaf songs in 1987. ''He is probably the most outstanding black lyricist we've ever had,'' said Mr. Short.

title: Outdoors; Birds for Shooting or Eating
description: Game birds, including pheasant, quail, mallard ducks, turkeys, chukar and Hungarian partridge, have been appearing on the menus of posh restaurants with greater frequency in recent years, according to Herbert Jordan, a poultry scientist with Pennsylvania State University.

title: The Long-Distance Lithuanian
description: On Friday, the day before his first long-distance shootout on foreign shores, Rimas Kourtinaitis, the mustachioed and innocently controversial Lithuanian guest of the National Basketball Association, was asked, ''Are you nervous?''

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FAMILY NATURE Since this is between seasons on the Sunday television front - you know, after football, but before Steinbrenner - it is a great time for some family togetherness in yet another area. Nature, for example. And the Environmental Centers of Setauket-Smithtown have just the program to fit the bill today: ''Dinosaurs for the Family.''

title: Kabul Accuses Pakistan of Planning Invasion; Afghans Take Over Bases
description: As the last Soviet military units in Afghanistan headed home, reports relayed from the front today by Soviet newspapers and television pictured an army that was rolling up like a carpet.

title: GOPHERS UPSET MICHIGAN BY 88-80
description: Willie Burton scored 5 of his 27 points during a 33-second span late in the game to put Minnesota ahead for good, and the Gophers continued their string of home upsets by beating 10th-ranked Michigan, 88-80, today.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: MOTHER'S GIRL. By Elaine Feinstein. (Dutton, $16.95.) In prose boiled down to its purest poetic essence, the British novelist and translator Elaine Feinstein tells a story about the irresolvable complications of storytelling. The book is a duet between Halina, the primary narrator, and her American half sister, Lucy, who come together at their father's funeral to compete, by reciting their disparate histories, over which memory of him should prevail.

title: BEST SELLERS: February 12, 1989
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 3 MIDNIGHT, by Dean R. Koontz. (Putnam, $19.95.) Inexplicable deaths and strange horrors take over a once idyllic California town. 2 2 13 THE SANDS OF TIME, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $19.95.) Four nuns become pawns in a struggle between the Spanish Army and Basque separatists. 3 3 4 RIVALS, by Janet Dailey. (Little, Brown, $18.95.) Feuding families compete in business and romance. 4 4 28 THE CARDINAL OF THE KREMLIN, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan races to the rescue of an American secret agent. 5 5 4 A SEASON IN HELL, by Jack Higgins. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) A young widow's quest for her stepson's killers leads to horrendous adventures across Europe. 6 6 3 MUTATION, by Robin Cook. (Putnam, $18.95.) A physician's attempt to create a superior child results in a prodigy that turns into a terror. 7 7 21 BREATHING LESSONS, by Anne Tyler. (Knopf, $18.95.) The many facets of a 28-year marriage are revealed during a drive to a friend's funeral. 8 9 5 THE LYRE OF ORPHEUS, by Robertson Davies. (Viking, $19.95.) The staging of an unfinished Hoffmann opera causes its participants to relive the legend of King Arthur. 9 12 3 A TWIST IN THE TALE, by Jeffrey Archer. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) Short stories set in a variety of locales and with surprising endings. 10 8 15 ONE, by Richard Bach. (Silver Arrow/Morrow, $17.95.) A couple find themselves in a fantasy world where the possibilities of their pasts still exist. 11 10 8 SPY HOOK, by Len Deighton. (Knopf, $18.95.) The agent Bernard Samson on the trail of a financial scam within the British secret service. 12 * 13 38 LOVE IN THE TIME OF CHOLERA, by Gabriel Garcia Marquez. (Knopf, $18.95.) A Colombian poet's perdurable love for a woman is tested by life's changing conditions. 13 11 17 THE QUEEN OF THE DAMNED, by Anne Rice. (Knopf, $18.95.) Continuing the chronicle of 6,000 years of vampirism begun in ''Interview With the Vampire'' and ''The Vampire Lestat.'' 14 15 33 ALASKA, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $22.50.) The history of the 49th state told in fictional form. 15 14 17 ANYTHING FOR BILLY, by Larry McMurtry. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) The exploits of Billy the Kid, as shared by a dime-novel writer. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction 1 2 3 BLIND FAITH, by Joe McGinniss. (Putnam, $21.95.) The family tragedy that came to light after the 1984 murder of a Toms River, N.J., woman. 2 1 15 ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert Fulghum. (Villard, $15.95.) Inspirational essays. 3 3 43 A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking. (Bantam, $18.95.) A scientist reviews efforts to create a unified theory of the universe. 4 4 13 GRACIE, by George Burns. (Putnam, $16.95.) The life of the comedian Gracie Allen, recalled by her widower and show business partner. 5 5 17 THE LAST LION, by William Manchester. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) The second volume of a biography of Winston Churchill, covering the years 1932-40. 6 6 5 PARTING THE WATERS, by Taylor Branch. (Simon & Schuster, $24.95.) The rise of the American civil rights movement under the leadership of Martin Luther King Jr. 7 11 8 ''WHAT DO YOU> CARE WHAT OTHER PEOPLE THINK?'' by Richard P. Feynman with Ralph Leighton. (Norton, $17.95.) Memoirs of the Nobel Prize-winning physicist. 8 7 14 CHILD STAR, by Shirley Temple Black. (McGraw- Hill, $19.95.) The former actress's autobiography. 9 8 16 A BRIGHT SHINING LIE, by Neil Sheehan. (Random House, $24.95.) A biography of Lieut. Col. John Paul Vann that is also a history of American involvement in Vietnam. 10 12 13 DON'T BEND OVER IN THE GARDEN, GRANNY, YOU KNOW THEM TATERS GOT EYES, by Lewis Grizzard. (Villard, $15.95.) Humor with a Southern accent. 11 10 2 LEGENDS, LIES, AND CHERISHED MYTHS OF AMERICAN HISTORY, by Richard Shenkman. (Morrow, $15.95.) An expose of tall tales that have become part of our national heritage. 12 9 18 THE FIRST SALUTE, by Barbara W. Tuchman. (Knopf, $22.95.) A historian's view of the American Revolution. 13 15 31 TALKING STRAIGHT, by Lee Iacocca with Sonny Kleinfield. (Bantam, $21.95.) More experiences and opinions of the Chrysler chairman. 14 * 13 16 GOLDWATER, by Barry M. Goldwater with Jack Casserly. (Doubleday, $21.95.) The memoirs of the longtime Senator from Arizona. 15 19 SENATORIAL PRIVILEGE, by Leo Damore. (Regnery Gateway, $19.95.) A reporter's reassessment of Chappaquiddick. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 84 THE 8-WEEK CHOLESTEROL CURE, by Robert E. Kowalski. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) How to lower your blood cholesterol level. 2 3 3 WEALTH WITHOUT RISK, by Charles J. Givens. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) A Florida entrepreneur's advice about how to make a personal fortune. 3 2 13 THE DICTIONARY OF CULTURAL LITERACY, by E. D. Hirsch Jr., Joseph F. Kett and James Trefil. (Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) An annotated list of ideas and facts ''Americans need to know.'' 4 41 SWIM WITH THE SHARKS WITHOUT BEING EATEN ALIVE, by Harvey Mackay. (Morrow, $15.95.) Strategies for succeeding in business. 5 5 16 WEBSTER'S NEW WORLD DICTIONARY. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) The Third College Edition of a standard work, revised in 1988. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 28,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) CAT'S EYE, by Margaret Atwood. (Doubleday, $18.95.) In Ms. Atwood's seventh and most emotionally engaging novel, the artist-narrator recalls her nightmarish youth with a crew of manipulative, tormenting older girls who try to remodel her from a child into an orthodox middle-class female. A TURN IN THE SOUTH, by V. S. Naipaul. (Knopf, $18.95.) The American South as seen through the eyes of a keen and astute traveler, himself a child of the hemisphere's planter culture. THE MEZZANINE, by Nicholson Baker. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $15.95.) No plot roils the depths of this strange, insightful, very funny little novel about the interior life of a man who worries about his interior life - complete with charts and equations. THE COMING SOVIET CRASH: Gorbachev's Desperate Pursuit of Credit in Western Financial Markets, by Judy Shelton. (Free Press, $22.50.) The author, a research fellow at the Hoover Institution, discusses the prospects for a Soviet Union that has been running enormous deficits and now faces the consequences. SEDUCTION BY LIGHT, by Al Young. (Seymour Lawrence/Delta Fiction, Paper, $7.95.) A sneaky, poetic novel in which the black experience meets the L.A. thing in the persons of a maid, her husband's ghost and a white Hollywood producer. FIVE SEASONS, by A. B. Yehoshua. (Doubleday, $19.95.) A best seller in Israel, where it was published in 1987, Mr. Yehoshua's vivid novel presents the love life of a good, sweet-tempered, dutiful civil servant whose wife has died just before the book begins. THE SATANIC VERSES, by Salman Rushdie. (Viking, $19.95.) Expatriation, exile, history and dreams mingle in this heady comic novel, which concerns two men from Bombay who, just for starters, fall out of an airliner and into England.

title: The Advertising That Commemorates Past Presidents Is No Honor
description: DEAR George and Abe:

title: Sarah Whiting Macdonald Is Married To H. G. Bissinger 3d in Massachusetts
description: Sarah Whiting Macdonald, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin Macdonald of Framingham, Mass., was married there yesterday at the First Parish Church to Harry Gerard Bissinger 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Gerard Bissinger 2d of New York. The Rev. Dr. Patrick T. O'Neill, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony.

title:
GARDENING;
It's Time To Think About Spring
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH snow had been forecast and a raw wind was rising out of the Northeast, the sign outside Sprainbrook Nursery, 448 Underhill Road in Scarsdale, N.Y. said, ''We're in Bloom! Daffodils, Tulips, Primulas!'' Inside, the scene was vibrant with the reds and yellows of tulips, the pinks of geraniums and the blues of cinerarias.

title: On Screen, a Kiss Is Still a Kiss
description: With Valentine's Day approaching, this is as good a time as any to point out that Cupid doesn't always shoot straight. Sometimes he creates star-crossed lovers of the sort that Hollywood adores, lovers who meet under the most inopportune circumstances imaginable. The couple in the 1963 LOVE WITH THE PROPER STRANGER (Paramount Home Video, $19.95), which is newly available on videocassette, are especially star-crossed, since the salesgirl (Natalie Wood) is already pregnant by the footloose musician (Steve McQueen) when the film begins. Otherwise, the interlude between them has not made much of an impression, but during the course of the story, they fall in love. There is much arm-waving and ethnic flavor in this forerunner to ''Moonstruck,'' which has both stars playing flamoyant Italian-American types. Cupid doesn't always cast right, either.

title: Portrait of a Gangster
description: To the Editor:

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: GOOD ROCKIN' TONIGHT. By William Hauptman. (Bantam, Paper, $7.95.) The playwright William Hauptman's first collection of stories, published as part of Bantam's New Fiction line, is set, for the most part, in his native Texas. And in a place where everything is purportedly larger than life, we might surely expect that the small and tangled moments of our days and ways will be easier to see, if not easier to understand.

title: Sex Charges Threaten Congressman's Career
description: Twenty years ago, Representative Donald E. (Buz) Lukens was a rising star in Ohio Republican politics, a man many envisioned as a future Governor or United States Senator.

title: Reviews/Dance; Western Abstraction Inspired by the East
description: Islene Pinder and her Balinese American Dance Theater presented a program of contemporary dance inspired by Balinese theater on Friday night at the Marymount Manhattan Theater. In her program notes, Ms. Pinder writes of attempting to produce a blend of Balinese theatricality and Western abstraction that will have a universal resonance. But the 10 pieces on the program hovered in some vague middle ground, looking tentative and diluted.

title: On A Shoestring, the Dedicated Keep Black History Alive
description: DURING most of the year, the door to the Connecticut Afro-American Historical Society is locked, and entrance is by appointment only. There is no money to hire someone to run the society. Instead, a handful of dedicated people volunteer their time - 10 to 20 hours a week each - so that the place can simply exist. It is the only collection of its kind in the state.

title: Stroessner Leaves Very Little Opposition
description: AS Gen. Alfredo Stroessner entered his fourth decade in power in 1984, the shadow of Cuba and Nicaragua - countries where rightist caudillos were swept away by Marxist revolutionaries -began to haunt Paraguay. Since he allowed no room for moderate opposition, it was argued, leftist extremism would inevitably appear here. And with no natural successor in sight, the post-Stroessner era became analogous to chaos.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I have a stall shower that has tiled walls up to the painted ceiling. Every two or three years this paint peels and flakes and we have to repaint. Is there a special paint I can use?

title: Dr. Sheryl Ann Ross Wed To Dr. Mitchell D. Becker
description: Dr. Sheryl Ann Ross, a resident in obstetrics and gynecology at the University of Southern California Medical Center in Los Angeles, and Dr. Mitchell Douglas Becker, a resident in internal medicine at the University of California at Los Angeles Medical Center, were married last evening at the Beverly Hills Hotel. Rabbi Ronald Shulman officiated.

title: A Merger Monitor
description: To the Editor:

title: Father Survives Ordeal at Sea
description: A Frenchman on a vacation fishing trip in the Caribbean was rescued after drifting 37 days across the Caribbean and watching his son die of thirst and hunger, the French Embassy said. The man, Fernand Samson, 36 years old, and his son Jeofere were off the island of Guadeloupe in a 19-foot motorboat when the motor went out on Dec. 30, said Federico Fajardo, a counselor with the French Embassy in Mexico City. News reports said the father subsisted on rainwater and fish. Mr. Fajardo said the father buried his son at sea. Fishermen from a village in Quintana Roo state in the Yucatan peninsula rescued Mr. Samson Feb. 4.

title: Amy Steinman Affianced
description: The engagement of Amy Steinman to Dr. Peter Mark Blauzvern, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Blauzvern of North Bellmore, L.I., has been made known by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Leon Steinman of Roslyn, L.I. Miss Steinman, a graduate of Boston University's School of Management, is an assistant media director at Ammirati & Puris, an advertising agency in New York. The future bridegroom, a dentist in Jericho, L.I., graduated from Drew University and the Dental Center of New York University. A May wedding is planned.

title: Fumes From Blocked Pipes Kill Four in a Chicago House
description: Blocked heater pipes spread deadly fumes through a house, killing four men and leaving a woman in critical condition, the authorities said Friday.

title: Reviews/Music; One Night in 'The Year of Russian Music'
description: The New York University Chamber Music Society has hit on an imposing format for its concerts this year. Six - the first of which was held at Merkin Hall Thursday night - will be given over to contemporary Soviet composition and are to bear a blanket title, ''The Year of Russian Music.''

title: Question Of the Week; Will Free Agency Work In Football?
description: The N.F.L. has opted to go for a field goal instead of a touchdown in the area of free agency. By protecting three-quarters of its roster players from being eligible for free agency, it has kept the stars on the sidelines. About the only players eligible will be expendable members of the kicking teams, plus the aged and the malcontents. Better than nothing, but not by much. REID GROSKY Astoria, Queens

title: Cutting Big Government, Round 2
description: Time and again during his eight years as President, Ronald Reagan depicted the Federal Government as a wasteful monster that needed to be cut down to size.

title: Pied Piper of Kennebunkport Goes for a Stroll
description: President Bush had planned to stay quietly at home today, going over some paperwork, chatting with Brent Scowcroft, his visiting national security adviser, and unpacking some boxes of winter clothes.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Tourist Rates To Go Up In China

title: Testing By State Draws Ire Of Health Aides
description: LEAD: BEDRIDDEN with arthritis so severe that even sitting up is an ordeal, Geraldine Mason is totally dependent on the homemaker-home health aide who comes to her apartment here each day. ''She is my hands and feet,'' Miss Mason said. ''Once she leaves, that's it.''

title: WHEN LIFE IS MOOT
description: THE AMORALISTS & OTHER TALES Collected Stories. By Cyrus Colter. 283 pp. New York: Thunder's Mouth Press. Cloth, $19.95. Paper, $10.95.

title: Sharpening Chisels and Planes
description: WOODWORKING chisels and at least one hand plane have a place in almost every household tool kit. However, if you own such tools, learning how to sharpen them is as important as learning how to use them. Dull cutting tools are ineffective. They are also dangerous because they require more effort to use than sharp tools and so are more difficult to control.

title: Breaking a Deadlock In Panama
description: On the face of it, there is complete deadlock. Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, Panama's strongman, has withstood U.S. efforts to strong-arm him out of power, and Washington isn't about to back down and accept him. But there is a whiff of deals being reconsidered.

title: Arkansan Sentenced to Die for Killing 14 Relatives
description: A 48-year-old man has been sentenced to death for the murder of 14 members of his family near this northwest Arkansas town a year ago.

title: AIDS Lessons Replace Tupperware at Parties
description: Faced with the increase in AIDS among minority groups, women here and elsewhere are turning an old concept, the Tupperware party, into a medium for sex education.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: DR. NINA S. EVANS;
Psychiatric Analysis of Winter's Gloom
description: LEAD: DOES winter weather give you the blahs? In most instances, when weather affects a person's mood the feeling is completely psychological; there is seldom a physical reason for the depression or weariness and such reactions last for short spells. But there is a small group of people who, scientists say, have a real physical reaction to the weather - specifically to the absence or presence of outside light.

title: Kabul Accuses Pakistan of Planning Invasion
description: President Najibullah accused Pakistan today of planning to invade Afghanistan with the intention of annexing the country.

title: A Hitch in Plans for Nuclear Posterity
description: IN the Nevada desert, geologists and engineers are beginning a task that will take decades, preparing an underground repository meant to isolate radioactive wastes for at least 10,000 years.

title: Israel Against Itself
description: ''Mr. Prime Minister, to achieve order in the casbah I have to act brutally toward people free of crime, too. I feel humiliated by this behavior. The situation has become a catastrophe. It's breaking us and strengthening the Arabs.'' - - Israeli soldier, when Prime Minister Shamir visited troops in the West Bank city of Nablus last month.

title: EVERYONE IS SOMEBODY'S CHILD
description: EQUAL AFFECTIONS By David Leavitt. 268 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $18.95.

title: Across the Seas The Game Is Popular
description: THE power center of bridge in Europe has been slowly moving North for the past two decades. In the 1950's and 1960's Italy, Britain and France regularly contended for the top honors in European Championships. Nowadays that threesome is still in the hunt, but the Poles and the Scandinavians frequently emerge with the medals.

title: Scientist Gets $20,000 From Foundation
description: Dr. Daniel Tranel, a neuroscientist at the University of Iowa College of Medicine, has been awarded a $20,000 grant from the Rita G. Rudel Foundation of New York City. The funds will support his research in the field of behavioral neurology.

title: MILLEN AND BLUES SHUT OUT ISLANDERS
description: Greg Millen stopped 33 shots for his sixth shutout of the season and Brett Hull had a goal and two assists, leading the St. Louis Blues to a 5-0 victory tonight over the Islanders.

title: 3 Governors in the South Join to Lift Their States
description: With their aggressive agendas, Ivy League pedigrees and boyish good looks, the young Governors of Mississippi, Arkansas and Louisiana have forged an alliance that is raising both their national visibility and that of their often lagging states.

title: Afghan Guerrillas Fight for the Limelight
description: After nine years of war in Afghanistan, most of the guerrilla groups have raised public relations to a fine art. Each of the seven guerrilla parties based in Pakistan has its own English-speaking press and political officer and issues English translations of its publications.

title: A Bibliophile Finds a Career in Books
description: Robert Snell's telephone caller wanted a book entitled ''Fakes.'' ''We'll try to find it,'' Mr. Snell told the caller. Then he answered the next call. ''Encylopedia of American Shipwrecks?'' he said. ''Sounds Interesting. We'll get right on it.

title: Orchestra to Play 4 Concerts in March
description: FAR and away the busiest orchestra in Westchester, the Philharmonia Virtuosi, presumably refreshed from its nearly two months of vacation, returns to plunge into the year with four county concerts this month - and two more in Manhattan in the same period.

title: From Minos To Motorbikes In Crete
description: HOMER referred to it as a ''land of 90 cities,'' but Crete today is an island of hundreds of villages and small towns. Of its fabled ''90 cities,'' only three remain, all on the north coast: Iraklion, the modern capital, a busy port city, sophisticated and self-conscious; Chania, to the west, in the shadows of the White Mountains overlooking Souda Bay, and between them, on a spit of rock that curves out into the Sea of Crete, Rethymnon, smaller and poorer than the others, but fiercely spirited, perhaps the best reflection of the complex mixture of past and present that is modern Crete.

title: Elizabeth H. Cohen, Art Consultant, To Wed Stephen M. McPherson Jr.
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Hansen Cohen to Stephen Mather McPherson Jr. has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Kip H. Cohen of Bristol, R.I., and Long Boat Key, Fla. Mr. McPherson is a son of Mrs. Gregory A. Sharp of Northford, Conn., and Fishers Island, N.Y., and Mr. McPherson of New York.

title: Seidman Wins One For the Banks
description: In the draconian $90 billion rescue of the savings industry, one person has clearly emerged as a victor.

title: South Africans Ban Protests In Support of 300 Prisoners
description: The Government today banned all protest meetings intended to show solidarity with 300 black detainees who are refusing food to protest being held without charge.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
When the Squeeze Is on, Raise the Roof
description: LEAD: A 45,000-SQUARE-FOOT warehouse in Albertson, occupied by Crockett & Buss, a carpet and flooring wholesaler, looks little different from other older industrial buildings that dot Long Island except that it stands, in part, nine feet higher than most of its 30-year-old contemporaries.

title: Holiday Tomorrow
description: Abraham Lincoln's birthday, actually today, will be observed tomorrow. Below are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Federal and state offices open, local offices closed. Post offices: Regular delivery. Banks: State-chartered banks have option to close; federally chartered banks open. Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation: No collections or street cleanings. Schools: Local option. Financial markets: Open. Transportation: Subways and buses, Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North on regular weekday schedule. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Federal offices open, state and local offices closed. Post offices: Regular delivery. Banks: Option to close. Schools: Local option. Transportation: N.J. Transit on regular weekday schedule. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Federal offices open, state and local offices closed. Post offices: Regular delivery. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: New Haven line on regular schedule.

title: Making the Point By Radio, Too
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
A Rocky Road to Success in Runnemede
description: LEAD: TEN years ago, Runnemede officials designated a hilly 78-acre tract at the northwestern edge of the borough as a special economic development district to attract commercial growth to their primarily residential Camden County community.

title: 'Romeo and Juliet' in Opera and Ballet
description: TWO Romeos with their Juliets, Summer Music in winter and Brahms are just a few of the highlights on this week's music calendar.

title: Communism Knew Diversity Before Gorbachev; Russian Peasant's Diet
description: To the Editor:

title: Syracuse Outruns Redmen
description: St. John's found out tonight just how much a healthy all-America point guard and a home crowd of more than 32,000 mean to the fortunes of the Syracuse Orangemen.

title: Communism Knew Diversity Before Gorbachev; For a New Vocabulary
description: To the Editor:

title: Alternatives To Incineration
description: I would like to clarify some points in ''Opening a New Era in Garbage Disposal'' [ Jan. 15 ] .

title: Two Boys Commit Suicide
description: Two despondent 15-year-old boys carved their own tombstones from plastic foam and wrote suicide notes, then fatally shot themselves in a wooded area near their homes, the authorities say. The bodies of the boys, Phillip Gomiser and David Olive, who disappeared a week ago, were found Wednesday night by Phillip's father. Jim Cappello, a classmate at Santaluces High School in Lantana, said Phillip and David talked openly of ending their lives since another classmate committed suicide several months ago.

title: Top Teams Sign Area Stars
description: When the list of high school players who signed letters of intent to play football at Division I-A colleges next fall came out last week, it was not surprising to find some of the best New York-area players going to some of the top-rated teams.

title: St. John's University Appoints New President
description: The president of Niagara University, the Very Rev. Donald J. Harrington, was chosen last week to be the next president of St. John's University. He will succeed the Very Rev. Joseph T. Cahill, who is completing almost 25 years as president of St. John's.

title: THE WORLD: Gorbachev's Summit; Another Warming, With Limits, For Beijing
description: AFTER Mao and Khrushchev bumped egos for the last time, during celebrations for the 10th anniversary of the People's Republic of China in 1959, the Chinese leader set a punitive schedule for relations between the world's two great Communist powers. The Soviet Union had earned 10,000 years of hostility from China, he is reported to have said, but he would allow a thousand years off for good behavior.

title: WHERE SHOULD BABY SLEEP?
description: Contemporary bed sharing might be regarded as an important social adaptation among families with working parents. Nesting in the family bed may be a way to find some of that elusive ''quality time'' as well as compensation for the separation that occurs during the day. FRANCES LEVINE THOMAS W. MERLAN Sante Fe, N.M.

title: Review/Dance; Richard Biles's Many Modes
description: Richard Biles enterprisingly choreographed big works and little, solos and ensembles, for the program his Richard Biles Dance Company presented Friday night at the Nikolais/Louis Choreospace. But only a few of those dances were theatrically effective.

title: A Station That's a Stop in Itself
description: DINING on grilled lobster in the splendid salon where President Kennedy once greeted Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethopia and President Roosevelt received King George VI and Queen Elizabeth of England. Or shopping and browsing for one-of-a-kind works of art and jewelry in a setting of Romanesque columns and Pompeiian frescoes.

title: Amy D. Wardell Engaged to Wed G. D. Iverson 6th
description: Mr. and Mrs. John M. Wardell of Bay Head, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Amy Dickenson Wardell, to George Dudley Iverson 6th, a son of Ellen B. MacNeille of Chevy Chase, Md., and Mr. Iverson 5th of Washington. The couple plan to marry in April.

title: 'I WALK IN DIGNITY'
description: LEAD: PAUL ROBESON A Biography. By Martin Bauml Duberman. Illustrated. 804 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95.

title: Yes, Socrates, Ethics Can Be Taught
description: The corporate and Wall Street communities are wrestling not only with the issue of profitability, but also with the more difficult and subtle issue of ethical behavior. A number of tools have been designed to bring ethics to the forefront of business development training.

title: Kendo: Rising From a Samurai Tradition
description: ROBED, barefoot figures with faces shielded. Respectful bowing, advancing and striking. Shouted expressions of self-mastery and spirit. All this is part of kendo, the Japanese martial art with roots in the samurai tradition.

title: Miss Heikkenen, Science Teacher, Becomes a Bride
description: Christine Nell Heikkenen and William Fletcher Ludington Jr. were married yesterday at Castle McCulloch, a historic site in Jamestown, N.C., by the Rev. Dr. Robert Cook, an Episcopal priest.

title: Flimsy Excuses
description: THE SOCK DRAWER was a large drawer to the right of our kitchen sink, just below the knives and forks and next to the junk drawer. It was my mother's solution to the laundry. The name was a euphemism, for, although it did house the entire family's abandoned mateless socks, its chief function was to contain the underpants of the female offspring. The drawers drawer, if you will. But we were of Irish descent and reticent in certain areas, and so we called it the sock drawer. Or was the name simply due to the number of syllables in underpants as against socks? (We would never have shortened it to panties! We hated the word panties. It has connotations.) There were 10 children, so to avoid total chaos, my mother liked to have a system when she could. For her laundry system, she set up metal shelving in the cellarway and affixed our names to it with masking tape. She put each child's pile of folded clean clothes above the name. You were responsible for emptying your pile. If you didn't, it got quite high, in inverse proportion to the contents of your bureau. Paul, for example, almost never emptied his pile. ''Empty your pile!'' my mother would yell at him in frustration. A lost article of clothing would invariably be discovered weeks later at the bottom of an unemptied pile.

title: Rabbi Samarious Gourary, 91, an Educator
description: Rabbi Samarious Gourary, the executive director for the past 48 years of United Lubavitcher Yeshivoth, the educational arm of the Lubavitcher Hasidim, died after a brief illness at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center yesterday. He was 91 years old and lived in Montclair, N.J.

title: Deal Seen on Smaller U.N. Force for Namibia
description: The five permanent members of the Security Council appear to have succeeded in reducing the size and cost of the peacekeeping force the United Nations will send to Namibia this spring, diplomats said Friday.

title: New Order Keeps Marching to Its Own Mystery
description: How cool is coldness? For the British band New Order, near ly a decade of cold standoffishness, musically and otherwise, has paid off with one of rock's most dedicated cult followings. New Order songs have become standards for college radio stations and rock dance clubs and moved on to more commercial outlets; despite a stage presence best described as efficient, New Order concerts are dependable sellouts. With a poker-faced public image and deadpan music, New Order proves that playing hard to get still works in the 1980's - especially when the message behind the enigma assures fans of their own superior individuality.

title: Samuel Constant, 94, Retired Colonel, Dies
description: Samuel Victor Constant, a retired colonel in the United States Army, died of pneumonia Thursday at DeWitt Army Hospital in Ft. Belvoir, Va. He was 94 years old and had moved recently to Alexandria, Va., after living in Manhattan.

title: 'Confronting the Third World'
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpts From the Federal Judge's Ruling
description: Following are excerpts from a preliminary ruling by Judge Jack B. Weinstein of Federal District Court in Brooklyn in the civil racketeering case against the Long Island Lighting Company:

title: Correction
description: A picture caption last week with an article about Citicorp misidentified the executives pictured with the chairman, John S. Reed. The photograph showed, left to right: Richard S. Braddock, head of the consumer bank; Michael A. Callen, in charge of the investment bank, and Lawrence M. Small, head of the corporate bank.

title: Utz the Utzer
description: To the Editor:

title: For Afghans, Bickering and Sadness
description: Not long ago, after the Soviet troops had gone, Mohammad Sadiq went back to the village in Afghanistan where he was born. The setting bestowed on it by nature and the structures built by men had been reduced to desolation.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Suffocated by the Public Gaze

title: In 'Sly Fox,' Greed Is Timeless
description: A GOOD play can withstand a battery of assaults by the combined theatrical cannons of inept direction, poor acting, incompetent set designers and audience members who have uncontrollable urges to crinkle cellophane-wrapped candy. In some cases, it can even stand up to bizarre translations and wacky adaptations.

title: Call North Not Patriot Or Felon, but Dupe
description: To the Editor:

title: Carolyn Haibt to Wed Edward Norton in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Luther H. Haibt of Katonah, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Carolyn Mitchell Haibt, to Edward Colburn Norton, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard A. Norton of Hingham, Mass. An October wedding is planned.

title: Caroline Lowrey Engaged
description: The engagement of Martha Caroline Lowrey to Thomas John Luz, a son of Mrs. Alan J. McCartney of Chestnut Hill, Mass., and John J. Luz of Amesbury, Mass., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Walter B. Lowrey of New Orleans. The couple plan to marry in April.

title: Tower Gave Varying Statements on Work for Aircraft Concern
description: John G. Tower said in a divorce deposition in 1987 that he advised a unit of British Aerospace about commercial aviation sales and about the sale of military systems to the Pentagon, according to Administration officials. But last month he gave a statement to the Senate saying he could not ''recall'' any military work for British Aerospace.

title: About Cars; '89 Thunderbird Is Something Special
description: Thirty-four years ago, I lived in the Wil-Mar trailer court in Allentown, Pa., and the guy across the way was the service manager for Dahl Ford. I had bought a car from him, a '48 Mercury, and I thought it was the sexiest thing on wheels.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Beverly Hills, Calif.;
A New Look For a Queen
description: LEAD: THE original Beverly Wilshire Hotel reopened for guests this month after a two-year, $68 million renovation.

title: Sihanouk Is Reported Returning to Coalition
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk has decided to resume his post as president of the Cambodian coalition fighting the Vietnamese occupation forces, Thailand's Foreign Minister said today.

title: Hungary's Party Compromises on View of Uprising
description: The Communist Party Central Committee today endorsed a compromise to end a leadership dispute over whether the 1956 Hungarian uprising, which was crushed by the Soviet Army, was a popular uprising or a counterrevolution.

title: ANJELICA RISING: Stardom for Another Huston
description: ANJELICA HUSTON PAUSED AND STUDIED a charcoal drawing of a woman in profile. The scene was the Metropolitan Museum of Art; the 37-year-old actress was taking an afternoon off from working on Woody Allen's latest movie to see the Degas show. The drawing was of a handsome, dark-haired, strong-featured woman with a long, aristocratic nose. The handsome, dark-haired, strong-featured Huston smiled. ''Great nose,'' she said.

title: Resort Owner Is a Maverick Of the Slopes
description: At the start of this winter's ski season, when most of Vermont's ski areas were vying for honors like the fastest lift, Mad River Glen announced: ''Two thousand bales of hay were spread over the trails to induce and create top soil on the steepest part of the trails.

title:
HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: FAST FORWARD;
A Jump on The Oscars for Stay-at-Homes
description: LEAD: Nineteen eighty-eight was a big year for Tom Hanks, whose performance as a suddenly grown-up kid in ''Big'' is likely to earn him an Academy Award nomination when the list is announced on Wednesday. For filmgoers who missed the movie's theatrical run but want to be in the know on Oscar night - March 29 - ''Big'' will appear on home video on March 23 (CBS/Fox, $89.98).

title: Taking the Guilt Out of Sweets
description: MANY people like sugar, but too many people feel guilty about consuming it, the Sugar Association believes.

title: Tire Trouble
description: After spending hundreds of thousands of dollars to develop a radial tire for the Nascar circuit, Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company has had to admit that the tires are just not up to speed.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: TIFFANY EXHIBIT

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
PRISONERS OF WAR IN THEIR LAND
description: LEAD: In 1942 the United States Government issued the first in a series of orders that incarcerated 120,000 nisei (citizens of Japanese descent) in concentration camps throughout the Western states. They had committed no crime; rather, they were victims of deep-rooted racism that reached a hysterical pitch following the bombing of Pearl Harbor.

title: Red Baron Wasn't Downed From the Air
description: To the Editor:

title: From Rowing Machines to Tiny Lights
description: The design of products has been recognized as a major competitive resource by the Europeans and the Japanese for years. Product design is not only appearance, but also - and just as important - the ease with which the product is understood, used and serviced. The product also represents the company. The product, its packaging and presentation, are strong elements in any company's identity.

title: Philipsburg Manor Restores the Song of a Water Wheel
description: INCH by inch, the fallen tree was crafted into a four-ton white oak shaft to drive the gristmill at Philipsburg Manor here. Soon the song of the water wheel at the Upper Mills will be heard once more on the Pocantico River, where a replica of an 18th-century mill demonstrates the power of falling water.

title: Romantic Evening For Dining
description: LEAD: ''WITHOUT bread and wine, Venus will starve,'' goes the translation of a Latin proverb, and many New Jersey restaurants are offering special Valentine's Day dinners for two on Tuesday to assure that both romance and the goddess of love will be well nourished.

title: Years of Performance Make An Impressive Bottom Line
description: Exactly 15 years ago tonight, a club called the Bottom Line opened its doors at Mercer and Fourth Streets in lower Manhattan. It's still there, going strong, and its adaptability and sheer survival prompts some reflections on the institution of the pop-music club.

title: Making a Safe Exit in an Airplane Emergency
description: YOU know those cardboard sheets in airline seat pockets - the ones with pictures of the life jacket and oxygen mask and diagrams of exit doors? I now read them with a lot more interest and even put a book down and watch the flight attendants' talk with something like curiosity.

title: Robert Klugman And Ms. Rattner To Wed June 30
description: The engagement of Bonnie Hope Rattner and Robert Alan Klugman has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Michael Rattner of Wheatley Heights, L.I. Mr. Klugman is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Klugman of New Rochelle, N.Y. A June 30 wedding is planned.

title:
INVESTING;
More Than One Way to Stay Liquid
description: LEAD: In recent months, there has been an extraordinarily large amount of uncertainty about the courses of interest rates, the economy and the stock and bond markets. As a result, many experts have been recommending that investors keep a substantial portion of their money in liquid investments. While money market funds are one option, they are not the only one.

title: One Day at a Time
description: A NEW building for adolescent alcohol and drug abusers that will have all the equipment, treatment, schooling and resident experts that their physical, mental and behavioral disorders will require is under construction at South Oaks Hospital.

title: POSTINGS: 12-Shop Complex; From Art Deco to Arcade
description: The Strand Theater, an Art Deco cinema in downtown Summit, N.J., dark for about five years, is being redeveloped into a 12-store shopping arcade. The 40,000-square-foot building is scheduled to open this spring, according to Peter Kalkus, president of the Lamar Companies of Morristown, N.J., which is undertaking the $10 millon project.

title: BUD MCFARLANE: SEMPER FI
description: As counsel to Robert McFarlane, I find much that is objectionable in Brock Brower's article ''Bud McFarlane: Semper Fi.'' (Jan. 22).

title: Fielding Debits For Strawberry
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: 4 Types of Agencies Providing Health Aides
description: LEAD: There are four types of agencies that provide homemaker-home health aids in New Jersey:

title: Setting the Record Straight
description: To the Editor:

title: SPIES & THRILLERS
description: Diamonds are what Gerald A. Browne knows about, and diamonds are what he writes best about, starting with the spectacular caper he dreamed up for ''11 Harrowhouse'' in 1972. In his latest book, HOT SIBERIAN (Arbor House/Morrow, $19.95), the subject again is diamonds - but this time Russian diamonds.

title: Varied Causes, Many Parties
description: Scholarship Benefit

title: Review/Music; Athleticism and Poetry Spar at the Piano
description: The program Anne-Marie McDermott chose for her Wednesday evening piano recital at Alice Tully Hall was neatly divided between the athletic and the poetic, and was offered in that order.

title: In a Late-Night Sport, the Game Is Fighting Crime
description: G. Van Standifer chose a Tuesday night in June 1986 for the debut of his Midnight Basketball League, a summer program to get young men off the streets and into the gym. But he did not choose the weather. It was sweltering.

title: Respect the Fears Of Children
description: Carl Bosch is understandably distressed at his 6-year-old daughter's awareness and fear of terrorism, following the crash of Pan Am Flight 103 (''What Do You Tell Children About Terrorism,'' Opinion page, Jan. 15). So what does he do about it? He compounds the terror and brings the fear straight home by insisting that she fly with her parents, against her will, to that ''shrine of childhood, Disney World.''

title: It's a Compelling Ghost, And It Sings in Hebrew
description: Ira Levin, who scared us to death with ''Rosemary's Baby,'' ''The Boys From Brazil'' and ''Deathtrap,'' has come up with a new supernatural twist: a play about a ghost that doesn't go ''Boo!'' but instead chants in Hebrew.

title: Carolyn Trepel Marries
description: Carolyn Anne Trepel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Trepel of Belle Harbor, Queens, and Robert Fain, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sigmund Fain of Brooklyn, were married yesterday at Temple Sholom of Mill Basin in Brooklyn. Rabbi Avner German performed the ceremony. Mrs. Fain, a special-education teacher at Public School 279 in Brooklyn, graduated from Brooklyn College, as did her husband, who also received an M.B.A. from Pace University. Mr. Fain is a consultant to the United States Treasury Department in New York.

title: A New Order Stays in the Wings in South Africa
description: FREDERIK W. DE KLERK, who succeeded P. W. Botha as the new leader of South Africa's governing National Party, rose in Parliament last week to assume the mantle of an ailing leader and call for new thinking.
