He envisioned ''a South Africa free of domination or oppression in whatever form,'' declared his party ''against domination of any one group by others,'' and added: ''White domination, insofar as it exists, must go.''

title: Suspected I.R.A. Member Arrested With Fake Bills
description: A man who Federal officials say is a member of the Irish Republican Army is being held on charges of carrying $13,500 in counterfeit $50 bills at La Guardia Airport, where he was arrested last week.

title: WAS THERE LIFE AFTER PERCY?
description: MARY SHELLEY Romance and Reality. By Emily W. Sunstein. Illustrated. 478 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $24.95.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Boston;
111 New Rentals For Roxbury
description: LEAD: ALL but three of the 111 apartments in a private development just completed in the poor, predominantly black and Hispanic Roxbury neighborhood were occupied by late last week despite the fact that three-quarters of the units are going for nearly market rents.

title: BIGGER JAPAN ROLE SEEN IN THE I.M.F.
description: Additional resources for the International Monetary Fund and a bigger role for Japan in the 151-nation lending agency were projected this week by the chairman of its policy-making Interim Committee, Finance Minister H. Onno Ruding of the Netherlands.

title: Bike to the Future
description: ''THE ASSIGNMENT,'' SAYS C. Martin Smith, ''was to design a two-wheeled bicycle. The design was to be market-driven. That is, students would first identify an area of the market,'' and then tailor a design to it. Standard homework, perhaps, for students of industrial design. But Smith, associate chairman of the industrial design department at Art Center College of Design, in Pasadena, Calif., says: ''We felt there was an opportunity to change the way a bicycle was manufactured.''

title: NONFICTION
description: AMERICA. By Jean Baudrillard. Translated by Chris Turner. (Verso, $24.95.) Tourists, beware. Although the French philosopher Jean Baudrillard has drawn inspiration from his travels around the United States, and has included verbal snapshots of New York City and Los Angeles, Monument Valley and Salt Lake City, his illustrated book contains little in the way of travel writing - that is, the sights, sounds and textures of daily life. Instead, Mr. Baudrillard's goal is to define what he calls ''astral America, not social and cultural America . . . but the America of desert speed, of motels and mineral surfaces.'' He escorts the reader through an abstract nation, one elaborately draped around a handful of leitmotifs - space, speed, cinema, technology and, most of all, the desert. In the deserts of the Southwest, Mr. Baudrillard detects an essential American emptiness, a ''brilliant, mobile, superficial neutrality, a challenge to meaning and profundity.'' What's more, he characterizes the desert as this country's ''primal scene,'' the taproot of its culture, politics and even its sexuality. But here, as at various other points throughout his densely composed text (fluently translated by Chris Turner), Mr. Baudrillard will leave most American readers rubbing their eyes with disbelief: his astral America has jumped the rails from hermetic to solipsistic to nonsensical. The author has been canny enough to prepare an escape hatch for these occasions. ''Perhaps,'' he admits, after advancing one ticklish thesis, ''this is merely the crazy notion of a European, a fascination with an unreal America.'' A mixture, in fact, of crazy notions and dead-on insights, ''America'' is a valuable (and voluble) picture of what Mr. Baudrillard calls ''the only remaining primitive society'' - ours.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: The Dec. 18 article ''Two Lives on Hold,'' by William Squadron, husband of Dr. Joan Longer, described the heart-lung transplant undergone by Dr. Longer, in July 1987, to correct the ravages of cystic fibrosis. Dr. Longer died on Jan. 19 in Papworth Hospital, Cambridgeshire, England, from the consequences of organ rejection.

title: A Break for Parking Scofflaws
description: People guilty of parking violations here would no longer be considered criminals and threatened with arrest if the City Council approves a proposal by Mayor W. Wilson Goode.

title: OUR MONEY IS ON THE WAITER
description: THE EDGE By Dick Francis 324 pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $18.95.

title: Q and A
description: Copper Canyon

title: Pretoria Medical Policy Faulted in Detainee Death
description: A long investigation into the death in detention of a black youth leader two years ago has again pointed up the lack of medical attention given political detainees.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: BIOGRAPHICAL BOON Scholars, students and the public may avail themselves of an unusual collection of 15,000 biographical books recently donated to the Manhattanville College Library in Purchase by Emery Allain of Greenwich. Mr. Allain, retired chief financial officer of Great Northern Nekoosa paper company, collected biographies as a hobby. The huge collection is still in cartons stacked in the library's corridors and rooms, awaiting cataloguing. ''It will take about four years to do the job,'' said Edward O'Hara, the library director, ''but we are trying to make the books accessible now by temporarily arranging them alphabetically by the subject's name.'' There are 200 biographies on Winston Churchill alone, and five cartons of Franklin Delano Roosevelt, he noted, explaining that Mr. Allain sought out biographies of people he admired, ''but he rarely read them; his interest was in hunting them down.''

title: Doctors Perform Abortion On Comatose L.I. Woman
description: A team of doctors here performed an abortion today on a comatose Long Island woman, ending a bitter two-week court battle between the woman's family and opponents of abortion.

title: Dali's Gift to Spain: No Homage to Catalonia
description: Salvador Dali's last joke is reverberating across Spain, sowing the kind of consternation and dissension that the Surrealist master succeeded in creating so successfully in his lifetime.

title: NEW &NOTEWORTHY
description: LIVES OF THE TWINS, by Rosamond Smith. (Avon, $3.95.) After Molly Marks moves in with her psychotherapist, she embarks on a secret affair with his estranged identical twin. Written pseudonymously by Joyce Carol Oates, this is ''a marvelous metaphysical novel,'' Susan Fromberg Schaeffer said here last year. ''The use of a pseudonym oddly clarifies the novel's concerns - the pressing need both for a double (or soul-mate) and for a unique viewing, a new look at a face we think we already know.'' THE TRIAL OF SOCRATES, by I. F. Stone. (Anchor/Doubleday, $9.95.) For almost two decades, I. F. Stone was editor and publisher of I. F. Stone's Weekly, a oneman effort to expose all that he found venal about Washington politics. Late in life, he retired from the enterprise and immersed himself in the world of Golden Age Greece, trying to understand how the Athenian democrats he so admired could have put Socrates to death. Last year our reviewer, Julia Annas, said that Socrates was not the enemy of democracy that Mr. Stone has made him out to be. But she called the book ''a noble and urgent 20th-century reflection on an ancient theme'': the danger that a supposedly free society will answer its critics by betraying its very ideals of free expression. MONGOOSE, R.I.P., by William F. Buckley Jr. (Dell, $4.50.) Recruited to help assassinate Fidel Castro, the Central Intelligence Agency operative Blackford Oakes uncovers a counterplot to kill President John F. Kennedy and launch a nuclear missile at the United States. This novel, the eighth in the Blackford Oakes series, is ''a remarkably complex, compelling and literate thriller,'' Robin W. Winks said in The Book Review last year. William F. Buckley Jr. ''gives us his best book - fiction or nonfiction.'' THE FORBIDDEN ZONE, by Michael Lesy. (Anchor/Doubleday, $7.95.) Taking personal journalism to an extreme, Michael Lesy kills a steer at a slaughterhouse and lets himself be strapped into an electric chair, all to learn what it is like to make one's livelihood dealing routinely with death. ''Mr. Lesy does indeed venture to places few of us have ever glimpsed,'' Lis Harris said here in 1987, ''and he forces himself to confront the worst they have to offer.'' FIRE LAKE, by Jonathan Valin. (Dell, $3.50.) Late one night, the Cincinnati private eye Harry Stoner is called to a motel where his old college roommate has tried to commit suicide. In 1987, The Book Review's Newgate Callendar called the author ''an expert writer who provides coherent plots and believable dialogue.'' FEARFUL SYMMETRY: The Search for Beauty in Modern Physics, by A. Zee. (Collier/Macmillan, $9.95.) In trying to divine a pure crystalline order beneath life's seemingly erratic surface, theoretical physicists look for abstract mathematical patterns they call symmetries. In The Book Review in 1987, Ronald Kahn called this ''the first popular book to specifically focus on the search for beauty in physics, and it has no competitors.'' FAMILY LIFE, by Mary Elsie Robertson. (Penguin, $8.95.) During an annual family vacation on Nantucket, Philip Sloan, an anthropologist, leaves the family cottage to move in with his lover. Writing in The Book Review in 1987, Patricia Mandell said this novel ''insightfully portrays the inexorable and irreversible deterioration of a family.'' AND WE ARE NOT SAVED: The Elusive Quest for Racial Justice, by Derrick Bell. (Basic, $9.95.) Using two fictional narrators, a black civil rights worker and her colleague, Derrick Bell explores America's failure to achieve true racial justice. The result is ''a fascinating and provocative contribution to the continuing search for a more perfect union,'' Vincent Harding said here in 1987. Basic Books has also reprinted IF I HAD A HAMMER . . . : The Death of the Old Left and the Birth of the New Left, by Maurice Isserman ($8.95). In the book, a historian of radical politics argues that the 1960's campus revolt was not a cataclysm but rather a continuation of the leftist undercurrents of the supposedly docile Eisenhower years. ''Mr. Isserman takes us through the tangled jungles of leftist politics in the 50's and 60's,'' Gus Tyler said here in 1987. ''For veterans of those days of rage, his diligent narrative will evoke nostalgia and nausea, a glad-sad remembrance of scenes on the barricades.'' THE TALLULAH BANKHEAD MURDER CASE, by George Baxt. (International Polygonics, $5.95.) The actress is joined by Dorothy Parker and Lillian Hellman in a murder mystery set amid the Red Scare of the 1950's. The novel ''sketches deft parallels between the paranoia induced by a serial killer and the mania generated by McCarthy-era blacklisting,'' one reviewer said last year. THE TIES THAT BOUND: Peasant Families in Medieval England, by Barbara A. Hanawalt. (Oxford University, $8.95.) A historian finds remarkable parallels between families in medieval times and today. ''One comes away from this stimulating book with [ a ] sense of wonder,'' David Levine said here in 1986. THE ALL-GIRL FOOTBALL TEAM, by Lewis Nordan. (Vintage, $5.95.) In Arrow Catcher, Miss., a boy and his mother escape the weird life around them by creating a fantasy world based on characters in the Sears, Roebuck catalogue. In this and other stories, Lewis Nordan shows a ''distinctive gift for blending the grotesque and the ordinary,'' Ursula Hegi said here in 1986.

title: Brawley Case Details Sought
description: The New York Daily News asked the State Supreme Court in Manhattan Friday to force a special prosecutor, Charles J. Hynes, to disclose details of his inquiry into the source of a disclosure to The New York Times in the Tawana Brawley case last year. Mr. Hynes said in January that he could not establish how The Times obtained summaries of evidence in the case. A grand jury found that the black Dutchess County teen-ager had fabricated her account of a four-day abduction and sexual abuse by white men in November 1987.

title: Cards Send Another Valuable Message
description: YOU might want to take a closer look at any Valentine you receive or send this year. There could be more there than the message - there could be a hedge against inflation.

title: Review/Music; New Voice in Met's 'Castle'
description: Jessye Norman took half the night off at the Metropolitan Opera on Wednesday, relinquishing the role of Judith in Bartok's ''Bluebeard's Castle'' but appearing as usual in ''Erwartung,'' the Schoenberg monodrama that fills out this new double bill.

title: Playing Baseball As a Group
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: DATA UPDATE: February 12, 1989
Justice Is a Defense Against Terrorists
description: Sharon L. Bass's interview with Caroline O. Dinegar (Connecticut Q&A, Jan. 15) brings out an all too typically skewed view of what the overused word ''terrorism'' means and who practices it.

title: Peggy Koch Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert N. Koch Jr. of New York and East Orleans, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Peggy A. Koch to Briggs S. Palmer Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Palmer of Fort Myers, Fla. A September wedding is planned. Ms. Koch, a freelance film production coordinator, graduated from the Nightingale Bamford School and the University of Vermont. Her father is the chairman of the board of R. N. Koch Inc., a costume-jewelry manufacturer in New York and Providence, R.I.

title: As the Eastern Front Softens, A New Skepticism About Bonn
description: AS Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d tours Western Europe this week, he is scheduled to divide his time equally among the 14 members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. But schedules can be deceiving. If the trip were organized not on the basis of protocol, but on the basis of which NATO country was most preoccupying the Bush Administration, then Mr. Baker would probably be visiting 13 countries in one day and spending the rest of the week in West Germany.

title: A Stranger in a Strange Land
description: On the morning of Jan. 4, 1945, an Englishwoman in her mid-30's walked up the stone steps of a grim office building in the Prinz Albrechtstrasse in Berlin to offer herself for interrogation by the Gestapo.

title:
INVESTING;
Baby Food Nourishes Gerber
description: LEAD: With baby boomers still having babies and with prepared food growing popular again with mothers, the Gerber Products Company's profits and stock prices have been soaring. But although the baby-food maker's stock is trading on the New York Stock Exchange at about $61, near its 52-week high of $63.50 and far above its 52-week low of $34.25, some analysts believe it has not peaked.

title: Question Of the Week; Will Free Agency Work In Football?
description: The free agency will do to football what it did to baseball: It will make millionaires out of mediocre players. Big-city teams with big-city budgets will become a collection of overpriced underachievers. Owners will be tried and found guilty of collusion in an effort to stop the bidding madness. And the fans will enjoy it all from their $500 seats, while waving their $25 programs, eating their $15 hotdogs, and sipping their $5 sodas. STEPHEN OSTROW New York

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Amid Blue Hens, Buffalo Roam

title: Ojai, Calif.
description: To the Editor: Milena Jovanovitch (''California's Tranquil Ojai Valley,'' Travel, Nov. 6) has fulfilled one of my fondest dreams, that of returning to my former home. In such fully detailed descriptions did she so aptly convey the soul of the Ojai Valley that I was permitted once again to savor the experience of that wonderful place. Thankfully, it seems that the valley's essence has been preserved despite growth. CHRISTINE COVELLI Santa Fe, N.M.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE MEMOIRS OF MARGARET S. MAHLER. Edited by Paul E. Stepansky. (Free Press, $17.95.) In her ''Memoirs,'' Margaret S. Mahler, the Vienna-trained child psychoanalyst and pediatrician who died in 1985 at the age of 88, reveals as much by what is unstated as by what is said. Paul E. Stepansky, a research associate at the Cornell University Medical College, has compiled and edited Mahler's notes and transcripts of what she deemed the essence of her life.

title: Reuse of Old Buildings Deserves Consideration
description: The new use of old historic buildings is a wonderful idea. It allows people to enjoy the beauty of architectural landmarks in different and creative ways. In the article ''Stamford's Old Town Hall May Have a Future in Art'' (Jan. 22), where the proposal to convert a virtually empty landmark edifice into a museum is discussed, is a plan which deserves serious consideration.

title: To U.S., Afghanistan Seems to Move Farther Away
description: FOR the United States, the word Afghanistan once evoked obscurity. One of the world's most isolated countries, it has no railways, no navigable rivers, no outlet to the sea, few natural resources and a history notable primarily for its turbulence. Before the Soviet occupation nine years ago, the United States imported little more than sheepskins and carpets from Afghanistan in exchange for American cigarettes, fertilizer and used clothing.

title: Clan Consciousness
description: To the Editor:

title:
ART;
N. C. Wyeth, Patriarch
description: LEAD: FOLLOWING the exhibition of murals painted by N.C. Wyeth for the Metropolitan Life Assurance Society, the Heckscher Museum in Huntington is presenting a further examination of Mr. Wyeth as the patriarch of a dynasty that includes seven other artists in the two succeeding generations.

title: Rhode Island Resident Convicted in Snipings
description: A Superior Court jury convicted Peter T. Trepanier today on 27 counts stemming from sniper attacks that terrorized northern Rhode Island two winters ago.

title: Curbs Easing, Cuba Expects A Papal Visit
description: Roger Cardinal Etchegaray, a special envoy from the Vatican, turned away from the altar toward the hundreds of people crowded into the Cathedral of Havana and asked what message he should take back to the Pope.

title: WHERE SHOULD BABY SLEEP?
description: Melvin Konner does not take into account that, in 1989, the term ''parents'' frequently refers to one natural parent and one stepparent. My own memories of blissfully drifting into sleep with my mother and father at age 4 stand in contrast to recollections of being placed in bed between my divorced father and his new wife just three years later. ABIGAIL MEISEL New York, N.Y.

title:
GARDENING;
Time for Seeding Is Drawing Near
description: LEAD: THE myth of the groundhog notwithstanding, it is a good bet that wintry weather will remain at least another four to six weeks. Yet the time to prepare for spring planting is drawing close. Fast-growing seedlings like tomatoes and marigolds can become tall and lanky if sown too early. But plants like pansies and perennials and slow growers like celosia, impatiens, coleus, geraniums and vincas should be sown right away if they are to be large enough to plant at the correct time.

title: AND NOW, A WORD FROM OUR CREATOR
description: An enlightened contemporary minister of a Protestant church in an upscale academic community is about to enjoy a dinner his wife is preparing on the backyard charcoal grill, when he - a somewhat aloof intellectual graduate of Yale Divinity School - is shaken and disturbed by this experience he neither expects nor wants. It turns his comfortable world upside down, threatening his marriage and, ironically, his career. It is the beginning of a skillfully written first novel, published last year, Peggy Payne's ''Revelation,'' which is one of a growing number of new literary works in which God - who for so long seemed absent if not ''dead'' as a subject of concern in serious fiction, as in the culture at large - has returned as a force or a ''character'' in the action.

title: Lesbian Parents Prove to Be in No Way Inferior
description: To the Editor:

title: Decision on Tower as Elusive as Facts
description: Nearly eight weeks after President Bush named John G. Tower as his choice for Secretary of Defense, the Senate Armed Services Committee is divided, largely along partisan lines, over whether the former Texas Senator should be confirmed.

title: Behind the Awesome S.A.T., A Company With a Product
description: The Educational Testing Service, whose tests have helped shape the lives of tens of millions of Americans, is often thought of as an impenetrable and awe-provoking institution on the lines of, say, Fort Knox or the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: The Lure of Educational Houses
description: Last fall, when Robert Maxwell spent $2.6 billion to acquire Macmillan Inc., he was in part making an expensive bet on the educational publishing industry.

title: 3 Networks Forming Trade Alliance
description: In a move that television and advertising executives say is long overdue, the three major networks are about to begin promoting themselves with one voice. ABC, CBS and NBC are expected to announce, perhaps as early as this week, the formation of the first trade group to be devoted solely to the marketing of network television as an advertising medium.

title: 6 Injured in Shooting on a Bronx Subway Platform
description: A gunman followed a group of teen-agers leaving a ''sweet 16'' party onto a crowded Bronx subway platform and opened fire on them, the Transit Police said yesterday.

title: Zeroing In
description: It may be true that you can't get something for nothing. But as the folks at Shearson Lehman Hutton would like to be the first to tell you, you can get a lot for a little if you put your money in the right place and are willing to wait a couple of decades.

title: GEO International Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

The securities have an estimated average life of 14 months and are backed by car loan receivables. Common Stock * Tandy Brands Inc. is offering 800,000 common shares at $13.375, through Montgomery Securities. Rating * Toro Co.'s senior debt rating has been raised to BBB- from BB+ by Standard & Poor's Corp.

Daimler Exports Questioned
description: The automobile giant Daimler-Benz sold trucks to the military in Pakistan without proper export permits, a news magazine reported Saturday.

title: Review/Cabaret; Jim Bailey as Judy Garland
description: Seen on television over the years, Jim Bailey's portrayals of such entertainers as Judy Garland, Barbra Streisand and Peggy Lee have been marked by an almost eerie accuracy of detail. That's why Mr. Bailey bills himself not as a female impersonator but as an ''illusionist.'' Where most female impersonators caricature their favorite divas, he would like to blend into his.

title: A GUIDE TO SPRING TRAINING: ATLANTIC COAST
description: Miami - The Baltimore Orioles' spring stadium is theirs again because the Nicaraguan refugees have been transferred elsewhere. But the Orioles won't need the stadium until March 3, when they return from their new pre-exhibition training complex in Sarasota.

title: Hinderliter Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $70,000 for the quarter and $260,000 for the 6 months. c-After gains from discontinued operations of $72,000 for the quarter and $184,000 for the 6 months; losses on the disposal of discontinued operations of $54,000 and $94,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and tax credits of $2,000 and $49,000 for the same periods, respectively. The year-ago periods' results were restated to reflect the sale of Johnson Manufacturing and accounting adjustments.

title: Supreme Court Hobbles 14th Amendment
description: To the Editor:

title: The Edlerly And Students Aid Neediest
description: At 75, Donald Bartlett manages to cut enough wood to keep the house cozy and warm, even these days when the temperature has staggered between minus 10 and plus 5 degrees on the shores of Lake Champlain.

title: A GUIDE TO SPRING TRAINING: GULF COAST
description: Dunedin-Grant Field, spring home of the Toronto Blue Jays, is a home-run hitter's delight. But some home-run hitters were unhappy there last spring. Of course, the field had nothing to do with the atmosphere.

title: Bacolod Journal; Inside the Rebel Camp, a Different Kind of Revolt
description: Nemesio Dimafiles, a Communist rebel now fighting against the rebellion that once absorbed his life, leaned on his pitchfork and eyed a visitor suspiciously.

title: More Companies Raise Dividends
description: After several years of higher and higher profits, corporations are beginning to share the wealth with stockholders. Dividend increases are climbing sharply this year as many blue-chip companies find themselves awash in cash.

title: Southwestern Energy Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Maxwell House Is in Review
description: As far as the General Foods Corporation is concerned, the decline of Maxwell House coffee has gone far enough, so the consumer-products subsidiary of the Philip Morris Companies has put the account into review.

title: Japan Ruling Party Suffers Setback in By-Election
description: Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita suffered a political setback tonight when his party's candidate lost a by-election seen as a test of public anger about a widening stock scandal and a recently enacted sales tax.

title: Government by Black Boxes
description: Has Congress abdicated too much responsibility to special blue-ribbon commissions? Have elected officials become addicted to extra-constitutional devices that shield them from tough choices?

title: Tambrands Chief Out; Former Head Returns
description: Edwin H. Shutt Jr., whose efforts to diversify Tambrands Inc. disappointed Wall Street, has retired as chairman, president and chief executive.

title: They Got America Humming: A Celebration
description: Victor Herbert, Louis Armstrong, Johnny Cash and Aaron Copland are eminent names in American music, but because each represents a different tradition, one rarely hears them mentioned in the same breath. But at a new exhibition in the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center for the 75th anniversary of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers, the memorabilia connected with those and other famous musicians are displayed side by side.

title: New Episcopal Bishop Starts Her Work
description: On Saturday she earned a place in church history by becoming a bishop; today Bishop Barbara Clementine Harris of the Episcopal Church began the less dramatic work of simply being one.

title: Big Rate Rise Said to Be Unneeded
description: Further rises in short-term interest rates are viewed as inevitable by credit market participants, but analysts say that big additional increases are not necessary to achieve one of the Federal Reserve's primary objectives: slower economic growth.

description: b-Net income

title: NASA Said to Clear Unfit Men
description: Two astronauts who were not medically qualified were given permission by the space agency to fly on space shuttle missions, a newspaper reported yesterday.

title: Bowman Takes Men's Title
description: After four years of biding his time behind Brian Boitano, Christopher Bowman skated well enough in his freestyle program today to win his first national senior figure-skating championship.

title: Caracas Loan Plan Reported
description: The Venezue lan central bank has approved a plan to seek a $600 million loan based on future gold sales, two leading Caracas newspapers reported Saturday.

title: Towering Inferno
description: The ordeal of John Tower is the shame of the United States Senate. The man permitting the prolonged besmearing of the next Secretary of Defense is his successor as Chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, Sam Nunn.

title: Richfood Holdings Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 7
description: The comparable year-ago quarter and 9-month per share nets were not applicable; the company went public on May 1, 1988.

title: Georgetown Seen as Making Gains In Recruitment of Minority Students
description: When Georgetown University's basketball coach, John Thompson, walked off the court to protest a new N.C.A.A. rule as discriminatory against poor blacks, he drew attention not just to the rule but to Georgetown and its effort to educate black students.

title: Unlikeliest All-Star
description: ''YOU'RE like Cinderella,'' someone suggested. He thought for a moment. ''Yes,'' he said. ''That's true.''

title: Once Moldy, Now Worth $1 Million, a Mural Starts a Fight
description: A school tosses out a moldy old mural. It falls into the hands of an art conservator, who restores the painting. Sixteen years later, the once-worthless work is appraised at $1.25 million. Who is the rightful owner? The school? Or the conservator?

title: Lesbian Parents Prove to Be in No Way Inferior; Children of Courage
description: To the Editor:

title: New Free Agency Slow to Catch On
description: In the two weeks since 619 players became unfettered free agents, only one has been signed by another National Football League team. He is Darryl Usher, a kick-returner who was not protected by the Patriots and was picked up by the Browns.

title: For Families, Killer's Death Eases Doubts but Not Pain
description: While Ted Bundy awaited the electric chair and crowds outside the prison at Starke, Fla., chanted in jubilation, a Seattle family gathered to reflect on the killer's final confessions.

title: West Stars Set Mark and Win
description: During the long walk through the tunnel from the arena to the dressing rooms today, Isiah Thomas asked Charles Barkley in a bantering tone: ''Did you get enough shots? Did you get enough playing time?'' Both smiled.

title: Wrong Message
description: Why did New York City Schools Chancellor Richard Green appear at a press conference with a Bronx school board member who was recently indicted for bribery?

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If anyone would have told me then that I would be here, 25 years or so later, I would not have believed it. But that means I did not have enough faith in you.'' - Elie Wiesel, at the opening of a Jewish cultural center in Moscow. [ A1:5. ]

title: Round 1 to Bush, Democrats Agree; Mitchell: No More Giddiness
description: President Bush threw Congress on the defensive with his budget presentation Thursday night. While Democrats have praised his tone, they fear that he has found a formula for taking credit for good news and sharing blame with them for the bad.

description: Advent Bio Products, to the Mingo Group, a subsidiary of Muse-Cordero-Chen & Baca Advertising, Los Angeles, with a budget of $3 million.

description: Aviva Aranovich, a pianist, made her New York debut at Weill Recital Hall on Saturday afternoon, and gave a performance that was remarkable for its passion and energy, but also for its lack of interpretive discipline and technical control.

title: Gen. Charles Bolte, Ex-Army Vice Chief Of Staff, Dies at 93
description: Gen. Charles L. Bolte, the Army's vice chief of staff from 1953 to 1955, when he retired after 40 years of service, died of a stroke Saturday in Mount Vernon (Va.) Hospital. He was 93 years old and lived in Alexandria, Va.

title: A GUIDE TO SPRING TRAINING: ARIZONA
description: Phoenix-On a road outside of Phoenix, a traveler passes two signs. The first announces, ''State Prison.'' The second warns, ''Do not pick up hitchhikers.'' Here's another warning: Stay away from the Phoenix-Scottsdale area the weekend of March 11-12. On those days, the Oakland Athletics and the San Francisco Giants play a home-and-home series, and fans from the Bay Area have bought up all the tickets and reserved all of the rooms at the teams' hotels.

title: Boston Marathon of Skiing
description: ONE of the favorite topics of conversation around Hayward, Wis., these days is about waves, but not the cresting kind. A wave to a Hayward local is a surge of skiers lined up for the start of the Curel American Birkebeiner. It is the largest cross-country ski race in North America and tends to attract as many as 6,000 competitors to the start.

description: After only one relief flight, the United Nations has suspended its airlift of food and medicine to Kabul, the besieged Afghan capital, because airlines are refusing to make the trip, the coordinator of the project said today.

title: Review/Theater; Martha Mitchell, the Outspoken Watergate Wife
description: Speaking her mind during the depths of Watergate, Martha Mitchell was either a virago gone haywire or a protector of democratic principles. David Wolpe's play ''The Unguided Missile'' bolsters the first description, while making it clear that Mrs. Mitchell kept her tunnel vision fixed firmly on the interests of herself and her husband, John N. Mitchell, the indicted former Attorney General.

Knife Attack on British Train
description: About 15 knife-wielding youths robbed passengers on an inter-city train early today and attacked some who resisted, resulting in some injuries, the transport police said. ''At least 11 people were robbed of cash, jewelry and other valuables, and two people were taken to a hospital with head and neck injuries,'' a police official said. The police said they believed that the youths boarded an afternoon train for King's Cross station in St. Albans, 19 miles northwest of London.

title: At Storm's Eye Are Questions Over a Law on National Secrets
description: The celebrated trial of Oliver L. North now seems likely to go ahead, but yesterday's agreement between the special prosecutor and the Justice Department did not resolve the issue of Government secrets that almost delayed it indefinitely.

description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d began talks with senior West German officials today to clarify whether the Bonn Government is prepared to take the politically contentious step of allowing NATO to modernize the short-range nuclear missiles based on West German soil.
