title: RESULTS PLUS
description: DOG SHOW Ready for Westminster: Seventeen specialty shows were held at 10 sites in the metropolitan area yesterday as preludes to the 113th annual Westminster Kennel Club show, which opens today at Madison Square Garden. Two of the events took place in Loew's Summit Hotel: the Pug Dog Club of Greater New York and the Empire Miniature Pinscher Club of Greater New York. The best pug was a fawn, Ch. Sheffield's Jersey Bounce, owned by Margery Shiver and Michael Wolf and handled by the latter. Barbara Zagrodnick, a professional handler, showed her Ch. Goldmedal Morning Star TT to the breed honors at the pinscher event. The dark mahogany gained his championship on his first birthday last Aug. 20. ''He's just a good little dog,'' said Richard Hammond, the judge, after he singled out the 8-pounder. GOLF Sauers Wins by a Stroke: Gene Sauers chipped in for a birdie on the final hole yesterday to win the rain-shortened Hawaiian Open tournament in Honolulu by one shot. Sauers took the lead with a 12-foot birdie putt on the 17th hole, then finished a final-round 65 by chipping in from just off the back fringe of the green for the second victory of his six-year PGA career. He finished the 54-hole event in 19-under-par 197, the best three-round score on the PGA Tour this season.(AP) Mowry Wins Seniors Title: Larry Mowry made a 5-foot par-saving putt on the 18th hole yesterday to edge Al Geiberger and Miller Barber by one stroke and win the 50th PGA Seniors championship. Mowry, who posted a final-round 73, overcame a poor start and played the back nine at PGA National in Palm Beach Garden, Fla., in one under par. He earned $72,000. Mowry finished with a 72-hole total of seven-under 281 on the 6,530-yard Champion course. (AP) TENNIS Gilbert Falls to Lendl: Ivan Lendl survived a rocky start and a close finish, outlasting Brad Gilbert in a baseline battle yesterday, 6-2, 7-6, to win the Volvo tournament in Chicago. The world's top-ranked player came in against Gilbert after staving off 2 match points in a semifinal Saturday over Tim Mayotte and looked lethargic in the early going. Gilbert, ranked 20th, was no sharper. (AP) TRACK AND FIELD Hemery Takes 1,000-Meter Race: Phil Hemery of Archbishop Molloy ran away from the competition in the 1,000-meter race to win in 2 minutes 32.7 seconds at the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association indoor championships yesterday at Manhattan College's Draddy Gym. A little over an hour later, Hemery took the lead in the 1,600-meter run from Joe Tuttle of Moor Catholic with one and a half laps to go and won the race in 4 minutes 21.5 seconds with Tuttle second at 4:22.4. Hemery's victories led Molloy of Queens to its 21st title in the indoor championships in the last 25 years. HORSE RACING Gelding Wins at Santa Anita: Super Diamond, a 9-year-old gelding who missed most of 1988 with a tendon injury, captured the San Antonio Handicap at Santa Anita. Ridden by Laffit Pincay Jr., Super Diamond finished 1 3/4 lengths in front of Frankly Perfect, ridden by Eddie Delahoussaye. Cherokee Colony, with Rafael Meza, finished third, two lengths farther back in the race of a mile and an eighth, which drew seven starters. Super Diamond, clocked in 1:46 4/5, paid $13 for $2 to win. (AP) N.H.L. Flames 4, Penguins 2: Doug Gilmour scored twice as the Calgary Flames stretched their winning streak to seven games in Pittsburgh last night. The Flames, 10-0-1 in their last 11 games, lead the National Hockey League standing with 88 points, 6 more than Montreal.(AP) Kings 6, Blackhawks 2: Wayne Gretzky scored 40 goals for the 10th consecutive season, an N,H.L. record, and recorded his 45th career hat trick as visiting Los Angeles overpowered Chicago. Gretzky's 40th goal was his first of three in the game. He had been tied with the former Islanders' star Mike Bossy, who scored more than 40 goals in each of his first nine N.H.L. seasons.(AP) Canucks 3, Flyers 2: Brian Bradley scored two goals for Vancouver handed Philadelphia its fifth loss at home in its last six games. The Canucks swept Philadelphia, 3-0, to win their first season series from the Flyers since 1983-84, when they won two of three games. (AP) Sabres 5, Blues 2: Ray Sheppard and Mike Foligno each scored twice as the Sabres took advantage of poor defensive play by St. Louis for a victory in Buffalo. After Scott Arniel snapped a 2-2 tie in the second period, Foligno and Sheppard added their second goals of the night in the third period to help the Sabres end a four-game losing streak.(AP)

title: Lawyer Inclined to Settle Lilco Case
description: The lawyer representing customers of the Long Island Lighting Company in the racketeering suit against the utility said today that she was leaning toward accepting a settlement of the case.

title: Effort Begun to Extend Limits on Steel Imports
description: Steel industry officials are campaigning for Bush Administration support for legislation introduced in Congress last week to extend for five years a measure aimed at protecting against imports from asures with 29 countries.

title: Policing Insults
description: New York City's Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward has twice publicly insulted Hispanics. Mayor Edward Koch continues to react as if his Commissioner were a naughty but gifted child whose excesses have to be tolerated. ''Ben, how could you be so goddamned dumb?'' is Mr. Koch's strongest reaction; at times he has accompanied his comments with exasperated chuckles.

title: Plane Kills Woman in Car
description: A small plane whose pilot was trying to make an emergency landing at Barnstable Municipal Airport sheared off the roof of a car on a Cape Cod highway Saturday, killing a passenger, Doris L. Chase, 63 years old, the police said. Her husband, who was driving the car, and the plane's three passengers were treated at Cape Cod Hospital and released. The pilot, Robert A. Feversanger, 27, said his throttle jammed, State Trooper Robert Knott said.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Quaker Oats Shifts 2 Pet-Food Accounts
description: The Quaker Oats Company sought out the familiar last week in awarding the accounts for two pet-food brands to a pair of Chicago agencies. Chiat/Day Inc., which handled both accounts, lost Gravy Train to Bayer Bess Vanderwarker, while Cycle was picked up by J. Walter Thompson, Chicago.

title: Limit Sought On Contracts From Navy
description: A Congressional committee has asked the Government to restrict the Navy's authority to award computer contracts without the supervision of the General Services Administration.

title: Hungary Under New Management: A Cart Pulling a Horse?
description: When Karoly Grosz unseated Janos Kadar as leader of the Communist Party nine months ago, he promised far-reaching reforms to lead Hungary out of economic stagnation, modernize its political system in tune with Mikhail S. Gorbachev's ''openness'' and restore confidence in Communism among a disaffected population.

title: Chrysler Model Change
description: The Chrysler Corporation, which based its recovery from near-bankruptcy on a series of front-wheel-drive products, said it was considering a return to rear-wheel drive in some car models because of American consumers' changing tastes.

title: Site of the Latin Quarter Giving Way to a Tower
description: After the sun set, the little block between 47th and 48th Streets had more dazzle per square inch than any around Times Square - crowned by a neon aureole that defied the night, home to the Latin Quarter and Cotton Club and Palais Royal.

title: Business Digest
description: The Economy President Bush's savings rescue plan is taking its lumps after a glowing initial reception. Lawmakers are now complaining that the package is short on money, weak on detail and likely to become a budgetary nightmare in the future. Nonetheless, quick Congressional approval is likely. [ Page D1. ] Some of the nation's largest companies plan to fight proposed accounting rules to require them to subtract tens of millions of dollars from reported net earnings. The rules would require employers to report obligations for future employee health-care costs. [ D1. ] A Congressional committee has proposed restrictions on the Navy's authority to award computer contracts. The panel told the General Services Administration that it had information suggesting ''a pattern of institutional bias'' in Navy bidding procedures. [ D1. ] Steelmakers are urging the extension of import quotas for five years. They say the measures are needed to protect them from steel subsidized by foreign governments. But many manufacturers say the quotas have created shortages and raised prices. [ D2. ] International Report Japanese conformity is under attack, and the assault vehicles have names like PAO, S-Cargo, Be-1 and Lettuce. Sensing a trend toward more individuality, Japan's auto makers are offering a vehicle with a related line of safari clothes and a car sold in supermarkets that has two doors on one side and one on the other. [ A1. ] Many Israelis are saying that only peace can revive an economy suffering from stagnation and rising inflation. [ A1. ] Spain's ''supply-side Socialism'' has drawn praise from business people and protests from labor unions. Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez is pressing on with the mix of free-market and leftist policies that has resulted in Europe's strongest economic growth. [ D1. ] While Aeroflot predicts a 1989 profit of $3.7 billion, its critics expect another year of flight delays, airport chaos and rude treatment from employees. The Soviet airline's monopoly is also being challenged, with one economist proposing a breakup. [ D12. ] Companies Corporations are beginning to share their new wealth with stockholders. Dividend increases are climbing sharply this year as many blue-chip companies find themselves awash in cash. [ D1. ] Gov. Cuomo said he would insist on legislative approval of any deal to close the Shoreham nuclear power plant. [ A1. ] The Media Business The three big networks are said to plan joint marketing of network TV to advertisers. A new trade group, the Television Network Association, is seen as an effort to counter audience declines. [ D11. ] More educational publishers are seen as takeover targets. The field is the most lucrative in book publishing by far. [ D10. ] Many authors have changed their attitude about conglomerates that publish books. The writers are finding that being part of a huge corporation can have financial advantages. Publishing. [ D10. ] Procter & Gamble is increasing payments to ad agencies at a time when many clients are forcing agencies to accept reduced fees. Because the company is the nation's second-largest advertiser, its move could have a widespread effect. Advertising. [ D8. ] Some writers of spoof ads are now doing the real thing, making commercials for paying advertisers. [ D11. ] Today's Columns Is electronic commodity trading the wave of the future? The answer is likely to be yes, with both the Chicago Board of Trade and the Merc moving to explore new systems that would leave an almost perfect audit trail. Market Place. [ D1. ] Higher short-term interest rates are inevitable, people in the credit markets say. But analysts say big additional increases will not be needed to curb economic growth. Credit Markets. [ D7. ] Valuable deductions may be overlooked, tax experts say, especially those resulting from changes in the law. Tax Watch. [ D2. ]

title: 2 Women Deny Being Victims Of Sex Abuse
description: Four New Yorkers testifying at the Federal trial of two transit police officers described last week how ordinary subway trips were turned into nightmarish ordeals by sex abuse charges they said were contrived.

title: Election Campaign in Sri Lanka Closes With a Flurry of Violence
description: At least 55 people were killed over the weekend in the final two days of campaigning for parliamentary elections to be held this week, officials said today. The victims included 36 people massacred while they slept in a remote village Saturday night.

title: Jaclyn Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago share earnings restated to reflect 4 percent stock dividend paid in June 1988.

title: Israelis View a Battered Economy As Motivation for a Peace Effort
description: It is lunchtime, and Yaacov Nachum, a restaurateur, is sitting alone at one of his cafe's sunlit street-side tables, sipping Turkish coffee and considering the banks of empty tables around him.

title: Nycor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $871,000. c-Included an extraordinary loss of $1,519,000. d-Net income Latest fourth-quarter and year results included a one-time restructuring charge of $1,100,000. Latest-year operating and final share net were less than one cent.

title: Include a Woman On Ethics Panel
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Plan On Savings Under Fire
description: After an almost euphoric reception by Congress last Monday, President Bush's plan to rescue the savings and loan industry is getting somewhat bruised. Lawmakers are complaining that the proposal is short on money, weak on detail and likely to become a budgetary nightmare down the road.

title: 22 Die in Indian Truck Wreck
description: A speeding truck overturned in eastern Bihar state, killing 22 people and injuring 15, news reports said today. The victims reportedly included 10 children and the driver of the truck. According to the reports, the truck flipped over late Friday near the town of Gaya, more than 500 miles southeast of New Delhi.

title: Software Developer's reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Eastern Air Ousts Magazine
description: Eastern Airlines has banned in-flight distribution of the latest Fortune magazine because of its unflattering portrait of Frank Lorenzo, chairman of Eastern's parent company, an Eastern spokesman said today.

title: National Mine Service Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $348,000 and $850,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: A School Remembers
description: After 49 years of coaching high school basketball, 76-year-old George Cella could name only two players he thought were ''totally outstanding.''

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * AAR Corp., Elk Grove, Ill., an aerospace manufacturer and distributor, said Barton J. Levin, president and chief operating officer, had resigned. * Ameritrust Indiana Corp., Indianapolis, a subsidiary of Ameritrust Corp., said William E. Puckett had been promoted to senior vice president and president of its division, Ameritrust National Bank. * F. W. Woolworth Co., said Gary Brown had been appointed vice president. * Genetics Institute Inc., Cambridge, Mass., a biotechnology company, said Robert I. Kamen, senior vice president, had resigned and Edward F. Fritsch had been named acting senior vice president. * General Electric Co., Fairfield, Conn., announced the election of H. Brewster Atwater Jr., chairman of General Mills Inc., to its board. * Gulfstream Aerospace Corp., Savannah, Ga., a subsidiary of Chrysler Corp., said John W. Sandford had been named president and chief operating officer. * Intelligent Electronics Inc., Exton, Pa., said Bert I. Helfinstein had resigned as president and chief executive of its subsidiary, Entre Computer Centers Inc. * Jaymar-Ruby Inc., Michigan City, Ind., a clothing manufacturer and subsidiary of Hartmarx Corp., said William D. Grasso and Louis A. Dubrow had been appointed executive vice presidents. * Maytag Corp., Newton, Iowa, said it had elected Lester Crown, chairman of Material Service Corp.; Harvey Kapnick, former chairman of Chicago Pacific Corp., and Neele E. Sterns Jr., president of CC Industries, to its board. * New York City Health and Hospitals Corp. announced the appointment of Pamela S. Brier as executive director of the Bronx Municipal Hospital Center. * Paramount Pictures Corp., a subsidiary of Gulf and Western Inc., said Larry Gleason had been named senior vice president of its theatrical exhibition group. * Samsung Electronics America Inc., Saddle Brook, N.J., a subsidiary of Samsung Electronics Co., said I. T. Kim had been appointed president.

title: Cathy Silver Has Wedding
description: Cathy Simon Silver and Sidney S. Prince were married yesterday afternoon by Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel at the Tower Suite in the Time & Life Building. The bride is the daughter of Judge Caroline K. Simon of New York and the late Leopold K. Simon. Mr. Prince is the son of Mrs. Theodore Prince of New York and the late Mr. Prince.

title: Vicon Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Tocogen Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $15,000 and $2,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Muslims Storm U.S. Mission in Pakistan
description: Five people were killed and as many as 80 were reported injured today as the center of Islamabad was turned into a battlefield when several thousand Muslims marched on the American cultural center, throwing stones and demanding the death of an author and the banning of a book.

title: Big Schedule of Tax-Exempts This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of new issues this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month Treasury bills. In the tax-exempt market, however, the calendar of tentative offerings is brimming with large financings, notably by Massachusetts, Puerto Rico, the Oklahoma Turnpike Authority and the Texas Water Resources Finance Authority.

title: A GUIDE TO SPRING TRAINING: YANKEES
description: THEY are still smiling at each another, still sharing the warmth of a relationship that has kept the winter months thawed. But the good times that Dallas Green is enjoying now with his new employer, George Steinbrenner, may seem like some distant dream in July, when the heat is turned up and the compliments have been forgotten.

title: City High Schools Starting Playoffs
description: Tickets for the Public Schools Athletic League championship basketball games, at the Felt Forum on March 13, go on sale today for $12.50 and $10, but there is plenty of playoff action between now and then.

title: Another Simon Smiles Through the Tears
description: It was the first performance of the first produced play by a 31-year-old playwright, it was being presented at the small Sheafer Theater on the Duke University campus here and there were no stars in the cast. But seated excitedly, and nervously, in the audience were Neil Simon, his former wife, Marsha Mason, and his longtime producer, Emanuel Azenberg.

title: Poll Shows Withdrawals
description: Six percent of depositors with accounts in the nation's savings and loan associations say they plan to withdraw their money in the near future because of the industry's problems, according to a national poll by ABC News.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Briefing; Rescuing the Past
description: A storage and retrieval system that rescues and preserves documents ravaged by time, water or insects is being tested by the National Archives.

title: Kustom Electronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WPL Holdings Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Mother, 16, Is Charged With Stabbing Infant
description: A teen-age mother has been charged with trying to stab her newborn son to death moments after his birth in the bathroom of her Brooklyn apartment. The child was in guarded condition yesterday at Kings County Hospital, suffering from eight stab wounds.

title: Monarch Machine Tool Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Fitness; Starting Small With Weights
description: AT first, weight training for the beginner might seem intimidating, whether you are using barbells, known as free weights, or the machines found in health clubs that seem reminiscent of medieval instruments of torture. The people working out are so intense - grunting, groaning and straining, their faces contorted in massive exertion and concentration. Everyone goes around expelling breath in great noisy gasps. Who needs this, you might ask? The short answer is that if you are merely interested in the cardiovascular fitness and protection against heart disease that aerobic workouts provide, you can skip weight training with a clear conscience. It does little for aerobic fitness.

title: Spain's Daring Experiment In 'Supply-Side Socialism'
description: The Socialist Government of Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez is pressing ahead with one of this decade's most daring economic experiments - a mixture of free-market and leftist policies that has often been called ''supply-side Socialism.''

title: Trio-Tech International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Net income

title: Distributed Logic reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Tellabs Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Metro Matters; Bergman Legacy: $1,376,032 Check And 110 Auditors
description: For nearly 14 years New York State's special nursing-homes prosecutor kept hoping that the check was in the mail. It has finally arrived, and with it a sorry chapter in the annals of health care has ended.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Publishing; A Growing Acceptance Of Goliaths
description: WHEN the Robert M. Bass Group disclosed recently that it had acquired 5.6 percent of the Houghton Mifflin Company, little reaction was heard from the publisher's authors. But 11 years ago, when Western Pacific Industries acquired a slightly larger stake in the same company, that was not the case.

title: Aeroflot's Rosy Report Confirms Critics' Point
description: When Aeroflot, the Soviet national airline, produced its equivalent of an annual report here last week, it projected the kind of performance for 1989 that would make a Western investor's heart leap: a profit, converted at the official exchange rate for the ruble, of $3.7 billion.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Which players in the National Basketball Association would be the league's leading career scorers if each were listed alphabetically by the first letter of his last name?

title: Spoof Writers, Now Taken Seriously
description: ''Her style is unforgettable,'' one radio commercial boasts of the singer Stevie Nicks, ''her lyrics, unintelligible.'' Another lauds ''Infidelity Bank, the bank that wants to help you with your affairs.''

title: Colgate-Palmolive Names 2 In Global Marketing Effort
description: The Colgate-Palmolive Company has established a new executive position, chief operating officer, and named William S. Shanahan to fill it. The company also filled another senior position, naming Edward T. Fogarty president of its United States division.

title: DSC Communications reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $202,000 for the quarter and $1,003,000 for the year, and a loss on the disposal of discontinued operations of $7,300,000 and an extraordinary gain of $856,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Included gains from discontinued operations of $4,699,000 and $13,928,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and extraordinary gains of $130,000 for the quarter and $3,806,000 for the year. The company said the latest year and prior year and fourth quarter results have been reclassified to exclude operating results of discontinued operations from continuing operations. Net results of discontinued operations are separately presented in DSC's consolidated results of operations. Extraodinary gains for both years resulted from purchases of part of the company's outstanding 8 percent convertible subordinated debentures at favorable prices. The 1987 extraordinary gain is net of a premium for early retirement of part of the company's senior debt.

title: Two Men Who Fought L.I. Abortion
description: Lawrence Washburn had never met Nancy Klein, the comatose Long Island woman who had an abortion on Saturday. Neither had John Short. Both were strangers to Mrs. Klein and her husband, Martin.

title: Chemical Treatment Is Wrong Answer to Cocaine Addiction; Research Is Proceeding
description: To the Editor:

title: Conquest Exploration reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included provisions for the impairment of producing oil and gas properties of $1,405,000 and $41,756,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included provisions for the impairment of producing oil and gas properties of $291,000 for the quarter and $881,000 for the year.

title: TJ International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Reviews/Music; The Kronos Quartet
description: The success of the Kronos Quartet defies conventional wisdom about audience building in ways that are truly mystifying. The quartet -David Harrington and John Sherba, violinists; Hank Dutt, violist, and Joan Jeanrenaud, cellist - specializes in contemporary music, which other groups have shown to be ineffective as a box-office lure. Yet the Kronos's crowds are sizable; indeed, Alice Tully Hall was packed for the group's Saturday evening concert, the second of three it is playing there this season.

title: A GUIDE TO SPRING TRAINING: METS
description: LOOK, they're opening with high cards and great expectations, with deep pitching and five years of rave reviews, and even Manager Davey Johnson skips the customary caution and says, ''We don't have a lot of problems.''

title: Double Gold for Austrian
description: Two treacherous courses took more than their share of victims in the men's slalom as the world Alpine ski championships concluded today.

title: Rent Agency Begins Moving Beyond Chaos
description: After falling into administrative chaos and developing a backlog of nearly 90,000 cases, the state agency that administers New York City's rent laws has registered a small victory. In recent weeks it resolved more cases than it took on.

title: Correction
description: A report in the Sports World Specials in SportsMonday last week about a basketball game filmed for the Cosby Show misidentified the gymnasium where the game was played. It was at Xavier High School in Manhattan. Another report in the column, about the Fordham basketball team, misidentified the coach. He is Nick Macarchuk.

title: Outdoors: Reading Winter's Log
description: WHEN the winter woods are brown and the bare branches of trees rattle and squeak in the wind, one can be half-persuaded that the forest is empty of animal life except, perhaps, for an occasional curious chickadee, but snow changes all that.

title: Goodbye, Klan; Hello, G.O.P.
description: The chickens are coming home to roost for the Republican Party. Just at the time when the G.O.P. is trying to attract blacks at the national level, its 20-year-old Southern strategy of playing to racist fears has produced a major embarrassment -David Duke.

title: Douglas & Lomason Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said start-up costs of two new plants reduced net earnings by $1.09 a share for the fourth quarter and by $2.79 a share for the year. The company also said engineering and design costs totaling $1.7 million determined to be unrecoverable in future periods, adjustments for unusable or obsolete inventory totaling $1.2 million and additional customer-required development costs of $1 million were absorbed in the fourth quarter, cutting net income by $1.10 a share.

title: St Lawrence Cement reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Squash Rankings Still Go by the Letters
description: THE elegant simplicity of squash rankings used to place a great deal of importance on that first jump up, from level D to C. Level D in those days was, in addition to being the lowest, the broadest and deepest of the four - ''like second gear in a car,'' -said Pat Canavan, head pro at the Lincoln Racquet and Fitness Club in Manhattan. Level D seemed like a vast, tundralike landscape to most serious amateurs.

title: Lesbian Parents Prove to Be in No Way Inferior; Heterosexual Monsters
description: To the Editor:

title: R.D. Sanborn, 52, Conrail Chief
description: Richard Dyer Sanborn Jr., who became chairman and chief executive officer of Conrail on Jan. 1, died yesterday at Greater Baltimore Medical Center after suddenly becoming ill at his Baltimore home. He was 52 years old.

title: A Soviet Censor, Uncensored
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with Vladimir A. Solodin, a Soviet censor with the Main Administration for Safeguarding State Secrets in the Press (known as Glavlit). Conducted by Laura Starink, it appeared Dec. 28 in NRC Handelsblad, a daily paper in Rotterdam, the Netherlands. An English version was published in America in the Foreign Broadcast Information Service's Daily Report on Jan. 11.

title: Southwest Water Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Dinkins Bid Could Scare Off Rivals
description: The anticipated announcement tomorrow by David N. Dinkins that he will run for Mayor of New York City will add one candidate to the Democratic primary field but subtract three or four others.

title: GLOBAL BRIEFS
description: Iran has negotiated a $750 million credit deal with France to finance Iranian oil exports vital to rebuilding its war-shattered economy. A spokesman for Banque Paribas said the credit letter, covering exports this year by the state-run National Iranian Oil Company, was signed in Teheran in early January. He declined to give details. French banking sources said other French and foreign banks had signed similar agreements. Economists say 90 percent of Iran's export earnings, estimated to total $10 billion to $11 billion this year, will come from oil. * Indonesia, one of the world's biggest debtors, promised not to renege on its debts and said it needed its Western creditors to provide further aid in the coming year. Finance Minister Johannes Sumarlin said he expected the country's major creditors would provide at least the same amount of aid in the new fiscal year, starting in April, as the record $4.01 billion of soft loans and grants in 1988-89. Indonesia's outstanding foreign debt stood at about $40 billion last September, of which $35 billion was owed by the Government. * In Amman, Jordan, police sealed the offices of at least three brokerage firms yesterday and posted armed guards at their doors, witnesses said. There was no immediate explanation for the move, which followed similar action on Wednesday against the kingdom's 70-or-so money-changers, accused of speculation against the dinar. The stockbrokers, who provide information and other services for Jordanians with investments abroad, are normally closed on Sunday and could not be reached for comment. In the last month, the dinar has fallen about 12 percent in value against the United States dollar.

title: Penwest Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included income of $2,450,000 and $642,000 from discontinued operations for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Review/Ballet; New Titania in 'Dream'
description: Valentina Kozlova, dancing the role of Titania for the first time in the New York City Ballet's ''Midsummer Night's Dream'' on Saturday afternoon, suggested a woman who had married well.

title: JERRY BROWN WINS STATE PARTY POST
description: Edmund G. (Jerry) Brown Jr., the former Governor of California who has been alternately labeled a visionary and a ''space cadet,'' was elected chairman of the state Democratic Party late Saturday.

title: Killings in Greece Complicate Terror Case Pressed by U.S.
description: In a rampage of terror last month, left-wing urban guerrillas shot three state prosecutors, killing two of them, including one who died last week after a long struggle to survive.

title: Cavco Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
No News, Good News for Poverty Law
description: President Bush's budget message says nothing about the Legal Services Corporation, the Federal program that provides lawyers for the poor, and that's progress: the Reagan Administration campaigned for eight years to destroy the program.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 Israel's economy is in deep recession with inflation rising as the economy stagnates. Experts point to excessive state economic involvement and regional tensions that hurt exports and foreign investment. Page A1

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Briefing; Romance, Romance
description: Valentine's Day seems to bring out the extravagant and loony in the people of the national capital. The personals columns in the Washington newspapers balloon with sweet sentiments, pages of them.

title: Terminal Island Journal; Writing Contest Gives Inmates an Escape of Sorts
description: In Southern California, where aspiring screen writers are as thick as rush-hour traffic, some of the people spending time behind typewriters are also doing time behind bars.

title: The Jazz Connection Connects
description: There is nothing subtle about the way Karl Malone of the Utah Jazz plays basketball.

title: ACCORD IS REACHED TO GUARD SECRETS AT NORTH'S TRIAL
description: The Bush Administration and the independent prosecutor in the trial of Oliver L. North defused an angry five-day court battle today with an agreement covering how national secrets will be handled at the trial.

title: First Financial Caribbean reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said the lower net is mainly due to an unusual charge of $4,204,000 from spin-off expenses and a $1,837,000 deferral of income resulting from an accounting change. The company was spun off from Culbro Corp. in December.

title: Correction
description: An article and a picture caption in Business Day on Tuesday about Sports Illustrated's swimsuit issue misidentified the issue's editor. She is Jule Campbell.

title: Computing in America: A Masculine Mystique
description: Women and girls use computers; men and boys love them. And that difference appears to be a critical reason that computers in America remain a predominantly male province.

title: U.S., in Shift, Asks Arbitration in World Court
description: The United States will submit an international dispute for arbitration by the International Court of Justice in the Hague on Monday for the first time since President Reagan rejected the Court's jurisdiction in a quarrel with Nicaragua three years ago.

title: Academics on List of N.C. State Woes
description: The longtime friends share ties with the same athletic shoe manufacturer and both coach teams in the top 20. No strangers to controversy, one awaits word on potential National Collegiate Athletic Association sanctions deferred by litigation for more than a decade, while the other has a program under investigation by the N.C.A.A. and his own state university system.

title: Change Sought in Retiree Cost Rules
description: Financial executives of some of the country's largest companies will begin a major campaign tomorrow to try to modify proposed accounting rules, due out tomorrow, that would require them to subtract tens of millions of dollars from reported net earnings.

title: Belcor Inc reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
Old Republic International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included realized investment gains of $1,085,262 and $3,753,247 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included realized investment losses of $152,016 for the quarter and realized investment gains of $9,505,779 for the year. d-Net income

title: Schools Must Reform Themselves, Study Says
description: New York City's public schools should take more responsibility for themselves, and those that are failing should be given extra resources and attention so they can improve, a new report recommends.

title: Oklahoma Stops No. 1 Arizona, 82-80
description: Arizona went to the top of The Associated Press's ranking and was beaten today, less than a week later.

title: Despite Its Warnings of Shortage, U.S. Sells Vital Nuclear Gas
description: The Federal Government has sold American and foreign companies millions of dollars worth of tritium for commercial use even as it has raised alarms over whether it will have enough of the radioactive gas to maintain the nation's nuclear arsenal.

title: Stuart Breidbart Wed To Dr. Sarise Freiman
description: Dr. Sarise Freiman, a daughter of Martin Freiman of New Rochelle, N.Y., and the late Marilyn Freiman, was married yesterday in Scarsdale, N.Y., to Stuart R. Breidbart, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Breidbart of Coconut Creek, Fla. Rabbi Jeffrey Segelman performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Porosoff, the bride's sister and brother-in-law.

title: Halifax Engineering Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a $27,000 loss from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The year-ago results were restated to reflect the adoption of SFAS 96.

title: Sun Electric reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $2.2 million restructuring charge. The company, which recently changed its fiscal year-end to Dec. 31 from Oct. 31, said it also reported net income of $151,000, or 2 cents a share, on sales of $28,431,000, for the two months ended Dec. 31. For the year ended Oct. 31, 1987, the company said it posted net of $4,951,000, or 70 cents a share, which included a tax benefit of $1,688,000. Sales were $203,904,000.

title: Review/Television; Achille Lauro Tragedy
description: The big problem for ''The Hijacking of the Achille Lauro'' is that we all know before we tune our sets to Channel 4 at 9 tonight that a cruise ship will be taken over by Palestine Liberation Organization terrorists, as it in fact was in October 1985, and that one American will be killed. This NBC ''Monday Night at the Movies'' -produced by Sue Milliken - manages to generate some tension between hijackers and passengers, but for most of the way, it's a routine cruise.

title: Tiny Statue, Major Mess and Much at Stake
description: A $3 million disagreement, the reputation of a major Renaissance scholar and the disputed activities of a varied cast of characters, including a Paris art collector, a Dutch dealer once convicted of fraud and a major auction house: all are elements in the tangle surrounding an eight-inch plaster statue declared two years ago to be a long-lost work by Michelangelo.

title: Chemical Treatment Is Wrong Answer to Cocaine Addiction
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: A number of clever moves in the game are rarely made in practical play. If they come up at all, it is in the post-mortem, causing somebody to announce ruefully, ''I should have thought of that.''

title: TBC Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Great Lakes Group reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Garan Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Telematics International reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $1,061,000.

title: Spring Training
description: EVERY team sport has its training season, but baseball is the only sport whose pre-season preparation has a special name that conjures up special feelings. No one speaks expressively about ''summer training'' in pro football. Everyone, however, talks about ''spring training,'' as in, ''I can't wait 'til spring training starts.''

title: More Is Less
description: A sharp increase in the number of major injuries suffered by the nation's 1 million high school football players could be a sign that the sport is getting safer.

title: Thursday's Child Sails In, Sets Mark
description: Under a sparkling, cloudless sky, Thursday's Child sailed under the Golden Gate Bridge at about 12:30 this afternoon, breaking a record that had stood since 1854. Completing her New York-to-San Francisco journey in 80 days 20 hours, she beat by 8 days 12 hours the record set by the old clipper ship Flying Cloud.

title: Oilers Find Way to Shut Down Rangers, 3-1
description: There's no greater teacher than experience, and for the Edmonton Oilers, there has been no worse experience than trying to find a way to play without Wayne Gretzky. Lessons have been numerous and painful. Last night, it turned out those lessons could be useful, too, as the Oilers beat the Rangers, 3-1, at Madison Square Garden.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; P.&G. to Pay Its Agencies More Money
description: PROCTER & GAMBLE, the nation's second-largest advertiser and one of advertising's most influential forces, has informed its agencies that it is increasing the amount it will pay them to handle its advertising.

title: Sakharov Arrives in Canada; He Will See Mulroney Today
description: Dr. Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet human rights campaigner, began a three-day visit to the Canadian capital today that will include a meeting with Prime Minister Brian Mulroney and discussions with rights groups.

title: Country Lake Foods reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago periods' share earnings are not available because the company went public in April 1988.

title: New Soviet Political Groups Come Under Attack
description: A senior member of the ruling Communist Politburo has made a sharp attack on unofficial political organizations, exhorting party leaders here in the Moldavian capital to battle against ''the creation of legal and illegal structures standing in opposition to the party.''

title: Energynorth Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Jacalyn R. Claire Becomes the BrideOf Brad David Rose, a Lawyer, on L.I.
description: The marriage of Jacalyn Robin Claire, a daughter of Allen B. Claire of Fort Lee, N.J., and Marilyn A. Claire of Great Neck, L.I., to Brad David Rose, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Rose of Baldwin Harbor, L.I., took place yesterday at Temple Emanuel in Great Neck. Rabbi Lawrence M. Colton officiated.

title: Lasting Faith Of Soviet Jews Moves Wiesel
description: Elie Wiesel looked out tonight at an audience of Jews from Kiev, Tbilisi, Leningrad and Moscow, and from Jewish organizations around the world, as he inaugurated the first officially approved Jewish cultural center in the Soviet Union. He looked into the faces in the audience, recalling his first visit to Jews in the Soviet Union.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Mastercard in U.S.S.R.
description: Mastercard will be the next capitalist tool advertised on Soviet television. The company (along with the Coca-Cola Company) is sponsoring the 14 National Basketball Association games that will be broadcast in the U.S.S.R. beginning later this month. Mastercard/Eurocard is held only by a small number of Soviet citizens who extensively travel abroad, said Richard A. Woods, Mastercard International's director of public affairs. ''But our feeling is that at some point, regular Soviet consumers will be using credit cards, so we wanted to create some awareness of ours,'' he added. Lintas: U.S.A. will do the ads.

title: Japan, Land of Look-Alike Cars, Goes Offbeat
description: Japan, it seems safe to say, bears little resemblance to sub-Saharan Africa.

title: Launching of Delta 2 Rocket Is Postponed a Second Time
description: The launching of the Air Force's new generation of Delta rockets was delayed for the second day in a row today because of high winds, an Air Force spokesman said.

title: Massachusetts Senate Chief Is Focus of Suit
description: One of Massachusetts's most powerful and colorful state politicians, Senate President William M. Bulger, is facing embarrassing questions about possible influence peddling involving construction of a 31-story downtown office building.

title: Action Auto Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change of $334,172.

title: Bond Default Hearings Set
description: Bondholders involved in the $2.25 billion default on two Washington state nuclear plants are being alerted today through notices in 14 newspapers that a Federal judge will hold hearings April 11 on whether a $750 million settlement is adequate and reasonable.

title: Forschner Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Uproar Over Envoy Strains Ties With Mexico
description: Carlos Salinas de Gortari and George Bush have yet to complete their first 100 days in office, but already their hopes for a ''new beginning'' in relations between Mexico and the United States are fading, done in by an outcry over Mr. Bush's choice as the new American ambassador here.

title: Palfed Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago quarter and year earnings are restated to reflect a 25-percent stock dividend on Dec. 15, 1988, which increased the total number of outstanding shares to 1,332,506 from 1,066,123.

title: Reviews/Television; How to Snare an Adonis
description: Can a fat woman with the kind of face one describes as ''pleasant'' find happiness with a fantastically handsome, slim fellow, if she can find the fellow in the first place? That question tells the story of ''Babycakes,'' a romantic Manhattan comedy that is the TV movie on CBS at 9 P.M. today.

title: Press Notes
description: Freedom's Bad Year

title: Arrow Automotive Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Therapeutic Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $163,973 gain on lease termination.

title: Review/Ballet; Small-Town America
description: The New York City Ballet honored Lincoln's Birthday by giving an eloquent performance of Jerome Robbins's ''Ives, Songs'' on Sunday afternoon at the New York State Theater. It proved interesting to see this work when there is a revival of Thornton Wilder's ''Our Town'' on Broadway.

title: Berkeley Journal; For Every Hotel Room, a Valentine
description: This city's constant eagerness to experiment with new ideas has earned it the nickname ''Berserkeley'' from its more parochial neighbors. But for some people here a proposed ordinance requiring that every hotel room have a ''safe sex kit'' of condoms and educational literature about AIDS may be going too far.

title: Precocious Devil Is Prominent at Last
description: There wasn't really a logical reason for feeling washed up at 19, but when Brendan Shanahan climbed onto the Devils' roster at 18 only to have the stardom that had tinged his junior career thoroughly escape him, that's how he felt.

title: Review/Music; Rock Values in Common
description: Both the New Sounds program and its many listeners at Merkin Concert Hall Sunday seemed outgrowths of rock-and-roll. First was the audience - largely under 40 years old, intent, but certainly not the faces one sees at Beethoven quartet concerts or latter-day homages to the Second Viennese School.

title: Robert C. Swain, 81, Chemist and Executive
description: Dr. Robert C. Swain, a research chemist and former president of Cyanamid International, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Riverside, Conn. He was 81 years old.

title: At This Retreat, A Cat Becomes His Own Master
description: One day melds quietly into the next here at the Last Post, a lovely 37-acre wooded retreat for elderly cats. Many of the cats spend entire days lounging in one of the 60-foot-long pine-paneled cat sitting rooms, with the skylights, ceiling fans and large wood beams trucked in from Maine. Hundreds of happy cats rest on the sitting room armchairs, couches and tables. On the deck and down by the Housatonic River, cats snooze in the winter sun.

title: New York Marine & General Insurnce Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included realized investment gains of $81,945 for the quarter and realized investment losses of $310,112 for the year; the year also included a tax benefit of $539,480. c-Included realized investment gains of $55,638 and $86,883 for the quarter and year, respectively; the year also included a tax benefit of $544,979. Prior-year figures are restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: Reagan Active on Contra Aid, North Lawyers Say
description: Lawyers for Oliver L. North said today that former President Reagan and other senior United States officials made ''direct, personal'' deals under which Central American and other nations provided secret military aid to rebels inside Nicaragua in the time when Congress had banned military aid to them.

title: Hey! Valentine's Day? Walk This Way
description: LEAD: Hey . . . Won't you be mines today?It's Valentine's

title: Drop in Europe Jobless
description: The unemployment rate in the 12-nation European Community fell in December to 10 percent, its lowest level in more than five years, the community reported today. The jobless rate in November was 10.1 percent. The community last had an unemployment rate of 10 percent in the summer of 1983. Unemployment peaked at 11 percent in the fall of 1984.

title: Western Waste Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Iran to Lift Oil Capacity
description: Iran plans to raise its oil production capacity to 4 million barrels a day from 3.5 million, the Middle East Economic Survey said today. The publication quoted the oil minister, Gholam Reza Aghazadeh, as saying that Iran expected to reach its higher capacity in a year. ''But having this production capacity does not mean we would ever violate our OPEC production quota,'' Mr. Aghazadeh said. He said Iran expected that its quota of 2.64 million barrels a day, established by the Organization Petroleum Exporting Countries in November, would eventually be increased.

description: b-Net loss

title: Oshakati Journal; African Homecoming Promises to Be Triumphant
description: They are waiting for Swapo in this dusty Ovambo town near the Angolan border.

title: Chess
description: Anatoly Karpov, the former world titleholder from the Soviet Union, was almost everyone's favorite to win his quarterfinal world championship candidates match with the Icelandic grandmaster Johann Hjartarson, which ended Feb. 6 in Seattle, and he did, by 3 1/2 to 1 1/2. Indeed, right from the start of these elimination matches, Karpov has been unanimously expected to zip on through to another title bout with his countryman Gary Kasparov.

title: IOWA STOPS SLIDE BY BEATING OHIO STATE, 83-75
description: Roy Marble scored 18 of his 24 points in the first half, and B.J. Armstrong added 20, including six straight free throws in the closing seconds, to lead No. 15 Iowa to an 83-75 victory over No. 16 Ohio State in the Big Ten Conference tonight. Iowa (18-6, 6-5) broke a two-game losing streak.

title: Linpro Specified Properties reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Bush Officials Revising Reagan Budget for 1990
description: The Bush Administration's budget office today issued some minor revisions of the spending estimates for President Ronald Reagan's budget for the fiscal year 1990 and for the current fiscal year, trying to clear up misunderstandings about comparative spending.

title: Historians Need Access to U.S. Documents
description: To the Editor:

title: Nicks to Examine Vandeweghe's Health
description: The Portland Trail Blazers said yesterday that Kiki Vandeweghe would come to New York today to undergo a physical examination for the Knicks. Vandeweghe, who has been the subject of trade talks with the Knicks since last June, saw a doctor in Los Angeles yesterday for an examination of his back, the Blazers' general manager, Bucky Buckwalter, said in a statement. ''It is just one step in the on-going process of discussing a trade which may be made in the next few days,'' Buckwalter said. The trading deadline is Feb. 23. Earlier yesterday, Al Bianchi, the Knick general manager, said the last thing he was told by Buckwalter was that ''they were exploring other avenues and they would get back to us.'' Bianchi said that he would insist on a physical for Vandeweghe before any trade, but said that he had no information that the forward was coming to New York for an examination.

title: Frank G. Taormina; Manufacturer, 89
description: Frank G. Taormina, a food importer and manufacturer who was chairman of Progresso Quality Foods when he retired in 1969, died yesterday at Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. He was 89 years old and lived in Peapack, N.J.

title: U S Sprint Accuses A.T.&T.
description: The U S Sprint Communications Company yesterday accused the American Telephone and Telegraph Company of distributing misleading promotional materials to solicit long-distance telephone accounts for pay telephones.

description: b-Included a non-recurring after- tax capital gain of $5 million, or 49 cents a share, from the sale of marketable securities.

title: Correction
description: Because of producers' changes in plans, articles in the Arts and Leisure section on Sunday about the plays ''Love's Labor's Lost'' and ''In a Pig's Valise'' gave incorrect opening dates in some copies. ''Love's Labor's Lost'' is to open on Feb. 22. ''In a Pig's Valise'' opens tonight.

title: Study Finds No Link Between Cancer Risk And DDT Exposure
description: A STUDY that spanned a decade in the lives of nearly 1,000 people found no statistically significant link between the amount of DDT in their bodies and risk of death by cancer.

title: FASHION: By Design; Be Still, My Heart
description: We know what sort of lingerie men are likely to choose for Valentine's Day gifts. Most women are charmed - or pretend to be - when they receive them. But the underpinnings many women would be happy to get right now are meant to be seen outside the boudoir.

title: Panel Unaware of Baker Stock
description: Some members of the Senate committee that voted to confirm James A. Baker 3d as Treasury Secretary in 1985 were not aware that he held a large amount of bank stock, a Senate aide said today.

title: American Dogwoods Are Unable to Resist Devastating Fungus
description: THE hope that some native American dogwoods might be resistant to a spreading fungal disease that is killing many of the flowering trees has been dashed by a new study.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS

title: Need for Computer Link Seen on Warrants
description: A New York City Councilman charged yesterday that the lack of a computer link between the courts and the police gives a break to bail-jumpers and contributes to a backlog of 400,000 arrest warrants in the city.

title: Politics and Golf
description: Politics and business: Now the mix involves formation of a new Washington bank. The connection was made on a golf course.

title: Debt Swaps In Nigeria Gain Interest
description: In Nigeria, sub-Saharan Africa's first major debt-conversion program has provoked a sharp surge of investor interest, according to figures released today at the African Development Bank.

title: Correction
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday with an article about dividend increases referred incorrectly to the Dow Jones industrial average. The 30 stocks that make up the average do not include Ford Motor.

title: Trade Surplus Up in Japan
description: Japan's trade surplus rose in January from a year ago as low oil prices continued to keep down import costs, the Finance Ministry reported today.

title: Savings Industry Foresees Failures If Capital Requirement Is Doubled
description: The Bush Administration is running into opposition from large segments of the savings and loan industry over the President's proposal to double by 1991 the amount of capital that savings institutions are required to keep on hand.

title: Dave Tarras, 95, Clarinetist, Dies; Purveyor of Klezmer Dance
description: Dave Tarras, a clarinetist who was one of America's most important klezmer musicians, died of pneumonia yesterday at South Nassau Community Hospital on Long Island. He was 95 years old.

title: General Motors Acceptance Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Attack Sub Joins Fleet
description: The nuclear-powered attack submarine Pasadena joined the Navy's fleet Saturday. Thirty-five 35 nuclear weapon opponents conducted a peaceful demonstration outside the commissioning ceremonies. The 360-foot submarine, which displaces 6,900 tons and will carry a crew of 12 officers and 115 enlisted men, was built at General Dynamic's Electric Boat division shipyard here.

title: Genuine Parts Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Mosquito Genes Altered
description: In a possible first step toward a far-off day when mosquitoes would be rendered incapable of carrying diseases like malaria, scientists at Colorado State University have inserted foreign genes into mosquitoes.

description: An Art of Our Own The Spiritual in Twentieth-Century Art By Roger Lipsey Illustrated. 518 pages. Shambhala Publications. $40.

title: Fossil Findings Fan Debate on Human Origins
description: NEW fossil discoveries and genetic evidence have fueled a resounding debate among anthropologists over the timing and circumstances of the last major event in human physical evolution, the emergence of the anatomically modern Homo sapiens.

title: Review/Piano; Andreas Bach Plays Bartok And Beethoven
description: The young West German pianist Andreas Bach returned to the 92d Street Y on Saturday night playing Bartok, Beethoven, Schumann and Liszt. A look at Mr. Bach's brief biography in the printed notes suggests that he is not the product of high-powered conservatories, but has studied quietly with the same teacher for the last nine years. He has won small competitions at home yet does not come to us by way of the larger international events.

The company said 1988 and 1987 results have been restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: Black Officers Defend Ward Against Critics
description: A fraternal organization of black New York City police officers yesterday defended Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward against accusations of insensitivity toward Hispanic New Yorkers, saying two episodes in which he made offensive remarks were ''miscues'' that should not overshadow his ''overwhelming attributes.''

title: For Pants, a New and Softer Mood
description: Trousers are poised once again for a major fashion statement. Last month's haute couture collections put the final stamp of approval on pants for formal daytime and evening wear. Earlier, ready-to-wear designers in every fashion center and at all price levels filled their spring collections with pants in various forms. But it was the couture, with its more rarefied approach to dressing - including a traditional emphasis on grand evening clothes - that gave cachet to the current movement toward pants.

title: Computer Network Technology Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Trenwich Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Fire at McFarlane Town House
description: A fire broke out Sunday afternoon at the home of Robert C. McFarlane, the former national security adviser, Fire Department officials reported. They said no one was injured. Damage to the home, a town house in the Georgetown section, was estimated today at $75,000. Mr. McFarlane, who was national security adviser under President Ronald Reagan, pleaded guilty last year to four misdemeanor counts of withholding information from Congress in connection with the Iran-contra affair.

title: Whistle Up a Billion
description: ''A billion here, a billion there, and pretty soon you're talking about real money,'' Senator Everett M. Dirksen frequently observed.

title: Dexter Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $4,393,000. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $796,000 for the quarter and $606,000 for the year.

title: Ralph Black Is Dead; Arts Manager Was 69
description: Ralph Black, a widely known arts manager and advocate, died of cardiac arrest Monday at Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, Md. He was 69 years old and lived in Bethesda.

title: Albany Can't Afford to Pay All Inflation Costs for Municipalities
description: To the Editor:

title: Rig Count Down Again
description: The number of working oil and gas rigs continued to decline last week, plunging by 34, to a total of 746, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. A year ago the count totaled 968. Baker Hughes's economist, Ike Kerridge, said the count usually falls from late December through late March or early April. The rig count is a widely watched industry index of drilling activity. It reflects the number of rigs exploring for oil as of last Friday.

title: F.B.I. PLAN FAULTED AS RIGHTS THREAT
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation's plan to expand its crime computer to track suspects not charged with any crime poses a serious threat to constitutional rights, a panel of computer scientists says in a new report.

title: Careers; Growth Seen In Ecological Economics
description: YOUNGER economists are increasingly aware of the world's ecological problems and thinking of ways to solve them, said Dr. Paul Ehrlich, a professor of biological sciences at Stanford University.

title: Uribe Charges Dropped
description: A judge in the Dominican Republic ruled yesterday that there was insufficient evidence to take the San Francisco Giant shortstop Jose Uribe to trial for rape. Judge Freddy Matos Nina made the decision in Santo Domingo after questioning Uribe for more than two hours. Uribe, 29, was accused by a woman of threatening her with a gun and raping her. He has denied the charges. (AP)

title: English-Only Bill Ignites Debate and Fear on L.I.
description: A proposal to make English the official language of Suffolk County has ignited a bitter debate over the rights of the county's foreign-speaking residents.

title: Palme Killing: Suspect but No Motive
description: After nearly three years, millions spent and hundreds of thousands of man-hours dedicated to the pursuit of theories of international conspiracy, the hunt for the killer of Prime Minister Olof Palme has apparently narrowed down to a ''lone, mad Swede.''

title: Caution Asked On World Debt
description: Hopes for a dramatic new solution to the $1.3 trillion third-world debt crisis might be running too high, the head of the development panel of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank said today.

title: Fire Linked to Chimney Flaw Kills 8 in an Arkansas Family
description: Eight members of a family here lost their lives over the weekend as a fire swept from a faulty chimney to engulf a farmhouse.

title: Phoenix Re Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MBIA Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
New Presence for Mizrahi
description: When Isaac Mizrahi showed his spring fashion collection at a downtown loft in October, the scene resembled a nightclub opening. The fashion throng milled around a single doorway on lower Broadway near Houston, fighting to get in. Inside, the press and retail executives, normally undemonstrative, alternately shrieked and swooned with delight as models in Mr. Mizrahi's clothes swept down the runway.

title: Klecko Retires at 35
description: Joe Klecko announced his retirement from the National Football League yesterday. Klecko, 35 years old, spent 11 years with the Jets, earning four Pro Bowl trips, before joining the Indianapolis Colts last season. ''My time has passed,'' Klecko said. ''When I came in the league, and even four or five years ago, I remember playing against centers who were 250 or 260 pounds. This year, I played against nine guys that were 290 pounds. It's time for the little guys to move aside.''(AP)

title: Sen. Armstrong of Colorado Says He Will Not Run Again
description: Senator William L. Armstrong, a Colorado Republican who has served in Congress since 1973, said today that two terms were enough and that he would not seek re-election in 1990.

description: Champion Products Inc. announced today that it had agreed to be acquired by the Sara Lee Corporation for $77 a share, or a total of about $320 million.

description: * American Tobacco Co., Stamford, Conn., promoted Vivian A. Parks Jr., Donald S. Johnston and Robert E. Sprinkle 3d to senior vice president and Thomas P. Kriz to controller.

title: 3 DIE AND 60 HURT IN INDIAN PROTEST
description: At least three people were reported killed and more than 60 wounded on Monday when policemen and Muslim demonstrators clashed in the capital of the northern state of Jammu and Kashmir in a protest over the United States publication of Salman Rushdie's novel ''The Satanic Verses.''

description: Cuba announced a campaign today to increase sugar production to an all-time high over the next couple of years, mostly for export to socialist bloc countries.

description: A pair of Brooklyn parents who reported their 7-year-old son missing yesterday afternoon were arrested on charges of child abuse after the police saw the battered boy on a subway train, the police reported.

Honeywell said the contracts cover the supply of process control systems and site services for modernizing ammonia fertilizer units at three chemical plants.

For That Special Valentine, It May Be Love at First Fax
description: Valentine's Day finds Aggi Roselli of Manhattan waiting by a facsimile machine, listening for the bleep, bleep of the fax mating call, hoping it signals the advent of true love on thermal paper. Or at least a date for the weekend.

title: Rangers Puzzled by Feeble Power Play
description: Talk about the power play and the Rangers' locker room instantly resembles an encounter group for millionaires suddenly gone bust. The players sit, palms upturned, expressions downcast, unable to say where the millions and the magic have gone.

description: Gruntal & Company, a large regional brokerage, yesterday announced the appointment of Marshall S. Geller as vice chairman, a move that signals an expansion for Gruntal.

title: Doberman, Wheaten, Puli Gain
description: A Doberman, a soft-coated wheaten terrier, a black standard poodle and a puli won in group judging last night at the 113th annual Westminster Kennel Club show in Madison Square Garden.

description: b-Net loss The company acquired Basic American Imaging Inc. on Dec. 15, 1988, and the results of its operations have been consolidated since that date. Revenue represents revenue under management.

title: Child Care Bills Pour In And Obstacles Arise
description: Many of the issues that occupy Washington, from Afghan politics to agricultural prices, do not directly affect the lives of ordinary citizens. But now the capital is starting to worry about a problem confronting a number of American families every day: who will take care of the children when both parents work?

title: Brown Stock Up
description: Shares of Brown Group Inc. rose today after the St. Louis-based shoe manufacturer announced plans to restructure its operations. Brown Group gained 50 cents, to $34.75, on the New York Stock Exchange. Late Friday, Brown Group said it would take an $18 million charge against earnings to cover losses on the sale of three specialty retailing businesses. The restructuring also includes the disposal of a group of retail shoe stores and a phase-out of two imported shoe brands.

title: KEY RATES
Barrera and Lukas Cited In Drug-Use Investigation
description: D. Wayne Lukas and Laz Barrera, a member of the racing Hall of Fame, are among six trainers under investigation for having run horses that had cocaine in their systems.

title: No More Pretty Flowers
description: Valentine's Day 1989 finds a new President's honeymoon with Congress nearing its inevitable end somewhat sooner than usual. Divorce or even separate bed-rooms may not be in order yet, but they're not sending pretty flowers anymore.

title: Adelphia Communications reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Dailey Reinstated
description: The Los Angeles Clippers guard Quintin Dailey, who was suspended Feb. 6 for being overweight, was reinstated yesterday and will be in uniform tonight at Dallas. Dailey, who leads the Clippers in scoring with a 17-point average, said he weighed 229 pounds when he was suspended. The Clippers' coach, Don Casey, said at that time that he wanted Dailey to weigh under 205 pounds.(AP)

title: Oklahoma Star Arrested by F.B.I.
description: Agents of the F.B.I. arrested Charles Thompson, Oklahoma's starting quarterback, tonight on a complaint of selling cocaine to an undercover agent, authorities said.

Total worldwise retail sales were $64,334,000 versus $61,097,000 for the latest and year-ago quarters, respectively. Total worldwide retail sales were $129,036,000 and $121,582,000 for the latest and year-ago 6 months, respectively.

title: Pact for Lilco Could Restore Fiscal Health
description: After years of financial woes, the Long Island Lighting Company was poised for a settlement with ratepayers last night that would remove the threat of bankruptcy, renew the utility's access to capital markets and begin a process of fiscal recovery.

title: Apogee Robotics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DEBATE ON BUDGET HEATS AS CONGRESS FEARS A BUSH TRAP
description: President Bush and Democrats in Congress intensified their debate today over whether Mr. Bush's $1.16 trillion budget was a realistic effort to trim the deficit or a shrewd political ploy to leave the Democrats with the task of cutting popular social programs.

title: New England's 'Miracle' Economy Slows Down to a More Prosaic Pace
description: The New England economy, whose rocket-like growth was the envy of the nation for most of the decade, is returning to earth.

title: Regrowing Spinal Cord
description: A SOUTH AMERICAN fish that has the unusual ability to regrow a severed spinal cord and nerve cells is being studied by researchers in an effort to find ways to improve treatment for humans who are paralyzed from spinal injuries or degenerative nerve diseases.

title: McGraw-Hill Ryerson reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Mexico-U.S. Loan Called Off But Broader Talks Continue
description: The United States and Mexico have failed to agree on the conditions for the disbursement of an emergency $3.5 billion credit line announced last fall, but broader negotiations aimed at reducing Mexico's foreign debt burden have not been affected, bankers, economists and diplomats here say.

title: Communist Rule Under Challenge in Slovenia
description: Two organizations have been founded here since December to contest openly the ruling Communist Party's monopoly on political power.

title: U.S. Judge Orders Texas Refugee Center Reopened
description: A Federal district judge today overrode local officials and ordered the reopening of a refugee processing center in Harlingen, Tex., that was padlocked last week as a health and fire hazard.

title: LILCO IS REPORTED IN PACT TO SETTLE RACKETEERING SUIT
description: The Long Island Lighting Company and its customers reportedly reached a tentative agreement last night to settle a racketeering case that could have bankrupted the utility.

title: Oswald Goldschmidt; Accountant, 65
description: Oswald Goldschmidt, a certified public accountant for more than three decades who practiced in New York City and Great Neck, L. I., died of respiratory failure last Thursday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 65 years old and lived in Great Neck.

title: Grey to Handle Tonka
description: The Tonka Corporation, whose toy trucks have gladdened many a child's heart, brightened the halls of Grey Advertising yesterday by consolidating its $60 million worth of business there. The company moved the creative and marketing assignments for its Tonka Products division to Grey from Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor, which had been Tonka's agency for seven years. Grey had already been doing Tonka's media-buying and had been fully servicing the company's Kenner Products division since 1977.

title: Silvercrest Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results are restated.

title: Can Knicks And Rangers Win Titles?
description: Now that the Knicks and the Rangers are approaching 3-point and blue-line range of the playoffs, New York's most compelling sports question is being asked almost in a whisper, as if a jinx might be generated if the words were too loud. The question: Is either team capable of winning its championship, the first for the Knicks since Red Holzman deified hitting the open man, the first for the Rangers since the glacier age?

title: Lone Star Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an after-tax loss of $1,564,000 from the extinguishment of debt, and after a pre-tax gain of $75,162,000 on asset dispositions. c-After income of $17,114,000 from the cumulative effect of accounting changes and a pre-tax gain of $49,245,000 on asset dispositions.

title: Steinbrenner Works Out Provisional Deal With John for Tryout
description: Tommy John, who at one time seemed out of the Yankees' plans for this season, said yesterday he had accepted an offer from the club's principal owner, George Steinbrenner, and would be in camp on Thursday.

title: Results Plus
description: TENNIS Zivojinovic Advances: Slobodan Zivojinovic of Yugoslavia defeated Yahiya Doumbia of Senegal, 3-6, 6-3, 6-4, yesterday in the first round of the $492,500 Stella Artois indoor tournament in Milan, Italy. Christian Bergstrom of Sweden beat Patrick Kuhnen of West Germany, 6-4, 6-4., and Joakim Nystrom of Sweden was beaten, 6-1, 1-6, 6-1, by Wally Masur of Australia.(AP) N.H.L. Nordiques 3, Canadiens 2: The left wing Mike Hough assisted on one goal and scored on a short-handed effort as Quebec ended Montreal's five-game winning streak with the victory at Montreal. The defensemen Jeff Brown and Randy Moller had scored first-period goals around a goal by Chris Chelios before Hough made it 3-1 at 2:56 of the second period. It was the fourth victory in six games for the Nordiques over the Canadiens. (AP) Jets 2, Red Wings 2: The Winnipeg goaltender, Bob Essensa, survived a shaky start and a goal off a penalty shot in his league debut, turning aside the final 23 shots he faced as the Jets gained the tie at Detroit. (AP)

title: Review/Theater; Gelbart's Scorn for Scandals
description: Maybe it was foolish to hope that Congress, the press or the courts could ever explain the Iran-contra scandal to anyone's satisfaction. From Fawn Hall's shredder to Robert McFarlane's planned birthday cake for the Ayatollah, this Washington escapade was a farce whose lunatic logic only Hollywood could understand - and only a Hollywood-trained President could have presided over.

title: Home Office Reference Laboratory Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Ailing Robot Industry Is Turning to Services
description: The robotics industry, whose sales have been in the doldrums for the last three years, is getting closer to the day when applications in the service sector of the economy will free it from dependence on industrial users.

title: Appeals Court Orders That Buses Be Fitted for Handicapped
description: A Federal appeals court today ordered the United States Department of Transportation to require transit authorities around the country to equip new buses with wheelchair lifts.

title: Siliconix Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $82,000 and $338,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from the repurchase of debentures at less than face value, and the year also included a gain of $409,000 from an accounting change. c-Included an extraordinary credit of $1,126,000 from the repurchase of debentures.

title: From Remains of West Side Highway, a Reef for Long Island Fish
description: Two New York State agencies have decreed the eventual fate of Manhattan's West Side Highway: it will be sunk to the bottom of the Atlantic to benefit both fish and fishermen.

title: Probation for Star
description: Deion Sanders, the Florida State all-America cornerback, received six months probation and an $800 fine yesterday for grabbing a clerk's blouse and striking a security guard during a shopping mall scuffle. Sanders, 21, pleaded no contest in Fort Myers, Fla., to two simple battery charges and one count of disorderly conduct. All three charges were misdemeanors. Sanders had originally been arrested on the felony charge of battery on a police officer. He is also a baseball star and was expected to arrive at the Yankees' spring training camp next week. (AP)

title: Fencing Streak ends at 51
description: The Columbia University men's fencing team lost a match on Saturday, ending a victorious span that was only two days short of four years. Columbia lost to Penn State, 17-10, during a triangular competition with the Nittany Lions and Haverford at Temple University in Philadelphia.

title: Shevardnadze to Tour Mideast
description: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, will tour the Middle East and the Persian Gulf later this month to discuss regional problems and promote diplomatic links, a Soviet spokesman said today.

title: Shriver Drops Out
description: Pam Shriver, ranked No. 5 in the world, withdrew yesterday from the Virginia Slims of Washington singles competiton.''I'm not going to take the singles court again until I can concentrate on winning some singles matches until I can get my life organized,'' she said. ''I want to prepare for the Grand Slam tournaments, and maybe playing 20 tournaments a year isn't the answer.'' She will be playing doubles in Washington. ''I scared myself last week when I had a physical and emotional collapse for about 12 hours,'' she said. ''Then I picked myself up and started to rearrange things.'' (AP)

title: Jefferson-Pilot Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After gains on investments of $2,382,000 for the quarter and $3,678,000 for the year. c-After a loss of $2,327,000 for the quarter and a gain of $56,489,000 for the year, both on investments.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the dispute over government secrets at the trial of Oliver L. North misstated the Supreme Court's involvement. The action the Court had planned, before an agreement between the White House and the independent prosecutor, was consideration of a stay, not judgment on the merits of the arguments. The Justices would have considered the stay at a regular private meeting, not a public hearing.

title: Leslie Fay Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included the after-tax effect of a non-recurring credit of $5,035,000, or 26 cents a share, due to the elimination of an estimated liability that had been assumed from a predecessor company.

title: A Second Chance for Michael Manley
description: Last week's election in Jamaica did credit to both the new Prime Minister, Michael Manley, and the man he defeated, Edward Seaga. In 1980, when the two men last fought it out, 750 people died in a brutal campaign that Mr. Seaga won. Three years later, farce replaced chaos: Mr. Manley boycotted the election over procedural issues and Mr. Seaga won all 60 parliamentary seats.

title: Carlyle in Talks Over Fairchild
description: The Carlyle Group said today that it was holding talks with third parties about a possible acquisition of Fairchild Industries, the Chantilly, Va., electronics company.

title: Hospitals Try Frivolity to Cut Costs
description: In a room at Hermann Hospital one recent afternoon, a group of nurses huddled near a homemade covered wagon and tried to guess the prices of a variety of products they use every day: a suture removal kit ($11.80), a roll of tape ($4.50), an intravenous set ($12.60), a pair of disposable plastic gloves ($2).

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY Many savings executives are warning that the Administration's proposed capital requirements could drive more than 1,000 associations out of business and add to the industry's crisis. By the 1991 deadline only the top half of the industry will be able to meet the required level of 6 percent of assets, they say.
