[ Page A1. ] The F.D.I.C. is set to take over 197 insolvent institutions. [ D15. ] Prosecutors have promised commodity traders limited immunity if they cooperate with a Federal inquiry, some defense lawyers said. As recently as last week, the prosecutors were reportedly saying that all wrongdoers would be charged with crimes. [ D1. ] The debate over President Bush's budget has intensified, with Democrats questioning whether it is realistic. [ A1. ] COMPANIES Pacific Telesis received permission to invest in a foreign venture, the first such waiver since A.T.&T. was broken up in 1984. But Federal District Judge Harold H. Greene said another Baby Bell company, Nynex, could not enter a trans-Atlantic venture. [ A1. ] Lilco and its customers moved toward settling a racketeering case that could have put the utility in bankruptcy. [ A1. ] Consolidated Freightways agreed to buy Emery Air Freight for $230 million. The acquisition will make Consolidated the nation's largest air-freight operator. It is now No. 3. [ D1. ] Champion Products agreed to be acquired by Sara Lee for $77 a share, sending Champion's stock up 19.1 percent. The athletic apparel company has been fighting a hostile offer from Walsh Greenwood. [ D5. ] Higher fourth-quarter profits were reported by two G.M. subsidiaries, GMAC Financial Services and GM Hughes Electronics. A third unit, Electronic Data Systems, had a decline. The parent is expected to report record profits today. [ D6. ] G.M.'s merit-pay program has drawn an age-discrimination lawsuit. [ D6. ] I.B.M. plans new or expanded operations at four sites in a move to develop computers and software for specific industries. [ D5. ] Carlyle Group is talking with third parties about possibly buying Fairchild Industries, which rejected a previous bid. [ D5. ] MARKETS The London Stock Exchange introduced rules aimed at stemming the losses of British securities houses. Some exchange members, including American firms in London, contend that the changes are an effort to aid old-line British concerns. [ D1. ] Stock prices were mixed as blue-chip issues declined again. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 3.57 points, to 2,282.50. [ D8. ] Treasury bond and note prices slipped in very quiet trading among dealers. Retail investors stayed out of the market. [ D14. ] Copper prices dropped sharply on reports of higher-than-expected inventories in London. Crude oil futures rose. [ D16. ] The dollar edged lower in light trading in anticipation of new economic reports. Gold fell to $386.20 on the Comex. [ D16. ] INTERNATIONAL The U.S. and Mexico failed to agree on terms for a $3.5 billion emergency loan. But officials say the impasse has not affected talks on reducing Mexico's foreign debt burden. [ D1. ] Investors have shown great interest in Nigeria's debt-conversion program. [ D18. ] Four men were arrested on bribery charges in Japan, adding to the furor over a scandal involving Recruit Cosmos stock. [ A6. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Honda is striving to become more American, says its North American president, Tetsuo Chino. Talking Business. [ D2. ] The chances of block commodity trading could grow as a result of the inquiry into ''open outcry'' practices. Market Place. [ D8. ] A hybrid agency with three international parents has proved the skeptics wrong. After just a year and a half, HDM boasted $1.9 billion in billings in 1988. Advertising. [ D19. ]

title: BAKER FINDS FEAR OF 'GORBY FEVER'
description: After three days of talks with Western European leaders, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d is finding that Mikhail S. Gorbachev's charm has so captivated European public opinion that it could begin to inhibit NATO's political room for maneuver, a senior official traveling with Mr. Baker said today.

title: Builder Announces Campaign for Mayor
description: Henry Hewes, who was state chairman of Pat Robertson's Presidential campaign last year, said yesterday that he will run for mayor on the Right to Life Party line.

title: Pentagon, Decisions Await a Leader
description: With the nomination of former Senator John G. Tower as Secretary of Defense in doubt, critical policy decisions at the Defense Department are being put off, especially those on how to cut its budget, officials say.

title: Pride Petroleum Services reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included charges of $600,000 related to restructuring. The net was less than 1 cent a share. Comparable results are not available. The company switched to a calendar year from a fiscal year ending Aug. 31, following the company's spin-ff from DeKalb Corp. on Aug. 31.

title: Future Is Now at Oklahoma Track
description: Five years ago, when the Edward DeBartolo Corporation purchased an undeveloped 375-acre tract from the Oklahoma City Zoo and began building a race track, company officials wondered how the zoo had been using the empty land. When a bulldozer unearthed the first set of elephant bones, they realized where the zoo had long been burying its deceased attractions.

title: Esselte Business Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $116,000 for the quarter and $776,000 for the year.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Alexander & Baldwin Inc., Honolulu, said it would report a one-time gain of $101.6 million, or $2.16 a share, in its first quarter because of the sale of its Wailea Development Co. subsidiary to the Swinwa Golf Group for $197.5 million.

title: Review/Theater; A Moral Puzzle as a Plot
description: Gordon Rayfield's political melodrama ''Bitter Friends'' is a play so charged with incident and moral debate that by the end one is left almost breathless from chasing its labyrinthine arguments.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 President Bush has rewarded major financial contributors and longtime supporters by naming them to prestigious ambassadorships, senior officials say. Page A1

title: INSIDE
description: North Lawyers Cite Reagan In court briefs, Oliver L. North's lawyers say that former President Reagan helped make deals to supply rebels in Nicaragua when Congress had banned military aid. Page A19. The Darker Side of Casinos Atlantic City officials are finding that growing numbers of casino employees have drug, alcohol, marital or other personal problems. Page B1. Highway to Atlantis The West Side Highway's fate is decided: it will be sunk to the bottom of the ocean for fish to live in. Page B1. Antarctic Food Web Threat Krill, tiny shrimplike crustaceans that are the keystone of the Antarctic food chain, are besieged by human intrusions. Science Times, page C1.

title: Cancer Tool Is Used to Save Poisoned Swans
description: LEAD: USING advanced medical techniques developed for treatment of human colon cancer, veterinarians are struggling to save a fragile Midwestern population of trumpeter swans from a severe threat: lead poisoning from shotgun pellets they ingest.

title: 197 Insolvent Institutions Set for Takeover by the F.D.I.C.
description: Following is a list of 197 failed savings and loan institutions set for takeover by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, according to the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.

title: Last Russians Prepare to Depart From Afghanistan by Tomorrow
description: The last Soviet military garrisons in Afghanistan were reported to be packing for home today, less than 48 hours before the Wednesday deadline agreed to by the Kremlin for its final troop withdrawal.

title: Puget Sound Power & Light Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Industrial Training Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Oneita Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
New Rules For Stocks In London
description: The London Stock Exchange introduced new share-trading rules today that it hopes will help stem the losses being suffered by securities houses that make a market in British shares.

title: Outpatient Treatment Helpful for Alcoholics
description: Many alcoholics can be treated as effectively, and much more cheaply, at outpatient clinics as in hospital treatment wards, researchers have found.

title: Brunswick Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest year included a net gain of $10.6 million from the sale of the company's filtration technology business and the writedown of certain assetst. The year-ago fourth quarter and year included an after-tax charge of $6.6 million for the relocation and planned disposition of certain industrial products division businesses.

title: James River Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 22
Reebok's New Models, Fully Loaded
description: Reebok International Ltd., which became a $1.79 billion company on the strength of its high-fashion sneakers, is counting on high technology to increase a lead over Nike Inc. that has been narrowing in the $7 billion worldwide sports shoe market.

title: GM Hughes Electronics Corp reports earnings for
description: An accounting change added $18.7 million, or 5 cents a share, to the company's net income in 1988.

title: Correction
description: An article on the Washington Talk page yesterday about former Senator J. William Fulbright gave a middle name incorrectly for the architect who designed the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. He was Edward Durell Stone.

title: Chris-Craft Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the quarter's decline in net income primarily resulted from a 46 percent decline in television division operating income and the reversal into income last year of previously recorded expenses associated with stock appreciation based compensation plans. The year-ago fourth quarter included a gain of $950,000 associated with stock appreciation rights. The latest year included a loss of $125,000 associated with stock appreciation rights; the prior year included a loss of $5,850,000 associated with stock appreciation rights. The 1988 results included gains of $6,451,000 on sales of marketable securities. The 1987 results included a provision of $1,956,000 on early redemption of debt. Chris-Craft's results are in large part attributable to its investment in Warner Communications Inc. However, Chris-Craft said Warner's January 1989 acquisition of Lorimar Telepictures Corp. is being recorded as a pooling of interests and that Warner's net income for 1988 and prior periods will be restated to reflect Lorimar's substantial losses in recent years.

title: Enron Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $2.7 million for the quarter and an extraordinary loss of $21.2 million for the year from the early extinguishment of debt. c-After a gain of $2 million from discontinued operations. d-Net loss and after a loss of $83 million from discontinued operations. The year-ago periods' results are restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: Give U.S. Math Students More Rote Learning
description: To the Editor:

title: Hybrid Shop Disabuses Naysayers
description: WHEN HDM, the unusual hybrid offspring of Young & Rubicam, Dentsu of Japan and Paris-based Eurocom, was born a year and a half ago, skeptics said it would never work. The three parents had such different cultures that the infant would be pulled apart, they cried. Worse, clients would surely ignore it in favor of its elders.

title: Donald S. Gilpatric; Diplomat, 79
description: Donald S. Gilpatric , a retired Foreign Service officer, died of emphysema Jan. 30 in St. Augustine, Fla. He was 79 years old. Mr. Gilpatric, a Brooklyn native, retired from the Foreign Service in 1981 after nearly 20 years as director of the Office of Foreign Commercial Services in the Department of Commerce. In World War II he was director of the China Relief Mission and economic adviser to Allied Forces Headquarters in Algeria.

title: Winnie Mandela Losing Allies in Soweto
description: Winnie Mandela appears to be increasingly isolated among blacks after weekend reports in the South African press that she took part in the beating of four black youths, one of whom is presumed dead, at her home in Soweto on Dec. 29.

title: Boston's Jewish Population Surges as Soviets Ease Emigration
description: A new wave of Jewish immigrants from the Soviet Union has been flocking to Boston, straining the resources of social service agencies and adding new life to a small but growing community of Jews who have settled in the Allston and Brighton sections of the city and in neighboring Brookline.

title: In a Challenge to Auction Houses, Art Dealers Stage an Exhibition
description: New York's newest - and most short-lived - art museum is to open tomorrow at the Seventh Regiment Armory, on Park Avenue at 67th Street, where the first group exhibition ever organized by the Art Dealers Association of America begins a five-day run.

title: Reynolds Chairman to Quit
description: In a surprise announcement, Edward A. Horrigan Jr., chairman of the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company for the last nine years, announced late yesterday that he would leave RJR Nabisco Inc. on March 1.

title: Celebrating Two Mad Decades of Pythonmania
description: Near the end of the Monty Python seminar yesterday, a member of the audience asked the Python troupe to define the difference between English and American humor.

title: Talking Business with Chino of Honda; The Campaign To Be 'American'
description: Last week at the Chicago Auto Show, the Honda Motor Company introduced the prototype of a sophisticated, high-performance sports coupe that will sell for $50,000 to $60,000 when it appears in Honda's Acura luxury-car franchises in about a year.

title: Ruling Favors Player
description: A former Seattle Seahawk wide receiver, Sam McCullum, was illegally discharged by the Seahawks when he was cut before the strike-marred 1982 season, the National Labor Relations Board ruled yesterday. McCullum, then the Seahawks' player representative, must be given back pay, with interest, from the time of his release and a job ''substantially equivalent'' to the job he lost, the N.L.R.B. ruled in a 2-1 decision. The Seahawks did not have immediate comment. The team can appeal. (AP)

title: Accounts
description: * Yellow Spots Inc., a marketing firm, to Ahern & Heussner, with a budget of $1 million.

title: NICARAGUA PLANS EARLIER ELECTIONS
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua said today that his Government was planning to advance the date for national and municipal elections by up to 10 months as a step toward greater democracy in Nicaragua.

title: U.S. Issues Slip in Slow Trading
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds dipped again in very quiet intra-dealer trading yesterday. Meanwhile, retail investors, stung by last week's sharp selloff, retreated to the sidelines.

title: FlightSafety International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago share earnings adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in August 1988.

title: Air-Freight Companies To Merge
description: Consolidated Freightways Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Emery Air Freight Corporation for $7.75 a share, or about $230 million. The acquisition will make Consolidated the nation's largest air-freight operator.

title: Drawing the Line in the Arctic
description: LEAD: In his budget address last Thursday, President Bush called for the ''cautious'' development of oil and gas resources in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. But for this last Arctic coastal wilderness, that is an oxymoron.

title: GATT Talks on Subsidies
description: The world trade body GATT deliberated today on how to cut or freeze farm subsidies, a main cause of trade friction between the United States and Europe.

title: Toussie Seeks To Acquire Lionel
description: Robert I. Toussie L.P. said it wanted to acquire the Lionel Corporation, the New York maker of electronic components and retailer of toys, games and leisure products. Toussie, a New York partnership that already owns 9.9 percent of Lionel's stock, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it was seeking a meeting with Michael J. Vastola, Lionel's chairman and chief executive.

title: Teleflex Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Johnson & Johnson reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
In Home Health Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Diversified Energies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest periods' results included gains of $6 million for the quarter and $6.3 million for the year, both from accounting changes. The latest and prior year share earnings included 36 cents and 20 cents, respectively, for income related to the settlement of take-or-pay disputes in 1988 and 1987.

title: Dow Loses 3.57 Points, Closing at 2,282.50
description: LEAD: Stock prices were mixed yesterday, although blue-chip issues fell, as they have most of this month.

title: Italy Is Sued by the U.S.
description: The United States asked the World Court today to order Italy to pay more than $12 million compensation in a dispute over the Italian Government's 1968 requisition of a United States-owned company.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The dying order always likes to give a few kicks before it goes to rest.'' - Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto of Pakistan, on motives for demonstrations in Islamabad. [ A14:2. ]

title: New Tactic In Chicago Inquiry Seen
description: In what appeared to be a change of tack in the Government's inquiry into commodity trading practices here, Federal prosecutors have told some traders that they will not be charged with crimes if they cooperate, three defense lawyers said today.

title: Backward-Facing Seat No Help in Air Crash
description: To the Editor:

title: Schultz Sav-O Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect stock splits effected May 1987 and February 1989.

title: Neeco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $722,061 gain from the repurchase of debentures.

title: Cooper Tire & Rubber Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Lorenzo Orders Magazine Back
description: Frank Lorenzo, chairman of the Texas Air Corporation, has told officials of Eastern Airlines, a subsidiary, to allow copies of the Feb. 27 issue of Fortune magazine on the airline's fleet even though it carries a less-than-flattering profile of Mr. Lorenzo, Eastern officials said today.

title: Assix International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Secretary Baker's Debt
description: Imagine that you are a cabinet officer whose actions can rescue American banks that have lent billions in shaky loans to third world countries. Should you hold stock in one of those banks? The obvious answer is no, but it doesn't seem obvious to Secretary of State James Baker.

title: Office Depot Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $102,000 and $648,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss The 1988 net from operations included life insurance proceeds of $2,000,000, or 27 cents a share. Latest fourth-quarter results included 14 weeks and the year-ago fourth quarter included 13 weeks. The 1988 year had 53 weeks while the 1987 results are for 52 weeks.

title: Helping the Ex-Homeless Furnish a Home
description: One year after they lost their apartment and ended up in a single room at the Brooklyn Arms, Linda Adeyeye and her five daughters are starting over.

title: 2 Liposome Units Agree to a Merger
description: Liposome Technology Inc., which is based in Menlo Park, Calif., and the Liposome Company of Princeton, N.J., said they had agreed to merge, forming the Liposome Companies. The two biotechnology concerns were independently formed in 1981. Both are developing drug-delivery technology using liposomes, fat globules that can be filled with a pharmaceutical for a specific area of the body.

title: Argentine Military Foils Second Attack On Army Barracks
description: Argentine soldiers repelled an attack shortly before dawn today by an unidentified group of armed men on a provincial army barracks, an army spokesman said.

title: Affiliated Publications Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
description: b-After losses of $43,718,000 for the quarter and $132,768,000 for the year from Affiliated's equity share of McCaw Cellular Communications' losses. c-Net income d-Included losses of $19,252,000 for the quarter from Affiliated's equity share of McCaw Cellular's losses and Affiliated's equity share gain of $39,978,000 for the year on the sale of McCaw's discontinued operations; the year also included income of $17,879,000 from a McCaw extraordinary credit. The prior year's net from continuing operations is after a gain of $121,750,000 from Affiliated's equity interest in McCaw's initial public offering.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Alabama Housing Finance Authority is tentatively offering $50 million of single-family mortgage revenue bonds, which in turn are collateralized by the Government National Mortgage Association's mortgage revenue bonds. The bonds are rated triple-A by Standard & Poor's.

title: National Loan Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Comparable earnings for the full year 1987 are not available because the bank originated on May 1. For the eight months of 1987, National Loan Bank, which is now in liquidation, reported a loss of $5,198,000.

title: Senate Votes, for 13th Time To Bring Back Death Penalty
description: In the first step in what has become an annual ritual, the New York State Senate voted overwhelmingly today to restore the death penalty.

title: In Antarctica, New Threats to the Fragile Web of Life
description: IN this icy world virtually devoid of the land plants that sustain most animal life elsewhere, survival of the spectacular species that live here - from albatrosses and penguins to seals and whales -hinges on a frigid sea teeming with microscopic plants and the tiny crustaceans called krill that eat them.

title: No Breakup Seen For Blue Arrow
description: Mitchell S. Fromstein, the recently named chief executive of Blue Arrow P.L.C., said he had no plans to break up or sell off parts of the temporary-services giant. Britain's Blue Arrow, the world's largest employment group, bought the American personnel company Manpower Inc. in 1987. In the last year, Blue Arrow has struggled to meet earnings expectations amid management disagreements, spurring rumors that part or all of the company might be sold.

title: G.M. Truck Plants
description: The General Motors Corporation said it planned to refurbish and retool assembly plants in Janesville, Wis., and Flint, Mich., for the production of new truck models in the early 1990's. G.M. said it would convert its Janesville plant, which now builds cars and trucks, into a truck-only plant. It will build the next generation of its Suburban and Blazer or Jimmy sport utility vehicles. Those vehicles are now built at the Flint plant, which G.M. said would receive a new truck line.

title: Sage Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Tyson Extends Holly Farms Offer
description: Tyson Foods Inc., the Springdale, Ark., chicken processor, said it had extended its $60-a-share tender offer for the Holly Farms Corporation of Memphis until Friday. Holly Farms has spurned the Tyson offer.

title: Shanahan and Verbeek Register Hat Tricks
description: The Devils have had more than their share of difficulty against teams with poor records this season, but they had their largest production of the season tonight against the next-to-last team in the league.

title: Bass Group Buys 5.7% Xicor Stake
description: A group led by Sid R. and Lee M. Bass of the wealthy Texas family said it had bought 5.7 percent of the outstanding stock of Xicor Inc. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Bass group said it had acquired about one million of Xicor's shares for investment purposes. Xicor is a Milpitas, Calif., maker of semiconductors. Xicor shares rose 37.5 cents today, to $7.75, in over-the-counter trading.

title: Fraud in Medical Research Tied to Lax Rules
description: An ''excessively permissive'' attitude by institutions tends to allow careless and sometimes even fraudulent medical research, a committee of the national Institute of Medicine reported today.

title: Stepping Down
description: Frank Hodsoll, chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts for seven years, will leave soon, people close to him say. Mr. Hodsoll, a former Foreign Service officer and White House official, said last month that he planned to complete his term, in November. He has been associated with James A. Baker 3d, now the Secretary of State, and Richard G. Darman, now the director of the Office of Management and Budget.

title: Laclede Gas Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
At the Tone, Hang Up
description: The White House switchboard operators are vaunted for always getting the right party on the line, but Phyllis Jeacock of Ridgefield, Conn., says she has a hard time getting the operators to stay on the line.

title: Market Place; Block Trading In Commodities
description: ON Wall Street, it has become commonplace to arrange big stock trades off the floor of the exchange. In the Chicago commodity markets, such block trading is illegal. All trades must be arranged on the floor.

title: Hearts and Arrows
description: If I love you, what business is it of yours? GOETHE

title: Lincoln Center Award Named for Beverly Sills
description: Lincoln Center has established a new award for young American singers in honor of Beverly Sills, who is leaving the directorship of the New York City Opera in May.

title: ARCO Spending
description: ARCO said its board had approved a 30 percent increase in its 1989 capital spending program, to $2.6 billion, from $2 billion last year. ARCO said that it would increase capital spending in all business segments in 1989 and that worldwide spending for oil exploration and production would rise to $1.5 billion, from $1.1 billion in 1988. The company said $1.15 billion would be spent on exploration and production in the United States.

title: 2 G.M. Subsidiaries Post Higher Earnings
description: Two subsidiaries of the General Motors Corporation, GMAC Financial Services and GM Hughes Electronics, today reported higher fourth-quarter profits, while a third, Electronic Data Systems, posted a decline.

title: Anti-U.S. Protesters in Seoul Battle With Police for Hours
description: South Korean riot policemen fought running battles with thousands of club-wielding anti-American demonstrators trying to storm the parliament building in Seoul today, witnesses said.

title: Fiat Ex-Official Goes to Ford
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it had hired the former president of Fiat S.p.A., Vittorio Ghidella, as a consultant to its Ford Automotive Group.

title: Drexel Counsel Leaves Firm
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. said yesterday that its general counsel had left to go into private practice.

title: Heekin Can Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Student Slain, Suspect Flees With Girl, 17
description: A nationwide alert has been issued for a 19-year old Sussex County man suspected of stabbing to death a high school student and forcing a young woman to go with him as he fled from a party early Sunday.

title: Delphi Information Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Verdix Corp reports earnings for
description: b-Net loss

title: Georgetown Tightens Its Grip On Syracuse
description: When it became apparent about three weeks ago that Georgetown was the dominant team in the Big East Conference, there was a groundswell of anticipation for tonight's showdown with Syracuse, the league's other power.

title: Cincinnati Microwave Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain from discontinued operations of $423,000 for both the quarter and year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $157,000 for the quarter and $1,408,000 for the year.

title: Wyse Technology
description: Wyse Technology, a manufacturer of personal computers and computer terminals, said it expected an operating loss for its fourth fiscal quarter, ending March 31. Wyse, based in San Jose, Calif., suffered a loss of $26.4 million in the third quarter. The expected loss in the fourth quarter will put Wyse in violation of certain credit agreements and force it to seek waivers from its lenders or alternative financing, the company said. Wyse's shares rose 37.5 cents today, to $5.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Attack on U.S. Site In Pakistan Growing Into Crisis for Bhutto
description: The attack on the American cultural center here is growing into a crisis for Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto.

title: TOKYO TOLL GROWS IN STOCK SCANDAL
description: The political furor over a stock scandal worsened today when the police arrested four men on bribery charges linked to insider trading in the company's stock.

title: Boonton Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter results reflect temporary conditions, primarily transition costs from the acquisition of Integra Inc.

title: Chip Makers Report Gains
description: The semiconductor industry's closely watched indicator, the book-to-bill ratio, climbed to 1.0 in January, the best showing since August, the Semiconductor Industry Association reported today.

title: 7% Note Issue By Puerto Rico
description: The Commonwealth of Puerto Rico yesterday tapped the short-term debt market and priced $530 million of tax and revenue anticipation notes through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Lawyer at Fed Resigns; Joins Washington Firm
description: Michael Bradfield, the general counsel of the Federal Reserve Board and a supporter of cautious deregulation of banking, has resigned to join the law firm of Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue in Washington.

title: For Casino Employees, Pace Takes a Personal Toll
description: Along with the economic rebirth that casinos have brought to this resort area, social and mental-health workers are finding growing personal problems that they link to the intense round-the-clock style of the gambling industry.

title: International Aluminum Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest periods included losses from discontinued operations of $408,000 for the quarter and $565,000 for the 6 months.

title: Milgray Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $351,200 from a change in accounting.

title: Home Loan Banks Financing Set
description: The Federal Home Loan Banks plan to announce the interest rates today for a five-part financing totaling $6.38 billion.

title: BABY BELL CLEARED TO INVEST ABROAD
description: For the first time since the 1984 breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, one of the seven regional telephone companies has been given permission to invest in a major foreign telecommunications operation.

title: Coverage of Jury After Steinberg Trial Sets Dangerous Precedent; Eloquent Testimony
description: To the Editor:

title: Cuomo and Shoreham: Sharing the Responsibility
description: By insisting that the State Legislature approve any settlement to close the Shoreham nuclear power plant, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has raised questions about what is more important to him: closing the plant or sharing responsibility for his actions with lawmakers.

title: Cow Manure Fuels a California Power Plant
description: A desert power plant fueled by cow manure is generating enough electricity to supply up to 20,000 homes.

title: UNC Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $8,909,000 and $12,221,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also included a gain of $3,915,000 from an accounting change. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $1,107,000 and $5,933,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and a tax credit of $963,000 and $7,203,000 for the same periods, respectively.

title: True to Custom, Bush Appoints Allies as Envoys
description: President Bush has rewarded several major financial contributors to his Presidential campaign and longtime supporters by naming them to prestigious ambassadorships, senior officials said today.

title: Armenian Patriarch Makes A Bid for Unity in U.S. Visit
description: On the day before returning to Soviet Armenia, Patriarch Vasken I, the Supreme Patriarch and Catholicos of All Armenians, looked back on a remarkable week.

title: 2 Hurt in Midtown As Car Loses Control
description: A speeding car went out of control yesterday afternoon on West 53d Street, hitting objects on either side of the street before plowing into scaffolding across from the Sheraton Centre, the police and witnesses said.

title: Poor Little Westway Jr.
description: It's easier to untangle a snarled fishing line than to get straight the facts behind Gov. Mario Cuomo's recent decision to stop the work of the task force on Westway Jr. The 14-member group was defining the riverbank esplanade and other areas adjacent to the scaled-down version of Westway, the proposed highway on Manhattan's West Side that was killed in 1985.

title: Making Learning Fun
description: WHAT do you do when you see a grizzly bear? Keep quiet, make noise or run?

title: JP Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After gains from discontinued operations of $344,000 for the quarter and $3,145,000 for the year. c-After gains from discontinued operations of $889,000 and $3,235,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Skywest Airlines reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Telefonica de Espana SA reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Share earnings were based on U.S. GAAP and on an exchange rate of 113.592 pesetas to the dollar as of Dec. 30.

title: Celltronics Inc reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
New Discrimination Charge Is Lodged Against G.M.
description: The General Motors Corporation, which two weeks ago settled a lawsuit accusing it of racial discrimination, is now faced with another that accuses it of discriminating against its older salaried employees.

title: Tests Hint Drug May Invigorate Older Brain
description: Tests with rabbits suggest that a drug approved for some stroke patients may also reinvigorate aging brains, a group of Chicago researchers have reported.

title: Q&A
description: Q. What happens when you crack your knuckles? Does it cause arthritis? A.The bones and the series of ligaments that form the knuckles and many other joints have a little elasticity, said Dr. Robert L. Swezey, director of the Arthritis and Back Pain Center in Santa Monica, Calif.

title: Bridge
description: Card magic comes in two varieties: the physical illusions of the card manipulator, and the technical brilliancies of the card player. Sidney Lenz, a great star of the past, could bring off both kinds of tricks. That is why he never played bridge for a money stake.

title: Terrorism Trial in U.S. Moves Minor Actor to Center Stage
description: A year and a half ago, Fawaz Yunis became the first accused terrorist to be spirited out of Lebanon to face American justice. Now he is about to become the leading figure in a trial designed to demonstrate the effectiveness of a 1984 law that makes overseas hijacking a crime in the United States if Americans were victims.

title: Crib Death: Suspicion Turns To the Brain
description: THE explanation for sudden infant death syndrome, a mysterious malady that kills 8,000 American babies each year, seems to lie in the developing brain, scientists are concluding.

title: Simpson Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
National Healthcorp LP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are in units.

title: Grainger, W W Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Harvard Captures Beanpot Final
description: In a wild 15-goal game, Harvard persevered tonight at Boston Garden and defeated Boston University, 9-6, to win the Beanpot tournament for the first time since 1981.

title: Changes for Cowboys
description: Coach Tom Landry, stung by a 3-13 season and a last-place finish in 1988, hinted he might stay with the Dallas Cowboys into the next decade while announcing several changes on his staff yesterday. Landry replaced the defensive coordinator, Ernie Stautner, and the pass coordinator, Paul Hackett. He hired George Hill as defensive coordinator and Jerry Rhome as quarterbacks coach. ''I have no intention of retiring unless it is forced upon me,'' Landry said. Stautner, the Cowboys' defensive coordinator for 20 years, and Hackett were reassigned to work on special projects. (AP)

title: Outcry Saddens Him, Novel's Author Says
description: ''The Satanic Verses,'' the book that provoked mob violence in Pakistan, is a phantasmagoric tale that begins with a plane crash over the English Channel in which two men survive to be ''born again,'' one marked with a halo, the other with slowly developing horns and hoofs.

title: Roanoke Electric Steel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
The Heart of the Matter
description: LEAD: All lovers are secret lovers.

title: Dennison Manufacturing Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $916,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. c-After a charge of $506,000 from the early extinguishment of debt for the quarter and year; the quarter also included an after-tax charge of $1,993,000 from the sale of an equity interest in Geha-Werke. Earnings for 1988 have been restated to reflect an accounting change. The full-year 1987 included after-tax charges of $1,993,000 and $7,123,000 on the sale of two wholly owned subsidiaries and an after-tax gain of $9,802,000 from the sale of Hygeia Sciences Inc. common stock.

title: Reviews/Television; Chernobyl Revisited
description: Tonight, ''Nova'' returns to Chernobyl, the site of the world's worst nuclear accident, to explore what happened the morning of April 26, 1986, and what has been happening since -and, as an aside, whether it could happen here. Easily understood graphics lay out the causes of the explosion at a nuclear reactor - the lack of adequate safeguards, compounded by operators who apparently made every mistake that could be made. Soviet officials concede that the initial response was confused and that anti-nuclear stirrings among the citizenry are causing them trouble. ''Back to Chernobyl'' can be seen at 9 P.M. on Channel 13 and at 8 on Channels 21 and 49.

title: Abuse Cases Inspire Gifts To Neediest
description: On ''this holiday of love,'' wrote Barbara Seaman of Manhattan, she wanted to remember Lisa Steinberg and Jessica Cortez. She sent a gift to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund as a memorial to the two young victims of domestic violence.

title: Reece Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TV Station Settles Harassment Case
description: Five female employees of an Albany television station who filed sexual discrimination complaints against a station manager will receive $25,000 each under a settlement, Attorney General Robert Abrams said yesterday.

title: Worldwide Value Fund reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Net asset value at Dec. 31 was $58,684,108, or $19.53 a share, versus $49,462,941, or $16.46 a share, for year- ago period.

title: Home Loan Banks' Offering in 5 Parts
description: The Federal Home Loan Banks is offering $6.38 billion in bonds, including a competitive issue, in five parts. All are priced at par, except for the competitive deal, which went to an underwriting group led by Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.

title: Penny-Stock Firm Closes
description: A penny-stock firm accused of defrauding thousands of customers has halted its operation, citing the financial pressure from a flood of investors seeking their money back.

title: Fischbach Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of about $2 million relating to a pension plan termination. c-Net income and included an extraordinary credit of $10,433,000, or $2.67 a share from an accounting change and interest income relating to income tax refunds amountin to $6.9 million.

title: Crown Cork & Seal reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago quarter and full year results are restated to reflect a 3-for-1 stock split in September.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Rubin Postaer
description: Rubin Postaer & Associates, known best for its largest client, Honda automobiles, has taken in another Japanese account: Seiko Instruments U.S.A., a division of Hattori Seiko, which makes consumer electronics products. This is Seiko Instruments' first consumer ad agency. The account is expected to bill $5 million.

title: ...So My Husband And I Decided to Take a Car Trip Through New England
description: LEAD: Even if I had a Ph.D. in psychology, Even if I were a diplomatic whiz, Even if I were Queen of the Charmers and more irresistibly sexual Than whoever the current reigning sexpot is, And even if I had a fortune to squander on payoffs, And even if I had Mafia connections, I still would be incapable of persuading my husband, when lost, To stop - please stop - the car, and ask for directions.

title: Welter of Braille Codes Create 'Tower of Babel'
description: Michael J. McDermott Jr., an 11th-grade honor student who is a computer whiz, cannot read a book or write a term paper.

title: Revenue Bonds For Texas Agency
description: The Texas Water Resources Finance Authority is offering $511.1 million in revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 7.75 percent for an issue due in 2008 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Academic Elite Using Sports Too
description: In an era when more and more evidence suggests that big-time college sports runs the universities rather than the other way around, a number of schools with small-time sports programs are putting those programs to work for them.

title: Conrail Board May Select Chief Today
description: The board of directors of Conrail may select a successor today to Richard D. Sanborn Jr., the chairman and chief executive who died Sunday after suffering a heart attack.

title: Crude Camp Arises in Texas Brush After Immigration Center Is Moved
description: The Government announced today that Central Americans seeking political asylum would be processed at a remote detention center near here, and within hours dozens of aliens began setting up a primitive camp in the brush outside the gates.

title: Viking Free-Agent Camp
description: Seventeen players, including Onzy Elam, a Jets linebacker, turned out yesterday for the start of the Minnesota Vikings' free-agent camp in Orlando, Fla. They were part of the group of 619 players who were declared unfettered free agents by their teams Feb. 1.

title: Loss Reported by Affiliated
description: Affiliated Publications Inc. said on Monday that it lost $29.5 million in the fourth quarter of 1988 and $80.9 million for the year, largely because of its share of the losses of a cellular telephone company.

title: Masco Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest year restated for acquisitions accounting for as pooling of interest.

title: Khomeini Urges Muslims to Kill Author of Novel
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini of Iran declared today that the author and publishers of a novel deemed offensive to Islam had been ''sentenced to death.'' The novelist, Salman Rushdie, author of ''The Satanic Verses,'' said he was taking the threat seriously.

title: Conflict Over Ethics Divides 2 of Bush's Closest Advisers
description: With his plan to set higher ethical standards for his Administration, President Bush has inadvertently created problems for two of his closest advisers and pitted them against each other in a tense public conflict over ethics.

title: Lilco Judge: Panache, Perseverance
description: As a teen-ager in the 1930's, Jack B. Weinstein played bit parts in Broadway shows and was briefly one of the bad boys in the original ''Dead End.'' In those same years, the future law professor and judge delivered milk and worked at a trucking company to earn money for school.

title: Dollar Ends Sharply Lower After Bush's Rate Remarks
description: The dollar tumbled against leading foreign currencies yesterday, largely in response to President Bush's remarks opposing further tightening of credit by the Federal Reserve Board. The statement coincided with indications that the Japanese and West German central banks are about to raise interest rates.

title: Alan Saul Pomerance, Dentist, 62
description: Dr. Alan Saul Pomerance, a dentist, died of lung cancer Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 62 years old.

title: Book Notese
description: An Unusual Selection

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * British Airways P.L.C., London, said it would begin daily flights between London and Newark starting in the spring of 1990.

title: WINE TALK
description: IF you like language and wine, you will be interested in two events of recent weeks that may not at first seem connected. One was the creation of a new viticultural district in the Napa Valley. The other was the announcement of a new wine.

title: ITT Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest periods included ''fresh start'' tax benefits at the Hartford of $16.9 million, or 11 cents a share, for the quarter, and $52 million, or 36 cents a share, for the year, and an after-tax provision of $41 million for discontinued operations, primarily for several environmental clean-up issues at the company's Southern Wood Piedmont unit, for the both periods. The year-ago periods included tax benefits at the Hartford of $30.9 million, or 21 cents a share, for the quarter and $100.5 million, or 67 cents a share, for the year; a gain of $252.8 million, or $1.68 a share, on the sale of ITT's 24 percent interest in STC Plc. for the both periods. The 1987 year also included a charge of $66.7 million from an accounting change at ITT Defense Technology.

title: 2 Trading Practices Could Bring Prosecution
description: A former United States Attorney hired to advise the Chicago Board of Trade on the criminal inquiry into commodity trading activities today identified two types of illegal trading practices that could be prosecuted under the Federal racketeering law.

title: Rushdie Is Still Planning to Visit U.S. Next Week
description: A death sentence by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini and other protests have not altered the plans of the novelist Salman Rushdie to come to the United States next week to promote ''The Satanic Verses,'' his American literary agent said yesterday.

title: Report Says Bomber Had Fire Before Crash
description: The Air Force said today that investigators had been unable to determine the exact cause of a B-1 bomber crash in Texas in November but that a fire on board had been fed by a fuel leak and had destroyed control lines. All four aviators aboard ejected and parachuted to safety.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 India's Supreme Court ordered the Union Carbide company to pay $470 million in damages for the toxic gas leak at Bhopal, ending a legal battle over compensation Page A1

title: Mosbacher Pessimistic On Steel Pact
description: Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher said today that the domestic steel industry was assured continued trade protection because there was no chance anytime soon of concluding an international agreement that would ban trade-distorting steel subsidies.

title: Agencies at Odds on Japan's Role in Fighter Plan
description: The Bush Administration is split over whether to delay a project under which Japan would develop a new version of the F-16 fighter, Administration officials and Congressional aides said today.

title: Roslyn Journal; Where Have All the Forests Gone?
description: Looking up at the shaved hillsides outside this frontier mountain town, Marianne Gordon sees her old nature trails turned to stubble and her husband's hunting grounds denuded of trees.

title: BHOPAL PAYMENTS BY UNION CARBIDE SET AT $470 MILLION
description: Ending a legal battle over compensation for victims of the world's most deadly industrial disaster, the Indian Supreme Court today ordered the Union Carbide Corporation to pay $470 million in damages for the toxic gas leak at Bhopal.

title: Impartial Juries, Yes, But Not Ignorant Ones
description: To the Editor:

title: Dolph C. Simons, 84, Newspaper Executive
description: Dolph C. Simons, chairman of the board of The Journal-World, a daily newspaper in Lawrence, Kan., and of the World Company, its parent company, died in his sleep yesterday morning at his winter home in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 84 years old and lived in Lawrence.

title:
BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Who's on First? Ask the Baseball Card
description: LEAD: Dave Winfield and Keith Hernandez, take note: Baseball cards can now talk. Will voice inflection soon count as much as batting averages?

title: For Hindu Millions, Rivers of Divine Nectar
description: A gathering of millions of Hindus for a major festival has served as an impressive display of the hold that faith continues to have on the life of this young nation and ancient land.

title: Economic Scene; Business Subdued In Tax Debate
description: WHEN it comes to lobbying Congress for tax breaks, business executives aren't wallflowers. Their representatives are usually vociferous and persistent. Year after year, they have argued that one tax concession or another is needed to make companies more competitive. But 1989 is different. In the developing debate over taxes, the voice of corporate America is strangely subdued.

title: Coastal Extends Texas Eastern Bid
description: The Coastal Corporation extended its $2.6 billion cash offer for the Texas Eastern Corporation by 10 days after the deadline for its original offer expired Monday. Coastal officials extended the $42-a-share offer to next Thursday, a spokesman, Robert Wells, said. Both companies are based in Houston.

title: To Be a Little Flower: 5 Years and 16 Pounds
description: ''It's like a laboratory, my house, for the creation of character,'' Tony Lo Bianco was saying. ''When I'm working, I'm like a mad scientist. One day my wife came home from shopping, and she heard this voice and she thought it was somebody else in the house. That was when I knew I could play La Guardia.''

title: Baker Selling His Stocks to Avoid Any Conflict in State Dept. Role
description: James A. Baker 3d said today that he had decided to sell his shares in Chemical Bank and all his other stocks so as to avoid any appearance of conflict of interest with financially related decisions he might make as Secretary of State.

title: Group Fails to Get Stake in Lampoon
description: The Grodnik Matheson Company, a Los Angeles investor group, said it had tried unsuccessfully to buy a 10 percent stake in National Lampoon Inc. from the company's chairman, Matty Simmons. Reached at his office in Los Angeles, Mr. Simmons said he would not comment on the proposal. Mr. Simmons said he holds between 10 percent and 11 percent of National Lampoon's 1.5 million shares outstanding.

title: Review/Television; Stand-Up Comedy at a Safe Distance
description: The scene for stand-up comedy can be confusing these days, encompassing everybody from outrageous Sam Kinison to gentle Louie Anderson. Sometimes the audiences are more interesting than the performers as they submit happily to being insulted or ferociously jump to their feet with clenched fists raised. But more and more comedians are working full time, and cable television, especially, has been taking full advantage with a steady progression of comedy specials, offering viewers the chance to observe from a safe distance.

title: Star Game: The Lullaby Of Basketball
description: rrSid the Doorman was home watching the N.B.A. All-Star Game Sunday afternoon when he soon began having great difficulty staying awake. At first he thought he might be coming down with some terrible jungle sleeping sickness, or maybe it was the early hours he was keeping.

title: Real Estate; Wall Street Office Rents Are Bearish
description: FOUR years ago, when London & Leeds, the American real estate division of the British Ladbroke Group, acquired the old Cocoa Exchange building at the intersection of Beaver, Pearl and Wall Streets, its plan to turn around the dilapidated building looked like a solid bet.

title: British Retail Sales Dip
description: British retail sales dropped 1.5 percent in January, in a dramatic shift from December, the Department of Trade and Industry reported on Monday.

title: Review/Art; Britain's Heritage, a Rich Attic, on View
description: One of the best things that has happened to Britain since the end of World War II was the establishment in 1980 of the National Heritage Memorial Fund. An act of Parliament stood behind it, but as is often the way in Britain, the trustees of the fund had no precise mandate. ''Heritage'' was nowhere defined in the act in question. Nor were provisions made for regular Government grants.

title: Charles S. Gage, Executive, 85
description: Charles S. Gage, a retired treasurer of Yale University, died Sunday at Yale-New Haven Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in Hamden, Conn.

title: James Hunter 3d, 72, Federal Appeals Judge
description: James Hunter 3d, a judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit since 1971, died of heart failure Friday at Burlington County Memorial Hospital in Mount Holly, N.J. He was 72 years old and lived in Medford, N.J.

title: LATIN PRESIDENTS ANNOUNCE ACCORD ON CONTRA BASES
description: The presidents of five Central American countries announced an agreement today under which contra bases in Honduras would be closed in return for open elections in Nicaragua.

title: Mining Plans in Vietnam
description: An Australian mining and investment company said Monday that it had secured rights to mine for gold and chromite in Vietnam. Convictory Investment said it hoped to complete feasibility studies within six months on the Bong Mieu gold mine in southern Vietnam and the Thanh Hoa chromite mine in the north. Bong Mieu, mined by the French until 1942, could produce 16,000 ounces of gold a year for 10 years, Convictory said. The Thanh Hoa mine is an alluvial deposit 7.5 miles long by two miles wide, and the company put possible production levels at 200,000 tons of chromite or 105,000 tons of ferrochrome annually.

title: Reuters Posts 15.8% Rise in Profits for 1988
description: Reuters Holdings P.L.C., the London-based international news and information agency, reported yesterday that its net profits rose 15.8 percent in 1988, reflecting increased orders and cost-cutting efforts.

title: AIDS Study Finds Virus At High Rate In the Bronx
description: Testing of blood samples from a group of 143 emergency-room patients at a South Bronx hospital has shown that 23 percent of them were infected with the AIDS virus, a finding that health officials call a disturbing sign of the extent of the epidemic.

title: Review/Music; Pieces by Virtuoso Pianists
description: Voytek Matushevski, a pianist from Poland, devoted his Sunday afternoon Alice Tully Hall recital to music by four composers who were also virtuoso pianists. Prominent on the program were Ignace Paderewski and Josef Hofmann, who thrived in the twilight of Romantic pianism, and whose works are rarely played today.

title: McFarlanes Put Up
description: When fire damaged the house of Robert C. McFarlane on Sunday, the former national security adviser to President Ronald Reagan became temporarily homeless.

title: Limited Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article and a picture caption in some copies yesterday about negotiations over the Long Island Lighting Company and the Shoreham nuclear power plant misidentified the Federal judge in the case. He is Judge Jack B. Weinstein; he resigned the post of Chief Judge in the Eastern District of New York in March 1988.

title: Massachusetts Sets Offering Of $430 Million in Bonds
description: Massachusetts is tentatively offering $430 million in general obligation bonds with a maximum yield of about 7.55 percent for an issue due in 2007 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Reviews/Music; Violinist Plays the Blues
description: Howard Armstrong, the 79-year-old violinist and mandolin player who stole the show on Sunday afternoon at the World Music Institute's blues festival at the Triplex, is in total control of his environment.

title: Wide Medication Misuse Is Found Among Elderly
description: Misdiagnoses by doctors, faulty prescriptions and improper use of drugs by patients have created widespread problems among the elderly, a new Government study has found. For example, 51 percent of deaths from drug reactions in this country involve people 60 years of age or older, even though they account for only 17 percent of the population, the report said.

title: Patents on Equations: Some See a Danger
description: Encouraged by a new attitude in the courts and at the Patent and Trademark Office, universities and corporations are rushing to stake patent claims in a whole new arena of intellectual property: mathematical equations.

title: Lincoln National Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After realized investment losses of $11,067,000 for the quarter and $38,646,000 for the year. c-After realized investment losses of $28,026,000 for the quarter and realized investment gains of $826,000 for the year.

title: Sales of Cars and Light Trucks Fall 15.1 %
description: Sales of domestic light vehicles fell 15.1 percent in the first 10 days of February, prompting analysts to predict today that deeper price discounts and production cuts are inevitable.

title: Court Orders the Use Of Wheelchair Lifts Aboard New Buses
description: A Federal appeals court ordered the Department of Transportation on Monday to require transit authorities around the country to equip new buses with wheelchair lifts.

title: Note and Bond Prices Fall Again
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds continued to slide in light trading yesterday, pushed lower by a retail sales report that was stronger than expected and a drop in the dollar.

title: Results Plus
description: TENNIS Graf Advances: Steffi Graf had four aces and surrendered only 5 points on her serve yesterday in a 6-1, 6-1 victory over Stacey Martin that put her into the second round of the $300,000 Virginia Slims of Washington in Fairfax, Va. Graf, the world's top-ranked player, needed only 39 minutes to dispose of the Tennessee freshman. Graf will next meet Carling Bassett-Seguso of Canada, who made a triumphant return from a three-month absence by beating a qualifier, Renata Baranski, 6-3, 6-1. (AP) Mecir Upset: Second-seeded Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia was upset yesterday by Omar Camporese, 6-4, 7-6, in the opening round of the $492,500 Stella Artois indoor championship in Milan, Italy. Mecir joined seventh-seeded Henri Leconte of France and eighth-seeded Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union as losers in the Nabisco Grand Prix tournament before the completion of the first round. Camporese, an Italian who is ranked 204th in the world, entered the tournament on a wild-card invitation. (AP) Mansdorf Gains: Amos Mansdorf of Israel adjusted his serve after a first-set loss and overwhelmed Glenn Michibata of Canada, 5-7, 6-1, 6-1, yesterday in second-round play at the Volvo Indoor championships in Memphis. In an earlier match, seventh-seeded Kevin Curren used a serve-and-volley attack to overpower Richard Matuszewski, 6-3, 4-6, 6-3. (AP) N.H.L. Penguins 7, Sabres 3: Mario Lemieux scored 3 goals to raise his season total to 61 and added 2 assists at Pittsburgh. Lemieux's points increased his league-leading total to 153. Lemieux had a hand in all three first-period goals for Pittsburgh and has points in 17 of the last 18 games.(AP) Capitals 5, Blues 3 Mike Gartner broke a 3-3 tie with with 2:36 remaining as the Capitals overcame a two-goal third-period deficit at St. Louis. Gartner scored from the crease off a pass from Mike Ridley, extending his goal-scoring streak to nine games, as the Capitals overcame a 3-1 deficit and snapped a three-game losing streak. (AP) Blackhawks 4, North Stars 2 Wayne Presley's goal with 2:57 remaining broke a 2-2 tie at Minnesota. Chicago's Denis Savard was kicked in the back of his right ankle by Minnesota's Shawn Chambers six minutes into the game. Team officials said they iced the ankle and would take Savard to a Chicago hospital today. Minnesota's Neal Broten left the game after taking a shoulder in the chest from Chicago's Doug Wilson. Broten was taken to a local hospital for tests.(AP) N.B.A. Cavaliers 109, Heat 98: The team with the best record in the National Basketball Association beat the team with the worst record as Mark Price scored 21 points and Larry Nance 20 for Cleveland at Miami. Miami is 5-41. Cleveland is 36-11.(AP) 76ers 113, Pacers 108: Charles Barkley scored 26 points as the 76ers handed the host Pacers their eighth straight loss. Scott Skiles scored 20 points for the Pacers.(AP) Rockets 137, Celtics 123: Akeem Olajuwon had 35 points and 19 rebounds as Houston, playing at home, reached its highest point total of the season. Reggie Lewis led Boston with 31 points. Houston's previous high was 129 last Nov. 13 against Sacramento. The 137 points were the most ever scored by Houston against Boston.(AP) Hawks 106, Bulls 98: John Battle came off the bench to score 8 fourth-quarter points and Dominique Wilkins scored 36 as Atlanta won at Chicago. Michael Jordan had 32 points for the Bulls.(AP) WOMEN'S BASKETBALL 57th Free Throw in Row Ties Mark: Baldwin-Wallace's Valerie Kepner was 4 for 4 from the free-throw line last night in Berea, Ohio, to tie the career National Collegiate Athletic Association women's record of 57 consecutive free throws. Kepner is tied with Central Michigan's Jodi Beerman, who set the record in 1986 and 1987. Kepner broke the collegiate record for consecutive free throws in a season with her 49th. The previous mark was 45, set by Wendy Scholtens of Vanderbilt last month. Baldwin-Wallace, 9-13 over all and 4-11 in the Ohio Conference, lost to Heidelberg, 71-54. (AP) Auburn 82, South Alabama 61: Patrena Scruggs and Linda Godby both scored 21 points for No. 1 Auburn (22-0). (AP) Tennessee 82, Louisiana Tech 65: Bridgett Gordon scored 29 points to help end No. 3 Louisiana Tech's 42-game home winning streak, longest in the nation. Tennessee is 22-2; Louisiana Tech fell to 21-3.(AP) Texas 86, Houston 72: Susan Anderson had 22 points and Vicki Hall had 21 for No. 8 Texas (18-4, 12-0) in a Southwest Conference game. Houston fell to 6-5 and 13-9. (AP) Mississippi 87, Memphis St. 55: Jackie Martin scored 20 points for 12th-ranked Mississippi (18-5). Memphis State fell to 8-14.(AP) L.S.U. 86, Kentucky 72: Dee Dee Franklin scored 19 points for No. 20 Louisiana State (14-7, 3-3) in a Southeastern Conference game. Kentucky is 11-13, 2-5.(AP)

title: Centaur Partners Lifts Offer for Pennwalt
description: Centaur Partners, a New York investment group, today raised its bid for the Pennwalt Corporation to $110 a share from $100 a share.

title: At Afghan Guerrilla Base, Frustration
description: ''The mujahedeen are not enjoying their victory,'' an Afghan guerrilla said, because their leaders ''are locked up in a room talking about the number of seats each group should get.''

title: How Lilco Pact Would Affect Customers
description: In the agreement signed yesterday between the Long Island Lighting Company and a lawyer representing its customers, the utility agreed to pay customers $390 million through reduced rates in the next decade. In return, the customers will not participate in a racketeering suit by Suffolk County against Lilco.

title: Knicks Have a Rough Night, But They Come Up a Winner
description: Charles Oakley made 23,388 enemies tonight at the Charlotte Coliseum.

title: VF Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest quarter and year results included pre-tax restructuring costs of $15 million and $16.4 million, respectively.

title: Inside New Yorker, a Splash of Color
description: In its 64th anniversary issue, The New Yorker offers its first color art inside the magazine in decades and a redesigned Goings On About Town section.

title: Judge in North Case Rejects Plan By Justice Dept. to Guard Secrets
description: A Federal district judge today rejected a proposed agreement by the Justice Department and the independent prosecutor that would have limited the ability of lawyers for Oliver L. North to disclose state secrets at his criminal trial without prior Government approval.

title: Metro Mobile CTS Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Corrected from yesterday.

title: Pilots at Eastern Urged To Back Other Unions
description: The governing body of the pilots' union at Eastern Air Lines Inc. issued a strongly worded resolution yesterday recommending that its 3,500 members respect any picket line set up by the airline's other unions.

title: Belgian Rate Up Again
description: Belgium's central bank increased a key interest rate today for the fourth time this month and the sixth time this year. The bank raised the rate on the three-month Treasury bill by 0.15 percentage point, to 8.10 percent. The bank also raised the rates on one- and two-month Treasury bills by 0.10 percentage point each, to 7.7 percent and 7.9 percent, respectively, and the rate on four-month certificates by 0.35 point, to 8.10 percent.

title: White House Delays Making Choice on Modernizing Missiles
description: The White House announced today that it would not meet a Congressional deadline of Wednesday for deciding how to modernize the nation's land-based nuclear missiles, a choice that has been debated for a decade.

title: Limited Net Rises 89.7%
description: The Limited Inc., the nation's largest women's apparel retailer, today reported a surge in fourth-quarter profit.

title: Beyond the Basics: What U.S. Students Know
description: Percentage of students in high school (age 17) who were at or above proficiency levels in each category. Reading figures are from 1984; others are from 1986. SCIENCE Can infer relationships and draw conclusions using detailed scientific knowledge . . . 7% Has some detailed scientific knowledge; can evaluate the appropriateness of scientific procedure . . . 41% Understands basic information from the life and physical sciences . . . 81% Understands some basic principles, for example, simple knowledge about plants and animals . . . 97% Knows everyday science facts . . . 100% MATH Can solve multi-step problems and use basic algebra . . . 6% Can compute with decimals, fractions and percents; recognize geometric figures; and solve simple equations . . . 51% Can add and subtract two-digit numbers and recognize relationships among coins . . . 100% Knows some basic addition and subtraction facts . . . 100% READING Can synthesize and learn from specialized reading materials . . . 5% Can find, understand, summarize and explain relatively complicated information . . . 39% Can search for specific information, interrelate ideas and make generalizations . . . 84% Can comprehend specific or sequentially-related information . . . 99% Can carry out simple, discrete reading tasks . . . 100% (Source: Educational Testing Service)

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * iBank One, Columbus, Columbus, Ohio, a unit of Banc One Corp., said Tod J. Ortlip, president and chief executive of Planned Communities Inc., had been elected to its board.

title: 'African-American' Is the Correct Term to Use; Afrindeur-American
description: To the Editor:

title: About Education
description: More than 100 bills dealing with the needs of children and families were introduced in the 100th Congress. None passed. Sociologists and educators generally agree that children, and particularly poor children, need a new deal. But lawmakers still have not agreed on policies to enhance early child care and education. The only hopeful sign is that in recent weeks liberals and conservatives appear to have come closer to agreement on the need for action. Last week, President Bush proposed a 20 percent increase in money for Head Start, the preschool program for 4-year-olds.

title: Missouri's Coach Undergoes Surgery
description: Norm Stewart, coach of third-ranked Missouri, had surgery yesterday for removal of a cancerous tumor on his colon and a diseased gall bladder, the university announced.

title: Proposed Bill Would Require Trash Recycling
description: New York City residents and businesses would be required to separate their garbage into three categories under a proposed recycling law submitted to city officials yesterday.

title: New Director to Be Named For the 1994 World Cup
description: Preparations for the 1994 World Cup, the first to be held in the United States, are barely under way and a change has already been made at the top of the organizing committee.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Kim Macalister has been named president and chief operating officer of Thompson Recruitment Advertising, a subsidiary of the J. Walter Thompson Co.

title: Seoul Journal; Censor's Scissors: No Longer Just Open and Shut
description: The play ''Honeysuckles'' closed recently, on schedule and not because the Government shut it down.

title: Robert T.S. Keith, 83, Retired Vice Admiral
description: Robert Taylor Scott Keith, a retired Navy vice admiral, died of congestive heart failure Sunday at his home in Falls Church, Va. He was 83 years old and previously lived in Virginia Beach and Coronado, Calif.

title: Nets Play a Richly Embarrassing Game
description: By CLIFTON BROWN

title: Queens Officer Is Said to Face Criminal Counts
description: A New York City police officer faces criminal charges stemming from an encounter with two people in South Jamaica in October, the officer's lawyer said yesterday. The action is the first by a special grand jury investigating complaints of police brutality in Queens.

title: Joan Wetmore, Actress On Broadway, Was 77
description: Joan Wetmore, an actress who portrayed many elegant women in her nearly 30 years on Broadway, died of cancer Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 77 years old.

title: United Asset Management reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
General Motors reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split payable March 31. The company said the 1988 earnings were favorably affected by a lower statutory tax rate, the continuing amortization of investment tax credits earned in prior years, and tax benefits amounting to $354 million, or 58 cents a split share, from tax loss carryforwards at certain overseas operations.

title: Corrections
description: The headline of a report in the Sports People column yesterday misstated plans for physical examinations of Kiki Vandeweghe, the Portland Trail Blazers' forward. He will undergo exams, but one has not been scheduled by the Knicks.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Capitalist Eye On the Soviet Consumer
description: WHEN Ernest Dichter says he is ''going to the Soviet Union to look for hidden persuaders,'' he does not mean to suggest that he will search Moscow's dark corners for agents of the K.G.B.

title: Homefed Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $2,757,000 from an accounting change.

title: Richard D. Lombard, Executive, 58
description: Richard D. Lombard, a co-founder and former chairman of Lombard, Vitalis & Paganucci Inc., a securities firm, died of lung cancer Friday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 58 and lived in Manhattan.

title: NEAR DEPARTURE, RUSSIANS EXPECT WORST FOR KABUL
description: In the final hours of the Soviet military withdrawal from Afghanistan, the Soviet Union seemed braced today for a rapid deterioration of the military situation it is leaving behind.

title: For the Public Schools, A Mixed Report Card
description: A comprehensive educational study released today gives the nation's schools a mixed report card: good marks on teaching of basic skills but poor grades on conveying the kind of advanced abilities needed to succeed in college and in the workplace.

title: Little Drop Seen in Property Values
description: The regulator designated by President Bush to oversee about 200 insolvent savings institutions said today that property values in the Southwest would not suffer as a result of quick sales of troubled institutions or portions of the thousands of failed projects they financed.

title: Afghans and the Soviet Psyche: Military Myths Fade as the Troops Pull Out
description: Soviet troops are leaving Afghanistan, but their escape from nine years of war does not erase their humiliation.

title: South Africa Frees 17 Amid Hunger Strike
description: The South African Government released 17 people detained under the nation's emergency regulations today as a hunger strike by 300 other blacks in detention ended a third week.

title: Wolohan Lumber Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $47,600,000 for the quarter and $257,000,000 for the year. and gains from the sale of Arizona real estate of $9,600,000 for the quarter and $73,800,000 for the year. Latest quarter included unusual after-tax charges of $26,800,000 from the voluntary employee separation program and the pension settlement and asset reversion.

title: WHITE HOUSE VOWS DETAILS ON BUDGET
description: In the face of sharp Congressional criticism over the lack of details in President Bush's budget proposals, top Administration officials promised today to provide more specifics before the end of the week.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I am not sure, did we need this war? Have our many victims been justified?'' - Maj. Pavel Pinchanov, a Soviet officer leaving Afghanistan. [ A12:2. ]

title: Cuban Doctors and Builders Also Aid Angola
description: Speaking Portunhol, a mixture of Caribbean Spanish and African Portuguese, three Cuban pediatricians recently attended a long line of Angolan mothers and children in Josina Machel Hospital here.

title: For Federal Mediator, A String of Tough Cases
description: Kenneth R. Feinberg, the lawyer appointed to mediate the racketeering case against the Long Island lighting Company, has grown accustomed to handling complex cases.

title: Safe From Enemy Eyes
description: When I was very, very young I assisted in creating a club. It met under a large piece of burlap nailed to an apple tree. There were three members: a president, a vice president and a doorman. The doorman's job was to sit outside and keep an eye peeled for enemies while the president and vice president sat inside pretending to smoke candy cigarettes. Being the youngest and frailest member of the club, I was the doorman.

title: Bhopal Outcome: Trial Is Avoided
description: The formidable legal obstacles faced by plaintiffs in the Bhopal disaster made the $470 million settlement, the largest award for an industrial accident, a reasonable conclusion to a thorny case, lawyers and legal academics said yesterday.

title: Review/Piano; Baekkelund Brings Norway To Weill Hall
description: Kjell Baekkelund, a pianist deeply respected in his own country, brought himself and a bit of Norway to Weill Recital Hall on Sunday night. Grieg's familiar Ballade and Christian Sinding's B-minor Sonata were there. Also played were newer pieces by Finn Mortensen, Arne Nordheim and Antonio Bibalo. All three testified to a variety of styles at work in Norway, none of which seem to include a return to tonality.

title: Trial for Czechoslovak Writer
description: The Czechoslovak playwright Vaclav Havel will be tried separately from eight other civil rights campaigners arrested with him at a rally in Prague last month, an emigre publication said today. The trial of the eight will start next Tuesday in Prague, said Palach Press, a London-based newsletter monitoring events in Czechoslovakia.

title: Masco Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $5,390,000 from an accounting change. c-After a charge of $930,000. Masco said the latest fourth quarter included net losses totaling $16 million from realized losses on the sales of certain marketable securities, litigation settlements and other unusual expenses. The company also said its 1987 net income was adversely affected by a fourth quarter decline in the value of its marketable securities portfolio which reduced earnings by $43 million after tax.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Note: Women Aren't All Alike
description: Seven years ago, Rena Bartos shook up the advertising world with a book describing how the surge of women into jobs shattered the notion of a monolithic female consumer market. In a new book, ''Marketing to Women Around the World'' (Harvard Business School Press), Ms. Bartos, a former senior vice president at J. Walter Thompson, widens her scope to encompass the global female market.

title: Mayor in Mississippi Pleads Guilty to Cocaine Trafficking
description: The mayor of a small town in Mississippi has agreed to resign and enter a drug treatment program after pleading guilty to selling cocaine, court records show.

title: BOXING: Notebook; Givens Lawyer Says Tyson Divorce Is Granted
description: The marriage of Mike Tyson and Robin Givens is over, according to one of Givens's lawyers, Neal Hersh. The final decree was granted yesterday in the Dominican Republic, a year and a week after they were married, Hersh said.

title: Maverick Distillers in Vermont Produce Maple Syrup With a Kick
description: Steve Israel and Brian Tyrol, Vermont business executives and friends, were driving around in Mr. Israel's pickup a few years ago dreaming up ways to ''have fun and make money,'' as Mr. Israel put it. They settled on a plan to manufacture small home stills similar to Mr. Coffee machines.

title: Large Hospitals Have Less Need of Emergency Medicine Training
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Commonwealth of Puerto Rico is tentatively offering $245 million in general obligation bonds with a maximum yield of about 7.815 percent for those due in 2017 through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc.

title: Retail Sales Increase 0.6%; Higher Interest Rates Seen
description: Retail sales climbed a hefty six-tenths of 1 percent in January despite weakening automotive sales, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Thermo Electron Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Federal Cancer Researcher Is Ordered to Stop Private Fund Raising
description: A researcher at the National Cancer Institute has been ordered by Federal officials to stop raising funds for a foundation he established, the scientist's lawyer said today.

title: Reading of Love Poetry
description: The actors Christopher Reeve and Barbara Feldon will read love poetry by Andrew Marvell, Pablo Neruda and others, today at 8 P.M. at the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park. The event is a benefit for the Poetry Society of America. Tickets are $50. Information: 254-9628.

title: Thousand Trails reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $700,000 and $1,900,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss

title: EATING WELL
