description: THE ancient Greeks said eating figs caused the teeth to rot. Twentieth-century parents say the culprit is candy. Both are right, but only partially.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Coleco Industries to KGF Advertising for Cabbage Patch Kids, Scrabble Word Games and other toy lines.

title: NL Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $15,609,000 for the quarter and $21,517,000 for the year, and a reversal of a tax credit of $1,220,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $7,220,000 for the year. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $44,192,000 for the quarter and $107,779,000 for the year.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: Calf's liver has always been a favorite of mine, especially when quick-cooking is essential. Fresh, thinly sliced calf's liver cooks in two minutes, and the modes of preparation are endless.

title: Bryn Smith Arrested
description: The front office of the Montreal Expos refused comment yesterday about the arrest of the pitcher Bryn Smith in a prostitution sweep last week in which six police officers in West Palm Becah, Fla., posed as prostitutes along a busy street. Smith, 33 years old, was among 116 people charged with solicitation.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Grey Advertising
description: Grey Advertising reported that its 1988 earnings rose 13.6 percent, to $11.7 million, or $8.88 a share. This figure excludes the one-time earnings lift from the sale of foreign and domestic subsidiaries. Grey's net income was $10.3 million in 1987. The company's gross billings in 1988 were $2.48 billion.

title: Savimbi Halts Offensive at Ivory Coast's Request
description: The guerrillas fighting the Angolan Government are calling off their rainy-season offensive to avoid undercutting an effort by the Ivory Coast to reconcile the two adversaries, the Angolan guerrilla leader said today.

title: Lead Lawyer for Carbide Relieved by End of Case
description: Bud G. Holman, the lawyer who led the defense of the Union Carbide Corporation against lawsuits arising from the Bhopal disaster, learned of the resolution of the four years of litigation in a telephone call from India at 3:30 yesterday morning to his Manhattan home.

title: Soviets Catch Last Plane Out
description: The last Soviet troops flew out of Kabul under cover of darkness tonight, ending nine years of occupation hours ahead of schedule.

title: Quayle Pressed Salvador for Inquiry on Massacre
description: On a recent visit to El Salvador, Vice President Dan Quayle demanded a thorough investigation of an incident in which 10 peasants were killed last year, and American officials said today that evidence strongly suggested that the Salvadoran Army was responsible.

title: Arbitration Not Needed As Yanks Sign Hudson
description: The Yankees signed Charles Hudson, who was used as a starter and a relief pitcher last year, to a one-year contract today worth $525,000. The agreement enabled both sides to avoid arbitration three days before spring workouts begin.

title: Esiason Recovering
description: Boomer Esiason, the Cincinnati Bengals quarterback, is under a doctor's care for a lingering injury in his throwing shoulder and hopes to return to full-speed workouts next month.

title: Wessex Corp reports earnings for
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $11,490,000 from early retirement of debt for the quarter; the 9 months included a loss of $2,265,000 from writedowns from sales of nursing homes. The latest 9-month figures do not include the results of a speech and hearing facility that was sold on March 31, 1988. c-Net loss

title: Kobe Steel to Buy 50% of USX Plant
description: Kobe Steel Ltd. of Japan the last of Japan's big integrated steelmakers to enter a joint venture with a United States producer, will buy half of the USX Corporation's plant in Lorain, Ohio. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: Athlone Industries reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $1,585,000. c-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $2,467,000, an extraordinary charge of $1,436,000 and a credit of $2,839,000 representing cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: In Butter Sculptures, Monks Honor Tradition
description: ''When I first presented the idea to the museum, I think they had a vision of a four-ton cube of butter that was going to be carved,'' said Richard Gere, the actor, who is a Buddhist and president of Tibet House, a New York-based cultural group that supports Tibet. ''So then we showed them photographs of this very intricate stuff. On the spot they said 'yes.' ''

title: THE POP LIFE
description: 'Mystery' Music When Roy Orbison died of a heart attack last December, he was on the brink of one of the most remarkable comebacks in pop history. This week, the singer - whose posthumously released album, ''Mystery Girl'' (Virgin) makes its debut on Billboard's pop-album chart at No. 55 - has more records on the chart than any other artist. In addition to ''Mystery Girl,'' which has sold over 750,000 copies, two anthologies of Orbison hits stand at No. 95 and No. 110. ''The Traveling Wilburys, Volume One,'' his collaboration with Bob Dylan, George Harrison, Tom Petty and Jeff Lynne, holds firmly at No. 3, and ''You Got It,'' the first single from ''Mystery Girl'' has become Orbison's first Top 40 single in nearly 23 years.

title: Hancock's New Unit
description: John Hancock Financial Services announced yesterday that six investment bankers formerly with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. had formed a new Hancock affiliate to specialize in banking services to the alternative energy and independent power industries.

title: After Bhopal, the Company Rebuilds
description: While the $470 million settlement of the Bhopal case will apparently enable the Union Carbide Corporation to put the disaster largely behind it, the company has undergone a transformation that stems directly from the turmoil and seems likely to face more change.

title: Tandy's Shift In Marketing
description: The Tandy Corporation, a consumer electronics manufacturer and retailer, announced today that its new division, the Grid Systems Corporation. would take over marketing the company's computers to corporations and governments.

title: Scholarship Plan Can Affect Scientist Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: Grey Advertising reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: 1988 included $3,730,000 in gains from the sale of foreign and deomestic subsidiaries. The company said share figures are after giving effect to amounts attributable to redeemable preferred stock and the assumed exercise of dilutive stock options. Revenue represent gross billings.

title: Caribbean Flavor
description: To The Living Section:

title: Apple Sets Rebates On Four Models
description: Apple Computer Inc. has begun offering rebates of between $150 and $800 on four of its computer models. An Apple spokeswoman, Carleen LeVasseur, said the promotion, which began Saturday, would last until March 31 and would apply to Apple's Macintosh SE, Macintosh II, Macintosh IIX and Apple II GS computer models.

title: Breaking Taboo, Soviets Report Big Jump in Crime
description: In the first disclosure of detailed crime statistics in 56 years, a Soviet official said today that per capita crime in the Soviet Union rose by 17.8 percent last year, with especially sharp increases in violent crimes.

title: Belgian Politician Is Freed by His Kidnappers
description: Former Prime Minister Paul Vanden Boeynants, who was kidnapped here a month ago, turned up safely at his home early today, apparently after his family paid a ransom.

title: 'African-American' Is the Correct Term to Use
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Exhibitions on Women and AIDS
description: Two exhibitions on women with AIDS are to be presented from Feb. 24 to April 16 at the New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Houston Street.

title: Polls Show Discontent With Health Care
description: Eighty-nine percent of Americans say they believe the nation's health care system needs fundamental change, and far more Americans than Canadians or the British say financial barriers keep them from getting the health care they need, polls taken in the three countries last fall have found.

title: New Mexico Police Catch Jersey Man In Kidnap-Murder
description: A 19-year-old man sought in the fatal stabbing of a high school student at a party last weekend in New Jersey was captured by the police in New Mexico last night after an hour-long car chase, officials said.

title: McDermott International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest 9 months included a loss of $25,140,000 from discontinued operations and is after a gain of $52,888,000 from an accounting change. The results for the year-ago third quarter and 9 months have been restated to reflect the discontinuance of certain operations.

title: No New Tower Findings Seen
description: A senior White House official said today that the renewed investigation into former Senator John G. Tower's background had produced no damaging new findings that would be likely to jeopardize Mr. Tower's nomination as Defense Secretary.

title: Food Notes
description: Bass-Playing to Baking

title: Corrections
description: An obituary in late editions on Sunday and in all copies on Monday about Rabbi Samarious Gourary, executive director of United Lubavitcher Yeshivoth, gave his residence incorrectly. He lived in Brooklyn, not Montclair, N.J.

title: Mattel Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and after extraordinary charges of $1,068,000 for the quarter and $20,668,000 for the year. The latest year share earnings reduced by accounting change. The year-ago periods included restructuring expenses of $60,620,000 for the quarter and $65,165,000 for the year.

title: Five Pasta Lovers Test-Drive A Fork With Too Much Spin
description: ''THERE were conversations just like this when Catherine de' Medici brought the fork to France,'' said Carole Lalli, a senior editor at Simon & Schuster. ''And they said the same thing: 'fingers are better.' ''

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press in some editions on Tuesday about a court ruling on transit service for the disabled misidentified the lawyer who argued before a Federal appeals court. He was Timothy M. Cook, director of the Washington-based National Disability Action Center.

title: Reuters Holdings Plc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary item of $13.3 million covering the cost of stopping operations in the course of 1989 at the company's U.S. manufacturing subsidiary, IDR Inc. Both 1988 and 1987 net income figures are after a minority interest charge of $1.4 million. The figures have been converted to U.S. dollars at a rate of $1.81 for each U.K. pound.

title: Cincinnati Milacron Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $4,925,000 and $12,114,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss and after an extraordinary reorganization charge of $83 million for both the quarter and year, and charges primarily related to the company's early retirement program of $3,667,000 for the quarter and $2,148,000 for the year.

title: T.E.B. Clarke, Writer, Dies at 81
description: The British screenwriter T. E. B. Clarke, whose screenplays included the Academy Award-winning script for ''The Lavender Hill Mob,'' died of cancer here on Saturday. He was 81 years old.

title: Third Party Enters Battle for Ransburg
description: A third party entered the battle to acquire the Ransburg Corporation when Eagle Industries offered to buy the industrial equipment maker for $21 a share in cash, or a total of $170 million. Eagle is a subsidiary of Great American Management and Investment Inc., a manufacturing and financial services concern based in Chicago.

title: Irate Pakistani Muslim Calls for More Protests
description: In a rising tide of religious fervor that might have been unimaginable only a week ago in Pakistan, Islamic leaders today called for nationwide protests on Friday, the Muslim Sabbath, against the wider publication in the West of the book ''Satanic Verses.''

title: Steroid Sentence
description: Dan Duchaine, a former body builder and self-described expert in steroid use, has been sentenced by Judge J. Lawrence Irving of San Diego Federal Court to a maximum of three years in Federal prison for his part in a steroid distribution ring.

title: George O'Hanlon, 76, George Jetson's Voice
description: George O'Hanlon, who became the voice of the cartoon world's man of the future, George Jetson, after unsuccessfully auditioning for the role of the cartoon caveman Fred Flintstone, died of a stroke on Saturday at St. Joseph Medical Center in Burbank, Calif. He was 76 years old.

title: Angelos E. Papatestas, Surgeon, 50
description: Dr. Angelos E. Papatestas, a professor of surgery at the Mount Sinai Medical Center, died of heart failure Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 50 years old.

title: Doberman Chosen As Best
description: A sleek, elegant red Doberman bitch, Ch. Royal Tudor's Wild as the Wind, C.D., who answers to the name of Indy, last night was named the supreme winner of the 113th annual Westminster Kennel Club show in Madison Square Garden.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the removal of State Senator Israel Ruiz of New York after his Federal felony conviction described state law on the removal process incorrectly. It specifies that the post is vacated when a legislator is convicted of a felony; it does not require that the crime be considered a felony under New York State law.

title: In India, Prayers First, Then Some Spice
description: LEAD: WHEN the onslaughts of winter make the body yearn for hearty, warming foods, vegetarians - or anyone wishing to eat a meatless meal -may look to the spicy treats offered in the 3,000-year-old city of Banaras. Every year at this time, as the moon assumes its correct waxing position in the heavens, Hindus in this northeastern city on the Ganges River line up to pay homage to

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Pitt Topples St. John's by 87-77
description: Jason Matthews and Brian Shorter scored 22 points each as Pitt, avoiding a letdown after its upset of Georgetown last Saturday, pulled away in the final five minutes tonight for an 87-77 victory over St. John's in a Big East Conference game.

title: William Garbe Dead; Watercolorist Was 41
description: William Garbe, an artist known for his large-scale watercolors of birds, flowers and seashore life, died last Thursday on the way to St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 41 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Financial Analysts Contribute To the Neediest Cases Fund
description: A committee of financial analysts and other professionals from 15 Wall Street investment banking concerns have sent $46,739 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Ethics Panel Votes to Relax Stock Sale Rule
description: President Bush's ethics commission today approved a plan that would allow new Federal appointees to defer capital gains taxes on stock holdings that they sold to avoid potential conflicts of interest.

title: Our Vietnam, And the Soviets'
description: Recently, I took a Soviet friend to the Vietnam Veterans Memorial.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Rocking for Pepsi
description: The star wars between Coke and Pepsi heated up yesterday with news that Rod Stewart, the British rock singer, signed a contract to promote Pepsi in television ads in Latin America.

title: Review/Theater; The Gumshoe Stomp, Or, Sleuthing to Music
description: ''In a Pig's Valise,'' the ''hard-boiled yarn with music'' at the Second Stage, is an homage to detective fiction by a playwright whose affection for Raymond Chandler and Dashiell Hammett may be second only to his love for the sound of his own voice. The playwright is Eric Overmyer, the author of the widely produced ''On the Verge,'' a work of such relentless erudition that its icy intricacies of diction linger long after the play's subject and human mouthpieces have evaporated. ''In a Pig's Valise'' offers more of the same showy verbiage, but, as they say, ''with music.'' Nonetheless, one is most likely to leave the theater humming the similes.

title: About New York; Picture the Plaza As a Man. That's Fred Cristina.
description: A half century, 50 years, more than 26 million minutes ago. Most of a man's life. It has been that long since Fred Cristina reported for his new job as a busboy in the Oak Room of the Plaza Hotel. Joe Louis was heavyweight champion, Tallulah Bankhead was wowing Broadway, youngsters danced the Big Apple and Hitler was still far, far away.

title: NATO's German Woes; Deep National Rumblings and Gorbachev Behind Dispute on Missile Modernization
description: The routine replacement of a battlefield nuclear missile five years from now hardly seems an issue to get very excited about.

title: Sudan Agrees to Discuss Emergency Famine Aid
description: The Sudanese Government has invited representatives of United Nations relief agencies and other humanitarian organizations to Khartoum next month to discuss emergency steps to avert mass famine this spring, officials say.

title: Canadian Pacific Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included special gains of $55 million and $46 million for the quarter and year, respectively. c-After special charges of $165 million for the quarter and special gains of $189 million for the year. In 1988, the $46 million of gains consisted of gains on the sale of 18 bulkships, offset by a loss on the sale of its stake in Algoma Steel Corp. and writedown and restructuring costs for CP Telecommunicaitons. In 1987, the $189 million of gains consisted of gains on the sale of Canadian Pacific Air Lines Ltd., Maple Leaf Mills Ltd. and a Canadian Pacific ships office building, offeset by writedown and restructuring costs for AMCA International Ltd. and a provision for the future sale of leased hotel properties in West Germany. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Motown Stake For Diana Ross
description: The singer Diana Ross has become a part owner of Motown Records and has agreed to resume recording for the label she helped propel to popularity in the 1960's.

title: 'African-American' Is the Correct Term to Use; Not All Are Black
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. CONVENTION AGAINST RECRUITMENT, USE, FINANCING AND TRAINING OF MERCENARIES - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. Economic and social council STATISTICAL COMMISSION - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Police Raid Crack House, Then Have It Torn Down
description: As a cluster of neighborhood residents watched yesterday, a burned-out tenement on a drug-ravaged Brooklyn block became the first building in New York City to be torn down because of drug activity.

title: The Happy Face Has a Nice New Day
description: LEAD: WHEN the ''smile'' face became a fad in 1970, it was like a lighthearted punctuation mark at the end of a tumultuous decade. Now, after nearly 20 years in eclipse, the happy face is back, its 100-watt smile lighting up T-shirts, canvas tote bags, spandex cycling shorts and other merchandise in newly opened shops at Macy's and Bloomingdale's stores in New York and Chicago.

title: G.M. Net Rises 67.5% In Quarter
description: Having achieved solid gains in worldwide vehicle sales, the General Motors Corporation announced record profits yesterday for the fourth quarter and the year.

title: Bridge
description: One of the more mysterious characters in bridge literature is a lady named ''Sylvia,'' who appeared frequently in the bridge columns of B. Jay Becker. He died in 1987, after one of the greatest careers in the history of the game, but Sylvia, one hopes, lives on.

title: Rock Hudson's Most Paradoxical Role
description: The Rock Hudson trial was in full swing in Los Angeles last week, and the courtroom was nearly empty: a few trial groupies, a few Hollywood fans, a few clerks, a few reporters, and that was about it. Where were the prurient mobs who adore the lurid allure of the tabloids, who hang on every talk-show host's words?

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE BHOPAL SETTLEMENT Union Carbide was ordered to pay $470 million in damages for the December 1984 toxic gas leak in Bhopal, India, ending a legal battle over compensation for victims of the world's deadliest industrial accident. The Indian Supreme Court's settlement proposal was accepted by Carbide, and all suits against the company and its former chairman, Warren Anderson, were dropped. [ Page A1. ] Union Carbide is a much smaller company four years after the disaster. Analysts say the Bhopal incident began the chain of events that led to a takeover attempt and a restructuring. [ D3. ] The formidable legal obstacles faced by the plaintiffs made the settlement a reasonable solution to a thorny case, legal experts said. News Analysis. [ D3. ] The settlement was a relief to Bud G. Holman, the lawyer who led Carbide's defense. [ D3. ] COMPANIES G.M. announced record profits for the fourth quarter and the year. But its chairman said earnings from North American vehicle operations remained unsatisfactory. [ D1. ] Coleman's chairman offered to buy the company, famous for its lanterns and camping equipment, for $64 a share, or $450 million. The stock rose $21, to $70.125. [ D1. ] A union council recommended that Eastern's pilots cross other unions' picket lines. A machinist strike could begin March 3. [ D2. ] Centaur Partners raised its offer for Pennwalt. [ D4. ] Reuters said its net profits rose 15.8 percent in 1988. [ D19. ] Conrail's board is likely to select a new chief today. [ D4. ] THE ECONOMY The Administration released a detailed outline of its savings and loan rescue plan. It also announced new measures likely to arouse opposition. [ D1. ] Property values in the Southwest should not suffer from the quick sale of troubled institutions and the failed projects they financed, the F.D.I.C. chairman said. [ D13. ] Retail sales climbed a hefty 0.6 percent in January despite a weakening automotive sector. The latest sales figures indicate that the economy is growing faster than the Fed desires. [ D1. ] Sales of domestic vehicles fell 15.1 percent in early February. Analysts predicted price discounts and production cuts. [ D13. ] U.S. steelmakers are assured of continued trade protection, Commerce Secretary Mosbacher said. [ D1. ] Two types of trading abuses could be prosecuted under Federal racketeering law, a former U.S. Attorney told members of the Chicago Board of Trade, which hired him as an adviser. [ D8. ] TECHNOLOGY A rush is on to patent mathematical equations. But the growing number of these patents is causing concern that basic research and the free exchange of information could be inhibited. [ D1. ] MARKETS Stocks were mixed after rising early in the day. The Dow industrials finished at 2,281.25, down 1.25 points. [ D8. ] Treasury notes and bonds continued to slide, pushed lower by the stronger-than-expected retail sales report. [ D16. ] The dollar tumbled. Dealers cited remarks by President Bush opposing further tightening of credit. [ D15. ] Soybean and corn prices rose sharply, amid talk of higher overseas demand. [ D15. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Corporate lobbying for tax breaks is unusually subdued this year. Rather than seek new breaks, the strategy seems to be to preserve the status quo. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] What motivates Soviet consumers? A psychologist known for his motivational research will develop psychological profiles of the Russian people to Western companies. Advertising. [ D19. ]

title: C.I.A. SAYS SOVIETS DID NOT TAP CODES
description: The Central Intelligence Agency denied today that the communications machines at the American Embassy in Moscow had been subject to electronic eavesdropping by Soviet agents, an assertion made in a new book on security lapses at the embassy.

description: Debt

title: Home Prices Increase 3.4%
description: Prices of existing homes rose 3.4 percent last year, but despite the moderate increase, many first-time buyers are being priced out of the market in some areas, a national real estate group said today.

title: Reviews/Music; A Violin and Cello Duo
description: Chamber groups come in odd combinations these days, but one would think a violin and cello duet might have trouble finding enough repertory, let alone engagements, to keep it busy. The Seaton-Friedlander Duo, which played a confident and invigorating New York debut concert at Weill Recital Hall on Monday evening, seems prepared to overcome these limitations.

title: Getting to Know You: Brownies Tell Their Tales
description: ''IT started with Betty Crocker, who didn't exist,'' said George Lois, the chairman and creative director of the Lois/GGK advertising agency in New York, referring to eponymous food products. ''Uncle Ben, Aunt Jemima - they didn't exist,'' he said, but they helped consumers identify with rice and pancakes. ''You are more likely to believe in a new brand if there is a personality attached. It's great schmaltz, and it works.''

title: Oregon Steel Mills Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest-year results included a gain of $639,000 from a change in accounting and a gain of $1.7 million from the sale of equipment.

title: Waves on Airwaves: Power to the People?
description: This city, ever sensitive to shifts in power, is debating the prospects of the latest group to make a bid for influence: the hosts of the nation's radio talk shows. Is government-by-talk-show the wave of the future?

description: New York Republicans and the White House have worked out a solution to the dispute involving State Senator Roy M. Goodman's quest for a senior appointment in the Bush Adminstration.

description: Converse Inc. has retained a heavy-artillery expert to help it fight the athletic-shoe wars: BBDO New York and its chairman, Philip B. Dusenberry. The agency has been named to invent the marketing for the Converse Performance Brand, the company's new entry in the ''jock'' end of the sneaker market. The account will bill $4 million to $5 million annually.

description: Using Tolstoyan license, one can imagine this cry of pain from the last officer leaving Afghanistan today as the Soviets complete their momentous withdrawal:

A Fight Before Game, Then Flyers Dominate
description: Michel Bergeron, the coach of the Rangers, wanted Chris Nilan to make the trip here for tonight's game against the Flyers. He wanted his team's injured tough guy and emotional leader in the bus, in the hotel for the team meal, in the locker room before the game.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Pro Bono
description: * Ann-Margret, the film actress, is the spokeswoman in a public service ad campaign created by the Venet Companies, a subsidiary of GMI Group Inc., for the Myasthenia Gravis Foundation. Myasthenia gravis is a neuromuscular disease.

title: A Story of 12 Roses on Their Big Day
description: Before Paula Howard could sniff the dozen red roses she received for Valentine's Day yesterday, they had to be flown from California to Newark with thousands of others, trucked through the Holland Tunnel to Manhattan, sorted on West 28th Street, driven to Second Avenue and delivered to 59th Street and Lexington Avenue. All in 24 hours. For Valentine's Day, the biggest day of the year for roses, thousands of roses make their way into New York vases from as far off as South America, France and the Netherlands. This is the story of 12 of them.

description: A proposal in New Jersey to end a 72-year-old physical education requirement for high school students has touched off a debate among state officials and educators over what place gym class has in a tougher school curriculum.

description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation's top-ranking black employee, John D. Glover, is retiring later this year, at a time when the agency has found itself besieged by charges that too few black, Hispanic and female employees are moving up the career ladder.

title: Fighting Crime Wholesale and Retail
description: What's the best way to prosecute crime? The standard answer is, one case at a time. Yet the limits of that approach have long been clear, and some criminal justice authorities are pondering a broader strategy that helps fight crime wholesale rather than retail. The concept is by now familiar to police. There may be an even stronger case for it among district attorneys.

description: The Bush Administration, releasing a detailed outline of its $90 billion plan to restructure the savings industry, proposed several new measures today that are likely to arouse opposition.

description: J. Newton Hill, a former dean of Lincoln University in Oxford, Pa., died of pneumonia Saturday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Review/Rock; Southern Apocalyptic
description: ''Here's yet another gruesome song,'' Nick Cave announced to a full house Friday night at the Ritz. He then sang ''Knocking on Joe,'' a dying prisoner's delirious ravings: ''You can lay your burden down upon me, but you cannot lay down those memories!''

title: A Job for Mrs. Sununu
description: The wife of John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, has been hired by the Republican Governors' Association to prepare a book and do political fund raising, the director of the association says.

title: Gibson Still Hurting
description: Kirk Gibson of the Los Angeles Dodgers, the National League's Most Valuable Player last season, continues to be bothered by a sore right knee but does not need surgery, the team said yesterday. After examining Gibson, Dr. Frank Jobe, the Dodgers' team physician, said the outfielder has tendinitis of the adductor tendons in his right knee but the ailment does not require an operation. Jobe said that Gibson would regain full strength in the knee by the end of spring training.

title: Dr. Helane S. Rosenberg of Rutgers And Dr. Yakov M. Epstein Are Wed
description: Dr. Helane Susan Rosenberg and Dr. Yakov Michael Epstein, both faculty members at Rutgers University, were married last evening at the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue in New York. Cantor Philip Sherman performed the ceremony.

NEW ROCKET PUTS SATELLITE IN ORBIT
description: An advanced navigation satellite was launched into orbit today on the maiden flight of the Air Force's new Delta 2 rocket, a booster developed to carry vital military payloads grounded after the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger.

title: Bhopal Tragedy: The Key Events
description: Dec. 3, 1984: Methyl isocyanate gas leaks from pesticides plant of Union Carbide India Ltd. in Bhopal, India. Final death toll is estimated at more than 3,500. Dec. 7: Warren Anderson, chairman of Union Carbide, and Keshub Mahindra, chairman of Union Carbide India, are arrested on charges of negligence and corporate liability. Mr. Anderson is released after a few hours on personal bail bond of about $3,000. April 9, 1985: The Indian Government files suit against Union Carbide in Federal court in New York seeking unspecified damages. April 16: Federal District Judge John Keenan in New York orders Union Carbide to make an emergency payment of $5 million for immediate relief to disaster victims. April 2, 1986: The Indian Parliament passes legislation making it the sole representative of all victims of the gas leak. May 12: Judge Keenan transfers the case against Union Carbide to India. Sept. 5: Bhopal district court admits suit for damages against Union Carbide that was filed by the Indian Government on behalf of victims. Nov. 22: The Indian Government files suit for damages worth $3.12 billion against Union Carbide in Bhopal district court of Judge G. S. Patel, who later is removed when he is discovered to be one of more than 500,000 claimants for compensation. Jan. 17, 1988: Bhopal District Judge M. W. Deo, the fourth judge hearing the case, orders Union Carbide to pay interim relief of $270 million. Union Carbide challenges the order. April 4: High Court Judge S. K. Seth reduces volume of interim relief, ordering Union Carbide to pay $190 million. Nov. 15: Bhopal district court issues arrest warrants for Mr. Anderson on homicide charges, after he fails to respond to summonses issued in the case. February 1989: The court declares Mr. Anderson tried to escape the law. Feb. 14, 1989: Supreme Court orders full and final settlement of $470 million. India and Union Carbide agree, and all related cases are ordered closed, including criminal charges against Mr. Anderson. (Source: Associated Press)

title: Stanley Benn, Lawyer, 49
description: Stanley Benn, a lawyer, died of a heart attack Saturday at Community Hospital in Boca Raton, Fla., while on vacation. He was 49 years old and lived in West Deal, N.J.

title: If the Shoe Doesn't Fit
description: Nike, the shoe company, has come out with a television commercial for hiking shoes that was shot in Kenya using Samburu tribesmen. It combines broad shots of brightly clad, dancing men and women, and close-ups of the colorful new boots. There are no words until the very end. Then the camera closes in on the one tribesman who speaks, in native Maa. As he speaks, the Nike slogan, ''Just do it,'' appears on the screen.

title: Islanders Hold Off Oilers
description: When David Volek defected from Czechoslovakia on July 25, he was smiling, and not even the disappointing season compiled by the Islanders has been able to shake his delight at being able to play for them.

title: Judge Rebuffs U.S. on North
description: Federal District Judge Gerhard A. Gesell appeared to remove manh of the national security obstacles to the start of Oliver L. North's criminal trial.

title: Mayor of San Antonio Plans Investment Firm
description: When Mayor Henry G. Cisneros of San Antonio said last year that he would leave office this spring, the job offers rolled in. He was asked, among other things, to be a college president and a television anchor. But he says the position he ended up accepting surprises even him.

title: Rake's Progress
description: ''Womanize'' is an unattractive verb, evoking rubberize, galvanize, oxidize, personalize and also stigmatize. Its derivative, ''womanizer,'' is unattractive too, since it conveys nothing of what may attract men to women beyond the utilitarian.

title: Mushroom Farmers Bring Exotica In From the Wild
description: LEAD: NO longer are once-exotic mushrooms found only where the wild things are; now they flourish on farms in environments designed to suit their particular growing requirements.

title: The Time to Save Water: Now
description: Much of Pepacton Reservoir, one of New York City's largest, is dry and the Catskills are almost bare of snow, the water of the near future. New York City responds by announcing a drought watch - but it still hesitates to mount an effective water conservation campaign. That's a risky gamble.

description: The on-again, off-again trade of Kiki Vandeweghe to the Knicks is still in a state of confusion.

description: A cocaine distribution ring whose leader sometimes wore a gold crown was broken up today with a raid that led to 16 arrests, Federal and state authorities said.

description: Lawyers for John A. Mulheren Jr. and the United States said yesterday that a magistrate had granted a 30-day extension that gives them more time to resolve the case and possibly avoid an indictment.

description: A man who was imprisoned for killing two people on Long Island in a drunken driving accident and who has served less than eight months was temporarily blocked from parole by a state judge yesterday.

title: Close to Home
description: ''BLACK coffee and a cinnamon doughnut,'' I said to the man behind the counter. ''No sugar, right?'' he replied. When, a minute or so later, I left the store, a half-stifled smile was curling up the corners of my mouth. Recognized! Acknowledged! A regular at Al's coffee shop at last! All I could think of was the day a little girl I used to escort around town ushered me up to the newsstand where she bought her comic books and said grandly, ''They know me here.''

title: Cavaliers Combine for 36 Assists and Defeat Knicks
description: During his playing days, Lenny Wilkens was considered among the best passers in the game. The 7,211 assists he made during his 15 pro seasons rank third on the National Basketball Association career list behind Oscar Robertson and Magic Johnson.

title: Vishay Intertechnology Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said that the large increase in sales was primarily a result of the recent acquisitions made by the company. On July 1, 1988, the company acquired the remaining 50 percent of Dale Holdings Inc. and now owns 100 percent of Dale. Until June 30, 1988, Dale was accounted for on an equity basis. In addition, the company said that effective Oct. 1, 1988, the company acquired Sfernice S.A., a manufacturer of electronic resistors headquartered in Nice, France. The company also said it would change its fiscal year-end from June 30 to a calendar Dec. 31 year-end, effective Jan. 1, 1989.

description: The Government thanked the Soviet Union today for its help in Afghanistan but said future relations should develop on the basis of non-interference in each other's internal affairs.

description: A new laser treatment can safely erase port-wine birthmarks from the faces of children, even in infancy, a study has found.

description: THE Bauer Group, a West German publishing company, clearly believes that once is not enough. Having already started Woman's World, a weekly magazine, Bauer has added a monthly, First for Women, to its American magazines.

description: The board of the Conrail Corporation elected one of its members, Stanley E. G. Hillman, as its president and chief executive yesterday.

title: Bridge
description: Defenders face most of their problems early in the play, when there are few clues and many options. The reverse is true in the end-game, and the defender can usually relax. But that is not always true. As the diagramed example shows, a player who is not alert can easily fall into a little trap.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Science Times on Tuesday about steps to reduce research fraud referred to the Institute of Medicine incorrectly. It is a branch of the National Academy of Sciences, not the National Institutes of Health.

title: Tokyo Market at a High
description: A stable yen and impetus from Wall Street's gains pushed the Tokyo stock market's Nikkei index to a record high in trading here this morning. It ended the morning session up 197.78 points, or 0.62 percent, at 32,347.26. Earlier, it had reached a trading high of 32,354.75. The previous high of 32,270.48 was set Feb. 9, and on Wednesday the index rose 166.59 points to a record close of 32,149.48. After drifting, the dollar was firmer at midday, at 126.40 yen.

title: G.S.A. to Curb Navy On Computer Contracts
description: The General Services Administration said yesterday that it would restrict the Navy's authority to award computer contracts, after a request made by a Congressional committee investigating allegations that the Navy's bidding procedures were designed to favor the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: Police Deploy Narcotics Team in Hunts Point
description: Just after midnight yesterday, the New York City Police Department's special anti-drug unit began operating and making arrests in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx.

title: Review/Theater; Revival of Wilson's '5th of July'
description: No Talley, in Lanford Wilson's trilogy about the Talley family, ages gracefully - and a revival of ''Fifth of July'' at the Equity Library Theater reveals that the first play in the series has aged considerably, if not well, in 11 years. The Talleys are not as fascinating here as they would become in ''Talley's Folly'' and ''Talley and Son,'' and Mr. Wilson's skeptical, sometimes caustic, reflections on the illusions of the 1960's, so startling when the Circle Repertory Company first produced the play in 1978, have lost some of their punch.

title: Lancaster Colony Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Advice on Long Island For Saltwater Fishing
description: A daylong seminar this Sunday in the Tilles Center auditorium of Long Island University's C. W. Post campus in Greenvale, L.I., will focus on saltwater fishing in the Northeast.

title: Fees for Federal Services: Is the Sky the Limit?
description: More than any Federal agency of its size, the Department of Transportation pays its own way on the basis of fees that are levied on the users of the services it provides.

title: Sallie Mae Offers Fixed-Rate Notes
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, also known as Sallie Mae, is offering $200 million of fixed-rate notes due in 1993 through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.

title: In Storm Over Winnie Mandela, Body Is Identified as Soweto Boy's
description: A storm over Winnie Mandela that has embarrassed the country's anti-apartheid movement took an ominous turn today. The police identified a decomposing body as that of a missing 14-year-old whom Mrs. Mandela's bodyguards are accused of having abducted.

title: Behrens Cancels Date With Orchestre de Paris
description: Hildegard Behrens has canceled her appearance in the performance tomorrow night of Beethoven's Missa Solemnis with the Orchestre de Paris at Avery Fisher Hall, because of a problem that prevented her from taking part in the rehearsals in Paris. Alison Hargan, a British soprano, will take her place.

title: 'Gorby Fever' and Mr. Baker
description: ''Trust, but verify'' was Ronald Reagan's constant advice for dealing with the Soviet Union of his new friend Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The Bush Administration should take it to heart. Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d would find the Reagan formula the best remedy for ''Gorby fever'' - the ill-concealed admiration for the Soviet leader that he reportedly has found sweeping through the bodies politic of our allies.

title: Northrop Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest quarter and year results included a $150 miillion loss provision from the company's conclusion that it will probably sustain a loss on certain classified long-term fixed price research and development contracts. The latest year also included a one- time gain of $135.1 million from a tax adjustment, or $2.87 a share, recorded in the first quarter.

title: Dykstra Wins Big Raise
description: Lenny Dykstra, sometimes benched and frequently angry over sharing center field with Mookie Wilson, won some comfort and a major raise yesterday when a labor arbitrator ruled in his favor and against the Mets and awarded him $575,000 in salary.

title: Valmont Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Accusations Filed
description: The California Horse Racing Board will file accusations against two trainers, Laz Barrera and D. Wayne Lukas, for running horses that tested positive for cocaine, the board said yesterday. Leonard Foote, executive secretary of the board, said he expected to find even more horses with cocaine in their urine samples as the testing continues. ''We've learned to hope for the best and expect the worst,'' Foote said at a news conference at Santa Anita Park. Since November, the horses of six trainers, including Barrera and Lukas, have tested positive for cocaine, the board said. Only one trainer, Roger Stein, has gone to a hearing so far. While Foote said it did not sound plausible that any of the trainers could have deliberately administered cocaine to their horses, they are still held responsible. (AP)

title: Broad F.D.I.C. Powers Seen in Savings Plan
description: The Bush Administration plan to bail out the savings industry would give the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation broad new powers to increase deposit insurance premiums for banks and savings institutions far above previously disclosed levels, according to an outline of the plan released Tuesday.

title: Ex-Jets Assistant Gets Browns Post
description: The Cleveland Browns today hired Dan Radakovich, a former Jets assistant, as defensive coordinator and linebacker coach.

title: Coleman Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Harold Abelson, 84, Ex-City College Dean
description: Dr. Harold H. Abelson, retired dean of the School of Education at City College, died of heart failure on Feb. 6 at St. John's Hospital in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 84 years old and lived in Santa Monica.

title: Sheldon H. Blank, 91, a Professor of Bible
description: Rabbi Sheldon Haas Blank, a professor of Bible who was a faculty member at the Cincinnati campus of Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion for more than 60 years, died Tuesday at Jewish Hospital in Cincinnati. He was 91 years old and lived in Cincinnati.

title: In Texas, Farewell to Old Post Office
description: After 142 years, the post office here has finally outgrown T. C. Lindsey's general store. The post office is among the nation's oldest in an original site and has been used in movies because of its old-fashioned look.

title: Saving Tree Roots During Construction
description: LEAD: In 1985 the owner of a cottage in East Hampton, L.I., decided to install air-conditioners and an electric stove, and asked an electrician to bring in a heavy-duty line. The work was done promptly and neatly, but now the stately copper beech that graced the front lawn is dead.

title: Mavericks Send Aguirre To Pistons for Dantley
description: Mark Aguirre, a high-scoring but temperamentally unpredictable forward for the Dallas Mavericks for all eight of his National Basketball Association seasons, was traded yesterday to the Detroit Pistons for Adrian Dantley. Included in the trade for Dantley, the N.B.A.'s 10th-leading career scorer, was the Pistons' first-round draft choice in 1991. If the Mavericks take part in the 1988-89 Western Conference finals, the Pistons would also receive Cleveland's 1989 second-round draft pick and the Mavericks' 1991 second-round choice.

title: Ramos and Gaze Lead Seton Hall Past Connecticut
description: Ramon Ramos had 27 points, 18 in the second half, as 12th-ranked Seton Hall held off Connecticut, 72-69, tonight in a Big East Conference game.

title: Flu Affecting Young More Than Elderly
description: The current influenza season appears to be having a greater effect on children and young adults than on the elderly, the group usually hardest hit by the seasonal infections, experts said today.

title: Lasting Costs for Child Found From a Mother's Early Drinks
description: Even moderate drinking by women in the first month or two of pregnancy, often before they realize they are pregnant, can impair the child's intellectual ability upon reaching school age, a new study indicates.

title: UniCare Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Currents; A Designer's Clockwork Work Space
description: MARCO DE PLANO, a Manhattan graphics designer, is fascinated by clocks. Not only does he have a collection of 50 clocks and watches, his business, De Plano Design, is on the 26th floor of the Metropolitan Life Tower at 1 Madison Avenue where it is surrounded by a clock that is to its neighbors as Big Ben is to Londoners. Three of the tower's four 26 1/2-foot clock faces are part of the exterior walls of Mr. de Plano's office.

title: Prudential Unit Nears a Shift
description: Prudential Bache Securities Inc. plans to announce a new president today, Wall Street professionals said yesterday. They said that W. James Tozer

title: Chrysler Sees Irregularities
description: The Chrysler Corporation issued a statement late today saying that an internal audit had uncovered irregularities in its facilities management operations.

title: Freni Recital Canceled
description: The soprano Mirella Freni has canceled, because of illness, the recital she was to give at Carnegie Hall on Sunday evening. Information: 247-7800.

title: 2 More Top Executives Held in Japan Scandal
description: A Japanese prosecutor's office today arrested two more top executives of companies at the center of a stock-trading scandal, news reports said, bringing to six the number of people charged in the affair.

title: Khomeini's Judgment; Iranian Leader's Instruction to Kill Writer May Reflect a Calculation Rooted in Politics
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's call for the execution of a writer he has accused of blasphemy appears to be largely a political maneuver by the Iranian leader to reassert his role as spokesman and protector of Islamic causes.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Farley Industries, Chicago, said its Farley/WPM Acquisition Corp. unit had extended its $52-a-share cash offer to midnight Friday for West Point-Pepperell Inc.

title: Salvadoran Union Bombed
description: The offices of El Salvador's largest anti-Government union, the National Union of Salvadoran Workers, were bombed early today, wounding one person and causing serious damage. The Maximilano Hernandez death squad took responsibility for the bombing. It left behind a statement saying that a new unit, the People's Counterrevolutionary Army, carried out the attack.

title: Newhall Land & Farming Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings are in units.

title: Bradford W. Stone, Executive, 83
description: Bradford W. Stone, a retired automotive executive, died of heart failure Tuesday at Alexandria (Va.) Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in Falls Church, Va.

title: Aetna Life & Casualty Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $13.7 million for both the quarter and year, and realized capital losses of $1.2 million for the quarter and realized capital gains of $31.2 million for the year. c-Included a reversal of a tax credit amounting to $10.6 million for the quarter and a tax credit of $49.5 million for the year, and realized capital losses of $20.2 million for the quarter and realized capital gains of $3.7 million for the year. The company said for 1988, the tax benefit resulting from the ''fresh start'' provisions of the Tax Reform Act of 1986 was $76 million, compared with $134 million in 1987. The ''fresh start'' tax benefit for the fourth quarter of 1988 was $19 million, compared with $39 million a year-ago.

title: Accord on Designer's Name
description: After a two-year legal battle, the fashion designer Rebecca Moses has exclusive ownership of her name. A court-approved settlement reached between Ms. Moses and Victor Coopersmith Enterprises Inc. was announced yesterday.

title: English Garden, Picture Perfect
description: THERE'S nothing like a private tour through a great English landscape with the owner as your guide. And for those who prefer not to leave these shores, there is the option of enjoying ''Gertrude Jekyll: A Vision of Garden and Wood,'' a book whose publication this month coincides with an exhibition of the same name that opens at the Paine Webber Gallery in Manhattan tomorrow.

title: Israelis Study Devices In Blasts in West Bank
description: The Israeli Army, Air Force and national police began an investigation today to identify mysterious exploding devices that have killed and wounded several West Bank Palestinian children in the last two weeks, the army said.

title: MAN IN THE NEWS: Boris V. Gromov; Afghanistan: Last Man Out
description: Soviet officials had repeatedly vowed that their men would not leave Afghanistan in disarray, like the last Americans clambering onto helicopters from the roof of their embassy as Saigon fell around them.

title: Grubb & Ellis Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and included a gain of $3,412,000 from an accounting change. The company said the 1988 results were negatively affected by $6 million in property valuation and other reserves.

title: Iranian Protest and Threat
description: A protest against ''The Satanic Verses'' was reported in Teheran as an Iranian was quoted as offering $1 million to the killer of the author, Salman Rushdie. Page A6. Mr. Rushdie canceled his U.S. book tour. Page A7.

title: Experts Disagree if Baker's Stocks Posed Conflict With Treasury Post
description: The decision by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d this week to sell his holdings in a banking company has left experts divided on whether it was proper for him to own that stock as Treasury Secretary and whether the bank benefited from his policies.

title: Echo Bay Mines Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a pre-tax gain of $14.9 million on the prepayment of a silver note receivable. All results are in U.S. dollars. The company said earnings for the year were reduced by an increase in exploration expense to $18.7 million from $8.7 million in 1987.

title: Settlement in Karcher Case
description: The president of Carl Karcher Enterprises Inc., the fast-food company, and five family members have agreed to settle Federal charges of insider trading, the Securities and Exchange Commission said this week.

title: Oil Imports in January Topped Output in U.S.
description: For the first time in a decade, the United States imported more oil in January than it produced, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.

title: Italy Says NATO Neglects the Mediterranean
description: The Italian Defense Minister has asserted that the NATO alliance consistently slights Italy and other Mediterranean countries, paying more attention to the problems of central and northern Europe.

title: Maloney Studies Racial Strife
description: The Federal prosecutor in Brooklyn has begun an investigation into accusations that Hasidic Jews have intimidated and in some cases have beaten black residents of the Williamsburg section, the United States Attorney said yesterday.

title: Richard Roud, 59, First Director Of New York Film Festival, Dies
description: Richard Roud, a former director of the New York Film Festival who developed a risky experimental venture into an ornament of the city's cultural life, died of cardiac arrest on Monday in Nimes, France, where he had been in a coma in the Hopital Doumergue since suffering a heart attack on Jan. 15. He was 59 years old and lived in Paris.

title: Structure of Enzyme in AIDS Virus Is Identified
description: Scientists have determined the complete three-dimensional structure of an enzyme of the AIDS virus, opening new possibilities for designing drugs to combat the deadly disease.

title: Sneak Peek: T. J., Gator In 'Dallas'
description: Throughout the George Steinbrenner reign, Yankee tradition has often resembled the unsmiling scenario of a soap opera. And today in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., that glorious tradition will continue with the filming of the first episode of ''Dallas Dugout,'' the principal owner's new afternoon series.

title: Blacks As They Are
description: February is Black History Month and, to mark this, the Town and Gown Theater of the University of Alabama at Birmingham will perform an unusual collage of material drawn from the works of black leaders, poets and composers at the National Museum of Natural History in Washington on Saturday evening.

title: SCHOOL BOARDS: WHO'S REPRESENTING WHOM
Mr. Baker's Conversion
description: Secretary of State James Baker, who showed skill at political damage control as President Bush's campaign chief, has belatedly changed his mind about holding on to large amounts of stock in a bank holding company with billions in outstanding loans to third world nations.

title: Pannill Knitting Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a charge of $463,000 from writeoffs of unamortized deferred financing costs associated with a prior debt agreement which was replaced in 1988.

title: Judge Not
description: LEAD: The testimony of the conservative activist Paul Weyrich before the Senate Armed Services Committee alleging personal misconduct on the part of Secretary of Defense-designate John G. Tower discomforted official Washington and temporarily halted momentum toward the nominee's approval. Whatever else may be said about Mr.

title: Last Soviet Soldiers Leave Afghanistan After 9 Years, 15,000 Dead and Great Cost
description: MOSCOW--The last Soviet soldier came home from Afghanistan this morning, the Soviet Union announced, leaving behind a war that had become a domestic burden and an international embarrassment for Moscow.

title: Home Improvement
description: SQUEAKY, wobbly stairs are more than a nuisance; they can be hazardous if not repaired. Some stair problems are easy to fix. But because of the complexity of stair construction, severe problems are often best left to an experienced carpenter.

title: Illinois Power Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $34,012,000 from an accounting change. The latest fourth quarter net did not cover preferred stock requirements.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 3 P.M.

title: General Electric Canada Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest fourth quarter and year included restructuring costs of $2,136,000 and $5,002,000, respectively. The year-ago fourth quarter and year included restructuring costs of $407,000 and $6,320,000, repsectively. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Dreyfus Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting change of $1,419,000. The company said total revenue for all periods before the latest quarter have been restated for an accounting change.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Our living room ceiling, which was painted about nine years ago, is showing dark streaks where each of the overhead beams in the attic crosses. These streaks don't wash off easily. We have a humidifier on the furnace and the attic above this ceiling is unheated. We plan to repaint, but want to avoid this happening again. Have you any suggestions? A. This is not uncommon. It usually results from the fact that while most of the ceiling is relatively warm the parts that are in contact with the beams in the attic are always slightly colder, wood being a poor insulator.

title: Nets Erase Big Deficit But They Still Lose
description: The Nets deserved a better ending tonight.

title: Klan's Ghost Haunts Louisiana Vote
description: Despite concerted opposition from national and state Republican leaders, a former Ku Klux Klan leader is locked in a tight battle with a local home builder in a state legislative race that has received extraordinary national attention.

title: British Law Reforms Need Change on Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: Nanometrics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: 11,000 Buyers Look Forward to School
description: For young people on vacation, the annual blitz of back-to-school sales is a rude reminder that the endless summer always ends too soon. But the hubbub of 1,000 merchants at a recent trade show reflected another reality - that the back-to-school market thrives year round.

title: Why Renwick Hospital Isn't Official Landmark
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Music; Jazz Orchestra's Memories of Basie
description: During the American Jazz Orchestra's program on the early years of the Count Basie Band at Cooper Union on Tuesday evening, John Lewis, who conducted the orchestra and played the Basie piano role, pointed out that Basie's band depended on outstanding soloists for its distinction. This was in contrast with the Duke Ellington and Jimmie Lunceford Bands, which featured complex arrangements.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the Broadway play ''Hizzoner!'' misstated the opening date. The show, which is in previews at the Longacre Theater, opens next Thursday, not today.

title: Catching the Spirit
description: Ronald H. Brown, the new chairman of the Democratic National Committee, accepted victory last week with praise for such Democratic Governors as Bill Clinton of Arkansas, Ray Mabus of Mississippi and Madeleine M. Kunin of Vermont.

title: Talking Deals; Cutting Rate Risk On Buyout Debt
description: WHILE critics of corporate takeovers have worried about the dangers of the heavy borrowing needed to complete the mergers, financiers are learning to reduce their risk by protecting themselves against the danger of rising interest rates.

title: An Industry Revamped By Disaster
description: Chemical industry leaders in the United States said yesterday that the Bhopal disaster had led to profound changes in the way they handle their safety procedures.

title: Lonvest Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Utilitech reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Year-ago quarter and nine-month results included a charge of $522,200 to write down certain excess equipment to net realizable value.

title: Inmac Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
Sony Corp of America reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings represent American Depositary Share. The results are in U.S. dollars that had been translated from yen at the rate of 126 yen equals U.S. $1.00, the Tokyo foreign exchange market rate as of Dec. 30, 1988.

title: Satan as Islamic Scapegoat
description: It violates minimal comity among nations for the leader of one state to clamor for the murder of citizens of another. Ayatollah Khomeini goes further. He not only calls on the Muslim faithful to kill a British novelist and his American publishers, but also offers a passage to Heaven and a cash reward to those who carry out the crime. His threat cannot be ignored, propitiated or rationalized; it deserves categorical condemnation.

title: New Chairman Tells Democrats to Be Tough
description: Ronald H. Brown, the new Democratic national chairman, said today that his party must be ''a lot tougher'' in dealing with the Republicans and in making clear its firmness on the issues of crime and national defense.

title: CNA Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included realized investment gains of $25,843,000 and $141,987,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-After realized investment losses of $9,248,000 for the quarter and $27,762,000 for the year.

title: LAST SOVIET SOLDIERS LEAVE AFGHANISTAN AFTER 9 YEARS, 15,000 DEAD AND GREAT COST
description: The last Soviet soldier came home from Afghanistan this morning, the Soviet Union announced, leaving behind a war that had become a domestic burden and an international embarrassment for Moscow.

title: Officer's Killer Gets 37 1/2 Years to Life
description: A Brooklyn judge said yesterday that a man convicted of killing a transit police officer was a ''scourge on society'' and sentenced him to 37 1/2 years to life in prison.

title: Currents; Furniture Au Naturel, Sort Of
description: GERD VERSCHOOR is a furniture designer whose medium is nature. One of his chairs has an antique upholstered seat and a six-foot back of newly cut birch branches.

title: Giuliani Is Said to Be Joining Firm as Partner
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former United States Attorney in Manhattan, will become a partner in White & Case, an old-line financial law firm, according to sources close to the situation.

title: Currents; 500 Artisans to Show Wares in Baltimore
description: THE A.C.C. CRAFT FAIR in Baltimore, the largest of four fairs sponsored annually around the nation by the American Crafts Council, opens tomorrow. Some 500 artisans from 44 states are to exhibit.

title: Reputed I.R.A. Operative Held in Smuggling
description: A reputed operative of the Irish Republican Army was indicted yesterday on Federal charges of smuggling counterfeit American money into the United States.

title: Bolivian Planning to Sell 8 Paintings at Auction
description: Eight paintings by Gauguin, Cezanne, Renoir, Monet, Pissarro, Fantin-Latour and Boudin - most of them acquired in the 1980's by Jaime Ortiz-Patino of Geneva, an heir to a Bolivian tin fortune - are to be auctioned on May 9 in New York. David J. Nash, who heads Sotheby's fine art sales, said yesterday that the paintings are expected to sell for more than $50 million.

title: Hein-Werner Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Trial Separation Is Set For Fonda and Hayden
description: The actress Jane Fonda and her husband, Assemblyman Tom Hayden of California, have decided to separate on a trial basis, a spokesman for the couple said today.

title: Verit Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Campaign Trail in Chicago's Mayoral Race Takes a Pair of Twists
description: With less than two weeks to go before voters here cast their ballots in the mayoral primary, the campaign trail took a couple of sudden twists today.

title: Local Boards: A Failure to Reflect Schools
description: In 4 of the 32 decentralized New York City school districts, where black, Hispanic and Asian-American pupils make up half or more of the public school enrollment, all the members of the locally elected school boards are white.

title: IRANIANS PROTEST OVER BANNED BOOK
description: Thousands of people reportedly threw stones and waved pictures of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini outside the British Embassy in Teheran today in protest against a book that has been deemed offensive to Islam.

title: Balsam Oil of Israelite Kings Found in Cave Near Dead Sea
description: Israeli archeologists, searching caves near the Dead Sea, have discovered what they believe is a 2,000-year-old jug of once-fragrant oil of the kind used to anoint the ancient Israelite kings.

title: Loews Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $18,067,000. c-After net of $23,722,000 for the quarter and $39,794,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations. Loews said that exclusive of securities transactions, its latest fourth quarter net would have been $243.4 million, or $3.21 a share. The latest year net included realized investment gains of $143.8 million, or $1.89 a share, compared with $68.2 million, or 87 cents a share, of realized investment gains in 1987.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: Amid a heavy volume of new tax issues, New Jersey yesterday priced a $350 million competitive issue of general obligation bonds through underwriters led by the BT Securities Corporation.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Becker and McEnroe Gain: Top-seeded Boris Becker and third-seeded John McEnroe won their first-round matches yesterday at the $492,500 Stella Artois indoor championships at Milan, Italy. McEnroe, who will be 30 years old today, routed Carl-Uwe Steeb of West Germany, 6-3, 6-2, at Palatrussardi Arena. Becker survived a first-set scare before defeating Ronald Agenor of Haiti, 6-7, 6-2, 6-1. McEnroe will next play unseeded Michiel Schapers of the Netherlands. McEnroe took 1 hour 16 minutes to beat Steeb, a member of the West German team which defeated Sweden in the finals of the Davis Cup last December. In another second-round match, Eric Jelen of West Germany upset seventh-seeded Jonas Svensson of Sweden, 6-4, 6-0. (AP) Graf Wins: Steffi Graf yielded only 16 points in routing Carling Bassett-Seguso yesterday, 6-0, 6-0, to gain a spot in the quarterfinals of the $300,000 Virginia Slims of Washington at Fairfax, Va. Graf, the world's top-ranked player, faced only 3 break points - all in the same game - in the 42-minute victory. Graf will next face Helen Kelesi, seeded eighth, who moved into the quarterfinals with a 6-3, 6-4 victory over Isabelle Demongeot of France.(AP) Connors Gains: Second-seeded Jimmy Connors took advantage of Jason Stoltenberg's break in concentration to wrap up a 6-3, 7-5 victory last night in the second-round of the Volvo Indoor Tennis Championships. Connors, ranked seventh in the world by the Association of Tennis Professionals, broke Stoltenberg's service at 15-40 in the second set to take the match. Connors returned to tournament play following three months off for foot surgery. Earlier, Jimmy Arias upset 13th-seeded Robert Seguso, 6-2, 7-6, and Leif Shiras beat eighth-seeded Andres Gomez, 6-3, 3-6, 7-5. (AP) N.H.L. Red Wings 4, North Stars 2: Adam Oates had a goal and two assists last night for Detroit at home. Jim Pavese made it 2-0 midway through the period before teammate Gerard Gallant connected on a power play for his 33d goal. Gallant, Steve Yzerman and Paul MacLean, Detroit's top line, have combined for 115 goals, breaking the club mark of 114 set in 1968-69 by Frank Mahavolich, Alex Delvecchio and Gordie Howe.(AP) Whalers 4, Maple Leafs 2: Paul MacDermid had a goal and two assists for the Whalers in Toronto. Kevin Dineen, Ray Ferraro and Dave Tippett also scored for the Whalers. Daniel Marois and Mark Osborne scored for Toronto. Hartford outshot Toronto, 39-28.(AP) Blackhawks 7, Capitals 4:Dirk Graham's second goal of the game 40 seconds into the final period broke a 3-3 tie and snapped the Capitals' eight-game unbeaten streak on the road. (AP) Flames 6, Jets 1: Theoren Fleury and Joe Mullen scored 16 seconds apart in a four-goal second period as the Flames gained their team-record eighth consecutive victory in Winnipeg. The Flames' unbeaten streak reached 12 games (11-0-1).(AP) N.B.A. 76ers 113, Pacers 98: Reggie Miller scored a season-high 28 points for Indiana, which scored just 16 points in the fourth quarter. Maurice Cheeks of the 76ers became the 146th player in league history to reach the 10,000-point mark. Cheeks has 10,002 points. (AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL/WOMEN Tennessee 88, Georgia Tech 71: Bridgette Gordon scored 24 points to lead No. 3 Tennessee (23-2) last night. For Georgia Tech (14-10), Ida Neal had 35 points.(AP) S. Carolina 67, N.C. State 62: Beth Hunt scored 17 points as No. 19 South Carolina (17-5) beat No. 13 North Carolina State (18-5).(AP) Maryland 104, Virginia 99: Carla Holmes scored 9 of her 32 points in overtime as No. 6 Maryland (20-2, 10-1) beat No. 14 Virginia (18-6, 8-4) in an Atlantic Coast Conference game. (AP)

title: Brazil Drops Charges Against Two Indians
description: Brazil's court of appeals has dropped charges against two Indians who lobbied abroad against construction of dams on their land and an American scientist who served as their interpreter, a court official said today.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a Hindu festival in India, and its map caption, gave an incorrect date in some copies for the ritual bath in which 15 million pilgrims joined. The date, described as the most auspicious for such a bath, was Feb. 6.

title: Shell Finds Oil In Barents Sea
description: Norway said this week that Anglo-Dutch Shell had made the first oil find in the Barents Sea but said further tests would be needed to see if the deposit was worth exploiting.

title: Sony's Profits Up 44.4%
description: The Sony Corporation said today that its earnings rose 44.4 percent in its third quarter on healthy sales gains. The company's profits in the period ended Dec. 31 totaled 28.9 billion yen, or $229 million, up from 20 billion yen a year earlier. Sales totaled 613.8 billion yen, or $4.87 billion, an increase of 36.8 percent from 448.7 billion yen. The dollar equivalents were calculated on the basis of an exchange rate of 126 yen to the dollar that prevailed at the end of the reporting period.

title: U.S. BISHOPS PLAN TALKS WITH POPE
description: Preparations for a long-awaited summit meeting between Pope John Paul II and representatives of Roman Catholic bishops in the United States entered their final stage this week.

title: Jiffy Lube International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest quarter included a charge of about $39 million related to the restructuring of certain franchise operations.

title: Wilderness Society Assails Proposal For More Logging in Federal Forests
description: Plans by the National Forest Service that would double allowable timber sales and nearly double the mileage of roads in six southern Appalachian national forests over the next 10 years would damage the recreational and scenic value of the rugged mountainous areas and harm their fragile ecosystems, a Wilderness Society study says.

title: LATIN AGREEMENT RAISES EYEBROWS AT WHITE HOUSE
description: The Bush Administration was caught off guard by the agreement by five Central American countries to disarm the Nicaraguan guerrillas, American officials said today, even though Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d met with the Foreign Ministers of Costa Rica and Honduras just last week.

title: Deficit Cited by Northrop
description: The Northrop Corporation said today that it lost $86.1 million in the fourth quarter after setting aside $150 million for possible losses on several classified military research and development projects.

title: Linking Environment and Competitiveness
description: To the Editor:

title: Stocks Regain Ground as Dow Jumps 22.68
description: LEAD: The stock market yesterday pulled out of its recent doldrums, and the Dow Jones industrial average jumped 22.68 points, closing at 2,303.93.

title: Talks on Takeover Of Envirodyne
description: Envirodyne Industries, a Chicago food-packaging company, said it had held preliminary talks with Donald P. Kelly, the former chairman of the Beatrice Company, about a possible takeover. Envirodyne said it had not received a formal offer from Mr. Kelly and had not determined if the company was for sale. Envirodyne's stock rose 50 cents a share, to $32.75, in over-the-counter trading.

title: Sakharov Withdraws From the Moscow Elections
description: Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist and human rights advocate, announced today that he was ending his campaign to represent Moscow voters in the new national Congress of Deputies.

title: Profits Scoreboard
description: $ Net Income Percent Oct.-Dec. Change 1988 From '87 Alexander & Alex. Services $ 14,400,000 +34.6 Anchor Glass Container (9,200,000) - Enserch Corp. 6,900,000 +1.5 GAF Corp. 22,000,000 +2.8 Loews Corp. 264,100,000 -9.4 Lubrizol Corp. 74,400,000 +485.8 News Corp. Ltd. 224,300,000 +76.7 Northrop Corp. (86,100,000) - Salant Corp. 9,400,000 +123.8 Sony Corp. of America 229,400,000 +44.4 See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss) *Loss in year-earlier period.

title: Cuomo Sets AIDS Plan, Admitting It Falls Short
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo yesterday released a broad five-year state plan for combatting AIDS in New York, but he said fiscal problems are preventing his administration from fully meeting current needs or mounting major new programs this year.

title: Gorbachev Aide Says U.S. Should Lift Trade Barriers
description: A top Moscow economist predicted here today that if the United States abolished trade barriers with the Soviet Union, commerce between the countries would expand ''by a factor of 5 to 10 times'' in five years.

title: Cuomo Proposes A Panel to Help New York City
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said today that leaders from New York State, the Federal Government and New York City - including Mayor Edward I. Koch and his rivals in this year's mayoral campaign -should get together ''in partnership, in family, in synergism'' to form a commission to resolve the city's problems.

title: Market Place; If Closed Funds Go Open-Ended
description: WHEN it comes to closed-end funds, Wall Street seems to think that what happens to one fund in a group will not affect the rest.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BALTIMORE (AL) - Signed Brian Holton, pitcher, to a one-year contract. BOSTON (AL) - Agreed to terms with Roger Clemens, pitcher, on a three-year contract. CINCINNATI (NL) - Signed Van Snider, outfielder, to a one-year contract. KANSAS CITY (AL) - Signed Bo Jackson, outfielder, and Luis Aquino, pitcher, to one-year contracts. BASKETBALL DETROIT (NBA) - Traded Adrian Dantley, forward, and a first-round 1991 draft pick to the Dallas Mavericks for Mark Aguirre, forward. If Dallas plays in the 1989 Western Conference final, the Pistons will also receive the Mavericks' 1991 second-round draft pick and a second-round pick in 1989. FOOTBALL CLEVELAND (AFC) - Named Dan Radakovich defensive coordinator and linebackers coach. SAN DIEGO (AFC) - Named Larry Beightol offensive coordinator in charge of the offensive line. WASHINGTON (NFC) - Named Jack Burns quarterback coach. HOCKEY ISLANDERS (NHL) - Traded Tomas Jonsson, defenseman, to the Edmonton Oilers for future considerations. Loaned Brad Lauer, left wing, to Springfield of the American Hockey league. Recalled Dale Henry, left wing, from Springfield. PITTSBURGH (NHL) - Assigned Bruce Racine, goalie, to Muskegon of the International Hockey League.

title: Florio Says U.S. Agents Gave Party Free Space
description: Regulators of the savings and loan industry allowed a Republican organization in Florida to use office space without paying rent, Representative James J. Florio of New Jersey said today.

title: Jaco Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $127,129. c-After tax credits of $79,000 for the quarter and $198,000 for the 6 months.

title: Metro Matters; Years of Contrast: From Sutton '77 To Dinkins '89
description: Twelve years have gone by, but Percy E. Sutton, who was then the Manhattan Borough President, can't forget the news conference he held in the Empire State Building observatory.

title: Pro Bono
description: * Ketchum Public Relations, a division of Ketchum Communications Inc., has been selected to design a public relations campaign for the United Way of New York City.

title: Threats to Author Lead to Canceling of Book Tour
description: Salman Rushdie and his publisher yesterday canceled Mr. Rushdie's book tour of the United States, scheduled for 11 cities beginning next week, because of the threats on the author's life.

title: ACTION ON NEW JET TO AWAIT A REVIEW
description: The Bush Administration has put off until mid-March a decision on whether to allow an American company to help Japan develop a new version of the F-16 fighter, Administration officials and Congressional aides said today.

title: 3CI Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Debate Grows on Development Fees
description: Local governments are increasingly demanding that real estate developers pay for everything from road improvements to day-care centers, a practice that is driving prices of new homes higher in some regions and intensifying the debate over whether such charges amount to an unfair tax on new residents.

title: A Latin Peace Plan Not So Broad: Ball in Nicaragua's Court
description: By forcing anti-Sandinista rebels out of their Honduran base camps in return for free elections in Nicaragua, a meeting of Central American presidents has brought the focus of the region's peace process back where it started: the battle over the future of Nicaragua.

title: Bulova Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
