description: b-Included a loss of $7,000 and a gain of $865,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, both from asset dispositions, and extraordinary tax benefits of $588,000 for the quarter and $1,038,000 for the year. c-Net income d-Included gains from asset dispositions of $358,000 and $3,163,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and extraordinary tax benefits of $169,000 for the quarter and $491,000 for the year.

title: Rockwood National reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Victoria Creations reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Fisher-Price Report
description: Quaker Oats Company stock fell after the president of its Fisher-Price unit said the division's contribution to this year's earnings would be flat. The share price dropped 75 cents today, to $51, on the New York Stock Exchange. Fisher-Price's president, R. Bruce Sampsell, said at the New York Toy Fair that the unit's operating results for the year ending in June would be about even with the $106 million earned in the 1988 fiscal year.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about ambassadorial appointments for longtime supporters of George Bush described political contributions by two of them incorrectly. The appointees, Joseph Zappala, who has been selected as Ambassador to Spain, and Melvin F. Sembler, the choice as Ambassador to Australia, contributed $100,000 each to the Republican Party, not to the Bush campaign. The article also misidentified the nominee to be Ambassador to Turkey. He is Morton I. Abramowitz.

title: 'Legs Diamond' to Close
description: ''Legs Diamond,'' a musical with book by Harvey Fierstein and Charles Suppon and music and lyrics by Peter Allen, will close after the matinee on Sunday at the Mark Hellinger Theater. The play, directed by Robert Allan Ackerman and starring Mr. Allen, will have run for 64 regular performances and 72 previews.

title: More Fertilizer Use Seen
description: Fertilizer use by American farmers is expected to rise by 9 percent this year because of larger crop plantings and higher crop prices, the Agriculture Department said on Tuesday. The greater demand will also drive up fertilizer prices by about 7 percent, the department's Economic Research Service said in a report.

title: Troupe to Make Paris Debut
description: The San Francisco Ballet is to perform for the first time in Paris at the Theatre des Champs-Elysees from May 18 to 25. The engagement is scheduled as part of the annual Festival de Paris, which this year celebrates the bicentennial of the French Revolution. The company is to present a production of ''Swan Lake'' by Helgi Tomasson, its artistic director, and a mixed bill

title: Bonn Discloses 9 Years of Warnings on Libyan Gas
description: The West German Government disclosed today a steady flow of warnings it received since 1980 about Libyan efforts to manufacture poison gas, including reports from its embassies, secret service and the United States about possible German participation.

title: Synergen Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: S.A.T. Scores Are Valid, Reliable and Consistent; People vs. Tests
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. WILL CONTINUE AFGHAN REBEL AID
description: The United States will continue military aid to the Afghan rebels despite the completion of the Soviet troop withdrawal from Afghanistan, the State Department said today, announcing a policy decision that President Bush made last week.

title: TV NOTES
description: Channel 4's 'Fish'

title: Atlantic Southeast Airlines Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest quarter and year included expenses of about $500,000 for the write down of spare parts associated with a certain type of aircraft being returned to a lessor.

title: Alexander & Alexander Servces Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $6 million for both the quarter and year, and the year also included an extraordinary credit of $2.5 million from the utilization of Reed Stenhouse net operating loss carryforwards. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $10 million and an extraordinary credit of $3.5 million. The company said the after-tax gain of $18.2 million from the previously announced sale of Tifco Inc. is included in the fourth quarter results. The gain is offset, in part, by a net provision of $12.1 million. This provision covers estimated losses from the pending sales of two small operations and costs connected with certain indemnities given in the sale of Shand, Morahan & Co. The company also said the financial statements were prepared under the provisions of SFAS No. 94 with restatement of prior periods. Included in the restatement is the reclassification of fiduciary investment income and amortization of intangibles to operating revenues and operating expenses, respectively.

title: Review/Dance; Rioja's Spanish Idiom
description: Pilar Rioja is a superb concert dancer whose choreography is drawn from a variety of Spanish idioms. Not for her the conventional format of the ebullient Spanish dance program. Purity and seriousness are her trademarks. To appreciate her is to understand her first and foremost as a creative artist.

title: Vari-Care Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Youth Sought in Jersey Killing Is Seized in New Mexico
description: A 19-year-old man wanted in the slaying of one high-school student here and the kidnapping of a second ended his three-day, 1,800-mile flight in the New Mexico desert Tuesday night when he ran a roadblock and a shower of police bullets before being forced off the road by New Mexico state troopers.

title: Satirizing Evangelical Scandals
description: Since almost every contemporary controversy becomes grist for the television movie mill, it was inevitable that the recent scandals within the evangelical movement would be dramatized on television. The subject has surfaced not in the usual docudrama but in an outrageous satirical musical, ''Glory! Glory!,'' which will be shown on Home Box Office on Sunday and Monday evenings at 9 o'clock in segments of 90 and 120 minutes.

title: Peruvians Join March for Slain Union Chief
description: Thousands of Peruvians shouting anti-Government slogans marched today in the funeral cortege of Saul Cantoral, the country's top mining-union leader, whose killing unionists have traced to a right-wing death squad.

title: Jonsson Traded to Oilers As Islanders Stress Youth
description: The Islanders announced today that Tomas Jonsson, a veteran defenseman, had been traded to the Edmonton Oilers for future considerations.

title: Notions Big and Small, For Sewing It Yourself
description: Do you need a doohickey, a whatchamacallit or a thingamajig? Then try Greenberg & Hammer, a 70-year-old Manhattan company that bills itself as selling ''everything for the sewing room.''

title: Turning Savage on an Island South of Burma
description: John Dollar By Marianne Wiggins 214 pages. Harper & Row. $17.95.

title: Kleinert's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $460,000 for the quarter and $1,198,000 for the year.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * B. Altman & Co., said Donald Ziccardi had been named senior vice president for sales promotion and marketing.

title: INSIDE
description: Rare Virus Is Spreading

title: For Allergy Tests, Experts Suggest A More Conservative Approach
description: Some doctors frequently misuse allergy tests, subjecting patients to unnecessary procedures and treatment, false diagnoses and needless expense, allergy experts say.

title: Helter-Shelter: Brian Murphy Designs for Himself
description: WHEN Brian A. Murphy was an architecture student at the University of California at Los Angeles, he used to stand on the green rim of the Santa Monica Canyon and, like many exhausted joggers, just gaze. To the west lay the surf (this former lifeguard loves to surf). To the north, perched on a rim above the furrows of the canyon, was another dreamy California fantasy, a coral-colored 1926 Spanish-style house that to Mr. Murphy was ''the idiosyncratic jewel of the canyon.''

title: Zytec Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
'Out of Africa' Chair Right Out of Africa
description: WHEN the producers of ''Out of Africa'' were combing Kenya for period pieces that would give the movie the right look, they stumbled across some unpacked boxes in an antiques store not far from the home of Karen Blixen, who under her pen name, Isak Dinesen, wrote the book on which the movie was based.

title: Transform Logic reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Golf Balls With a Beat In Ayer's Dunlop Spots
description: The advertising world's passion for 1960's music is as intense as ever. In a new campaign by N. W. Ayer, the funky sounds are used to promote a most unfunky product: golf balls.

title: Inventories Rise 0.9%; Sales Up 0.8%
description: Business inventories rose nine-tenths of a percent in December and sales increased at almost the same pace despite growing stockpiles of unsold autos as car purchases lagged.

title: Snub for Drug Czar?
description: Once again, William J. Bennett, the President's choice to lead the war against illegal drugs, has been snubbed. Mr. Bennett was not invited to the White House Tuesday to the first organizational session of the Domestic Policy Council, a Cabinet sub-group that includes top agency heads.

title: Northeast Kingdom Journal; In Vermont, Old Promise, New Fury
description: The lakes are frozen solid and the mountains covered with several feet of snow, but if anger were heat, all traces of winter would vanish here in the Northeast Kingdom.

title: For Infants, Quiet And a Warm Bath
description: ''WE must begin by understanding. Understanding why the newborn infant suffers so much.'' The call was Dr. Frederick Leboyer's in his book ''Birth Without Violence,'' first published in France in 1974.

title: Parent & Child
description: THERE is more to a child's crush than puppy-eyed gazes and irrepressible giggles. Beneath all the silliness and awkwardness of a child who is in love, there lies a serious purpose. Psychologists and others who study child development are beginning to understand the reasons childhood crushes appear when they do.

title: Battle Erupts for Texas Deposits, Making Savings Plan More Costly
description: A bidding war for savings deposits has broken out in Texas, just days after the Bush Administration announced its proposal to rescue the savings and loan industry. That proposal was intended, in part, to shut down insolvent institutions that were forcing up deposit rates for the rest of the industry.

title: Review/Dance; Exuberant Minimalism
description: Eliot Feld choreographs ballets of so many different kinds that their variety virtually guarantees that any program of the Feld Ballet can be counted on to contain something to interest dancegoers of the most divergent tastes. On Saturday night, when his company performed three works at the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street), ''Aurora II'' was especially impressive.

title: Capacity Use Approaching 10-Year High
description: The nation's industry is using more of its capacity than at any other time in nearly a decade, with operating rates approaching levels that can worsen inflation.

title: Omnicom Agrees to Sell New England Agency
description: Ingalls, Quinn & Johnson, the second-largest advertising agency in New England, said yesterday that a group of its employees had reached an agreement with the Omnicom Group to buy the agency.

title: Review/Jazz; Blue Note Series at Birdland
description: The trumpeter Jack Walrath opened his set at Birdland on Monday night with ''Monk on the Moon,'' a sequel to his ''Ray Charles on Mars.'' Set at a rocking tempo with a stiff back beat, the tune, like many of Mr. Walrath's other compositions, was filled with unusual twists and turns. The engagement opens a series of Monday-night shows featuring artists who have recorded for Blue Note Records.

title: John P. Coakley, Executive, 70
description: John P. Coakley, a retired president of the United Tanker Corporation, a shipping company, died Monday at Marcus Lawrence Hospital in Cottonwood, Ariz. He was 70 years old and lived in Sedona, Ariz.

title: Oscar Nominees Include the Unexpected
description: For the second year in a row, Academy Award voters mixed major surprises into their brew of Oscar nominations.

title: Health Foods Introduced By Heart-Attack Victim
description: Charles M. Harper, a strapping 6-foot-6 chief executive, suffered a heart attack three years ago and from that experience, he said, came a yearning for tasty food that was also low in cholesterol, fat and salt.

title: Los Angeles Delays Ban on Assault Rifle Pending Court Case
description: The city agreed today to a one-week delay in its ban on the possession of assault rifles while a Federal judge decides if he has jurisdiction in a lawsuit filed by Colt Industries Inc. challenging the new law.

title: John H. Batten Dies; Manufacturer Was 77
description: John H. Batten, former chairman of the board and chief executive officer of Twin Disc Inc., a manufacturer of power transmission equipment, died of cancer Tuesday at St. Luke's Memorial Hospital in Racine, Wis. He was 77 years old and lived in Racine.

title: With Soviet Forces Out, the Afghans Look Ahead
description: ''Some people may think it was the Geneva agreement that paved the way - or external pressures,'' an Afghan guerrilla leader, Abdul Rasul Sayyaf, said today, after hearing that Soviet troops were finally out of Afghanistan.

title: Thompson Released
description: Charles Thompson, the suspended Oklahoma quarterback, was released from jail yesterday in the custody of his mother while he awaits trial on a charge of selling cocaine to an undercover agent of the F.B.I. Thompson, who made his second court appearance since his arrest Monday night, waived his right to a preliminary hearing. The United States Attorney's office waived its request for a detention hearing because of what it said were Thompson's strong ties to the area.

title: Long-Missing Little League Comes Back to Harlem
description: Little League Baseball, the prepubescent passion of Middle America, has returned to a part of the city where it has been missing for almost two decades.

title: Microsoft Stake In Unix Maker
description: The Microsoft Corporation said today that it would make a minority investment in the Santa Cruz Operation Inc., a privately held company that produces Unix system software.

title: Gunman Kills 3 and Himself In Bank Outside Washington
description: A man described as a ''disgruntled employee'' shot three women co-workers to death and then killed himself at the office of a savings and loan association today, the police said.

title: 40 Die, 90 Are Hurt as Christians Battle in Lebanon
description: Lebanese Army troops and Christian militiamen fought a fierce battle today for control of Christian areas of the country, and the police said 40 people were killed and 90 wounded.

title: Green a Bit Wary, but Confident
description: On the first day of his first year as the Yankee manager, Dallas Green met with reporters and a dozen or so of his players, sat in his office taking copious notes and later strolled the back field at Fort Lauderdale Stadium - his arms folded, a ball in his right hand, a Yankee cap pulled tightly over his brow - in near silence.

title: Salant Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $1,700,000, or 47 cents a share, from the reversal of a portion of the reserve for estimated settlements and costs related to Salant's Chapter 11 reorganization. Periods for 1988 included operating results from Manhattan Industries Inc., which was acquired in 1988. Results for the year-ago fourth quarter have been restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: Joslyn Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included a $16.8 million charge for clean-up of a contaminated soil site.

title: Jepson Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Executive at D.M.B.&B. To Join Image Group
description: Lured by a big city and the bright lights of an innovative advertising agency, Albert Lerman, the deputy managing director of D'Arcy, Masius, Benton & Bowles in St. Louis, will come east to join the Image Group at Wells, Rich, Greene.

title: Vikonics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Intel Reports An Advance In Processor
description: The Intel Corporation's semiconductor designers reported yesterday on a million-transistor microprocessor that integrates many functions, such as graphics and mathematical processing, that had previously been placed on separate chips.

title: Bhopal Details Remain Unresolved
description: In the wake of the Union Carbide Corporation's agreement to pay $470 million to settle claims arising from the toxic gas leak at Bhopal, attention shifted to the complex and daunting task of disbursing the money to the victims.

title: VS Services Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Latest quarter represents 13 weeks. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Malaysian Coal Deposits
description: A West German team has found two coal deposits with about 93 million tons of coal worth an estimated $2.56 billion, it was reported Tuesday. The two deposits were found in the Tebulan and Merit South areas of the Malaysian state of Sarawak, The New Straits Times reported, quoting S. P. Chen, director of Sarawak's Geological Survey Department. The coal is of the sub-bituminous type suitable for industrial use as fuel.

title: Enserch Exploration Partners Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings represents units.

title: A Play Grows Out of Family Art and Tradition
description: In the Playbill for Cindy Lou Johnson's ''Brilliant Traces'' at the Cherry Lane Theater, there is a poem titled ''Individuation'': If I must be wrung through the paradox, - - - broken into wholeness, wring me around the moon; pelt me with particles from the dark side. Fling me into space; hide me in a black hole. Let me dance with devils on dead stars. Let my scars leave brilliant traces, for my highborn soul seeks its hell - - - in high places.

title: Chrysler to Export Axles to China
description: Acustar Inc., the wholly owned auto parts subsidiary of the Chrysler Corporation, said it had agreed to export up to 80,000 axles a year to the Beijing Jeep Corporation of China. Acustar said in a statement that it would begin exporting the axles for rear-wheel-drive applications with a 1,000-axle shipment scheduled for March. It said it was also developing front-drive axle assemblies for eventual use in Beijing's Cherokee models.

title: Pepsico in Sale Pact
description: The General Cinema Corporation signed a definitive agreement for the previously announced $1.75 billion sale of its soft-drink bottling business to Pepsico Inc. The company said the transaction remained subject to clearance by the Federal Trade Commission under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Antitrust Improvements Act. General Cinema said the deal was expected to close by late March or early April.

title: Review/Organ; Cesar Franck Marathon
description: When the organist Anthony Newman prepared the specifications for the Rieger tracker organ that was installed at the Church of the Holy Trinity (316 East 88th Street) in 1987, he may already have been planning the Franck marathon he played there on Sunday afternoon. The program, which included Franck's 12 major works for organ, was reportedly the first such traversal in New York since 1972.

title: Personal Health
description: For nearly a third of Americans the standard response to the typical greeting ''How are you?'' is usually a blatant lie. Although they may say, ''Fine, thank you,'' they do not really mean it.

title: Phillips Cables reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Preserve Your 'Piffiab'
description: ''Ford's D.C.I. is pulling the seacock on Piffiab.''

title: THE BAKER FAMILY HOLDINGS
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said Tuesday that he would sell his personal stock holdings and those of his wife and a minor child to avoid any appearance of a conflict of interest. Questions have been raised about his substantial holdings in the Chemical Banking Corporation of New York. When he was Treasury Secretary, Chemical had large investments in loans to third-world countries that were being pressured by the Treasury to repay their loans, and as Secretary of State, he may have to consider issues involving third-world finances.

title: Unitronix Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Realty Refund reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss of $380,350 on redemption of debentures.

title: Transcapital Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an after-tax writedown of $1.8 million, which represented the company's required prepayments to FSLIC's secondary reserve.

title: British Airways reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings represent American Depositary Share; one ADS equals 10 U.K. ordinary shares. Results are in U.S. dollars; U.S. dollar equivalent amounts are translated at the exchange rate at Dec. 31, 1988, for the 1988 periods, of $1.81 to one against the pound sterling, and the 1987 results are translated at the exchange rate at Dec. 31, 1987 of $1.83.

title: GAF Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary credits related to the company's investment in Union Carbide Corp. of $208,000 and $9,578,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included an extraordinary credit of $1,885,000 for the quarter related to the company's investment in Union Carbide, and the year included extraordinary credits of $137,505,000, primarily representing $97.1 million in net gains from a tender of the company's Borg-Warner shares and $39.5 million in gains related to GAF's investment in Union Carbide. Latest quarter included a $4.5 pretax LIFO charge and a $4 million charge for the settlement of a lawsuit related to a company-owned radio station. The latest year results also reflect $29.8 million of expenses in connection with a management-led buyout of the company.

title: Vulcan International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Bush Heads South to Build Support for His Budget
description: President Bush said today that his proposal to reduce the tax rate on capital gains would increase revenue, employment and the nation's competitiveness in international trade.

title: Big Bucks and High School Sports
description: Apparently undeterred by the systemic corruption of college sports, the national coordinating body for high school athletics is negotiating with a cable television network to present a high school basketball game of the week. Educators and school boards would be wise to block this plunge into commercialism quickly, while there's still time.

title: Burke's Early Miscue Costly for Devils
description: Sean Burke is the cornerstone of the Devils. He inspires them when he plays well and they have difficulties when he is unsteady.

title: Refac Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $327,000 loss from discontinued operations. c-Included a loss of $186,000 and $15,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Lilco Granted Rate Increase, With a Proviso
description: The New York State Public Service Commission yesterday granted the Long Island Lighting Company a 5.4 percent rate increase, the utility's first in three years, but made the increase conditional on Lilco not operating the Shoreham nuclear power plant while negotiations over its future continue.

title: Making A Duplex: No Place to Go But Down
description: ILENE HOCHBERG, author of the magazine parodies Dogue, Catmopolitan and Vanity Fur, in which pets play the parts of people, takes at least one thing seriously: her apartment. ''I live in a little jewel box,'' she said.

title: Passages From Rushdie Book
description: The passages in ''The Satanic Verses'' that Muslim critics have condemned as blasphemous refer to a figure named Mahound, whom they regard as a thinly and perversely disguised representation of the Prophet Mohammed. Mahound appears in the novel only as a character in another character's dreams. This character, Gibreel Farishta, suffers from the delusion that he is really the archangel Gabriel, and he later concedes that he is mentally ill. In Gibreel's dreams, Mahound is a businessman turned prophet, who is trying to preach to the city of Jahilia, a city ''built entirely of sand.'' Here are excerpts from the novel. Message Is One One One

title: United States v. North
description: The prosecution of Oliver North ran into many frustrations before the agreement by the independent counsel and the Attorney General that lets the trial go forward. But that should not be a reason for surprise. The case is a hard test of three weighty and sometimes conflicting interests: national security, justice and accountability.

title: Stewart Information Services Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an after-tax gain on termination of the company's employee pension plan of $481,000. c-Net loss d-Included a tax benefit of $7,394,000, or $1.83 a share.

title: Bronx Youth Shot Dead During Play With Gun
description: A Bronx teen-ager was shot and killed early yesterday while he and a friend played with a gun, the police said.

title: Carbide India Subsidiary Sees Chance for Renewal
description: Vijay Gokhale, the chairman and managing director of Union Carbide India Ltd., said today that the settlement of the court case would help his company rehabilitate itself.

title: OFFICERS IN TAMPA CLEARED IN DEATH
description: An investigation found no criminal wrongdoing or negligence by police officers in the death of a suspected drug dealer that touched off two nights of disturbances, prosecutors said today.

title: Israeli Inflation Up 4.7%
description: Israel's consumer price index rose 4.7 percent in January, the highest monthly inflation in three years, after an economic austerity plan was put into effect, the Central Bureau of Statistics said today. A spokesman said the rise, compared with an increase of five-tenths of 1 percent in December and 1.6 percent in January 1988, was caused by price increases in all consumer goods.

title: Fed Blocks Continental Bid To Acquire Bank in Arizona
description: In an unusually tough move to enforce Federal law encouraging banks to invest in their local communities, the Federal Reserve Board yesterday turned down an application by the Continental Bank of Chicago to acquire the Grand Canyon State Bank of Scottsdale, Ariz.

title: Three New Productions Set For City Opera's '89 Season
description: New production of Mozart's ''Don Giovan-ni,'' Schoenberg's ''Moses und Aron'' and a Ravel double bill of ''L'Heure Espagnole'' and ''L'Enfant et les Sortileges'' are among the 20 works to be presented by the New York City Opera during its 1989 season, which opens on July 6.

title: Presidential Snacks
description: A debate is under way among close associates of George Bush over the favorite snack of the President. Mr. Bush has long shown a fondness for pork rinds, so much so that Congressional leaders recently brought him some as a good-will gift. But some longtime Bush friends, such as Don Rhodes and Vic Gold, insist that his true love is popcorn. When he recently invited guests to the White House theater for a screening of the movie, ''Working Girl,'' he made sure they had plenty of popcorn before the lights went down.

title: Intel Files Lawsuit Against ULSI
description: The Intel Corporation said it had filed a civil lawsuit against ULSI System Technology Inc. of Santa Clara, Calif., accusing the company of misusing trade secrets and confidential information. In a complaint filed in Superior Court in Santa Clara, Intel said ULSI has been engaged in the development of chips that substitute for Intel's 80387 math co-processor.

title: Vitran Corp reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: b-Included a special gain of $750,000. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Virus That May Cause Leukemia Is Spreading Among Drug Addicts
description: A troubling virus that was thought to be very rare is now spreading widely among groups of intravenous drug users in this country, according to new surveys that have not yet been published.

title: Review/Television; Elephants And Their World
description: The decline of the biggest land mammal of us all is the subject of tonight's ''National Geographic Special.'' With humans encroaching on its native grounds in Asia and Africa, with poachers after its tusks, the elephant is under siege. The qualities and predicament of the species are on display at 9 P.M. on Channel 13 and at 8 on Channel 50.

title: Currents; Soap Opera Set Modeled On Wright
description: IN 1923 Frank Lloyd Wright designed La Miniatura in Pasadena, Calif., for Mrs. George Madison Millard. It was one of his first houses made of precast textured concrete blocks. This month when viewers switch on ''One Life to Live,'' the ABC soap opera, they will see the characters trapped in Eterna, an underground city modeled after La Miniatura.

title: Text of Accord by Central American Presidents
description: Following is the text of the Central American Presidents' accord issued in El Salvador on Tuesday, as translated by the Nicaraguan Foreign Ministry:<

title: ACCORD ON SECRETS FOR NORTH'S TRIAL
description: Ending a dispute that nearly scuttled the criminal trial of Oliver L. North, the Bush Administration and the independent prosecutor in the Iran-contra case agreed today to abide by a Federal judge's rules for handling secret evidence.

title: Cubic Officer Investigated
description: The Cubic Corporation has disclosed that its senior vice president, Colvin C. Wellborn, is a target of the Justice Department's investigation into possible fraud in the Pentagon's procurement of arms and equipment.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-21

title: Corrections
description: An illustration and a caption in Science Times on Tuesday about threats to Antartica's wildlife mislabeled a penguin species and incorrectly described the diets of two species. The illustration showed a Chinstrap penguin, not an Emperor; both the Chinstrap and the Adelie penguin, also pictured, eat mainly krill, not fish and squid. The names of two researchers were also given incorrectly in some references. They are a married couple, Langdon Queton and Robin Ross.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY A rate war has erupted among Texas savings institutions since the Bush Administration announced a proposal to rescue the industry. A major effect of the rate wars is that an industry bailout could become more costly as institutions vie for deposits. [ Page A1. ] The F.D.I.C. would receive broad new powers to increase deposit insurance premiums for banks and savings units far above previously disclosed levels under the Bush rescue plan. [ D15. ] The nation's industry operated at a rate of 84.4 percent of capacity in January, the highest since October 1979. Industrial production climbed 0.3 percent in January. [ D1. ] Business inventories rose 0.9 percent in December, and sales jumped 0.8 percent. [ D5. ] The General Services Administration said it would restrict the Navy's authority to award computer contracts. [ D2. ] INTERNATIONAL A top Moscow economist has predicted that if the U.S. abolishes trade barriers with the Soviet Union, commerce between the two would expand ''by a factor of 5 to 10 times'' in five years. [ D1. ] Now that Union Carbide has agreed to pay $470 million to settle claims arising from the toxic gas leak at Bhopal, India, attention has shifted to disbursing the money to the victims. [ D6. ] Chemical industry executives say the Bhopal disaster has resulted in profound changes in safety procedures. [ D6. ] COMPANIES A.T.&T. plans to cut long-distance rates an average of 1.6 percent on April 1. The reduction, if approved by the Government, would save customers more than $533 million a year. [ D1. ] The Federal Reserve rejected an application by the Continental Bank to acquire Grand Canyon State Bank of Scottsdale, Ariz. [ D15. ] Intel's semiconductor designers are developing a million-transistor microprocessor that integrates many functions. [ D5. ] Microsoft said it would make a minority investment in the Santa Cruz Operation, which produces Unix system software. [ D5. ] News Corporation said profits rose 76.7 percent in the second-fiscal quarter and 55 percent in the six-month period. [ D21. ] MARKETS Morgan Stanley is resuming the use of stock-index arbitrage in managing its own capital. The firm said it would refrain from using the strategy during periods of ''market stress.'' Kidder, Peabody said it would soon decide whether to reinstate the strategy. [ D1. ] For the first time in a decade, the U.S. imported more oil in January than it produced, an industry group said. Partly in response to the news, oil prices rose sharply on the New York Mercantile Exchange. [ D1. ] The stock market pulled out of its recent doldrums, and the Dow Jones industrial average jumped 22.68 points, closing at 2,303.93. It was the Dow's first gain in six sessions. [ D8. ] Treasury note and bond prices rose on the expectation that West Germany might raise interest rates and that the Fed would follow. [ D16. ] Yields on C.D.'s and bank money market accounts rose in the recent week. [ D13. ] The dollar closed with minor losses on expectations of higher interest rates abroad. [ D18. ] Soybean futures advanced modestly after rising strongly on Tuesday, while cattle and pork futures were off slightly. [ D18. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Financiers are learning to reduce their risk in corporate takeovers by protecting themselves against rising interest rates with rate caps, swaps and other hedges. Talking Deals. [ D2. ] When a closed-end fund becomes open-ended, it does not necessarily mean that others will follow. Market Place. [ D8. ] Bauer Group has a new publication. First for Women, a monthly, made its debut two and a half weeks ago. Advertising. [ D21. ]

title: U.S. and Britain Call for Stricter Aviation Security
description: The United States and Britain proposed a worldwide tightening of aviation security rules today at a special meeting of the United Nations aviation organization.

title: How to Use a Dowel to Repair a Break
description: LEAD: The dowel - a peg or pin of hardwood - is a somewhat late development in furniture making; it replaced the traditional mortise and tenon joint in the early 19th century. The presence of dowels often determines whether a piece of furniture that appears to be from the 18th century is in fact a Victorian reproduction.

title: Programs Resumed at Key Firm
description: Morgan Stanley & Company, the Wall Street firm that spurred four of its competitors to suspend program trading for their own accounts last year, said yesterday that it was resuming the controversial practice.

title: Oh, Say Can You Hear. . .?
description: A giant American flag may fly over Long Beach, but only if it does so quietly. The Long Beach City Council voted Tuesday night to allow Thomas Demski to fly the flag from his 125-foot flagpole, a local landmark, as long as it does not violate the city's antinoise ordinance. Neighbors had complained that the flapping of the flag on windy nights kept them awake.

title: Review/Music; A 15th-Century Rarity
description: Jacob Obrecht was born in Holland sometime within hailing distance of 1450, entered the priesthood, spent his life neglecting administrative duties and composing wonderful, imaginative music, and died of the plague in Ferrara in 1505. It is hard to know just how much he wrote and when, since biographical information is sparse; he did not achieve the fame and influence of his near-contemporary Josquin Desprez. The entry for Obrecht in the New Grove Dictionary of Music runs to nine pages, almost twice the space devoted to Leoncavallo and Mascagni put together, but one hardly ever hears his music in New York concerts (is it done in the churches?). So the Sine Nomine Singers' performance of the Missa Salve Diva Parens at Merkin Concert Hall Saturday evening was a welcome event.

title: Atlanta Is Taking Long Shot at Games
description: Atlanta may have given the world Martin Luther King Jr., Jimmy Carter and Coca-Cola, but to members of the International Olympic Committee considering the city's bid to be host of the 1996 Summer Olympics, Atlanta is just a dot on the map.

title: Wells American Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Little-Noticed Tax Change Revives New York-New Jersey Border War
description: A change that was slipped into New York's tax code revision of two years ago and recently revealed will cost out-of-state commuters who work in New York State an estimated $50 million this year, state officials said today.

title: Rate Cut Is Proposed By A.T.&T.
description: Continuing a trend toward lower long-distance prices, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it plans to cut its rates an average of 1.6 percent on April 1.

title: Review/Music; Beethoven, Vehemently
description: The New Hampshire ensemble known as the Apple Hill Chamber Players carries off the prize for most wholesome-sounding musical appellation, but its merits do not stop there. The group's concerts are distinguished by not only high professionalism but also an unspoiled enthusiasm for music. Such eagerness to search for the expressive heart of a score can lift a performance out of the bog of routine concert-giving, reminding one of the playing of the better class of amateurs - a word that in its uncorrupted sense merely meant a lover.

title: Yields Post Modest Rise
description: Yields for certificates of deposit and bank money market accounts rose modestly for the week ended yesterday, bolstered by last week's increase in the prime lending rate to 11 percent from 10 1/2 percent and by a Federal funds rate that is well above 9 percent.

title: Report From Chernobyl Area Describes Deformed Animals
description: A soaring rate of deformed animal births on a farm more than 30 miles from Chernobyl has created fears about lasting damage from the 1986 nuclear accident, Moscow News said today.

title: Rock Hudson's Lover Wins Suit
description: A jury awarded $14.5 million to the former lover of Rock Hudson today, saying the actor's conduct in concealing his AIDS from his sex partner was ''outrageous.''

title: Linking Environment and Competitiveness; Let It Snow
description: To the Editor:

title: Afghan Turmoil: Wars and Coups of 2 Centuries
description: 1839-42 British Indian forces, fearing a Russian thrust into India, occupy Afghanistan. Guerrilla wars break out and eventually prompt a British retreat. Guerrillas turn the retreat into a massacre. 1878-80 Second British-Afghan war erupts, again because of British worries about Russian intentions. 1880-1901 Rule of Abd ar-Rahman brings peace and strong central authority. 1901-19 Abd ar-Rahman's son, Habibullah, upholds his father's absolute rule and keeps the country out of World War I. 1919-29 After Habibullah's assassination, his son Amanullah seizes the throne. A third military confrontation with the British ensues; it is inconclusive. An uprising by tribal chiefs forces Amanullah into exile. 1929-33 A tribal assembly elects Nadir Khan as ruler. He rebuilds the army and establishes a legislature. The accession of his branch of the family over Amanullah's divides the Afghan elite; he is assassinated. 1933-53 Nadir Khan is succeeded by his son, Zahir Shah, who continues his policies and remains neutral in World War II. But real power begins to shift to other members of the royal family, in particular those who serve as Prime Minister. 1953 With Zahir still the nominal leader, Lieut. Gen. Mohammad Daud, the King's cousin and brother-in-law, becomes Prime Minister and pursues modernization with increasing ruthlessness. 1956 Afghanistan starts a five-year plan for better roads and communications, to be financed with American and Soviet aid. 1963 Prime Minister Daud resigns and is succeeded by the first government chief not of royal blood, Dr. Mohammad Yousuf. He repairs relations with Pakistan and embarks on more liberal policies, including the introduction of women's suffrage. 1965 Student riots and factional fights in Parliament force the Government to resign. The radical left gains strength. July 1973 A coup ends the 40-year reign of Zahir Shah, who goes into exile in Rome. The coup leader, General Daud, proclaims a republic but rules in an authoritarian fashion. April 1978 President Daud is killed in a coup. The People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan forms a pro-Soviet Government led by Noor Mohammed Taraki. September 1979 Mr. Taraki is killed and his former Deputy Prime Minister, Hafizullah Amin, takes over. December 1979 The Soviet Union begins wide-scale intervention in support of the Afghan Government, sending the first of more than 100,000 troops to fight Muslim guerrillas. Mr. Amin is killed and is replaced by Mr. Taraki's Vice President, Babrak Karmal, who returns from exile in Moscow. June 1982 Indirect talks between Afghanistan and Pakistan, the base for most guerrilla groups, begin in Geneva under United Nations sponsorship. Feb. 8, 1986 Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the new Soviet leader, says withdrawal will come ''in the nearest future.'' May 4, 1986 Mr. Karmal resigns and is replaced by Najibullah, former head of the secret police. Jan. 1, 1987 Moscow and Kabul announce a cease-fire plan and call for negotiations, but the guerrillas fight on. April 14, 1988 Accords providing for Soviet withdrawal are signed in Geneva. Feb. 15, 1989 The Soviet Union completes its withdrawal from Afghanistan.

title: Memorial Service in Beijing For Panchen Lama of Tibet
description: Communist leaders mourned the Panchen Lama as a great Chinese patriot at a mass memorial service for the Tibetan Buddhist leader today.

title: Parents Try to Avert Los Angeles Teacher Strike
description: As Los Angeles teachers vote this week on whether to strike in June, parents here are organizing to push for an end to the long and bitter contract negotiations in the nation's second-largest school district.

description: By reading T-shirts on this remote West African island, a casual visitor detects a common theme: Brown University, The Christian Science Monitor, Belchertown Fire Department and ''Green Stuff - Boston Celtics.''

description: The Carlyle Group said that it had offered to buy certain business segments of Fairchild Industries but that Fairchild executives had expressed no interest in the proposal and had declined to meet with representatives of the Washington-based investment firm. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Carlyle said it ''is continuing to review all of its available alternatives with respect to its shares'' in the Chantilly, Va., electronics concern.

description: The Second New York International Festival of the Arts will be staged in June 1991 rather than in 1990 as originally planned, and will be the showcase for foreign arts companies who have never before performed in New York or who have infrequently appeared here.

title: Clemens and Red Sox Agree On 3-Year, $7.5 Million Deal
description: The Boston Red Sox and Roger Clemens, their two-time Cy Young Award winner, escalated baseball's salary scale another major notch yesterday, agreeing to a three-year, $7.5 million contract. Then they stepped back and waited to see if the Los Angeles Dodgers and Orel Hershiser would escalate it even further before their scheduled salary arbitration hearing today.

title: For Vietnamese Children, Gift of a Smile
description: A group of American doctors and nurses left for Vietnam today on a mission known as Operation Smile. Their objective is to perform plastic surgery on about 100 children whose deformities prevent them from smiling.

Violating both the promise and the fairness of that landmark law, he seeks to revive favorable tax treatment for capital gains. That might spur investment, a little. More certainly it would benefit the rich, a lot.

title: U.S. Notes and Bonds Inch Higher

description: A Manhattan man convicted of killing another man with a karate-like kick has been released on bail because his lawyer says new evidence suggests that the defendant acted in self-defense. But the prosecutor who handled the case said yesterday that the new information was a misrepresentation of a conversation between the defense lawyer and a police detective.

description: Terrorists killed at least 49 people and the police killed 7 today during the first legislative elections in 11 years, the authorities reported.

description: Becton Dickinson & Company, a maker of medical supplies and diagnostic equipment, said yesterday that it had named Raymond V. Gilmartin, its president, to the additional post of chief executive.

description: A year after Mayor Edward I. Koch pledged a sweeping reorganization of the New York City Human Rights Commission to better handle complaints of discrimination, the agency remains plagued by problems and has fallen far short of its own goals for finishing investigations.

This week Mr. Bush took to the road to sell his proposals to the public.

title: A Musician Studies the Past's Realities
description: ''You know, there's a lot of talk about authenticity these days, and I think it's nonsense,'' said Albert Fuller, the harpsichordist and director of the Helicon Ensemble. Mr. Fuller and his group have been presenting an early-music festival at Weill Recital Hall since Wednesday, with the final concerts scheduled for this weekend. ''The authenticity I'm interested in is our contemporary sense of the reality of the past, and what the music we have inherited has to do with us today. I believe that music is a window into the unconscious, and the miracle of it is that it lets us get close to what Beethoven, Bach and Mozart were thinking.

title: Australia Trade Deficit
description: Australia's current account deficit, the broadest measure of trade, jumped 65 percent, to $1.54 billion (Australian), or $1.31 billion (United States), in January from the previous month, the Government said today. It was the worst January deficit on record and was sharply higher than the shortfall of $543 million (Australian) a year earlier.

title: Kemp Asks Savings Tie To Housing Aid for Poor
description: Jack F. Kemp, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, proposed today that Federal aid to the savings industry be conditioned on a commitment to finance inner-city housing.

title: As Credit Comes Easily, More Car Buyers Default
description: Easy credit, including longer repayment periods, has led to a sharp increase in defaults on auto loans, the two biggest American car makers say.

title: Zenith Electronics Shares Jump 6.8%
description: The Zenith Electronics Corporation's stock rose 6.8 percent today on positive reaction to the company's expanding television picture-tube business and forecasts that it had broken a string of losing years, analysts said. Shares of Zenith, based in Glenview, Ill., the last significant American television maker, rose $1.375, to $21.50. It was the eighth-most-active issue on the New York Stock Exchange, with a volume of more than two million shares.

title: BRITISH CONCLUDE CASSETTE PLAYER HELD PAN AM BOMB

title: Review/Film; Exploring A World In a Mind
description: Films about the unconscious ought to make more sense than films about more sensible things. They need an internal logic to take the place of the external logic that's missing. But ''Paperhouse,'' which opens today at the Carnegie Hall Cinema, has a scheme that doesn't go much beyond the visual, perhaps because its director, Bernard Rose, has had previous experience making rock videos. ''Paperhouse'' works less as a psychological thriller than as a ghost story, but it shies away from any real depth or from the heart-stopping ending that might have made it memorable.

title: Choice Seen for Harvard Post
description: Harvard University is expected to name Robert C. Clark, a profesor on its law faculty, as the new law school dean, according to The Harvard Crimson, the student newspaper, and several students at the law school. The announcement by Harvard's president, Derek C. Bok, could come as early as Friday. Mr. Clark would replace James Vorenberg, who said last April that he would resign at the end of the 1988-89 academic year.

title: Biscayne Holdings Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $904,000 and $3,051,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; a gain of $6,561,000 on the sale of discontinued operations for both the quarter and year, and tax credits of $2,343,000 for the quarter and $4,351,000 for the year. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $253,000 for the quarter and $2,041,000 for the year, and tax credits of $440,000 and $2,558,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Intellicall Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TV Weekend; Spoofing Home-Screen Evangelism
description: Home Box Office deserves points for tackling television evangelists, a subject that generally induces pronounced skittishness among entertainment executives at the commercial networks. ''Glory! Glory!,'' a three-and-a-half-hour musical comedy being presented in two parts - Sunday and Monday at 9 P.M. on the cable channel -goes behind the scenes of the fictional Church of the Companions of Christ to put the squeeze on a juicy collection of frauds.

title: Dewey Electronics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $42,600 and $74,600 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Officers Waiting Longer in Courthouses, Union Says
description: Police officers are spending longer hours waiting in courthouses because of a sharp rise in drug-related arrests in New York City and limited space in prosecutors' offices, officials said yesterday. The problems have slowed the early processing of all kinds of criminal cases.

title: 2 Afghan Cities Under Rebel Fire; Guerrillas' Council Studies Plan
description: Afghan guerrillas fired rockets into two Afghan cities, killing at least 12 people, radio and Afghan Foreign Ministry reports said today.

title: Don't Impose a Sales Tax on Cable TV Bills
description: To the Editor:

title: Hilb, Rogal & Hamilton reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results for both quarters have been restated to reflect a recent pooling of interests merger and a 10 percent stock dividend. The results for both years have been restated.

title: Switzer Goes on Defense Against Rush of Problems
description: Barry Switzer, who has weathered numerous storms during his 16-year career as the football coach at Oklahoma, has admittedly never faced anything as threatening as now.

title: Review/Art; Works From Nature
description: The sculpture of Robert Lobe needs the kind of space it has been given by the Blum Helman Gallery and the Blum Helman Warehouse. In previous gallery shows, there have been questions about the range, versatility and possible academicism of work in which sheets of anodized aluminum are fitted around trees, earth and stone and then hammered into shape. This show does not answer all the questions, but it leaves no doubt about the seriousness and poignancy of Mr. Lobe's artistic enterprise.

title: F.W. Harder, 85, Former Investment Banker
description: F. William Harder, a retired investment banker, died Wednesday at the Miami Heart Institute in Miami Beach. He was 84 years old and lived in Bal Harbour, Fla.

title: Now, Who Will Speak for Rushdie?
description: In a few days, I was to have introduced Salman Rushdie to an audience in Berkeley, Calif.

title: Golden Valley Microwave Foods reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Islanders Avoid a Big Sweep
description: If there is a precedent that can be set by the Islanders' 7-3 victory tonight against the St. Louis Blues, Jeff Norton thinks the Islanders ought to take the revenge motif that fueled it and apply it for the remainder of their season.

title: Nynex Vice Chairman Is Named to Top Posts
description: The Nynex Corporation, one of the most profitable of the companies that became independent after the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, said yesterday that William C. Ferguson had been named to its top posts.

title: Prudential-Bache Shift Called Wall St. Signal
description: For W. James Tozer, the newly named president and chief operating officer of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., the appointment signals the changing face of Wall Street.

title: Tours of Brooklyn
description: Singer's Brooklyn is to give minibus tours of of Brooklyn tomorrow and on subsequent Saturdays through the end of March. Each tour is to emphasize a different aspect of the borough. On Sundays the group gives tours of Manhattan. Each tour is from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. and leaves from a midtown Manhattan location. Tickets are $25. Reservations required: (718) 875-9084, from 7 to 11 P.M.

title: Cigna Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included investment gains of $7.2 million and $7.8 million for the quarter and year, respectively, and income from discontinued operations of $12.5 million for the quarter and $54.2 million for the year. c-After an investment loss of $34.1 million for the quarter and an investment gain of $34.4 million for the year; income from discontinued operations of $13.9 million and $56.4 million for the quarter and year, respectively, and a charge of $20.9 million on a reversal of a tax loss carryforward for the quarter and a gain of $13 million from tax loss carryforwards for the year, and the year also included a loss of $3.8 million from early extinguishment of debt.

title: Ex-Official Defends Role on Eastern
description: Former Transportation Secretary Jim Burnley said Wednesday that an ethics official allowed him to rule in a case involving Eastern Airlines even though he was negotiating at the time for jobs with law firms linked to the company.

description: Composers Concordance is to present a concert of recent works by Patrick Hardish, Wendy Chambers, Awilda Villarini, Joseph Pehrson, Beth Anderson, Louis Karchin and James T. Anderson at 8 tonight at CAMI Hall, 165 West 57th Street. The performers are to include Rolf Schulte, a violinist; Alicia O;Malley, a guitarist; Douglas Schultz, a pianist, and Annabel Gordon, a cellist. Tickets are $6. Information: 564-4899.

title: Review/Theater; The Real Lowdown From an Old Friend
description: It's commonplace to watch star actresses impersonate forlorn working-class women - they almost always win awards for it - but Willy Russell's one-woman play ''Shirley Valentine'' takes the truly brave risk of asking an audience to spend an evening with a performer who is unmistakably as unglamorous as her humble role.

description: b-Included a loss of $1,341,000 on early extinguishment of debt. c-Net loss

Kollmorgen Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: 1988 included net income equal to 25 cents a share as a result of a paid-up patent license with Hitachi Chemical Co.

School's Turnabout: 328th to 9th in Reading
description: Sheldon Ofodile, a 9-year-old pupil at Public School 153 in the Bronx, has an hour set aside each night to read a story or novel. ''My mother,'' he said by way of explanation. ''It's a rule.''

title: House Speaker Delays Vote On Foreign Investor Rules
description: Bowing to protest from the White House and from House members of both parties, Speaker Jim Wright today postponed a vote he planned for next week on legislation that would require foreigners to disclose most major investments in the United States.

title: For Ghost Oil Town in Iran, Postwar Renewal Is Starting
description: This Iranian city facing Iraq across the Shatt-al-Arab was once a thriving port inhabited by 400,000. Today not even stray dogs or cats are to be seen.

title: 2 Groups Interested In G. C. Murphy
description: Four years after it acquired the G. C. Murphy Company for $200 million, Ames Department Stores Inc. is considering offers to sell the discount store chain. Ames's spokeswoman, Catherine Leonard, said the Connecticut-based retailer was entertaining offers from a Murphy management group and the McCrory Corporation.

title: Seagull Energy Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Latest-year results included a $9.9 million pretax, non-cash valuation allowance taken in the first quarter due to lower natural prices and three unsuccessful exploratory wells. Without the allowance, Seagull said its 1988 net income would have been equal to $1.03 a share.

title: 3 Days of Washingtonia
description: Step back into the world of George Washington, 200 years ago before he took the oath of office as the first President of the United States, courtesy of the Washington Headquarters State Historic Site in Newburgh, N.Y.

title: Sri Lanka's Ruling Party Wins
description: President Ranasinghe Premadasa's United National Party won a decisive majority in Parliament after an election campaign in which more than 1,000 people were killed, according to results announced today.

title: CALIFORNIA SHAKEN OVER AN INFORMER
description: In the seamy world of jailhouse informers, treachery has long been their credo and favors from jailers their reward. Now lawyers and prosecutors must ponder whether fiction was often their method.

title: Savannah Foods & Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago share data was restated to reflect a 100-percent stock dividend to be paid April 1. The company attributed the increase in fourth quarter and 1988 net income to improved earnings in its cane sugar operation.

title: Polish Report Blames Russians for Katyn Massacre
description: Poland's official press has for the first time published evidence that the Soviet Union, not Nazi Germany, carried out a World War II massacre of Polish Army officers in the Katyn Forest.

title: Coors, Adolph Corp reports earnings for 12wks to Dec 25
description: The company net income for 1988 was impacted by aggressive marketing and advertising expenditures in the beer business, and research and new product development costs in all the company's businesses.

title: 6th Officer Indicted in Tompkins Sq. Melee
description: A New York City police sergeant was indicted yesterday for assault, making him the sixth officer to be charged with misconduct and assault arising from the disturbance in Tompkins Square Park in August, the Manhattan District Attorney said.

title: Review/Recital; Portuguese Pianist in Debut
description: The Portuguese pianist Maria Joao Pires is known to many in this country through her many recordings on the Erato label, and she has performed with the New York Philharmonic. But she had not played a solo recital in New York until Tuesday evening, when she made her belated debut at Carnegie Hall.

title: Rawson-Koenig Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $143,000 tax credit.

title: The Great Outdoors, Within City Limits
description: UNTIL spring, most New Yorkers would probably prefer to forget that there even is an outdoors, a place where chill winds nip mercilessly at bundled-up strollers. But for hardy urban explorers, New York is more than just an agglomeration of warm buildings. About one-seventh of the city's 303.7 square miles is parkland, and in it one can hike and ice-skate, savor the stark beauty of wintertime nature or just listen to the quiet.

title: Cahners Sets Reorganization
description: Cahners Publishing, the United States publishing division of Reed International, which has been aggressively expanding its trade magazine operations, said yesterday that it was reorganizing its operations.

title: Taxpayer Cost of Bailouts Put at $80 Billion
description: The Bush plan to bail out the savings and loan industry will cost the taxpayer $80 billion during the next 10 years, at least $20 billion more than projected by the White House, according to a report by the Congressional Budget Office that is scheduled to be released on Friday.

title: Longview Fibre Co reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31

description: The merger of Church's Fried Chicken Inc. and Popeye's Famous Fried Chicken and Biscuits will create a company that is solidly No. 2 in the industry, but still only about a third of the size of the leader, the Kentucky Fried Chicken Corporation.

description: Fairchild Industries said it had approved amendments to its bylaws, which would make it more difficult for its spurned suitor, the Carlyle Group, to seek board representation. Under the amendments, approved by Fairchild's board on Wednesday, a special stockholders meeting can be called only by the Fairchild board.

title: BRITAIN PUTS TIES WITH IRAN ON HOLD
description: The British Government protested today to Iran in the ''strongest terms'' over Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's death threat against the novelist Salman Rushdie and announced that recent moves toward establishing closer relations with Iran would be shelved.

title: Koch Suggests Linking Zoning-Law Penalties to 'Ill-Gotten Gains'
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch, whose administration has been criticized for dealing too lightly with zoning violations, announced yesterday that New York City would seek severe economic penalties tied directly to ''ill-gotten gains'' when it took zoning violators to court.

title: The 'Untouchable' in the Wall Street Firm: Of Incongruities Are Partnerships Made
description: In this Valentine's Week, White & Case loves Rudolph Giuliani. In announcing that the former prosecutor had joined its ranks, the firm described him with terms like ''successful,'' ''vigorous,'' ''fearless,'' ''energetic,'' ''effective.''

title: TOSHIBA SUPPLIED A LIBYAN FACTORY
description: The Toshiba Corporation says that in late 1985 it provided electrical equipment for a plant in Libya now suspected by the United States to be producing containers and shells for chemical weapons.

description: Joe Barry Carroll, the Nets' starting center, will miss the game tonight at Philadelphia because of a sprained left ankle. Carroll is also doubtful for tomorrow night's game against the Knicks at Madison Square Garden. Roy Hinson will replace Carroll in the starting lineup.

Bush Dismisses Speculation On Conflict With Greenspan
description: Although the Federal Reserve has been nudging up interest rates to fight inflation, President Bush today sought to put to rest speculation that he and the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, are at odds over the issue or that they are headed for another of the Administration/Fed confrontations that exploded periodically in the Reagan years.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 454 money market mutual funds increased by $1.46 billion, to $289.01 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Those of the 137 institutional funds decreased by $851.20 million, to $73.39 billion. The assets of the 224 general-purpose funds were up by $1.42 billion, to $92.30 billion. The 93 broker-dealer funds increased by $883.9 million, to $123.33 billion, the institute said.

title: Trouble at a Reactor? Call In an Admiral
description: At troubled civilian nuclear reactors these days, the newest, most sophisticated and most coveted improvement is likely to be a former admiral, fresh from the ranks of the Navy's submarine program.

title: Genentech Drive To Lift TPA Sales
description: To spur sales of its heart attack drug, tissue plasminogen activator, Genentech Inc. has enlisted the help of the American sales force of Boehringer Ingelheim Pharmaceuticals Inc. of Ridgefield, Conn. The 400-member staff will spend about a fifth of its time promoting TPA to physicians who operate in offices and are not cardiologists.

title: Market Place; A Highflier of '88 Is Lagging in '89
description: THERE are few things nicer in life than a monopoly in a rapidly growing market, which is the main reason that Wall Street fell in love with Adobe Systems Inc., a Silicon Valley company whose principal product is an integral part of desktop publishing systems.

title: Tyson Referee Named
description: The referee Richard Steele was named yesterday to work Mike Tyson's heavyweight title defense against Britain's Frank Bruno in Las Vegas Feb. 25. The judges for the fight will be Jerry Roth of Las Vegas, Nev., Omar Minton of Mexico and Rodolfo Maldonado of Panama.(AP)

title: Dining Out Guide: Gramercy Park Area
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have stars. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. Brandywine ** (July 29, 1988), 274 Third Avenue, near 21st Street (353-8190) - Dedicated beef lovers who prefer their steakhouses less clamorous than the norm may appreciate this warm, neighborly restaurant with equestrian artwork hung on dark cherrywood walls. At lunch, the menu offers main-course salads (grilled quail with arugula and straw potatoes, for example) and lighter cuts of beef. Recommended appetizers include broiled shrimp with garlic butter and herbs, and house salads. Porterhouses, T-bones and filet mignon are cooked precisely to order. In addition, there are veal chops, lamb chops with roasted garlic cloves and grilled fish. Home fries and sublime mashed potatoes are not-to-be-missed side dishes. Appetizers are $5 to $9, entrees $16 to $28. Open 11:30 A.M. to 3 P.M. Friday and 5 to 11 P.M Friday and Saturday. Closed Sunday. Friend of a Farmer Diner's Journal (July 11, 1986), 77 Irving Place (477-2188) - The husband and wife owners have created a country-kitchen atmosphere in which to have their homespun cooking. Lunch and weekend brunch feature homemade breads, buckwheat pancakes, salad sandwiches and brown-egg omelets served in individual cast-iron pans. The restaurant recently began serving dinner with such straighforward American dishes as chicken pot pie, grilled fish and vegetarian plates. (No liquor license, but patrons may bring their own wine.) Brunch is $6 to $8; dinner entrees are $8.95 to $14.95. Open 11 A.M. to 10 P.M. Friday and 10 A.M. to 3:30 P.M. Saturday and Sunday. La Colombe d'Or *** (Sept. 16, 1988) 134 East 26th Street (689-0666) - The charm of French Provincial design is inspiration for La Colombe d'Or's inviting terra cotta and brick dining room. Among the appetizers are house-smoked salmon salad and grilled quail with goat cheese and noodle frittata. Two typical Provencal entrees that are recommended are poached fresh cod over fennel and arugula with a potent aioli sauce, and salmon glazed with mustard and olive oil and served with a butter-and-chive sauce. Grilled chicken with red wine, olives and rosemary is another choice; the house specialty is bouillabaisse. Appetizers are $4.50 to $12, entrees $16 to $25. Open 6 to 11 P.M. Friday and Saturday. Closed Sunday. Pesca * (Nov. 21, 1986), 23 East 22d Street (533-2293) - Patrons dine in the warm light cast by the glazed salmon-pink walls of this elegant seafood cafe. Seascapes and other nautical art are the decorations. The kitchen has a flair for risotto (shrimp and primavera are two from the current menu). Other good choices are the mixed seafood chowder with salmon and shellfish, and San Francisco-style cioppino, an Italian fish stew. New to the menu are carpaccio of tuna and sauteed trout almondine. Appetizers are $4.95 to $9, pastas and risottos $16 to $18.50, entrees $19.95 to $25. Open 6 to 11 P.M. Friday and Saturday, until 10 P.M. Sunday. Positano ** (Jan. 25, 1985), 250 Park Avenue South, at 20th Street (777-6211) -Housed in a lofty neo-Gothic building, Positano is an informally chic restaurant painted pink and white. The cuisine is related to that of the Campania region of Italy's Amalfi coast. A variety of salad plates are colorful and refreshing with well-balanced vinaigrettes. Most of the pastas are superior. Sauteed baby squid with garlic, olive oil and parsley is recommended, as are the grilled red snapper and, when it is available, osso buco. Appetizers are $8 to $10, pastas $14 to $16, entrees $18 to $26. Open noon to 3 P.M. Friday and 5:30 P.M. to 12:30 A.M. Friday and Saturday. Closed Sunday. What the stars mean, page C28.

title: Reviews/Art; Wheeling Through the Dealers' Festive Show
description: ''The Art Show,'' at the Seventh Regiment Armory, is a consistently engaging and discreetly provocative affair. It serves a very good cause -that of the Henry Street Settlement -and, with the lightest possible touch, it makes history. Art dealing is essentially an independent and often secretive affair, and to get 57 members of the Art Dealers Association of America to march arm in arm is an undertaking that would have taxed Talleyrand.

title: PENTAGON WORKING ON A NEW MISSILE FOR WEST GERMANY
description: The Pentagon has taken the first steps toward developing a new short-range nuclear missile despite West German reservations about the project, Administration officials say.

description: Moving to Movies

title: Ford Motor Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Effective Dec. 31, 1988, the company adopted Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 94, ''Consolidation of All Majority-owned Subsidiaries.'' As required under this standard, the company's financial services and real estate subsidiaries, previously accounted for by the equity method, now are accounted for as consoldiated subsidiaries. The company also adopted in 1988 Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 95, ''Statement of Cash Flows.'' Starting with 1988 year-end results, the company's consoldiated financial statements will be shown in a new format that provides details on the assets, liabilities, operating results and cash flows for the company's two major business segments- -automotive and financial services. Vehicle manufacturing and sales comprise more than 90 percent of the automotive segment; this segment also included the company's agricultural equipment and its aerospace and communications operations. Prior years' financial statements have been restated to conform with the 1988 presentations adopted under the new accounting standards. The restatements had no effect on previously reported net income or stockholders' equity.

title: Siena Wins In Isolation
description: In a game that was closed to spectators tonight, Jeff Robinson had 21 points, 8 rebounds and 6 blocked shots to lead Siena to a 76-49 victory over Maine in a North Atlantic Conference game.

title: Ex-Player Still Jailed

Richard, 36, of Quebec City, was arrested by Canada Customs officers at Mirabel airport Monday and charged with importing about $1.8 million worth of cocaine in a golf bag.(AP)

title: Please Press 2 for Service; Press ? for an Actual Human

description: A separatist Christian group in Valley Stream obtained a temporary court order today exempting its members' children from receiving state-mandated AIDS education in high school.

title: Lincoln Center Plans Videocassette Sales
description: Lincoln Center is planning the commercial release of videocassettes of nine programs from the ''Live From Lincoln Center'' television series. The first three, to be made available in late April, are Natalia Makarova and Mikhail Baryshnikov dancing in ''Giselle,'' Beverly Sills in a New York City Opera production of ''The Barber of Seville,'' and Danny Kaye with the New York Philharmonic.

title: Cecilia Lester Sarasohn, Guidance Director, 79
description: Cecilia Lester Sarasohn, a former deputy director of guidance for the New York City Board of Education who directed college preparatory programs, died of complications from leukemia on Wednesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 79 years old.

title: George W. Denton, 64, Insurance Executive
description: George W. Denton, chairman of the National Pension Service and the Denton Hyman insurance agency of White Plains, died of complications Tuesday after heart surgery at the Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 64 years old and lived in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: Hormel, Geo A reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28

description: Unseasonably warm weather helped push construction starts on new housing up 8 percent in January, to an annual rate of 1.69 million units, the highest monthly level in nearly two years, the Commerce Department reported yesterday.

title: U.S. Bars German Air Shows
