description: College hockey, like the professional side of the sport, puts such emphasis on the year-end tournaments that the signficance of regular-season games can be questioned.

title: Chicago Journal; Daley's Ward Is Eager To Taste Power Again
description: The Bridgeport neighborhood, with its modest bungalows, discount stores and shot-and-a-beer taverns, is an unlikely setting for a throne. But for more than 30 years, this hard-nosed ward on the near South Side was, indeed, the seat of power in Chicago.

title: N.F.L. Assistant Coaches Now Victims of the Sack
description: There used to be an axiom in the National Football League: if the team did badly, dismiss the head coach. Now, the head coach remains and the assistants go.

title: Jersey Police Fetch Suspect In Murder-Kidnapping Case
description: Police investigators returned Michael R. Ardila to New Jersey early this morning from New Mexico to face charges of fatally stabbing one Sparta, N.J., teen-ager and forcing a second to flee with him on a three-day, cross-country drive.

title: Review/Film; Plain Jane, Her Perils And Pathos
description: Rachel River, a fictional town in northern Minnesota, has a run-down cafe, a hardware store and a Ford dealership lined up along its deserted main street. So you can only hope this slice-of-life film turns out to be less earnest, picturesque and predictable than its setting and opening scenes suggest. At the start, Momo - there is no other term for him; he is the village idiot - discovers the body of an old woman, named Svea, who has died alone in her shack. From then until Svea's funeral, we ramble through the lives of the townspeople.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday FILMS BY DREYER

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Birthday Present: John McEnroe, seeded third, celebrated his 30th birthday yesterday with a 6-2, 6-3 victory over Michiel Schapers of the Netherlands and reached the quarterfinals of the $492,500 Stella Artois indoor championships in Milan, Italy. McEnroe received applause from the crowd and a cake with 30 candles from the organizers. ''I feel good, not old,'' he said. ''I am happy with what I have done.'' Top-seeded Boris Becker of West Germany displayed fine volleys, passing and drop shots as he beat Guy Forget of France, 6-3, 7-6. (AP) Maleeva Advances: Manuela Maleeva of Bulgaria came alive in the third set to beat Ann Henricksson yesterday in Fairfax, Va., and move into the quarterfinals of the $300,000 Virginia Slims of Washington. Maleeva, ranked No. 7 in the world, allowed only 4 points in five service games in the final set en route to a 6-4, 4-6, 6-3 victory. Zina Garrison joined Maleeva in the round of eight by eliminating Mary Lou Daniels, 6-2, 6-0. Garrison will face Gigi Fernandez, who needed only 54 minutes to score a 6-2, 6-0 victory over Dinky Van Rensburg of South Africa. (AP) GOLF Trio in Lead:Frank Conner, Mark Lye and David Peoples all shot 7-under par 65s yesterday to share the first-round lead of the $700,000 San Diego Open at Torrey Pines. One stroke behind the co-leaders at 66 were Bob Tway, Dave Barr and Dennis Trixler. Peoples, who has never finished higher than eighth place in five years on the PGA Tour, had birdies on six of the first nine holes, with four of his putts coming from at least 20 feet. He also birdied the 14th hole from six feet. Conner, another nonwinner on the tour, had five birdies and one bogey through nine holes. He birdied the second through fourth holes on his back nine.(AP) N.H.L. Candadiens 7, Flyers 4: Shayne Corson scored twice as Montreal earned its first victory at the Spectrum in five years. The Canadiens had lost four and tied two since last winning at the Spectrum Sept. 16, 1984. The victory was the Canadiens' sixth in their last seven games, while the Flyers have lost six of eight. Corson's second score broke a 4-4 game with 1:01 left in the second period, beating the goaltender Ron Hextall to the stick side. Bobby Smith and Brian Skrudland made it 7-4 with goals 1:02 apart in the third period. Russ Courtnall opened the scoring, beating Hextall from the right faceoff circle at 3:41. Ron Sutter tied the score on a power play, but Montreal took a 3-1 lead when Corson and Ryan Walter scored 1:50 apart.(AP) N.B.A. Bulls 117, Bucks 116 Michael Jordan capped the 17th 50-point game of his career with a 20-foot shot with one second remaining to lift the Bulls at Chicago Stadium. Jordan, who tied Elgin Baylor for second place behind Wilt Chamberlain's 118 50-point games, had 27 in the final quarter. (AP) Jazz 129, Celtics 114: Karl Malone scored 36 points, 23 in the second half, as the Jazz snapped the Celtics' four-game winning streak against Utah. The Celtics, who have lost the first two games of their six-game road trip, are 21-21 without Larry Bird. (AP) Mavericks 93, Heat 80: James Donaldson pulled down a career-high 22 rebounds while scoring 16 points to power Dallas at Reunion Hall.(AP) HORSE RACING Pop John Wins: Pop John made a successful jump from claiming to allowance company by scoring a one-length upset victory in the feature race yesterday at Aqueduct. Pop John, ridden by Diane Nelson and carrying 115 pounds, led throughout in scoring his second victory in four starts this year. Sunrise Shower, under Herb McCauley, finished second in the field of seven, two lengths ahead of Winter Drive. Pop John covered six furlongs in 1:10 1/5 and earned $21,600 for his owner-trainer, Gregory Martin. He returned $22.80, $8.40 and $4.60 for $2 across the board. Sunrise Shower paid $18 and $7.80, and Winter Drive returned $3.20 to show.(AP)

title: Our Towns; On a Rural Lane, 2 Friends Recall An Urban Savant
description: Four times a year, W. H. Ferry drives to see his friends in the country, the Mumfords. Mr. Ferry has long admired Lewis Mumford's classic writings on architecture and cities. The two began corresponding 25 years ago, after Mr. Ferry read a Mumford essay on the dangers of nuclear weaponry. ''The important thing to me about Lewis, beyond his vaulting passages, has always been the moral tone,'' Mr. Ferry said. He parked his Volkswagen on a country road by a small, old home, the sort that covers basic needs but not much more. On such visits, Mr. Ferry can't help thinking that the great minds of our time are paid nowhere near as well as the great anchormen of our time.

title: British Jobless Rate Dips
description: Unemployment in Britain fell to a seasonally adjusted 7 percent of the work force in January from 7.2 percent in December, bringing the number of jobless to its lowest level in eight years, the Government said today.

title: Bad News for Boggs
description: With the Roger Clemens contract negotiations behind them, the Boston Red Sox got the news they were dreading yesterday. Penthouse magazine announced that it would publish in its April and May issues the interview with Margo Adams, the woman with whom Wade Boggs has acknowledged having had an affair for four years. The April issue will be out March 2 and the May issue April 4.

title: 9 Jail Guards Are Arrested In Drug Case
description: Nine New York City correction officers have been arrested on charges of attempting to smuggle cocaine to inmates in New York City jails in an undercover investigation, officials said yesterday.

title: Krause to Be Honored
description: Edward H. (Moose) Krause, the athletic director at Notre Dame for 32 years until his retirement in 1980, has been named winner of the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame's Distinguished American Award for 1989 and will be honored Dec. 5 at the foundation's annual dinner in New York.

title: Opinion Shifting on Proposition 42
description: Less than 40 percent of the National Collegiate Athletic Association representatives now support Proposition 42, a survey by The Washington Post shows.

title: Review/Music; As Corelli Heard Corelli
description: Helicon is the Grecian mountain where the Nine Muses reside and from which they descend, never often enough, to inspire artists to works of greatness. Helicon is also the aptly optimistic name of Albert Fuller's early-music ensemble, which gave the first of four original-instrument concerts on Wednesday evening at Weill Recital Hall. Mr. Fuller, whose professional involvement with older music dates back to his Carnegie Hall debut in 1957, went on to found the Aston Magna Festival in 1972 and to impart his findings to students at Yale, Harvard, the Juilliard School and other centers of scholarship.

title: Review/Theater; Straightforward Corporate Raider
description: New England Wire and Cable, a solidly established but outmoded Rhode Island business, is ripe for a takeover. Here comes Lawrence Garfinkle, Larry the Liquidator, riding into town in his stretch limo and plotting to annihilate the company. Later, when Garfinkle (Kevin Conway) is about to assume control, he cuts up with a chorus of ''The Farmer and the Cowman'' from ''Oklahoma!'' The song reminds us that, for all its stock-market timeliness, Jerry Sterner's ''Other People's Money'' is a kind of Eastern western (the corporate raider is the carpetbagger) as well as board room melodrama.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: George Washington's birthday, actually Feb. 22, will be observed on Monday. Here are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only; main office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Banks: Option to close. Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation: No collections or street cleanings. Schools: Closed. Financial markets: Closed. Transportation: Subways and buses on Saturday schedules, Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North on holiday schedules. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Option to close. Schools: Option to close. Transportation: N.J. Transit on Saturday schedule, no service on the Pascack Valley and Boonton lines. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: New Haven line on holiday schedules.

Provisions for losses included $53 million of additional reserves related to its mortgage loan portfolio and those of its wholly- owned subsidiaries San Jacinto Savings Association and Southmark Life Group. The provision for losses on marketable securities was increased by $23 million to state the remaining portion of Southmark's securities portfolio at current market value. Other provisions for losses included reserves against miscellaneous receivables, real estate and other assets. Excluding provisions for losses and reserves, Southmark lost approximately $22 million from operations in the second quarter. The company said the loss in the second quarter is not sufficient to cause default on its unsecured indentured debt.

He was born in Scranton, Pa., and served in the Army Air Corps during World War II.

title: Thomas Bernhard Is Dead at 58; His Last Play Enraged Austrians

title: Music and Tales In Celebration Of Black History
description: In and near Manhattan, Black History Month is being celebrated with special activities. Here is a selection: Today COLLEGE OF STATEN ISLAND/CUNY, 120 Stuyvesant Place, Gallery 313, St. George campus (718-390-7948). The Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture's exhibition on black migration, ''Give Me Your Tired, Your Poor . . .? Voluntary Black Migration to the United States,'' through next Friday. 1 to 5 P.M. weekdays. Free. NEW YORK PUBLIC LIBRARY, Harlem Library, 9 West 124th Street (348-5620). Abiodun Oyewole, a poet and musician, is to present a program of stories, songs and poems about the struggles and successes of blacks. At 4 P.M. Free. Tomorrow AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West at 79th Street (769-5315). Dr. Ralph Watkins will speak on ''Evolution of Black Community in New York City'' tomorrow. Tomorrow and Sunday, Hazel Rodriquez will use slides and music to illustrate the Harlem Renaissance, especially such well-known personalities as Langston Hughes and Duke Ellington. There is also to be a demonstration of dance forms from Africa to Broadway by Mellow Moves Plus One tomorrow and Sunday. On Sunday only, Pam Patrick is to tell Brer Rabbit and Anansi tales. 1 to 4:30 P.M. By contribution. CULTURAL CROSSROADS, Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church, 85 South Oxford Street, Fort Greene, Brooklyn (718-625-7515). Presenting ''Burnin' So Deep,'' a musical revue by the Interborough Repertory Company. The Black History Month production is intended for children. At 3 P.M. tomorrow. Free. SCHOMBURG CENTER FOR RESEARCH IN BLACK CULTURE, Hunter College West Building, Lexington Avenue at 68th Street (491-2248). In conjunction with the exhibition ''Dechoukaj: The General Uprising in Haiti, 1986-88,'' two films, a slide presentation and a panel discussion 9:30 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. tomorrow. Free. Sunday BROOKLYN CONSORTIUM FOR ARTISTS AND THE ARTS, Open House Gallery, 135 Eastern Parkway between Underhill and Washington Avenues, Park Slope, Brooklyn (212-503-2680). Show by black artists, 2 to 6 P.M. Sundays through March 5; other days by appointment. Free. HISTORIC HUDSON VALLEY, Philipsburg Manor, Route 9, North Tarrytown, N.Y. (914-631-8200). Noon to 5 P.M. Sunday and Monday, Rufus James, a performer, will play the role of a slave who was the miller at Philipsburg Manor in the mid-18th century. Beginning at 10 A.M., there are to be tours of the Manor House, gristmill and Dutch-style barn. Admission: $5, $4.50 for the elderly and $3 for students. MUSEUM OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street, (534-1034). ''The Sounds of Gospel,'' traditional and new gospel music to be performed by L. D. Frazier at 2 P.M. Admission: $3, $1 for children.

title: Excel Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Goodbye To the Contras
description: If President Bush and his aides harbored any lingering thoughts of trying to revive the contras as a fighting force in Nicaragua, the new plan agreed to by the Central American presidents should have extinguished them. Praise the contras as ''freedom fighters'' or scorn them as agents of the C.I.A. (they include both); either way, their day is done.

title: Reviews/Film; Suspicious Goings-On Next Door
description: ''The Burbs'' is a big unfurnished movie about some very small characters living in a suburbia that is consciously designed to look like sit-com land. It opens today at the National and other theaters.

title: Tosco Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a LIFO inventory gain of $1.5 million for the quarter and a LIFO charge of $2.3 million for the year; the year also included a charge of $1,806,000 from the early retirement of debt and a tax credit of $36,994,000. c-Included a tax credit of $9,575,000 and $25,233,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. Share figures reflected the payment of preferred stock dividends.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: JRM Holdings Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sjafruddin Prawiranegara, 76, of Indonesia
description: Sjafruddin Prawiranegara, who was Indonesia's Prime Minister in 1948-49 and later rebelled against Sukarno, the nation's first President, has died. He was 76 years old.

title: B.P.'s Profit Down 20.8%
description: The British Petroleum Company P.L.C. said today that its fourth-quarter profit fell 20.8 percent from the period a year ago because of a weaker dollar and lower crude oil prices.

title:
THE LAW;
Private Justice for a Fee: Profits and Problems
description: LEAD: A new industry is emerging in the shadow of the courts, providing private justice for a fee.

title: On Stage
description: Kirkwood's Piquant Valentine

title: Reviews/Film; Teen-Agers On a Tour Of History
description: The one dimly interesting thing about ''Bill and Ted's Excellent Adventure'' is the way the two teen-age heroes communicate in superlatives. ''We are about to fail most egregiously,'' says Ted to Bill, or maybe it's Bill to Ted. They are also fond of odd words, such as bodacious.

title: W. H. Baumer, 79, Industrialist; Helped Plan Normandy Invasion
description: William H. Baumer, an industrial executive and a retired United States Army officer who helped plan the invasion of Normandy in World War II, died of heart failure Tuesday while aboard an airplane flying to Los Angeles from Washington. He was 79 years old and lived in La Jolla, Calif.

title: David Heilweil, Drama School Director, Dies at 71
description: David Heilweil, the former director of the drama school at the University of Connecticut and the co-founder of the Arena Theater, the first professional theater-in-the-round in New York City, died of pneumonia Wednesday at Windham Hospital in Willimantic, Conn. He was 71 years old and lived in Storrs, Conn.

title: New President For Seagram
description: The Seagram Company, the Montreal-based distilling giant, announced yesterday that Edgar Bronfman Jr., previously an executive vice president, had been named president and chief operating officer.

title: Fast Folk Revue
description: Jack Hardy, Rod McDonald, David Massengill and other singers and songwriters are to share the bill in the sixth annual Fast Folk Revue at the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-7880). Tomorrow at 7 and 11 P.M.; tickets are $13.

title: Poe & Associates reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $800,000.

title: Newport Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
School Choice Can Lead in Time to Inequalities
description: To the Editor:

title: Glatfelter, P H Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Corporate Image Ads Tried in Yellow Pages
description: Long the home of ads for sewer rooters and malpractice lawyers, the Yellow Pages is seldom perceived as a medium for the elegant and esthetic image advertising that graces glossy magazines like Esquire or Fortune.

title: Nordic Ski Finals To Start Today
description: The world Nordic ski championships will start a 10-day run Friday in this hotbed of cross-country skiing and ski jumping, with the traditional powers of Finland, Norway and Sweden trying to stay on top.

title: My Book Speaks for Itself
description: Dear Rajiv Gandhi:

title: James Bond, Ornithologist, 89; Fleming Adopted Name for 007
description: James Bond, a leading ornithologist whose name was adopted by Ian Fleming for the fictional British agent 007, died at Chestnut Hill Hospital Tuesday. He was 89 years old and lived in Philadelphia, Mr. Bond, a native of Philadelphia and graduate of Cambridge University, was a former curator of ornithology at the Academy of Natural Sciences in Philadelphia. He was the leading authority on birds of the West Indies for more than half a century and is best known among scientists for proving that birds of the Caribbean originated in North America, not South America.

title: Will Preps Become the New Pros?
description: What this nation has been sorely in need of these last 213 years are nationally televised high school basketball games followed by a national schoolboy basketball tournament.

title: Metalbanc Corp() reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Review/Film; 60's Ideals Gone Awry, In Taut 'True Believer'
description: A long, graying ponytail and a fondness for marijuana are all that remain of Eddie Dodd's 1960's idealism - these, and a reflexive tendency to stick up for the underdog, no matter how disreputable the underdog might be. So Eddie, who once had the reputation of a brilliant and courageous lawyer and is still thought of as a very clever one, makes it his business to defend the constitutional rights of drug dealers - drug dealers who are apt to drive away from the courthouse in their sports cars, smiling. Some part of Eddie knows this is wrong. But another part is trapped in a time warp, and can't get free.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: On Piano

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Alltell Corp., Hudson, Ohio, signed an agreement to acquire HWC Corp. for $26 a share, or about $143 million.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Coca-Cola to Alter Claim After Pepsi Challenge
description: Coca-Cola has agreed to alter a claim made in four television advertisements for Diet Coke after they were challenged by Pepsi-Cola last month.

title: Moscom Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Dr. Joseph Eller, 92, Skin-Cancer Specialist
description: Dr. Joseph Jordan Eller, a dermatologist and skin-cancer specialist, died Monday at the West Palm Beach (Fla.) Hospice. He was 92 years old and lived in West Palm Beach.

title: Transamerica Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $1,470,000 and $10,792,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $2,976,000 for the quarter, and the year included an extraordinary gain of $34,475,000 and $76,069,000 income from discontinued operations.

title: Times Company Executives Given New Assignments
description: The New York Times Company assigned new responsibilities to a group of senior executives yesterday. The changes, effective immediately, were announced by Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, chairman and chief executive, and Walter E. Mattson, president and chief operating officer.

title: The Dollar Rises in Europe But Settles Lower in U.S.
description: After a strong showing in Europe early yesterday, the dollar turned weaker in later trading in New York. The early strength in the dollar developed after the West German central bank decided not to increase interest rates. The decision also strengthened the British pound.

title: Mother Sentenced for Killing Daughter With Salt Overdose
description: A woman was sentenced Tuesday to 12 years in prison for force-feeding her 4-year-old daughter a fatal dose of salt as punishment for stealing sugar.

title: Proponents of Death Penalty Seek to Limit Jersey Appeals
description: Proponents of the death penalty in New Jersey, frustrated that no one sentenced under the state's seven-year-old capital-punishment law has been executed, are looking for ways to shorten the time between the conviction and execution of a murderer.

title: Vanzetti Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Review/Art; Abstraction That Opens a Window on the Psyche
description: In his third exhibition of paintings in Manhattan, Carroll Dunham continues to develop his singular brand of abstraction, one that is as psychologically revealing as it is formally self-conscious. Each work features one shape rendered in one bright color on a rectangular surface composed of one or more 40-by-60-inch sheets of paper mounted on panels. As this eight-painting series progresses, the surfaces enlarge, as if the artist was testing his wings.

title: Anti-Apartheid Groups Cast Out Winnie Mandela, Citing Terror
description: Winnie Mandela was effectively cast out today by the anti-apartheid movement to which she and her husband, Nelson Mandela, have devoted their lives.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Orbit Instrument reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bilzerian Rebuffed In Semi-Tech Bid
description: Semi-Tech Microelectronics (Far East) Ltd., the Hong Kong-based company that has agreed to acquire SSMC Inc., said it had rejected an offer from Paul A. Bilzerian to acquire certain SSMC assets for his support of the $163 million agreement. SSMC is the sewing machine unit spun off by the Singer Company in 1986. Mr. Bilzerian, Singer's chairman, emerged as a potential challenger when he sought antitrust clearance to raise his SSMC stake to more than 50 percent, from 27 percent.

title: John Braswell Is Dead; Theater Head Was 51
description: John Braswell, a co-director of the E.T.C. Company and the director of the experimental theater program at Sarah Lawrence College, died of AIDS on Wednesday at his family's home in Champaign, Ill. He was 51 years old and lived in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Salvadoran Guerrillas Kill 12 In Attacks on Army Outposts
description: Leftist guerrillas attacked six military posts today, killing at least 12 soldiers and wounding 14, the military said.

title: Review/Dance; Inside William Forsythe's Cubes and Squares
description: Although his ballets have been seen for the last 10 years with various companies in the United States, the American choregrapher William Forsythe remains an elusive figure to the public in New York.

title: Dyanmics Research Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Mesa LP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings are in units. The earnings included results of properties acquired from Tenneco Inc. beginning on Dec. 6. The latest year included a gain of $43.3 million from the sale of certain properties and an impairment of $30 million for other properties which may be sold in the future.

title: Town Shaken by Ex-Justice's Arrest
description: As a 144-count indictment was being handed up against Albert Montaneli last fall, the former justice of this Columbia County town was hiding out in Bozeman, Mont.

title: Break in Underground Pipe Discovered at Weapons Plant
description: The operator of the Government's crippled nuclear weapons complex in South Carolina said today it had discovered a break in an underground pipe that carries slightly radioactive waste water to a treatment plant.

title: MMR Holding Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Palmer on TV Team
description: Jim Palmer, who won 268 games for the Baltimore Orioles from 1965 to 1984, has signed to broadcast play-by-play descriptions on the club's telecasts over a local Baltimore station this summer. Palmer will be teamed with an ex-teammate, Brooks Robinson, the former third baseman, who will serve as an analyst. Palmer replaces Jim Simpson, whose one-year contract with the team wasn't renewed after last season.(AP)

title: NAC Re Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After realized investment losses of $351,000 for the quarter and realized investment gains of $94,000 for the year; tax credits of $396,000 and $1,176,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also included a gain of $1,919,000 from an accounting change. c-After realized investment gains of $49,000 for the quarter and $585,000 for the year.

title: Steinbrenner Report Said to Stress Efficiency
description: George Steinbrenner has promised that the report his committee will present this weekend at the United States Olympic Committee's executive board meetings in Portland, Ore., ''cuts right to the core'' of what ails American performances in worldwide sports competitions.

title: McCarthy to Read
description: The Irish Arts Center has invited Eugene McCarthy to read his own poetry and that of William Butler Yeats to celebrate the center's recent renovation. The reading is today at 6 P.M. at the center, 553 West 51st Street. Contributions requested. Reservations: 757-3318.

title: Green Mountain Power reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Myths and Marshals
description: The United States Marshal Service, whose members were long ago cast as rough-hewn dispensers of frontier justice, is marking its bicentennial this year. Part of it is an exhibit that attempts to dispel some of the popular mythology surrounding the nation's oldest law-enforcement agency.

title: U.S. Limits Increase on Van Tariffs
description: The Treasury, revising a Customs Service ruling that touched off an outcry from foreign automobile makers early this year, ruled today that most imported vans and sport-utility vehicles would continue to be classified as cars, not trucks, thus avoiding an almost tenfold increase in their tariffs.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums ''A FOLK TALE QUARTET,'' a play by Open-Eye: New Stagings for Youth, for 5- to 10-year-olds, 2 P.M. Sunday, at Open-Eye: New Stagings, 270 West 89th Street. Tickets: $6 and $8. Reservations: 769-4143. ''THE SOUNDS OF GOSPEL,'' a selection of old and new gospel music performed and interpreted by L. D. Frazier, 2 P.M. Saturday, at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street. Admission: children, $1; adults, $3. Information: 534-1672. ''WE HAVE STORIES TO TELL OF AFRICA,'' a program of two African folk tales, one humorous and the other a mysterious myth, presented by the Philadelphia Theater Caravan, 1 P.M. Saturday, at the Triplex, 199 Chambers Street. Tickets: $5. Reservations: 618-1900. ''THE HOW TO'S OF MAPLE SUGARING,'' a program led by John Mancuso, a naturalist, with demonstrations showing tapping trees, boiling sap and making a variety of treats, 2 P.M. Sunday, at the Greenburgh Nature Center, Dromore Road off Central Avenue, Scarsdale, N.Y. Admission: $2. Information: (914) 723-3470. THE VELVETEEN RABBIT,'' a musical based on the story by Margery Williams, presented by Theaterworks/USA, 12:30 P.M. Saturdays, at the Promenade Theater, Broadway and 76th Street. Tickets: $10 and $14. Reservations: 677-5959. ''THE SNOW QUEEN,'' a play with music, adapted from the Hans Christian Andersen tale by Randolph Pearson, who is also the director, with music by Judy Spencer, 1 and 3:30 P.M. Saturdays, at Hartley House Theater, 413 West 46th Street. Tickets: $5. Reservations: 666-1716. ''HANSEL AND GRETEL,'' a show by Nicolas Coppola's Puppetworks, 1 and 3 P.M. Sundays through Feb. 26 at 287 Third Avenue, in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn. Tickets: children, $3.75; adults, $4. Reservations: (718) 834-1828. ''THE GIRL WITH THE ENAMEL EYES ('COPPELIA' SUITE),'' a show by the Neubert Ballet Company and the Children's Ballet Theater, 3:30 P.M. Sundays, Studio 819, Carnegie Hall. Tickets: $10. Information: 246-3166. ''NO PROBLEM,'' #10 new vignettes by the Paper Bag Players, set to the music of Donald Ashwander, with Judith Martin, who also wrote the material, directing, 2 P.M. Saturdays and Sundays through Feb. 26 at Symphony Space, 95th Street and Broadway. Admission: $10. Reservations: 864-5400. ''MOSTLY MAGIC,'' a magic-and-comedy show with audience participation, presented by Bob McAllister and Imam at 2 P.M. Saturdays at 55 Carmine Street. Admission: $7.50. Reservations: 924-1472.

title: Meeting P.L.O. Backers Splits Coalition in Israel
description: Israel's new coalition Government broke into open argument for the first time today on the question of whether to hold talks with Palestine Liberation Organization advocates.

title: Envirosafe Services reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest year included a $500,000 charge for costs of a management restructuring. Results for 1987 included refunds and reversed liabilities that had the effect of increasing pretax earnings by $930,000 in the fourth quarter and $1,663,000 for the full year.

title: Bush Opposes a Ban On Assault Firearms But Backs State Role
description: President Bush said today that he was ''not about'' to support a ban on semiautomatic firearms, despite new public calls for such a measure. He said the answer to curbing use of the firearms was for states to enforce tough penalties against criminals.

title: Molecular Biosystems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Kerr to Be Deputy Director Of Intelligence Organization
description: Robert Kerr, a career intelligence officer, has been named deputy director of Central Intelligence, the White House said Wednesday.

title: Dow Is Up 7.50 as Trade Report Is Awaited
description: Stock prices rose moderately yesterday as many investors remained on the sidelines awaiting the December trade deficit report that is scheduled to be released today.

title: Howtek Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago quarter included a charge of $3,386,000 for litigation-settlement expenses.

title: Anacomp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $4,950,000 from discontinued operations. c-Included a tax credit of $3,575,000. Final share earnings results reflect the payment of $541,000 in preferred stock dividends and discount accretion in the latest quarter, compared with $538,000 a year-ago. The company said net income in the latest first quarter included a contribution of more than $6 million from the micrographics operations of the former Xidex Corp., acquired by Anacomp in August. The consolidation of Xidex's domestic and European micrograhpics operations into Anacomp's micrograhpics business is expected to contribute as much as $30 million to net income by the end of the fiscal year.

title: Ida Ehre, 88, West German Actress, Is Dead
description: Ida Ehre, one of West Germany's best-known actresses, died of a heart attack today. She was 88 years old.

title: The Pillars of Udall
description: Now the sun not only rises but also sets on ''Udall Point.''

title: Daniel Fox, 65, Inventor of a Plastic, Dies
description: Daniel W. Fox, an inventor who was the retired manager of chemical development for General Electric Company's plastics division, died of cancer Thursday at his home in Pittsfield, Mass. He was 65 years old.

title: Prince of Wales Arrives for Overnight Visit
description: The Prince of Wales arrived in New York City yesterday, spending a private night with friends at the home of the British Consul General, the British Embassy in Washington said.

title: Emerson String Quartet
description: The Emerson String Quartet -Philip Setzer and Eugene Drucker, violinists; Lawrence Dutton, violist, and David Finckel, cellist - is to play Prokofiev's Quartet No. 1, Haydn's Quartet in E flat major (Op. 33, No. 2) and Brahms's Quartet No. 2 at 3 P.M. Sunday at Alice Tully Hall. Tickets are $17.50. Information: 362-1911.

title: Santiago Journal; Church (a Steadfast Bishop) vs. State (the Army)
description: For nearly three years a dispute has been slowly coming to a boil, promising a confrontation between a tough military regime and the quietly determined leadership of Chile's Roman Catholic Church.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly AD HOC COMMITTEE ON DRAFTING OF AN INTERNATIONAL CONVENTION AGAINST RECRUITMENT, USE, FINANCING AND TRAINING OF MERCENARIES - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Oppenheimer Files On Ausimont Bid
description: The New York brokerage Oppenheimer & Company said it could block completion of a $282 million takeover of Ausimont N.V. by the Italian chemical concern Montedison S.p.A. Montedison already controls 73 percent of Ausimont and has begun an offer to purchase the remaining shares at $35 each. But analysts have said that the price is too low and a special committee of Ausimont's board has determined likewise. The full Ausimont board took no position on the offer.

title: Frivolousness in Court No Laughing Matter
description: To the Editor:

title: Celebrating Dates in George Washington's Life
description: This weekend is not only the 257th anniversary of the birth of George Washington, but it also begins the countdown to yet another bicentennial - the 200th anniversary of Washington's inauguration as the first President on April 30, 1789. Several New York museums are presenting exhibitions in honor of these milestones, and other celebrations are scheduled this weekend.

title: KEY RATES
Graphic Scanning Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included losses on sales of business interests of $573,000 for the quarter and $68,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income and included gains on sale of business interests of $32,674,000 and $102,281,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

description: The company said the latest third quarter included a $210,000 writeoff of development costs for a planned mainframe system.

title: Mercury General Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included realized investment gains of $109,000 and $1,069,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included realized investment gains of $88,000 and $634,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Carlisle Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter loss included a charge of $7,469,000 for asset writeoffs and writedowns and cost of plant relocation. The company also said the full year income reflects a gain of $915,000 on the sale of assets and International Wire Products Co.

title: Pop/Jazz; A Sampling of Music That Sings the News As Well as the Blues
description: BEFORE television, before newspapers, even before alphabets, news was spread and history recorded by song. Melodies and rhythms turned raw data into art; rhymes, verse structures and repetitions (like Homer's ''wine-dark sea'' and ''rosy-fingered dawn'') were aids to memory. While modern telecommunications and general literacy have challenged music's monopoly on carrying information, they haven't eliminated that role. Music still holds cultural memories and comments on current events; it still reinforces shared beliefs and makes convincing new connections.

title: Baker Balks at Dutch Request That He Undertake Mideast Mission
description: The Dutch Foreign Minister called on Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today to undertake a Middle East peace mission as early as possible, a senior American official said. But Mr. Baker responded that the conditions in the area were not yet ripe for an initiative.

title: BC Sugar Refinery Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Natural Gas Decontrol Is Nearer
description: In a meeting of minds that could soon end a 35-year era of Federal regulation in the energy industry, key Congressional and industry leaders have reached basic agreement on lifting the remaining controls on the price of natural gas.

title: Amtech Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $93,000 for the latest quarter and $21,000 for the year-ago period.

title: Spectrum Control reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income The latest fourth quarter included negative adjustments of $548,000 for recognition of unrealized losses in the company's financial investment portfolio.

title: Todd Shipyards Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income Preferred dividends exceeded net income in the year-ago quarter.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Money Market Mutuals
description: Uncertainty in the stock market has caused some investors to increase their cash holdings or to invest in a cash equivalent like a money market mutual fund. Last year, investors earned maximum market yields on funds that were easily accessible without penalties for early withdrawals. Among the funds in the general-purpose category that yielded the most last year were the Alger Money Market Portfolio with an average yield of 7.81 percent and a bank-sponsored fund, NCC Funds Money Market Portfolio, with an average yield of 7.84 percent. The best-performing tax-exempt fund was the Horizon Tax-Exempt Money Fund, yielding 5.39 percent last year. Category 1988 Average 1987 Average Yield Yield Government Funds 6.82% 5.82% General Purpose Funds 7.11 6.12 Tax-Exempt Funds 4.79 4.14 (Sources: Donoghue's Money Fund Report; Lipper Analytical Services)

title: HUMAN ERROR SEEN IN CRASH IN AZORES
description: Suspected mistakes by pilots and controllers and lack of clarity in radio exchanges have become the focus of the inquiry into the crash of an American-operated jet airliner in the Azores last week, safety experts close to the investigation say.

title: Ford Payments For Employees
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that its 1988 profits would generate $460 million in profit-sharing payments, or more than $2,800 per employee, the second highest since the payments began six years ago.

title: Goldome Loses $63.1 Million
description: Goldome, a financially pressed savings bank holding company that is undergoing a major reorganization, yesterday announced a loss of $63.1 million for the fourth quarter and $119.1 million for all of 1988.

title: Takeovers By F.D.I.C.
description: Following is a list, by state, of the 25 savings and loan institutions in 14 states put under the control today of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, along with their total assets as of last Sept. 30: ALABAMA: Guaranty Federal Savings and Loan Association, Birmingham, $414 million. ARKANSAS: Independence Federal Savings and Loan Association, Batesville, $266 million. FLORIDA: Southern Floridabanc Federal Savings and Loan Association, Boca Raton, $150 million, and First Federal Savings and Loan Association, Largo, $351 million. ILLINOIS: Concordia Federal Bank for Savings, Lansing, $544 million. KANSAS: Anchor Savings Association, Kansas City, $840 million, and Sun Savings Association, Kansas City, $190 million. MISSOURI: Blue Valley Federal Savings and Loan Association, Kansas City, $861 million. NEBRASKA: Equitable Federal Savings Bank, Fremont, $232 million; Platte Valley Federal Savings and Loan Association, Gering, $367 million; Midwest Federal Savings and Loan Association, Nebraska City, $157 million; Occidental/Nebraska Federal Savings Bank, Omaha, $695 million, and Nile Valley Federal Savings and Loan Association, Scottsbluff, $62 million. WISCONSIN: Community Savings and Loan Association, Fond du Lac, $197 million.

title: Patents; Home-Built Devices at Exhibition
description: The people who gathered in Crystal City, Va., last weekend to exhibit their work at the annual Inventors Expo came from all walks of life. Among the more than 50 who promoted their achievements were an opera singer, two pediatricians, an electrical engineer and a Federal official.

title: Alliant Computer Systems Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $350,000 for the quarter and $3,303,000 for the year. c-Net income and included extraordinary credits of $1,592,000 for the quarter and $3,359,000 for the year. Results for 1987 were restated to reflect the acquisition of Raster Technologies. The latest fourth quarter and year both included a pretax restructuring charge of $19,937,000.

description: b-After a charge of $9.2 million from prepayment of debt.

title: Texas Utilities Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Boyd Accepts Contract
description: Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd of the Boston Red Sox avoided salary arbitration yesterday by agreeing to a one-year contract for $550,000, the same salary he has received the last two seasons. He can earn $200,000 more in performance bonuses Boyd, 29, had asked for $700,000 in arbitration, with the club countering with a $525,000 proposal. After winning a career-high 16 games in 1986, Boyd lost in salary arbitration in 1987, then had a 1-3 record in seven appearances before undergoing surgery on his pitching shoulder. He had a 9-7 record,with a 5.34 earned run average in 23 starts last year, when his season was curtailed by a blood clot in the upper right arm.(AP)

title: WHITE HOUSE GETS NEW TOWER QUERY BY G.O.P. SENATOR
description: The senior Republican on the Senate Armed Services Committee forwarded new questions about John G. Tower to the White House today, and the Bush Administration sought to rally conservative support for its nominee for Secretary of Defense.

title: KEY RATES
Clare Boothe Luce Said It at the Waldorf; We All Said It
description: To the Editor:

title: Liberal Party Leader Giving Political Advice to Giuliani
description: In just two weeks, Raymond B. Harding, the Liberal Party leader, has emerged as a major political adviser to Rudolph W. Giuliani in what is viewed as a likely prelude to the Liberal Party's endorsement of the former Federal prosecutor for New York City mayor.

title: Nets Win 19th for a Milestone, of Sorts
description: The Nets saw a glimpse of their future tonight.

title: Bush Continues Efforts To Sell Public on Budget
description: President Bush today ended his weeklong attempt to sell his budget proposals almost exactly the way he started.

title: Tokyo Aide Is Held in Stock Scandal
description: The Recruit stock scandal, which is rocking Japan's Government and business circles, widened further today with the arrest of the first Government official to be charged with accepting bribes in the case.

title: Review/Music; From Paris, Barenboim And Complete 'Faust'
description: Everything appeared to be in place at Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening for a memorable performance of ''La Damnation de Faust.'' The Orchestre de Paris and its music director of 14 years, Daniel Barenboim, could be expected to have the idiom of Berlioz's ''dramatic legend'' in their bones. This was, furthermore, not the usual collection of orchestral excerpts, but the complete score, with the orchestra's own 163-member chorus imported for the occasion. An extra pinch of spice went into the pot, too: this was Mr. Barenboim's first New York appearance since his recent embroilment in the cultural politics of Paris, where he was dismissed as head of the new Bastille Opera, and his almost simultaneous engagement to replace Sir George Solti as music director of the Chicago Symphony.

title: Trimas Corp. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company's stock began trading Feb. 14, 1989. Effective Oct. 1, Trimas acquired its nine operating businesses plus cash from Masco Industries in exchange for 2,300,000 common shares, 70,000 shares of convertible participating preferred stock and $128,000,000 principal amount of 14 percent subordinated debentures due 2008. In a related transaction, Masco Corp. acquired 1,800,000 common shares for $56,000,000 in cash.

title: Wary Toy Makers Exploit The Tried and Profitable
description: LEAD: Chastened by recent failures of new products, toy makers are cloning dolls, reviving old products and expanding established lines.

title: Johnson Still Sidelined
description: Magic Johnson's injured hamstring has improved, but not to the extent that he will be able to play for the Los Angeles Lakers in tomorrow's nationally televised game against Boston, Dr. Stephen Lombardo said yesterday.

title: Japanese Resume Aid to Burma; Rangoon Calls Elections for 1990
description: The Japanese Government said today that it had reversed itself and recognized the new Burmese Government, paving the way for Japan to resume its role as Burma's largest source of foreign aid.

title: Miron Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Atkinson, Guy F. Co. of Caliornia reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Hopes for Thaw in Ulster Politics Appear Dim
description: Hopes for a political thaw here appear scattered by the icy winds of sectarianism that have made Northern Ireland a synonym for violence and despair.

title: N D L Products reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Killing Deer Is Ineffective Against Lyme Disease
description: To the Editor:

title: Strange Timing to Oppose Water Metering in Period of Drought; Open Your Books
description: To the Editor:

title: A.T.&T. Realigning Units In Effort to Diffuse Power
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it had begun a major restructuring of its large business groups in a move intended to put greater responsibility in the hands of lower-level managers.

title: Met Manager's Optimism Shows
description: Davey Johnson pitched camp for his sixth straight year as manager of the Mets today and fired the kind of opening salute that makes most managers cringe.

title: Don't Imagine Brazil Wants to Burn Its Future; Debt-Relief Tradeoff
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Thursday about the resignation of Frank Hodsoll as chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts misidentified Dr. Mary Schmidt Campbell, who was among those mentioned as candidates to replace him. She is New York City's Commissioner of Cultural Affairs, not consumer affairs.

title: Tasty Baking Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Intrex Financial Services reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a charge of $1,320,000 from the reversal of a tax credit for the quarter and a gain of $406,000 from discontinued operations for the year. c-Included charges of $10,411,000 and $14,673,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, both from discontinued operations.

title: BRIDGE
description: Advice on the subject of opening leads against small slams in a suit can be confusing: Lead an ace or don't lead an ace. Don't lead a singleton unless your partner might have an ace. Make an attacking lead. Make a passive lead. Don't lead a singleton trump, except when it's right.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 52.

title: Patents; Home-Built Devices at Exhibition: Automatic Transmission For the Bicyclist
description: The people who gathered in Crystal City, Va., last weekend to exhibit their work at the annual Inventors Expo came from all walks of life. Among the more than 50 who promoted their achievements were an opera singer, two pediatricians, an electrical engineer and a Federal official.

title: Patents; Home-Built Devices at Exhibition: Taking the Danger Out of Baby Walkers
description: The people who gathered in Crystal City, Va., last weekend to exhibit their work at the annual Inventors Expo came from all walks of life. Among the more than 50 who promoted their achievements were an opera singer, two pediatricians, an electrical engineer and a Federal official.

title: Treatment for Perez
description: Pascual Perez, the pitcher who previously had problems with substance abuse, has been in a drug-rehabilitation center in Florida the last two weeks, the Montreal Expos announced yesterday.

title: Clare Boothe Luce Said It at the Waldorf; Pearls Before Swine
description: To the Editor:

title: Pennwalt Fight Against Suitor
description: The Pennwalt Corporation's chairman, Edwin Tuttle, believes that Centaur Partners will be foiled in its bid to oust the board of the specialty chemicals company if a special shareholders' vote is held on the issue. But Mr. Tuttle said in an interview, ''I am absolutely confident that before any such meeting is ever held, the Pennwalt board will put forward an alternative scenario which would be much more attractive to shareholders than the Centaur offer.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Air Midwest Inc., Wichita, Kan., said it would acquire 15 aircraft from British Aerospace Inc., with an option on 15 more

title: Don't Imagine Brazil Wants to Burn Its Future
description: To the Editor:

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Springfield, Mass.;
Soft Market Forces Change
description: LEAD: A SLUGGISH condominium market has prompted two local companies to shelve plans to convert a five-building factory complex into housing units. Instead, they may turn the complex into offices and warehouses for small businesses.

title: Ida Ehre, 88, Is Dead; West German Actress
description: Ida Ehre, one of West Germany's best-known actresses, died of a heart attack on Thursday. She was 88 years old.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A brief article yesterday about the visit of Prince Charles to the United States misidentified a member of a group that was to meet with him in Washington. The member was Arthur Ochs Sulzberger Jr., deputy publisher of The New York Times, not Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, the publisher. A report about the luncheon meeting appears today on page 1.

title: Harris Planning Employee Cuts
description: The Harris Corporation said its semiconductor sector was reducing its worldwide work force by about 270 employees as part of a restructuring after the acquisition of GE Solid State in November. Harris said these cuts follow a voluntary layoff program completed last month in which more than 500 employees participated, including 280 in the United States. After the acquisition, the company said, worldwide semiconductor employment totaled more than 14,000.

title: Dr. Joseph J. Eller, 92, Skin-Cancer Specialist
description: Dr. Joseph Jordan Eller, a dermatologist and skin-cancer specialist, died Monday at the West Palm Beach (Fla.) Hospice. He was 92 years old and lived in West Palm Beach.

title: Ohio Governor Orders State Workers Out of Uranium Plant
description: The Governor of Ohio told the Federal Department of Energy yesterday that he had ordered state inspectors to leave the department's Fernald uranium plant because they might be exposed to elevated levels of radiation, even in offices.

title: Central Maine Power Co reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Inter Federal Savings reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $201,000 for the quarter and $909,000 for the year. c-Included tax credits of $192,000 and $852,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. Prior year earnings per share figures were based only on income after Aug. 21, 1987, the day of the company's initial stock issuance.

title: BMC Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Broadway Producer Is Held In $280,000 Fraud Scheme
description: Adela Holzer, the Broadway producer who served two years in prison for stealing from investors 10 years ago, appeared in Criminal Court in Manhattan yesterday on charges that she posed as David Rockfeller's ''secret'' wife and swindled $280,000 from investors in fraudulent oil and land deals.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Penn Valley, Pa.;
Conversion Near Main Line
description: LEAD: A LARGE rental property is being converted into a condominium in this well-to-do western suburb of Philadelphia. It is one of the few major conversion attempts outside central Philadelphia in the 80's, a period of numerous conversions of luxury rentals nationwide, but not in the Philadelphia region.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Lancaster, N.H.;
Condominium Farmsteads
description: LEAD: A DEVELOPER is seeking approval for a subdivision to provide 16 ''farmstead retreats'' with condominium features in this rural northern New Hampshire town.

title: Baker Sees No Major Rift With Bonn on Missile Issue
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that he was confident that differences with West Germany over the upgrading of a battlefield missile would be resolved by the time NATO leaders meet in May.

title: Resuscitating Potted Bulbs
description: Flowers of the hardy bulbs are beautiful at this time of year. Tulips, crocuses, hyacinths, daffodils and Dutch irises that have been forced into bloom provide elegant previews of spring. Display these pots in a cool bright place and water lightly so the soil is moist. Enjoy the flowers while they last. When the blooms start to wither and fade, cut them off, but keep the bulbs' leaves growing. The bulbs are still alive and need to be kept strong. The moist soil sustains the leaves.

title: Micro HealthSystems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sundstrand Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $32,507,000 from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for contracts. c-Net income The latest fourth quarter included after-tax provisions for government contract disputes of $31 million and provisions for potential interest charges related to the ultimate resolution of previously disclosed tax disputes amounting to $13.9 million after tax. Sundstrand said a change in accounting for contracts reduced its latest fourth quarter net by $3.6 million after tax, or 20 cents a share. The year-ago fourth quarter included an after-tax provision for several non-recurring losses in the aerospace business segment in the amount of $19.3 million. The 1988 results included provisions for government contract disputes amounting to $79.6 million after tax. The company said the accounting change required the restatement of the first three quarters of the year.

title: Candelaria Returns To Patch Wounds
description: He did not want to remember 1988, but it kept coming back this morning as he sat in front of his dressing stall and prepared for the first workout of the spring. John Candelaria - who last summer engaged in periodic skirmishes with the Yankees and finally said he did not intend to return - is back.

title: West Virginia's Losses Bring Heavy Criticism
description: Under heavy pressure to resign, A. James Manchin, the State Treasurer, announced today that he would not leave office even though the state's Consolidated Investment Fund had lost $295 million.

title: Ridder Chain Is Selling 5 TV Stations
description: Knight-Ridder Inc. said yesterday that it had reached agreements to sell five of its eight television stations and was still negotiating to sell the other three.

title: Takeovers By F.D.I.C. Continuing
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation took control of 25 insolvent savings and loan associations today, but only after the nation's central bank agreed to provide cash for any of those institutions that experience an excessive withdrawals of funds, Government officials said.

title: Reviews/Dance; Little Dramas in Self-Contained Worlds
description: Reka creates small, self-contained worlds charged with emotion. She might almost be a reincarnation of the novelist Shirley Jackson, for there is sometimes an occult edge to the mini-dramas embedded in her dances.

title: Steinberg Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 14
description: b-After special gains of $730,000 for the quarter and $4,238,000 for the 6 months. The results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Montreal and Toronto stock exchanges.

title: Vernon (Lefty) Gomez, 80, Dies; Starred as a Pitcher for Yankees
description: Lefty Gomez, who mixed a sense of humor with a knack for winning consistently as a pitcher with the powerful Yankee teams of a half-century ago, died of congestive heart failure yesterday at Marin General Hospital in Larkspur, Calif. He was 80 years old.

title: Dow Up 13.39, Adding 38.75 in Week
description: LEAD: The stock market moved higher yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average, which lost ground for most of the first half of the month, rose for the third consecutive session.

title: Maine Public Service Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $830,300 from an accounting change. The company said the latest quarter and year nets reduced by $525,191 by the deferral of profit on certain secondary sales of electricity.

title: Laurentian Capital reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included investment losses of $151,000 for the quarter and investment gains of $731,000 for the year. c-Net income d-Included investment losses of $625,000 for the quarter and investment gains of $2,033,000 for the year. The company said share earnings for the prior year was less than one cent a share.

title: About New York; Creating Beauty Out of Suffering As Life Fades
description: A hospice is a place where people with incurable diseases go to slide out of earthly existence with as much comfort and dignity as possible. It is a place where a pretty hairdo or a good shave, small talk and a helping hand take on vital importance. The lesson one learns from such a place is at once life's most basic and elusive: You live until you die.

title: Primark Corp.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $27,852,000 and a loss of $1,580,000 from accounting changes. c-Net loss and after income from discontinued operations of $47,681,000 and a gain of $4,767,000 from accounting changes.

title: Artists Join Quake Benefit
description: Vadim Repin, the Soviet violinist, and Kallen Esperian, the American soprano, have joined the roster of artists who are to perform in a benefit concert for the Soviet-Armenian Earthquake Relief Fund of the American Red Cross at 8 P.M. Tuesday at Carnegie Hall. Participating artists also include Placido Domingo, Frederica von Stade, Samuel Ramey, Mstislav Rostropovich and Aprile Millo. Loris Tjeknavorian will conduct members of the American Symphony Orchestra. Seats in the first tier and parquet at $1,000 and $250 may be ordered by calling 903-9650. Tickets at $60, $45, $30 and $15 are available at the box office or through Carnegie Charge: 247-7800.

title: Rothmans Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Guy Laroche, 67, French Designer And Founder of a Fashion House
description: Guy Laroche, the French couture designer, died of intestinal cancer early yesterday at his home in Paris. He was 67 years old.

title: U.S. Vetoes U.N. Measure on Arab Uprising
description: In a move that risks complicating Washington's new contacts with the Palestine Liberation Organization, the United States today vetoed a Security Council resolution deploring Israel's treatment of Palestinians in the occupied territories.

title: Medical Action Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Brentwood Instruments reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: President Bush and the Rambo Guns
description: Even as gunfire erupts alarmingly in the nation's capital - 75 killings were committed there in the first 46 days of 1989 - President Bush remains curiously aloof, a victim of knee-jerk gun lobby oratory and plain ignorance.

title: Geico Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included investment gains of $15,273,620 and $54,595,334 for the quarter and the year, respectively. c-After an investment loss of $25,531,296 for the quarter and an investment gain of $27,731,277 for the year.

title: State Regents Press New York City For Series of School Improvements
description: The New York State Board of Regents, saying it would ''no longer tolerate excuses and delays'' from top school officials in New York City, ordered a series of improvements today for the school system and threatened to force the removal of the officials if the plans were not carried out.

title: The Sadness of Winnie Mandela
description: For supporters of black freedom in South Africa, watching Winnie Mandela over the last few years has been like watching a bad accident happen in slow motion and feeling one's confusion turn to anguish and, finally, to profound sadness.

title: Herbert Sadkin, 72, Former L.I. Developer
description: Herbert Sadkin, a former Long Island builder and developer, died of cancer Thursday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Miami Beach, Fla. He was 72 years old and lived in Fort Lauderdale.

title: Servico Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: b-Net income

title: West Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a first quarter charge equal to 6 cents a share related to an early retirement program. c-Included charges of $2,723,000 for the quarter and $1,628,000 for the year, both for estimated future environmental expenses.

title: Suave Shoe reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included a non-recurring charge of $165,000 incurred in connection with the company's October 1987 self-tender offer. Year-ago quarter results are also restated to conform to new accounting standards.

title: Withdrawal Rise Tied to Bush Plan
description: The much-publicized step by President Bush to place insolvent savings institutions under the direct authority of bank regulators has led to an increase in deposit withdrawals in the Southwest since he announced the plan on Feb. 6, industry experts and regulators say.

title: Motion by Kodak Reported Denied
description: The Polaroid Corporation said a United States appeals court had denied the Eastman Kodak Company's motion to have the original trial judge's orders vacated in its patent infringement case. A trial on damages has been set for April 17. Kodak had sought to have all orders of Federal Judge Rya Zobel vacated because Judge Zobel inherited 2,250 Kodak shares when her mother-in-law died last year. She is no longer hearing the case.

title: Actmedia Inc reports earnings for 16wks to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said that as a result of the termination in September 1988 of the proposed leveraged buyout by certain members of management, expenses incurred in connection with such offer of $3,900,000 were charged to operations for 1988. The net after- tax effect of this charge is a $2,400,000 reduction in earnings for the year, of which $200,000, or 2 cents a share, is reported for the 16-week fourth quarter.

title: Clare Boothe Luce Said It at the Waldorf
description: To the Editor:

title: Terrell Loses Ruling
description: An arbitrator ruled in favor of the San Diego Padres yesterday in the arbitration case involving Walt Terrell. Terrell, a pitcher who was acquired during the off season from the Detroit Tigers, will earn $775,000 this year rather than the $941,000 he requested. He made $665,000 in 1988. With three decisions to go, the players and teams are tied, 5-5, in this winter's arbitration results.(AP)

title: Big-Band Music
description: The Harlem Renaissance Band is to play big-band music at 7:30 P.M. tomorrow at St. Peter's Church, Lexington Avenue and 54th Street. Tickets are $7, $5 for students and the elderly, $15 for families; information, 722-8283.

title: New Early-Warning Satellite Ready for Launching
description: The first of a new generation of satellites to watch for signs of enemy attack is to be launched on the forthcoming flight of a big new rocket, an aerospace magazine reported yesterday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 18, 1989
description: The Economy

title: Texas American Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the loan loss provisions for the latest periods totaled $59.6 million for the quarter and $372.7 million for the year, compared with $56.7 million and $110.2 million for the same year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Review/Film; Skateboards, Vietnamese And Intrigue
description: Hollywood has been slow to recognize skateboarding as a great movie subject, and so ''Gleaming the Cube,'' the skateboard drama that opened yesterday at the Criterion Center and other theaters, is about other things as well. It centers on the death of a young Vietnamese boy, Vinh Kelly (Art Chudabala), which occurs in a motel room with a view of an elevated railroad train. How is this possible in Southern California, where the film and its skateboarding antics seem right at home? The motel is next to Disneyland.

title: Article 506189 -- No Title
description: A 19-year-old was ordered held today in $750,000 bond on charges of first-degree murder and kidnapping in the stabbing of a teen-ager and the suspect's three-day trip to the Southwest with a former girlfriend.

title: Myers Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend in September.

title: Soviet Teacher in Fatal Plunge
description: A Soviet ballet instructor smashed his head through a glass window and jumped to his death from an apartment building a day after his arrival in the United States, the police here said today. Boris Sinitsyn, 55 years old, apparently committed suicide Thursday morning by jumping from the 35th story of the Galaxy Towers complex, where he and his wife, Mina, 69, also a ballet instructor, had been visiting relatives, the police said. Paul M. DePascale, the Hudson County prosecutor, said the death was ''clearly a suicide'' but that it was not known why Mr. Sinitsyn wanted to take his life.

title: GAF Reschedules Annual Meeting
description: The GAF Corporation rescheduled its annual meeting to March 2 to give shareholders time to review proxy materials, which include revised financing for a proposed management-led buyout of the company. The meeting was originally set for next Wednesday.

title: Clerics Challenge Rushdie 'Sentence'
description: The winner of last year's Nobel Prize for Literature says Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini is guilty of ''intellectual terrorism'' in declaring that the author Salman Rushdie has been ''sentenced to death'' for a novel deemed offensive to Islam.

title: Lilco Gaining Through Compromise
description: A week ago the Long Island Lighting Company won a major victory when a Federal judge dismissed a lawsuit charging it with lying to obtain rate increases. Damages from the suit could have been bankrupting. A few days later the utility agreed to forgo $400 million in future rate increases to block any possibility that the judge's decision would be appealed.

title: American Ship Building reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $1,247,000 for the latest quarter and $829,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: Hudson's Lover Wins $7 Million More
description: The jury that awarded Rock Hudson's lover $14.5 million for emotional distress awarded him $7.25 million more today in punitive damages.

title: John Giordano, 93, Retired Judge in Jersey
description: John C. Giordano, a lawyer and retired Superior Court judge in Freehold, N.J., died Wednesday at the Monmouth Medical Center in Long Branch, N.J. He was 93 years old and lived in Long Branch.

title: Despite Pact, Contras Vow To Fight On
description: While Central American leaders are preparing to disperse the Nicaraguan rebels camped here, the contras themselves say they are getting ready to resume their war against the Sandinista Government.

title: Hungarian Calls the East Bloc a Crisis Zone
description: A member of the Hungarian leadership, Imre Pozsgay, has described Eastern Europe as the world's largest crisis zone.

title: Reviews/Music; Poetry as a Unifying Force For Bernstein's 'Songfest'
description: Leonard Bernstein was 70 years old for an awfully long time last year. The movable and seeminglessly endless feast that marked this anniversary is over, but as Leonard Slatkin and the New York Philharmonic are reminding us this week, the memory lingers on.

title: To Cut Costs, Buy Just Part of a Jet
description: LEAD: When executives of the Stouffer Foods Corporation travel to their frozen-food plants, hotels and restaurants around the United States, they travel in style: in a fleet of sleek Cessna Citation corporate jets.

title: Zeus Components reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $59,000 from the repurchase of notes and is after a loss of $60,000 from operations of the company's Tactech unit. c-After a loss of $70,000 from Tactech operations for the period.

title: President Revives Adelphi, but at a Price
description: On the greenbelt campus of Adelphi University here, an effort to remake the 93-year-old school for commuter students into an elite liberal arts college with national appeal has caused turmoil and division.

title: Chrysler May Build Mini-Van Overseas
description: The Chrysler Corporation is thinking about building its popular mini-van overseas but is not sure whether it wants to do so alone or with a partner, the auto maker's head of international operations said. Michael Hammes, Chrysler vice president, also said in an interview that the company expects its revenues from sales of cars and trucks outside the United States to double to $2 billion in 1989, its first full year of selling autos abroad.

title: Journal Target: New York Area
description: The Wall Street Journal said yesterday that it would soon begin regional advertising aimed at the New York metropolitan area. Beginning March 27, The

title: Election of Officers Today
description: More than 350 members of the United States Olympic Committee's house of delegates will vote Saturday for the six officers who will lead the organization through the 1992 Olympic Games in Albertville, France, and Barcelona, Spain.

title: United Healthcare Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company attributed the decline in fourth quarter revenue in part to the sale in the third quarter of its Peak Health Care Inc. unit.

title: Furor Over 'Satanic Verses' Rises As 2 More Book Chains Halt Sales
description: The furor surrounding Salman Rushdie's novel ''The Satanic Verses'' spread yesterday as the B. Dalton and Barnes & Noble chains, which have more than 1,250 stores in the United States, said they would no longer sell the book.

Vanzetti Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Clare Boothe Luce Said It at the Waldorf; Not Dorothy Kilgallen?

title: The Grapes Of Wrath At Oklahoma
description: It was 1951 or '52, as Dr. George L. Cross remembered it, a year or so after the University of Oklahoma won its first national football championship, and he, the school president, was defending a budget request to the combined appropriations committee of the State Legislature.

title: U.S. Trade Deficit Shrinks to $11.9 Billion
description: The United States trade deficit narrowed modestly to $11.9 billion in December, capping the year with the first annual decline since 1980, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Durocher Hospitalized After Traffic Accident
description: Leo Durocher, the fiery former manager who built a reputation for baiting umpires and his do-anything-to-win philosophy, was listed in fair condition last night at Desert Hospital in Palm Springs, Calif., yesterday with injuries sustained in a traffic accident on Wednesday.

title: Fewer Cattle on Feedlots
description: Cattle being fed for the slaughter market in the seven leading beef-producing states totaled 7.7 million head as of Feb. 1, down 2 percent from a year ago but up 5 percent from inventories of two years ago, the Agriculture Department said Thursday.

title: How the Storming of the Bastille Liberated the Printing Press, Too
description: Among the most common images of the French Revolution are those of frenzied bloodshed, the Terror, the Committee of Public Safety and a confusing alternation in power among cliques and factions. But underlying the event was something less conspicuous and, in the end, more important. It was the word - sudden free speech - or what the organizers of an exhibition opening today at the New York Public Library are calling ''Revolution in Print.''

title: Spas Can Rub Wrong, Dermatologists Warn
description: For people in the throes of midwinter doldrums, the spa treatments increasingly offered by skin-care salons hold the allure of a desert oasis.

title: AMCA International Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary and unusual gains of $5,277,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Net loss and after extraordinary and unusual charges of $185,000,000 for both the quarter and year. The company noted that the $185 million charge in 1987 was related to restructuring activities.

description: b-Included tax credits of $63,500 and $70,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Included tax credits of $10,000 for the quarter and $750,000 for the 6 months, and the 6 months also included a gain of $2,167,000 from the sale of real estate.

title: TEHERAN QUALIFIES THREAT TO AUTHOR
description: Iran's President indicated today that a death threat against the novelist Salman Rushdie might be withdrawn if he apologized for insulting Islam and Muslims.
