description: b-After a loss of $667,000 for the quarter and income of $685,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations, and the year also included a gain of $1,636,000 from the disposal of discontinued operations. c-Net loss and included a loss of $892,000 for the quarter and income of $4,313,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations. The company said the latest year included a charge of $1,300,000 for employment termination costs, compared with a charge of $3,700,000 for the prior year.

title: Review/Dance; Students Have Their Night on Stage With the Feld Ballet
description: The children of the New Ballet School performed Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater in one of the most charming and eloquent dance events of the year. The choreography, by teachers at the school, offered the children an uncondescending chance to shine at a variety of simple and difficult steps and to gobble up the stage space with buoyant well-trained dancing.

title: Everybody Into the Pool, but Carefully
description: It's Opening Day for the swimming pool season.

title: Market Holiday
description: Stock, bond and futures markets will be closed Monday in observance of Presidents' Day.

title: Alberta Energy Co reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $15.3 million on the sale of its interest in Ipsco Inc. Year-ago revenue is restated. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Western Investment REIT reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $364,000 gain on the sale of real estate investments.

title: Campbell Soup Co. Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: 'Fantastic Food'
description: The Fantastic Food Festival begins today at the New York Hall of Science, 47-01 111th Street in Corona, Queens. Exploring the science of flavors, the festival includes scientific demonstrations of food tastes, food preparation techniques and taste testings. Today is Bread Day, and bread-making skills will be shown throughout the day. Running through Feb. 26, the festival is open 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Wednesday to Sunday.Admission is $2.50; $1.50 for children and the elderly. Reservations for groups over 10: (718) 699-0301. Information: (718) 699-0005.

title: Rates Steady; Trade Data Shrugged Off
description: Interest rates were little changed yesterday as both the currency and credit markets shrugged off the latest trade deficit data. Dealers said there was a brief period of weakness in both markets after the Government released the December trade figures at 8:30 A.M., Eastern standard time.

title: Clinical Data reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $15,000 for the quarter and $242,930 for the 9 months. c-Net loss d-After tax credits of $3,000 and $179,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Florida Public Utilities reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Judge Rules Agency Can Resume Keeping Aliens at Border in Texas
description: A Federal district judge ruled today that the Immigration and Naturalization Service could reinstate a policy that confines Central American aliens to South Texas while their applications for political asylum are considered.

title: German Whose Company Is Tied To Libya Apparently Tries Suicide
description: An official of the chemical company accused of helping Libya build a poison-gas plant was reported in critical condition today after apparently attempting suicide.

title: Review/Theater; Of Racism and the Jeffersonian Double Standard
description: ''The Estate,'' Ray Aranha's probing drama about a crisis in the life of Thomas Jefferson, was first presented at Hartford Stage in 1976, one of the rare theatrical recognitions of the Bicentennial season. Thirteen years later the play has finally arrived in New York (produced by the Blue Heron Theater at the Westbeth Theater Center), its passions - and its problems - intact.

title: John Scofield Trio
description: John Scofield, a guitarist, is leading a trio tonight and tomorrow at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: Vanbiesbrouck Takes Brunt of Onslaught by Leafs
description: The move was certainly unusual, and perhaps to some it appeared even cruel. Certainly for John Vanbiesbrouck, it was terribly tough to swallow. But, in fairness to Michel Bergeron, so was just about everything that had preceded it.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture yesterday with an obituary of William H. Baumer, an industrial executive and former United States Army officer who helped plan the World War II invasion of Normandy, was published in error. It showed Maj. William H. Baumer, an Air Force officer captured during the Korean War.

title: Perkins Papers Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: KCS Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $393,000. The company became a separate entity on June 1, 1988, as part of a spin-off from its former parent company. Financial results for the 1987 quarter are based on the operations of the spin-off companies as if they had been owned by KCS at that time.

title: Knicks Closer To Acquiring Vandeweghe
description: Kiki Vandeweghe is coming to the Knicks. No he's not. The Portland Trail Blazers are discussing a trade for the 6-foot-8-inch high-scoring forward with the San Antonio Spurs, the Indiana Pacers and anyone else who is willing to listen and better the Knicks' offer, which would include at least one first-round draft choice, for the 30-year-old Vandeweghe and his aching back.

title: Review/Television; Maggie Smith Is Back As a Doting Mother
description: Last weekend on public television's ''Masterpiece Theater,'' Maggie Smith could be seen giving what promises to be the performance of the year in the Alan Bennett monologue ''Talking Heads: Bed Among the Lentils.'' This weekend, tomorrow night at 11 o'clock on Channel 13, the superb British actress can be seen in ''Mrs. Silly,'' a 1983 Granada Television adaptation of a William Trevor short story. There are some coincidental similarities between the two 50-minute productions.

title: Memtek reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Baltimore Gas & Electric Co.  reports earnings for 12mo Jan 31
Medical Workers Responding To the Plight of the Neediest
description: The medical and dental staff of Mid Island Hospital in Bethpage, L.I., sent a gift to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund on behalf of all the employees of the hospital. The $2,000 contribution was sent by the president of the staff, Dr. Paul Lehmuller.

title: U.S. Pulls a Dozen Employees Out of Beirut
description: At least a dozen employees of the United States Embassy in Lebanon were evacuated today and taken by helicopter to Cyprus so they would not be endangered by intense new fighting in Beirut, Administration officials said.

title: Tempest in a Wealthy Alpine Teapot
description: Liechtenstein has been plunged into what it considers a political crisis. But since the Alpine principality has the highest per capita income in Europe, no unemployment and a coalition Government that has lasted for five decades, the turmoil will probably not shake its sturdy foundations.

title: Vallone Offers A Plan to Assist Homeless People
description: In an election year in which homelessness promises to be a pivotal issue, the majority leader of the City Council, Peter F. Vallone, announced his program yesterday to improve conditions for the thousands of homeless New Yorkers.

title: Navajo Leader Drops Offer To Take Leave of Absence
description: Peter MacDonald, chairman of the Navajo Indian Nation, who said Thursday that he would take paid leave of absence amid accusations that he had taken kickbacks, reversed himself today and said he would stay in the job.

title: Officer Arrested in Sex Abuse
description: A Transit Authority police officer was arrested yesterday on charges of sexually abusing a teen-age girl, the police said. The suspect, Officer John Pirrello, 25 years old, of 70-17 Penelope Avenue in Middle Village, Queens, was charged with sexual abuse and endangering the welfare of a child in connection with incidents from March 1986 to July 1988. Officer Pirrello has been suspended pending the resolution of his case. The victim, who was not identified, is an acquaintance of Officer Pirrello and was 13 when the assaults began, the police said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-6, 30 A Gorbachev note to President Bush urges their countries to work together to arrange a cease-fire in Afghanistan and foster conditions for a broad-based coalition government, a senior Soviet official said. Page 1 Nicaraguan contras in Honduras say they are preparing to resume their war against the Sandinista Government, even while Central American leaders are preparing to disperse the rebel camps. 1 Iran's death threat against a novelist might be withdrawn if he apologized for insulting Islam and Muslims and admitted his book was a ''blunder,'' the President of Iran indicated. 1 The furor around the novel spread as two bookstore chains said they would no longer sell ''The Satanic Verses,'' and Canada halted its import. Some authors defended the book. 1 Khomeini accused of ''intellectual terrorism'' 6 An official of the chemical company accused of helping Libya build a poison-gas plant was reported in critical condition after apparently attempting suicide. 2 U.S.-West German differences over the upgrading of a battlefield missile would be resolved by a NATO meeting in May, said Secretary of State Baker, who also commented on the issue of his stock ownership. 3 An inquiry into last week's crash of an American-operated airliner in the Azores has focused on suspected mistakes by pilots and controllers and a misunderstood radio message. 3 Chinese intellectuals have called for the Government to release political prisoners this year. The unusual petition for human rights was sent to top officials. 30 Japan's stock scandal widened again with the arrest of the first Government official to be charged in the case. The official was charged with accepting bribes. 5 Japan resumes aid to Burma; Ragoon calls for elections 5 Washington vetoed a U.N. resolution deploring Israel's treatment of Palestinians in the occupied territories. The move risked complications in new American contacts the P.L.O. 3 Belfast has little hope for peace, despite recent reports that Protestant and Catholic politicians met to discuss resuming talks. Political experts say intransigence and vested interests are to blame. 4 National 7-9 Doubts about the Tower nomination swept Capitol Hill and the White House as the Senate Armed Services Committee received new information about the nominee for Secretary of Defense. 1 An Arctic ozone threat has been found by an expedition. But it is too early to know how much damage to expect. The disturbed chemistry in the stratosphere was similar to what has been found over Antarctica. 1 Prince Charles is quite serious about his visit to Washington, in contrast to his luxuriant 1985 visit, when Princess Diana's glamour dominated. 1 Taking over 25 savings units, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said it did so only after the Federal Reserve agreed to provide cash for institutions that suffer excessive withdrawals, offficials said. 37 Bush bailout leads to withdrawals in the Southwest 39 The trade deficit narrowed modestly to $11.9 billion in December, capping the first year with a decline since 1980, the Commerce Department reported today. Imports and exports both soared in December. 37 In a reversal, the Navajo leader, Peter MacDonald said he would stay in the job. Mr. MacDonald had said he would step down as chairman of the Navajo Indian Nation amid accusations that he had taken kickbacks. He denied any wrongdoings. 7 President Bush's budget campaign ended the week with students in St. Louis in much the same way it started: He defended the budget and said Federal spending is not enough to solve social problems. 8 Midwest voters give Bush support but differ over priorities 8 The North trial will start Tuesday, according to a judge's order, after the last legal debates over measures to protect Government secrets that may become evidence were settled. 9 A new dean of Harvard Law School has been appointed. The new dean, Robert Clark, has taught at Harvard for 10 years and is a leading spokesman for the traditional view of legal philosophy. 7 The pilots' union is emerging as the pivotal group at Eastern as the airline and the machinists' union near a showdown. 37 U.S. given clearance for keeping aliens at border 7 Rock Hudson's lover awarded an additional $7.25 million 7 Regional 31-34 School system improvements in New York City were ordered by the New York State Board of Regents, which said it would ''no longer tolerate excuses and delays'' from top school officials. 1 To avoid forcing the police to wait long hours on overtime, New York City officials said they were seeking more space to process arrests and reduce the crowding in courthouses and booking units. 31 A Broadway producer was held on charges that she posed as David Rockfeller's ''secret'' wife and swindled $280,000 from investors in fraudulent oil and land deals. She is Adela Holzer. 31 Change at Adelphi has meant turmoil for the 93-year-old university in Garden City, L.I. At the heart of the push to make the school an elite liberal arts college is Peter Diamandopoulos, who was hired as president in 1985. 31 Ending basic training at Fort Dix in New Jersey, part of proposed cutbacks at military bases around the country, was supposed to occur without an outcry. Instead, the Pentagon has a fight on its hands. 31 News analysis: Lilco has changed under the storm over the Shoreham nuclear power plant, becoming agreeable to working out a compromise in the long controversy over its $5.5 billion plant. 32 Jersey holds 19-year-old on murder and kidnapping charges 32 Liberal party leader giving political advice to Giuliani 33 Neediest Cases 34

title:
COMSUMER'S WORLD;
COPING: With Compact Disk Storage
description: LEAD: As the number of compact disks increases, so does the problem of where to put them. The clear plastic boxes they come in can stand on edge and be stored on any open shelving, but empty shelf space is at a premium for most city dwellers. But now the CD collector can choose from a variety of space-efficient holders and cabinets.

title: A Moment of Truth for Opera Lovers: Three Major Events on Monday
description: Operaphiles will face a difficult choice on Monday evening, when three major operatic performances - all of important works led by well-known conductors and with attractive casts - compete for their attention.

title: Diana's Husband Shows U.S. The Man Within the Prince
description: There was no talk of blue eyeliner, beaded bolero jackets, sister-in-law rivalries or marital disharmony. There was, instead, debate about greenhouse gaseous reduction, tropospheric chemistry, the ozone layer, the role of minorities in the global family and the interdisciplinary interconnectedness of innovative people.

CORRECTIONS
description: An obituary last Saturday about Joseph J. Enright, a Christian Brother who was a retired teacher, misidentified his order. He was a member of the Congregation of Christian Brothers, not the Brothers of the Christian Schools.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Graf Gains Semifinal: Steffi Graf, continuing her methodical devastation of the field in the Virginia Slims of Washington tournament in Fairfax, Va., blasted seven aces yesterday in a 6-0, 6-1 victory over Helen Kelesi that put her in the semifinals. Graf will face Natalya Zvereva of the Soviet Union, who won the final nine games in a 6-2, 6-0 victory over Leila Meskhi, also of the Soviet Union. The other semifinal match will pit 15-year-old Monica Seles against Zina Garrison. (AP) Kriek and Chang Advance: Johan Kriek and Michael Chang wasted little time in their quarterfinal matches yesterday and advanced in the $415,000 Volvo indoor championship with straight-set victories in Memphis. Kriek beat unseeded Richey Reneberg, 6-3, 6-3 to set up a semifinal against Chang, seeded 11th, who beat Broderick Dyke of Australia, 6-3, 6-2.(AP) SKIING Finland Sweeps: Marja-Liisa Kirvesniemi pulled away from the field early and won the world Nordic ski championships' opening event yesterday, leading Finland to a sweep of the medals in the women's 10-kilometer cross-country race in Lahti, Finland. Marjo Matikainen took the bronze medal.(AP) Alpiger Wins Downhill: Karl Alpiger of Switzerland, coming off a nearly perfect training run the day before, raced to his fifth career World Cup downhill victory yesterday in Vail, Colo., and Marc Girardelli clinched the season title in the event. (AP) N.B.A. Heat 103, Hornets 102 Rory Sparrow beat the buzzer with a turnaround jumper from the free-throw line, giving Miami a victory at home last night over its expansion rival Charlotte.(AP) Hawks 108, Cavaliers 100Moses Malone scored 11 of his 21 points in the final period, including 4 key free throws and a dunk in the final 1:27 as the Hawks became the first team to beat Cleveland three times this season.(AP) Rockets 121, Nuggets 111Akeem Olajuwon had 34 points and 15 rebounds and Sleepy Floyd hit all 5 of his 3-point shots for the Rockets. (AP) HIGH SCHOOL BASKETBALL Christ the King Triumphs Jamal Faulkner and Khalid Reeves combined for 47 points - 26 by Faulkner - to defeat Bishop Loughlin, 92-57, for the of Brooklyn-Queens championship of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Assciation last night at Bishop Ford High School in Brooklyn. It was the 14th straight victory for Christ the King (21-1).

title: R. Newton Laughlin, 83, Baking Executive
description: R. Newton Laughlin, retired chairman of the Continental Baking Company, died of pneumonia and complications from Parkinson's disease Wednesday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in Rye, N.Y.

title: Beef Compromise Seen In U.S.-Europe Dispute
description: A trade compromise being negotiated here this weekend is expected to call for the United States to ship some beef certified as hormone-free to the European Community and for the Atlantic partners to submit their dispute over the use of hormones to a panel of experts, American and European officials said.

description: The American General Corporation, a Houston-based financial services holding company, said today that it would sell its Maryland Casualty Company to a leading Swiss insurance company for $740 million in cash.

description: Dozens of F.B.I. agents based in New Jersey, chagrined that they were denied a 25 percent cost-of-living increase awarded fellow agents in New York, are planning to seek transfers to go where the money is.

title: Holida>y on Monday
description: George Washington's birthday, actually Feb. 22, will be observed on Monday. Here are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only; main office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Banks: Option to close. Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation: No collections or street cleanings. Schools: Closed. Financial markets: Closed. Transportation: Subways and buses on Saturday schedules, Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North on holiday schedules. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Option to close. Schools: Option to close. Transportation: N.J. Transit on Saturday schedule, no service on the Pascack Valley and Boonton lines. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: New Haven line on holiday schedule.

title: Reviews/Dance; Irving Penn Photos Brought to Life
description: In ''12 Most Famous Fashion Models of 1952,'' Matthew Nash has his dancers portray the figures in two well-known photographs by Irving Penn. Both photos are on display in the piece, which had its premiere Thursday night at the Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater (219 West 19th Street).

title: Military Consultant Barred From U.S. Government Work
description: William Galvin, a military consultant, has been suspended from doing business with the Government in connection with the Federal investigation into military purchasing, the Pentagon said today.

title: Refugees, or Gate-Crashers?
description: Who is a refugee? That's the tormenting question raised on the Mexican border as immigration officials struggle to stem the flow of undocumented Central American aliens. Many may be legitimate refugees, victims of political persecution. But many are not, and the officials seek to deter false claims by denying all the right to work and travel while their cases are pending.

title: Louisiana Bank Fails
description: The Louisiana Bank and Trust Company of Shreveport, La., was closed and its deposits transferred to the Hibernia National Bank of New Orleans, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said on Thursday. The failed bank had $272 million in assets, and the F.D.I.C. said it had advanced $99.6 million to facilitate the transaction. Louisiana Bank's 17 offices will reopen as branches of Hibernia. So far this year, 22 banks have failed nationwide, including five in Louisiana.

description: The Cable Value Network has agreed to change its marketing practices after the New York Attorney General's office objected to the price-comparison methods used by the Minneapolis-based home-shopping service.

Pilots' Stance Called Pivotal If Machinists Strike Eastern
description: Although it is not involved in the dispute, the pilots' union is emerging as the pivotal group as Eastern Airlines and its machinists' union continue to prepare for a strike that could come as early as March 3. A 30-day cooling off period mandated by Federal law expires then and the union will be free to set up picket lines.

title: Jersey Vows No Surrender In Fight Over Cuts at Ft. Dix
description: It was all supposed to go smoothly, the elimination of training activities at this sprawling Army base in central New Jersey, where generations of recruits had their heads shaved and learned to tell their left foot from their right.

title: Ted Bundy's Last Lie
description: LEAD: Ted Bundy was a liar all his life. In a dramatic last-hour interview conducted by the religious broadcaster James Dobson and televised the same day Mr. Bundy went to Florida's electric chair, we are asked to believe this serial killer one last time.

He was 71 years old and lived in Storrs, Conn.

title: 2 Killed in Crash After Chase
description: A 30-mile police pursuit of a stolen car ended when the vehicle hit a parked van, flipped over and burst into flames, killing two teen-agers and seriously injuring three others, the authorities said yesterday. The North Haven police spotted the stolen vehicle shortly before 11 P.M. Thursday, and two cruisers chased the car from North Haven through New Haven and into Naugatuck before the crash on Route 63, Naugatuck Police Chief William Long said.

description: Some Washington insiders may have turned against President Bush since his budget speech to Congress, accusing him of vagueness and a lack of vision, but here in the Midwest most people still seem prepared to give him the benefit of the doubt.

Its Schubertiade project would explore this music chronologically and would last a decade, ending in 1997, on the bicentennial of the composer's birth.

description: New York City officials said yesterday that they were working to find more space to process arrests in Brooklyn, Queens and Manhattan and reduce the crowding that has forced some police officers to wait long hours on overtime to book prisoners.

description: LEAD: President Bush hardly needs to launch his European diplomacy with a crisis with West Germany. Yet that's what the Administration is courting with its demand that Bonn commit itself now to modernizing short-range nuclear forces.

description: Plans to rebuild a financially strapped Harlem hospital have been cast in doubt by a New York State judge's rejection of a plan to reduce the hospital's $16.2 million tax bill.

title: Lawson Mardon reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Avery Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $352,000 loss from discontinued operations and a $3,276,000 gain from early extinguishment of debt. c-Net loss and included a $15,329,000 loss from discontinued operations. The latest quarter included a nonrecurring gain on sale of its Triangle Industries affiliate of $8,400,000. The company said the year-ago quarter loss was due primarily to realized and unrealized losses on the portfolio of marketable debt and equity securities stemming from the October 1987 decline in the financial markets.

title: The Fast Fantastic
description: New Yorkers walk faster than the people of any other American city. This fact is not scientifically established, I am glad to say, which means it can probably be relied upon not to be scientifically disestablished by the next shipment of laboratory rats.

title: Neurotech Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Engraph Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split declared in July 1988 and a 10 percent stock dividend declared in February 1988.

title: Arctic Expedition Finds Chemical Threat to Ozone
description: An Arctic expedition has found chemicals in the stratosphere that threaten substantial destruction of the Arctic ozone shield, scientists said today.

title: When Is Abortion Equal to Murder?
description: LEAD: When does life begin? That value-laden question will come to the forefront of the abortion debate this year, when the Supreme Court is scheduled to take up the case of Webster v. Reproductive Health Services.

title: Edward Zang, Actor, Is Found Dead at 54
description: Edward Zang, an actor who appeared in many Off Broadway and regional-theater productions, was found dead on Tuesday in his Manhattan apartment. He was 54 years old.

title: 6 Die in Detroit Hotel Fire
description: Six people were killed in a fire that gutted a residential hotel in Detroit's Cass Corridor district early this morning. The fire, which destroyed the four-story Billinghurst Hotel, also injured 52 residents, three of them critically, as well as four policemen who were involved in rescue efforts.

title: Alleghany Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $5.1 million. The company said the latest year included aftertax gains on investment transactions of 8 cents a share, compared with $1.20 a share a year-ago. The company also said prior year results also reflect a positive ''fresh start'' adjustment of 81 cents a share resulting from the Tax Reform Act of 1986.

title:
Your Money;
Regional Firms: Local Expertise?
description: LEAD: If there is one constant - other than luck - that makes for a successful stock investor, it is good information. Not the kind of ''good'' information that leads to clanging jail doors for insider trading, but the kind timely research can provide.

title: SMALL TOTS, BIG BIZ
description: I never cease to be amazed at my generation (''Small Tots, Big Biz,'' by Tamar Lewin, Jan. 29). The same parents who will pursue any avenue during pregnancy to assure a ''perfect'' baby will readily institutionalize that same baby during its most vulnerable developmental period.

title: Taking a Meeting
description: Adrian Dantley, acquired by the Dallas Mavericks last Wednesday from the Detroit Pistons in a trade for Mark Aguirre, has requested a meeting with the Mavericks' owner, Donald Carter, before he will report. Dantley's agent, David Falk, informed the owner of Dantley's wish by telephone yesterday.

title: Mr. Cuomo's Sorry Record
description: LEAD: After two terms as Governor of New York State, it is apparent that Mario M. Cuomo has demonstrated neither moral courage nor political leadership. When he came into office, Mr. Cuomo appeared to be a compassionate liberal who also held a view of state government that might result in proper fiscal management.

title: A Dance-Student Exchange by Leningrad and Maryland
description: Towson State University is to participate in an unusual exchange with the Rimsky-Korsakov Leningrad State Conservatory in the Soviet Union. Under terms of an open-ended exchange announced last week at the university in Towson, Md., Towson dance students and students in the conservatory's ballet school are to study for a semester at each others' schools in 1990.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
SURVIVAL OF THE FURRIEST
description: LEAD: ''So what's the big deal about getting close to a wolf den? Why should that be a highlight of anyone's lifetime?'' L. David Mech, an internationally recognized authority on the white arctic wolf, poses these questions early in THE ARCTIC WOLF: Living With the Pack (Voyageur Press, $27.95). Then, with 95 color photographs, he beckons the reader to relive with him the two years he spent observing the endangered species.

title: The New Kind of House Call
description: LEAD: JOSEPH DISPENZIERE is not a physician, but six days a week he makes house calls. Toting his list of nutrition tables and exercise schedules, he provides a customized physical fitness and nutrition program to his clients in the privacy of their own homes.

title: Why Aging Athletes Can't Let Go
description: In 1982, when I was playing with the St. Louis Cardinals, Bob Watson pinch-hit against me and I struck him out. That was rare; he was a good right-handed hitter who had had success against me. The next day Watson saw me and said, ''Hey, that was really a good change-up you struck me out on.'' But it wasn't a change-up. It was my hard slider. I said to myself, ''Well, I guess my hard slider isn't so hard anymore.''

title: Correction
description: An article on page 27 in some copies of Arts and Leisure about the soprano Mirella Freni carries an outdated reference to a recital at Carnegie Hall today. It has been canceled because of illness.

title: Adding Bones To Hot Dogs
description: FOR more than a decade, consumer groups have successfully fought attempts by manufacturers to add ground bone to hot dogs, sausages and other processed meats without telling buyers. The mixture of meat and bone results when machines are used to strip animal carcasses, and the Federal Department of Agriculture has always required that a label on the package disclose such mechanical separation of meat.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Palm Springs, Calif.; A $100 Million Resort Hotel
description: CONSTRUCTION is proceeding on a $100 million resort hotel that is part of the evolution here from a community with dozens of small poolside bungalow hotels to one that serves convention-goers as well as tourists.

title: DEVISL LOSE A 3-1 LEAD
description: Vince Damphousse's two third-period goals rallied Toronto and Mark Osborne scored the winner on a power play as the Maple Leafs defeated the New Jersey Devils, 5-3, tonight.

title: Review/City Ballet; Cast Changes and Debuts In Balanchine's 'Dream'
description: The New York City Ballet's marathon of debuts and cast changes in George Balanchine's ''Midsummer Night's Dream'' continued Friday night at the New York State Theater.

title: THE REGION: The Polls Agree; As Koch Talks Like An Underdog, Dinkins Takes Him Up On It
description: RE-ELECTED by the largest margin in New York City history the last time his job was at stake, Mayor Edward I. Koch now says he regards himself as an underdog. Is the Mayor being honest, or merely modest? Can David N. Dinkins thwart Mr. Koch's attempt to secure an unprecedented fourth term, and in the process become the city's first black mayor?

title: NONFICTION
description: WRITERS ON ARTISTS. Edited by Daniel Halpern. (North Point Press, $25.) Proust on Chardin, Sartre on Tintoretto, Huxley on El Greco, Hemingway on Miro - writers discussing painters hold the irresistible promise of insight beyond formal analysis, interpretation beyond conventional art history. But writers commenting on painting is tricky business: they risk turning visual images into words, replacing the art under study with their own. In ''Writers on Artists,'' edited by Daniel Halpern, the editor of Antaeus, some of the 41 authors collected in the anthology do transmute into literature the works of artists from the 16th century to the present. Norman Mailer reduces Picasso's fragmented visions to bouts of sexual violence, and Gertrude Stein, caught in her verbal incantations, never quite delivers Matisse. But as Zbigniew Herbert points out when he credits Stendhal with saving Piero della Francesca from oblivion, writers have a long history of making discoveries before art historians. Not limited by academic strictures, not writing for tenure, writers enjoy a wide-angle perspective on painting that basically comes out of fiction: they see works as expressions of character, time, place and feeling. The writers in this anthology seem most comfortable when they know the biographical facts or actually know the artist. In ''Caravaggio and the Unseen,'' Stephen Koch conjures the demimonde of Roman streets that were the painter's milieu and inspiration, and suddenly we understand the subtext in the realist's paintings. John Ashbery, who lived downstairs from the painter Jane Freilicher, weaves the people and ideas into a portrait of the times and notes that paintings that influenced her also influenced him. Like many anthologies, ''Writers on Artists'' suffers discontinuities, but the essays nonetheless form a strong history of art, one based on an unexpected point of view. It is not a classically linear history but a pointillist history of stories and apercus and ruminations; surprisingly, the dots add up to a coherent whole.

title: Sled Dogs Compete in Races
description: LEAD: ''THREE minutes, three minutes, three minutes!'' warned the timekeeper as the contestants guided their teams toward the starting line.

title: Susan Margaret Schaefer Is the Bride Of Douglas Hartley Kliman in Tucson
description: Susan Margaret Schaefer, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Paul Schaefer of Tucson, Ariz., and Douglas Hartley Kliman, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Allan Kliman of Brookline, Mass., and Ogunquit, Me., were married yesterday. The Rev. Alexander Meek Jr. performed the ceremony at the Unitarian-Universalist Church in Tucson.

title: Let's Stop Worrying About the Budget Deficit
description: To the Editor:

title: TALKING: Inspectors; Checking A Home For Flaws
description: EVALUATING the qualifications of a home inspector has never been easy. And it may become even more difficult in the coming months as professional and trade groups battle over who is more competent to make inspections.

title: Toll Plaza Change Worries Larchmont
description: CONCERNED Larchmont and county officials predict that the doubling of the northbound toll to $1 at the New Rochelle toll plaza of the New England Thruway, scheduled to take effect this week, will cause traffic tie-ups in neighboring communities and further burden the heavily used Hutchinson River Parkway. The southbound toll at New Rochelle will be eliminated and five northbound toll lanes will be added in the plan to alleviate congestion on the highway.

title: The Underdog's Moment of Glory
description: ONE of the fascinating facets of chess is the chance it offers the underdog to produce an incredible combination, a magnificent upset, a creation that would be worthy of a brilliancy prize.

title: A Way to Raise Student Progress
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Prospects; Pushing Up Pay
description: The Commerce Department's report early this month on January employment was seen by some economists as one more sign that wage increases are about to accelerate, adding to inflationary pressures. Hourly wages, for example, rose at an annual rate of more than 7.6 percent. Also noteworthy was the addition of 408,000 to the nation's payrolls in January, an unexpectedly sharp increase that was only partly explained by unseasonably mild weather. Four experts discuss where wages are headed. Daniel Mitchell Director, Institute of Industrial Relations and professor in the Graduate School of Management at U.C.L.A.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: AT WASHINGTON'S HQ George Washington's birthday will be celebrated in 18th-century style at the general's headquarters in North White Plains today. From noon to 4 P.M. the 18th-century farmhouse property where his troops where stationed during the Battle of White Plains in 1776 will be filled with costumed soldiers, their women and children, all carrying out their respective duties and chores.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Q & A column on Jan. 15 about renting apartments in Paris misstated the rents quoted by agencies in Paris and in the United States. The apartments rent for $70 to $700 a day.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: LONESOME TRAVELER: The Life of Lee Hays. By Doris Willens. (Norton, $17.95.) It was Lee Hays who made the revolutionary suggestion that he and Pete Seeger form the singing group that became the Weavers. ''The Hammer Song'' might never have been recorded, union organizing tunes might remain the domain of scholars and ''Goodnight, Irene'' might have died with Leadbelly were it not for Hays.

title: Putting Motown Back on the Map
description: As a young black man starting out in the record industry during the early 1970's, Jheryl Busby regarded Motown Records as more than just ''Hitsville U.S.A.,'' the nickname the label justifiably bestowed on itself during its glory days.

title: AIDS Spreading Into Border Areas of Angola
description: On a recent morning near the airport here, Cuban soldiers filed into a military medical center, rolled up their sleeves and gave blood for tests for the AIDS virus.

title: Agent Poised to Crack the $8 Million Barrier for Viola
description: About a month ago, Andy MacPhail wanted to talk to Craig Fenech about Frank Viola. ''There are a couple of shoes to drop,'' Fenech, Viola's agent, told the Minnesota general manager. ''I think I'll wait.''

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My wife and I recently bought a 63-year-old house and we are planning a number of renovations. The heating system is covered with asbestos, so we have done some air quality tests. There are no dangerous levels of asbestos in the air. Should we put removing the asbestos at the top of our priority list?

title: Safaris
description: To the Editor: I hope that mine is not the only voice to reply in outrage to Roxana Robinson's novelesque description of a vacation in the south of Kenya, entitled ''Investing in an Absence of Civilization'' (Travel, Dec. 4).

title: 'You Don't Have to Lose Yourself'
description: AS the new director of the Afro-American Cultural Center at the University of Connecticut, Ronald D. W. Powell is responsible for meeting the needs and interests of black students and for helping them learn more about their heritage.

title: FICTION
description: LONGING. By Paul Reed. (Celestial Arts, $14.95.) A crucial test of a good writer is whether he or she can take a basically trite story and turn it into something memorable. In his second novel, Paul Reed passes that test. If ''Longing'' were the sort of teen-age saga that's devoured by 10-year-old girls, its plot would go like this: A girl moves to a new city, looking for love. She falls in with the wrong crowd, one that worships money and physical beauty. Then she meets the boy of her dreams, but her friends warn her not to fall for him. He's in love with another girl, they tell her, and will only use her to win back his true love. But the girl, blinded by her desire for this boy and in love with the idea of being in love, ignores these warnings. The inevitable happens and she loses the boy to the girl he was in love with all along. At the end, she realizes that she was lured by the glittery facade of her new friends and that their lives are hollow, their loves mirages. If you change all the girls and all the boys in the story to young men, you'll have an outline of ''Longing.'' What makes the book work is Mr. Reed's sensitivity and his sheer writing ability. When the narrator is unsure of his lover, for example, he looks for the subtlest signs of betrayal: ''Like a filter through which passes only the purest of a substance, I sifted through hours of conversations and glances to isolate each betrayal of love - the sigh, the faint glint in the eye, the sad gaze out the window at sunset.'' This story takes place in the early 1980's, when AIDS was just a dread rumor and when promiscuity was not feared. It is a tribute to Mr. Reed that he sustains the dramatic tension until the novel reaches its predictable conclusion.

title: Lease Renewal
description: To the Editor:

title: Whitaker Captures I.B.F. Title
description: Pernell Whitaker,the 1984 Olympic gold medalist, won the International Boxing Federation lightweight title today when he beat the champion, Greg Haugen, on a unanimous 12-round decision at the Hampton Coliseum.

title: Times Square: Lurching Toward a Terrible Mistake?
description: The news these days is full of references to Times Square, and a lot of them seem contradictory. There are reports that the massive city-state renewal project at the corner of 42d Street and Broadway - a project that was announced in 1981 but which after eight years has yet to begin construction - is about to get a major boost with the decision of one of the city's biggest banks to relocate its headquarters in the project. But there is also the news that the Mark Hellinger Theater is being leased to a church, an event that underscores the extent to which the Broadway theater, the Times Square area's anchor for three-quarters of a century, is ailing. And then there are the continual reports of crime, of drugs, of welfare hotels.

title: Life as a Program on a Cosmic Machine
description: AT the same time that computer scientists are thinking of their machines as organisms, biologists are thinking of organisms as though they were computers. In fact, some physicists have come to believe that the universe itself is a kind of giant calculating machine.

title: Up From Subjection
description: It was a milestone in the bitter history of South Africa. A hunger strike by hundreds of prisoners held without trial moved the Government.

title: A Graphic Artist Risks Branching Out
description: ''WE never fade,'' reads the caption under the picture of a grinning little black boy straddling a spool of Clarks black thread. Standing nearby on the floor is a painted wooden figure, also a smiling black child, this one clutching a piece of hose.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: JAPAN AS NO. 1;
A Trade Deficit That Refuses to Die
description: LEAD: The formidable chairman of Nomura Securities International, Masaaki Kurokawa, was expressing skepticism in a conversation about whether American political leaders would take action on the trade and budget deficits. The badly needed solutions, he said, might have to come from Japan.

title: Photography Contest Asks for More Realism
description: LEAD: THE summer evening sun shimmering on the Hudson may make a scenic picture, but the organizers of the second yearly Hudson River photography competition and exhibition say they are hoping this year's entries will include a few grittier shots as well.

title: Wrestling Proves a Boon for Publisher
description: LEAD: TO most people, professional wrestling means pure theatrics. To G. C. London Publishing in Rockville Centre, it means big revenues.

title: Uprising Keeps Israeli Tourism Outlook Grim
description: After more than a year of trying to assure travelers that the Holy Land is safe - that Arabs and Jews aren't fighting on every corner - tourism officials here admit that 1988 was a terrible year and agree that Israel's tourism woes will not be solved until its political problems are.

title: First, a Possible Murder Tale, Then, What Became of Body?
description: Gravediggers who were ordered to exhume the body of a man who may have been murdered apparently dug up the wrong body twice and do not know where to dig next, a cemetery owner says.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My wife and I recently bought a 63-year-old house and we are planning a number of renovations. The heating system is covered with asbestos, so we have done some air quality tests. There are no dangerous levels of asbestos in the air. Should we put removing the asbestos at the top of our priority list?

title: Mary A. Garrity To Wed in June
description: The engagement of Mary Anne Garrity to Mark Anthony Whitney, a son of Mrs. Richard Whitney of Exeter, N.H., and the late Mr. Whitney, has been made known by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. James L. Garrity of Rye, N.Y. A June wedding is planned.

title: SANDINO, SOMOZA AND OLD GIMLET EYE
description: A FEW GOOD MEN By William Overgard. 356 pp. New York: A Thomas Dunne Book/ St. Martin's Press. $18.95.

title: Marjorie Samoff And James Olson Exchange Vows
description: Marjorie Ann Samoff, the daughter of Zelda Samoff of Philadelphia and the late Dr. Bernard Samoff, was married last evening at the Philadelphia Art Alliance to James Wallace Olson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl W. Olson of Manhattan Beach, Calif. Rabbi Mayer W. Selekman and the Rev. Charles Casper, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Yale Samples the Contemporary German and Austrian
description: ON the banner outside the Yale University Art Gallery, ''German and Austrian Contemporary Art From the Bareiss Collection'' is proclaimed in a benign, Helvetica-like typeface. Behind the legend are dribbles of dull red mixed with gray that for some reason seem like the automatism of defacement rather than of high art. The sign is disturbing, though not as disturbing as the show it advertises.

title: Understanding Homosexuality
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Are Film Tastes So Parochial?
description: As I read the interesting article, ''Chinese Films Offer New Perspective'' (Jan. 22), I pondered the question of why we Long Islanders accept some foreign products eagerly while avoiding others. We clasp alien cars, television sets and home appliances eagerly, while avoiding others. When it comes to entertainment, though, we seem convinced that nothing on our screens is worthy of attention unless it is of domestic origin.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title:
GARDENING;
Strawberries That Grow All Season
description: LEAD: EVERBEARING strawberries can produce a moderate crop all season with the best of care and plenty of water during the summer along with a bit of fertilizer.

title: Air Fares
description: To the Editor: The airlines should offer a discount fare to relatives who have to fly on short notice when a family member dies unexpectedly. It would be a plus to the airlines and create a better feeling among passengers, showing that the airlines have a humanitarian feeling.

title: Correction
description: A caption on page 5 in some copies of the Arts and Leisure section today with an article about the theater director Ruth Maleczech reverses the two actors' identities. Roger Guenveur Smith, who has a beard, is on the left; Tomas Milian is on the right.

title: Not All the Boys of Summer Were Out on the Playing Field; Polo Grounds Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: YODER, LIKE A ROLLING STONE
description: COLD FEET By Patricia Weaver Francisco. 331 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: Warsaw Begins to Tell Its Own History
description: THE report that appeared in an official Polish publication last week attesting that Soviet troops were responsible for the wartime executions of 4,443 Polish officers in the Katyn forest was hardly a revelation. The entire Polish nation has known this for decades. It was a fact of life that grandmothers routinely told grandchildren.

title:
DANCE;
Work Stresses Black-Jewish Ties
description: LEAD: TWO choreographers with modern-dance companies based in New York, JoAnne Tucker and Louis Johnson, have joined forces to create a dance-theater piece to coincide with Black History Month. The work uses a poem, a spiritual and the story of Passover to focus on the issues of slavery and the suppression of human rights.

title: This Collection Is Entirely Possible
description: AN entire collection of United States ''entires'' probably does not exist. But this certainly does not prevent a hobbyist from trying to build - who knows - what might become the first such collection.

title: Alumni Return as Coaches
description: A SPECIAL group of young people has been climbing the stairs to the music rooms of the Hackley School in Tarrytown this month. Recent graduates of Hackley, they were once students in the school's conservatory program. Now, as prizewinning professional musicians, they have returned to help current undergraduates prepare for a concert.

title: Suspect Admits Guilt in Officers' Shooting During '74 Robbery
description: A one-time member of the Black Liberation Army has pleaded guilty to wounding two police officers in a 1974 bank holdup, ending the oldest criminal case in Connecticut's courts.

title: Asharoken Readies for Beach Battle
description: LEAD: OFFICIALS of Asharoken Village are preparing to battle the state over an erosion control law that they fear could change the face of their beachfront community of 700 people on Long Island Sound.

title: HIGHER EDUCATION-THE REAL CRISIS
description: Ten years ago, I received a Ph.D. in Engineering, and have been working in industry, primarily because there have been few faculty openings available. Demographics show that we will have a shortage of faculty in the 1990's; however, I believe there is a relatively simple solution to the problem.

title: Lori Meltzer to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Murray A. Meltzer of Tenafly, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lori Glazier Meltzer to Peter Desider Starer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Starer of Tenafly. A May wedding is planned.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: DR. ANITA S. CURRAN;
New Orders on AIDS and Confidentiality
description: LEAD: IN January, the State Department of Health fined the County Medical Center in Valhalla $6,000 for violating the confidentiality of a pharmacist, a carrier of the AIDS virus, who had had applied for a job there. In response to that incident, the county-owned Medical Center tightened up procedures to insure that the same kind of problem would not happen again.

title: STREETSCAPES: The Naumburg Bandshell; Everyone but the Donor's Family Wants It Gone
description: THE future of the 1923 Naumburg Bandshell on the Mall in Central Park, while not exactly a controversy, presents a messy problem nonetheless.

title: Phone Regulation
description: To the Editor:

title: Basketball Twins On a Tear
description: ON a basketball court, Jenny and Krissy Kuziemski resemble each other in so many ways that it is difficult to tell them apart. In fact, if it were not for the difference in their uniform numbers, it would be virtually impossible to tell them apart at all.

title: SIMPLY AMERICAN AND MOSTLY FREE
description: GOOD WOMAN Poems and a Memoir 1969-1980. By Lucille Clifton. Illustrated. 276 pp. Brockport, N.Y. BOA Editions. Cloth, $25. Paper, $12. NEXT New Poems. By Lucille Clifton. 185 pp. Brockport, N.Y. BOA Editions. Cloth, $18. Paper, $9. THE COLLECTED POEMS OF JEAN TOOMER Edited by Robert B. Jones and Margery Toomer Latimer. 111 pp. Chapel Hill: The University of North Carolina Press. Cloth, $16.95. Paper, $8.95.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''As author of 'The Satanic Verses,' I recognize that Muslims in many parts of the world are genuinely distressed by the publication of my novel. I profoundly regret the distress that publication has occasioned to sincere followers of Islam. Living as we do in a world of many faiths, this experience has served to remind us that we must all be conscious of the sensibilities of others.'' - Salman Rushdie. [ 1:6. ]

title: Naval Aviator Is Expected to Get F.A.A. Post
description: The Bush Administration is expected to name Adm. James B. Busey 4th as head of the Federal Aviation Administration, according to Government and aviation industry officials.

title: It's the Moves That Challenge
description: MANY of the technical moves in cardplay seem to have straightforward parameters until examined closely. Then they begin to blur around the edges. A finesse is difficult to define satisfactorily. An endplay can occur at the first trick. A squeeze can operate in a single suit, and the declarer can be the victim.

title: Reviews/Music; Art and Virtuosity in Spanish Piano Sounds
description: Spanish piano music made an uneasy pact with virtuosity at the turn of the century, embracing a florid complexity that both emboldened and burdened its composers. At Alice Tully Hall Wednesday night, Joaquin Soriano gave us two examples.

title: Suit Raises Issue of Firefighters' Safety
description: A LAWSUIT filed by a captain in the Belleville Fire Department alleging that the department's lack of an adequate communications system constitutes a serious safety and health hazard has highlighted the need for mandatory, statewide firefighting procedures and training, fire union officials say.

title: PRO BASKETBALL: Big East; St. John's Dampens DePaul's Spirits
description: The St. John's coach, Lou Carnesecca, tried to keep his mind off how DePaul had come back to beat his Redmen two years ago.

title: Core Curriculum: Other Opinions
description: The article on Fairleigh Dickinson's core curriculum that appeared Jan. 22 suggests that Dr. Robert Donaldson, the president of the university, believes that undergraduates ''should be exposed to the world beyond themselves.'' Therefore, as the article illustrates, those whose vocational goals might be science or engineering are required to take a program of liberal arts.

title: Honeyghan Responds
description: Considering what a disaster his last visit turned out to be, it's a wonder that Lloyd Honeyghan wants to go back to Nevada. The British boxer not only lost his World Boxing Council welterweight title to Marlon Starling there on Feb. 4, he also flunked the post-fight drug test when traces of the banned painkiller lidocaine were found in his urine.

title: A Question of Whether to Go to Work? Let It Snow, Let It Snow, Let It Snow
description: THESE questionable winter mornings are for the birds. The world outside looks black and white but whether or not to venture out is anything but.

title: THE WORLD - Q & A: Liu Binyan; The Party's Loss of Control Is a Chinese Dissident's Gain
description: THE status of human rights is not likely to be high on the agenda during President Bush's scheduled visit to China next weekend. Indeed, few Americans can name the Chinese counterparts of Andrei D. Sakharov, Natan Sharansky and Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn. If they could, they might think of Liu Binyan, with little doubt China's most widely read and respected writer.

title: Alison Wylegala To Wed in April
description: The engagement of Alison Ramona Wylegala to Stephen Joseph Lewis, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Lewis of Honesdale, Pa., has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Raymond V. Wylegala of Buffalo. The couple plan to marry in April. Miss Wylegala is an associate producer in New York with GTG/East, the producer of ''USA Today on TV,'' a nationally syndicated program. She is a graduate of Vassar College. Her father is a lawyer in Buffalo; her mother, Barbara Wylegala, is a former flight attendant with American Airlines.

title: In the Heart ofIstanbul
description: IF you order tea in one of the Ramada Istanbul's several spacious restaurants, you will notice pink tulips on the cups and saucers - for the handsome new cream hotel, combining modern atriums with beautiful Turkish design, is at the center of the Laleli district, and lale is Turkish for tulip. As with tulips (said to have arrived in the Netherlands from Turkey), life in Laleli is always a treat for the eye. Situated on a slope, cut horizontally by the wide commercial Ordu Caddesi, narrow, shady uphill streets alternate small hotels, middle-class apartment buildings and clothing shops geared to an Eastern European clientele. And Laleli offers an ever-changing kaleidoscope of national costumes seen only in a few great cities.

title: Call My Agent!
description: MORT JANKLOW TELLS THIS story to illustrate how far the balance of power in book publishing has tipped in his favor:

title: The Town That Wants What The Others Don't
description: THE announcement that a 25-acre site in Montville would be used as a landfill for ash waste from a trash-to-energy incinerator closely followed a decision by the state to build a prison there and the start of construction of a huge coal-burning electric generating plant by a private company.

title: Heidi R. Pfluger Is Wed in Jersey
description: The marriage of Heidi Ruth Pfluger, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford W. Pfluger of Bernardsville, N.J., to Julian Gammon 3d, the son of Marion Jordan of Pittsburgh and the late Julian Gammon Jr., took place yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in Bernardsville. The Rev. Donald R. Pepper performed the ceremony.

title: The Cult of Original Genius Is Our Curse
description: It is probably by chance rather than an attempt to shock us with yesterday's sensations that three of opera history's most celebrated events will be paid homage this week on New York stages. The Metropolitan unveils its new production of Strauss' ''Salome'' tomorrow evening, the Philadelphia Orchestra offers a concert version of Verdi's ''Nabucco'' at Carnegie Hall the same night, and on Saturday, also at Carnegie, Herbert von Karajan and the Vienna Philharmonic present Act I of Wagner's ''Tristan und Isolde.'' Each was a pathbreaking work in its own way and, so far as the words may be sensibly applied, the work of a genius.

title: Now on View, New Work by Freelance Curators
description: Art curators, once as anonymous as starving artists, have stepped into the spotlight of contemporary art. With them comes a new definition of the job. While curators of tradition are academically trained art historians who work in museums behind doors that say ''No Admittance,'' many of the new curators are young, often fashionable, art-world operators who are more a part of the scene than an establishment.

title: Prison Officers Tackle Thankless Job
description: The stereotype - conjured in the black and white of 1930's Hollywood prison pictures - is of a piggish brute, blackjacking cowering prisoners in the dark, dank cells of solitary.

title: Dramatic Handel From Gardiner's Forces
description: Suddenly, John Eliot Gardiner seems to be everywhere. At the moment, he and his Monteverdi Choir and period-instruments English Baroque Soloists are in New York, an early stop on a world tour that's taking them from London to Calcutta, and there are ambitious recording projects on three labels, with repertory ranging from Monteverdi to Messager.

title: Review/Pop; Love Songs for Dancing
description: On one side of Latin pop - the commercial side - are handsome young crooners who deliver internationalized ballads. On the other are unglamorous bands that play salsa for dancers. Luis Enrique, a Puerto Rican singer who opened a week of New York engagements on Tuesday at S.O.B.'s, seeks to bring together both audiences.

title: Policeman As Teacher And Model
description: Sgt. Robert Tinker of the Boston Police Department is one of a growing number of police officers who believe that the front line of law enforcement can be found in rows of fifth graders at their desk.

title: Seeking Vandeweghe, Knicks Look to Playoffs
description: In the hours leading up to last Wednesday night's Knick-Cavalier game, Wayne Embry, the Cleveland general manager, was askedwhether the Detroit Pistons or the Dallas Mavericks got the better of the Adrian Dantley-for-Mark Aguirre trade earlier in the day.

title: For Muslims in North England, Anger and Passion
description: Muslim leaders in this northern industrial city last month nailed copies of ''The Satanic Verses'' to wooden stakes and set them ablaze outside City Hall, illuminating both the religious fervor and fiercely guarded isolation among sections of one of Britain's largest Muslim communities.

title: Review/Music; Wringing Melody From Percussive Sound
description: Chunk, the three-man band that played its debut set Tuesday at the Knitting Factory, could only exist in the 1980's, when almost any sound imaginable is just a digital formula away. Samm Bennett, David Simons and Kent Spelios of Chunk are all percussionists, but by using electronic percussion consoles that produced various sounds, a few visible instruments (rattles, cymbals, steel guitar, jew's-harp), prerecorded rhythms and Mr. Bennett's voice, they could assemble full-fledged songs.

title: New Careers For Defense Workers
description: There is a fifth ''R'' in addition to the four ''R's'' in the Jan. 29 article on reduction in force (''The Plight of Long Island Defense Workers'') and that is: Reincarnate as an entrepreneur. (The story said: retire, retrain, relocate or get rehired by another company.) From my knowledge of NASA cutbacks in the Boston area, I believe that 10 to 20 percent of ''riffed'' (reduced in force) workers at all levels of previous employment have the potential for a significantly better-than-average probability of success as entrepreneurs. This is especially true for those who are already in part-time businesses or who have family, friends or other support and informational sources to call upon during the emotionally shattering period of being laid off. Economic security is important, but so is the old venture-capital adage, ''Funds chase good deals and not the other way around.''

title: Correction
description: Because of a distributor's change, an article on page 17 of Arts and Leisure today about the film ''Rachel River'' misidentifies the theater. It is at the Gemini.

title: UNSPORTSMANLIKE CONDUCT
description: Rather than apologizing for not being interested in sports, why not show your individualism (surely, as American a virtue as spectator sports): proudly do yard work, in plain view of the neighbors, during some championship game. Boldly tell co-workers of the book you read last night - when everyone else was tuned to ''the game.'' MARK OBBIE Dallas

title: Tax Imported Oil?
description: To the Editor:

title: Tribal Council Puts Navajo Leader on Leave
description: Peter MacDonald, chairman of the Navajo Indian Nation, was placed on leave with pay Friday despite his last-ditch effort to stay in power while fighting accusations of bribery.

title: JOURNEY'S BEGINNING : A TALK WITH DIANA TRILLING
description: Diana Trilling, the social and literary critic, is the author, among other books, of ''Claremont Essays'' and ''Mrs. Harris: The Death of the Scarsdale Diet Doctor.'' She is currently writing a memoir of her life with the critic Lionel Trilling and their role in the nation's cultural history. In interviews on Cape Cod last summer, Mrs. Trilling talked about her life and new book, which she brings to an end in 1950, when she and her husband were in their 40's. To describe lives ''entangled in the cultural experience of a whole era,'' I said, ''must be an extraordinary process.''

title: NONFICTION
description: THE ULTRA RICH: How Much Is Too Much? By Vance Packard. (Little, Brown, $22.95.) Fans of television's ''Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous'' will enjoy ''The Ultra Rich,'' Vance Packard's thumbnail sketches of 30 individuals whose average net worth was $330 million when he began interviewing them in 1985. He concludes, not surprisingly, that they are far too wealthy for their own good, or anyone else's, and that the concentration of vast wealth among a fortunate few is bad for the American economy. And they are stingy to boot: although his subjects' collective worth is close to $10 billion, Mr. Packard found that they gave about one-third of 1 percent of that amount to philanthropic foundations. Mr. Packard proposes that the Government tax net worth in addition to income and place a cap on the amount of individual inheritances. Although Mr. Packard states that he wanted to engage his subjects in some frank talk about their bloated bank accounts, he devotes more space to how those fortunes were made - and spent - than to insights about their social relevance. However, the life style details are delicious. We learn that Robert Guccione, publisher of Penthouse magazine, furnished his live-in lover's bathroom with a gold-leaf toilet seat, a Picasso and a Dali; that Samuel LeFrak, a New York City builder, scrapped plans to build a 135-story skyscraper because he ''didn't want to intimidate the Statue of Liberty''; that Georgia Frontiere, the seven-times wed owner of the Los Angeles Rams football team, cannot get into a Newport, R.I., golf club, even though she owns a house on the grounds. Mr. Packard relates all this in a brisk, chummy style. His portraits of the rich are surprisingly sympathetic, given his conclusions. If he is truly appalled by their obscene affluence, he seems not to have let on while in their company.

title: Rain Boy
description: HE hums a pretty fair ''Yogi Bear'' theme and loves He-Man and potato chips. His smile glows from within, and giggles start from unknown places. He loves to sit on the windowsill and stare out at a world he cannot comprehend. Every day of my life he breaks my heart - and makes my heart sing, as well. His name is Michael and he is autisic. He is my son.

title: Customs
description: To the Editor: I read with interest the lament of Sandra Maury (Letters, Nov. 13) about the lack of knowledge among customs agents regarding duty exemptions. My experience was similar to hers. I came through customs on Oct. 18, 1988, in San Francisco. I, too, bought items that were handmade works of art that I fully believed to be (and previously were) exempt from duty. The agent said he had never heard of any items being exempt. I had a connection to make and an agent who would have happily taken hours to resolve this issue. I, too, was overcharged by the U.S. Customs Service and resent it strongly. LOIS F. LIPSETT Washington Ed Kittredge, a public affairs officer at Customs, replies: Whenever anyone has a complaint, he or she should ask the customs agent for the address and phone number of the district director of customs for the port of entry. There is a formal procedure for handling complaints, including an appeals procedure. Lots of people protest and receive satisfaction.

title: Democracy Working
description: To the Editor:

title: Addenda
description: To the Editor:

title: Spain
description: To the Editor: Regarding Paul Delaney's article (Travel, Jan. 1) on the national inns of Spain, the system is no longer government owned and has not been for several years. The system is now independent, although like all of Spain's hotels the paradors are subject to strict regulation as to quality and prices.

title: Holiday Tomorrow
description: George Washington's birthday, actually Feb. 22, will be observed on Monday. Here are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only; main office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Banks: Option to close. Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation: No collections or street cleanings. Schools: Closed. Financial markets: Closed. Transportation: Subways and buses on Saturday schedules, Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North on holiday schedules. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Option to close. Schools: Option to close. Transportation: N.J. Transit on Saturday schedule, no service on the Pascack Valley and Boonton lines. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: New Haven line on holiday schedule.

title: New Jersey Q & A: Carol Botwin; Trying to Cope With Male Infidelity
description: CAROL BOTWIN, a co-founder and co-director of the Westfield-based Better Relationship Training Institute, is the author of ''Men Who Can't Be Faithful.'' In the book - as in her earlier works like ''Is There Sex After Marriage?'' - she writes about relationships between men and women.

title: GORGEOUS LIAISONS
description: Something was astir at the Papillon showroom on lower Madison Avenue. Paula Carbone, the designer and president of the New York lingerie company, was bent over a sheaf of costume sketches. At her elbow, Sydney Bachman, a fashion consultant to Bloomingdale's, cooed her approval of a particularly lavish design. ''We like the square neckline,'' she prompted Carbone. The dress in question -Bachman had rendered it precisely in felt-tip marker - was inspired by a period costume created by British designer James Acheson for the movie ''Dangerous Liaisons.'' At Bloomingdale's directive, that neckline and a myriad of other nuances evoking 18th-century France, would find their way into a line of lingerie commissioned by the store.

title: Alexandra Davis to Marry Anthony DiPentima
description: Mr. and Mrs. Otis Benson Davis of Kent, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Alexandra Davis to Anthony Francis DiPentima, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Pantaleone Rocco DiPentima of Sunrise, Fla. A May wedding is planned.

title: 'Boots' Made for Walking
description: HERE are shoes that look like cutoff cowboy boots in stenciled leather, with silvery filigree buckles, squared-off toes and low heels. By Guess, they are part of spring's parade of comfortable shoes to wear with jeans and other casual weekend clothes. The price is $155 at Bloomingdale's. These styles have a hint of Western dash but are not as cumbersome as boots.

title: Question Of the Week; Can The Yanks Use Guidry And John?
description: I don't believe Tommy John can help the Yanks. He was a great pitcher, but at age 45 he is just taking up space and depriving some youngster of a chance to make the team.

title: Take Me Out to the Ski Lift
description: BASEBALL season doesn't start until April, but from all appearances baseball-cap season is a year-round affair. A Yankee cap, for instance, is a perfect midwinter match for a full-length fur coat, and it doesn't look too bad with something more casual, like a windbreaker and turtleneck. For men, the recommended attire is pin stripes or a bomber jacket, or both.

title: Bum Rap?
description: To the Editor:

title: Reviews/Music; Rock Riffs, Fireworks And Poison
description: Poison's sold-out concert at the Meadowlands on Tuesday night started with flashing red and blue lights, an explosion and a roar of disheveled guitar sound. An hour and a half later, things hadn't calmed down: a set of timbales had been lowered from the ceiling, guitars were changed every song or so, fireworks had gone off and confetti had been sprayed over the audience.

title: Suspect in Elevator Thefts and Attacks Is Caught
description: A New Jersey man responsible for a string of armed robberies in elevators in midtown Manhattan office buildings was arrested Friday evening after a woman he was trying to rob resisted, the police said.

title: BOUTIQUE CHIC
description: People in France may be perfectly happy hopping from store to store - in one shop for a loaf of bread, another for a few sausages and yet another for a bar of soap or a box of lily of the valley dusting powder.

title: Review/Recital; A Soloist Epitomizes A Current Singing Style
description: William Sharp, a baritone who hails originally from Kansas City, Mo., won the 1987 Carnegie Hall International American Music Competition, and Monday night he was presented for a song recital in the main hall.

title: Bobby Brown Brings A New Attitude to Pop
description: By PETER WATROUS

title: Miami's New Ethnic Conflict: Haitians vs. American Blacks
description: At Miami Edison Senior High School, many black students who came from Haiti share a common lie, insisting that they really came from the Bahamas. They are trying to avoid the ridicule of some American blacks, who denounce Haitian blacks as obsequious.

title: Why Growth Stocks Could Soon Surge
description: President Bush's proposal to cut the tax rate for capital gains faces an uphill battle in Congress. But investment experts say if such a cut were enacted the big winners would be the stocks of young companies whose earnings are growing rapidly but which pay out very little in dividends. Even without a tax cut, however, many Wall Street professionals believe that such stocks currently represent some of the best bargains around.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''People I think like to try always - whoever's President - to drive a wedge between the President and the chairman of the Fed. It's one of the best fights in town.'' - President Bush, in an interview denying that he has substantial differences with Alan Greenspan.

title: The Scooter's Partner
description: George Grande, who has broadcast baseball for CBS Radio and ESPN, will join Phil Rizzuto for Yankee telecasts on WPIX this season. In teaming with Rizzuto, who will return for his 33d season, Grande replaces Bill White, who becomes National League president April 1.

title: Mobilizing Against Campus Rape
description: LEAD: THE first image that comes to mind when one thinks of rape on a college campus is that of a stranger jumping out of the darkness.

title: Inside
description: Bush Firm for Tower

title: POP/JAZZ
description: Tone Loc: 'Wild Thing' Delicious Vinyl/Island, 12-inch single. A massive dance club hit, ''Wild Thing,'' which has a silly rap about seduction, mixes the glittering, silvery sound of club music, a little grinding rock-and-roll and hip-hop. Tone Loc (Tony Smith) is part of a blossoming Los Angeles hip-hop scene, and his rap has a nice sort of amble to it. The elements - an easy but not slack gait, a sharply articulated guitar figure, Mr. Smith's loose rap, the repeated leer in the two words, ''wild thing'' - have a clarity that make it easy to understand its sucess. Like many hits historically, Mr. Smith has tied into a variety of different generes attracting a wide audience. And detractors: many of the rap stations in the New York area aren't playing it.

title: Lynn Thomas to Wed
description: Mrs. James H. Thomas 3d of Yarmouth Port, Mass., has announced the engagement of her daughter Lynn Bryson Thomas to Bradley Craig Heinbach, the son of Mary Ellen Heinbach of Cincinnati and Edgar Heinbach of Oak Brook, Ill. A May 6 wedding is planned.

title: THE NATION: Friends and Ethics; Bush Finds Old Money Can Be Hard To Handle
description: GEORGE BUSH never cheats at tennis. Unlike many highly competitive players, the President does not even give himself the benefit of the doubt on marginal line calls. His parents instilled in him such strict standards of personal behavior that some old Texas friends have been known to complain that he is ''too ethical.''

title: Rainy Days
description: To the Editor:

title: To Pay Tribute to the Dead, Many Donate to the Neediest
description: In remembrance of her parents and her sister and brother, killed during the Holocaust in Poland on Aug. 19, 1942, Tonia Rotkopf Blair of Manhattan sent a contribution of $20 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Gulf Coast's Rewards For Bird Watchers
description: IT was a brilliant morning on a two-lane farm road about 50 miles southeast of Houston, not far inland from the Gulf of Mexico. The big Texas sky was bright and blue, the air still except for the occasional passing of a clanky pickup truck. We had stopped our car along the side of the road to show out-of-state guests a spectacle worthy of a cowboy's boast. An unsown rice field, muddy from the winter rain, had been transformed into a shimmering white mass by 50,000 snow geese culling every bit of seed. Pecking for food, their large white bodies and black-tipped wings moved like a fluttering blanket across the land. My husband and I waited for the moment we knew would leave our visitors breathless, and soon it arrived. The flock took flight and the sun played on the thousands of white-and-black wings, creating a vast checkerboard against the sky. For several moments, the amount of time it took for every bird to leave the ground, the huge mass hung suspended above the field, then slowly moved off toward other seed-strewn acres, wings and bodies glinting in the sun.

title: BEST SELLERS: February 19, 1989
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 4 MIDNIGHT, by Dean R. Koontz. (Putnam, $19.95.) Inexplicable deaths and strange horrors take over a once idyllic California town. 2 2 14 THE SANDS OF TIME, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $19.95.) The family tragedy that came to light after the 1984 murder of a Toms River, N.J., woman. 2 2 16 ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert Fulghum. (Villard, $15.95.) The former actress's autobiography. 10 11 3 LEGENDS, LIES, AND CHERISHED MYTHS OF AMERICAN HISTORY, by Richard Shenkman. (Morrow, $15.95.) An expose of tall tales that have become part of our national heritage. 11 9 17 A BRIGHT SHINING LIE, by Neil Sheehan. (Random House, $24.95.) A biography of Lieut. Col. John Paul Vann that is also a history of American involvement in Vietnam. 12 10 14 DON'T BEND OVER IN THE GARDEN, GRANNY, YOU KNOW THEM TATERS GOT EYES, by Lewis Grizzard. (Villard, $15.95.)
