Rapoport. (Dutton, $17.95.) A psychiatrist's account of the symptoms and treatment of an obsessive-compulsive disorder. 15 14 17 GOLDWATER, by Barry M. Goldwater with Jack Casserly. (Doubleday, $21.95.) The memoirs of the longtime Senator from Arizona. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 85 THE 8-WEEK CHOLESTEROL CURE, by Robert E. Kowalski. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) How to lower your blood cholesterol level. 2 2 4 WEALTH WITHOUT RISK, by Charles J. Givens. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) A Florida entrepreneur's advice about how to make a personal fortune. 3 5 17 WEBSTER'S NEW WORLD DICTIONARY. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) The Third College Edition of a standard work, revised in 1988. 4 3 14 THE DICTIONARY OF CULTURAL LITERACY, by E. D. Hirsch Jr., Joseph F. Kett and James Trefil. (Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) An annotated list of ideas and facts ''Americans need to know.'' 5 4 42 SWIM WITH THE SHARKS WITHOUT BEING EATEN ALIVE, by Harvey Mackay. (Morrow, $15.95.) Strategies for succeeding in business. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 28,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) PAUL ROBESON: A Biography, by Martin Bauml Duberman. (Knopf, $24.95.) Mr. Duberman, scrupulously investigating previously closed archives, renders vivid the career of the great athlete, actor and singer, with a nonjudgmental account of his attachment to political ideas that brought him little but trouble. THE FINAL OPUS OF LEON SOLOMON, by Jerome Badanes. (Knopf, $18.95.) A novel in the form of a memoir, full of paradox and contradiction, by a disgraced scholar and Holocaust survivor who plans suicide but encounters rebirth of a sort. EQUAL AFFECTIONS, by David Leavitt. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $18.95.) Mr. Leavitt's second novel, gritty and passionate, concerns a family of four, especially its raging, self-dramatizing, dying mother, whose children agree she has led a terrible life. SPECIAL RELATIONSHIPS: A Foreign Correspondent's Memoirs From Roosevelt to Reagan, by Henry Brandon. (Atheneum, $24.95.) Forty years in official Washington with the shrewd, well-connected correspondent of The Sunday Times of London. STRAIGHT THROUGH THE NIGHT, by Edward Allen. (Soho Press, $17.95.) An ambitious, sometimes beautifully written, proletarian novel with an upper-class twist: its hero is a son of Protestant privilege who can't keep a job. MARY SHELLEY: Romance and Reality, by Emily W. Sunstein. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) The carefully evoked life of the brilliant, accomplished (five languages) woman who wrote ''Frankenstein'' at 19 and made the best of a world that offered few opportunities. HOOVER DAM: An American Adventure, by Joseph E. Stevens. (University of Oklahoma, $24.95.) How the mighty monolith came to be; a taut, fact-filled paean to the energy and competence this country could muster during the Great Depression.

title: Lincoln Wins Playoff Opener
description: Although he was sitting on the bench with his team, the Lincoln High School basketball coach, Bobby Hartstein, declined to take any credit for his Railsplitters' 56-36 victory over Midwood yesterday in the opening round of the Public Schools Athletic League championship tournament.

title:
WINE;
New Tastes From Tuscany
description: LEAD: JUST when you thought you knew all there was to know about Italian wine, Tuscan enologists come along and develop dozens of new products.

title: Frank Gilroy: The Subject Is Movies
description: LEAD: What would you do if you had treated your friends poorly all your life, and then just missed a plane that crashed on takeoff? If you were the protagonist in Frank D. Gilroy's new film, you would consider yourself ''The Luckiest Man in the World'' - and begin to treat everyone better.

title: Soviets Report Flooding Disaster in Caucasus
description: Flooding caused by a man-made sea in southern Russia has ruined 870,000 acres of prime agricultural land and threatens the homes of more than half a million people, the Soviet newspaper Izvestia reports.

title: Question Of the Week; Can The Yanks Use Guidry And John?
description: T. J. is a seasoned veteran who knows how to win games. Like a magician he knows the sleight-of-hand to induce a ground ball to short. Gator, after going 22-6 in 1985, hit a dismal stretch of bad luck, late signings, operations, poor offensive support. These boys have got a lot more wins in 'em and they both deserve to stand tall on that hill 'cause they sure ain't over it. JONATHAN PETERS Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.

title: Field Foundation, Civil Rights Pioneer, to Die at 49; Survivors Will Be Legion
description: After 49 years of pioneering programs in support of children, minority groups and the poor, the Field Foundation is deliberately spending itself out of existence, hoping to leave a legacy of organizations to carry on its work.

CLASSICAL

title: 'Boy Friend,' '50's Show of '20's Shows
description: STILL boop-a-dooping after all these years, ''The Boy Friend'' has got to be the English theater's quintessential giddy musical. And by now, it has conquered American audiences in sufficient numbers to qualify as our daffiest one, too.

description: Schubert's Piano Sonata in B-flat Major, D. 960 (Op. post.) and Impromptus, D. 899 (Op. 90) Carol Rosenberger, piano. Delos 3018, CD.

title: New Satellite Channel Opens Computer Link to the Soviets
description: A new satellite computer link between the United States and the Soviet Union is opening a new phase in communications between the two countries. Scientists, academicians, business executives and even computer hobbyists have begun to exchange messages and data over the channel.

title: Canada Geese: Thriving Immigrants Prompt a Backlash
description: MAJESTIC in flight, intriguing in habit and a mess to clean up after, the Canada goose arouses passionate emotions.

title: Why Do I Worry? So the Rest of You Don't Have to
description: In every life we have some trouble, When you worry, you make it double. Don't worry, be happy.

title: Winnie Mandela Agrees to Shed Guards
description: Winnie Mandela, who has been cast out of the anti-apartheid movement because of the reported violence of her bodyguards, has agreed to sever her links with them and remove them from her home, a prominent church leader said here today.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
Capital Idea on Capitalization
description: LEAD: WE recently received an emergency phone call from one of our more prominent clients. He was writing an important document to present to the board of trustees and was desperate for some aid. ''Is it a matter of diction? Tone? Rhetorical implications?'' I queried. ''No,'' he gasped, ''it's a matter of capitals: whose title gets one and when?

title: Radioactive Gas Is Released At Connecticut Power Plant
description: An undetermined amount of radioactive gas was inadvertently released today from the Connecticut Yankee nuclear-power plant, but a plant spokesman said the amount was probably well below hazardous levels.

title: There's Something About Horses...
description: IT is likely that there are more horses in Monmouth County than in any other part of New Jersey. This may be true, yet no statistic can indicate the adventure of having a farm adjoining one of a horse trainer.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My wife and I recently bought a 63-year-old house and we are planning a number of renovations. The heating system is covered with asbestos, so we have done some air quality tests. There are no dangerous levels of asbestos in the air. Should we put removing the asbestos at the top of our priority list?

title: Question Of the Week; Can The Yanks Use Guidry And John?
description: The Yanks have many question marks such as Leiter, Jones and Eiland. If any one of these guys can't cut it, John and Guidry might be able to step right in. John didn't have that bad a season last year, and he does need only 14 games to reach 300. If that isn't enough incentive to win I don't know what is. Guidry might also be capable of a good year. Besides Gator is still the captain, isn't he?

title: HIGHER EDUCATION-THE REAL CRISIS
description: In his article ''Higher Education - The Real Crisis,'' (Jan. 22), Michael I. Sovern mentions the coming retirement (in the 1990's) of many great teachers and also the so-called ''lost generation'' of scholars, of whom I (Ph.D. in English, Princeton University, 1976) am one. I have never found university work. I tried for about 10 years and then gave up, in bitterness and some despair.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: MACY'S FOR SALE. By Isadore Barmash. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $19.95.) Isadore Barmash is not too keen on leveraged buyouts in general and the one involving Macy's in particular. In ''Macy's for Sale,'' which chronicles the largest such deal involving a retailing company in history, Mr. Barmash, a reporter for The New York Times, clearly sides with the shareholders and employees - two constituencies commonly thought to be wronged in the current wave of leveraged buyouts - although he does not present convincing evidence that either group was mistreated in the Macy's deal.

description: To the Editor:

description: Give Me Your Insulted and Injured

description: Re-signing Tommy John and Ron Guidry would be a monumental, catastrophic mistake.

title: THE WORLD: A Peace Offensive; While Washington Reorganizes, The Sandinistas Are Talking Fast
description: AFTER eight years of war and an almost obsessive loathing for Ronald Reagan, Sandinista leaders started this year apparently determined to reshape American-Nicaraguan relations. And a month into the new Administration of George Bush, they have taken advantage of the Washington transition to make striking progress toward that goal.

title: Lisa R. D'Angelo Marries David Kaput, Consultant
description: Lisa Rosemary D'Angelo, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Michael D'Angelo of Bedford Village, N.Y., was married there yesterday to David Lee Kaput, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Roland H. Kaput of Cottage Grove, Minn. Deacon Vincent Parisi performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church.

title:
DINING OUT;
Charming Atmosphere in Bucks County
description: LEAD: THE Pear & Partridge Inn, in the Bucks County community of Doylestown, is one of the most charming eating establishments I have visited in a very long time. The inn is actually in the tiny historical village of Dyerstown, which has only about 10 or 12 other houses, all beautifully restored.

title: A Vowel Tip From White
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Diane Beth Eliasoph Wed To Thomas David Sherman
description: The wedding of Diane Beth Eliasoph, a daughter of Ann Eliasoph of New York and Dr. Ira Eliasoph of White Plains, to Thomas David Sherman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arlie Sherman of Corona Del Mar, Calif., took place last evening at the Westbury Hotel in New York. Rabbi Thomas K. Weiner officiated. Mrs. Sherman was until recently the public programs coordinator at the Staten Island Children's Museum. She graduated from the Fieldston School and Connecticut College and received a master's degree in museum education at George Washington University.

title: Question Of the Week; Can The Yanks Use Guidry And John?
description: Yes, the Yankees can use Ronnie and T. J. My presumption is that they have sufficient expertise to give the club the aid the team needs in securing that long-needed pennant. FRANK BERTE West Paterson, N.J.

title: Chamber Concerts Fill the Schedule
description: THE music scene in the county resumes its busy post-holiday pace next weekend, with chamber concerts leading the way. For starters, there is an intriguing program organized by the Improvised Music Collective, at 9 P.M. Friday in the Bedford Presbyterian Church.

title: SQUARE ROOTS
description: It was an abandoned shell of a house with a trailer parked in the front yard. Inside, the floors were nothing but gravel, and rather than finished rooms, exposed two-by-fours formed a skeletal interior. Still, Mark McDonald and Ralph Cutler, owners of the Manhattan store Fifty-50, were taken with the building and with the Hudson Valley site. The wooded property has a stream running through it, and the house itself, a simple cabinlike facade, is nestled into the side of a hill. Moreover, they welcomed the challenge of finishing a raw house that hadn't been touched since it was constructed in 1961.

title: Roberts W. Brokaw 3d Wed To Allison Huntting Egbert
description: The marriage of Allison Huntting Egbert, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Cook Egbert of Greenwich, Conn., and Roberts Wyckoff Brokaw 3d, the son of Mr. Brokaw Jr. of Greenville, Del., and the late Mrs. Brokaw, took place yesterday at Christ Church Christiana Hundred in Greenville. The Rev. Adam Lewis officiated.

title: Repairing a Squeaking Floor
description: SQUEAKS in a wood floor are annoying. However, the condition is seldom more than an inconvenience and repairs are usually easy, even for the inexperienced.

title: Delegations To Congress Select Deans
description: There is fresh leadership in Washington - and not just the names that immediately spring to mind. The New York and New Jersey delegations in the House of Representatives have elected new deans.

title: Excitement and Dismay at Space Telescope Center
description: Astronomers applying Einstein's general theory of relativity to three-dimensional space believe that the universe is curved and has no center.

title: Church Shut Amid Protest In Bridgeport
description: A predominantly Polish Roman Catholic Church was closed indefinitely today, hours after the city's bishop summoned police to evict dissident parishioners who had occupied the church for a week.

title: Gripping Saga
description: FOR THE NEW YORK METS, spring training has just gotten under way in Port St. Lucie, Fla., but Bob Ojeda, a left-handed starting pitcher, has been warming up almost daily since the cast came off his throwing hand in mid-November. By now, Ojeda says, his arm is strong, the muscles in his hand have been resuscitated by exercise, and his catchers are telling him his ball is moving as well as it ever has. Ballplayers are ever-optimistic this time of year, of course. But for Ojeda it's remarkable there's a season to look forward to at all, after the accident in his yard last fall that imperiled his career. On Sept. 21, Ojeda, 30 years old, mishandled a hedge clipper at his home in Port Washington, L.I., nearly severing the left middle finger at the top knuckle. Doctors were forced to fuse the bones at the end of the finger, permanently depriving the top joint of its flexibility. They purposefully set the joint at an angle between 10 and 15 degrees, hoping to accommodate the pitcher's grip on a baseball. (It is the foreground finger at right.) Ojeda says repetition is making the artificial grip familiar, and that the loss of flexibility has not interfered with his delivery. ''I'd never thought about this before,'' Ojeda says. ''But what I discovered is that my fingertips only sit on the ball just before it leaves my hand, when it's too late, really, to make any difference. Your 'touch' comes into play at the top of your delivery and as your arm comes forward, but it's the touch of your whole hand, the palm, the length of the fingers.''

title:
MUSIC;
Mirella Freni - Grandmother as a Young Girl
description: LEAD: Last December, Mirella Freni made a quick stop between San Francisco and Italy to sing a pair of Micaelas at the Met. It was a bit strange for her: Micaela was her debut role back in 1955, and one of her regular parts for many seasons, but she hadn't sung the role on stage in 15 years, though she recorded it recently for the third time.

title: Drawing a Bear, or Anything Else
description: Back in mechanical drawing class we would labor for hours to create front, top and side views of a flange. (No one was ever quite sure what a flange was, but we had to draw one nonetheless.) Three views required three drawings and usually resulted in at least three inconsistencies.

title: French Say 'Vite,' Kent Says 'No' to Rail Link
description: While cities in northern France are vying with each other to get on the high-speed rail link between Paris and London when the channel tunnel opens in 1993, towns and villages in southeastern England are up in arms against it, fearing permanent damage to their environment, eardrums and the English way of life.

title: A Machine That Shows How Viruses Respond to Drugs
description: As a researcher in the life sciences laboratory of the Eastman Kodak Company, Vanessa Lum spends a lot of time determining how proteins and viruses interact with drugs. Simulating their behavior on computer is now easier than ever.

title: Motorola's Labor War
description: The violence is over at Motorola Korea Ltd. - at least for now. There are no more workers dousing themselves with paint thinner, barricading themselves in the computer room and threatening to die for the right to form a union. But the fledgling union and management are no closer to agreement than before.

title: 3 U.S. Soldiers Slightly Hurt In Bomb Attack in Honduras
description: Assailants hurled a bomb at the back of a bus carrying American troops today, wounding three soldiers, the United States Embassy said.

title: Mexico Puts Signs From Bush in the Worst Light
description: SOONER or later, every United States Administration learns a basic truth about relations with Mexico: more often than not, what you do matters less than what the Mexicans think you have done. For George Bush that lesson has come earlier than usual, and in a particularly instructive set of circumstances.

title: Question Of the Week; Can The Yanks Use Guidry And John?
description: The Yankees have picked up a lot of ''young'' arms during the off season but what they basically have are ''new'' arms, not ''good'' arms.

title: Model for Rockwell Retires
description: A small-town doctor who was the model for a well-known illustration by Norman Rockwell retired today on his 83d birthday.

title: Minority Hiring 'Goal' Studied, Bush Nominee Says
description: Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, President Bush's nominee to head the Department of Health and Human Services, said today that the Administration was ''looking at'' establishing a goal of 25 percent minorities and women in senior positions in the Government.

title:
GARDENING;
Strawberries That Grow All Season
description: LEAD: EVERBEARING strawberries can produce a moderate crop all season with the best of care and plenty of water during the summer along with a bit of fertilizer.

title: UNSPORTSMANLIKE CONDUCT
description: I'm delighted to read that I'm not the only American male who doesn't turn to the sports pages first.

title: Regan Fees Paid by Campaign and State
description: New York's State Comptroller, Edward V. Regan, is spending up to $400,000 in state funds and campaign money for lawyers as a result of investigations of his campaign financing practices by the State Commission on Government Integrity and Federal and state prosecutors.

title: Man Dies After Shot on Sidewalk
description: A Long Island man died late last night after being shot during a robbery on a Greenwich Village sidewalk, the police said.

title: Farms in Its Future? Delaware Must Decide
description: In a national game of word association ''Delaware'' is most likely to be followed by ''DuPont,'' the giant chemical company based here.

title: Correction
description: An article in some copies of Arts and Leisure last Sunday about the Jewish Repertory Theater misidentified the author of the play ''Bitter Friends.'' He is Gordon Rayfield.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of Caribbean cruises on Feb. 5 misstated the departure port and ports of call for some seven-night voyages on the Regent Sea of Regency Cruises. From March 5 to April 16, the ship will sail between San Juan and Tampa, calling at Grand Cayman Island, Santo Domingo, St. Croix and St. Martin.

title: 3d in Row for St. Peter's
description: Willie Haynes hit a 16-foot jumper with 11 seconds to play tonight to give St. Peter's a 50-49 victory over Fordham in a Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference game. The victory was the third straight for St. Peter's (19-6, 11-2) and its 11th in 12 games.

description: An article in The Times Magazine today discusses the Democratic primary race for Mayor of Chicago, in which Acting Mayor Eugene Sawyer and Richard M. Daley are the front-runners.

description: Yellow Fever Alert Issued In Trinidad

description: These are some of the hundreds of items in the ''black box,'' a group of domestic programs on which President Bush proposes to spend no more in all of fiscal 1990 than in fiscal 1989, $136 billion. Energy

title: FICTION
description: COMING HOME AND OTHER STORIES. By Farida Karodia. (Heinemann, Paper, $7.50.) In ''Coming Home,'' Farida Karodia's collection of stories set in South Africa, home is where the hate is. From the townships to the large cities, the remote villages to the white suburbs, Ms. Karodia, a South African writer who now lives in Canada, depicts a land deformed by rage and random violence. Racists and sadists roam through these pages with impunity. Their victims hide, avert their eyes or set out for somewhere else with their lives' belongings rolled into awkward bundles. When they fight back, they're cut down. More disturbing, the cruelty is not confined to the white police or the Government. Out of frustration and rage, blacks turn on other blacks. Husbands beat their wives, then abandon them. Sons murder their fathers. And even when the characters are kind and innocent, voracious misfortune takes over. Ms. Karodia's heroes and villains are a varied lot, black and white, men and women, rich and poor. She is able to convey many voices easily and quickly. But, unfortunately, some of her stories have a tinny ring, with writing that is disappointingly plain in patches, prone to ham-handed descriptions and threadbare phrases. In the sad title novella, for example, a young man awaits his brutal father's return from prison, wondering what the old man will be like, and concludes with a cliche: ''A leopard never changes its spots.'' But in the end, these lapses fade from memory. What remains is Ms. Karodia's clear vision of the South African tragedy. The obligatory note on the dedication page reads: ''The characters in this book are all fictitious and are not based on any known person, living or dead.'' Would that it were so. J. R. MOEHRINGER

title: Connecticut Studies Schools' Racial Imbalance
description: Connecticut has 166 school districts spread out over its 169 independent towns, but the numbers disguise a deep imbalance: More than 80 percent of all minority children in the state - most of them black and Hispanic - are concentrated in just 14 districts in the largest cities, while elsewhere the schools are overwhelmingly white.

title: RACIAL POLITICS: CHICAGO'S RAW NERVE
description: ON THE SOUTH SIDE OF CHICAGO, in the lobby of a former union hall, there hangs an old photograph. Striking stockyard workers, blacks and whites, are huddled together for solidarity, and perhaps for warmth, against the fierce winter wind that whips off Lake Michigan, an infamous gale known here as ''The Hawk.'' Across the photograph is emblazoned the slogan, ''Negro and White - Unite to Fight!''

title: Blooms, Blooms on the Range
description: APRIL wildflowering is a ritual as vital to Texans as an October foliage outing is for Northerners. It's a celebration of the delightfully warm, sunny days of midspring, before the blistering sun of the Southwestern summer makes a midday outdoor excursion an ordeal. It's an extra excuse to search out the weathered, old wood and stone homes, stores and churches that form classic landscapes in the Texan countryside.

title: Review/Theater; Updating Oscar Wilde, Earnestly
description: When we left the characters in ''The Importance of Being Earnest,'' Jack and Algernon had discovered that they were long-lost brothers. Each was about to marry the woman of his choice - Jack matched with Gwendolyn and Algernon with Cecily. Thirty-four years later, in Thom Thomas's sequel, ''Without Apologies,'' each brother is married to the other's intended, and they have all settled down to a life of middle-class dullness.

title: Hardly Ted Truehearts
description: To the Editor:

title: Reverse Mortgages: An Assessment
description: The article ''Elderly Are Offered Reverse Mortages'' [ Jan. 29 ] is misleading. The mortgages described are home-equity loans that place a second or possibly first mortgage on a house based on the house's value without regard to income and must be repaid in full with interest at the end of 10 years. This could prove a disaster and ripoff for many elderly.

title: Alcoholic Beverages To Get Danger Label
description: Beginning Nov. 18, all bottles or other containers of wine, beer or distilled spirits must bear a warning label saying alcohol can cause health problems and birth defects, the Federal Government says.

title: DEMOCRACY WAS HIS BEST SUBJECT
description: LEAD: TOCQUEVILLE A Biography. By Andre Jardin. Translated by Lydia Davis with Robert Hemenway. 550 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $35.

title: Of Blasphemy, Belief and Fury
description: THE gap in understanding between a resurgent, faith-filled Islam and a secular, pluralist West became a yawning chasm last week when accusations that a novel called ''The Satanic Verses'' was blasphemous led to riots and deaths in Pakistan and India, huge demonstrations in Iran and a death sentence pronounced on its author, Salman Rushdie.

title: A Rare Look Inside Public Works
description: New York City's infrastructure - the manmade web of steel and concrete that holds the five boroughs together and links them to the rest of the world - has loomed before the public lately as a series of problems that need to be fixed.

title: Customs
description: To the Editor: Sandra Maury wrote that she was overcharged on her Bangkok purchase when she came through customs.

title: Review/Dance; Tics, Aches And Other Behaviors
description: Janet Panetta and John Jasperse depicted compulsive behavior in the dances they presented Friday night at St. Mark's Church under the auspices of the Danspace Project. Both choreographers took obvious pains to devise elaborate tics and tremors. Yet neither managed to make them consistently interesting.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: The Salomon Solution; A Building Within a Building, at a Cost of $200 Million
description: BEFORE it moves into a new office tower in downtown Manhattan, Salomon Brothers, the brokerage firm, intends to spend nearly two years and more than $200 million cutting out floors, adding elevators, reinforcing steel girders, upgrading power supplies and making other improvements in its million square feet of space.

title: How Silk and Tea Spawned Early Fortunes
description: LEAD: THE China trade that spawned some of New England's earliest fortunes is the subject of a new exhibit at the Connecticut River Museum in Essex.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: NEW AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some of the most notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted. Classical

title: Where British Found Haven In Antigua
description: It was on his second voyage to the New World, in 1493, that Christopher Columbus spotted the oval island that he would call Santa Maria la Antigua in honor of a church in Seville. Today his experience is shared in some small measure, by the tourists who decend upon Antigua by plane and cruise ship.

title: Success Is Within Reach IS THE COLD WAR OVER? - An occasional series.
description: With the withdrawal from Afghanistan and the unilateral reductions in tanks and troop divisions in Eastern Europe, Mikhail S. Gorbachev will have sharply reduced the major military threat to American vital interests. If he continues pursuing his current agenda for the next several years, he will pose for the West for the first time since the late 1940's a conceptual challenge: What do we want beyond victory in the cold war?

title:
DINING OUT;
Chinese Fare Holding Own in Hartsdale
description: LEAD: DINERS putting great stock in restaurant service might be disappointed in Hartsdale Garden. When service happens to be off, decent food may not be enough to soothe hungry, waiting guests. And those who remember the place for the unusual dishes it carried in its early days will find the current menu rather conventional.

title: POSTINGS: 2 Bedrooms for $119,000; Town Lottery For Houses
description: More than 300 residents of the Town of Yorktown in upper Westchester County are applying for inclusion in a new program that will provide a few modestly priced homes for applicants who are qualified and who win a special lottery. Five semi-detached two-bedroom homes costing $119,000 each will be available this summer.

title: Passing Sentence Before A Trial
description: On Thursday, the Justice Department made it official: An undisclosed number of traders on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange were being investigated for illegal trading.

title: Atomic Plant in Pennsylvania Wins Good Marks From U.S.
description: The Philadelphia Electric Company's long-idled Peach Bottom nuclear power plant in central Pennsylvania could be restarted in April if no more serious problems are uncovered, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said Friday.

title: THE 'WALKURE' FACEOFF
description: Like Deutsche Grammophon, EMI has begun its new digitally recorded ''Ring des Nibelungen'' with ''Die Walkure.'' The EMI version, conducted by Bernard Haitink, features Eva Marton, Cheryl Studer, James Morris, Reiner Goldberg, Matti Salminen, Waltraud Meier and the Bavarian Radio Symphony (EMI CDS 7 49534; four CD's and LP's three cassettes). Interested record buyers will naturally want to decide betwen the DG/James Levine set and this new Haitink performance.

title: Moscow to Get Academy of Jewish Learning
description: Moscow, which got a new Jewish cultural center last week, will get a yeshiva this week, the first such academy of Jewish learning on Soviet soil in 60 years.

title: Suzanne Burnette Engaged To Marry Cloyd Laporte 3d
description: A June wedding is planned by Suzanne Rae Burnette and Cloyd Laporte 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Cloyd Laporte Jr. of New York. Their engagement was announced by the future bride's mother and stepfather, Mr. and Mrs. Jerry F. McGehee of Kingwood, Tex.

title: Nuclear Evacuation: Much Misinformation
description: It is positively amazing to consider the misinformation spread regarding what might happen if there was an accident at the Shoreham nuclear plant. The latest is the article which appeared on the Opinion page Jan. 29 under the title ''Shoreham Evacuation: Like the Blizzard of '86?''

title: John Billhardt 2d, an Equities Trader, Marries Kara Lynn Glover, an Actress
description: Kara Lynn Glover and John Philip Billhardt2d were married yesterday at the Marble Collegiate Church by the Rev. Dr. Robert Williams.

title:
FOCUS: COLORADO SPRINGS, COLO;
Colorado Springs Annexes Ranch, Growing Nearly 50%
description: LEAD: On a scale unusual even by Western standards, Colorado Springs recently increased its size by nearly half. It annexed the 25,060-acre Banning-Lewis Ranch, a 14-mile-long, 4-mile-wide expanse of sagebrush and scrub oak along its eastern border. The next-largest annexation was of 9,000 acres in 1986.

title: POP/JAZZ
description: Brazil Classics 1/ Beleza Tropical Compiled by David Byrne. Fly/Sire/Warner Bros. 25805, all three formats.

title: Review/Concert; Barenboim Conducts the 'Missa Solemnis'
description: The Beethoven of the early 1820's, the time of the Missa Solemnis, presents one of the unforgettable portraits in artistic history. Here is the old master, deaf, unkempt, bewildered, buffeted by life, poring over the old masters of sacred music, pressing relentlessly inward and outward the frontiers of his own creative realm, composing a mass for the ages (''singing, howling, stamping'' it, in one famous account), while he slides recklessly into debt and negotiates duplicitously with half a dozen publishers for rights to (and advances on) the work.

title: Israeli Student Is Slain In Attack Near Old City
description: A Jewish seminary student was stabbed to death today near Jerusalem's walled Old City in what the police said was apparently a terrorist attack.

The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Jews in an Arab Land: Morocco's Rare Amity
description: When the Palestinian uprising in the Israeli-occupied lands broke out, a Jewish businessman here said, he found that his Muslim friends at first did not want to discuss the issue lest the passions of distant conflict blight their relationship.

title: Friendly Hunan in West Haven
description: A RESTAURANT writer could keep busy reviewing Connecticut's Chinese restaurants alone. It is not just the reviewing, but the need for re-reviewing, as nothing in the food service industry seems to change faster than the personnel in a Chinese restaurant kitchen. ''Very good'' today can turn into a mere ''satisfactory'' in a matter of weeks; such is the speed of the chef's revolving door.

title: Jersey Will Send Home Report Cards on Schools
description: Starting next fall, New Jersey parents will get a report card on the school as well as the children they send there, Gov. Thomas H. Kean and the state's Education Commissioner announced this week.

title: Deborah L. Stone Planning to Wed
description: Deborah Lynn Stone and Daniel J. Grossman, third-year law students at Duke University, are planning an August wedding, the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Michael B. Stone of Atlanta, have announced. Mr. Grossman is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sanford Grossman of Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: For Panama, Old U.S. Ties Still Run Deep
description: When he was a little boy, the lawyer's mother often bounced him on her knee and described life here before the United States built the Panama Canal.

title: CLASS ACTS II
description: A few weeks back, we tossed off an informal classification of top California wines based - as was the famous 1855 Bordeaux classification -mostly on track record. The wineries that made the cut: Beaulieu, Beringer, Caymus, Clos du Val, Chalone, Diamond Creek, Grgich Hills, Heitz, Inglenook, Mayacamas, Stag's Leap, Robert Mondavi and Ridge.

title: Iona Merges With Elizabeth Seton College
description: A new charter for Iona College, recognizing its consolidation with Elizabeth Seton College under the Iona name, has been approved by the New York State Board of Regents.

title: Question Of the Week; Can The Yanks Use Guidry And John?
description: Not if the intention is to win the 1989 American League East title.

title: Islanders Remain On a Hot Streak
description: For a moment, Brent Sutter felt almost nostalgic about the victory, and not just because he was the Islander who scored the game-winning goal.

title: What If Shoreham Doesn't Open?
description: Re Barry Edelson's ''Shoreham Evacuation: Like the Blizzard of '86?'': Mr. Edelson raises the possibility that Long Islanders will behave in an irrational manner if there is a nuclear accident at the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: Jeffrey Cosiol Wed in Pennsylvania To Dr. Paulat-Adams, a Psychologist
description: The marriage of Dr. Kristine Paulat-Adams, the daughter of the late Dr. Robert J. Paulat of Narragansett, R.I., and the late Joanna Paulat Turk of Buffalo, to Jeffrey Cosiol, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jaime Cosiol of San Jose, Costa Rica, took place yesterday. The ceremony was performed at Appleford, a historic mansion in Villanova, Pa., by Mayor Jonathan W. Flint of Malvern, Pa.

title: Review/Revue; A Trove of Songs From Micki Grant
description: Few theater composers can claim as broad a stylistic grasp as Micki Grant, whose body of work is being celebrated in a new revue, ''Step Into My World,'' at the Amas Repertory Theater.

title: Separate Ways
description: Vietnam is seeking American tourists and trade, and the Presidency is becoming a dim memory for Democrats. And now Jane Fonda and Tom Hayden are saying it's over for them, too. When they were married in 1973, Ms. Fonda and Mr. Hayden formed a union emblematic of the antiwar movement and the pop-leftist politics that grew out of the Summer of Love. She visited Hanoi in wartime and was indicted by the right; he visited Chicago for the 1968 convention and was indicted by the Government, as were Abbie Hoffman and others of the Chicago Seven. Now he is a California state legislator (and considering a run for state insurance commissioner), she is in the aerobics business, and together they are 100 years old. Last week they announced they were ready to be apart, calling it a trial separation.

title: The Public Ordeal of Ehrlich Bober
description: When Ehrlich Bober & Company, a small but high-flying municipal bond house, raised $8 million in an initial public offering in late 1986, the thought was to use the money to expand the business it had been building for nearly two decades.

title: U.S. Panel Warns of Transport Ship Shortage
description: A Presidential commission has warned that the country is dangerously short of the transport ships it would need in a major war and has proposed a 10-year, $13 billion construction program to start filling the gap.

title: Death Rattle for a Dated Industry
description: From Washington to Wall Street, and increasingly in the halls of academe, a growing chorus of economists and other financial experts is arguing that there is little justification for a separate savings and loan industry.

title: Understanding Homosexuality
description: To the Editor:

title: On Thin Ice
description: To the Editor:

title: ONCE THEY WERE EVERYWHERE
description: THE BEAR HUNTER'S CENTURY By Paul Schullery. Illustrated. 252 pp. New York: Dodd, Mead & Company. $19.95.

title: The No Generation: A Modern Glossary
description: WHEN the Me Generation came along, I knew instinctively that it would affect primarily Them, and when the Now Generation was announced, I was still working on the day before yesterday. With the onset of the No Generation, I am hopelessly out of touch. It appears we are living in a society whose parameters are defined by negatives, bringing out the worst in us all. To wit:

title: High-Powered Computers - Not Tools for Scientists Alone
description: Long a technology confined to national research labs and defense contractors, supercomputers are breaking out of the laboratory and into the corporate computer room. A growing number of companies are depending on supercomputers to perform tasks once handled by mainframes.

title: Agency Protests Flights Over Adirondack Park
description: The Adirondack Park Agency, a New York State regulatory body, criticized the United States Air Force Friday for scheduling low-level flights over the park.

title: Teacher Responds To Her Critics
description: Regarding my article, ''Failing in Teaching'' (Opinion page, Jan. 1), I agree completely with my critics: There are many noble and dedicated people in the teaching profession. Now that teachers have heaped sufficient praise upon themselves (Letters to the Connecticut Editor, Jan. 22), perhaps we can discuss some unpleasant facts:

title: The First - Fearful - Hundred Days
description: Thirty of President Bush's first hundred days are gone, yet he still has no government capable of managing foreign affairs and national security.

title: Rushdie's Publisher Assails 'Censorship by Terrorism'
description: A spokesman for Viking Penguin yesterday condemned ''censorship by terrorism and intimidation,'' and he coupled his remarks with criticism of the major bookstore chains that have pulled ''The Satanic Verses'' from their shelves.

title: IN COLD DNA
description: LEAD: THE BLOODING By Joseph Wambaugh. 288 pp. New York: A Perigord Press Book/ William Morrow & Company. $18.95.

title: Q and A
description: Mortgage for a Veteran

title: Israeli Troops Prove Newcomers to Riot Control
description: Many Israeli Army officers feel that the Palestinian uprising in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip is subsiding, and they say that their soldiers can cope with any major new outbreak of violence.

title: Farming the Wilds Of Middlefield
description: As I read Bill Earls's essay, ''More Feed, More Line, More Wood: Down (and Out) on the Farm'' (Opinion page, Jan. 22), I'm convinced of one thing; namely, the more things change, the more they stay the same.

title: Chocolate Pots Brewed Ingenuity
description: Only minutes into ''The Way of the World,'' William Congreve's Restoration play set in a fashionable London chocolate shop in 1770, a leading character orders: ''Bring me some chocolate.''

title: Trail Blazers Dismiss Coach
description: The Portland Trail Blazers dismissed Coach Mike Schuler today and replaced him on an interim basis with an assistant coach, Rick Adelman. Schuler, 48 years old, was named the National Basketball Association's coach of the year in his first season at Portland, in 1986-87, when the Blazers had a 49-33 record. Last season, the team was 53-29, but this season it is struggling with a record of 25-22.

title:
IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut;
Shaping a Marina to Meet Ecological Needs
description: LEAD: WHEN the Half Moon Bay Yacht Club - part of a $90 million, 342-unit condominium development in Croton-on-Hudson at Haverstraw Bay, where Henry Hudson dropped anchor in 1609 - opens next May with the first 162 of a projected 300 slips in place, there will be significant changes from the original plans to address environmental concerns of Hudson Sloop

title: Notre Dame School Plans Move to the Village
description: The Notre Dame School, the 77-year-old Upper West Side high school that was to close in June, has found new life in the East Village. The girls school will move to 104 St. Marks Place, near Tompkins Square Park, according to a letter sent to parents and alumnae last week.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: MUTATION. By Robin Cook. (Putnam, $18.95.) Robin Cook has written a bad book. It's not a bad book because it's badly written, although it is. It's a bad book because Dr. Cook, the author of numerous medical thrillers, shows so much disregard for his readers' intelligence, expecting them to keep reading about the antics of characters so unperceptive that no one can possibly care about them past the first hundred pages.

title: Outdoors; Helping Salmon to Return
description: Although the number of fish that returned to the rivers of New England to spawn last year was disappointingly low, Alan Erdossy, coordinator of Trout Unlimited's Atlantic Salmon Task Force, is not depressed.

title: Gramercy Park
description: To the Editor:

title: Pakistan Taking Steps to Modernize Its Air Force By BARBARA CROSSETTE
description: The Pakistani Air Force, concerned about the possibility of Afghan or Soviet air attacks to the west and wary of the military power of India to the east, is modernizing its inventory of fighter and trainer aircraft, according to diplomats and news reports here.

title: Past as Prologue
description: ''This gives me chills.'' says Joseph Abboud, the New York men's-wear designer, who has been leafing through a volume of Norman Rockwell illustrations. He finds what he is after, a 1940's Saturday Evening Post cover, whose subject, he admits, never fails to stir him. Rockwell's depiction of a war veteran turned scholar is abrim with nostalgic detail. Propped on the sill of his dormitory window, the still-youngish student glances up from his reading to take in the autumn afternoon. His honorable discharge is framed on the wall behind him, and a helmet hangs above the window. He wears a sweatshirt and chinos, and the pipe he smokes gives him a suave, contemplative air.

title: Wisconsin Routs Illinois With Defense
description: Trent Jackson scored 27 points today as Wisconsin jumped to a 14-point halftime lead and crushed No. 5 Illinois, 72-52, clinching its first winning season in 9 years.

title: Former Leader of Klan Narrowly Wins Contest in Louisiana
description: A former grand wizard of the Ku Klux Klan, narrowly defeated his opponent to win a seat today in the Louisiana Legislature after a campaign peppered with charges of racism.

title: 5 Held in Plot to Forge 7,000 Bank Machine Cards
description: Five people have been charged with conspiring to steal millions of dollars from the Bank of America with automatic teller cards forged on the accounts of more than 7,000 customers.

title: THE TWISTED ROAD TO AUSCHWITZ
description: WHY DID THE HEAVENS NOT DARKEN? The ''Final Solution'' in History. By Arno J. Mayer. 492 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $27.95.

title:
FILM;
For Mike Leigh, It's Rue Britannia
description: LEAD: While there are few absolute certainties in this increasingly chaotic world, it's fairly safe to assume that Margaret Thatcher is not a big fan of Mike Leigh's film ''High Hopes.'' It's not just that the film's protagonists - a shaggy, bohemian working-class couple named Cyril and Shirley - have a large cactus called Thatcher, or that, on a wall of their small, shabby flat hangs a poster bearing two pictures of the Prime Minister and the caption ''Crime Wave.

title: Tax Imported Oil?
description: To the Editor:

title: CORE CURRICULUM: OTHER OPTIONS
description: Out-of-school people who missed a core curriculum during their formal education may do the reading for Fairleigh's core (or any other core) through their local public library. Most libraries own most of the books, and any books not immediately available can easily and quickly be obtained through New Jersey's Interlibrary Loan Network.

title: Steinbrenner Wins U.S.O.C. Post
description: George Steinbrenner's involvement in sports expanded today when the United States Olympic Committee house of delegates elected him as one of three vice presidents to serve through 1992.

title: In Boston, Portrait of Mass Murderer as Artist
description: Cheery cartoon colors and Walt Disney characters dominate an exhibition of eight paintings that was opened here, the organizer says, to challenge taboos.

title: Unique Instrumental Trio Challenges Composers
description: WHEN the musical trio Fidelio formed two years ago in Hartford, its members had a problem. ''There's almost no existing music for our combination,'' said Harry Clark, the group's cellist.

title: 'Rachel River': Long Journey From Dream to Screen
description: SO YOU WANT TO MAKE A MOVIE? Most people at one time or another dream about it, but that's all they do, particularly if they don't happen to have gone to film school, worked at one of the major studios and eventually made their way up to director, which can take some time.

title:
FOCUS: Colorado Springs;
Annexing a Ranch Brings 50% Growth
description: LEAD: ON a scale unusual even by Western standards, Colorado Springs recently increased its size by nearly half. It annexed the 25,060-acre Banning-Lewis Ranch, a 14-mile-long, 4-mile-wide expanse of sagebrush and scrub oak along its eastern border. The next-largest annexation was of 9,000 acres in 1986.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE BRIDGE By Emily Cheney Neville. Illustrated by Ronald Himler. Unpaged. New York: Harper & Row. $13.95. (Ages 4 to 8)

title: Colt Drops Suit Against Los Angeles Weapon Ban
description: Colt Industries has dropped its Federal lawsuit against the city's new ordinance banning possession and sale of semiautomatic assault weapons, the city attorney said Friday.

title: CRIME
description: Thomas H. Cook triumphs at teaching an old dog some new tricks in FLESH AND BLOOD (Putnam, $17.95). When we met the series hero (in ''Sacrificial Ground''), Frank Clemons was a homicide detective working for the Atlanta police and nursing an obsession with a teen-age murder victim. Clemons has since turned private eye and relocated to New York, where he is again fixated on a homicide victim. This time, the murdered woman's fascinating past justifies his obsession.

title: Court Denies Club's Request For Names of Rifle Owners
description: New York State's highest court has issued a ruling that could curtail efforts by groups to use Freedom of Information laws to obtain lists of potential members from the government.

title: Brazilian Is Looking to Japan To Link Amazon to the Pacific
description: When Flaviano Melo, the young Governor of Acre, holds up his favorite map, it shows a new highway stretching west from the Amazon rain forest, across the Peruvian Andes and down to the Pacific coast. There it joins a giant arrow pointing to Japan.

title: Unintended Satire On Intellectual Failings
description: Thank you so much for printing Karen Cooney's article, ''Failing in Teaching,'' (Opinion page, Jan. 1). It clearly illustrated one of the purposes of mass communication: to involve the reading public through a clever rhetorical move. The letters that appeared in response to Ms. Cooney's article (Jan. 22) were so strongly worded and heartfelt that I was compelled to read the original.

title: Review/Dance; A Soloist of Many Moods Astonishes Even Herself
description: What's she doing now? Whatever will she do next? Ellen Cornfield raised such questions in two quirky solos she presented as part of a program of dances and video works on Thursday night at the Dia Art Foundation.

title: FICTION
description: SERIOUS LIVING. By Tom Lorenz. (Viking, $17.95.) Tom Lorenz, the author of the highly praised 1980 novel ''Guys Like Us,'' has returned to print with a rewarding coming-of-age story set in Chicago. ''Serious Living'' is the comic but also poignant tale of 21-year-old Ritchie Kohler, high school graduate and truly ordinary guy. The younger of Big Joe Kohler's two sons, Ritchie seems so unlikely to succeed that his father has groomed him since childhood to take over the family's shabby corner grocery. Bored to death with this fate, Ritchie strains his already tense relationship with his father through on-the-job antics - and when he finally breaks free, he heads for the Oasis, a swank nightclub near the airport that looks ''like a sheik's palace.'' The club is run by his old friend Mars, a guy with ''definite criminal tendencies.'' Soon Ritchie is rooming with Mars, tending the Oasis bar and scoring with women like never before. The high life is his until he unwittingly causes the firing of an Oasis waitress, an aspiring torch singer named Louise. In this cynical yet determined woman, a single mother damaged by men, Mr. Lorenz has wrought his most complex character. And with her growing attraction to Ritchie - and his growing responsibility for both her and her young son Joey - both Ritchie and the novel deepen. He is now a man taking care of others, remembering how the widowed Big Joe once cared for him. ''Serious Living,'' at its best, is reminiscent of the work of Anne Tyler; it's a novel that explores the humor, pain and affection lurking in even the messiest of domestic relationships.

title: Weight Costs Woman $500
description: A woman who was given the option of losing 100 pounds to wipe out a fine on a marijuana conviction has failed to do so and must pay $500. Judge Michael Fisher told the woman, Tina Usinger, last year that she could reduce her fine by $5 for each pound she lost, but when she returned to court this week, she still weighed 265 pounds. Ms. Usinger's probation officer had recommended the option, saying that with a better self-image she would be less likely to turn to crime.

title: More on Magazines
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: It is only poetic justice that Nina Wolff (''Sneezing Beauty in a Raccoon Coat,'' Jan. 29) should have to suffer physical discomfort from wearing her new garment. After all, many innocent animals had to suffer the tortures of the damned to satisfy her desire for glamour and status.

title: Votive Figures for Collectors
description: JUST 50 years ago, almost every Catholic church in Italy had an area set aside on one of its interior walls for displaying ex votos, small flat silver figures giving visible testimony of the initiation or fulfillment of a believer's vow (voto).

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: PLATITUDES. By Trey Ellis. (Vintage Contemporaries, Paper, $6.95.) Trey Ellis's ''Platitudes'' is a jazzy scatting around the traditional novel - and when it works, it works very, very well. The book is about a writer and the problems he has writing a book about two teen-agers named Earle and Dorothy.

title: Kimberly Waldorf to Wed Brian K. Mercer March 18
description: The engagement of Kimberly Gail Waldorf to Brian Krick Mercer has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Helmuth Waldorf of Brookville, L.I. A March 18 wedding is planned.

title: Manager-Broker Tie No Longer Binds
description: FOR many years, a real estate brokerage's path to commissions on the sales of cooperative apartments was built on contracts to manage the buildings. That insider's edge led many firms to serve as managing agents for New York apartment houses at little or no profit, or even at a loss, as long as fat brokerage fees were coming in.

title: DATA UPDATE: February 19, 1989
Make Federal Subsidy a Last Resort
description: President Eisenhower's warning about the dangers of a military-industrial complex continues to have relevance for succeeding generations. The issue has become increasingly urgent as the United States struggles to adjust to the challenges of a new internationally competitive environment.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: SELECTED LETTERS OF STEPHANE MALLARME. Edited and translated by Rosemary Lloyd. (University of Chicago, $27.50.) A life telescoped into letters, written only in moments of leisure or exhaustion, naturally is distorted. This collection of letters by Stephane Mallarme, the author of ''L'Apres-Midi d'un Faune'' and ''Herodiade'' and one of the most influential poets of 19th-century France, portrays him as witty and kind, but a constant complainer and a flatterer.

title: An Emergence of Political Will on Acid Rain
description: THE question of what to do about acid rain has pitted region against region and produced an angry stalemate in Congress for the better part of a decade. Now, with President Bush backing action and with a realignment of forces on Capitol Hill, a revised Clean Air Act with strong acid rain controls is a distinct likelihood, perhaps as early as this year.

title: Images of Coney Island Coming to the Whitney
description: ''Coney Island of the Mind: Images of Coney Island in Art and Popular Culture 1890-1960'' will be at the Whitney Museum of American Art, downtown, at Federal Reserve Plaza, from Wednesday through April 21. The work of painters and photographers like Joseph Stella, Margaret Bourke-White and Diane Arbus is to be included among the approximately 90 paintings, drawings, prints and photographs. The exhibition will depict Coney Island in its heyday and its decline. The museum is on the lower concourse level at 2 Federal Plaza, 33 Maiden Lane, at Nassau Street. There is no admission; the museum is open Monday through Friday from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Information: 943-5655.

title: Casting a Line in New Zealand
description: AS the full spring moon climbed over the silhouetted Livingstone Mountains, the lakeshore quieted. Under the cover of darkness, Fiordland's Lake Te Anau had been alive with brown and rainbow trout cruising the shallows. But, as if a light switch had been thrown, they stopped feeding and the elusive trout retreated to darker, deeper waters.

title: Within and Without, Disputes Rend a School
description: A dispute over a troubled Brooklyn elementary school has flared into a rancorous fight involving a principal who says he fears for his life, a local school board seeking to dismiss its superintendent and a new parent association that wants to topple the official one.

title: CLASSICAL
description: Mozart Piano Concertos No. 26 ''Coronation'' (K. 537) and No. 27 (K. 595) Mitsuko Uchida, piano. Jeffrey Tate, conductor. The English Chamber Orchestra. Philips 420 951.

title: RISING TO THE TOP
description: Debra Ponzek, a demure, methodical 27-year-old from Morristown, N.J., is the least known three-star chef in New York - a status achieved by design, not chance.

title: Informal Learning: A Sampling of the Spring Lectures
description: LEAD: THIS spring a varied selection of lectures around the county will provide many opportunities for informal learning. Notable professionals in the fields of literature, history, psychology, art and science will be visiting Westchester colleges and museums to share their knowledge - from tips on collecting folk art to recollections of life in China during the Cultural

title: Rustic Italian, With Sophistication
description: SMITHTOWN'S Casa Rustica is a champion among Italian restaurants on an island loaded with contenders. Some of the also-rans may be ritzier or have snappier service, but a look at the menu and a taste of the food separate Casa Rustica from the pack.

title: Knicks' Streak Now 18 At Home
description: Individually, the night belonged to Gerald Wilkins. Collectively, it was another home victory for the Knicks as they easily defeated the injury-riddled Nets, 125-115, to run their Madison Square Garden winning streak to 18 in a row.

title: Correction
description: An article last week about Joyce Copleman's role as a member of the Lawrence Township Planning Board was outdated in describing her tenure. She recently lost a bid for reappointment to the board.

title: Car Theft Fraud Rampant at Nassau Shopping Mall
description: LEAD: WHEN cars are stolen here, the police hunt the victims of the crime. That's because the victims are sometimes the thieves.

title: County Warns of 'Devastating' Mental Health Cuts
description: A PROGRAM of enhanced mental-health services that the state encouraged counties to develop in the years after World War II would be devastated if Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's proposed cuts in the state budget become law, said those who run the program in the county.

title: Q and A
description: Fear of Flying

title: U.S. LAWMAKERS SEE SLIM HOPE OF RAISE
description: When the public gets what it wants, it moves on to other things, as members of Congress have been reminded in their 10-day recess.

title: DATA BANK: February 19, 1989
Ordeal on I-80
description: WE'RE GOING TO hit,'' I called out to my two sons and my wife, Ann, once it became apparent that control of our station wagon was no longer in my hands but was governed instead by the transparent sheet of ice that had formed on Interstate 80 two miles from our exit. It would turn out to be our good fortune that we slammed into the concrete wall of the bridge on which we came to a rest rather than being in the left lane, where I had tried to maneuver the car as it slid a good 10 to 12 car lengths.

title: Somebody Up There Likes Billie and Heidi
description: Heaven will protect the working girl, but only up to a point.

title: Travel Jitters
description: To the Editor: ''Take it Easy! You're Going on Vacation'' by John Brannon Albright (Practical Traveler, Jan. 15) reminded me of some of the ways my husband and I relieve our travel jitters.

title: A Chilling Idea: Tide of Tourists At South Pole
description: ''SKI SOUTH POLE,'' say the T-shirts, ''two inches of powder, 10,000 feet of base.''

title: Computers Are Starting to Seem More Like Living Things
description: IN her recent book ''AIDS and Its Metaphors,'' Susan Sontag reflects on how the sudden emergence of computer viruses evokes many of modern society's most primal fears. Just as AIDS has unnerved people by conjuring up earlier visions of human plagues, she suggests, the advent of the computer virus is undermining the public's faith in the information revolution and changing the way people think about computers, as organisms rather than machines.

title: New Hot Line for Teen-Agers
description: LEAD: THE teen-age years have always presented difficulties, but perhaps never more so than today, with drugs, peer pressure and AIDS. Loneliness and the lack of someone to talk with can be the toughest part, young people say.

title: Jerome Alper, Lawyer, 91
description: Jerome Alper, a lawyer in Newark for more than 50 years, died Tuesday at the Van Dyk Manor in Montclair, N.J. He was 91 years old and lived in Montclair.

title: An Open Letter to My Two Mothers
description: I HAVE always known that I was adopted. It is a constant in my life, like being left-handed, an accident of fate over which I had no control at all. I don't know what it feels like to have Aunt Jessie's smile, Uncle Jack's mean temper or Grandma's legs: my smile, temper and legs are mine alone and although I am aware that somewhere out there the matching set exists I am not constantly reminded of them. This is, in many ways, comforting.

title: Dr. Lori Beth Zimmerman, Internist, Is Married to Scott Richard Benson
description: Dr. Lori Beth Zimmerman and Scott Richard Benson were married last evening at the Harmonie Club in New York. Rabbi Miriam Shapero and Cantor Jacob Yaron officiated.

title: Aouita Leaving
description: A matchup of Marcus O'Sullivan and Said Aouita in the mile did not materialize Friday night at The Los Angeles Times meet in California, and it will not happen this indoor season. After Aouita won the mile in 3 minutes 54.99 seconds and O'Sullivan finished second in the 3,000 meters in 7:51.56, Aouita announced that he was cutting short his United States tour and returning home to Morocco. Doug Padilla won the 3,000 in 7:51.33.

title: Dixieland Brass A Winner Again
description: At least until Easy Goer makes his seasonal debut next month, Dixieland Brass is clearly the best 3-year-old in Florida. The colt won the Hutcheson Stakes by six lengths last month, then returned today to run down Mercedes Won in deep stretch to win the $130,000 Fountain of Youth Stakes at Gulfstream Park.

title: Lyme Disease Bills in Congress
description: SPURRED by growing concern over the spread of Lyme disease, Northeastern legislators, led by Representative George J. Hochbrueckner of Long Island, have introduced companion measures to channel $10.5 million into fighting the tick-borne infection.

title: 3 Schools Reach Last Round in National Competition
description: LEAD: THREE secondary schools in Westchester have to make it through only one more elimination round before being named among the best in the country in their category this year by the United States Department of Education.

title: Patriotic and Gothic
description: French Gala

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Feb. 5 about Cedar Key, Fla., misstated the telephone number for the Island Hotel. It is 904-543-5111.

title: An Auction to Honor Our First President
description: ON Wednesday, George Washington's 257th birthday, the Coin Galleries of Stack's, 123 West 57th Street, New York City, will close out its mail auction of United States and foreign coins. In the auction, and on view 10:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Tuesday, are several Washington pieces.

title: Old Stones Surface, in Patios
description: Ancient paving stones that were removed and stored during restoration of Florence's historic Piazza della Signoria have turned up in paths and patios at luxury villas, judicial officials said today. They said magistrates were investigating four council employees and six homeowners in connection with the discovery.

title: Miss Cabot Is Engaged
description: Stephanie Mariette Cabot, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Powell M. Cabot of Greenwich, Conn., is engaged to Marcus Lovell-Smith, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Lovell-Smith of Taunton, Somerset, England, the future bride's parents have announced. The couple plan to marry in June.

title: After Losing 'Sludge War,' New York Seeks Alternative to Sea Dumping
description: Four months after the enactment of a Federal law banning sludge dumping at sea by 1992, New York City is exploring a range of alternatives, including transforming sludge into artificial soil, injecting it deep into the earth and burying it beneath the ocean floor.

title: An Open Letter to President Bush
description: Dear Mr. President:

title: New York's Confusing War on AIDS
description: DESPITE the need for a united front against the AIDS epidemic, fragmentation and feuding among city and state leaders have so far prevented concerted action in New York, which has a fourth of the nation's caseload.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Taos
description: Anchored by the massive adobe landmarks of St. Francis de Assisi church on the south and by Taos Indian Pueblo on the north, Taos seems comfortably settled into winter. Cozy interiors are a specialty here in New Mexico's high desert country, with beehive-shaped kiva fireplaces, Indian rugs, wooden beams overhead - and the sprinkling of hot tubs to be expected in a ski town. But Taosenos also appreciate the outdoors; proximity to nature is what keeps many of them here. That, along with a blend of Indian, Spanish and Anglo cultures - and some of the nation's finest skiing - also brings an influx of winter visitors.

title: Behind the Plight Of the Stranded Ukrainian Troupe
description: The needlessly dramatic plight of the Donetsk Ballet from the Soviet Union, stranded in Baltimore after its American producers ran out of funds, is part of a tangled and cautionary tale. United States-Soviet cultural exchange will now have to take into greater account the differences that exist between our two societies.

title: Deaths Force Rethinking of Sea Lion Plan
description: A program to capture sea lions in Puget Sound and move them down the coast is being re-evaluated after two of the first four animals died.

title: We Must Act Locally for Housing
description: WHEN I was my daughter's age, I used to enjoy sketching room plans for my house-to-be. (I think this followed hot on the heels of fashion layouts and bridal dress.) Usually the rooms were spacious and numerous, with no regard for such construction details as plumbing, insulation and electricity. The houses had conservatories and morning rooms, and money was no object.

title: Faith Frankel Plans to Marry in May
description: Faith J. Frankel, a senior financial analyst at Macmillan Inc., and Dr. Howard I. Levy, a physician, plan to marry May 20.

title: Let's Stop Worrying About the Budget Deficit; For Capital Budgeting
description: To the Editor:

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: DEAF THEATER COMEDY The National Theater of the Deaf will give two performances of Philip de Broca's ''King of Hearts,'' based on the French film of the same name. A romantic comedy originally released in the 1960's, the movie has become a cult classic.

title: Light on the Subject
description: ORDINARILY, this is the time of year when I would be writing about how to adjust your exposure when photographing snow or how to carry your camera while cross-country skiing. But the weather has conspired against these topics.

title: Alejandra Aleman Marries Xavier Burillo Azcarraga
description: Alejandra Aleman, the daughter of Karin Doedl Aleman of Acapulco, Mexico, and Mexico City, and the late Miguel Aleman, a former President of Mexico, was married yesterday to Xavier Burillo Azcarraga, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexandro Burillo of Mexico City.

title: 13 Families Homeless After Chinatown Fire
description: Thirteen families were left homeless last night after a three-alarm fire heavily damaged a six-story building in Chinatown, fire officials said.

title: A New 'Salome' at the Met: Brutal and Corrupt, With a Feeling of Twilight
description: If you are planning to attend the Metropolitan Opera's new production of Strauss's ''Salome,'' which opens tomorrow evening, don't expect to see such familiar trappings as palm trees, ancient robes, a brightly shining moon, or even the cistern in which John the Baptist is held prisoner. Prepare instead for a glassy, high-rise palace with Mesopotamian columns and architectural designs drawn on the outer walls; a fire escape leading into a hole, meant to serve as the prison; and characters whose dress runs the gamut from rococo to punk.

title: Guard Scores 65 For Evansville
description: Scott Haffner scored 65 points - tied for sixth-most in a Division I game -and led Evansville past Dayton, 109-83, in a Midwestern Collegiate Conference game today.

title: Lucky Number?
description: He has won 73 Winston Cup races, but none at Daytona International Speedway. So Darrell Waltrip is hoping the matching numbers are a favorable omen for today's Daytona 500, when No. 17 will make his 17th attempt to finish first. ''If I win, I'm gonna spike my helmet in the winner's circle, and then I'm gonna do the Ickey Shuffle,'' Waltrip said yesterday. He will start in the front row today with Ken Schrader, who won the pole position.(AP)

title: 'THE WHITEFELLAS DON'T UNDERSTAND'
description: MY PLACE By Sally Morgan. 360 pp. New York: Seaver Books/Henry Holt & Company. $19.95.

title: 'Trans-Hudson Economy': Let's Maintain The Growth
description: THE end of 1988 completed a dozen years of uninterrupted growth for metropolitan New Jersey and New York. Though the rate of growth may moderate, there is every reason for confidence that 1989 will bring continued prosperity to the region.

title: A Mother's Mission for the Blind
description: LEAD: CARYL GOLDSTEIN'S first son, Howard, was born 35 years ago, and when he was 8 weeks old, he was diagnosed as being blind. Exploratory surgery later revealed he had separated retinas. The surgeon said there was a one-in-a-million chance of a reoccurrence in another child, but Mrs. Goldstein's second son, David, was born with the same condition two and a half years later.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Becker Beats McEnroe: Top-seeded Boris Becker of West Germany defeated third-seeded John McEnroe, 6-2, 6-3, yesterday in the semifinals of the Stella Artois indoor tournament in Milan, Italy. In the final today, Becker will meet Aleksandr Volkov of the Soviet Union, who defeated Eric Jelen of West Germany by 6-2, 2-6, 7-6. in the other semifinal match. (AP) Graf Moves Into Final: Steffi Graf of West Germany overcame a second-set scare yesterday and defeated Natalya Zvereva of the Soviet Union, 6-3, 6-4, to advance to the final of the Virginia Slims of Washington tournament in Fairfax, Va. After notching her second service break of the second set, to pull to 4-4, Zvereva took a 40-15 lead in the ninth game. But Graf rallied to win the game, then held serve to improve to 11-0 this year. Graf will face Zina Garrison, who advanced when Monica Seles of Yugoslavia withdrew with a sprained ankle. (AP) Kriek Tops Chang: Johan Kriek was able to call upon his power game when he needed it most as he beat Michael Chang, 6-1, 1-6, 6-3, in the semifinals of the $415,000 Volvo Indoor Championship at Memphis. In the final, Kriek will face Brad Gilert, who beat Kevin Curren, 7-6, 6-4.(AP) Golf Australian Grabs Lead: Steve Elkington of Australia took a two-stroke lead over Greg Twiggs after three rounds of the San Diego Open in La Jolla, Calif. Elkington offset three bogeys with six birdies and an eagle for a five-under-par 67. He has a three-day total of 200.(AP) Hill Ahead by a Stroke: Dave Hill shot a three-under-par 69 to take a one-stroke lead after two rounds of the $300,000 Suncoast Classic, a PGA Senior Tour event in Tampa, Fla. Hill is at 137, a shot ahead of Chi Chi Rodriguez, Bob Charles and Doug Sanders. The first-round leader, Don Massengale, shot double-bogeys on the 15th and 16th holes and finished with a 74 for 140, tying for fifth place with Miller Barber. (AP) Victory for Turner: Sherri Turner fired a six-under-par 66 to win the $300,000 Hawaiian Ladies Open in Honolulu. Turner shot a bogey-free round to finish at 11-under-par 205, four strokes ahead of Sara Ann McGetrick.(AP) Boxing Brown Keeps Welterweight Title: Simon Brown of Washington stopped Jorge Maysonet of Puerto Rico at 2:01 of the third round yesterday to retain his International Boxing Federation welterweight title. The fight, in Budapest, was the first pro bout in a Warsaw Pact country since World War II. Brown is 28-1; Maysonet is 19-3. (AP) Nordic Skiing Soviet Racer Is First: Vladimir Smirnov of the Soviet Union won the men's 30-kilometer classical style event by 6.7 seconds yesterday at the world championships in Lahti, Finland. Smirnov's winning time was 1 hour 24 minutes 56.9 seconds. Vegard Ulvang of Norway was second in 1:25.03.6. (AP) Alpine Skiing Swede Wins Super Giant Slalom: Lars-Boerje Eriksson of Sweden won a men's World Cup super giant slalom in Aspen, Colo., yesterday by three-hundredths of a second over Markus Wasmeier of West Germany. It was the first triumph by a Swedish skier in a speed race, and was also the 22-year-old Eriksson's first World Cup victory. Eriksson, whose best previous World Cup finish was a sixth in a downhill race last season, was timed in 1 minute 17.98 seconds. Wasmeier's time was 1:18.01 and Helmut Mayer of Austria was third in 1:18.29.(AP) Figini First in Downhill: Michela Figini and Maria Walliser of Switzerland finished first and second yesterday in a World Cup race in Lake Louise, Alberta. The victory increased Figini's lead over Walliser in the World Cup downhill standing to 24 points, 126 to 102, with two downhills remaining. (AP) College Basketball Milestone for Seton Hall Player: Geraldine Saintilus of Seton Hall yesterday became the second woman in Big East Conference history to score 1,000 points in her career. The 5-foot-10-inch senior guard from Staten Island reached the milestone on a layup with 1 minute 46 seconds to play in Seton Hall's 63-37 victory over Georgetown. Horse Racing A. M. Swinger Wins Whirlaway: A.M. Swinger, the favorite, won the featured race at Aqueduct yesterday. Ridden by Chris Antley, A. M. Swinger finished one length in front of Militron. A. M. Swinger paid $5 for $2 to win. (AP) Track and Field Three Events for McCord: Tamyka McCord won three events yesterday in the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association girls indoor championships at Fordham. McCord, a senior at the Academy of St. Joseph's in Brentwood, L.I., took the 55-meter dash in 7.1 seconds, the 300 meters in 42.7 seconds and the 600 meters in 1 minute 36.2 seconds, a meet mark.

title: Getting Medical Aid In the Caribbean
description: IF you are seriously sick on a Caribbean island, one expert says, the best piece of medical equipment a hospital can use to help you is the next airplane out.

title: The British Are Coming, With Song and Gadgetry
description: THIS is American Music Month, but the British are coming. Expect visits this week from the composers Thea Musgrave and Nicholas Maw, plus two unusual vocal ensembles: Electric Phoenix and the King's Singers.

title: POSTINGS: Theater Conversion; Chico, Harpo, Groucho, Condo
description: The 80-year-old RKO Keith's Prospect Theater in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn, where many actors and vaudevillians started their careers, is itself taking on a new role. The 500-seat theater, which once featured the Marx Brothers, the Three Stooges, Burns and Allen and other stars of pre-electronic entertainment, is being converted with an existing supermarket into the 19-unit Park Plaza Condominium.

title: A Dirty War Comes Home to the Soviet Union
description: IN the final scene of a new documentary called ''Wound,'' dozens of young Soviet war invalids hobble down a beach to the sea, tossing their crude wooden crutches into a pile as they splash into the waves. A viewer recoils at first from the unsightly stumps of legs, and then asks, as the filmmakers intend the audience to ask, and as one of the damaged veterans has already asked the camera: ''Za chto?'' - ''For what?''

title: Safaris
description: To the Editor: Safaris in Kenya and Tanzania are often very expensive, as you highlighted on Dec. 4. Many of your readers might, therefore, be interested to learn that South Africa offers the same safari experience for a substantially lower price. For example, the cost of a night in Kruger National Park ranges from approximately $20 to $40 a person a night. One can stay in a luxurious private game park for as little as $150 a person a night, including all meals and the services of rangers and trackers.

title:
TV VIEW;
Dreamlike Tale Recalls the Nazi Nightmare
description: LEAD: Whether exploring or exploiting the horrors of World War II, television drama is at a disadvantage. Certainly the Holocaust cannot be conveyed by obviously healthy actors whose brightly capped teeth keep twinkling through their makeup. The mere effort is generally embarrassing. The story of the death camps is perhaps told most effectively when approached indirectly, through individual, contained incidents - ''The Diary of Anne Frank,'' for example, or John Hersey's ''The Wall.

title: Elizabeth Walker Weds
description: Elizabeth Anne Walker, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John R. Walker of Waterloo, Iowa, and Longboat Key, Fla., was married last evening in New York to Dr. Steven Harris Schoenberger, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Stanford L. Schoenberger of Livingston, N.J. Jean S. Kotkin, a leader of the Ethical Culture Society in New York, performed the ceremony at the Four Seasons. Mrs. Schoenberger is a real estate associate at 680 Fifth Avenue Associates in New York. The bridegroom is a urologist in New London, Conn.

title: Bass to Bass
description: It is always comforting when things come full circle. Ashes to ashes, dust to dust, bass to bass. This thought is prompted by news that a stretch of Manhattan's deteriorated West Side Highway is about to assume a new identity - as an ocean reef for sea bass and other marine life.

title: How 'Managing' Is Managing
description: A MANAGER IS NOT as big a deal as an >executive. If you do not understand this, you will never get ahead in business or in the media.

title: Sports of The Times; Pop Gates Earned His Grits
description: At age 71, he's as lean as the backboard pole in the playground below his fifth-floor Harlem apartment. But arthritis had Pop Gates sitting on pillows on the long curved couch in his living room. Asked if he would rather move to a favorite chair, he smiled.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Penn Valley, Pa.;
Conversion Near Main Line
description: LEAD: A LARGE rental property is being converted into a condominium in this well-to-do western suburb of Philadelphia. It is one of the few major conversion attempts outside central Philadelphia in the 80's, a period of numerous conversions of luxury rentals nationwide, but not in the Philadelphia region.

title: Good Reading On Plants and Design
description: LAST call to go over seed and nursery catalogues and mail orders for woody plants, perennials, groundcovers and seeds.
