Prune mature grapevines, fruit trees, large shade trees, overgrown shrubs and hedges. Start indoors seed of impatiens, celosias, snapdragons, begonias, geraniums, petunias and coleus. Worth Reading

title: HIGHER EDUCATION-THE REAL CRISIS
description: The problem for research universities like Columbia is not, as Michael Sovern contends, finding more money, and his suggestion that professors are going to start leaving these secure havens for rewards outside is laughable. A low-level opening in the humanities produces 80 to 100 applications, even in a second-rate university. Most universities already have staggering endowments, nourished by ever-increasing tuition revenues, and professors today are both underworked and overpaid.

title: Employee Rights In the C.I.A.
description: THE director of the Central Intelligence Agency has always had broad authority to discharge any employee deemed a security risk, and that authority was acknowledged last year by the United States Supreme Court. But, the Court added, the power is not unrestrained.

title: East Hartford Drops School Drug-Test Plan
description: LEAD: AN East Hartford Board of Education subcommittee has scuttled a proposed voluntary drug-testing program for high school students in extracurricular activities. In unanimously rejecting the proposal Jan. 30, the three-member policy and audit subcommittee cited legal concerns and questioned how effective the screening would be, among other problems.

title: WHERE EVERYONE IS FAMOUS
description: NEBRASKA Stories. By Ron Hansen. 193 pp. New York: Atlantic Monthly Press. $16.95.

title: Myers Absent From Met Camp
description: Randy Myers was back home in Vancouver, Wash., but 22 other pitchers and 6 catchers opened the Mets' 28th spring training camp today with a show of force and probably the best young arms in baseball.

title: The Rules Are From Washington, And the Refugees Are in Texas
description: THE smell of the border, the sweet, dirty aroma of the Rio Grande, stuck to two Nicaraguan teen-agers as they crawled toward a confusing encounter with the land of their dreams.

title: The Depth Of the Anger In Pakistan Tests Bhutto
description: PAKISTAN'S Prime Minister, Benazir Bhutto, should have come back from her first official visit abroad last week to a welcoming crowd.

title: Political Notes; Minority Groups Oppose Purge of Voter Rolls
description: On Friday, the Board of Elections is slated to mail letters to 300,000 New York City residents telling them that, as required by state law, they are being removed from the voter rolls because they have not voted in the last four elections. Each letter will include a new registration form and a postage-paid return envelope.

title: Schools Are Cleared in Assaults on Teachers
description: The state's highest court has ruled that New York City was not liable for injuries to two teachers assaulted on school grounds.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Marble Hill
description: EVER since Marble Hill was severed from the rest of Manhattan by the construction of the Harlem Ship Canal nearly a century ago, the 52-acre enclave has led an isolated existence. Its narrow, winding roads, lined with one- and two-family houses, give it the feel of a small village.

title: FLOATING A FEW PROPOSALS
description: COMMAND OF THE SEAS By John F. Lehman Jr. Illustrated. 464 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $21.95.

title: In Trouble, Papandreou Strikes Back
description: Hobbled by political scandals, wounded by jokes about his private life, plagued by doubts about his health, Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou has invoked the time-honored sports maxim that the best defense is a good offense.

title: POP/JAZZ
description: R.E.M.: 'Green' Warner Bros. 25795-1, all three formats.

title:
BODY AND MIND;
Chest Pains: What Do They Mean?
description: LEAD: THE PATIENT IS AN athletic, muscular policeman, 31 years old, with chest pain - a ''heaviness'' along his breastbone that has bothered him all day. As we talk, I find that he has no ''risk factors'' for coronary disease; nor has he ever had pain like this before. After a while, he volunteers, a bit hesitantly, some additional and valuable information: yesterday, on a challenge from his sergeant, he tried weight lifting for the first time.

title: WAR WAS BETTER THAN LIFE AT HOME
description: LEAD: V FOR VICTOR By Mark Childress. 289 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: Momentum of New Administration Could Slow if Posts Are Vacant Long
description: Congress resumes the task of confirming appointees to the Bush Administration next week amid growing concern that the White House is lagging in filling senior posts throughout the Federal Government.

title: Council of Veterans Refuses Membership to Jewish Group
description: The local Veterans Council has sparked cries of anti-Semitism and the possibility of legal action by refusing to amend its charter to admit a local Jewish veterans group.

title: Ashes of Six Who Died in Firebombing Rouse People Against Crime
description: At 2:45 A.M. on Jan. 20, a flash of flame engulfed a silent house in a sleeping northeast Kansas City neighborhood, and six people died, victims of a firebomb and the country's narcotics plague.

title: On Preservation And Confrontation
description: The order of the State Supreme Court requiring the owner-contractor James Patrick Kennedy to remove the 26-by-47-foot addition on his home in order to preserve the integrity of the Grove Street Historic District in Tarrytown [ ''Preservationists Praise Tarrytown Ruling,'' Jan. 22 ] is a prime illustration of a worthy objective gone awry.

title: Harvey R. Nova, Neurosurgeon, Dies at 53
description: Dr. Harvey R. Nova, a neurosurgeon at Englewood Hospital in New Jersey, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Tenafly, N.J. He was 53 years old.

title: Skippy Redmon Is Planning to Wed Alexander Campbell Banker in April
description: Coates D. Redmon of Washington has made known the engagement of her daughter, Skipwith Carter Winslow Redmon, to Alexander Campbell Banker, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas H. Banker of Garrison, N.Y. The couple plan to marry in April.

title: Book on Murder Stirs Debate About Limits of Nonfiction
description: LEAD: ''BLIND FAITH,'' the best-selling book about the 1984 murder of a Toms River woman that was arranged by her husband, has provoked a debate about the use of novelistic techniques in a nonfiction work.

title:
GARDENING;
Strawberries That Grow All Season
description: LEAD: EVERBEARING strawberries can produce a moderate crop all season with the best of care and plenty of water during the summer along with a bit of fertilizer.

title: Lavish Treasures of an Extravagant Collector
description: On the European museum circuit this winter the most important single event has been, beyond question, the exhibition called ''Prague in 1600: Art and Culture at the Court of Rudolf II.'' First seen in Essen, West Germany, as one of a series of historical evocations of great European cities, it arrived at the Kunsthistorisches-museum in Vienna in a much enlarged form toward the end of November. Voluminous beyond expectation, it is consistently beautiful and surprising to look at. (Voluptuous, too. The court of Rudolf II was no place for prudes).

title: Elvis Costello's Happy Marriage Of Lyrics and Music
description: Elvis Costello's sheer productivity used to trip him up. A dozen full-length albums from his 1977 debut, ''My Aim Is True,'' to the new ''Spike'' (Warner Bros. 25848, LP, cassette and CD) haven't been enough to hold his output. But with ''Spike,'' his first album since 1986 (when he released two), Mr. Costello has taken the time to make his tunes and arrangements as well crafted - and crafty - as his words. It's his best album since 1981's ''Trust.'' Although Mr. Costello's first songs established him as an articulately venomous observer of characters and scenes, he went on to write narratives, free associations, love songs, political parables and pure conundrums, spewing aphorisms as often as other rock songwriters used the word ''baby.'' Between albums, he recorded singles, EP's and enough unreleased material to fill two catch-up albums, ''Taking Liberties'' and a 1987 British compilation, ''Out of Our Idiot.'' And he put out batches of genre experiments - soul, country, jazz, Beatlesque pop, punk - and widely varied assortments that assured he would never be typecast. Just to make sure, he multiplied his pseudonyms, among them the Coward Brothers (with T Bone Burnett), the Imposter, Napoleon Dynamite and his real name, Declan Patrick Aloysius MacManus.

title: 'Singin' in the Rain' Staged in Darien
description: ONE expects a stage musical to entertain, enlighten or excite. But ''Singin' in the Rain'' has to do more. It has to justify its existence.

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.
description: SAY what you want, it's not really putting ''it'' off, whatever ''it'' may be, and it's certainly not the same thing as postponing. It's simply neater. It makes more sense. Who ever heard of starting a diet on a Tuesday, or beginning an exercise program on a Thursday, or finally getting down to a long-term project on a Friday?

title: Not All the Boys of Summer Were Out on the Playing Field
description: To the Editor:

title: Predicting When Men Retire And When Women Give Birth
description: Can supercomputers help social scientists unravel the mysteries of how people make decisions?

title: The Shakespeare Marathon: The Coach's View THEATER; Running The Marathon
description: The Shakespeare marathon has been characterized in this newspaper [ ''Peaks and Valleys in Papp's Marathon,'' by Frank Rich, Feb. 5 ] as an enterprise lacking a unifying vision and having no unifying principle other than ''Joseph Papp presents.'' Needless to say, I consider such charges baseless and I resent them.

title: Aleksandr Yakovlev, Gorbachev's Little-Known Alter-Ego
description: TWO SONS OF RUSSIAN PEASANTS - ONE A rising Communist star, the other a Kremlin exile - found themselves together in May 1983 on a 10-day puddle-jumping tour across the plains of Canada, from Niagara Falls to Calgary.

title: Rights Group Says Hungarians Suffer in Rumania
description: A human rights monitoring group says Rumania's two million Hungarian-speaking citizens are the victims of a Government campaign to destroy their separate cultural identity.

title: Expensive Deception
description: In the view of a California jury, there are certain secrets that lovers must share. The jury said it was ''outrageous'' of Rock Hudson, who died of AIDS in 1985, to have concealed his disease from his lover, Marc Christian.

title: Lou Gossett Jr. Battles the Hollywood Stereotype
description: Louis Gossett Jr., the new, improved, sober and unresentful Louis Gossett Jr., was talking about freedom. The freedom that ticket-buying audiences have given him to play roles he calls colorblind, and the freedom he feels now from the drug and alcohol addiction that beseiged him after his Oscar-winning performance in ''An Officer and a Gentleman.''

title: Correction
description: The Music View column on page 27 of Arts and Leisure today describes a concert performance of excerpts from ''Tristan und Isolde'' incorrectly. It is Act II that will be performed - tomorrow night, by the Orchestre de Paris under the direction of Daniel Barenboim at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Cleanup of the Sound is Left Adrift by Budget Cutting
description: THOSE who expected last year's concern about the pollution of Long Island Sound to result in cleaner water and beaches this year may well find their hopes smothered in the budget battle in Hartford.

title: A Doctor Who Makes House Calls for Chats
description: LEAD: A GROUP of 11 friends met at the home of Mitzi Friedman in Fairfield on a recent Wednesday afternoon. The women, in their 40's, 50's and 60's, sat around the living room, sipping coffee and talking about health concerns they shared.

title: Toys That Teach
description: Games like Riddle Riot and Clever Endeavor. Huggable animals like Luvawool. Construction toys called Flexiblocks and Googolplex. A radio-controlled fowl named Quickshot Dudley Duck.

title: Former Mexican Soldier Describes Executions of Political Prisoners
description: In the first public acknowledgement of death squad activity in Mexico, a former Mexican Army soldier is maintaining that he was part of a secret military unit that executed at least 60 political prisoners here in the late 1970's and early 1980's.

title: POSTINGS: Tips From Pros; Home Show Workshops
description: Homeowner Harrys and Harriets might benefit from professional house and apartment improvement tips at a series of workshops to be held Wednesday through next Sunday at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. The demonstrations and seminars are being offered as part of the Greater New York Apartment and Home Show, which will feature 40 hour-long presentations by 30 home-renovation specialists and interior decorators.

title: Dr. Catherine Popkin to Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ralph R. Popkin of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Dr. Catherine D. Popkin to Marc I. Berens, a son of Yolana Berens Somlo of Miami Beach and the late Julius G. Berens. A June wedding is planned.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: THE IMMORTAL BARTFUSS, by Aharon Appelfeld. Translated by Jeffrey M. Green. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $7.95.) A retarded daughter helps a concentration camp survivor break out of his bleak inner world. Last year our reviewer, Leonard Michaels, said the novel ''offers an extraordinary adventure in character portrayal that is reminiscent of 'The Stranger' by Albert Camus, but more extreme in its vision of alienation, more daring in its art.'' THE CARE OF STRANGERS: The Rise of America's Hospital System, by Charles E. Rosenberg. (Basic Books, $12.95.) Equipped with millions of dollars of sophisticated machinery and staffed by doctors imbued with the power over life and death, the modern hospital has become a monument to America's reverence for technology and expertise. Charles E. Rosenberg's story of the institution's rise is ''a splendid history,'' our reviewer, Gert H. Brieger, said in 1987. ''Very well written and rich with interpretation, it deserves a wide audience not only among those concerned with medicine but also those with an interest in cities, social welfare and the professions. We are all patients, and Mr. Rosenberg does much to interpret the complex culture of medicine we all must confront.'' CHRONICLE IN STONE, by Ismail Kadare. (New Amsterdam, $10.95.) In an old stone city in Albania, a young boy's neighbors include an inventor who is making an airplane powered by perpetual motion. Ismail Kadare's fiction ''has been compared with that of Gabriel Garcia Marquez,'' Leonie Caldecott said here last year. ''Certainly he induces the same ironic double take in his readers, by means of the child's magical view of life that is larger than most adults realize.'' A TIME OF CHANGE: A Reporter's Tale of Our Time, by Harrison E. Salisbury. (Bessie/Perennial/Harper & Row, $10.95.) In the second volume of his memoirs, Harrison E. Salisbury, the former Times reporter and editor, describes such journalistic coups as persuading the Chinese Government to let him retrace the footsteps of Mao Zedong's Long March. ''Mr. Salisbury fairly earns his bragging rights,'' Thomas Griffith said here last year. His book is ''a lively and fascinating tale by a hardworking, exuberantly contentious journalist who has brought his own stubbornly independent witness to many of the major events of our times.'' A DRAM OF POISON, by Charlotte Armstrong. (International Polygonics, $4.95.) In 1956 our reviewer, Anthony Boucher, said that reading this ''bubblingly gay and warm story of attempted suicide [ is ] an experience as delightful as it is unclassifiable.'' STRANGER IN THE FOREST: On Foot Across Borneo, by Eric Hansen. (Penguin, $8.95.) Trekking through the jungles of Borneo, an American adventurer learns about barter, blood sacrifice and the ancient art of headhunting. ''It is beguiling to encounter a man who is more interested in the people he meets than in discussing his own considerable courage and endurance,'' Tim Cahill said here last year. ''And there is a charm beyond simple romance in Mr. Hansen's insights.'' Penguin has also reprinted NOTHING TO DECLARE: Memoirs of a Woman Traveling Alone, by Mary Morris ($7.95). In 1988 our reviewer, Molly Peacock, called this account of a trip through Latin America ''the union of a travel book and a journey into the self. The vibrancy of this union is on every page.'' THE LAST SHIP, by William Brinkley. (Ballantine, $9.95.) In the aftermath of a nuclear war, the passengers on a United States destroyer search for an uncontaminated land to begin civilization anew. Last year our reviewer, Andrew Postman, said the novel ''draws on the legacies of Melville and Conrad but is full of its own nuclear-age quandaries and horrors.'' CLOAK & GOWN: Scholars in the Secret War, 1939-1961, by Robin W. Winks. (Quill/Morrow, $14.95.) Since World War II, Yale University has provided the Office of Strategic Services and its offspring, the Central Intelligence Agency, with very well educated spies. This history of the relationship ''is not only an entertaining contribution to the secret history of the 1940's and 50's, it is also an important one,'' Godfrey Hodgson said here in 1987. A SCRAP OF TIME: And Other Stories, by Ida Fink. Translated by Madeline Levine and Francine Prose. (Schocken, $6.95.) Set in Poland during the Holocaust, this collection of short fiction won the first Anne Frank Prize for literature. In 1987 our reviewer, Johanna Kaplan, said the stories ''allow us powerful imaginative passage to an unimaginably infernal world.'' THE PALACE FILE, by Nguyen Tien Hung and Jerrold L. Schecter. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $10.95.) To persuade Nguyen Van Thieu, the President of South Vietnam, to sign the Paris peace accords, the United States made secret promises of military support that it had no intention of keeping, the authors argue. ''An extraordinary collection of previously undisclosed exchanges of letters between Mr. Thieu and Presidents Nixon and Ford combines with the authors' interviews with many key Americans and Vietnamese to make this an important study,'' George McT. Kahin said in The Book Review in 1987. THE CHINESE EMPEROR, by Jean Levi. Translated by Barbara Bray. (Vintage, $8.95.) During the third century B.C. a Chinese emperor tries to achieve perfect order in an oppressive, all-powerful dynasty. In 1987 our reviewer, Jonathan Spence, called this historical novel ''an ambitious and at times extremely powerful book, where moments of ghastly violence are interspersed with flickers of rare beauty.''

title: WHO'W AFRAID OF THE NEW WOMAN?
description: NO MAN'S LAND The Place of the Woman Writer in the Twentieth Century. Volume Two: Sexchanges. By Sandra M. Gilbert and Susan Gubar. Illustrated. 455 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $29.95.

title: Understanding Homosexuality
description: To the Editor:

title: Beirut Christians Strive to Avert a Showdown in the Military
description: Christian leaders today tried to avert a military showdown between militants and the regular army that threatens to devastate mostly Christian East Beirut.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE CROTON RESERVOIR GATEHOUSE;
Water, Water Everywhere, and It All Flows Through Here
description: LEAD: ANYONE who takes for granted the water that pours from his tap is invited to take a look at the gatehouse at the Croton Reservoir. On the lip of the 20-mile-long lake in Yorktown, near the Croton border, is a turn-of- the-century structure of stone. Step inside, into a room smelling faintly of chlorine and full of equipment to inject that purifying chemical into nature's liquid bounty.

title: Where the Mushroom Is King
description: MUSHROOMS have always been the stuff of fairy tales but in Kennett Square, Pa., the noble fungus is a way of life. The town is the heart of Chester County, which calls itself the world's mushroom capital. According to the Federal Department of Agriculture, two-thirds of the country's annual crop of nearly 400 million pounds is produced in the county by 160 growers, the largest concentration anywhere. Almost every mushroom for sale in the Northeast is from this region. Through European history mushrooms were reserved for royalty.Mushrooms have been blamed for the deaths of Emperors Tiberius and Claudius, Czar Alexander I, Pope Clement VII and Charles V of France. (Indeed, the poisonous varieties were a favorite of the Borgias.) Although there is some evidence of cultivation by the Japanese as long as 2,000 years ago, the common Agaricus campestris was first grown at the beginning of the 18th century in limestone quarries near Paris (the word comes from moisseron, the moss in which they were grown), but it wasn't until early in this century that they became affordable. At 14 calories a cup, low in fat, cholesterol and sodium-free, they are a good diet food. Annual per capita consumption has gone from 6 ounces to 3 1/2 pounds in the last 30 years, according to the American Mushroom Institute.

title: A Clash Over Revival of a Queens Landmark
description: In 1862, when New York City was Manhattan only and Queens was a separate area with towns and villages like Flushing, the Flushing Town Hall was built as a center of civic and social life in that community.

title: Remembering The Sixties
description: To the Editor:

title: Salvador At a Crossroads
description: One thing Marxist rebels and the far right in El Salvador agree on is that U.S. policy in Central America is a resounding failure. Of course they have opposite reasons.

title: Paying the Price
description: Britain's track and field team did not do very well at the 1988 Summer Olympics, and the poor showing is going to be costly. Partly as a result of the Olympic disappointment, the British Amateur Athletic Board announced that it was cutting its budget for payments to athletes by more than 25 percent to $700,000. It is also slashing the amount an athlete can win at an event from $13,500 to $10,000. Anyone who sets a world record will earn a $50,000 bonus.

title: Madrid
description: To the Editor: As a frequent business traveler to Spain, not successful or pretentious enough to stay at the Ritz, I can attest in response to R. Pujol's letter (''Madrid,'' Travel, Jan. 8) that I have never been robbed in a hotel in Madrid. I have stayed at the Miguel Angel, the Emperatriz and the Palace. I cannot compare them with other European hotels since I am not an international traveler like Mr. Pujol, but I can say that the security of my property has always been perfect. The staff in those hotels - concierges, maids, waiters and bellboys - has been most helpful and honest. The affirmation that ''you are sure to be robbed when staying at hotels that are not of the caliber of the Ritz'' is pure slander against the Spanish people.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATEz
description: LEAD: WE are river people today. Call it a ritual. Call it a rite of the season, a winter pageant where old bonds are forged anew. Call it tradition.

title: New Medical Unit Aiding Children
description: LEAD: MOST of the children at the new long-term-care pediatrics unit at Children's Specialized Hospital - believed to be the first of its kind in New Jersey - will not be going home again. Their parents and the hospital staff expect no miracles.

title: NEXT WEEK CALLED CRUCIAL ON TOWER
description: White House officials said today that President Bush had stiffened his support for John G. Tower as the Administration prepared for what the aides described as a critical week in the nomination of Mr. Tower as the Secretary of Defense.

title: Review/Jazz; Slightly Eccentric Be-Bop
description: Bertha Hope, a pianist who brought a quartet to Birdland on Thursday night, has a terrific rhythmic sense. Working with the be-bop vocabulary, she smacks a series of syncopated notes, throws in descending series of chords, and lets her left hand rumble.

title: Afraid? Learn to Breathe
description: LEAD: IN her self-defense class at Adelphi University, the first thing that Zosia Gorbaty teaches her students is how to breathe. By using breathing techniques, she says, potential rape victims can control fear and panic that may prevent them from taking action. Once they are calm, she says, they can then start to think rationally.

title: West Milford Journal; Limits on Delivery of Mail Stir a Community to Action
description: ON most days, residents of Shady Lake Park do not have far to travel to pick up their mail: there are 14 mailbox clusters in this lakeside community at the foot of the Ramapo Mountains. But in winter, they say, the hilly, winding roads coated with snow and ice sometimes become impassable and dangerous. The local post office agrees.

title:
THEATER;
Maleczech Plumbs The Mystery Of Sor Juana
description: LEAD: Little is known about Sor Juana Ines de la Cruz, the 17th- century Mexican nun and poet. But apparently she spent most of her life doing two things: arguing with everyone about her right to study, and making money. She was repeatedly admonished by her bishop to curb her secular reading, and eventually she capitulated.

title: Madrid
description: To the Editor: We came back from Madrid just in time to see Mr. Pujol's letter and can offer a sad second to his comments about the city's hotels. We stayed at the Grand Hotel Victoria, part of the Tryp chain, which is architecturally grand and has a helpful staff, but otherwise left much to be desired. The colder the temperature, the less heat we got, and every morning at 4 o'clock the maids' laundry wagons were wheeled up and down the hotel corridors to make sure we'd get up bright and early. The crowning touch was the hotel's renovation, which went on while we were staying there, and all day long walls were being knocked down on the floor below ours. Also, we were mugged the first night of our stay in Madrid. HERBERT J. GANS New York, N.Y.

title: Elizabeth J. Kramer to Marry in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. Martin B. Kramer of Brookville, L.I., and Carefree, Ariz., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Jane Kramer to James F. Wood, a son of Alan F. Wood of Utica, N.Y., and the late Anne Wood. A July wedding is planned.

title: U.S.-Europe Trade Talks Easing Meat Dispute
description: Negotiators for the United States and the European Community today stepped back from a confrontation over trade in hormone-injected meat with compromises that could lead to the easing of American sanctions against $100 million worth of European farm exports.

title: Albert McFall Jr. Is Wed To Marie-Louise Gifford
description: At St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Madison, Conn., Marie-Louise Conyngham Gifford, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Cammann Gifford of Madison, was married yesterday to Albert Dodge McFall Jr., the son of Mrs. Albert Dodge McFall of Jacksonville, Fla., and the late Cmdr. McFall, U.S.N. The Rev. John G. MaCort Jr. performed the ceremony. The bride, a graduate of Skidmore College, was until recently a second vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank in New York. Her father is an associate director of development at Yale-New Haven Hospital, where her mother, Wendy Thorsen Gifford, is the associate director of volunteer services.

title: Review/Dance; Lepkoff's Friendly 'Gestures'
description: Much of the program presented by Daniel Lepkoff on Friday night at Performance Space 122 might have inspired the most loyal of mothers to wonder why she'd sent her boy to dance school. In ''Boneyard,'' for instance, Mr. Lepkoff and Paul Langland progressed from sitting and performing simple arm gestures to sitting and pulling at each others' mouths and poking fingers through the curling fingers of each others' hands. In ''Jungle Breath,'' created, like ''Boneyard,'' by the two performers, the men worked their way from uttering syllables in goatlike cries to the monosyllabic-sound equivalent of full-throttle Beethoven. But the duets were often spellbinding.

title: Keeping the Jazz Flame Burning
description: LEAD: JIMMY McPARTLAND doesn't take out his silver cornet much these days; maybe once or twice a year, at most.

title: Jerome Robbins Dances Back to Broadway
description: Jerome Robbins, master choreographer, famed Broadway director, is leaning against a piano and singing. The words are not from his new show, ''Jerome Robbins's Broadway,'' which opens next Sunday at the Imperial Theater. Nor are they from any of the many musicals he directed and/or choreographed on Broadway from 1944 to 1964, from ''On the Town'' to ''Fiddler on the Roof'' - 11 of which are represented in this new production. The words he is singing are from a different era: from the 30's, when Mr. Robbins was a young man, going to high school, graduating, attending New York University for a while, beginning his career. It is a song from the Depression, a period that certainly shaped Mr. Robbins's life, just as it shaped the lives of everyone who lived through it.

title: Review/Recital; Russell Sherman, in a Liszt Etude Program
description: As a champion of the interpreter's individual rights, Russell Sherman, I hope, will not mind this writer's own explanation of why Friday's piano recital at the Metropolitan Museum was so strangely ordered.

title: Fighting-Trim Tyson Hunkers Down to Business
description: On Jan. 10, six and a half weeks before he was to fight Frank Bruno, Mike Tyson skipped his regular workout at Johnny Tocco's Ringside Gym in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: CORE CURRICULUM: OTHER OPTIONS
description: Allow me to add my appraisal to those voiced in the article ''Fairleigh Dickinson's Core Curriculum Appraised.'' I had a chance to observe Fairleigh Dickinson students in 1980 and 1981 when I earned an M.B.A. on Saturdays in the university's ''M.B.A. for data- processing professionals program,'' an excellent concept that I wish could be expanded to the Ph.D. level.

title: CLASSICAL
description: Peter Dawson Sings Traditional Favorites (recorded 1912-1937). Pearl CD GEMM 9336, CD only.

title: Volunteers Strive To Help Homeless
description: LEAD: INSIDE the last white ranch house on a dead-end street in the Town of Hempstead, Peter, Bill and Carol prepare a supper of hamburgers, pastina salad and snow peas.

title: 2 Plays With Powerful Themes
description: WHAT do an American comedy about child-rearing by a lesbian couple and a Russian docudrama dealing with the devastating effects of the 1986 nuclear disaster at Chernobyl have in common?

title: Chicken: Cheap and Able To Marry With Many Flavors
description: FOR an easy inexpensive meal, you can't beat chicken. Because of its fairly bland taste, it is probably the most versatile food in the kitchen. It goes with almost any kind of flavor, with herbs and mustard, or with Oriental, North African or Latin American spices.

title: Too Much Power for National Security Council
description: To the Editor:

title: Political Memo; Seeking Reasons Besides Dukakis, Democrats Mull Last Fall's Defeat
description: While most Americans have happily forgotten about the 1988 election campaign, Democrats are quietly fighting the war of interpretations. Since election results, like scripture, can be cited to many purposes, Democrats sifting through the returns are coming up with some very different views about what ails the party.

title: POSTINGS: Canadians in Connecticut; Armed to Fit
description: A major Canadian pharmaceutical house is going to build a $70 million headquarters in Ridgefield, Conn., for two of its American subsidiaries in an innovative structure that will accommodate 700 employees. The company, Pharma-Investment Ltd. of Toronto, will erect the 266,000-square-foot building for the administrative staffs of its wholly owned subsidiaries, the Boehringer Ingelheim Corporation and Boehringer Ingelheim Pharmaceuticals Inc.

title: Needed: A Camp to Train Adults as Parents
description: THERE is a war in the news these days and the wounded are almost all women and children. This is not a war on foreign shores fought between fanatical factions. It is going on right around us between women and the judicial system, and the object of the war is the children, who are the victims.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Clearing the Cloudy State Cleanup Act
description: LEAD: IN the six years since the state passed a law requiring owners to remove toxic wastes from old industrial properties, 700 sites throughout the state have been cleared by the private sector at a cost of $125 million.

title: Sara Bruce Wed To C. P. Whitin
description: At St. Joseph's Chapel at the Kent School in Connecticut, Sara Magruder Bruce, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Scott Bruce of Pittsburgh, was married yesterday to Charles Pinckney Whitin, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Thomson M. Whitin of Haddam, Conn. The Rev. Richardson Schell, headmaster of the Kent School, performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: Some Teams Showing Interest in Free-Agent Giants
description: Billy Ard of the Giants, one of the National Football League's newly created free agents, has talked to several teams. He said he liked some of the things he saw. One of those teams, the San Francisco 49ers, said it was interested in Ard.

title: Understanding Homosexuality
description: To the Editor:

title: Galveston's Sense Of Delight and Danger
description: WHEN I first moved to Galveston in the summer of 1984, it was less than a year after Hurricane Alicia and the building boom that insurance money had brought to the island. The people I met would invariably steer conversations to the aftermath of Alicia: the swimming pool lifted six inches out of the ground by a spin-off tornado, the water marks on the den paneling. Their eyes would twinkle, their voices rise in excitement. ''Welcome to the island!'' they would say.

title: WASHED ASHORE WITHOUT PARENTS
description: JOHN DOLLAR By Marianne Wiggins. 214 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $17.95.

title: RUSHDIE EXPRESSES REGRET TO MUSLIMS FOR BOOK'S EFFECT
description: The author Salman Rushdie, facing a death threat from Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini of Iran, said today that he regretted the distress that his novel ''The Satanic Verses'' has caused Muslims.

title: Pick Key Industries and Exploit Them
description: To assure the economic competitiveness of industry in an international marketplace increasingly dominated by government-assisted foreign competition, we need a strategy that focuses on key technologies. Responsibility for such a strategy would cut across agencies that deal with trade, defense, employment, capital markets, science and technology, and the international relations of the United States. Successful implementation of such a strategy would also require the development of a continuing relationship among government, the private sector and academia.

title: For Users, Falling Prices and Endless Choices
description: Six years ago, when the General Motors Corporation was considering purchasing a supercomputer for its research laboratory, determining which model to buy was not as big an issue as the cost. At the time, there were only a handful of machines to choose from, all of them expensive. Rather than shell out from $5 million to $20 million for a new machine, G.M. ultimately chose to lease.

title: Reconstructionist Jews Turn to the Supernatural
description: Miracles and the Messiah are being restored to the liturgy of a small but influential movement in American Judaism that has spurned supernatural concepts for more than 40 years.

title: Rangers Defeat Penguins, Stop Slide
description: Moments after his team's abysmal performance against the Maple Leafs on Friday night, Michel Bergeron was a confused, concerned coach. He admitted he might have overestimated his players, that he might have been misled by the Rangers' remarkable first half of the season. There were a lot of questions to be resolved.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My wife and I recently bought a 63-year-old house and we are planning a number of renovations. The heating system is covered with asbestos, so we have done some air quality tests. There are no dangerous levels of asbestos in the air. Should we put removing the asbestos at the top of our priority list?

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: A Laughing Matter

title: Teufel, By Decision
description: Midway through last Friday's hearing that would determine Tim Teufel's salary with the Mets this season, the arbitrator, Richard Bloch, saying ''I've never done this before,'' halted the proceedings.

title: ABOUT THIS PAGE
description: Home Entertainment/Recordings will appear biweekly, alternating in this space with Home Entertainment/Video.

title: Safaris
description: To the Editor: The articles on luxury travel in Kenya were fascinating reading. But I'd hate for your poorer readers to come away with the idea that reasonable comfort on safari is out of their price range.

title: Mary Crisp to Wed Otto Lowe April 22
description: Mary Louise Nowell Crisp, the law clerk to Judge Marvin Wooten of Federal Bankruptcy Court in Charlotte, N.C., and Otto Wescott Lowe, an assistant vice president of the First Boston Corporation in New York, plan to be married April 22.

title:
MUSIC;
State Opera to Do the Rare and New
description: LEAD: AS the New Jersey State Opera begins several major projects for this year, it is quite clear that the company is moving away from a season of traditional offerings.

title: THERE'S A FUNGUS AMONG US
description: THE MUSHROOM-PICKER By Zinovy Zinik. Translated by Michael Glenny. 282 pp. New York: A Thomas Dunne Book/ St. Martin's Press. $16.95.

title: croton Group Working to Save Nation's Seafaring Heritage
description: SAVING historic ships these days can be as perilous and expensive a venture as sailing those same ships was a century ago, leaders of the maritime-preservation movement agree.

title: Events for Schoolchildren on Vacation
description: LEAD: MANY children in the county have vacation from school this week. With this in mind, libraries, performing-arts centers, sanctuaries, museums, Y's and other organizations have scheduled a variety of activities to interest and entertain them.

title: POP/JAZZ
description: Simply Red: 'A New Flame' Elektra 60828-4, all three formats.

title: FICTION
description: RUMORS. By Catherine Mann. (Delacorte, $18.95.) Hollywood is so replete with real-life caricatures that it would seem superfluous to create a mannerist portrait of them. Yet Catherine Mann, herself a one-time Hollywood reporter, has done exactly that. ''Rumors'' has all the hallmarks of a perfunctory nod to the literary form en route to the big payoff: the television mini-series. There are crises and cliffhangers galore and countless opportunities for commercial tie-ins. And even the thumbnail characterizations cannily lend themselves to cameo appearances by members of the Hollywood firmament. The plot revolves around an ace reporter's efforts to uncover the truth about the grande dame of glitter, Renata Desmond, the ruthless owner of a mighty show-business newspaper. The rumors surrounding Desmond are shocking and incredible, but it should come as little surprise that the truth is even more decadent and implausible. Myriad subplots introduce an array of distracting personalities, among them a debauched, corpulent studio head, a brash Texas millionaire and an enigmatic beauty with the requisite checkered past. This is a frothy concoction of sex, scandal, manipulation and affectation - a production that looks like a mock-up of a stage set or a phony counterfeit bill.

title: BURN THE BUILDINGS, HANG THE PROFESSORS
description: PROFSCAM Professors and the Demise of Higher Education. By Charles J. Sykes. 304 pp. Washington: Regnery Gateway. $18.95.

title: Wastebaskekt Ball, Anyone?
description: EVER since I read that five or six games - Ping-Pong for one - had been added to the long list of sporting events included at the Summer Olympics in Seoul, I've been wondering how I could promote one of the most popular but least recognized games for inclusion in the 1992 games in Barcelona. That sport is wastebasket ball, the game we all play in the home, at work, in the classroom or wherever there is a wastebasket.

title: Woodbury Suit Threatens Highway Interchange Work
description: ALTHOUGH reconstruction of the interchange of the Northern State and Meadowbrook State Parkways is proceeding on schedule - the completion date is Oct. 31, 1991 - the $61 million project has met with resistance from the Village of Westbury.

title: NONFICTION
description: THE WAY TO THE WESTERN SEA: Lewis and Clark Across the Continent. By David Lavender. (Harper & Row, $22.95.) It is a thrill to read ''The Way to the Western Sea,'' an intimate account of the cross-continental expedition up the Missouri River, then on to the Pacific Coast undertaken by Meriwether Lewis and William Clark from May 14, 1804, to Sept. 23, 1806. Their exhaustive agenda of diplomatic, commercial and scientific research was set by a visionary Thomas Jefferson. The motley Corps of Discovery traversed the newly acquired Louisiana Territory in a frequently flooded keelboat and two pirogues that often had to be hauled over boggy islets. David Lavender, the author of ''The Rockies'' and ''Land of Giants,'' writes virile, disciplined, yet personal prose. We jig with drunken oarsmen around the campfire and collapse on bark mattresses. We share their provisions of elk jerky, licorice, wild plum and catfish. Mr. Lavender also describes the murky psychological eddies in the relations between the explorers and British, French and Indian traders, as well as with the White House. He also tells of Lewis's brutal self-flagellations in his journal. His mission nearly over, at age 31, he had ''as yet done but little, very little, indeed, to further the happiness of the human race or to advance the information of the succeeding generation.'' In future, he ''would live for mankind as I have heretofore lived for myself.'' The well-placed introspective excerpts build to a suicide that is mourned deeply, long after the last page is reluctantly turned.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: WASHINGTON SEMINAR

title: When Passing Is Not a Game
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Baker's Grand Tour Sets a Style for the Bush Era
description: As Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d's blue and white Air Force 707 jetliner was about to leave London for Bonn last Sunday, it found itself waiting on the runway for takeoff behind another blue and white plane - a Soviet Aeroflot passenger plane.

title: Guidry Is Hoping Arm Will Hold Up
description: There is a part of him that yearns to finally become a gentleman farmer, to leave baseball behind and to spend his days mending fences and his nights in front of a warm fire with his family.

title: Police Forces Pool Applicant Screening
description: TEN Fairfield County towns expect to save thousands of dollars a year by letting someone else do the initial screening of their police applicants.

title: 175 Are Rescued from Ice Floe in Lake Erie
description: About 175 people trapped on a mile-long stretch of ice on Lake Erie that broke free and floated about a mile out on the lake were rescued today by helicopters and boats, officials said.

title: From the Inside Of a Camera, Children Discover Photography
description: HOW do you ''draw'' with a flashlight? Why do rays of light sometimes turn the world upside down? Such questions spanning science and art are imaginatively answered in the school programs and family workshops sponsored by the Katonah Gallery in connection with its current show, ''Stopping Time.''

title: Vermont Community Deeply Split Over Teacher
description: William Altman clearly loves teaching history, classics and philosophy at the local high school, but for the past 17 months the community has been rent over his ethics and classroom behavior.

title: Tiny Miracles Become Huge Public Health Problem
description: A newborn boy, a mere patch of flesh with a tangerine-sized head and limbs like splinters, lay tethered to a thicket of tubes on a heated table in a special ward for premature infants at New York Hospital.

title: Sniffing Through History
description: Two thousand years ago, in a cave near the Dead Sea, somebody buried a small clay jug of the oil used to anoint Israeli kings. Last summer, an archeologist unearthed it. The jug is still whole and the oil is still fluid, but the fragrance is gone forever - as is the ancient persimmon plant from which it was extracted. The world will never know the scent of this precious oil or, for that matter, of the kings of Judah on the day they were anointed and ascended their thrones. Ah, what the nose could tell us about the past did it but have the proper archives.

title: WUTHERING HEIGHTS
description: MOTION-PICTURE FANS AND SCHOLARS agree that Hollywood's creative energy clearly peaked in 1939, the miracle year that produced ''Gone With the Wind,'' ''The Wizard of Oz,'' ''Mr. Smith Goes to

title: Haunted by An Ad
description: To the Editor:

title: Ticket Lottery For Rangers
description: The Rangers, who missed the playoffs last season but may be headed that way this spring, have announced a lottery to allocate tickets for the first three playoff rounds.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Taking the Option to Buy an Office Condo
description: LEAD: FACED with signing a new lease calling for rent payments of $19 a square foot plus $1.25 a square foot for utilities on office space it was leasing in Melville, the accounting firm of Brill Stevens & Bellissimo decided that ownership would be more advantageous.

title: Supporting Mediocrity Is Not the Solution
description: As a product of the West Hartford and Fairfield school systems, a current university student and a prospective teacher, I found Jacqueline Weaver's interview with Gail Mellow, director of the Connecticut Project for Equal Education Rights, to be interesting and pertinent (Connecticut Q&A, Jan. 1). However, I am quite disturbed by Ms. Mellow's desire to teach women to fail and to accept mediocrity.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Counce, Tenn.;
Lakeside Community
description: LEAD: EIGHT miles upstream from a Civil War battlefield and six miles downstream from the future home of a booster rocket plant, a Memphis developer is starting work on Shiloh Falls, a $200 million mixed-use community on the Tennessee River's Pickwick Lake.

title: Abortion Law In Italy Draws Growing Fire
description: A decade after Parliament legalized abortions in this fundamentally Roman Catholic country, the law is under increasing attack on all sides, from those who believe it is too liberal to those who say it creates too many obstacles for women.

title: The Budget's Impact on One Agency
description: ON a recent ''wish list,'' The Northern Westchester Guidance Center cited a need for dollhouses and dolls, especially ''families'' of dolls. The toy houses and imagined families serve as essential clinical tools to help troubled children and adolescents communicate about the often indescribable reality of physical and sexual abuse, suicidal depression or serious illness.

title: Miss Wolfe Is Married
description: At the First Presbyterian Church of New Canaan, Conn., Elizabeth Ann Wolfe, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul J. Wolfe of New Canaan, was married yesterday to Nicholas Leonidas Spyros Jr., the son of Mrs. John R. Kennedy, also of New Canaan, and the late Mr. Spyros. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speers Jr. performed the ceremony. Lee Ann Carson, the bride's sister, was the matron of honor and Eric Moscahlaidis was the best man.

title: Safaris
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed your article in the Dec. 4 issue on the high cost of trekking in Africa. I did a photo safari a few years ago to Kenya and Tanzania with Mountain Travel.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-25

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Did Babe Ruth Call His Shot?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Talk Shows: Morbid Curiosity
description: I agree with Geraldine M. Fox [ Topics, ''Abuse on TV,'' Jan. 29 ] . Afternoon and evening expose and talk shows are not in the business of educating the public. They are in business, period. Dollar signs dance before them as they probe open wounds before the eyes of the morbidly curious.

title: Tofu Innovator Dreams of New Creations
description: AT black-tie dinners, on a beach in Florida, even in his sleep, David Mintz is thinking tofu - that spongy white substance with an origin no one seems quite sure of.

title:
GARDENING;
Strawberries That Grow All Season
description: LEAD: EVERBEARING strawberries can produce a moderate crop all season with the best of care and plenty of water during the summer along with a bit of fertilizer.

title: Tea in London
description: To the Editor: The article said that at the Empire Tearoom, High Tea is available and then described it as consisting of sandwiches, scones and jam, cake, etc. This is Afternoon Tea. High Tea is a larger meal eaten later in the afternoon or evening, is often a cooked meal and nowadays is more likely to be the family supper. Afternoon tea is sometimes known as a Cream Tea, especially if clotted cream is served with the scones, but High Tea it is not. JANET SCHMELZER Pine Bush, N.Y.

title: Miss Sarnoff Is Affianced
description: Susan Lynn Sarnoff, a second-grade teacher at the Brearley School, and Jonathan David Bram, a financial analyst at Drexel Burnham Lambert, plan to be married in June. The future bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur I. Sarnoff of New York and Charleston, S.C. Mr. Bram is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard Bram of Andover, Mass.

title: CARZY IN VIENNA
description: LEAD: WITTGENSTEIN'S NEPHEW A Friendship. By Thomas Bernhard. Translated by David McLintock. 100 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title: Spread of Ticks Carrying Lyme Disease Surprises Experts
description: LEAD: TICKS infected with the Lyme disease organism are spreading ''extensively and more rapidly than expected'' across Long Island and into lower New York State, according to the State Health Department official monitoring the trend.

title: Tea in London
description: To the Editor: Sorry to inform you that your tea time in London article (Travel, Jan. 1) was incorrect. The Ritz no longer has Sunday tea dances. This I know because I have just returned from London and am an avid tea dancer. ANITA ARNOLD ADLER New York

title: Spain
description: To the Editor: It would be a pity if the negative comments about Spanish paradors were to cause anyone to pass up one of the great travel experiences of Europe. In more than 80 locations in all parts of Spain, these inns offer an opportunity to relive history amid charming and often spectacular settings.

title: COUTURE REPORT: SEXY CHIC
description: Word has been wafting through the perfumed Paris air that Yves Saint Laurent is up to something big. Now, here it is, show time on the next-to-last day of the spring 1989 Paris couture collections. In the ornate velvet and red gilded ballroom that Saint Laurent traditionally uses to present his season's oeuvres, a runway stretches beneath the low-hanging chandeliers from a stage smothered with red and purple bougainvillea. Packed around the runway, in rows of cheek-to-jowl little gold chairs, are the fashion powerbrokers of the world, those who buy and those who render judgment.

title: Report Says U.S. War Planes Nearly Hit 6 Passenger Jets
description: Six United States warplanes on a low-level training flight changed course without warning last Tuesday and flew dangerously close to six passenger jets, a magazine reported today.

title: 'Citizen Kane' Site Changing Hands
description: WHEN a house has at least 70 rooms, 30-foot-high ceilings, walls two feet thick and a dining room that can seat 200 guests, is it a chateau, a mansion, a castle, or perhaps a hotel? Realty people called the house, in Huntington, L.I., one of the largest private homes in the nation.

title: Lauder's Erosion Plan Is Questioned
description: LEAD: RONALD LAUDER'S plan to reduce beach erosion near his property in Wainscott has been praised by environmentalists, but it has met with mixed reviews from those who would be affected most: The owners of neighboring million-dollar properties.

title: Shoreham Solution Remains Elusive
description: LEAD: THREE hundred and sixty-one illuminated panels grid the ceiling of the Brooklyn courtroom in which Federal Judge Jack B. Weinstein overturned a jury verdict against the Long Island Lighting Company last weekend.

title: The Gray Area in Government Bonds
description: The Bush Administration's recently announced plan to float $50 billion of bonds to bail out failing savings and loan institutions would add yet another security to a wide array of fixed-income obligations issued by Federal agencies. The agencies - including the Farm Credit System, the Federal National Mortgage Association (Fannie Mae) and the Federal Home Loan Bank system - use the proceeds to provide loans to farmers, grant mortgages and the like.

title: Curtains Down
description: Adela Holzer, a Broadway producer, has put on one act too many, according to the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau. Ms. Holzer, who was the toast of Broadway two decades ago as the producer of the rock musical ''Hair'' and other theatrical hits, was arrested last week on charges that she swindled investors out of $280,000 while posing as David Rockefeller's ''secret'' wife. Authorities said that Ms. Holzer's scheme, involving nonexistent oil and land deals, may have taken in more than two dozen investors and involved more than $1 million, which Ms. Holzer was planning to use to back a new Broadway show. They also said Mr. Rockefeller did not know her. Ms. Holzer, who served two years in prison for a 1979 fraud conviction, pleaded not guilty.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Measles Make A Quiet Game

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: Sketchy Statistics; The Rape Laws Change Faster Than Perceptions
description: ELIZABETH HOLTZMAN, the Brooklyn District Attorney, tells of a recent rape prosecution: A 21-year-old woman had gone to her former boyfriend's apartment at his request to pick up some belongings. As the jury heard it later, he tied her wrists with telephone cord, raped her and broke her nose. The jury convicted him of assault and acquitted him on the rape charge.

title: THE REGION
description: RACIAL tensions in the nation's largest police department, already inflamed by accusations of racism by white officers in a Queens precinct, seem to be multiplying. Last week the leader of a fraternal officers' group for blacks criticized the leader of a Hispanic officers' group over accusations that Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward is insensitive toward Hispanic New Yorkers.

title: Cassavetes, A Model Of Defiance
description: John Cassavetes, who died two weeks ago, will be as appreciatively remembered for what he didn't do as for what he did. In conceiving, writing, directing, financing and sometimes distributing his own films, Mr. Cassavetes most definitely did not play ball. He did not get along with either conventional Hollywood or the New York avant-garde, and he did not set much stock in an acting career of which others would have been proud. Instead, he treated acting as a way of raising money to make films that were stubbornly and emphatically his own. Referring to John Cassavetes merely as an independent film maker is greatly understating the case.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Henry Kloss's Mail-Order Speakers
description: A basic rule for picking a loudspeaker is to allow plenty of time for listening comparisons. In fact, willingness to let customers become amply acquainted with a variety of loudspeakers under appropriately unhurried conditions is the touchstone that separates reliable and conscientious audio dealers from the rest.

title:
INVESTING;
Prospering From Climbing Rates
description: LEAD: Rising interest rates typically translate into lower housing and automotive sales. But the current bout of rising rates may help rather than harm Fleetwood Enterprises Inc., the leading manufacturer of recreational vehicles and mobile homes.

title: ANGELENOS ON WHEELS: FROM BAD TO WORSE
description: It has never been easy, but this has been one of the worst months in memory for the harried freeway drivers of Los Angeles, where the price of living near warm palm-fringed beaches, lovely mountains and deserts is that one can hardly get there.

title: Places to See How Things Are Made
description: TO the list - never long enough - of what to do with children on winter weekend afternoons can be added some instructive alternatives: visiting factories, studios or plants to see how things are made.

title: Jo-Anne Welsch Is Married
description: Jo-Anne Welsch, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Delane Welsch of St. Paul, was married yesterday to Alexander Lafcadio Cortesi, the son of Alexandra C. Anderson and Alexander C. Cortesi of New York. The ceremony was performed at the Knickerbocker Club by Justice E. Leo Milonas of New York State Supreme Court.

title: Football's Booted Chance
description: Another year. Another opening. Another retread.

title:
ART;
Tracing the Impact of the Geometric
description: LEAD: GEOMETRIC abstraction is the old reliable of 20th-century art. The wide swath it cuts is demonstrated in ''Geometric Abstraction and the Modern Spirit,'' at the Neuberger Museum on the campus of the State University of New York at Purchase through April 3. More than half of the 150 works in the show are drawn from the collection of George and Edith Rickey that has been given to the Neuberger.

title: John H. Jackson, Executive, 73
description: John H. Jackson, a retired vice president and copy chief of Geer, DuBois Inc., an advertising agency, died of a heart attack Monday at his home in White Plains. He was 73 years old.

title: REFLECTIONS OF A CONSERVATIVE OPTIMIST
description: THE PRICE OF EMPIRE By J. William Fulbright with Seth P. Tillman. 243 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $17.95.

title: The Rediscovery Of an Outsider
description: JOSEF MEIERHANS (1890-1981) was featured at the Princeton Gallery of Fine Art in 1985, and some of his pastels were included in the recent miscellany of Delaware Valley painters at the Trenton City Museum. The artist, nevertheless, is but a rediscovery-in-progress, and it is as such that he is now making a second appearance at the Princeton gallery with works on paper and canvas from the 1940's.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: NORTH FORK MUSIC Just in time to bring some cheer to the winterbound North Fork, the Oysterponds Historical Society begins its series of occasional concerts at Poquatuck Hall today. Opening-day honors go to Anima, a Baroque ensemble that was lured back after a successful performance last summer. The trio - Arthur Haas, harpsichordist; Martha McGaughey, violist and Nina Stern, recorder virtuoso - plays at 3 P.M. at the hall on Village Lane in Orient. The series, which is showcasing only chamber groups this season, will also include the Bay Chamber Players on June 17 and the New York Virtuosi, the chamber orchestra based at C.W. Post, on Aug. 26. For information about tickets and /subscriptions, call 323-2480. 'SHAKESPEARE IN MUSIC'

title: Sports of The Times; The Uebie Years: A Retrospective
description: Peter Ueberroth grimaces at the word ''caretaker.'' He thinks of himself as an activist who ran baseball as a chief executive officer for four full years, and is leaving profits behind.

title: Bleak, Stubborn Life of the Marsh
description: THERE is plenty of ocean south of Long Island, but there are closer, more intimate seas in our marshes; seas of reeds, penetrated by tidal creeks whose vistas coil through acres of spartina grass and giant phragmites in paths hidden from casual observers, but open to explorers in canoe, johnboat or sneak box.

title: SOVIET PEACE PLAN DISCUSSED IN SYRIA
description: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, met in Damascus today with President Hafez al-Assad in what Syria depicted as a show of support for its policies in the region.

title: UNSPORTSMANLIKE CONDUCT
description: Let me encourage Leonard L. Riskin, who shows no interest in team sports (About Men: ''Unsportsmanlike Conduct,'' Jan. 22) . Indeed, working at a large university more frequently known for its athletic teams than for its intellectual accomplishments, I am aware of the magnetic force fields that radiate from the stadium; they are the greatest of a long list of academic diversions that make up modern university life. The reply ''I'm not an athletic supporter'' lets the inquirer draw his own conclusions. EDGAR MEYER Professor of Biochemistry Texas A & M University College Station, Tex.

title: STEPPING THROUGH THE TRAPDOOR
description: LEAD: THE NEXT NEW WORLD By Bob Shacochis. 209 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $16.95.

title: Boundless Greed Infects Landowners
description: It is precisely individuals like Moreton Binn (''Muttontown Zoning Opposed,'' Jan. 22) who confuse and disrupt the effort to retain a reasonable quality of life on Long Island, and whose boundless and tasteless greed spreads like a virus to other landowners.

title: A View of 350 Years in Fairfield
description: LEAD: TO help the town of Fairfield begin its 350th anniversary celebration, Fairfield University is displaying an exhibition of art and artifacts that trace the community's past.

title: Soviet Ship Bolsters New England Fishermen
description: A Soviet factory ship stationed two miles off the coast has been a boon to local fishermen who find herring plentiful but buyers scarce.

title:
GARDENING;
Vegetables: Screening for Good Taste
description: LEAD: IN our garden, my wife does flowers while I gratify my palate. I am constantly seeking flavor - new tastes and nuances. Will a small tomato come along to match my favorite Yellow Pear, a corn to surpass Golden Cross Bantam, a crispier lettuce? In this epicurean quest, I try vegetables I have never grown.

title: Historian's Pivotal Assertion On Warfare Assailed as False
description: Two historians and a writer have sought to prove that a major work by the prominent military historian S.L.A. Marshallwas based on faked evidence. At issue is whether a majority of American foot soldiers in World War II actually fired their weapons in battle.

title:
ART;
A Broad Spectrum At Nassau Museum
description: LEAD: THE annual ''Long Island Artists'' exhibition at the Nassau County Museum of Fine Art in Roslyn Harbor is no longer restricted to residents of the county, but now includes artists from all over the Island. The 10 in this year's show, which will be on view through March 19, represent a geographic spread from Rockville Centre to East

title: So Far, the Biggest Budget Issue Is How to Apportion the Blame
description: UNLIKE the budget battles of Ronald Reagan's first term, President Bush's first engagement with Capitol Hill is not a fight for fiscal direction so much as a dance around political blame.

title: HIGHER EDUCATION-THE REAL CRISIS
description: Michael Sovern endorses recently-enacted legislation that exempts from taxation the interest earned on Series EE savings bonds when the proceeds are used to pay for a family member's college education. Mr. Sovern is certainly correct in recognizing this as a highly attractive vehicle for college savers. It was created, however, without careful examination of how tax benefits could most effectively be employed.

title: WEEK IN BUSINESS;
description: Union Carbide will pay $470 million in damages for the 1984 gas leak disaster in Bhopal, India, that killed more than 3,500 people and injured 200,000. The payments were ordered by the Indian Supreme Court, and Robert D. Kennedy, Union Carbide's chairman, said the company would accept the order. The Indian Government also accepted the settlement, even though it had sought $3.3 billion for 500,000 claimants. Making a $470 million payment will perhaps be the least-burdensome consequence of Bhopal for Carbide. The tragedy produced four years of international legal turmoil for the chemical company and a plunging stock price that set it up for a takeover attack. Carbide took on heavy debt to make special payouts to shareholders, sold $3.5 billion in assets and shrank its work force to 43,000, from 98,000.

title: At Last, the Battle of the Century Ends
description: ONE of the longest, bitterest conversion fights in Manhattan apartment house history has ended with the imposing Century Apartments at 25 Central Park West becoming a condominium, huge profits for both the sponsors and residents and the payment of millions of dollars in legal fees.

title: CLASSICAL
description: Nielsen's Fourth (''Inextinguishable'') and Fifth Symphonies San Francisco Symphony, conducted by Herbert Blomstedt. London 421 524, CD and cassette.

title: ATLANTA CONTEST MAY TURN ON STYLE
description: With the announcement that Maynard Jackson is seeking to be Mayor of this city again, the lines have been drawn for an election that may turn as much on differences in the histories and styles of the candidates as on promises for the future of the city.

title: Italy Arrests 2 Linked To Anti-NATO Spying
description: A Yugoslav and an Italian have been arrested in Italy on charges of acquiring classified military information for the Soviet Union, including documents on a computer system being developed for NATO, news reports said today.

title: Camp Octopus: 23 Yankee Arms
description: THERE are 23 of them in camp, and if you laid them end to end it is possible they would stretch halfway to Cypress Creek Road, just north of the ball park. Some of them have been through the rigors of spring before; some are simply new to the whole thing, their names unfamiliar to the fans who come here early every morning to see the Yankees work out.

title: Business and the Law; Uncommon Judge In Drexel Case
description: MOMENTS after a magistrate selected Kimba M. Wood to preside over the criminal case against Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., a throng of reporters and lawyers went to her fourth-floor office to obtain legal papers that the investment house wanted to keep confidential.

title: Review/City Ballet; Passionate Arithmetic in Laura Dean's 'Space'
description: Laura Dean's ''Space,'' which the New York City Ballet presented Saturday night at the New York State Theater, unites logic and passion.

title: Solidarity May Win 40% of Parliament
description: Two weeks after the start of talks between the Government and the outlawed opposition, both sides say they have reached ''fundamental accord'' on allowing the Solidarity-led opposition to control as many as two-fifths of the seats in Parliament through pre-arranged elections.

title: Indictments In Mexico
description: Four top officers from two of Mexico's biggest brokerage firms were indicted Saturday on charges of illegal trading and criminal fraud.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: INTERNATIONAL REPORT A new effort has begun to resolve U.S.-European differences on farm policy. A proposal by Trade Representative Carla A. Hills has raised hopes of progress in the GATT talks with the European Community. The U.S. has previously insisted on the elimination of all farm subsidies. The weekend talks also resulted in a temporary agreement for the resumption of some American beef exports to Europe. [ Page D1. ] A dispute over the FSX fighter plane is considered by many a sign of how trade friction and technological competition are beginning to color the U.S.-Japan military alliance. Some Americans view the plane as a symbol of technology being handed away to foreign competitors. [ D1. ] Capitalism is slowly creeping into Angola, undermining one of the last strongholds of socialism in Africa. A liberalized foreign investment code took effect last year, and areas now open to the private sector include retail trade, industry, farming, trucking, restaurants and hotels. The changes come as the Soviet Union loses its hold in several African countries, including Ethiopia. [ D6. ] Carrefour's U.S. stores are operating more smoothly after some serious startup problems. The French company, which pioneered the hypermarket, has adjusted its formula to increase the appeal of its stores to American consumers. [ D6. ] Spain's biggest industrial company plans a large share offering. Repsol will sell approximately 30 percent of its equity to investors in Spain, Western Europe, the U.S. and Japan. [ D2. ] THE ECONOMY The takeover of United Savings Association of Texas illustrates the methods used and the problems inherited when investors acquire insolvent savings companies. The experience of Hyperion Partners also suggests that making money from sick institutions, with their risky investments and jumbled corporate structures, will be far more difficult than generally perceived. [ A1. ] Medicare has begun to make nursing home payments for thousands of people who had not previously qualified for the benefits. The change will help many elderly people and may significantly raise nursing home revenues. [ D1. ] Charges of technical trading violations are more likely than a string of felony indictments from the commodity trading inquiry in Chicago, defense lawyers say. Indictments seem unlikely before next month. [ D2. ] COMPANIES A new fund plans to invest $300 million in paintings and other works of fine art. The fund, organized by a unit of Chase Manhattan, will probably require a minimum investment of $10 million. [ D1. ] THE MEDIA BUSINESS The appeal of TV journalists to viewers is crucial to the profitability of networks or stations. Many broadcasting executives say the million-dollar salaries of news anchors are justified by the advertising revenue they bring in. [ D1. ] Book publishers are emerging from the dark ages of technology with the aid of desktop publishing. Computers and other technology are finally being used throughout the industry. [ D7. ] Nike put together an unorthodox but apparently successful team to do ads for its Air Jordan athletic shoes. Spike Lee, the Brooklyn film maker, is paired with Michael Jordan, the Chicago Bulls basketball player. [ D7. ] E. W. Scripps completed the sale of The Sun Tattler to DTH Media. The newspaper is published in Hollywood, Fla. [ D7. ] A Pulitzer Prize can lift both the morale and the profits of newspapers. It can also overwhelm them. Press. [ D7. ] TODAY'S COLUMN Federal District Judge Kimba M. Wood has been thrust in front of the klieg lights. After just six months on the bench, she is hearing the largest and most closely watched criminal securities fraud case ever seen by Wall Street: the Government's case against Drexel Burnham Lambert. Business and the Law. [ D2. ]

title: Steel Imports Decline
description: Steel imports declined 16 percent in December from a year earlier, to 1.42 million tons, but imports for all of 1988 rose 4.9 percent, to 20.89 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute said Friday. Despite climbing from 19.92 million tons in 1987, imports last year represented a 20.3 percent share of the United States market, down from 20.9 percent.

title: Review/Dance; Eliot Feld's Intricacies for a Company of 2
description: ''Shadow's Breath,'' Eliot Feld's most recent and ecstatically tinged premiere, continues the creative surge manifest in the unusually large number of new and inventive works he has choreographed this season for his company.

title: Flyers Outslug Islanders
description: What an ugly afternoon, right from the pre-game shoving and insults - a ritual used by the Flyers to let opponents know that domination is the name of the game played here - to the fencing match between the Islanders' Randy Wood and the Flyers' Ron Sutter at the game's end.

title: No Headline
description: Considering that this year's salary arbitration group produced the four largest raises ever gained by baseball players, it should come as no surprise that the group's overall percentage of salary increase was greater than it was a year ago.

title: Venezuelan Talks of Debt
description: President Carlos Andres Perez, in a ceremony honoring the former chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, David Rockefeller, said Friday that Latin America's foreign debt is a real obstacle to economic reform and growth.

title: Sirhan Felt Betrayed by Kennedy
description: Sirhan Sirhan, in his first television interview, said he felt betrayed by Senator Robert F. Kennedy's support for Israel in the 1967 Arab-Israeli war and said he killed Mr. Kennedy out of concern for the Palestinians.

title: Death Threats Frighten Watertown
description: ''We will start shooting the children on the St. Magdalen schoolyard real soon,'' the letter began. ''Thought you should be there.''

title: Rowers Going Nowhere In Lighthearted Competition
description: Terry DeVries is a bicycle racer from Fairbanks, Alaska. Lori Rea is a world-class swimmer and a graduate student at Wichita State. Matthias Sikowski, at 6 feet 10 inches and 245 pounds, is the world's largest oarsman. Jack Fucci is a former college football player who is now an exercise physiologist for a Boston health-care center.

title: Muslim Anguish in U.S.
description: For Muslims and Arab in the United States, the uproar over ''The Satanic Verses'' has caused embarrassment and indignation. Page A6.

title: Chase Fund To Invest In Artworks
description: At a time when pieces of fine art are being sold for breathtaking prices, a unit of the Chase Manhattan Bank is seeking to raise $300 million from large pension funds to invest in paintings and other works.

title: Waltrip's Daring Pays Off at Daytona
description: Darrell Waltrip ended 16 years of frustration today with a victory in the crash-filled $1.7 million Daytona 500, winning the biggest race of his life by taking perhaps the biggest chance of his career.

title: Introducing a 3-Wheel Roller Skate
description: Joseph Wheelwright, a sculptor in Boston, has taken his work on human anatomy out of the studio and into the streets.

title: Argentine Market Closed
description: The Argentine Government said today that Monday would be a market holiday to allow it to finish drawing up new market and price measures to halt a slide in its currency. ''The objective of the exchange modifications is to increase the offer of dollars on the free-exchange market and provide greater incentives to export, while minimizing the inflationary impact,'' the central bank said. Treasury Secretary Mario Brodersohn said the measures would be announced on Monday. The Economy Ministry said on Friday that the measures would be announced today.

title: Lawyers See Hurdles For Futures Inquiry
description: A month after news of an undercover ''sting'' operation shook the commodity futures industry, defense lawyers here are predicting that the charges resulting from the investigation will involve a few minor technical trading violations rather than numerous felonies.

title: Coach Steps In For Ailing Bucks
description: The Milwaukee Bucks brought Mike Dunleavy, an assistant coach, out of retirement today and sent him into a close game with the Chicago Bulls in the final seconds.

title: A Town in Putnam Is Battling a Landfill Plan
description: Putnam County's choice of Patterson, its smallest town, as the preferred site for a modern garbage landfill has run into a mountain of old-fashioned outrage from the town's residents.

title: One Killed and One Injured in Plane Crash
description: A single-engine plane crashed and burst into flames today in a heavily wooded area of Washington County, killing one man and seriously injuring another, investigators said.

title: Hong Kong Journal; In Despair, Boat People Sign Up to Go Back Home
description: Last summer, Nguyen Minh Phuong climbed into a tiny sailboat with four other Vietnamese and made his way across the South China Sea to Hong Kong, a journey that took almost two months. Now, that same young man has volunteered to return to the country he risked his life to flee.

title: West Virginia Lifts Streak to 21
description: Chris Brooks scored 22 points and Ray Foster 17, leading 14th-ranked West Virginia past Rhode Island, 90-66, today and extending the nation's longest winning streak to 21 games.

title: Searle Loses Court Ruling
description: The $8.15 million awarded to a woman who said a birth control device sold by G. D. Searle & Company had left her infertile was not so ''shockingly excessive'' as to force a new trial, a judge has ruled.

title: Maxwell May Delay Paper
description: The British publisher Robert Maxwell canceled an important address Friday about the introduction of his English-language newspaper, The European, saying his editorial team was not yet ''pursuing shared goals and a unified concept.''

title: Discussion On Trade Progresses
description: The United States and the European Community have begun a new effort to resolve differences over long-term agricultural policy changes that caused a breakdown in talks on global trade liberalization two months ago in Montreal.

title: House Unit Studies Conduct Of Tower Geneva Colleague
description: House investigators today questioned a State Department security official for more than seven hours about his 1986 inquiry into alleged misconduct and security breaches by members of the American arms control delegation in Geneva while John G. Tower was a negotiator there.

title: Bank School in Hungary
description: Hungary opened Eastern Europe's first school of Western-style banking Friday, the latest sign of its determination to move toward a freer economy. The International Training Center for Bankers Ltd. is a joint venture of 28 Hungarian financial groups and the Paris-based Center International de Formation de la Profession Bancaire. The center is another step in Hungary's growing tolerance of market-economy practices. In November, Hungarian, Italian and United States businessmen founded a business school to train Hungarians in Western-style management practices. A stock exchange, suppressed after the Communist takeover 40 years ago, reopened in January.

title: Weekend Blazes Kill a Man And Injured 40 Firefighters
description: Fire swept through four buildings in Manhattan and Brooklyn over the weekend, killing one man, injuring at least 40 firefighters and leaving more than two dozen families without homes.

title: Sun Hires Apple Official
description: Charles Berger has resigned as vice president of integrated systems at Apple Computer Inc. and has joined Sun Microsystems Inc. of Mountain View as vice president of product marketing in the entry systems group. Mr. Berger, 35 years old, is the eighth top executive to leave Apple in its recent reorganization. At Sun, he will focus on increasing the company's share of markets dominated by Apple, said Tim Bajarin, executive vice president with the market research company Creative Strategies Research International of Santa Clara.

title: Argentine Raid Called a Political Test
