description: Dante Caputo, the Foreign Minister of Argentina, has called his Government's response to a raid by an armed band on a military outpost last month a victory for democracy in Latin America.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Nixon vs. ABC
description: Colleagues and friends of Richard M. Nixon are being urged not to cooperate in the production of an ABC Entertainment adaptation of ''The Final Days,'' the book by Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein about the Watergate scandals and the end of the Nixon Presidency in 1974.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Does Nolan Ryan hold the record for most one-hitters pitched in a career, as well as the mark for no-hitters?

title: INSIDE
description: Olympic Effort Faulted A report asserts that the United States has inadequately developed Olympic athletes. SportsMonday, C1. Doctor's Second Thoughts Eight years after Ronald Reagan was shot, his doctor says Presidential power should have gone temporarily to Vice President Bush. Page A13. Polish Accord Emerges The Polish Government and Solidarity say they agree on letting the opposition control up to 40 percent of the seats in Parliament. Page A3. Harsh Words in G.O.P. Fresh from an upset victory in Louisiana, a former Ku Klux Klan leader traded barbs with the Republican National Chairman. Page A8.

title: College Athletes Should Be Paid Openly
description: To the Editor:

title: New U.S. Rules Will Help Nursing Homes
description: In a policy change that will help many elderly people and may also significantly increase nursing home revenues, the Federal Medicare program has begun to pay the nursing home charges for thousands of people who had not previously qualified for the benefits.

title: Why Pound Life Into the Dying?
description: LEAD: Since cardiopulmonary resuscitation was introduced in 1960, it has saved countless lives.

title: Colombia Bullring Collapses; 7 Are Killed and 300 Injured
description: Seven people were killed and more than 300 injured when a temporary bullring collapsed in the small town of Honda, witnesses and officials said today.

title: Fight to Retain Polish Heritage Divides a Catholic Church
description: The bell tower high above St. Michael the Archangel Roman Catholic Church rang out in perfect harmony this morning, but the church below was closed and the members were in deep discord.

title: When Exercise Isn't Enough
description: EVER wonder how many calories a cookie contains? One typical cookie contains around 80 calories, meaning that an innocent snack of six chocolate-chip cookies and a glass of milk probably has at least 600 calories, depending on how full of chocolate and nuts the cookies are. A middle-aged male who is 6 feet and 180 pounds probably needs between 2,500 calories a day to meet his nutritional needs without gaining weight. So, the simple snack has accounted for one-quarter of what he should eat that day.

title: Searches Could Delay Overseas Air Travelers
description: Passengers flying overseas on United States airlines may have to learn new habits to avoid inconvenient searches for bombs in common electronic devices like coffeepots with electronic timers, cameras and lap-top computers.

title: Laws Shift, Theft Persists
description: Operation Sludge began in 1983 as a major drive by Federal and New York State law-enforcement agencies to stop gasoline-tax evaders.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; One Man's Suspension
description: It is no secret that the United States Commission on Civil Rights has been stalemated in recent years by ideological quarrels, but lately some of the criticism has become personal.

title: Rangers Relieved To See Slide End
description: Michel Bergeron had difficulty controlling himself all night. He hurled a water bottle into the stands, climbed atop the sideboards, rattled the protective glass, and taunted Pittsburgh players and officials alike.

title: Deciding Who Makes a Million in TV News
description: Diane Sawyer will reportedly earn $7.5 million under her new five-year contract with ABC, which hired her away from CBS with the offer of an anchor's chair. CBS is negotiating with Connie Chung of NBC for a job that will give her more visibility and most likely more than a million dollars a year. And in New York two weeks ago, the CBS flagship station hired away Ernie Anastos, an anchor at the ABC station - also for more than $1 million a year.

title: Can 2 Tracks Co-Exist in Conflict?
description: WHEN casual racing fans first heard that this year's Breeders' Cup races would be held in Florida, they may have envisioned a backdrop of flamingos at Hialeah instead of the condominiums towering behind Gulfstream Park.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Even if Salman Rushdie repents and becomes the most pious man of time it is incumbent on every Moslem to employ everything he's got, his life and wealth, to send him to hell.'' - Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini [ A1:4. ]

title: Review/Opera; New Met Lucia and Edgardo
description: This season's run of Donizetti's ''Lucia di Lammermoor'' at the Metropolitan Opera came to an end with the Saturday matinee. The cast featured performances by two young singers who had joined the production earlier in the week.

title: Winnie Mandela: A Symbol Now Tarnished
description: She was South Africa's most celebrated heroine, hailed as the ''mother of the nation,'' a woman so revered for her courage that she was nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize and offered academic honors from abroad.

title: Boston Broker is Arrested
description: A Boston stockbroker whose disappearance led to the discovery that millions of dollars of his clients' funds were also missing was arrested Friday by customs agents in Massena, N.Y.

title: Repsol's Share Offering Seen as the Boldest Ever in Spain
description: Spain's largest and most profitable industrial company, Repsol S.A., plans to begin this spring the country's most ambitious share offering ever.

title: Sink or Swim
description: While Columbia University's football team remains mired in a seemingly endless rebuilding cycle, one Columbia squad has come full circle: the men's swimming and diving team.

title: Lafayette Thwarted By Brooklyn Tech
description: Brooklyn Tech, led by Conrad McRae, its 6-foot-9-inch all-America center, eliminated Lafayette, 78-75, yesterday in overtime in the opening round of the Public Schools Athletic League playoffs. Boys and Girls defeated Grady, 79-73, in the other game at Canarsie High School with a little help from an unearned point.

title: Technology Pact for Fighter Creates Dispute With Japan
description: To the Japanese, the American tempest over the FSX fighter is a puzzling tale of what happens when two of the world's closest military allies are also two of its fiercest commercial rivals.

title: In Time, China Will Tolerate Difference Better
description: To the Editor:

title: Quick, Throttle the Prodigal Thrifts
description: The savings and loan sickness gets worse by the day. Bankrupt thrifts continue to pile up losses -more than $1.5 million every 24 hours - while solvent thrifts bicker about President Bush's plan to rescue their industry. Critics say the President's plan is inadequate. But there should be no doubt that he is on the right track. The urgent next step is for Congress to act, quickly.

title: Angola Inches Toward Capitalism
description: Behind a dirt-streaked store facade here, Ambrosio Pereira da Gama welcomed a visitor to his well-lit, air-conditioned office. He briskly proffered a new triple-tone, fold-out business card and started talking rapid-fire about his growing business empire: ice cream, baked goods, health care and tourism.

title: Lefty Gomez Was Hard to Beat
description: IN a 1931 photograph in the book ''The American League: An Illustrated History'' by Donald Honig, three strapping young ballplayers, three Yankees, are smiling into the camera. In the middle is Lefty Gomez, his glove, looking as big as a cushion (baseball gloves were puffier in those days), is thrown over the right shoulder of Bill Dickey, and Gomez's left hand - the one that won all those games - rests on the left shoulder of Lou Gehrig.

title: Book Publishers Play Catch-Up in Computers
description: For decades Harper & Row used outside designers, artists and typesetters to help prepare its book catalogues, and the process often took six to eight weeks. Now Harper's catalogues take only a few days to produce, at a savings of more than $200,000 a year.

title: TV Notes
description: ABC's New Program

title: Nike Pairs Michael Jordan With a Down-to-Earth Guy
description: As a comedy duo, Mike and Spike are no Laurel and Hardy. For starters, Spike Lee does all the talking, while Michael Jordan restricts his efforts to 360-degree reverse slam dunks and other forms of basketball artistry.

title: French Hypermarket Adjusts to U.S.
description: When Carrefour, S.A., the owner of France's largest chain of hypermarkets, decided to break into the United States, it hardly received a warm Yankee welcome.

title: Karen M. Muller, Lawyer, Married To Albert Hansen
description: Karen Marie Muller, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph J. Muller of Syracuse, and Albert Hansen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Christian R. Hansen of Briantown, Md., were married yesterday at St. Paul the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan. The Rev. Stephen Connor officiated.

title: Philip Morris Links 2 Units
description: The Philip Morris Companies announced the formation Friday of the Kraft General Foods Group to combine Kraft Inc. and the operating companies of the General Foods Corporation into one organization.

title: Flight From Albany Diverted
description: A United Airlines Boeing 727 was forced to make an unscheduled landing today, after a pilot noticed vibrations in one of the jet's three engines. Flight 597 from Albany, bound for Chicago, was diverted to Syracuse about 35 minutes after an 8:27 A.M. take-off. ''One engine developed a vibration,'' said an airline spokesman, Joseph Hopkins. ''The captain elected to make a precautionary, unscheduled landing in Syracuse.'' Mr. Hopkins said none of the flight's 84 passengers or six crew members was injured. He added that all the passengers would be scheduled onto other flights to finish the trip to Chicago.

title: Equal Opportunity - Without Minority Set-Asides
description: In City of Richmond v. J. A. Croson Co., the United States Supreme Court dealt a severe, perhaps fatal blow to local minority set-aside programs, the practice of reserving a fixed percentage, or quota, of public contracts for companies owned by minorities.

title: A Job Easier Said Than Done For New Savings-Unit Owner
description: Riding in a taxi to his newly acquired savings and loan association here, Lewis S. Ranieri was trying to explain exactly what he had received for his $200 million investment. Mid-conversation, he turned to the driver and asked whether he was riding in a Yellow Cab. Told yes, Mr. Ranieri let out a howl of laughter. ''Well,'' he said, ''we own this, for example.''

title: Tying Into a New Skill
description: One of the best books about fly tying, published this month, is titled ''Poul Jorgensen's Book of Fly Tying: A Guide to Flies for All Game Fish'' (Johnson Books, Boulder, Colo.; $19.95 paperback and $34.95 hardbound). It is superbly organized and illustrated and written with delightful clarity. It includes descriptions of tools and materials and detailed instruction on how to create flies for all situations. Jorgensen concentrates on trout, Atlantic salmon and steelhead flies. Those for saltwater species are also included, as is instruction for tying cork and hair popping bugs.

title: For Warm Change of Pace, Try Running on Indoor Track
description: IF your running needs a change of pace, or you would just like to come in from the cold, try working out at an indoor track in your area. They offer excellent opportunities to improve running form, experiment with speed training and receive expert coaching.

title: James J. Reilly, Administrator, Dies at 78
description: James J. Reilly, a former personnel director of the New York City Housing Authority, died of kidney failure Saturday at New York Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived in Forest Hills Gardens, Queens.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF First for Twiggs: Greg Twiggs shot a three-under-par 69 yesterday for a two-stroke victory in the $700,000 Shearson Lehman Hutton San Diego Open. It was his first victory in five years on the PGA Tour. Twiggs, who had a four-day total of 271 at Torrey Pines Golf Course in La Jolla, Calif., won $126,000. The third-round leader, Steve Elkington, struggled to a one-over-par 73 to finish in a second-place tie at 273 with Mark Wiebe, Brad Faxon and Mark O'Meara.(AP) Charles Takes Playoff: Bob Charles dropped a 15-foot birdie putt on the third playoff hole yesterday to win the GTE Suncoast Seniors Classic, which had ended in a four-way tie at the Tampa (Fla.) Palms Golf and Country Club. Charles closed with a six-under-par 66 for a 54-hole total of nine-under-par 207, and tied Harold Henning, Jim Ferree, and the second-round leader, Dave Hill. By the third playoff hole, only Henning and Charles remained. After Henning missed his 15-foot birdie putt, Charles sank one from the same distance to win the $45,000 first prize.(AP) SKIING Figini Wins Again: Michela Figini won her third straight World Cup downhill championship, completing a weekend sweep of the Husky double downhill in Lake Louise, Alberta, and again holding off the challenge of her Swiss teammate Maria Walliser. Figini finished in 1 minute 41.58 seconds; Walliser in 1:41.82, and Michaela Gerg of West Germany in 1:42.44.(AP) Stenmark Edges Girardelli: Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden overtook Marc Girardelli of Luxembourg with his second run and won a men's World Cup giant slalom in Aspen, Colo., yesterday. Trailing by .21 of a second after the first run, Stenmark was .33 of a second faster than the Luxembourg star on the second run. Stenmark, 32, who will retire next month, had a total time of 2 minutes 16.40 seconds. Girardelli was second in 2:16.52. (AP) HORSE RACING Gaily Gaily by a Nose: Gaily Gaily held on by a nose to edge Anka Germania, who was probably making the final start of her career, and win the $200,000 Orchid Handicap yesterday at Gulfstream Park in Florida. Gaily Gaily, a 6-year-old mare ridden by Julie Krone, paid $15.40 for $2 to win and ran the mile and a half on the grass in 2:26 4/5. She carried 110 pounds, 10 fewer than Anka Germania, a popular 7-year-old mare who had won 16 races and yesterday increased her career earnings to $959,674. Krone scored her first major stakes victory in Florida. N.B.A. Lakers 119, Celtics 110: Byron Scott scored 14 of his season-high 35 points in a span of less than eight minutes yesterday to lead Los Angeles in the teams' first matchup without both Larry Bird and Magic Johnson since the two joined the league. The Lakers earned a split of the season series with Boston, which has lost four straight road games since the All-Star Game break. (AP)

title: Review/Pop; A Bluesman Plumbs The Depths
description: Mighty Sam McClain, the opener on a soul-blues double bill at the Village Gate, delivered the show's real blues power in Saturday's early set. Mr. McClain, who recorded soul music around Louisiana during the 1960's and was rediscovered in the early 80's, plunged immediately into songs of pain-wracked romance and distant hope, pleading for release and redemption with the dramatic timing of classic blues. His face working, his voice moving from plushness to desperate rasps, Mr. McClain carried listeners through repentance, anger, uncertainty and loneliness. Even a warhorse like ''Every Day I Have the Blues'' was convincing in its misery as Mr. McClain sang, ''I just don't know what to do.''

title: Aguilera Wants Mets to Trade Him
description: The job crunch on the Mets' pitching staff sent Rick Aguilera into Davey Johnson's office today with another plea to be traded. But 20 minutes later, the 27-year-old pitcher left the office, still with no job and no promise to be traded.

title: As Hirohito Funeral Nears, Security Forces Get Nervous
description: A few weeks ago near Tokyo's famous Meiji Shrine, Takeshi Mitsu, a 21-year-old college student, got a taste of what happens these days to those who cross Japan's increasingly jittery police.

title: The Editorial Notebook; For Young Mothers: Lessons in Love
description: The seven teen-agers who live with their babies in the Bleibtreu Residence, in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx, are poor and poorly educated. At least one of them is abusive, a second may be dangerous to her child and a third has tested positive for the AIDS virus.

title: Dr. Francis X. Reynolds, 66, Bronx Surgeon
description: Dr. Francis Xavier Reynolds, a surgeon, educator and former chief of trauma service at Fordham and Misericordia hospitals, died of heart failure Saturday at Montefiore Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Landmark Appointment
description: Mayor Koch chose well in appointing David Todd to head New York's Landmarks Preservation Commission. He is an experienced architect who combines sense with sensibility. Further, he has the ability to distinguish landmarks from dross without abusing the city's architectural heritage or giving in to obstructionism.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-7

title: Karcher Executive Indicted
description: The Carl's Jr. fast-food chain's general accounting director has been indicted by a Federal grand jury on one count of securities fraud in connection with insider trading.

title: Few Expecting Pact on Coffee
description: Leading coffee trading nations are under pressure to draft a new accord to support low world prices, but few market analysts expect a breakthrough at talks scheduled to start Monday.

title: City College Works It Out
description: The 24th annual City University of New York tournament, which opens today at City College's Nat Holman Gymnasium, is a throwback to the days when students played basketball for fun and nobody dreamed of making a big impression on the National Basketball Association. And Steve Mack, a 6-foot-1-inch City College sophomore, is a throwback to the American work ethic. Welcome to the N.C.A.A. Division III.

title: A 'Strong' Earthquake Hits Japan's Capital, Killing Man
description: A strong earthquake hit the capital and much of northern Japan today, killing one person and injuring another, shaking buildings and briefly halting some train and airline service, officials said.

title: Outdoors: Find Time to Prepare for Fly Fishing
description: WITHIN a week or two, you should be seriously engaged in tying the flies that you will be using this spring, summer and fall.

title: After Years in Shadow of the U.S., Soviets Take the Mideast Initiative
description: The Soviet Union's first major Middle East initiative in years gathered momentum today with word that Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze is to meet separately with both the Israeli Foreign Minister and the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization this week to discuss revived proposals for peace.

title: Presidential Power: Reagan Doctor Says He Erred
description: Eight years after Ronald Reagan was shot and seriously wounded, his doctor at that time says he now believes Presidential power should have been temporarily transferred to Vice President George Bush.

title: Slow and Steady
description: Forgetting speed for the moment, Alfredo Rego realized his goal at the world Alpine ski championships in Vail, Colo. He entered the combined slalom, the super G, the giant slalom and the special slalom, and he finished each race. Last, to be sure, but Rego finished.

title: A.K.A. Trial Is a Study In Evasion Of Gas Tax
description: On paper, the A.K.A. Petroleum Sales Corporation appeared to be a thriving wholesale gasoline dealer, doing business throughout the New York metropolitan region. In its first five months of existence, the company bought and sold eight million gallons of gasoline and $10 million flowed through its bank accounts.

title: Review/Television; Streetwise Anthropology, on ABC
description: Set in New York City, ABC's ''Gideon Oliver'' is not likely to do much for the city's tourist trade. Tonight's premiere, at 9 on Channel 7, offers in detail a satanic cult specializing in black masses, child pornography and murders brazenly committed in public. The next installment features brutal Tong wars in Chinatown. This burg isn't even a place you'd like to visit.

title: Pentagon Cuts Contract List
description: The Defense Department said Thursday that it would soon raise the dollar amount for contracts listed in its daily report to the public and Congress.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10:30 A.M.

title: Small Businesses Deserve a Break as Much as NBC and Chase
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington's Birthday
description: NEW YORK Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only; main office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Banks: Option to close. Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation: No collections or street cleanings. Schools: Closed. Financial markets: Closed. Transportation: Subways and buses on Saturday schedules, Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North on holiday schedules. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Option to close. Schools: Option to close. Transportation: N.J. Transit on Saturday schedule, no service on the Pascack Valley and Boonton lines. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: New Haven line on holiday schedule.

title: A Pulitzer Prize Can Bring Profits as Well as Prestige
description: AROUND the country, editors, reporters and commentators who produced exceptional material last year are agonizing as they await the announcement March 30 of the Pulitzer Prizes in journalism.

title: Who Set Museum Fire? A Puzzling Jersey Arrest
description: How could a man who dedicated his personal and professional life to trying to preserve a museum end up accused of trying to destroy it?

title: GLOBAL BRIEFS
description: * Egypt will keep its oil prices unchanged for the rest of February, with the top Suez and Ras Bahar grades at $14.75 a barrel, a spokesman for the state-owned Egyptian General Petroleum Corporation said. Egypt, which is not a member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, sets prices twice monthly, based on market trends. It is taking part in a London conference of non-OPEC producers this week on measures to stabilize markets. The head of its delegation said last week that Egypt would consider cutting its oil output, which averages 870,000 barrels a day, and would abide by any agreement made by other non-OPEC producers.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Essef Corp., Mentor, Ohio, a plastics manufacturer, said John B. Calfee Jr. had been appointed vice president and chief financial officer.

title: Indiana Overcomes Michigan at Buzzer
description: Jay Edwards made a 3-pointer at the buzzer today, sending ninth-ranked Indiana past No. 13 Michigan, 76-75, and giving the Hoosiers a 15-game home winning streak.

title: Dropouts Put Lives and a Building Back Together
description: Not long ago, the gutted building at 755 Dawson Street in the South Bronx was an example of the neighborhood's neglect and abandonment. For years, it stood empty, dark and useless.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Bush Is True to Blue
description: When White House advisers were sitting around recently trying to decide what color the budget book should be, they went through as many colors as a paint store palette. The color of the budget book changes every year, so the one color they wanted to avoid was the one used by Ronald Reagan for his 1990 budget book, royal blue.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Music for a Birthday
description: The National Park Service has arranged to have some of the favorite music of George Washington's time played today at Arlington House, on the grounds of Arlington National Cemetery, in honor of the 257th anniversary of his birth. A quartet accompanied by a violinist and a pianist will perform in the main parlor room of the home that was built by Washington's adopted son, George Washington Parke Custis. The concert will consist of 18th century songs that were popular during the Founding Father's day, including ''Chester,'' ''Pop Goes the Question,'' ''Drink to Me Only With Thine Eyes,'' ''Washington's March'' and, of course, ''Yankee Doodle.''

title: ISRAELI MINISTER MEETS SOVIET AIDE IN CAIRO THIS WEEK
description: The Israeli Foreign Minister, Moshe Arens, has accepted an invitation from his Soviet counterpart, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, to meet him in Cairo this week to discuss proposals for peace in the Middle East.

title: The Weather Service Faces Cuts in Budget And Office Closings
description: The National Weather Service is facing a shortage of money and a reorganization that could lead to the closing of many local weather offices in the next several years.

title: Scripps Sells Florida Paper
description: The E. W. Scripps Company announced Friday that it had completed the sale of The Sun-Tattler, a newspaper in Hollywood, Fla., to DTH Media Inc., which owns The Dallas Times Herald. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Love of Politics Brings More
description: They met in the Maine Legislature on the Republican side of the aisle, she a raven-haired representative from Auburn and he the handsome young floor leader from Bangor.

title: New Measure Would Extend Family Leave
description: With little fanfare and so far little opposition, the General Assembly is considering what legal experts say would be the most comprehensive law in the United States to give workers the right to take time off during periods of family crisis or joy.

title: U.S. Wary of Afghan Interim Regime
description: The Bush Administration reacted cautiously today to moves by Afghan guerrilla leaders to form an interim regime that would take control in Kabul if the Soviet-backed Government fell.

title: A Soviet Shadow Over Bush's Asian Trip
description: President Bush knows the part of the world he will visit soon better than any previous President, having served in the Pacific in World War II and lived in China as Ambassador in the mid-70's. Thus, he is in a better position than most Americans to comprehend the vast changes sweeping over the region, and the opportunities and challenges that Asia poses for us.

title: Times Designer to Open Own Firm
description: Louis Silverstein, longtime publication designer for the New York Times Company, has announced that he is retiring as a consultant to the company's regional newspaper group and opening a design firm in Manhattan. The firm, Silverstein Design Associates, will specialize in promotion, graphics and publications in the United States and abroad.

title: Immigrants Share Success In Gifts to the Neediest Cases
description: Ben Steyger, who immigrated to the United States not long ago, finds living in New York City to be a struggle. Nevertheless, he has a place to stay, food to eat and a job and is ''happy to be able to live here and share the American Dream with countless others.''

title: Ex-Finance Chairman Complains Few Jobs Go to Bush Fund-Raisers
description: Robert A. Mosbacher Sr., the Commerce Secretary who was finance chairman of President Bush's campaign, says he is distressed that more campaign fund-raisers have not been rewarded with political appointments.

title: A New Knick? Not Yet
description: The wait continued yesterday as another day passed and Kiki Vandeweghe was still a Portland Trail Blazer, waiting to learn about his future.

title: Bridge
description: Suppose that you drop in to a major tournament and sit down in the South-West position to kibitz a team event. At the table are four players you do not know, and you wonder how good they are.

title: Edgar Bronfman Jr. Promoted at Seagram
description: Edgar Bronfman Jr., a young man who has moved rapidly ahead in his father's business, is getting more respect these days as a business executive and the heir apparent to the Seagram empire.

title: Limited Winter Range Starves Yellowstone Elk
description: Native elk and bison from the two largest natural herds of their species in North America are dying at rates unheard of in recent times due to subzero cold and a shortage of winter feeding range.

title: Envirodyne Chief Braces For Formal Buyout Bid
description: Ronald K. Linde, chairman and chief executive of Envirodyne Industries Inc., is waiting for details of an unsolicited offer for the company he founded in 1970.

title: Going for the Pins
description: What with a Honus Wagner fetching $100,000 or so and other rare items selling for penthouse prices, it's a bit late to get in on the ground floor of baseball card collecting.

title: Reporter's Notebook; An Art Dealers' Fair in the New York Manner
description: For five days ending yesterday, Park Avenue at 67th Street was the hottest gallery scene in town. The precincts where art is usually sold - 57th Street, SoHo, TriBeCa - were by no means deserted. But the real action was at the Seventh Regiment Armory as dealers, their clients and thousands of other art trippers disported at ''The Art Show,'' New York City's first high-level art fair. There gallery owners hoped to make new friends among the public and project a collective image as alluring as that of the auction houses.

title: Market Holiday
description: Stock, bond and futures markets are closed today in observance of Presidents' Day. Government offices and most banks are also closed, as are many businesses.

title: Maryland County Sets Health-Plan Standard
description: To the Editor:

title: Steinbrenner Report Faults U.S. Progress
description: A study by a special commission headed by George Steinbrenner has concluded that the United States Olympic Committee and its affiliated organizations have done an inadequate job developing and supporting Olympic-caliber athletes.

title: Fay Wray Writes The Story of Her Life
description: At age 81, Fay Wray is still in love with the gorilla.

title: Winner in Louisiana Vote Takes On G.O.P. Chairman
description: David Duke, former Ku Klux Klan Grand Wizard, fresh from winning a seat in the state legislature despite opposition from President Bush, today took on the chairman of the Republican National Committee.

title: After 3 Years, Crack Plague In New York Only Gets Worse
description: Looking back over the last three years, in which crack use in New York City has grown to epidemic proportions, Bronx Borough President Fernando Ferrer found a metaphor. He said it was like a balloon filled with water: ''When it's squeezed on one end, it expands in another.''

title: Fredericksburg Journal; Washington's Legends Come Home Once More
description: From the looks of the place, George Washington wouldn't want to sleep there now. The house at the end of the muddy lane is unremarkable, run down and badly in need of paint, certainly not a colonial original. All else is bramble and scrub.

title: Graf Trounces Garrison
description: Steffi Graf won the first 20 points, then capitalized on two late service breaks in the second set to win the Virginia Slims of Washington tournament today with a 6-1, 7-5 victory over Zina Garrison.

title: Barges Strike Bridge, Spilling Gas Into River
description: Seven barges carrying gasoline broke free from a towboat on the Ohio River today, spilling an estimated 40,000 gallons of fuel into the river after striking a railroad bridge piling, officials said.

title: Baltimore Symphony Ends Its Strike
description: Members of the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra ratified a contract late Saturday night that assures a minimum $1,040 a week in the 1991-92 season and ends a 22-week strike, the longest in American symphony history.

title: About-Face for 'Valley Forge' Statue? Maybe.
description: Al Frantz wants his Boy Scouts to look up to George Washington. At Washington Plaza in Brooklyn, they usually look up and see only the top of his hat and the back of his horse.

title: On Stage and Screen, Tap-Dancing's Encore
description: As a child, Bunny Briggs danced outside a record shop on 137th Street and Lenox Avenue. ''All the people came around to hear 'Amos 'n' Andy' on the radio,'' Mr. Briggs recalls. ''They'd stand around in the street and listen. Then the man who owned the shop would put on a record and I'd dance. People would throw money, and I'd take it home to my mother.''

title: Sickness in the Cockpit Simulator
description: The incidence of an illness known as simulator sickness appears to be growing among military pilots who spend long sessions at sophisticated computerized airplane simulators. Although the causes remain poorly understood, the illness appears to be related to conflicting sensations.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Magazines; Many Opinions Flourish In the Political Hothouse
description: The Don Quixote of Washington magazines is celebrating an anniversary this month, having tilted at this city's bureaucratic windmills for 20 years.

title: Cambodia Factions Mired in History
description: As they gathered here tonight to discuss a peace settlement, the warring Cambodian factions faced not only the frayed politics of the moment but the tangled and emotional residue of almost 20 years of betrayal, revolution, genocide, invasion and civil war.

title: Happy Birthday, George, et al.
description: What used to be known as George Washington's Birthday never was an excuse for big parades and fireworks. But in elementary school classrooms all over the country it was the day you took construction paper and blunt scissors and cut out your version of a cherry tree and a hatchet. Then you pasted them on the classroom window. Then you resolved never to tell a lie. Then you broke the resolution. By nightfall, usually.

title: In Time, China Will Tolerate Difference Better; Distrust of Foreigners
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Matters; Urban Dance: Choreographing The City Streets
description: Where are some of the best steps in New York? One of the worst building entrances anywhere? Which city has the worst record of preserving its sun and light? The tallest blank wall? Which city boasts the most street-smart pedestrians in the world?

title: Booksellers In Chains
description: Couple of years ago, the publisher of a novel of mine had a good idea to promote sales. She took me up to Stamford, Conn., to meet the most powerful man in American letters today: Harry Hoffman, boss of Waldenbooks, the chain of 1,200 bookstores that has brought modern merchandising techniques to the archaic book business.

title: King Kong's Obsession at the Top Again
description: Don't think for a minute that Fay Wray's encounter with an enormous gorilla atop the Empire State Building back in 1933 has made her leery about visiting New York. No, indeed.

title: Review/Book; A Reporter's Odyssey In Urban Lower Depths
description: The Lost World By Edwin McDowell 217 pages. St. Martin's Press. $15.95.

title: U.S. Muslims Embarrassed, Indignant
description: Muslim and Arab figures in the United States have expressed different views about the Salman Rushdie novel ''The Satanic Verses'' and the reaction to it in the Islamic world.

title: False Claim of Anti-Semitism Brings a Ruling of $5.5 Million
description: A Jewish businessman has been ordered to pay $5.5 million after a court found he forced a Florida restaurateur out of business by falsely accusing him of anti-Semitic conduct.

title: Eric F. Goldman, 73, a Historian And Presidential Consultant, Dies
description: Eric F. Goldman, chronicler of 20th-century America, special consultant to President Lyndon B. Johnson and an immensely popular author and lecturer at Princeton University, died of complications after a stroke yesterday at Princeton Medical Center. He was 73 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: SERIOUS DROUGHT SEEN AS UNLIKELY IN U.S. THIS YEAR
description: Heavy snow this winter has brought much-needed moisture to the Northwest, the northern Great Plains and the Rockies, leading the Agriculture Department's chief meteorologist to tell the White House and Congress that another serious drought is unlikely this year in the United States.

title: AZT Is Not a Poison
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times; The Arab World, Whose Values Lead to Troubles
description: The Closed Circle By David Pryce-Jones 464 pages. An Edward Burlingame Book/Harper & Row. $25.

title: Sidney G. Albert, Executive, 80
description: Sidney G. Albert, a philanthropist and former board chairman and president of the Albert Pipe Supply Company, died of cancer Friday at his home in Clearwater, Fla. He was 80 years old.

title: Morocco-Polisario Talks Seen
description: Polisario Front guerrillas will hold a new round of peace talks with King Hassan II of Morocco next week, the Polisario Front's secretary general, Mohammed Abdelaziz, said today. ''I received information yesterday that a second meeting will be held next week,'' said Mr. Abdelaziz, who is here on a three-day visit. Mr. Abdelaziz said the date of the meeting had not been set but it would take place in Morocco. Polisario leaders held a first round of talks with King Hassan over the disputed Western Sahara in early January.

title: Mattingly Has No Predictions for 1989
description: Except for a few players and some coaches, the clubhouse was virtually empty when Don Mattingly arrived in camp this afternoon, changed his clothes and began to lift weights. He had been in town since last Thursday, but he was here now, ready to work under the warm Florida sun, although unwilling to offer the predictions of the past.

title: PANEL CONSIDERING NEW ETHICS RULES
description: A Presidential commission is considering a radical simplification of financial disclosure forms as part of changes it recommends in the nation's ethics laws, a member of the group said today.

title: Not-So-Loyal Lieutenants
description: Life becomes lonely for New York's lieutenant governor if he doesn't get along with the governor. The rapport between the state's present Lieutenant, Stan Lundine, and Gov. Mario Cuomo has spared Mr. Lundine such isolation. It also underscores the importance of a governor choosing his own running mate.

title: Reviews/Dance; Japanese Traditional Done in Modern Guise
description: New Yorkers have seen celebrated performers of traditional and iconoclastic modern Japanese dance and theater forms. But ''Japan's Traditional Dance - Now,'' presented on Saturday night at the Carey Playhouse of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, was something new. Produced by the Japan Classical Dance Association, the program offered traditional dances interpreted by modern-day Japanese choreographers and dancers, the latter selected from members of some of the 100 or so traditional dance groups in Japan today.

title: South Dakota Workers Lose 18 Percent of Pay
description: John Morrell & Company today imposed a contract cutting the wages of 2,000 workers at its strife-torn meatpacking plant by up to 18 percent.

title: Hinson and Morris Carry Tattered Nets
description: The Nets have so many injuries these days, their locker room resembles a hospital ward.

title: Suns Activate Majerle
description: The Phoenix Suns activated Dan Majerle, a rookie guard, putting him into uniform before their game last night with the Utah Jazz and putting Steve Kerr on the injured list to make room for him. Majerle had missed the previous 28 games, having been stricken by mononucleosis in mid-December. (AP)

title: Reporter's Notebook; At Persepolis, Shadows of Two Pasts
description: There is no sound-and-light show in Persepolis anymore. Tourist buses no longer crowd the entrance to these magnificent ruins. Those palaces and temples built 2,500 years ago by the descendants of Cyrus the Great to glorify their Persian empire stand serene, surrounded by the majesty of the Zagros mountains.

title: Lebanese Army Gains Ground in Christian Areas
description: The Lebanese Army appears to have gained the upper hand after a week of violent clashes with militia fighters for control of Christian areas of Lebanon.

title: Books of The Times; An Argument for Paying No Mind to Intellectuals
description: INTELLECTUALS By Paul Johnson 385 pages. Harper & Row. $22.50.

title: John H. Blair, Lobbyist, 44
description: John H. Blair, the chief spokesman and lobbyist for Connecticut's insurance industry who was previously an aide to Gov. Ella T. Grasso, died of a heart attack today at John Dempsey Hospital here. He was 44 years old and lived in Farmington.

title: Issue for Thornburgh
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh has found himself confronting a new adversary: the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson.

title: Arena Football Is Halted
description: Arena Football will suspend operations this year while attempting to restructure, the general manager of the Detroit Drive said today.

title: A Medical Mystery
description: THE President may be a very special patient, but that does not guarantee dependable handling of his medical records. Consider the case of the missing X-rays.

title: Settlement of S.E.C. Charges By Drexel Is Said to Be Near
description: Significant progress has been made toward settlement of a wide variety of civil charges brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission against Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., people involved in the talks said yesterday.

title: Here's a Big Surprise: Homework Is Disliked
description: A study in which students carried electronic beepers and recorded their feelings whenever researchers signaled them indicates that some stereotypes about the adolescent psyche are false.

title: Islam and the West
description: Is the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, in demanding the execution of Salman Rushdie, really defending the faith of Islam, which he contends was blasphemed by certain passages in Mr. Rushdie's novel ''The Satanic Verses''?

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Beira Journal; Road to Prosperity Has a Special Hazard: Rebels
description: On the 180-mile pockmarked road that connects this coastal town on the Indian Ocean with landlocked Zimbabwe, there are good zones and bad.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 The recall of diplomats from Iran was agreed upon by the 12 European Community nations to protest Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's death threats against Salman Rushdie, author of ''The Satanic Verses.'' Page A1

title: Crop Study Finds Severe Ozone Damage
description: LEAD: OZONE, which at ground level is an air pollutant, can reduce grain crop yields far more severely than previously known, scientists have reported. The report suggests that farmers can lose as much as 30 percent of a potential crop from ozone pollution, even at levels that comply with Federal standards.

title: Argentina Seeks to Rebuild Links to Paraguay
description: Soon after Gen. Alfredo Stroessner seized power in Paraguay in 1954, he began reducing the country's links to Argentina and set about building what eventually became a relationship of economic, political and military dependence on Brazil.

title: In China, Democracy Makes Yet Another Big Comeback
description: Like the bamboo shoots that emerge everywhere after a spring rain, to use a Chinese simile, democracy is sprouting again in China.

title: 2-Year and 5-Year Notes to Be Auctioned
description: The Treasury's schedule of new issues for this holiday-shortened week include today's regular weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills. New two-year notes will be auctioned tomorrow and five-year notes will be sold on Thursday.

title: U.S. SET TO DETAIN REFUGEES IN TENTS BEGINNING TODAY
description: The Federal Government announced plans today to detain Central Americans who file invalid claims for political asylum and hold them in a tent city it will erect near here with space for 5,000 people.

title: Motel Body Ruled a Homicide
description: A woman whose body was found in a motel room here over the weekend was the victim of a homicide, the Nassau County police said today. Tabitha Vaughn, 19 years old, of Hempstead, was strangled, the police said, and investigators are seeking a man who checked into the Hempstead Motor Inn at 131 Hempstead Avenue with her at 8:40 Saturday morning. The couple rented the room for four hours, and the body was found just before 2 P.M.

title: Heart Drug Shows Promise in Strokes
description: THE patient was already in the hospital when he suffered a massive stroke that paralyzed his entire left side. It began about 10 P.M.

title: New Hungarian Constitution To Yield Some Party Primacy
description: Hungary's leaders agreed today to drop the constitutional guarantee of a leading political role for the Communist Party when a new charter is published this year.

title: Review/Television; Evolution vs. Creation
description: Although clashes between evolutionists and creationists continue to generate heat around the United States, they do not set off intellectual sparks these days. As ''God, Darwin and Dinosaurs'' reports, the nation's scientific community dismisses the belief that man was created in more or less his present form as based on faith in the Bible rather than in the findings of laboratory or field. Rejecting supernatural explanations, the evolutionists see man's development as the product of a very long process of human genes interplaying with the environment. And the courts have ruled repeatedly that creationism's attachment to religion bars it from being taught in the public schools.

title: Reviews/Music; Recorders in Transcriptions
description: In celebration of the American Recorder Society's 50th anniversary, the Music Before 1800 series at Corpus Christi Church presented a concert by the Amsterdam Loeki Stardust Quartet, a Dutch recorder ensemble, on Sunday afternoon. The program was devoted the transcriptions of late Renaissance viol music and Baroque works originally composed for strings or organ.

title: INSIDE
description: Mideast Diplomatic Moves The Soviet Foreign Minister, in Cairo, claimed new Arab support for Moscow's latest proposals, but he faced little prospect of Israeli assent in talks later in the week. Page A6. Gorbachev in Kiev The Soviet leader ventured into the streets of Kiev to drum up support for his policies, only to be confronted with complaints. Page A3. The Uprising's Wounded The Palestinian uprising against Israel is producing many permanently disabled victims, most of them uninsured, and Arab groups are hard-pressed to provide for them. Page A6. Fairfield Loses Some Luster Fewer companies are relocating to Fairfield's Gold Coast, dissuaded by high prices and traffic and forced out by corporate mergers. Page B1. Sex and Drugs at Kingsboro Officials are looking into charges that adolescents at a psychiatric center were having sex and smoking crack in abandoned rooms. Page B1.

title: Mets' Aging Stars See Only New Beginnings
description: If there are two marked men in the training camp of the Mets, they are Gary Carter and Keith Hernandez, the captains, aging stars with the best records on the team, both earning $2 million a year, both entering the final year of their contracts at the age of 35 with everybody wondering: Is this the end?

title: Writers Defend Rushdie
description: Writers, publishers and human rights organizations in London formed a committee today to challenge the death sentence proclaimed by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini on the author Salman Rushdie.

title: It's Tight Squeeze, but 2 Men Escape Jail in Bergen County
description: Two men convicted of armed robbery escaped from the Bergen County Jail annex today through a hole less than a foot wide and two feet high, the Sheriff's Department said.

title: Cambodian Dream
description: One week after starting to work at the White House, Sichan Siv remains awe-struck. ''It still is a dream,'' said Mr. Siv, the only Cambodian-American working as a senior official in the White House, a 40-year-old who endured his own version of the killing fields of his homeland.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: British Base Is Bombed; Soldiers Unhurt
description: More than 50 soldiers escaped injury today when they were evacuated minutes before a series of explosions extensively damaged their barracks in central England.

title: New York's Garbage Disposal Plans Won't Do for 21st Century
description: To the Editor:

title: Results Plus
description: SKIING Sweden Sweeps 15K Freestyle: Gunde Svan skied to an expected victory and Jari Puikkonen flew to an unexpected triumph yesterday at the world Nordic championships in Lahti, Finland. Svan, the Swede who has been the world's best cross-country skier this decade, led the men's 15K freestyle race from start to finish. Torgny Mogren finished as runner-up and Lars Haland was third. It was Sweden's first sweep of the medals in this distance in world championship history. Puikkonen dethroned the triple Olympic champion, Matti Nykanen, by soaring 113.5 and 107 meters for 218.5 points. (AP) HORSE RACING Its Acedemic Triumphs: Its Acedemic, ridden by Diane Nelson, came from off the pace to score a 2 1/4-length victory in the $115,000 Stymie Handicap for horses 3-years-old and up at Aqueduct yesterday. Congeleur was runner-up in the field of seven, another seven lengths ahead of Lord of the Night. The victory was the third straight for Its Acedemic and the second consective stakes victory. The 5-year-old son of Sauce Boat-After School took Aqueduct's Assault Handicap on Jan. 28. Its Acedemic covered the mile and an eighth on the fast track in 1:51 1/5 to earn $69,000 for Marcus Vogel and returned $4.20 for $2 to win. Feather Ridge Wins Golden Grass: Feather Ridge, a Kentucky Derby nominee, ran down Group Process in the stretch and drew away to a 2 1/2-length victory in the $64,150 Golden Grass Stakes yesterday at Gulfstream Park. Group Process, the early leader, held second by 1 3/4 lengths over Ringerman, and it was another 2 1/4 lengths to Verbatree, the 2-to-1 favorite in a field of 11. Feather Ridge, a Cox's Ridge colt owned by Taylor Asbury and trained by Rusty Arnold, ran the mile and a sixteenth on the grass in a stakes record 1:41 3/ 5 under Randy Romero, and paid $19.40 for $2 to win. N.H.L. Kings 5, Maple Leafs 4: Wayne Gretzky scored two goals and had an assist and Mike Allison, getting a chance to play on Gretzky's line, added a goal and two assists to lead Los Angeles to a victory over the Toronto last night in Inglewood, Calif. Gretzky, who reached the 1,800-point plateau with a 7-point game Saturday night, and Allison, a former Maple Leaf, combined up to give Los Angeles its first lead, 3-2, at 7 minutes 49 seconds of the second period.(AP) Flames 6, Capitals 2: Hakan Loob had a goal and two assists for Calgary at home. Larry Murphy and Geoff Courtnall were the only Capitals to beat the Flame goaltender, Rick Wamsley, both in the third period after Calgary had mounted a 6-0 lead.(AP) BASKETBALL/WOMEN Maryland 88, Clemson 63: Vicky Bullett scored 26 points to lead Maryland to a victory over Clemson last night in an Atlantic Coast Conference in College Park, Md. The Lady Terrapins improved to 22-2, 12-1 in the A.C.C. The Lady Tigers fell to 15-9 and 7-5.(AP)

title: PARTY WON'T PRESS G.O.P. IN LOUISIANA
description: Despite statements by the Republican national chairman that a former Ku Klux Klan member elected in Louisiana under the Republican banner should be driven from the party, Republican officials said today that the party would not pressure Republicans in the state to exclude him from their legislative caucus.

title: Mainstream Islam Rapidly Embraced By Black Americans
description: Over the din of a nearby commuter train roaring from the elevated line into a tunnel in Brooklyn, the voice from a megaphone intones in Arabic: ''Allah is great. . . . Come to prayer. . . .''

title: Coats That Shun Any Shower and Lift Spirits, Too
description: Slide a shiny red coat lined with small red and white gingham checks over a skinny white wide-wale pique jump suit, and you're ready to face the sunniest spring day. In case it's windy and cold instead of balmy, the coat is roomy enough to slip on over a bulky sweater or even a jacket.

title: New York's Principals Tell Why They 'Break the Rules'
description: New York City principals say they are beleaguered by daily stresses and frustrations - comforting children frightened by the surrounding streets and plowing through mounds of paperwork - that hamper their ability to run effective schools.

title: Lauder Spends Heavily on Campaign
description: Just three weeks into his New York City mayoral campaign, Ronald S. Lauder has already spent $500,000 for television advertising and has hired a 12-person staff and at least five consultants.

title: Alcohol and Muscles
description: The amount of alcohol consumed over a lifetime contributes to heart and muscle weakness, according to a study conducted by Spanish and American researchers. The study involved 50 chronic alcoholics and 50 healthy men of similar age. Nearly half of the alcoholics suffered weakness of their shoulder and pelvic muscles and a third had damaged heart muscles.

title: LIT America Makes Changes To Address Consolidation
description: LIT America Inc. has named David J. Vogel as its chairman and chief executive and John J. Ruth as its president and chief operating officer.

title: Bees' Threat Arises From Mass Attacks
description: THE threat from Africanized ''killer'' bees arises from their mass attacks rather than their venom, according to research reported in a recent issue of the journal Nature.

title: New York's Garbage Disposal Plans Won't Do for 21st Century; Commuter Recycling
description: To the Editor:

title: Should Computer Orphans Fight or Switch?
description: THERE are a lot of computer orphans out there.

title: Dollar and Gold End Higher
description: The dollar rose today against all major currencies in European trading, subdued by the closing of United States markets for the President's Day holiday. Gold prices also moved higher. Dealers said the dollar received a slight lift from Friday's announcement that the United States trade deficit narrowed to $11.9 billion in December from a revised November figure of $12.2 billion.

title: Drug Agents Arrest 12 People In 3 Heroin Raids in Queens
description: Twelve people were arrested and 100 pounds of heroin was seized during raids on three homes in College Point, Queens, last night, the police said.

title: Chicago Board Discussing Trading Link With London
description: The Chicago Board of Trade has begun talks with the London International Financial Futures Exchange about the possibility of hooking up their similar electronic trading systems, an exchange official said.

title: Afghan Premier Quits as Effort For Pact Fades EUROPEANS RECALL ENVOYS FROM IRAN OVER RUSHDIE CASE
description: The Prime Minister of Afghanistan resigned today in a move seen by American experts as symbolizing the failure of efforts to establish a broad-based coalition government of national reconciliation.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. Calls on Bush To Intervene in Eastern Case
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. urged President Bush today to intervene in the bitter dispute between Eastern Airlines Inc. and its machinists by appointing an emergency mediation board to avert a strike that could take place on March 3.

title: Mathematicians Link Knot Theory to Physics
description: MATHEMATICIANS and physicists have discovered that a major tool in knot theory, a branch of mathematics, applies as well to elementary particle physics.

title: Our Towns; A Mind Erodes, A Wife Goes On, But With Dignity
description: rrThe other day, W. H. Ferry was making his quarterly visit to his longtime acquaintances, the Mumfords, when the subject turned to suicide. Writing had been everything to Lewis Mumford, the great architectural critic and urban historian who is now 93 years old. He wrote 29 books, the last when he was in his mid-80's. He kept trying to write, even as his mind began to go.

title: Dr. Edith Taglicht Schmidt, Psychologist, 88
description: Dr. Edith Taglicht Schmidt, founding director of the Educational Institute for Learning and Research, died Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 88 years old.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
An Ex-Im Bank Head Gets Post at Moody's
description: LEAD: John A. Bohn Jr. has been named president of Moody's Investors Service Inc., says its parent, the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation. He will assume his duties on March 1.

title: Market Place; Valley National: Different Opinions
description: JAMES SIMMONS says he has seen it all before, and he isn't worried. ''I've been here 30 years, and this is the fourth real estate downturn that we've had,'' said Mr. Simmons, chairman of the Valley National Corporation, the owner of Arizona's largest bank.

title: Cubans Are Curious to See U.S. TV
description: From President Fidel Castro to the most anonymous of students, Cubans are awaiting an American television station that is expected to bring them news, sports, music videos and soap operas whether they like it or not.

title: Shevardnadze Claims New Arab Support for Peace Bid
description: The Soviet Foreign Minister claimed new Arab support today for Moscow's latest Middle East proposals in Egypt, but he faced little prospect of Israeli assent in discussions here later in the week.

title: At Last, Plain Words About the Sudan
description: Secretary of State James Baker has broken an unbecoming silence on the Sudan. Pressed by Congress, Mr. Baker has issued a written statement expressing ''profound concern'' about ''massive human suffering'' caused by the Sudan's six-year civil war: ''Most of the war's victims are civilians who are displaced and impoverished, or who starve to death for lack of delivery of available food. The death toll from starvation in 1988 alone is estimated to range in the hundreds of thousands.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about a Soviet appeal for American help in securing an Afghan cease-fire misstated remarks by Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, about Soviet advisers in Afghanistan.

title: Nomination Intricacies For Foreign-Film Oscar
description: When the Academy Award nominations were announced last Wednesday, the list included ''The Music Teacher,'' a Belgian film that few academy members had seen and most had never heard of.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Pro Bono
description: * Apple Inc., a drug treatment agency, has selected Bergelt Litchfield, Inc. to handle its public relations and advertising.

title: Rushdie And Us
description: LEAD: The First Amendment, which guarantees freedom of speech, is a straightforward statement and one that Waldenbooks wholeheartedly endorses. It's a statement I've had occasion to consider from a variety of perspectives in recent days.

title: Sutter Out 5 Games
description: Duane Sutter of the Chicago Blackhawks was suspended for five games yesterday by the National Hockey League for a stick incident involving Neil Sheehy of the Washington Capitals. With five seconds left in the game Feb. 15, Sutter struck the Capital defenseman with his stick. He was assessed a high-sticking major and a match penalty, and the foul prompted a videotape review by Brian O'Neill, the National Hockey League executive vice president who handles discipline. O'Neill said in a statement, ''Despite the fact no injury resulted to the Washington player, this incident was deliberate and cannot be condoned by the league.''(AP)

title: Groh Joins Giants
description: The Giants, who had been looking for a defensive backfield coach, ended their search yesterday in an unusual way. They hired Al Groh as linebacker coach and said that Bill Belichick, the defensive coordinator, would double as defensive backfield coach. Len Fontes, who coached the Giants' secondary for six years, resigned after last season. Groh, 44, had been South Carolina's offensive coordinator. A New York City native, he coached with Bill Parcells, now the Giants' head coach, at Army (1968-69) and the Air Force Academy (1978). Groh was the head coach at Wake Forest from 1981 to 1986 and the special-teams coach for the Atlanta Falcons in 1987. At South Carolina, he was considered a candidate for the head coaching job after Coach Joe Morrison suffered a fatal heart attack Feb. 5. Groh was not interviewed for the vacancy. Last night The Associated Press reported that Sparky Woods, who guided Appalachian State to Southern Conference titles in 1986 and 1987, would be South Carolina's new coach. The South Carolina athletic director, King Dixon, would not confirm Dixon's appointment. He said a news conference would be held today.

title: Thayer Cumings, Ex-Executive, Dies at 84
description: Thayer Cumings, an advertising executive who worked for Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborne and a predecessor agency for more than 30 years, died Sunday after a long illness at his home in York Harbor, Me. He was 84 years old and also had a home in Manhatttan.

title: BASEBALL: Hershiser Paying Price For New-Found Fame; He Wants Some Time to Himself
description: The aftermath of his unprecedented feats became more difficult than the feats themselves, Orel Hershiser said today as he sought the seclusion of spring training.

title: Q&A
description: Q.I used to hear the saying, ''Green Christmas, full graveyard.'' Is there a correlation, for example, between warm winter weather and flu deaths? A.There is no evidence of any link between warm winters and flu deaths, said Dr. Walter J. Gunn, an epidemiologist with the viral diseases division of the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta.

title: Fruit of That Forbidden Tree an Apricot?
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Make National Youth Service a Ghetto; Open Program to All
description: To the Editor:

title: Imhausen Aide Says Concern Shipped Ecstasy Drug to U.S.
description: A West German company suspected of playing a key role in building a poison-gas factory in Libya said today that it produced and shipped an illegal drug known as Ecstasy to the United States.

title: Biologists Say Radios May Harm Rare Owls
description: Are the spotted owls that live in the ancient forests of the Northwest really endangered or are they being victimized by the miniature radio transmitters that scientists use to track their movements?

title: Test-Tube Insect Parts Aid Study On Pests
description: INSECT wings grown in laboratory dishes from a few dissected cells are being used in research aimed at producing environmentally sound ways of halting the development of crop-damaging pests.

title: Farley Extends Bid
description: Farley Inc. extended its $1.53 billion tender offer for the textile giant West Point-Pepperell Inc. on Friday, the second time in a week and 12th over all, setting the latest deadline for midnight Tuesday. The expiration of the $52-a-share offer had been extended from midnight Wednesday to midnight Friday earlier last week.

title: F.D.A. Acts To Speed Approval Of Drugs
description: In a two-year project started last week, a group of experts is updating research guidelines for manufacturers in an effort to speed the approval process for antibiotics to treat infectious diseases.

title: New Editor at Journalism Review
description: Suzanne Braun Levine, a former editor of Ms. magazine, has been appointed editor of The Columbia Journalism Review. She succeeds Spencer Klaw, who left the magazine after the January-February issue and who will retire at the end of this month from his faculty responsibilities at the Graduate School of Journalism at Columbia University.

title: Women Triumphant In Claire Bloom Series
description: ''No, 'feminist' is not the right word for it,'' said Claire Bloom, speaking of the series of three readings entitled ''These Are Women'' that she will present at the New York Public Library beginning tonight.

title: REPORT ON TOWER IS SAID TO SATISFY THE WHITE HOUSE
description: President Bush reviewed the latest F.B.I. report on John G. Tower today and concluded that there was nothing in it to prevent the former Texas Senator's confirmation as Secretary of Defense, the White House said.

title: Panhandle Agrees to Buy Gas Concern
description: The Texas Eastern Corporation, a major pipeline company that transports natural gas to the Northeast from the Gulf Coast, has accepted a friendly takeover offer valued at $3.2 billion from the Panhandle Eastern Corporation, the companies said today.

title: Study Finds Servicewomen Harassed
description: American military women serving in Southern Europe have been sexually harassed by European and American men, have mistakenly thought they would be evacuated in wartime and have weakened their units by being absent while pregnant, an unpublished report says.

title: Family on Trip to Disneyland And 3 Others Killed in Crash
description: A family of seven on a trip to Disneyland was among the 10 people killed when a chartered twin-engine plane crashed into a mountain peak in southern California, aviation officials said today.

title: The Palestinian Cost: To Be Young and Maimed
description: Huddled in a wheelchair against a warm radiator, lifeless legs tangled beneath her, 19-year-old Zuhriyeh Naji thought aloud about the life that lay ahead, and her despondency bordered on despair.

title: Unique Problems for a Physician Who Makes (White) House Calls
description: TO many, the White House physician may seem to hold a glamorous government position. But to Dr. Daniel Ruge, who was the physician during Ronald Reagan's first term, the job of caring for a healthy President is ''vastly overrated, boring and not medically challenging.''

title: 5 People Killed As Planes Crash In Adirondacks
description: Five people died and a sixth was injured critically Sunday in the crash of two small private planes in the Adirondack Mountains in upstate New York.

title: Boeing Curtails Testing Of New Bomber's Bolts
description: A Boeing Company subsidiary may have curtailed testing of nuts and bolts for the Air Forces' new B-2 stealth bomber in order to save money, according to a report published Sunday.

title: Sooners Cancel Reunion
description: The 1949 Oklahoma football team announced yesterday that it has canceled its April reunion to express embarrassment over recent problems plaguing the university's football program. In a letter, James D. Owens, co-captain of the 1949 team, said he did not plan to take part in any reunions on campus ''until a drastic change in leadership takes place.'' Owens said he had contacted a ''representative number'' of his teammates, ''and they have concurred that we should cancel our reunion.'' In December, the Oklahoma football program was placed on probation by the National Collegiate Athletic Association. Since then, five Sooner football players have been arrested. Owens did not attend the news conference. His letter was read by J. D. Roberts of Oklahoma City, president of the O Club, a group of former Oklahoma athletes. Roberts, referring to the Oklahoma football coach and athletic director, said the letter meant the 1949 team was calling for ''some sort of action, I suppose to relieve people of their jobs.'' Coach Barry Switzer issued a statement saying he found it ''regrettable'' that the 1949 team felt compelled to speak out on the current team's leadership.(AP)

title: New Tactics Emerge In Struggle Against Smog
description: AFTER two decades of progress, the campaign to control smog from cars and trucks is now losing ground because of an enormous increase in the number of vehicles on the road. Experts believe that new anti-pollution strategies may be needed to hold hazardous exhaust emissions in check.

title: 100 More Rare Ferns Found
description: The known population of one of the rarest plants in North America has been increased more than tenfold by the discovery of about 100 more. Before the discovery of the additional Aleutian-Shield ferns, biologists thought only six of the plants remained. The fern is unique to two of the Aleutian Islands. Botanists say they believe it comes from pre-glacial times and survived in a few mountain areas that escaped the glaciers.

title: Chess
description: The first player to score in a short match, as in the recent six-game elimination quarterfinals for world championship candidates, is supposed to have a great advantage, yet the results did not bear that out.

title: North's Trial in Iran-Contra Case to Begin Today
description: The criminal trial of Oliver L. North begins Tuesday morning in Federal District Court here, promising more political and legal drama than insights into the scandal that gave birth to the case about 28 months ago.

title: Man Returns Two Money Bags, Unopened
description: A man said he was not at all tempted to find out what was in two locked canvas bags he discovered on a street over the weekend, but his interest was piqued when he learned what was inside.

title: John Cheever's Wife Wins Ruling in Book Dispute
description: A court order has been issued in Chicago in the yearlong contract dispute between Mary Cheever, the widow of the writer John Cheever, and Academy Chicago Publishers, a small independent publishing house. The order says Mrs. Cheever fulfilled her obligations to the publisher by providing 15 uncollected stories of her own choosing for an Academy Chicago edition of Cheever works. The publisher had planned a volume of 68 stories but was stopped from bringing it out last year when Mrs. Cheever contended in the state lawsuit that the contract was invalid.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Feb. 20, 1989: MONDAY Baxter Intl Inc Dana Corp Financial Corp St Barbra Genuine Parts Co Goodrich BF Co Nafco Finl Group Inc Ntl Convenience Stores Wendys Intl Inc TUESDAY Coleman Inc First UN Corp Foote Cone & Belding Gap Inc Interpublic Group K N Energy Inc Long Drug Stores Corp Ohio Edison Co Pub Svc Enterprise Group Reebok Intl Ltd WEDNESDAY Cigna Corp Deere & Co First Va Bks Inc Penn Pwr & Lt Co Philip Morris Cos Scana Corp Service Corp Intl UnionFed Finl Corp THURSDAY Amcast Indl Corp Arvin Inds Inc Conseco Inc Contel Corp Eastern Gas & Fuel Emhart Corp VA Interlake Corp Loctite Corp Pennzoil Co Springs Inds Inc Union Pac Corp Unisys Corp FRIDAY Aetna Life & Cas Co Dexter Corp Graco Inc Harris Corp Del Nashua Corp Pacific Telesis Group Piedmont Nat Gas Inc USLICO Corp Whittaker Corp

title: Cavaliers (39-12) Win 18th in a Row at Home
description: Mark Price scored 27 points and Larry Nance blocked seven shots today as the Cleveland Cavaliers used a relentless defense to beat the Houston Rockets, 110-90. It was the Cavaliers' 18th consecutive victory at home.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Foreign Ministers view those threats with the gravest concern. They condemn this incitement to murder as an unacceptable violation of the most elementary principles and obligations that govern relations among sovereign states.'' - The European Community Foreign Ministers, on Iranian threats against the author Salman Rushdie. [ A8:1. ]

title: Museum on Kennedy Opens in Dallas
description: The sixth floor of the former Texas School Book Depository, the place from which Lee Harvey Oswald shot President John F. Kennedy, was opened to the public today for the first time since the assassination 25 years ago. It has been made into a Kennedy museum with an emphasis on the events surrounding the assassination.

title: John Senise Wed To Hillary Fabian
description: The marriage of Hillary Fabian, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Fabian of Forest Hills, Queens, to John Senise, the son of Adeline Senise of Little Neck, Queens, took place last evening at the 5 and 10 No Exaggeration restaurant in SoHo. Rabbi Milton Goodman officiated.

title: Rangers Hope for Help From Czechoslovak Star
description: The Rangers signed another finesse-style defenseman, Miroslav Horava of Czechoslovakia, yesterday in an attempt to improve their power play or enhance a trade.

title: How Guns Are Classified
description: All firearms, whether military assault rifles or civilian pistols, are classified into three broad categories: fully automatic, semiautomatic and other. The groupings are based on how the weapon fires and loads bullets into its chamber for the next firing.

title: McKay's First Goal Goes Well Beyond Money
description: Had Antonio McKay run in indoor track meets Friday night in Los Angeles or Saturday night in Cleveland, he would have earned handsome appearance fees. He also would have probably earned points that would have given him a better chance to win the $16,000 prize as the men's overall winner in the indoor Grand Prix.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Swatch Watch Has Campaign
description: Ernest Hemingway might have worn a Swatch Watch, if the company's new ad campaign is any indication of the type of person who owns the trendy timepiece. While the ads do not feature bullfighting, they depict some of the more dangerous leisure activities in the world, including paraponting over thousand-foot waterfalls.

title: Buddhists in U.S. Agonize on AIDS Issue
description: America's largest Tibetan Buddhist group has been thrown into turmoil by allegations that its leader knew he had AIDS and transmitted it to his sexual partners.

title: Does 'Drug Czar' Face A Mission Impossible?
description: Even before William J. Bennett takes office to lead the Federal effort against illegal drugs, key officials who championed the new post are skeptical that he will acquire sufficient influence to succeed in what many regard as a kind of Mission Impossible.

title: Frederick Weitzen, 77, Bookstore Founder
description: Frederick Weitzen, a bookseller who pioneered in mail-order techniques and who was a founder of the Marboro Books retail chain, died of lung cancer on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 77 years old. Mr. Weitzen, with Frank Bang and Henry Exstein, started Marboro in 1946 as a mail-order enterprise, advertising extensively to promote sales of popular books at low prices. The small-print advertisements, sometimes four newspaper pages long, summarized hundreds of books, many of them reprints and publishers' remainders.

title: At Chicago Boards, Styles Differ
description: Whether the subject is baseball or commodities, Chicago is a city that breeds different styles at its rival institutions and fierce loyalties among their supporters.

title: Focus Is on Greenspan Testimony
description: Amid growing concern in the markets on the direction of interest rates, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, faces Congress today in the start of two days of testimony on the Fed's outlook for monetary policy, the economy and inflation.

title: Don't Make National Youth Service a Ghetto; Start Them Younger
description: To the Editor:

title: LIBRARIANS FIGHT GOVERNMENT PLAN
description: Librarians are protesting a proposal that would take the Government out of the business of interpreting and organizing some of its computerized information.

title: Unusual Forces Help Move Rangers Into First
description: The list of players injured or suspended was lengthy and therefore the possibility existed that the Rangers might spend the afternoon against the Devils discovering a large assortment of excuses to match.

title: Don't Make National Youth Service a Ghetto
description: To the Editor:

title: Senator Opens His Campaign To Be Governor of California
description: Senator Pete Wilson, who won re-election to his second six-year term just three months ago, today announced his candidacy for the Republican nomination for governor in 1990.

title: Redskins Sign Tice
description: Mike Tice, the Seattle Seahawks' veteran tight end, has signed a three-year, $1.1 million contract with the Washington Redskins. 4 million. Tice was the first of 19 Seahawks left unprotected under the National Football League's new free-agency plan to sign with another team.(AP)

title: Salvadoran Party Leaders Open Talks With Insurgents in Mexico
description: Representatives of El Salvador's main political parties today began their first formal talks with leaders of the guerrilla movement that has sought for nearly a decade to bring down the country's American-backed Government.

title: Want a Happy Marriage? Learn to Fight a Good Fight
description: WHAT'S the difference between a marriage that gets happier as time goes on and one that grows more miserable? In many cases it is fights, according to a new study that pinpoints exactly which kinds of arguments help a couple grow closer and which split them apart.

title: Public Split Evenly On Whether North Should Face a Trial
description: The American public is evenly split over whether Oliver L. North should go to trial or the charges against him should be dropped, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: When Is a Winter Not Wintry? Now!
description: Holden Caulfield, the disaffected teen-ager of ''The Catcher in the Rye'' who fretted about where the ducks in Central Park go for the winter, need not have worried this year. They didn't go anywhere. Elsewhere in Central Park, it has been so warm that people taking cross-country skiing lessons from the Park Rangers have had to practice indoors. ''We usually set up some kind of carpeted area inside, so people can try out their actual skis,'' said Namshik Yoon, who is known professionally as Ranger Namshik.

title: Metro Datelines; Princeton Male Clubs May Face Top Court
description: The nine-year legal battle over whether Princeton University's two all-male eating clubs should be forced to admit women could end soon before the New Jersey Supreme Court.

title: By Design
description: It's that time of year - winter receding, spring not quite here - when everyone's wardrobe could use a little fashion pick-me-up. This season consider a colorful handbag.

title: Minorco Lifts Bid for Gold Fields
description: The overseas investment arm of South Africa's Anglo American and De Beers group today began a new, record-setting bid for Consolidated Gold Fields P.L.C. of Britain that values the company at $5.65 billion.

title: Turtle Safety Device Cuts Shrimp Catch
description: Trap doors on shrimp nets save the lives of sea turtles, but they significantly reduce the shrimpers' catch, researchers have found.

title: Iran-Contra Trial On Today, at Last
description: Twenty-eight months after the Iran-contra scandal broke, the trial of the central figure in the case, Oliver L. North, begins today. But it promises more political and legal drama than insight into the scandal because of successful Government objections to the use of secret material. Article, page A19.

title: Epidemic in Urban Hospitals: Wounds From Assault Rifles
description: In the roughest neighborhoods of cities besieged by the drug trade, where buildings are pocked with bullet holes and the streets ring with gunfire, hospitals have become urban MASH units, with paramedics and doctors treating wounds once seen only on the battlefield.

title: Final Touches Put on Savings Plan
