description: The Bush Administration, putting the final touches on the savings bailout plan it will present to Congress this week, has made a number of modest changes that will make the proposal somewhat less onerous for the banking and savings industries, an Administration official said today.

title: Fairfield County Losing Its Corporate Midas Touch
description: Here on Connecticut's Gold Coast, where scores of company headquarters relocated in the 1970's and early 1980's, the great corporate migration from Manhattan has all but ended.

title: Dinah Halpern, Actress, 79
description: Dinah Halpern, a Yiddish actress who appeared in New York, Chicago and Europe, died of cancer on Saturday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Chicago. She was 79 years old and lived in Chicago.

title: Colonel North's Other Commander
description: One Oliver North trial has already ended - the trial over whether there would even be a trial. Today, after three weeks of jury selection and arguments over classified documents, a second Oliver North trial begins. The former Marine lieutenant colonel faces charges of lying to Congress about the Iran-contra affair. What Judge Gerhard Gesell calls the ''triability'' of the criminal case will remain in peril throughout. But there is a powerful reason for enduring all the complexity and maneuvering.

title: Drugs and Sex Investigated At Kingsboro
description: State mental health officials are investigating charges that adolescent patients at Kingsboro Psychiatric Center in Brooklyn used abandoned rooms on the aging 28-acre campus to have sex and to use drugs.

title: Text of European Statement
description: Following is the text of the declaration by the European Community Foreign Ministers on Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's call for the death of the British author Salman Rushdie:

title: Reading Scores: Additional Data
description: The following table supplements information released Thursday by the New York City Board of Education on the reading tests given in the city's public elementary and junior high schools in May 1988. It gives information about schools' performance compared with their performance the previous year, omitted from a chart published in The Times on Friday.

title: Eight Events Demoted From Grade I Status
description: After a decade of pretending that American racing was getting better by the year, the committee that designates the relative importance of the year's top races has finally reversed itself and begun to tell the truth.

title: Playland Inquiry an Issue In District Attorney Race
description: An investigation into charges linking the Westchester Republican Party to a corruption scandal at the Playland Amusement Park in Rye has become a factor in the county race for district attorney, as the Republican incumbent has asked Gov. Mario M. Cuomo to appoint a special prosecutor.

title: Reviews/Music; Bellicose Handel Oratorio With the Gardiner Touch
description: John Eliot Gardiner belongs to the first circle of England's busy early-music leaders, and his presentation of Handel's ''Israel in Egypt'' at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday afternoon gave many reminders of why. It was almost nothing like the Handel oratorio performances most of us grew up on, and it was very beautiful at its best.

title: Reviews/Dance; New Cast in 'Serenade'
description: Who is to say which is the greatest performance a specific ballet has ever received? It is an impossible question. But a possible answer with respect to ''Serenade'' lies with the power and passion that a new cast led by Darci Kistler, Kyra Nichols and Valentina Kozlova swept into this Balanchine classic over the weekend.

title: Sihanouk Grudgingly Sings Old Enemy's Praises
description: In seeking to hold together a coalition that will replace Cambodia's Vietnamese-installed Government, Prince Norodom Sihanouk seems unhappily and awkwardly to have become the chief advocate of his longtime adversary, the Khmer Rouge.

title: A Rude Dose of Reality for Gorbachev
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev ventured anew into the streets of a Soviet city today to drum up support for his policies, only to be confronted with a barrage of complaints about living standards, nuclear power and the people's fears of speaking out for change.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; BBDO Official Leaves
description: Lonny Strum, a senior vice president of BBDO Worldwide, will go south next month to become president of Earle Palmer Brown & Spiro, a Philadelphia agency. Mr. Strum supervised major ad campaigns for Polaroid, General Electric and Du Pont in his 11 years with BBDO. Walter A. Spiro, the chairman of the agency, said Mr. Strum would head a drive to attract national clients.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday None Wednesday Consumer Price Index ... Jan. Thursday Durable Goods ... Jan. Friday None

title: Variety's New Look for New Readers
description: VARIETY INKS 4-COLOR FUTURE; NIX ON PIX IS EIGHTY-SIXED

title: For Gorbachev, Port Arthur Holds a Lesson
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; F.T.C. Plans Rule Change On Co-op Ads
description: THE Federal Trade Commission is expected to change some rules on cooperative advertising, a move that may upset some smaller retailers and discounters.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Child World Inc., Avon, Mass., a toy-store chain, said Leo Crowley and David Stewart had been named senior vice presidents.

title: Patterns
description: The 'Young' and the Hopeful

title: Terrorism in America
description: Jesse Jackson called to talk about what was most on his mind. This is the gist of what he had to say:

title: Hartford Archbishop Starts AIDS Ministry
description: Archbishop John F. Whealon, urging Roman Catholics not to become ''paralyzed by fear and hopelessness,'' has established an office of AIDS ministry in the Archdiocese of Hartford, church officials said today.

title: Reviews/Dance; Cartoonlike Movement
description: The brief dances that Sara Pearson and Patrik Widrig presented Sunday night at the Ethnic Folk Arts Center resembled cartoons. Not animated cartoons or comic strips, which can develop narratives at length, but newspaper or magazine cartoons: isolated drawings that are funny in themselves.

title: Guard Troops Are Called In As Hospital Workers Strike
description: National Guard troops in combat fatigues bathed and fed patients today at a state hospital after nurses and attendants walked out in a contract dispute.

title: Metro Datelines; Driver Hits 4 Cars While Fleeing Police
description: A Connecticut truck driver was arrested on the New Jersey Turnpike after he crashed into four cars, two of them police cars, while reportedly fleeing a drug arrest, a state police spokesman said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A table on Friday showing reading scores in New York City schools omitted the year-to-year change in scores for several schools and omitted one school, Junior High School 99 in District 4. A corrective table appears today on page B6.

title: Corporate Profits Larger Than Expected
description: Continued economic growth, a weak dollar and relatively low cost pressures helped to swell Corporate America's bottom line in the fourth quarter and pushed profits at many companies to levels that surprised Wall Street.

title: Fax Machines and Modems: Who Needs Which?
description: FAX modems and fax boards are valuable tools for certain specialized applications on personal computers. These tools are widely misunderstood, though, and under no circumstances should they be considered a substitute for a stand-alone fax machine.

title: European Fighter: Cost vs. Pride
description: Europeans boast that the European Fighter Aircraft, one of the continent's most ambitious military projects, is a prime example of international cooperation that will spread costs among nations and heighten their aerospace expertise.

title: Careers; A Good Side To Unwanted Job Changes
description: AN outplacement expert, a management consultant and a management recruiter have some encouraging words for middle managers who have lost their jobs: maybe they will be better off changing jobs.

title: 4 Young Children Burn to Death in Brooklyn Fire
description: Four young children in two families, apparently playing with matches in a bedroom whose door was blocked with a mattress, were fatally burned in an apartment fire in Brooklyn yesterday as their mothers cried hysterically from the street.

title: Pacers Deal Tisdale to Kings; Eye Move to Get Vandeweghe
description: While the Indiana Pacers altered their chemistry yesterday with one trade, Donnie Walsh, their general manager, said he was still hoping to get Kiki Vandeweghe before the trading deadline Thursday. The Knicks have been pursuing the Portland Trail Blazer forward for more than six months.

title: President Clarifies
description: Promising ''a scoop'' to a correpondent visiting him last week in the White House, President Bush disclosed that, previous reports to the contrary, he refers to his wife as ''the Gray Fox'' and not as ''the Silver Fox.''

title: Tower: Worth the Fight
description: In nominating John Tower to be Secretary of Defense, President Bush accepted the controversy and confirmation fight that he knew would follow. For this willingness to do battle for the man he believes best qualified to lead, Mr. Bush deserves praise. Most new Presidents would have chosen a less controversial - and less capable - nominee.

title: U.S.O.C. Goes to Work on Steinbrenner's Report
description: It took a year for George Steinbrenner and his Overview Committee to develop a report that addresses many of the problems facing the United States Olympic Committee. It probably will take another year for the recommendations to go into effect.

title: How New York Law Neglects Babies
description: In 1981 a teen-ager from Long Island handed over her newborn daughter to her obstetrician and his lawyer, Joel Steinberg, believing she was doing the best thing for her baby. In 1986 another Long Island teen-ager handed over her newborn son to the same lawyer and the physician who took over the previous obstetrician's practice.

title: Paul Brown Honored For Role With 2 Teams
description: Paul Brown, the vice president and general manager of the Cincinnati Bengals, has been named the Gold Medal honoree of the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame. Brown, 80 years old, will receive the award at the foundation's annual dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Dec. 5. After coaching at Ohio State and the Great Lakes Naval Training Station, Brown became the first coach of the Cleveland franchise in the All American Football Conference after World War II. He coached the Browns to a string of championships in that league and the National Football League.

title: Chicago Journal; Syntax Is a Loser in Mayoral Race
description: In the age of the blow-dried candidate, of politicians packaged to look and sound good on television, Chicago's Democratic mayoral primary endures as a kind of reassuring anachronism.

title: At Last, The U.S.O.C. Turns Pro
description: rrWith his usual bluster, George Steinbrenner has offended the purists who think the Olympic ideal still exists. The essence of his Olympic Overview report is that the United States Olympic Committee needs to turn pro.

title: As Major Prague Trial Opens, Moscow Presses a Softer Line
description: As the playwright Vaclav Havel and eight other opposition figures prepare to go on trial Tuesday, the Czechoslovak Government is under pressure to expand political freedoms.

title: Amer Group to Acquire Wilson Sporting Goods
description: Amer Group Ltd., a diversified company based in Finland, said yesterday that it would acquire the Wilson Sporting Goods Company, the largest sporting goods maker in the United States.

title: Bridge
description: An economical form of benevolence, guaranteed to bring instant happiness, is to give someone some match-points. That is one possible explanation for South's bid of three no-trump on the diagramed deal in the face of a three-club opening. Alternatively, he may have misheard the bidding, believing that his partner had opened or that the opening bid was three of some other suit. Or he may have relied optimistically on the unlikelihood of a solid suit in the East hand.

title: Helene van de Velde, Psychologist, Dies at 95
description: Helene Eliat van de Velde, a psychologist and writer who elucidated Freudian insights into the literary portrayal of human behavior, died of cardio-respiratory failure on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 95 years old.

title: Walter Shields, 82, Inventor and Designer
description: Walter A. Shields, an inventor, designer and manufacturer of pharmaceutical machinery, died of cancer Sunday at Palms of Pasadena Hospital in St. Petersburg Beach, Fla., where he was vacationing with his wife. He was 82 years old and lived in Floral Park, L.I.

title: Business and Health; Employers of 90's: Caught in Middle
description: WHEN Lance D. Tane tries to get employers to focus on an oft-ignored benefits problem, he sometimes encourages them to think back on the gasoline crisis of the 1970's. Mr. Tane, a consultant at the Wyatt Company, asks his clients to remember the long lines for service, the sharp inflation eating into family money that could have gone for food, clothing and housing. That, he tells them, is what health care could be like in the 1990's, with one major difference.

title: Pitt Squanders Lead, But Defeats Villanova
description: Brian Shorter scored 30 points as Pittsburgh squandered a 16-point lead, then rallied to beat Villanova, 73-72, tonight for the Panthers' fourth consecutive Big East victory.

title: Secret Fat
description: Federal dietary guidelines urge Americans to ''choose lean meat'' to avoid heart disease. Yet current labeling rules leave consumers confused about ground beef - which contributes the most fat to the American diet.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: LEAD: IT is the oyster grower's great misfortune that the lowest winter tides come at night, when it is most cold. And the especially frigid nights of early February may have severely hurt this year's crop, growers fear.

title: Wesray Queried On Outlet Stake
description: The Wesray Capital Corporation, a company headed by the former Treasury Secretary William E. Simon, and the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company said they had received ''unsolicited expressions of interest'' in their controlling interest in Outlet Communications Inc.

title: Nesselrode Days
description: To The Living Section:

title: Optical Radiation reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
Littman Leads Eagles And Helps Own Cause
description: David Littman, Boston College's goalie, enhanced his chances of being voted the Hobey Baker Award as college hockey's player of the year when he helped shut down the powerful Black Bears of Maine in two weekend victories for the Eagles.

title: Kinetic Concepts Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reduced by a special compensation expense of $2.3 million for the quarter and after an extraordinary charge of $816,000 for the year.

title: Excerpts From Bush's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Issues
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of President Bush's news conference in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times: OPENING STATEMENT

title: Angeion Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: INSIDE
description: Greenspan Firm on Inflation Before the Senate Banking Committee, Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, suggested that he would keep pushing interest rates up until inflation eased. Page D1. Ruling in Obscenity Case The Supreme Court ruled that First Amendment guarantees bar officials from seizing the inventory of adult bookstores before publications have been found obscene at trial. Page A18. A Vote on Tower Nears After weeks of turmoil, the Senate Armed Services Committee tentatively scheduled a vote on Thursday on the nomination of John G. Tower to be Secretary of Defense. Page A17. Cambodia Talks Break Off Indonesian-mediated talks ended with a narrowing of differences but no formula for power-sharing among the three opposition factions and the Phnom Penh Government. Page A3. Amoco Judgment Raised Amoco may have to pay $115 million, $30 million more than originally set, for damages relating to a huge 1978 oil spill from a supertanker off the Brittany coast. Page D1.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: EVEN before President Bush and his wife, Barbara, dined at i Ricchi last week, the month-old restaurant had already become Washington's hottest new eating spot.

title: ITL Industries reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: b-After a charge of $3,201,000 from the closing of the tool division and a $928,000 gain from insurance proceeds. c-Net income There were no share earnings for 1987 after preferred-share dividends. The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Hewlett-Packard Net Rises
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company today reported a 7.8 percent increase in its first-quarter earnings, but the results fell short of Wall Street's expectations. Hewlett-Packard's shares closed today at $59.25, down 75 cents each, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Europe Air System Plan
description: The Association of European Airlines said today that it would study the costs and savings of a single air traffic control system for Western Europe. The 21-airline group said such a consolidation might help reduce delays and it called on the European Community for help.

title: Birth Control Industry Is Being Transformed
description: The birth control industry has changed radically in recent years. Research spending is down and the number of companies offering contraceptive products has fallen off sharply, but the field has been lucrative for those that remain.

title: Indepth Data reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MicroAmerica Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Modern Controls Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Ernest F. Easterbrook, Retired General, 80
description: Ernest Fred Easterbrook, a retired Army major general who was the son-in-law of Gen. Joseph Stilwell, died Sunday. He was 80 years old. General Easterbrook served in World War II as an infantry instructor of Chinese troops under General Stilwell, the commander of United States forces in China, Burma and India. In the Korean War he commanded the Seventh Infantry Regiment. He retired in 1967 after a tour as deputy commanding general of the Sixth Army.

title: Building a Better Mouse
description: If the old saw about building a better mousetrap is true, what happens if you build a better mouse? Jack S. Hawley, a Berkeley, Calif., inventor, believes he has built just such a device. In computer jargon, a mouse is a pointing device used with a personal computer. By sliding the mouse across a desktop, the user controls a cursor on the screen to make selections and issue commands.

title: Wendy's International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain on early extinguishment of debt, net of income taxes, of $1,033,000.

title: United Medical Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included net from discontinued operations of $322,000 and $831,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also included a tax benefit of $322,000. c-Net loss and included net from discontinued operations of $112,000 and $152,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and tax benefits of $33,000 and $789,000 for the same periods, respectively.

title: Nautilus Plus Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds. Revenue for 1987 is restated.

title: Lefty Swing May Set Things Right
description: Mac O'Grady, who has always been a refreshing difference on the PGA Tour, may become the first man in PGA Tour history to play one or more rounds of competitive tournament golf from the opposite side of the ball to which he normally plays. In his case, he may tee off Thursday in the Ryder Doral Open by playing left-handed instead of right-handed.

title: Morton Overcomes Injuries to Lead Pirates Past Redmen
description: John Morton, playing with 12 stitches in his left hand and a torn tendon in his right hand, missed all four of his field-goal attempts in the first half tonight.

title: Uranium Resources Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Director Plans to Leave Equity Library Theater
description: George Wojtasik, who has been the producing director of Equity Library Theater for 22 years, announced yesterday that he would leave his position Friday. He will be succeeded by Jeffrey R. Costello, assistant general manager of the New York Shakespeare Festival.

title: Pennwalt-Centaur
description: The board of directors of the Pennwalt Corporation said it had unanimously rejected the sweetened offer of $110 a share, or a total of about $850 million, from Centaur Partners, a New York investment firm. Pennwalt, a diversified chemical company based in Philadelphia, said it regarded Centaur's proposed price as inadequate. Pennwalt's shares jumped $3.375 yesterday, to $118.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: SFE Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
Pioneer Lifeco Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $149,000 special gain. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: METRO DATELINES;
description: By posing as David Rockefeller's secret wife, Adela Holzer may have swindled as much as $8 million from investors, officials in the Manhattan District Attorney's office said yesterday.

title: Gerber Scientific Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Market Place; Egghead Booms But Stock Sags
description: SINCE last June when it went public, Egghead Inc., the nation's largest retailer of personal computer software, has added 60 company-owned stores to the 120 in operation and 60 salespeople to the 132 it already had calling on corporate and government clients.

title: Hemlo Gold Mines Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said it was only in operation for 11 months in 1987 when it had net earnings of $52,694,000, or 60 cents a share, and revenue of $201,788,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Loblaw Cos reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a net special charge of $14.6 million. The company said the 1988 charge is comprised of a $2.1 million gain on the sale of the Peter J. Schmitt Co. division and a $16.7 million provision for the planned sale of a substantial part of its New Orleans division. The results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: Crackdown on Latin Refugees Has a Shaky Start
description: The Federal Government's crackdown on Central American refugees began slowly today as officials working in makeshift facilities were only able to process a handful of the aliens seeking political asylum.

title: IIS Intelligent Information Systems Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The dollar amounts were adjusted to the rate of exchange from new Israeli shekels on Dec. 31 of Nis 1.8065 equals U.S. $1.00.

title: Atlantic Express reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Rig Count Up in Week
description: The number of working oil and gas rigs increased last week by 20, to a total of 766, after plunging the previous week by 34, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. A year ago, the count totaled 978. The rig count is a widely watched industry index of drilling activity and reflects the number of rigs exploring for oil as of last Friday.

title: Rview/Television; With Humor, the News of Long Ago
description: ''Timeline'' is a tongue-in-cheek, head-on-straight sequel to ''You Are There.'' The weekly series of half-hours that begins tonight at 10:30 P.M. on Channel 13 offers a drolly designed evening-news approach to some big events of the Middle Ages.

title: Autodesk Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Literary World Lashes Out After a Week of Hesitation
description: After an initial period of sputter and stall, the public indignation of writers, librarians and civil libertarians grew yesterday in response to the death threats against the author Salman Rushdie and the removal of his novel from many bookstores.

title: Brooklyn's Streak Halted
description: After having run off the longest losing streak in National Collegiate Athletic Association history, the Brooklyn College women's basketball team finally put a stop to its futility by beating Concordia College, 60-54, in Bronxville, N.Y., on Monday night.

title: MICC Investments reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included special gains of $5,721,000 and $26,181,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included a special gain of $5,587,000 for the quarter and a $18,923,000 gain on the sale of assets and a $28,670,000 tax credit, both for the year. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Laurentian Group Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Results Plus
description: TENNIS Rostagno Upset: Milan Srejber of Czechoslovakia upset No. 13-seeded Derrick Rostagno, 6-4, 6-4, yesterday in the second round of the $600,000 United States Pro Indoor Championships at Philadelphia. Srejber, at 6 feet 8 inches the tallest player on the pro circuit, won with low passing shots and hard serves. (AP) Leconte Beats Tulasne: Henri Leconte of France beat a Davis Cup teammate, Thierry Tulasne, 6-3, 6-2, yesterday to advance to the second round of the $291,000 Lyon Grand Prix tournament. In other matches, four Swedish players advanced. Fifth-seeded Anders Jarryd downed Michiel Schapers of the Netherlands, 6-3, 6-2; Jonas Svensson beat Gaullaume Raoux of France, 6-3, 6-3; Christian Bergstrom downed Diego Nargiso of Italy, 6-4, 7-6, and Niclas Kroon defeated Thierry Champion of France, 3-6, 6-4, 6-2. (AP) SKIING Finns Sweep: Marjo Matikainen, after winning a bronze and a silver, finally got a gold at the world Nordic championships in Lahti, Finland, yesterday. The Finns completed their second medal sweep of the meet as Matikainen edged Marja-Liisa Kirvesniemi by two seconds and Pirkko Maatta took third in the 15-kilometer classic-style race. (AP) CUNY BASKETBALL Defending Champions Advance: Defending champion Staten Island advanced to the semifinal round of the City University of New York men's championship tournament on Monday night in the Nat Holman Gymnasium at City College. The Dolphins, who defeated Medgar Evers, 95-46, were led by Rob Roesch, a senior forward, who scored 23 points, grabbed 21 rebounds and blocked 6 shots. Staten Island (21-5) will oppose Baruch (14-13) tonight in the first semifinal game, at 6 P.M. In the second game, City College (10-14) will play Lehman (15-11). In other games on Monday night, Baruch topped Hunter, 65-61; Lehman pounded York, 63-29, and City College downed John Jay, 88-77. In women's games at the Hunter College Sportsplex, John Jay defeated Staten Island, 66-53, and Baruch crushed York, 57-28. Today at 4 P.M., Hunter will play Jay, and at 6 P.M. City College will oppose Baruch. N.B.A. Bullets 123, Clippers 109: Bernard King scored 33 points and Jeff Malone had 27 last night as Washington, playing at home, handed Los Angeles its sixth straight defeat and the 25th in its last 26 games.(AP) Sonics 96, Celtics 91: Derrick McKey scored 12 of his 19 points in the last quarter and Dale Ellis had 30 as Seattle, playing at home, completed a season sweep of Boston. (AP) Bucks 116, Packers 90: Paul Pressey scored 19 points and sparked second-half runs of 12-2 and 11-0 as Milwaukee handed Indiana its 11th straight loss. The new-look Pacers, who have made two trades this week, lost for the 25th time in 26 road games this season.(AP) N.H.L. North Stars 2, Penguins 1: Wally Schreiber scored on a power play at 9 minutes 37 seconds of the third period last night to break a tie at Pittsburgh as Minnesota ended a four-game losing streak. The Penguins have lost three straight. (AP) Nordiques 4, Jets 3: Michel Goulet and Marc Fortier scored goals 6:16 apart in the second period to rally Quebec at home. Walt Poddubny and the rookie Joe Sakic had the other Quebec goals, while Dale Hawerchuk, Brent Ashton and Laurie Boschman scored for Winnipeg. (AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL/WOMEN N.C. St. 92, Duke 78: Andrea Stinson scored 30 points last night to lead the 15th-ranked Wolfpack (20-5, 11-2) past the Blue Devils (11-14, 1-11) in the Atlantic Coast Conference game at Raleigh. (AP) Ohio St. 66, Iowa 57: Nikita Lowry scored 25 points and Lisa Cline added 24 as No. 20 Ohio State (19-5, 12-2), playing at home in Columbus, defeated seventh-ranked Iowa (21-4, 11-2) and took the Big Ten Conference lead from the Hawkeyes. (AP) Texas 99, Old Dominion 78: Clarissa Davis scored 32 points and sparked a second-half comeback that gave eighth-ranked Texas (20-4) the victory at home. Davis finished the game one point shy of tying the Southwest Conference career scoring record of 1,798.(AP)

description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $619,000 and $1,617,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $507,000 for the quarter, and the year included a loss from discontinued operations of $4,903,000. d-Net loss

title: Stake in Arvin
description: Shares in Arvin Industries jumped $2.50 a share today, to $24, on the New York Stock Exchange after an Indonesian investor, Ismanto Wanandi, diclosed Friday that he had acquired a 5.6 percent stake and was considering seeking control of the Columbus, Ind., maker of auto supplies.

title: Satellite Information Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
How Tower's Character Became the Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: On Second Thought, Courage
description: Finally, the tide has turned in the fearful Salman Rushdie affair. It started out plenty ugly when Ayatollah Khomeini put a price on the head of Mr. Rushdie, the author. The initial response to this vengeful lawlessness added the stench of cowardice. Governments hemmed and hawed. Booksellers hastened to yank ''The Satanic Verses'' from their shelves. Only a handful of famous writers were willing to raise their voices when asked by talk shows to discuss the death threats against a reputable author and his American publishers.

title: First Federal of Alabama reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Streak Comes to Ends
description: Valerie Kepner, a junior at Baldwin-Wallace in Berea, Ohio, ended her streak of successful free throws at 69 Monday night, 9 short of Calvin Murphy's National Basketball Association record of 78. In a game in which Baldwin-Wallace defeated Mount Union, 70-58, Kepner made her first attempt but missed her second one. Her streak is a National Collegiate Athletic Association record. (AP)

title: Mavericks Trade Schrempf for Williams
description: The Dallas Mavericks, still waiting for Adrian Dantley to end his holdout, traded the 6-foot-10-inch forward Detlef Schrempf to the Indiana Pacers yesterday for the 6-11 forward Herb Williams and a second-round draft pick in either 1990 or 1991. The 31-year-old Williams, a first-round draft pick in 1981, was averaging 12 points and 8 rebounds a game. Schrempf, a 26-year-old West German who was a first-round draft pick in 1985, was averaging 9 points and 4 rebounds. Dallas is not expecting its rebounding ace, Roy Tarpley, who is in a drug rehabilitation center, to return this season. The Mavericks have given Dantley, whom they obtained from Detroit in a trade last week, until today to report or face suspension.(AP)

title: Jackson Play Helps Knicks Stretch Streak To 19 Games
description: It was an ending fit for Broadway.

title: Dr. Cecil Mantell, 74, a Gastroenterologist
description: Dr. Cecil Mantell, a gastroenterologist and a founder of the Skylight Center, a new psychiatric rehabilitation center on Staten Island, died of complications from leukemia Monday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 74 years old and lived in St. George, S.I.

title: Athey Products reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Consolidated-Japex Deal
description: The Consolidated Natural Gas Company and the Japex U.S. Corporation have completed the acquisition for about $245 million in cash of substantially all of the exploration and production assests of Mark Producing Inc. of Houston, which held extensive natural gas and oil properties in the Gulf of Mexico. C.N.G., a unit of Consolidated, acquired a 60 percent interest in the properties, and Japex, a unit of the Japan Petroleum Exploration Company, acquired 40 percent.

title: Topics of The Times; Mud Crocuses
description: It is not too late, a New Yorker muses, for the wind to change direction and begin howling from the north. For the sky to cease sending down rain and replace it with sleet, even snow. For skiing, skating, sledding and snowballs. For frostbite, chilblains, windburn and a runny nose. For the purple down coat. For a few square feet of crocuses to pierce a snow crust, as is their late winter wont.

title: Washington Talk: The Homeless; Law Guaranteeing Shelter Cannot Keep Out the Heartbreak
description: Every evening as darkness falls on the nation's capital, a dozen or more homeless people gather outside City Hall, just two blocks from the White House on Pennsylvania Avenue. Many are clad in grimy rags, dragging behind them a nondescript collection of bags and boxes.

title: Superior Surgical Manufacturing Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Man Whose Killings Led to Tougher Law Is Convicted Again
description: Willie Bosket Jr., whose five-year sentence for two subway murders led New York State to toughen its penalties for juvenile violence, was found guilty today of attempted murder in the 1988 stabbing of a prison guard.

title: Champion Parts Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $99,000 gain from the repurchase of debt.

title: HOUSE DEMOCRAT DEFECTS TO G.O.P.
description: Representative Bill Grant of Florida switched today from the Democratic Party to the Republicans, saying that he could ''better represent the values and priorities'' of his constituents in his new party. But Democratic leaders here said his conversion was part of a much broader battle over Congressional reapportionment for the 1990's.

title: A Walking Disaster

title: Homeless Stir Aid to Neediest
description: The past holiday season was especially troublesome to Herbert and Mercedes Hill of Brooklyn. Never had they seen so many people in need - sleeping in subways, begging in the streets, living in cardboard boxes behind Macy's.

title: Economic Scene; U.S. Companies Lift R.&D. Abroad
description: THERE is no mistaking the trend: American corporations increasingly are doing their research outside the United States. The evidence is abundant.

title: Officials Widen Sex-Abuse Inquiry
description: In an effort to prevent sexual abuse and sexual activity among young psychiatric patients, New York State officials said yesterday that they have extended a review of the care and supervision of juvenile patients to all state psychiatric centers.

title: William Fagal, 70, Religious Broadcaster
description: The Rev. William A. Fagal, founder of a religious television program that has been broadcast since 1950, died Thursday at the Pleasant Valley Hospital in Camarillo, Calif., from complications of a stroke. He was 70 years old and lived in Camarillo.

title: Integrated Computer reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $178,619 for the quarter and $1,080,913 for the 9 months; the 9 months also included a loss of $1,201,754 from the disposal of a unit. c-Net income and after losses from discontinued operations of $36,801 for the quarter and $201,791 for the 9 months; the 9 months also included a tax credit of $40,000.

title: Eating Well
description: IT is impossible to predict the reaction of readers to certain Eating Well columns. What may seem noncontroversial at the time can produce a spate of mail that takes strong exception to the information provided. In the process the letters often offer new perspectives.

title: New York Landlords Will Get a New Trial
description: Two Manhattan landlords convicted of conspiring to force tenants out of rent-controlled buildings will get a new trial because of a judge's mistake, the Court of Appeals ruled today.

title: North Trial Opens After Long Delay
description: After more than 11 months of delays and pretrial maneuvering, Oliver L. North went on trial in Federal District Court today, accused of a dozen crimes stemming from his role in diverting profits from the secret sale of arms to Iran to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Several Oil Countries Pledge Support for OPEC on Prices
description: Several independent oil-producing countries said today that they would cut or freeze oil exports during the second quarter to help OPEC support world oil prices.

title: Rescuers Find Wreck But No Jet Survivors
description: Rescuers used a helicopter, bulldozers and bridge-building equipment in an unsuccessful search today for the eight people aboard an Air Force cargo plane that crashed and burned in a swamp.

title: Review/Film; Changing an Outlook
description: Frank D. Gilroy is an amiable movie maker with a bad habit. Having made a joke, he keeps making it, his elbow working its way into your rib until your smile becomes pained.

title: Setback for Nilan
description: Michel Bergeron, the coach of the Rangers, said Chris Nilan, the forward and one of the team's emotional leaders, had suffered a setback in his recovery from an injury to ligaments in his pelvic area. Nilan was tentatively scheduled to play Monday afternoon against the Devils, but was scratched before the game after he aggravated the injury. Bergeron said it was now uncertain when Nilan, who has missed the last 26 games and 30 of the last 33, would return.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Zenith Reports Annual Profit
description: The Zenith Electronics Corporation reported today that its earnings soared in the fourth quarter and that it had an annual profit for the first time in four years.

title: Kirk to Appeal
description: The former Memphis State basketball coach, Dana Kirk, has notified the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit that he plans to appeal his one-year prison sentence for tax evasion and obstruction of justice. The one-sentence notice of appeal was filed by Kirk on his own behalf and did not include any grounds for the appeal.(AP)

title: Likely Result On Pepperell
description: The winning bidder for West Point-Pepperell Inc., the big textile producer, may be announced as early as today, executives close to the deal said yesterday. But Pepperell's stock fell 87.5 cents yesterday, to $56.25, on the New York Stock Exchange after traders concluded that the response to Pepperell's invitation to bid for the company might have been less successful than expected.

title: View-Master Ideal Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
International Income Property reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company said the loss for 1987 included depreciation expenses on a development project.

title: Greenwell Agrees
description: Mike Greenwell agreed to a two-year, $1.7 million contract with the Boston Red Sox yesterday. Greenwell will get $500,000 this year and $1.2 million in 1990 plus bonus clauses for finishing among the top three in the American League most valuable player voting that could amount to another $100,000 each year. Greenwell, who earned $205,000 in base salary last year and $100,000 in bonuses, batted .325 with 22 homers and 119 runs batted in and was runner-up to Jose Canseco in the m.v.p. voting. Greenwell had been asking for $1.9 million over two years and the Red Sox were offering $1.2 million.(AP)

title: Evans & Sutherland Computer Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $1,094,000 net gain from the repurchase of convertible debentures and an inventory write-off of $4,048,000 in the third quarter.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Back on the Court
description: Many people have seen Bill Bradley play basketball. Many people have seen Senator Bill Bradley on television. But until now, no one has seen Senator Bill Bradley play basketball on television.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY President Bush's savings-industry rescue plan is based on assumptions that interest rates will decline sharply and deposits will increase steadily, according to figures from the Office of Management and Budget. Some analysts criticized the projections as being too optimistic. [ Page A1. ] Alan Greenspan suggested that interest rates would be pushed up until inflation abates. The Fed chairman issued his strongest inflation warning in an appearance before the Senate Banking Committee, but signaled no sharp departure from current policy. [ D1. ] The Supreme Court ruled that states may not go beyond the scope of Federal patent law to protect unpatented products or manufacturing processes against duplication. [ D2. ] The I.R.S. proposed an overhaul of tax penalties to make the system simpler and fairer for taxpayers. [ D11. ] COMPANIES Compaq is ending its six-year relationship with Businessland in a dispute over strategic direction. [ D1. ] Manufacturers Hanover is restating fourth-quarter earnings to reflect unauthorized bond trading by an employee. [ D1. ] Amoco should pay about $115 million for damage caused by the grounding of the Amoco Cadiz oil tanker in 1978, a Federal judge said, revising a previous judgment. [ D1. ] Holly said its board was exploring whether to sell the company. Shares in the oil refiner soared $9.625 on the news. [ D4. ] Cooper Industries agreed to buy Champion Spark Plug for $800 million in cash. Champion ended its previous deal with Dana. [ D4. ] MARKETS The commodity market's regulator criticized the Chicago Board of Trade for failing to detect fraud and other violations on its trading floor. The surprisingly critical report said the exchange's computerized systems for spotting abuses was deficient. [ D1. ] An administrative law judge cleared Drexel Burnham Lambert and a Florida investor on a charge that they tried to manipulate the price of orange juice concentrate in 1984. [ D4. ] Blue-chip stocks rose, but the overall market showed weakness. The Dow industrials gained 1.61 points, to 2,326.43. [ D8. ] Treasury notes and bonds were little changed in slow trading. [ D16. ] The dollar was mixed after the Fed's chairman failed to signal any striking shift in monetary policy. [ D15. ] Several oil-producing countries said they would cut or freeze exports, but there was little reaction in the futures market. [ D15. ] INTERNATIONAL The Bank of Spain promised drastic measures to fight inflation, which was double the official target last year. [ D17. ] The U.S. warned five trading partners that they could face sanctions unless they open their markets to more American telecommunications products. The notice was served on South Korea, Japan, France, West Germany and Canada. [ D25. ] A dispute panel will hear Brazil's complaint against punitive U.S. tariffs. [ D24. ] TECHNOLOGY About 50 FM radio stations are using a new system intended to improve the quality of stereo reception and increase their service area. But the system, called FMX, has drawn criticism. [ D6. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS U.S. corporations are doing more research abroad, a trend that poses dangers. Louis Uchitelle: Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Egghead thinks it did almost everything right in its first nine months as a public company, but its stock is trading far below the initial offering price. Market Place. [ D8. ] Bowery Savings Bank has turned again to Joe DiMaggio. The former Yankees star will again go to bat for the company in a new ad campaign. Advertising. [ D19. ]

description: * Brookhurst Partners has lowered its holdings in Zenith Electronics Corp., Glenview, Ill., to 1.6 percent, from 6.1 percent.

description: Promoting a Book

WILDLIFE SERVICE ASSAILED OVER OWL
description: Officials of the Fish and Wildlife Service, in an effort to keep the spotted owl off the list of endangered species, ordered changes in a report that originally said the bird might face extinction, according to a General Accounting Office report released today.

description: The Compaq Computer Corporation said yesterday that it was ending its six-year relationship with Businessland Inc., the nation's largest non-franchised computer retail chain, in a dispute over strategy, including a disagreement over industry standards for personal computers.

title: For London, A Basic Error
description: In virtually suspending diplomatic relations with Iran, Britain has acknowledged a basic miscalculation in re-establishing its mission to Teheran only a few months earlier.

The Founder of ASK Severs Her Last Ties
description: Sandra L. Kurtzig, considered the most successful woman entrepreneur in Silicon Valley history, has resigned as the chairwoman of ASK Computer Systems Inc., the company she started in the bedroom of her apartment 17 years ago.

title: A Star Rekindles Love for the Game
description: The tools that made Kris Durham a star are displayed in her backyard: the glass backboard on the garage, the driveway painted with a foul lane and a 3-point line.

title: Toxic Spill Hurts 3; 100 Are Evacuated
description: A highly toxic chemical spilled from a 30-gallon drum in a warehouse near Linden Airport yesterday, injuring at least three workers and forcing the evacuation of about 100 others, officials said.

title: An Odd Way to Raise Ethical Standards
description: President Bush seems to be wavering on ethics already. He took office trumpeting calls for higher standards, determined to combat ''even the appearance'' of impropriety. That promised a welcome departure from eight years of ethical indifference and scandal in the Reagan Administration.

title: The Pop Life
description: A Rap Against Violence

title: As Ranks Grow, Indians at Dartmouth Grapple With Adjusting
description: When Eleazar Wheelock founded Dartmouth College here in 1769, he wrote in the school's charter that the primary objective was to educate Indians.

title: Topics of The Times; Slimmer Campaign Pickings?
description: It's too soon to say whether New York City's new system of public campaign financing will reduce candidates' reliance on wealthy favor-seekers. But the latest filings are encouraging. The voluntary plan provides public matching funds for all municipal candidates who agree to strict disclosure rules and reasonable limits on spending and private contributions. The most likely Democratic candidates for mayor and comptroller have all agreed to participate in the new system.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Watch Out, Archie: Veronica Is a Star
description: SHE may still have to battle Betty for Archie's affections, but when it comes to winning readers' attention, Veronica is gaining ground. As of this month, she has a comic book all to herself.

title: Joseph Milgram, 88, Surgeon and Teacher
description: Dr. Joseph E. Milgram, a former director of orthopedic surgery at the Hospital for Joint Diseases Orthopedic Institute in Manhattan, died of heart failure on Sunday at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Wendy's President Adds Chief Title, Too
description: LEAD: James W. Near, a former franchise owner of Wendy's International Inc. and currently the company's president and chief operating officer, has been appointed chief executive of the fast-food restaurant chain, the company announced yesterday.

title: Synercom Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $227,000 and $29,000 for the latest and prior periods, respectively.

title: Dole and A.F.L.-C.I.O Are Off to a Friendly Start
description: Elizabeth Hanford Dole, the new Labor Secretary, and leaders of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. had the type of cordial meeting here today that they hope will set the tone for their relationship.

title: I.R.S. Panel Asks Penalty Overhaul
description: The nation's chief tax official today presented to a House of Representatives subcommittee a report of an Internal Revenue Service group recommending a significant overhaul of the penalty system, with an eye toward fairness and simplicity for taxpayers and effectiveness and more flexibility for the I.R.S.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Feb. 7 about the effect of economic sanctions on South Africa misstated the name and title of the head of the nation's central bank. He is Gerhard de Kock, governor of the bank.

title: Trans-Atlantic Plans by United
description: United Air Lines Inc, the nation's largest carrier, plans to establish trans-Atlantic routes by 1992 and will place record orders for aircraft in the next two years, the chairman of its parent company, the UAL Corporation, said.

title: Muncie Is Sentenced
description: A former San Diego Chargers running back, Chuck Muncie, was sentenced yesterday to two and a half years in Federal prison for perjury and dealing cocaine to an undercover federal agent. ''The only way you're going to get the message in this case is if you go to jail,'' United States District Judge J. Lawrence Irving told Muncie in San Diego. Muncie, 35, played for the Chargers from 1980 to 1984, earning all-conference honors in 1981. (AP)

title: Eldon Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Review/Music; Of Tibet's New Year
description: Because the first full moon after the Tibetan new year occurred Monday night, the eight Tibetan monks from the Drepung-Loseling monastery who are now touring the United States gave the first performances in the West of excerpts from Mon-lam Chen-mo, the Great Prayer Festival. In Lhasa, the ceremonies would last for three weeks and reach a peak at the full moon. The concert, at St. Paul's Chapel of Columbia University, was presented by Tibet House and Columbia's Tibetan Studies Society.

title: SALVADOR REBELS OFFER TO DISARM IF ARMY IS CURBED
description: Salvadoran guerrilla leaders said today that they would lay down their arms permanently and ''incorporate ourselves into the nation's political life'' if the Salvadoran Government made fundamental changes in the military apparatus.

title: The Usual Gallows Chatter
description: After the Ayatollah Khomeini offered financial and spiritual incentives for the murder of Salman Rushdie, the press fell to with a will.

title: Greenspan Cautions On Inflation
description: Citing signs of additional inflationary pressures in an otherwise sound-looking economy, the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, suggested today that he would keep pushing interest rates up until inflation abated.

title: Fewer Students Seek Admission to Top Colleges
description: After several years of record and near-record numbers, freshman applications for next fall's class have declined as much as 18 percent at some Ivy League and other highly selective colleges and universities. But admissions officers at the next tier of slightly less selective colleges say they are holding their own or reporting increases.

description: Figures are in Canadian funds. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: Vernon Crudge, 76, Aerospace Consultant
description: Vernon Grant Crudge, an aerospace industry consultant, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 76 years old.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: THE 19th-century whale and cod fisheries drew Portuguese sailors to southeastern Massachusetts. The textile factories kept their descendants there. Today, about 60 percent of Fall River's 92,000 residents are ethnically Portuguese, which keeps the city's dozen or so Portuguese bakeries doing a brisk business. Now, a favorite Portuguese muffin, bolo levedo, is being found in fine food stores as far away as New York City.

title: Young Hosts Discover The 50's Dinner Party
description: MELISSA PALEOLOGOS is tired of going to nightclubs and restaurants crammed with couches, rugs and other accouterments of an imagined home. For the last year, she and her husband have been seeing friends and sharing pastas, pastries and chardonnay in a real home - their home.

title: Syrian-Soviet Meetings Said to Be Stepping Up
description: Syria and the Soviet Union will increase political and military consultations to head off a possible split as Moscow increases its diplomatic efforts in the Middle East, Arab diplomats say.

title: Black Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Drexel Makes Key Changes
description: The director of compliance at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. is being reassigned and the general counsel of the firm left earlier this month after requests were made for the changes by the Securities and Exchange Commission, people at Drexel said yesterday.

title: Awards Curbed for Unconscious Patients
description: In two decisions that are likely to have far-reaching effects on personal-injury and malpractice awards, New York State's highest court ruled today that victims cannot be compensated separately for the ''loss of enjoyment of life.''

title: Iran's Response: Envoys in Europe Ordered Home
description: Iran responded to a diplomatic censure from the European Community today by recalling its own top diplomats from most of Western Europe.

title: Posters Proclaim New York's Cultural Riches
description: Dinosaurs and clarinets, gilded mummies and toe shoes, and an ever-smiling Mayor Edward I. Koch are among a kaleidoscope of images that will soon be appearing on posters throughout the New York area as advertisements for the city's vast and varied cultural resources.

title: Oshkosh B'Gosh Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Companie Agricole et Maraihere de Sherrington Terres Noires Ltee reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 24
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title:
EDUCATION;
Effort to Reach Homeless Students Puts Increasing Strain on Schools
description: LEAD: As Federal and state education officials begin to get official statistics on the number of homeless students across the country, local educators and child advocates are scrambling to enroll these children in school and to determine how to respond to their needs.

title: Many Found Cuban Missile Crisis Real Enough
description: To the Editor:

title: Southern Mineral Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Surely a Novel Can't Shake Islam
description: LEAD: Riots, book burning, the demand that a work be banned worldwide, publishers boycotted, the threatened toppling of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto of Pakistan and at least five dead in Pakistan - has ever a book been the pretext for such a frenzy of righteous barbarism?

title: Langston Trade Rumors Are Revived
description: The trade winds blowing across the Mets' training camp began to howl today with new reports from Seattle that the Mariners were close to sending their ace left-handed pitcher Mark Langston to the Mets for Howard Johnson, Sid Fernandez and David West. But the Mets replied that they had not discussed anything with the Mariners in the last week, and Davey Johnson said flatly that he was opposed to the deal.

title: Joseph's Estimate on AIDS Is Supported by Review Panel
description: The New York City Health Commissioner was generally correct when he reduced the estimate of residents infected with the AIDS virus, a panel of scientists selected by the Commissioner to review his findings reported yesterday.

title: Uniroyal Goodrich reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included $1.9 million in extraordinary income. c-Net loss and included a $9.1 million provision for a reduction in force. Latest year operating income included a recapitalization charge of $16.3 million, and prior year operating income included a formation charge of $3 million. The company changed its year-end from Nov. 30 to Dec. 31.

title: About New York; A Church Fights For Its Bus Lines And Its Future
description: St. Stephen's Church last Sunday morning. A thin, white steeple against the winter sky. Dainty stained-glass windows. A baby crying during the Bible reading. Well-thumbed copies of the Book of Common Prayer. The Rev. D. Stewart Alexy clearing his throat.

title: New FM System Is Challenged
description: A new method of broadcasting on FM radio that is intended to improve the quality of stereo reception and increase a station's service area is beginning to come into use. About 50 stations are using a technology called FMX to broadcast their signals and another 50 are committed to altering their transmitters for it.

American Medical Buildings reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss of $447,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net loss

title: BUSH FINDS THREAT TO MURDER AUTHOR 'DEEPLY OFFENSIVE'
description: President Bush today criticized Teheran's death decree against the novelist Salman Rushdie as ''deeply offensive to the norms of civilized behavior'' and warned that Iran would be ''held accountable'' for any violence against American interests.

title: China Pledges to Keep Close U.S. Ties
description: China's Foreign Minister said today that despite normalization of relations with the Soviet Union, China will maintain a special and closer relationship with the United States for the foreseeable future.

title: Universal Voltronics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Lamson & Sessions Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $638,000 from an accounting change for the quarter and a $2 million gain from a litigation award and a $1 million charge in connection with divestitures, both for the year. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $660,000 for the quarter and the year.

title: Griffith Joyner Is Honored
description: Florence Griffith Joyner of Los Angeles received the Jesse Owens International Trophy Award last night for athletic excellence and international understanding. Earlier in the day, she reiterated her stand against the use of illegal performance-enhancing drugs by athletes.

title: Mediator Proposes An Accord on Lilco
description: A court-appointed mediator in talks to settle a racketeering suit against the Long Island Lighting Company yesterday proposed an accord he said would end the court action and be ''an important first step'' toward closing the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: Joule Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Net income and after a tax credit of $400,000, or 11 cents a share.

title: Futures Judge Clears Drexel And Investor
description: An administrative law judge with the Commodity Futures Trading Commission has cleared Drexel Burham Lambert Inc. and a Florida investor on a charge that they tried to manipulate orange-juice concentrate prices in 1984.

title: Books of The Times; Burton's Life and His Love Affair With the Press
description: Richard Burton A Life By Melvyn Bragg Illustrated. 533 pages. Little, Brown & Company. $22.95.

title: VI Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: DiMaggio Bats Again For Bowery
description: THE Bowery Savings Bank of New York, in need of a home run hitter, turned again to Joe DiMaggio, the former New York Yankees baseball star who had previously been its public spokesman. But this time, Mr. DiMaggio has a story to tell.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Vice President Named By G.E. to Head Audits
description: LEAD: The General Electric Company announced last week that its board had elected Teresa M. LeGrand as a vice president who will direct its corporate audit staff. The department, based in Schenectady, N.Y., oversees the finances of the company's operations and acts as a liaison with outside accounting firms.

title: Edith Taglicht Schmidt, Psychologist, 88
description: Dr. Edith Taglicht Schmidt, founding director of the Educational Institute for Learning and Research, died Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 88 years old.

title: A Kansas College Teeters on Brink
description: Marymount College, a small Roman Catholic school here, is struggling to stay open amid financial problems and might have to close June 30.

title: Bridge
description: Deals that call for guessing the location of a queen or a jack are common. Guesses for a king are rarer, and guesses for an ace, with no other honor involved, are very uncommon indeed. When they happen, as the diagramed example shows, the need for the guess may not be obvious.

title: Commonwealth Edison Co reports earnings for 12mo Jan 31
Bangor Journal; A Clergyman Returns, And Some Rancor, Too
description: Three years ago the Rev. Herman (Buddy) Frankland, married and the father of four children, admitted a sexual relationship with a parishioner and resigned as pastor of the 3,000-member Bangor Baptist Church, one of the largest fundamentalist churches in New England.

title: UGI Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $17,000 for the quarter, and the year included income from discontinued operations of $2,806,000. The company said that results for the year also benefited from a 62-percent increase in equity income contribution from AP Propane, the company's joint venture with Prudential Insurance Co. The company also said AP Propane contributed $4,034,000, or 40 cents a share, to net income for the latest year. Last AP Propane contributed $2,493,000, or 26 cents a share, to net income.

title: Rooney Suit Irks Tyson
description: Mike Tyson said today Kevin Rooney, his former trainer, would have wound up back in his corner had he not brought a $10 million lawsuit against him last week. ''Now he'll never have a chance to be involved with me,'' said Tyson. ''Never. Never.''

title: South Carolina's $85 Million Issue
description: South Carolina yesterday tapped the domestic debt market with an $85 million issue of general obligation bonds, which was put up for competitive bidding and awarded to a group of underwriters led by First Chicago Capital Markets Inc.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''The evidence will show that when the time came for Oliver North to tell the truth, he lied. When the time came for Oliver

description: To the Editor:

title: Seitzer Signs
description: Kevin Seitzer, a third baseman who hit .304 last season for the Kansas City Royals, has signed a one-year contract for $340,000, a raise of $165,000. Seitzer, 27 years old, is entering his third season with the Royals. He had 5 homers and 60 runs batted in last year.(AP)

title: Dow Up 1.61, but Declines Lead Advances
description: Stock prices ended mixed yesterday, with blue chips gaining and the broader market showing weakness.

title: Haverty Furniture Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

description: Interest rates rose again yesterday at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper.

title: IPM Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

description: The company said the latest fourth quarter and year relected a $302,000 charge for moving three offices and startup costs for three new businesses.

title: Linamar Machine Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Lease Finance In Big Jet Deals
description: The International Lease Finance Corporation said today that it had arranged to lease 26 commercial jet aircraft to 10 airlines in deals it valued at more than $770 million.

title: Many Found Cuban Missile Crisis Real Enough; What Castro Won
description: To the Editor:

title: Treasury Prices Little Changed
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were little changed in slow trading yesterday, as market participants shrugged off the dollar's weakness and Congressional testimony by the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Alan Greenspan.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: IN French cuisine there is a mode of preparing chicken or seafood that is called a la king, although I confess ignorance of which, if any, monarch had a role in popularizing it. Many believe it to be an American invention that found its way to France, as in chicken or turkey a la king.

title: U.S. Warns Against Telecommunications Curbs
description: The United States has put South Korea, Japan, France, West Germany and Canada on notice that they could face American trade sanctions unless they open their markets to more American telephone systems, switching gear and other telecommunications products.

title: Comsat Corp reports earnings for
description: b-Net loss c-After a gain of $15.5 million for the quarter and a loss of $65.1 million for the year, both from discontinued operations. The company said the Intelsat Satellite Services and Maritime Services businesses, both in the international reporting segment, contributed almost equally to $22 million of the company's 1988 revenue growth.

title: The Brian McNally Recipe: He Can't Define It But His Restaurants Work
description: NEARLY every night there are celebrities at the tables near the front of Canal Bar. Big stars like Madonna, and little ones like the gossip columnist Taki. Lesser mortals, too, trek to this isolated part of SoHo, where neither cabbies nor pedestrians normally venture.

title: Can't Afford the Wine? Try a Slice of the Company
description: IF buying a bottle of Chateau Lafite-Rothschild is a bit beyond your means at the moment, you might consider another tack: investing in the Domaines Barons de Rothschild, which runs the place. Here's how you do it: Tell your broker to buy some shares for you in Chalone Inc., which closed yesterday at $12.25 in over-the-counter trading. The 1985 Chateau Lafite currently sells for about $80 a bottle or about $900 a case.

title: Bart Winer, 70, Expert On Coleridge, Is Dead
description: Bart Winer, the associate editor of ''The Collected Works of Samuel Taylor Coleridge,'' died after a heart attack Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 70 years old and had homes in Manhattan and London.

title: Polaroid Sets Stock Tender
description: The Polaroid Corporation began a cash tender offer today for 16 million of its shares at $50 a share and announced that it had designated $325 million for privately negotiated share purchases.

title: Norstan Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
Reporter's Notebook; Power Is the Theme In the Budget Drama
description: Tom Foley left the White House in a driving rain but he paused, as House majority leader, to make a simple statement of Congressional power and prerogative. What of the budget, the reporters asked? ''The regular process will go forward,'' he replied.

title: Another Embarrassing Appointment?
description: LEAD: President Bush's nomination of Edward J. Derwinski to be Secretary of the newly created Department of Veterans Affairs appears inconsistent with his pledge to establish a high code of ethics for his Administration. It adds to the problems posed by designating John G. Tower as Defense Secretary and C.

title: Sigma-Aldrich Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KABUL GIVES SHIITE PREMIER'S DUTIES
description: The only Shiite Muslim in the leadership of the Government in Kabul was effectively appointed Prime Minister today.

title: Catherine M. Conroy, Feminist, 69
description: Catherine M. Conroy, who helped to organize the National Organization for Women, died of cancer Saturday. She was 69 years old.

title: Reviews/Opera; Barenboim Conducts Concert Version of 'Tristan'
description: Monday night offered the New York opera lover some glamorous choices. But those who opted for the concert performance of the second act of Wagner's ''Tristan und Isolde'' by the Orchestre de Paris at Avery Fisher Hall picked wrong. Even with some first-rate singing, this was a most disappointing 75 minutes of music making.

title: A Comedy Club Magazine
description: The publishers of a new magazine for the thriving comedy industry know that getting laughs has become a serious business. Their publication, Laughtrack, aims to capitalize on the tremendous growth of stand-up comedy in recent years - from a handful of dimly lit clubs in Los Angeles and New York to hundreds of clubs and cable television screens across the country.

title: Wessex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $11,490,000 from early retirement of debt for the quarter; the 9 months included a loss of $2,265,000 from writedowns from sales of nursing homes. The latest 9-month figures do not include the results of a speech and hearing facility that was sold on March 31, 1988. c-Net loss

title: Review/Music; Young Talent on Display
description: Sunday's American Symphony Orchestra concert at Carnegie Hall had a lot to do with being young. George Hanson, the winner of the 1989 Leopold Stokowski Conducting Competition and a talented young man, conducted this afternoon affair. Leonidas Kavakos, the 22-year-old Greek violinist who won last year's Naumburg award and who is quite gifted, played the Tchaikovsky Concerto. And the program had one of the most enticing products of Leonard Bernstein's youth, ''Trouble in Tahiti,'' his brief opera done here in concert form.

title: L.I. Police Suspect Arson in Blaze At Site of a Proposed Group Home
description: A group home being prepared for 12 retarded adults in the affluent Lawrence section was damaged in a fire Sunday night, and the police said today that they suspected arson.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-10

title: China Sets Import Curb
description: China has banned cigarette and liquor imports this year to save foreign currency and end abuses in its foreign trade system, official reports said today. The China Daily quoted the Foreign Economic Relations and Trade Minister, Zheng Tuobin, as also announcing tighter controls on imports of all products that can be made in China and a ban on the reselling of export licenses.

title: Bush's Savings-Plan Math: Critics See a Lot of Big Ifs
description: LEAD: President Bush's plan to resolve the financial troubles of the nation's savings industry is based on assumptions that interest rates will decline sharply and deposits increase steadily in coming years, according to figures made available yesterday by the Office of Management and Budget.

title: Kewaunee Scientific Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After tax credits of $75,000 for the quarter and $366,000 for the 9 months. c-After tax credits of $33,000 and $156,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Paballelo Journal; For One Moment of Mob Rage, Must 25 Now Die?
description: Alfred Gubula, a soft-spoken man who walks with the aid of a brass-handled walking stick, can recall the events of Nov. 13, 1985, as though they happened yesterday.

title: The New Contra Issue
description: The vacuum of policy on Central America in the Bush Administration is causing considerable nail-chewing in the region. But it is also an opportunity that the Latins are moving to use before they come up against decisions they wouldn't like.

title: The Sounds Of Spring Training
description: (Parking Lot) When'd you get down? What's the weather like up north? I hear it's raining. (Clubhouse) Show your pass. Show your pass. Hot enough for you? The press guide isn't ready yet. We had to get Tommy John in it. Sorry, guys, clubhouse closes from 10 until after the workout. Dugout is open. Don't go on the field. New rules. (Enclosed Batting Cage Behind First Base) Whiz. Crack. Ching. Whiz. Crack. Ching. (Dugout) Where's my clipboard? We were all reading it, Dallas. Doesn't matter; I don't have any secrets. (Outfield) Put your knees up to your chest. Reverse it. Sit up. Grab your ankle. Now your right one. Hips are square while you run. That's it. I'm grooming Hondo for this job. Oh, that's great.

title: Deere & Co reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included a one-time gain of $28.7 million from an accounting change and $9.3 million gain from a tax loss carryforward.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:
