description: b-Net income The company said the loss in the latest period was due to lower-than-expected sales due to a fire in October.

title: Many Found Cuban Missile Crisis Real Enough; Khrushchev's Cards
description: To the Editor:

title: Soldiers in the Crack War: Fighting Street by Street
description: ''Uncle Leader,'' the woman's voice came soft over the radio. ''Steppin' out.''

title: Court Says Patent Law Limits Action by States
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that states may not go beyond the scope of Federal patent law to protect unpatented products or manufacturing processes against duplication.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Environmental Control Group, Maple Shade, N.J., an environmental services company, said Morgan R. Jones, a managing partner in the law firm of Drinker Biddle & Reath, had been elected to its board.

title: Spain Will Act on Inflation
description: The Bank of Spain announced today that it would take drastic measures against inflation, which rose 6.3 percent in the year ended Jan. 31, more than double the official 3 percent target.

title: Brazil-U.S. Dispute Set For GATT
description: The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade decided today to set up a dispute panel to hear a complaint by Brazil against punitive tariffs imposed by the United States against it last fall.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: IN mid-January, Howell Boone turns his 60-foot shrimp boat over to sturgeon fishing, thus marking the beginning of the domestic caviar season. Since 1976, Mr. Boone, 31 years old, has been building a reputation for his brand, Walter's Caviar, which he processes here in a tiny shack on the banks of the Altamaha River.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Delivery, at Last
description: It has taken years, but the Postal Service today will deliver two letters written by a World War II serviceman killed in aerial combat over Verona, Italy, in July 1944.

title: Wings Top Islanders As Yzerman Excels
description: Steve Yzerman, the multi-talented center for the Red Wings, set a club record for points and tied the record for goals in a season tonight in Detroit's 6-5 victory over the Islanders.

title: Reviews/Opera; 'Salome,' the Biblical Headhunting Tale
description: The Metropolitan Opera's new ''Salome'' is a schizoid affair. In this Nikolaus Lehnhoff production, the musical and theatrical elements of Strauss's biblical horror story lead parallel lives, never really making contact. Fortunately for those who care about such things, the score's exhausting musical challenges were met triumphantly on Monday evening, particularly by Eva Marton in the grueling title part. She was in good hands under Marek Janowski, whose masterly conducting continually brought the orchestra to a furious boil without loss of control. The result was a tour de force of sustained hysteria.

title: Byrne's Slaying Called 'Symbolic Message'
description: A Queens prosecutor declared in court yesterday that three men had murdered a New York City police officer on a South Jamaica street because they were ''agents of death'' delivering a ''symbolic message.''

title: Harold Christensen, 84, a Dancer And Ballet School Director, Dies
description: Harold Christensen, a dancer, a teacher and for 33 years the director of the San Francisco Ballet school, died of prostate cancer on Monday at his home in San Anselmo, Calif. He was 84 years old.

title: Foxboro Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The fourth quarter and full-year 1987 results included pre-tax charges of $65,908,000, including $62,585,000 of restructuring costs.

title: Harley-Davidson Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses for additional cost of the 1983 AMF settlement of $658,000 for the quarter and $1,776,000 for the year, and losses on the repurchase of debt of $584,000 and $1,468,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included tax credit of $482,000 for the quarter and $3,542,000 for the year.

title: H. Lyman Stebbins, 77, Retired Stockbroker
description: H. Lyman Stebbins, a retired stockbroker and a prominent Roman Catholic layman, died of emphysema Sunday at his home in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 77 years old.

title: Tucker Is Looking for a Comeback
description: Not long ago, Mike Tyson, the heavyweight champion, said that his toughest fight had been against Tony Tucker.

title: Claudio Arrau Cancels
description: The pianist Claudio Arrau has canceled his performances with the New York Philharmonic tonight, tomorrow and Friday because of illness. He is to be replaced by Elisabeth Leonskaja, who is also scheduled to appear with the orchestra in concerts on Saturday and Tuesday. The program for these concerts remains unchanged.

title: Passengers on Airliine Shuttle Fly High on Calories and Fats
description: SEVERAL years ago when complaints about airline food were at their peak, many suggestions were made on ways to improve its quality. A simple snack was most often suggested as the alternative to gummy, overcooked, tepid, tasteless food. What most people envisioned was a sandwich and a piece of fruit or crackers and cheese.

title: Surely a Novel Can't Shake Islam
description: Johannesburg

title: International American Homes Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Revenue and net income for the latest 9 months from the sale of investment and land resale were $4,337,000 and $700,000, or 9 cents a share, respectively. In the year-ago 9 months, revenue and net income were $2,432,000 and $239,000, or 3 cents a share, respectively, from the sale of investment and land resale.

title: Shaer Shoe Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included a writeoff of a large receivable of $300,000.

title: Amoco's Damages Raised By $30 Million in Cadiz Spill
description: LEAD: A Federal district judge in Chicago recommended yesterday that the Amoco Corporation pay about $115 million to France and nearly 90 French citizens and businesses that suffered damage from the huge oil spill of the Amoco Cadiz supertanker in 1978.

title: Prague Jails a Major Playwright For Inciting Protests Last Month
description: A Czechoslovak court today convicted the playwright and dissident author Vaclav Havel of inciting illegal protests and obstructing the police and sentenced him to nine months in prison.

title: Tyco Toys Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Reviews/Opera; Riccardo Muti's Hand In a Fiery Verdi Work
description: Riccardo Muti's latest opera-in-concert presentation at Carnegie Hall was ''Nabucco'' Monday night, the fiery opera that established Verdi's career at La Scala and inaugurated Mr. Muti's directorate of the same theater.

title: Crystal Brands Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $476,000 and $2,626,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The latest quarter included results of operations for Trifari, Krussman & Fishel Inc., acquired on April 30, 1988. Trifari's operations reflected net income of $2,516,000, or 28 cents a share, which included charges of $635,000 resulting from purchase accounting. The latest year included the results of Trifari from May 1. Trifari's operation incurred a net loss of $2,117,000, which included total purchase accounting charges of $4,438,000, or which $3,157,000 are non-recurring. Results do not include Palm Beach Inc., which was acquired on Dec. 15, 1988.

title: Stray Buffalo Killed in Red Harvest on the Snow
description: At dawn the buffalo moving north along the Yellowstone River are covered with fresh snow, their enormous heads wearing crowns of white. In sub-zero cold they exhale steam through the fist-size holes of their nostrils.

title: Hanover Cuts Its Net After Bond Trades
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation said yesterday that it will restate its fourth-quarter earnings, reducing them by $14 million to reflect unauthorized bond trading by an employee.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the People section of the Advertising column of Business Day last Wednesday misstated Terry L. Rosenquist's new position at Lintas:

title: Supreme Court Rejects L.I. Case on Abortion
description: The Supreme Court today threw out an emergency request by abortion opponents who had sought to prevent a Long Island man from having an abortion performed on his comatose wife.

title: United Canadian Shares Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a special gain of $2,108,000. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday with an article about the Chicago commodities exchanges reversed the average prices of seats. A seat on the Chicago Board of Trade sells for $405,000, while a seat on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange sells for $490,000. The chart also misstated the Board of Trade's average daily volume in 1988. It was 563,144.

title: Champion Sets Cooper Deal
description: The Champion Spark Plug Company agreed today to be acquired by Cooper Industries Inc. for $800 million in cash.

title: Rose Is the Subject, Mum Is the Word
description: Pete Rose, the irrepressible manager of the Cincinnati Reds, acknowledged today that he was summoned to New York for a meeting Monday with Commissioner Peter Ueberroth and Commissioner-elect A. Bartlett Giamatti, but none of the principals would talk about the reason for the session.

title: Ninth-Grade Bronx Teacher Arrested in Heroin Purchase
description: A high school teacher at a Roman Catholic preparatory school in the Bronx was arrested with a companion for possession of heroin yesterday by officers from the New York City Police Department's special anti-drug unit, the police said.

title: C.F.T.C. Criticizes Exchange
description: In a surprisingly critical review, the Federal regulator of commodity exchanges said today that the Chicago Board of Trade had done a poor job of detecting fraud and other violations on its trading floor.

title: Review/Film; Second Thoughts on a Murder Case
description: Lawrencia Bembenek was a beautiful bride, a 22-year-old blonde who had worked as both a policewoman and a Playboy bunny, when she was arrested in Milwaukee for the murder of her husband's ex-wife. Though the evidence was circumstantial and none of it implicated Miss Bembenek directly or exclusively, she was sentenced to life in prison. Her husband, who had expressed resentment over having to support his ex-wife, sought a divorce soon after his wife's conviction. ''Dear Lawrencia,'' he wrote to her. ''Goodbye. Good luck - Fred.''

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Century Telephone Enterrises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest quarter and year results included an after-tax gain of $1,324,000 from the sale of cellular interests. The year-ago quarter and year results included an after-tax gain of $5,597,000 from the sale of the company's cable television properties. Results for all periods reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in August 1988 and a 3-for-2 stock split to be effected next month.

title: Heroin Seizure at 3 Queens Sites Is Called Biggest U.S. Drug Raid
description: Federal agents and the New York City police seized more than 800 pounds of heroin in Queens late Monday and early yesterday, confiscated $3 million and arrested 19 people linked to a major Southeast Asian heroin network in what the city and Federal authorities said was the largest drug seizure ever in the United States.

title: Mandela Bodyguards Charged With Murder
description: Two bodyguards of Winnie Mandela who were arrested Sunday were charged today with murder, abduction and assault, a police spokesman said.

title: A Second Life for Plastic Cups? Science Turns Them Into Lumber
description: A new park bench made of sturdy plastic sits in the hallway of a research office at Rutgers University here, an ornamental testament to a useful second life for the plastic-foam cup and hamburger box.

Economic and Social Council DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM - GOVERNING COUNCIL - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. POPULATION COMMISSION - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M

title: Holly Board Studying Sale of the Company
description: The Holly Corporation, a small independent oil refiner, said today that its board was exploring the possibility of selling the company, which mainly operates in New Mexico and the surrounding area.

title: Denison Mines Ltd reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a $125,000,000 after-tax write-down of the company's oil and gas property and a special gain of $25,932,000 from the sale of the 44.8 percent interest in Standard Trustco Ltd. c-Net income The company said after payment of preferred dividends, there were no earnings applicable to common shares in either period. Results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Interpublic Profit Up
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies said its 1988 earnings increased 21.9 percent, to $60.1 million, or $2.72 a share, from 49.3 million, or $2.25 a share. Interpublic - a holding company comprising McCann-Erickson Worldwide, Lintas: Worldwide, Dailey & Associates and other agencies - said its gross billings in 1988 were a record $1.19 billion, a 22.6 percent increase over 1987 revenues of $970.7 million.

title: How Tower's Character Became the Issue; Reputation Is Decisive
description: To the Editor:

title: Gorman-Rupp Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Wine Talk
description: The controversy over the 1982 vintage in Bordeaux goes on - and on - and an important tasting of these wines here this month did little to calm things down.

title: Dyatron Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
S. Carolina Gets Coach
description: Sparky Woods, the football coach at Appalachian State University for the last five years, was named the new head coach at South Carolina yesterday, concluding a search that began about two weeks ago after the sudden death of Joe Morrison. Woods, 35 years old, had a 38-19-2 record at Appalachian State. ''I think he's got a fire in his stomach,'' said James B. Holderman, the president of the university.(AP)

title: Daniel G. Butera, Radiologist, 79
description: Dr. Daniel G. Butera, a retired radiologist, died of leukemia Monday at his home in Bayside, Queens. He was 79 years old.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Racketeering Law Limited in Pornography Cases
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that the First Amendment's guarantee of free speech bars law-enforcement officials from seizing the inventory of adult bookstores before any of the publications have been found at trial to be obscene.

title: Zenith Electronics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $6,400,000. c-Net loss Results for 1988 included pre-tax gains of $6,000,000 from the disposition of several properties and pretax charges of $5,000,000 primarily for employee severance pay and a consent solicitation. Results for 1987 included pre-tax charges of $16,000,000 associated with staff reductions and other reductions.

title: Aloette Cosmetics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Joseph R. Marro Dies; A Retired Justice, 81
description: Joseph R. Marro, a retired justice of the New York State Supreme Court, died of heart failure yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 81 years old.

title: POLICE TRANSFERS STUDIED IN CAPITAL
description: Officials today prepared a plan that would permit the deployment of several hundred Washington police officers from desk jobs to at least part-time duty on streets where homicides are running at a record rate.

title: Tucker Drilling Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Frozen Food Express reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Cambodia Talks End; Progress Is Slight
description: After some progress on the details of an overall solution, talks on a Cambodian settlement ended today with a call for the two warring Cambodian factions to meet on their own to settle their differences.

title: Fresh Horizons In Hawaiian Food
description: LEAD: HAWAII, long a bastion of tired American resort cooking (coquilles St.-Jacques, duck a l'orange, crepes suzettes), is full of restaurants that seem to be stuck in a time warp. When it's 8 P.M. in New York, it's still 1955 in the Hawaiian Islands.

title: Lawson Products reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-earlier share earnings reflected a 3-for-2 stock split paid April 1988.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball BOSTON (AL) - Agreed to terms with Mike Greenwell, outfielder, on a two-year contract, and Luis Rivera, infielder, on a one-year contract. Signed Bill Laskey, pitcher, to a minor league contract and invited him to spring training. CALIFORNIA (AL) - Purchased the contract of Gary Buckels, pitcher, from Midland of the Texas League. KANSAS CITY (AL) - Signed Kevin Seitzer, third baseman, to a one-year contract. MILWAUKEE (AL) - Signed George Canale, infielder; Matias Carrillo and Mike Felder, outfielders, and Jay Aldrich, Tom Filer and Doug Henry, pitchers. CINCINNATI (NL) - Signed Randy St. Claire, pitcher, to a one-year contract. METS (NL) - Signed Wally Whitehurst, pitcher, to a one-year contract. PITTSBURGH (NL) - Agreed to terms with Doug Drabek, pitcher, on a one-year contract. ST. LOUIS (NL) - Signed Alex Cole, outfielder, to a one-year contract. Basketball DALLAS (NBA) - Traded Detlef Schrempf, forward, to the Indiana Pacers for Herb Williams, forward, and a second-round draft pick. Football ATLANTA (NFC) - Signed Bob Brotzki, offensive tackle. CLEVELAND (AFC) - Named Lionel Taylor special offensive assistant and tight ends coach. WASHINGTON (NFC) - Signed Greg Horne, punter. Hockey TEAM CANADA - Named Dan Maloney assistant coach. WASHINGTON (NHL) - Recalled Chris Felix, defenseman, from Baltimore of the American Hockey League. College BOSTON UNIVERSITY - Announced that Jack Parker has declined a promotion to athletic director. Named Gary Strickler acting athletic director. MISSISSIPPI STATE - Named Jim Tompkins assistant football coach. NEW MEXICO HIGHLANDS - Announced that Lionel Taylor, head football coach, has resigned. PORTLAND - Placed Josh Lowery, basketball guard, on disciplinary probation. SOUTH CAROLINA - Named Sparky Woods head football coach. STANFORD - Named Mike Riley defensive coordinator. VANDERBILT - Named Ron Case secondary coach and defensive passing-game coordinator; Rick Christopel defensive coordinator; Bill Schmitz offensive coordinator; Bob Campiglia outside linebackers coach; Mark Bradley running backs coach; George Warhop offensive line coach, and Lynn Hailstock administrative assistant and full-time recruiter. WISCONSIN - Named Jacob Burney defensive line coach.

title: Barrett Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $15,000 for the latest quarter and $157,000 for the year-ago period.

title: Pepsi Spot in Spanish With No Translation
description: Last year, Pepsico sought to appeal to the taste buds of the perestroika generation with the first English-language television commercial in the Soviet Union.

title: Toy Maker Finds a Buyer
description: Worlds of Wonder Inc., the toy maker known for its talking Teddy Ruxpin bear, said today that it had agreed to sell operating control of the company to Eli Jacobs, a New York investor, after the bankruptcy court approves its reorganization plan.

title: PAM Transportation reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Santana Eager to Show His Stuff
description: There were two new gloves sitting in his locker, both of them still in the large plastic bag in which they had arrived. Rafael Santana took one out, slid it over his left hand and pounded his fist loudly into the palm. He did the same with the other glove. It was one of the sounds of spring, and Santana seemed eager to begin again. On the first day that players could report to camp and drop off their equipment, the Yankee shortstop took part in his first full workout at Fort Lauderdale Stadium.

title: Panel, Beginning an End to Ordeal, Sets Vote on Tower Nomination
description: The Senate Armed Services Committee today tentatively scheduled a vote for Thursday on John G. Tower's nomination as Secretary of Defense.

title: Real Estate; Industrial Park to Rise In the Bronx
description: ENCOURAGED by the success of the Bathgate Industrial Park, a 21-acre complex carved out of a decaying Bronx neighborhood by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the city's Public Development Corporation decided five years ago to establish a similar development in the West Farms section of the borough. It designated a 10-acre tract of abandoned apartment buildings as the Mid Bronx Industrial Park.

title: Interpublic Group of Cos Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest periods included losses from exchange and translation of foreign currencies of $7,491,000 for the quarter and $12,203,000 for the year. The year-ago periods included losses from exchange and translation of foreign currencies of $2,632,000 for the quarter and $4,326,000 for the year. Revenue represents total gross income.

title: Investors Group Inc reports earnings for
description: The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Statesman Bush's Debut; President Will Take World Stage in Asia, But Many Criticize Delay in Raising Curtain
description: President Bush steps onto the world stage this week without much of his supporting cast and without a polished script, at a time when his rival for international stardom, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, is winning plaudits almost everywhere.

title: Hewlett-Packard Co reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said the latest first quarter earnings reflect the consolidation of the accounts of Hewlett- Packard Finance Co., a wholly owned subsidiary previously accounted for under the equity method, and a change in the classification of profit sharing and retirement costs.

title: Unwelcome Windshield Washers Are Targets
description: Saying that residents and tourist were being frightened, the Dade County Commission voted today to allow the jailing of anyone who approaches a stopped car to offer to wash its windshield in exchange for money.

title: Lessons
description: For Mishelle Chambers, dropping out of school is a family tradition. Like her mother, she lasted only to the 11th grade, when the struggle became too painful and she traded further education for early marriage.

title: Cooking on Safari: A Challenge for a Chef
description: Of course there are lions and wildebeests in the Serengeti Plain and the Ngorongoro crater. The surprises were caramel custard and guacamole.

title: Student Articles Hostile to Israel Divide Campus at U. of Michigan
description: A university campus that has struggled with racial tensions now finds itself embroiled in a controversy over anti-Israel editorials in the student newspaper.

title: Advanta Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a charge of $2,500,000 from the settlement of a class action suit. c-Net income

title: TransCanada Glass Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included special gains of $3,400,000 and $8,200,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included a special gain of $200,000. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: What David Duke Owes Willie Horton
description: Credit Lee Atwater, the Republican National Chairman, for responding quickly and unequivocally to the victory of a former Ku Klux Klansman, David Duke, in a Louisiana state legislative election. He called Mr. Duke, who ran as a Republican, a ''charlatan'' and urged the party's national executive committee to censure him.

title: Bias Judge Faced Harassment Charge
description: The chief administrative law judge in the New York State division of human rights, who heads the unit reviewing discrimination complaints, was appointed to the job without the divison's knowing he had been charged with ridiculing a homosexual supervisor in a previous job with the Labor Department, state officials said yesterday.

title: KEY RATES
Diagnostic Products reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
E.P.A. Chief Puts Waste Cleanup At Top of His Agency's Agenda
description: William K. Reilly, the new head of the Environmental Protection Agency, said today that he would enforce the nation's toxic waste cleanup law more aggressively than it has been up to now.

title: Europe Seeks TV Backing
description: The European Community is seeking United States support for its standard of high-definition television as the world norm, a senior community official said today.

title: Accounts
description: * Sun-Maid Growers of California to Grey Advertising, with a budget of $7 million.

title: Sunshine-Jr Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Latest year sales cover a 52-week period, compared with a 53-week period in 1987.

title: A Correction
description: Lines were omitted from a letter Feb. 12 by Ethel Dunn on the Russian peasant's diet. The sentences affected should have read: ''My data suggest that consumption of fruits and vegetables, though higher now than under the czars, is well below official Soviet nutritional norms. I guess Mr. Zaychenko doesn't read Jane Brody, who recommends meat servings of three ounces, much less dietary fat and sugar, and emphasis on vegetables, fruits and grains. The ordinary Soviet citizen equates eating meat with prosperity, and therefore meat consumption is a political issue.''

title: Le Reve Winery on L.I. Says It Isn't in Trouble
description: Le Reve, a major Long Island winery, is reportedly in financial trouble. But the owner, Alan Barr, said it was not in danger even though a bank has taken steps to foreclose on a loan that he characterized as ''slightly more than $6 million.''

title: Global Marine Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Royal Gold Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $207,000. c-Net loss

title: Vintage Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Spiegel Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $8 million from an accounting change. Share earnings included cumulative effect of change in accounting for income taxes.

title: Dana Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said 1987 earnings were restated to reflect accounting changes. It said fourth quarter 1987 earnings were reduced by 31 cents a share because of restructuring related to plant closings and change in real estate market valuations, but the reduction was offset by gains from the sale of a subsidiary.

title: Castle, A M & Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Troy R. Westmeyer, Professor, 72
description: Troy R. Westmeyer, a professor emeritus of the New York University Graduate School of Public Administration, died Saturday at Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived in Stamford.

title: New Moscow: More Hymns To Old Russia
description: Three church choirs lofted sonorous a cappella hymns to the rafters of the Wings of the Soviets hockey arena, transformed for the evening into an incongruous cathedral.

title: Dip in Jobless Yields Tax Cut For Businesses
description: New York State businesses will get a $480 million tax cut this year - about $70 per worker - because low unemployment figures have led to the suspension of a special surtax for unemployment insurance, the State Labor Commissioner said today.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Checks on Drugs?
description: The World chess champion, Gary Kasparov, came to Washington yesterday on a whirlwind tour to promote an American-British-Soviet effort to fight drugs by introducing chess into inner city schools. ''I think it will open new horizons for young people; we can't afford to lose this game,'' said Mr. Kasparov at the National Capital Children's Museum, which will be the setting for one of the events, a chess camp for 300 inner city school children this summer. It is hoped, said Maciej P. Jachimczyk, one of the organizing officials, that Soviet young people will participate in the Washington program, which will be supported by private funds.

title: CLOSE TO HOME
description: ONCE I lived in a world inhabited by people who always knew who had made ''the best little black dress in Paris.'' (The best little black dress in Paris is born twice a year, at the couture collections, and no fashion writer fails to proclaim its arrival.) These people also knew where to get the best boots and who made the most significant belts, and said things like ''bigger! fuller! looser!'' and ''It was to die.''

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * American Franchise Group, Fort Lauderdale, Fla., a printing concern, said Frank Sorrentino had been appointed president and chief executive of its subsidiary Print Shack International Inc.

title: POW! Cartoon Heroes Zap Drug Abuse
description: AT first glance, the Drug Avengers seem like yet another bunch of Saturday morning television cartoon characters entertaining glassy-eyed children. But through catchy songs and short tales, their message to young viewers is that drug use is all around them, and that they can do more than ''Just Say No.''

title: A Mack Goes to Bat
description: Sen. Connie Mack, the Florida Republican whose grandfather is in the Hall of Fame, yesterday told the incoming commissioner that Florida should have three major league teams. ''As citizens of the fourth-largest state, Floridians have supported with much enthusiasm the teams that travel to Florida each spring to get in shape in the best possible environment,'' Mack said in a letter to A. Bartlett Giamatti, the National League president. His letter noted that his namesake, Cornelius McGillicuddy (Connie Mack), trained in Florida 101 years ago with the Washington Club professional team, then brought the Philadelphia Athletics team he owned and managed to Florida for spring training starting 66 years ago.(AP)

title: Allen Eaton Throop, 89, Is Dead; Ex-Counsel to Federal Agencies
description: Allen Eaton Throop, a lawyer and former general counsel to several Federal agencies, died of cardiac arrest Sunday at Goodwin House West, a retirement community in Falls Church, Va., after a long illness. He was 89 years old and lived in Falls Church.

title: Marimekko Viewed Afresh
description: FOR as long as many people can remember, at least since the 60's, Marimekko's patterned fabrics have been icons of modern design. But in the last few years the Finnish company's bold and colorful fabrics seemed to fall out of favor with some generation of avant-garde designers.

title: A Designer Tests His Wings: Maximal Style For Minimalist Tastes
description: ''PEOPLE react with surprise, almost with horror,'' a nonplussed Jeff Fazio said of his newly renovated Chelsea co-op.

title: Out of the Faint Past, a Trace of Fun
description: In a Manhattan so distant that it cannot be remembered, two players put their markers away after one last round of nine men's morris. What they left behind, to baffle modern custodians and visitors in the 18th-century Dyckman House, was a mysterious grid - square within square within square - carved into a granite outcropping in the cellar.

title: Pulitzer's Net Rises by 35.1%
description: The Pulitzer Publishing Company today reported a 35.1 percent increase in its fourth-quarter profit, partly because of increased revenue from the company's broadcasting division.

title: Kerr Glass Manufacturing Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and after a gain of $1,271,000 from an accounting change. The latest fourth quarter included other expense of $308,000 after tax, primarily relating to certain severance costs. The latest year included expenses of $509,000 after tax, primarily relating to the settlement of retiree medical care and life insurance litigation and certain severance costs. The year-ago quarter included expenses of $349,000 after tax, relating to a work force reduction, and $140,000 after tax relating to restructuring of facilities. The 1987 year results were adversely impacted by other expense of $71,000 after tax.

title: New Role for Mahovlich
description: Pete Mahovlich, general manager and coach of the Denver Rangers since 1987, will leave the International Hockey League franchise to work for its parent team, the Rangers, as a scout of possible playoff opponents. (AP)

title: TV Notes
description: Small-Screen 'Cafe'

title: A Quirky Style All His Own
description: INEVITABLY, anyone who meets Scott Strasser, a 34-year-old Dallas designer, tends to gaze quizzically at his hair. ''There's not a hair of the same length,'' Mr. Strasser explained. ''And it seems to do it all on its own.''

title: Handleman Co reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The latest 9 months and prior year amounts have been restated to reflect the pooling of interest of Video Treasures and its related companies, which was acquired on Jan. 1 through a stock transaction.

title: Banner Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $14,339,000 and $14,100,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also included an extraordinary charge of $8,070,000. c-Net loss and included income from discontinued operations of $4,280,000 for the quarter and $4,824,000 for the year.

title: Personal Health
description: More than seven million healthy Americans have spouses who are chronically ill. For the well spouses, life is a constant struggle against emotional debilitation, physical exhaustion and often financial destitution. They have in many ways lost a life's companion and gained an albatross, a sick person who bears a dwindling resemblance to the one they loved and married.

title: Chicago Journal; New Funeral Option For Those in a Rush
description: The convenience and high technology of drive-through banks and hamburger places have come to the funeral world.

title: West Coast Words
description: To The Home Section:

title: Child-Care Decisions
description: To The Home Section:

title: HEALTH: Treatment Advances; Studies Cite Benefits of Chemotherapy in Early Breast Cancer
description: Even breast cancer patients whose cancer has not spread to the lymph nodes could benefit from chemotherapy, four new studies have shown. The therapy somewhat improves their chances of remaining free of cancer in the years immediately after surgery, although there is no evidence that they ultimately live any longer.

title: Investor Discloses Bilzerian Talks
description: The Malaysian investor Vincent Tan said he had been talking with the Florida investor Paul A. Bilzerian about a possible alternative bid for SSMC Inc. Mr. Tan has said he may make a hostile bid to defeat the $163 million merger accord between SSMC and Semi-Tech Microelectronics (Far East) Ltd., a Hong Kong concern.

title: On Eve of Funeral, Hirohito War Role Needs Airing; Should Bush Attend?
description: To the Editor:

title: Union Carbide Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an aftertax charge of $53 million to cover litigation contingencies including environmental matters, the Bhopal case and general corporate litigation. Results have been audited. Audited 1988 earnings have been adjusted from preliminary amounts to reflect an aftertax charge in the fourth quarter of $58 millionfor settlement of the Bhopal litigation. On Jan. 23 the company reported unaudited results for the latest fourth quarter of $219 million, or $1.59 a share. Preliminary share net fully diluted was reported as $1.51. The company had reported preliminary net income for the full year of $720 million, or $5.31 a share.

title: Capital Holding Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Witness Tells of Informer in Officer's Slaying
description: A Queens detective testified yesterday that the police had been led to four men accused of executing a rookie police officer by a man who, the authorities said, was at a session where the killing was planned.

title: JM Smucker Co reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Agency Said to Fail Children Placed in Relatives' Care
description: New York City's child-welfare agency is failing to properly supervise thousands of abused and neglected children who have been placed in foster care with relatives, say caseworkers, union officials and lawyers representing the children.

title: On Eve of Funeral, Hirohito War Role Needs Airing
description: To the Editor:

title: International Proteins Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The year-ago quarter and prior year results included a $4,445,000 restructuring charge.

title: Brawley Lawyer Is Rebuffed
description: One of Tawana Brawley's lawyers, C. Vernon Mason, will not be allowed to view the confidential minutes from the grand jury investigation of her asserted abduction and sexual assault, Justice Angelo J. Ingrassia ruled today in State Supreme Court. Mr. Mason had asked to see the minutes to defend himself against possible disciplinary actions requested by the State Attorney General, Robert Abrams.

title: Witness in Trial Of Gotti Breaks Plea Agreement
description: A convicted bank robber accused of perjury in connection with his testimony at the racketeering trial of John Gotti two years ago broke an agreement to plead guilty yesterday and asked for a trial.

title: Sudan's Army Said to Give Premier an Ultimatum
description: The Sudanese commander in chief and 150 other military officers have given Prime Minister Sadiq al-Mahdi a week to reform his Government and work to end the nation's civil war, newspapers reported today.

title: UAL Stake Raised
description: The New York investor Saul P. Steinberg has increased his stake in the UAL Corporation to 6.9 percent from 5.8 percent. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Mr. Steinberg said that his Reliance Financial Services Corporation had purchased 227,200 more UAL shares on the market between Feb. 8 and Feb. 17 for $28 million, or an average price of $123 a share.

title: Schwab Safe Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $190,134 gain from an accounting change.

title: French Bank Settlement Called Near
description: The four-month fight by the financier Georges Pebereau for control of Societe Generale, France's fourth-largest commercial bank, is apparently near an end.

title: General Binding Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with a television review of ''Timeline'' misidentified the actor playing Peter the Hermit. He was Paco Catala; Homer Sykes is the photographer who made the picture.

title: Ecologically Correct Catalogue
description: LEAD: ALAN NEWMAN has a vision of the household of the 1990's, and it is not exactly glamorous.

title: Generational View From 2 Nations
description: The Perspective from Japan

title: Greiner Engineering reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings reflected 25 percent stock dividend paid Dec. 2, 1988.

title: A Writer's Voice: Rushdie's 'Verses'
description: The ''The Satanic Verses,'' is the most autobiographical and least political of Salman Rushdie's several perspectives on India and Pakistan.

title: Hrudey Is Traded by Islanders In an Effort to Bolster Future
description: The last-place Islanders, confounded by their inability to produce a competitive hockey club this season, took a step bordering on the drastic today and traded Kelly Hrudey, their cornerstone goaltender, to Los Angeles for a pair of 20-year-old prospects, Mark Fitzpatrick, a goaltender, and Wayne McBean, a defenseman.

title: Review/Music; Booming Drums At the Center Of a Septet
description: Peter Erskine earned his reputation as a drummer with the jazz-rock band Weather Report. Opening a six-night engagement on Tuesday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street, he sounded like a rock drummer playing jazz. He tunes his drums low, to boom rather than to articulate, and like rock drummers he likes to land just behind the beat. The music lumbers.

title: Richard Roud Memorial
description: A memorial service for Richard Roud, a former director of the New York Film Festival, is to be held on Tuesday at 5 P.M. in the 12th-floor loft of the actor Michael Wager at 126 Fifth Avenue, at Liberty Street, in lower Manhattan. The public is invited, although space is limited. Among the speakers at the service will be Nestor Almendros, John Ashbery, Martin Scorsese and Susan Sontag. Mr. Roud died of cardiac arrest on Feb. 13 in Nimes, France, at the age of 59.

title: Corrections
description: A caption yesterday, with an article about Salvadoran rebels' conditional offer to disarm, described the picture incorrectly in some copies. It showed members of Salvador's political parties, not rebel leaders.

title: Formica Accords
description: The Formica Corporation, which has agreed to be acquired in a management-led buyout for $18 a share, or about $230 million, said its financial adviser, Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., had been reached by third parties interested in taking over the decorative-laminates concern. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Formica, based in Wayne, N.J., said it had entered into confidentiality agreements with an unspecified number of the parties.

title: Cone Won't Tie Statistics to His 1989 Expectations
description: On a team of achievers, David Cone is probably the great overachiever on the Mets, a man who began last season as an extra pitcher and ended it with 20 victories, 3 defeats, the best winning percentage in baseball and one of the best in baseball history. And it was only his second season in the big leagues.

title: Three Plagues
description: Modern America's Three Plagues blight the South Bronx: poverty, drug addiction and AIDS. The population is now widely infected with a disease that slowly drains the body of control, sight, mind and life. When the administrations of Mayor Edward Koch and Gov. Mario Cuomo are long forgotten, history will surely note that the New York of their era left the poor to rot, in unparalleled numbers, from the cruelest of diseases.

title: Monograms and Such For Stylish Writers
description: ''WE do stationery for yachts, with yachting flags engraved in a corner, along with the names of the ship,'' said Jack Gallagher, manager of Dempsey & Carroll. In business since 1878, this midtown Manhattan company engraves stationery, wedding invitations, birth announcements and more.

title: F.B.I. Investigating Threats to Rushdie Publisher and Stores
description: Federal agents are analyzing scores of threats against both the American publisher and some retailers of the novel ''The Satanic Verses,'' but nothing so far suggests the threats are organized or directed by Iran, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Tiger in the Office
description: High on a bookcase above the fireplace in John H. Sununu's White House office, looking more placid than ferocious, a small, plush toy tiger lies curled up. Next to Vice President Dan Quayle's desk in the Old Executive Office Building sits a large black cloth Labrador retriever with a chain around her neck.

title: Jacobs-Shaklee
description: The Minneapolis investor Irwin L. Jacobs has raised his stake in the Shaklee Corporation to 11.7 percent from 9.7 percent. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, he said he had bought 265,700 Shaklee shares for $32.75 to $34.04 each. He gave no reason for the additional purchases.

title: Kemp Plans Close Encounter With Homelessness
description: In the rain at 1 o'clock this morning the 11 homeless men and women huddled together on the concrete steps of the Federal Reserve Bank here. They were talking about what they would say to Jack F. Kemp, the new Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, if he stopped there Thursday night on his two-city tour to get a firsthand look at homelessness.

title: Open Positions on Short Sales Edge Up 0.8% on Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest on the Big Board edged up eight-tenths of 1 percent in the four-week period ended Feb. 15.

title: Ex-Democrat Joins Chicago's G.O.P. Race
description: Edward Vrdolyak, a former Alderman who once headed the local Democratic Party, declared tonight that he would be a write-in candidate in the Republican mayoral primary next Tuesday.

title: NUNN TERMS ISSUE OF TOWER DRINKING STILL UNRESOLVED
description: Sam Nunn, the Senator everyone is watching to determine the fate of John G. Tower's nomination to be Secretary of Defense, said today that the inquiry by the Federal Bureau of Investigation did not resolve whether Mr. Tower still has a drinking problem.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Oldsmobile Dealer Communications to Margeotes, Fertitta & Weiss, with a budget of $6 million.

title: Shearson Executive Shifts to Dillon, Read
description: For Francois de Saint Phalle, assuming the post of managing director at Dillon, Read & Company means a return to his roots in smaller, specialized firms.

title: Salman Rushdie, Blame Yourself
description: LEAD: Dear Salman Rushdie, A few years ago, when I read your ''Midnight's Children,'' I was overwhelmed. It was not the exuberance of your narrative and stylistic craft, nor the threads of your rich imagination woven with such effective intellectual control that engulfed me. Rather, it was your formidable grasp of history and, through that, of the psyche of a complex culture in all its variations that formed the substratum of your tale.

title: Irate Soviet Air-Traffic Controllers Shun Pay
description: Exasperated by what they consider inadequate salaries, bureaucratic inertia and outdated equipment, Moscow's air-traffic controllers have resorted to a novel form of strike: instead of refusing to work, they have spent the last two months refusing to collect their pay.

title: Sutton Reported Out
description: Eddie Sutton will leave as the Kentucky basketball coach ''in 10 days to two weeks'' and will be replaced by Lee Rose, a Nets' assistant coach, according to a report in The Columbus Dispatch today. The paper quoted a source close to the Kentucky program as saying ''Sutton is going to be told he's gone in 10 days to two weeks. The new coach is picked and it's Rose.'' The source said Rose was the choice of C. M. Newton, who will become athletic director April 1, replacing Cliff Hagan, who resigned last year.(AP)

title: Unisys Announces Plans to Eliminate 2,500 Jobs
description: The Unisys Corporation said yesterday that it intended to eliminate up to 2,500 jobs as part of a previously announced effort to shrink its 93,000- person work force by 3 percent.

description: Born in Bombay to a Muslim family (which later moved to Karachi, Pakistan), Salman Rushdie has spent the last two decades living in England, and in all his fiction, he has used his multi-cultural perspective - what he calls his ''stereoscopic vision'' - to look at the subcontinent both from within and without.

title: SUNY Tuition Rise Is Backed
description: Tuition should be increased this year for New Yorkers at the State University if the Legislature adopts Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's proposed budget, the SUNY board chairman, Donald M. Blinken, said today. Most students could afford a modest increase, he said. He would not specify the size of the increase, adding that it should be ''as little as possible.''

In Winter Grasses, a Rough Bouquet of Copper and Beige
description: ONLY now, after several months of magnificence, are the tall ornamental grasses in my garden becoming a sorry sight. It is their season of collapse and meltdown.

title: Gardener, Spare That Tree (From Salt Damage)
description: Anyone who walks to the bus stop or drives a car in the winter knows about the white rock-salt residue that coats boots and fenders. Rock salt is more than an eyesore and a potential corrosive, however; it is also dangerous to animals and potentially deadly to trees.

title: William Cassin Jr., a Developer, Dies at 49
description: William F. Cassin Jr., a real-estate developer, died of pancreatic cancer Monday at his home in Rye, N.Y. He was 49 years old.

title: Yanks Gather, Minus Henderson
description: Dave Winfield arrived on time today, but Rickey Henderson did not. The day came and went, and the Yankees worked out despite a persistent rain, but Henderson - reportedly somewhere between here and California - never appeared.

title: Viacom Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Latest-quarter results included $13,600,000 in non-cash charges for interest expense and a $4,300,000 non- cash charge relating to a long-term deferred incentive compensation plan. Results for 1988 and 1987 included non-cash charges for interest expense of $53,416,000 and $48,949,000, respectively. The company said its earnings from operations increased 105 percent in the latest quarter, to $66,903,000 from $32,706,000 in the year-ago quarter. For the year, earnings from operations rose 51 percent to $149,940,000 from $99,098,000 in 1987.

title: The Rise and Fall of a High Roller
description: Bankrupt, facing foreclosure and clinging to the slope of bitter depression, 51-year-old Stanley Kallman, sometime high roller and big-time loser, swears he would sooner pick up a tarantula than a hand of blackjack.

title: Bowl America Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
ADC Telecommunications Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
The Latest Entry In Barnyard Chic
description: ROGER SCHLAIFER was an early fan and collector of the carved-wood animal sculptures of Bryan McNutt, an Arlington, Tex., artist. As president of a licensing and product-development firm in Atlanta, Mr. Schlaifer had an ambitious idea. Why not use the sprightly, brightly colored pieces as a source of inspiration for a whole line of housewares?

title: Premier in Italy Loses Party Leadership Post
description: Prime Minister Ciriaco De Mita lost the leadership of his party today in an election that raises questions about the future of his country's coalition Government.

description: b-Net income c-Included a gain of $1.5 million from an accounting change.

description: Tokyo was transformed into a maze of vacant streets, a blur of precisely timed motorcades and an endless series of diplomatic meetings today as world leaders began to arrive for Japan's first Imperial funeral since 1927.

title: Oneida Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago quarter and full-year earnings included an unusual gain of $11,093,000 as the result of the settlement of pension obligations, partly offset by a reserve to cover anticipated losses on leasing obligations.

title: Pretoria to Lift Key Rate
description: The South African central bank said today that it would raise a key interest rate to counter the impact of weak gold prices and a surging money supply. The Reserve Bank will increase its discount rates, which set the cost of loans to the commercial banks, by one percentage point, to a floor of 16 percent after Thursday. The bank's governor, Gerhard de Kock, said the move, which represents a significant credit tightening, was prompted by the recent steep decline in the gold price, excessive growth in the money supply and higher interest rates in the United States and Europe.

description: b-After a tax loss carryforward of $592,000 for both the quarter and year.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; TV Sports Ads Up 67%
description: Advertising on network television sports broadcasts last year jumped 67 percent over 1987, to a total of nearly $2.7 billion, the Television Bureau of Advertising reported yesterday. That represented an increase of $1 billion over 1987, and $500 million more than in 1984, the last Olympic year. The top three network sports advertisers were General Motors, Anheuser-Busch and Philip Morris, the bureau said.

title: Honda Motor Co Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: As a transitional measure made necessary by the change in the company's fiscal year, the corresponding period last year consisted of 10 months. In order to provide a convenient comparison, the financial results for the 10-month period have been adjusted to approximate a 9-month period by combining the 3-month period ended December 1987 with the 7-month period ended September 1987, which was multiplied by the fraction 6/7 to obtain a 6-month period. The U.S. dollar amounts have been translated from yen at the rate of 126 yen equals U.S. $1.00, the approximate exchange rate prevailing on the Tokyo foreign exchange market on Dec. 31, 1988. The share earnings are in American Depository Share (ADS) and each ADS represents 10 shares of Honda common stock. Revenue represents net sales and other operating revenue.

title: Cavaliers Leave Nets In Disarray And Defeat
description: Beating the Cleveland Cavaliers would be difficult for the Nets under any circumstances. But without three injured players, and with teammates accusing each other of lackluster play, the Nets came about as close to beating Cleveland tonight as Michael Spinks came to beating Mike Tyson.

title: Transco Energy Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and included a $22,476,000 extraordinary gain. c-Included a $20,973,000 extraordinary gain. Latest quarter and year results included net charges of $37,700,000 for natural gas contract settlements and $24,900,000 for liquidation costs. Prior-year results included an $81,200,000 charge for natural gas contract settlements.

title: Making Home a Safer Place for Children
description: Alarmed by the number of children who die each year from preventable injuries, Surgeon General C. Everett Koop has urged the nation to join him in a fight against the leading killer of children, accidents.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: ''I WANTED to strangle the kid!'' said Walter Simmons, a marriage and family therapist in Yorktown Heights, N.Y., recalling the behavior of a guest at his daughter's sixth birthday party. Although Mr. Simmons did not yield to the temptation, his anger and frustration highlight the difficulties that arise when parents consider disciplining other people's children.

title: Cox to Sell TV Station
description: Cox Enterprises Inc. said today that it had agreed to sell its independent television station here to Better Communications Inc. for an undisclosed sum. The station, KDNL, Channel 30, is affiliated with the Fox Network. Atlanta-based Cox also owns newspapers, other television stations and radio stations. Better Communications was formed last fall by Barry Baker, former vice president and director of Koplar Communications Inc. of St. Louis, and Larry Marcus, former vice president of business affairs for Koplar. Koplar owns KPLR-TV, Channel 11 in St. Louis.

title: Code-Alarm Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Corrected from yesterday.

title: Results Plus
description: N.B.A. 76ers 139, Heat 108: Charles Barkley hit 12 of 15 shots, including 6 3-pointers, and scored 39 points despite sitting out the fourth quarter as Philadelphia cruised last night in Miami. Mike Gminski added 22 points for the 76ers. Jon Sundvold scored 26 points for the Heat. A 17-4 Philadelphia run gave the 76ers a 44-26 lead late in the first period. Gminski had three baskets and Barkley scored 5 of his 15 first-quarter points during the surge. Miami's only serious chance to get back in the game came midway in the second quarter. A 10-2 spurt, sparked by 4 points and an assist by Dwayne (Pearl) Washington, closed the gap to 55-49 with 5 minutes 34 seconds left in the half. Philadelphia responded with a 10-2 run, taking a 65-51 lead with 3:33 left in the half. The 76ers were never threatened again.(AP) Bulls 130, Hornets 102: Michael Jordan scored 24 points, and the Bulls hit 81 percent of their shots in a 42-point first period at Charlotte, N.C. Horace Grant had 20 points and 10 rebounds for the Bulls, who hit 52 of 76 shots (68 percent) as they won their fourth consecutive game.(AP) Pistons 105, Trail Blazers 94: Mark Aguirre, making his first home start for Detroit, scored 5 of his 16 points in a key second-quarter run. Aguirre, who was traded to the Pistons from the Mavericks a week ago, received a standing ovation from the sellout crowd of 21,454 at the Palace in Auburn Hills, Mich., when he entered the game with four minutes remaining in the first quarter.(AP) Warriors 118, Spurs 107: Chris Mullin scored 11 of his 27 points in the final seven and one-half minutes last night as Golden State rallied in San Antonio. The loss was the Spurs' eighth straight. Manute Bol blocked 12 shots, a Warriors record.(AP) TENNIS McEnroe Advances: John McEnroe, the second-seeded player, beat a fellow American, Richard Matuszewski, 7-6, 6-2, yesterday in a first-round match at the Lyon Grand Prix tournament in France. In an earlier second-round match, Guy Forget of France lost to Carl Steeb of West Germany, 4-6, 7-5, 6-3. Jakob Hlasek of Switzerland, the tournament's top-seeded player, beat the defending champion, Yaya Doumbia of Senegal, 6-4, 7-6, in the first round. In second-round matches, Magnus Gustafsson of Sweden and Patrick Kuhnen of West Germany advanced. Gustafsson beat Mark Koevermans of the Netherlands, 6-4, 6-2. Kuhnen came from behind to defeat Niclas Kroon of Sweden 2-6, 6-2, 6-3.(AP) Agassi Wins: Andre Agassi defeated Veli Paloheimo, 6-3, 6-2, yesterday in the United States pro indoor championships in Philadelphia. In other matches, second-seeded Boris Becker defeated David Wheaton, 6-1, 6-4; eighth-seeded Dan Goldie spoiled Michael Chang's 17th birthday with a 2-6, 6-4, 6-2 victory, and fifth-seeded Brad Gilbert eliminated No. 12 Paul Annacone 7-6, 7-5. In an afternoon match, fourth-seeded Mikael Pernfors beat Jim Pugh 6-3, 7-5. In another match, Robert Seguso defeated Scott Davis 6-2, 6-2.(AP) Savchenko Gains: Fourth-seeded Larissa Savchenko of the Soviet Union, seventh-seeded Natalie Tauziat of France and unseeded Jenny Byrne of Australia advanced yesterday to the quarterfinals of the Virginia Slims of California tournament in Oakland. Savchenko, the runner-up here last year, beat Jill Hetherington of Canada, 6-3, 7-5. Tauziat, a 21-year-old ranked 28th in the world, stopped Eva Pfaff, 6-2, 6-4. Byrne, who upset eighth-seeded Ros Fairbank in the first round, defeated Monique Javer of Hillsborough, Calif., 6-3, 6-4.(AP) NORDIC SKIING Finns' Success Continues: Harri Kirvesniemi captured the men's 15-kilometer classic-style cross-country race and Finland took the ski-jump team competition yesterday at the world championships in Lahti, Finland. Kirvesniemi came from fifth early in the race to win his first major international title in 42 minutes 40.7 seconds. The Finnish team of Matti Nykaenen, Jari Puikkonen, Ari-Pekka Nikkola and Risto Laakkonen easily won the team jumping title on the 90-meter hill with 645 points. Norway was second with 626 points.(AP) HORSE RACING Buddah Luke Wins: Buddah Luke, ridden by Chris Antley, took the lead after entering the stretch and then withstood a claim of foul by the runner-up's jockey to post a 1 1/4-length victory yesterday in the $23,000 Sanguine Sword Purse at Aqueduct. Turkey Point, with William Fox Jr. aboard, was second in the field of eight, a nose ahead of Occultism. The victory was the first in six starts this year for Buddah Luke, who went six furlongs on the sloppy track in 1:11 3/5. The winner returned $8.80 for $2 to win. SOCCER American Youth Team Triumphs: The United States' under-20 national team advanced to the quarterfinals of the Youth World Cup in Saudi Arabia yesterday despite a 3-1 loss to Brazil in the last game of the first round. Brazil also advanced. COLLEGE BASKETBALL/WOMEN Auburn 89, Alabama 44: Linda Godby scored 22 points and had 10 rebounds last night to lead top-ranked Auburn in a Southeastern Conference game. It was the 39th consecutive home victory for the Lady Tigers (24-0, 7-0), the longest current streak in the nation. Alabama fell to 13-13 and 1-7.(AP) Georgia 86, Howard 49: Sherelle Warren scored 17 points last night to lead five Georgia players in double figures as the fifth-ranked Lady Bulldogs (22-3) won at home. The victory was the 250th for Coach Andy Landers. Howard fell to 12-14.(AP) FENCING Lion Opponents Foiled Again: Columbia won its fourth consecutive Ivy League fencing championship yesterday, defeating Princeton by 18-9 at Princeton, N.J. The Columbia women's team beat Princeton, 14-2, to win its first Ivy League title and the first Ivy championship in any sport for a women's team at Columbia.(AP)

title: Treasury Notes and Bonds Drop
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds fell in moderately active trading yesterday, pushed lower by a consumer price report that shows inflation is heating up.

title: Blasphemy: Islam's View
description: In Islam, the term blasphemy covers a multitude of sins, including any kind of public insult to the faith, to its founder or to its practices. Blasphemy is not distinguished from heresy: it has been used to condemn both learned intellectual challenges to Islamic doctrine as well as dramatic statements that outrage the devout.

title: CLOSER TIES BIND U.S. AND JAPANESE
description: As world leaders prepare to attend the funeral of Emperor Hirohito in Tokyo on Friday, a simultaneous opinion survey in both countries has found that Japanese and Americans now take a more positive view of ties between the two countries after a period of strain over economic relations.

title: Europe Inflation Threat
description: Rising inflation is threatening the European Community's brisk economic growth, the 12-nation bloc's Executive Commission said today. The community's economy is expected to grow by about 3 percent a year over the next two years, but the trend is at risk because of several factors, notably higher inflation, the commission said. Inflation is expected to reach a community average of 4.25 percent this year after 3.7 percent in 1988, said Henning Christophersen, the European commissioner for economic and financial affairs.

title: Q&A
description: Q.The roof over our carport also serves as a deck. To keep water from dripping through onto the car below, we had the deck covered with tar paper, then a layer of plywood. The plywood was primed and painted with an oil-based deck paint. We would now like to cover it with outdoor carpet, but are worried about this causing the plywood to rot. We have received conflicting advice on this. What is your opinion? A.If you use outdoor carpet, use the kind that has no backing, since it will be less likely to hold moisture. Do not cement it down; use nails or staples if fastening is necessary.

title: Venezuela Pact With I.M.F.
description: Venezuela will sign a letter of intent for a credit agreement with the International Monetary Fund next week, an official in the Finance Ministry said Tuesday.

description: Yields for certificates of deposit and money market mutual funds rose for the week that ended yesterday, while yields for bank money accounts slipped.

description: Fourteen Afghan field commanders and scholars, meeting as a committee, failed today to reach agreement on a slate of ministers for a proposed Kabul interim government.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Never on Sunday
description: Many Government departments in Washington have press officers on duty over the weekend and on holidays to answer queries from a relentless press, to respond to contentious statements from abroad and generally to mind the public store.

description: The Soviet and Israeli Foreign Ministers met here today, and both reported readiness for a new dialogue despite profound differences over the agenda for peace in the Middle East.

The Once and Future Kitchenless House
description: TO Charlotte Perkins Gilman, anatomy wasn't destiny. Space was. The late-19th-century author and lecturer found the odes to home-sweet-home a bogus morality for not-so-sweet housekeeping. The private doll's house must fall, she preached. Neighborhoods must be designed to serve domestic life. Architecture was the means.

title: Oliver Leeds, 68, Ex-Head of CORE Chapter
description: Oliver H. Leeds, a former chairman of the Brooklyn chapter of the Congress of Racial Equality, died of cancer last Thursday at LaGuardia Hospital in Queens. He was 68 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: REFORMS PROMISED BY ENERGY NOMINEE
description: James D. Watkins, the Energy Secretary-designate, said today that he was ''aghast'' at the mismanagement and deterioration of the nation's nuclear weapon industry. He vowed to end the culture of complacency and secrecy that he said caused it.

title: Padres Name Smith
description: Tal Smith temporarily assumed general manager duties yesterday for the San Diego Padres as Manager Jack McKeon formally relinquished his dual role as club executive. McKeon was the Padres' general manager for nine years before replacing the dismissed Larry Bowa as manager last May.(AP)

BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Miniscribe to Be Headed By Venture Capitalist
description: LEAD: The Miniscribe Corporation named Richard P. Rifenburgh its chairman and chief executive yesterday, in accordance with the recommendation of Q. T. Wiles, whom he succeeds. Both men are partners in Hambrecht & Quist Inc., a venture capital investment firm that specializes in turning around troubled companies.

description: Charles Smith scored 18 points and Dikembe Mutombo added 13 tonight, leading third-ranked Georgetown to a 76-74 Big East victory over Providence.

title: An Advertisement, Clarified
description: Yesterday's editorial ''On Second Thought, Courage,'' about the reaction to Salman Rushdie's novel ''The Satanic Verses,'' referred to an advertisement elsewhere in The Times. The ad was placed in most but not all editions, however, so the reference mystified some readers. It was signed by the national associations of publishers, booksellers and librarians, to support the book on the occasion of its formal publication date ''in the spirit of America's commitment to free expression.''

title: Crinkley Service
description: A memorial service for Richmond Crinkley, who was executive director of the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center in the early 1980's, is to be held at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, Madison Avenue at 73d Street, at 4:30 P.M. Tuesday. Mr. Crinkley died of cancer on Jan. 29 at the age of 49.

title: An Industry's Race With Summer
description: Manufacturers of room air-conditioners are running their production lines at full speed to refill a distribution pipeline that dried up last August after two successive steamy summers. But because of a worldwide scarcity of compressors, a key component, another long, hot summer this year could find some people left out in the heat again.

title: 17 Lost as Freighter Sinks in Atlantic Storm
description: All 17 seamen on a Panamanian-registered freighter were believed dead today after the ship sank in a North Atlantic storm northwest of Ireland.

title: Dow Jones Fills Post
description: Dow Jones & Company announced yesterday that Karen Elliott House, foreign editor of The Wall Street Journal, had been named vice president of the Dow Jones International Group. The appointment will take effect March 1. In her new post, Ms. House, 41 years old, will direct all editors and publishers of The Wall Street Journal/Europe, The Asian Wall Street Journal, The Far Eastern Economic Review, The Asian Wall Street Journal Weekly. She will also direct the Dow Jones International Marketing Group.

The performance will benefit the Fifth Annual Dancers' Emergency Fund. Ticket prices are $55, $46, $40 and $35. Information and ticket sales: 870-5690.

title: Spoils Are Going to the Young

But the odds are that a player who is between 28 and 34 years of age will win the $234,000 top prize this year in the $1.3 million tournament, which starts Thursday on the Blue Monster course at the Doral Country Club.

title: Erudite Simplification Of Art's Complexities
description: Although he's a vastly erudite grappler with the complexities of art history, Sir Ernst Gombrich has managed to write what is perhaps the most readable survey of his thorny field. Called simply ''The Story of Art,'' it was first published in 1950, and is about to go into its 15th printing. Published in this country by Prentice-Hall, it has been translated into 18 languages and has sold more than two million copies.

description: GETTING rid of an unwanted subsidiary isn't easy. Just ask the Enserch Corporation, the energy pipeline company that branched out in 1972 by acquiring an oil service operation, a move it has regretted for most of this decade.

This figure includes the estimated $2.8 million start-up cost associated with Foote, Cone's recently completed alliance with Publicis, a French-owned agency. Foote, Cone's 1987 net income was $17.1 million. The Chicago-based company's gross billings in 1988 were $386 million, a 12.3 percent increase over the previous year.

''After wearing the black and gold for so long, I just couldn't look at any other jersey and imagine myself wearing it,'' Mike Webster, 36 years old, the team's center, said.(AP)

title: Bridge

title: Got a Match?
description: LEAD: A month or so ago, I started smoking again, after seven years of smoke-free virtue. Everybody, of course, asked me why I did this terrible thing, so I evolved the following, exactly truthful answer: They were the worst seven years of my life, excluding my childhood, where I had no power over anything.

But as with structural brick, working with conventional facing brick is time-consuming and often requires the skills of an experienced mason.

title: Syntex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: During the second quarter the company revised its estimated annual effective tax rate from 12 percent to 10 percent. As a result, the tax rate provision for the fiscal 1989 second quarter was lowered to 7.7 percent in order to achieve an estimated annual effective rate of 10 percent for the year to date. This revision contributed about three cents to quarterly earnings per share.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Arianespace, Paris, the European space rocket operator, said it would launch a broadcast satellite in December for a Japanese television station.

title: Competition Opens for Peace Garden
description: Organizers of a public garden that would serve as a ''living monument to peace'' have opened a national competition for its design.

title: Wright Is Termed 'Target No. 1' By G.O.P. Aide Planning for '90
description: A top official of the Republican Party today outlined a fiercely partisan campaign for the 1990 Congressional elections, declaring House Speaker Jim Wright ''Target No. 1.'' His comments came on the day that the House ethics committee said it had received the results of an outside counsel's investigation into the Speaker.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Unionists Fly Eastern While Fighting Airline Chief
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s annual winter meeting here was dominated not by the usual oratory about the future of organized labor but by a man and his company who have been anathema to the movement: Frank Lorenzo and his troubled Eastern Air Lines.

title: Review/Theater; A Mix of 3 Latin Strands
description: ''Suenos,'' the new Ruth Maleczech-Herschel Garfein musical, draws inspiration from the murals by Eduardo Carrillo that decorate the stage at the Triplex Theater. The sweeping canvases have a somber, impressionistic quality until we look closely at the figures in the setting. In one painting, a pack of emaciated dogs stares hollow-eyed - the hounds of war about to destroy their victims.

title: Pulitzer Publishing Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Review/Theater; You-Know-What Conquers All Again
description: The freshness of Gerald Freedman's production of ''Love's Labor's Lost'' at the Public Theater extends from John Ezell's verdant setting to the cast, which is filled with talented newcomers. It is Don Adriano de Armado, the fantastical Spaniard, who suggests that green is ''the color of lovers,'' and by green he means the innocence that accompanies immaturity.

title: Corroon & Black Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a non-recurring aftertax gain of $73,851,000, or $4.31 a share, from the sale of investment in Minet Holdings. c-After a $4,672,000 loss from discontinued operations and a $4,443,000 extraordinary gain.

title: Consumer Index Increases 0.6%; Inflation Feared
description: In what many analysts considered strong evidence that inflation has accelerated, the Labor Department reported today that the Consumer Price Index jumped six-tenths of 1 percent in January, the biggest rise in two years.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''The underlying rate of inflation is accelerating. The whole background says all the early warnings of inflation are present.'' - Alfred G. Smith, chief economist for the NCNB Corporation. [ A1:2. ]

title: El Paso Electric Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $4,240,000 from an accounting change. The company said results for the prior quarter and year included a $17.6 million provision for realized and unrealized losses sustained in 1987 on the company's investments in marketable securities. The results for the prior year also included a $24.4 million after-tax non- cash regulatory writeoff of plant costs in connection with the settlement of a 1987 rate case. Results for the latest quarter and year included a provision for the expected losses on the sale of real estate of about $36 million.

title: Reviews/Music; An Homage, In 18 Minutes, By Bolcom
description: The novelty on Tuesday evening's Philharmonia Virtuosi program at Town Hall was an 18-minute homage to the French suite, by William Bolcom. It was called ''Orphee Serenade,'' and consisted of six short movements whose titles give, in acrostic, the French name of the mythical singer: Ouverture, Romance, Pas des Bacchantes, Hurluberlu, Elegie, Energique. It is scored for strings, small wind group and piano.

title: Court Says State Intervention In Child Abuse Isn't Mandated
description: The Supreme Court, ruling in a child abuse case it described as ''undeniably tragic,'' declared today that the Constitution does not obligate state and local governments to protect their citizens against harm from private individuals.

title: Metro Matters; Spanish Lesson: The Solutions Are Regional
description: rrJosep Serena, an affable official of Barcelona's metropolitan government, left New York City last month after months of studying urban problems shared by the United States and Spain.

title: Consolidated Fibres reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $175,000 for the quarter and $449,000 for the 6 months. The company said this year's second quarter and first half revenue included no direct paper activity as in the prior fiscal year periods, since this activity is now reported by U.S. Recycling Industries, a joint venture formed in April 1988 between the company and Friedman & Son Inc.

title: Dick Clark Productions reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Staten Island, Lehman Win
description: Staten Island eased past Baruch, 97-75, and Lehman edged City College, 61-56, last night in the semifinals of the City University of New York tournament at Nat Holman Gymnasium in Manhattan.

title: Salvadoran Leaders Spurn the Rebels' Peace Plan, Calling It a Ruse
description: In almost certain doom for a guerrilla peace initiative, senior members of the army and the governing Christian Democrats today rejected a rebel plan to stop fighting in return for reducing the size of the armed forces and postponing elections.

title: Even The Turkeys Were Purple
description: rrVerne Gagne wrestled Gorgeous George nearly 40 years ago. Gorgeous routinely wore his dyed-blond hair in marcelled waves and threw golden bobby pins to fans who both squealed and hissed as he made his entrance in his flowing, purple sequined robe. Gorgeous loved the color purple, and had purple shorts, a purple limousine, and a farm in his native Nebraska on which, said Gagne, he raised purple turkeys.

title: Schott Reacts to Rose
description: The Cincinnati Reds's owner, Marge Schott, is looking into reports that Pete Rose had been summoned to Commissioner Peter Ueberroth's office apparently because of Rose's gambling. Rose denied that the meeting covered gambling, saying only that the session was routine and private. Ueberroth declined to discuss the subject of the meeting. Rose's name surfaced recently in connection with the payoff of a $265,669.20 Pick Six bet at a track in a Cincinnati suburb. Rose denied he was involved, de-spite the prevailing belief at the track that he was. (AP)

title: Computer & Community Techology reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Group Seeks to Halt Study Of Drug in Form of Lollipop
description: A health research group asked the Food and Drug Administration today to stop experiments in which children facing painful medical procedures are given lollipops laced with a powerful narcotic.

title: U.S. CHARGING 33 OVER DRUG FUNDS
description: The authorities charged at least 33 people and a corporation today with laundering more than $500 million in Colombian cocaine profits through jewelry merchants in New York, Los Angeles, Texas and Florida.

title: Farce in Prague
description: These are hard times for writers. The Czechoslovak playwright Vaclav Havel has drawn a nine-month sentence for allegedly inciting an illegal protest and interfering with the work of the police. The charge is absurd, the trial disgraceful and the prospect of further jailing of other dissidents alarming. Consider the nature of the playwright's supposed crime:

title: Full of Fight, Yeltsin Feels He's the One
description: Boris N. Yeltsin leaned into the microphone at the elegant Hall of Columns and bellowed his determination to battle the almighty bureaucrats: ''I am physically fit and ready to fight.''

title: Court Refuses To Remove Drexel Judge
description: The Federal Court of Appeals in New York has declined to review the matter of whether the presiding judge should be disqualified from a civil lawsuit brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission against Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and four of its employees.

title: Redskins Sign Elam
description: The Washington Redskins yesterday signed Onzy Elam, a free-agent linebacker who had been left unprotected by the Jets. The 6-foot-2-inch, 230-pound Elam, who has been in the National Football League for two seasons, has played primarily on special teams. He played only two games last season before the Jets put him on their inactive list because of an intestinal virus. (AP)

title: Canadian Occidental Petroeum Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included is a special gain of $14.3 million. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: INSIDE
description: Salvadorans Reject Offer Army and ruling party officials said the rebels could not be trusted to lay down their arms in exchange for political concessions. Page A8. Speaking Fees Opposed A Presidential commission said lawmakers and other senior Government officials should be barred from accepting honorariums. Page B6. Tossing Wasteful Habits New York City, facing high disposal costs and quickly filling landfills, is beginning to come to grips with its need to recycle. Page B1.
