Testimony on North A former House chairman testifies that White House officials misled his committee about Oliver L. North's work with the contras. Page A20.

title: At Managua Embassy, Contra War Protested
description: To the Editor:

title: Harold Clifford Hoffman, Banker, 79
description: Harold Clifford Hoffman, a retired banker and former president of the New Jersey Historical Sites Council, died of cancer Friday at his home in Elizabeth, N.J. He was 79 years old.

title: Apple Sued By Beatles
description: The Beatles, who founded Apple Records at the height of their popularity in the 1960's, filed a multimillion-dollar suit today against Apple Computer Inc., charging copyright infringement.

title: Suffolk-Lilco Negotiations Broken Off Over Shoreham
description: Negotiations between Suffolk County and the Long Island Lighting Company to settle a $23 million racketeering suit against the utility collapsed yesterday amid disagreement over the future of the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: Grammys to McFerrin and Chapman
description: Bobby McFerrin's blithe ''Don't Worry, Be Happy'' took two of the top four awards, for song and record of the year, at the 31st annual Grammy Awards ceremony last night.

title: La-Z-Boy Chair Co reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: Both year-ago periods included $1.1 million, or 6 cents a share, of after-tax income from recognition of a pre-acquisition net operating loss carryforward.

title: Dollar Falls Despite Jump In Consumer Price Index
description: The dollar fell yesterday despite the largest monthly increase in the Consumer Price Index in two years.

title: Rax Restaurants Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 23
description: b-Net income Latest second-quarter and 6-month results included a charge of about $2.5 million, principally associated with the sale, closing, or refranchising of 11 restaurants. An additional $1 million was provided for further promotional and advertising costs and allowances against royalties. Prior-year 6-month results included a tax credit of $292,000.

title: Met Opera Announces New Season
description: The Metropolitan Opera announced yesterday that it would present five new productions during its 1989-90 season, and three more complete cycles of Wagner's ''Ring des Nibelungen'' at the end of the season.

title: Wheat Stockpile Low
description: The United States wheat stockpile is expected to be whittled this spring to one of the smallest since the end of World War II, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday. By June 1, the beginning of the 1989-90 wheat marketing year, the inventory may be about 534 million bushels, the smallest since the mid-1970's, the department's Economic Research Service said. On June 1, 1988, the carryover was 1.26 billion bushels.

title: Review/Ballet; 'Stranded' Soviet Troupe in New York
description: Necessity is the mother of circumvention. How a formerly unknown Soviet ballet troupe found itself stranded in Baltimore and on the verge of being sent home is a tale familiar to anyone following the plight of the Donetsk Ballet in the last two weeks.

title: Review/Television; Jonathan Miller's Mafia 'Rigoletto'
description: Jonathan Miller first produced and directed ''Rigoletto'' in 1975. Instead of placing the action in 16th-century Mantua, as tradition would have it, he moved it up to the 19th century, which he felt would be more compatible with Verdi's score. Then in 1982, Mr. Miller went further, transferring the opera to Little Italy in New York City in the 1950's, the world of the godfather and the Mafia. The result attracted international attention, not to mention a cascade of bravos and Bronx cheers.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Time Inc. Workers Call A Fortune Ad Sexist
description: An advertisement for Fortune magazine has touched off a furor among employees of its publisher, Time Inc., who said it was sexist and demeaning toward women. Employees took issue with the ad, which appeared in The New York Times and The Wall Street Journal on Friday and promoted the cover article in this week's issue of Fortune about tough corporate managers. The ad's tagline read: ''You don't build a company like this with lace on your underwear.''

title: Saudi Muslim Weighs Rushdie Trial
description: Saudi Arabia, often a bitter rival of Iran within the Islamic world, is moving in its own fashion against Salman Rushdie for the perceived affront to Islam in his novel ''The Satanic Verses.''

title: Bush to Fill Treasury Post
description: President Bush plans to nominate Robert Glauber to be an under secretary of the Treasury, the White House said today.

title: HEALTH: Physical Fitness; Young Women Are Getting Fatter, Study Finds
description: Young American women, but not men of similar age,have generally been getting fatter for several decades, recently published findings suggest. The researchers say this is the first data to indicate such a trend.

title: Funeral's Shinto Rite: Specter of the Past
description: Like the country that spawned it, the Shinto religion by whose rites Emperor Hirohito will be buried has taken many forms over the centuries.

title: Eastern Pilots Could Forge Alliance With Management
description: Officers of the pilots' union at Eastern Air Lines Inc. indicated yesterday that an offer by Frank Lorenzo, the chairman of the Texas Air Corporation, could win their support in management's struggle with the machinists' union.

title: Consolidated-Tomoka Land reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a net gain of $1,885,000 on the sale of real estate.

title: MEI Diversified Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $3,430,000 for both periods, and the year also included a $267,000 gain on the early extinguishment of debt. c-Net loss and included a $2,321,000 credit from the early extinguishment of debt for both periods. Year-ago fourth quarter and year results included pretax writedowns of $14,441,000 and $14,617,000, respectively, from marketable securities.

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: The National Westminster Bancorp said yesterday that it planned to acquire the Ultra Bancorporation, a bank holding company based in Bridgewater, N.J., for $282 million.

title: U.S. Had Surplus in January
description: The Federal Government had a surplus of $2.81 billion in January, leaving the budget deficit so far this fiscal year slightly below its pace of a year earlier, the Treasury Department said today.

title: ECI Telecom Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Cambodia Impasse: Patrons of the War Are Absent
description: After six days of inconclusive and suspended talks on a Cambodian settlement, the regional peace process seems at its end, with the likeliest source of a solution to be found three months from now in Beijing, where Chinese and Soviet leaders will hold their first summit meeting in 30 years.

title: Review/Music; Classical World Joins Politicians to Aid Armenians
description: The classical music world has mobilized on behalf of the survivors of the Armenian earthquake in December. Within days of the disaster, a starry cast of performers put on a ''Musicians for Armenia'' benefit concert in London, a recording of which has already been issued by RCA. Proceeds from the concert and the disk are earmarked for the British Red Cross Armenian Earthquake Appeal.

title: Nordson Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
Calendar: Flowers Bloomng In Jersey
description: Early Spring,

title: Federal Agency Threatens to Cut Off Grants to L.I.R.R.
description: The Long Island Rail Road is so lacking in management capabilities that it can no longer qualify for Federal grants for capital projects, Alfred DelliBovi, the Urban Mass Transit Administrator, said today.

title: After Early 3-0 Lead, Islanders Slip, 7-5
description: Scott Arniel scored twice, including the game-winner 50 seconds into the third period, and Kevin Maguire added two more goals as the Buffalo Sabres rallied from a three-goal deficit twice to beat the Islanders, 7-5, tonight.

title: Volt Offers To Buy Triad
description: Volt Information Sciences Inc. has offered to buy all the shares of the Triad Systems Corporation for $15.50 each, or for more than $120 million. In a letter dated Feb. 21 to

title: Late Challenges Fail; Duke Takes His Seat
description: David Duke, a former grand wizard of the Ku Klux Klan, overcame two last-minute challenges and was sworn in today as a member of the Louisiana Legislature.

title: Catherine M. Conroy, Feminist, 69
description: Catherine M. Conroy, who helped to organize the National Organization for Women, died of cancer Saturday. She was 69 years old.

title: Scana Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Belvedere reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Washington Talk: The Cabinet; Bush's Guideline on Ethics: Be Above Suspicion
description: Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher has announced he will not participate in official decisions involving oil, gas and the cosmetics industry because he and his wife have investments in those industries.

title: Brady Adds to Savings Numbers: $24 Billion for Closings in the 90's
description: Less than three weeks after the Bush Administration announced a $90 billion rescue plan for the savings industry, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said today that the Government would have to spend an additional $24 billion to shut savings and loan associations that become insolvent in the 1990's.

title: Eugene O'Neill House Saved; Owners Decide to Rebuild It
description: The owners of a 130-year-old former boarding house where Eugene O'Neill wrote some of his earliest plays have decided to renovate the building, saving it from being razed or moved.

title: Charity Doesn't Begin in the Welfare State
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Bitter Over Chocolate
description: President Bush's chief trade negotiator, Carla A. Hills, accepts all the help she can get in trying to pry open foreign markets for American products.

title: Esther Hargrave Greenleaf, Artist, 84
description: Esther Hargrave Greenleaf, a painter, printmaker and ceramist, died yesterday. She was 84 years old and lived in Kennett Square, Pa.

title: Federal Farm Credit Offering
description: The Federal Farm Credit Funding Corporation is offering three-month, six-month and one-year bonds totaling $2.849 billion through the corporation itself and through various securities dealers. All the bonds are priced at par.

title: Bush Restates U.S. Determination To Remain a Power in the Pacific
description: President Bush on Wednesday reasserted the determination of the United States to remain a Pacific power, calling the region one ''of great and growing importance in international affairs.''

title: Kean Seeks More Money for Schools
description: Gov. Thomas H. Kean announced today the first major change in his proposals for next year's budget, joining leaders of the Democratic-controlled Senate in a plan to ease the burden of rising property taxes and increase aid to public schools.

title: No Headline
description: Just a month after it moved dramatically to root out corruption in Mexico's most powerful union by arresting 21 labor leaders, the Government of Carlos Salinas de Gortari is turning its attention to the financial industry.

title: Dr. Morris C. Finkel, 82, Ex-School Official
description: Dr. Morris C. Finkel, a former assistant superintendent of the New York City public schools, died of pneumonia Monday at the Meridian nursing home in Silver Spring, Md. He was 82 years old and lived in Silver Spring.

title: Renaissance GRX Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Boeing Gets $3.15 Billion Order for Jets
description: LEAD: A leading Japanese airline yesterday announced a $3.15 billion deal for 20 of Boeing's newest jumbo jets, the 747-400. The deal is the biggest purchase yet of the long-range, wide-body airplanes that are equipped with engines made by the General Electric Company.

title: Moore Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Brazil Criticizes Coffee Plan
description: Brazil, the world's largest coffee producer, today criticized Western European proposals for a new agreement to support coffee prices.

title: Japan Loses 'Dump' Ruling
description: The International Trade Commission issued a preliminary ruling today that the American metal-forming industry was being injured by Japanese imports, paving the way for import duties.

title: 7 More Dissidents Convicted in Prague
description: In the second trial of opposition figures here in as many days, a Czechoslovak court tonight found seven people guilty of hooliganism and handed down penalties ranging from suspended sentences and fines to one year in prison.

title: Dudes, Nerds and Horrors
description: To The Home Section:

title: Gossip Checks In At Red Sox Camp
description: The Margo Adams bomb hit the Boston Red Sox camp today, but from the looks and sounds at Chain O'Lakes Park, the team escaped unscathed. At least for now.

title: Regan Criticizes Costly Services In Adult Shelters
description: New York City shelters for homeless adults provide inadequate and costly services, State Comptroller Edward V. Regan said in releasing audit reports yesterday.

title: B. Dalton to Resume Its Sales of 'Satanic Verses'
description: Five days after ordering the removal of ''The Satanic Verses'' from the shelves of its 1,250 stores, the B. Dalton Company said yesterday that it would resume sales of the book ''as soon as it is available from the publisher, in approximately 10 days.''

title: Passages in Defense of a Colleague: Writers Read and Speak for Rushdie
description: Faced with complaints from within their ranks that they have been slow to show support for the threatened writer Salman Rushdie, authors held readings from his work in New York and other cities yesterday and called on each other to stand firm against attacks on freedom of speech.

title: A Listing of Grammy Award Winners
description: Here is a partial list of winners at last night's 31st annual Grammy Awards. Record of the Year: ''Don't Worry, Be Happy,'' Bobby McFerrin. Album of the Year: ''Faith,'' George Michael. Song of the Year: ''Don't Worry, Be Happy,''

title: Cells in the Nose May Offer Clues to Alzheimer's
description: Researchers who studied nine Alzheimer's patients have identified changes in cells in the lining of the nose that they said might eventually lead to a diagnostic test for the disease.

title: Home Rink for the Smallest Ice Skaters
description: TWO years ago, Roger Kaufman, a stationery and housewares manufacturers' representative who lives in Weston, Conn., wanted to teach his son, John, then 2 1/2 years old, to ice-skate ''without going to a pond and worrying about whether or not the ice was frozen enough,'' he said.

title: Aldo J. Jacuzzi, 67, Pump Manufacturer
description: Aldo Joseph Jacuzzi, former chairman of the whirlpool pump manufacturer, died Tuesday at St. Vincent's Infirmary in Little Rock., He was 67 years old.

title: Lawmaker Says Reagan Officials Misled Panel on North and Rebels
description: A Congressman who had prime responsibility for monitoring American intelligence operations testified today that Reagan Administration officials repeatedly misled his committee about Oliver L. North's efforts in behalf of the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Books of The Times; Death Without the Sting in 'The End of Tragedy'
description: The End of Tragedy By Rachel Ingalls 191 pages. Simon & Schuster. $16.95.

title: Shaklee Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Latest year and prior-year results included a gain of $2.4 million and $1.6 million, respectively, from the sale of about 1 percent of Shaklee Japan K.K. stock.

title: Reviews/Music; Multi-hued Bill By Guitarist
description: Stephen Aron, one among the dozens of cultivated and musical young guitarists who pass through New York these days, gave a pleasing debut recital at Merkin Concert Hall Saturday evening. Except for the avant-garde, he touched all the guitarist's bases: Italianate bel canto by Broca and Regondi; Bach (''The Lute Suite,'' BWV 1006a); Spanish and Spanish-flavored music of Mangore and Burle-Marx; conservative 20th-century scores by David Bernstein and Nikita Koshkin.

title: Cairo Journal; Deputies in Melee? Striking a Blow for Democracy
description: When tackled on the issue of Egypt's emergent democracy, the authorities here liken themselves to physicians, prescribing freedoms by the shot. This week, Egyptians got an overdose, and on television, too.

title: Those Chinese Missiles
description: If you keep tugging on a loose thread, the Hong Kong tailors warn, your whole suit could fall apart.

title: Talking Deals; The Proprieties Of 'No Comment'
description: STOCK MARKET rumors have always been a big problem for the New York Stock Exchange. These days it is an even bigger problem because so many companies are refusing to comment about what may be going on when their stock is moving sharply.

title: Court Restudies Issue of Government-Sponsored Christmas Displays
description: The Supreme Court, hearing arguments in a case from Pittsburgh, returned today to the troublesome question of what type of Christmas holiday display the Constitution permits government to sponsor.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Oklahoman Takes Post At a Top Kansas Bank
description: LEAD: The Fourth Financial Corporation, the largest bank holding company in Kansas, has appointed K. Gordon Greer to be the president of its principal bank, Bank IV Wichita.

title: Alexander Brown Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FPA Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $370,000 for the quarter and $446,000 for the 6 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $688,000 for the quarter and $1,653,000 for the 6 months; the 6 months also included a gain of $5.7 million from an accounting change. d-Net income

title: KEY RATES
CONTRAS CHAFING AT U.S. INDECISION
description: Nicaraguan guerrilla leaders are becoming impatient with the uncertainty of United States policy toward Central America and say they tried unsuccessfully to arrange meetings with top officials of the Bush Administration to discuss their future.

title: Seahawks Hire Flores As General Manager
description: Tom Flores, former coach of the Los Angeles Raiders, yesterday succeeded Mike McCormack, who was dismissed last month, as the president and general manager of the Seattle Seahawks. Flores, who guided the Raiders to two Super Bowl victories during his nine years as coach that ended last year, apparently won a power struggle with Mike Blatt, a former sports agent who is a business associate of Ken Behring, the team owner. Blatt had been running the team since McCormack left last month.(AP)

title: Pinochet Is Keeping Chile Guessing
description: Augusto Pinochet, the tough military ruler who surprised the world by accepting his defeat in a plebiscite last October, has spent the months since then confusing both supporters and opponents about his future intentions.

title: J.B. Powers, 96, Publishers' Representative
description: Joshua B. Powers, a publishers' representative, died at his home in Manhattan Tuesday after a short illness. He was 96 years old.

title: Chicago Suburb Bans Pistols
description: Wilmette has become the fourth Chicago suburb to ban the private possession of pistols. Proponents of the ban said a shooting last year at an elementary school in neighboring Winnetka that left one child dead and five wounded helped bring about the ban. The suburbs of Oak Park, Morton Grove and Evanston have enacted similar bans.

title: Kerr Scores 3 Goals as Flyers Defeat Rangers
description: Tim Kerr has played in more than 500 career games, accumulating 554 points and countless more body checks. He had his right shoulder operated on once and his left shoulder surgically repaired another five times last season alone. He is not, perhaps, the force he once was, but he as close to an unmoveable object as there is in the National Hockey League.

title: Kinder-Care Learning Centers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an after-tax charge of $2,640,000 for permanent impairment of certain investment securities. c-Net income The share earnings not applicable; the company was a wholly owned subsidiary of Kinder-Care Inc. prior to its spinoff in August 1988.

title: Bruno Must Control Tension, Then Tyson
description: In the summer of 1983, Frank Bruno, a heavyweight from Britain, was scheduled to fight for the first time in the United States.

title: Energy Conversion Devices reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago second quarter included costs of $5,276,000 associated with litigation and a conset decree. The company said in connection with its increased sales in the latest periods, it cited sales of photovoltaic products, and of products and prototypes of the Ovonic Imaging Systems Inc. unit.

title: Money for New York's Good Intentions Can't Get Out of Albany
description: To the Editor:

title: Frontier Thrills
description: What brave hunters they breed near Yellowstone Park, hunters who get their kicks from slaughtering hapless buffalo with rifles at almost point-blank range.

title: HEALTH: Childhood Illness; In Ear Infections, Bacteria Gain on Penicillin
description: Bacteria that cause ear infections in children are becoming increasingly resistant to penicillin, new studies have found. Although the resistant bacteria respond to other antibiotics, the alternative drugs are much more expensive.

title: New York Area Costs Rise By 0.8%, Outpacing Nation
description: The Consumer Price Index for the metropolitan New York area rose a sharp eight-tenths of 1 percent in January, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Book on N.C. State Is Withdrawn
description: A book that promised to expose widespread corruption in the North Carolina State basketball program was withdrawn from publication yesterday after the publisher, who was threatened with libel action, concluded that the manuscript did not meet the company's publishing standards.

title: Health Care in New York Is Not for All, Report Finds
description: In spite of its vast network of public hospitals and prestigious private medical centers, New York City has failed to provide adequate care for large segments of the population, particularly for the growing numbers of poor and working poor, according to a study released yesterday.

title: Ampco-Pittsburgh Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $10,940,000 and $32,647,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net income d-After losses from discontinued operations of $3,881,000 for the quarter and $4,387,000 for the year, and a loss from the reversal of a tax credit of $1,750,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $1,800,000 for the year.

title: LAW SCHOOL BARS F.B.I.'S RECRUITERS
description: The University of Michigan Law School has decided to bar the Federal Bureau of Investigation's personnel recruiters from campus for the rest of the school year because of a judge's finding that the bureau discriminated against its Hispanic agents.

title: Service for Diana Tendler
description: A service for Dr. Diana Tendler, professor emeritus of social work at Hunter College, will be held today at 5 P.M. in the auditorium of the Hunter College School of Social Work at 129 East 79th Street. Dr. Tendler, who died Jan. 15 while traveling in Mexico, was 69 years old.

title: Lance as Missile, Lance as Chip
description: Secretary of State Baker has returned from his tour of NATO capitals having learned how hard it is to hold a nuclear umbrella over Europe when many Europeans fear the risks and some doubt the need.

title: Transco Exploration Partners Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Latest quarter and year results included a $20 million charge for liquidation costs.

title: Review/Dance; Encountering A Post-Modern Cassandra
description: ''I don't know what it was all about, but it was fun,'' a member of the audience said to a friend as he left the Space at St. Clement's on Tuesday night after a performance of Charles Moulton's ''Dangerous Glee Club.''

title: Vandeweghe Not Going to Knicks
description: The sagas of the Knicks' six-month chase of Kiki Vandeweghe and the trade of Adrian Dantley to the Dallas Mavericks took strange turns yesterday, hours before the National Basketball Association trading deadline.

title: Bush Plan To Expand I.R.A. Seen
description: The Bush Administration wants to expand tax breaks for Individual Retirement Accounts to help it meet one of its top priorities for the economy, more saving and investing, according to senior officials.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Keyes Martin Gaby
description: Keyes Martin Gaby Linett has broken the Jersey barrier - the barrier that has generally prevented New Jersey ad agencies from landing Atlantic City casino accounts. The shop, based in Springfield, N.J., has become the full-service agency of record for Caesars Atlantic City Hotel/Casino, formerly the province of Wunderman Worldwide. Dan Gaby, Keyes Martin's chairman, said the account would bill in excess of $6 million annually, with a ''substantial amount'' allocated to direct marketing but the majority in media advertising.

title: Dow Falls 42.50 in Biggest Drop in 3 Months
description: Stock prices plunged yesterday, for the biggest decline in three months, as the report of a sharp rise in consumer prices added to concern about inflation and interest rates.

title: Deltak Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Golden Oldies: Jukeboxes Are Big Again
description: PERRY ROSEN paid $200 for his first jukebox, a Seeburg Model C. It was a chrome and glass machine from the 1950's with a Select-O-Matic carriage gliding over a rack of records.

title: Nucor Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $38,558,822 from the sale of Research Chemicals.

title: Phoenix American reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Hospital Corp of America reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included a pre-tax charge of $126 million to write down the company's investment portfolio at certain properties, a pre-tax charge of $73 million to increase allowance for doubtful accounts and the deferral of a $300 million pre-tax gain on the sale of hospital. The results also reflected $141 million in income taxes resulting from the divestiture of 104 hospitals effective Aug. 31, 1987.

title: Bally Manufacturing Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss of $2,307,000 for the quarter and income of $63,497,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations.

title: Astro-Med Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Rose Says Kentucky Has Not Contacted Him
description: Lee Rose, once interviewed as a candidate to be the coach at Kentucky, has been mentioned for that job again. This time he would replace Eddie Sutton, who got the job instead of Rose.

title: Reviews/Film; From Coal Dust to Hollywood Glitter With Robert Lindsay
description: It would be hard not to like a coal miner who exits his mine singing ''The Continental'' a la Fred Astaire - especially when the miner is played by the delightful Robert Lindsay, the original star of Broadway's ''Me and My Girl.'' But it would be equally hard not to notice that ''Bert Rigby, You're a Fool,'' the film that Carl Reiner has fashioned around Mr. Lindsay's music-loving mineworker, is extremely odd. Its pace isn't quick. Its point isn't clear. Its satire is so gentle that it hardly has a target. Its only guiding sentiment is a loose, soft-hearted affection for a certain kind of show-business magic.

title: Public Service Co of New Hampshire reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and for the year included a $398,691,000 loss from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The company is operating under Chapter 11 of the U.S. bankruptcy code and has ceased recognizing preferred dividend requirements. The company said non-recognition of preferred requirements improved earnings by $38 million in 1988.

title: Washington Talk: The Budget; Political Stances Clear, The Negotiation Begins
description: President Bush is in Japan. Richard G. Darman, the budget director, is back in his office next door to the White House. The focus in Congress has turned elsewhere.

title: Greenspan-Wall Statement
description: Following is the text of the statement today by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and M. Danny Wall, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, on support for savings and loan institutions:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY The Federal Reserve said it stands ready to provide cash to any insolvent savings institution that runs short because of big withdrawals. The statement, issued by Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, and M. Danny Wall, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board was intended to calm depositors' fears. [ Page A1. ] Chase Manhattan Bank raised its prime lending rate by half a percentage point, to 11 1/2 percent, the second increase in less than two weeks. The Republic National Bank was the only major bank to follow Chase's move immediately. [ D1. ] Congressional experts estimate that President Bush's proposal to cut taxes on capital gains would increase the Federal budget deficit instead of reducing it. [ D1. ] Durable goods orders fell 3 percent in January, reflecting drops in transportation and military orders. Some analysts said the report could portend a slowdown in economic growth. [ D2. ] Sales of new domestic cars and light trucks rose 2 percent in mid-February, but analysts said the improvement was still not good enough to clear inventories and avert a discounting war. [ D4. ] COMPANIES Sears, Roebuck will cut prices by up to 50 percent on more than 50,000 items in an attempt to revive its sagging profits and rebuild market share. To put new prices on 1.5 billion pieces of merchandise, Sears will close all 800 of its stores on Tuesday. [ A1. ] West Point-Pepperell agreed to be bought by Farley for $58 a share, or $1.53 billion in cash, ending a bitter takeover fight. [ D1. ] Allegheny International signed a merger agreement with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, a suitor it had formerly rebuffed. [ D4. ] An investor group announced a $35-a-share offer for Emhart. If completed, the deal would total about $2.4 billion. The group includes Gordon P. Getty and the Fisher brothers of New York. [ D1. ] Chrysler said a plant in Detroit would be transformed to produce a new-model Jeep. The new vehicle will be aimed at more affluent drivers than its Jeep Cherokee model. [ D1. ] Burlington Resources amended its ''poison pill'' shareholder rights plan and filed suit against Pennzoil, which Burlington claims is threating a hostile takeover bid. [ D4. ] I.B.M. agreed to settle a $100 million lawsuit brought by a small company in Maryland, which contended that I.B.M.'s personal computers had violated a patent on word processing. [ D4. ] MARKETS The Fed, in an apparent signal that it has raised short-term rates, aggressively drained reserves from the banking system. At the time of its open market operation, the overnight Federal funds rate was at 9 9/16 percent. [ D14. ] The dollar declined against most major currencies. But it received an unexpected lift when the Chase Manhattan Bank raised its prime lending rate to 11 1/2 percent. [ D15. ] Stocks rose narrowly and the Dow Jones industrial average added 5.53 points, to end at 2,289.46. [ D8. ] Gold futures prices ended higher amid renewed fears of inflation. [ D15. ] The General Accounting Office told Congress that it had questions about the ''intensity'' of the discipline and oversight of the futures markets and of its Federal regulator. [ D2. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The moment of truth on the Administration's budgetary policy is fast approaching, spurred by the sharp increase in the Consumer Price Index. Leonard Silk: Economic Scene. [ D2. ] It appears that Polaroid has won its hostile battle with Shamrock by using a strategy that may become a classic in the history of corporate defense. Market Place. [ D1. ] Shandwick has agreed to acquire the North American operations of Golin/Harris Communications, which would reduce competition in public relations. Advertising. [ D17. ]

title: E-L Financial reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included gains on investment of $7,299,000 and $5,157,000 for the latest year and year-earlier period, respectively; profit on sale of securities of $6,063,000 for the latest year and $6,813,000 for the year-earlier period, and tax credits of $12,400,000 and $6,538,000 for the latest year and year- earlier period, respectively. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Article 985189 -- No Title
description: An investment group including Gordon P. Getty, the oil heir, and the Fisher brothers of New York yesterday announced a $35-a-share offer for all the shares of the Emhart Corporation of Farmington, Conn. If completed, the deal would total $2.4 billion.

title: E'Town Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
French and Germans to Publish Book
description: Publishers in France and West Germany reversed themselves today and announced that they had decided to go ahead with the publication of Salman Rushdie's ''Satanic Verses'' despite threats from Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini of Iran.

title: Binks Manufacturing Co reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included a gain of $375,000 from an accounting change.

title: Pivotal Southerner Votes Thumbs Down on Tower
description: His words were parsed and scrutinized for weeks, every statement studied, every question analyzed. Finally, tonight, in a crowded hearing room, Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia, the influential chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, delivered a devastating judgment against John G. Tower's nomination as Secretary of Defense.

title: Writers Without Names
description: God willing, Salman Rushdie will escape the assassins. But it is already too late for so terribly many others who also lived by the mind and were murdered for it. We do not even know most of their names, simply that they existed and are gone.

title: Georgetown's President Named Head of Public Library
description: The Rev. Timothy S. Healy, the president of Georgetown University in Washington, was named yesterday to be the next president and chief executive officer of the New York Public Library.

title: How the Committee Voted
description: The following is the 11-to-9 vote on the Tower nomination by the Senate Armed Services Committee. Eleven Democrats voted no; all Republicans voted yes.

title: Corrections
description: A report on Tuesday about the marriage of Hillary Fabian to John Senise misstated the bride's occupation. She is an art director at D'Arcy, Masius, Benton & Bowles.

title: Leggett & Platt Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Mariupol Journal; In Hometown, Stalin's Henchman Has Great Fall
description: For years this city was held up as a model. It was heavily industrial, with two of the country's biggest steel plants. In addition, it bore the name of Andrei A. Zhdanov, one of the architects of the Stalinist system.

title: Benefit Readings
description: Kurt Vonnegut, Russell Banks, Manlio Argueta, Auturo Arias, Jayne Cortez and others are to participate in an evening of readings and music in Cooper Union's Great Hall, 7 East Seventh Street, tonight at 8. Sponsored by the publisher Four Walls Eight Windows, the event celebrates the publication of the anthology ''And We Sold the Rain: Contemporary Fiction From Central America,'' edited by Rosario Santos. Proceeds will benefit Madre, a women and children's health organization that works in Latin America and the Caribbean, and the Julio Cortazar Fund, which builds hospitals and sends medical supplies to that region. Suggested contribution: $7. Information: 353-4195.

title: Canadian Utilities Ltd reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Reality in Fantasy: Rushdie's Method
description: Writers have tried many techniques to portray a century in which reality has so often outdone the imagination. Salman Rushdie, the author of ''The Satanic verses,'' uses magic realism, with its heightened language and elements of the surreal.

title: At The Movies
description: Denzel Washington

title: Brooklyn Bands
description: Four bands from Brooklyn are to perform tonight at Downtown Beirut II, Houston and Allen Streets (614-9040). Medicine Sunday is to perform at 9:30, Formaldehyde Blues Train at 10:30, Chemical Wedding at 11:30 P.M. and Frank's Museum at 12:30 A.M. Admission is $6,

title: Rosa Slade Gragg, 86, Civil Rights Advocate
description: Rosa Slade Gragg, a civil rights advocate appointed in the 1940's to a national advisory post by President Franklin D. Roosevelt, died Monday at Harper Hospital. She was 86 years old.

title: Article 001389 -- No Title
description: Two men in ski masks slipped into a gold merchant's office in midtown Manhattan yesterday, handcuffed three women and stole $2 million in gold, most of it jewelry, from a safe, the police said.

title: Producer Is Indicted in Fraud
description: A grand jury in Manhattan has indicted Adela Holzer on charges of stealing more than $1.2 million by selling nonexistent shares in real estate, oil wells and mineral mines to investors, the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, said yesterday. Ms. Holzer, 54 years old, a Broadway producer, spent two years in prison on similar charges 10 years ago.

title: General Development Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $9.9 million. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $10,410,000, a charge of $3,341,000 from the early retirement of bank debt, and a gain of $18,315,000 from an accounting change. d-Net income and after a loss from discontinued operations of $515,000. e-After a loss from discontinued operations of $580,000.

title: Chase Lifts Prime Rate By 1/2 Point
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank raised its prime lending rate by half a percentage point yesterday afternoon, to 11 1/2 percent, the second increase in less than two weeks.

title: Economic Scene; Moment of Truth On the Budget
description: WITH the six-tenths of 1 percent increase in the Consumer Price Index for January, 7.2 percent at an annual rate, the moment of truth on budgetary policy is fast approaching for the Administration. And the markets clearly sense that the test is coming.

title: Ambassador to Britain To Join Times Co. Board
description: Charles H. Price 2d, the United States Ambassador to Britain, will become a member of the board of The New York Times Company next month, Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, chairman and chief executive, announced yesterday.

title: BUSH CHOICE BACKED FOR HEALTH CHIEF AFTER AN APOLOGY
description: The Senate Finance Committee today voted 19-to-0 to approve Dr. Louis W. Sullivan's nomination as Secretary of Health and Human Services after the nominee apologized to a Senator for having ''misspoken'' on the abortion issue.

title: On Stage
description: Reno's Fast-Paced Angst

title: EMC Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Portland General Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $35,044,000 from an accounting change.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums ''AFRICAN DRUM,'' an adventure about a girl and her animal friends, presented by the Shadow Box Theater, 2 P.M. Sunday, at the Louis Abrons Arts for Living Center, Henry Street Settlement, 466 Grand Street. Tickets: children, $1; adults, $2.50. Information: 598-0400. THOMAS McKEAN STORY HOUR, a free one-hour program with Mr. McKean, who is to present pantomimes and songs for ages 3 to 7, noon Saturday, at Books of Wonder, 132 Seventh Avenue, at 18th Street. Information: 989-3270. ''A FOLK TALE QUARTET,'' a play by Open-Eye: New Stagings for Youth, for ages 5 to 10, 2 P.M. Sunday, at Open-Eye: New Stagings, 270 West 89th Street. Tickets: $6 and $8. Reservations: 769-4143. ''THE VELVETEEN RABBIT,'' a musical based on the story by Margery Williams, presented by Theaterworks/USA, 12:30 P.M. Saturdays, at the Promenade Theater, Broadway and 76th Street. Tickets: $10 and $14. Reservations: 677-5959. ''NUMBER 21,'' a play about the career of Roberto Clemente, the rightfielder for the Pittsburgh Pirates, 10:30 A.M. today and 2 P.M. Sunday, by the Don Quijote Experimental Children's Theater, at the Lincoln Square Theater, 250 West 65th Street. Tickets: daily, $2; Sunday, $5. Information: 496-8009. ''THE SNOW QUEEN,'' a play with music, adapted from the Hans Christian Andersen tale by Randolph Pearson, who is also the director, with music by Judy Spencer, 1 and 3:30 P.M. Saturdays, at Hartley House Theater, 413 West 46th Street. Tickets: $5. Reservations: 666-1716.

title: Fed Signals Another Rate Rise
description: The Federal Reserve yesterday sent a strong signal that it has moved to push short-term interest rates still higher.

title: Court Allows S.R.O.'s to Keep Units Vacant
description: In a minor victory for owners of single-room-occupancy hotels in New York City, the state's highest court yesterday ruled that the owners do not have to rent vacant rooms before the court rules on the validity of a city law protecting S.R.O.'s.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a ruling in a copyright dispute between the author Jonathan Kwitny and Kennett Love, a former journalist, described the issue incompletely. In his book ''Endless Enemies,'' Mr. Kwitny repeatedly cited Mr. Love as the author of an unpublished paper on the overthrow of the Iranian Government in 1953. The argument was not over credit but over permission for Mr. Kwitny to quote extensively from the paper, which Mr. Love copyrighted only after the publication of ''Endless Enemies.''

title: Inspiration Resources Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a net gain of $3.5 million on the sale of certain leased assets for the quarter and year; the year also included a $26.7 million gain on the sale of the U.S. copper operations. c-Included credits of $4.3 million for the quarter and $13.8 million for the year from the capitalization of previously expensed exploration costs; the year also included a $10.4 million gain on the sale of an interest in a Canadian mining property. Due to the adoption of a new accounting standard, latest quarter and year income tax provisions reflected a $6 million and $27.3 million benefit, respectively, from the use of tax loss carryforwards. The 1987 utilization of tax credits was classified as an extraordinary credit.

title: JWP Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Trinova Unit Sale
description: The Trinova Corporation, based in Maumee, Ohio, agreed to sell its laminated products unit to Pioneer Plastics Holdings Inc., a company formed by the Raebarn Corporation, a merchant banking concern in Los Angeles. Terms were not disclosed. The unit, which serves the furniture, building and construction markets, had sales of $137.3 million in 1988.

title: Bank Accord In France
description: A four-month battle for control of France's fourth-largest bank, Societe Generale, ended today with a compromise between a Government-backed financier and the bank's management.

title: Jersey System Of School Aid Is Ruled Fair
description: The State Education Commissioner today rebuffed a challenge to New Jersey's system of financing public schools, the latest move in a 16-year battle over whether the state discriminates against its poorest school districts.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief report on the obituary page yesterday about a memorial service for Richard Roud, former director of the New York Film Festival, misstated the location. The service is to be at 5 P.M. Tuesday in the 12th-floor loft of the actor Michael Wager at 126 Fifth Avenue, near 18th Street.

title: Combustion Engineering reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a pretax charge of $125.3 million for the recognition of increases resulting from the reestimation of costs to complete waste-to- energy plants and fluid bed power plants and restructuring charges for the power generation segment and a pre-tax charge of $11 million for the quarter, and the year included pretax charges of about $273 million for costs in excess of estimates for development and commercialization of circulating fluid bed systems to burn low- grade fuels cleanly and waste-to- energy systems. The company said the loss for 1988 also included pretax gains of $36.8 million from the completion of the previously announced disposition of Jamesbury Corp., of $5.4 million from the sale of a foreign equity basis investment, and a pretax charge of $14 million for anticipated losses on the potential sale of certain other businesses. c-Net income and the year included pretax gains of $12.7 million from the sale of certain investments in the second quarter and of $7.7 million from the sale of the company's interest in Northern Engineering Industries Plc in the first quarter. Also included are pretax charges of $32 million.

title: Due Process Is Respected in Grenada Trial
description: To the Editor:

title: New Units At Shearson
description: In a reorganization of its growing international business, Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. yesterday named three top executives to head its new divisions for Europe, Southeast Asia and Japan.

title: Review/Concert; In Place Of Arrau, Leonskaja
description: Being asked on short notice to take the place of Claudio Arrau as piano soloist with the New York Philharmonic must have put an extra gram or two of pressure on Elisabeth Leonskaja, who made her debut with the orchestra on Thursday evening. The prospect of hearing the mature thoughts of Mr. Arrau on Beethoven's Concerto No. 4 must have enticed many of the 86-year-old artist's admirers to this concert. Instead, they heard the concerto addressed, under the baton of Kurt Masur, by a young Soviet-born musician whose reputation until now has been largely confined to Europe.

title: Stockton Journal; Rift Over Newspaper Jolts Town and Family
description: This community of 1,800 people in oil and cattle country of western Kansas has seen both good and bad times over the last few years, but nothing so jolting emotionally, many here say, as the birth of a second newspaper in a one-paper town.

title: Injured Rangers Skate
description: The condition of Jan Erixon and Carey Wilson, the forwards for the Rangers who have missed the last three games with injuries, has been upgraded to possible for tomorrow night's game in Quebec. Both Wilson, who has a sore right wrist, and Erixon, who has been sidelined with back trouble, skated yesterday at an optional practice.

title: Not-So-Ugly Ducks
description: The muscovy duck is no beauty, not with a large crest, red wattles and a wheeze in place of a quack. It's obese, too, and its feathers have no sheen. Furthermore, the name that hints of a romantic Russian origin is a snare and a delusion. The muscovy is so called because of the musk glands in its rump. If it is one of those ''things counter, original, spare, strange'' that Gerard Manley Hopkins poeticized about, it is also a pest, at least to some Southerners, especially in Florida.

title: Review/Music; Schubertiade Continues
description: When it comes to classical music, the 92d Street Y's 10-year Schubertiade project is about the classiest act in town. Wednesday evening's installment - the first of the eight concerts of ''Year Two'' devoted to orchestral and orchestrally accompanied choral music - was just about perfect.

title: Reviews/Film; Optimism In England Of Today
description: A traveler from the country who is lost in London wanders into the flat shared by Cyril (Philip Davis) and Shirley (Ruth Sheen), and he has such a hard time going home that they wind up nicknaming him ''E. T.'' It's easy to see why the stranger, only a minor character drifting through Mike Leigh's ''High Hopes,'' is so drawn to these two. Cyril and Shirley, who travel about in matching motorcycle leathers, are an utterly spontaneous and unpretentious duo, which sets them in marked contrast to everyone else in Mr. Leigh's astute socioeconomic satire. The title refers to Cyril and Shirley's optimism, a sentiment that often seems badly misplaced in view of Mr. Leigh's larger portrait of the England of Margaret Thatcher, for whom Shirley has named her prickliest cactus.

title: Pan Am Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Latest quarter and year results included income from discontinued operations of $3,700,000 and $24,100,000, respectively. Year-ago quarter and year results included income from discontinued operations of $4,100,000 and $22,200,000, respectively.

title: Results Plus
description: TENNIS McEnroe in Quarterfinals: John McEnroe, seeded second, breezed into the quarterfinals of the $291,000 Lyon Grand Prix tournament in France yesterday with a 6-3, 6-2 victory over Christian Bergstrom of Sweden. Top-seeded Jakob Hlasek of Switzerland rallied to defeat Erik Winogradsky of France, 3-6, 6-4, 6-3. McEnroe used his big serve to dominate the Swede, firing 11 aces and numerous service winners. McEnroe next faces a West German, Carl Uwe Steeb.(AP) SKIING Fin Wins Fourth Medal: Marjo atikainen became the first four-time medalist as Finland kept its home-track winning streak alive at the world Nordic championships yesterday with a victory in the women's 20-kilometer relay in Lahti, Finland. Matikainen, a 24-year-old student from Helsinki who won a gold in the 15-kilometer classic-style race, a silver in the 10-kilometer freestyle and a bronze medal in the 10-kilometer classic-style race, anchored the Finnish team to a 7.1.-second victory over the Soviet Union. The Finnish quartet of Pirkko Maatta, Marja-Liisa Kirvesniemi, Jaana Savolainen and Matikainen covered the four five-kilometer laps in 54 minutes 49.8 seconds. Norway finished third. The United States placed 11th out of 14 finishers. (AP) >N.B.A. Hawks 100, Pacers 97: Dominique Wilkins scored 26 points, all in the second half, as the Hawks handed Indiana its club record-tying 12th consecutive loss last night in Atlanta. The Hawks, who trailed much of the first half, went ahead to stay four minutes into the third quarter, but almost blew a 12-point lead in the final two minutes. The Pacers cut the lead to 100-97 with six seconds left. After Atlanta's Cliff Levingston missed two free throws, Chuck Person's 30-footer bounced off the rim.(AP) N.H.L. Penguins 6, Red Wings 6: Steve Yzerman scored his second goal of the game with five minutes left in regulation the Red Wings rallied from a 6-0 deficit in Detroit. Lee Norwood's power-play goal early in the final period trimmed Pittsburgh's lead to 6-5 and set the stage for Yzerman's game-tying score. Yzerman carried the puck into the Penguins' zone and was checked by the Pittsburgh defenseman Paul Coffey. But as Coffey completed his check, the puck slid along the ice and past the goalie Tom Barrasso, who was bothered by Detroit's Paul MacLean standing in front of the crease. Glen Hanlon replaced the starting goalie Greg Stefan after Pittsburgh scored its sixth goal at 6:06 of the second period. Detroit broke loose for four goals in the final 12 minutes of the middle period.(AP) Whalers 4, Nordiques 2: Dave Tippett and Tom Martin scored 33 seconds apart late in the first period to lead Hartford to the home victory. Dave Babych added a power-play goal and Ray Ferraro scored his 30th of the season into an empty net in the final minute, extending his goal-scoring streak to seven games. Mike Hough and Michel Goulet scored for the Nordiques.(AP) HIGH SCHOOL BASKETBALL Christ the King Wins Easily: Christ the King, ranked third in the nation, routed St. Peter's of Staten Island, 91-61, in the opening round of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association tournament at Fordham University last night. Khalid Reeves, a 6-3 junior, scored 34 points to lead the Royals (23-1). Joe Castgronovo leading scorer in the Archdiocese of New York with a 28.3 average scored a team high 27 points for St. Peter's, which fell to 19-6. In an earlier game, Ron Arnold scored 33 points and grabbed 11 rebounds, both game high's to lead Rice to a 75-70 victory over Bishop Loughlin (14-10), which finished second to Christ the King in the Brooklyn-Queens diocese.

title: China Denounces Petition Drive For Political Prisoners' Amnesty
description: In a sign of Government concern at growing calls for human rights, China's official media today attacked a dissident petition drive for an amnesty of China's political prisoners.

title: Kiki Yes, Mark No: Good Deals?
description: rrNow that Kiki Vandeweghe is finally, definitely, absolutely, coming to the Knicks, and Mark Langston is positively, Scout's honor, cross-Joe McIlvaine's-heart, not coming to the Mets, whatever shall we do for diversion on these cold February days and nights?

title: Testing Urged for Airliner Safety Device
description: The technical research agency of Congress took an important step yesterday on a prime aviation safety issue, proposing legislation to require sweeping new in-service tests of anticollision devices before equipping the nation's entire airline fleet with them.

title: Joan Woodbury, Actress, 73
description: Joan Woodbury, an actress who starred in dozens of low-budget films, died of respiratory failure on Wednesday. She was 73 years old.

title: Our Towns; Public Planners: You See Them And Then, Poof!
description: This is a lovely time in history to work for government. Members of Congress and Federal judges are paid about the same as 25-year-old corporate lawyers, and when a commission recommends a pay increase, the public revolts. Ronald Reagan started the 1980's chopping away at government, and succeeded in less than a decade at getting even liberal governors to join in.

title: Moral Turpitude Case vs. Lawyers' Public Image
description: When a California lawyer became angry at a former client who he believed was harrassing and threatening him in the early 1980's, he paid a hit man to have the former client murdered.

title: I.B.M. to Settle Patent Suit
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said today that it had agreed to settle a $100 million lawsuit contending that its personal computers had violated a basic patent on word processing held by a small Rockville, Md., company. The settlement calls for

title: SOWETO GIRL DIES IN A FIREBOMBING
description: A 13-year-old girl was killed and two people were injured Wednesday night by a firebomb hurled into the house of a woman involved in the investigation of the murder of one of Winnie Mandela's bodyguards.

title: Review/Art; An Approach to AIDS
description: Although there have been painters and photographers - Nicholas Nixon, Rosalind Solomon and the group General Idea among those who have exhibited in Manhattan - taking on AIDS as a subject, few artists have concerned themselves with the disease. Apart from the commercial considerations that no doubt have dissuaded many, some may be unsure how to approach the subject. For instance, how not to present AIDS patients as victims and curios? How not to make the viewer a voyeur?

title: About Real Estate; Battery Park City Grows Despite '87 Wall St. Crash
description: The layoffs in the brokerage industry after the October 1987 stock market crash were expected to dampen rentals and sales of new apartments then going on the market in Battery Park City, the Manhattan community built on landfill within walking distance of the financial district.

title: Crown Central Petroleum Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After net from discontinued of $367,000 and $1,050,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and a net gain of $62,740,000 on sale of discontinued operations for both the quarter and year.

title: 8 in Vehicle Agency Held In Sale of Fake Licenses
description: Eight employees of the New York State Department of Motor Vehicles office in Queens were arrested yesterday on charges of selling fraudulent driver's licenses and auto registration certificates to customers who included drug dealers, car thieves, fugitives and scofflaws.

title: Huge Advance Order for 'Satanic Verses'
description: Demand for ''The Satanic Verses'' is so strong among independent booksellers that they say they have taken orders for almost 200,000 copies - copies they say they could sell as soon as the books arrive, a New York Times survey has found.

title: New York's Tax Is Under Attack In Connecticut
description: Five Republican state legislators from Fairfield County, angered by what amounts to an increase in the New York income-tax rate for out-of-state commuters, called on Gov. William A. O'Neill today to challenge the legality of the change.

title: Mall to Evoke Memories of Times Sq.
description: To re-create Times Square where Times Square once stood, the developers of a new mall on Broadway have had to call on a special-effects designer and set their stage behind a high glass wall.

title: Prof. Abel Wolman, 96, Is Dead; Led Efforts to Chlorinate Water
description: Prof. Abel Wolman, who led American and foreign efforts to chlorinate drinking water, died Wednesday at his home in Baltimore. Professor Wolman, a retired professor of sanitary engineering at Johns Hopkins University, was 96 years old.

title: Calcavecchia Takes 2-Shot Lead With 65
description: Three years and $1.8 million after he played in a qualifying round to earn a spot in the 1986 Doral Open, Mark Calcavecchia today continued his exciting, front-running play on the PGA Tour when he carved a windblown, 7-under-par 65 in the first round of the Doral Ryder Open. That gave the 28-year-old Floridian a two-shot lead over Ben Crenshaw, the defending champion, who needed only nine putts on his back nine for a 67.

title: Air Canada Sees Gain in Rival Deal
description: Air Canada's president, Pierre Jeanniot, said the merger of his two largest competitors would end a ''kamikaze'' price war and help him to create an international carrier. In his first interview since the PWA Corporation said last month that it would buy Wardair Inc., Mr. Jeanniot forecast that Canadian airlines would raise fares modestly, be more selective with points for frequent fliers and offer fewer discounts.

title: Soviet Writers, and Government, Avoid Public Outcry on Rushdie
description: The predicament of the novelist Salman Rushdie, condemned to death by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomenei for his ''Satanic Verses,'' has a certain historical resonance in the land of Stalin.

title: Critic's Notebook; Telling Truth Through Fantasy: Rushdie's Magic Realism
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's death sentence against the author Salman Rushdie, a half-dozen deaths and hundreds of injuries in Pakistan during riots over his novel, the subsequent disappearance of ''The Satanic Verses'' from bookstores around the world and a continuing international furor - had such events occurred in a novel (even one of Mr. Rushdie's own fantastical productions), they would have been dismissed by critics as the improbable inventions of a writer bent on satire or absurdist mischief.

title: Mid-Month Vehicle Sales Increase 2%
description: Sales of new domestic cars and light trucks rose by 2 percent in mid-February over the comparable period last year, but analysts said the improvement was still not good enough to clear inventories and avert a discounting war.

title: G.A.O. Questions 'Intensity' Of Futures Trade Oversight
description: The General Accounting Office told Congress today that it had questions about the ''intensity'' of the discipline and oversight of the futures markets and of its Federal regulator.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Cigna Corp., Philadelphia, plans to repurchase up to $500 million shares, or 12 percent, of its common stock.

title: John Zorn Takes Over The Town
description: After five months of relaxation in Tokyo, the composer and saxophonist John Zorn has returned to New York. When he's here, Mr. Zorn, the most prominent musician to come out of the downtown scene, is ubiquitous. A performance guerrilla, he hits small clubs and spaces all across the city, improvising with visiting Soviet musicians, playing with his fellow downtown improvisers, working with a repertory group dedicated to the compositions of the jazz pianist Sonny Clark, or with another dedicated to the tunes of Ornette Coleman. An immensely prolific musician, Mr. Zorn takes an important element of the downtown scene with him when he leaves.

title: Auctions
description: A Poet's Library

title: Crownx Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a losses from discontinued operations of $11,306,000 and $41,769,000 for the latest year and year-earlier period, respectively, and charges of $116,798,000 for the latest year and $101,180,000 for the year- earlier period. Year-ago results have been restated. The company said the 1988 charge of $116,798,000 is comprised of a $88.5 million writedown relating to the company's divestiture program and a $28.3 million charge from its share of Crown Life Insurance Co.'s withdrawal from the U.S. group insurance business. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Hands Across the Pacific; For Japan, Bush's Presence Is Gratifying As Symbol of Its High Place Among Nations
description: Japan is a society sensitive to symbol, a place where gestures count.

title: Clae Rosengarten, 89; Founder of Orchestras
description: Clae Rosengarten, a founder of one of the first professional symphony orchestras on Long Island and of the New York Youth Orchestra in Manhattan, died of colon cancer Wednesday at her home. She was 89 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
First American Named To Key Philips Group
description: LEAD: Philips N.V., the Dutch electronics company, has named Richard D. Capra, president and chief executive of the Philips Lighting Company, to its executive management committee. Mr. Capra is the first North American to be named to the group, which oversees Philips's lighting interests worldwide.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Education page on Wednesday about applications for college freshman classes misstated the percentage of early admissions for the incoming class at Reed, in Portland, Ore. One-third (not two-thirds) of the class of 300 freshmen has already been admitted.

title: AMC Entertainment Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The latest 9 months included the sale of the company's United Kingdom operations, which resulted in a realized gain of $24,615,000.

title: Dining Out Guide: Roast Chicken
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. Amsterdam's Bar and Rotisserie

title: Idaho Will Accept Some Waste
description: Gov. Cecil Andrus today partly lifted his four-month-old ban on shipments of nuclear waste bound for temporary storage at the Idaho National Engineering Laboratory, citing national security concerns.

title: Soviets Propose Mideast Inspections
description: Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze said today that Moscow's plans for peace in the Middle East called for on-site inspection of Arab and Israeli military installations and a ban on all chemical and nuclear weapons in the region.

title: Junior, Dolphins Agree
description: The Miami Dolphins, desperate to improve their defense, have reached an agreement with E. J. Junior, the free-agent former All-Pro linebacker.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * J. W. Charles Securities Inc., Boca Raton, Fla., an investment firm, said Kenneth W. Germain had been appointed president.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''There is no smoking gun in the FBI reports, but there is enough smoke to cause one to be uneasy with this nominee for this position.'' - Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia. [ D19:6. ]

title: Two Happy Stars Who Add Luster To Donetsk Ballet
description: Vadim Pisarev and Inna Dorofeyeva had just arrived in New York City with the rest of the Donetsk Ballet, but they had already settled into the hectic pace of the city. A morning sitcom burbled on the television set. Mr. Pisarev sported an apple pin on his natty overcoat, and a scroll proclaiming ''I Love You New York'' hung on a wall of their hotel room. The telephone rang repeatedly, and as visitors trooped in they were politely offered tea, little gifts and a bit of the dancers' breakfast.

title: Accounts
description: * Freddie Mac, to J. Walter Thompson, for a national image campaign.

title: Weicker to Join Group Backing Aid to Research
description: Former Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., who was defeated last November in his bid for a fourth term, is joining a nonprofit educational organization that will promote medical and scientific research.

title: Review/Theater; Tony Lo Bianco as Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia
description: Impersonation is not simply the art of mimicking mannerisms but of reaching to the heart of the manner, creating, even for an instant, an incarnation rather than an imitation. Such is not the case with Tony Lo Bianco's Fiorello La Guardia in ''Hizzoner!,'' the one-man show that opened last night at the Longacre Theater.

title: Koch Hopes Jackson Will Stay Away
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch, facing what he calls the toughest electoral challenge of his career, said yesterday that he hoped non-New Yorkers like the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Mayor Andrew Young of Atlanta would not come to New York City to campaign for his mayoral rival, David N. Dinkins.

title: Hudson Bay Mining & Smeltng Co Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $3.4 million. c-Included gains of $15.7 million from the sale of mining properties, $14.3 million from the capitalization of exploration expenses and $10.5 million from an income-tax recovery. The results are in Canadian dollars. The company is a wholly owned subsidiary of Inspiration Resources Corp.

title: Fisher Scientific Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
20th Century Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included realized investment losses of $1,845,859 for the quarter and investment gains of $3,418,903 for the year. c-Included realized investment gains of $971,962 and $1,554,664 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Relocating the Indian Museum Will Be a Breach of All Trusts
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Raymond Boller, Hospital Official, 72
description: Dr. Raymond J. Boller, who spent his medical career at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center in Manhattan, died Wednesday at the hospital after a short illness. He was 72 years old and lived in Flushing, Queens.

title: New Officer at Cytogen
description: The Cytogen Corporation, a biotechnology company based in Princeton, N.J., this week named George W. Ebright as its president and chief executive. Mr. Ebright recently resigned as president and chief operating officer of the SmithKline Beckman Corporation. In the Cytogen posts, he succeeds Robert F. Johnston, who remains the company's chairman.

title: Plain Talk on Planes for Japan
description: During his visit to Tokyo Mr. Bush has the chance to address an irritation in American-Japanese relations - Japan's decision to develop a fighter plane largely of its own design instead of buying an American plane off the shelf.

title: Sanderson Farms Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included a $1,250,000 gain from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for income taxes.

title: Federal Reserve Says It Is Ready With Cash for Savings and Loans
description: Trying to calm depositor fears, the Federal Reserve Board said today that it stands ready to provide cash to any insolvent savings institution that runs short of cash because of large withdrawals.

title: INSIDE
description: Moscow's Mideast Plan

title: F.C.C. Reaffirms Decision On TV Syndication Rights
description: The Federal Communications Commission has reaffirmed its decision to let television stations buy exclusive rights to syndicated programs, despite the cable industry's warnings of programming blackouts and viewer confusion.

title: Savings Unit Stake For Castle & Cooke
description: Castle & Cooke Inc. has acquired an 8.2 percent stake in Firstfed America Inc., a Honolulu-based savings and loan association. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Castle & Cooke said it regards Firstfed as ''an attractive investment at the prices prevailing to date on the open market.''

title: Belgium's Diamonds
description: Belgium consolidated its status as the leading trading center of polished and rough diamonds last year, taking more than half the world's business, the industry said today. Belgian sales rose 27 percent, to $12.5 billion, in 1988, the Diamond High Council said in its annual report. Mark Van den Abeelen, the council's director general, said diamond imports had risen 30 percent, to $6.29 billion, and exports, 25 percent, to $6.23 billion.

title: Review/Cabaret; 2 Shows, a Decade in Each
description: A year ago, when Cynthia Crane put together an evening of familiar and unfamiliar songs of the 1920's with commentary that put them in the context of the decade, the response was so favorable that she has now moved on to the 1930's and the 1940's. Each decade is a cabaret act in itself, but she has been making a complete evening of both decades on Wednesdays this month at Dannys' Skylight Room in the Grand Sea Palace, 346 West 46th Street, doing one decade at the early show, the other at the late show.

title: Panel Demands Release of Bomb Plant Health Data
description: A Congressional subcommittee said today that it would intervene to compel the Department of Energy to release thousands of pages of secret documents that describe the risk from radiation emitted by the nation's nuclear weapons plants and laboratories.

title: Caesars New Jersey Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Article 899389 -- No Title
description: Columbus, Ohio, yesterday priced $56.1 million of general obligation bonds through competitive bidding. Underwriters led by Chase Manhattan Capital Markets successfully bid on the financing that includes three separate structures.

title: Pepperell Agrees to Farley Offer
description: After a bitter takeover battle, West Point-Pepperell, the large Georgia-based textile producer, agreed yesterday to be bought for $58 a share, or $1.53 billion in cash, by Farley Inc., the Chicago manufacturer known for its BVD and Fruit of the Loom underwear.

title: SKIPPER CONVICTED OVER BOAT PEOPLE
description: A United States Navy court-martial today found Capt. Alexander G. Balian guilty of dereliction of duty for failing to provide adequate assistance to a group of Vietnamese boat people adrift in the South China Sea last June.

title: Gluck Opera Rarity In American Premiere
description: ''Telemacco,'' an opera by Christoph Willibald Gluck, will be given its American premiere this weekend by the Pro Arte Chorale. The work, written to celebrate the second marriage, in 1765, of Joseph II of Austria, is based on the adventures of Ulysses and his son Telemachus and their escape from Circe, the enchantress.

title: Dollar Continues to Decline But Gets Lift on Prime Rate
description: The dollar declined again yesterday against most major currencies. But it received an unexpected lift when the Chase Manhattan Bank announced late in the day that it would raise its prime lending rate to 11 1/2 percent from 11 percent.

title: Market Place; The Polaroid Defense: A Potential Classic
description: Eight months and millions of dollars since Shamrock Holdings Inc. started a hostile bid for the Polaroid Corporation, it appears that Polaroid has won with a strategy that may become a classic in the history of corporate defense. Only court rulings against Polaroid could revive the Shamrock challenge.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Melvin Taylor

title: Potomac Electric Power reports earnings for 12mo Jan 31
Washington Talk: Briefing; Bennett's Habit
description: William J. Bennett, President Bush's designee as Director of the Office of National Drug Policy, recently went to a Virginia health clinic to try to rid himself of his addiction to cigarettes. He set Tuesday as his quitting date. That is the eve of his confirmation hearing before the Senate Judiciary Committee.

title: Baldwin & Lyons reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included realized investment gains of $805,119 and $1,714,103 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-After realized investment losses of $2,284,208 for the quarter and realized investment gains of $307,205 for the year. Results for all periods included federal tax credits resulting from the ''fresh start'' provisions of the 1986 Tax Reform Act.

title: Windmere Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Congress Study Sees Deficit Rising if Gains Tax Is Cut
description: Congressional experts estimated tonight that President Bush's proposal to cut taxes on capital gains would sharply increase the Federal budget deficit instead of reducing it as the Administration asserts.

title: Their Votes on Tower: Six Senators Explain
description: ''I cannot in good conscience vote to put an individual at the top of the chain of command when his history of excessive drinking is such that he would not be selected to command a missile wing, a SAC bomber squadron or a Trident missile submarine. Leadership must be established from the top down.'' Sam Nunn Democrat of Georgia (Chairman) ''The key test, not withstanding the White House 'spin control' on the F.B.I. report, is that John Tower most likely could not qualify for duty at the Strategic Air Command control center in Omaha. He has an exceptional talent that could be put to use, but with regrets, I must conclude not as Secretary of Defense.'' J. James Exon Democrat of Nebraska ''Perhaps in spite of his extraordinarily lucrative financial ties to the country's largest defense contractors involving hundreds and hundreds of thousands of dollars, Senator Tower could still bring an open mind to the awesome decisions that lie ahead on our national defense. But America should not be forced to take that chance.'' Edward M. Kennedy Democrat of Massachusetts ''The allegations and information which concern me the most are those which suggest a long-standing habit of excessive drinking. Those allegations and that information do not come from one or even a few sources. It comes from a great many unconnected sources. The allegations and information are not limited to a particular time period, but span the last several decades.'' Jeff Bingaman Democrat of New Mexico ''Several thousand individuals have been named by Presidents to become a member of their team and the Senate but a mere 11 times has rejected those nominations. Eleven out of thousands. That indicates to me, and indeed tradition and history confirm it, that while this institution is by no means a rubber stamp, historically we have accepted the President's judgment and his decision that he needs an individual to serve him in a specific capacity. That decision and that judgment has been rendered by the President of the United States George Bush. I accept it and I shall vote for John Tower. '' John W. Warner Republican of Virginia ''It's a very sad day when I see friends turn against such a man, admitting that there's no smoking gun. . . . We are clearly setting new standards here if John Tower's nomination is refused. I don't believe that he's a saint. I believe he's a good man. I believe he's a good man who has been an effective, loyal American who has served his country with distinction. He's not deserving of what he is experiencing tonight.'' John McCain Republican of Arizona

title: Michael Foods Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss of $6,062,000 from an accounting change.

title: Wright Says Bush Must Pick Cooperation or Partisanship
description: House Speaker Jim Wright said today that President Bush was going to have to choose between the cooperative approach he says he wants with Congress and the fiercely partisan tone struck this week by a top official of the Republican Party.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about a French retailer, Carrefour S.A., misstated the outlook for a plan to build a hypermarket in Brookhaven, L.I. Carrefour is suing Brookhaven to gain the right to build a retail center there; it has not given up on the location.

title: General Sees Lack of Panama Policy
description: The commander of American forces in Latin America has charged that the Bush Administration is not prepared to deal with Panama's political crisis because of a policy vacuum in Washington.

title: Review/Art; Sculptors Using the Wall as Venue and Inspiration
description: Like several other shows organized by Kenkeleba House, an alternative space that will soon be 15 years old, ''Pillar to Post'' has an unusual energy and tone. It brings together 12 emerging artists who make either wall sculptures or freestanding sculptures inspired by the idea of a wall. There is little or no irony or skepticism here. There is no art about art.

title: Gorbachev, at Chernobyl, Urges Environment Plan
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev strolled through the Chernobyl power plant today and then called for a sweeping new program to protect the environment, including a public referendum on any disputed public project.

title: Wyman-Gordon reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $8,530,000 from an accounting change.

title: Review/Art; Quick Study Blooms Late
description: The career of Bradley Walker Tomlin, an American painter who lived between 1899 and 1953, corroborates the notion that the activities of great artists frequently bring out the best in their less-than-great contemporaries.

title: Imperial Chemical Industries Plc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results have been expressed into U.S. dollars at an exchange rate of $1.80 to the pound, the rate prevailing on Dec. 31, 1988. The net income figures are after extraordinary items. The share earnings represent American Depository Receipt (ADR) and four ICI ordinary shares are represented by each ADR.

title: Chrysler Plant to Make A New Jeep
description: Responding to growing consumer preference for sports-utility vehicles, the Chrysler Corporation said today that an assembly plant here would be transformed to produce a new-model Jeep.

title: Agency Revises A Museum Plan At Battery Park
description: In a hotly disputed move, the Battery Park City Authority announced a plan yesterday that could pave the way for a Jewish museum and memorial at its complex, but would change who would pay for much of the musuem.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Archives Exhibition
description: It seems that Fidel Castro, the Cuban leader, started out life with a friendly attitude toward the United States, so much so that he once asked for some personal financial support.
