In the collection of the National Archives there is a letter written by him Nov. 6, 1940, to Franklin D. Roosevelt when Mr. Castro was 12 years old, asking the President for $10 because, in his own words, ''Never, I have not seen a ten dollar bill green American and I would like to have one of them.''

title: With Pomp and on a Global Stage, Japanese Bury Emperor Hirohito
description: With rites reaching back to its ancient past and a massing of world leaders testifying to its modern ascent, Japan embarked today upon the daylong funeral of Emperor Hirohito.

title: Hans Helmut Kirst; West German, 74, Wrote About Nazis
description: Hans Helmut Kirst, one of West Germany's most popular postwar novelists, died yesterday in Bremen, West Germany. He was 74 years old.

title: Ceasars World Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Knicks Set Home Streak Record Going Away
description: The victory last night could not have come more easily. It was a laugher from the opening tap as the Knicks thrashed the hapless Charlotte Hornets, 139-114, at Madison Square Garden. It was the 20th straight home victory for the Knicks, equaling the club record set by the 1969 team and matched in 1973.

title: New Look Emerges In Tyson's Corner
description: For 35 fights, the familiar voice in the corner of Mike Tyson was Kevin Rooney's. No more. Rooney was dismissed in December for remarks that Tyson said the trainer had no business making.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
NCNB Has a Tough Job For a Banker in Texas
description: LEAD: Having skillfully negotiated his way through difficult economies in Latin America and the American Southwest during the last 15 years, F. Karl Zavitkovsky may have taken on his biggest challenge yet.

title: Memorial Gifts Help Neediest
description: When Katherine Hollister died in the crash of Pan American World Airways Flight 103 over Scotland in December, her parents, Babette and William Hollister, both faculty members of Queens College, suggested that memorial contributions be made to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund or to the University of Rochester, where their 20-year-old daughter was a student.

title: Reviews/Theater; An Overstuffed and Uninhibited John Guare
description: John Guare, the author of ''The House of Blue Leaves'' and ''Landscape of the Body,'' was not born to write neat plays. So the good news from the Yale Repertory Theater is that Mr. Guare has abandoned the sober classical style he lavished on his ''Lydie Breeze'' trilogy during much of this decade and has instead brought forth a completely uninhibited comic mess.

title: Kinder-Care Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The latest quarter and year included $16 million pretax charge related to asset writedowns.

title: Committee Vote Against Tower Nomination Marks Personal Defeat for Bush
description: The vote against John G. Tower by the Senate Armed Services Committee marked a significant and highly personal defeat for President Bush and Vice President Dan Quayle, who lobbied intensely for the nominee for Defense Secretary in the face of persistent questions about his personal life.

title: Restaurants
description: La Metairie

title: Like Too Bad, Yeah
description: Asked at a news conference about his refusal to support a ban on semiautomatic rifles, President Bush promised to take ''a hard look.'' Beyond that, he said little and said it badly:

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. COMMITTEE ON PEACEFUL USES OF OUTER SPACE - SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL SUBCOMMITTEE - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. Economic and Social Council DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM GOVERNING COUNCIL - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. POPULATION COMMISSION - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Latecomers
description: The ''latecomers'' in Anita Brookner's elegiac new novel are two aging migrs named Hartmann and Fibich who run a successful greeting-card business in London. Both are variations on familiar Brookner types: Fibich is one of those polite, overly cautious individuals who expect little from life and constantly fear the worst, while Hartmann is one of those blustering bons vivants, blessed with the optimism conferred by good health and a sunny disposition.

title: Duriron Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Marshall Steel reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $12,000 and $311,000 for the latest and prior years, respectively; the latest year also included a gain of $1,291,000 on the sale of a plant, and the prior year a gain of $12,560,000 on the sale of assets. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: New Evidence in a Landmark Case
description: Thirty years after he was found guilty of contempt of Congress, the last person imprisoned for refusing to answer questions from the House Un-American Activities Committee asked the courts today to vacate his conviction, charging improprieties by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Who Speaks For American Jews?
description: LEAD: The Bush Administration will soon face heavy lobbying from the Jewish organizations that claim to speak for all American Jews. In fact, they don't.

title: Leonard, Tyson Cited
description: Sugar Ray Leonard and Mike Tyson were named the World Boxing Council's co-boxers of the year yesterday in Las Vegas, Nev, at the W.B.C.'s annual awards dinner.

title: TV Weekend; Embroidering Chicago in the 1930's
description: This being a ratings sweeps period, the networks are predictably rushing toward the obvious. Sex is all over the screen, from last week's ''Swimsuit'' (the ads promised: ''When it comes to helping a girl win a swimsuit contest, everyone is willing to pull a few strings'') to this week's ''Naked Lie'' starring Victoria Principal as an assistant district attorney (''In the courtroom, she knows him as a judge; in the bedroom, she knows him as a lover''). There is, to be sure, an alternative: violence. And that means it's gangster time. The best of the lot - NBC's ''Revenge of Al Capone'' - can be found this Sunday at 9 P.M. on Channel 4.

title: Legislators Resist Cuomo on Medicaid Cuts
description: Despite wide agreement among New York State lawmakers that Medicaid costs should be curbed, legislators are resisting major elements of the Cuomo administration's plan to cut $350 million in Medicaid spending, illustrating the difficulty of revamping the system.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Crytoclearance Gets A Chance to Show Off
description: It always seemed that if you gave him enough time, Cryptoclearance might get there. Over the last three seasons, running against the strongest crop of horses this decade has produced, the smallish colt was always making up ground at the end and finishing close to the best while rarely getting to the finish line first.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY AFFORDABLE ART, MAYBE

title: Books of The Times; Brookner's Outsiders as Opposites Who Attract
description: Latecomers By Anita Brookner 248 pages. Pantheon Books. $16.95.

title: Allegheny Reinstates Merger
description: Allegheny International, the Pittsburgh-based appliance maker, announced that it had signed a merger agreement yesterday with a suitor it had formerly rebuffed, Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.

title: His Life Transformed, Rushdie Is 'Bearing Up'
description: As the full implications of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's death sentence on the British author Salman Rushdie sink in, his friends here are saying that whatever happens to him in the future, he will never be able to go back to the highly active and visible life he was leading until last week.

title: JLG Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Fannie Mae Unit To Be Phased Out
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, also known as Fannie Mae, will phase out the operations of its Software Systems division, which provides software and hardware to small and medium-sized mortgage lenders, over the next 18 months. As a result, Fannie Mae said it would take a charge of less than $10 million before taxes against its first-quarter results.

title: Study Identifies Part of Brain As Important Site of Anxiety
description: Scientists report that they have located an important site of normal anxiety in the human brain.

title: Crown Life Insurance Co reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $11,986,000 and a charge of $30,000,000. c-Net income and after a loss from discontinued operations of $21,858,000. Year-ago figures have been restated. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Labor Threatens the President
description: Like President Reagan before him, President Bush faces an early challenge from labor in the air transport industry. Mr. Reagan stood firm against a strike by air traffic controllers that could have grounded civil aviation. The question now is whether Mr. Bush will stand up with equal courage to unions that threaten to shut down the railroads unless the White House intervenes in their dispute with beleaguered Eastern Airlines.

title: Bally Cancels Plan For Casino Spinoff
description: The Bally Manufacturing Corporation has canceled a proposed restructuring because of opposition by New Jersey gaming officials to a spinoff of its casino-hotel operations. Bally had announced a plan in October to make its four casinos - two in Atlantic City and two in Nevada - a separate publicly owned company.

title: Torstar Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included special gains of $19,993,000 and $29,390,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included special charges of $1,097,000 and $1,966,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. Share earnings are fully diluted. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: N.H.L. Plans Soviet Trip
description: As expected, the Calgary Flames and the Washington Capitals yesterday were named as the first National Hockey League teams to visit the Soviet Union next fall. The official announcement was made at a news conference at the United Nations by ambassadors from the United States, Canada and the Soviet Union.

title: Nets Ease Past Clippers, and Deadline
description: The National Basketball Association trading deadline passed today without the Nets making a deal.

title: Henderson Due Today But Green's Anger Grows
description: Another day and still no Rickey Henderson. Although the missing Yankee outfielder was on a plane bound for Florida today, his absence continued to test the patience of the new manager, Dallas Green.

title: The Hands Have It: A Nonet Of Pianists
description: FOR some musicians and music lovers, the piano is not merely an instrument, it is the technological embodiment of the classical music tradition. From it, one can elicit everything from subtly shaded melodies and balanced lines of counterpoint to thunderous waves of chordal sound. And for Mozart, Beethoven, Schubert, Chopin, Liszt, Rachmaninoff and Bartok, it was the instrument of choice.

title: Benjamin Englander, A Rabbi, Is Dead at 81
description: Dr. Benjamin H. Englander, a prominent Conservative rabbi, died Tuesday at Good Samaritan Hospital in Suffern, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 81 years old and lived in Monsey, N.Y.

title: Medtronic Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Israel and P.L.O.: Pressure Grow for Negotiations
description: From home and abroad, the Israeli Government is under assault as friends and opponents alike unite in an uncommon chorus of disenchantment with Israel's refusal to talk to the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Bolivian Sounds

title: Now, Enter The 'Media Adviser,' A New Line Of Defense For The Sophisticated Legal Firm
description: The primers tell lawyers how to deal with the wiliest of adversaries: how to anticipate their strategems, exploit their weaknesses, protect their clients and themselves. But the enemy they are speaking of is not opposing counsel. It's the press.

title: Fleet St. Building Sold
description: London's distinctive Daily Express building on Fleet Street has been sold to British and Japanese buyers for $:80 million ($140 million), its owner said Wednesday. United Newspapers said it had sold the building, whose unusual curved black-glass facade is considered a leading example of 1930's architecture, to the insurance group Guardian Royal Exchange and the Japanese property developer C. Itoh. The newspaper's departure from Fleet Street follows a three-year exodus of news organizations to the newly developed Docklands district in east London.

title: McFerrin and Chapman Top Grammys
description: Here is a complete list of winners at Wednesday night's 31st annual Grammy Awards. Record of the Year: ''Don't Worry, Be Happy,'' Bobby McFerrin. Album of the Year: ''Faith,'' George Michael. Song of the Year: ''Don't Worry, Be Happy,''

title: George Weston Ltd reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a special gain of $53.1 million which was mostly from the sale in the first quarter of Interbake Canada. Figures are in Canadian funds. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: MCI Loses Appeal On U.S. Contract
description: A Government appeals board yesterday dismissed a protest by the MCI Communications Corporation over a multibillion-dollar contract awarded to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to build part of a new Federal telephone system. The General Services Administration's Board of Contract Appeals ruled that MCI did not have a right to file the protest because it was not a primary bidder. MCI, based in Washington, was a subcontractor in a losing bidding consortium led by the Martin Marietta Corporation.

title: Fischer & Porter Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest quarter and year included $3.3 million special charge for personnel reductions and inventory writedowns at certain international operations.

title: Ecolab Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $100,063,000. The company said the prior year net included a pretax restructuring charge of $31,441,000.

title: Beretta Cites G.M. Accord
description: The Italian gunmaker Beretta S.p.A. said it had settled its lawsuit accusing the General Motors Corporation of trademark infringement for using its name for a Chevrolet car. In a statement released on

title: Hugo Largo
description: Hugo Largo, a drumless rock band, performs tonight at midnight and tomorrow at 9 P.M. and midnight at the Knitting Factory, 47 East Houston Street (219-3055). Tickets are $10.

title: People
description: * Barry Day has joined Lintas: Worldwide as vice chairman and director of international advertising development.

title: Mr. Bush: Help Cambodia
description: Dear President Bush, In a short time, you will be sitting down with Deng Xiaoping in Beijing. There will be many pressing matters on your agenda, but none more vital than insuring that Cambodia becomes free after the Vietnamese troops withdraw and that the Khmer Rouge, who are supplied by the Chinese, do not fill the vacuum.

title: Federal Express Post
description: T. Allan McArtor, former administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration, will return to the Federal Express Corporation as senior vice president of air operations, company officials said. Mr. McArtor will assume his duties March 1. He succeeds James Riedmeyer, who is retiring.

title: Empresa Nacional de Electriidad SA reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in U.S. dollars. U.S. dollars figures converted from Spanish pesetas at the Dec. 30 rate of 113.450 pesetas to the dollar.

title: Top Afghan Rebels Select Centrist as Interim Leader
description: Afghan guerrilla leaders elected a moderate today as president and a fundamentalist as prime minister of the government they hope will lead Afghanistan if the Soviet-backed Government falls.

title: Sterner Lighting Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SENATE PANEL VOTES TO DENY RECOMMENDATION OF TOWER AS BUSH'S DEFENSE SECRETARY
description: The Senate Armed Services Committee tonight recommended rejection of John G. Tower's nomination as Secretary of Defense, dealing a stern blow to President Bush and raising serious doubts about whether Mr. Tower can win confirmation by the full Senate.

title: Southam Inc reports earnings for
description: b-Included special gains totalling $130,027,000 and $132,368,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, mostly from the sale of its stake in Selkirk Communications Ltd. c-Included a charge of $1,230,000 for the quarter and a special gain of $4,380,000 for the year. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Knicks, in a Surprise, Get Vandeweghe; Celtics Trade Ainge
description: In an about-face, the Portland Trail Blazers finally reached agreement with the Knicks yesterday on a deal to send the high-scoring forward Kiki Vandeweghe to New York. The deal was made after almost a year of on-again, off-again negotiations marked by a series of false starts and dashed hopes. As recently as Wednesday night, the Trail Blazers said Vandeweghe was not available for a trade with the Knicks.

title: York Papers Seek to Join
description: The York Dispatch and The York Daily Record announced Wednesday that they are asking for a joint operating agreement that would unite the business and production functions of the newspapers.

title: REBEL CHIEF TELLS OF HELP BY NORTH
description: Adolfo Calero, a leader of Nicaraguan rebels who once depended on Oliver L. North for money, arms and battlefield advice, testified against him today.

title: Aubrey Menen, 76, Indian Critic, Novelist and Essayist From Britain
description: Aubrey Menen, a novelist, critic and essayist, died of throat cancer on Feb. 13 in Trivandrum in Kerala, India. He was 76 years old. Word of Mr. Menen's death was received yesterday by Dr. Howard Gottlieb, curator of his papers in the manuscript collections at the Boston University library.

title: Russ Berrie and Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Latest quarter results included a litigation charge of $2,696,000 and a reduction in the provision for income taxes of $1,048,000.

title: Duplex Products Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
KEY RATES
West Virginia Wins 22d Straight
description: West Virginia extended its winning streak to 22 games tonight and clinched the Atlantic 10 Conference title with a 65-60 victory over St. Joseph's.

title: Health Workers Exposed to AIDS To Be Offered Experimental Drug
description: The National Institutes of Health is to announce Friday that it will offer an experimental drug treatment to its employees who suffer a significant occupational exposure to a virus that causes AIDS.

title: Leon's Furniture Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Atlanta Concertmaster Joins Cleveland Quartet
description: William Preucil, the concertmaster of the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra, will replace Donald Weilerstein as first violinist of the Cleveland Quartet next season, the Atlanta orchestra has announced.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11 Emperor Hirohito's funeral began with rites reaching back to the ancient past and a massing of world leaders. The ceremony will formally conclude Hirohito's era of militarism, defeat, and rebirth. Page A1

title: Dunkin' Donuts Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
Ruuttu Suspended
description: Christian Ruuttu, a Buffalo Sabres center, was suspended for five games yesterday by the National Hockey League for high-sticking Larry Melnyk of Vancouver last Feb. 10. Brian O'Neill, the league's executive vice president, said in a statement that Ruuttu did not deliberately try to injure Melnyk, but called the action ''extremely careless and reckless,'' adding that ''players must be held responsible for their actions and must take all means to avoid injuring an opponent.'' The suspension will take effect March 2 unless the club waives the right to appeal. (AP)

title: Threat by Beirut Captors
description: A pro-Iranian group that says it is holding three American professors captive vowed vengeance today against the British author Salman Rushdie for his book ''The Satanic Verses.''

title: Job Offer to Feminist Scholar May Mark Turn
description: Last week, Catharine MacKinnon, a leading feminist legal scholar and a critic of the legal system, received a telephone call offering a tenured seat on the faculty of the University of Michigan Law School.

title: Goodyear Canada Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $9,394,000 on the sale of property. c-Included a special charge of $8,072,000. The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: New York State's Fiscal Woes Seen Lasting for 3 More Years
description: New York State's fiscal problems will continue for at least another three years, the State Budget Division said in projections released today.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Symphony Cafe

title: Bought, With Sewer Money
description: Secretary of Commerce Robert Mosbacher, the Bush campaign's finance chief, complains that the Bush Administration hasn't found enough jobs for contributors. ''Quite a high percentage of those who have been helpful haven't gotten anything - at least 50 percent,'' he said.

title: Duran Seeks 4th Title And Past Admiration
description: Las manos de piedra, the hands of stone that have knocked out 61 opponents, are square and a little plump now, with tiny half moons rising on carefully trimmed fingernails.

title: Gibson Still Bothered by Knee
description: His knee problem cannot be talked away, so Kirk Gibson would rather not talk about it. The knee problem, though, will be a widely and oft-discussed subject until and unless Gibson fulfills the vow he made today.

title: Events of Black History Month
description: February is Black History Month. A selection of events follows. Today LEHMAN COLLEGE, Bedford Park Boulevard West and Goulden Avenue, in the Bedford Park section of the Bronx. A talk by Donald Polk, the president of the New York Urban League, at 11 A.M., and a performance by Joan Miller's Dance Players at noon (960-8283). Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President, will sponsor a Black History Month celebration at 6 P.M. with a reception, an awards ceremony and an appearance by Rod Rogers Dance Company (590-3980) Both events, in the Theater of Lehman Center for the Performing Arts, are free. ''Black Printmakers and the W.P.A.'' will be seen through June 6 at the Lehman College Art Gallery. Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Free (960-8731). NEW COMMUNITY CINEMA, 423 Park Avenue, Huntington, L.I. (516-423-7653). As part of the series ''The Films of Black Directors: Past and Present,'' Soulemane Cisse's ''Wind'' tonight and tomorrow night at 8 and 10:15 and ''School Daze,'' by Spike Lee, on Sunday at 2:30, 5 and 7:30 P.M. Tickets: $5; $3 for members and the elderly, $2.50 for 16 years and under. Tomorrow BLACK ARTS NATIONAL DIASPORA, Veterans Administration Hospital, 179th Street and Linden Boulevard in St. Albans, Queens (718-657-1168). Walter Nicks Dancers at 5 P.M. Free. CATHEDRAL OF ST. JOHN THE DIVINE, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, at 112th Street (662-2133). The third installment of Black Women in Jazz presents Diedre Murray at 8 P.M. Free. CITY OF NEW YORK PARKS AND RECREATION, Mullaly Recreation Center, 164th Street and Jerome Avenue, near Yankee Stadium in the Bronx (397-3131). ''Black History Festival,'' with speakers; a Girl Scout song-and-dance program; workshops to make ''story vines,'' a traditional African mnemonic device, and other African crafts. 1 to 4 P.M. Free. LEHMAN COLLEGE, Theater of Lehman Center for the Performing Arts, Bedford Park Boulevard West and Goulden Avenue, in the Bedford Park section of the Bronx (960-8211). In conjunction with the exhibition ''Black Printmakers and the W.P.A.,'' a symposium and panel discussion on the history, art and literature relevant to the black experience of the 1930's, followed by a reception. At 1 P.M. Free. REVOLUTION BOOKS, 13 East 16th Street (691-3345). Screening of ''The Murder of Fred Hampton.'' At 7:30 P.M. Admission: $2.50. Sunday HENRY STREET SETTLEMENT, Arts for Living Center, 466 Grand Street (598-0400). Shadow Box Theater presents ''The African Drum,'' an adaptation of four African folk tales to the accompaniment of drum and dance. For children ages 4 to 12 and their families. Tickets: $2.50, $1 for children. At 2 P.M. NEW ALLIANCE PRODUCTIONS, Dunlevy-Milbank Center, 1432 Lenox Avenue, entrance on 118th Street near Fifth Avenue (862-2378). Harlem Children's All Stars Talent Show at 3 P.M. Tickets: $7, $4 for children under 12. VOICES OF THE FAITH, the Brooklyn Museum, Third Floor Court, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Washington Avenue, in the Crown Heights section (718-783-3077). Multi-denominational mixed choir will perform all original works by Rachiim Ausar-Sahu, the founder of the group. At 2 P.M. Admission by donation.

title: Stocks Up Narrowly; Volume Off
description: Stocks rose narrowly yesterday after remaining lower throughout most of the trading session.

title: Bush Discusses Mideast With Leaders in Japan
description: President Bush on Thursday began a five-day visit to Asia with a packed schedule of talks with world leaders in which the prospects for peace in the Middle East figured prominently.

title: Tseng Labs Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Rep. Lukens Charged in Sex Case
description: Representative Donald Lukens was indicted today on a misdemeanor charge that he had sex with a teen-age girl.

title: Review/Dance; In the French Manner
description: Members of American dance companies offered the musical and balletic equivalents of French Champagne on Wednesday night at Alice Tully Hall. The bubbly program was ''France-Danse,'' a benefit for the Dance Collection of the New York Public Library and La Maison Francaise of New York University.

title: Review/Art; When Three's No Crowd
description: It is a curious coincidence that brings into town three exhibitions of substance by artists who have been known to pace themselves over the years, to get the most out of their every perception, and to maintain certain protective apartness. One of these is the Spanish painter (and, latterly, sculptor) Antoni Tapies, born in 1923, who in a discreet way was one of the heroes of art during the Franco regime in Spain.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Bush's Orders
description: Now hear this!

title: Shandwick To Acquire Golin/Harris
description: IN a move that could substantially alter the competitive climate in the public relations industry, Shandwick P.L.C., the world's third-largest public relations company, has agreed to acquire the North American operations of Golin/Harris Communications, the Chicago-based public relations subsidiary of Foote, Cone & Belding Communications.

title: Computer Products reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $307,000 for both the quarter and year, and the year also included an $8,500,000 restructuring charge. c-Net loss d-Included losses from discontinued operations of $8,276,000 for the quarter and $9,379,000 for the year.

title: Palestinian Rebels Killed In Border Region in Lebanon
description: Three Palestinian guerrillas on their way to attack Israel were killed today inside Israel's border buffer zone in southern Lebanon, the Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army said.

title: Danish Stock Exchange
description: The Copenhagen Stock Exchange held its last ''open outcry'' bond trading session today before giving way to an electronic system. The new system will make the trading floor redundant by enabling stock and bond dealers to trade through screens and keyboards linked to a central computer without leaving their office.

title: Why Classical Music and Rock Shouldn't Mix; Only the Future Knows
description: To the Editor:

title: Relocating the Indian Museum Will Be a Breach of All Trusts; 96th Street Boondocks
description: To the Editor:

title: A 2d Soviet Vaulter Finds Room at Top
description: The whispers among the pole vaulters are getting louder. They say Sergei Bubka's reign may be approaching an end. They say another vaulter from the Soviet Union might surpass him this year. They say watch out for a 23-year-old medical student from Tashkent known as the Mad Doctor.

title: Oil-Dri Corp of America reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Durable Goods Orders Dropped 3% in January
description: Orders to factories for ''big ticket'' durable goods dropped 3 percent in January, the Commerce Department said today. Some analysts said the report could portend a welcome slowdown in economic growth.

title: Sears Cutting Prices By as Much as 50% In a Shift of Strategy
description: In an ambitious attempt to revive its sagging profits and rebuild market share, Sears, Roebuck & Company announced today that it would cut prices by up to 50 percent on three-fourths of its inventory -more than 50,000 items.

title: Paul Harris Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Included a gain of $844,000 from an accounting change. c-Net loss

title: Why Classical Music and Rock Shouldn't Mix
description: To the Editor:

title: Gleason Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-After a gain of $2,951,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The latest quarter and year results included an after-tax gain of $2 million from the sale of certain land and buildings. The year-ago quarter and year results included after-tax restructuring charges of $4,045,000 and $4,997,000, respectively.

title: USAir Orders Jets From McDonnell
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said it had signed a letter of intent with USAir Group Inc. for the carrier to buy up to 40 MD-82 aircraft. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. Industry sources have estimated the cost of the MD-82 at between $22 million and $25 million, which would put the value of the sale between $880 million and $1 billion.

title: China and Indonesia Agree to Renew Ties Suspended in 1967
description: China and Indonesia agreed today to normalize relations, 22 years after they were suspended over allegations that China supported a Communist coup attempt against the Indonesian Government.

title: For U.S. Intelligence, Indeed a High Standard
description: To the Editor:

title: Johnson Wins Argument: Mets Kill Langston Trade
description: After a protest by Davey Johnson that shook the top management of the Mets, the club broke off negotiations with the Seattle Mariners today and abandoned the six-player trade for Mark Langston that ruffled the Mets' players and their manager all winter.

title: Pardy to Coach Marist
description: Rick Pardy, an assistant coach at Hamilton College, has been named football coach at Marist College, officials at the Division III school announced yesterday. Pardy, 27 years old, was also coordinator of recruiting at Hamilton. Pardy succeeded Mike Malet, who resigned to become assistant athletic director after the 1988 season. (AP)

title: Ranger Oil Ltd reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $5,402,000 and $7,307,000 for the latest and prior years, respectively.

title: Why Classical Music and Rock Shouldn't Mix; Frat-Boy 'Blues' Gala
description: To the Editor:

title: Series of One-Acts Aims for the 'Slightly Bent'
description: The Manhattan Class Company, which won notice in 1987 with a festival of one-act plays that included Alan Bowne's highly praised ''Beirut,'' has opened its third such festival, in the Nat Horne Theater on Theater Row.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Neither Mud Nor Lost Divinity Mars Emperor's Rites
description: By the time that Emperor Hirohito's funeral procession wound its way through Tokyo's gray streets this morning, Shinjuku Gyoen was already a sea of mud.

title: Regulators Express Doubts On California Savings Deal
description: Regulatory officials say they have growing doubts that the American Continental Corporation's deal to sell its Lincoln Savings and Loan subsidiary will be completed.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 19.

title: 9 Lost, 23 Injured as Jet's Skin Rips Over Pacific
description: Part of the outer fuselage of a United Airlines jumbo jet ripped away shortly after takeoff early this morning, sucking out passengers to the darkness of the Pacific Ocean below.

title: Komag Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $4,000 and $1,140,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included tax credits of $750,000 for the quarter and $2,845,000 for the year.

title: Perceptronics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Salvador Army Tied to 10 Killings
description: Despite stiff warnings from the United States to respect human rights, elite Salvadoran Army troops raided a guerrilla field hospital and killed five medical workers and five wounded rebels, the Roman Catholic Church said today.

title: A Hole-in-19
description: In an exhibition of ineptitude that would give many an understanding duffer a thrill of recognition, an Australian golf pro, Robert Edmond, took 19 strokes to complete the par-5 first hole in the second round at the Australian Tournament Players Championship at Sydney yesterday and thereby wrote his name into the record book.

title: Mozambique Says Pretoria Is Behind Surge in Violence
description: In the five months since Mozambique signed a cooperation pact with South Africa, there has been an increase in violent raids and sabotage of key economic installations by rebels who the Government says are supported by South Africa.

title: Lawsuit Seeks Aid for Poor In Evictions
description: New York State should be required to provide lawyers for poor people facing eviction just as it must for indigent people facing criminal charges, advocates for the poor said in a class-action lawsuit filed yesterday.

title: Cancel That, Er, Winter Storm Watch
description: A winter storm warning was announced, alternate-side parking rules were suspended and forecasters assured everyone who would listen that it would be the big one of the season. But as of 10:30 P.M., no snow had fallen in New York City yesterday.

title: About New York; The Happy Feet Of Minnetonkans At the Rainbow
description: Just how happy was Janet Erickson, the star pupil of the Arthur Murray Dance Studio in Minnetonka, Minn.?

title: Sponges Luring Divers To Undersea Gold Rush
description: The work is dangerous, and Doru Bogatescu knows nothing about it. Still, fresh from Manhattan, he paces along the pier, asking anyone who passes to help him become a sponge diver.

title: Hooper Holmes Inc.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $2.6 million on the sale of a division.

title: Merger Efforts Ended At 2 Spanish Banks
description: Efforts to merge two leading Spanish banks and create the country's biggest financial group collapsed today in a tangle of infighting and financial intrigue among leading stockholders.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a speech by President Bush in Alaska on American policy in the Pacific misstated the part of the Japanese gross national product devoted to the military. It is slightly over 1 percent.

title: Bernard Wiess, Lawyer and Ex-Judge, 85
description: Bernard Wiess, a Sullivan County lawyer for 50 years, died Tuesday at Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 85 years old and lived in Liberty, N.Y.

title: Browns Sign Banker
description: The Cleveland Browns announced yesterday that they had signed Ted Banker, a 6-foot-2-inch, 275-pound offensive lineman who started in eight games last season for the Jets, then was left on their unprotected list of free agents.

title: North's Attorney Assails Conduct Of U.S. Lawyers in the Courtroom
description: Oliver L. North's chief defense lawyer accused Government attorneys of outrageous conduct in attempting to portray the Nicaraguan rebels as ''killers and warmongers,'' according to a record of a private session Thursday with the trial judge that was released today.

title: Medical Properties reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

But be guided by this warning from the Council of Better Business Bureaus: ''Anyone can set up shop and hang out a shingle as a tax preparer. There are no national educational and professional requirements.''

description: Poland's Government urged the Soviet Union today to disclose the truth about the Katyn Forest massacre of Polish officers in World War II.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Bargains in Ski Gear
description: Sales of ski equipment are early because of meager snow in many areas. Shops are advertising 20 to 50 percent off. Shoppers need to be knowledgeable, and also cautious about bargains they don't need or that are not suitable. Here are some pointers: Boots Bring the socks or orthotics that you use while skiing. Try on boots from at least three manufacturers to learn which shape and size fit best. Your toes should have room to wiggle, but your heels should not move up, down or sidewise. Spend at least 15 minutes wearing both boots before deciding to buy. When you remove them, examine your feet for red spots that indicate where stretching is needed; all-over pinkness means the boots are too small. Negotiate a guarantee for adjustments and refitting. Skis Ideally, you have been thinking about this purchase all season, testing skis at resorts and questioning instructors. The sales person should ask how long you have skied, the terrain you prefer, what type of turns you make, what boots you wear and your goals for improving your technique. Top-of-the-line recreational skis, perhaps originally priced at $300 to $500, are usually superior to midpriced skis, especially for intermediates who plan to improve. Beware of stiff racing skis and ignore cosmetics. Bindings Better bindings have been paramount in reducing injuries. Each year manufacturers introduce subtle technological and design changes, which can mean big discounts on old models at the end of the season. The shop should have technicians certified to install the brand you buy, and you should be asked your height, weight, age and skiing ability so toe and heel units can be adjusted. Shop around, compare prices and try to negotiate a free or discounted installation if you buy new skis.

title: Teknowledge Sets Cimflex Merger
description: Teknowledge Inc. of Palo Alto, Calif., a pioneering company in artificial intelligence and expert systems, said its merger with the American Cimflex Corporation of Pittsburgh had been approved. Cimflex is a privately held company specializing in computer-integrated manufacturing and flexible assembly systems.

title: Health Risks of Used Batteries Prompt Action on Disposal
description: Every year Americans throw away several billion household batteries, sending hundreds of tons of toxic compounds into landfills, incinerators and, ultimately, the environment. The health risk has not been measured, but pressure is building to force manufacturers to recycle the batteries or to collect them and dispose of them safely.

title: Norris Cotton, 88, Former New Hampshire Senator
description: Norris Cotton, who represented his native New Hampshire for 20 years in the United States Senate as one of its staunchest Republicans, died yesterday at his home in Lebanon, N.H. He was 88 years old.

title: More Prosperity, More Hunger
description: LEAD: Throughout this decade, domestic hunger has been one of the most public of personal tragedies. The suffering of hungry American families, a wholly preventable condition, has been chronicled by numerous Government reports and academic studies. Research indicates a clear relationship between inadequate nutrition and illness, including more babies born at low birthweight and the risks of higher infant mortality and permanent disability.

title: Recouple the Long Island Rail Road
description: Having allowed itself to become uncoupled from the rest of New York's Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the Long Island Rail Road is fumbling its efforts to build a modern rail car repair shop adjacent to its main line in Hollis, Queens. The Federal Government, which is paying half the final cost, sternly warns that it may refuse to finance future L.I.R.R. projects.

title: Pier F. Paci Dies at 58; Pathologist in Boston
description: Dr. Pier F. Paci, a pathologist at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston who taught at Harvard Medical School, died of pancreatic cancer on Feb. 15 at his home in Brookline, Mass. He was 58 years old. Dr. Paci, who was born in Assisi, Italy, and received his medical degree from the University of Florence, specialized in the diagnosis of breast cancer and other tumors. In 1964, after six years of residency at Boston hospitals, he returned to Italy to teach at Bari University and at the Regina Elena Cancer Institute.

title: Prize for James Merrill

Mr. Merrill accepted the medal Thursday at an awards dinner at the club, 15 Gramercy Park South. His latest collection of poems, ''The Inner Room,'' was published recently by Alfred A. Knopf.

title: G.M.'s Plans for Plant

A G.M. spokeswoman said Thursday that the auto maker had tried but failed to conclude deals with two companies to sell the factory so that it could continue as a stamping plant. No other prospective buyers have stepped forward, she said. The 1.5-million-square-foot plant employed up to 2,500 workers in this southwestern Ohio community before it was closed six months ago.

title: Henderson Arrives, Makes Peace
description: At about 9:15 this morning, under a bright sun that was unable to break the daylong chill, Rickey Henderson finally bounced into camp. He wore sunglasses and a smile, sang to himself as he walked through the parking lot and dressed for his first full day of work with the Yankees. Late? He insisted he was early. Even though players are not required to report to spring training until Wednesday, the commotion created by Henderson's absence while his teammates showed up early intrigued the Yankee outfielder.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS McEnroe Advances: Second-seeded John McEnroe beat Carl Uwe Steeb of West Germany, 6-2, 6-2, yesterday to gain the semifinals of the $291,000 Lyon Grand Prix tournament in France. McEnroe will meet Jonas Svensson, who beat a fellow Swede, Magnus Gustafsson, 6-2, 6-0. In another quarterfinal, top-seeded Jakob Hlasek of Switzerland defeated Patrick Kuhnen of West Germany, 6-3, 7-6.(AP) Agassi Gains: Top-seeded Andre Agassi defeated Dan Goldie, 6-1, 6-4, last night at the United States Pro Indoor Championships in Philadelphia. The victory advanced Agassi to a semifinal today against third-seeded Tim Mayotte, a two-time defending champion. Mayotte defeated Brad Gilbert, 6-4, 5-7, 6-4. Late last night, second-seeded Boris Becker of West Germany rallied to defeat 10th-seeded Christo van Rensburg of South Africa, 3-6, 6-1, 6-4. Fourth-seeded Mikael Pernfors of Sweden defeated 11th-seeded Robert Seguso, 6-4, 6-3.(AP) GOLF 5 Seniors Tie for Lead: Harold Henning holed a 50-foot chip shot on the 18th hole yesterday to join four others in a tie for the first-round lead in the Senior Challenge at Naples, Fla. Henning's chip-in, his second of the day, gave him a birdie and a two-under-par 70, the same score registered by Miller Barber, Chick Evans, Gene Littler and Bruce Crampton. Another shot back at 71 were Butch Baird, Mike Hill, Don Massengale and the defending champion, Gary Player.(AP) SKIING Figini Wins Downhill: Michela Figini of Switzerland scored a half-second victory over her teammate Maria Walliser in the final women's World Cup downhill of the season yesterday in Steamboat Springs, Colo. It was the sixth downhill triumph of the season and third in a row for the 22-year-old Figini, who captured her third successive World Cup downhill title last weekend by winning two races in Canada. Figini led a Swiss sweep of the top three places. She was clocked in 1 minute 25.90 seconds. Walliser was second in 1:26.49, and Chantal Bournissen took third in 1:26.99. (AP) N.B.A. Cavaliers 128, Trail Blazers 91 Larry Nance scored 17 of his 28 points in the first half as Cleveland took its 20th straight home victory.(AP) Celtics 125, Bucks 112: Kevin McHale scored 26 points and Boston had a 31-15 spurt in the first 8:10 of the final period at Hartford. (AP) Heat 111, Clippers 91: Kevin Miami's Edwards had 22 points, Grant Long had 20 and the Clippers had only 29 in the first half at Miami. (AP) Pacers 112, Spurs 93:Chuck Person scored 10 of his 25 points in a decisive third-quarter spurt as Indiana ended their franchise-record losing streak at 12 games.(AP) Nuggets 121, Jazz 102: Michael Adams scored 32 points to help end a five-game winning streak for the Jazz. (AP) HIGH SCHOOL BASKETBALL All Hallows Upsets Molloy: Kenny Anderson, the leading schoolboy scorer in New York State history, saw his final season stopped short last night as All Hallows of the Bronx upset Archbishop Molloy of Queens, 64-63, in the opening round of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association tournament. Anderson scored a game-high 23 points to finish with 2,619 points in his four years. All Hallows (18-7) will meet Christ the King (23-1), ranked second in the nation, in a semifinal Tuesday. In the second quarterfinal, played at Fordham University, Xaverian upset Tolentine of the Bronx, 48-47. Tolentine (17-9), was led by Waymon Boone with 13. Amadi Penn, a 6-6 senior, led Xaverian (15-10), which will meet Rice in a semifinal.

title: List of the Missing In Hawaii Accident
description: Following is a list, released by United Airlines, of the passengers, all seated in business class, who were missing. CAMPBELL, Lee, of Wellington, New Zealand. CRAIG, Susan and Harry, of Morristown, N.J. CRAWFORD, Dr. John Michael, of Sydney, Australia. FALLON, Anthony and Barbara, of Long Beach, Calif. HANDLEY, Mary, of Bay City, Mich. HARLEY, Rose, of Hackensack, N.J. SWANN, John, of Sydney.

title: System Software Associates reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The year-ago first quarter included a gain of $300,000 from an accounting change.

title: New Radiation Study Planned in Ohio
description: Government scientists will re-evaluate and possibly recalculate the Department of Energy's estimates of radiation exposure and cancer risks to residents in the area of the Fernald uranium plant in Ohio, Senator John Glenn said yesterday.

title: Coping: With Bulky Junk Disposal
description: The old car is dead and beyond repair; the sofa is worn out and has to go; the washing machine fell apart and must be disposed of, and then there is the rusted stove in the garage that was supposed to have been picked up by a nephew a year ago.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Sports Pages on Wednesday about the Doral Ryder Open golf tournament misstated the rule on changing clubs during a round, as Mac O'Grady planned to do.

title: Reviews/Music; Fad and Fashion in Modern Works
description: Composers - like the rest of us -are compulsive followers of fashion. Indeed, the Fiati Chamber Players' program at Merkin Concert Hall Thursday night often seemed more about fads of style than about the people who were using them.

title: Black Who Opposes Racial Quotas Gets Justice Dept. Rights Post
description: William Lucas, a black lawyer from Detroit whose views on civil rights enforcement have drawn criticism from black and other minority groups, was selected today to direct the Justice Department's civil rights division.

title: G.O.P. Leaders in Senate Striving To Keep Tower Nomination Alive
description: Senate Republican leaders struggled today to save the nomination of John G. Tower as Secretary of Defense, but they faced an uphill battle against a Democratic majority and the weight of weeks of allegations about the conduct of their onetime colleague.

title: U.S. Curbs Chemical Exports To 4 Nations in Middle East
description: The Commerce Department said today that it would impose export controls on 23 chemicals and 5 classes of biological agents that can be used to make chemical and biological weapons.

title: Ropak Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results for the latest fourth quarter were aided by a fiscal year adjustment of $450,000 resulting from a policy change in estimate of the useful life of major equipment netted against the writeoff of obsolete tooling. The year-ago figures were restated for an accounting change.

title: CTS Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $1,100,000 for both the quarter and year, and the year included also included a loss of $625,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The latest year also included provisions of $16.6 million for restructuring and recognizing additional costs of past businesses. c-Net income and after an extraordinary loss of $43,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $1,000,000 for the year.

title: Arts Agency Appoints An Acting Chairman
description: Hugh Southern, the deputy chairman of the National Endowment of the Arts, was named acting chairman today. He will run the agency until a successor to Frank Hodsoll is chosen.

title: Is John Tower Judged by a Double Standard Or by Just an Appropriately Higher One?
description: The immediate issue before the Senate Armed Services Committee was the fate of John G. Tower's nomination as Secretary of Defense. But two underlying issues, for months unspoken, are the Senate's own drinking habits and the fairness of the confirmation process itself.

title: INSIDE
description: North Trial: Angry Words

Consoltex Canada reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: Donald Duck, in Fact, Can Teach Students a Lot
description: To the Editor:

title: Emhart Rises By 7 1/8, to 39 7/8, Topping Bid
description: Shares in the Emhart Corporation rose $7.125 yesterday, to $39.875, lifted by Thursday's $2.2 billion takeover bid from Gordon P. Getty, heir to the Getty oil fortune, and the billionaire Fisher family of New York.

title: TransNet Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-7 An Afghan ''free Muslim state'' was declared by rebels who vowed that their government-in-exile would be operating inside Afghanistan within a month. Page 1 A riot against ''The Satanic Verses'' in Bombay left at least 12 people dead and 40 wounded. The rioting reportedly began when demonstrators tried to march on the British diplomatic mission. 3 Sabotage in Mozambique has risen in the five months since the Government signed a cooperation pact with South Africa. The Maputo Government says South Africa supports the rebels responsible for the raids. 5 Mexico plans to pardon hundreds of political prisoners to defuse complaints about human rights violations. It moved simultaneously to rid itself of a police official accused of rights abuses. 3 Salvadoran troops raided guerrillas at a field hospital and killed five medical workers and five wounded rebels, the Roman Catholic Church reported. 3 President Bush met other leaders after Emperor Hirohito's funeral to discuss East-West relations and military tensions in several regions. 7 President Bush returns to China on Saturday for a 40-hour visit that will include talks with top leaders, withwhom he is on familiar terms. Mr. Bush is expected to raise human rights issues. 7 An Iranian-directed group blamed for the 1983 bombing of the Marine barracks in Lebanon may have had a role in the destruction of Pan Am flight 103 in December, American officials said. 6 Lebanese man gets life term in fatal hijacking 6 Moldavia is getting a new identity as the Soviet Union ends its insistance that the tiny Soviet republic comprises a distinct ethnic group. The Soviets created Moldavia in the 1920's to keep the land from Rumania. 4 Warsaw asks Soviets to tell truth about the Polish massacre 2 National 8-12, 30 The Federal Reserve raised the rate on its loans to banks, the discount rate, pushing its drive to halt inflation by putting upward pressure on interest rates. 1 Rise in interest rates leads to a 43.92-point drop in the Dow 35 Trying to save the Tower nomination, Republicans faced an uphill battle against a Democratic majority and the weight of weeks of allegations about the conduct of their former colleague. 1 President Bush continued support for Defense Secretary-designate John Tower, declaring that he stood with the embattled nominee despite his rejection by a Senate panel. 10 News analysis: The alcohol issue in the Tower confirmation process has raised another question, for months unspoken: whether the Senate has a double standard about drinking. 1 Nine passengers were lost after part of the outer skin of a United Airlines jumbo jet ripped away shortly after takeoff in Honolulu, sucking out the nine to the Pacific Ocean below. 1 Experts look at cargo door as likely source of mishap 6 A black lawyer was selected to direct the Justice Department's civil rights division. The lawyer, William Lucas, has drawn criticism from some groups for his views on civil rights enforcement. 10 Oliver North's lawyer said attorneys for the Government had been ''outrageous'' in trying to portray Nicaraguan rebels as ''killers and warmongers,'' according to the record of a session with the trial judge. 9 Do Republicans play racial politics? The party says the election of a former Klansman in Louisiana is an affront, but Democrats say it is an inescapable result of a two-decade Republican strategy. 8 Chicago's blacks are mobilizing to hold on to the mayor's seat as the Democratic primary approaches. Polls show the city's Acting Mayor, Eugene Sawyer, gaining on his white opponent, Richard Daley. 8 Outside scientists will re-evaluate the Energy Department's calculations on the radiation exposure around the Fernald uranium plant and the cancer risk to people who live there, Senator John Glenn said. 8 Sponge hunting has brought a boom for divers in Tarpon Springs, Fla. A worldwide shortage has increased the price of a sponge from $4 to as much as $16, drawing would-be hunters from around the country. 9 A sheriff's deputy was arrested in Los Angeles and the authorities linked a gun he owned to the killings of three prostitutes last fall. 12 Officer convicted in refugees case 7 Regional 31-34 Shelters will take mental patients directly from New York City hospitals to relieve overcrowding on psychiatric wards treating the homeless, the Koch administration has decided. 1 A Koch aide has resigned under pressure, Mayor Koch of New York City said. The aide was in charge of the Mayor's Talent Bank, which has come under scrutiny for helping the politically connected get city jobs. 1 Poor people have a right to lawyers in New York State to fight evictions just as indigents facing criminal charges do, advocates for the poor said in a class action lawsuit. 31 A shortage of affordable housing has prompted Connecticut lawmakers to search for a way to overrule local officials without violating a Yankee tradition of town autonomy. Critics say the quest is doomed. 31 Officials are worried about summer, trying to devise steps to prevent the reappearance of floating garbage that fouled beaches in the last two years. 31 Snow shunned New York City again. A storm rampaged through the South, dumping nearly a foot of snow on parts of southeastern New Jersey, but it sidestepped the city and moved out to sea, predictions notwithstanding. 31 A report card for Governor Kean of New Jersey is being prepared at Henry Hudson Regional High School, where students have evaluated the Governor's wide-ranging education proposals. 32 Jesuits say library post fits in with mission 33 Official says judge's brother got special aid 33 33 Five die in Bronx, Queens fires 33

title: Staten Island Takes Final
description: Staten Island won its seventh City University tournament in the last nine years by defeating Lehman, 55-48, last night at Nat Holman Gymnasium in Manhattan.

title: Skipper's Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
description: b-Net income

title: How To Miss The Point
description: Another onset of Puritanism is upon the country. Witness John Tower, an unlikely Hester Prynne to be sure, but a man struggling nevertheless to avoid having scarlet letters sewn on his wardrobe.

title: Boeing Faces Questions on Quality
description: Cases of misrouted wiring and plumbing, along with production delays, have raised concerns among airline officials and aviation analysts about manufacturing problems at the Boeing Company, which has long enjoyed a reputation for superlative quality.

title: At Weigh-In, No Signs of an Underdog
description: Frank Bruno may be a decided underdog, but judging from the clamor his presence caused today at the weigh-in for his heavyweight title bout with Mike Tyson, he will not be lacking for support when the opening bell sounds Saturday night.

title: Youths Debate Kean Education Plans
description: Last month Gov. Thomas H. Kean made a number of wide-ranging educational proposals, from ending mandatory physical education to teaching morals and ethics. Now students at Henry Hudson Regional High School are eager to tell him what they think of his ideas.

title: Fairfax Financial Holdings reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included special gains of $260,000 and $1,700,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Sandor Weores, a Poet, Dies at 75 in Budapest
description: Sandor Weores, Hungary's leading poet, who had been nominated several times for the Nobel Prize for Literature, died in Budapest on Jan. 22. He was 75 years old.

title: Patents; A Sonic Buoy to Find Schools of Fish
description: The Honda Electric Company of Aichi, Japan, won a patent this week for a sonic buoy that finds schools of fish by using sonar echoes.

title: Gen-Probe Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
United Industrial Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Paul Michael Bator Is Dead at 59; Lawyer-Teacher Also Served U.S.
description: Paul Michael Bator, a lawyer, educator and an expert on the Federal courts and constitutional law, died yesterday at his home in Chicago after a long illness. He was 59 years old.

title: Toro Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
Muncie Is Sentenced
description: On Tuesday in San Diego, Chuck Muncie received a two-and-a-half-year Federal prison term for perjury and selling cocaine to an undercover agent. On Thursday in San Diego, there was an instant replay of sorts for Muncie, a former Charger running back, as he was sentenced to one year in jail for violating probation in connection with his failure to file a 1983 California income tax return after pleading guilty to the charge in 1987. Muncie was also fined $3,000 by Municipal Court Judge E. Mac Amos Jr., who ordered the jail sentence to run concurrently with the Federal prison term.(AP)

A Rockefeller Legacy in Buffalo
description: The State University of New York at Buffalo this month became the first public institution in New York or New England to join the Association of American Universities. It's an honor worth special notice.

title: Victoria and Albert Tries to Catch Up
description: The Victoria and Albert Museum, widely viewed as the world's pre-eminent decorative-arts institution, has begun to make basic changes in its management and organization, setting off an uproar in the museum world.

title: 43.92 Drop Puts Dow At 2,245.54
description: Stock prices plunged broadly yesterday in a sharp reaction to rising interest rates.

title: U.S. Suspects Iran Unit In the Pan Am Bombing
description: American investigators are looking into the possibility that an Iranian-directed group that organized the 1983 bombing of the Marine barracks in Lebanon had a role in the destruction of Pan Am Flight 103 in December, according to Administration officials.

title: Patents; Space Station Structure
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration won patent approval this week for part of the structural skeleton of a space station. The skeleton, which consists of struts connected in a latticework of squares and tetrahedrons, would be outside the station's pressurized housing and would be used to mount monitoring instruments and other equipment. The inventor, Clarence J. Wesselski, said the skeleton could be folded compactly into the space shuttle and then expanded when erected in space. Mr. Wesselski received patent 4,805,368, assigned to NASA.

title: Esterline Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $254,000 for the latest quarter and $468,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: Methode Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Huffy Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago quarter and year share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effective July 1, 1988. The company said the latest year results included sales of $17,280,000 from its Raleigh Cycle Co. unit, which was sold in October 1988. The latest year also included losses of $5,721,000, representing a loss from the sale of Raleigh and operating losses. In 1987, Raleigh had sales of $37,603,000 and a loss of $233,000.

description: The bank attributed the lower fourth quarter net primarily to the increased short term interest rates for borrowings and deposits and an adjustment to the valuation of certain assets. It said the adoption of SFAS 91 reduced its 1988 net income by about $500,000.

title: Experts Look at Cargo Door As Likely Cause of Accident
description: Initial evidence suggests that mechanical or structural failure of a cargo door caused a gaping hole to be ripped in the skin of a United Airlines Boeing 747 in flight today, Federal officials said.

title: Photon Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Pesticides Termed High Cancer Risk for Children
description: An environmental group contends in a new report that preschool children are consuming chemicals in fruits and vegetables at levels that expose them to a risk of cancer many times greater than the Government considers safe.

title: Review/Television; A Play About Cockneys Who Speak in Verse
description: Steven Berkoff came into some prominence recently after directing ''Coriolanus'' at Joseph Papp's Public Theater. But it is not as if Mr. Berkoff has not been around for a while doing consistently good and often provocative work. As an actor he offered a shrewd portrait of Hitler on the mini-series ''War and Remembrance.'' And going back to the early 1980's, he has also been a playwright. His ''West,'' produced and directed by John Frankau in 1983 for Britain's Channel 4, can be seen on the ''Channel Crossings'' series on Channel 13 tomorrow night at 11 o'clock.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Today is the start of the free Muslim state of Afghanistan.'' - Sibgatullah Mojadedi, president of the government-in-exile. [ 1:4. ]

description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Theater; A Rising Nazi's Fall As Bad Parades as Good
description: William James once wrote that the difference between a good man and a bad one is the choice of a cause. John Halder, a mild-mannered professor of German literature, takes up the National Socialist Party.

title: Judge Accused of Bias Steps Down From Post
description: The chief administrative law judge of the New York State Division of Human Rights stepped down yesterday amid assertions that he had harassed a homosexual supervisor and made racially derogatory comments.

Bhopal Funds From Carbide
description: The Indian Supreme Court received $465 million today from the Union Carbide Corporation and its affiliate Union Carbide India Ltd. to compensate victims of the Bhopal disaster.

description: Afghan guerrilla leaders today proclaimed the birth of a ''free Muslim state'' and vowed that their newly chosen government-in-exile would be operating inside Afghanistan within a month, in a step toward what they hope will be the fall of the Soviet-backed regime in Kabul.

description: b-Net income

title: Tsepon W. D. Shakabpa, Tibetan Scholar, 82
description: Tsepon Wangchuk Deden Shakabpa, a Tibetan scholar and former Cabinet minister, died of stomach cancer Thursday at the home of a son in Corpus Christi, Tex. He was 82 years old and lived in New Delhi and Manhattan.

title: This Actor-Politician Says It's Bedtime for Bases
description: When Senator Joseph Estrada, a man with his eye on the presidency, was Mayor of San Juan, a suburb of Manila, the distinctions between his role in Government and his career as a popular movie tough guy sometimes blurred.

The company said preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in all periods.

title: U.S.-Canada Trade Talks Set
description: Canada and the United States are about to begin new trade negotiations after receiving requests from American and Canadian companies to accelerate tariff reductions on more than 50 goods, trade officials say.

title: Rise in Cleanup Cost Seen
description: The cost of cleaning up radioactive and toxic wastes at the Government's 12-state nuclear weapon complex is likely to exceed the official $63 billion estimate, a senior Energy Department official told Congress today.

title: For the Starving in the Sudan, There Is No Substitute for Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Klansman's Victory Poses Hard Questions for G.O.P. Head
description: For Lee Atwater, the Republican national chairman, the election of a former Ku Klux Klansman to the Louisiana State Legislature is an affront to his party and to his own effort to reach out for black votes. For Democrats, it is the ultimate expression of a two-decade-long Republican strategy to appeal to white resentment, a strategy perfected by Lee Atwater.

title: Prospects Best at Second for Jefferies
description: Gregg Jefferies, the rookie who roared into the National League last September, made his springtime debut in the camp of the Mets today and said that he would prefer to play third base instead of second. But Howard Johnson, the resident at third, who just escaped being traded to the Seattle Mariners, said in return, ''Nobody else will play third but me.''

title: Tests and Questions for Vandeweghe
description: Amid signs that he may have already made a good team better without even donning a uniform, Ernest Maurice (Kiki) Vandeweghe 3d spent his first full day as a Knick yesterday. He breezed through a full-scale physical examination, picked up his team jersey and endured his first full-court press, a crowded news conference at Madison Square Garden, with aplomb.

title: No. 1 Savings Unit Seeks Shift to F.D.I.C.
description: Registering a sharp protest to a key element of the Bush Administration's plan to bail out the savings and loan industry, the nation's largest savings institution said today that it had applied to join the deposit-insurance fund that covers banks.

title: CPC-Rexcel Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bank Agencies Defend Policies
description: Federal bank regulators rejected charges today that their policies discourage banks from forgiving part of the huge debt owed by developing countries.

title: Louis Collins, Executive, 74
description: Louis Collins, a retired president and chief executive officer of Crush International Inc., which produces Orange Crush and Hires Root Beer, died of a heart attack Thursday at his winter home in Naples, Fla. He was 74 years old and also lived in Park Ridge, Ill.

title: Farr Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a pretax charge of $457,000 from the sale of Canadian land.

title: McKenzie Ends Joyner-Kersee's Streak
description: Jackie Joyner-Kersee's winning streak ended. Diane Dixon kept hers in tact. Gwen Torrence took the first step toward a new one. And Marcus O'Sullivan of Ireland, the master of the indoor mile, lost at the distance for the first time this season.

title: 12 Slain in Bombay In Anti-Rushdie Riot
description: At least 12 people were killed and 40wounded when the police fired on Muslims rioting against ''The Satanic Verses'' in Bombay, birthplace of the novel's author, Salman Rushdie.

title: Bush Confers With Other Leaders After Funeral
description: President Bush concluded his visit to Tokyo this morning, meeting with other leaders on East-West relations and regional tensions and offering an upbeat assessment of relations with the Far East as he prepared to leave for China.

title: World-Wide Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago 9-month figures are not available because the company began operations Sept. 1, 1987.

title: Confession in Moldavia: They Speak Rumanian
description: Here in the tiny Republic of Moldavia, the Soviet authorities are quietly beginning to undo one of the great cultural hoaxes of the 20th century: the Moldavians.

title: Berry Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the decline in revenue and earnings was due principally to the sale of the company's Cypress property and 50 percent of its interest in the Rincon leases in the fourth quarter of 1987.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, the meaning of a sentence in an article Feb. 18 by Howard H. Hiatt and Cyrus Levinthal was altered. The sentence, about when life begins, should have read: ''Since the question of when that occurs cannot now be answered by science or, under our Constitution, by religion, we believe that for abortion decisions in the latter part of pregnancy, the courts should give the states leeway to set guidelines.''

title: Dantley Ends Holdout
description: Adrian Dantley, who reported to Dallas eight days after his trade from the Detroit Pistons for Mark Aguirre, received a standing ovation when he entered the Mavericks' game against Golden State with 3 minutes 50 seconds left in the first quarter last night.

title: Virginia Tightening Gun Law
description: The General Assembly passed a bill Thursday that would make Virginia the first state to require instant checkups on buyers of pistols with barrels shorter than 5 inches or assault rifles with ammunition clips of more than 20 rounds. Gov. Gerald L. Baliles has said he would sign the bill. The state police told legislators that a computerized search for records of felony convictions of Virginia residents could be made in the course of a telephone call. Out-of-state residents would have to submit to a more complicated background check that could delay a purchase up to a week.

title: Mr. Bush's Pacific Overtures
description: President Bush would not have chosen to make a trip to Asia only five weeks after his Administration began. The timing was dictated by Emperor Hirohito's death. Thus the way to assess the President's trip is by its symbolic impact, and on that basis it has been highly useful. It reassures Japan, China and South Korea as to America's interest and it shows that Mr. Bush intends to play a strong role in Asian affairs.

title: Narcotics Officer's Gun Tied To the Killings of 3 Prostitutes
description: A sheriff's deputy has been arrested for investigation of murder in the deaths of three prostitutes last fall in South-Central Los Angeles, where at least nine prostitutes have been killed in the last four years, the police said today.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption on Thursday about New York City's efforts to begin recycling misstated the office held by Sheldon S. Leffler. Mr. Leffler, a Democrat from Queens, is a City Councilman, not an Assemblyman.

title: National Gypsum Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest fourth quarter loss included a $12.9 million gain resulting from a revision of the estimated loss on the sale of the company's American Olean Tile Co. unit and an extraordinary loss of $978,000 from debt repurchases. The latest year results included a $64 million loss from the sale of American Olean Tile, and extraordinary net gains of $35.1 million from sale of securities and $4 million from repurchases of outstanding debt issues. The year-ago quarter and year results included extraordinary gains from debt repurchases of $6.6 million for the quarter and $8.2 million for the year; the year also included an $8.4 million one-time charge from refinancing transactions. The year-ago quarter and year results are restated to reflect the reclassification of American Olean Tile as discontinued operations and the reclassification of cash flow information in accordance with FASB No. 95. National Gypsum is a unit of privately-held Aancor Holdings Inc.
