title: Official Says Judge's Brother Got Special Aid
description: A Criminal Court judge in Manhattan gave special treatment to the brother of a New York Federal judge last month, court records and an account by the borough's District Attorney indicate.

title: The Shout From Central America; There: Progress, Despite the U.S. Policy Gap
description: Whenever Washington stops paying attention to Central America, one or more of the warring parties always seems to take a big step toward peace. Now it has happened again, this time with the Bush Administration barely functioning in foreign affairs. Political and guerrilla leaders have outdone themselves with promising new proposals.

title: Around The Garden
description: For This Week: Keep up with seed planting, especially flowers such as impatiens, begonias, petunias and blue salvia, which need a head start indoors; wait a few weeks to plant indoors seed of vegetables such as peppers, eggplants and tomatoes. Tubers of begonias and caladiums can be started indoors, too, to form roots; use a mixture rich with peat moss so it retains moisture. An Early Flower

title: NONFICTION
description: OFF ON A WILD CABOOSE CHASE: True Adventures, Folklore, and a Farewell Tribute to the Old Train Caboose by a Writer Who Lives Aboard One. By Adolf Hungry Wolf. (Morrow, $17.95.) The enthusiasms of the rail fan, like a taste for olives, are not readily communicated to the uninitiated. To most people, the romance of the rails means the lure of travel and faraway places. For the rail fan, the faraway places mostly serve as a backdrop for the machines, which he regards with a fondness most reserve for babies or pet cats. Adolf Hungry Wolf, a rail fan to the core, is a former railroad fireman who lives with his family in a collection of old cabooses in the Canadian Rockies. ''Off on a Wild Caboose Chase,'' his disquisition on the vanishing caboose (now rendered obsolete by technology) and other bits of railroadiana, may interest other train freaks but will likely reinforce the general reader's impression that these guys are pretty weird. Many of the stories are of the loyal-dog-awaits-deceased-master variety, told in a gee-whiz manner that quickly cloys. The photographs, normally a train book's glory, are depressingly muddy. On the plus side, Mr. Hungry Wolf does have a few teen-age disaster stories that will warm the heart of any former adolescent who ever wreaked havoc on a summer job. Like the time he was too late relaying a signal and sent a freight car rolling off the Los Angeles docks into the Pacific Ocean. A few more such stories and a little more restraint in the matter of exclamation points and this book would be easier to recommend.

title:
SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
Baseball Song: Sympathy for the Rabbit
description: LEAD: On Tuesday the Veterans Committee will announce whether it has found any old-timers worthy of enshrinement in the Baseball Hall of Fame.

title: Restoring Heirlooms to Ready to Wear
description: EVELYN SIEFERT KENNEDY washes heirlooms in her bathtub, shores up shredded silk, hides horrible stains, and - using herbal teas - dyes new lace to match old. Her mission is to get the clothes of past decades ready to wear now.

title: The Sun Rises for Soviet Jews
description: LEAD: I remember October 1965. I will always remember it. Gathered in front of the Great Synagogue in Moscow's Archipova Street, a dense crowd resonated with the excitement of the songs that emerged from the depths of its tormented memory. This was Simhath Torah: Jews everywhere joyfully celebrated the Law.

title: Welcome or Not, D'Amato Is a Presence in Local Politics
description: SENATOR ALFONSE M. D'AMATO has been called ''the pothole Senator'' because of his attention to the minutiae of New York's local issues and Republican politics. But with the New York Republican Party often divided and floundering with few recent election victories to savor, some G.O.P. leaders say that Mr. D'Amato may be doing more to deepen the party's rut than to repair it.

title:
ART;
A Quietness Pervades Surreal Works by Three Photographers
description: LEAD: ''STILL SURREAL,'' the title of a photography exhibition at the Sarah Lawrence College Art Gallery here, has, it seems, a double import. It means that Surrealism is still continuing after all these years but it might also refer to the eerie quietness that pervades the work of the three featured photographers.

title: Miss Dunn to Wed Lieut. Col. Charles Steiner Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. James P. Dunn of Pound Ridge, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Mary Dunn, to Lieut. Col. Charles R. Steiner Jr., U.S.A., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Steiner of Toledo, Ohio. An April wedding is planned.

title: Measles Defense
description: An outbreak of measles at two schools belonging to the E.C.A.C. North Altlantic Conference has led officials to bar spectators from the conference basketball playoffs at the Hartford Civic Center next month. ''You have to put it into the act-of-God category,'' C. Donald Cook, the athletic director of the University of Hartford, said Friday after he and other athletic directors met in Boston with the conference commissioner, Stu Haskell.

title: Youth's Release in Shooting Irks School and Prosecutor
description: A state prosecutor and Bridgeport's schools superintendent were fuming after learning that a 15-year-old youth was released by the police here shortly after a gun he is accused of taking to basketball practice went off, wounding another student.

title: Successes in Affirmative Action
description: THE board of trustees of the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, meeting Feb. 9, voted unanimously to take strong issue with the New Jersey Opinion page article by State Senator Ronald L. Rice on Feb. 5. The article contains serious distortions about the university's service to the minority community.

title:
LIFE STYLE;
Parrots, Urban Pets of the Moment
description: LEAD: Stuart Blay was nervous. At the Bird Jungle, a Greenwich Village bird shop, the 35-year-old sculptor was contemplating his white cockatoo, Lady, who was being boarded there. A flirtatious male bird was nibbling her ear.

title: Trends in Taste Come and Go, but There's No Place Like Home
description: A GREAT deal of attention is being paid these days to what is called nostalgia food. The homey staples of childhood have become chic.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Yale University; Cure for February: Just One Party After Another
description: February always seems to be the cruelest month, a cold, slushy torment of flu and midterms between the winter holidays and spring break. For undergraduates at Yale College, however, February is not a total loss.

title: Seeing Zambia, Wart Hogs and All
description: IT is the sense of intimacy with the landscape that lingers - climbing down river bank chutes carved by hippos' bellies, uncovering the speckled eggs of the water dikkop bird, or the delicate trace of a crocodile's tail etched in the warm sand.

title: Educators Assess Black History Efforts
description: THE observance of Black History Month each February has succeeded in teaching Westchester residents about black contributions to history, but many public schools should do more to include a black historical perspective throughout the year, some local educators say.

title: Review/Ballet The Donetsk 'Giselle' Presents a New Cast
description: The Donetsk Ballet, which concludes its brief engagement this afternoon in New York, offered a new cast in 'Giselle'' Friday night. Marina Leonkina, who had not been featured on the company's previous performances at the City Center (131 West 55th Street) made her local debut in the title role and scored nothing short of a triumph.

title: And Now Pitching for Cuba: Castro; Batting for Reds: Rose
description: After finishing second for four successive seasons, Pete Rose would like to finish first this year. But after his team finishes first, he has another desire. If he fulfills that one, it would result in a meeting of the managers of the two largest contingents of Reds in the Westen Hemisphere.

title: Paris Fashions
description: To the Editor:

title: AT DARTMOUTH THE CLASH OF '89
description: TWO DAYS INTO THIS YEAR, ON JAN. 3, A NEW Hampshire judge ordered Dartmouth College to reinstate two suspended students. Chris Baldwin, former editor in chief of The Dartmouth Review, and John Sutter, executive editor, were suspended last spring for disorderly conduct, harassment and invasion of privacy. The central incident in the case was a classroom confrontation between four Review staff members and a Dartmouth music professor, William Cole, whom The Dartmouth Review has frequently attacked. The Committee on Standards, the school's disciplinary board, found Baldwin guilty ''because he initiated and persisted in a vexatious oral exchange with Professor Cole, despite Professor Cole's repeated requests to leave his classroom.''

title:
HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: FAST FORWARD;
From Screen To Store, In a Hurry
description: LEAD: When is a feature film rushed onto videocassette? Sometimes when it's a spectacular success, and its distributor hopes to capitalize on its popularity (e.g. ''Dirty Dancing''). And sometimes when it's an unexpected flop, and its distributor hopes to at least recoup some losses (e.g. ''The Good Mother'').

title: A New Focus on a Worsening Housing Crisis
description: COUNTY officials seeking solutions to a worsening homeless crisis are looking anxiously to Washington for some help from the office of Jack Kemp, the new Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, for increased financing and new legislation.

title: Enlightened and Refined, By Meets Girl
description: FOR many single adults, the notion of meeting a mate at a bar or on a blind date is distasteful. But without a partner, they often feel they cannot do some of the things they would like to, like go to concerts and plays.

title: HISTORY IN FLAGRANTE DELICTO
description: FROM: THE PRESIDENT Richard Nixon's Secret Files. Edited by Bruce Oudes. 661 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $22.50.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I am having a constant problem with the sliding wooden doors on my closet. The plastic wheels are supposed to slide along in a metal track fastened to the top of the door jamb. Mine seem to have come off the track, so it is almost impossible to move the doors unless I pick them up.

title: WILD MAN OF THE GLOBAL VILLAGE
description: LEAD: LAWS OF MEDIA The New Science. By Marshall McLuhan and Eric McLuhan. 252 pp. Toronto: University of Toronto Press. $27.50.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Tradition Falls as a Fairview Tower Rises
description: LEAD: UNLIKE neighboring communities in southeast Bergen County, Fairview was long a holdout against high-rise apartment houses.

title: After a Pause, Writers Stood Up for Rushdie and Themselves
description: FOR a dictator to want to kill a person for his opinions is as old as political power itself.

title: A Church's Turmoil
description: The teachings of Vajradhatu, a branch of Tibetan Buddhism with 3,500 to 5,000 followers in the United States, Canada and Europe, do not prohibit homosexuality or sex with more than one partner. But the religious group has been shaken over accusations that its leader, Osel Tendzin, regent of the Vajradhatu International Buddhist Church, knew he had AIDS and transmitted it to his sexual partners. Members of the congregation, founded 18 years ago in Boulder, Colo., said Mr. Tendzin's male companion unknowingly passed the virus to a woman.

title: Section 1 Part 2
description: New: Reports from the nation's campuses on what students are thinking, eating and wearing.

title: U.S. Team to Inspect Soviet Mental Hospitals
description: A team of American experts will begin a long-awaited visit to Soviet mental hospitals next week to determine if political dissidents are still imprisoned there, American and Soviet officials said today.

title: Partnerships Weave Security Blankets for Working Parents
description: Having considered a child-care bill for the last 20 years without much progress, the Federal Government may not pass any of the 150 measures now before Congress anytime soon, especially in light of the budget deficit. But state initiatives to bolster child care are on the rise, and in many cases, are partnerships with industry.

title: 'People Power' Revolution Is Commemorated in Manila
description: President Corazon C. Aquino joined a crowd of tens of thousands today in commemorating the 1986 revolt that swept her to power. She also heard the Archbishop of Manila assail corruption.

title: 'Red Star Over China'
description: To the Editor:

title: CAMPUS LIFE: University of Texas; 'Paper Chase' Is Giving Way To 'L.A. Law'
description: Forget about justice. Forget about helping oppressed people. Mark Yudof, the dean of the University of Texas Law School, describes what he calls the ''glamour theory'' of why more students are applying to law school these days.

title: Along The East-West Fault Line, Signs of Stress as Ideology Erodes
description: Western European policy makers and academic specialists believe that momentous changes are unfolding in Eastern Europe that could ultimately undermine the Soviet Union's hold on several nations and recast the continent's balance of power.

title: Joan Little, Tried for Killing Jailer In 1974, Is Arrested in New Jersey
description: Joan Little, whose trial and acquittal in the 1974 slaying of a North Carolina jail guard roused worldwide attention and controversy, was arrested Friday by the Port Authority police in Jersey City for driving a car with a stolen license plate, among other charges, the authorities said yesterday.

title: What Television Can't Do
description: To the Editor:

title: A CHILDHOOD COLD AND WET
description: THE COUNTRY I COME FROM By Maura Stanton. 106 pp. Minneapolis: Milkweed Editions. Paper, $9.95.

title: Historical Group's Role in Book Project
description: The article on the recently completed Livingston Papers publication project (''About Books,'' Jan. 22) was a gratifyingly thorough account of a 14-year effort that involved many talented and dedicated people and provided the historical community with an invaluable new resource.

title: Tufts to Divest All Its South Africa Holdings
description: Tufts University will divest itself of all its holdings in businesses operating in South Africa, university officials announced late today.

title: Jay Leno: Not Just Another Funny Face (Feb. 26, 1989)
description: THEY LAUGHED WHEN JAY LENO said, ''President Bush is starting to get tough. Last week he said he wouldn't tolerate cost overruns from defense contractors. So from now on if the Pentagon wants to get sophisticated weapons, they're going to have to go down and buy 'em at the gun shop like everybody else.''

title: Welcome, but Pas at Your Own Risk
description: ''ROAD Under Construction. State Liability Limited. Pass at Your Own Risk.''

title: Growing Old Together In 'The Eighties'
description: ''I'M slowing up,'' She says wearily. ''I'm bored,'' He responds.

title: Agents, and System, Are Going on Trial
description: In a case that promises to provide a window into the abuses of big-time sports in higher education, two sports agents go on trial Wednesday in United States District Court in Chicago. They are accused of inducing college athletes to sign professional contracts in violation of National Collegiate Athletic Association rules, and of threatening harm to some athletes who wanted out of the deals.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: TUNGSTEN. By Cesar Vallejo. Translated by Robert Mezey. Preface by Kevin O'Connor. (Syracuse University, $19.95.) Set in the desolate tungsten-mining country of the Peruvian highlands during World War I, ''Tungsten'' is a Marxist retelling of a familiar story of economic imperialism, class struggle, racism and sexism.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: AMERICA'S GLASS Twentieth-century American glass, pottery and china are featured in the second annual show by the Mountain Laurel Depression Glass Club of Newington. ''So many American glassmakers have gone out of business,'' said the chairman of the show, William Dunn. ''What remains is becoming very rare.''

title: White House Outlines Drive To Save Tower Nomination
description: President Bush and John G. Tower began a public relations effort today to salvage Mr. Tower's nomination as Defense Secretary. Meanwhile, White House aides hastily drafted a summary of a dozen findings by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in an attempt to show that allegations about Mr. Tower's drinking and personal life were unfounded.

title: WHY STREET PEOPLE RE LIKE CANARIES
description: LEAD: CITY Rediscovering the Center. By William H. Whyte. Illustrated. 386 pp. New York: Doubleday. $24.95.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Columbia University; A Bar Closes, And So Does A Swinging Era
description: When the West End Cafe closed last November, customers mourned the loss of a bar and restaurant where generations of Columbia University students had enjoyed ice-cold drinks and red-hot jazz. ''It was a fun place,'' said Rob Stephen, a junior from Salt Lake City. ''It was good because they had free popcorn, too.''

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: ROCK ME. By Marcelle Clements. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) A surprisingly disappointing first novel by a respected journalist, ''Rock Me'' suffers from so many time-battered cliches that I had to consider, midbook, that it might be a parody. I was wrong. Casey, a burned-out rock star approaching 40, retreats from New York to Hawaii to recover from liquor, drugs and fame, and to review her checkered past, which began with the Ex-Lovers, the band she started in prep school in the 1960's.

title: HOME IS WHERE THE DEATH SQUADS ARE
description: A CASUAL BRUTALITY By Neil Bissoondath. 376 pp. New York: Clarkson N. Potter/Crown Publishers. $18.95.

title: Election's Weight
description: Special elections to fill vacancies in state legislatures seldom turn heads, but the one last weekend in an affluent, nearly all-white suburb of New Orleans had heads shaking across the country. With a huge turnout of 78 percent of the electorate, David Duke, a former grand wizard of the Ku Klux Klan running under the Republican banner, won the legislative seat in Metairie by 234 votes out of the 16,688 cast. He beat John Treen, a Republican who had been endorsed by President Bush. The Republican national chairman, Lee Atwater, repudiated Mr. Duke, calling him ''a pretender, a charlatan and a political opportunist.'' Mr. Duke said he was ''just as much a Republican as Mr. Atwater.'' Democrats, eager to make the most of their opponents' discomfort, said the election was the result of longstanding Republican efforts to take advantage of hostility toward blacks among some white voters.

title: Ethics - In and Out of the Classroom
description: The article, ''The Tough Job of Teaching Ethics'' (Jan. 22), prompted an unusually strong response from readers. Some of their comments follow. To the Editor:

title: YOU TELL ME YOURS, I'LL TELL YOU MINE
description: THE CALL OF STORIES Teaching and the Moral Imagination. By Robert Coles. 212 pp. Boston: A Peter Davison Book/ Houghton Mifflin Company. $18.95.

title: Indoor Pollution: Other Views
description: New Jersey doesn't have enough real problems for legislators to address! We don't need to fix the auto insurance mess. We don't need to stop the sexual transmission of AIDS. We don't need to force an independent audit of waste in autonomous authorities. We don't need real progress in the fight against drugs. State Senator John H. Dorsey thinks we need consciousness-raising legislation to protect us from the 45 chemical-spraying aerosol cans we have in our homes! (''A Hazard at Home: Air Pollution,'' Opinion page, Jan. 15.) If Senator Dorsey is pleased with the Senate-approved legislation to fight public ignorance of the indoor air pollution problem, perhaps he can cite the number of New Jersey deaths that could be attributed to such pollution? Perhaps the State Health Department can? Or would they rather get funds to inform the public about the hazards already described on the outside of those containers?

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Hampden Township, Pa.;
Projects Bestir A Sleepy Lane
description: LEAD: ORRS BRIDGE ROAD, once a quiet country lane winding past farms and a creek in Hampden Township, is abuzz with residential construction.

title: Artistic Ambiguity
description: Merce Cunningham hopes his dances speak for themselves, and he hesitates to explain them. Thus, when asked recently why he used the word ''cargo'' in the title of ''Cargo X,'' the choreographer said, ''It's just a word. I picked it.'' But why? ''It provokes something,'' he finally acknowledged. ''It's a poetic, ambiguous word. And X, of course, can stand for the unknown quantity.''

title: TIME INC. MEANS BUSINESS
description: J. RICHARD MUNRO COMES NATURALLY to the nice-guy ebullience he has projected in his 31-year career at Time Inc. But ask him about the chances that his company will be taken over, and the chairman and chief executive bristles like the ex-Marine he is:

title: Rushdie Novel Stirs Passions East and West; Gandhi Saved Lives
description: To the Editor:

title: Paris Fashions
description: To the Editor:

title: Colonial Waters Returns in Style
description: The last time Colonial Waters took an eight-month vacation from the races, she returned in a seemingly impossible spot but cruised to victory in a Florida stakes races. Today, she did it again.

title: Building Anew in the Yucatan
description: IT is a cruel and sardonic god, the Mayan rain diety Chaac, who rules over the Yucatan Peninsula of Mexico. Five months ago he unleashed his fury in the form of Hurricane Gilbert, wreaking devastation on the glorious white beaches, coral reefs and hotels and restaurants that have long lured visitors to the resorts of Cancun and the nearby island of Cozumel. It will take years, perhaps decades, to repair some of the damage to nature. But visitors to Cancun can once again pump up at Gold's Gym, have a Domino's pizza delivered to the hotel room or swim up to the palapa bar at the rebuilt Ramada Renaissance Hotel and sip a rum-and-brandy concoction from a watermelon cut into the shape of a penguin.

title: Iran Election Set for August; Test Between Factions Seen
description: Iran will hold presidential elections in August, the Islamic Republic News Agency reported today.

title: Paris Fashions
description: To the Editor:

title: A Federal Introduction to the Homeless
description: AS a nine-term conservative Republican Congressman, Jack F. Kemp voted consistently against assistance for the homeless. But now, as the new Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Mr. Kemp is proclaiming himself a champion of the homeless. To that end, he left Washington last week for an overnight tour of soup kitchens and shelters in Baltimore and Philadelphia.

title: Kayoko Mizuno to Marry
description: Kayoko Mizuno and Michael Andrew Hunter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Hunter Sr. of Stratford, Conn., plan to marry in June, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Akira Mizuno of Nagoya, Japan, have announced. Miss Mizuno, who graduated from the Kunitachi College of Music in Japan, is studying eurythmics at the Dalcroze School of Music in New York. The bridegroom, who expects to receive a medical degree in May at Yale University, graduated from Harvard University.

title: Q and A
description: The 80/20 Co-op Rule

title: Camera
description: The notion of changing cameras must be in the air. Last week two friends asked me to recommend new models that would suit their needs better than their current gear. Both want to upgrade from 10-year-old cameras to something more contemporary.

title: Week's Concerts Come in Threes
description: GOOD things often come in threes, and this week offers a trio each of piano recitals, vocal programs and orchestral concerts.

title: Jody Bier Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard H. Bier of Riverdale, the Bronx, have made known the engagement of their daughter Jody Ann Bier to Robert L. Lawrence, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sherman S. Lawrence of Roslyn, L.I. Ms. Bier, an account executive at WCBS-TV in New York, graduated from the Bronx High School of Science and Cornell University. Mr. Lawrence, a partner at the New York law firm of Kane, Kessler, Proujansky, Tullman, Preiss & Nurnberg, graduated from Johns Hopkins University, where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, and received a J.D. degree at the Columbia University School of Law. An April wedding is planned.

title: Question Of the Week; Did Babe Ruth Call His Shot?
description: Did George Washington really chop down a cherry tree? Did Colin Kelly really dive his plane into a Japanese warship? What's the difference? Ruth's called shot, too, is part of American lore. JIM KENSIL Massapequa, L.I.

title: A HEAVY SCHEDULE OF PILGRIMAGES
description: THE WHITE CUTTER By David Pownall. 320 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

title: Leonard Is in Duran's Sights
description: Roberto Duran, 37 years old, but splendly agile at 156 1/4 pounds, turned into a nemesis for Iran Barkley Friday night by winning a split decision and taking Barkley's World Boxing Council middleweight title. Then Duran, the only fighter to beat Sugar Ray Leonard, turned his attention to Leonard, who beat Duran in their famous ''no mas'' rematch almost nine years ago.

title:
DANCE;
A Glimpse of 'Sleeping Beauty'
description: LEAD: TAKE a deep breath and get ready to sigh. ''Sleeping Beauty'' is coming to town. The New Jersey Ballet Company will present Act III of this much loved ballet on Friday and Saturday at Raritan Valley Community College, in North Branch, in two evenings of all-classical dance.

The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) WHY DID THE HEAVENS NOT DARKEN? The ''Final Solution'' in History, by Arno J. Mayer. (Pantheon, $27.95.) The author, a distinguished historian at Princeton, describes an anti-Communist alliance of upper-class social anti-Semites and Nazi racial theorists in the years leading to the Holocaust; the actual decision to proceed, he believes, came as late as 1941-42. JOHN DOLLAR, by Marianne Wiggins. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) A quirky, provocative historical novel in which a group of British would-be Robinson Crusoes encounter cannibals, leaving their surviving children - girls only - to re-create a civilization. THE PRICE OF EMPIRE, by J. William Fulbright with Seth P. Tillman. (Pantheon, $17.95.) This distillation of Senator Fulbright's critical reflections at 83 examines America's errors and suggests reforms - including a parliamentary system. NO MAN'S LAND: The Place of the Woman Writer in the Twentieth Century. Volume Two: Sexchanges, by Sandra M. Gilbert and Susan Gubar. (Yale University, $29.95.) In this installment of their study, two scholars examine the ''modern literary asymmetry'' between men's lapse into misogynist hysteria (''She,''

title: But We Are Free?
description: Salman Rushdie can see no end to the terror called up by the Ayatollah Khomeini. For the rest of us in the Western world, there is an answer to intolerance and fanaticism. That is to understand our own values, and accept the responsibility of defending them.

title: Help for Yellowstone Elk Is Being Planned
description: The director of the National Park Service viewed herds of elk dying of starvation today and said he hoped to unveil a plan soon to alleviate their suffering.

title: Fashions of The Times/Magazine Part 2
description: Special reports in this issue include:

title: Global-Warming Panel Urges Gas Tax in West
description: Delegates at a conference on global warming have recommended steps to deal with the problem that emphasize the responsibilities of poor as well as rich nations.

title: New Procedures On Unemployment Pay
description: From the tone of a recent article by Norma Miller, ''The Benefits of Unemployment'' (Opinion page), it sounds as if Ms. Miller's experience was not too terrible. Nor was it very recent, since we had to close our office at 615 Nye Avenue in Irvington in June 1987 because of budgetary consideration.

title: DEWARE OF JUSTICE, TRUTH AND BEAUTY
description: ANY OLD IRON By Anthony Burgess. 360 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95.

title: Review/Opera; New Mimi in Metropolitan 'Boheme'
description: ''La Boheme'' returned to the Metropolitan Opera in poorish health Friday evening. Good elements were on hand, and one went anticipating a good result, but the chemistry was not right.

title: Drop-Dead Clothes Make the Working Woman
description: In the movies, on television, even in the theater - women finally have careers. Not just jobs - like the job as an art gallery drone that miraculously supported Jill Clayburgh in ''An Unmarried Woman.'' These women are real, honest-to-god professionals - lawyers, professors, editors, business executives.

title: Question Of the Week; Did Babe Ruth Call His Shot?
description: In 1969, while I was a roving radio sports reporter for several suburban New York radio stations, I had the pleasure of interviewing Pat Piper at Wrigley Field in Chicago. Piper was the public-address announcer at Wrigley and had performed those duties at that ball park for more than 50 years. I posed the same question to the now-deceased Pat Piper: ''Did Babe Ruth call that famous shot?''

title: DATA UPDATE: February 26, 1989
Focus on Teamwork, Vision and Values
description: Charisma is our elixir. We swallow it as a cure-all for what ails us. Nowhere is this more apparent than in our companies. It shows up even in the way we use language. We say we want leaders for our corporations, not mere managers.

title: Article 589689 -- No Title
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Assembling Brooklyn's Hispanic History
description: The Brooklyn Historical Society, which adopted its new name and changed its focus to emphasize the people who live in the borough now rather than those who originally peopled it, has embarked on an ambitious project to present the first full picture of Brooklynites with Latin roots.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Reviving West Hartford's Retail Enclave
description: WEST HARTFORD'S evolution from farming to affluent suburb began in 1854 when it broke away from Hartford and incorporated. Its current population of 61,000 has been well-served by several shopping centers; a few reliable industries, including Pratt-Whitney, Coleco and Colt Firearms, help keep the tax rate from becoming burdensome.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE BOY WHO COULDN'T STOP WASHING: The Experience & Treatment of Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder. By Judith L. Rapoport. (Dutton, $18.95.) There is Morris, the 18-year-old who scrubbed his arms and hands for 60 minutes each morning with Top Job or Mr. Clean; Paul, who would get ''stuck'' in a doorway for hours before he could enter a room; Jackie, who was compelled to pull out her hair, strand by strand, until she was bald.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: SUNKEN RED. By Jeroen Brouwers. Translated by Adrienne Dixon. (New Amsterdam, $15.95.) This haunting novel, reprinted nine times in the Netherlands since it was first published in 1981, is based on the Dutch writer Jeroen Brouwers's childhood concentration-camp imprisonment in Japanese-occupied Indonesia during World War II - and the traumatic impact of that experience on his adult life.

title: Top Tapes: Top Values?
description: Is there any point in buying premium tapes? Does it make enough difference to justify the cost?

title: State Preparing to Act on Full Landfills
description: THE East Haven landfill was filled to capacity more than two years ago, but the town continues to use it. ''We're in the same boat as a lot of other towns at this point,'' Mayor Robert M. Norman said.

title: College Prospects Deserve Chance
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some of the most notable releases of the last few months.

title: On Hand for the Civil War and Manifest Destiny
description: IF there were such a category as ''Found Earthworks,'' the print ''Granite Canyon, From the Water Tank'' might qualify for it. Photographed by Andrew Joseph Russell (1831-1876), it is said by some reference books to be the Union Pacific Railroad heading west from Cheyenne, Wyo., no doubt for Promontory Point in Utah, where it was joined to the Central Pacific line in 1869.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: HULLABALOO IN OLD JEYPORE: The Making of ''The Deceivers.'' By Ismail Merchant. (Doubleday, $24.95.) Given the budgets, egos, logistics and sheer numbers of people involved in even the most inconsequential film, it is no wonder that the making of a movie seems like an epic adventure itself. The mishaps of filming and the off-screen activities of the stars have long filled gossip columns.

title: MORE THAN A BIMBETTE - YOU BET
description: THE FORTUNE By Michael Korda. 481 pp. New York: Summit Books. $19.95.

title: Electrician Held in Fatal Fire
description: An electrician was arrested Friday and charged with manslaughter in a fatal fire that the authorities said began in a baseboard heater that he had installed improperly.

title: Philadelphia Alters Its Plan to Ease Jail Crowding
description: Mayor W. Wilson Goode has set aside plans to build a courthouse and prison complex because the proposal has already cost the city $30 million and produced little but disagreement and a hole in the ground at City Hall.

title:
PASTIMES: GARDENING;
How Much Value Do Trees Add to Property?
description: LEAD: A homeowner will often pay an additional $3,000 to $5,000 more for a home because there are trees on the property. Wooded lots in new subdivisions will often sell for thousands more than adjacent lots without trees. Often, these wooded lots are the first to sell in a region, despite the higher prices.

title: The Hard Truth About Soft Money
description: MONETA WAS THE cult title of the Roman goddess Juno, in whose temple coins were stamped out; that's where the word >money comes from. The root of much evil, however, is in the modifiers of >money - the adjectives that sow such confusion that you have to flip a coin to decide their meanings. >Funny money is clear: counterfeit. >Tight money is equally specific: money that is costly to borrow, coming from a policy aimed at stifling inflation; the opposite is >easy money or >cheap money, when the money supply is increased by the central bank to commercial banks, and loans are available at low interest rates.

title: Anne-Louise Waskiewicz Is Engaged
description: The engagement of Anne-Louise Waskiewicz to Gregory William Benning has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Leon Edward Waskiewicz of Suffield, Conn. Mr. Benning is a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Arthur Benning of Malvern, Pa. The wedding is planned for April 22.

title: PERSPECTIVES: Business Parks; 'Master Developer' Sought for a Frontier
description: IF New York City can be said to have an unsettled frontier, it surely is in the flat outer reaches of western Staten Island, inland from the Arthur Kill, the waterway between Staten Island and New Jersey.

title: Waiting for the Bus, A Cherished Time
description: WHEN my son was born five years ago, and I decided to work from home, I thought that my days of shivering in the cold while waiting at a bus stop were behind me.

title: Panel Denies Parole Despite New Doubts Over Inmate's Trial
description: A man whose conviction for the slaying of a police officer was questioned in the documentary film ''The Thin Blue Line'' has been refused parole despite a state judge's strong backing.

title: America's Backyard Is Rich With Oil
description: In the aftermath of the 1973 oil embargo, the Federal Energy Administration published its Project Independence report. Energy self-sufficiency for the United States was ruled out as an impractical goal. Instead, the report adopted the more modest objective of reducing our vulnerability to oil import disruptions.

title: Limits to the Duty to Rescue
description: IT may be the most basic purpose of government, but a state's protection of citizens from one another is required by the Constitution in only a few circumstances. Last week, the Supreme Court decided that shielding a child from abusive parents is not one of them.

title: Child Abuse: The Interrogation Warning Signs
description: MY SON Benjamin was 2 1/2 years old, and I supposed he and his father were out having dinner somewhere, and I envied them. Me, I was stuck in the hospital, the intern covering the pediatric cardiology ward, feeling more than a little sorry for myself.

title: The Nassau Mounties
description: ''NO cans, no bottles, no weapons.'' The security guards repeatedly shouted the list of taboo items to the 17,000 teen-agers lined up outside the Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum.

title: Hearing Is Believing
description: To the Editor:

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: CHESTER'S LAST STAND. By Richard E. Brown. (University of Nevada, $17.95.) There's a funny story in this book. The problem is, it doesn't get told very well. And that's too bad because ''Chester's Last Stand'' has all the elements of a humorous Gothic novel. There's Chester, a disillusioned hobo, alone in the world and looking for work.

title: Three Rats
description: To the Editor:

title: A Restaurant Sums Up Capital's New Social Life
description: Dan and Marilyn Quayle and their children ate ribs there. Lee Atwater brought the Rolling Stones guitarist Ron Wood there after a night of boogying and jamming. And Representative Don Sundquist, a Tennessee Republican, is a general partner there.

title: A Hot Health Care Stock Cools
description: LEAD: When a small, fast-growing company reports even a minor disappointment, its stock can take a beating. That happened to the Healthcare Compare Corporation, a company based in Downers Grove, Ill., that specializes in helping employers control health costs.

title: Bush's Man And Mandate On the Line
description: HANGING like smoke above the debacle of John G. Tower's nomination to be Secretary of Defense is one central question: Who's really in charge here?

title: Suicide Prevention in Jails: A Lack of Rules
description: WHEN Louis Soto took his own life in the Englewood City Jail last month, a television monitoring system designed to keep detainees under constant observation had been inoperative for almost three months.

title: Miss Steinbreder Wed in Southport To M. A. Luciani
description: At Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn., Susan Gay Steinbreder, a daughter of Mrs. Harry J. Steinbreder Jr. of Fairfield, Conn., and the late Mr. Steinbreder, was married yesterday to Michael Angelo Luciani, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor A. Luciani of Fairfield. The Rev. Francis X. Cheney performed the ceremony. Gillett and Sarah Steinbreder, the bride's sisters, were the maids of honor, and William Francis Quinn was the best man.

title:
GARDENING;
The Two Sides of Sphagnum Moss
description: LEAD: IN his New York Botanical Garden Illustrated Encyclopedia of Horticulture, T. H. Everett described sphagnum moss as an ideal medium in which to sow seeds, because of its antiseptic qualities. Indeed, stories tell of its use as a dressing for wounds during World War I. One reason sphagnum has been considered to be quite sterile is that it has a pH level of 4.0 to 4.5, which is below the range in which most plant pathogens thrive.

title: ISLAND HOPPING
description: I'VE LIVED IN ST. THOMAS for a number of years, but my real introduction to Caribbean cooking began when I met Tijoe Ledee, a French West Indian fisherman. Sailors here never take an impending storm seriously until Tijoe moves his boat to safety in the nearby mangroves. When this occurs, all boats in the harbor are instantly moved to safety, hatches are battened down, candles and flashlights readied.

title: The 'I Hate Opera!' Challenge: Converting Youngsters
description: LEAD: THEY didn't send the Fat Lady. She's the woman who is supposed to come out and sing so loud everyone knows it's time to wake up and go home.

title: Kathryn Hess, Lawyer, to Wed in May
description: Kathryn Joan Hess, an associate in the Washington law office of Linowes & Blocker, and William Joseph Selle, an associate in the Landover, Md., law office of Blumenthal, Wayson, Downs & Offutt, plan to be married in May.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Brunch; All Around Manhattan
description: This is a summary of reviews by Bryan Miller of Manhattan restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. Cafe des Artistes

title: Schools Undertake Effort on Bias
description: LEAD: UNLIKE other areas of the country, Westchester's colleges and schools have not recently experienced violent clashes over race. But all forms of bias - racial, ethnic, religious, economic and sexual - do exist in the county's educational institutions, say administrators, teachers and students.

title: Gut Course: Introduction to Looting
description: THE reason SUNY campuses are situated near outlying small towns, some hugging the Canadian border, is for the same reason 16th-century pirates retreated into quiet, hidden coves after a session of pillage and plunder. An isolated, distant place is ideal for sorting, evaluating and arranging recently acquired previously owned treasure.

title: CHILDREN AFTER DIVORCE
description: I am from a small town in central Vermont. My parents divorced when I was 10 or 11. One sunny spring afternoon, my brother and I were sitting atop a hill near our home. We were waiting for my best friend to walk from his house to ours. He was to stay in our house for an entire week, while his parents were on vacation. We sat there talking; spring smelled so good. I remember the day and how I felt because it marked such a painful change in my life.

title: Policy Cuts Asylum Applications
description: So few people are applying for political asylum since the Government toughened procedures here in south Texas early this week that the Immigration and Naturalization Service is reducing the extra staff it brought in to start its new program.

title: Knicks Want Own Record
description: ''And now, let's greet the newest member of the Knicks, number 55, Kiki Vandeweghe.''

title: Caroline Slusser Is to Marry
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. W. Peter Slusser of New York and Windsor, Calif., of the engagement of their daughter Caroline Evelyn Slusser to Floyd McElroy Converse, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Chandler B. Converse of West Palm Beach, Fla. The couple plan to marry in May. Miss Slusser attended the Spence School and graduated from St. George's School in Newport, R.I., and Duke University. She is an account executive at TBWA Advertising in New York. Her father, who retired as a managing director of Paine Webber in New York, is the president of Slusser Associates, an investment banking company in New York.

title: Career and Family; An Elusive Balance
description: IT is 7:30 on a weekday morning as I stand in the bathroom of my home ready to leave for another day at the office. There I am, the picture of the professional woman, dressed in a business suit under a tan raincoat, briefcase in hand.

title: Pirates Hang On to Top Friars
description: With 10 minutes remaining in the first half at Byrne Meadowlands Arena today, Andrew Gaze had 17 points and Providence College 14. Since Gaze's Seton Hall teammates had supported him with 10 additional points, the situation was grim for the Friars.

title: Italy Convicts 7 in Bombing Of Train Fatal to 16 in 1984
description: A court today convicted seven people, including five organized crime figures, in a 1984 train bombing that killed 16 travelers and wounded more than 200.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: MARDI GRAS GALA For about six weeks now, the Long Island State Park Region has been holding a Winter Arts Festival at Bethpage State Park, an event that ends today with what is called a Mardi Gras Gala.

title: 3 Women Found Shot, 2 Fatally, in the Bronx
description: A bank clerk and two other women were each found handcuffed and shot in the head in the clerk's Bronx apartment Friday in what the police said yesterday may have been a retaliation killing over drug trafficking.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Stanford University; Houses Divided: 'Focus' Dorms Are Debated
description: Stanford University's 10 ''focus'' houses - dormitories set aside mainly for students of the same ethnic group or academic interest - have become the focus of a debate this semester. At issue is whether the separate living quarters are fostering diversity or segregation.

title:
DINING OUT;
A Romantic Air in Yorktown Heights
description: LEAD: SINCE early December, Panarda has taken over the attractive, remodeled roadside house last occupied by Elliott's. An offshoot of Roberto's in Tuckahoe, Panarda, like its parent restaurant, offers perfunctory Italian dishes that could and should be better. Nevertheless, Panarda has the advantage of atmosphere: a veranda where diners can sip their drinks and, ignoring the parking lot, look up at the moon; intimate lighting and romantic frosted candle lamps on every table; a free-standing central hearth aglow under a copper hood (more romance), and pretty peach linens playing against gray wall

title: New Jersey Q & A: Dennis Foy; Testing the Limits of Traditional Cuisine
description: FROM the time he was 14 years old, Dennis Foy knew he wanted to be a chef. A native of Philadelphia, he went from busing tables in a small northern Italian restaurant there to an apprenticeship in a restaurant that was owned by his brother, John. Dennis Foy moved to Summit in 1974, where he still lives.

title: L.I. Rebels Over Property-Tax Rises
description: Long Island residents, angry over property tax increases of almost 20 percent in most communities this year, are organizing grass-roots campaigns to roll back assessments and cut government spending.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Palm Beach
description: Palm Beach, the jewel of the American Riviera since the end of the 19th century, is valiantly resisting the coming of the 21st. The Old World sophistication that made the island distinctive is threatened by a booming mainland population.

title: INSIDE
description: Soviets Pressed on Rushdie

title: Rushdie Novel Stirs Passions East and West
description: To the Editor:

title: FACE VALUE
description: IN THE COSMETICS industry, a business built on image, simple products are often wrapped in elaborate packaging, given snappy names and big price tags and photographed next to alluring faces. Implicit in these advertisements is a promise that the product is at least partially responsible for the face, and that the face is something to strive for. Choosing that face has become increasingly important to cosmetics companies, many of which use a single model to convey their notions of beauty.

title: CORRECTION
description: A map on Feb. 19 with an article about flooding in southern Russia misidentified the body of water north of the Black Sea. It is the Sea of Azov, not the Aral Sea.

title: Somers Residents Frustrated as Two Spills Contaminate Wells
description: THE attention of residents here is focused on a gasoline spill and a separate hazardous-waste spill that are passing through the wells of about two dozen homeowners and businesses.

title: Family Dogs Attack 3-Year-Old
description: A 3-year-old girl left in a Brooklyn apartment with a younger child was mauled yesterday afternoon by four dogs belonging to her family while her grandmother was out buying milk, the police said.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Harvard University; How Freshmen Use Their Time: They Study
description: Harvard freshmen typically spend an hour more in class or studying every week than adults typically spend at work.

title: Heckscher Salutes Artistic Couple
description: LEAD: ''I LOVE the swashbuckling around the water,'' the painter Arthur G. Dove wrote in his diary in 1938, as he looked out his beloved house on the millpond in Centerport.

title: On the Road Again: Uneasy Riders
description: What kind of bounty hunter travels by train, pickup truck and Jeep? One who finds himself, on the flimsiest pretext, in a road movie. In MIDNIGHT RUN, just out on video (MCA Home Video, $89.95), Robert De Niro is the wisecracking, softhearted bounty hunter, and Charles Grodin the meek but wily white-collar criminal he captures. Sure, they're chased by the Mafia and shot at from a helicopter, but these shrewd actors bring comic elan to the two-guys-hit-the-road formula.

title: The Solitude Is Ending
description: Distant events no longer trickle slowly, slowly into the everyday. For a generation, Gabriel Garcia Marquez's novel ''100 Years of Solitude'' was a metaphor for the introverted, hopelessly closed circle of Latin America's societies, punctured now and then by clumsy, greedy incursions of the U.S. giant but still absorbent and self-sealing.

title: How to Take The Curse Off Convention Centers
description: Surely no building type is as disdainful of urban values as the convention center. Everything about a convention center flies in the face of what cities ought to be. To make a good one, you need vast amounts of horizontal space, far more than can fit on a single city block. So most convention centers end up stretching on for block after block, riding roughshod over any streets that are unlucky enough to fall in their path. And nothing is less wanted in all that exhibition space than natural light, meaning that these buildings are not only big boxes; they are big boxes without any windows. The typical convention center is like a beached whale on a city street - enormous, inert, and totally out of place.

title: What Awaits an Energy Secretary
description: OF all the challenges facing James D. Watkins, President Bush's nominee for Secretary of Energy, perhaps none is more difficult than the department's penchant for keeping secrets from itself.

title:
RECORDINGS;
Listening to Old Records With New Ears
description: LEAD: Recordings revive the sounds made by performers of earlier times, and sometimes their personalities, too. Harder to recapture is the effect of their music-making when it was fresh and innovative, when it sounded different from what people were used to hearing. With performers who spearheaded breakthroughs in virtuosity and expressivity that have since become standard equipment in every player's armory, such as the violinists of the turn of the century, we need a little historical perspective, a shift of focus away from present-day comparisons.

title: Switzerland
description: To the Editor: Having vacationed in Switzerland over 30 times during the past 30 odd years and having enjoyed many delightful meals in the top restaurants of main railway stations, my wife and I greatly enjoyed Mr. Shenker's article.

title: HYPOCRISY YOU CAN COUNT ON
description: THE INVISIBLE PLAYER By Giuseppe Pontiggia. Translated by Annapaola Cancogni. 259 pp. Hygiene, Colo.: Eridanos Press. Cloth, $23. Paper, $14.

title: Mergers Raise Fear for Angel Network
description: FEARS about the consequences of corporate mergers and buyouts extend beyond the business community. Priscilla H. Blum and Jay N. Weinberg, for example, who founded the Corporate Angel Network, worry about the consolidation of corporate fleets. Their nonprofit organization relies on those aircraft to transport about 60 cancer patients a month to major cancer centers across the nation.

title: AN AMERICAN BOY IN GANGLAND
description: BILLY BATHGATE By E. L. Doctorow. 323 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95.

title: Cowboys' Buyer Hires a New Coach
description: Tom Landry's career as the only coach the Dallas Cowboys had in 29 years ended tonight when an Arkansas oilman bought the team and made the University of Miami's Jimmy Johnson the coach.

title: Glasson Leads on Birdie at 18
description: Bill Glasson blasted into the 18th hole from a greenside bunker today for birdie 3 to take a one-shot lead into the final round of the $1.3 million Doral Ryder Open, the richest full-field tournament on the 1989 PGA Tour.

title: Barbados
description: To the Editor: It was a pleasure to learn in ''A Barbados Synagogue Is Reborn'' by Nancy Sharkey (Travel, Dec. 11) that the synagogue in Barbados is being restored to its original function and condition.

title: Young New Yorkers Turn Party-Giving Into Parties That Give
description: At some point this winter, maybe while she was striding past a homeless woman asleep on a subway platform, or watching a shivering panhandler near a cash machine, or listening, a bit skeptically, to a clown-costumed fund-raiser on the street, Melissa Mack decided it was time to have a party.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Bricktown $111,000 25 Brandywine Court 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 6-year-old condominium town house; central air-conditioning, eat-in kitchen, den, monthly maintenance $96; taxes $1,100. Freehold $218,000 42 Stratford Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 23-year-old colonial; full basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,923. Howell Township $154,000 104 Starlight Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 2-year-old contemporary; family room, cathedral ceiling in living room, eat-in kitchen; taxes $2,079. Lakewood $99,900 614 East Country Line Road 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 45-year-old colonial; enclosed front porch, renovated kitchen, 0.5 acre; taxes $1,400. Spring Lake $375,000 510 Washington Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 10-year-old Cape Cod; 1-car garage, c/a, w/w carpeting; taxes $2,820. Tinton Falls $173,000 5 Charles Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 3-year-old colonial; oak cabinets, 1-car garage, underground sprinklers; taxes $2,333. OTHER AREAS Williston Park, L.I. $193,000 12 Remsen Street 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; dining room, attic, basement; taxes $1,900. Killingworth, Conn. $285,000 85 Bar Gate Trail 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 6-year-old colonial, French doors off living room to terrace, tiered deck, 3 acres; taxes $3,074. Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. $372,000 22 Hyatt Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 38-year-old ranch; 20-foot-deck, 1 acre; taxes $6,290.

title: Distilling the Drama in the Building of the A-Bomb
description: In an article last Sunday about ''Day One,'' a TV drama about the building of the first atomic bomb, James F. Brynes was misidentified, and his involvement in the decision to drop the bomb on Japan was incorrectly described. He was Secretary of State under President Truman and argued in favor of using the bomb.

title: On the Sandinistas
description: To the Editor:

title: VANBIESBROUCK REGAINS FORM AND FIRST PLACE
description: Bad habits and a creeping sense of complacency have set John Vanbiesbrouck up for a fall. That the fall turned out to be a huge public flop only increased the impact of the embarrassment.

title: Chess
description: What is the right time limit for international chess? The purists have seen the traditional 40 moves in two and a half hours dwindle to 40 in two hours, but they don't want to see further cuts in thinking time.

title: House Calls to Help New York's Elderly Chinese
description: Ka-Lam Pang's world has shrunk to a single narrow room, barely wide enough to accommodate his bed. Bars set in the wall allow him to swing himself along in his wheelchair to reach the stove or sink when he is alone during the long shifts his wife works in a garment factory.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Fantasy While Falling

title: Prospects; As Interest Rates Climb
description: On Thursday, the nation's major banks raised their prime rates to 11.5 percent - the highest level in nearly five years. Then, on Friday, the Federal Reserve Board raised the discount rate to 7 percent, the highest level since May 1986. Four experts discuss how higher interest rates affect the economy. Arthur F. Brimmer President of Brimmer Associates and former member, board of governors of the Federal Reserve.

title: STREETSCAPES: The Inspiration Point Shelter; Restoration for an All-but-Ruined Hudson 'Temple'
description: THE roadside shelter at Inspiration Point, on the Henry Hudson Parkway and 190th Street, was built in 1925 as a destination point for promenaders and pleasure drivers.

title: In Borneo's Wilds, Legend Takes Root
description: ''I'm a romantic,'' says John Milius. He is standing on a cliff in Sarawak, above the Borneo jungle, fitting a stone to a slingshot that the Malays call ''pana'' and his Iban extras call ''la stika.'' The black-bearded writer-director of ''Farewell to the King,'' which opens on Friday at Loews Astor Plaza and 84th Street Six, is competing with his star, Nick Nolte, in trying to hit the tallest tree jutting up through a cloak of jungle fog whose milky opacity will keep Mr. Milius from filming on that day in October 1987 until the equatorial sun burns it off. ''For all its problems for a film maker, the jungle is a romantic place,'' Mr. Milius says.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: WHEN U.S. WELLS GO DRY;
Don't Count on 'Cooking With Gas'
description: LEAD: Is the United States vulnerable to another bout of natural gas shortages like the one we experienced in the 1970's? The answer is ''Yes.'' And if we had not had such a warm winter this year, the Northeast and the Middle Atlantic States probably would have been hit hard.

title: Paris Fashions
description: To the Editor:

title: Justice For Whom? Wife Fears For Safety
description: LEAD: WHEN she thinks, as she often does, of the day more than two years ago when her estranged husband plunged a kitchen knife into her 33 times, Cecilia Eagleston feels guilty to be alive. It is the thought of the three Long Island women murdered this winter by their husbands, who then committed suicide, and of Lisa Solomon, strangled by her husband, Matthew, last Christmas

title: Children Learn to Make Music
description: ON Saturday, about 15 high school students who ordinarily might be ice skating or shooting baskets will instead be learning how to write music with a jazz ensemble at Wesleyan University in Middletown.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
Some Innovations We Can Live With
description: LEAD: THE new year is 57 days old and already it's a disaster. Why? Has anyone invented a high-fiber, low-fat, low-carbohydrate, 23-calorie hot-fudge sundae? Or a computer that humans can operate? (Humans whose last technological triumph was mastering a 45-r.p.m. phonograph?) Or a pill to turn cellulite into hair?

title: Dana Friedman And Paul Kiesel To Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. K. Evan Friedman of New York and Lakeville, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dana Caryl Friedman, to Paul Robert Kiesel, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard L. Kiesel of Short Hills, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: Do-It-Yourself Customized Software
description: Computer-aided software engineering, or CASE, is a process that is supposed to simplify the creation and maintenance of computer software. It is just the type of help that is desperately needed by the many large businesses where the problem of maintaining, updating and fixing aging software has reached crisis proportions. Collectively, American businesses maintain 50 billion lines of custom computer code, and the maintenance alone siphons off 70 to 80 percent of all the dollars they spend on management information systems.

title: About Cars; A Fan and Vintage Wheels
description: It is late at night, and I have been talking to friends. As happens, the conversation turned to automobiles, and I started to hold forth on the cars I have always wanted and never had. They are a strange mix, and they say something of who I am - which is one of the important things that cars are supposed to do.

title: An Old Pitcher Who'll Never Die
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Nanci Grant Is a Bride
description: Nanci Jill Grant, a third-year law student at Wayne State University, and Mark Frankel, a lawyer in Southfield, Mich., were married last evening at Temple Israel in West Bloomfield, Mich., by Rabbi Steven Losh. The bride, the daughter of Probate Judge and Mrs. Barry M. Grant of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., graduated from the University of Michigan. Mr. Frankel, a graduate of Oakland University who received a J.D. from Wayne State, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Frankel of West Bloomfield. His father is a builder and developer.

title: THE NATION: Life Without Reagan; Conservatives Like Bush, but They're Watching Him
description: WITH President Bush trafficking liberally in liberal oratory about the good things government can do, one might wonder whether conservatives are feeling a bit uneasy. Certainly Mr. Bush sometimes seems to mix his signals. While Vice President Quayle reassured the faithful this weekend that Reagan-era policies were being carried forward, advocates for the homeless, for example, were being promised a change from the last eight years.

title: Investigation Is Expected to Focus on Cargo Door Latch
description: Among the first steps taken after the United Flight 811 accident near Honolulu on Friday was checking the status of the damaged Boeing 747's cargo door latch, which may have allowed the door to open in flight, Government officials said today.

title: Arab Girl Critically Wounded In Clash With Israeli Troops
description: A 6-year-old girl was in critical condition with a broken skull after clashes with Israeli soldiers today, Arab doctors said. Troops raided homes in search of Arabs who had killed a soldier by dropping a cement block on his head.

title: Lebanon Moves to Dismantle Ports Run by Militias
description: In the first such measures since the Lebanese civil war broke out nearly 14 years ago, the authorities in Christian and Muslim areas are moving to close ports operated by private militias.

title: HOW THE MIDDLE CLASS GOT THAT WAY
description: THE RISE OF RESPECTABLE SOCIETY A Social History of Victorian Britain, 1830-1900. By F. M. L. Thompson. 382 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $30.

title: Fredrik Schiotz, 87, Lutheran Leader, Dies
description: The Rev. Dr. Fredrik Axel Schiotz, a retired president of the American Lutheran Church, died of the effects of a stroke yesterday at Martin Luther Manor in Minneapolis, where he lived. He was 87 years old. In 1954, he was elected president of the church, now known as the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America, based in Chicago. Dr. Schiotz was president until 1970, when he retired. Since then he had lectured widely on interchurch activities.

title: Question Of the Week; Did Babe Ruth Call His Shot?
description: Of course Babe Ruth called his shot. And the bat he used was carved from a log which was part of the log cabin Abe Lincoln was born in. And that log came from a tree chopped down many years before by George Washington. RICHARD T. POTTER, Jr. Ridgewood, N.J.

title: Moscow Urging a U.S.-Soviet Pullout in Gulf
description: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, today renewed a proposal for a mutual withdrawal of naval shipping in the Persian Gulf by his country and the United States.

title: Hospital Day Care for Sick Children Makes Gains
description: Working parents with sick children in Massachusetts and several other states are increasingly able to turn to hospital day care.

title: A Low-Key Foundation That Likes to Take Risks in Giving
description: LEAD: IN an ordinary group of offices in a mundane building on Route 24 on the edge of town, the staff of the Geraldine R. Dodge Foundation goes about the business of giving away large sums of money. There is no special letterhead or fancy logo, and in the annual reports there are no pictures of the trustees, the director or the program officers.

title: As Viewers Wander, the Networks Scurry After
description: The first thing you notice in Lee Currlin's office at NBC's New York headquarters is the huge magnetic board that overwhelms one corner of the room. Thin colored strips with the titles of television shows are stuck to it alongside numbers signifying different time slots. At the far left side of the big board are clusters of strips in jagged disarray, as if they are captured pieces in a chess game. In effect, that's what they are - losers in the game of prime-time television.

title:
INVESTING;
The Trucking Industry Roars Back
description: LEAD: While many trucking companies are still struggling to survive in deregulated markets, some of the industry's leaders have been enjoying large earnings increases. Thanks to strong demand, companies have been able to raise the rates they charge in the past year. And with a recession still beyond the horizon, analysts expect some trucking stocks to rise this year.

title: Albanian Strikers Cripple Yugoslav Province
description: Yugoslavia will send paramilitary police reinforcements to Kosovo Province after leaders failed to end a general strike by its ethnic Albanian majority, an official statement said today.

title: Review/Dance; The Amazon's Mystery
description: The daughter of an American diplomat, Martita Kingsley Goshen grew up in South America, and in ''On the Way to Going Home'' she choreographically recalls her experiences in the upper Amazon. Her company, Martita Goshen's Earthworks, performed it with great concentration on Friday night at the Alwin Nikolais-Murray Louis Choreospace. Yet her journey into the past became a journey into the fog.

title: Concerts to Celebrate Americana
description: There is still a few days left in American Music Month, and several final concerts are offering a wide and intriguing range of Americana.

title: A Semi-Kind Word for Opera Scheduling
description: If hercules were still around and looking for a 13th labor to perform, an opera company might profitably engage him to put together a repertory that would please everyone. He would probably decide that he had it easier in the days when all a hero was required to do was cleanse a few stables or steal an Amazon queen's girdle. It is a fact of operatic life that any announcement of a company's plans comes with a guarantee of dissatisfaction, at very least, by opera lovers. Disgust or angry puzzlement are common reactions. Can you imagine, choruses of dissenters cry, any sensible person choosing such junk as A, B and C, while passing up X, Y and Z?

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Adelphi University; When Secretaries Are Away, Who's to Pay?
description: Remember the schoolyard canard about no more pencils and no more books? At Adelphi University this semester, students are learning to make do with no class rosters, no reading lists and no one to credit their tuition payments. Secretaries at the 93-year-old college are on strike.

title: Distribution And Opportunity
description: The interview with Edward Dowdy, newly appointed affirmative-action officer for Westchester County [ Westchester Q&A, Jan. 15 ] , compels me to make two observations. On three different occasions during the interview, Mr. Dowdy defined his role as insuring that there is equitable distribution of opportunity for ''people of color and women.''

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ending Feb. 11 MANHATTAN Carnegie Hill $355,000 25 East 92d Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,000-sq.-ft. prewar duplex co-op in a town house; 2 fireplaces, high ceilings, hardwood floors; maintenance $800, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: B.J. Gottesman) Greenwich Village $305,000 11 Fifth Avenue (9th St.) (Brevoort) 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 900-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24 hr. doorman, concierge, terrace; maintenance $850, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Kanelba & Robilotti) Upper East Side $1.65 million 935 Park Avenue (81st St.) 2-bedroom, 3-bath, 2,400-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining room, maid's room, fireplace, library, marble kitchen; maintenance $1,823, 49% tax-deductible (Broker: William B. May) Upper East Side $505,000 525 East 86th Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,340-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, manned-elevator, dining room, East River view; maintenance $1,366, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Sulzberger-Rolfe) Washington Heights $195,000 360 Cabrini Boulevard 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,400-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; part-time doorman, dinette, Hudson River view; maintenance $607, 39% tax-deductible (Broker: Simone Song Properties) BRONX Fordham $160,000 6 Fordham Hill Oval 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 1,600-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; dining room, parquet floors; maintenance $878, includes gas and electricity; 37% tax-deductible (Broker: Brown, Harris, Stevens On-Site) Gun Hill Road Area $149,000 3223 Fenton Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, single-family, semi-attached brick house; dining room, large kitchen, front porch, 1-car garage, 20- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $953 (Broker: J.A.V. Realty) BROOKLYN Brooklyn Heights $137,500 160 Columbia Heights 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 900-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, entry foyer, dining area, sunken living room, harbor view; maintenance $870, 62% tax-deductible (Broker: Markgraf Group) Flatbush $165,000 964 East 37th Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, single-family semi-attached, aluminum-sided house; dining room, large kitchen, den; 20- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $864 (Broker: Dwork & Korn) Prospect Heights $145,000 34 Plaza Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 900-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining area, windowed kitchen, Manhattan skyline view; maintenance $327, 35% tax-deductible (Broker: Warren Lewis Realty) QUEENS Forest Hills $425,000 68-11 Exeter Street 2-family, detached brick house; 3 bedrooms, 1 1/2 baths in primary duplex; 2 bedrooms, 1 bath in other; dining room, large kitchen in each; basement, 2-car garage, 29- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,600 (Broker: Sarah Jones Real Estate) Jackson Heights $327,000 30-16 80th Street 2-family, semi-attached brick house; dining room in top floor unit; large kitchen in lower; 2 bedrooms, 1 bath in each; finished basement, 2-car garage, 25- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,800 (Broker: Century 21/Metalios Real Estate) STATEN ISLAND Great Kills $155,000 290 Dewey Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, single-family, semi-attached, aluminum-sided house; dining room, large kitchen, rear deck; 25- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $918 (Broker: Schlott Realtors) Sunset Hill $289,000 72 City Boulevard 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, single-family, detached Tudor; dining room, large kitchen, finished basement, chestnut trimming throughout; 1-car garage, 40- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,500 (Broker: Weichert Realtors)

title: Miss Hansen Weds
description: Bara-Cristin Hansen, an actress in New York, and Mark Steven Milon, a lawyer in Washington, were married yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church in New Hope, Pa. The Rev. William H. Wood 3d performed the ceremony. Mrs. Milon is the daughter of Mrs. Frederick J. Hansen of Bay Terrace, S.I., and the late Mr. Hansen. Mr. Milon is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles F. Milon of Glenside, Pa.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: CONVOY SOUTH. By Philip McCutchan. (St. Martin's, $14.95.) Standing on the wind-battered bridge of the Royal Fleet Auxiliary oiler Coverdale as it crosses the Indian Ocean, Commodore John Mason Kemp faces quite a difficult assignment. His mission is to shepherd a convoy carrying an entire Australian Army division from Australia to, of all places, the United States.

title: CHILDREN AFTER DIVORCE
description: I have made a retrospective study of children of divorce who now are parents. I began the study assuming that perhaps divorce was just another incident in people's lives. Instead, I was overwhelmed by respondents in their 50's, 60's and 70's still struggling with feelings about their parents' divorce.

title: Clerics and Politics: Why There Are No 'Moderates' in Iran
description: AYATOLLAH MOHAMMED YAZDI'S green eyes flashed with impatience during a flight from Teheran to the Persian Gulf island of Lavan about two weeks ago. He had just been asked whether he considered himself among ''pragmatists'' or revolutionary ''purists'' in Iran's leadership. Such terms, the ayatollah replied, do not apply to Iran.

title: Rushdie Novel Stirs Passions East and West; Create a Devil
description: To the Editor:

title: Pursuit of Dreams in 'The Rabbit Foot'
description: There's a potentially boiling hot play that, right now, is just simmering at the Crossroads Theatre Company. What is holding back ''The Rabit Foot,'' by Leslie Lee, which ends its run next Sunday? It is overwritten - much, much too windy - overlong discursive, even unclear. But not irreparable.

title: Cold Comfort and a Beaten Child
description: Judges and lawyers, like other humans, are moved by natural sympathy in a case like this to find a way for Joshua and his mother to receive adequate compensation for the grievous harm inflicted on them.

title: Reviews/Music; Proclaiming Nationalism
description: Heads thrown back, mouths wide open, the Proclaimers shout their songs with gawky exuberance and thick Scottish accents. Originally the duo of Craig and Charlie Reid, identical twins from Edinburgh, the Proclaimers came to the Bottom Line on Thursday night with a band that connects Scottish traditionalism to rockabilly. They performed with the rousing, loose-limbed informality of street-corner buskers.

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.
description: There is something about the middle of a sidewalk, preferably the middle of a crowded sidewalk, that acts like a magnet for two groups of people - the thoughtless and the amorous. The thoughtless meet a friend or acquaintance and, in the midst of swirling crowds, stop and chat, unconcerned about pedestrian flow and the detours and side steps they cause. The lips-meeting-lips couples are more interesting to observe, although their public displays of affection are no less menacing to sidewalk traffic.

title: Switzerland
description: To the Editor: Israel Shenker's article ''In Switzerland Train Stations Are for Eating'' (Travel, Jan. 8) brought back memories. On our annual trip to our summer house at Les Avants, we left Berlin on the 4 P.M. train and arrived in Basel at 7 A.M. A change of trains left us one hour, and our first stop was the station restaurant, for breakfast. The fresh coffee with rolls and croissants revived our spirits. At that time there were only two restaurants, first class and second class. Both of them were noisy but served hearty food.

title: Life Without Your Own Orchestra
description: A quarter of a century has passed since the 15-year-old Pinchas Zukerman made his debut at Town Hall. Since then, he has worn many hats, as viola soloist, chamber player and conductor. At 29, when he joined the St. Paul Chamber Orchestra as music director and brought the ensemble to national attention, his career as a conductor seemed to have unstoppable momentum. But, in 1987, he suddenly resigned, and today he does not have his own orchestra.

title: Bridge
description: Computers can play backgammon well enough to beat a world champion and chess well enough to beat everyone except the greatest. But in bridge they have trouble advancing beyond the beginner stage. Zia Mahmood, the globe-trotting Pakistani star, has offered a million dollars to a computer that can beat him at bridge.

title: Lynn Stofan, Lawyer, Weds
description: Lynn Ellen Stofan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew J. Stofan of Denver, and Alan Bennett Kaplan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Kaplan of Jericho, L.I., were married last evening at the Tower Suite of the Time-Life Building in New York. Rabbi J. Rolando Matalon performed the ceremony.

title: Review/Opera; A Try at Authenticity In Sarasota 'Rigoletto'
description: The Sarasota Opera is celebrating its 30th season this year, but that's a little misleading. From 1960 to 1974, Sarasota opera lovers sponsored a visiting troupe from Woodstock, N.Y., at the tiny Asolo Theater on the Ringling Museum grounds, then began producing their own vest-pocket productions there. It was only five years ago that the company moved into its own theater downtown, a converted vaudeville house that will eventually seat 1,000 when the balcony is renovated.

title: Cowboy Poetry
description: To the Editor:

title: For Czechs, Caution Is a 20-Year Habit
description: ''LAYING flowers is not a punishable crime,'' Alexander Vondra, a defendant in one of the dissident trials last week, told a Prague court. But the Czechoslovak authorities thought it was. Mr. Vondra and seven other dissidents, including the prominent playwright Vaclav Havel, were convicted and given prison sentences for last month's gathering in Prague's Wenceslaus Square to mark the death 20 years ago of Jan Palach, a student who set fire to himself to protest the 1968 Soviet invasion.

title: Congratulations, Thursday's Child
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Ojeda and His Finger Pass the First Test
description: It was only batting practice, and it didn't count. But to the Mets, it may have been the most important test of spring training: the first time Bob Ojeda faced hitters since the tip of his left middle finger was severed and re-attached surgically five months ago. And when he was done, the 31-year-old pitcher said, ''I've answered the question in my mind.''

title: Kathleen Jackson, Nurse, Weds Investment Banker
description: Kathleen Ann Jackson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward R. Jackson of Piscataway, N.J., and Frank Jeffrey Setian, a son of Constance M. Setian of Needham, Mass., and the late Zohrab Y. Setian, were married yesterday at St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church in New York by the Rev. Russell Abata.

title: Just Give Me a Ring (And No More)
description: I'M old enough to remember when dialing the telephone required equal parts of manual dexterity, physical exertion and mental concentration, back in the days when a dial was a real dial and not just a bunch of sissy buttons.

title: Some Surprises From the Italy Of This Century
description: ''Italian art in the 20th Century'' is the subject (through April 9) of a monumental exhibition at the Royal Academy of Arts in London. Every inch of the Academy's stately spaces is filled. Even the doorways have been redesigned in a handsome, if slightly authoritarian, manner. The Academy's exemplary retail outlet for art books and artists' materials has been mated with an Italianate cornucopia in which Italian herbs, Italian cookies and Italian olive oil all have their place.

title: Soviet Lawyers, in Feisty Session, Form Bar Group
description: An article last Sunday about the founding congress of the first Soviet bar association referred incorrectly to the name it selected. The congress adopted an amendment changing the name from the Soviet Advocates' Association to the Soviet Advocates'

title: Time for a Public Broadcasting Overhaul
description: Public broadcasting is broke, and it ought to be fixed. Viewers and listeners have been saying that for years - they want more and better programs for their money. Yet, this important institution lumbers on, unable to rise to its full potential because of the way it was set up in the first place. The question is, how do you fix it?

title: Karen Fitz-Patrick to Wed
