description: Karen Martha Fitz-Patrick plans to wed Peter Bruce Sundlun, a son of Bruce G. Sundlun of Providence, R.I., and Madeleine Schiffer Gimbel of Washington. The announcement has been made by the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Jeremy James Fitz-Patrick of Newport News, Va. An April wedding is planned.

title: AN EDEN NOT MADE FOR HER
description: INSIDE APARTHEID One Woman's Struggle in South Africa. By Janet Levine. Illustrated. 287 pp. New York: Contemporary Books. $18.95.

title: Conservationists Turn to Tough Tactics
description: WHEN a Manhattan lawyer named Neil Brown purchased vast tracts of Sullivan County forest land in the early 80's, local officials thought he was planning a development they would happily endorse, something that would mean wealthy new residents and a lucrative source of taxes.

title: Gloria: Backlash on Beach
description: MORE than three years after Hurricane Gloria struck Long Island, hundreds of homeowners with beach-area property are still feeling its blows.

title:
GARDENING;
The Two Sides of Sphagnum Moss
description: LEAD: IN his New York Botanical Garden Illustrated Encyclopedia of Horticulture, T. H. Everett described sphagnum moss as an ideal medium in which to sow seeds, because of its antiseptic qualities. Indeed, stories tell of its use as a dressing for wounds during World War I. One reason sphagnum has been considered to be quite sterile is that it has a pH level of 4.0 to 4.5, which is below the range in which most plant pathogens thrive.

title: Moscow Tries to Make Up and Catch Up in the Middle East
description: WOODY ALLEN once observed that 90 percent of life is just showing up.

title: NO ONE SHALL 'SCAPE WHIPPING
description: THE SHOEBLACK AND THE SOVEREIGN Reflections on Ethics and Foreign Policy. By George Walden. 176 pp. New York: A Thomas Dunne Book/ St. Martin's Press. $14.95.

title: Provence's Almond Calissons
description: AIX-EN-PROVENCE is known for many things - the shielding plane trees lining its broad Cours Mirabeau, the healing waters sprinkling in its fountains, the elegance of its centuries-old buildings and the excellence of its ancient university. One of the city's biggest attractions, however, is a little iced diamond of marzipan, the celebrated calisson d'Aix.

title: With Tears, Griffith Joyner Bows Out
description: For the third time in a week yesterday, Florence Griffith Joyner cried in public. In all likelihood, it will not happen again for quite a while.

title: Yes, We Do Need A 'Methadone Clone'
description: Recent calls for developing a ''methadone clone'' for cocaine are altogether right. We have a public health emergency on our hands, and there is no prospect of an effective response without some pharmacological treatment.

title: Oyster Bay
description: To the Editor:

title: A CORRECTION
description: An article on the Century Apartments on Feb. 19 misstated its landmark status. The building was designated a New York City landmark in 1985.

title: A Challenge for Young Minds LBy BOB WACKER
description: THEY might discuss the color green, or tell what a glass of water makes them think of. They might act out a television commercial, in which Hercules, having cleaned out the Augean stables, endorses a deodorant.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 12 about efforts to negotiate a chemical weapons treaty referred incorrectly to a guilty plea by Alcolac International, a Baltimore chemical company. In a case resulting from its sale of thiodiglycol to a German company, Alcolac acknowledged that it had ''knowledge or reason to know'' that Singapore, the destination listed on the shipper's export declaration, was not the ultimate one. The company says it did not know the ultimate destination was Iran.

title: Nancy Goddard Becomes Bride Of E. F. Smith 3d
description: Nancy Beth Goddard and Edward Farrelly Smith 3d were married yesterday evening at the Colony Club in New York by Acting Justice Carol Berkman of State Supreme Court.

title: MIAMI J'YCE: LOVE WALKS RIGHT OUT OF A 'ULYSSES' SYMPOSIUM
description: From all the references to the man in the street heard at the University of Miami's recent James Joyce conference, you would think that he is walking around with a copy of ''Ulysses'' under his arm.

title: Doorbell Problems
description: WHEN a doorbell malfunctions, the problem is usually easy to diagnose and correct. Most systems consist of only three main parts and the wiring that links them. Here is how an ordinary doorbell works: At one or more doors, pushbuttons are attached. Each of these has a pair of thin wires connected to them. One of the wires links the button to the bell or other signaling device; the other wire links the button to the power source, a transformer connected to one of the household electric circuits. A third wire is connected between the transformer and the bell. At the transformer, high-voltage household current (120 volts) is reduced to low-voltage current (usually less than 16 volts), which is all that is required to power the system. Because of its low voltage, doorbell components and wiring are safe to handle, even when electricity is flowing through them.

title: For Cable Networks, the Road Gets a Little Steeper
description: In 1983, only one cable television programming service was profitable: TBS, the Atlanta-based ''superstation'' that doubles as a local broadcaster.

title: FOCUS: Enterprise Zones; Turning a Town From Gloom to Boom
description: EVERYONE here remembers September 1984. They call it ''Black September'' because that was the month that two factories closed, another laid off half its employees and unemployment in this town of 2,100 soared to 18 percent.

title: Question Of the Week; Did Babe Ruth Call His Shot?
description: Yes, he called his shot, though the Babe himself reportedly denied it. But this legend has a twist. Rather than guaranteeing the monstrous trajectory over the right-center-field wall of his next four-bagger off Charlie Root in the third inning of Game 3 of the 1932 World Series at Wrigley Field, Ruth might just as plausibly have been pointing to the downtown saloon where he would be celebrating the day's 7-5 victory. CHARLES LANGS New York

title: Joanne Galett Is Bride Of Andrew N. Sperling
description: At Congregation Rodeph Sholom in New York, Joanne Galett, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Galett of New York, was married last evening to Andrew Nathan Sperling, a son of Dr. and Mrs. David A. Sperling of Randolph, N.J. Rabbis Gunter Hirschberg and Harvey Tattelbaum performed the ceremony.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''The box the Fed is in is not of its own making: Federal budget deficits will be worse if monetary policy gets much, much tighter, and short-term interest rates will move sharply higher.'' - Allen Sinai, chief economist, the Boston Company.

title: POSTINGS: Singer Restoration; A Stitch in Time
description: Until 1967, when it was torn down, the 47-story Singer Sewing Machine Company Building at Broadway and Liberty Street in lower Manhattan stood as testimony to the architect Ernest Flagg's pioneering techniques in glass and steel skyscraper construction.

title: Business at Home May Mean Problems Before Zoning Board
description: LEAD: MORE and more people are trying to meet the rising costs of housing and doing business by living and working under the same roof. It has worked well for some, but been a source of conflict with towns and neighbors for others.

title: A REMEDY BUT NOT A CURE
description: SECOND CHANCES Men, Women, and Children a Decade After Divorce. By Judith S. Wallerstein and Sandra Blakeslee. 329 pp. New York: Ticknor & Fields. $19.95

title: Taking Toys Seriously: Mini-Movement or Sideshow?
description: When David Levinthal was a student at the Yale School of Art in 1972, he bought a package of toy Nazi soldiers over his Christmas vacation and began to photograph them on the floor of his parents' house. He doesn't remember why, except that he had liked playing with soldiers as a boy, and he wanted now to try shooting indoors in a studio.

title: Rushdie Novel Stirs Passions East and West; Answer to the Cardinal
description: To the Editor:

title: Varied Vietnamese at Fair Prices
description: IT is a pity that Lotus, a tiny Vietnamese restaurant in Vernon, about 13 miles east of Hartford, could not be cloned and relocated in other parts of the state. Not only is the food among the best Vietnamese cooking found in Connecticut, but it is also fairly priced.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Livingston, Tex.;
Wuxtry! Read All About Deals
description: LEAD: A YOUNG writer who moved to this small lakeside town north of Houston from New Hampshire last September has started a newsletter telling out-of-staters where to find real estate bargains.

title: Getting Out the Adoption Message
description: LEAD: WHEN Mary Ellen Salazar, chairwoman of the Nassau/Suffolk Bi-County Adoption Exchange, goes out ''to spread the word,'' it's usually to civic or religious organizations. ''Any place,'' she says, ''where we can let people know that children are waiting.''

title: Randy Lee Blume, Airline Pilot, Weds Capt. John D. Pickle, a Meteorologist
description: Randy Lee Blume, a pilot for Continental Air Lines, and Capt. John David Pickle, U.S.A.F., were married yesterday evening at the Burden Mansion in New York. Justice Helen Freedman of State Supreme Court officiated.

title:
DINING OUT;
Sunny Provencal Cuisine in Maplewood
description: LEAD: SUNNY Provencal cuisine is the main attraction at this three-month-old restaurant in the Essex County town of Maplewood. Basil-scented vegetable soupe au pistou, fish soup the color of burnished copper and a mid-Atlantic version of bouillabaisse, the Mediterranean fish stew, are some of the regional dishes offered by Emile

title: What Is It?
description: To the Editor:

title:
THE VIEW FROM: SUFFIELD;
Town With No Hotels Fights Bed-and-Breakfast Inn
description: LEAD: IN its 315-year history, Suffield has fought to keep out the railroad, the interstate highway and a new state prison to preserve its rural character.

title: Bright Outlook For Casinos In 2d Decade
description: THE casino industry here is moving into its second decade with a torrent of revenues and slowly improving profitability.

title: WHOSE CANON IS IT, ANYWAY?
description: William Bennett and Allan Bloom, the dynamic duo of the new cultural right, have become the easy targets of the cultural left, which I am defining here loosely and generously as that uneasy, shifting set of alliances formed by feminist critics, critics of so-called minority culture and Marxist and post-structuralist critics generally - in short, the rainbow coalition of contemporary critical theory. These two men (one a former United States Secretary of Education and now President Bush's ''drug czar,'' the other a professor at the University of Chicago and author of ''The Closing of the American Mind'') symbolize the nostalgic return to what I think of as the ''antebellum esthetic position,'' when men were men and men were white, when scholar-critics were white men and when women and people of color were voiceless, faceless servants and laborers, pouring tea and filling brandy snifters in the boardrooms of old boys' clubs. Inevitably, these two men have come to play the roles that George Wallace and Orville Faubus played for the civil rights movement, or that Richard Nixon and Henry Kissinger played during Vietnam - the ''feel good'' targets who, despite internal differences and contradictions, the cultural left loves to hate.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: South Kingstown, R.I.;
Shore Homes With Services
description: LEAD: ON a 22-acre tract farmed by one family for 80 years, a developer is trying to sell homes at prices far higher than the average value of existing homes in the town, and offering maintenance services to buyers as a way of luring them in.

title: Hoyas Hang On to Beat Redmen
description: St. John's, staggering after a 3-point loss to Seton Hall and desperately fighting for a tournament berth, took Georgetown to the wire last night but came up short.

title: Britain Asks Soviets for Action on Iran
description: Britain has asked the Soviet Union to raise the issue of the death sentence against Salman Rushdie, the author of ''The Satanic Verses,'' with Iranian officials, and more Western nations have reportedly agreed to join the Common Market in withdrawing envoys from Teheran.

title: CHILDREN AFTER DIVORCE
description: The thrust of Judith Wallerstein's article is that divorce per se is harmful to children. I am concerned that this focus will distract attention from the more significant issues, which are that dysfunctional families and parents are harmful to children, regardless of marital status. Ms. Wallerstein briefly acknowledges that divorce may be a more satisfactory solution to problems than continuing a harmful marriage. As a pediatrician, I believe this is the central point. When a divorce results in better functioning for the parents, it is an improvement for the children as well. SUSAN B. SHURIN, M.D. Shaker Heights, Ohio

title: 'Billy Bathgate'
description: For nearly 30 years now, E. L. Doctorow has been serving as a sort of human time machine. He carried his readers back to the days of the Wild West in ''Welcome to Hard Times,'' to the early 20th century in ''Ragtime'' and to the 1930's in ''Loon Lake'' and the American Book Award-winning ''World's Fair.'' Each trip worked, but the most successful was that of ''World's Fair,'' with its lingering, affectionate, deeply textured evocation of the Bronx in the 30's. Clearly, this is where Mr. Doctorow (himself born in New York City in 1931) feels most at home, and even those who have never seen that particular time and place have the eerie sense that they must have been there in some previous incarnation, once they've read his description of the sweet-potato seller on Eastburn Avenue, or the candy store at Eastburn and 174th Street, or the Hindenburg floating majestically over Claremont Park.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: University of Illinois; Engineers' Devices Aid The Disabled
description: Todd Schmiedl has not been able to speak above a whisper since his larynx was damaged in an automobile accident nine years ago.

title: Lilco Deal: Judge Asks Customers' Reaction
description: LEAD: REACTION among one million Long Island Lighting Company customers to a proposed court settlement that would cut $390 million from future electric rates will be measured this week by a Federal judge.

title: Would the Savings Industry Do Better Without Help?
description: AS Washington reverberates with the latest cost estimate of the savings and loan industry debacle, economists are beginning to ask what implications this sorry episode has for the age-old debate over whether Government should play a greater role in directing the economy.

title: Classic Appeal: Long Silhouette
description: Those who sell material by the yard have had a few worries lately, with the return of the miniskirt. But it's not all bad news for purveyors of cloth, not by any means. The long look remains very much with us, a stylish alternative to the shorter clothes that have become popular.

title: THIS SPRING'S UNDER-STATEMENTS
description: PLAIN BRAS, NUDE body stockings, simple camisoles: These are the operative words in fashionable lingerie for spring.

title: Part of Old Boston Is Transformed, Drawing Shoppers to the Back Bay
description: More people than ever - Bostonians and tourists alike - are flocking to Newbury Street, a fashionable eight-block stretch in the Back Bay where one can find shops and boutiques offering everything from Swiss lingerie to Japanese food to a Swedish massage. The new magnet is ''upper'' Newbury Street, the blocks between Exeter and Hereford Streets, at the far end of Newbury's gateway at the Public Garden and the Ritz Carlton Hotel (Newbury's cross streets run alphabetically, from Arlington to Hereford). The upper end, near Copley Square, is evolving from an area with a bohemian bent to one with a broader appeal. Fewer Green Mokawks

title: Doris Mack to Wed in March
description: Doris Ruth Mack, a daughter of Joseph M. Mack of Estevan, Saskatchewan, Canada, and the late Elizabeth Veronica Mack, and Thomas Carhart Amory, both of Santa Barbara, Calif., plan to be married next month in Santa Barbara. Mr. Amory is the son of the late George Sullivan Amory and the late Marion Renee Carhart Amory of New York and Tuxedo Park, N.Y.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE PENTAGONISTS: An Insider's View of Waste, Mismanagement, and Fraud in Defense Spending. By A. Ernest Fitzgerald. (Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) Here is Richard Nixon on A. Ernest Fitzgerald: ''I said, get rid of that son of a bitch. You know, 'cause he is, he's been doin' this two or three times.

title: Stamps
description: Stamp designs reflect current events - new nations, new leaders, new currencies. Collectors can also become embroiled in current events - like trade embargoes.

title: Billy on Billy
description: As the first notes of Aaron Copeland's ''Billy the Kid Suite'' were played by the Binghamton (N.Y.) Symphony Orchestra last night, a modern-day Billy known for his fiery temperament told the audience of rowdy times gone by.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Murder Trial Sees Juggling Of Two Juries
description: Justice Thomas A. Demakos looked down from his bench in State Supreme Court in Queens and addressed the two juries sitting before him - one in the regular jury box, one on chairs temporarily set up in front of it.

title: Four Scenarios for Failure
description: THE REAL ISSUE FOR THE FUTURE OF THE Soviet Union is not whether Gorbachev will last or even whether he will succeed or fail in his attempts to revitalize the Soviet economy and state. The real issue is whether Soviet Communism is evolving into a significantly more permissive and innovative system or whether it is decaying or even fragmenting. On that question depend not only the fate of the Soviet Union as a major power but also the prospects for Communism around the world.

title: TALKING: Transfer Tax; Proposed Increases Challenged
description: ANYONE planning to buy or sell a one-family house, condominium or co-op apartment in New York State later this year should be aware that new state and local transfer taxes may be payable at the time of closing.

title: CHILDREN AFTER DIVORCE
description: I was interested to read Judith S. Wallerstein's article ''Children After Divorce'' (Jan. 22). I believe not enough attention is given to the children of broken homes. I can testify to the fact that often deep wounds are sustained and that even after a lifetime they may never have healed.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. Urges Congress To Protect Pensions' Assets
description: Labor leaders concluded their winter meeting Friday by calling for Congress to make it tougher for employers to skim assets from pension funds. The labor federation also pledged that it would be a major force in Congressional redistricting.

title: THE GUIDE
description: LEAD: WRITERS' CONFERENCE Aspiring amateur and professional writers, as well as those who simply want to hone their writing skills for everyday communication, will find valuable assistance at the New Jersey Institute of Technology in Newark on Saturday.

title: THE AMAZON'S SAVVY INDIANS
description: IT IS GETTING DARK WHEN Chief Kanhonk sits down in the yard outside his home, ready for a long evening of conversation. Night birds are calling from the bush that sparkles with fireflies. Whooping frogs make a racket by the river.

title: Polish Police Fight Protesters As Solidarity and Regime Talk
description: While the Communist leadership is negotiating with Solidarity, the police cracked down over the weekend on demonstrations and meetings in Cracow and other cities staged by small, independent groups that support the banned union but reject the negotiations.

title: Paul M. Giddens And Liz Loewy Engaged to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Robert G. Loewy of Loudonville, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Esther Elizabeth Loewy to Paul Michael Giddins, a son of Ellen Giddins of New York and the late Robert Giddins. An April wedding is planned.

title: 'Everyone Is Anxious to Do Very Well''
description: FOR the 60 women who comprise the Green Fingers Garden Club in Greenwich, gardening means more than growing the perfect tulip or putting together the loveliest flower arrangement. It also means taking responsibility for the environment and trying to get others to do the same.

title:
Kinnelon Journal;
Groups Are Trying to Save Their Beloved Mountain
description: LEAD: WHILE environmentalists and municipal officials struggle to keep developers at bay, residents in this borough and nearby communities sound worried about their prospects in a battle to preserve Pyramid Mountain, regarded by some conservationists as among New Jersey's most desirable tracts of privately held open land.

title: THE REGION: A Bill in Suffolk; As the Suburbs Speak More Spanish, English Becomes a Cause
description: AS Latin American immigrants settle in suburbs across the metropolitan area, state and local efforts to help them are coming under attack. The immediate target is the use of Spanish by public workers and in official forms and pamphlets. But the underlying issues are far larger.

title: Beckoning Spring With Brightness
description: Consider a new jacket - one with nonaggressive shoulders, a gentler fit through the body and in a thin fabric: wool, silk or synthetic. It could rejuvenate many clothes already in your closet, and continue to be useful right through the summer.

title: Missouri Trips Up No. 1 Oklahoma
description: The long arm of Norm Stewart reached out to the seventh-ranked Missouri Tigers today. With Missouri a point behind top-ranked Oklahoma at halftime, the Missouri coach, who is recovering from cancer surgery at a hospital here, telephoned his team's acting coach, Rich Daly.

title: When Mia Meets Mama, It's Mae Questel
description: ''She has that combination of traits that one frequently sees in mothers,'' said Woody Allen. ''There was no question in my mind that she was absolutely right for the part.''

title: Magic Returns
description: The two-time defending N.B.A. champion Los Angeles Lakers got their Magic back Friday night after he was sidelined for five games by a partially torn hamstring. The Lakers went 3-2 without him, but they dominated the Sacramento Kings, 115-103.

title: Trying to Capture the Allure of Norwalk
description: NORWALK residents are being asked to dream up a short slogan to symbolize their town. A bank will give $2,000 to the person who comes up with an equivalent to ''I H New York.''

title: A Gymnasium For Actors
description: To the Editor:

title: Libby Schmeltzer And Rick Hinson Engaged to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edward Schmeltzer of Potomac, Md., of the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Sabine Schmeltzer, to Rick Franklin Hinson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Eldon F. Hinson of Redding, Calif. The couple plan to marry in June.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I am having a constant problem with the sliding wooden doors on my closet. The plastic wheels are supposed to slide along in a metal track fastened to the top of the door jamb. Mine seem to have come off the track, so it is almost impossible to move the doors unless I pick them up.

title: Mary Hart, TV Host, To Marry a Producer
description: Mary Hart, a co-host of the syndicated television program ''Entertainment Tonight,'' and Burt Sugarman, a television and movie producer, have announced their engagement. Both are residents of Beverly Hills, Calif. Miss Hart is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Harum of Fresno, Calif. Mr. Sugarman, who also is chairman of Giant Group Ltd., an entertainment and industrial products company in Beverly Hills, is the son of Al Sugarman of Beverly Hills and the late Mrs. Sugarman. No date has been set for the wedding.

title: The Parks' Wildlife Issue, Again, Is Whether to Interfere
description: AS hungry bison leave the sanctuary of Yellowstone National Park to be slaughtered by hunters in the largest buffalo kill of the century, conservationists are left once again to contemplate the difficulties of maintaining wildlife in a landscape that is, for the most part, no longer wild.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Dr. Betsy von Kreuter Weds Dr. Juan Felix
description: The wedding of Dr. Betsy Frances von Kreuter, a postdoctoral fellow in pathology, and Dr. Juan Carlos Felix, a fellow in gynecologic pathology, both at Cornell Medical College, took place yesterday in Darien, Conn. The Rev. Vincent Veich performed the ceremony at St. John's Roman Catholic Church.

title: THE NATION: The Fed Moves; Inflation Anxiety Is Back
description: WITH the economy, when things are too good for too long they can turn bad quickly. Inflation creeps up, then starts to gallop. Fears of recession loom.

title: Company Spies
description: To the Editor:

title: Rushdie Novel Stirs Passions East and West; Literary Terrorism
description: To the Editor:

title: At City Ballet, Virtuosity From the Ranks
description: The New York City Ballet ends one of its most brilliantly danced seasons in years tonight, a tribute especially to many of its youngest dancers who took part in an unprecedented cavalcade of debuts.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Old Orchard Beach, Me.; Fitting the Last Puzzle Piece
description: IN an effort to change the honky-tonk image of this once-vibrant southern Maine seaside community, town leaders, developers and private citizens are planning an ambitious revitalization to attract businesses and residents to the downtown area.

title: Wrong Number
description: When Deion Sanders, the Yankees' rookie outfielder and an all-America defensive back from Florida State, took part in his second day of workouts at Fort Lauderdale Stadium yesterday, he did not get through the morning without a change of uniforms and uniform numbers.

title: Spring Phenom a Yankee Perennial
description: He is their phenom this spring, their kid with unlimited talent and untapped potential. He is only 20 years old, but the coaches who work with him daily say he has the skills of a big leaguer. The people in the front office speak of his intellectual and his physical growth. They all say he simply can't miss. When he hears these things, Bernie Williams smiles and shrugs and says he hopes they are right. His youth prevents him from gloating immodestly. His past has shown him that anything can happen in baseball.

title: FICTION
description: INCLINE OUR HEARTS. By A. N. Wilson. (Viking, $17.95.) A. N. Wilson is prodigious. Praised most recently for his biography of Tolstoy, he now deserves applause for this witty and tender, delightfully written and perceptive novel. Its hero is the orphaned Julian Ramsay, brought up, cared for if not absolutely loved, by his aunt and uncle in an English vicarage. His uncle is obsessed with the Lampitt family, local gentry who number among their members James Petworth Lampitt, a once-renowned, now utterly out of style Edwardian man of letters. Later this Lampitt is seized upon as a subject of biography by Raphael Hunter, a charming and unscrupulous character who weaves in and out out of Julian's life as rival, stimulus and nemesis. Julian Ramsay can surely take his place with the small handful of utterly real and intermittently delightful small boys in literature. And Julian as sullen adolescent and as chastened young man also ring true. If ''Incline Our Hearts'' were no more than a delicious account of Julian's coming of age, his passage through what Mr. Wilson calls the ''Gulag'' of the English public school system, this book would still be absorbing. But Mr. Wilson, the author of 10 novels and 4 biographies, probes more deeply. He is interested in the writer's paradox of the truth of fiction and the fiction of ''truth'' as they apply to accounts of the human condition, and is uniquely equipped to examine both sides. His book is as enchanting as it is intelligent.

title: Private Lagoons, Ancient Ruins
description: LEAD: SOME 30 years ago, when I was living in Mexico City, I used my apartment as a kind of base camp for archeological expeditions from the lava-strewn outskirts of the capital all the way to the mysterious Mayan ruins of Yucatan and Quintana Roo.

title: Abigail Dennis To Wed in May
description: Announcement has been made by Anita V. Dennis and Robert W. Dennis, both of New York, of the engagement of their daughter Abigail Barker Dennis to Franklin Paul Lynch, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William W. Lynch of North Palm Beach, Fla. A May wedding is planned.

title: U.N. Finds Some Gain in Cubans' Rights
description: The first United Nations report on the human-rights situation in Cuba suggests that while there have been big improvements in church-state relations and the treatment of political prisoners, basic political liberties are still widely denied.

title: It's Farce - So Please Do Slam the Door
description: To hear the director Jerry Zaks tell it, farce is the most dangerous, treacherous, dead-earnest business there is. If you don't have a door to hide behind, you're a goner.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Ho-Ho-Kus
description: LEAD: COVERING just 1.8 square miles, Ho-Ho-Kus is among the smallest communities in northwest Bergen County, but its unusual name gives it a recognition far beyond its size.

title: Northern Comfort in Vermont
description: AMONG many skiers the feeling is, the closer the ski area the better. Such thinking may account in part for the popularity of such ski resorts as Hunter Mountain in the Catskills or Mount Snow in Vermont. The proximity brings with it bigger crowds, longer lift lines and higher prices. On the other hand, longer drives to relatively remote ski areas in northern New England can mean more for less money, not to mention shorter, or even nonexistent, lift lines.

title: Changes Loom for Home Equity Loans
description: Because of the changes brought by tax revision, the home equity loan has been one of the hottest banking products for the last couple of years. Now, new changes in Federal law are likely to reshape the market for these loans. While many of the changes are designed to bolster legal protections for borrowers, they are also likely to make the loans less readily available and more costly, banking experts say.

title: Calls for End Of Army Rule Grow in Haiti
description: Anti-Government protests have broken out in a half dozen coastal towns and cities since mid-January and calls for the ouster of the military ruler, Lieut. Gen. Prosper Avril, have been stepped up. At the same time, however, Haiti peacefully celebrated its first Mardi Gras since the collapse of the Duvalier dictatorship three years ago and political leaders held nationally televised discussions on the creation of an independent council to organize elections.

title: Egypt
description: To the Editor: Your stories on Egypt (Travel, Jan. 1) closely reflected my experience, but a fond memory of Shepheard's Hotel impells a mild demurral at the description of it as faded. The Cataract at Aswan, yes; the Winter Palace at Luxor, yes indeed - both great places for pondering the whereabouts of the snows of yesteryear - but not Shepheard's.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Suffolk Tea Party EVEN in protest, Long Islanders can be creative. Suffolk County Legislator Sondra Bachety received an herbal tea bag in the mail recently. ''My constituents send nothing but the best,'' Ms. Bachety said. ''I'm planning to enjoy it.''

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Courts Addressing Assessment Inequities
description: LEAD: PEOPLE usually inquire about existing taxes when buying a house, but in some eastern Long Island communities and in the Village of Atlantic Beach in Nassau County, the better question until recently would have been, ''How much will the taxes go up?''

title: Heyday of the Clipper Ships is Recalled in Stamford Exhibit
description: LEAD: THE clipper ship's short-lived dominance of the seas continues to capture the imagination and spur interest in the nation's maritime heritage. It is the raison d'etre for an exhibition, ''Neptune's Favorites: The Romance and Reality of America's Clipper Ships,'' on view through May 27 at the Stamford Historical Society.

title: Can a Kinder, Gentler Fed Do the Job?
description: When prices were rising at double-digit rates back in 1979 and 1980, inflation was enough of a public concern for the Federal Reserve Board to raise interest rates dramatically and push the economy into a recession.

title: Halpern Ready to Act on Grace Church Site
description: LEAD: CONSTRUCTION work on an office complex and plaza adjacent to the Grace Episcopal Church that would dramatically change the look of the intersection of Mamroneck Avenue and Main Street could begin by the end of this year and could be completed in 20 months, according to Jon Halpern, the developer.

title: Tgoward a G.O.P. Rainbow
description: LEAD: Three days after George Bush was elected President, the syndicated columnist William Raspberry wrote:

title: What to Do When the Taj Mahal Is for Sale for Half the Price
description: BY the time I sell my house, an efficiency apartment will be plenty big enough. I've been so obsessive and obnoxious, no one is going to want to live with me anyway. I'm convinced that selling your house is divine retribution for the mortal sin of trading up.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-19

title: A Bedroom Farce
description: ONCE again, I was in bed with the Asian flu. For two weeks, my husband brought me a lovely white Victorian bed tray and served Saltines and cups of soup. And for a while afterward on weekends, even when I wasn't sick, he would bring coffee up to the bedroom.

title: Measles, Not Yet a Thing of the Past, Reveals the Limits of an Old Vaccine
description: Every year, at least one American city finds itself overwhelmed by the measles, a disease many people thought had gone away.

title: In Asia, Taking A Long View Of U.S. Power
description: THE trip was supposed to be all about reassurance - reassuring allied countries about American commitment, reassuring a whole region about American capacities. But before George Bush had spent even 24 hours in Asia on his first major journey abroad as President, a note of uncertainty crept into the upbeat message.

title: Governors Warning of an Ignorant U.S.
description: A panel of Governors warned today that the economic well-being of the United States was in jeopardy because so many Americans are ignorant of the languages and cultures of other nations.

title: Unlikely Coalition Fights Plan to Cut Medicaid
description: Groups that have traditionally regarded each other with suspicion have joined in denouncing Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's proposed $350 million cut in Medicaid spending.

title: Doctors Preferred Over Medical Tests in Malls
description: The article ''Medical Testing at Mall'' (Jan. 1) raises the specter of ''let the buyer beware.'' The article focuses on a shopping center-based, walk-in medical testing unit which produces cholesterol test results in 10 minutes. This is based on newer medical technology advances well known to those of us in the clinical laboratory profession.

title: 'Jerry's Girls,' Revue, in East Windsor
description: AS new musicals fade and newly available ones fail, ''Jerry's Girls'' is just the sort of melange to keep a dinner theater going.

title: Q and A
description: Fall Birding

title: DATA BANK: February 26, 1989
STYLE MAKERS: Richard and Robert Kitchen; HOUSEHOLD PRODUCT DESIGNERS
description: Beginning with their first major project - being born - the Kitchen twins have been collaborating in one way or another. And like so many identical twins, Richard and Robert are almost mystically in tune with each other.

title: IMAGINE THIS
description: Passers-by, intrigued by the distressed steel facade with ''One Off'' etched in a strange scribble, can look through a peephole for a fisheye glimpse of the architect Ron Arad's gallery and office. What they see will make them even more curious. The former storage space is now totally clad in an envelope of metal, with tiny pinpoints of light directed at an array of whimsical metal furniture. ''I wanted to create the sense of being in a new world,'' says Arad.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales
description: Madison, Conn. $415,000 Michele Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new antique colonial reproduction; palladian windows, moldings, 1.5 acres; taxes not yet available. Killingworth, Conn. $285,000 85 Bar Gate Trail 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 6-year-old colonial, french doors off living room to terrace, tiered deck, 3 acres; taxes $3,074. West Simsbury, Conn. $178,000 186 West Mountain Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; skylights, new kitchen, 0.75 acre; taxes $1,582. Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. $372,000 22 Hyatt Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 38-year-old ranch; 20-foot-deck, 1 acre; taxes $6,290. Cortlandt, N.Y. $235,000 15 Avenue A 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 13-year-old raised ranch; landscaped, stone fireplace, Florida room, 0.5 acres; taxes $4,800. Pound Ridge, N.Y. $445,000 Winterbottom Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 10-year-old contemporary; 4,000 square feet, 9 rooms, 2 acres; taxes $7,516. OTHER AREAS West Islip, L.I. $515,000 3 Cedar Point Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 22-year-old waterfront colonial; fireplace, basement, 2-car garage, 0.25-acre; taxes $6,900. Williston Park, L.I. $193,000 12 Remsen Street 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; dining room, attic, basement; taxes $1,900. Freehold, N.J. $218,000 42 Stratford Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 23-year-old colonial; full basement, 1-car garage, w/w carpeting; taxes $2,923.

title: Question Of the Week; Did Babe Ruth Call His Shot?
description: When Babe whacked that memorable blow, I was screaming along with my father and a thousand other fanatics who'd paid $1 for the privilege of listening to the amplified radio broadcast in the auditorium of the Knights of Columbus, as on stage young men scurried around posting runners on a huge, green diamond.

title: Highgate
description: To the Editor: The tour information in the article on Highgate Cemetery (Travel, Dec. 4) is no longer correct. Volunteers from the Friends of Highgate Cemetery are giving hourly tours on weekends only; others require special arrangements although the Friends hope to begin some weekday tours in April when the weather is warmer and visitors increase.

title: John Sculley's Biggest Test
description: It was a vision and a technology that created Apple Computer Inc., producing products that changed America, profits that made shareholders rich and a unique corporate mythology.

title: POSTINGS: Garden Spot; An Inside Job
description: Often the first clue to a building's rental tenants that a co-op or condominium conversion is in the works is when a formerly shabby lobby suddenly gets a fresh coat of paint and new carpets and furnishings. The residents of the Royal York, a three-building, 750-unit complex on 63d and 64th Streets between York and First Avenues that is being converted to a cooperative, have seen not only the makeover of their lobbies but also the transformation of the weed-infested interior courtyard into a landscaped garden.

title: A LOT HE DIDN'T KNOW ABOUT JAMIE
description: FATHER AND SON By Peter Maas. 316 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: Colleges Report Rise in Minority Students
description: COLLEGES in the state are accepting and graduating more minority-group students than ever, but state education officials said they were worried that the students were not pursuing teaching careers and not reaching their potential.

title: Aboard Flight 811: Passengers' Routine Dissolves Into Terror
description: Laura Falci of Chicago was already asleep in seat 24A when United Airlines Flight 811 took off for New Zealand early Friday, her hair falling over her black double-breasted jacket. Like most airline passengers, she never paid much attention when the flight attendants went through all those instructions about how to adjust oxygen masks in an emergency.

title: Islanders Erase Big Penguin Lead
description: The changes were glaring. Kelly Hrudey was gone, Billy Smith was scratched, and for the first time in several hundred games, two rookies, Jeff Hackett and the even newer Mark Fitzpatrick, were designated as guardians of the Islander goal. Fitzpatrick was acquired with the defenseman Wayne McBean from Los Angeles earlier this week for Hrudey.

title: Normalizing of Relations by China and Indonesia Ends a Two-Decade Feud
description: The announcement in Tokyo this week that Indonesia and China will normalize relations, frozen more than 20 years ago after the attempted coup here in 1965, closes one of the last great gaps in the circle of Southeast Asian diplomacy.

title: WHEN PRIVATE EMPLOYERS HIRE PUBLIC POLICE
description: On busy weekend days and nights, more than 300 uniformed city police officers can be seen patrolling this troubled city's streets, sidewalks, malls, parking lots, arenas and stadiums. They are all in uniform and armed with Miami police badges, radios, pistols and full official powers to stop, search, chase, arrest and summon reinforcements.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''For more than a century, Americans enjoyed unchallenged superiority in virtually everything we turned our hands to. We could afford the luxury of ignoring the seers and experts who urged us to learn the tongues and ways of other lands. But those days have gone the way of leaded gas and the nickel phone call.'' - - Gov. Thomas H. Kean of New Jersey [ 22:5. ]

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I am having a constant problem with the sliding wooden doors on my closet. The plastic wheels are supposed to slide along in a metal track fastened to the top of the door jamb. Mine seem to have come off the track, so it is almost impossible to move the doors unless I pick them up.

title: Bush: Following a Tough Act
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Chicago; Loyola Hopeful On Expansion
description: OFFICIALS of Loyola University of Chicago say they are confident that plans for a 16.8-acre landfill expansion into Lake Michigan at the school's North Shore campus will go forward this spring.

title: What the U.S. Has to Gain From Papandreou's Troubles
description: NO postwar Greek Government has lasted more than eight years, and it seems increasingly unlikely that Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou will be an exception to the rule.

title: Detroit Council's Plan Is Called Anti-Catholic
description: City Council is violating the principle of separation of church and state by scheduling a public hearing on the Archdiocese of Detroit's plans to close 30 churches in the city, Edmund Cardinal Szoka said.

title: STYLE MAKERS: Keiko Fukuzaki; SWIMWEAR DESIGNER
description: As soon as the Sports Illustrated swimsuit issue hits the newsstands, the bathing suit designer Keiko Fukuzaki gets a flood of phone calls from men all over the nation, who want to order her sexy styles for girlfriends and wives.

title: THE STEINBERG TRIAL
description: In her article ''The Steinberg Trial: Scenes From a Tragedy'' (Jan. 15), Patricia Volk got my quote all wrong. I said (unaware that it was for attribution) that Hedda Nussbaum was becoming media savvy, dressing smarter, watching her words, trying not to appear despicable. This came out, ''She's despicable,'' a far cry from the original thought. KEN GROSS Brooklyn THE AUTHOR REPLIES:

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Middlebury College; Needed for Graduation: A Cap, a Gown and Skis
description: Graduation usually means caps and gowns, a good-luck handshake from the college president and a diploma. But for some seniors at Middlebury College, graduation means caps and gowns, a good-luck handshake from the president and skis.

title: Rushdie Novel Stirs Passions East and West; Not Banned in Canada
description: To the Editor:

title: Michelle McGeown Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. John R. McGeown of Montclair and Mantoloking, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Michelle Mary McGeown to John E. Gerli 3d, the son of Mr. Gerli Jr. of Pawling, N.Y., and Mrs. Winston Hagen of Greenwich, Conn., and Block Island, R.I. A May wedding is planned.

title: PRESIDENT BACKS SOVIET OVERTURES ON TIES TO CHINA
description: President Bush said Saturday that improved relations between Moscow and Beijing could enhance the prospects for peace in Cambodia.

title: STYLE MAKERS: David McFadden; MUSEUM CURATOR
description: In an age of grand museum exhibitions, the curators who mount them are exerting an important influence on design and popular culture. Their impact can be felt in fashion, architecture, drama and, even, wallpaper, as David McFadden knows all too well.

title: Brazil Indians Meet on Protecting Amazon
description: Environmentalists are hailing a Brazilian Indian meeting that united former enemy tribes as a landmark event in the campaign to save the Amazon rain forests.

title: Tyson Stops Bruno In Fifth
description: Mike Tyson is back - with a vengeance. Tyson, who had not fought for eight months, was brutally efficient tonight as he took apart Frank Bruno and stopped him at 2 minutes 55 seconds of the fifth round of a scheduled 12-round heavyweight championship bout.

title: Indian Rights Group Says Police Abuse Sikhs
description: An Indian human rights group has accused the police in Punjab State, troubled by Sikh extremism for several years, of widespread intimidation, beatings, torture and killings of purported Sikh militants.

title: No Headline
description: The Notre Dame linebacker Michael Stonebreaker, who won all-America honors last season, was injured early yesterday when his car struck a utility pole near South Bend, Ind., the police said.

title: Egypt
description: To the Editor: Having visited Egypt in February 1987, I would like to comment on some of the notes on accommodations.

title: One Day the Phone Rang: 'Bubbles? This Is Izzy'
description: When ''The Pajama Game'' begins performances this Friday at the New York City Opera, the hit-filled 1954 musical about the garment trade will be a different kind of production from the sort of show that Beverly Sills, the company's general director, envisioned four years ago.

title: Passenger Arrested Over Joke
description: A charter flight carrying more than 350 people made an unscheduled landing at Indianapolis International Airport today after a passenger joked about having explosives, the authorities said. Anthony G. Pierson, 23, of Rochester Hill, Mich., was charged with violating the false information act and making threats, said Sgt. John Wheeler of the Indiana state police.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE NAGLE JOURNAL: A Diary of the Life of Jacob Nagle, Sailor, From the Year 1775 to 1841. Edited by John C. Dann. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $27.50.) Jacob Nagle was an ordinary American who lived a most extraordinary existence during the late 18th and early 19th centuries. He fought under George Washington during the Revolutionary War, served in the British Navy, wended his way to India, China and South America on East India Company ships and sailed as the only American on the first fleet to Australia.

title: Review/Recital; Istomin Does It His Way
description: The pianist Eugene Istomin had distinct ideas about how he wanted to interpret the works on his Carnegie Hall program Wednesday evening. But throughout the performance, his technique got in the way of his intentions.

title: Predetermined Body Type?
description: To the Editor:

title: Thornburgh to Review Deportation of I.R.A. Man
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh has decided not to support a Reagan Administration decision to deport an Irish Republican Army member convicted of murder in Britain.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about funds to study and clean Long Island Sound misstated Gov. William A. O'Neill's proposal for the state's Clean Water Fund for the next fiscal year. Mr. O'Neill recommended an appropriation of $75 million, not an elimination of $40 million.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: U. of Massachusetts; Evangelicals Demonstrate Their Faith
description: Down the hall, the Go-Go's were blasting on a stereo. The University of Massachusetts, like most colleges these days, is largely a secular place. But in one dormitory room, four undergraduates were reading from the New Testament.

title: STEVENSON BEATS J.F.K.
description: The Public Schools Athletic League has been having its basketball playoffs for the last two weeks, but the defending champion, Adlai Stevenson of the Bronx, did not play its first game until yesterday at the Fashion Institute of Technology in Manhattan.

title: SOUTH AFRICANS BURY SLAIN YOUTH
description: Stompie Moeketsi enlisted in the street war against apartheid when he was 10 years old. At 11, he was organizing other children to fight the municipal police. He spent his 12th birthday in jail as a political detainee, the youngest in South Africa.

title: Wildcare Rehabilitation Moving to Dutchess
description: LEAD: AFTER a prolonged effort to remain in Westchester, Wildcare, the nonprofit rehabilitation center for birds of prey, is moving to Dutchess County next month.

title: Physician's License Is Suspended in Sex Case
description: The state has suspended the license of a doctor whom some patients have accused of having sexual relations with them, then performing abortions on them without their knowledge after they became pregnant.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; How Will Vandeweghe Affect the Knicks?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title:
Westchester Q&A;: Sally M. Ziegler;
Into the Realm of Advocacy for Day Care
description: LEAD: DAY CARE has been in the news a lot this month. Workers at the Union Child Day-Care Center in Greenburgh went on strike, demanding higher wages. President Bush, following through on a campaign pledge, proposed in his first Federal Budget that low-income families be given a $1,000 day-care income-tax credit.

title: Rushdie Novel Stirs Passions East and West; Silence From New Delhi
description: To the Editor:

title: Boy Tries Skateboard Robbery, Police Say
description: An 11-year-old Brooklyn boy, wearing a .25-caliber handgun in a holster around his waist, skateboarded to the home of a friend yesterday, pulled the gun and demanded money to replace a toy gun the friend had broken on Friday, the police said.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: OLD DUTCH CHURCH The steeple bell that called early Dutch settlers to worship in North Tarrytown was cast in Amsterdam in 1685, and the 75 parishioners it summoned then were only 25 short of the 100-member congregation that is today fighting to preserve the 300-year-old Old Dutch Church of Sleepy Hollow.

title: Still Simon After All Those Years
description: IT was nearing the end of the season. The Yankees were four games out with enough games to go so that we could still cheer hopefully. The weather was perfect. Early in the game a former Yankee named Kittle hit a home run giving Cleveland the lead. But New York was in scoring position several times after that, so we continued to scream at Don, Dave, Jack and Rickey as they strode from the on-deck circle to the plate.

title: A Turning Point
description: To the Editor:

title: Jill L. Armel To Wed in '90
description: The engagement of Jill Lynne Armel, the daughter of Marilyn Armel and Paul H. Armel, both of New York, to Evan Dayan Dash, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Dash of New York, has been announced by the future bride's parents. A 1990 wedding is planned.

title: U.S. TO KEEP UP AID TO AFGHAN REBELS
description: The United States will continue to use Pakistan's intelligence services as the conduit for military aid to the Afghan rebels instead of sending it directly to the newly formed rebel government-in-exile, senior Administration officials said today.

title: SOCIAL EVENTS
description: Movie Awards

title: Teaching Corporate Executives the ABC's of Child Care
description: If the growth of consulting firms that design family benefits programs for corporations is a reliable bellwether, employer-provided day-care assistance is finally taking off.

title: Virginia Witherspoon To Wed J. E. Marlette
description: Mrs. Jackson T. Witherspoon 3d of Inverness, Calif., and Washington, has made known the engagement of her daughter, Virginia Rodgers Witherspoon, to John Elmer Marlette, the son of Mrs. John E. Marlette of Buffalo and the late Mr. Marlette. The couple plan to marry in April.

title: Reviews/Music; The Yma Sumac Mystique
description: Yma Sumac, the Peruvian vocal phenomenon, has always fearlessly straddled the line between the sublime and the ridiculous. In 1950, when ''Voice of the Xtabay,'' her first album of multi-octave mystical warblings, created a sensation, Miss Sumac was already regarded as something of a camp oddity, albeit one who possessed singular gifts. And today Miss Sumac, who is appearing at the Ballroom (253 West 28th Street) through March 11, remains an iconoclast, apparently oblivious to the possibility that her mystique involves more than a little hokum.

title: Dr. Eisemann Weds Dr. Wilson Crone
description: Dr. Donna Marie Eisemann, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Francis Eisemann of Lindenhurst, L.I., and Dr. Wilson Crone, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Seth Crone of Charleston, S.C., were married yesterday morning at the Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church in Durham, N.C. The Rev. Donald Frederick Staib officiated, assisted by the Rev. Anne Coile Estes, a Presbyterian minister.

title: Money Becomes More Expensive
description: The cost of money rose last week when the Federal Reserve increased its discount rate to 7 percent, from 6.5 percent, and banks lifted prime lending rates by a half point, to 11.5 percent. The Fed, which has been nudging short-term rates upward for some time, said it took the action ''in light of inflationary pressures.'' The discount rate has not reached 7 percent since April 1986. The increase influences the rate on overnight loans among banks, which rose to well above 9.5 percent. It prompted banks to raise prime rates for the second time in less than two weeks. The prime rate is now three percentage points higher than it was a year ago.

title: Homes for Art In Germany's Industrial Belt
description: MENTION the industrial area of West Germany around Dusseldorf, and most travelers will assume you're going to get your work done as quickly as possible and then head out. The local landscape consists mostly of smokestacks and factories linked by a maze of autobahns.

title: On the Road to the Vote on Tower: A Series of White House Missteps
description: White House and Congressional officials say that tactical errors, misjudgments and unlucky timing helped turn the confirmation hearings of John G. Tower into a quagmire for the Bush Administration.

title: Stalled U.S. Dialogue Annoys P.L.O. Factions
description: Lack of progress in the dialogue between the United States and the Palestine Liberation Organization, which started in December, is causing disappointment among guerrilla leaders and contributing to a widening rift among them.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Office-Space Statistics; Vacancy Rate Is Just One Element of the Equation
description: JUDGING from vacancy rates alone, Somerset County in northern New Jersey and Fairfield County in southwestern Connecticut are bloated twins, each with 22 percent of its office space empty. But step back to analyze a variety of market conditions and the picture changes: Somerset looks as if it will absorb its excess space in two years, while Fairfield will need five or six years.

title: From Dance To Bowling, Chacun A Son Gout
description: Napoleon and Josephine were unable to attend, but that didn't stop the France Danse benefit at Lincoln Center from being a sparkling tribute to the French Revolution in its bicentennial year.

title: At Bush's Beijing Villa, Marxists Pursue Profit
description: As President Bush visits here this weekend, his lodgings will be testimony to China's growing interest in market economics.

title: Dan Kelly Was Hockey's Voice
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Rushdie Novel Stirs Passions East and West; Question of Bomb Scare
description: To the Editor:

title: JAY LENO: NOT JUST ANOTHER FUNNY FACE
description: THEY LAUGHED WHEN JAY LENO said, ''President Bush is starting to get tough. Last week he said he wouldn't tolerate cost overruns from defense contractors. So from now on if the Pentagon wants to get sophisticated weapons, they're going to have to go down and buy 'em at the gun shop like everybody else.''

title: Stefanie Klein to Wed
description: Stefanie Klein and Andrew Bressman, a son of Mr. and Mr. Arthur Bressman of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., plan to marry March 25, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Klein of Parsippany, N.J., have announced. Miss Klein is a vice president of the Tie-It-Rite Ribbon Corporation in Parsippany. Mr. Bressman is the director of operations at the New York office of Arthur's Apparel Associates. He is a graduate of the Berkshire School and the University of Hartford, which Miss Klein attended.

title: The Influence of Dada and Its Offshoot
description: AT a distance, its window display suggests that the the City Without Walls Gallery is showing tribal art. But while the exhibition ''Under the Influence'' celebrates Black History Month and includes artists who are black, its subject is the influence that Dada still wields, 73 years after its official baptism in Switzerland - as if the art public needed a reminder.

title: Pollution Parable
description: ACCORDING TO TOM J. THORDARSON, when the developers of Big Bang Schtroumpfs, the $85 million theme park set to open on May 9 in Metz, France, approached him to create a theatrical extravaganza as an attraction for the new park, they gave him a few parameters. The show was to be nonverbal, so as to be accessible to all international visitors. The show was to make use of a motorcycle stuntman the sponsors favored. And ''the show was to have a moralistic undertone,'' says Thordarson. ''They wanted the story to educate youth about the seriousness of the problem of pollution.''

title: Fire Kills 200 Exotic Birds
description: Firefighters rescued about 100 parrots and other exotic birds from a burning house Friday, but about 200 others died in the blaze, officials said. ''It got too smoky and hot, and we had to back out of there,'' said Elva Asberry, a fire marshal with the Antonio Fire Protection District. No one was injured in the fire, which started on the second floor of the two-story wood frame house about 25 miles south of St. Louis. Most of the birds that died were caged on the second floor, he said.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Married to the Mob 1988. Orion. 1:43. $89.95. Closed Captioned (CC). Rated R. Jonathan Demme conjures some stereotypical gangsters ''with a comic garishness that is really something special.'' ''Everything we wear, eat or own fell off a truck,'' exclaims Michelle Pfeiffer as the mob wife. Dean Stockwell, in a role that won him an Academy Award nomination as Best Supporting Actor, plays Tony the Tiger, and his ''shoulder-rolling caricature . . . is the film's biggest treat.'' (Maslin) Horse Feathers 1932. MCA. 1:06. $19.95. Black and white. The Marx Brothers get loose at Huxley College, with Groucho as the school's incoming president (''I thought my razor was dull until I heard your speech,'' he tells his predecessor). Chico plays a bootlegger, the sedate Zeppo is a student and Harpo is a dog catcher, but Groucho is the life of the party. A Fish Called Wanda 1988. CBS-Fox. 1:48. $89.98. CC. R. A London jewel heist precipitates lunacy in Michael Crighton's caper-comedy, which stars John Cleese, Kevin Kline, ''a master of slapstick when he chooses to be,'' and Jamie Lee Curtis, who can ''locate the laughter in a simple reaction shot.'' It sounds fine, but ''plays like an extended lampshade joke . . . the worse the material becomes, the harder the actors work for increasingly less effect.'' (Canby) Dear America: Letters Home From Vietnam 1987. HBO. 1:25. $89.99. PG-13. The war is relived in the words of soldiers who wrote home ''in haste, without self-consciousness and, mostly, without pretense.'' The letters are read by professional actors, and when they attempt to act, ''the immediacy of the emotions becomes lost.'' When the letters are read straight, ''the effect is devastating.'' (Canby) U2 Rattle and Hum 1988. Paramount. 1:39. $24.95. PG-13. Phil Joneau's ''sinuous black-and-white style superbly showcases the simplicity and directness of the group's performing style'' in this concert documentary. Only when the film bursts into color for stadium appearances does it lose intimacy; the group is at its best in close-up ''when the camera's intensity matches their own.'' (Maslin) A Handful of Dust 1988. RCA-Columbia. 1:58. $89.95. PG. Evelyn Waugh's ''vicious, witty'' novel of 1934 about the last throes of upper-class English society has been transferred to the screen with ''erring good taste and misapplied intelligence'' by Charles Sturridge. The film's ''luxuriant look, left underdescribed in the novel, dulls the cutting edge.'' One bright spot is Anjelica Huston, who ''flies into the film in a biplane and takes command.'' (Canby) The Decline of Western Civilization Part II: The Metal Years 1988. RCA-Columbia. 1:30. $89.95. R. Penelope Spheeris's examination of the seamy side of the heavy-metal music world has a ''way of asking just the right questions'' of the rock stars she interviews.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Rushdie Novel Stirs Passions East and West; Ayatollah's Review
description: To the Editor:

title: Bronx Man Slays Sister, Sets Fire and Kills Himself
description: A Bronx man stabbed his sister to death Friday night, set fire to his apartment and then committed suicide by slashing his own throat, the authorities said.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I am having a constant problem with the sliding wooden doors on my closet. The plastic wheels are supposed to slide along in a metal track fastened to the top of the door jamb. Mine seem to have come off the track, so it is almost impossible to move the doors unless I pick them up.

title: Women Must Respect the Choices of Women
description: I HAVE learned that women who do not work full time outside their homes are not permitted complaints. Dissatisfaction with anything is strictly verboten. Since I chose to stop working full time at a high school three years ago in favor of teaching adults part time, I have had all rights to gripe rescinded, especially by women who remain in the workplace.

title: Many Clergymen Quiet in Rushdie Case
description: Few American religious leaders have made their voices heard in the controversy over Salman Rushdie's book ''The Satanic Verses,'' although the debate has raised important issues of religious sensitivity, freedom of conscience and the power of religious authority.

title: Question Of the Week; Did Babe Ruth Call His Shot?
description: I was 12 years old, listening to the game as it came out of the entrails of our old Majestic. I have a vivid recollection. The announcer fairly shrieked into the mike: ''The Babe is pointing to the stands, The Babe is pointing to the stands!''

title: FASHION: Leading Questions; Trade Stocks or Bonds, But Beware of Trading Your Suit for a Blazer
description: Only the armed services and the undertaking business are more regimented in their daily uniforms than Wall Street, where, for men at least, the color of money is gray. But some say there's light at the end of the street, as more men expand their fashion repertoire. Last summer's unrelenting heat stretched many suit wardrobes, driving even the most conservative men to don sport coats.

title: Donors to Neediest Cases Fund Celebrate Their Good Fortune
description: ''This year we are celebrating life,'' Denise Tredwell of Brewster, N.Y., wrote in a letter to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. A year ago her 8-year-old son was suffering from a paralysis that had been diagnosed as a symptom of a terminal form of cancer. Now he is regaining his strength and spirit and using a walker, she wrote, sending a donation of $100 ''to brighten the life of a small child.''

title: Encourage Liberal Arts At Community Colleges
description: As someone who teaches in the humanities at a community college, I was saddened but not surprised at the comment of Raymond Dennis, the coordinator of the opthalmic program at Middlesex Community College, that ''we're giving out too many liberal arts degrees'' (''Colleges Widen Their Job Courses,'' Jan. 29). On the contrary, I think that we are giving out too few liberal arts degrees and that too many students, teachers and potential employers are seeing college as merely a place where students get job-related training.

title:
The View From: Poets Corner;
Civic Group Seeks to Maintain Its Square Mile of Democracy
description: LEAD: THE members of the recently formed Poets Corner Civic Association tend to wax poetic when describing their organizaton. There may be dozens of other civic groups within the town of Greenburgh, but to residents of this small enclave, where most of the streets are named for famous writers, even the process of getting together with neighbors to address local issues is still fresh and exciting.

title: Why the Higher Rungs of Power Elude Black Politicians
description: IN the story of Peter Pan, the ''lost boys'' of Never-Never Land were children who had fallen from their prams and had not been claimed for seven days. Black politicians whose aspirations have taken them beyond the safe bounds of predominantly black constituencies have often found themselves in a limbo of their own.

title: Newsletters That Point the Way in Different Ways
description: TRAVEL newsletters are a growth business, not surprising considering that the tourism industry, now the No. 3 industry in the country (after food and autos), is predicted by the Commerce Department to be in first place by the turn of the century. Add to that the reality that a home computer enables almost anyone who can type a letter to be a publisher, and you have a decade in which newsletters have popped up with regularity, although they have often dropped off within months. The members of the Newsletter Association list 125 in the travel field.

title: Aguirre Leads Piston Victory
description: Mark Aguirre's accomplishments have always been accompanied by controversy. He spent eight and a half seasons with the Dallas Mavericks, excelling as one of the top small forwards in the National Basketball Association. He also endured tempestuous relationships with two head coaches. He was criticized for lack of effort. And teammates claimed they never knew which Mark Aguirre would show up.

title: Evelyn Wallace Is Engaged
description: Col. Bobby Wallace, U.S.A., retired, of Decatur, Ala., and Karin Wallace of Falls Church, Va., have made known the engagement of their daughter Evelyn Wallace to Steven E. Goldin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin S. Goldin of North Brunswick, N.J. Miss Wallace, a graduate of Rutgers University, is a business reporter at The Home News in New Brunswick, N.J. Mr. Goldin, the director of marketing and sales at K. Hovnanian Inner City Developments, home builders in Red Bank, N.J., graduated from Harvard University and received an M.B.A. degree at Columbia University.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Outing; Ice Rinks Far From the Madding Crowd
description: Each wintry Sunday, thousands of aspiring figure-eight carvers glide onto New York City's grand outdoor rinks - Wollman and Rockefeller - only to encounter a mob scene that sometimes more closely resembles a roller derby than choreography.

title: POSTINGS: Design Snag; 100 Affordables
description: Five years ago, the New York Housing Partnership identified six sites in the South Bronx for housing affordable by families earning up to $30,000 a year. It took that long for the Partnership to line up the financing and the many government approvals needed for the 50 two-family homes it planned, and then, late last year, the project hit a snag: The State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation asked that the design be modified to make it compatible with structures in the adjacent Longwood Historic District. The bill for the changes would come to $8,000 a unit, or $800,000 - enough to imperil the project.

title:
GARDENING;
The Two Sides of Sphagnum Moss
description: LEAD: IN his New York Botanical Garden Illustrated Encyclopedia of Horticulture, T. H. Everett described sphagnum moss as an ideal medium in which to sow seeds, because of its antiseptic qualities. Indeed, stories tell of its use as a dressing for wounds during World War I. One reason sphagnum has been considered to be quite sterile is that it has a pH level of 4.0 to 4.5, which is below the range in which most plant pathogens thrive.

title: Rizzuto Played Like K. C. Jones
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: 'High Hopes' Votes No On Thatcher
description: Cyril, in his 30's, born and bred working class, is a political militant cut off at the knees. He has nowhere to turn in Margaret Thatcher's Tory England. As he sees it, the rich get richer, and the poor, who are getting poorer, are too dazzled by the affluence they see around them to realize that they're not a part of it. The seeming economic boom has defused intelligent protest, leaving a few ineffectual fanatics like Cyril's friend Suzi.

title: LOOKING BACHWARD
description: THE EARLY MUSIC REVIVAL A History. By Harry Haskell. Illustrated. 232 pp. New York: Thames and Hudson. $29.95.

title: The Shout From Central America; Here: Migrants and the Need for Safe Haven
description: The long lines of undocumented aliens applying for political asylum at an immigration office on the border in south Texas attest to the reverberating effect of United States policies in Central America. So many Central American aliens have applied for asylum in recent months that immigration officials have finally felt compelled to devise a get-tough policy to deter other migrants, trying to escape poverty, not persecution.

title: Outdoors; From China, Pheasants to Go
description: The Michigan Department of Natural Resources has introduced a new strain of pheasant, which is native to Sichuan Province in China, into several areas in the south-central part of the state. Save for a small early shipment of the birds themselves, they have been raised in Michigan from eggs gathered in the wild by the Chinese.

title: Review/Music; Jerry Hadley in Song Recital
description: Jerry Hadley's tenor sounded in reasonably good health at Weill Recital Hall on Friday night. We know it mainly as an operatic instrument, but here Mr. Hadley - an American singer with a substantial international stage career - divided a recital of songs among Brahms, Vaughan Williams, Britten and Rachmaninoff. His wife, Cheryll Drake Hadley, played the accompaniments.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
Singing the Praises of Simplicity
description: LEAD: ''WE'RE no longer an amateur chorus,'' one of the sopranos informed me recently during a rehearsal break, ''we're an 'avocational chorale.' '' When I asked her why the change, she looked at me as though I had been asleep since the Nixon Administration.

title: Nancy Dickerson Is Married
description: Nancy Dickerson, a commentator for Fox Television in Washington, and John C. Whitehead, chairman of AEA Investors Inc., an investment concern in New York, were married yesterday at the bride's home in Washington. Judge Abner J. Mikva of the United States Court of Appeals in Washington officiated.

title: 'Lack of Nurses: Views and Facts
description: I am responding to the article ''A Lack of Nurses Brings Changes at County Hospitals'' in the Feb. 5 Westchester Weekly.

title: WHEN SEX WAS ALL THAT MATTERED
description: EIGHTY-SIXED By David B. Feinberg. 326 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

title: CONCEPTIONS MORE SUBLIME
description: LEAD: RUIN THE SACRED TRUTHS Poetry and Belief From the Bible to the Present. By Harold Bloom. 204 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $20.

title: A Reminder of Some Turkish Delights
description: THE sign in the window of Great Neck's Tarabya Restaurant reads ''Authentic Turkish Restaurant.'' Exotic, unknown and foreboding as that might seem, fear not.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Bay Shore $265,000 49 Saxon Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 30-year-old ranch; fireplace, den, enclosed porch, 2-car garage; taxes $5,200. Levittown $135,000 5 Amber Lane 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, attic, attached 1-car garage; taxes $2,700. Mineola $190,000 334 Foch Boulevard 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 60- year-old Tudor; eat-in kitchen, enclosed porch, basement; taxes $2,500. Seaford $187,000 2998 Bit Path 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 34-year-old brick split level; basement, attached 1-car garage; taxes $4,500. West Islip $515,000 3 Cedar Point Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 22-year-old waterfront colonial; fireplace, basement, 2-car garage, 0.25-acre; taxes $6,900. Williston Park $193,000 12 Remsen Street 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; dining room, attic, basement; taxes $1,900. OTHER AREAS Killingworth, Conn. $285,000 85 Bar Gate Trail 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 6-year-old colonial, french doors off living room to terrace, tiered deck, 3 acres; taxes $3,074. Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. $372,000 22 Hyatt Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 38-year-old ranch; 20-foot-deck, 1 acre; taxes $6,290. Freehold, N.J. $218,000 42 Stratford Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 23-year-old colonial; full basement, 1-car garage, w/w carpeting; taxes $2,923.

title: WESTCHESTER BOOKCASE
description: ''The Lost World'' By Edwin McDowell St. Martin's Press. 217 pages. $15.95.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a review of ''The Village by the Sea'' on Feb. 5 described the book, a children's novel, incorrectly. It was not a 1989 Newbery Honor Book.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: SPENCE + LILA, by Bobbie Ann Mason. (Perennial/ Harper & Row, $6.95.) In a novel by the author of ''In Country,'' a farmer helps his wife survive a bout with breast cancer. Bobbie Ann Mason is ''very good at eliciting the special poignancy of people who don't really understand what is happening to them,'' Frank Conroy said here last year. A RENAISSANCE TAPESTRY: The Gonzaga of Mantua, by Kate Simon. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) In her exploration of the ancient city of Mantua and the family that once ruled it, Kate Simon recreates the days of the Renaissance, when Italy was divided into a crazy quilt of warring city states. ''A reader can savor the gossip about arranged marriages, corrupt popes and the alliance of the church with dynastic families,'' Herbert Mitgang said in The Times last year. ''Delving into the past through paintings, sculpture and tapestries as well as manuscript records, Miss Simon has put her reporting abilities to work, filling in the historical blanks.'' LAZAR MALKIN ENTERS HEAVEN, by Steve Stern. (Penguin, $6.95.) After a visitation by the ghost of a writer who died in her 20's, a man from Memphis collaborates on a series of cabalistic short stories set in a mythical neighborhood that is a cross between his hometown of Memphis and New York's Lower East Side. ''Reaching back to a neglected corner of the Jewish psyche, [ Steve Stern ] has taken well-worn materials and turned them alchemically into something rich and strange,'' Morris Dickstein said here in 1987. IN SEARCH OF MELANCHOLY BABY, by Vassily Aksyonov. Translated by Michael Henry Heim and Antonina W. Bouis. (Vintage, $7.95.) When a Russian emigre finally gets to move to the United States, he eagerly signs up for eight credit cards, joins the American Automobile Association and the Book-of-the-Month Club, and learns that America too has its petty bureaucrats. In 1987, The Times's Michiko Kakutani said that parts of Vassily Aksyonov's book have ''the passion, humor and verbal brio that distinguished his powerful novel 'The Burn.' '' A FRIEND FROM ENGLAND, by Anita Brookner. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $6.95.) Through her friendship with a younger woman, a British bookseller named Rachel Kennedy learns vicariously about the disasters of romance. Last year our reviewer, David Plante, called the novel ''a delicate portrait of a brave woman who suffers the loss of the world.'' WOMEN AND LOVE: A Cultural Revolution in Progress, by Shere Hite. (St. Martin's, $5.95.) In the third of her ''Hite Reports,'' the author reveals that an alarming number of the women who answered her questionnaires are sick of their male companions. ''If 'Women and Love' isn't good social science, it is a valuable, provocative, loosely argued, searching meditation on how culture influences love, illustrated by many hypnotizing, sad, sweet, chilling and lurid stories,'' Arlie Russell Hochschild said in The Book Review in 1987. THE PORK BUTCHER, by David Hughes. (New Amsterdam, $9.95.) A dying German revisits the French town where two events changed his life 40 years before: he participated in a massacre, and he met and lost the only woman he ever loved. This novel ''deftly explores the inescapable burden of the past on the present, and has much to say about the nature of love in our times,'' Gregory A. Schirmer said here in 1985. STEVIE: A Biography of Stevie Smith, by Jack Barbera and William McBrien. (Oxford University, $10.95.) When Philip Larkin called Stevie Smith's poems ''William Blake rewritten by Ogden Nash,'' her fans might have taken it as a compliment, Katha Pollitt said here in 1987. This biography of the eccentric English writer is entertaining and sometimes fascinating, she said. WOMEN AND CHILDREN FIRST, by Francine Prose. (Ivy, $3.95.) In one of these short stories, a disillusioned lover is amazed to discover that ''what you'd hoped was the start of your life could turn out to be a scene in someone else's porno movie.'' Last year our reviewer, Stephen McCauley, praised Francine Prose's ''strong, distinctive voice; her acerbic humor . . . and her unsparing, though not unkind, insight into the subtleties of character and the nuances of relationships.'' FYODOR DOSTOYEVSKY: A Writer's Life, by Geir Kjetsaa. Translated by Siri Hustvedt and David McDuff. (Fawcett Columbine, $10.95.) When this portrait of the Russian writer by a Norwegian scholar was published last year, our reviewer, Maria Carlson, called it ''a readable and provocative biography that contributes a fresh viewpoint to our understanding of a difficult writer. [ It ] also demonstrates how much Dostoyevsky still has to say to today's reader.'' DOSTOEVSKY: The Stir of Liberation 1860-1865, by Joseph Frank (Princeton University, $9.95) is aimed at readers interested in a more scholarly and detailed approach.
