The third installment of a projected five-volume study concentrates on the years after Dostoyevsky's Siberian exile, when he made his literary comeback with ''Notes From Underground.'' In 1986 our reviewer, Harlow Robinson, called the book ''an important and conscientious study that is unlikely to be duplicated.'' CAT OF MANY TAILS, by Ellery Queen. (International Polygonics, $4.95.) What is the hidden motive linking a series of killings in Manhattan? This mystery story ''presents the puzzle-minded reader with a very pretty problem indeed,'' Anthony Boucher said in The Times in 1949. ''The actual protagonist of the novel, the City of New York, comes magnificently to life.''

title: Negative Image
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
The Two Sides of Sphagnum Moss
description: LEAD: IN his New York Botanical Garden Illustrated Encyclopedia of Horticulture, T. H. Everett described sphagnum moss as an ideal medium in which to sow seeds, because of its antiseptic qualities. Indeed, stories tell of its use as a dressing for wounds during World War I. One reason sphagnum has been considered to be quite sterile is that it has a pH level of 4.0 to 4.5, which is below the range in which most plant pathogens thrive.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Soccer U.S. Upsets Iraq and Advances: The United States scored a 2-1 upset of Iraq yesterday and moved into the semifinals of the fifth world Youth Soccer Cup championship, the farthest an American team ever has advanced in an international soccer competition. A goal by Dario Brose in the 57th minute broke a 1-1 tie at the King Fahd Sports City Stadium in Taif, Saudi Arabia. In other quarterfinal games yesterday in the tournament played in four Saudi Arabian cities, Brazil tied Argentina, 1-1; Nigeria topped the Soviet Union, 5-4, on penalty kicks, and Portugal beat Colombia, 1-0.(AP) Tennis McEnroe Moves to Final: Second-seeded John McEnroe defeated No. 4 Jonas Svensson of Sweden, 6-3, 7-5, yesterday to gain the final of the Lyon Grand Prix tournament in Lyon, France. McEnroe, ranked eighth in the world, will meet top-seeded Jakob Hlasek of Switzerland in the final. The Swiss was a 6-3, 6-3 winner over fifth-seeded Anders Jarryd of Sweden in the other semifinal.(AP) Becker and Mayotte Advance: Third-seeded Boris Becker defeated Mikael Pernfors, 6-3, 6-2, last night to advance to the final of the $602,500 United States pro indoor championships in Philadelphia. Becker's opponent will be the two-time defending champion, Tim Mayotte, who ousted top-seeded Andre Agassi, 6-4, 4-6, 6-4, in the first semifinal. (AP) Garrison Defeats Zvereva: Third-seeded Zina Garrison broke service eight times to score a 7-5, 6-4 victory over No. 2 Natalya Zvereva in a semifinal of the $250,000 Virginia Slims of California tournament in Oakland yesterday. (AP) Golf Brown Takes Lead: Nancy Brown birdied four of her final five holes yesterday to shoot a 4-under-par 68 and take the lead after two rounds of the $400,000 Women's Kemper Open in Princeville, Hawaii. Brown was at 132 heading into today's final round. Colleen Walker was second at 133. (AP) Henning and Littler Tied: Harold Henning and Gene Littler shot 70's yesterday to share the lead after two rounds of the $300,000 Senior Challenge in Naples, Fla. Henning and Littler, who also shot 70's on Friday, took a two-stroke lead over Bruce Crampton. (AP) Speed Skating Soviet Sprinter Ties World Mark: Igor Zhelezovsky of the Soviet Union equaled the men's 1,000-meter world record in the first day of the world sprint championships yesterday at Heerenveen, the Netherlands. Zhelezovsky also won the 500 meters before he tied the mark set at high altitude in the 1,000 meters with a time of 1 minute 12.58 seconds. (AP) Horse Show Lenehan Captures Jumpoff: Leslie Burr Lenehan of Westport, Conn., aboard Lenny, won the Johnnie Walker Challenge Jumpoff yesterday at the 31st annual Winter Equestrian Festival at West Palm Beach, Fla. Only 4 of 35 entries successfully completed the 14-jump, 505-yard first-round course at the Palm Beach Polo Equestrian Club. Lenehan turned in her second penalty-free ride of the day, finishing in 31.859 seconds. Skiing Canadian Takes Cup Downhill: Rob Boyd salvaged a disappointing season for the Canadian men's downhill team yesterday by streaking to victory before a home crowd in the final World Cup downhill race of the season, at Whistler, British Columbia. Boyd who started from the No. 9 position, had a time of 2 minutes 10.03 seconds. He finished 17-hundredths of a second ahead of Daniel Mahrer of Switzerland. Another Swiss skier, Pirmin Zurbriggen, was third in 2:10.34.(AP) Wolf Leads Austrian Team: Sigrid Wolf gave the Austrian women's team its first World Cup victory of the season, capturing a super giant slalom by 24 hundredths of a second over a teammate, Anita Wachter. Wolf was timed in 1 minute 18.97 seconds. Michela Figini of Switzerland was third. (AP) N.B.A. Hawks 125, Bulls 95: Moses Malone and Glenn Rivers scored 22 points each and the Hawks broke Chicago's five-game winning streak at Atlanta. (AP) Hornets 124, Spurs 113: Kelly Tripucka scored 40 points and Kurt Rambis added 16 points and a career-high 22 rebounds, for Charlotte at home. (AP) N.H.L. Bruins 9, Whalers 1: Randy Burridge and Glen Wesley each scored twice for Boston. Peter Sidorkiewicz allowed eight goals. (AP)

title: Speaking of the Unspeakable
description: IN 1981, ON THE LAST day of my freshman year in college, I was raped in a park near my dorm. In this country, nearly three out of every four women could be the victim of a violent crime during their lifetime. What is unusual in my case is that the rapist is now serving a maximum sentence of 25 years in prison. When I was raped I lost my virginity and almost lost my life. I also discarded certain assumptions I had held about how the world worked and about how safe I was.

title:
MUSIC;
American Women Focus of Concert
description: LEAD: AMERICAN women in music will be the focus of a concert Friday night when the Wayne Chamber Orchestra performs at the Shea Center at William Paterson College.

title: Smith-Corona, Writer, Dead at 28
description: THE internationally respected letterer Smith-Corona Electric died at his home in Great Neck, L.I., yesterday at the age of 28. The cause of death was advanced technology.

title: Ted Warmbold, at 45; Editor of Texas Paper
description: Ted Warmbold, editor of The San Antonio Light, died of meningitis today at Humana Metropolitan Hospital. He was 45 years old.

title: 3 in Pentagon Case Gain Partial Dismissal
description: A Federal district judge dismissed racketeering charges Friday against three men indicted last month in the Pentagon procurement investigation, defense attorneys said.

title: China's Showcase Company
description: The Gold Cup Automobile Company is China's pride: a behemoth corporation that embodies China's hopes of transforming its state-owned factories into efficient, market-oriented enterprises.

title: Lab Use Of Animals Puts Issue Into Court
description: LEAD: IN the wake of recent protests over the use of animals, a court battle is shaping up over public membership on the Laboratory Animal Users Committee at the State University at Stony Brook.

title: October Wedding For Miss Marache
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herbert W. Marache Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Eugenie Jebb Marache and Christopher Ivan Pavelic, the son of Ivan Pavelic of Greenwich and the late Irene Bodmer Pavelic. An October wedding is planned.

title: Seeking No-Fuss Day Care? Take Your Kids to Work
description: When Renee Mardis moved to the Boston area from Dayton, Ohio, in 1987 the high cost of day care - an average of $120 a week - threatened to force her to stay home to care for her 3-year-old daughter, Ashley.

title: Correction
description: An article on Jan. 1 about Hispanic residents seeking a larger role in government in Perth Amboy described the namesake of MacWilliam Stadium incorrectly. Joseph Lockwood MacWilliam was an Army lieutenant at the time of his death in 1936, not a World War I hero.

title: Report Accepted on Sewage Plant
description: STATE environmental officials have accepted a county study that measures the ability of the Yonkers sewage-treatment plant to handle additional capacity and analyzes potential environmental impacts, the Department of Environmental Conservation announced last week.

title: Jennifer Bingham to Wed Graham P. Agee in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Daniel D. Bingham of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Jennifer Lynn Bingham to Graham Pelham Agee, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Pelham Agee of Basking Ridge, N.J. The couple plan a June 3 wedding. Ms. Bingham, a financial officer at R. W. Frookies Inc., a venture capital firm in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., graduated from the Rudolf Steiner School and Skidmore College. Her father is a vice president and a creative director of the Young & Rubicam advertising agency in New York.

title: Sudan Leader Seeks to End Guerrilla War
description: Prime Minister Sadiq al-Mahdi, apparently yielding ground to the Sudanese military, said today that he wanted to broaden the political base of his Government and seek ''an acceptable peace formula'' to end a war with guerrillas in the south.

title: A Wedding For Miss Bell
description: Wendy Vanderlyn Bell and Michael Patrick Bentivegna, a son of Patricia Connelly of Bronxville, N.Y., and Dr. Saverio S. Bentivegna of Chappaqua, N.Y., plan to marry in May. Their engagement has been made known by the future bride's parents, Mrs. Hadley Comstock Ford of Bronxville and David Procter Bell of Wilton, Conn.

title: Fake Art
description: To the Editor: William Warren's article ''In Thailand, Faking Art Is an Art in Itself'' (Travel, Dec. 12) well reported on the buyer-beware situation in Thailand. My wife and I spent five years in Thailand (1982-87) with the American Embassy and, since she was both an artist and an inveterate collector, antique shops became well known to us.

title: Henry B. Minton Weds Shari Batt
description: Shari Paula Batt, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Batt of New York, was married yesterday to Henry Brewster Minton, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Dwight Church Minton of Princeton, N.J. Marvin R. Reed, the acting Mayor of Princeton Borough, officiated at the Omni Nassau Inn in Princeton.

title: Sports of The Times; A Surprise for Boxing's Wild Goose
description: For a boxing promoter, Mickey Duff was trying to be honest. Upstairs in the Las Vegas Hilton, Frank Bruno was waiting to challenge Mike Tyson last night, but now, in the lobby, the British co-promoter realistically assessed Bruno's opportunity to be the first British boxer to win the world heavyweight championship since Bob Fitzsimmons more than century ago.

title: Library's New Arrival
description: It is getting so that academia is to the New York Public Library what the arms industry is to the Pentagon. The library, which lost its last president, Dr. Vartan Gregorian, to Brown University, announced last week that its next chief executive will be the Rev. Timothy S. Healy, the president of Georgetown University. The choice of Father Healy, who was an administrator at City University of New York and Fordham University before moving to Georgetown in 1976, was widely praised. Robert Atwell, the president of the American Council on Education, said that picking the Georgetown Jesuit was ''a sensational move.'' Like Dr. Gregorian, Father Healy is known not just for his intellectual accomplishments, but also for his fund-raising ability. ''Everything I have done in higher education so far strikes me as preparation for this task,'' he said.

title: Indoor Polluiton: Different Views
description: Senator Dorsey, in his article, ''A Hazard at Home: Air Pollution,'' points to an important problem that is only beginning to receive significant attention. When we realize that employed adults average less than 45 minutes a day outdoors, it becomes obvious that air pollution indoors presents real cause for concern.

title: These Days, Rockers Are A Somber Bunch
description: I admit it: I was wrong. Back in the early 1980's, when a wave of seriousness rolled over rock songwriters, I thought it was a good idea.

title: Edison's Impact on Art? Musicians Provide Answers
description: Every college student who ever struggled through Philosophy 101 knows that you cannot step twice into the same river. What Heraclitus emphasized in his famous metaphor - the singularity of all events - certainly used to be true of music.

title: Other Aspects Of Hague's Career
description: I would like to comment on the well-written article on Jan. 8 about Frank Hague, who was Mayor of Jersey City from 1917 to 1947.

title: Fee Folly
description: To the Editor:

title: Start Tax Revolt With School Budgets
description: The article ''Higher Taxes, Dire Prospects'' (Feb. 5), ends with the statement, ''School budgets can only increase,'' attributed to the executive director of the Nassau and Suffolk School Boards Association. Since the next opportunity for the taxpayers on Long Island to express their opposition to the steadily rising tax bills will be school budget votes, it is likely that many of these budgets will be rejected. School boards will probably protest that they (or the children) are being made the scapegoat, but many of their actions or lack thereof can justify the rejection of a budget.

title: Bad Behavior
description: To the Editor:

title: Science Fiction
description: Literary ambition is all too rare among science fiction writers. Pamela Sargent aims commendably high. If only she had the talent to carry out her grand design.

title: SPRING EXPECTATIONS
description: Think about fresh new fashions, clothes in colors that are clear and appealing. Anticipate shapes that are clean, sometimes unexpected, but more often familiar. Keep an eye out for touches of exotica - they are the spice of this spring's style. Consider that, of course, the cost of fashion continues to rise. But bear in mind that the right looks can almost always be found at several price levels.

title: Rushdie Novel Stirs Passions East and West; Why It Is Offensive
description: To the Editor:

title: A Newport Desk's Towering Style
description: In Newport and neighboring Providence 200 years ago, merchants were kings and their desk-bookcases status symbols that dominated parlors and countinghouses. The announcement this month that the tallest of the 10 surviving block-and-shell Newport secretaries will be auctioned on June 3 at Christie's has sparked heated discussions among American furniture enthusiasts about the esthetic merits of such a desk. Christie's estimates that the secretary, owned originally by Nicholas Brown of Providence, will bring $3 million to $5 million.

title: HOW CAN WE KNOW IF IT'S TRUE?
description: PSYCHOANALYSIS A Theory in Crisis. By Marshall Edelson. 392 pp. Illinois: University of Chicago Press. $39.95.

title: INSURANCE PLANS A WASTE FOR MANY
description: More than five million older Americans, mistakenly believing they are adding to private coverage that supplements Medicare, are paying for unnecessary, duplicative health insurance.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Checking Out Health Risks On Cruise Ships

title: HIS BEST WAS THE BEST THERE WAS
description: Louis (Satchmo) Armstrong was one of the icons of the 20th century. The first major jazz soloist, he revolutionized the way the trumpet was played, and he changed forever the way music would sound. To the public at large, his stage presence - an image of joyous triumph over the blues - was instantly recognizable. Armstrong delivered the most serious kinds of artistic statements in a way that made people feel good; he was always himself, and his magic jumps off the pages of SATCHMO (Dolphin/Doubleday, $24.95), an imaginative assemblage of pictures and text. The book contains fascinating, previously unpublished photos of Armstrong performing and relaxing, scenes from his films and early life, reproductions of record labels, sheet music, an annotated restaurant menu and other memorabilia. The jazz critic Gary Giddins, author of the book and documentary film ''Celebrating Bird,'' provides a reliable, if necessarily sketchy, overview of Armstrong's career, a survey of his major recordings and some interesting observations about Armstrong's contributions to world culture. Especially welcome are the plentiful excerpts from Armstrong's diaries and letters. He was a genius of the spirit as well as of music, and his prose conveys much of his gusto for living, his warmth and generosity and his shrewdness. ''Satchmo'' is a valuable, jubilant look at a great man and artist, whose ability to fuse exaltation with profundity still inspires awe.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: February 26, 1989
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 18 LONESOME DOVE, by Larry McMurtry. (Pocket, $4.95.) The Old West seen larger than life. 2 4 THE SHELL SEEKERS, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (Dell, $4.95.) A woman and a painting tie together three generations of an English family. 3 4 INHERITANCE, by Judith Michael. (Pocket, $5.50.) The rivalries of a wealthy Boston family. 4 13 THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe. (Bantam, $5.95.) A bond trader caught in the jungles of New York. 5 5 MORTAL FEAR, by Robin Cook. (Berkley, $4.95.) A biologist's death leads to revelations about medicine's mysteries and Boston's nether world. 6 4 THE CHARM SCHOOL, by Nelson DeMille. (Warner, $4.95.) An American tourist in the Soviet Union stumbles on a K.G.B. plot. Union stumbles on a K.G.B. plot. 7 4 THE BUTCHER'S THEATER, by Jonathan Kellerman. (Bantam, $4.95.) Tracking down a serial killer loose in contemporary Jerusalem. 8 20 THE ACCIDENTAL TOURIST, by Anne Tyler. (Berkley, $4.95.) Family and friends impose order of a kind on the errant life of a travel writer. 9 3 THAI HORSE, by William Diehl. (Ballantine, $4.95.) A Vietnam veteran returns to the Far East to track down his best friend. 10 1 HOT MONEY, by Dick Francis. (Fawcett, $4.95.) Which member of a gold arbitrager's family was responsible for the murder of his fifth wife? 11 5 ZERO, by Eric Van Lustbader. (Fawcett, $4.95.) An American contends with a Japanese secret organization bent on destroying the United States. 12 10 ROCK STAR, by Jackie Collins. (Pocket, $4.95.) The glory and anguish of three rock-and-roll performers in tinselly southern California. 13 16 KALEIDOSCOPE, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $5.50.) Three sisters, separated by fate, and the lawyer whose mission is to find and reunite them. 14 18 BELOVED, by Toni Morrison. (Plume/NAL, $8.95.) Memories of her past haunt an escaped slave in post-Civil War Ohio. 15 * 4 VULCAN'S GLORY, by D. C. Fontana. (Pocket, $3.95.) A new ''Star Trek'' tale. 16 * 14 THE TOMMYKNOCKERS, by Stephen King. (Signet/NAL, $5.95.) Two writers' zealous attempt to unearth mysterious artifacts causes havoc. Weeks This On Week List Nonfiction 1 10 TRUMP: The Art of the Deal, by Donald J. Trump with Tony Schwartz. (Warner, $5.95.) The career and business style of the New York entrepreneur. 2 40 LOVE, MEDICINE & MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) The importance of a patient's mind and emotions. 3 4 ALMOST GOLDEN, by Gwenda Blair. (Avon, $4.50.) The rise and fall of Jessica Savitch. 4 279 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $9.95.) Spiritual inspiration. 5 10 CHAOS, by James Gleick. (Penguin, $8.95.) A new science that sees order in what appears erratic. 6 2 THE RISE AND FALL OF THE GREAT POWERS, by Paul Kennedy. (Vintage, $12.95.) The fortunes of great nations in the past 500 years. 7 * 37 THE POWER OF MYTH, by Joseph Campbell with Bill Moyers. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The ways in which mythology illuminates the stages of life. 8 5 THRIVING ON CHAOS, by Tom Peters. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $10.95.) How companies can survive. 9 5 DONNIE BRASCO: My Undercover Life in the Mafia, by Joseph D. Pistone with Richard Woodley. (Signet/NAL, $4.95.) A former F.B.I. agent's inside account. 10 1 BATTLE CRY OF FREEDOM, by James M. McPherson. (Ballantine, $14.95.) A history of the American Civil War era. 11 * 28 SMALL SACRIFICES, by Ann Rule. (Signet/NAL, $4.95.) Murder and incest in an Oregon town. Weeks This On Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 31 CODEPENDENT NO MORE, by Melody Beattie. (Hazelden/Harper & Row, $8.95.) How to solve your own problems while caring for other people's afflictions. 2 4 THE ARTHUR YOUNG TAX GUIDE 1989, edited by Peter Bernstein. (Ballantine, $11.95.) Advice prepared by the staff of a leading accounting firm. 3 * 7 RAND McNALLY ROAD ATLAS. (Rand McNally, $6.95.) The 1989 edition of a guide to the United States, Canada and Mexico. 4 3 CONTROLLING CHOLESTEROL, by Kenneth H. Cooper. (Bantam, $4.95.) A physician's preventive medicine program. 5 * 1 SWIM WITH THE SHARKS WITHOUT BEING EATEN ALIVE, by Harvey Mackay. (Ivy, $4.95.) Strategies for succeeding in business. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,250 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 38,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: POSTINGS: From Norway to L.I.; Town Houses on 1.6 Acres in Water Mill
description: The Scandinavian look - characterized by its sleekness, economy and efficiency - has long influenced home furnishing design, and now it is having an impact on housing as well. A case in point is a colony of town houses being built with Norwegian components on a 1.6-acre site on the Montauk Highway at Head of the Pond Road in Water Mill, L.I.

title: CHILDREN AFTER DIVORCE
description: My parents divorced 27 years ago, when I was 2. I consider myself lucky to have been too young to remember the actual event. I have always seen the world through the eyes of a child of divorce.

title: Old Aches And Pains
description: He has grown old and the aches and pains are worse, but as he approaches his 82d birthday, Luke Appling is still passing on advice to batters about how to hit a baseball.

title: OUR BEST-KNOWN COVERT OPERATIVE
description: EDWARD LANSDALE The Unquiet American. By Cecil B. Currey. Illustrated. 430 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $24.95.

title: Forget Flipper; Here's Fungie
description: LEAD: IN the cold, clear waters off the Dingle Peninsula in Ireland, I was courted in September by a wild dolphin, an experience that made the rest of Irish hospitality pale by contrast.

title: Car on Jersey Parkway Hits Sledders, Kills 1
description: One child was killed and two other children and four adults were injured today when a car went over a guardrail on the Garden State Parkway and hit a group of sledders, the authorities said.

title:
Art;
Visual Puns at Islip Juried Show
description: LEAD: FOR this year's juried exhibition at the Islip Art Museum, 84 works from among more than 330 entries were chosen by Susan Larsen, curator of the Permanent Collection at the Whitney Museum of American Art, and Margaret Moorman, a Newsday art critic.

title: Enterprise Zone Turns a Town From Gloom to Boom
description: Everyone here remembers September 1984. They call it ''Black September'' because that was the month that two factories closed, another laid off half its employees and unemployment in this town of 2,100 soared to 18 percent.

title: Daddy's Little Girl, Up to Date
description: FOR some of us who emerged from college in the 60's and married young, the meaning of fatherhood has shifted dramatically as the women's movement and changing family structures led to new opportunities and new challenges.

title: A Tool to Keep Women in the Work Force
description: Corporate-sponsored child-care programs are gaining ground across the country. Today, some 3,300 companies with more than 100 employees offer child-care benefits that rangefrom financial assistance, alternative work schedules and family leave options to on-site child-care services, according to the Conference Board. That is a dramatic increase over the 600 employers that offered such benefits in 1982 and the 110 that did in 1978.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: BLIMPS Written and illustrated by Roxie Munro. Unpaged. New York: E.P. Dutton. $12.95. (Ages 5 and up)

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: South Kingstown, R.I.;
Shore Homes With Services
description: LEAD: ON a 22-acre tract farmed by one family for 80 years, a developer is trying to sell homes at prices far higher than the average value of existing homes in the town, and offering maintenance services to buyers as a way of luring them in.

title: Hope Eiseman Is Wed To Robert R. Grusky
description: Hope Holmes Eiseman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Eiseman of Darien, Conn., was married there yesterday to Robert R. Grusky, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Burton Grusky of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. The Rev. Laurence Horton, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Talmadge Hill Community Church.

title: DEMOCRATS SPENT MOST ON ELECTION
description: Democratic candidates raised more money and spent more than Republicans last year in campaigns for the 101st Congress.

title: WEEKENDS: REAL-LIFE FASHION
description: Before the first crocus or daffodil even blooms, city dwellers show their colors in casual clothes based on down-to-earth comfort. It is a style that at first may appear downright messy, with a mix of tattered old pieces and possibly a new oversize sweater. But don't be fooled by the frequently disheveled look. A lot of thought goes into this recipe for nonchalance. Although the designer label may no longer shout, the sweater can still cost $1,000 or more; often, it's just toned down with jeans that have been laundered a hundred times and old sneakers that are too comfortable to throw out.

title: Officer Convicted in Marine's Death
description: The only officer charged as a result of the death of a Marine corporal abandoned in the Mojave Desert last August has been found guilty of dereliction of duty and sentenced to discharge and four months in jail.

title: Going The Distance
description: To the Editor:

title: Numismatics
description: Of the 637 Spanish silver pieces from the salvaged ship H.M.S. Feversham in the recent auction at Christie's, 319 were from the mint at Potosi in Bolivia. The auction coins ranged from the one real to the eight real ''piece of eight.'' Millions were minted and they were the standard coin of trade in the American colonies. The coin was barred from use as legal exchange in 1857.

title: The Sweet and Sour Sounds of South African Jazz
description: The tune ''Black Lightning'' opens ''Voice of Africa, The African Recordings'' (Kaz 101: record and CD, available from NMDS, 500 Broadway, New York, N.Y. 10012), the first of a four-album, eight-record set of South African jazz by the pianist and composer Abdullah Ibrahim (Dollar Brand). All the elements of South African Township jazz are there: the rolling ostinatos; the traditional African melodies; the gospel-inflected, sweet and sour tinged harmonies; the cotton-soft horn riffs and the relaxed dance beat implying that the world is, for the moment, without problems.

title: THE WORLD: Washington Is a Battlefield Again; So Far, El Salvador's Negotiators Are Not Interrupting Their War
description: WHILE Salvadoran political leaders and guerrilla commanders were discussing a rebel peace proposal in Mexico last week, there was a sharp surge in the violence that has once again come to characterize the civil war here. It demonstrated anew that El Salvador has turned on its head Clausewitz's dictum that war is a continuation of politics by other means. For the moment, at least, politics here is an extension of war.

title: Canadian Program Could Help Sick Americans Obtain Experimental Drugs
description: The Canadian Government has sent out notices to every doctor in Canada that it will allow patients with life-threatening diseases to obtain any drugs companies are willing to sell, even if no country has approved the drugs for marketing.

title: Private-Sector Jobs Stalled in New York in '88

title: Arena: Down an Alley Filled With Illusions

title: FICTION
description: SALAZAR BLINKS. By David Slavitt. (Atheneum, $16.95.) In September 1968, one of the world's most durable dictators, the Prime Minister of Portugal, Antonio de Oliveira Salazar, suffered a stroke that ended his nearly 40-year reign. A persistent rumor held that Salazar believed himself still in power until his death in 1970. His old Cabinet convened in his bedroom, supposedly to implement his will as he expressed it in supine winks, yawns and twitches. Meanwhile, a new Government, led by his protege Marcelo Caetano, filled the void. All this is the yeast for David Slavitt's witty 14th novel, ''Salazar Blinks.'' The narrator, Carlos, is a wily, much-censored poet and journalist. A political prisoner under Salazar, Carlos is transported, under orders from Caetano, to a new cell - a broadcast studio in Salazar's Lisbon residence, where his sentence is to transmit bogus news to the invalid's bedside radio. But Salazar, more alert than his keepers suspect, discovers the truth of this elaborate ruse when the insubordinate Carlos peppers his dispatches with clues. Thus an ironic burlesque is set in motion, with politicians, journalists and their lovers all manipulating the truth, all busily crafting their own notions about freedom and power. Carlos's ethical debates with himself, the reader and others are particularly spry and mischievous, especially since poetic justice is meted out against both the Salazar regime and this less than heroic scribe.

title: Joan Hirschhorn And David Bright To Marry in June

At Oklahoma, Excellence and Excess

title: The Curtain Rises On Kelp Lasagna And Chopped Liver
description: Although the current theatrical season has not yet provided much food for thought, it has given considerable thought to food. On stages all over New York, breakfast, lunch and dinner are being served along with beer, wine, schnapps, tea in a glass and blue tropical drinks with or without tiny umbrellas. Caterers and chefs should demand program credit. It has almost reached the point where one cannot tell a show without a menu. The obsession reflects the interests of a public that is captivated by the theatricality of the dining experience, by designer restaurants where presentation is as important as the food. People demand sizzle in their fajitas - show business for the money. In the theater, it may be an attempt to win back an audience that prefers to spend its entertainment dollar (or $100) eating rather than watching. Both ''Tamara'' and ''Tony 'n' Tina's Wedding'' capture two segments of the population by serving dinner along with drama. In the other examples of theater of food, the theatergoer becomes a voyeur. Only the aroma passes his way.

title: Bridge

title: Review/Music; A Blues Guitarist Takes Off
description: Greenwich House, where the young Chicago-based blues guitarist Melvin Taylor performed to a full house on Saturday night at a concert produced by Jazztrack, takes some work to be transformed into a roadhouse. Mr. Taylor did it in a few minutes at most; standing still most of the time and looking a bit like an off-duty accountant, he turned the audience into a shouting crowd who'd cheer his every solo and give him a standing ovation when he deserved it.

title: Review/Television; Teen-Ager's TV Angst

''What's Alan Watching?,'' an hourlong comedy special at 8 this evening, is the first production made by Eddie Murphy Television Enterprises under a contract with Paramount Pictures and the CBS Television Network. In addition to being the executive producer, Mr. Murphy makes some cameo appearances. The show was created and written by three of his former ''Saturday Night Live'' colleagues: Barry W. Blaustein, David Sheffield and Bob Tischler.

Then he started forward again, pausing to check the names of the players. With 271 pages, he had a lot of territory to cover.

title: Vital Economic Signs From Manila
description: In Bacolod, 18 restaurants opened last December and the provincial city experienced its first downtown traffic jams. In Cebu, real estate is at such a premium that the city sold its 108-acre golf course to the nation's leading land developer. In Manila, construction workers are clambering over the iron skeletons of half-completed buildings abandoned five years ago.

Clearly some sort of wonder, a miracle of a kind if one is willing to apply that term to human efforts, takes place when Herbert von Karajan raises his baton to lead an orchestra.

description: Even as adults in America moderate their sexual activity in response to the threat of AIDS and shifting standards of behavior, teen-agers in recent years have developed a widely held sense that they are entitled to have sex.

title: Bad Economics, Worse Politics
description: Inflation indicators point upward. The Federal Reserve responds by raising interest rates. The stock market goes down, among other unfavorable economic signs. Yet the Bush Administration continues to act as though the economy will hold and even grow, as it did during the Reagan years. President Bush cannot count on that kind of luck, and wishful thinking is no way to shape policy for an uncertain economy.

AZT, which emerged in 1986, is helpful but no miracle. No other major advance has appeared since then. That makes the reports of two promising new approaches to AIDS all the more welcome.

description: * H. Robert Greenbaum, Richard Meyer Jr. and Michael Shevack have been named senior vice presidents of BBDO New York.

title: New Paths to Lilco Pact Explored as Talks Fail
description: One path to a quick end to the stalemate over the Shoreham nuclear power plant was blocked last week when a mediator called off talks between Suffolk County and the Long Island Lighting Company. Now, with elected officials so far unable to break the jam, attention has shifted to two other fronts.

title: Hadron Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Mike Tyson's Rugged Reign
description: AS the undisputed, undefeated and unmerciful heavyweight champion, Mike Tyson reigns as ruggedly as only a few in boxing history have. With his fifth-round destruction of Frank Bruno on Saturday night, Tyson now has a 36-0 record with 32 knockouts. But the champion's dominance should be measured not so much by another swarm of his savage punches as by the British challenger's right hand that momentarily wobbled the 22-year-old champion in the first round.

title: Big Hit for Boggs in Court
description: An appeals court has thrown out a key portion of a $12 million lawsuit against Wade Boggs, ruling the former girlfriend of Boston Red Sox slugger cannot sue him for emotional distress, Boggs's attorney, Jennifer King, said today.

title: Sandwell Swan Wooster Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $956,000 and $867,000 for the latest and year- ago periods, respectively. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: American Travellers Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change of $333,000 for the both the quarter and year.

title: Venezuela Halt On Payments
description: Venezuela will suspend principal payments on the country's $5 billion private- sector foreign debt on Wednesday and will seek to refinance interest payments on virtually all the country's $32 billion foreign debt, the president of the central bank, Pedro Tinoco, said.

title: White House Recruiter For Ward Howell Board
description: E. Pendleton James, a management recruiter who helped fill top Government jobs for Presidents Richard Nixon and Ronald Reagan, has been named a director of Ward Howell International Inc., the big recruiting firm.

title: Hrudey Is Upended by Trade
description: As Kelly Hrudey, a notoriously sound sleeper, settled peacefully into the depths of his pre-game nap last Tuesday, his wife fielded a telephone call so unsettling that she ignored the protocol of good spouses and shook him awake.

title: Devils Tie Kings In Goalies' Duel
description: Inspired goaltending by Kelly Hrudey and Chris Terreri tonight limited total production to two goals in a 1-1 overtime tie between the Devils and the Los Angeles Kings.

title: Sports World Specials; Farewell to Marvel Gym
description: For reasons unknown, the ball always seemed to go through the hoop at Marvel Gym more easily and more often than elsewhere. Just ask Bill Bradley.

title: Killing in Bronx Is Found to Be In Self-Defense
description: An off-duty correction officer who shot and killed a grocery store owner in the Bronx Saturday night remained on active duty yesterday after a preliminary investigation found he apparently acted in self-defense, a spokeswoman for the New York City Department of Correction said.

title: Landry Won't Stay With the Cowboys
description: Tom Landry said today he was not angry over being dismissed by the Dallas Cowboys' new owner, Jerry Jones, but would leave the organization because ''it wouldn't be fair to keep me around hanging over everybody's shoulder.''

title: Digitext Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Computer Horizons reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a $961,000 charge from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Admiral Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Jacor Communications Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Aryt Optronics Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Net income The company said the loss in latest third quarter is due mainly to the devaluation of the Israeli shekel by 13.5 percent, which occurred at the very end of the quarter.

title: Nunn v. Bush
description: Before the Brinkley program began, in the ''green room'' (so named for the guest-relaxing color on its walls), I asked John Tower if he intended to challenge Senator Sam Nunn and others opposed to his nomination.

title: 5 Wounded by Gunfire In Queens Restaurant
description: Two women, two men and a teen-age girl were wounded Saturday night when a gunman opened fire in a restaurant in Elmhurst, Queens, the police said.

title: Results Plus
description: Track and Field Boys and Girls Takes Title: Boys and Girls of Brooklyn swept the final three relay events yesterday to win the Public Schools Athletic League boys' division indoor track and field championships for the first time since 1978. Tilden of Brooklyn was the winner of the girls title in Draddy Gym on the Manhattan College campus in the Bronx. Brian McAlpin led Boys and Girls with a victory in the 600-meter run in 1 minute 22.31 seconds and ran on the winning 3,200- and 1,600-meter relays teams. The 30 points the Kangaroos scored in the relays moved them past Curtis of Staten Island to a winning total of 58 points. Nnennah Lynch of Hunter College High School and Felicia Edwards of New Dorp were double winners. Lynch ran her fastest 1,500-meter race of the season in 4 minutes 33.68 seconds and also took the 3,000 easily in 10:56. Edwards captured the 300-meter dash in 40.64 seconds and the 600 meters in 1:34.4. Golf Littler Catches Henning: Gene Littler birdied two of the final three holes yesterday to capture the Aetna Senior Challenge in Naples, Fla., after Harold Henning made a double-bogey at the 16th hole to lose the lead. Littler had a 69 for seven-under-par 209, two strokes ahead of Henning. (AP) Skiing Victory for Girardelli: Marc Girardelli of Luxembourg won the last World Cup men's super-giant slalom of the season yesterday to give him victories in all four Alpine skiing categories. Girardelli, who had clinched the overall title, flashed down the 39-gate Whistler Mountain course in British Columbia in 1 minute 39.84 seconds. Lars-Boerje Eriksson was second in 1:40.29. Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland was third in 1:40.59, and won his second World Cup super-giant slalom title in a row. (AP) Speed Skating Two World Records Set: Bonnie Blair of the United States and Igor Zhelezovsky of the Soviet Union set overall-point records yesterday to win the world sprint championships at Heerenveen, the Netherlands. (AP) Road Racing Mieghen Breaks Mark: Candace Mieghen of the Central Park Track Club set a meet record of 22 minutes 1 second in earning the women's gold medal at the New York Road Runners' Club's 15th annual Snowflake four-mile run yesterday in Central Park. She broke the mark of 22:40, set last year by Gordon Bloch of the Atalanta Track Club, who finished second yesterday, 70 yards off the pace in 22:15. Kevin Sullivan of New York crossed the finish line in 19:36, 1 second faster than Mieghen's husband, Bob, to win the men's division. The Central Park Track Club swept both team titles.(AP) N.H.L. Red Wings 4, Blackhawks 4: Denis Savard, who had missed 13 games with an ankle injury, scored his 21st goal at 11 minutes 46 seconds of the third period yesterday to give Chicago the tie at home. (AP) Jets 1, Flames 0: Bob Essensa recorded his first league shutout as Winnipeg beat Calgary at home. Essensa made 23 saves to go 3-2-1 since being called up from the minors two weeks ago. (AP) Canadiens 5, Canucks 2: Bobby Smith had two third-period goals to break open a tight game and Montreal, playing at home, ended Vancouver's club-record seven-game winning streak.(AP) Whalers 8, Penguins 6: Jody Hull had his first league hat trick and Ray Ferraro scored twice for Hartford at home.(AP) N.B.A. Nuggets 122, 76ers 115: Bill Hanzlik came off the bench to score a season-high 22 points yesterday, sparking Denver, which won its ninth consecutive game at home.(AP) Pacers 128, Jazz 89: Rik Smits and Chuck Person had 10 points each as Indiana pulled away in the third quarter, scoring 42 points. (AP) Pistons 110, Clippers 98: Mark Aguirre had 17 points in his first start for Detroit, which, playing at home, ran its winning streak to three while the Clippers lost their ninth in a row.(AP) Blazers 124, Heat 102: Clyde Drexler had 26 points, 11 rebounds and 10 assists as Portland, playing at Miami, ended a six-game losing streak and gave Coach Rick Adelman his first victory.(AP)

title: Passenger Arrested Over Joke
description: A charter flight carrying more than 350 people made an unscheduled landing at Indianapolis International Airport Saturday after a passenger joked about having explosives, the authorities said. Anthony G. Pierson, 23, of Rochester Hill, Mich., was charged with violating the false information act and making threats, said Sgt. John Wheeler of the Indiana state police. The charges carry a penalty of up to five years in prison and a fine of $250,000. The plane continued to Mexico after a search found nothing suspicious, officials said.

title: Owner of Casino Fined Over a Nazism Display
description: A casino owner has been fined $1.5 million for displaying Nazi memorabilia and having parties on Hitler's birthday, state gaming officials said Friday.

title: Reviews/Dance; A Tapestry of Gullah Life
description: ''In Living Color,'' a dance-theater piece presented on Saturday afternoon at the Triplex Theater, glowingly lives up to its title. Dianne McIntyre and Oyamo - respectively the choreographer and the playwright -have taken the words and songs of the people of Johns Island, S.C., and fashioned a vibrant picture of the islanders' Gullah traditions and their fight to save them.

title: Fitchburg Gas & Electric reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $506,887 from the repurchase of debentures.

title: Health Plan Will Give Aid To Uninsured
description: Pilot programs to provide affordable health insurance coverage to 14,500 uninsured New Yorkers are expected to begin this spring, the state's Health Commissioner, Dr. David Axelrod, said today.

title: National Public Radio Gets By With Help From Its Friends
description: In 1983, National Public Radio teetered near bankruptcy. Employees were dismissed and programs canceled. Even after borrowing $7 million to keep afloat, the nation's oldest public radio network still faced a $3 million deficit.

title: INSIDE
description: Here to Stay, Aliens Insist In interviews, dozens of Central American refugees detained in Texas said they would risk anything to stay in the United States. Page A14. Land, Lots of Land Parks, prisons, shelters for the homeless: a host of new uses is being proposed for the military bases a Federal panel wants to close. Page B10. Roy Eldridge Dies Roy Eldridge, the jazz trumpet innovator, who was known for his range, intensity and brilliance, died at the age of 78. Page B16. Broadway the Way It Was ''Jerome Robbins's Broadway,'' a distillation of two decades of shows by an acknowledged master, opened at the Imperial Theater. Page C13.

title: Review/Theater; From Jerome Robbins, 20 Years of Broadway the Way It Was
description: For any child who ever fell in love with the Broadway musical, there was always that incredible moment of looking up to see the bright marquees of Times Square for the first time. I had always assumed it was an unrepeatable thrill until I saw the show that Jerome Robbins officially unveiled at the Imperial Theater last night.

title: Wilhelm Z. Stern, Physician, 61
description: Dr. Wilhelm Z. Stern, director of radiology at North Central Bronx Hospital, died of cancer Saturday at Montefiore Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: Tower Effort: Skirmish, Not a War
description: President Bush has decided, to judge from his own words and those of his key advisers, to go almost but not quite the last mile with former Senator John G. Tower of Texas: They will fight to win his confirmation as Secretary of Defense, but not so ferociously as to preclude any chance of future cooperation with the Democrats in Congress.

title: Enzon Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Track Star Is Robbed Of Car and Awards
description: A car filled with belongings of the track star Jackie Joyner-Kersee was stolen from a Brooklyn parking lot while she was making an appearance for Black History Month, the police said yesterday.

title: Tennis; McEnroe Captures Lyon Title in Style
description: Second-seeded John McEnroe, showing flashes of brillance, defeated top-seeded Jakob Hlasek, 6-3, 7-6, to win the $291,000 Lyon Grand Prix tournament.

title: Milton Roy Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

The company said year-ago quarter and prior year results were restated to give effect to the October 1988 acquisition of Liquid Metronics Inc.

title: Those Who Rejected Vows Find New Roles in Church
description: On Aug. 4, 1952, at midnight, Brother John abandoned his vows and left the Congregation of Christian Brothers. On June 22, 1986, after nearly 34 years of silence, Dr. John N. Nolan came back to visit.

title: Treasury Is Selling Only Bills This Week
description: The schedule for new Treasury issues this week is confined to the bill market, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills.

title: Disagreement on Inflation
description: President Bush's budget director, Richard G. Darman said Saturday that he disagreed with Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, on the threat of inflation to the American economy.

title: Ships Lost in Atlantic Storm
description: A fierce storm in the Atlantic Ocean sank or disabled eight ships, authorities said today. Eight people drowned, 25 were missing and presumed dead, and at least 80 people were saved, rescue workers said.

title: Review/Music; Cut-and-Paste Sounds From John Zorn Group
description: John Zorn showed his music's most easygoing side on Saturday night at Town Hall. His compositions often revel in discontinuity, jumping from recognizable genres to noise in sound-bite-size segments; now, the recognizable patches have grown. In two ''East Asian Bar Bands'' pieces, a few styles governed entire compositions. The second half of the concert - with music for Naked City, Mr. Zorn's five-piece rock band - had enough conventional tunes and rhythms to make jolts of noise sound like comic punctuation.

description: b-Included a special gain of $400,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Taking Tennis on a Vacation
description: RICHARD BUONOMO, who plays tennis an average of once or twice a week during the winter, takes at least one tennis vacation a year and knows exactly what he's looking for. ''I'm looking for a place that says 'We're going to have organized tennis play for at least five hours a day,' '' said the 31-year-old manager of the estate jewelry department at Tiffany and Company. ''I literally want to play tennis all day every day for however long I can get away.''

Charles Richard West Jr., Editor, 76
description: Charles Richard West Jr., former editorial page editor of The Dallas Morning News and a Texas journalist for 50 years, died Saturday after a long illness. He was 76 years old.

title: Argentina Seeking Aid
description: Argentina will ask the International Monetary Fund for a $300 million credit to help it meet arrears in service payments on its $60 billion foreign debt, Economy Ministry sources said today. Creditors have threatened to raise Argentina's financial risk level because of the arrears, which are estimated at $2.5 billion.

title: Review/Music; Harp Enchantment in Japanese Mode
description: Ayako Shinozaki, a harpist, made her New York debut on Saturday afternoon at the Asia Society. Her program, which included recent works by six of Japan's most prominent composers, was called ''The Enchanting Harp,'' an appropriate title, given the mysterious, shimmering nature of the music she played.

title: Farm Export Forecast
description: Both the value and tonnage of United States farm exports are recovering at a faster pace than expected three months ago, the Agriculture Department said on Thursday. The report said the department had increased its estimate for agricultural exports in the 1989 fiscal year to $38 billion and to 145 million metric tons, a rise of 8 percent in export values from $35.3 billion in the 1988 fiscal year that ended Sept. 30 and the highest since 1984, when they totaled $38 billion. Volume, however, would be down from 148.3 million tons last year.

title: Taiwan Flaunts Wealth With a Ford
description: After nearly four decades of slavish attention to personal savings and security, wealthy Taiwan is on a buying spree, and American cars top the shopping list.

description: b-Net loss The company said the prior year included a pretax charge of $8.2 million for the restructuring of the company's computer-aided engineering software business.

title: Packers Sign Ard to a 2-Year Contract
description: Since the middle of his rookie season in 1981, Billy Ard has started at offensive guard for the Giants. Yesterday, he left the Giants and signed a two-year, $800,000 free-agent contract with the Green Bay Packers.

title: Shift in S.E.C. Stance Seen Under Bush Nominees
description: Because of openings on the Securities and Exchange Commission, President Bush has the opportunity to reshape Federal regulation of the nation's securities markets. In the process, he will most likely hasten the demise of the deregulatory philosophy that was the standard of the Reagan Administration, people close to the commission say.

title: The Wrong Kind of Headlines
description: COLLEGE athletes, and even some coaches, continue to crop up in the sports pages in connection with criminal charges and behavior, contributing to the perception that a new level of permissiveness is leading to their getting into more serious legal trouble than in the past.

title: Mexican Labor Chiefs Feel the Heat
description: For more than 15 years Carlos Jonguitud Barrios has been the unquestionable boss of the union that represents more than a million Mexican teachers, as well as a pillar of the country's ruling party. But now the self-styled ''moral guide'' of the largest single union in Mexico finds himself on the receiving end of an unanticipated lesson in democracy.

description: Stuart M. Sloan, a Seattle retailing executive, was interviewing for a job for 14 years without realizing it. Three times a week, he and his jogging partner, Victor D. Alhadeff, run five miles and discuss business. In particular, they share an interest in Egghead Inc., a fast-growing chain of software stores founded by Mr. Alhadeff that had also attracted Mr. Sloan as an early investor and director.

description: On Friday, the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service detention center on Varick Street in lower Manhattan housed 180 aliens. None have been held there longer than Lyonel Dor.

description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York and Gov. Carroll A. Campbell Jr. of South Carolina today withdrew a bipartisan plan for reducing the Federal deficit after disagreeing about the possibility of a tax increase.

title: Jersey Suburb Hopes to Shoulder Less of Cities' Expenses
description: Residents of this swatch of swampland and suburbia in western Essex County would seem to have little in common with the people in Newark.

title: North Trial Courtroom Is a Stop on Capital's Must-See Circuit
description: There wasn't much doing in Dalton, Ga., and Craig Kimbrough had a discount airline ticket waiting to be used. So, not long after sunrise Friday, here he was, bundled in a sweater and jacket in the gusty vestibule of the United States Courthouse waiting for the guard to let him in.

description: b-Included a gain of $4,641,000 from the sale of real estate. c-Net loss d-Included a gain of $2,725,000 on the sale of the company's Whitehall petroleum production bonds.

title: Knicks' Record A Big Hit At Garden
description: As Mark Jackson emerged from the shower yesterday afternoon, smiling with his hand raised in triumph, he said, ''This team has walked into the Knick record books.''

title: Excerpts From Television Comments by Nunn and Tower on Nomination
description: Following are excerpts from the appearance of Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, on NBC News's ''Meet the Press'' as provided by the Federal News Service. He spoke before John G. Tower appeared on ''This Week With David Brinkley.'' SENATOR SAM NUNN Q. Senator, let's go right to the main issue here. You were perhaps not the first one to cast a stone against John Tower, but your stone was certainly the largest. Your committee went against him. Now, the White House Republicans are saying it is pure partisan politics. Does that make you angry? A. Well, not angry, but it's kind of amusing that the White House has done everything they could to break arms to get every Republican to line up behind the President. . . . So, when they talk partisan politics, I reject that. Q. Senator, the White House is leaking selectively portions of that F.B.I. report, showing that the charges are false, that they are phony charges, that the witnesses can't even remember being in the place where other people say they saw John Tower drunk. How do you combat that? A. I'm in a hopeless situation on that one, Andrea, because the President gave us that material from the F.B.I., and we receive other material on other nominees, on a confidential basis. I have not leaked anything on that report. I am not privileged to do that under the rules and under the understanding. And when the White House starts leaking it, as they have for the last week, on a selective basis, I think it's grossly unfair. If they continue to do this or if they put out information that they claim is a true representation of the F.B.I. report, and we decide it is not a true representation, then we would have no alternative but to open the hearings and go back and subpoena some people and have a full public airing of this. That would be unfortunate. It would not be the way to proceed, but the White House may force us into that. Q. Can you cite us any specific instances where you believe Senator Tower engaged in heavy drinking recently or in the '80's? A. Al, the information I have on that, the answer is, there is such information, but I cannot cite it because it's in the F.B.I. report. Q. Do you think he's a heavy drinker today? A. I have searched as hard as I know how and as conscientiously as I know how for a breaking point in what I consider a clear abuse of alcohol patter in the 1970's. I found no breaking point. . . Q. Let me just try one more. If Senator Tower and his doctor were to come to you this week, and say, 'All right, I'm going to quit. No drinking at all, and we will systematically verify this with you, Senator Nunn.' Would that satisfy you? A. Well, I cannot supervise the Secretary of Defense. . . . . so it depends on what he wants to do and what he says he wants to do.

title: Boxing; A Brutal Iron Mike Shakes Off the Rust
description: At the end, it was a familiar sight: there was Mike Tyson pivoting at the hips so the full force of his body was behind the punches he bounced off the head of Frank Bruno, beloved also-ran of Britain.

title: Koor Granted Delay on Debt
description: Koor Industries, Israel's biggest company, has won a seven-week reprieve from an American bank that had threatened to break up the company for failure to repay a $20 million loan. Koor's chief executive, Benny Gaon, said Bankers Trust had agreed to withdraw its liquidation suit while Koor, the Israeli Government, Israeli banks and the Histadrut trade federation, which owns the company, work out a recovery program. Bankers Trust said it would revive the suit if no accord is reached by April 13.

title: Reviews/Dance; Donetsk Troupe Ends Surprise Run
description: The Donetsk Ballet concluded its brief and unexpected season at the City Center Sunday afternoon with Mikhail Baryshnikov in the audience. Mr. Baryshnikov - who left Leningrad and the Kirov Ballet in 1974 -offered his assistance when Lee Lamont, the president of ICM Artists, and the Howard Gilman Foundation, with the City Center, brought the Soviet company to New York. While the troupe was in Baltimore, its original producers ran out of funds.

title: Tool Orders Fell by 27.1% In January
description: Orders for American-made machine tools, reversing a two-month pattern, dropped by 27.1 percent in January, according to a report scheduled to be released today by the industry's trade association.

title: Books of The Times; They've Seen the Future, and It Doesn't Work
description: The Grand Failure The Birth and Death of Communism in the Twentieth Century By Zbigniew Brzezinski 278 pages. Charles Scribner's Sons. $19.95. The Coming Soviet Crash Gorbachev's Desperate Pursuit of Credit in Western Financial Markets By Judy Shelton 246 pages. The Free Press/Macmillan.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; International Approach Of McCann
description: WHEN the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company introduced its new advertising campaign in 36 countries three years ago, it hewed to a single slogan: ''Goodyear, Take Me Home.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Steel Industry Employment Is Up After Years of Decline
description: The USX Corporation will formally open a $200 million steelmaking caster this week in Birmingham, Ala., that will not only produce steel more efficiently but will also increase employment at the Birmingham plant 50 percent above the 1987 average, to about 2,000 workers.

title: College Basketball; Streak Ends at 22 For West Virginia
description: Mik Kilgore, a freshman, made seven 3-pointers in scoring 33 points as Temple beat No. 11 West Virginia by 74-56 tonight, ending the longest major-college basketball winning streak at 22 games.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; JWT Wins Eyelab
description: J. Walter Thompson, New York, has been awarded the advertising and direct marketing account for Eyelab, a chain of optical stores. The account is valued at $12 million, said Mary Churchill, a spokeswoman for JWT, and will include print and television ads. JWT won the account after a four-month review process involving seven agencies, including Liggett-Stashower, a Cleveland agency that had held the account.

description: b-Included a gain of $8,530,000 from an accounting change.

title: Finance Shift For Britain
description: The British Department of Trade and Industry today dismissed as speculation news reports that it was about to issue new amendments to Britain's Financial Services Act.

title: Cerprobe Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a charge of $184,101 from the writeoff of unusable inventory. c-After a gain of $169,500 from an accounting change.

title: Heinz Goes It Alone in Zimbabwe
description: When the H. J. Heinz Company signed a deal in 1982 for a majority holding in a successful family-owned oil and soap business here, it was the first major American company to invest in the post-independence era. At the time the Zimbabwe Government said it hoped the deal would act as a magnet for other foreign investment.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Television; Recent Gains Remind CBS Of Power of Runaway Hits
description: THEIR names come tripping off the tongues of television programmers with intonations of awe: ''I Love Lucy,'' ''Bonanza,'' ''The Beverly Hillbillies,'' ''All in the Family,'' ''Dallas,'' ''60 Minutes,'' ''The Cosby Show.'' All have been runaway hits.

title: An Eager Vandeweghe On Target in Workout
description: rrKiki Vandeweghe didn't get into the Knicks' game against the Celtics yesterday, but he gave the club a preview of his shooting prowess.

title: If Bases Shut, Who'll Get the Land?
description: A Hasidic Jewish community would like to turn the Brooklyn Naval Station into a residential area. Three towns in Illinois are vying for Fort Sheridan along Lake Michigan for a park or housing. The University of Utah wants Fort Douglas - free.

title: Anchorage Journal; Soviet Rock-and-Roll Bridges the Bering Strait
description: With enough decibels to shatter the remnants of the ''Ice Curtain'' that sealed Alaska's western border for four decades, Soviet and American rock stars blasted out a farewell Saturday to an extraordinary week-long encounter.

title: Skateboarding On Snow
description: The snowboard has come closest to duplicating the sensation of skateboarding. But now Sno-Tek, a company based in Costa Mesa, Calif., has come up with a board for snow that more closely resembles a skateboard. Marketed as the Snowster, the board is mounted on dual sleds instead of wheels. The sleds, each 12 inches wide, are attached to the 2-foot board by heavy-guage aluminum truck assemblies.

title: Private Scene Led to Oath Before World
description: At 10 P.M. on Saturday, his nomination for Secretary of Defense hanging by a thread, John G. Tower asked two fellow residents of the Jefferson Hotel to meet him in one of the hotel's suites.

title: Steinbrenner Doesn't Mind Yanks' Underdog Role
description: Not far from where he sat, the sights and sounds of spring training began again. Fans moved through turnstiles, bought programs and settled quickly into seats. Players ran through drills as coaches stood and watched. The sun rose steadily as morning stretched into the afternoon.

title: Tax Watch; New York's Rule And Commuters
description: TWO tax experts at Arthur Young & Company have comforting words for residents of New Jersey who work in New York. With charges and countercharges flying across the Hudson as a result of New York's new method of calculating its income tax owed by residents of other states, many Garden State residents fear that their tax bills may grow like weeds.

title: Rise Seen for Short-Term Rates
description: Short-term interest rates may move a bit higher over the next week or so, credit market analysts say, even without any further credit tightening by the Federal Reserve Board.

title: Micro Tempus reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Latest first-quarter net equaled less than one cent a share. Revenue figure for 1987 was restated. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: New York Muslims Pledge More Protests On Rushdie's Book
description: A day after several thousand Muslims marched against ''The Satanic Verses'' in Manhattan, an organizer of the event said yesterday that the protests would not stop until the book had been recalled and its author and publisher had publicly apologized.

title: Vigil by Protesters On Change in Pastor
description: About 175 people staged a brief prayer vigil yesterday outside St. Michael the Archangel Roman Catholic Church, from which they had been blocked the week before.

title: U.S. Progress in Energy Efficiency Is Halting
description: Energy efficiency in the United States has stopped growing, Government statistics show, ending a powerful trend dating from the energy crisis of the early 1970's.

title: Treating Drug Addicts: Who Should Pay?
description: Despite growing pressure to combat the surge in drug abuse, New York City and state officials are at odds over how to increase the number of slots in treatment programs and who is responsible for doing so.

title: School Basketball; Christ The King Aims for Revenge
description: Khalid Reeves, who scored a game-high 34 points Thursday night to lead Christ the King to a 91-61 victory over St. Peter's in the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association quarterfinals, was asked about his preference for an opponent in his next game. His first choice was Xaverian (15-10).

title: North East Insurance Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $175,000 and $590,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included a tax credit of $108,000 and $540,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: H&R Block Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Farah Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income and after a gain of $1,262,000 from an accounting change.

title: Ruder Stance On Futures
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission will not seek to regulate the commodities futures markets in the wake of the investigation into corrupt trading on Chicago's markets, the S.E.C.'s chairman said today.

title: U.S. Team Selected
description: Four defending champions were among the 23 men and 16 women named yesterday to represent the United States in the world indoor track and field championships Friday through Sunday in Budapest. The Americans who will defend titles won in 1987 are Antonio McKay in the 400-meter dash, Tonie Campbell in the 60-meter hurdles, Larry Myricks in the long jump and Mike Conley in the triple jump. The women's team includes Gwen Torrence (60 meters), Diane Dixon (400 meters) and Joetta Clark (800 meters).

title: Weighing the Tower Nomination
description: The last act of the drama of John Tower's nomination to be Defense Secretary opened Sunday with his startling pledge to abstain from alcohol. That adds yet another factor to the complex balance senators must strike this week when they decide whether to give their advice and consent.

title: Ranchmen's Resources Ltd reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: After preferred share dividends, 1988 net per share was less than one cent. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Ecology & Environment reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
Tonka Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-After an extraordinary loss of $2.1 million for the quarter and year. Results reflected the acquisition of Kenner Parker Toys in October 1987.

title: Pacific Bell Settlement
description: Pacific Bell, the California telephone operating company, said today that it had agreed to settle a $700 million rate reduction proposed by the California Public Utilities Commission's Division of Ratepayer Advocates in August 1988. The proposed settlement, which came as a result of the division's audit of Pacific Bell's investment practices, calls for Pacific Bell to reduce future rates by $144 million over four years.

title: 'Set Up' for Sex Case, Congressman Asserts
description: Representative Donald Lukens, Republican of Ohio, said today that he was ''set up'' and solicited for money in connection with an alleged sexual incident involving a teen-age girl.

title: Sidney Poitier on 40 Years of Change
description: Sidney Poitier spoke wistfully about his mind-set as an actor just starting out in the Hollywood of 40 years ago: ''I had the attitude that I could be as good an actor as Brando, as good as Monty Clift, as good as any American actor of substance. I may have fallen short - but what a wonderful reach.''

title: Liz Claiborne Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company had 53 weeks in its 1988 fiscal year, compared with 52 weeks in 1987.

title: Valhi Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $3,500,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $5,200,000 for the year. c-Net loss d-After a loss from discontinued operations of $25,500,000 for both the quarter and year, and an extraordianry gain of $300,000 from securities transactions for the quarter and an extraordinary loss of $7,000,000 from the early extinguishment of debt for the year.

title: Core-Mark International Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations and other items resulting in a total charge of $23,002,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: 4 Prisoners on Hunger Strike Are Released in South Africa
description: Four hospitalized prisoners who were among those fasting to protest detentions without trial were released today, and they said they had been placed under restrictions barring them from political activity.

title: Deficit Panel Prepares to Submit Final Report Split on Party Lines
description: The National Economic Commission, a blue-ribbon panel established by Congress to devise a politically acceptable way to cut the budget deficit, has been unable to reach a consensus and this week will file a final report divided along party lines.

title: Study Faults Trade Schools' Results
description: New York State's trade and business schools are taking in more than half a billion dollars a year in Federal and state aid and loans, but are doing such a poor job that only 22 percent of the students find work in the fields in which they are trained, a study that is being released today asserts.

title: People
description: * Jeff DeJoseph and Anthony Romeo have been promoted to senior vice president, planning, and senior vice president, group creative director, respectively, of Lord, Einstein, O'Neill & Partners.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HORSE RACING Major McCallum Triumphs: Major McCallum, with Frank Lovato Jr. aboard, rallied in the stretch to score a 2 1/4-length victory in the featured race at Aqueduct yesterday. Chicot County, who was coupled in the wagering with Parsimonious as the favored entry, was runner-up in the field of seven. The winner covered six furlongs on the fast track in 1:11 1/5 and posted his second victory in five starts this year. Major McCallum returned $14.20 for $2 to win.(AP) N.B.A. Hawks 105, Mavericks 83: Moses Malone scored 8 points and Dominique Wilkins had 6 during a decisive 23-11 run in the second quarter last night, and Atlanta cruised to its seventh victory in eight games. Wilkins led the scoring with 20 points and Malone added 18 for the Hawks.(AP) Bucks 105, Spurs 96: Ricky Pierce scored 11 fourth-quarter points as Milwaukee, playing at home, squandered a 24-point lead, then rallied with two 10-0 runs to beat San Antonio, sending the Spurs to a club-record 11th straight loss.(AP) Bullets 104, Rockets 98: Bernard King scored 34 points, including 8 straight in a 17-4 Washington run late in the game, giving the Bullets the victory at Houston. It was the Rockets' fifth consecutive loss.(AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL/WOMEN Louisiana Tech 68, L.S.U. 60: Nora Lewis scored 20 points to lead No. 3 Louisiana Tech (25-3) to the victory last night in Baton Rouge, La. L.S.U. fell to 17-9. Shelia Ethridge scored 18 points for Louisiana Tech and Venus Lacy had 16. Patricia Woods led L.S.U. with 15 points.(AP) N.H.L. Blues 7, Maple Leafs 5: In Toronto last night, Bernie Federko's third goal of the game with 1 minute 56 seconds remaining in the third period helped St. Louis end a seven-game losing streak. The seven straight losses had tied the club record set in November 1967, the Blues' first year in the National Hockey League. Daniel Marois tied the score at 5-5 with 3:04 remaining, capping a Toronto comeback from a 4-0 deficit. (AP) Flames 6, Flyers 3: Joe Mullen scored one goal and had three assists for Calgary at home. Mullen sparked a first-period spree that produced a 4-1 lead and sent the Flyers' goalie, Ron Hextall, to the bench. (AP) TRACK and FIELD Senior Breaks Lewis Meet Mark: Carl Lewis's 10-year-old long-jump meet record at the Eastern States Boys Interscholastic Indoor Championships was erased last night by Dion Bentley of Penn Hills High School in Pittsburgh. Bentley, a senior, jumped 26 feet 3/4 inches at Princeton's Jadwin Gym, shattering Lewis's 1979 record leap of 25-5 1/2. Last week, the 6-4 Bentley set a national indoor record with a jump of 26-6 1/2 at Penn State. Craig Halyard of Ridgewood, N.J., won the triple jump last night at 49-6 1/2 for a meet record.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Canton Industrial Corp., Canton, Ill., announced that a Chicago businessman, Nelson Carlo, had acquired a controlling interest in the company.

title: Bohemia Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included a $1,972,000 tax credit. c-Net loss

title: Dow Up 4.82 Points in Moderate Trading
description: LEAD: Stock prices were mixed yesterday, as blue chips staged a modest rally even as the broader market weakened.

title: A Pianist With Roots in the Music of the Present
description: ''I do play music from the standard repertory when I'm asked,'' said Anthony de Mare, a 31-year-old pianist whose endeavors have been devoted largely to 20th-century music, and who is playing a concert of contemporary works tonight at the 92d Street Y. ''But as much as I love the great works of the past, my commitment is to this century. I have always been drawn like a magnet to music that communicates what's going on in the world today. And in the past week alone, I've met with Aaron Kernis, James Sellars, Fredrick Rzewski and Meredith Monk to go over the works of theirs that I'm playing on my program. You can't beat that. I learned a lot from those sessions.''

title: Seabrook Utility in a Battle Over Who Regulates Rates
description: Thirteen months after the Public Service Company of New Hampshire entered bankruptcy, the utility is involved in a tangled, bitter proceeding over who will regulate its rates - the state or a friendlier Federal agency.

title: A Joint Offer For SSMC
description: Vincent Tan, a Malaysian investor, and Paul A. Bilzerian, chairman of the Singer Company, have begun a joint tender offer of $33 a share for control of SSMC Inc., a bid with a total estimated value of $160 million.

title: Skippy Peanut Butter Chooses BBDO for Ads
description: After a three-month review, Best Foods has chosen BBDO New York to create advertising for Skippy peanut butter. The company, a division of CPC International, looked initially at eight agencies before giving BBDO; Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor; and the incumbent, Saatchi & Saatchi, fees to do speculative creative work.

title: Equity Funds Gain Support
description: Investors started 1989 with their most positive attitude toward equity mutual funds since the stock market crash of October 1987, according to the Investment Company Institute.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''Is there any such thing as quiet rock music?'' - Justice Thurgood Marshall. [ A1:2. ] ''No.'' - Leonard J. Koerner, New York City's chief assistant corporation counsel. [ A1:2. ]

title: Varity Withdraws Bid for Fruehauf
description: The Varity Corporation withdrew its second bid in five months for the Fruehauf Corporation, which it said had refused an offer to extend a deadline of last Saturday. ''We are very much on the sidelines now,'' said John McCarter, secretary of Varity, a Toronto-based maker of farm machinery. But Mr. McCarter did not rule out the possibility of making yet another bid for the tractor-trailer and auto-parts company. Executives of Fruehauf, which is based in Detroit, could not be reached for comment.

title: Chevron Capital Offering Priced
description: Chevron Capital USA Inc., a unit of the Chevron Corporation, is offering $100 million of 10 percent notes due in 1990 at various prices through the First Boston Corporation.

title: Dress Barn Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
Appointment at Harper's
description: Ed Breslin, the editor in chief of the Berkley Publishing Group, has been named editor in chief of Harper & Row's new mass-market paperback division. The appointment is effective March 6. The new division is planning to publish its first books late this year.

title: Market Place; Is the Public Back In the Market?
description: ARE individual investors coming back? Did they, in fact, leap into the stock market as 1988 ended and 1989 began?

title: 4% Pickens Stake In Polaroid Seen
description: A lawyer for the Polaroid Corporation, the target of a $2.95 billion takeover bid by Shamrock Holdings Inc., said T. Boone Pickens held 4 percent of the company's stock. The lawyer, Frederick Schwarz, told a Delaware Chancery Court that the Texas oilman owned 2.9 million Polaroid shares. He also said a large block of Polaroid stock was held by arbitragers, whose desire for short-term gain would presumably lead them to back Shamrock.

title: Foster Wheeler Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The latest year included net gain of $5.5 million, or 16 cents a share, on the sale of Conergics Corp. The year-ago quarter included gain of $1.5 million, or 4 cents a share, from settlement of several of the company's pension plans. The year-ago quarter and prior year included after-tax charge of $14 million for restructuring costs. The prior year included net gain of $13.9 million, or 40 cents a share, from the settlement of several of the corporation's pension plans.

title: Hijacking Trial Begins in Washington
description: The first accused terrorist to be spirited out of the Middle East to face charges in an American court went on trial today, with the defense and prosecution drawing sharply differing pictures of the 1985 hijacking at the heart of the case.

title: Bush in Asia: Diplomacy on the Fly
description: As President Bush stumbled through a speech to the National Assembly in Seoul today, speaking of ''the last members of the Olympic flame'' instead of ''last embers,'' and uncharacteristically mangling other parts of his text, some may have wondered whether the President was wise to undertake a grueling trip to Asia with his Administration still in its formative stage.

title: Flow General Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest quarter and 6 months included a gain of $3.8 million from the sale of a unit. Both year-ago periods included a gain of $2.2 million from the sale of a Finnish joint venture interest.

title: Biaggi Loses Bid to Avoid Prison Term
