description: Former Representative Mario Biaggi's long struggle to avoid prison was lost yesterday when the United States Supreme Court refused to hear his appeal of a 1987 conviction for accepting an unlawful gratuity and obstructing justice.

title: ACM Government Income Fund Inc reports earnings for As of Dec 31
description: Assets represent net assets.

title: Holtz Plays Down Title
description: Spring football practice at Notre Dame will begin March 15, and the 17th is the date of the annual dinner for the squad that won the national championship. ''After that, we'll never talk about it,'' Coach Lou Holtz said. ''It will be history.'' Notre Dame's season will begin Aug. 31 when the Irish play Virginia at Giants Stadium in the Kickoff Classic. That event is what brought Holtz and George Welsh, the Virginia coach, to the Meadowlands yesterday for a news conference.

title: American Woodmark reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Hundred of Aging Planes Face a Sweeping Overhaul
description: The nation's airline industry is calling for a repair program for its aging planes that would be the most sweeping ever in commercial aviation.

title: Mr. Kirkland's Words, Mr. Bush's Test
description: Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., protests that an editorial on Friday wrongly characterized his position on the labor dispute at Eastern Airlines. The editorial, drawing from published news reports, said he had warned, if there should be a strike against Eastern, of widespread disruption in the transportation industry, including moves against railroads. Mr. Kirkland says he said no such thing [ see Letters ] , and we accept that, with apology for the error.

title: Diamond Coatings Grown on Silicon Chips
description: A TEAM of American and Israeli scientists has discovered a way to grow diamond coatings on silicon wafers, a process they said may lead to a powerful new generation of computer chips.

title: There May Be Too Many Americans Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; A Lens in the Door
description: It was just a start - a lens in the door, so to speak - but the barricades against television cameras in Federal courthouses came down a notch last week when the Court of Military Appeals allowed the American Broadcasting Company to tape three hours of courtroom arguments. It was the first time a legal argument had ever been filmed in a Federal courtroom.

title: Escalade Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $161,000 gain from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for income taxes. c-Included a $232,000 tax credit for both the quarter and year.

title: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and after income from discontinued operations of $4,605,000 for the quarter and $16,795,000 for the year; a $136,959,000 gain on the disposal of discontinued operations for the quarter and year, and extraordinary charges of $65,000 for the quarter and $11,231,000 for the year. The prior year results included $98,947,000 recapitalization charge and a $15,543,000 pretax charge for relocation of the company's insurance operations.

title: Price Riots Erupt in Venezuela
description: Demonstrations against price increases across Venezuela turned violent today as thousands of protesters threw stones at the police, broke store windows and looted businesses. Hundreds of people were reported injured.

title: INSIDE
description: 79 Aliens Seized on Jet Immigration officials boarded a jet in Atlanta and removed 79 Latin American aliens thought to have been illegally transported. Page A16. Supply of Weapon Fuel The Government has a large supply of tritium, a perishable gas in nuclear weapons, but lacks a plant to extract it. Science Times, page C8. No Answer on the Deficit A blue-ribbon panel on cutting the budget deficit will issue its final report with no consensus. Page B5.

title: 79 Aliens Seized on Jetliner in Atlanta
description: Federal immigration officals boarded an Eastern Airlines jet here this morning and removed 79 people believed to be illegal aliens transported by one or more transcontinental smuggling rings.

title: Four Arrested in an Extortion Plot Asking $10 Million From Du Pont
description: LEAD: A two-month international investigation of industrial espionage culminated in a Geneva parking lot yesterday when four people were arrested after they tried to extort $10 million from E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, law-enforcement and company officials said.

title: Auburn Women Won't Let Up on Title Dream
description: When the Auburn University Lady Tigers returned home from their 56-54 loss to Louisiana Tech last year in the final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament in Tacoma, Wash., they were a devastated bunch.

title: Doner Makes It Without Big Apple
description: THE song ''New York, New York'' made a bold claim for the Big Apple: If you can make it here, you can make it anywhere. In advertising, that raises a tough question: If you choose not to make it in New York, can you make it at all?

title: New York City's Economic Growth Fails to Curb Rise of 'New Poverty'
description: The percentage of New York City's population reported to be living below the poverty level has risen despite the city's economic growth.

title: Open Positions on Short Sales Are Up by 1.6% on Nasdaq
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers yesterday reported a 1.6 percent monthly increase in short interest for the most active over-the-counter securities in its national market system.

title: PWA Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a special charge of $29.5 million for non-recurring costs when it acquired Canadian Airlines International Ltd. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Cambior Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a special charge of $531,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Q&A
description: Q. There seem to be no pigeons in the countryside, only in cities. Why? A. Pigeons, or rock doves, are actually fairly common in agricultural areas. There they find niches in barns and lofts that resemble the rocky ledges that are their natural nesting sites as well as plentiful supplies of their favorite food, small grains.

title: Buell Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Addict Guilty in Crack Rampage Killing
description: A jury in Manhattan quickly convicted an 18-year-old man of two counts of second-degree murder yesterday for the slaying of an East Harlem bodega owner in what the police said was a cocaine-inspired rampage that left five people dead and six others wounded last year.

title: Lumex Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-After losses from discontinued operations of $75,000 for the quarter and $278,000 for the year, and a loss of $1,058,000 from the disposal of discontinued operations for the both periods.

title: Solvent Used in Tanneries Is Linked to Cancer
description: A solvent used in tanning leather appears to be associated with an increased risk of testicular cancer, the Federal Centers for Disease Control have reported.

title: No Coastal Bid
description: The Coastal Corporation said it would not raise its $42-a-share cash tender offer for the Texas Eastern Corporation in the face of a $53-a-share offer from the Panhandle Eastern Corporation. The Houston-based energy company also said it might sell some or all of its stake of almost 2.5 million shares in Texas Eastern. Coastal is expected to gain more than $50 million on the sale of its Texas Eastern shares, which were trading for about $30 before Coastal made its offer. Texas Eastern shares closed at $50.625 today, down $1.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES An investigation of industrial espionage culminated in a Geneva parking lot when four people were arrested after they attempted to extort $10 million from Du Pont, law-enforcement and company officials said. The case involved some of Du Pont's most important secrets for the production of Lycra, the company's brand of spandex fiber. [ Page A1. ] Morton Thiokol plans to spin off its commercial operations from its aerospace unit, which has been under intense scrutiny since one of its booster rockets led to the 1986 explosion of the space shuttle Challenger. The new company will be involved in specialty chemicals, airbags and salt. [ D1. ] Public Service of New Hampshire is involved in a tangled, bitter proceeding over who will regulate its electric rates - the state or a friendlier Federal agency. [ D1. ] Arvin Industries has sued an Indonesian industrialist, accusing him of manipulating the market for Arvin stock by making ''misleading, false and incomplete disclosures'' of his plans. [ D2. ] U.S. Shoe agreed to sell its footwear division to an investment group led by Merrill Lynch Capital Partners for $422.5 million. U.S. Shoe's stock fell $5.75, to $20 a share. [ D3. ] The First Nationwide Bank said its deposits dropped by more than $3 billion in December. [ D4. ] Empire of America asked Federal regulators for financial aid. [ D5. ] National Semiconductor agreed to sell its National Advanced Systems subsidiary to Electronic Data Systems and Hitachi. [ D3. ] Whittaker plans to sell more than half of its businesses and make a one-time $40-a-share payment to stockholders. [ D3. ] Harcourt Brace Jovanovich reported a loss of $53.9 million for the fourth quarter. [ D20. ] THE ECONOMY The Federal Communications Commission set new guidelines for five telephone companies that have been shown to charge very high rates to consumers for long-distance calls made from hotels, hospitals, universities and some pay telephones. But it fell short of imposing any regulation on those rates. [ Page A1. ] The United States and Japan plan to alter a component of their 30-month computer chip agreement to make it conform with international trade rules. [ D6. ] The National Economic Commission has failed to reach a consensus on politically acceptable ways to cut the budget deficit. [ B5. ] MARKETS Treasury bill rates soared to their highest level in four years, reflecting recent moves by the Federal Reserve to push up the cost of borrowing and curb inflation. [ D1. ] Stock prices were mixed as blue chips staged a modest rally while the broader market weakened. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 4.82 points, to 2,250.36, in moderate trading. [ D8. ] The head trader of a West Coast brokerage made stock purchases in 1986 to inflate the price of Union Carbide stock, according to testimony in the GAF stock-manipulation trial. [ D1. ] The dollar gained strength in New York after a weak performance overseas. Gold fell $3.80, to $387.30 an ounce. [ D16. ] Cotton futures prices surged. [ D16. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Pic 'N' Save has achieved considerable success as a close-out retailer. Its chief executive discusses the company's strategy. Talking Business. [ D2. ] Individual investors appear to be coming back to Wall Street, accounting for almost a quarter of the trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month. Market Place. [ D8. ] W. B. Doner is trying to prove that it can be a large, successful agency without a New York office. Advertising. [ D20. ]

title: Sun Microsystems Shares to A.T.&T.
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. said it would issue about 3.2 million more shares of its common stock to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company for about $79.1 million. The sale comes under the terms of a January 1988 agreement under which Sun can sell to A.T.&T., at Sun's option, newly issued shares equal to 15 percent of its total outstanding common shares. A.T.&T. can purchase an additional 5 percent on the open market, bringing its total holding to 20 percent.

title: Sudan Chief Rides Out Storm
description: The Prime Minister of the Sudan appeared today to have won another reprieve for his leadership by stalling on demands by the military that he broaden his Government and end the civil war.

title: Hungary Criticizes Rumania
description: Hungary accused Rumania today of violating the rights of its Hungarian minority and urged a United Nations investigation. A Hungarian official told a United Nations rights panel that Rumania was victimizing the minority by wrecking villages, destroying cultural treasures and restricting use of the Hungarian language. It was the first time Hungary formally criticized its Warsaw Pact ally before the United Nations.

title: 'New Authoritarianism' Seen in Chinese Actions
description: President Bush had an embarrassingly conspicuous front-row seat here Sunday to a spectacle that may have been inspired by a new theory that has come to be known as ''new authoritarianism.''

title: Review/Music; Karajan Leads Vienna In Heroic Bruckner 8th
description: Herbert von Karajan and the Vienna Philharmonic are presenting two programs in their three-concert visit to Carnegie Hall. Saturday's -to be repeated tonight - was an almost popsy affair devoted to Schubert's ''Unfinished'' Symphony and various confections of the Strauss waltz dynasty. But Sunday night, Mr. Karajan got serious, with Bruckner's Symphony No. 8 in C minor, all 89 minutes of it in his statement of the Haas edition.

title: Thiokol to Spin Off Non-Aerospace Units
description: Morton Thiokol Inc., the maker of the booster rocket whose failure set off the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger three years ago, said today that it would spin off its commercial operations from its troubled aerospace unit.

title: In the End, Africa Will Shape Its Own Future
description: To the Editor:

title: American Reliance Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $1,395,000 gain for an accounting change.

title: Wasserstein Wins Award
description: Wendy Wasserstein was awarded the Susan Smith Blackburn Prize yesterday for her play ''The Heidi Chronicles.'' She was presented the $5,000 prize by the actess Jessica Tandy during a ceremony last night at the Century Association in New York.

title: Snowstorm Shuts Oil Pipeline
description: Snow driven by winds of more than 110 miles an hour shut down a pumping station on the trans-Alaska oil pipeline and halted the flow of oil in the line for several hours over the weekend, an official said today.

title: Arvin Industries Sues Indonesian Executive
description: Arvin Industries, a leading automobile parts producer and military contractor, has sued an Indonesian industrialist, accusing him of manipulating the market for Arvin stock by making ''misleading, false and incomplete disclosures'' of his plans and purposes.

title: Ethnic Albanian Miners End A Political Sit-In in Yugoslav
description: Ethnic Albanian miners ended an eight-day sit-in deep in a mineshaft today after three provincial Communist Party leaders resigned, as the strikers demanded, and the Yugoslav military mounted a show of force.

title: Israeli Stabbed in West Bank
description: An Israeli policeman was stabbed by a Palestinian teen-ager today during a patrol in the West Bank, the army said. It was the third attack on an Israeli in 10 days. Also today, a group called the Palestinian Arab Army said it had seized a soldier who has been missing for 12 days.

title: Cocaine Case Proves Testers Are Gaining
description: There is a line in an old blues song that says ''cocaine is for horses,'' but until recently, horse racing's cocaine problems were confined to the people in the game: stable workers looking for a jump start as they began work before dawn, jockeys seeking a pre-race rush and an appetite suppressant, owners and trainers chasing a fast-lane life.

title: Who Can Feel Safe on an Airline Plagued With Low Morale?
description: To the Editor:

title: Galveston-Houston Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax benefits of $223,000 for the quarter and $965,000 for the year. c-After a tax benefit of $199,000. d-After an extraordinary gain of $5,242,000 from the early redemption of notes.

title: Women Fault Soviet System For Abortion
description: The 29-year-old woman was nervous as she arranged the hospital appointment for her fifth abortion recently, remembering the nightmarish pain when she ended an earlier pregnancy.

title: Top Lawyer at Lilco To Become President
description: The Long Island Lighting Company said yesterday that Anthony F. Earley Jr., its executive vice president and general counsel, will become president on April 1, replacing Russell C. Youngdahl, who will retire.

title: Cavalier Homes Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $115,533 for both the quarter and year.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON PEACEFUL USES OF OUTER SPACE - SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL SUBCOMMITTEE - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. Economic and Social Council POPULATION COMMISSION - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Johnson's Coach to Talk Of His Role in Drug Use
description: Ben Johnson's track coach will tell a crowded hearing room Tuesday his version of what was behind one of the most sensational scandals in sports history.

title: In the End, Africa Will Shape Its Own Future; Ivory Coast Basilica
description: To the Editor:

title: Eastern Acts Against Union
description: Eastern Airlines went back to court today, accusing its machinists' union of an illegal slowdown as a Friday strike deadline approaches.

title: Reviews/Television; 2 Personal Perspectives on AIDS
description: ''The AIDS Quarterly'' is public television's effort to keep the attention of a fickle public on the personal costs and social consquences of Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome. The first of this year's four programs, on Channel 13 at 10 o'clock tonight, sets about the job by looking at the pandemic through the eyes of Adm. James D. Watkins, the former Chief of Naval Operations who was chairman of President Reagan's Commission on the Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) Epidemic, and then focusing on a family in Salt Lake City that lost a member to the disease.

title: GAF Trial Told of Stock Maneuvers
description: The head trader of a major West Coast brokerage testified yesterday in the GAF Corporation's stock manipulation trial that he executed a series of stock purchases in the fall of 1986 to inflate the price of Union Carbide stock.

title: Foot and Mouth Virus Captured on X-ray Film
description: SCIENTISTS have painted the first three-dimensional portrait of the virus that causes foot and mouth disease, a widespread scourge of livestock in large areas of the world.

title: Fonar Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $71,000 for the quarter and $505,000, or 2 cents a share, for the 6 months. c-Included tax credits of $310,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and $745,000, or 4 cents a share, for the 6 months.

title: U.S. Praises Salvador Chief's Plan As Best Chance to End Civil War
description: The State Department today praised a peace proposal by President Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador as ''potentially the most significant opportunity ever'' for a resolution of that country's nine-year-old civil war.

title: Northgate Exploration Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $2,403,000 and $3,503,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; the quarter also included a pretax gain of $67 million. Latest fourth quarter net equalled less than one cent a share. Figures are in Canadian funds. The company's 1987 results included an after-tax gain of $55 million on the sale of its Chibougimu Mining properties. The sale left Northgate without an operating gold mine and, as a result, it had no metal production revenues for the latest fourth quarter.

title: ABC Names Producer Of a News Program
description: ABC News announced yesterday that Phyllis McGrady has been appointed executive producer of its new prime-time news program to be anchored by Diane Sawyer and Sam Donaldson. Ms. McGrady, who had been executive producer of the ''Barbara Walters Specials'' at ABC, is to oversee development and production. The magazine-style program, which has not yet been titled, is expected to be go on the air this summer.

title: French Inflation Rises
description: French inflation accelerated to a 3.3 percent annual rate in January, fueled by higher prices for energy, rents and television licenses, the statistics office said today. The office said consumer prices in January rose four-tenths of 1 percent, pushing the rate for the last 12 months to 3.3 percent, from 3.1 percent in December. Despite the rise, France narrowed its inflation gap with West Germany in the last 12 months to seven-tenths of a percent, the closest it has come to matching its neighbor's success against rising prices since 1973.

title: Bridge
description: One of America's greatest players, the late Lew Mathe, would often groan at his partner during a post-mortem: ''Do a favor to an old man and lead my suit.'' He would certainly have repeated this line if he had been sitting East on the diagramed deal, played Feb. 20 in a Regional Swiss Team Championship in New Haven.

title: As Mr. Bush Partied in Beijing . . .
description: LEAD: The futile determination of Fang Lizhi, China's most respected advocate of human rights, to attend President George Bush's Sunday barbecue in Beijing had all the elements of tragic farce. For four and a half hours - by car, by bus, by taxi and on foot - Mr. Fang tried to gain entrance to the dinner, clutching his invitation.

title: Japan Vehicle Exports
description: Japan's vehicle exports in January rose 1.9 percent from a year earlier, to a total of 534,633, according to Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association statistics published today.

title: Ironwood Journal; Seeking a Skiing High In 5 Seconds of Flying
description: Ski-flyers call it ''the feeling.''

title: Duran Wants Leonard or Hearns
description: Roberto Duran, who picked up the fourth world boxing title of his 22-year pro boxing career Friday night, could face Sugar Ray Leonard for a fifth before the end of the year.

title: Omnicom Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GW Utilities Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After special gains of $7 million for the quarter and $3 million for the 6 months. c-After a $7 million special gain. d-Net income and after a $25 million special gain. The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Galanos and Scaasi: A Vivid Spring; A Master of Chiffon
description: The spring and summer fashion openings have drawn to a close, now that James Galanos and Arnold Scaasi have presented their collections. Galanos brought his clothes from Los Angeles to the Plaza hotel last week and is showing them to store buyers this week. Scaasi, the only major American designer who still shows made-to-order clothes, introduced his collection to private customers in his Fifth Avenue salon yesterday.

title: Delay by Enserch
description: The Enserch Corporation, based in Dallas, said it was delaying its previously announced shareholder-rights offering of its Pool Energy Service Company subsidiary to allow for talks with a potential buyer. The price of the offering was to have been set today. Under the tentative arrangements being discussed, Enserch said, the company would eliminate several contingent financial commitments required under the proposed public offering.

title: Vital Gas for Nuclear Weapons Lies Untapped at Reactor Sites
description: THE Federal Government has a large supply of the perishable gas tritium that it cannot use because it decided years ago not to build a separation plant to extract it. The amount, worth $56 million, is enough to replenish thousands of nuclear weapons now that traditional supplies of the vital weapons fuel are growing scarce.

title: Rig Count Dips in Week
description: The number of working oil and gas rigs fell last week by nine, to a total of 757, Baker Hughes Inc. reported. A year ago, the count was 983, the company said.

title: Interpoint Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Washington Talk: Briefing; Ferraro Back in Capital
description: Former Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro of Queens, the Democratic Vice-Presidential candidate in 1984, is in Washington today as president of the recently established International Institute for Women's Political Leadership.

title: American Barrick Resources Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a $2.2 million special charge for both the quarter and year. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Let Education Become a Shortcut Out of Prison
description: To the Editor:

title: Landry Bids an Emotional Farewell to His Cowboy Players
description: Tom Landry tearfully bid farewell to the Dallas Cowboys today, saying he loved them and asking them to give their best for their new coach, Jimmy Johnson.

title: CDI Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $7,639,000 gain for an accounting change.

title: BRE Properties reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Dukakis in Defeat: No Time to Brood
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis says he really has no time to reflect on his loss, to feel sorry for himself, to brood over the hard turns of the last six months.

title: Willcox & Gibbs Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Chinatown Shopkeeper, 71, Called 'Elder of Heroin Trade'
description: He moved quietly through the streets of Chinatown, a portly stoop-shouldered man with a receding thatch of black hair. He traveled without fanfare or bodyguards in and out of Offtrack Betting offices and mah-jongg parlors, residents said.

title: Who's Having Sex? Data Are Obsolete, Experts Say
description: PUBLIC health officials and therapists grappling with soaring rates of sexually transmitted diseases, teen-age pregnancies, sexual abuse of children, rape and divorce say that progress is being seriously hampered by out-of-date information about the sexual behavior of Americans.

title: Seaver Joining Broadcast Teams
description: Tom Seaver, who took two years off to tend his garden and learn what raising a family was like, has returned to baseball at the age of 44. The 300-game winner will double up this coming season, working for NBC on its network games and being one of two replacements for Bill White as a Yankee broadcaster over WPIX (Channel 11) in New York. Seaver will handle 50 of the 75 Yankee games on Channel 11, alternating between play-by-play and analyst. He will be teamed with Phil Rizzuto, and may also be spotted with another new Yankee announcer, George Grande. On NBC's games, Seaver replaces Joe Garagiola, and will be united with Vin Scully. Their first game together will be on March 25, when the network televises a Red Sox-Dodger exhibition. Seaver's last season was 1986 with the Red Sox. He won 311 games and lost 205 in his 20 seasons, 12 with the Mets.

title: Novel Theory Challenges The Big Bang
description: THE Big Bang theory, generally regarded as the best explanation for the origin, expansion and ultimate fate of the universe, is facing the first serious challenge to its validity in more than two decades.

title: Drum Atop Burning Leaves Explodes and Injures Youth
description: A 14-year-old boy suffered second-degree burns on his neck, face and hands yesterday afternoon when a 55-gallon drum resting atop burning leaves in a Harlem park exploded.

title: Summit Health Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
World Trade Spurted in '88
description: World trade grew at its fastest rate in four years in 1988, the GATT trade body said today.

title: Careers; Specialists In Computer Security
description: CORPORATE directors are asking a troublesome question about computer security these days: ''How safe are we?''

title: General Dynamics Contract to Smiths
description: Smiths Industries said it had been chosen by the General Dynamics Corporation to provide the navigation system for use on the United States Army's main battle tank, the Abrams M1A2. Smiths said production of its POS/NAV navigation system for this and other uses is expected to generate orders worth about $200 million in the next five years. Smiths is engaged in aerospace, medical systems and industrial products.

title: Soldier Faces Court-Martial in Spying Case
description: An Army warrant officer accused of spying for the Warsaw Pact will be tried at a court-martial beginning Monday, the Army said today.

title: Bush Says 'Common Ground Was Found' in Asia Trip
description: As he returned home facing a battle with Congress over his nomination for Defense Secretary, President Bush asserted tonight that his trip to Asia had ''underscored for me what can be achieved through a strong and bipartisan working relationship between the White House and Congress.''

title: Complaints Spur F.C.C. Rules On High-Cost Calls at Hotels
description: Responding to a flood of consumer complaints, the Federal Communications Commission set new guidelines yesterday for five telephone companies that have been shown to charge very high rates to consumers for long-distance calls made from hotels, hospitals, universities and some pay telephones.

title: U.S. Shoe Agrees to Sell Footwear Unit
description: The United States Shoe Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell its footwear division to an investment group led by Merrill Lynch Capital Partners Inc. for $422.5 million in cash.

title: ALC Communications Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said its latest year results reflect writeoffs of $9.3 million for network conversion and a provision of $1.7 million for non-recurring salaries and benefits related to management changes.

title: Ethics Prosecutors Weighed
description: An ethics commission created by President Bush is expected this week to debate a recommendation to appoint special prosecutors to investigate members of Congress and Federal judges accused of wrongdoing.

title: Rushdie Ads By Sussman
description: Sussman & Sugar, the book-publishing advertising subsidiary of Ogilvy & Mather, is the creative force behind an ad scheduled to run Thursday in dozens of publications around the world protesting the threats by the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini of Iran against the author Salman Rushdie.

title: Saskatchewan Oil & Gas reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Beaux Arts Trio
description: The Beaux Arts Trio - Isidore Cohen, violinist; Menahem Pressler, pianist, and Peter Wiley, cellist - is to perform at Carnegie Hall Friday at 8 P.M. The program will include the Haydn Trio in C (Hob. XV:27), the Ravel Trio in A minor and the Schubert Trio in E flat (Op. 100). Tickets are $14 and $30. Information: 247-7800.

title: Angry Judge Delays North Trial as Sides Clash Over Secrecy
description: An angry judge today abruptly halted the trial of Oliver L. North until Tuesday after the defense appeared ready to ask a witness to disclose a name the Government wants to keep classified.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15

title: In a First, the Neediest Cases Tops $4 Million
description: The 77th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund ends today, with contributions passing the $4 million mark for the first time.

title: American Western Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $875,000 from an accounting change.

title: East German Theorist Rejects Soviet-Style Change
description: The leading theorist of the East German Communist Party has rejected a political and economic renewal in line with Mikhail S. Gorbachev's restructuring and openness in the Soviet Union.

title: Racial Lines Drawn for Primary Today in Chicago
description: Acting Mayor Eugene Sawyer and his challenger, Richard M. Daley, today ended their campaigns for Tuesday's Democratic mayoral primary with each promising to attract broad support across racial lines. But all signs point to the contrary.

title: Huge Conservation Effort Aims to Save Vanishing Architect of the Savanna
description: THE African elephant - mythic symbol of a continent, keystone of its ecology and the largest land animal remaining on earth - has become the object of one of the biggest, broadest international efforts yet mounted to turn a threatened species off the road to extinction.

title: Savings and Loans That Prosper
description: Even as Congress considers a rescue package for the beleaguered savings and loan industry that the Bush Administration estimates could eventually cost $157 billion, more than 80 percent of the 3,100 savings and loan companies are solvent and about half of them are considered in the best of health.

title: Mets Trying to Speed Up Baserunners
description: Steve Williams says he never played much baseball when he was growing up in New York or attending Evander Childs High School or San Diego State University. But then, none of the Mets ever did what Steve Williams did.

title: Callahan Mining reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Latest year loss included a $4,993,000 price and reserve-related writedown at the company's Ropes Gold Mine in Michigan. The company said declaration of a dividend for the current year wasn't considered because retained earnings of the company are currently in deficit which, under Arizona Law, precludes payment of dividends.

title: 15 in Moscow Protest Iran's Rushdie Threat
description: About 15 people waved placards and banners and shouted ''Shame on Khomeini!'' today outside the Iranian Embassy in a demonstration in support of the British novelist Salman Rushdie.

title: SBE Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Greenery Rehabilitation Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Ayatollah's Other Victim
description: After a bookstore in Washington sold out of Salman Rushdie's ''Satanic Verses,'' Marianne Wiggins's new novel, ''John Dollar,'' appeared in the window instead. ''If you can't read the husband's book,'' said a sign above the display, ''read the wife's.''

title: Ewing Is Honored
description: Patrick Ewing, who averaged 29.8 points, 7.8 rebounds and 4.50 blocked shots in leading the Knicks to three victories in four games, has been selected the National Basketball Association player for the week for the period ending Sunday. Ewing had a career-high 45 points last Friday night. ''I hope this paves the way for most valuable player consideration,'' Ewing said.

title: Smog as a Barrier: It May Limit Exposure to Radiation
description: ENVIRONMENTAL scientists in recent months have been faced with a seeming paradox: one group of researchers has determined that the ozone shield, which screens out harmful ultraviolet radiation, is slowly being depleted over North American latitudes. But contrary to what might be expected, other researchers have found no increase in the amount of ultraviolet radiation reaching the ground in eight American cities.

title: Empire of America Seeks F.S.L.I.C. Aid
description: Empire of America, the Buffalo-based savings bank that acquired more than a dozen savings and loans and savings banks in the early part of this decade, asked the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation yesterday for $900 million in financial help.

title: St. John's Prevails in Overtime
description: In what otherwise has been a season of uncertainties, at least two preseason expectations have held up in the Big East. Dana Barros of Boston College has scored a lot of points, and St. John's has suffered through the maturing process of its young but talented players.

title: Thousands Dead in Ethiopia Meningitis Outbreak
description: A particularly virulent strain of meningitis has reached epidemic proportions in Ethiopia, killing as many as 10,000 people in one region, aid workers in Addis Ababa said today.

title: Agreement Set For a Cleanup At Nuclear Site
description: The Energy Department, the Environmental Protection Agency and Washington State said today that they had reached an agreement to clean up radioactive and toxic wastes at the Hanford Reservation, the most contaminated of the nation's nuclear weapons plants.

title: General Homes Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Economists More Hopeful
description: The nation's economy is expected to slow significantly this year, but the chances of a recession in the next two years have eased slightly, according to a poll of economists issued today.

title: Connecticut Natural Gas Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain equal to 26 cents a share from income tax-related transactions, including a gain of 17 cents a share from an income-tax accounting change. c-Included a gain from a revenue accounting change equal to 33 cents a share.

title: More Wheat to China
description: China has been authorized to buy two million more metric tons of American wheat at subsidized prices, the Agriculture Department said today. Richard W. Goldberg, the Acting Under Secretary, said the wheat would be available to China under the department's Export Enhancement Program. Under the program, private exporters can sell American commodities at reduced prices to meet foreign competition in selected overseas markets and then collect free Government surpluses of grain or other commodities as bonuses. Under previous authorizations, China has bought more than 7.4 million tons of wheat for delivery in 1988-89.

title: A Koppers Unit Is Sold by Beazer
description: Beazer P.L.C. said it had sold the polyester resin business of the Koppers Company to Reichhold Chemicals Inc., which is owned by Dainippon Ink and Chemicals Inc., for $78 million in cash. The division, a leading producer of polyester thermoset resins, had annual revenues of about $120 million in 1988.

title: Anthony Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split in September 1988.

title: Fuqua Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $5,682,000 for the quarter and $15,970,000 for the year. c-Net income and included income of $3,079,000 from discontinued operations. d-After income of $19,784,000 from discontinued operations. The latest periods included after- tax gains of $1,008,000 for the quarter and $3,184,000 in the year for the closing of certain Fuqua photo-finishing plants. The latest quarter and year included a charge of $9,594,000 for severance benefits and the termination of certain employment agreements. The latest year included $68,803,000 after-tax gain from the combination of Fuqua's photo-finishing operations with the domestic photo-finishing operations of Eastman Kodak Co.

title: World Bank and I.M.F. In a Conflict Over Roles
description: Although neither is a commercial enterprise, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund are encroaching on each other's turf as if deregulation had just come to global economics.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Hope for Democracy
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan believes there are reasons to be optimistic about the future of democracy in the world. One is the easing of the cold war between the Soviet Union and the United States, he says. Another is the likelihood that candidates from the two major political parties will seriously vie for election as the next Mayor of New York City.

title: Cayton Asks Action Against King
description: Bill Cayton, the embattled manager of Mike Tyson, asked the New York State Athletic Commission today to take action against the promoter Don King for interfering with Cayton's contractual relationship with the heavyweight champion.

title: Books of The Times; Fantasy Amid the Reality of Naples
description: Thus Spake Bellavista Naples, Love, and Liberty By Luciano De Crescenzo Translated by Avril Bardoni. 206 pages. Grove Press. $17.95.

title: Lafleur's Hat Trick Gives Rangers a Needed Lift
description: He probably could have used one of the hats, for it is cold outside and his hairline is slowly receding. Guy Lafleur, though, sat unmoving as the hats honoring his third goal of the game were shoveled up. If he had a use for them, it was only as handsome additions to his large and incredibly still expanding collection of memorable moments.

title: Washington Talk: Senate; Bradley's Covert Effort To Become Panel Chief
description: After four years of serving on the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence and hearing about the Government's most confidential operations, Senator Bill Bradley began a covert action of his own late last year: He tried to wrest the committee chairmanship from Senator David L. Boren.

title: Harry Gorman, 72, Space-Animal Trainer
description: Dr. Harry Gorman, a veterinarian who trained animals that the United States sent into space, died Friday. He was 72 years old.

title: Kremlin's Mideast Sprint; Diplomats See Gains Outweighing Setbacks On Wide-Ranging Tour by Shevardnadze
description: In a 10-day Soviet diplomatic swing through the Middle East and the Persian Gulf, Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze displayed a broad diplomatic reach that extended to both Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization, to both Iraq and Iran.

title: New Charges Weighed Against Walters
description: Federal prosecutors are considering new charges, including perjury and obstruction of justice, against Norby Walters, the former sports agent accused of signing college athletes and then threatening them if they backed out of agreements, District Attorney Anton Valukas said in Chicago yesterday. Walters and Lloyd Bloom are facing racketeering, wire fraud, mail fraud and extortion charges in a trial scheduled to start Wednesday in Chicago. The new charges center on a tax scheme Walters is accused of engineering with Paul Palmer, a Kansas City running back, Valukas said. He said documents recently supplied to the government by defense attorneys may not match Walters's testimony before a grand jury last summer.(AP)

title: Study Questions Adequacy of Warnings About Tainted Fish
description: LEAD: A NEW study sponsored by an environmental group suggests that eating pesticide-tainted sport fish from the Great Lakes might pose a far greater cancer risk than is acknowledged by state health departments.

title: Joe Silver, 66, a Broadway Star And Actor in Film and Television
description: Joe Silver, an actor who appeared on and Off Broadway, in films and in more than 1,000 television programs, died of a heart attack yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital in Manhattan. Mr. Silver, who had been suffering from liver cancer, was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Quake Toll For 1988 Is Highest Since '76
description: Earthquake deaths last year approached three times the world's annual average, largely as a result of the tremor in Armenia, the United States Geological Survey estimated today.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption Friday about an interfaith group's statement denouncing the death threat against Salman Rushdie misidentified the dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. He is the Rev. James Park Morton.

title: Japan and U.S. to Change Part of Chip Agreement
description: The United States and Japan today signaled for the first time that they would alter a component of their 30-month computer chip agreement to try to make it conform to international trade rules.

title: Harcourt Brace in the Red Amid Its Recapitalization
description: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc., the publishing company, yesterday reported a fourth-quarter loss of $53.9 million, in contrast to a profit of $95.1 million, or $1.36 a share, a year earlier. Revenues rose to $392.8 million from $329.7 million.

title: Fleet/Norstar
description: Fleet/Norstar Financial Group Inc. tapped the debt market yesterday with a $100 million issue of 10 1/4 percent notes due 1992 at a price of 99.875, to yield 10.30 percent, through Salomon Brothers Inc. At pricing the notes were yielding about 78 basis points more than the three-year Treasury note. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. Underwriters said that the issue is noncallable for 18 months and rated A-1 by Moody's and AA- by Standard & Poor's.

title: Whittaker Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Reflected a provision for costs relating to the consolidation of two technology units amounting to $3,500,000 pretax.

title: Partners Buy A Computer Subsidiary
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell its National Advanced Systems subsidiary to Electronic Data Systems and Hitachi Ltd. for $398 million in cash.

title: Woman Gets Term in Raiders' Fatal Shooting
description: A 23-year-old woman was sentenced yesterday to 5 to 15 years in prison on a gun charge stemming from a drug raid at her apartment in Manhattan in which a police officer shot and killed another officer.

title: Nets Let Stockton and Jazz Run Away With Victory
description: Watching John Stockton run the Utah Jazz offense is like watching a conductor run a symphony orchestra.

title: Reliability Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Visual Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
If You Really Want a Fax Board, Ask About . . .
description: IN the world of electronic communication, facsimile transmission is behind only the telephone in volume of messages; more than a million fax devices were sold in this country last year.

title: Review/Theater; Innaurato Befriends Mahler in 'Gus and Al'
description: It's hard to believe that four years have passed since Albert Innaurato, the author of ''Gemini'' and ''The Transfiguration of Benno Blimpie,'' last had a new play in New York. As a writer, Mr. Innaurato has an intense operatic voice, by turns comic and sentimental, that lingers in the ear. Even ''Coming of Age in SoHo,'' his jumbled comedy of 1985, retains a vivid afterlife. Among other distinctive traits, it may be the only play ever to have changed the gender of its protagonist (from female to male) during previews.

title: Sydney Houghton Weinberg Marries Stanley F. Buchthal, Film Executive
description: Sydney Houghton Weinberg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney J. Weinberg Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., was married in New York yesterday to Stanley F. Buchthal, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Buchthal of Hackensack, N.J. Judge Phyllis Gangel-Jacob of Civil Court in Manhattan performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Peter A. Weinberg, the bride's brother and sister-in-law.

title: Printer Problems Cured
description: MYSTERIOUS problems may crop up when you change from a nine-pin to a 24-pin dot-matrix printer, as many people are doing.

title: Xerox Credit Notes
description: The Xerox Credit Corporation is offering $175 million of notes due 1992 through Salomon Brothers Inc. Underwriters gave the notes a 10 1/8 percent coupon and offered them at a price of 99.90, to yield 10.165 percent, or 68 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. Noncallable for two years, the notes are rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: When an Exotic Virus Strikes: A Deadly Case of Lassa Fever
description: A RESIDENT of a Chicago suburb died two weeks ago from a rare African viral disease that he caught after flying to the funerals of his parents in Nigeria. It was the first case of Lassa fever in the United States in more than a decade and only the third since the dramatic discovery of the deadly virus that causes it in 1969.

title: PATTERNS
description: Fierce on the Runway

title: RIGHTISTS REJECT DUARTE PEACE BID
description: A proposal by President Jose Napoleon Duarte to postpone elections, begin a cease-fire and meet leftist guerrillas was rejected today by a key right-wing party and by the rebels' political allies.

title: New Head Of Garden Is Elected
description: Gregory R. Long, director of the $307 million campaign for the New York Public Library, was elected yesterday as president of the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx, with a promise that the 98-year-old institution would come to the fore on environmental issues.

title: Shamir Won't Make Peace
description: The Bush Administration is being urged to respond swiftly to a recent Soviet peace plan for the Middle East.

title: Vietnam Constitution Drops Charges of U.S. Aggression
description: Vietnam has rewritten the preamble of its Constitution to remove all accusations of aggression and imperialism by the United States, China, France and Japan.

title: Honduran Army Backing Dismantling of Contras
description: After years of cooperating closely with Nicaraguan rebel groups, key Honduran military commanders say they will support the new accord by Central American presidents calling for the dismantling of rebel camps in Honduras.

title: Fed Names Top Lawyer
description: The Federal Reserve said today that James V. Mattingly Jr. had been appointed general counsel. The 44-year-old Mr. Mattingly, currently deputy general counsel, has been on the Fed's staff since 1974. He replaces Michael Bradfield, who resigned to return to private law practice.

title: John Patierno, Aerodynamics Engineer, 54
description: John Patierno, who pioneered development of the B2 Stealth bomber, died Saturday of cancer at Hoag Memorial Hospital in Newport Beach, said a Northrop spokesman, officials of the Northrop Corporation said today. He was 54 and lived in Newport Beach.

title: Article 950189 -- No Title
description: The First Nationwide Bank confirmed today that its deposits dropped by more than $3 billion in December, a month in which savings institutions in the nation lost a record amount of deposits.

title: One More Event
description: Marty Stern, the women's track coach at Villanova, wanted the Penn Relays to add a women's 6,000-meter relay because he thought his team could run the fastest time ever. Tim Baker, the meet director, said he did not want a one-sided race. So Stern persuaded such women's track powers as Oregon, Oklahoma State and Wisconsin to enter the April 27-29 meet in Philadelphia and run against Villanova in the 3,200-meter and 6,000-meter relays and the distance medley. Stern also promised that Vicki Huber, Villanova's 1988 Olympic finalist in the 3,000 meters, would run in all three relays. That convinced Baker, and he said yesterday that the 6,000-meter relay would be squeezed in.

title: Rauch Industries reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a LIFO adjustment which reduced earnings by 20 cents a share.

title: Roy Eldridge, 78, Jazz Trumpeter Known for Intense Style, Is Dead
description: Roy Eldridge, a jazz trumpeter who was the connecting link in the line that went from the pioneering Louis Armstrong to the modernist innovator Dizzy Gillespie, died Sunday at Franklin General Hospital in Valley Stream, L.I. He was 78 years old.

title: Housing Survey Planned
description: More than 41,000 homes in 11 metropolitan areas will be visited from April to November in an annual survey for the Department of Housing and Urban Development to learn more about the condition and number of housing units in use, the Census Bureau said today.

title: Reviews/Television; Lower Life Among the Cutthroats
description: ''Harry's Kingdom,'' produced by Richard Broke for the BBC, enters the competitive world of salesmen and decimates it. Written by Ron Pearson and directed by Robert Young, the film can be seen on cable tonight at 9 and tomorrow morning at 1 A.M. on the Arts & Entertainment Network.

title: Chancellor Aims to Purge 'What-Cha's and Aint's'
description: New York City's Schools Chancellor, Richard R. Green, is beginning a campaign to purge New York of New Yorkese and other offending speech patterns.

title: Whittaker Sets Plan To Thwart Takeover
description: Under the threat of a possible takeover attempt, the Whittaker Corporation said today that it would sell more than half of its businesses and make a one-time $40-a-share payment to stockholders.

title: Westmark International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax benefits of $39,000 and $326,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss and included for the quarter an extraordinary loss of $221,000. The company said the improvement in 1988 results resulted from a 25 percent growth in revenue, substantially improved gross margins, particularly in patient monitoring ultrasound operations, and lower marketing and administrative expenses. The results for the year included significantly lower foreign exchange gains than were reported in 1987. The company also said it had special charges in 1987 totaling $9.6 million which stemmed from the consolidation of management of international and domestic ultrasound operations and from a writedown of international ultrasound inventories.

title: Our Towns; This Is a War Being Waged Over Bird Feed
description: Until Robert A. Lange moved from southern Westchester County, which can look an awful lot like New York City, to northern Westchester, which looks the way a suburb should, he thought every bird was a sparrow.

title: New Focus On Tower
description: The debate in the Senate over whether John G. Tower's work as a military consultant should bar him from being Defense Secretary turns on two areas that are as difficult to judge as the drinking and other issues that are troubling the nomination.

title: UAP Inc reports earnings for
description: b-Included a special charge of $1,113,000. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: KEY RATES
Conseco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Review/City Ballet; At 40, Standards and Surprises
description: For the fifth year the New York City Ballet has turned the closing night of its winter season into a benefit for its own Dancers' Emergency Fund. This new company tradition has all sorts of thematic possibilities and Sunday night's program at the New York State Theater was not only stupendously danced but also brilliantly arranged.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; A Revision in Jargon
description: Representative Ronald V. Dellums, a California Democrat, has long been bothered by the Pentagon's term for secret programs, budgets and operations. They are called ''black programs'' or ''black budgets'' and Pentagon people often talk of ''operations in the black world.''

title: Neutrogena Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included a credit of $345,000 representing cumulative effect of an accounting change. Share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split to be effected March 31.

title: Topics of The Times; Cowboy Takeover
description: Texas's already battered pride suffered a sharp new blow last year when word circulated that Japanese investors might be interested in buying the troubled Dallas Cowboys football team. Not only was there no billionaire Texan available to rescue this Texas institution, but ''America's Team'' - as the Cowboys styled themselves during the 1970's - was actually in danger of passing into the control of foreigners.

title: Conflicting Studies Cloud Development of an Osteoporosis Drug
description: VITAMIN D hormone, once considered one of the most promising drugs for treating osteoporosis, has become mired in controversy over conflicting studies and safety concerns.

title: Church & Dwight Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago quarter and prior year included pretax gain of $2,800,000 on a pension plan termination and curtailment.

title: Decade Of Decision
description: In August 1988, Thomas Lovejoy, a biologist for the Smithsonian Institution, offered a chilling prediction to the American Institute of Biological Sciences:

title: Topics of The Times; Subway Censor
description: Last year New York's Metropolitan Transportation Authority began an ill-conceived war on subway concessions, evicting many small businesses and demolishing 42 of the subway system's 97 newsstands. Top transit officials are now taking aim against subway musicians and pamphleteers. Restrictive new regulations proposed by David Gunn, head of the city's Transit Authority, would sap more life from the system while stifling First Amendment rights.

title: Kennerly Woody, 86, Telephone Executive
description: Kennerly Woody, a retired vice president and secretary of the New York Telephone Company, died yesterday at his home in New Canaan, Conn., after a brief illness. He was 86 years old.

title: F.D.A. Approves Genentech Claim
description: Genentech Inc. said today that the Food and Drug Administration had approved its claim that its heart attack drug, tissue plasminogen activator, saves lives.

title: Trader Fined $1,125,000
description: A futures trader already serving a six-year jail term for engineering a scheme to make illegal trades in in the bond futures pits was fined a record $1,125,000 and barred permanently from the Chicago Board of Trade, the exchange said today.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Hearing Set on Sex Shop Ownership
description: Picking up its review of obscenity regulations where it left off last week, the Supreme Court agreed today to decide the constitutionality of a Dallas law barring those convicted of certain offenses from operating sexually oriented bookstores and movie theaters.

title: TOWER PROSPECTS FOR CONFIRMATION SEEM TO BE DIMMER
description: John G. Tower apparently failed to win new supporters among Senate Democrats today with his pledge not to drink if confirmed as Defense Secretary, and his Republican backers conceded that renewed concerns about his financial ties to military contractors raised an additional threat to the nomination.

title: Talking Business with Merrifield of Pic 'N' Save; Close-Out Stores: Growth Is Sharp
description: The close-out segment of the nation's retailing industry is one of the fastest-growing and most profitable because of its stripped-down operating methods and high public demand. One of the largest close-out retailers, the Pic 'N' Save Corporation of Carson, Calif., operates 159 stores in 11 states. It sells housewares, gifts, stationery, apparel, wine, luggage and cosmetics and had revenue last year of $400 million. Last December, the company acquired 15 Job Lot close-out stores in the New York area.

title: Kentucky Medical Insurance reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $353,938 for the quarter and $737,938 for the year. c-After tax credits of $35,412 and $169,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Quiet Towns In an Uproar Over Waste
description: This small town in the Mohawk Valley generally concerns itself with the care of cows and vegetables, not of low-level radioactive waste. That changed one day shortly before Christmas, however, when New York State announced that Root was in one of 10 areas across the state being considered for disposal of the waste.

title: Reviews/Television; Relearning Fatherhood, In 'Coach'
description: Proceeding on the not unreasonable assumption that plot logic is hardly a priority among sitcom fans, ABC is launching its new series ''Coach'' almost brazenly out of sequence. Tonight's ''preview,'' at 9:30, shows a college football coach, Hayden Fox (Craig T. Nelson), desperately trying to become a good father when his daughter, Kelly (Clare Carey), newly enrolled at the college, announces she has a date with an older member of the faculty. It is only in tomorrow night's ''premiere,'' at 9, that the coach first learns Kelly has decided to enroll at the college. That's when we find out that the restless coach ''split up'' with Kelly's mother 16 years ago and hasn't paid much attention to his daughter in the intervening years. What will ''Coach'' have to face first: comprehension or cancellation?

title: Supreme Court Accord: Rock Music Is Loud
description: The only proposition on which everyone at the United States Supreme Court today appeared to agree was that rock music is loud music.

title: U.S. Bill Rates Set 4-Year High
description: Treasury bill rates soared yesterday to their highest level in four years, reflecting recent moves by the Federal Reserve to push up the cost of borrowing. By tightening credit, the Fed hopes to arrest what it perceives to be accelerating inflation.

title: Airgas Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $36,000 and $324,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and an after-tax gain of $3,501,000 from the sale of Cylinder Manufacturing operations for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $42,000 for the quarter and $255,000 for the 9 months, and the 9 months also included an extraordinary gain of $167,000.

title: Chess
description: ''I have played in the world championship candidates' cycle eight times and enough is enough,'' complained Lajos Portisch after losing his quarterfinal match to Jan Timman in Antwerp, Belgium, on Feb. 8.

title: Article 943089 -- No Title
description: Nearly 16,000 apartments in vacant New York City-owned buildings in the South Bronx - 80 percent of all such apartments in that borough - are being rehabilitated under a $5.1 billion city program.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Results Plus column in some copies of Sunday's Sports section misstated the outcome of a quarterfinal game in the world Youth Soccer Cup championship. Brazil defeated Argentina by 1-0.

title: By Design; The Universal Ponytail
description: If your coif is chin- or, better yet, shoulder-length, you are a prime candidate for a ponytail.

title: New F.D.A. Cough Medicine Guidelines
description: The Food and Drug Administration issued standards today for expectorants in nonprescription cough-cold medicines.

title: Galanos and Scaasi: A Vivid Spring; Glitter and Lace
description: The spring and summer fashion openings have drawn to a close, now that James Galanos and Arnold Scaasi have presented their collections. Galanos brought his clothes from Los Angeles to the Plaza hotel last week and is showing them to store buyers this week. Scaasi, the only major American designer who still shows made-to-order clothes, introduced his collection to private customers in his Fifth Avenue salon yesterday.

title: Spec's Music reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting change of $206,000.

title: For Landry, Unkindest Cut of All
description: In pro football, the cut hangs over everybody's helmet or headset like a guillotine. Even adequate players know that sooner or later they will be cut from the roster. Sometimes great players are told to retire to avert the embarrassment of being released, but they know they've been cut. And coaches, good and bad, are let go depending on their won-lost record or a club owner's whim.

title: Envirodyne Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
747 Repairs: Determining the Timetable
description: Two years ago, a Boeing 747 operated by Pan American World Airways lost air pressure in its cargo bay as it rose to 20,000 feet, and it made an emergency landing in San Francisco. Inspectors there found the plane's cargo door open an inch and a half, and all eight of its locks damaged or broken, according to Government documents.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Avnet, Inc., Great Neck, L.I., said Edward Kaniger had been named president of Hamilton/Avnet, and David Shaw had been named president of Time Electronics. Both are subsidiaries of the parent company.

title: Israel Dvorine, 89; Developed Eye Test
description: Israel Dvorine, an optometrist who was the first American to develop a test for colorblindness, died Friday. He was 89 years old and lived in Baltimore.

title: After 8 Years, a Dip in Families in Shelters
description: The number of homeless families sheltered by New York City decreased by 500 last year to 4,637, social service officials said yesterday.

title: The Gap Expects Record Earnings
description: The Gap Inc. said it expected to report record sales and earnings for both the fourth quarter and the fiscal year ended Jan. 28. Gap and Gap Kids clothing stores significantly improved sales and earnings, although comparable-store sales declined at its Banana Republic travel and safari clothing stores, the company said.

title: Zakhel Journal; Outside Besieged City, War's Fuse Burns Slowly
description: For more than two months Afghan rebels have tightened their siege of the eastern city of Jalalabad, but the war in this green valley at the foot of snowcapped mountains is at an impasse.

title: J T Moran Fincl Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
In the End, Africa Will Shape Its Own Future; Getting On in Ghana
description: To the Editor:

title: Paramedics Criticize Montefiore in a Death
description: Two city paramedics who brought a critically ill 89-year-old Bronx woman to Montefiore Hospital by ambulance Sunday afternoon have charged the hospital with failing to treat the woman promptly, officials said.

title: Four Years of Captivity
description: Four years ago, three foreign correspondents and an editor of The New York Times met in Amman to talk about coverage of the Middle East.

title: Research Pioneer Quits Salomon Brothers Post
description: Salomon Brothers Inc. has lost yet another important executive with the departure of Laszlo Birinyi Jr., who developed Wall Street's most detailed research on institutional stock trading patterns.

title: Contract Ultimatum Issued by Henderson
description: Rickey Henderson, back in good graces after missing the first two days of voluntary workouts in the Yankee camp last week, today offered the team an unexpected ultimatum: Sign him by the All-Star Game or lose him to free agency when the season ends.

title: Gamma Ray Bursts
description: Orbiting astronomical satellites occasionally detect puzzling bursts of gamma rays from points in the sky. The several hundred bursts observed during the past decade have ranged in duration from less than one-hundredth of a second to about 18 minutes, and most have been seen only once.

title: Perry Drug Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 21
description: b-Net loss and included a loss from discontinued operations of $11,740,000 and a gain of $1,800,000 from an accounting change.

title: Milton W. Hamilton, 87, Colonial Historian
description: Milton Wheaton Hamilton, an authority on New York Colonial history, died Sunday at the home of his daughter, Gwendolyn Stevens of Wappingers Falls, N.Y., after a brief illness. He was 87 years old and lived with his daughter.
